name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Roberta Metsola and Kashetu Kyenge, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to immigration (2015/2095(INI)) (A8-0066/2016).

name: Roberta Metsola
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, if one thing is clear, it is that there is no quick fix to migration. There is no magic silver bullet. What we wanted to do is look at every single aspect and come up with an all-encompassing plan, and I would like to thank Cecilia and everyone who cooperated so well to get us to this stage. What we are saying here is that we must shift our thinking: no more emergency solutions to emergency situations. We want a sustainable long-term vision. Our departing point is that solidarity must be the point of principle upon which any action on migration is based. It is clear that we still need to do more to prevent loss of life at sea, and we call for a permanent Union response in search and rescue. When it comes to Frontex and the European Border and Coast Guard, we acknowledge that Frontex and naval operations such as Operation Sophia have played their part in saving lives, but we need to go further. Any holistic approach to migration must also necessarily contain measures aimed at criminal networks, and our report also tackles this point. This is crucial. We draw differences between those who are in need of protection and those who come to Europe for work, because we understand that while people fleeing war and persecution have a right to protection, it is true that this does not equate to an inalienable right to migration. So we highlight that when it comes to labour migration, for example, it must be the Member States who have control over the labour market, and that they and the Union must see how best to fill any possible gaps in the market. When it comes to beneficiaries of international protection, we have come back again and again to the issue of relocation. If we are a Union of shared values we must now truly become a Union of shared responsibility. Relocation is a move in the right direction, but the numbers of people relocated from Italy and from Greece are very disappointing. When it comes to safe and legal routes, we want a binding legislative approach for resettlement. On security, we cannot bury our heads in the sand. Security fears do exist among our citizens, and states must fulfil their obligations at the external borders if these fears are to be in any way allayed. The abolition of internal border controls and Schengen has to go hand in hand with strengthening external borders. This is simply a prerequisite if we are to save our celebrated Schengen zone. We know that not everyone who arrives in Europe is in fact eligible for protection, and we understand that the return of those who are not eligible must be carried out. Only 36% of those who were ordered to leave the Union were actually returned in 2014. On Dublin, we know that there is an upcoming legislative process, but we have put forward one option whereby the establishment of a central system could be considered and the ‘country of first entry’ principle should no longer be applied. We want a new approach on integration. The way forward is to have a two-way process, and while, yes, everyone’s rights must be protected and yes, we must do more to keep families together, it is also fair to expect people to respect the values upon which our Union is founded. We also talk about tackling the root causes and understand that greater commitment is needed to solve the geopolitical issues of our time. This means that Europe must help build capacity in third countries which can eventually allow people to seek protection also in safe countries outside the EU. In conclusion, 1.8 million people crossed into Europe last year. 3 771 drowned in the Mediterranean. This year already more than 77 children have died. This is the magnitude of the situation we are facing and, as politicians, all of us have a duty to take a stand to ensure that these are not just nameless statistics. We cannot allow ourselves to become desensitised to the fact that migration is, above all, a human issue. These are real people with real lives, and we must all do better. It is time for action, and I hope that you will vote precisely for that today.

name: Kashetu Kyenge
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's vote has come to the end of a political path that lays the foundations for a future common migration policy.  It has been an extraordinary effort to align the different positions – and I thank Mr Metsola for the work he has done together – to smooth out individual sensitivities and to share a common approach: the phenomenon of migration is not opposed but managed. It is managed through all the policies and instruments at our disposal, in the optimal combination of domestic policy and foreign policy. It is managed through the full involvement of all the actors involved, both at European, national and local level. It is managed through short-term concrete actions and forward-looking medium and long-term policies. It is managed if there is the political will to implement a founding principle of the Union, the principle of solidarity and full sharing of responsibilities between all the Member States. We have assumed this political responsibility.  The draft resolution provides concrete answers to what is the largest movement of men and women since the Second World War, as well as outlines structural policies aimed at curbing the phenomenon and combating its root causes. The guiding principle of our proposals is the global approach and the centre on which they are based is the principle of solidarity. The saving of human lives becomes a top priority, as does the development of mechanisms for allocating beneficiaries of international protection to all Member States of the European Union. The time has come for the Member States to assume their responsibilities and fulfil their obligations in connection with the relocation measures strongly desired by this House.  We insist on the need for a binding and compulsory mechanism for the resettlement of a considerable number of asylum seekers directly from the refugee camps of third countries to the Member States, the so-called 'humanitarian corridors', without, however, neglecting the strengthening of similar forms of solidarity, such as humanitarian admission and humanitarian visas. We call for specific measures for children, starting with the right to legal, health, education, protection, and above all non-detention because of their condition.  Let us analyse the critical issues of the Common European Asylum System and decree the end of the Dublin Regulation.  Our proposal is clear: to go beyond the concept of the port state. We propose the establishment of a central and collective system for the allocation of responsibilities. A system that could be designed by setting thresholds per Member State for the number of arrivals. There will no longer be an asylum application in Italy or Greece, but in Europe. Mr Timmermans, this is the Dublin amendment that we expect of you, not cosmetic changes to a regulation which, on the evidence, has shown that it does not meet the migratory challenges of recent years. Managing migration also means acting on the root causes of migration. We call for greater cooperation with third countries, for the relaunch of certain processes, including Rabat and Karthoum, and, above all, for strong measures to combat trafficking and trafficking in human beings.    Migration flows also include economic migrants, we call on the Member States to review their fragmented policies on economic migration and to lay down new rules on entry and residence. Turning to you, Commissioner, I hope that the change to the Blue Card will be ambitious and up to the needs identified in the labour market. The success of a migration policy is also measured in terms of integration. We call on the Member States to take concrete measures to provide housing, access to education and to intensify intercultural dialogue. Mr President, with this resolution we are lay the foundations for a common migration policy that is equal to the challenges of the twenty-first century. It is now up to the Member States to decide whether to follow our path or to decree the definitive decline of the process of European integration. The future of Europe also depends on how much we are able to share our European dream and our values.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by expressing my thanks to our rapporteurs Ms Metsola and Ms Kyenge for this comprehensive report. They and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) have invested a great deal of serious work to achieve this result. We all share a common objective. We all agree that the time has come to replace chaotic, irregular and dangerous migratory flows with organised safe and legal pathways to Europe. Like the European Agenda on Migration, your report rightly stresses the need to work on all aspects of migration in order to reduce the incentives for irregular migration, assist migrants in need of protection, secure our external borders and attract skills to support our economic growth. We cannot work on one of the aspects and ignore the others. We cannot pick and choose what to focus on. We need to enhance all aspects of our policy in parallel, to coordinate with all key players and be both realistic and ambitious looking ahead. The agreement reached between the European Union and Turkey should also be seen in this broad context. Implementing this agreement is a challenge. We are working tirelessly to put in place all the legal, practical, logistical and financial arrangements to implement it. We are doing so with the Greek and the Turkish Governments, as well as with international organisations and NGOs to ensure that the European Union and international law is fully respected. People who apply for asylum in Greece will have their applications treated on a case-by-case basis in line with EU law. I was in Ankara last week to discuss how the EU-Turkey agreement is being put into practice. Discussions are still ongoing on the protection guarantees for both Syrian and non-Syrian asylum seekers. As a result, the first promising steps have been taken. In the short time since its implementation, which started on 4 April, 74 Syrians have been resettled in Europe and more than 300 migrants returned to Turkey. We have started to finance projects to support Turkey in hosting millions of refugees. More generally, the current crisis has shown that the present system is not working, and many elements are reflected in your report. In particular we need to overhaul the asylum system. Currently, the first place of arrival of a person in the European Union decides which Member State should handle an asylum claim. This is neither fair nor sustainable, as we have seen in the last months. Last week’s communication presented two options for the establishment of a sustainable and fair system for determining the Member State responsible for examining asylum claims. The first alternative is to add a corrective fairness mechanism to Dublin: what I would call ‘Dublin plus’. We would keep the current criteria and supplement them with adjustments enabling redistribution to other Member States in specific circumstances. The objective would be to have a threshold that is not too high. Redistribution should start before the asylum system of a Member State is over-stretched. The second, alternative, line of thought we are proposing is changing the basic criteria. In this scenario, responsibility for an asylum claim would be decided from the very start and for every case on the basis of distribution between Member States. Both options would provide the much-needed solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities between Member States. Indeed, under both options, the distribution mechanism should be activated automatically. But a reformed Dublin mechanism alone will not make our asylum policy more fair and efficient. This is why the Commission will present complementary initiatives in order to achieve greater convergence in the EU asylum system and to limit secondary movements across the European Union. The Eurodac system will be reinforced. The asylum procedures and the qualification directives will be replaced with fully-harmonised regulations. Targeted modifications will be proposed to the Reception Conditions Directive and a new reinforced mandate will be given to the EASO. We also need to enhance safe and legal pathways to Europe to stop migrants from embarking on dangerous journeys. This is why we will put forward a horizontal mechanism for resettlement. Right now there are many differences between Member States’ approaches to a settlement. It would be more efficient if EU Member States pooled their offers and use the same methodology. We also agree that in the future we will need migration to fill the skills gap and to address the demographic challenge that all our nations in Europe face. We will propose a reform of the blue card scheme for highly skilled migrants, as well as measures to attract and support innovative entrepreneurs. I also want to emphasise that we are working on an action plan on integration for all third-country nationals. This will be a crucial element to increase acceptance in our societies. All these actions are complementary to the actions initiated to protect our borders and reduce incentives for irregular migration. Last week we proposed making our borders smarter and stronger. We created an EU entry/exit system to improve our external borders management by better monitoring over-stayers. The Commission is pursuing its efforts, together with Member States, to improve arrangements for the return of irregular migrants not in need of protection, especially regarding sub-Saharan countries. Let me assure you once more that the Commission is working very hard with all actors to ensure that the current deficit in the migration system is being addressed. The refugee crisis has been a catalyst for the acceleration of these changes. The picture sometimes looks very dark. I will not hide from you that my first thought every morning is whether we as Europeans will overcome this crisis and turn it into an opportunity instead of a disaster. But I still want to believe that we are all now realising the need to adapt to a new era, which is characterised by human mobility. Most importantly, we have started realising that we can only face this new reality united and based on our common values of respect for human rights, and it is true that this Parliament was the first to show the way ahead and this Commission’s mission was from the beginning to tackle the issue in a comprehensive way. In this framework, I welcome the fact that many constructive proposals can be found in your report, which shows our common understanding of the challenges and potential solutions. I am looking forward to a constructive debate.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Mr President, the title of the report refers to the Mediterranean, but the crisis appeal has taken on such dimensions that we must talk about a holistic approach to immigration on the part of the European Union, based on solidarity, full respect for the fundamental rights, principles and values of the European Union.  The reasons for deciding to leave their country are wars, terrorism, lack of security, poverty, hunger. We must be told that the participation of European Union countries in the deregulation of our flammable neighbours leads to huge flows of migrants, refugees and displaced persons. Europe must be a force for peace and stability in the neighbouring regions. The countries receiving the largest migration flows need support and there must be a fair distribution of responsibilities. Europe seemed like the Promised Land for migrants and refugees but, now, only shame is caused by the images in Idomeni or the shelters that have been turned into detention centres. We must stop building walls at the internal borders of the European Union and replace unorganized, irregular and dangerous migration flows with organised, safe and legal routes to Europe.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: Draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, Commissioner, up to nine committees have worked on the preparation of this 85-page report. A great joint work of rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, with only one common objective: to articulate a comprehensive approach of the European Union on migration. Imagine that we had set up months ago, as my group proposed and endorsed the Treaties, a European emergency intervention force for refugees that was receiving, registering and ensuring first and for all the essential rights of the most vulnerable who come to Europe: children. We would be guaranteeing them access to guardianship, legal and health care, accommodation and education and we would not all be violating the principle of best interests of the child. We would not be covered by the oprobrium and shame of ignoring the whereabouts of thousands of minors who have entered Europe. In November I already alerted the Commission to the growing number of unaccompanied minors who were reaching our borders. In January, and as an emergency, I again asked a question about the 10,000 missing minors that Europol acknowledged, many of them possibly victims of mafias, slavery and exploitation. Yesterday, Germany recognized more than 6,000. Commissioner, we have been waiting months for clarification from the Commission on this matter. Can you please tell me today, at least, if you don't know, you can't or don't want to explain it?

name: Gérard Deprez
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the two rapporteurs, who have done a very good, very comprehensive job and which contains all the strategic elements of a genuine coherent and responsible European asylum policy. There is - I totally agree - the organization of legal access routes to avoid the sad disaster we are witnessing in the Mediterranean. It is the demand for a fairer distribution of refugees to avoid the overload and asphyxiation of the first host country that stems from the Dublin system. There is , and I agree with it - the need for tighter border control, a more effective fight against smugglers and the return to their countries of origin of people who cannot claim asylum. It also includes , and I am particularly pleased with this - the outline of a fully integrated asylum policy.  Asylum must be a European asylum in the future. We must be able to apply for asylum in the European Union. It is the European agency EASO that must investigate applications. All procedures, all remedies and all deadlines must be harmonized. Last but not, Mr President, on the budgetary front, the budgetary resources provided for in the multi-year financial framework are clearly insufficient. Hence, Commissioner: can you confirm to us today that the Commission - I will speak to you when you listen to me - intends to propose in the context of the revision of the multi-year financial framework the additional means necessary for the European Union to fulfil its asylum responsibilities?

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this morning, with the subject of migrants and the reception of migrants as part of a comprehensive approach in the Mediterranean, is an opportunity to check the adequacy of our conduct and the policies we are pursuing with the values we proclaim. The first point is welcome: there is no social integration without professional integration, and the challenge is to integrate migrants professionally even as we are hit by an unprecedented wave of unemployment. Of course, refugees need to learn the language; we must recognize their diplomas, give them equivalencies, promote training. But I would like to draw your attention this morning to one point: once refugees have their papers, they have been welcomed by non-governmental organisations on a site, they must be relocated to sites that offer jobs. And here I ask you, Commissioner, two things: the first is to mobilise the Member States for this relocation which has difficulties which they are not aware of, and the second is to increase the amount spent on the European Social Fund, because we will not be able to do everything within the multi-year financial framework to integrate both European citizens and refugees.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, we need concrete and credible proposals to resolve the long-standing crisis, a crisis that is in many ways inhumane and unsustainable from the point of view of people.  The Committee on Transport is concerned about the humanitarian aspects of the crisis, but also about the impact on Mediterranean shipping, the safety of ships and their crews and public maritime safety. The concern is that the Mediterranean will see accidents that could lead to further loss of life and also to environmental damage.  Under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, ship masters are always obliged to provide assistance in the case of people at risk of drowning at sea and always to participate in search and rescue operations. Indeed, the resources of the authorities in the Mediterranean have been too weak, and our merchant bases throughout the world have had to bear an unacceptably high responsibility for rescue work on their own. Funding for temporary rescue operations in the Mediterranean must be increased in order to ensure the safety and fundamental rights of both refugees trying to reach Europe and those working in the Mediterranean.  I would like to thank the rapporteurs for taking account of the position of the Committee on Transport and Transport, and I hope that we will be able to find solutions that can be resolved by people.

name: Andrea Cozzolino
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the two rapporteurs for the work that has been presented here.  There is a very great distance between what we are doing here this morning, the work that has been done, and the news that continues to reach us even in these hours, such as the last, that of the two hundred and fifty-metre wall between Italy and Austria, so to speak, of which the newspapers are informing us this morning and how unsatisfactory, once again, the response that the States give to the migration crisis is unsatisfactory.  We make two important contributions, Commissioner, to this resolution. The first is to put cohesion policy at the service of a new migration policy and to make cohesion policy more flexible, more open, more willing to be less blocked in its programmes and to be more concrete in aid, so to speak, of the policy to combat the migration emergency, but also as a structural policy for the coming years.  The second point we make in this report is to point out the need to progressively introduce measures derogating from the Stability Pact so that the resources that individual States and the European Commission itself make available for migration policy are increasingly being taken out of a narrow logic of the Stability Pact. From this point of view, we call for reflection on these two points.

name: Mary Honeyball
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, at every stage of their journeys to, and indeed within, Europe, women and girls are targeted by people who seek to exploit them. Women and girls are targets for smugglers and traffickers and are at risk of being sold into prostitution and domestic servitude. Many of these are underage girls travelling on their own, as we have heard from one of the other speakers. All of these women and girls are at heightened risk of all forms of violence and sexual assault. Therefore we need measures to meet the specific needs of women, and they have too often only been considered as an afterthought. Most of the time there are not even minimum standards in reception centres for preventing violence against women, such as single-sex sanitation facilities, which would seem absolutely obvious. What we need, therefore, is gender sensitivity in all aspects of our policies, from the design stage to delivery and evaluation.

name: Marlene Mizzi
text: Rapporteur għal opinjoni tal-Kumitat għall-Petizzjonijiet. – L-Ewropa qed tħabbat wi大大ha ma' kriżi bla pre大edent ta' emerġenza umanitarja - kriżi li wriet bi大ar li s-soluzzjonijiet eżistenti fuq livell Ewewrop definittivament mhux qed jilħqu l-iskopħhom. L-uniku mezz biex nimxu 'l quddiem huwa permezz ta' soluzzjoni Ewropea komuni.  Bħala rapporteur tal-Kumitat PETI, rajt ħafna petizzjonijiet li din hija waħda mill-problemi għa大-大ittadini Ewropej. Wasal iż-żmien li nuru li大-大ittadini tagħna, li t-tħassib tagħhom finalment ser jinstema'. Kliem sabiħ bħal "tqassim fair ta' responsabilità", "integrazzjoni" u "solidarjetà" ma għandhom l-ebda effett jekk ma jkunux appoġjati minn azzjonijiet konkreti, viżibbli u effettivi.  Għalhekk, għandna bżonn sistema 大entrali għall-allokazzjoni tar-responsabilitajiet, sabiex talbiet tal-ażil jinfirxu b'mod aktar ugwali madwar l-Istati Membri; irridu nirrevedu d-Dublin Regulation, li fil-forma preżenti hu inutli u bla funzjoni; hemm bżonn ta' rotot għal aħal aħ大ess legali lejn l-Ewropa, sabiex b'hekk ikollna control aħjar tal-migranti li jkunu ġejjin lejn l-Ewropa; u fl-aħħar, u mhux l-anqas, hemm bżonn li jiġu indirizzati l-kawżi tal-migrazzjoni u naħdmu biex dawn in-nies nagħtuhom futur ġo pajjiżhom u ma jkollhomx għalfejn andħarbu u jiġu lejn l-Ewropa.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, the report edited by Mrs Metsola and Mrs Kyenge is very important, a very correct holistic balanced approach which does not address the problem at the level of temporary management, but instead proposes a definitive prospect of solving the problem which has come to surprise us.  Ladies and gentlemen, the migration problem calls on the European Union to confront its principles and values. There is a need, here and now, for a change of mindset, a change of perception and a change of approach to this problem, and I say this because you know very well that the institution of relocation cannot work if there are Member States that do not agree with our decisions. The institution of resettlement by third States also cannot work if there are Member States that close borders and are balding the essential institution of Schengen.  We must therefore understand in this approach that there must be a common immigration policy and that, as the Commissioner said, a common European asylum policy must be promoted. Otherwise, we will not be able to deal with either unaccompanied children, the most sensitive core of this case that the report rightly understands, or those desperate people, some of them counting as simple statistics and figures, and not as human lives, who have left as persecuted to come to see, on our continent, a better life and a better level of decent living.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. With a heart full of sad, memorable, ai billion scenes that every single one of us should see. So that we know who we're even discussing and what we're even deciding. The politicians of all Member States should do their work on the ground in order to make their personal experience of persuading us who we are, with a slow response and, above all, by the complete non-cooperation of the European Union as a whole, not only to make life very difficult, but also to devalue life. The Greek islands where migrants are housed are becoming prisons, closed camps where, apart from food, refugees have no legal, social, psychological or other assistance. They do not know their rights and their possibilities, if they do, they are often unable to take advantage of them at all. You also probably know how impossible the situation on the Greek mainland is at the moment. But you probably don't know that refugees can only apply for asylum there via Skype? This is a completely absurd situation. We must help Greece with all the professional and other possible resources. The relocations need to start working. This weekend, we again experienced an inhumane situation at the border with Macedonia when the Macedonian police intervened. I am in favour of introducing as soon as possible the revised Dublin legislation, under which a person wishing to apply for asylum could apply for asylum in the European Union, and not in a particular country. This would relieve the country of the coup and spread the refugee burden immediately. This requires, of course, the full cooperation of all the Member States, and if we do not achieve this, then it is pointless to talk about any further joint European action. I urge you, my colleagues, to take a live look at the borders, camps, tents, and when you are on the ground, you will not be able to turn the button on the television or turn off your computer. Because the responsibility for innocent children's eyes will be too great.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – This report, which was supposed to set out a strategic vision for asylum and migration for this legislature, is a missed opportunity. First of all, asylum and legal migration are two completely different themes, each of which deserves its own treatment. But it became a soup!  Secondly, where the report contains new proposals, they are completely unrealistic. Turning the Dublin system into a dispersion mechanism is up to now, but do this without attaching restrictions and strict conditions to it, with no maximum quotas and barely a word on return? But about new legal routes to the EU? Hello common sense! We must take off our blinkers and finally put realistic and well-thought-out solutions on the table.  We have to work in several areas at the same time. So, on the one hand, make sure that our borders are properly guarded and that every Member State applies the Dublin rules. On the other hand, we are committed to the successful integration of recognised refugees into our society.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the report on a holistic approach to migration contains many good elements, and I would like to thank the co-rapporteurs for their excellent work on this. I consider this report an important blueprint for how the EU could create a common well-functioning asylum system fit for today. The crisis in Europe demonstrates the complete failure of our national governments to set up a functioning asylum system fit for the world of today, but unfortunately national leaders have played the rhetoric up to such a level that they manage to convince both themselves and parts of the electorate that we cannot do anything about the crisis. We need to get this straight: one million refugees as against 500 million Europeans represents 0.2% of our population. Compare that to a country that I visited last week, Lebanon, where a 30% ratio is facing the everyday life of the Lebanese people: there we are talking about a great influx and a big, big problem. I am convinced that the vast majority of European citizens want to see a fair system that grants protection and dignity to people fleeing persecution and war, and at the same time they want Member States to share the responsibility in a fair way, where each country gives its contribution and shares the responsibilities. Today I hope that we are going to send a clear message to the citizens of Europe that this European Parliament has the vision for such a system. As the rapporteur for the reform of the Dublin Regulation, I am especially proud of the joint commitment from all major political groups in this House to real reform of the Dublin Regulation, which will enable us finally to see a centralised European system where applicants are distributed fairly among EU Member States. But after the vote of today, we will all need to get to work to ensure that this initiative is followed by determined and concrete legislation.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the co-rapporteurs for their great work.  For a year and a half, the groups negotiated, often and harshly, to arrive at today's resolution. We started with two strong ambitions: to give ourselves a holistic view of the Mediterranean and the thousands of deaths at sea, to understand that we are not dealing with an issue of 'immigrants', but a question of 'refugees and refugees'.  If holistic means overcoming a difficulty by tackling its aspects together and when I think of the European policies of the last year and a half, I wonder whether we have been up to the task. The concentration of the Member States and the Commission, including Frontex, on border control and the refoulement of refugees is not a holistic view, on the pretext that Schengen is only saved in this way; Donald Tusk's phrase, calling on fugitives from wars not to come mainly to Europe, is not a holistic view; it is not holistic Frontex transformed into a new Agency for Collective Refoulement; Above all, the agreement with a regime, Turkey, which rejects thousands of returnees to Syrian war zones while repressing their Kurdish compatriots at home, is not holistic.  This report contains positive points, particularly with regard to the application for legal avenues of access to the Union, European search and rescue systems, and the mutual recognition of asylum decisions. It would live up to its initial ambitions if it were to clearly denounce the agreement with Turkey, as called for in specific amendments by my group, if it understood that we are facing a refugee crisis, not an immigrant crisis. If it does not do so, this Parliament will not be able to say that it has a holistic view of the Mediterranean either.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would also like to thank the rapporteurs for their excellent work. We do indeed need a holistic approach – people have said that – and we need one that is much better than the piecemeal solutions and unilateral actions offensive to human rights that have been taken by several Member States. This Sunday, children were tear gassed in Idomeni, and it was not just the Macedonian police who did this – several Member States were present there. I really hope, Commissioner, that you can remind those Member States of the importance of human rights and the fact that you cannot tear gas people who are in need of international protection and fire rubber bullets at children. What we need instead in the European Union is legal and safe passage for people in need of international protection, because even the best asylum system does not do its job if we close access to that asylum system. I recognise that the Commission acknowledges this problem in its communication, but I think we need concrete and binding proposals so that all Member States are obliged to offer that legal access. Far too few governments in the Member States are willing to welcome refugees, but it is our duty and our international obligation to open the doors to those people in need. We need common standards for asylum rules, but we also need better standards for asylum rules. The review that will be proposed by the Commission should lead to better standards, because current procedures are very often taking too long. They are not very transparent, and legal advice and legal security for people is not there. Accommodation is, in many cases, horrendous. The issue of distribution is crucial: the European Union is based on solidarity, and solidarity should also be reflected in an allocation key, which we urgently need in order to have all Member States participating in receiving asylum seekers and dealing with their claims. However, such an allocation system also needs to take into account the fact that we are dealing with people and not with numbers. We need to be able to take into account their family ties, their community ties and their language skills, because this will also make it easier for them to integrate. Member States will also benefit from that. Integration is indeed key, and we need to find common rules and fight the causes of why people have to flee. We also need to do something on that as the European Parliament. We can contribute to a fairer trade system and a fairer agricultural system. There are a lot of things we can do, and we should never forget that we are talking about people who are in need of protection – not problems, not numbers, but people.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the co-rapporteurs, the shadow rapporteurs and my fellow Members who have worked on the opinions that come from the other committees.  We can say that we have tried, during this year and a half, the European Parliament has tried to find a united position for a holistic approach to the issue of migration, but it is also true that, on the other hand, the total powerlessness of the European Parliament has emerged in the face of the selfishness of the Member States, and this result can only be a total failure of the European Union in its approach to the issue of migration.  Because, gentlemen, it's a failure that we're seeing. The relocation that has been voted on, announced by 160 000 people, has resulted in a few hundred that have been relocated so far; in the meantime, walls and borders have sprung up everywhere, as my fellow Member rightly said, that another wall is being built between Austria and Italy; Schengen is at risk; human rights are being violated ing every place and, last but not least, this agreement with Turkey, to which I ask Commissioner Avramopoulos for his opinion, is only the latest step in a totally nonsensical approach that we have on the subject of immigration.  The starting point was to be the Dublin Regulation, we had to overcome it, we have not yet succeeded because there is a unified vision on this issue. If we fail to distribute ourselves, to look together at how to deal with the problem, it becomes impossible to find the solutions and all the solutions that we are discussing are the solutions that are not enough and that risk making the border countries, such as Italy, such as Greece, corks and huge refugee camps.  We need a more transparent, smarter approach to managing funds, because internally there are jackals who speculate on immigration management, both economically and politically. Unfortunately, what we are experiencing is a sad page of history, someone has remembered what is happening in Idomeni where tear gas is fired in camps where there are children. And when this page of history is remembered tomorrow, it will be difficult to say that we are free from blame, it will be difficult to find excuses.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – A colleague has just said that no less than nine committees have been working on this report. Négen commissions! These are many parliamentarians who are supposedly supposedly to represent the people of the European Union and who have wasted an enormous amount of time and money on this in recent months.  Because all you are proposing is to create more opportunities to come to the European Union. Holistically, in the sense of all-encompassing, you take it quite literally by inviting the whole world to come this way. No proposal to end asylum inflation, nothing about IS terrorists travelling with the asylum seekers to sow death and destruction. No representation of the people who have had enough of this asylum influx and who want their country to remain their country.  The ruins of open borders are not solving by more European Union. To do so, you have to close the borders and de-Islamize!

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Mr President, the European Union, together with its allies and competitors, such as Syria, is treating refugees, victims of its bombing, accordingly. "Prevention of secondary migration and movement", so you baptize your decisions, entrapment in the wretched conditions of Idomeni and Piraeus. The European Union and the Greek Government, with your dangerous decisions, take full responsibility for the situation that has arisen, with the involvement of the NGOs that you "golden".  In your language, 'active immigration policy' means Schengen, Dublin being strengthened, imprisonment, deportations of refugees and migrants. With the 'fast track' rejection of the majority of asylum applications, you accept very few, those who have the standards demanded by business groups for their profits.  The peoples with their fight against the imperialist war and with their solidarity to enforce an end to the wretched conditions of residence of refugees and their immediate transfer to the countries of their final destination.

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE).
text: – Mr President, firstly I wish to thank rapporteur Metsola for doing this very difficult job. One of the best examples of a holistic approach in our history and literature is Sherlock Holmes. Here is an example to take when looking at the migration crisis. Applying the method of deduction to the migration crisis shows the weaknesses of our current system and politics, which arose as a result of delaying foreign and security policy. It also shows the current weaknesses in our value system, our border-security system and in internal cooperation between different institutions, as well as weaknesses in the institutions themselves. If we really want to regain the trust of our citizens, we must be successful in solving the migration crisis, and to do this we have to proceed step by step. This step-by-step approach entails, for example, trying to fix these problems one after another. I see the upcoming file at Parliament on our border agency and more secure European external borders as a contribution to this holistic approach. This is because we cannot survive with our current values and Schengen system of open internal borders without fixing our external borders. Let us do it step by step and we will also succeed with the migration crisis. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I have heard here and you and everyone: some say to open the gates, others to close the borders. Do you think that both the Commission and the Council have done everything necessary to ensure clear, fair and uniform procedures for the reception of refugees and only refugees only? Do you not think that it is necessary to explain clearly and transparently what are the methods by which we can solve the refugee problem without affecting the security of either party, not of refugees, nor of Europeans?

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I have no reason to believe that the Commission is not, just like ourselves, doing its job to the best of its capability. We must understand that none of us is a god here. The Commission, the European Parliament, the Council and the world in general have restricted capabilities, so the only way we can proceed is not just to paint ideals on the wall and think about a wished-for world in the future, but to fix every issue step by step. That is the only practical solution in politics that I can suggest to you.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which A common migration policy is more than just a common asylum policy. And how important it would be, we will see again this summer. We know from our services that around 200 000 , if not more – people in Libya and elsewhere in North Africa are waiting to enter the EU. And at the end of the summer we will see how many of them are still alive and have not drowned in the Mediterranean, because we are still unable to check on the spot and then, if it is possible, to carry out regular transport. I would like to mention a second aspect. Commissioner, you referred to the Turkey agreement, with which I agree in principle. But I would like to know from you or the Council, if someone ever takes part in such a debate again, why so much does not work. Why can't those who are deported back to Turkey apply for asylum at the moment? Why do the EU Commission not send staff there if the Member States fail to do so? Why do we always hear action plan, but we don't see what it means? Because we would like to know where the money is going. Last, but not least, if we do not want to neglect our values – we have always told you and, above all, the Council – then you must open Chapters 23 and 24. But that has not happened, and no one explains to us why not. We have to stand together. We are also doing well, the Council and the Commission. But we need to get a little better information, otherwise it will not go well in the long run.

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I want to thank the rapporteurs for their work, but I think the report has been a missed opportunity. The ECR Group supports much of the European agenda on migration, but Parliament has not focused on getting the EU’s asylum system working properly. Combating human trafficking, returns, readmission, third-country cooperation agreements, detention conditions, fingerprinting, sharing of resources, external border controls and integration policies are themes that are merely touched on but absolutely key to finding a way forward. Furthermore, the radical and impractical options suggested by Parliament for the Dublin Regulation will not serve as well in a time when what we want is for Member States to start following the rule book, not tearing it up. Despite this, I look forward to working in the coming months on many of the Commission proposals which my Group can support. This is an important area and we must get it right.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE).
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to say a few words to thank The Members, and especially our two colleagues, for the dense and in-depth work of our Parliament on this very important text and on this subject which we have been talking about for many months, if not many years. It is a long-awaited vision proposal and it is a balanced and comprehensive framework. This vision is important insofar as it finally corresponds to our values and, in essence, to the survival of Europe. I welcome the key points of solidarity and the clear commitment made in this text to save lives and people in distress at sea. I also welcome the proposal to step up the fight against smugglers, to revise the Dublin Regulation and to create legal routes of entry on European soil. If I welcome these points, I hope, Commissioner, that together with the Council you will be able to take the Member States out of their selfishness and their torpor and get them to commit to implementing this balanced proactive policy so that the spectacle of these misfortunes will cease, with special attention, I would like to say this in conclusion. thousands of isolated children on European soil.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Many of our countries do not agree with the principle of the forced deployment of immigrants in Europe. The European Commission and a majority of Parliament are stubbornly seeking this. Are you aware that we are really witnessing not only the social decomposition of Europe, but, in fact, the political dismantling of the European Union, if we ignore the positions of countries that simply disagree on such a policy and, moreover, are in law to disagree.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear Colleague, as a Democrat, of course, I agree with you with a number of diverging positions. Today, I am pleased that we are becoming aware of the difficulty of the European territories, of european citizens, of the Member States of Europe, by adopting a global vision which also allows us to have a comprehensive policy. This vision prevents some of the Member States from bearing the burden because geography predisposes them to be the first to be affected. It is a question of showing solidarity, by sharing, of course, the burden of welcoming in a democratic way, based on decisions.  From a legal point of view, it is simply a matter of respecting our obligations under international law to take in refugees fleeing war and violence. But we must do so in an organised way, avoiding the need for some Member States to take in too many refugees and, in others, none, while protecting our external borders.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, from the Delegation of the United Left-Plural Left I already announce our vote against this report, because it is a report that supports the European Union's criminal policy against migrants, because it is a report that supports the agreement of shame - The European Union - Turkey - and that people are currently being gassed at the borders and that thousands of people are surviving in inhumane conditions in detention camps , because it is a report that continues to bet on the 'Fortress Europe'. It is a report which seems to have been drafted in Mrs Le Pen's office, placing migrants as enemies from which we must protect ourselves.  The only concrete proposal made by the report is the deportation of those who dare to set foot on our continent, and I remind you that the forced displacement of people to another territory is covered by international law as a crime against humanity. Think about it when you're going to press the voting button.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are other criminal acts, not in this report which seeks to find a solution to a tragic reality. No one is talking, except for a few hints, I would like to know what the Commissioner thinks, about the walls that are being built; schengen that is breaking; What does she think when she talks about criminal acts of what Austria is doing on our brenner border?

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Yes, they are criminal policies. Any report that does not call into question the policies of the 'Fortress Europe', which continues to state that there are people who are illegal or that it relates Schengen's internal security to refugees or migrants is continuing the same policies we are suffering, and is therefore a report that does support these criminal policies. Yes of course.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is just as many have said, namely that we have been working on this report for a very long time now, and we did so even before the large influx of refugees came to us in the autumn. I am not nearly as critical as the previous speaker, but I can also say that this report also has a very great focus on what is happening in Europe rather than on the holistic approach to migration and the reason why people are actually moving. However, after the large influx of refugees in the autumn, the debate has largely been about how we are going to cope with the emergency situation, what we call a refugee crisis. At the same time, it is not a refugee crisis that we have, but it is our reception systems that have collapsed, and they are the ones we must work with to have a better opportunity in the future. However, I think that what is perhaps most important in this report is the issue of humanitarian visas. We in Parliament have a report in the pipeline. The Commission has put forward proposals to amend the visa regulation, and parliament will propose the introduction of a possibility of humanitarian visas for those who come as refugees. It is a legal and long-term way of solving people without using people smugglers. However, we also need to have a model for those who come as economic migrants. The report also deals with legal avenues for economic migrants. It cannot be enough just to have the so-called Blue Card procedure, but we must find a model for economic migrants other than the highly educated. In this way, we can also solve the long-term that poor people do not have to leave via the boats in the Mediterranean.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr How do you even think it is possible to establish a common asylum policy when certain countries, which are in favour of an incredible, irresponsible immigration policy, have taken over their heads and begged for exemptions in order not to be included in the proposed compulsive distribution mechanism that the EU wants to impose on the Member States? How can you even believe in a common asylum policy when the limit has long since been reached for many Member States, which have received more than they can manage? We heard here earlier that there was talk of there being work in the Member States. Then I wonder which Member States can offer work to these low-level migrants. In Sweden we have a very high unemployment rate, and it does not get better. It could therefore be interesting to know which Member States are able to offer work. We are talking about solidarity. We're talking about integration. Integration is something that everyone talks about a lot, but it rarely works. How can integration even be achieved when Member States are not even allowed to decide for themselves how many migrants they believe they can accept? What is being done with those Member States that reject a common asylum policy? (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – There are certainly a great many problems with the integration of immigrants, but could you think for a moment of such a longer-term perspective, for example the fact that europe's population will fall by 100 million people by 2050?  Would it not be positive to think that we need these immigrants?

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: answer ("blue card"). Yes, I can say that I have heard many times that we have to have immigration because we have a reduced population. But it is the case that for many of the migrants who come, it takes up to 20 years before they enter the labour market. It is therefore just nonsense. What we need is usually highly educated people. I believe that for these migrants who come usually take a very long time to enter the labour market.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall start by saying straight away that, in order to solve the problem of demographic decline, we must ensure that there are more children on the part of Europeans, not other strange enough issues.  I say something else from my point of view, when we talk about a holistic approach to immigration, we should ask ourselves whether immigration is a good thing or a bad thing. Since immigration comes from evil, which is often war or poverty, it is clear that bad cannot be good, so migrations as large as at this time are bad, they are bad and therefore we should try to see what the causes are and try to solve them. And the issue is dealt with in this report only in paragraph 103, in some lines in paragraph 103, but it was the first thing; are geopolitical issues, issues of wars.  And then we take one thing into account: when these people come here, we need a period of integration. I have seen that it says that it is a two-way process, no, it is a one-way process, it is they who must integrate with us because otherwise cases such as Molenbeek happen, where there has been immigration, where there has been no integration and where there are very serious problems now. So we want to create Molenbeek in every city?

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, 'catastrophic failure' is the most precise condition to describe the Union's efforts to deal with migration flows. This is because we are not looking for the causes of migration, smuggled or not, from the Middle East and Africa to European countries. On the contrary, we seek to deal with its results, more painless and economically profitable for pro-money European leaders.  The policy of mass migration is not a solution to Europe's demographic and labour problem. On the contrary, it leads to population change, the dismantling of the social fabric and, unfortunately, Islamisation with the accessories of the creation of jihadist terrorist pockets. Open borders policy is an incentive and encouragement for the largest invasion of illegal immigrants in Europe. A Europe which, on the altar of multiculturalism and diversity, has lost moral values and is seeking to lose the national consciousness and homogeneity of the Member States.  Immediate and feasible solutions exist: annulment of the agreement with Turkey, restoration of the protection of national borders, immediate deportation of illegal immigrants, criminal offence of illegal entry, severe penalties for illegal traffickers. But these can only be achieved with nationalist governments.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this is an excellent report. ‘Holistic approach’ means a multidimensional understanding of the problem of migration. There is a refugee crisis and a big influx of people. Challenging this phenomenon, we need to establish well—coordinated European policies oriented at making our borders secure and under smart control. But at the same time we need solidarity in our location of the refugees, better organised transit measures and new procedures for Dublin schemes. The only guarantee is real cooperation on the part of Member States, not the marketing games led by some politicians. There is only one honest political message: be open to solving the human dimension of the problem and separate the matters of refugees and terrorists rather than connecting them. What about migration? This is a challenge, especially now vis-à-vis the many social fears all over Europe. The added value of the report is to look at legal migration as an opportunity for aging European societies and for solving the problem of shortages on the labour markets. On the other hand, for a successful story in that area, we also need reasonable policies – not only in Member States but above all at European level – and we have recommendations for those policies in this report. This report is a background for further decision-making processes. We need to move from the chaotic emergency activities to the well-integrated long—term ones.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European While we are debating a holistic approach to migration here, refugees are living in inhumane conditions on the Greek-Macedonian border. The Hungarian Prime Minister wants to force a referendum against the quota system. Refugees are hiding on the Greek islands to avoid being sent back to Turkey, and the Austrian government wants to close the Brenner Pass. I will mention these few examples only to make it clear how big the difference is between the political debate here and the reality.  Still, I don't think there's another way. If we want an inclusive Europe, regulated, controlled, legalised immigration, we need a single, comprehensive system, a common European immigration policy. Not only in the Mediterranean, but everywhere in Europe. And this report serves this purpose well and therefore deserves support. But we must not back down from extremist and populist forces. You mustn't give in to scaremongering, fear-mongering, alien hatred. Both the Commission and Parliament must take much stronger action than before against governments that, for reasons of their own party interests or even for nationalist motives, are sabotaging the common European policy, who refuse to acknowledge that there is no European Union without responsibility and solidarity.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (
text: ECR). Mr President, Commissioner, I wanted to remind you that European citizens, refugees too, have been living in the European Union for years in miserable conditions, without any support, and yet they are warmly embracing the refugees who are currently arriving in Europe. Migration is developing into a tsunami ready to flood Europe and is not being tackled by repressive measures.  We must implement a universal policy, based on mutual benefit, on the development of peoples who are in difficulty, on peace in war zones. We need solidarity between the Member States, a proper asylum system, a proper immigration policy, fair burden-sharing. Today, Greece faces the biggest problem, but the Republic of Cyprus is also becoming the new target of Turkey, which has begun channelling poor refugees to get extortionate rewards from the European Union, which rewards it by opening funds.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Perspective is one of the most common words when talking to politicians, officials and NGOs in the Middle East about the Syrian refugee crisis. They need a perspective. The European debate often focuses only on short-term financial support. But we need to ensure more than just short-term survival.  If the money stops flowing because our strategic interests are shifting, the region will only be further destabilised. You and we, we all need a perspective. This means that we have to be honest with our citizens and realise that the sunny days are over for the moment. We need holistic access to the issue, and our discussion must move as quickly as possible towards the best possible on-the-spot assistance.  After all, every euro invested locally is much more effective than any euro even for the best integration measure in our country.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the report we are debating today rightly highlights the weaknesses of the Dublin Regulation and rightly calls for an immediate review of the legal framework, based on the principle of a fair distribution of responsibility and providing adequate financial and technical support to the Member States of first entry of asylum seekers, such as, in particular, Greece and Italy.  No revision, however, will succeed if the other Member States of the Union do not assume their responsibilities. A typical example is the migration program. Of the planned 160,000 posts, only 2,200 have been made available by the Member States and, of course, in addition to the Member States, respect for the European authorities must also be shown by the candidate countries.  The excessive use of force against refugees and migrants the day before yesterday by Skopje police officers and the throwing of chemicals from them into Greek territory is incompatible with the status of a candidate country. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You mentioned the issue of re relationality and the fact that all Member States really need to cooperate on this, we agree on that. But I come from a country, Hungary, where the Hungarian Government stubbornly resists any attempt of this kind, and all such agreements are blocked. I ask you: do you see a mechanism in which the twenty-seven Member States can persesdant one twenty-eight to cooperate, or do we agree that this should go on so that a country can prevent everything.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), answer to a question with a "blue card". – Hungary, like any other Member State, must realise that membership of the Union entails not only rights, but also obligations. It cannot ignore the decisions of the European Council and refuse to accept the people who are its own and who are only a small percentage of the total. If everyone follows this tactic, then the Union is going to break up.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, anyone in Britain who is still unsure on how to vote in the EU referendum should think about what is to come if they vote to remain in the EU. The report states that the EU Treaty gives a legal basis to implement the principle of solidarity in the area of migration. This is part of a common immigration and asylum policy which Britain cannot avoid if it stays in the European Union. It calls for a binding mechanism on all Member States for the distribution of asylum seekers. It says that asylum seekers should be viewed as seeking asylum in the Union as a whole and not in individual Member States. Mrs Merkel opened the floodgates by inviting anybody to come who wanted to. They took her at her word. More than a million have come and many millions more will try to follow. This was not done by accident. The EU has a commitment to endless, mass, uncontrolled migration, both within its borders and from without. David Cameron did not even try to gain concessions on immigration in his so—called renegotiation with the European Union. There is nothing in his famous reforms that takes back any control whatsoever over migration. If the British people want their government to have any control on migration whatsoever, then they must vote to leave the European Union on 23 June.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Mr President, I wish I could thank the rapporteurs for the report but, yet again, they have not confronted the elephant in the room: Islam. The most comprehensive study of British Muslims – and I would say Muslims in Europe, actually – ever conducted, by Trevor Phillips, the former chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality, draws some very disturbing conclusions, particularly for the Socialists in this House and the members of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. 39% of British Muslims say that a woman must always obey her husband and submit to chastisement from him. More than half of Muslims think lesbian and gay relationships should be illegal. More than 100 000 British Muslims said that they had sympathy for people who take part in suicide bombings. Only one out of three would report to the police if they knew someone was supporting terrorism in Syria. A quarter would like Sharia law to take precedence over English law. We are currently not talking about a tiny minority. Unfortunately, these are widespread views among the Muslim communities in the UK. I think the so-called refugees on our borders need to be repatriated to Muslim countries, as their values are clearly incompatible with our liberal western democracies. This will avoid the current clash of cultures that denigrates the achievements of Western civilisation and flouts the protection of women, the gay community and vulnerable children, who are being attacked by Muslim gangs and migrants who deplore our way of life.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are called upon to prove that the European Union is capable, through the compromise of which this report is the result, of giving concrete answers to the migration challenge. I would therefore like to thank the report-readers for their efforts and efforts in this year of work.  The text offers balanced general lines, avoiding extremist pressures on both side, which could certainly tear apart the moderate sense of cooperation and compromise of which this report is imbued. This own-initiative report is yet another call for action that we are calling on the Member States to act together for the general good of all. I am pleased that we all agree that the Dublin Regulation must be urgently amended to remove the obligation to apply for asylum in the country of first port, a provision that has put a strain on Italy, Malta and Greece.  Sharing responsibility, solidarity between Member States, constructive spirit and sharing of financial burdens are the keys to succeeding where individual Member States have failed. For this reason, I welcome the paragraphs in which we insist on the need for a common plan for the return of economic migrants, on combating human traffickers, on plans to relocate migrants suitable for international protection. I would like to thank Mr Sley for his excellent report. Metsola for insisting on the inclusion in the text of clear references to the risks that weak and soft immigration policies pose to the security of our citizens. We need more security.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for more than a year the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has debated this holistic, comprehensive report on migration policy, which deserves to be approved by this European Parliament. But above all, it deserves to have an opportunity to make a contrast to the pathetic and regrettable reality that characterises the present moment, because, when we talk about solidarity, we are denouncing the insolidarity that is currently taking place between the Member States.  When we talk about reforming Dublin, we are talking about a permanent mechanism that ensures the solidarity of the Member States in the management of asylum and refuge demands, we are talking about the need to change the direction of Frontex and the European Border and Coast Guard so that it does not become an agency for the return or rejection of migrants seeking their hope on European soil.  When we talk about a binding and permanent mechanism of solidarity, we are talking about legal and secure access and, therefore, humanitarian visas, which are essential for there to be a legal way to enter the European Union and, ultimately, for those who aspire to enter the European Union to have an opportunity to see a today and a tomorrow as European citizens , hope to realize their dream and can be Europeans without dying in the attempt.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking the question. You speak about solidarity between the Member States of the EU, and I understand from your speech that you wish to enforce that solidarity by forcing Member States to take certain numbers of immigrants into their countries and also finding ways of legalising the immigrants so they become citizens of the EU. Do you not realise that this is completely against the views of many – certainly of my constituents, but maybe even of yours? The people of the EU are not united behind you on this and you are enforcing something that nobody really wants.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – The raison d'eer of the European Union and which explains our presence here is precisely that the Member States, their societies, their citizens and also their public opinions learn that there are challenges that cannot be addressed by any Member State alone; that we need each other; and that this must be done in practice whenever a Member State is in difficulty, especially if policies implemented in recent years, such as recessionive austerity, have created additional difficulties so that it can ensure the external border of the European Union, as is notoriously the case with Greece. But I also dispute the false premise, because it has no empirical contrast, that rulers who dare to be supportive are punished for their public opinions. No. Evidence of reality shows that European citizenship has been more supportive in non-governmental organisations and citizens as a whole more supportive than the pettiness that governments have unfortunately shown in addressing this problem in recent years.

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the shortcoming of the solutions proposed by both the Commission and Parliament is that they focus on the question of how we could make irregular immigration more regular. This is what we mean when we talk about creating more legal pathways into Europe. This approach does not address the core problem, which is that there are more people coming than Europe can absorb. The more we take in, the more will try to come. For a very long time, Europe has failed miserably to integrate third—world immigrants, as shown, for example, by the no-go areas in European cities, religious radicalism, and the horrible crime and unemployment rates. As the number of immigrants grows dramatically, this failure is likely to become catastrophic – both economically and socially.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the fact is that, more than a year after the start of the refugee crisis, we do not have an applicable, concrete and credible plan. The European Parliament has worked hard but we have all lost credibility and thousands of people have died and hundreds of thousands are living and may fall into despair - we are seeing it on Greek borders with Macedonia. EASO has not had the resources to process the relocation.  And we have been effective in initiating expulsion and paying for Moria's wire fences or to cosify those desperate children and women, and part of it is our responsibility. The key is that we forced them to play their lives in order to ask for the asylum to which they were entitled, and for this reason we will move on to the history of infamy.  Canada manages in its consulates and embassies the safe flows and asylum of the quota it has established, transparently, without deceiving anyone, without lies. We didn't do it because governments have said things they didn't want to apply. My question is: within six months will the Commission be able to say that it has an applicable, concrete and credible asylum plan?

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current picture of Europe, after thousands of deaths in the Mediterranean, is bleak. Closed borders, displaced refugees, incidents of violence against them, mass returns and imprisonment, conflicts of intolerance and, most seriously, provocative statements by leaders of Member States. On the other side, a comprehensive agreement with Turkey that violates international legitimacy and regulations of integrated strategies that move to the limits of wishful meals.  Ladies and gentlemen, today's resolution, albeit slowly, and despite its individual negative elements, seeks to monitor the framework and practices imposed by international treaties. It prioritises the need for permanent strong and effective search and rescue operations in the Mediterranean. It requires safe and legal avenues for refugees, with binding and mandatory legislation to resettle large numbers of them. It recognises the failure of Dublin and calls for a new regulation with responsibility-sharing, child protection and family reunification and, finally, ladies and gentlemen, calls for sanctions on states that apply repulsion tactics. Even timid, it's a first step. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF)
text: blue-card question. – You talk about international law not being implemented and you talk about pathways. Have you thought – because the Commission is here, Mr Avramopoulos is here – about asking Qatar, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, all those Muslim countries in the Middle East, if they would like to take their share? Because at the moment they have taken zero.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL), answer to a question with a "blue card". – Madam Colleague, have you ever thought about asking to take your share of the responsibility that your Prime Minister has publicly stated that he used fake evidence to attack Iraq, to break up an entire country? Have you ever thought about this as a people, have you ever thought about the responsibilities you have towards all these people for forcing them to take to the streets, to have no homes, to starve their children, right now to have to be refugees all over Europe and beg to live as human beings? Have you ever thought about that?

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Mr President, this report on the migration crisis has the merit of encouraging the fight against the smuggling of migrants, but for the rest it gives way to the usual whims of the European Union in trying to save the Schengen area. Worse, it proposes measures that will seriously damage the identity of the peoples of Europe.  It wants to organise two legal channels of mass immigration: one for asylum seekers, for whom the report wants to set up - and I quote - safe routes to enter the Union, the other for economic migrants, which the report wants to welcome in the millions to replace European workers who will be missing because of the demographic crisis, rather than encouraging a birth policy. Instead of combating migration submersion, the Union is organising it. This is further proof that it is a technocratic oligarchy that mocks the peoples of Europe, their identities and aspirations.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Dear Sirs, allow me to make a few brief interventions on this report. Firstly, there is no doubt that the European Union needs an integrated and uniform approach to tackling the migrant crisis. Secondly: radicalisation: the intelligence services are talking about the infiltration of terrorists between refugees and migrants. Their job is to radicalise defectors, so that, too, is proof – the migrant crisis and the security situation are linked. Thirdly, securing the external border – at this point, the european border and coast guard proposal is more than welcome, but implementation is still too slow. We would have needed such a guard yesterday, and support for Frontex and Europol should have been significantly higher. Fourthly: The European Union should not allow Turkey to blackmail, otherwise it should lose its partner status as russia as it did in the context of the management of the migrant crisis. Fifthly, Macedonia – this candidate has proven to be a true ally of the European Union, thanks to it, we have stopped the Balkan route and facilitated a deal with Turkey. Paradoxically, however, the European Union is still punishing Macedonia for not setting a date for the start of accession negotiations. Sixthly: let me make it clear that I am strongly against so-called dialological or two-way integration. It assumes the mutual acceptance of value and behavioral forms. – I strongly oppose this. Finally, it should be made clearer that once it is safe enough, refugees must return home where they will be needed to rebuild the country.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking Mrs Van Heuvel for her excellent report. Kashetu Kyenge and Roberta Metsola for this work.  Whether we like it or not, with immigration, Europe will have to deal with it for a very long time.
