It is a subject, a challenge that will accompany us in our European development, and if we do not resolve it in the fairest and most effective way, it risks jeopardising, and is already doing so, what we have built up to now in Europe. For this reason, every short-sightedness, every closure are only forms of defence, destined to be inevitably overwhelmed.  Instead, as the report says, let us approach it in the most open way, with a global approach. Let us address it where it is born, this theme, solving the causes on the ground: poverty, war. Let us tackle them where it arrives, in our countries, with intelligent and effective management, with regular channels for arrivals and with a European asylum system. Let us also do this with openness to coexistence, to integration, focusing above all on women who are a key element and on young people, with a lot of education, a lot of training, because this is the path to integration. I think that this is the only way and it is not abstract idealism, mine, it is rather the healthy realism of those who want to govern problems and build their own future.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Anyone who witnesses the current misery of the refugee crisis in the Mediterranean knows that real aid must be given to genuine refugees. However, it is not possible, from the position presented, to impose quotas on The Member States. The example in the Czech Republic, from where the refugees left, shows that they themselves do not agree with the designated relocation. Our help is a matter of mercy. The European Union was founded on Christian values, so we must follow the example of a good Samaritan from Jesus Christ. He didn't bypass the injured passenger, but he gave him help and treatment. He defied cultural prejudice, the cynicism of others and showed mercy to a stranger. However, it is also a question of fairness. The war and crisis have given smugglers the opportunity to act on a number of atrocities and exploitation. Our efforts must be directed towards prosecuting organised smuggling gangs and also thwarting people smuggling with their approach to refugees. Parliament should clearly define to whom the European door is open, firstly, to refugees in danger of living in areas of struggle and, secondly, to ensure the control of the external borders in cooperation with all Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, what are we talking about today? We're talking about the consequences of our interventions in Libya, in Iraq, what we're doing in Syria, that's what we're talking about today. We're talking about the consequences of one policy that didn't yield results.  Obama at least had the courage to say the other day that intervention in Libya was his worst career move. We didn't hear anything from Cameron, we didn't hear anything from Sarkozy and we didn't hear anything from many others.  Today we are talking about the consequences of what we have done and that we might think long term about what we will do in the Mediterranean in the future, let's also talk about what we have done in recent years in the Mediterranean. Of course, here I want to clearly express my support for Dublin plus, everything that is written in these reports because I am sure that it is the cooperation of the Member States of the European Union that can only contribute to the solution to the problem of the migrant crisis, but let us not forget why it occurred.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: Mr President, as I went through this umpteenth report on the terrible migration crisis facing our peoples, I first thought it was a salutary awareness. Indeed, you are aware that the integrity of the Schengen area and the removal of internal border controls depend on the effective management of external borders. You even go so far as to admit that the Union needs to strengthen the protection of its external borders. Alas, if you finally recognise the evidence that the control of the external borders of the European Union, a consideration expressly provided for by the Schengen Convention, is not respected, which turns our continent into a real sieve, you are not proposing any solution to remedy it. On the contrary, this report written by two MEPs (EPP and S-D) comes to the following conclusion: since Member States cannot prevent illegal immigration, then it must be legalised and organised. Among other crazy ideas, you say, and I quote, that 'Member States should remove any legal or practical obstacles to speed up decisions on family reunification'. So finally open your eyes and give up your globalist utopia that is breaking today on the wall of reality!

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – First of all, let me do one thing, namely to thank both rapporteurs for their honest approach to the whole subject.  Taking this material that they have prepared and which we are discussing here today, we can say that it contains all aspects of migration and, in my opinion, is an excellent basis for the migration debate.  However, we must not ignore the fact that the situation has changed dramatically since the initiative was launched and is changing every day. Although I largely agree with the report, it is, in my opinion, unrealistic in many respects and long overdue. It turns out that the model of redistribution supported in it is virtually impossible. I have warned several colleagues for a long time that refugees in many countries do not want to stay. A specific case from the Czech Republic only illustrates this. So why invent meaningless quotas?  As I have already mentioned, we must look for a comprehensive solution, and I agree with 70% of the text of this report, but I do not agree with one crucial thing on which this debate is shrinking, namely the redistribution of refugees.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the two co-rapporteurs, Mrs Kyenge and Mrs Metsola, for their long and difficult work in getting to this report.  The holistic approach of the report is fundamental and was what we also appreciated on the European immigration agenda, but today we are more concerned because this approach is being lost. We would have liked to have seen more courage in last week's Commission communication on the need to reform the common European asylum system, with a single strong position rather than several alternatives, and I strongly call on the Commission not to allow itself to be carried away by the selfishness of governments towards the usual and unsuccessful securitarian approach.  We are only prepared to work on an ambitious and comprehensive reform of Dublin, not cosmetic tweaks. What is the point of saying, as we do here, that Dublin is over, that it is not working and that it must be overcome, and then stop at a 'Dublin plus'? That would be a therapeutic relentlessness. The report clearly calls for solidarity and the fair distribution of responsibilities to be put at the centre, and calls for the criterion of the first country of access to be finally exceeded, but goes further towards centralising the examination of asylum applications, which would become a European responsibility.  What is happening in Idomeni is a source of shame for every European. People who shouldn't even be there if governments had taken their responsibilities and kept their relocation commitments. It must be clear that until the relocations really start, the whole system cannot work.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There is a word of solidarity in many speeches, but I would like to stress that only a safe and responsible Europe can effectively provide assistance to refugees. Only a europe that is responsible and secure can be truly united. I therefore share Mr Zdechovský's view that the report is a little late in view of the realistic turn that the European Union has made recently for the protection of the external borders, the supply of Frontex and the construction of a European border guard, which I strongly support.  I repeat once again: only a Europe that is responsible can be in real solidarity, which is why rational decisions must be taken: european border guards must be strengthened, not all trust must be placed in a relocation mechanism that is not functional, which is rejected by an important part of society and, above all, by refugees themselves, as the Members from Slovakia and the Czech Republic have said. Rationality is a prerequisite for effective solidarity.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE).
text: – In my opinion, the greatest achievement of the Metsoli report is to indicate what comprehensive measures are necessary to reduce the migration crisis in such a way that irregular migration is gradually replaced by a legal procedure for access to Europe. Although much remains to be done, it seems that the European Commission has already taken a step forward in preparing the proposal for a migration package. In this context, however, today the most depends on the Member States, which have their previous commitments in the European multifaceted plan to combat the migration crisis. So far, as we can see, the relocation mechanism has been a failure. Of the planned one hundred and sixty thousand resettlements, at most about 1,000 have been achieved.  Another problem is the effective prevention of secondary migration, if only in such a way that migrants are relocated in areas where there is the greatest demand due to labour market shortages. For this, however, member states need to prepare a map of the need for workers in certain professions and to properly train refugees. Thank you!

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, according to the United Nations, life expectancy in Syria during the war has increased from 77 to 55 years and this is exactly what many people are fleeing from North Africa and the Middle East to Europe. People who have the legal right to be welcomed and protected by Europe and who, for lack of a legal gateway, a common asylum system, have ended up entering through the window and making the Mediterranean the deadliest frontier in the world, with more than 3,500 deaths last year. In the face of this, the Institutions of the Union which have been overwhelmed, but above all, some Timorese Member States and national governments, which have blocked a solidarity response to this phenomenon. With honorable exceptions. For example, Germany welcomed more than one million people over the past year and Spain, in the relocation system, has only hosted eighteen people. All this has led to the closure of borders, to have people trapped in Greece in inhumane conditions, to put a stopper as a policy in the Aegean or to outsource our responsibilities to Turkey. That is why we demanded an answer to the idea of Europe, because Europe was not a map; it was an idea based on solidarity, a system of common immigration, of common asylum, of burden-sharing with a system of relocation and a policy of integration, labour integration, in line with circumstances.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Since this report began to be written, we have been facing an unprecedented migration crisis. And this cannot be combined with the crisis of the refugee situation, nor can it respond to the demographic problems of some Member States. Only a fraction of the masses heading to Europe are genuine refugees, most of whom we can help by supporting reception camps close to their country. If they can be provided with dignible conditions, health care and education, we will make it easier for them to return to their home countries as the situation stabilises. And for immigrants arriving for a better living, clear, clear messages must be sent. Every ambitable gesture is interpreted as an invitation to hundreds of thousands of others who risk their lives in this way. Solidarity can take many forms, not artificially imposed mandatory quotas. We need to strengthen and protect our external borders. That is why I think it is important that, after months of inaction, decisive action has been taken on the Western Balkans route to alleviate migrant pressure. We must stop the uncontrolled arrival of hundreds of thousands of people into the Union, because we have all seen recently the serious security risks of this.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Kyenge-Metsola report proposes solidarity and common sense, unlike what I saw in the wild camp in Idomeni, where yesterday men, women and children were miserably shot by forces in neighbouring FYROM. The opposite is also the opposite of the EU-Turkey agreement, which focuses on forced return, which puts the European Union in violation of international law and human rights, also by detaining thousands in hotspots, as I saw in Moria, Lesbos – in fact, a detention centre. It doesn't dedeterrent refugees from coming and gives more business to the mafias of traffickers.  Without proclaiming it, Chancellor Merkel does the opposite of what she has proclaimed in the summer: she gives in to populism and puts the Union into deportation of asylum seekers. And so the Commission and the Council do not sanction the members of Visegrad, shamefully captained by Austria, who, in gang, violate Schengen, closing borders, choking Greece and now building walls with Italy.  This is not a refugee crisis, it is a European crisis of leadership and values. I'm ashamed of myself.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – Back in February, the Commission published a proposal for an index of regions' social progress according to indicators going beyond GDP. According to him, social progress in the so-called old Member States is significantly higher than in the new ones, plus in Italy and Greece. It is these states that have a problem in accepting refugees, and the Social Progress Index explains why they simply have trouble ensuring decent conditions for the lives of a large part of their own populations. It is not fair to impose on them the obligation to accept other dependent refugee people. The present report still sticks to criteria such as GDP, which do not reflect the reality of determining the quotas of enforced solidarity. The poorer half of Europe must reject this. You need to look for another solution. Therefore, I will not support the report.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Everyone talks about solidarity. The only solidarity I see today is the joint action to dismantle respect for human rights and the fundamental values of the European Union. What we are seeing today in Europe is that we are locking up refugees, we are deporting them to an increasingly authoritarian state. We see a candidate country firing tear gas at women and children. Thus, the EU is doing everything possible not to assume its responsibilities, according to the UN Refugee Commission. They say we don't have the resources to receive more. One example: at the same time, border controls between Sweden and Denmark cost about EUR 300 000 every day. The problem is not money. The problem is the rise in nationalism and xenophobia that is affecting politics today. This issue will determine the future of Europe. We must send out a clear signal of a new direction for migration policy, based on respect for human rights, in which we stand up in the sun for what europe's fundamental values are about. Refugees should be regarded as people with fundamental rights, whose lives are worth being saved and protected. We need immediate action that saves lives and creates safe and legal routes to Europe. To Kristina Winberg's speech on unemployment in Sweden, I would just like to point out that it is a lie. She's lying. We are actually down to six percent in Sweden today.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you always have my esteem and all my support for what you have done for Italy. But it is time to act, to act forcefully, of course in all the peaceful ways that we have. I would like to draw your attention, and I would also like to thank the rapporteurs, on a number of points.  Schengen: the governments are not asking for it, our people are asking for it, our businesses, our frontier workers, artisans and farmers are asking not to close their borders. The closure of the Brenner only affects Italian workers, not illegal immigrants. No to Schengen means that all refugees and illegal immigrants would remain in Italy, because there is no amendment to the Dublin Treaty. And so truly those who love Italy and those who love their homeland must fight to close the external borders and not the internal ones.  European countries that do not respect quotas, I am sorry, do not receive European funds. I have also said this in recent years: there is no longer a time for solidarity when one does not show it to you. And I'll end with the repatriations. Repatriations are fundamental to us, as we also wrote as the PPE in the Milan document, and if a country of origin – I am going to conclude, Mr President – does not help us, we cannot give aid. So when it naturally agrees to have its citizens back, whether or not they are illegal, they will also receive our trade agreements.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Mr President, not long ago, a non-European international leader pointed out that the European Union should be declared a political, social and cultural heritage of humanity because we were a soft power intervening in conflict resolution, ensuring social protection for our citizens and those who live with us, showing internal and outward solidarity, practicing tolerance and practicing pluralism. Can we keep saying we're that model? The humanitarian crisis has shown that we are squandering the moral power before the world, and we will only rebuild that much-needed European Union if we are able to respond decisively to this humanitarian crisis. The report we are debating today is the report on the right track. Solidarity with immigrants; respect for international laws and humanitarian law; dignity with the human rights of immigrants.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that today's debate will be the last opportunity for discussion and debate in this House on an absolutely strategic issue, such as immigration, on which we are playing a great deal of credibility.  All too often we have spent hours of our time in this Parliament debating, debating and greeting with great satisfaction some of the choices made by the Juncker Commission, and then recording their failure, thanks above all to the insensitivity and inability of the Council in particular. That is why we need to tackle and resolve once and for all the issue of returns, to which Mr Syod has referred. Comi, of those who do not qualify for political asylum. That is why the issue of amending the Dublin 3 Regulation, which is the real anomaly of the European reception system, must be addressed and resolved once and for all. Only in this way can the right balance be struck between the requirements of solidarity, those of concrete solidarity, but also of security, which is a priority for Europe.  Commissioner – and I am coming to my conclusion – the solution to the problem of immigration cannot be just the agreement with Turkey, which has cost six billion euros, which is in fact blocking the flow of migrants from the Balkan route and transferring it to the Mediterranean route.

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you have been talking for several years now about the need for a comprehensive policy on the refugee crisis and migration, and it is still not working.  There can be no successful migration policy for only one external border or with just one agreement, as concluded with Turkey.  Maritime operations off Italian shores have directed refugees to the Balkans. The closure of the Balkan route brought them back to the doors of Italy. Now new corridors will open through Bulgaria and through Albania. The agreement with Turkey is not a benchmark for European policy, it has started to buoy, it creates more problems than concrete results. The new border and coast guard strategy will keep Schengen Europe as a fortress, but has left three countries – Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia - out of this policy. Finally, the Commission is proposing new ideas for reforming Dublin. We expected more, Commissioner, you only offer cosmetic adjustments. Again, the solidarity principle will be surrounded, and to some countries there will definitely be a double standard. You asked if the crisis was an opportunity to deal with or a disaster. There is no such dilemma, Mr. Avramopoulos, because the crisis has taken thousands of lives already.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Mr President, I think we are on the right track, despite the difficulties, because the balance is slowly being restored. In other words, in the last two weeks we have had an 80% reduction in flows, which is a very positive development, because we do not want a fortress Europe, we want a Europe that accepts the persecuted, accepts the poor, but accepts them at a pace that does not put its own social and political system to the test.  Just the fact that all the people who have a problem around the world are looking for a better better fate in the European Union, I think it shows that, despite our problems, we also have great successes that we must support. I therefore believe that by restoring balance, by limiting flows, we will be able to manage the problem in a humane and cost-effective way.  Finally, I would like to say a few words about my British colleagues, who have a negative attitude, I would say, to some of them. I do not think we are doing anything different at European Union level than they are at Commonwealth level, and I think that what they have been doing, in general, in recent decades in the United Kingdom, is right. So, as they give a poor Pakistani a chance, shouldn't we give a terrified Iraqi a chance?

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Metsola and Mrs Kyenge for their excellent work. Immigration, which is no longer an emergency, but has become almost a structural problem, requires a systemic response and a constant and shared commitment on the part of all Member States. The scenes of which we are also witnessing these days unfortunately show us an approach that is still fragmented and inadequate to the management of the migratory flow that continues to grow.  And if in such a dramatic situation we can talk about priorities, we should look at the issue of minors, especially unaccompanied minors, ten thousand of whom have disappeared in Europe in the last two years. That is why I have tried to contribute to the drafting of the report with a number of amendments on this point. However, the Commission must follow up the provisions of the European Agenda on Migration by preparing and implementing a comprehensive strategy that adequately protects unaccompanied minors, in order to prevent their disappearance and thus prevent them from running serious risks.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, with this report, Parliament is asserting real European sovereignty, bringing about a powerful, comprehensive and coordinated response to the refugee crisis. The priorities are clear: we need to address the root causes in our neighbourhood countries, we need to ensure the proper reception, redistribution and integration of refugees across Europe, and we need to build up a real European border. But we need to have a clear vision about what the European border should be. This is not a wall. This is rather a border system ensuring control of movement but, most of all, decent, dignified reception and distribution of refugees in connection with the relocation centres and in connection with the whole system of resettlement in our neighbourhood countries. The next step, which is decisive, is to replace the Dublin system with a real European system. We should be clear that all Member States which want to benefit from this European border must make a contribution to this European asylum system.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which A holistic approach to the Mediterranean must also take into account the financial dimension of this task. Anyone who wants an area without borders cannot leave the states with the external borders alone. Neither Greece nor economically stronger Italy can guard the long coastline alone and rescue the shipwrecked. Frontex is now to be strengthened, which I think is right, and to grow out of its previous role as a consultant into a coordinating role. This will cost money, even if the Agency is not to bear the personnel costs for staffing from other Member States. I am concerned that, with all the necessary efforts to protect the border, we are losing sight of the humanitarian side. Coastal protection must also include the search and rescue of shipwrecked people. That is why I support the fact that search and rescue is becoming a task for a European coastal protection agency and that this too must be adequately funded.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I rise to express my full support for the motion for a resolution before us, because it is capable of a synthesis useful for taking concrete steps towards a common policy in the European Union, through a fair assumption of responsibility on the part of all, a condition that also responds to the demand for security. Two highlights among many: the need for a centralised asylum system to manage the growing flows of migrants and asylum seekers and humanitarian corridors, legal channels and secure legal instruments, such as humanitarian visas, to guarantee third-country nationals entry into the Union, without having to risk their lives and having to resort to human traffickers. In this regard, significantly, on April 16, Pope Francis with Patriarch Bartholomew and the Archbishop of Athens will travel to Lesbos, the island already referred to as the Lampedusa of the Aegean.  Another strong, authoritative call for the Union to build bridges and not walls, through the assumption of responsibilities based on realism and concreteness.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, more than ten years ago, on 29 January 2004, in this Chamber, un secretary-general Kofi Annan, in a magnificent speech receiving the Sakharov Prize, told us that population movements were not going to stop and that, as an international community, we had to "manage much better than we do now cross-border movements. , not only for the sake of the people who are on the move, but also for the sake of the countries they have left, the countries they cross and the countries to which they migrate." That is exactly what The report from Ms. Metsola and Ms. Kyenge proposes to do. I therefore want to thank them and congratulate them because, fundamentally, behind their report there is the question of our capacity for integration. Some would like to maintain the confusion between, on the one hand, refugees who would be destined to return to their country and, on the other, economic migrants who would have to be driven out.  The reality is that refugees are now in our societies, in our states, for periods that no one can imagine will be short-lived. Therefore, everything proposed in this report for integration policy to be a success must be strongly supported not only by this European Parliament, but also by the Commission, in a comprehensive approach.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr. President, I congratulate my colleagues on their content report, and I particularly agree with the calls for a revision of the Dublin and Blue Card systems. We need new rules in integrating migrants into the labour market in line with the needs of member states. We also need mutual recognition of approved asylum applications between members, clear measures when it comes to rescue operations, as well as sharing responsibilities between members when it comes to sites. In the context of the discussions we are leading right now on the proposal to establish a European Border and Coast Guard, this report is a great reference.  As a member of Croatia, a country through which over 650,000 people have passed without a single incident since September last year, and which has been fenced off by wire from the rest of the European Union, I would like to highlight in particular a passage that correctly emphasises that the new proposals should not only cover the Schengen area but also the external borders of the European Union.  It would be a good idea for future European policies on migration and border control to have similar consensus support in the European Parliament on this report.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: We have completed the list of registered speakers. I have received 15 requests for the catch the eye procedure, but we are already off schedule with a significant delay and we are obliged to be on time for the votes at 12.30. I will therefore only accept five, one from each political group, to proceed on schedule.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – I very much appreciate the report on the Mediterranean and the comprehensive approach, on the migration crisis, which very truthfully describes the situation and describes it through the eyes of those who live in these countries.  My colleague Metsola, through the eyes of an MEP from Malta, a situation that shows well the attitude and perception of Members from Italy, Greece. They are doing a great job there for the benefit of refugees, but I would like them to listen to those who have different experiences. To those who call for solidarity to go hand in hand with security.  It's not against refugees. We want security measures for all Europeans and also for refugees, so that Europe is safe for both Europeans and refugees. That is why we are calling for the immediate introduction of external border protection so that Europe is safer.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The situation of refugees in the Mediterranean is catastrophic and, in my view, it is a disgrace to Europe that thousands of people drown every year as they flee in the Mediterranean. I would like to thank the rapporteurs for incorporateing the need for a holistic EU approach to migration in their report. The cessation of the European maritime rescue programme, Mare Nostrum, has begun an incredible patchwork of Member States. In this context, I am grateful to the initiatives of civil society for closing this gap. I would like to highlight the initiative of the private European maritime rescue sos Méditerranée. It is an association of initiatives from Germany, France and Italy. I have also supported this initiative since last May, because it is clearly committed to a stronger public discourse on combating the causes of flight. That is what we are fighting for here in the European Parliament. I would also like to thank the Commission for its commitment to reforming the old Dublin Agreement in order to achieve a permanent relocation mechanism.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Greece, following the influx of refugees and illegal immigrants, is marginal. Thousands of refugees continue to be stranded in Idomeni, on the border with Skopje, and as the relocation process has not started, the refugees are not even persuaded to go to the relocation and registration centres, since of the 66,400 refugees to be relocated to other European Union countries, only 569 people have been relocated from Greece, and as if that were not enough , the Macedonians, constantly violating Greece's territorial sovereignty, attacked thousands of refugees, children and women with rubber bullets, chemicals and flash grenades, injuring hundreds.  We must therefore, Mr Avraboule, finally put in place the process of relocating at least 6 000 refugees a month, as you have already said. In addition, the European Union-Turkey agreement must be systematically implemented and Ankara called upon to put an end to illegal migration flows to the Aegean islands.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we need a comprehensive and humane approach to immigration and an honest view of our economic relations with the world if we are to resolve this crisis. Commissioner, I appreciate your efforts, but the phrases you have repeated the most have been 'you have to replace...', 'we must improve...', 'we have to create...', while living with figures of missing children, images of gassed people and refugee camps that make us feel ashamed. We are tired of debates and words and need concrete proposals such as the ones you are announcing and those contained in the report we are discussing today. I would therefore like to ask you: how long do you intend to implement these measures? Do you have the commitment of the Member States, which are closing borders and refusing to accept their quotas and build harmonised systems? We need facts, clear responses and the commitment of States, which are a clear obstacle in managing the crisis of these people. And finally, if they refuse, what tools do you have to force them to act with democratic values and social justice, which are the hallmark of European identity? I would like you, Commissioner, to answer these three questions.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to deal with the refugee crisis, as the report rightly states, practical solidarity is needed. Equally important is the recognition of the failure of the Dublin Regulation and the call for the creation of legal and safe routes, the sharing of responsibilities in the Member States and the protection of the rights of refugees.  Unfortunately, however, the report also supports inhuman military operations, NATO's involvement in the Aegean sea and the strengthening of border controls, which make Europe a fortress and sustain crime against refugees. Just as unacceptable, in our view, is the call for the implementation of the European Union-Turkey Action Plan, which aims to rid the Union of refugees. An agreement which, in our view, violates international legitimacy, as the United Nations Commission has denounced.  With these policies, the Union's responsibilities for the military interventions that caused the crisis appeal are increasing dramatically. We demand that crime be stopped and that the Member States that receive the largest waves of refugees be directly supported. The European Union has become a country that maintains hot spots as concentration camps and that itself tramples on the human rights of refugees.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, could you please inform me what is the basis for discriminating against those Members who do not belong to a party but who are independent and non-inscrit? Why did you not give me the floor? I have been sitting here with a handful of other people – there are about a dozen people here – since 8.30, listening to the debate, and you refuse to give me the floor just because I do not belong to one of the party factions. This is very unfair. Do you agree with me?

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Thank you, Mrs Morvai, I have listened carefully to what you have said to me, there is no discrimination. I fully apply the Rules of Procedure and the powers it gives to the President. They asked 15 colleagues to speak under the Catch-the-Eye procedure, I explained why I can only give to 5, and it was accepted by everyone but you who protested by hitting the benches. I can assure you that I fully support the Rules of Procedure and there is no discrimination against anyone.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. –  Mr President, first of all I would like to express my thanks for this very constructive debate. There is no doubt that migration is a controversial topic. We should avoid playing on the stereotypes. On the contrary, I would say, we have to fight stereotypes. The images of migrants being tear gassed do no honour to our European history and values or to our civilisation. We have to treat these people with respect, but we also need to have a plan – a policy – and to implement this policy, and this is where the problem sometimes lies. This brings me to what many of you have mentioned during this debate. Relocation, yes, has to work. The numbers were mentioned before. Only 1 145 persons have been relocated since mid-March. It is unacceptable. And from this House I again appeal to Member States to make it happen, and to work at the same time on settlement. Later today the Commission will present a report on where we stand on relocation and resettlement. We need an objective and fair reform of rules on migrants for the European citizens, for the Member States and for our partners abroad. We need a policy that does not lead to closing borders, putting Schengen at risk. You know my position on fences and the closure of borders. I believe in building bridges, not walls. In particular, when there is a dispute between Member States, Schengen states – as is the case now, for example, between Italy and Austria – that this is not the proper solution. It is clear that the asylum system as it stands today is not functioning. Europe has to adapt its migration policy to provide orderly and safe pathways to the European Union for those who need protection and those who can contribute with their skills and talents to the European Union’s economic development. We need to share responsibility, reduce irregular arrivals, and prevent and sanction secondary movements. Let me be clear here, however: we do not want a cosmetic reform. We want an ambitious and substantial improvement of Dublin which leads to fair outcomes for everyone. A key point that some of you mentioned is that children, especially unaccompanied children, need protection, and this is what we have to ensure by all means possible. Many of you mentioned the EU-Turkey deal. Let me be frank with you. We – both the European Union and Turkey – have to use the common challenges we are facing as an opportunity to better respond to them and forge closer links through this cooperation. This can only be beneficial for both parties. Implementation, as I said before, is difficult. It is already difficult to cooperate among Member States and even more difficult with third countries, but we have achieved some important progress. I can assure you that this Commission, in close cooperation with governments, international organisations and NGOs, is investing a lot of effort and human resources and providing daily monitoring and dedication to make this deal work, while fully respecting European and international law. Turkey has adopted legislative changes in order to ensure that in practice all Syrians in Turkey will be granted protection or have their protection renewed. Discussions are ongoing to ensure that non-Syrians in need of international protection will have access to asylum procedures, and resettlement from Turkey has already started. Member States are deploying officers to the Greek islands. It is becoming clear now that frontline Member States need support to manage the situation, and the flows have decreased. Fewer people are putting their lives at risk; there are fewer victims of smugglers. This is what we want to achieve on a permanent basis. As some of you have rightly said, this is indeed a global challenge and requires a global response. That is why we keep an open channel of cooperation with UNHCR, the United Nations. This is why resettlement is a responsibility not just for the European Union but for all international partners, for the United States and Canada to the Gulf States. The Commission is determined to improve and strengthen our system to respond to the real needs of the new reality, whether that is asylum, legal migration, migration border systems or security. This not only means changing legislation, it also means putting the necessary human and financial resources together to effectively address the structural deficiencies of our migration and asylum system as a Union. Several of you mentioned the need to have a budget. I could not agree more, and I hope that I can count on your support to get it. We want to make our policies fit for purpose in the context of the challenges of the 21st century. This means building on what we have achieved so far but also being bold and honest to radically improve where needed. We are eager to take up a discussion with you, the European Parliament, as well as other stakeholders, to make all these ideas concrete.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Please don't be alarmed! Don't make me apply the Rules of Procedure. Please, Mrs Morvai, respect everyone else!

name: Roberta Metsola
text: Mr . – Nixtieq nirringrazzja flower-collo-kolleha li qagħdu hawnhekk tul din id-discusjoni twila u nirringrazzja wkoll lil hawkl min tana l-appoġġ matul dan il-pro大ess. Nixtieq nammetti li, meta bdejna dal-pro大ess 'il fuq minn sena beauty, i kontx naħseb li ser insibu ruħna hawnhekk, għaliex kif smajna tul id-diskussjoni dalgħodu, għandna kollegi li jaħsbu li dan ir-Rapport ser jikkrea Fortizza Ewropea, meta għandek kollegi ora li li jaħsbu li dan irħb ser jiftaħ il-bibien kollha.  Ir-risposta tiegħi hija li dawk iż-żewġ soluzzjonijiet jew dawk iż-żewġ argumenti ma jreġux. Aħna li ridna huwa li noħolqu bilan大, li noħolqu maġġoranza ta' kollegi f'din il-Plenarja li taqbel illi għandna jkollna soluzzjonijiet li għandhom viżjoni, li huma konkreti u li ambi humazzjużi, kif għadu kif qal il-sarsju. U jiena nixtieq li dan ir-Rapport ikun dik il-pjattaforma li jmur lil hinn minn dak li għamilna minn mindu jiena dħalt f'dan il-Parlament, fejn dejjem nadottaw riżoluzzjoni wara riżoluzzjoni li jgħiduħħ afna imma li imma li ijjjejn. Jiena nixtieq illum f'dan ir-Rapport nibagħtu messaġġ ħar minn din l-istituzzjoni li tixtieq li jkollna azzjoni konkreta fuq l-immigrazzjoni, anki fid-dawl tal-fatt li l-kriżi mhijiex ser tiġi riżolta, anki fid-dawl tal-fatt li għandna problemi fil-pajjiżi ġirien tagħna li mhumiex se jk riżolti malajr. Jiena nixtieq li llum, fi ftit ħin ieħor, ikollna rapport li jista' jiġi approvat mill-maġoranza ta' din il-Kamra, ħalli anki nibagħtu messaġġ lill-istituzzjonijiet l-oħra li l-Parlament Ewropew huwa kapaħi jieħu deħiżjonijiet ambizzjużi u kuraġjużi f'dan it-temp ta' kriżi li qħdin fih bħa.

name: Kashetu Kyenge
text: Rapporteur. Thank you, Mr President, and thank you to all my fellow Members who have contributed to this debate and to all those who have worked with us on this report.  Commissioner, like you, I wonder every day whether we will succeed in turning this crisis into an opportunity and whether we will be able to lay the foundations for a new society characterised by human mobility. Will we be able to lay the foundations for a common migration policy that is equal to the challenges of the twenty-first century? Yes, Mr President, we will succeed, but only if we are able to base our future policies on respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and the principles also enshrined in international law.  What is happening on the Greek-Macedonian border is shameful and the Member States must take responsibility for their actions. This resolution is only the first step on a political path that will bear fruit only if there is unity of purpose, only if the Member States decide once and for all to put aside the new policies of closure, to break down protective walls and to treat migratory flows as invasions.  We cannot deny our assistance to 0.2 % of the population of migrants. We cannot deny a process of integration to those fleeing war and persecution or simply to those who seek a better life prospect in our territories and stop criminalising certain realities and throwing mud on neighbourhoods that are experiencing difficult situations. Those who speak in these terms of Molenbeek, as well as the situation in so many other suburbs, do so in order to put their consciences in order and to gain easy electoral support.  The message I am sending out from this House today is different: rather, I call for us to come together, to join forces to build a society that can manage flows and develop resilience to migration.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – We cannot talk about migration as somebody else’s business. As the stronghold of democracy and liberal values, the EU should care about those lives lost at the sea. In the name of the security and prosperity of our peoples the EU should develop a well-functioning, strong mechanism to be able to adequately respond to this challenge of our highly globalised and interdependent world. We have to apply a holistic approach, which means involvement of all the stakeholders and setting the rules of play. The common external border of the EU should be strengthened and managed effectively and inside the EU the Schengen rules must be obeyed. Now we clearly see all disadvantages and gaps of the Dublin III Regulation and call for changes needed to ensure fairness, solidarity and shared responsibility between the EU Member States, as mentioned in the report. Moreover, crucial measures should be taken not only inside the EU managing migration. The Union should also help build necessary capacities in third countries to address the root causes of migration.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Faced with the peril posed by the massive and uncontrolled immigration that European states are experiencing, this Parliament already seems to be capitulating. We are being offered to manage a catastrophe when we can avoid further human tragedies and prevent the destabilization of our societies. The only smart borders are national borders.  The only acceptable asylum system is that of nation states, since citizenship is defined by belonging to a people and a nation. Alas, it is not your Europe of impotence and cultural amnesia that will have succeeded in forging the same community. You are looking at how to deal with the incessant flows into Europe when the urgency is needed to put an end to these inhumane displacements of people. You are responsible for the appearance of this gigantic cemetery that is the Mediterranean. Stop maintaining this air call and save Europe.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. – According to Frontex, 1.83 million people tried to enter the EU illegally last year, several times more than the previous years, and once again more points to the scale of the refugee crisis. From the perspective of the EU budget, I welcome the increase in asylum, migration and integration funding for last year and this year, but I regret the reduction in funding for legal migration and integration and better, fairer and effective return strategies. There is also a great deal of room for improvement in transparency over the use of funds for the functioning of Member States and third countries in the areas of migration, asylum and border management, thus giving a clearer picture of the European Union's overall spending on migration. The scale of the crisis and the need for swift action should not be an alibi for the opaque use of funds from the European Union budget.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – Mr President, the report touches on a very important topic on migration, which has become a problem for all The Member States of the European Union. Frontex figures alleging that 1.83 million people were detained in 2015. people trying to cross the EU's borders illegally are worrying and demand action by the Institutions of the European Union. Attention should therefore be paid to a number of important issues relating to migration. First of all, let us not forget that the influx of refugees is used by illegal carriers, that is, human smugglers. It is good that the report raises the need to combat this phenomenon at international level in order to eradicate human traffickers' networks and prevent the smuggling of migrants. Secondly, the European Union must effectively manage the protection of its external borders and put in place a transparent and uniformly understood visa policy in all EU countries. Cooperation with third countries is also of strategic importance in order to avoid the root causes of migration. And, above all, let us not forget that, when creating a new legal framework on migration, we must first not forget about ensuring the security of our citizens. All these activities shall be based on proportionate and appropriate financial support allocated to Member States in order to enable them to implement the safeguard mechanisms as soon as possible. In conclusion, I would like to stress that our main task should be the consistency of decision-making, which is lacking today on migration issues.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda concerns the oral question to the Commission on Measures to mitigate the impact of the crisis on the European agricultural sector, by Czesław Adam Siekierski, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (O-000055/2016 - B8-0352/2016) (2016/2611(RSP))

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski
text: Author. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Today we are once again discussing the difficult situation on agricultural markets in Parliament. At the outset, it is worth asking: why have the actions taken under the CAP instruments not produced the expected results? I am thinking here of the EUR 500 million aid scheme introduced last year, financing the private storage of milk powder, butter, cheese or pork. Efforts to limit the effects of the Russian embargo have also been extended.  We have repeatedly pointed out at Committee on Agriculture's level the impact of external conditions – that is, the situation on world markets – on what is happening on our European market. Global food prices have been falling in recent years, up 19% in 2015. Brazil, Argentina, m.in, as well as the weakness of their currencies, have clearly increased their production. Brazil is expected to replace the US as the world's largest soybean producer this season. Argentina has also increased its wheat production and exports as a result of the reduction in the export tax. Cereal harvests in Russia are also growing. All this is taking place with the declining demand for food from China, India. The Russian embargo, which is in its second year (as I have already mentioned), also had an impact on Europe.  A year ago, we abolished milk quotas, which encouraged many producers to increase production. Let us remember the forecasts of a 65-70% increase in food demand in 2050 as a result of the projected increase in the world's population to 9 or 10 billion people and the resulting increase in consumption, which has encouraged many farmers to increase their production.  So, with such complex external conditions, the instruments that we use in the so-called safety net are ineffective. Waiting for possible solutions to the mid-term review is to postpone the problem, which increases farmers' dissatisfaction. I think we underestimate the determination of farmers, which can end in mass protests.  Milk prices are already falling below the cost of production, as is the case in the pork market. This leads to a lack of financial resources for the continuation of production and, as a result, to the collapse of farms. Many farmers at risk of bankruptcy do not see an opportunity for their future in the agricultural sector. This will lead to a further increase in the size of farms, the scale of production and its intensity, which means moving away from the European agricultural model: sustainable and environmentally friendly. In this context, specific questions have been formulated as part of our general question. Firstly, could the Commission discuss more broadly the next steps taken to reduce the pressure on farmers in the sectors most affected? Secondly, how does the Commission assess the effectiveness of the 2015 aid package? Thirdly, how will the Commission combat unfair practices in the food supply chain and how will it ensure a fair income for farmers? Fourthly, what precautions can be taken to counteract the effects of future upheavals and disturbances on agriculture outside the borders? (What I developed at the beginning of my speech.) Fifthly, how will the Commission ensure that, following discussions with financial institutions, flexible and innovative financial instruments that producers can use are made available in a practical form? Commissioner Hogan is working very intensively in this area. It therefore seems that there is an urgent need to adopt measures for today, mainly by continuing the instruments and trends already in place, but at a correspondingly higher level – I repeat: a higher level – which would at least improve the very difficult current situation of farmers. The increase in de minimis aid can also be analysed, as it appears that additional direct support for farms is needed in such a complex situation. In this situation, farmers' expectations of the announced financial instruments and the possibility of using the European Strategic Investment Fund for important investments in the agricultural sector are increasing.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome the opportunity to address this House at a time of crisis in the agricultural markets in several of our Member States and indeed, to some extent, in all of them, particularly in the dairy and pigmeat sectors. It is just a few weeks since the Commission proposed another set of measures to provide much-needed support for European farmers. I was pleased to have the opportunity to brief the members of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) of this House immediately after that proposal was made. Yesterday I briefed the Council of Agriculture Ministers on the significant progress that has been made in the implementation of that package of measures of 14 March. In order to provide Members with the most up-to-date information on the implementation of that package, I have written to the Chair of AGRI with full details of the follow-up to the Council, and I hope that the information can be made widely available, because I know I have limited time here. This morning I want to focus briefly on a number of the main areas that featured in the March package. I am pleased to confirm that just yesterday the Commission adopted three draft regulations. The first of these provides for a doubling of the intervention ceilings for skimmed milk powder and butter. It is now the responsibility of the Council to approve this proposal swiftly, and I expect that they will do so in the next few days. I also want to reassure you that the Commission is committed to running a tender responsibly and in a way that helps the market and does not depress prices. In relation to the introduction of the voluntary supply management in the dairy sector, the Commission is activating the provisions of Article 222 of the CMO Regulation. The implementing regulation allowing for agreements between recognised producer organisations, their associations and recognised inter-branch organisations to plan milk production for a temporary period of six months and the delegated regulation extending the measure to cooperatives and other forms of milk producer organisations were also both adopted by the Commission yesterday. The responsibility for their speedy implementation is now with the co-legislators, and I call on you to seize that responsibility with a view to ensuring that this measure is used as an effective contribution towards greater market balance in the dairy sector. In order to encourage use of this tool as an effective contributor to this crisis, I met two weeks ago with COPA-COGECA and the European Dairy Association. I also want to draw the attention of the House, in respect of what Mr Siekierski said, to the fact that I have doubled state aid ceilings on a temporary basis to allow for greater flexibility for Member States in supporting their farmers. I want to reassure the House that the Commission has and is continuing to make every effort to lift the protectionist ban that has been imposed by Russia on pig products from the European Union. Over recent months and in parallel with the WTO procedure, the Commission has made numerous efforts to convince Russia to engage in meaningful technical negotiations for an agreed solution at EU level. We also made clear that we are ready to examine any concrete proposal that Russian may submit to the European Union. Commissioner Andriukaitis expressed the Commission’s position on this matter during a meeting with the Russian ambassador to the EU last month, and he continues to pursue efforts towards the lifting of the ban. Even though, so far, the Russian reaction has not been positive, the dialogue remains open. Over the past two years, the Commission has mobilised more than EUR 1 billion in additional funding to support our farmers, which complements the EUR 56 billion which farmers receive each year. As part of that, and in response to the deteriorating market situation last summer, you will recall that the Commission took swift action in September and provided a EUR 500 million package, including EUR 420 million in direct targeted aid.  Despite the loss of the Russian market, the EU is continuing to trade very successfully. EU dairy and pigmeat exports increased by 11% and 23%, respectively, in January 2016 compared with last year. However, this has not yet translated into the pockets of farmers in terms of improving their income. The increase in dairy exports reflected a significant improvement in import demand, once again, from China. I have prioritised a number of areas and countries to visit to identify and build on new market opportunities. I have just returned from Colombia and Mexico and tomorrow I leave for Kazakhstan, China and Japan. Following my visit to Mexico, we have received some very encouraging news in relation to pigmeat opportunities: the market is opening for fresh pigmeat and processed hams from Spain, we expect the approval for fresh pigmeat from France very shortly, and there are good prospects for fresh pigmeat from Germany, Romania and Italy. An audit is scheduled in May for Poland, after which I hope to see opportunities for fresh pigmeat products. Before passing judgement on the effectiveness of either the September package or the proposals I made last month, I would urge you to give those measures the opportunity to work. In particular, I would point to the fact that, at the end of February, only EUR 162 million of the EUR 420 million that I allocated to Member States last September had been spent in 14 Member States. I accept that Member States have until the end of June to spend this money, but I would appreciate it if they had the intentions to invest it in structural change, something which I welcome. Last month the Council had the opportunity to exchange views with the Vice-President of the European Investment Bank with regard to the development by the EIB of additional financial products and financial instruments for the benefit of farmers and processors. The Commission is prioritising its engagement with the EIB with a view to developing the appropriate financial instruments to assist farmers and processors in investing in their enterprises in order to improve the competitiveness of those enterprises or in investing in making any necessary structural adjustments. Yesterday, Vice-President Katainen told the Council of the opportunities offered by the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) in agriculture. Member States have been encouraged to look into the possibilities of setting up dedicated platforms for EFSI financing. It is essential that full use is made of the opportunities on offer. The Commission’s response to date, even though in a difficult financial situation, has been swift and robust. This package of measures, when taken with the full implementation of the September solidarity package, can have a material and positive impact on European agricultural markets. I would ask for your support for the measures proposed, and I believe that we should give them a chance to succeed and, like all of you, I look forward to a better market in the future. Finally, regarding the question on the food chain that was put by Mr Siekierski, I expect proposals from the AGRI task force to be submitted to me in September this year.

name: Albert Deß
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Many thanks to all those involved who have made it possible for us to discuss today the current situation in agriculture in the European Union. We are very concerned about the situation on the agricultural markets. And we also note that the measures taken so far are not working properly. We continue to have enormous price pressure on a wide range of agricultural markets and, Commissioner, I believe that we must all think together about how we can react more quickly, how we do not react until the child has fallen into the well.  In one of the last speeches, I have just mentioned the situation in the milk sector. The current intervention price system, that does not work. We need a different system, and we must all work together on this. We need a system whereby the Commission or a body can decide that certain quantities are withdrawn from the market at some point – not withdrawn from the market until we are at 22 or 20 cents milk price. And we could create such a system here. We have a completely free capital market, and yet central banks keep intervening in this capital market. If this market does not work, quantities will be withdrawn from the capital market. We need a similar system in agriculture so that we can intervene more quickly in the market situation.  As far as the situation with the retail chains is concerned, I am of course best aware of the situation in Germany, and we have huge retail chains. Here, too, I am very concerned – here legislation is passing the parliaments – that my dairy recently received a questionnaire with 47 requirements to meet the requirements that farmers are supposed to document, at a time when they are offering the worst deals. That is why, Commissioner, we must all work together to achieve a better situation in our markets.

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a few months later, we find ourselves discussing the serious crisis that is now affecting the majority of agricultural markets. The continuation of this situation calls for a thorough reflection on the responses that have been put in place: the idea of identifying resources to be managed at the level of the individual Member State is in fact proving ineffective, with the risk of a progressive renationalisation of a policy that has historically been a factor of European integration such as the CAP. This is demonstrated by the insignificant effects of the EUR 450 million allocated to the milk sector last autumn: the dispersion of these resources has in fact mortified the potential for organised use aimed at curbing European production. The search for urgent responses to the crisis must therefore not affect the ability to face complex challenges at European level, such as safeguarding the economic, social and environmental role of agriculture. The time has come to give serious thought to a mid-term review of the CAP.

name: James Nicholson
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I think everyone agrees that the crisis in agriculture throughout Europe has been about the worst we have experienced – certainly it is the worst experienced in my political lifetime of almost 27 years in this Parliament. I would like to say first that I do welcome the measures that have been taking place, but I have to say that they were not the solution. I also have to say that there are no easy solutions to the present problem we have. Commissioner, I would also like to say to you that, on the one hand, we are doing – and you are doing – all we can to help, but on the other hand, we are using agriculture as a bargaining chip in free trade negotiations with Mercosur and with TTIP. Is that a sensible way to go forward? Do you really understand that farmers cannot understand where Europe is hoping to go? You came to the Committee on Agriculture recently and you said that you were going to tackle bureaucracy and that there would be changes in the yellow card, for instance: one strike and two strikes. Now I understand that the Court of Auditors is making sure that does not happen! Commissioner, it has become even more complicated than what you tried to solve. Will you take that up and try and solve it?

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – The market situation of all our farmers and gardeners deserves attention. But we must talk about structural measures, otherwise we will be back here soon.  I am particularly interested in whether the EUR 500 million allocated by the EU seven months ago has really made a difference to the agricultural sector. Do we continue to suggest that politics can do something for market recovery or do we make real choices to make the sector stronger and healthier? Europe must take a one course and work towards improved competitiveness. First of all, look seriously at the cost side. Nationally and Europeanly, we must curb the regulatory drive. Ensure effective rules and leave room for innovation and entrepreneurship. With new techniques and insights, we can produce more efficiently and cheaply.  Secondly, create added value on our agricultural products by distinguishing ourselves by, for example, taste, quality or sustainability.  Thirdly, look for better opportunities to work together, between farmers and gardeners and along the entire chain. In short, come up with a concrete plan and don't write blank cheques.  Finally, it is good that the Commission is opening up new markets and promoting trade. Commissioner Hogan's commitment and ambition deserve a compliment, but keep a close eye on the importance of every agricultural sector and keep our trading partners to the agreements that have been made.  After all, what about the development of new trade treaties, which I welcome? And how does the Commission ensure that agreements are more tightly observed and that all sub-sectors, such as the poultry sector, are monitored more closely?

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this agricultural crisis highlights the great failure of the neoliberal guidelines of the common agricultural policy. It is urgent to abandon immobilistic proposals that have been repeated over the last thirty years and that have taken us where we are.  Agricultural public policies based on production regulation are needed; based on the prioritization of domestic markets; ensure production in the hands of farmers in the European Union; to make a fair distribution of the right to produce; and to put agricultural prices at the heart of European agricultural policy. Only then will we respond to this crisis. The rest are immobilistic proposals that will lead us to continue where we are.

name: Martin Häusling
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, you have a wealth of knowledge. You have not talked about a crisis for weeks, you have been talking about a crisis for four weeks. A great deal of valuable time has passed, and in time more and more farming families have really run into a state of need for livelihoods. But what you have not said here today is that we have a problem of production, of excess. That is what we need to address. What you are doing is throwing even more onto the world market. You travel to Kazakhstan, you travel to Mexico – a commissioner as a traveler who sells pork and milk. And in the end, the TTIP and Mercosur are supposed to help. All I can say is that this is a sign of poverty if the policy goes further and more strongly now. You have to tackle the quantity problem! I do not understand why you are not taking up more initiatives, that with a production restriction – voluntarily, but then, please, everywhere – you can get a grip on the milk market, for example. The small programme that you have now launched will not be enough. Unfortunately, we have lost our hands on the organisation of the market in many areas. Perhaps we need to think again about replacing the liberalisation policy with a policy that also uses market organisation in a very targeted way, so as not to allow overproduction to spread further. Where will we get to if we carry on like this? You said at the last meeting of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development: yes, the instrument of export promotion is back in the room. We had it all before in the 1970s! Export promotion - now you just call it a little different. And we also had stocks. This is all a policy that is a stark reminder of what was in the 1970s and 1980s. And in the end, the taxpayer will pay for all this, and more storage will, of course, also prolong the crises. What did you mean – and I did not quite understand that – that farmers needed money for structural change? What else are they supposed to do about structural changes on the farms? Farmers cannot repay their debts now. If we give them even more cheap money, it will not change the crisis. They need to change the direction of policy. That is the essence, and you do not want that. And the crisis will continue for as long as possible.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. –  Mr President, the Commissioner will be relieved to hear that most of my remarks are not going to be addressed to him directly because he is the wrong Commissioner, unfortunately, for this particular crisis in agriculture that is about to be visited on my industry by the European Parliament. I refer to the quite possible ban on the use of glyphosate on farms. We are voting on this tomorrow and it would be disastrous. This is a really big crisis. What has brought this about? Why are we even considering banning this very useful material? The reason is that the World Health Organisation has said that it is probably carcinogenic. On the face of it, we might all be very concerned about this, as it is serious and we should therefore not be using this material – until you look at what else the World Health Organisation also classes as probably carcinogenic. They say that sitting in front of a log fire in your home during the winter is probably a carcinogenic activity; they say that working night shifts is probably a carcinogenic activity; they say that cutting human hair (which will not worry the Commissioner or me) is probably a carcinogenic activity; exposure to dry cleaning fluid is probably a carcinogenic activity, and drinking the national drink of Argentina (which is called mate) is also probably a carcinogenic activity. When you look at these things, a ban on glyphosate is absolutely ludicrous – but it gets worse than that. What do they call definitely carcinogenic? Well, that includes the consumption of alcohol, the ingestion of the female contraceptive pill, and the consumption of processed meats. These are deliberately ingested, whereas glyphosate is just something that you may happen to be exposed to. If we do go ahead with this ban, what are the alternatives? The alternatives are for farmers to have to cultivate the soil far more than they ever used to. If you believe that farmers can improve the world’s weather by reducing CO2 emissions from their farms, you will have scored a massive own-goal here if you vote for this tomorrow, because you will pump out CO2 from all these tractor operations to try and control perennial weeds of twitch and thistles and the new weed we are all getting now called black grass. That is all going to become much more difficult. Now, what is all this really about? It is about not allowing farmers to grow GM crops, because if you ban glyphosate there will be no incentive to grow the GM crop. Let us face it: that what the ban is in aid of. I am not sure whether the Council are going to have a vote on this. I have been told that they may not, which means that our Secretary of State for Agriculture, Elizabeth Truss, will be told tomorrow that farmers in Britain cannot use glyphosate. What an extraordinary state of affairs.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, what improvements are you talking about, Commissioner? You're presenting us with a pseudo-crisis plan. The policies of the European Union have ruined European agriculture. The legitimate anger of farmers is expressed everywhere and every day in Europe. Let's stop circling the pot!  Let's take the example of milk: farmers are waiting for a return to regulation of volumes and prices. We must stop the current crisis of overproduction and maintain production balances between Member States, but not in any way. The re-establishment of quotas through national policies is a real trap. This non-measure will not change the situation. Good students who, like France, stabilize their production will be penalized while others, who are only looking to seize new market shares, will continue to produce more.  Ireland has already increased its production by 30% in one year without bringing new markets to the European market. It is time to change this European policy.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, in Northern Ireland, farm incomes have been under pressure for some time. In the dairy sector this has been very extreme, with farmers receiving prices below the cost of production over many months. The aid package has only been of limited immediate help. The emphasis on new markets and new financial instruments is welcome but brings no immediate relief. The current deal on the table with the Mercosur bloc will have a devastating impact on the beef sector in particular. It is unfortunate that a study on the cumulative effects of the trade agreements will not be complete until September. However, previous impact assessments carried out by Copa find that benefits to agriculture would be one-sided and that EU farmers would suffer a disrupted internal market and greater price volatility. Another predicted a 3% fall in farm income for Britain and producer prices falling by nearly 8%. In light of the UK referendum debate, many farmers are telling me that they think little has been done to help agriculture and that it is time to take back control.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I have the impression that we are standing still. It has been almost a year since we spoke in this Chamber about the crisis, it has been more than a year since farmers filed for bankruptcy, it has been more than a year since all the economic players in the sectors alerted us and, despite all the measures that have been taken, nothing changes on the farms. The European Parliament voted more than 70% in favour of a mechanism to limit production in times of crisis. This kind of mechanism can only succeed if it applies to all European countries. It is not an agricultural policy to leave a choice to the menu in times of crisis, because crises are general; it is not an agricultural policy to shift the burden of funding accompanying measures to the States, especially since the de minimis limit will only be raised within a very long period of time. Commissioner must, Commissioner, let the Commission as a whole - beyond yourself, who have become aware of the problems - wake up, otherwise agriculture will have disappeared from a number of our territories before the end of this Parliament.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I continue to believe that you and the Commission have not taken stock of the scale of the crisis. The answers you provide fall far short of the realities that we do on a daily basis. It is not by using section 222 in part, as you present, that we will respond to the intensity and difficulty of the economic situation. It was necessary, as has just been said, that Article 222 should indeed be applied in its entirety and that these regulatory measures apply to all farmers in all EU Member States. To do so, it had to be provided with additional resources. That is my point of view at the time of our discussions. Furthermore, Commissioner, I would like to draw your attention to the ongoing negotiations between the European Union and Mercosur. You must categorically reject any offer including sensitive products and, in particular, beef. It is not conceivable that livestock, which is experiencing an unprecedented structural economic crisis, will serve as an adjustment variable to the Commission's trade agreements.  So is our model of society and the European project itself.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: – On behalf of Polish agricultural producers, I would like to express my growing concern at the protracted destabilisation on all agricultural markets and the continued lack of effective action by the European Commission. The scale of the crisis is so great at the moment that it is impossible to mention, in such a short debate, even some of the problems plaguing farmers. We must take decisive action to improve the situation of agriculture. What you are proposing, Commissioner, these are not serious proposals. Indeed, your travel list is impressive, but I doubt that this will improve the situation of farmers. I therefore call once again on the Commission to take effective action to ensure even decent prices in the supply chain, from field to table. This decision is within the Commission's reach, but decisive legislative action must be taken, not just some of the recommendations made by the Commission. Thank you very much!  (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support You did not make it clear, but you mentioned that more measures would be needed. The way I see it, there is malnutrition in Europe, to some extent starvation and especially child hunger. In other words, increasing demand could be an important thing, and I ask you, could you agree with a measure to uniformly have a very low VAT level for food in Europe?

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I said that in one minute it is impossible to even list all the problems and identify all the markets, because basically the whole agricultural sector is collapsed. On the other hand, what I have been calling for since the beginning of this term of office is supply chain regulation. We know that the prices of agricultural products, i.e. the prices that farmers receive, are very low. However, at a time when consumers have to pay a high price in the markets, it is really a profit only for speculators. And here the European Commission has only introduced...  The President took the speaker's vote.
