name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We all hope that the market crisis will soon be over and that farmers will once again receive good prices for their products and daily work. I watch the Süddeutsche Butter and Cheese Exchange with its quotations every week, and unfortunately a turnaround is not in sight. That is why I would like to propose four things to you and ask you whether it is possible to implement this. Firstly, are you thinking of creating an incentive system for a temporary reduction in dairy cow populations? The second measure would be: do you want to reintroduce recovery surcharges for the processing industry, which will actually take butter and cream back into the production of baked goods and ice cream? Thirdly, aid for refugees is a very good and very important approach. But it must be ensured that European food is used. Fourthly, we urgently need an increase in the de minimis system in order to actually implement the national measures.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, there are five things that the Commissioner can do. Take on the large multiples in the retail sector, whose greed has continually eroded the farmers’ share of the retail price in the last few years. Milk prices have dropped in the region of 40% in the last 18 months and the consumer has not seen the benefit, yet the Commission sees no need for regulatory action in its weak response to its report on unfair trading. Take on the cartels and the primary processing sector. We are talking about a crisis in agriculture and how there is no money for farmers, but there is still EUR 38 million for Larry Goodman to buy himself a new private jet. Where did that money come from? Out of the farmers’ pockets. Examine the farmer input sectors and defend our interests in TTIP. Many studies have shown that agriculture will be the main loser in this trade agreement despite some of the claims about dairy exports. Reject the Mercosur deal. The trade deal with the South American countries will completely undermine the viability of European agriculture. Finally, while people are paying back bank debts, they cannot afford to pay decent money for food. Change that and there will be more money to buy food.

name: Maria Heubuch (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, thank you very much for being here today. We are once again talking about the agricultural market crises, and we are always talking here very theoretically, and perhaps we should remember this: this is about the farmers, the farms and the people who live and work there.  We had a low-income year in 2014, and in refining, we lost another 20 percent of our income in 2015, compared to 2014. This is really very difficult for the farms to bear. Humanly, too, this pressure is no longer very good to bear, and many of these companies are stuck in the financial commitments they have made in order to be competitive in order to survive in the market. You can't just get out of production now just because it doesn't pay off. It is a real dilemma, and this dilemma was predictable.  Warnings are now being issued time and again, completely independent of the Russia embargo. And then the question arises: are we dealing with political failure here because these warnings have not been responded to early enough, or is it accepted in a condoning manner so that our food industry can secure world market shares? World market shares, which are paid dearly by the farms, by farmers, who jeopardise the widespread production of milk and meat within Europe and bleed the whole region to death. This, too, is a kind of structural reform, but it is an unsightly one.  We also talk a lot about sustainability at different levels. We have also signed the SDGs here in Europe. But overproduction is not a form of sustainability, and certainly not when we have to bring the feed here from overseas, in order to dump our surpluses, our overproduction, back on the world market.  Let us organise an adaptation to the market, and with it we are taking a first step towards sustainability. We cannot leave that to the free market.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have talked about the agricultural crisis, but it is the milk sector that is most in crisis, an unprecedented crisis that is causing the slaughter of Italian stables. In one year, 1 500 stables closed in Italy as a result of the collapse in the price paid to farmers. The price is falling from 44 cents two years ago to 30 cents a litre this year. In Italy, 110 million quintals of milk are produced and 85 million quintals of milk are imported, but also of powders, concentrates, curds and semi-finished products. These, after the transformation of our industry, magically become Italian products and so on the shelves we find three out of four cartons of milk that are passed off as Italian and mozzarella that is passed off as Italian. That is why the first action to be made immediately, what the producers are asking for, the consumers, which I am asking for and which I hope the Commissioner also wants, is origin labelling. Only then will we know where that milk is produced.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, the countries most affected by the crisis in the agricultural sector are the countries of the European south, and in particular Greece, whose agricultural sector is at risk of disaster.  The European Union is responsible for the crisis in the agricultural sector and what will follow because of the wrong policies it pursues. Within the framework of the neighbourhood policy we have allowed agricultural and livestock products to be imported into Europe from third countries, resulting in conditions of unfair competition for European products. A typical example is the seventy thousand tonnes that will come from Tunisia in the next two years, which will destroy the economies of European countries. In Greece, the price of olive oil has fallen by fifty per cent, resulting in seven hundred thousand farmers involved in olive production suffering economic ruin.  Similarly, the questionable quality Turkish products that flood European markets are also dealt with. The Russian embargo has also created problems. We must therefore choose policies that serve European farmers.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the There is no doubt that agriculture is going through a difficult time. This applies in particular to the dairy industry, especially those areas which have to produce under difficult conditions and have higher production costs. How, for example, should a miner produce milk at such prices, and how can he still finance his maintenance? We have decided to end quotas and, of course, the end of quotas opens up new opportunities for those who can produce at low prices or costs. However, this also means that we will then help those who could get under the wheels in this situation, because otherwise we risk comprehensive agriculture in Europe and the comprehensive dairy industry. That is why we need a few measures, rapid internal convergence is needed in those Member States where this has not yet happened, for example in Italy. Above all, however, we need an aid programme for the producer organisations, for processors, especially in the mountainous region, who process milk into high-quality products and which could be financed in a similar way to the fruit and vegetables sector and which we could support. And it needs its own programme and fund to promote these high-quality products from the mountain region. If we do not do this, the dairy industry will disappear from the mountain, and that would change agriculture in the mountainous area in a lasting way.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I think measures have been taken, but I believe that these measures - as my colleagues have told you - are not enough. Surely it is not easy for you or us to find the right measures, but of course those that are not are those that are going to the renationalisation of Community agricultural policy. All these measures, such as the resources that have been given to the Member States, some unused, make us not address the problem in the background. The problem with European agriculture is the situation of the food chain and agreements with third countries. They are the two serious problems that put her in a problem that prevents us from getting out of this crisis. I would like to ask you for a few specific things: the fruit and vegetable sector needs an increase in withdrawal prices – other hand, this measure will not be useful – as well as the articulation of continuity measures with the effects of the Russian veto and that there is an extension and there is no time without continuity in the measures.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in the long term the future for agriculture is positive – not an easy message for farmers going through the most difficult times in living memory. I know Commissioner Hogan understands that well. I know that he will do everything within his powers to help this industry through very tough times. I also know that, relative to the depths of the farm income crisis, those powers are limited. But what he can and must do is find ways to help the industry become more productive, more competitive and more sustainable. Agriculture needs R&D, innovation and simplification, and above all agriculture needs regulation based on common sense and proven science, not on emotion. The Commissioner and the farmers understand that well. Unfortunately, too many Members of this House do not.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Let me reiterate that the crisis in the European agricultural sector affects many people operating in many different sectors: pigmeat, milk, fruit, vegetables, butter, etc. It requires us to take it seriously and to give an adequate response on the part of the European Union. I do not agree with those who say that the main problem is the conflict with Russia and Russia's actions. My conviction is that the crisis is largely caused by internal problems: inefficient market, dismembered sector overproducing, lack of innovation, weak competition, falling demand. All this is met with short-term solutions. The European Commission has so far come up with short-term solutions, such as private storage aid. I understand that such solutions are sometimes necessary. However, if the Commission has to resolve this situation, it must start to develop measures that address and solve the structural problems of agriculture. Before we deal with this, nothing will get any better in the long term.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, what we are discussing here today is evidence: that European agriculture is in crisis. But we're debating based on a chimera. Because we know, both you and I, that none of the measures taken by the Commission will bring improvement in the medium term.  Today we can talk about aid to farmers, rents and agricultural yields, which will be of little or no use as long as we continue to negotiate a free trade agreement with the United States that will only bring us ruin, increased imports of US products, and consequently falling prices for our products.  So I wonder, when are we going to start protecting local production? How much longer do we have to wait to change the paradigm of economic growth and our productive model? It's time to make brave decisions. Let's show that we're with and for people. First there is our agriculture, first there are our ranchers and first there is the food sovereignty of our people.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Already in the second week after the mass picket near the Lithuanian Ministry of Agriculture, milk producers protest in a tent, waiting for solutions to help them survive. This perfectly illustrates that the situation in agriculture is critical: milk buying prices range from 10 to 15 euro cents and continue to fall, the same happens with pork, problems exist in other sectors.  Dear Commissioner, I am grateful for the attention you have shown to Lithuania, where you have recently visited and met not only representatives of Lithuania but also farmers. This, of course, has given hope. However, I cannot only support voluntary production cuts. I wonder what effect do you expect from this? All the more so because the income foregone should be compensated by the parties themselves. I wonder how many such countries will emerge? I believe that production in the dairy sector must already be regulated, at least temporarily, throughout the European Union.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I want to thank the Chair of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development for this debate here this morning, and thank the Commissioner for his comments. Clearly this crisis in the agriculture sector is much deeper and more prolonged than the Commission had forecast or than we would desire, so it is important that we hear from Members, particularly what is happening in each Member State, because of our differences. But there is one clear message, and I am not sure whether many farmers are listening to the debate here in the Chamber – hands up if you are – but that is that the voice of farmers is, I think, not being heard loud and clear, because there are fewer of them. Consumers – and we are all consumers in this Chamber – are benefiting to some extent from the crisis in the agricultural sector with cheaper food, but perhaps others along the supply chain are benefiting much more. So on question 3, could the Commissioner say a bit more about what the Commission is going to do on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain? I hope it is going to do something concrete and effective. Can I also, Commissioner, say that implementing the measures that you have brought forward is important, but measuring their impact is even more important? And can I ask you a question on Article 222? Following on from Mr Dantin’s comments, do you really think that it can be effective if only one or two Member States apply voluntary production cuts, and can you explain how that will and can be funded? My last point relates to costs. We need to do something to tackle the high cost of production in European – including Irish – agriculture.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, although last autumn you unlocked EUR 500 million to help the dairy and livestock sector, this amount has been small and we are still in a structural crisis on the agricultural market, in particular with regard to dairy, pork, fruit and vegetables. The current context in the European milk market requires that we pay particular attention to milk producers, who are most affected. At the Agriculture and Fisheries Council in March you acknowledged that we are in crisis. But the measures taken are still timid and without the pressure of the Member States we would have had even less. Farmers must be urgently helped by measures that meet their liquidity needs today. We also need lengthy countercyclical measures that can work to stabilise the market. We urgently need urgent measures at the crisis, folded into the reality that exists in each Member State.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The very difficult situation on the milk and pigmeat markets, including in my country, Poland, is due, among other things, to the catastrophic drought in 2015, the effects of the Russian embargo on the pigmeat market, the effects of African swine fever, although it occurs only among feral pigs, but unfortunately this casts a shadow over the whole market. Polish The Minister for Agriculture presented, inter alia, the following proposals at the Agriculture Council meeting on 14Th March: reintroducing temporary targeted support for milk and pigmeat producers, raising the intervention price for butter and milk powder, mobilising export subsidies for pigmeat, increasing de minimis aid for one holding and general limits for individual Member States, and finally considering the use of the general budget or crisis reserve as a source of funding for these and other Commission measures to improve the situation on agricultural markets.  I would like to ask the Commissioner which of these proposals, or which of these proposals have a chance to be applied by the Commissioner. Thank you very much!  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – I am very glad to hear that you are also talking about the embargo. I want to ask you: how far can we go to find a solution to the Russian embargo on fruit and vegetables? I have said it already many times here in plenary: I think the priority for the agricultural sector should be that the Russian boycott should stop. Can your party support all the initiatives to ban the boycott?

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – The case in the case of the Russian embargo is indeed complicated. What is needed here is solidarity from all EU countries, and indeed, as the Commissioner said, in the World Trade Organisation, of which Russia is a member, the embargo should be lifted. I hope that such joint and several action on this matter will be possible.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: – Commissioner, our own European food producers and farmers are on the brink of bankruptcy and in a difficult social distress. We now need a large number of decisions: more money from the framework to deal with the agricultural crisis, and significant additional flexibility in agricultural policy practices.  The European Union's financial framework must also be able to be flexible in the management of acute crises in agriculture. Six years is far too long to wait or predict in such a sensitive area. We all know that money is tight, we need to prioritise things, but very recently eur 3 billion was found to treat, outsource, the refugee crisis in Turkey. Perhaps the same source can also be used to find the euros needed for this vital issue.  Then how do you be flexible? The ceiling on state crisis aid must be raised. €15,000 per estate is not enough. Secondly, payments for agricultural subsidies must be brought forward and made more flexible, and thirdly, it must also be possible to adapt national agricultural programmes several times a year. We expect action from the Commission on this.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are in an almost unique situation here in plenary today, because speakers from across every political group, from every country, have had basically the same message. That message, Commissioner, is that you are failing, and the Commission is failing, to address the farm income crisis that we have. While I welcome the fact that we have moved from a situation where the Commission was failing to acknowledge that there was a crisis at all to at least some measures being put in place, it is quite clear from listening to the remarks of speakers across the board today that those measures do not go far enough. I know you asked this morning, Commissioner, for your package to be given time and for us to give you time, but the difficulty is that many of the farmers who we are dealing with on a daily and weekly basis simply do not have the luxury of time. What they need is for the packages already in place to be strengthened. I am of the firm belief that, for example, intervention prices will have to be increased above the cost of production. Why delay any longer? Why not do it? I would like to reiterate the points which have been made in relation to the trade deals with Mercosur… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we need the perentorial need to provide ourselves with new instruments and to provide farmers with them to cope with market fluctuations. There is growing talk of state aid, but the problem is European and so must the solution. We must also remove, Commissioner, the psychological barriers which prevent your Commission from strengthening intervention in the milk sector or in withdrawal prices in the fruit and vegetable sector. Voluntary measures in Article 222 of the common single market organisation for milk shall be effective only if unanimous action in the sector is ensured. I would also like to recall what this Parliament has been saying for months now: more effective measures are needed in the milk sector and, in particular, an increase in intervention prices. It is also necessary to carry out a serious review of the dairy package and to promote contracts between farmers and industry, including distribution, and to promote more consumption. The Commission continues to ignore the demands of the fruit and vegetable sector, which calls for an increase in withdrawal prices, which no longer respond to the reality of the markets. Moreover, the new Delegated Regulation on the simplification of industry rules should not pose new problems such as those proposed by the Commission for the management of agri-environmental measures, because they would mean further declines in competitiveness. And let us not forget the meat sector – the particular situation of pork – which deserves to be paid attention with aid to private storage.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. In agriculture, it is quite simple: you harvest what you sow. That is the way it is in politics. You reap what you sow. And you, as Commissioner for Agriculture, continue to sow exactly the same arable furrow as we have known for thirty years. It is about liberalisation, it is about deregulation, and now you are reaping the rewards. You are there when, unfortunately, we all – unfortunately, because we are not the ones who want to sow the same policy – unfortunately harvest the same seeds with you. In other words, no regulatory organisation, deregulation, over-quantity, concentration processes, many farming farms give up, extreme pressure on people, on animals, on the environment, and, of course, the loss of quality of many products. In other words, no crisis falls from the sky, crises are made. Commissioner, finally change course so that we can really tackle the crisis!

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR).
text: Mr President! Commissioner! They talk about how much money has been given out, but not about the administration that comes with it to get the money, and thus they disappear. The crisis in agriculture is serious and it has led to large price fluctuations which are totally unreasonable for a pressured industry. Where is the will to create a level playing field between countries, focusing on agricultural policy? Some countries have to reduce ammonia by over 20%, others drop by around 5%. Where are they level playing? Where is the dialogue about getting the Russian market back again? It is the farmers who are paying the price right now. The big companies are letting go. They go to tax havens in, for example, Panama. To save this, we need a future-proof agriculture that invests in the best possible environmental technologies, more jobs and a better economy.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the agricultural sector in the European Union is going through the most difficult period in recent years, even though some measures that are regarded as exceptional were taken in 2015. Whether we are talking about the livestock sector or the vegetable sector, they have been severely affected primarily by the embargo imposed by Russia, by the impossibility of finding new markets, but also by unfair practices, which unfortunately could not be effectively controlled. The European Commission must only abandon reactive intervention policies and forecast agricultural policies in the medium and long term so that demand and supply remain in balance. There is a need to create rapid mechanisms to enable farmers to adjust their production according to market requirements. The development of a sector, whatever that may be, without taking into account the absorption capacities of the market merely buries that sector under its own weight. At the same time, with all due responsibility, I draw the attention of the European Commission to emerge from the state of inadmissible passivity towards the massive phenomenon of grabbing agricultural land, especially in eastern Europe, in the hands of latifundaires. This leads to the destruction of small and medium-sized farms and will certainly turn the locals into slaves on their former lands, with immeasurable consequences for economic and political stability in the medium and long term.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, indeed, we have been talking about this continuing crisis for over a year, and the solutions provided are only 'measures' in view of the scale of the problem.  I remind you that farmers are asking for two things: market regulation, to which we turn our backs, not only the Commission, but above all a majority of European governments, which no longer want regulation. They are also partly responsible for this disaster. Farmers also demand proper remuneration for their work.  The CAP is now at odds with the world's major agricultural policies. While the European Union bases its policy on decoupled support for production, in major producing countries such as the United States, Brazil and China, in particular, support for farmers is directly linked to price, production volume or input use.  In light of these observations, I think it is important to highlight two things: we must pay particular attention to the impact of free trade agreements that could further increase the instability of the most important agricultural markets - I am thinking of TTIP and Mercosur - and, finally, we need to think about putting in place countercyclical tools to help farmers in this CAP that no longer meets its objectives.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: – The crisis in our agricultural sectors continues. The distribution of value in the chain is very uneven and that is a structural problem. However, in a time of crisis, this can make the difference between surviving or going bankrupt for a farmer.  The agricultural markets task force is an important step for the long term. Article 222 on crisis cartels has also now been triggered, but only for dairy. Is the Commission prepared to use Article 222 more broadly and in a more timely manner so that farmers in other sectors can also agree? Commissioner, it must not be the case that one link in the chain (namely the primary producer) only pays for the consequences of the crisis. Just now, give farmers all the means to strengthen their position, so that the other links in the chain are proportionate to the consequences of the crisis.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has The negative political and economic mood is now having a full impact on our family farms. Especially in Austria, where we have a very small-scale agriculture, a large number of family farms are affected by this crisis. Milk prices and prices in the pig sector are in free fall, to be more specific here too, and are now a real threat to their livelihoods, including for farms. At these prices, as they are currently found on the markets, there is no cover in production. We therefore need genuine solidarity with our farmers in order to be able to ensure liquidity. I am also talking here, above all, about risk financing instruments – as the Commissioner has already mentioned today – and, of course, above all, of promotion measures that we have to take within Europe, but also, of course, on third markets. In addition to new export efforts, however, a sustainable aid package must above all also shed light on the role of the individual actors along the value chain. We see time and again that dumping prices, slingshot prices and slingshots are putting massive pressure on our mainly regional producers. We must fight this dumping. The extortion of producers by trading groups must finally be stopped. And perhaps a word about Russia, as you have also mentioned, Commissioner: I welcome the move to explicitly reopen the markets here in the future.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Mr President, one of the causes of the crisis in agriculture is the growing gap between the urban and the rural – the growing gap between the consumer and the farmer. How have we ended up with a situation where some farmers in the European Union are being paid below the cost of production? It simply is not fair. Twenty years ago I and others worked to tackle unfair trade treatment of farmers in the developing world, resulting in the Fairtrade mark. We now have lots of products from the developing world where the farmer has been paid a fair price: tea, coffee, bananas and cocoa. We now need to do the same for European farmers. Twenty to thirty per cent of EU customers are willing to pay a fair price to their farmers; that is a big market. A fair price scheme for EU farmers will be difficult to set up, but where there’s a will there’s a way, and our farmers deserve no less.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, six months after the first package of €500 million measures to alleviate the crisis in the dairy, pigmeat and fruit and vegetable sectors, the European Commission also announced the introduction of an additional package of extraordinary measures to support farmers in the European Union. This is an upgrade to the 1 billion euros already secured so far in the past year provided by the European Union to help the crisis-hit agricultural sector. While the Commission has really acted swiftly and adopted a range of measures, I must nevertheless say that measures such as milk and meat storage or a reduction in milk production are not measures to help farmers, especially those in new Member States such as Croatia. All surpluses end up in the market that is the weakest and the very attitude, Commissioner, that by helping the old Member States we must not drag towards the bottom of the new Member State, and this is happening right now. That is why I expect you to propose balanced and effective measures that will support every European farmer. I ask for the Support of the European Commission to adopt a regulation at European level that would prevent UTPs and at least to combat unfair competition in this way.  We all need food, and if those who produce food can't survive from their work, then we need to come up with new measures to help them and I believe we will get support from you.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, falling prices, the problem of overproduction and the Russian embargo are giving European agriculture a mortal blow. The 2015 aid package is not enough.  I agree that aid must be a safeguard network and not a general support for farm profitability, but the current level of unit prices for agricultural production poses the need to implement exceptional measures. In order to deal with such a devastating crisis, it is necessary to raise the withdrawal prices set by the European Union and differentiate them by type of production. We need more effective financial instruments for farms, and I would like to know how the Commission intends to guarantee producers the practical availability of flexible and innovative financial instruments, to be identified in conjunction with European financial institutions.  The Commission also needs more incisiveness on the indication of the origin of raw materials on the label. I am convinced that valuing origin helps to safeguard the European agricultural model, the work of our farms and to protect the consumer, who must be able to choose transparently and consciously.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: – I also speak on behalf of my colleague Tom Vandenkendelaere from Belgium.  Europe was created after the Second World War. At that time it was about peace, but also about sufficient food, food production, produced by farming families and family farms. We've almost forgotten that. But that is the strength of Europe.  Look at the Netherlands and Belgium: 60% of pig farmers do not make it. And 50% of dairy farmers have major financial problems. I am not talking about related sectors such as contractors and the like. Many think that market innovation is the solution, but it is not only so. It's also about other things. It is also a level playing field when it comes to state aid. It is also a matter of how crisis money should end up on the farmer's kitchen table at the moment. Last Year in July, I asked for an action plan. Some of them laughed at me then, but we're now a year away. Commissioner, you have proposed a plan and others have said things. Let us work towards a fair, social, balanced market economy within Europe. If we do this quickly, we will preserve the family and family farms and food production in Europe. But if we do not do that together, then power, capital and multinationals will take control of this whole sector. And what does that mean for a liveable countryside? Are we thinking about that enough here in this house, in this chamber?

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the situation in the milk sector is dramatic in my region, the Azores. 60% of farms are in technical bankruptcy, causing thousands of families and a region to despair to disaster. This is not acceptable, especially since the responsibility of these producers in this crisis is nil. They've been paying to work for a long time, getting even more indebted.  This is a European crisis and, despite some palliative measures that can be taken by Member States, the solution will have to be European to prevent abuse of the negotiating power of industries and distribution, which in Portugal impose penalties for increased production and request guarantees from producers, further harming them, in a shallow version of milk quotas that only works negatively and internally , causing even more asymmetries.  It punishes the least produced, letting others produce without limits. I again call for them to promote an ambitious European campaign to provide information and incentives for milk consumption, because it is being attacked, without giving the appropriate answer, clarifying the myths associated with it and promoting its benefits. It advocates clear rules for the indication of the origin and support of the certification of its composition. In the case of the Azores, there is talk of the presence of omega 3, CLA and others, among others. I question: do we want a globally competitive sector benefiting few and favouring members of a selective club of European producers, or do we want to be competitive by promoting the sustainable development of europe's centre and periphery, the most remote regions and territories of the Union?

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, Commissioner, for the debate today. I have three brief questions for the Commissioner.  Firstly, with regard to the intervention mechanism, do you not also think that our current intervention mechanism is too slow and too predictable? Should we not react more quickly and then deal with the market chains accordingly?  The second question is a question about pricing: why do we pay every litre the same? In other words, we pay just as badly or just as well for the litre of milk that is not needed. Should we not react accordingly in the drafting of the contract?  And the third question – price protection systems: would it not be time to even consider whether we are using price protection systems, including insurance schemes, to secure agricultural producer prices a little more? Could other countries, such as the United States, not be a good example to us here?

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Thank you for being here for this debate.  I welcome the plan you have presented to the Council on the crisis in the agricultural markets, I welcome the flexibility on the minimum system, the activation of Article 222 for the dairy sector and everything else. What I note, however, Commissioner, is that none of these measures are devoted to what is one of the main causes of the crisis that our fruit and vegetable markets are experiencing, namely trade policy with third countries.  Not only milk, Commissioner, there are tomatoes, oranges, what were once the symbols of agriculture in the south of Europe, which is still a very important sector today. There is no mention of the activation of the safeguard clause, there is no mention of initiating an assessment of the impact of current imports, nor of withdrawal prices. Europe's credibility and the confidence of the producers and consumers of the European agricultural system are at stake here. Our farmers are in enormous distress.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, we have four ways to resolve this crisis or at least four ways. The first is to open up conversations about whether this kind of policy towards Russia makes sense or makes no sense and whether we can really bring back the Russian market, or whether Mr. Commissioner will travel a lot and look for new markets: the Chinese market is certainly interesting. Either we find more money for our producers or, what I especially want to advocate here, we will change our overall agricultural policy and try to work on quality rather than quantity. The originality and excellence of our European products must be what must be our global competitiveness, competitiveness on the world market. I am in a long-term policy for such a long-term policy, but we need to start working on this immediately because it is evident that the increase in the world's population will allow our excellence and our originality to be even better recognized on the world market.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we have a dilemma here, unfortunately. The long-term prospects, as outlined by the Commissioner, seem to be quite good, with a growing population meaning greater demand for food. Also, of course, the Commissioner is trying to open up new markets, which is highly commendable. But for farmers there is a small element of ‘live, horse and you’ll get grass’ about this, because a short-term crisis could put a lot of them out of business. So that is why we have to try and come up with short-term solutions. I know the Commission has done an awful lot (EUR 500 million last year, etc.), but is there room for more in the short term? The situation, especially in my country, has been exacerbated by horribly bad weather and the threat of Brexit, so they need help now. Is there an opportunity, for instance, to have a short-term intervention for three or four months and then revert to the status quo? I think we need to look at short-term measures to get the farmers over the crisis right now.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all those who have contributed in the debate on this crisis in agricultural markets. I want to assure you that I share your concerns. However, we can only take action on the basis of the framework of the legislation that was agreed by you and the Council in 2013 and which I am implementing from 1 January 2015. I would like to say to Mrs Noichl that I am not ploughing my own furrow in this regard. I am exhausting all of the tools that have been given to me within the law and the budget. I do not of course need to go into the details about the backdrop to the situation that we have in terms of the market. We have a global oversupply in our milk and pig meat products and we have the Russian embargo, which has not helped and has resulted in a reduction of EUR 5.2 billion of exports to that destination. But I have responded on a number of issues, and I just want to go through them again. I have responded on intervention ceilings by increasing the ceilings by 100% for skimmed milk powder and butter. I am invoking Article 222 for the first time to bring about a stabilisation of milk production and to bring about greater balance in demand and supply. This can be funded through the existing targeted aid measures that have not yet been spent by some Member States or by state aids. I would draw your attention to the flexibility that we are giving in respect of state aids for the first time. Measures under state aid rules, which have been doubled from EUR 7 500 to 15 000 per farmer per annum, can be used for the purpose of the promotion of agricultural products or the closure of production capacity if they are notified and approved in the agricultural state aid guidelines. Holdings may be granted rescue and restructuring aid if they fulfil the conditions that are set out in the horizontal state aid guidelines. Member States could also be allowed to set up access to finance schemes under which aid in the form of loans or guarantees is granted in order to bridge liquidity gaps. Where farmers have undertaken at least to freeze their production during a certain period at a level that has been attained in comparison to a reference period to be determined by the Commission, the aid could be granted in the form of direct grants. So I am saying to Members who have raised the issue of how we are implementing Article 222 and creating some balance between supply and demand in the milk sector that we are giving the maximum flexibility in order to implement that measure. As I have said already, I allocated EUR 420 million in a targeted aid package last September and only EUR 162 million has been drawn down to date, so I wonder what the Member States are going to do with that money, although I know that some of them are considering structural reforms as well. We have more money for new market opportunities, for new promotion measures; we have new outlets for these particular funds; and we have more money for school schemes that Mr Tarabella has successfully brought through Parliament with your support, which is now EUR 250 million per annum, an extra EUR 50 million in the budget. We have EUR 30 million being invested in humanitarian assistance, and this is from products in the European Union as well. We allow flexibility for the modification of the rural development programmes to target sectors that are under financial pressure, and of course we have the voluntary coupled support, particularly in areas of national constraint. So we are not renationalising agriculture. We are providing EUR 56 billion from European taxpayers every year to farmers. So I disagree with Mr Takkula, who talked about EUR 3 billion for Turkey and nothing for farmers. EUR 56 billion every year for farmers is a significant amount of money. With regard to trade deals, it is essential in relation to the Mercosur negotiations on trade that we convey a consistent measure as governments. So it is important that the agriculture ministers and the trade ministers are working in tandem and that the EU is ready to make a meaningful contribution in agriculture. But we would ask – and I would ask, as Agriculture Commissioner – that Mercosur should moderate its expectations to what is manageable and acceptable to the EU both politically and economically, particularly in these difficult times for some of our sectors. I want to assure Mr Nicholson that the yellow card and simplification agenda is very much intact and that we are proceeding to give farmers who make minor errors the benefit of the doubt in relation to the yellow card system. Simplification proposals will emerge again for implementation shortly. I would say to Mr Häusling that I have outlined what I have done on Article 222, so I am seeking measures and implementing measures that are containing production and bringing about a greater balance in supply. So I do not accept it when you say that that I am doing nothing about bringing about a balance in the marketplace. You are advocating that we should not go to the extreme of opening new markets. Well, we are going to continue to open new markets and that will be part of the solution in creating further opportunities and outlets for our agricultural products. In relation to structural change and funding that structural change, the targeted aid measures and the state aids that I have just outlined are applicable in relation to structural change if regions in Germany – or indeed Germany as a whole – would wish to participate. Everybody wants access to more money. As I said, we have already allocated some money which has not been utilised yet, so it is very difficult for me to go looking for more money when that money has not been expended. Secondly, I would be interested in the views of Parliament in relation to the use of the crisis reserve. Should it be used? What are the circumstances in which we should use it? I would be interested in your views on that. In relation to the food chain, I note the unfair trading practices report which was published in January, and I do not agree with the conclusions that the report came up with. I look forward to the proposals of Members of this House to be submitted to the Agricultural Markets Task Force, which will report next September. I would urge you to make your proposals sooner rather than later. I would also mention that this group is looking at financial instruments and new tools which we can use to protect farmers in the context of price volatility. These include hedge funds and also insurance products. Regarding withdrawal prices in relation to fruit and vegetables that were mentioned by Ms Aguilera García and Ms Herranz García in relation to Spain, this is certainly under review. We also have to extend from 30 June – I am trying to find the money to do this – the impact of the fruit and vegetable sector in relation to the Russian ban. So these issues are still under review and we will be making a decision shortly. I would like to conclude by saying that I very much recognise the difficulties that exist across the markets, but this is the second package of proposals that we are implementing in order to reflect the concerns that have been expressed here. I hope that these will have an immediate impact during the course of 2016 to ameliorate the financial difficulties of our farming community.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We thank the Commissioner for this reply, although the volume was a little difficult at the end. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. - As milk, meat and fruit prices fall unstoppably, the EU has put in place crisis measures to help farmers. Despite them, the price of milk, for example, remains below the cost of production. The European Parliament welcomes the measures taken and stresses the need to evaluate whether aid has reached primary producers.  Europarlamentaries also addressed the issue of unfair practices in the food production chain. I am working on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee to abolish such practices. Precisely because of the perishability of agricultural products, commodity purchasers very often manipulate the contracts they have with farmers. Primary producers are put before the choice of 'either let your product rot or sell it for a trifle'.  Such practices not only destroy farmers, but ultimately also affect the price and quality of products on which the average household spends 14 percent of the budget. We are witnessing purchase prices falling steadily and farmers are failing, but the price of products for the final consumer remains the same.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – Firstly, allow me to thank you for the steps you and the European Commission have taken to recuperat from the crises in the dairy and pig sectors. However, the situation has not improved or even continues to deteriorate. The largest hungarian raw milk takeover price in Europe, suffering a price drop of more than 20 percent, is currently 24.38 euro cents per kg, which is far below the cost level. We need a solution that pulls the producer price of milk out of this pit. At the moment, I see no alternative but to adjust intervention and reference prices. That is why I ask, Commissioner: (a) do you support, on the one hand, increasing the intervention price for skimmed-milk powder and cheese to the cost level if the dairy farmers using intervention undertake to withdraw additional milk from the market by transferring this milk/milk powder/butter/cheese, etc., for charitable and relief purposes within the EU? b) do you agree with the need to immediately modernise the income stabilisation tool, which has proved cumbersome and bureaucratic, in order to create a successful instrument such as The Price Fall Insurance and the Milk Margin Insurance in the USA?

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – As stated in the question, despite the 2015 measures, there has been no visible improvement in European agricultural policy. I have also asked the question about the common agricultural policy in this House before, and because you were not present, Commissioner, I repeat it. What do you propose and what does the Commission propose to create a outlets in other non-European markets for pork if the embargo with Russia is extended? You have informed us that there are opportunities for exporting pork to other markets, but you are talking about a distant horizon. We're talking about now, today, tomorrow, next week. Meat products may not be sold at the cost level either. Commissioner, the speed of intervention must be increased, the impact must be measured immediately. Precise new measures are needed, targeted where necessary, to producers. It enters the domestic market products from non-European markets, in the US, often less qualitative and which undermine European producers.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The crisis in the European agricultural sector has been going on for several years, making the situation of farmers increasingly difficult, causing understandable frustration. Action to stabilise agricultural markets is therefore urgent and necessary. The further emergency measures introduced by the European Commission a month ago to help European farmers affected by the crisis are undoubtedly a step in the right direction. However, it is important to ensure that the aid offered goes primarily to farmers and not to intermediaries or to the farmers' environment, as it is the farmer who bears the greatest burden of falling prices.  The persistent Russian embargo on food imports, which has already resulted in European farmers already lost more than EUR 5 billion, has also been a huge problem, with the consequences of the difficult political situation on the EU-Russia line. The Commission's efforts to increase trade flows with third countries should be appreciated, but they still do not compensate for the losses resulting from the embargo and, consequently, it is necessary to step up efforts to reopen the Russian market.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – European farmers face many difficulties that reduce their incomes and prevent investment in the development of farms. A very serious problem is the continuing Russian embargo on agricultural products from EU countries, as well as the abolition of milk quotas.  In addition, we can see a fall in food prices worldwide and an intensification of agricultural production (e.g. in Asia or South America). There are also concerns about the negotiations under international trade agreements, which could have severe consequences for our agricultural sector. We have come to the point of justifying the question of the European agricultural model and the Treaty guarantee of a decent income for farmers.  Yes, it cannot be denied that the European Commission is making some efforts and introducing instruments to improve the situation. However, it must be said that the effects of these measures are lacking, farmers' dissatisfaction is growing and experts predict that this collapse in farmers' incomes could continue for several more years. The worst part, however, is that there is no vision of what to do next.  I believe that the EU should return to the quota of production, e.g. milk, and include pig production by tying the quota to direct payments guaranteeing income. Either the European agricultural model and the Treaty guarantee of income, or the invisible hand of the market and the disaster of European agriculture.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Additional punishment of Polish farmers for exceeding milk quotas in a crisis situation on the milk market and after the abolition of milk quotas on 1 April 2015 is absolutely unacceptable. The situation of milk producers in Poland and throughout the European Union is dramatic. The burden on even the most modern dairy farms with such high penalties, while the fall in milk purchase prices in Poland, leads to their bankruptcy.  I appeal to the Commission, in the face of an endless Russian embargo on dairy products, to remission the penalties imposed on Polish producers amounting to more than EUR 200 million. The solutions proposed by the European Commission in March do not correspond in any way to the scale of the crisis in the agricultural markets.  Once again, I call on the Commission to allocate additional financial resources to producers in the dairy, pig and other sectors affected by the crisis. The fate of milk producers depends on the Commission providing them with immediate financial assistance.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. – Farmers, particularly in the countries of the European South which produce 50% of the Union's agricultural product, have been brought to their knees by the programmes of violent fiscal adjustment, merch austerity and fiscal policies imposed on them by European banking.  In France, the impasse in which farmers have been driven is reflected in suicide rates that are higher than any other social group. The only way out is the road that the Greek farmers have taken with their grandiose mobilizations in the winter in the face of the agricultural memorandum and the new wave of tax policy that, if implemented, will certainly lead to the dissolution of the primary sector in Greece and turn Greek farmers into little ones on their own land.  With such struggles we will throw out troikas, memoranda and austerity policies to get our hands on the fate of our country.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – The crisis in European agriculture was triggered in part by political decisions taken in Brussels, the most tangible of which are the effects of the so-called "Russian embargo". Since 2014, milk prices in my country – Bulgaria continue to go down, and Bulgarian producers in the sector have reported a drop in income of nearly 20%. The losses of the agricultural industry in Bulgaria from the Russian embargo, including the processing industry, in different sectors reached nearly BGN 300 million from August 2014 to today. Despite the huge difficulties faced by our farmers and costing billions, the European Commission continues with the open-door policy towards imports from third countries, which often receives subsidies from the country of origin and which undermines European production. The European Commission must stop misleading the sector with disproportionately little help and offers to search for new markets in a sector with large seasonal amplitudes, such as agriculture. It is high time measures were proposed to protect the European producer from imports from third countries.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – For the first time in this forum, we are talking again about the crisis in the agricultural sector. Despite all the assistance measures in 2015, some agricultural sectors are deeply feeling the effects of the Russian embargo. Prices are collapsing, farmers are facing unstable incomes, while input prices are rising. The Common Agricultural Policy must respond to these challenges and we must jointly find intervention instruments that guarantee the stability of the European agricultural sector. The Commission must also find solutions to eliminate unfair practices in the food chain and to ensure that producers are paid decently for their work. I hope that, when reviewing the Common Agricultural Policy, we can implement instruments to ensure that we do not have a perpetual crisis in European agriculture.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. – The measures announced by the EC are virtually useless in solving the problems of milk producers, relieving only those with the greatest production capacity. This market logic aims to get rid of the many producers in less competitive regions with less adaptability.  The possibility of voluntary reduction of production shall have no effect if the neighbour does not adopt it. The EC has to question the usefulness of the current legal framework. We must therefore go further, with really European measures that lead to supply regulation and give traditional milk producers negotiating power over industry and distribution. Many producers do not currently receive a fair price for work and investments, with the future being mortgaged, especially in small-scale economies, such as the Azores, where a modernised dairy sector is making a major adjustment effort, resisting what it can. Commissioner, this deserves to be honoured with policies to stabilise prices at a truly rewarding level and not with the unregulated policy you have put in place. It is not with this Europe that I commit myself, nor the vast majority of Members of this Parliament as you have heard during the debate.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – In 30 years, the face of our agriculture has changed significantly. Thousands and thousands of farms have disappeared and agricultural employment has drastically decreased. At the same time, the level of agricultural indebtedness increased brutally, without matching in the level of profitability, which degraded significantly. Today producers work far below production costs and we are witnessing another wave of closures. Agricultural policies have only sought to apply a quick dressing on the system that is very ill. The politicians responsible for the European institutions continue to believe in intensive agriculture capable of competing with Brazilian, American or Australian agriculture. They're wrong. The agricultural policy that the peoples of Europe demand is one that raises the issues of social and territorial cohesion, as well as food and environmental security, above market laws and the logics of international competitiveness. Then it will be possible to have a model based on small and medium-sized agriculture, quality, safety and trust, properly articulated around local and regional production and consumption circuits.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to call Parliament’s attention to the fact that a group of democracy activists has been convicted in Angola for their criticism. They are in jail, and one of the young men, Nuno Dala, is dying because of a hunger strike. This Parliament recently adopted a resolution on human rights in Angola. I therefore call on you to request that President Schulz contact the authorities of Angola without delay to ensure that Nuno Dala does not die in prison and that all the prisoners are duly released. They were jailed on the decision of a kangaroo court. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: It will be done on be it. Mr Gomes, I will inform the President of your request. As you know, the European Union and Parliament actively support the defence of human rights not only within the Union but also outside the Union, as provided for in the Treaty. Thank you for your intervention and your request.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: Mr President, a few hours ago the co-founder of our political movement died. Therefore, the Italian delegation of the EFDD Group, The 5 Star Movement, is today renouncing any intervention in this Chamber as a sign of mourning.

name: Presidente. –
text: As I have already had occasion to do, I have expressed my condolences to your political movement for the loss of Mr Casaleggio.

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF).
text: A few weeks ago, I promised to keep you informed of the results of last week's referendum in the Netherlands. The Dutch people voted on an association agreement with Ukraine and voted overwhelmingly against it.  Two thirds of the Dutch people say no, but here 90% say yes. I round off, let this be a nice prelude to the referendum in the United Kingdom.  [The President deprives the speaker of the floor.]

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr President, you are not consulting the agenda, the House was informed of the result of the referendum. We shall proceed to the vote.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission for this cohesion exercise, which will bring not only greater transparency but also greater legal clarity to this document.

name: Michel Dantin
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, your Committee on Agriculture had wished to start the negotiations in a trilogue after the vote on this text. This is the first time that it has been discussed in plenary. I would like to thank the negotiating team and our interlocutors in the other institutions. The proposed list of votes is therefore the result of the negotiation. If one of the amendments tabled in plenary by a political group were adopted, the political agreement would fall. I therefore invite you to reject the amendments that have been proposed by a political group.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the My report was adopted in the Committee on Legal Affairs before the interinstitutional agreement between Parliament, the Council and the Commission was concluded. Parliament approved this interinstitutional agreement on 9 March this year. For this reason, some technical adjustments are needed, and I would ask the President to instruct the services to make these technical adjustments in order to adapt the text to the current situation.

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr President. Kaufmann to make it clear that the services will do everything necessary to update the text. Thank you, however.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the oral explanations of vote.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The ACP (African, Caribbean and Pacific) countries are poor countries which the EU aims to dominate politically and economically. One of the primary tools by which it does this is politicised trade deals, whereby market access is conditional upon submitting to EU political demands. The Economic Partnership Agreements are amongst the most intrusive and formalised means by which the EU gains control over poor countries. We will vote against any attempt to make the EU more powerful towards actors in the Global South.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Council Regulation No 1528/2007 lays down the arrangements for certain products derived from the Caribbean, the Pacific and certain countries belonging to the African (ACP) States. The regulation aims to codify European legislation in this area, contained in various agreements establishing or aiming to establish economic partnership agreements. It is a question of providing for a temporary instrument to facilitate the entry into the European market of products from less developed economies, thus attempting to progressively intensify EU-ACP trade. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report proposes the adoption of the codification and recasting of the various changes to the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the regime provided for goods originating in certain States belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) in agreements establishing or leading to their establishment. Although this is a technical report, I do not agree with the content of the Regulation to be recast, as it concerns EU Economic Partnership Agreements with third countries, in this case with the ACP countries. These agreements often do not have positive agreements in the EU counterparty and reinforce asymmetry. For this reason I have not been able to vote in favour, and I abstained.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to codify the 'market access regulation', a text governing the importation of products from certain ACP countries. This temporary instrument allows them access to the EU market, duty-free and quota-free, until the respective economic partnership agreements are concluded and implemented. Although I am opposed to the agreements to remove customs barriers, I have spoken in favour of this simpler codification as long as the provisions remain unchanged.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is a simple modification of the pre-existing European texts in this area. So I voted for this purely technical report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The ACP (African, Caribbean and Pacific) countries are poor countries which the EU aims to dominate politically and economically. One of the primary tools by which it does this is with politicised trade deals, whereby market access is conditional upon submitting to EU political demands. The Economic Partnership Agreements are amongst the most intrusive and formalised means by which the EU can hold poorer countries to ransom. I voted against this agreement.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it sets up a temporary instrument that gives products from the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific (ACP) access to the EU market. This authorization would be effective until WTO-compatible economic partnership agreements are concluded and implemented.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on certain products originating in the ACP States. The proposed interim measure provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in non-least developed countries and quotas in preparation for the conclusion and application of relevant Economic Partnership Agreements in line with the WTO system from 1 October 2016.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The ACP (Africa Caribbean Pacific) countries are poor countries which the EU aims to dominate politically and economically. One of the primary tools by which it does this is politicised trade deals, whereby market access is conditional upon submitting to EU political demands. The Economic Partnership Agreements are amongst the most intrusive and formalised means by which the EU gains control over poor countries. We will vote against any attempt to make the EU more powerful towards actors in the Global South.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As a member of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve the effectiveness of the legal provisions previously adopted for win-win exchanges with ACP countries.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. A series of products originating from certain ACP states (Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific) may be given more favourable rules for access to the EU EU market, including the abolition of import duties through monitoring and safeguard measures.  I voted in favour of this regulation proposed in co-decision because it will allow the Commission to adopt delegated acts that can limit surveillance and safeguarding measures to one or certain Member States and not to the whole of the European Union. This targeting seems to me to be more appropriate as long as the measures taken do not disrupt the functioning of the internal market, which would then penalise the other Member States and undermine the intended effect.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Wałęsa report on products originating in certain ACP states. It is a technical measure aimed at simplifying EU legislation on market access, for products from African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. This is an important report because the original legal instrument, Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, has given rise to considerable problems of clarity and a difficulty in its application due to the numerous changes that have taken place since 2007. The new proposal for a regulation, which I supported with my vote, provides for a temporary instrument for duty-free access to the EU market for products originating in ACP countries. The measure will not be activated until before 1 October 2016, for the period preceding the conclusion and implementation of the new Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA) in accordance with the requirements of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this report proposing regulation for trade in products from ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean and Pacific). It is a procedural recast, however, market access facilities for the signatory countries of the agreement will diminish the development potentials of non-signatory countries.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work with a view to approving the Regulation on goods originating in certain ACP States, which regulates imports of products from that area. This transitional instrument provides duty-free or quota-free access to the EU market. Transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation are also to be ensured.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I chose to vote in favour of this report on products originating in certain ACP states. This is only a legal overhaul, in particular that of Regulation (EC) No. 1528/2007 on access to the European market for these products. In particular, in the absence of an economic partnership agreement, this instrument provides for the acp countries outside the LDCs to have duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market. As a Member of the European Parliament of the EU-ACP delegation, I am very much in favour of these exchanges as long as they are part of a sound logic of co-development with our African friends.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the arguments set out in my colleague's report on compliance with the current legislation of Regulation No 1528/2007 governing access to the EU market for certain African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. I therefore supported the text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation for the codification and recasting of Regulation 1528/2007 regulating imports of products from certain ACP countries. This transitional instrument provides duty-free or quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) or Least Developed Countries (PMD) group in the pre-conclusion and implementation phase of the respective WTO-consistent Economic Partnership Agreements (AEAs) by 1 October 2016.  The aim of the coding exercise is to ensure the transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation when an original legal act has undergone numerous amendments. Since its adoption in 2007, the Market Access Regulation has already been amended nine times. Therefore, coding is essential to ensure the clarity and readability of the encoding.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the Consultative Working Party decided by consensus that this Commission proposal does not contain any substantive amendments other than those referred to as substantial amendments. The Consultative Working Party also found that, as regards the codification of the unchanged provisions of the previous legislation and the above-mentioned substantive amendments, the proposal merely seeks to codify the existing legislation without changing its substance. The commission proposal deals with the codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, the so-called Market Access Regulation, which governs imports, imports, and recasts of products originating in african, caribbean and pacific (ACP) States. This interim measure provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in non-least developed countries and quotas in preparation for the conclusion and application of relevant Economic Partnership Agreements in line with the WTO system from 1 October 2016. Annex I to the Market Access Regulation currently includes 27 countries. The codification aims to ensure transparency and clarity and simplify EU legislation, as the original legislation has been amended many times. Since its adoption in 2007, the Market Access Regulation has been amended nine times since its adoption, including the harmonisation of legislation after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon under the Omnibus II trade act and subsequent Commission delegated regulations (see Annex II). annex III to the Commission proposal). Codification is therefore necessary to ensure that the regulation becomes clearer and more comprehensible.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my vote for it, I expressed my support for the recast of the legal act, as the original has been amended too many times. By ensuring transparency and clarity, the legal act has become more comprehensible and more readable. The proposed amendments to the Articles empower the Commission to adopt delegated acts in the specific arrangements applicable to products originating in South Africa. Since the Treaty of Lisbon repealed Article 134 of the Treaty establishing the European Community, it was also necessary to delete the superfluous reference in Article 22.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the codification of these legislative acts is important in order to make clearer the legal framework governing access to the single market for products from certain ACP States.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We believe that the regulatory and linguistic adaptation linked to the process of recasting the regulations in question, aimed at better transparency and accessibility by EU citizens and partner countries, hoping for the protection of people's rights as a central element of any possible future trade and/or partnership agreement with the ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean and Pacific) and/or other areas of political or economic interest, is due.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the codification and redesign of Regulation 1528/2007 governing the importation of products from certain ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific). This temporary instrument grants these products quota-free access to the EU market until the respective partnership agreements are concluded and implemented. Although I am opposed to any agreement to remove customs barriers or import quotas, I have spoken in favour of this simple codification of an existing text as long as the provisions remain unchanged.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the arrangements applicable to products originating in certain States belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States proposes to regulate imports of products originating in those countries. The provision of duty-free access to the EU market for products originating in ACP countries which do not fall under the category of least developed countries in the run-up to the conclusion and application of economic partnership agreements shall be considered. These regulations are based on simplification and transparency of Union law in order to ensure easy access for citizens to their rights. In the context that the Market Access Regulation has already been amended nine times since its adoption, a clear and simplified codification of the relevant legislation is needed.  I think it is particularly important to create a concise, clear legal framework that allows citizens to make use of specific rights, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure itself is not problematic. There are no negative economic consequences for the commercial interests of our regions. In fact, as this is a 'recast' measure, we are faced with the need to adapt Regulation No 1528/2007 governing access to the EU market for certain ACP countries (Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific) to the rules in force in the meantime. Since 2007, this regulation has already been amended 9 times, also to bring it into line with the post-Treaty reforms of Lisbon. In particular, the changes in today's vote take place to bring the existing rules into line with the Economic Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Development Community and Southern Africa concluded in 2014.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. As Socialists, we support quota-free or tariff-free access to European markets by least developed ACP countries, as long as the AEAs are finalized. With David Martin's report in 2012, we managed to ensure that the regulation continued to be implemented until 2016, to ensure that ACP countries had sufficient time to conclude and implement signed ESA without their imports being interrupted into the EU.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree that the codification procedure should be undertaken in this case. Given that the Regulation was updated and amended several times since 2007, codification will make it simpler and more transparent. Codification will make no changes to the substance of the Regulation and the duty-free quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in non-LDC ACP countries will remain in place.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal is concerned with the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 implementing the arrangements for products originating in certain States belonging to the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States. It is a temporary instrument to ensure that certain products from the least developed ACP countries have access to the European market pending the signing and ratification of the various trade agreements under negotiation. I voted in favour of this proposal because it goes no further than simply codifying the rules on the recognition of these products.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
