text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report on the codification and recasting of the 'Market Access Regulation', which governs imports of products from certain ACP countries (Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific). This temporary instrument provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products from the least developed countries (LDCs). The purpose of codification is to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification in EU legislation.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report we voted on concerns the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application to products originating in certain countries of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States of the arrangements provided for in the Economic Partnership Agreements or in the agreements leading to the conclusion of such agreements.  This report contains a number of positive elements in the context of Europe's integrated relations with these regions, particularly in the commercial sector. The codification and recasting of the so-called 'Market Access Regulation', which governs imports of products from African, Caribbean and Pacific countries, cannot, as a primary objective, give the Commission the power to adopt acts defining the status for products from those regions.  Moreover, purely economic issues cannot be the only objective that Europe should have in order to improve relations with these regions. I have therefore decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was simple for me to vote in favour of this proposal as it represents a simple codification related to trade in products originating in certain states belonging to the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP). I agree because it simply aims at legislative clarification and also ensures greater transparency after the numerous changes to this original legal instrument. It is, in my view, an improvement in the quality of legislation.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This concerns the re-codification of the Council Regulation ‘Market Access Regulation’ which regulates the importation of products from ACP countries. This is a temporary measure which provides duty- and quota-free access to the EU market for products from ACP countries before the WTO-compatible Economic Partnership Agreements, October 2016. The codification is necessary to provide transparency and accessibility to the EU legislation. The amendment of article 3(4) would enable the Commission to adopt delegated acts concerning the regime relevant to products from South Africa, once provisions of the TDCA have superseded those of the EPA.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The simplification and clarification of EU law is a central OBJECTIVE of the EU to make it more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand, which will allow them new opportunities and the possibility to benefit from the specific rights granted to them. The dispersion of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially (which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it) leads to the codification of the rules, for the sake of legal clarity and transparency. I support the Walesa report authorising the codification of Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 which governs imports of products originating in certain ACP countries and which has been amended 9 times since 2007. Thus, the text becomes clearer and more readable and there are no background changes in its content.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The ACP (African, Caribbean and Pacific) countries are poor countries which the EU aims to dominate politically and economically. One of the primary tools by which it does this is politicised trade deals, whereby market access is conditional upon submitting to EU political demands. The Economic Partnership Agreements are amongst the most intrusive and formalised means by which the EU gains control over poor countries. We will vote against any attempt to make the EU more powerful towards actors in the Global South.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is limited to a mere codification of existing acts, without any substantial changes.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of the recast technique is to consolidate a legislative instrument, that has been amended a number of times into a single legal text, thereby making it more accessible and reader-friendly for the user. At the same time the text also includes some minor substantive changes. The favourable opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs confirms that the proposal is straightforward codification and limits itself to the identified substantive amendments. I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report proposes the adoption of the codification and recasting of the various changes to the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the regime provided for goods originating in certain States belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) in agreements establishing or leading to their establishment. Although this is a technical report, I do not agree with the content of the Regulation to be recast, as it concerns EU Economic Partnership Agreements with third countries, in this case with the ACP countries. These agreements often do not have positive agreements in the EU counterparty and reinforce asymmetry. For this reason I have not been able to vote in favour, and I abstained.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal refers to the reform of the 'Market Access Regulation' (RAP). I voted for a transparency and simplification of EU legislation, after this project has undergone numerous changes since its adoption in 2007. Access to the EU market duty-free for products originating in ACP countries is a normality.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal aims to unify the existing text of the Market Access Regulation. The Regulation contains general rules for economic partnership agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements with ACCS (African, Caribbean, Pacific) States. Annex 1 to the Regulation contains a list of states to which the Regulation applies. The purpose of the agreements provided for in this Regulation is to lay down rules governing products originating in certain members of those States. According to the Commission proposal, under Section 290 TSI, the European Parliament authorises the Commission to amend the Annex to the Regulation in order to delete from the list the States with which the agreement has already been concluded. In addition to the current amending proposal, the Regulation has been amended several times in recent years, so it was timely to unify each amendment.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal concerns the harmonisation and recast of the Market Access Regulation, which regulates imports of products originating in certain countries within the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) group of states. It is a temporary tool to ensure duty-free and non-contingent market access for ACP countries that are not classified by the World Bank as economically least developed countries and which do not benefit from preferential access to the EU market under the WTO-compatible Economic Partnership Agreement.  As Vice-President of the EU-ACP Delegation, I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report concerns access to the European market for products originating from certain states belonging to the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP). The European Commission regulation aims to update existing rules to establish rules for trade with ACP states. Considering that the ACP States are important political and trade partners for the European Union, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the codification and overhaul of the regulation governing the importation of products from certain states belonging to the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP). Codification ensures transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation when a legal instrument is subject to multiple changes. The numerous changes to this legislation have made this codification necessary.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal aims to unify the text of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 in force (Regulation on market access). The endelet contains the general rules for economic partnership agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements with ACS (African, Caribbean, Pacific) States. Annex 1 to the Regulation contains a list of states to which the Regulation applies. The purpose of the agreements provided for in this Regulation is to lay down rules governing products originating in certain members of those States. Under the current Commission proposal, under Article 290 TSI, the European Parliament authorises the Commission to amend the Annex to the Regulation in order to delete from the list the States with which the agreement has already been concluded. In addition to the current amending proposal, the Regulation has been amended several times in recent years, so it was timely to unify each amendment.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text relates to the importation of products from certain ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific). This is a legal overhaul of Regulation (EC) 1528/2007 which gives products from the least developed ACP countries (so-called LDCs) duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market until the respective economic partnership agreements are concluded and implemented. To the extent that this goes in the direction of better legibility and participates in the simplification of the law through codification, I voted in favour.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Codification is a normal thing and I always support such reports, of course this should happen smoothly and without change in substance or if such a change is necessary, it should be minimal. It has become clear that this is exactly the codification and thus reduces the administrative burden and this will allow more ACP countries to import quality goods into the Community. Of course, it should be noted here that most companies there are either involving or owned by EU companies, so this is how we help the EU economy.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal aims to unify the text of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 in force (Regulation on market access). The Regulation lays down general rules for economic partnership agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements with ACS (African, Caribbean, Pacific) States. Annex 1 to the Regulation contains a list of states to which the Regulation applies. The purpose of the agreements provided for in this Regulation is to lay down rules governing products originating in certain members of those States. Under the current Commission proposal, under Article 290 TSI, the European Parliament authorises the Commission to amend the Annex to the Regulation in order to delete from the list the States with which the agreement has already been concluded. In addition to the current amending proposal, the Regulation has been amended several times in recent years, so it was timely to unify each amendment.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report reports on the codification and recast of the 'Market Access Regulation', which governs imports of products originating in certain ACP countries. This temporary instrument provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in ACP countries other than LDCs, currently including 27 countries. Since coding is about ensuring transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: outright coding of existing texts.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, called the 'Market Access Regulation', which governs imports of products originating in certain ACP countries (Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific).  This temporary instrument provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in ACP countries other than Least Developed Countries (LDCs) in the run-up to the conclusion and implementation of the so-called "Economic Partnership Agreements" (EPAs), free trade agreements which are subject to the logic of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). Annex I to the Market Access Regulation currently includes 27 countries. Assuming that these single measures can immediately ensure the prolongation of a situation that is in the interests of the ACP countries, they have a limited time horizon, as the proposal is part of the framework of the EPAs, which it accepts and defends. The EPAs mean the increase of existing inequalities, the serious effects of deregulation of trade, the free movement of capital and investment, i.e. the deepening of the neocolonial neoliberal model, which has been imposed, particularly in countries with poorer economies. In view of the use of coding (of an eminently technical nature), we abstained.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The recast is on an issue concerning the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) with ACP countries. I doubt whether the EPAs are really having positive effects on ACP countries. I abstained as a result.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is about the introduction of a temporary instrument that will allow duty-free and non-tariff access for products on the European Union market originating in ACP countries. The proposal in question is a simple codification and is limited to the substantive changes marked.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of adapting European Regulation 1528/2007.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report A8-0010/2016. Any codification and recasting of a text promoting the purchase of products from non-EU countries and not from Member States is not a step in the right direction.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 (the market access regulation) governing imports of products originating in certain ACP countries. This temporary instrument provides duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in non-least developed countries (LDC) ACP countries in the run-up to the conclusion and application of respective WTO-compatible Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) before the 1 October 2016. I support the continuation of duty free quota free access to the EU market for those non-least developed countries (LDC) whilst EPA negotiations are continuing. Continuing market access for these countries at this time is to be supported.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it recommends the adoption without modification of the Commission's proposal, which aims to ensure transparency, simplification and clarity of legislation concerning products originating in ACP countries and their access to the EU market. In particular, the proposal regulates the importation of products from ACP countries that are not among the least developed countries (LDCs), granting them duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market until the respective economic partnership agreements are concluded and implemented. This temporary instrument, which has been subject to multiple revisions and modifications, is clarified and simplified in the Commission's new proposal. It is above all a question of increasing legibility and legal certainty, and that is why I supported this report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal aims to unify the existing text of the Market Access Regulation. The Regulation contains general rules for economic partnership agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements with ACCS (African, Caribbean, Pacific) States. Annex 1 to the Regulation contains a list of states to which the Regulation applies. The purpose of the agreements provided for in this Regulation is to lay down rules governing products originating in certain members of those States. Under the current Commission proposal, under Section 290 TSI, the European Parliament authorises the Commission to amend the Annex to the Regulation in order to delete from the list the States with which the agreement has already been concluded. In addition to the current amending proposal, the Regulation has been amended several times in recent years, so it was timely to unify each amendment.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I accept the report, as the consolidated and recasting of temporary market access free of tariffs and quotas is key to EU support for global free trade. We would like to continue unifying under the Market Access Regulation, which currently lists 27 countries. Our aim is to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation, and products from ACCS States may benefit from this, in accordance with WTO rules.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report taking into account that this transitional instrument offers duty-free or quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in non-PMD ACP countries in the pre-conclusion and implementation phase of the respective WTO-consistent Economic Partnership Agreements (EAS). The aim of codification is nothing more than to ensure the transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation when an original legal act has undergone numerous amendments, so codification is essential to ensure the clarity and readability of the Regulation.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the regimes for products originating in certain States belonging to the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) provided for in agreements establishing, or leading to, economic partnership agreements, because I believe it is important to maintain a form of economic support for those least developed countries in Africa and the Caribbean in the process of negotiating economic partnership agreements. international trade partnership.  Specifically, the vote at this session is limited to codifying legislation that has been amended several times over the years, thus guaranteeing those values of legal certainty and transparency, which are fundamental for the European Union. I also agree with the choice of merit, because support for the world's poorest countries through quota-free and duty-free access to the EU market for products originating in those countries is a fair measure, pending broader agreements establishing regular trade cooperation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on products originating in certain ACP countries, as, as coordinator of my ECR Group in the EU-ACP delegation, I support, in principle, a flourishing, fair trade with the ACP countries and welcome the technical simplifications of the processes proposed here.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The proposal is an extension and codification of the existing Market Access Regulation. Good access to the EU market is important to promote the single market. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This technical proposal aims to codify the Market Access Regulation (1528/2007). Having been amended nine times since its adoption, codification was necessary, hence I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this report proposing regulation for trade in products from ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean and Pacific). It is a procedural recast, however, market access facilities for the signatory countries of the agreement will diminish the development potentials of non-signatory countries.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it is a Market Access Regulation, which sets out transitional rules for some ACP countries ahead of the entry into force of Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA), and has been amended nine times since its adoption.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal aims to unify the existing text of the Market Access Regulation. The Regulation contains general rules for economic partnership agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements with ACCS (African, Caribbean, Pacific) States. Annex 1 to the Regulation contains a list of states to which the Regulation applies. The purpose of the agreements provided for in this Regulation is to lay down rules governing products originating in certain members of those States. Under the current Commission proposal, under Section 290 TSI, the European Parliament authorises the Commission to amend the Annex to the Regulation in order to delete from the list the States with which the agreement has already been concluded. In addition to the current amending proposal, the Regulation has been amended several times in recent years, so it was timely to unify each amendment.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report may be of a technical nature since it is a codification of earlier decisions. However, because it concerns economic partnership agreements and because of our negative position on these agreements, we consider this abstention to be a more appropriate attitude.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support the report of my colleague, Jarosław Wałęsa, which proposes a regulation for the arrangement of products originating in certain states which are part of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States. Such a regulation would ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation after an original legal instrument has been amended numerous times. The original legal instrument, Council Regulation (EC) No 152872007, or the Market Access Regulation (MAR) is a temporary instrument which provides duty-free, quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in Non-LDC ACP countries. Codification is therefore essential to ensure clarity and readability of the regulation.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution as the regulation will now supersede the various acts incorporated in it, allowing the preservation of the regulation’s contents whilst being codified

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal aims to unify the text in force of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, the so-called 'Market Access Regulation'. The Regulation contains general rules for economic partnership agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements with ACCS (African, Caribbean, Pacific) States. Annex 1 to the Regulation contains a list of states to which the Regulation applies. The purpose of the agreements provided for in this Regulation is to lay down rules governing products originating in certain members of those States. Under the current Commission proposal, under Article 290 TSI, the European Parliament authorises the Commission to amend the Annex to the Regulation in order to delete from the list the States with which the agreement has already been concluded. In addition to the current amending proposal, the Regulation has been amended several times in recent years, so it was timely to unify each amendment.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report regarding a codification and recast of the market access regulation that governs imports of products originating in certain states which are part of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on the application of arrangements for products originating in certain countries belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) Group provided for in the agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements, as this does not prejudice the substance of the proposal, but is mainly about technical changes.  Codified acts do not change in content, but they are simplified and become clearer and more accessible to citizens. The European Union must ensure a more efficient finding and understanding of its legal acts, and codification is heading in this direction. In this context, I support an interinstitutional agreement allowing for an accelerated process for the swift adoption of codified acts and for Commission staff to codify acts after a maximum of ten amendments.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal deals with the codification and redesign of Regulation (EC) No. 1528/2007, known as the 'Market Access Regulation', governing the importation of products from certain ACP countries. This temporary instrument grants products originating in ACP countries that are not among the least developed countries (LDCs) duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market until the conclusion and implementation of respective economic partnership agreements. As the provisions have remained unchanged, these are mere codifications of the existing texts, hence my vote in favour of the text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The ACP (Africa Caribbean Pacific) countries are poor countries which the EU aims to dominate politically and economically. One of the primary tools by which it does this is politicised trade deals, whereby market access is conditional upon submitting to EU political demands. The Economic Partnership Agreements are amongst the most intrusive and formalised means by which the EU gains control over poor countries. We will vote against any attempt to make the EU more powerful towards actors in the Global South.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade relations with the Countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific are undoubtedly important for the EU, in particular the issue of duty-free access of certain products to the European market. In order to ensure smooth and transparent trade between ACP countries and the EU, the documents that control imports of products should be adapted and codified several times in such a way that they are clear, legible and understandable to all actors. I was therefore happy to support the report of the Committee on International Trade supporting the Commission's intentions to simplify this legislation. Transparent and understandable legislation is a long-term objective in our ALDE faction and in Parliament in general.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jaroslaw's report on products originating in certain ACP states. The report aims to establish economic partnership agreements with some african, Caribbean and Pacific Group (ACP) states. I agree with this report which calls for more favourable access to EU market rules for a number of products from these states, in order to support their economies. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report, for which I voted, deals with the Commission's proposal on codification and overhaul of the regulation governing the importation of products from certain ACP countries. The aim of codification is to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation on this instrument, which has already been the subject of nine amendments and which governs access to the EU market for products originating in ACP countries.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it is simply a technical proposal aimed at codifying the ‘Market Access Regulation’ to ensure clarity and readability of the regulation.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it is a good step in simplifying EU rules on our trade with the African, Caribbean and Pacific group of countries (the so-called ACP). Our trading relations with the ACP has been in the process of being revamped for over 10 years, and as a result the applicable regulation has undergone many revisions, adding layers of complexity that now need to be simplified.  This vote today therefore represents a small but not negligible step in the broader context of the conclusion of new Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) with groups of ACP countries. The EPAs raise a number of concerns, in particular in terms of sustainable development and the role of civil society. Today’s vote does not preclude our final position on the EPAs, which will depend on whether our concerns are addressed, especially the need for a real monitoring process, including African trade unions and civil society.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Commission proposes to facilitate market access to EU countries for the 27 ACP countries that the World Bank does not include among the least developed countries. The proposal provides for a modernisation of the Market Access Regulation, which allows countries classified in this way to export domestic goods to the EU duty-free and without quantitative restrictions. The aim of the amendments is to codify the legislation of the Market Access Regulation, which has already been amended several times and is transparent, clear and legally binding. That is why I support the Wasasa report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of regulations for products originating in certain members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACCS States) as defined in the agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements (recasting) The Commission proposal aims to consolidated the text of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 (Market Access Regulation) in force. The Regulation contains general rules for economic partnership agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements with ACCS (African, Caribbean, Pacific) States. Annex 1 to the Regulation contains a list of states to which the Regulation applies. The purpose of the agreements provided for in this Regulation is to lay down rules governing products originating in certain members of those States. Under the current Commission proposal, under Article 290 TSI, the European Parliament authorises the Commission to amend the Annex to the Regulation in order to delete from the list the States with which the agreement has already been concluded. In addition to the current amending proposal, the Regulation has been amended several times in recent years, so it was timely to unify each amendment.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is on a Commission law on imports of products from ACP countries. The aim of the legislation is to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of the legislation. However, I voted abstention since I do not think that this legislation has only positive effects on products from ACP and reinforcing trade relations.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The recasting and consolidated of the Regulation was very timely, since the Regulation on market access, originally adopted in 2007, has since been amended nine times. Not to mention, the types of goods in particular play a significant role in the European consumer basket. In general, efforts should be made to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation in all cases.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is our job to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation. Therefore I support the codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 of 20 December 2007 applying the arrangements for products originating in certain states which are part of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States. In this sense, it is important to note that this proposal contains a straightforward codification of the existing legal text, without any significant change in its substance. On the other hand, this could serve as a basis for agreement establishing or leading to the establishment of Economic Partnership Agreements. Here it is vital to emphasise the fact that the establishment of Economic Partnership Agreements with ACP states will boost their economic growth and will promote reforms.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Walesa's report on products originating in certain ACP states (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific). The provisions are unchanged. This is a legal overhaul of the regulation (a temporary instrument) on trade preferences granted to these countries.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is overhauling the regulation on trade preferences granted to ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific), which makes them clearer.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The regulation, known as the 'market access regulation', is a temporary instrument used by the European Union to grant free, duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market. This measure is established between the European Union and certain ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific), pending the conclusion and implementation of respective economic partnership agreements. The text put to the vote is an overhaul and an arrangement of the text, and does not change the regulation itself, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report proposes the adoption of the codification and recasting of the various changes to the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the regime provided for goods originating in certain States belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) in agreements establishing or leading to their establishment. Although this is a technical report, I do not agree with the content of the Regulation to be recast, as it concerns EU Economic Partnership Agreements with third countries, in this case with the ACP countries. These agreements often do not have positive agreements in the EU counterparty and reinforce asymmetry. For this reason I have not been able to vote in favour, and I abstained.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Commission proposes the codification of what has so far been known as the Market Access Regulation regulating imports of products from certain countries. This transitional instrument provides duty-free or quota-free access to the EU market for certain products originating in ACP countries (Africa, The Caribbean and the Pacific). With this codification we are able to ensure the transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation, as it would have previously undergone numerous changes.  I support this initiative, at the same time as the amendments tabled where the Commission is given the powers necessary to establish the regime applicable to products from South Africa and which states that the superfluous reference to Article 134 of the Treaty establishing the European Community should be removed, as it was revoked by the Treaty of Lisbon. Taking into account the considerations set out in favour of the proposal for this codification and the amendments indicated.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Commission proposes to facilitate market access to EU countries for the 27 ACP countries that the World Bank does not include among the least developed countries. The proposal provides for a modernisation of the Market Access Regulation, which allows countries classified in this way to export domestic goods to the EU duty-free and without quantitative restrictions. The aim of the amendments is to codify the legislation of the Market Access Regulation, which has already been amended several times and is transparent, clear and legally binding. That is why I support the Wasasa report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. This is a codification of previous EU regulations, so the vote does not change the very essence of EU legislation. At the same time, However, I stress that I do not agree with Regulation No 1528/2007, which is concerned by the amendment, namely the fact that the EU is pushing the poor countries of Africa, the Pacific and the Caribbean in exchange for free trade into European-style subsidy programmes.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Commission proposal report proposes codifying the existing Council Regulation on products originating in ACP countries (a group of countries from Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific Ocean area) from 2007.  Codification of the text refers to market access, i.e. the management of goods and products from ACP countries so that they do not have to pay customs or have a limit on the quantity of imported products. Since the beginning of the council regulation, the text has been codified several times and in this way the final version of the text is intended to be made transparent and simple to all parties to the contract signatories, so I supported the report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this vote was to support the Commission's proposal to codifying and recasting Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007. This Regulation regulates imports of certain products originating in the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States and applies to goods produced in the least developed ACP countries, consistently providing them with duty-free and free access to the European Union market. At present, 27 ACP countries are included in this scheme. In other words, the idea is to continue to support developing countries with this kind of indirect economic assistance, enabling them to export their products to the Union. Since this scheme does not really distort the interests of local producers and consumers, and in parallel contributes to the expansion of the EU's role on a global scale in economic and political terms, it was logical to support it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the codification and clearer and more comprehensible regulation of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, which regulates duty-free and non-tariff-free imports of products originating in certain ACP countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application to products originating in certain countries of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States of the arrangements provided for in the Economic Partnership Agreements or in the agreements leading to the conclusion of such agreements (recast), because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This text merely codifies existing provisions, including Regulation 1528/2007 governing access to the European market for certain products originating from "ACP" countries (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific). These temporary agreements grant non-least undying products from ACP countries who are not "least developed countries" access to the EU market duty-free and quota-free.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal for the codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, the so-called ‘Market Access Regulation’ (MAR), governing imports of products originating in certain ACP countries. It is necessary because the Market Access Regulation has already been amended nine times.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on products originating in certain ACP States. The proposal consists of a mere codification of the existing and unchanged provisions, at a substantive level. We are talking about the market access regulation governing imports of products originating in certain ACP countries, providing for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market. Codification helps to ensure transparency and clarity in EU legislation, which is also why I am in favour of it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the regime laid down for goods originating in certain States belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) in agreements establishing economic partnership agreements or leading to their establishment in their consolidated version. The aim of this coding exercise is to ensure the transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation when an original legal act has undergone numerous changes. Since its adoption in 2007, this Regulation has already been amended nine times and codification is now essential to ensure the clarity and readability of the Regulation.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. In deciding on the Walesa report, the European Parliament was called upon to give its assent to a simple technical codification, aimed at merging provisions contained in previously negotiated agreements between the European Union and some ACP countries. The so-called "market access regulation" provides that countries in this region that are not part of the "least developed countries" (LDCs) can, on an interim basis (until the conclusion and application of respective economic partnership agreements), enjoy access without tariffs and quotas to the European Union market.  I supported the Walesa report, which brings greater legal clarity to this market access regulation, which has already been amended nine times since 2009. On the other hand, I dispute that this preferential treatment is only temporary in nature and expires in the coming months. Our African partners need more support in their development than "reciprocity" in their trade agreements.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I consider that the Commission's proposal to amend the current Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 should be amended accordingly. It is necessary to comply with the recent Economic Partnership Agreements aimed at continuing and strengthening free market access to the Union of third least developed countries.  The proposed changes do not, in essence, change the non-modifiable provisions of the Rules of Procedure. For these provisions there is only a recast, while some other articles are amended, such as Article 3 which will now enable the Commission to adopt acts relating to the import arrangements for products from the ACP countries, acts which will be in line with the corresponding provisions of the Economic Partnership Agreement of 15 July 2014.  The aim of the proposal is to ensure more transparency and clarity, as well as simplify European legislation in this area.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of recasting existing legislation surrounding market access regulation for products originating in certain African, Caribbean and Pacific states that will render the legislation more accessible and reader friendly.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report proposes an overhaul of the texts granting the most advanced countries in the Pacific Caribbean Africa area ACP access to the European market without quotas or tariffs until the conclusion and implementation of the respective economic partnership agreements. Without this change, these 27 countries would lose their privileged access to the European market, which would have significant economic consequences. Nevertheless, without being directly linked to it, this text announces the future conclusion of the EPAs which will be disastrous for these same economies. I abstain so as not to participate in the establishment of this looting system.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The legal overhaul of this text on acp products does not introduce a change in provisions. There has only been a work of coding existing texts. This ephemeral instrument allows ACP access to the EU market, duty-free and quota-free.  As a result, I voted for this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation applies to products originating in certain States belonging to the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States ("ACP") the schemes provided for in agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements. If there is no substantive amendment to the existing one, I shall vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this regulation as it codifies and recasts existing regulations on market access for developing countries. The proposed recast ensures transparency, clarity and a simplification of the current EU legislation in this field in a straightforward way.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the vote in favour of the report on codification and the overhaul of the European 'market access regulation' for products originating from certain ACP countries. In adopting this report, Parliament endorsed the Commission's proposal to codify the regulation, which since its adoption in 2007 has already been amended nine times.  This codification makes this regulation clearer, more consistent and more readable. It is an effective technique that ensures transparency and simplification of EU legislation when a legal instrument is subject to multiple changes.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The present proposal aims at codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 of 20 December 2007 applying measures to products originating in certain Member States which are part of a group of African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States, provided for in the agreements concluding or leading to the conclusion of economic partnership agreements. The purpose of such agreements is to contribute to global efforts to eradicate poverty and improve overall living conditions in these parts of the world by gradually integrating the economies of the ACP countries into the global trading system, as well as promoting regional integration. However, these agreements must comply with WTO rules. In order to try to achieve sustainable development and improve the economic situation of these countries and the lives of their citizens, I consider that the EU should continue the tariff-free and quota-free approach to imports of all products except arms, while it is essential that imported products meet European standards of quality, safety and public health. The proposal for a regulation provides for these guarantees and I am therefore voting in favour of the European Parliament's report as it stands.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the products originating in certain ACP states which aims to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of the EU legislation. This is a codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 (the market access regulation) governing imports of products originating in certain ACP countries. This temporary instrument provides duty-free quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in non-least developed countries (LDC) of the ACP countries, in the run-up to the conclusion and application of respective WTO-compatible Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) before 1 October 2016.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council a regulation on the application of regulations on products originating in certain African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACCS States). The proposal concerns the consolidated and recasting of council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 on market access. The consolidated approach is justified by the fact that the Regulation on market access has been amended nine times since its adoption in 2007.  The recast proposal concerns two points. On 15 July 2014, the EU and the South African Development Community concluded an Economic Partnership Agreement, the provisions of which will replace the relevant provisions of the EU-South Africa Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement. The amendment proposed for Article 3(4) would allow the Commission to subsequently adopt delegated acts setting out the rules applicable to products originating in South Africa. The proposal, in Article 22, proposes to delete the reference to Article 134 of the Treaty establishing the European Community, since this Article has been repealed by the Treaty of Lisbon. In its report, the Committee on International Trade recommends that Parliament support the Commission's proposal. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal deals with the codification and redesign of Regulation (EC) 1528/2007, governing the importation of products from certain ACP countries. This temporary instrument grants products originating in ACP countries that are not among the least developed countries access to the EU market duty-free and quota-free until the conclusion and implementation of respective economic partnership agreements. There is no need to oppose it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposal concerns the codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, called the 'Market Access Regulation', which regulates imports of products originating in certain ACP countries.  I believe that EU legislation must ensure transparency, clarity and simplification, and this proposal with the aim of codifying the unchanged provisions of the previous acts, together with the duly identified amendments, follows this assumption.  For the foregoing, this report deserves my vote in favour.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the revision of a regulation applying special regimes for the importation of products originating from certain states belonging to the group of African, Caribbean and Pacific states. The Commission's proposal is limited to an outright codification of existing texts, without altering their substance.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Walesa report on the regimes for products originating in certain African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) group states under the Economic Partnership Agreements (redesign). The redesign is a technique that aims to codify into a single legal act legislation that has been amended several times, so as to facilitate access and reading, while making substantive changes to the text. In order to recognise the substantive changes introduced in the text, they are highlighted in grey in the Commission's proposal. Article 104 of Parliament's Regulation explains the modalities of the redesign: the relevant text is referred to the relevant committee on the merits as well as to the Committee on Legal Affairs. The legal services of the three institutions (European Parliament, Council and Commission) meet and consider the proposals for an overhaul.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The redesign of the Council's market access regulation for certain products from African, Caribbean and Pacific countries should simplify existing regulations. The European Commission proposal that Parliament has just adopted, and which I have supported, replaces the various acts while preserving their substance. Parliament's decision will therefore lead to improved legislation and access to the European market.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposal concerns a codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, the so-called "Market Access Regulation", which regulates imports of products originating in certain ACP countries. The aim is to ensure the transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation by codifying in a single legislative act provisions scattered in different acts or adopted at different times in order to facilitate the reading and understanding of these rules.  I therefore voted in favour of the measure.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal is a codification of an earlier Council Regulation of 2007 on imports of products originating in certain ACS countries. It has been amended 9 times since the adoption of the regulation, so converting the partial amendments into a single legal text is, in my view, necessary for the transparency and transparency of EU legislation. The need for codification is supported by the favourable opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 1 January 2008 the provisions of the Market Access Regulation entered into force as a temporary unilateral scheme before the conclusion and application of the revised Economic Partnership Agreements. The Commission proposal concerns the codification and recast of the Market Access Regulation, governing imports of products originating in certain ACP Countries. I have voted for this report that aims to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU Legislation.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to reform the regulation on the regimes applicable to products originating in certain States which are part of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) group of States provided for in the agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs). Since 2002, the Union has negotiated the EPA with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States in seven regions comprising the Caribbean, Central Africa, East and South Africa, the East African Community, the Pacific Island States, the South African Development Community and West Africa. These agreements must comply with the obligations of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), support regional integration and promote the progressive integration of ACP economies into the regulated international trading system, thereby encouraging their sustainable development and contributing to the overall effort to eradicate poverty and improve living conditions in the ACP States. However, in view of the particular sensitivity of agricultural products, safeguard measures should be adopted where imports cause or are likely to cause malfunctions in the markets of such products or malfunctions in the mechanisms governing those markets.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained because, without the support of African states in exporting and improving employment opportunities, the migration crisis is in danger of worsening.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which provides for an overhaul of the texts to maintain access to the European market without quotas or tariffs for the most advanced countries in the Caribbean Africa Pacific (ACP) zone. Indeed, while it is justified for some ACP countries to have access to the European market without tariffs, this situation often has negative consequences for the outermost regions of the European Union located in the same geographical areas, which then suffer from a situation of unfair competition. I regret that the impact of such measures on the outermost regions is not sufficiently analysed upstream.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. EU regulation must be clear and transparent. EU rules need to be simpler and more accessible to citizens so that they can gain new opportunities and benefit from the specific rights conferred on them. The new regulation will replace the various acts whose provisions have been incorporated into it without any change in the content of the codified legislation. It should be noted that the involvement of acp countries in the rules-based world trade system is a crucial step towards promoting their sustainable development, eradicating poverty and improving living conditions.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The ACP (African, Caribbean and Pacific) countries are poor countries which the EU aims to dominate politically and economically. One of the primary tools by which it does this is politicised trade deals, whereby market access is conditional upon submitting to EU political demands. The Economic Partnership Agreements are amongst the most intrusive and formalised means by which the EU gains control over poor countries. We will vote against any attempt to make the EU more powerful towards actors in the Global South.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the current Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 of the Market Access Council is a temporary instrument which, pending the entry into the European market of products originating in non-LDCs, pending the conclusion of economic partnership agreements with the same countries; That this regulation has already been the subject of numerous amendments and that the current codification proposal helps to simplify EU legislation and that the proposal to recast certain paragraphs of the regulation is necessary as it concerns substantial parts of this regulation, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the application of arrangements for products originating in certain countries belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) Group provided for in the establishment agreements or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements, as there are no changes in the content of the legislation, but the proposed changes are limited solely to codification of existing texts already adopted by this Parliament.  The aim of this codification is to ensure greater transparency and clarity of legislation, as well as its simplification. Since the original regulation regulating the application of arrangements for products originating in certain countries belonging to the ACP group has been amended nine times since its adoption in 2007, it is necessary to harmonise, consolidate and codify any changes that have occurred in order to contribute to the creation of a cleaner legislative text.  Codification was done in agreement with the European Parliament, there have been no changes in the content of legislative acts, but it is about bringing together unchanged provisions of already existing acts already adopted by Parliament, so I supported their codification because it contributes to easier getting around in matter, visibility, as well as unity criteria.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal deals with the codification and redesign of Regulation (EC) No. 1528/2007, "Market Access Regulation", governing the importation of products from certain ACP countries. This temporary instrument provides products originating in ACP countries that are not among the least developed countries (LDCs) with a number of trade conditions until the conclusion and application of respective economic partnership agreements. The provisions are unchanged. These are pure and simple codifications of existing texts. So I'm voting for it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Council Regulation (EC) No 2012 1528/2007 regulates the import of products originating in a country of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Countries Group into the European Union, and this trade agreement is one of the tools aimed at strengthening the EU-Africa partnership, which gives African and European citizens more opportunities to participate.  I note that trade agreements are the most important instruments for boosting trade between the European Union and African regions, so market access to the European Union without customs duties and without quotas is an indispensable instrument to be nurtured.  For this reason, I welcome this agreement and believe that preferential market access to certain ACP countries should continue, i.e. continue without customs duties and import products originating in regions or countries other than least developed countries of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States without quotas. I also welcome the codification of the regulation, which aims to contribute to the transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It is a temporary instrument providing for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in ACP countries other than Least Developed Countries (LDCs) in the run-up to the conclusion and implementation of their World Trade Organisation (WTO) compatible economic partnership agreements (EPAs) before 1 October 2016. Annex I to the Market Access Regulation currently includes 27 countries. The meager positive effects that may result for acp countries contrast with the consequences of the EPA framework, which accentuate existing inequalities, the serious effects of deregulation of trade and free movement of capital and investment, i.e. the deepening of the neoliberal model that has been imposed, particularly in countries with poorer economies.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported my colleague Jarosław Wałęsa's report on the application of arrangements for products originating in certain countries belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) Group provided for in the establishment agreements or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements. In my view, The Council Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013 1528/2007 needs to be recast with a view to clarity, as further amendments are imminent.  I welcome the amendments in Article 3(4) to be made possible by the Commission for the Adoption of Confidential Acts, which will set the regime applicable to Products from South Africa, when the relevant provisions of the South African Trade, Cooperation and Development Treaty (TDCA) are replaced by the relevant provisions of the ECONOMIC Partnership Agreement between the EU and the South African Development Community (SADC).

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the adoption of this proposal to codify and recast the Council Regulation regulating imports of products originating in certain ACP countries. It must therefore be adapted in order to increase its transparency and clarity. Given that this temporary instrument has been amended many times, I welcome the efforts to recast it.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal concerns Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, the "Market Access Regulation" (RAM), which regulates imports of products originating in certain ACP countries (Africa, caribbean and pacific). The purpose of the report is to codify in a single legislative act provisions which until now have been divided into different acts, or had been adopted at different times. The aim is to facilitate the reading and understanding of these rules. This is a technical/legal act which has seen the Council and Parliament accede to the Commission's proposal, without proposing any amendments. I believe that European codification must always be able to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification. I therefore voted in favour of this report in the hope of contributing to a rationalisation of EU legislation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the European Commission's proposals for transparency and simplification of rules on products originating in certain African, Caribbean and Pacific states (ACP) and their access to the EU market. In particular, products from non-least developed ACP countries (LDCs) will have duty-free and quota-free access to the European market while the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) signed between the EU and these states are effectively implemented.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The ACP (Africa Caribbean Pacific) countries are poor countries which the EU aims to dominate politically and economically. One of the primary tools by which it does this is politicised trade deals, whereby market access is conditional upon submitting to EU political demands. The Economic Partnership Agreements are amongst the most intrusive and formalised means by which the EU gains control over poor countries. We will vote against any attempt to make the EU more powerful towards actors in the Global South.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Parliament's resolution because it refers to a regulation negotiated in a protracted manner by the Commission and the Council, which allows the implementation of economic partnership agreements (EPAs) with several African, Caribbean and Pacific countries, (ACP) which should be consistent with the obligations assumed by the World Trade Organisation (WTO), supporting regional integration and promoting the gradual integration of ACP economies into the rules-based world trade regime , thereby promoting its sustainable development and contributing to the overall effort to eradicate poverty and promote living conditions in the ACP States.  I am confident that these partnership agreements are concluded on the assumption that, in particular in the areas of customs and trade policy, account will always be taken of the particular structural, social and economic situation of the outermost regions of the Union and does not cause any damage from these agreements.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is only the codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, called the 'Market Access Regulation', which governs imports of products originating in certain ACP countries (Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific). This temporary instrument provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in ACP countries other than LDCs (Least Developed Countries). The aim of the codification exercise is to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation.  The Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that the Commission's proposal contains no sub-amendments and that it boils down to the codification of the unchanged provisions of the previous acts with those amendments.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation for the codification and recasting of Regulation 1528/2007 regulating imports of products from certain ACP countries. This transitional instrument provides duty-free or quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) or Least Developed Countries (PMD) group in the pre-conclusion and implementation phase of the respective WTO-consistent Economic Partnership Agreements (AEAs) by 1 October 2016.  The aim of the coding exercise is to ensure the transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation when an original legal act has undergone numerous amendments. Since its adoption in 2007, the Market Access Regulation has already been amended nine times. Therefore, coding is essential to ensure the clarity and readability of the encoding.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes up the Commission's proposal to codify Regulation (EC) 1528/2007 of the Council on 20 December 2007. The Market Access Regulation applies to products originating in certain African, Caribbean and Pacific Group (ACP) countries the regimes set out in agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements. It applies to products originating from the regions and states listed in Appendix I which advocate more favourable access to EU market rules for a number of products defined in the regulation.  It should be noted that this new regulation will replace the various acts incorporated into it, while fully preserving the substance of these acts. At the same time, it was also necessary to introduce some substantive changes to enable the Commission to adopt delegated acts and to adapt the rules on exceptional measures with limited territorial application.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because I have led the conclusion of the legal services consultative group that the proposal does not contain any substantive changes other than those referred to as substantial amendments. The Consultative Working Party also found that, as regards the codification of the unchanged provisions of the previous legislation and the above-mentioned substantive amendments, the proposal merely seeks to codify the existing legislation without changing its substance.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal concerns the codification and recast of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, commonly referred to as the "Market Access Regulation", which governs imports of products originating in certain ACP countries. This temporary instrument provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in certain ACP countries (Africa, caribbean and Pacific) in the run-up to the conclusion and implementation of their World Trade Organisation (WTO) compatible economic partnership agreements (EPAs) before 1 October 2016.  The technical purpose of the reformulation is the consolidation of a legislative piece, which has been amended several times, in a single legal text making it more accessible and easier to read for the user, while making some changes to it. Because I think it is important to simplify and make accessible all documents relating to European legislation, I voted in favour of this legislative resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the codification of Regulation (EC) 1528/2007 of the Council of 20 December 2007. This market access regulation applies to products originating in certain African, Caribbean and Pacific Group (ACP) countries the regimes set out in agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements. This is a codification and redesign procedure, which is a technique to codify in one legal act legislation that has been amended several times, so as to facilitate access and reading, while making substantive changes to the text. In the end, this procedure enhances the transparency and legal security of the European texts.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this report proposing regulation for trade in products from ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean and Pacific). It is a procedural recast, however, market access facilities for the signatory countries of the agreement will diminish the development potentials of non-signatory countries

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report proposes the adoption of the codification and recasting of the various changes to the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council implementing the regime provided for goods originating in certain States belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) in agreements establishing or leading to their establishment. Although this is a technical report, I do not agree with the content of the Regulation to be recast, as it concerns EU Economic Partnership Agreements with third countries, in this case with the ACP countries. These agreements often do not have positive agreements in the EU counterparty and reinforce asymmetry. For this reason I have not been able to vote in favour, and I abstained.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report voted on today concerns a codification and recast of the so-called 'Market Access Regulation', which provides for quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in certain African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States in the run-up to the conclusion and application of their respective Economic Partnership Agreements. Since this is a simple codification which does not involve any substantial changes, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the continuation of the non-least developed countries' quota-free and duty-free access to the EU Market whilst the negotiations for a WTO-compatible Economic Partnership Agreement are underway.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution sets up regulations for products from the African, Caribbean and Pacific group of states, leading to Economic Partnership Agreements. As the regulations support these countries, I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recast of the Report on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the application of arrangements for products originating in certain countries belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) Group provided for in the establishment agreements or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements, as the Commission proposal aims to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of European legislation, after the original legal instrument has been amended nine times. The recast is necessary due to limited changes in certain articles and the recast would allow the Commission to adopt delegated acts to establish a regime applicable to products originating in South Africa, once the European Partnership Agreement replaces the EU-South Africa Trade, Development and Cooperation Agreement. The Committee on Legal Affairs considers that the proposal in question does not contain any substantive amendments, other than those identified as such in the proposal and that, as regards the codification of unchanged provisions of previous acts with those amendments, the proposal contains a clear codification of existing texts without substantive changes.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal aims to unify the text of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 in force (Market Access Regulation). The Regulation contains general rules for economic partnership agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements with ACCS (African, Caribbean, Pacific) States.  Annex 1 to the Regulation contains a list of states to which the Regulation applies. The purpose of the agreements provided for in this Regulation is to lay down rules governing products originating in certain members of those States. Under the current Commission proposal, under Article 290 TSI, the European Parliament authorises the Commission to amend the Annex to the Regulation in order to delete from the list the States with which the agreement has already been concluded. In addition to the current amending proposal, the Regulation has been amended several times in recent years, so it was timely to unify each amendment.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union places particular emphasis on the development of global free trade, with a view to diversifying the supply of products to consumers around the world. At the same time, the Union supports the economic consolidation of countries in less developed regions, such as Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific (ACP countries). For these reasons, the EU supports the integration of those countries into the World Trade Organisation (WTO), but is aware that they need a period of preparation for their economies to become compatible with the developed economies of the WTO. In those circumstances, the Council decided, as early as 2007, to exempt products from developing ACP countries from customs duties. The extension of this measure until the adoption of economic partnership agreements between those States and the WTO was considered necessary precisely in order to facilitate the economic development and reform of those States. This document notes the extension of the period of validity of the measures exempting products from those countries, as well as a number of amendments to bring the legislative regulations up to date. I believe that these measures are necessary in order to provide an example of good cooperation at international level and I support the adoption of the document.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agreed with the proposal for a regulation by which the Commission intends to introduce transitional measures for products originating in African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. In essence, according to the evaluation of the EP's Working Party of Legal Services, it is, in particular, a clear and simple codification of the existing acts without significant changes. The Commission proposes to codify and recast the 2007 Regulation governing the conditions for access to the EU market, namely those relating to imports of products originating in certain African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries. The temporary instrument to be put into practice by this codification will allow duty-free and non-tariff access for products originating in ACP countries to the EU market before the conclusion and application of the relevant Economic Partnership Agreements in accordance with WTO rules before 1 October 2016. To this end, codification is intended to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of legislation in order to make the Regulation more readable. As the proposal does not contain fundamental changes to legislative acts and is a temporary measure, I support this proposal and believe that it will contribute to increased economic exchanges with the ACP countries.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, the so-called 'Market Access Regulation', refers to arrangements for imports of goods originating in certain countries which are part of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP). As provided for in the agreements, ACP States intending to establish or lead to the establishment of economic partnership agreements shall be considered. In this case, there is more favourable access to EU market rules for a number of products as defined in the regulation and, in particular, for the abolition of import duties on the EU market if the products originate in the regions or countries listed in the Annex to the Regulation. In addition, the Regulation also lays down rules for determining the origin of products from regions or countries taken into account, which may be amended in accordance with this proposal.
