The Commission proposal deals with the codification and recast of this Regulation and aims to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation, as they have amended the original Market Access Regulation nine times since its adoption in 2007. In view of the need to ensure the clarity and readability of the regulation, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation on the application of the arrangements for goods originating in certain ACP countries, in support of the codification of the regulation.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Commission proposes to facilitate market access to EU countries for the 27 ACP countries that the World Bank does not include among the least developed countries. The proposal provides for a modernisation of the Market Access Regulation, which allows countries classified in this way to export domestic goods to the EU duty-free and without quantitative restrictions. The aim of the amendments is to codify the legislation of the Market Access Regulation, which has already been amended several times and is transparent, clear and legally binding. That is why, as shadow rapporteur for the ECR, I support the Wasasa report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regional integration of the economies of African, Caribbean and Pacific countries into the regulated world trading system and their support contribute to the overall efforts to eradicate poverty and improve living conditions in ACP countries.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council concerns the recast of the Council Regulation on the application of the regulation for products originating in states belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP) Group provided for in the establishment agreements or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements.  The new regulation is necessary to make it easier to understand transparency and accessibility for citizens of the European Union, and it is for these reasons that it is important to replace the acts embedded there, by fully conveying the content of the acts being codified. This temporary instrument provides duty-free and invertebrate access to the EU market for products originating in ACP countries. Consequently, I support this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a technical proposal aimed at codifying the Market Access Regulation (1528/2007). The Market Access Regulation, which sets out transitional rules for some ACP countries ahead of the entry into force of Economic Partnership Agreements (EPA), has been amended nine times since its adoption. Codification is therefore necessary to ensure clarity and readability of the Regulation.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council concerns the codification and recasting of the so-called Market Access Regulation, which regulates imports of products originating in certain countries belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific Countries (ACP) Group. This durable instrument provides invertebrate and thus more favourable access to the EUROPEAN Union market with products originating in ACP countries that do not fall within the group of least developed countries. The new regulation will replace individual acts included in the regulation, but preserve the content of codifying acts. I support the report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the application of arrangements for products originating in certain countries belonging to the ACP Group provided for in the establishment or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements. I believe that the recast is necessary because the purpose of it is to consolidate the legislative part, which has already been amended countless times into a single legislative text to make it more accessible and clearer.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it was mainly legislative in nature, without fundamental changes.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of the arrangements to goods originating in certain countries of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) set out in the agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements. I support codification to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation. EU legislation needs to be updated all the time. The Market Access Regulation provides for access to the EU market free of duties and quotas for products originating in African, Caribbean and Pacific countries that are not less developed.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report is a codification of decisions taken by the so-called 'Market Access Regulation' (CFR), which governs imports of products from certain ACP countries. However, because of the nature of the economic partnership agreements which work to the detriment of the interests of the peoples, we have abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Any codification and recasting of a text promoting the purchase of products from non-EU countries and not from Member States is not a step in the right direction

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The aim of codification is to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation when a legal instrument undergoes multiple changes. Since its adoption in 2007, the market access regulation has already been amended nine times, notably in the context of the "post-Lisbon" alignment through the Omnibus Trade II Act and subsequent Commission delegated regulations. I therefore voted in favour of Mr Walesa's text

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as I believe that it will simplify, clarify and make more transparent the arrangements for imports of products originating in certain states, which are part of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) group of states. In fact, this regulation allows ACP states that are not among the Least Developed Countries (LDC) to benefit from quota-free, duty-free access to the EU market. This is a temporary instrument before the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) compatible with the World Trade Organisation (WTO) come into place in October 2016.  This initiative supports regional integration and promotes the gradual integration of the ACP economies into the rules-based world trading system, fostering their sustainable development and contributing to the effort to eradicate poverty and to enhance living conditions in the ACP countries.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the main economic and political player in sub-Saharan Africa. It is essential, in order to ensure the development of the ACP countries, to ensure reciprocity of preferential concessions between the EU and the ACP countries. The different generations of previous agreements have generally yielded little success in stimulating more trade as well as not guaranteeing economic growth capable of giving a prospect of improving the living conditions of the inhabitants of some of the poorest countries on the planet.  We need to change our approach to Africa: from a continent hungry and plagued by civil wars, to an economy emerging from rich opportunities.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal aims to unify the text of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 in force (Regulation on market access). The Regulation contains general rules for economic partnership agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements with ACCS (African, Caribbean, Pacific) States. Annex 1 to the Regulation contains a list of states to which the Regulation applies. The purpose of the agreements provided for in this Regulation is to lay down rules governing products originating in certain members of those States. Under the current Commission proposal, under Article 290 TSI, the European Parliament authorises the Commission to amend the Annex to the Regulation in order to delete from the list the States with which the agreement has already been concluded. In addition to the current amending proposal, the Regulation has been amended several times in recent years, so it was timely to unify each amendment.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report by Mr Wałęsa of the European Parliament on the so-called Market Access Regulation, which regulates imports of products originating in the ACP States. The aim of the new provisions is to standardise existing international agreements and, to be important, to ensure transparency and clarity and to simplify EU legislation. Such activities should be a legislative priority in the European Parliament. Complex, difficult to interpret rules is the biggest problem in EU legislation. Every simplification is worthy of support.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union has long-standing relations with the African, Caribbean and Pacific Countries Group (ACP) and their comprehensive partnership includes political dimension, economic and trade cooperation and cooperation in financing development.  The initial emphasis of the partnership between the two parties was on development assistance and trade, as seen in the provider-to-recipient relationship. Given the change in circumstances and relations, the partnership focused on meeting common interests. The Cotonou agreement signed in 2000 significantly strengthened the political foundation of the partnership by including a wide-ranging political dialogue with ACP states. I supported this proposal because it is about codifying existing texts without changing them.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of the arrangements to goods originating in certain countries of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) set out in the agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements (recast) as codification aims to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation after the original legal act has been amended several times. The Market Access Regulation has already been amended nine times since its adoption in 2007, including alignment with the Treaty of Lisbon under the 'Trade Synthesising Act II' and subsequent Commission delegated regulations. Codification is therefore essential to ensure the clarity and readability of the Regulation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this report proposing regulation for trade in products from ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean and Pacific). It is a procedural recast, however, market access facilities for the signatory countries of the agreement will diminish the development potentials of non-signatory countries.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is merely codifying the legal criteria governing imports from certain ACP countries (Africa, the Caribbean, the Pacific). So I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal concerns the restructuring and recasting of Council Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007 on imports of products originating in certain ACCS countries, the so-called 'market access' Regulation. By 1 October 2016, this Temporary Instrument shall provide eu market access free of duty and quotas for products originating in non-ACS countries other than the least developed countries until the conclusion and application of ECONOMIC PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENTS in accordance with WTO rules with those countries. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted abstention in this report proposing regulation for trade in products from ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean and Pacific). It is a procedural recast, however, market access facilities for the signatory countries of the agreement will diminish the development potentials of non-signatory countries.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this technical report which facilitates imports by the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report regarding codification and modification of the ‘Market Access Regulation’ (MAR), governing imports of products originating in certain African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. This temporary instrument provides duty-free quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in non-LDC ACP countries, leading to the conclusion and application of the respective WTO-compatible Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) before 1 October 2016. The aim of the codification application is to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of the EU legislation after revising the original legal instrument numerous times. Codification is crucial for ensuring clarity and readability of the regulation and this is why I voted in favour.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal aims to codify Council regulation No 1528/2007 of 20 December 2007. The regulation is responsible for regulating more favourable access to market rules for goods originating in certain ACP States. The objective of this proposal is to consolidate legislation that has been reformed several times into a single legal text that is more accessible and readable to the user, while making some substantive changes that improve current legislation. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report, as it is a codification of the 'market access regulation'. With this decision, we bring more clarity and transparency to these regulations.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report focuses on maintaining "privileged" access to the European market, without quota or tariffs, for the most economically "developed" countries in the Caribbean Africa Pacific region such as Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire before the imminent conclusion of economic partnership agreements (EPAs). In the long run, only the least "advanced" countries in terms of development aid in the strict sense of the word will continue to benefit from "privileged access". The EU is putting pressure on the so-called "most developed" states in the area to sign EPAs, i.e. conventional free trade agreements. These countries will therefore have to fully open their markets to EU companies, which will reinforce situations of imbalance with countries and companies that do not have the same economic weight. They will be subject to strong competition in their agricultural market, losing their essential customs revenues... By doing so, the EU will jeopardise the development of these countries.  However, refusing to maintain this privileged access was temporary did not seem possible to me. I have therefore chosen to abstain pending a decision against the EPAs.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This temporary instrument provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in non-eastern ACP countries (LDCs) in the run-up to the conclusion and implementation of their World Trade Organisation (WTO) compatible economic partnership agreements (EPAs) before 1 October 2016. Annex I to the Market Access Regulation currently includes 27 countries. Assuming that these individual measures may have positive, albeit circumstantial, effects for acp countries, the proposal is part of the ePAs that have achieved more than the emphasis on existing inequalities, the serious effects of deregulation of trade, free movement of capital and investment, i.e. the deepening of the neoliberal model that has been imposed , particularly in countries with poorer economies.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting because, on the one hand, the current wave of migration can only be contained if people from underdeveloped countries are given improved income opportunities, but on the other hand this economic agreement is very one-sided and the quota-free access is very critical.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on the Economic Partnership Agreements for goods originating in certain countries belonging to the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) group of countries. The Commission's proposal relates to a codification and recasting of Regulation (EC) No 1528/2007, the so-called "market access regulation", which regulates the import of products in certain ACP countries. The resolution refers to simplifications of the existing legislation with regard to the ACP countries. The aim of codification is to simplify EU legislation, which I fully support. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution tabled because it is about simplifying the existing rules governing the entry of products from the developing countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific into the European Union market. I support the efforts of this Commission to improve European legislation in this area. At the same time, I am glad that the EU market will continue to allow duty-free imports of products from these countries, as this greatly helps to improve their economies.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation on products originating in certain countries of the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States, as the purpose of codification is to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification in EU legislation.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Walesa report on goods originating in certain ACP States, which provides for duty-free and quota-free access to the EU market for products originating in acp countries other than least developed countries (LDCs). I would like to support this exemption while economic partnership agreements are being negotiated in order to give some of the world's poorest countries uninterrupted access to the EU market.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the proposal for codification and recast of the Regulation on the application of the arrangements to goods originating in certain countries of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) set out in the agreements establishing or leading to the establishment of economic partnership agreements. This temporary instrument provides for access to the EU market free of duties and quotas for products originating in the ACP States before 1 October 2016. I believe that this instrument supports and maintains unsucesd regional integration, promotes sustainable development and contributes to overall efforts to eradicate poverty and improve living conditions in the ACP countries. The codification is also intended to ensure transparency, clarity and simplification of EU legislation.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against because we oppose this standard EU agreement structure.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft deplores the fact that the role of the European Parliament in the adoption of fisheries partnership agreements is reduced to a simple approval procedure; it is considered that the European Parliament should play a more active role and be immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedures concerning the PAs and their subsequent renewals, in order to increase the transparency of the protocols. Attention is also drawn to certain aspects that need to be improved. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval of the new protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution between Greenland and the EU. This new Protocol promotes a collaborative framework to develop, for the benefit of both sides, a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenland fishing area. It grants fishing opportunities to Union vessels in the Greenland fishing area, in accordance with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of available surpluses.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on an agreement that determines the fishing possibilities of EU vessels in Greenland in exchange for an amount of around EUR 18 million. I voted in favour of this agreement, which is beneficial to both sides, since the fishing quotas purchased by the European Union have been reduced and adapted to actual consumption in order to achieve budgetary savings.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this new Protocol which should strengthen the cooperation between the European Union and Greenland. Moreover, it aims to promote the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and a responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in Greenland’s fishing zone. It is a multi-species agreement that foresees fishing opportunities for various species. The report contained some very positive provisions such as an emphasis on sustainable fishing practices having to be promoted in order to safeguard long-term productivity. There was a specific focus on the collapse of cod stocks in previous years, which was much needed and welcomed. For these reasons, we voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This fishing agreement with Denmark allows European fishermen to work in Greenland waters. Quotas were previously higher than actual fishing; these are less ambitious, but adaptable and less expensive. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this agreement. I oppose the European Union claiming Member States waters and fishing opportunities as its own. The EU should not be allowed to have jurisdiction over Member States´ natural resources. This agreement gives Greenland €17.8 million for various tonnages of 10 species.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it strengthens cooperation between the European Union and Greenland, while promoting the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Greenland's Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ).

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland. The aim of the proposal is to strengthen cooperation between the Union and Greenland and to promote a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible use of fisheries resources in greenland's fishing zone, taking into account the interests of both parties.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because we oppose this standard EU agreement structure.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which regulates for five years the modalities of European fishing in Greenland in the sense of a budgetary saving and more favourable conditions for fishermen: quotas have been reduced in order to reduce the cost of the agreement, while the share of shipowners in the settlement of these quotas is revised upwards , and that quota regulations are relaxed to better adapt to the practical conditions of the fishery.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The new protocol negotiated between the EU, the Government of Denmark and the Greenland Autonomous Government setting fishing opportunities and the financial counterpart establishes a joint EU-Groenland commission to express the Union's position and monitor its implementation and proper implementation. The Commission would be empowered to approve amendments to the protocol after negotiation with Greenland.  I voted in favour of the conclusion of this protocol because I believe that fishing opportunities and financial consideration must be monitored with the utmost attention and that the position expressed on behalf of the Union can be reviewed as and when taking into account the latest relevant statistical and biological information so as not to interfere with the agreed agreements.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. Greenland, which joined the EC in 1973 with Denmark and then left in 1985 following a referendum, is now one of the overseas countries and territories (OCTs) of the Union, in accordance with Article 355(2) TFET. After a first fisheries partnership agreement signed in 1985, a second APP was initialled in 2006, which remained in force until 31 December 2015 to bring the renegotiation of the Protocol into line with the renewal and revision of other EU policy instruments, in particular the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), the Overseas Association Decision and the EU-Greenland Partnership Initiative.  I supported the Affronte report, on the new partnership agreement with Denmark and Greenland, because I am convinced of the possibilities offered by the new agreement, both in economic terms and will be the third most important in this area for the whole Union, and in terms of sustainability. The new protocol specifically provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 17.8 million per year, including a contribution for access to greenland's Exclusive Economic Zone and support for its sectoral fisheries policy.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the European Union in recent years, the European Union has signed a number of fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with 'third countries'. Through these agreements, the EU grants financial and technical assistance in exchange for fishing rights in relation to a wide range of stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. In this case, a specific fisheries collaboration agreement has been concluded with the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland, hereinafter 'the EU-Greenland Fisheries Partnership Agreement'.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his cooperation in the Committee on Fisheries in order to approve this Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland on fishing opportunities and financial compensation. After three rounds of negotiations, the Protocol to the Agreement has been renewed, covering a period of five years from 1 January 2016. The EU's financial contribution is estimated at 17.8 million. I welcome this new Agreement, which will be very important to the European fleet.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report which supports a balanced fisheries agreement between the European Union, Denmark and Greenland. We have a win-win agreement here, since the quotas bought by the EU have been reduced in order to reduce costs, but Greenland will receive EUR 17,799,978 per year for five years. This financial consideration includes access to the fishing area (EUR 13,168,978), assistance to fishing and local infrastructure (EUR 2,931,000) and the annual reserve for additional fishing opportunities in the event of excess resources (EUR 1,700,000). We therefore have an advantageous agreement which allows, among other things, to introduce additional species and quotas to the extent that stocks allow.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland has facilitated the activities of member states' fleets, and that is why I wanted to support the report with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. On 20 March 2015, the new Protocol resulting from the negotiation between the Commission and the Government of Denmark and that of Greenland was initialed. This new Protocol covers a period of five years and is in line with the objectives of the Partnership Agreement on Fisheries, granting fishing opportunities to Union vessels in the Greenland fishing area, in accordance with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of available surpluses. Cooperation between the Union and Greenland is strengthened and a collaborative framework is promoted to develop a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenland fishing area. This Protocol establishes an annual financial contribution of EUR 17 799 978 during its term, of which EUR 13 168 978 corresponds to access to the Greenland fishing area, EUR 2 931 000 to the additional endowment paid by the EU in support of Greenland's fisheries policy and EUR 1 700 000 to the reserve for additional new fishing opportunities that may be accepted by the EU , in reserve for scientific advice and surplus resources. I voted for it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fisheries is an important economic sector that requires responsible and sustainable policies. There are a number of fisheries partnership agreements signed by the European Union, whereby the EU undertakes to provide financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights in the exclusive economic zone of the State with which the agreement has signed. One of the most important agreements in this area is with the Government of Denmark and the local government of Greenland, the EU-Greenland APP. The new Protocol strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland, as a mixed agreement providing ACCESS to a wide range of fish stocks in the Greenland economic zone. The current protocol provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 17.85 million per year, which includes support for fisheries at administrative level, but also in terms of scientific development and research. I was in favour of this report because I believe that the new protocol has significant economic advantages for both parties, being an important pillar in the development of sustainable fisheries policies, also regulating responsible exploitation in the Greenland area.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. – The agreement with Greenland is the third most important for the EU in terms of its economic value. The ex-post and ex-ante evaluation of the current protocol, carried out on behalf of the European Commission in the first half of 2014 and published in July 2014, delivers some key findings on the effectiveness of the current protocol, even though, as the European Commission mentioned, it focused only on the first out of three years of implementation of the current protocol. The main conclusion of the report is that ‘it would be in the interest of both the EU and Greenland to renew the Protocol, the Protocol provides important economic benefits to both Parties, and helps ensure coherence with EU fishing activities elsewhere in the region.’  Generally speaking, the FPA objectives have been achieved. Important exceptions include: agreed quotas for offshore cod that are not consistent with ICES advice, though noting that data collected from the fishery will be used to refine management of the stock; limited supply of fish landings to Greenland; and the generation of limited employment in Greenland.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The new Protocol, which is in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the Union and Greenland, strengthens and promotes cooperation and a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy. Since the Protocol is based on the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources and the ecosystem in the Greenland region, which is heavily dependent on fisheries as its second most important industry, a stronger focus is in the interests of both Parties in the sustainable development of fisheries policy, the conservation of the ecosystem and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources. The Protocol itself still provides for a test fishing programme, for species not covered by the Protocol and scientific cooperation in the field of sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources, which is why I supported the agreement.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this Agreement, which serves to maintain fishing opportunities for EU vessels in the Greenland fishing zone and contributes to better management and conservation of fishing resources through sectoral support, in particular to monitor domestic and foreign fleets and combat illegal fishing.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This partnership agreement with Denmark and Greenland sets out the fishing possibilities of Greenland Union vessels.  Traditionally, Europe buys more quotas than it fishes. Quotas have been reduced to limit the cost of the agreement, which is advantageous for both parties, with the agreement also allowing for the introduction of additional cash and quotas if stocks permit. Therefore, I voted for it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the renewal of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland in the context of fisheries policy represents an important opportunity for all contracting parties to continue cooperation that has brought very positive results in all respects.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first fisheries agreement between the EU and Denmark/Greenland dates back to 1985 and was applied for a period of ten years with renewal periods of six years until its replacement by the FPA currently in force. The current FPA between the parties was initialled in June 2006, and applied for six years (from 1 January 2007 to 31 December 2012), with renewal periods of six years.  The previous Protocol was applied from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2015 for a period of three years; the duration has been shortened in order to align the renegotiation of the Protocol with the renewal/revision of other relevant EU policy instruments, namely the CFP, the Overseas Association Decision and the EU-Greenland Partnership Initiative.  After three rounds of negotiations, a new protocol was initialled on 20 March 2015. It extends over a period of five years from the date of its provisional application. This is a multi-species agreement, and the third most important agreement for the EU in terms of economic value.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on an agreement that determines the fishing possibilities of EU vessels in Greenland in exchange for an amount of around EUR 18 million.  This is an agreement that is advantageous to both parties as the fishing quotas purchased by the European Union have been reduced and adapted to actual consumption in order to achieve budgetary savings. That is why I voted for this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 An agreement that has allowed profitable fishing activity for EU fleets; Vote.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The new Protocol is in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement, strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland and promotes a collaborative framework to develop, for the benefit of both Parties, a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenland fishing area. It grants fishing opportunities to Union vessels in the Greenland fishing area, in accordance with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of available surpluses.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. This report is a recommendation on the Council's proposed decision on the conclusion of the protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial consideration provided for by the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Community, the Government of Denmark and the Greenland Autonomous Government. The protocol to the fisheries agreement between the European Union and the Greenland Autonomous Government has been renegotiated between the Council and Greenland for a period of 5 years. It is a multi-species agreement providing fishing opportunities for EU vessels licensed for the following species: cod, pelagic rockfish, deepfish, halibut, northern shrimp, capelin and grenadier. I voted in favour of this agreement, which respects the surplus rule and strengthens cooperation between the European Union and Greenland while promoting the sustainable development of fisheries and the sustainable exploitation of fishing resources in the Greenland fishing area.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this agreement today because it provides important economic benefits for both the EU and Greenland and helps to ensure consistency with EU fishing activities in other parts of the region. In terms of economic value, the greenland agreement is the third most important agreement for the EU. Under the agreement, European vessels have had access to important fishing opportunities in Greenland with various advantages both for the EU catch sector and in terms of employment. The new Protocol is in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement (APP), as it strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland. It promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in Greenland's fishing zone.  I regret, however, that Parliament's role in the adoption of the PAs is reduced to a simple approval procedure. I believe that Parliament must play a more active role and be immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedures concerning the PAs or their renewals, in order to increase the transparency and democratic accountability of the protocols.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this new Protocol which should strengthen the cooperation between the European Union and Greenland. Moreover, it aims to promote the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and a responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in Greenland’s fishing zone. It is a multi-species agreement that foresees fishing opportunities for various species. The report contained some very positive provisions such as an emphasis on sustainable fishing practices having to be promoted in order to safeguard long-term productivity. There was a specific focus on the collapse of cod stocks in previous years, which was much needed and welcomed. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ By voting in favour of this report I gave my consent to the conclusion of the agreement between the EU, the Government of Denmark and the Government of Greenland. Greater cooperation between the EU and Greenland will benefit both parties. Very importantly, it will ensure better compliance with the EU Common Fisheries Policies and the Fisheries Partnership Agreements.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur regrets that the Role of the European Parliament in the adoption of fisheries partnership agreements is limited to the approval procedure. This agreement is multispecies, covers a five-year period and provides for a total annual financial contribution of EUR 17 799 978 for the whole period. The rapporteur considers the protocol to be in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement and, I agree with him, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report considering that the new protocol is in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement and strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland.  It promotes a partnership framework within which sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fisheries resources can be developed in the Greenland fishing zone. This is in the interests of both parties.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted on the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol establishing fishing opportunities, as well as a financial and technical contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland in 1985. This project is not only about economic issues, but at the same time it is also a positive plan that will also affect environmental issues.  I believe that such actions have a positive impact on Europe's operation and production process, since in previous years there have been significant gains from this cooperation for the fisheries sector and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the many advantages that this agreement brings to both parties are clear. Virtually all of Greenland's exports of fish products go to the EU, which is the third most important agreement for the EU in terms of economic value.  Furthermore, the intention is to develop a sustainable fisheries policy with responsible exploitation of resources and to strengthen cooperation between the Union and Greenland. I could only vote in favour because this report is a fundamental economic engine for the European Union, based also on full respect for the sustainability of the resource.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Greenland, covered under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, is economically dependent on its fishery sector. The consequences of climate and environment issues must be recognised and fishing opportunities must conform to relevant conservation initiatives. This Protocol aims to provide EUR 17 799 978 per year over a five-year period. This would foster cooperation between the European Union and Greenland, ensuring a sustainable fisheries policy. This agreement covers a range of marine species. The use of local labour and firms should be a condition for the provision of fishing licences.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against because we oppose this standard EU agreement structure.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the new protocol complies with the partnership objectives in the fisheries sector, as it strengthens cooperation between the European Union and Greenland and Denmark, in the interests of all the actors involved and in line with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of the available surplus.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU gives financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights to a wide range of fish stocks in the partner country’s exclusive economic zone. Greenland is one of these partners within the framework towards developing a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in line with relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of the available surplus. The renewal of these agreements is in the interests of both the EU and Greenland to ensure fulfilment of Protocol obligations. I support the benefits aimed at sustaining fish stocks and resolving some ongoing operational difficulties based on reliable scientific evidence.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval of the new protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution between Greenland and the EU. This new Protocol promotes a collaborative framework to develop, for the benefit of both sides, a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenland fishing area. It grants fishing opportunities to Union vessels in the Greenland fishing area, in accordance with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of available surpluses.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Protocol is in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement, thereby strengthening cooperation between the European Union and Greenland. I voted for an extension of the existing agreement for a period of 5 years, during which the annual financial contribution reaches a total of around EUR 18 million. Provisions are also provided for an experimental fishing programme for species not included in the Protocol, as well as scientific cooperation in the field of sustainable exploitation of fishery resources.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Fisheries Agreement on fisheries between Denmark and Greenland opens up access for EU vessels to mixed fishing in Greenland waters (the most commonly fished species are northern shrimp, halibut, cod and red fish). The Agreement with Greenland is the third most important for the EU in terms of economic value. In 2013, the agreement generated €10 million in direct profits for the EU fishing sector.  In view of the above, I voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the renewal of this agreement is in the interest of the European Union, because the economic advantages are on the side of both sides and are in line with the objectives of the CFP.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report concerns the new protocol between the Danish government and the Greenland Autonomous Government. It strengthens cooperation between the EU and Greenland and promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Greenland fishing area.  Considering that Greenland's marine resources can be a real asset for the European Union in terms of sustainable consumption, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the conclusion of the protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and the financial consideration provided for in the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Community on the one hand and the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland on the other. This protocol promotes cooperation between the European Union and Greenland and allows the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Greenland fishing area.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's agreement on the protocol.  30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced.  Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.  Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the agreements with Denmark and Greenland, which is its constituent country, Europe usually buys more quotas than it actually fishes. Through this text, they have been readjusted in order to reduce the cost of the agreement for Europe but also for Greenland and Denmark. Indeed, this 5-year agreement allows for the introduction of additional species and quotas, if stocks permit.  Since the financial counterparties are almost 17.8 million euros per year for 5 years, the revaluation of these is not negligible, so I voted for the text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the signing of the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial resources provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, of the one part, and the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland, of the other part, because the agreement is very important from an economic point of view for the EU.  The agreement with Greenland is the third most important for the EU in terms of economic value – it gives European vessels access to a wide range of fish stocks in the Greenland exclusive economic zone, while ordering EU financial assistance of €17.8 million a year for five years. Thus, the report guarantees financial benefit for both parties, as well as consistency of fishing activities in the EU.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's agreement on the protocol. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. In recent years, the European Union has signed a number of fisheries cooperation agreements and protocols with third countries. Agreements where the EU provides financial aid and technical support for fishing rights for a large population of species in the exclusive economic zone of those countries. Denmark and Greenland are from the two countries with specific agreements. The new protocol includes a financial contribution of EUR 17.8 million divided by access to the Greenland EZE of EUR 13.17 million and a specific support of EUR 2.931 million to help the country's fisheries policy and will increase the quantity of some fish species.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: this agreement allows for the introduction of additional species and quotas if stocks permit.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report focuses on the new Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, on the one hand, and the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland, on the other. This agreement provides eu member states' fleets with access to a wide range of fish stocks in Greenland's Exclusive Economic Zone. This agreement, which already has a long history, is the third most important for the EU in terms of its economic value, considering the rapporteur that the benefits for both parties have been significant. It is stated, however, that indirect benefits for Greenland have been limited (e.g. in terms of job creation and intervention of local ports in the fishing product cycle) – a fact which, once again, runs counter to the expressed objectives of the so-called "partnership" agreements. The new Protocol provides for a slight reduction in EU contributions to the existing protocol. This reduction, however, reflects the reduction in fishing quotas and is not considered to be significant. On the other hand, there is an increase in the part for sectoral cooperation. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the partnership agreement, which is the subject of the report because of the importance that access to mixed fishing in Greenland waters represents for EU vessels, both in terms of differentiation of species caught and from the point of view of economic value.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour. Overall positive.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the new Fisheries Partnership Agreement in question with Denmark and Greenland, the total financial contribution will be EUR 17 799 978 per year during its period of validity. The Protocol in question aims to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Greenland. The Protocol serves to maintain fishing opportunities for European Union vessels in greenland's fishing area and contributes to better management and conservation of fishery resources by supporting the sector, in particular as regards monitoring domestic and foreign fleets and combating illegal fishing, while also helping to develop local fisheries sectors, including the promotion of local employment, which is in line with the common fisheries policy.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the agreement allowing profitable fishing activities for EU fleets.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against report A8-0067/2016 as I disagree with Greenland's financial support in any form, as EU funds and European taxpayers' money cannot be driven to third countries. If the EU wants to work with the local government of Greenland it must find a way that does not harm European citizens.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The new Protocol is considered to be in line with the objectives of the CFP, to respect the principle of available surplus and the obligation to follow scientific advice. It strengthens cooperation between the EU and Greenland and promotes a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources, including through financial support (sectoral support) for the implementation of programmes, in particular for enhanced monitoring and combating of illegal fishing, as well as the support of the local fisheries sector, including the generation of local employment opportunities. The new Protocol ensures improved value for money for the EU by aligning the level of fishing opportunities with the effective level of utilisation; it provides for at least one annual meeting of the Joint Committee, at which the Commission and Greenland review the implementation of the FPA/Protocol, and, if necessary, adjust the programming of sectoral support/financial contribution. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's agreement on the protocol.  30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced.  Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.  Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I stand by the recommendation and agree with the conclusion of the new Protocol. Fisheries Partnership Agreements are a good means of expanding the EU's financial and technical support system and are the third most important eu agreement in terms of the economic value of the agreement with Greenland. The new Protocol strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland and helps to establish a partnership framework in which a sustainable fisheries policy can be developed by exploiting fishery resources within the Greenland fishing zone. This is in the interests of both parties.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation. We must keep in mind that, in recent years, the EU has signed a number of fisheries collaboration agreements and protocols with 'third countries', granting financial and technical assistance in exchange for fishing rights in the exclusive economic zone of the partner country. The current Protocol provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 17.85 million per year. The renewal of the Protocol will be in the interests of both the EU and Greenland.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland: fishing opportunities and financial compensation', as I, as a representative of the coastal region of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, warmly welcome the promotion of sustainable, highly medium-sized fisheries and cannot end biodiversity management in the sea at the EU's external borders.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. As a member of the Committee on Fisheries, I support the agreement. Greenland, and Denmark in particular, are important partners also in relation to the forthcoming North Sea plan. I believe that the sustainable unification of the rules on fisheries and responsible coordination with surrounding countries in the water zones are urgently needed.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Protocol which maintains fishing opportunities for EU vessels in Greenland’s Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). It will contribute to better management and conservation of fish stocks.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The fishing industry is an important one for the UK and for the South West; agreements like this which help to improve productivity in this sector are very welcome. This agreement will allow British fishing boats to access Greenland’s waters and access species such as northern prawns, Greenland halibut, cod and red fish. It represents the third most important partnership agreement for the European Union in terms of economic value. The previous agreement from 2013 generated EUR 10 million in direct value-added to the EU’s catching sector, so continuing the agreement will no doubt be economically beneficial. This is an excellent example of how agreements made at the EU level are directly benefitting fishermen in the UK and I was pleased to vote in favour alongside my British Conservative and ECR group colleagues.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This 5-year agreement sets out the fishing possibilities of EU vessels in Greenland, the autonomous government of Denmark. This type of agreement has been in place since 1985. The financial counterparties are as follows: the European Union will pay around 17.8 million euros per year, including 13.1 million euros for the right of access to the Greenland fishing area, nearly 3 million euros for sectoral policy and 1.7 million euros for additional fishing opportunities. The new agreement includes positive developments: on the one hand, the contributions of shipowners increase by 40-50%; on the other hand, quotas have been reduced to reduce the cost of the agreement. Indeed, the European Union traditionally bought more quotas than it fished.  Finally, the agreement also allows for the introduction of additional species and quotas if stocks permit. So it's an agreement that benefits both sides.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the European Union in recent years, the European Union has signed a number of fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with 'third countries'. Through these agreements, the EU grants financial and technical assistance in exchange for fishing rights in relation to a wide range of stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. In this case, a specific fisheries collaboration agreement has been concluded with the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland, hereinafter 'the EU-Greenland Fisheries Partnership Agreement'.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Protocol, it is the third most important Fisheries Partner Agreement for the EU in terms of its economic value and it helps ensure coherence with EU fishing activities elsewhere in the region.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the fisheries partnership agreement with Denmark and Greenland. It strengthens cooperation between the EU and two countries as well as promoting a partnership framework in which to develop a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenlandic fishing zone.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's agreement on the protocol.  30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced.  Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming and, in particular, to freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.  Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and marine aquaculture.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is essentially a renewal of the Protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the two parties, Denmark and Greenland. The new Protocol, which expired on 31 December 2015, is in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement, strengthens cooperation between the EU and Greenland and promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the continuation of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community on the one hand and the Government of Denmark and the Home Rule Government of Greenland on the other as it strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland. It also promotes a partnership framework in which to develop a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenlandic fishing zone. This is in the interest of both parties, in line with relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of the available surplus. Likewise, this agreement allows the Irish fishing industry to exploit and fish within Greenland’s fishing zone. In a Commission study on the agreement, it concluded that: ‘it would be in the interest of both the EU and Greenland to renew the Protocol, the Protocol provides important economic benefits to both Parties, and helps ensure coherence with EU fishing activities elsewhere in the region’. However, it is also important to note that whilst the overall objectives may be coherent, EU fisheries in the FPA have targeted stocks that are overexploited and/or contributed to catches that exceed precautionary advice. This aspect of the deal along with better data on fishing stocks needs to be taken into consideration by the Council.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of renewing the protocol as it benefits both the EU and Greenland while also benefiting the consistency of fishing activities elsewhere in the region.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's agreement on the protocol.  30 % of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.  Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Fisheries resources are important to both Greenland and the EU and this annual agreement is hugely beneficial to both parties.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In recent years the European Union has signed a series of fisheries partnership agreements. I have voted in favour of the most recent fisheries partnership agreement that covers a period of five years and provides an annual financial contribution of EUR 17 799 987 per year to Greenland in exchange for fishing rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, on the one hand, and the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland, on the other, as this gives consent for the conclusion of the agreement. With this agreement, the European Union provides financial and technical assistance to Greenland, representing the Union's third most important economic value agreement.  On the other hand, fishing rights in Greenland's exclusive economic zone contribute significantly to the EU economy and are in line with the Common Fisheries Policy. I fully support the proposal for a new Agreement for a period of five years which will surely ensure mutual benefit, but it should take into account the conservation of marine biodiversity and ensure that the activities to be implemented are sustainable and environmentally friendly.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text refers to a five-year agreement that sets out the fishing possibilities of EU vessels in Greenland, Denmark's autonomous government. The agreements with Denmark and Greenland have been in place since 1985. Europe traditionally buys more quotas than it fishes. This time, quotas were reduced to reduce the cost of the agreement.  This agreement benefits both parties and allows, among other things, to introduce additional species and quotas if stocks permit. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against because we oppose this standard EU agreement structure.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Marco Affronte's report on the fisheries partnership agreement with Denmark and Greenland. This new protocol strengthens cooperation between the EU and Greenland, enables the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of marine resources in the Greenland fishing area. I have therefore approved this proposal, which is as much in the interest of the Union as it is in Greenland's interest, since it implies significant economic gains on the one hand, and helps to ensure consistency with the Union's fishing activities elsewhere in the region on the other. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The report calls for the renewal of the protocol between the EU, Denmark and Greenland on fisheries agreements. It is in Europe's interest to renew this protocol with Greenland, which grants it, in exchange for technical and financial assistance, a right to fish in the EEZ of the island. That is why I voted for it.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of renewing the Protocol, as the Protocol provides important economic benefits to both parties and helps ensure coherence with EU fishing activities elsewhere in the region.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's agreement on the protocol.  30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced.  Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.  Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the fisheries partnership agreement with Denmark and Greenland. It is a 5-year agreement that sets out the fishing possibilities of European Union vessels in Greenland, Denmark's autonomous government. The financial counterparties are 17,799,978 euros per year for 5 years. The EU traditionally buys more quotas than it fishes. This time, quotas were reduced to reduce the cost of the agreement.  This agreement is beneficial to both parties. In particular, it allows for the introduction of additional species and quotas if stocks permit.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this fisheries agreement with Denmark and Greenland because it reasonably and respectfully increases the possibilities for stock renewal, the volume of fish that EU vessels can fish in their waters.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to conclude a five-year agreement between the European Union and Greenland, Denmark's autonomous region, in the context of fisheries.  In exchange for financial consideration, for Greenland's sectoral policy, the annual reserve for additional fishing opportunities and access to the fishing area, the European Union will have permission to fish in this maritime area. Contrary to its custom, it has reduced the amount of quotas purchased to reduce the cost of the agreement. In addition, the agreement promises to provide additional cash and quotas depending on the possibility of stocks. So I spoke for this text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval of the new protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution between Greenland and the EU. This new Protocol promotes a collaborative framework to develop, for the benefit of both sides, a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenland fishing area. It grants fishing opportunities to Union vessels in the Greenland fishing area, in accordance with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of available surpluses.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This recommendation gives the green light to the signing of the fisheries agreement which the European Union has long been negotiating with the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland.  Since 1985 we have signed successive agreements between the EU and the Danish and Greenlandish governments, which have proved extremely beneficial to both sides and in which the commitments and agreements established have been respected - while there is always some aspect to be improved. As for the economic magnitudes, it should be noted that this agreement is the third most important for the EU. According to the analyses that have been made of the implementation of the previous agreements, the impact on the EU fisheries sector, as well as for our production and processing industries, have been hugely positive.  Moreover, from the point of view of environmental care, these agreements ultimately seek to ensure that the European Union develops a sustainable fisheries policy and, to this end, thanks to European financial contributions, the Greenland government is improving the administration, conservation and control of its fisheries and also investing in scientific research.  From the foregoing, my vote will be in favour of this recommendation.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the principle that the EU should pay EUR 17.8 million a year to Greenland for the right to fish in its waters in 2016-2020. I do not agree in general with the principle that the EU buys the governments of poor countries at the expense of the economic development of these countries.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The first fisheries partnerships between the EU, Greenland and Denmark date back to 1985, when the first contract was signed for a period of ten years and extended for another six years at the end. Most of Greenland's fish exports are destined for the European Union market, while Denmark exports more than 90% to the Union market.  The Agreement with Greenland is of utmost importance to the EU for economic growth, as it is the third largest economic agreement. Restoring the Fisheries Partnership Agreement provides additional economic benefits, so I supported the report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Similarly to Iceland or the Faeroe Islands, Greenland's primary economic sector, as well as export commodity, are fisheries and fish respectively, which account for around 90 % of all exported goods, of which around 90 % goes to Denmark. In recent years, the Union has signed a number of fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with third countries. Within them, the EU provides financial and technical support in exchange for the right to fish in partner countries' exclusive economic zone. As Greenland is contractually part of the Kingdom of Denmark and fishing in its territorial waters is in the administration of Nuuca, and outside them Copenhagen, it was necessary to conclude an agreement with both parties. The initial fisheries agreement was signed in 1985, which was subsequently extended several times and finally replaced by a fisheries partnership agreement. The aim of this protocol is therefore to strengthen existing cooperation, since it is the third most important EU agreement in the context of economic value, in the scale of its action. Given the mutual benefits to the parties involved, it was, of course, logical to vote in favour. It would be important, however, to note that in future the agreement should pay more attention to the sustainability of fisheries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, of the one part, and the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland, on the other, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This agreement renews, for five years, the agreements already signed with Denmark and Greenland since 1985. Better negotiated, this time includes fishing quotas closer to practice for the European Union, which thus achieves a substantial saving. It also introduces additional species and quotas, which can be adjusted according to stocks.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal. The main conclusion of a study into the existing agreement is that ‘it would be in the interest of both the EU and Greenland to renew the Protocol, the Protocol provides important economic benefits to both Parties, and helps ensure coherence with EU fishing activities elsewhere in the region’.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland; Fishing opportunities and financial compensation see me in favour. This is a particularly developed sector, considering that fish account for almost 90% of exported products, just think that in 2011 1 238 were full-time engaged fishermen. This agreement allows EU vessels access to a wide range of fish stocks. The current Protocol provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 17 850 000 per year. The EU provides a fixed annual financial compensation for access, regardless of the fishing opportunities agreed under the Protocol. If the agreed fishing opportunities are less than the indicative fishing opportunities outlined in the Protocol, the Protocol allows Greenland either to offer the EU equivalent alternative fishing opportunities for the year in question, or to compensate the EU in the following year.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
