text: in writing. The EU's fisheries agreement with Greenland is the third most important in terms of its economic value.  I agree with the rapporteur that the new Protocol strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland. It promotes an partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenland fishing area. This is in the interests of both parties, in line with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the framework of the limits of available surpluses.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report that will continue the EU’s important Fisheries Partnership with Greenland and ensure proper management of fish stocks.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Almost all of Greenland's exports of fisheries products go to the European Union. In addition, due to the limited supply of fish landings in Greenland and the low capacity for job creation, a fishing agreement has been under way between the EU and Greenland since 1985. The report proposes to approve the continuation of this agreement which provides access to a wide range of fish stocks in the Greenland EEZ.  This system is being applied all over the world and I condemn it. The more favourable conditions of it do not make me change my mind. This productivist logic must stop. The protocol provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 17.85 million per year, of which EUR 2.74 million is provided to support Greenland's sectoral fisheries policy. Quotas for fish to be harvested are scientifically established and are intended to promote sustainable fishing.  I'm voting against this deal.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text, which allows EU vessels to fish in the maritime areas of Denmark and Greenland, is to some extent beneficial to both sides. Fishing quotas were reduced in order to lower the cost of the agreement since the EU did not fish to the extent of the quotas it bought. As a result, I voted for this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have voted in favour of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland: fishing opportunities and financial consideration. Access of the EU Member States' fleet to the Greenland EZE is vital for the EU fisheries sector. The Partnership Agreement with Greenland is, in economic terms, the third most important for the EU. This agreement strengthens cooperation between the European Union and Greenland with a view to the responsible and sustainable exploitation of Greenland's fishing resources. The economic importance for both parties is very relevant.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this agreement as it leads to more sustainable and realistic fishing practices and gives European fisheries access to Greenland’s waters, whilst also developing and increasing local employment opportunities in Greenland.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the conclusion of the Protocol to the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and Greenland. The continuation of this fisheries agreement, which is particularly important for both sides, will contribute to the strengthening of cooperation on sustainable fisheries.  To this end, this agreement - along with all other fisheries partnership agreements - must be perfectly in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy and in particular with its principle of precautionary and responsible exploitation of the resources of the sea. The Union is a key player in fisheries and therefore has a duty to promote, particularly through the fisheries agreements it concludes, sustainable management of the world's fisheries resources.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Greenland, with full self-government and its own government since 1978, is one of the EU's overseas territories, an adjustment to the relationship with which it is generally contained, in particular, in a partnership agreement approved by the Council in 2006. Greenland's natural wealth lies in adjacent seas, so the country concentrates almost all its economic activity on the fishing area. In this context, relations with continental Europe are crucial – almost all exports go to EU Member States, with Denmark's imports representing more than 90% for the Union. These relations are governed by the Fisheries Partnership Agreement, which gives EU vessels access to fish stocks in Greenland's exclusive economic zone, for which the Union pays annual financial compensation of EUR 15.1 million, as well as a specific amount of EUR 2.74 million for support to the fisheries sector in Greenland. As regards the proposal for a new protocol setting out fishing opportunities and a financial contribution, I see it as ensuring continuity in strengthening cooperation between the EU and Greenland and promoting partnership in order to develop a fisheries policy and the recovery of fish from Greenlandic waters. I also see as a positive of this protocol the inclusion of provisions and the protection of natural resources and the effective management of fisheries policy. I am therefore voting in favour of the recommendation on the proposal as it stands.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on a fisheries partnership agreement with Denmark and Greenland: fishing opportunities and financial contribution. The Protocol serves to maintain fishing opportunities for EU vessels in the Greenlandic fishing zone and contributes to better management and conservation of fishery resources through sectoral support, in particular for the monitoring of domestic and foreign fleets and combating illegal fishing, as well as helping the development of the local fisheries sector, including the support of local employment. It is in line with the objectives of the CFP, respects the principle of available surplus and the obligation to follow scientific advice. Regular reviewing ensures that the FPA/Protocol is implemented as intended and provides improved value for money.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has a specific Fisheries Partnership Agreement with the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland (hereinafter referred to as the EU-Greenland Fisheries Partnership Agreement). The Agreement entered into force on 1 January 2007 and is currently in force until 31 December 2018 and provides EU vessels with access to a wide range of fish stocks in Greenland's exclusive economic zone. The Protocol to the original Fisheries Partnership Agreement was in force from 1 January 2007 to 31 December 2012 and was replaced by a Protocol concluded from 1 January to 31 December 2015 for a period of three years.  The Commission received a mandate from the Council on 25 September 2014 and held negotiations with the Government of Greenland and representatives of the Government of Denmark with a view to renewing the Protocol. The new Protocol was corked on 20 March 2015 and the proposal for the renewal of the Protocol was adopted on 16 July 2015. The Council submitted a draft decision on the conclusion of the new Protocol. In its report, the Committee on Fisheries recommends that Parliament agree with the Council's draft. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement sets out the fishing possibilities of EU vessels in Greenland, the autonomous government of Denmark. The agreements with Denmark and Greenland have been in place since 1985.  It is beneficial for both parties. In particular, this agreement allows for the introduction of additional species and quotas if stocks permit.  It can therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The initial agreement on fishing activity between the European Union, Denmark and Greenland dates back to 1985. Virtually all greenland fish catch is exported to the European Union, and this Partnership Agreement with Greenland is the third most important for the EU in economic terms. The fisheries partnership agreement aims to strengthen cooperation between the Union and Greenland, promote a collaborative framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of resources in the Greenland fishing area.  I advocate the renewal of the Agreement, given the economic importance for both parties and the benefits of EU fisheries activity in the region.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of a protocol setting out fishing opportunities and financial consideration in the fisheries partnership agreement with Denmark and Greenland. This text strengthens cooperation between the European Union on the one hand and Greenland and Denmark, on the other, and promotes better management of the food resources brought by fisheries.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Face report on the partnership agreement. The initial fisheries agreement between the European Union, on the one hand, and the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland, on the other, dates back to 1985. This agreement ran for ten years and was then extended for an additional six years until it was finally replaced by the APA that is currently in force. Greenland's most important fisheries are the trawling of northern shrimp, Greenland halibut, cod and redfish. Fish accounts for almost 90% of exports.  Almost all of Greenland's exports of fisheries products go to the European Union, with Denmark accounting for more than 90% of EU imports. Frozen shrimp, Greenland halibut and cod are the most important exports. The European Union pays fixed annual financial compensation for access, regardless of the fishing opportunities provided in the protocol. The current protocol provides for a financial consideration of 17.85 million euros per year. The agreement with Greenland is the third agreement in order of economic importance for the Union.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The fisheries agreement between the European Union, on the one hand, and Denmark and Greenland, on the other, is the third agreement in order of economic importance for the Union. Given the economic stakes for all parties, but also the importance of achieving a sustainable and responsible fisheries policy, which the work of the European Commission must allow, the renewal of the protocol addresses all the challenges. So I voted in favour of renewal.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, the European Union has signed a series of fisheries partnership agreements (APP) and protocols with 'third countries'. Through the partnership agreements, the European Union provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights in relation to a wide range of fish resources in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. I voted in favour of the agreement with Greenland, a country which, in terms of economic value, is the third most important country in the EU.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Fisheries Agreement between the European Union and Denmark and Greenland goes back many years. We are talking about a partnership agreement in the fisheries sector that will bring significant benefits to both sides. In terms of its economic value, we are talking about the third most important agreement of the European Union, which provides significant added value to the EU fisheries sector year after year. For this reason, I see no impediment to a further extension of the agreement that has become traditional.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Several Fisheries Partnership Agreements have been signed by the EU in recent years. These sustainable fisheries agreements with non-EU countries are negotiated and concluded by the Commission on behalf of the EU. I voted for this report that will provide a financial contribution of EUR 17.8 m each year from the EU to Greenland in exchange for fishing rights.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Greenland Agreement is the third most important agreement for the EU in terms of economic value. It is in the eu's and Greenland's interest to renew the Protocol, providing important economic benefits to both parties and helping to ensure consistency with EU fishing activities in other areas of the region. In July 2015, the European Commission adopted proposals to renew the Protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, of the one part, and the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland, of the other part. The new protocol provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 17.8 million per year. This amount shall be: (a) more than EUR 13 million per year for access to the Greenland fishing zone; (b) EUR 2,9 million per year, corresponding to the additional package mobilised by the EU to support Greenland's fisheries policy, and (c) EUR 1,7 million as an annual reserve for additional and new fishing opportunities that can be accepted by the EU subject to scientific advice and surplus resources. This Protocol is also of strategic importance for the activities of Union vessels in fishing areas of other important bilateral partners in the North-East Atlantic, in particular Norway and the Faroe Islands.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the renewal of the fisheries protocol between the EU and the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland, because it unequivocally supports the conclusion of the protocol. This new protocol is in line with the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and is a fair and necessary one for both parties. The Protocol provides for access to Greenland's fish resources for vessels flying the flag of an EU Member State, and the EU undertakes to pay EUR 17.85 million per year for fishing opportunities over a period of five years. The previous Protocol with the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland generated a direct and indirect added value of around EUR 1,6 for every EUR 1 invested by the EU. In this respect, I believe that this protocol must be supported and that it should be re-repeated in other situations.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because a fisheries partnership agreement with Denmark and Greenland provides fishermen with EUR 17.8 million in support.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I welcome the conclusion of this Protocol on a special fisheries partnership agreement with the Danish Government and the Local Government of Greenland. It should be noted that this agreement is of economic benefit to both parties. It will also strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Greenland. EU vessels will be granted access to a wide range of fish stocks in Greenland's exclusive economic zone, while Greenland's fisheries policy will receive financial support. In addition, a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible use of fisheries resources will be developed in Greenland's fishing zone.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because we oppose this standard EU agreement structure.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the European Parliament approves the conclusion of the new protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and Greenland; that the APP between the parties has been in force since 2006 and has been renewed several times; that, according to the Commission's analysis, the renewal of the Protocol would bring further benefits to both the EU and Greenland, allowing the former to fish in Greenland and the latter to have a significant financial counterpart as well as generating employment in the sector; that, in the event of a fishing opportunity lower than laid down in the Protocol, Greenland is obliged to return to the EU part of the amount received against the permit granted; that the new protocol should increase the benefits in terms of the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks and overcome the difficulties encountered so far, I thought it appropriate to vote in a positive way.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the rapporteur's request for the European Parliament to approve the EU-Greenland fishing partnership protocol. I agree that the new protocol should be in line with the objectives of the Fishermen's Partnership Agreement, which will contribute to better cooperation between the Union and Greenland. A sustainable fishing policy and responsible exploitation of fishing riches should be a priority, as it is a common interest.  I express concern that as part of the fishing agreement, it is easumed for EU crews to already fish stocks that are above pre-strict scientific recommendations. They should not go beyond the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy, scientific recommendations by NAFO and ICES, as well as the objectives of fishing partner agreements. I welcome the initiative that the following protocol serves to increase financial interests in terms of sustainable exploitation of fish stocks. I also support better monitoring of scientific recommendations, as without such recommendations we cannot talk about sustainable fisheries that are of particular interest to the EU, especially because the EU is a leader in sustainable fisheries policy.  Increasing control and harmonization of financial compensations based on ex ante assessments is a goal that we need to aim for unequivocally and as efficiently as possible. Finally, I agree that the European Parliament needs to play a more significant role in approving fishing partner agreements with a view to better transparency and transparency of protocols.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Europe traditionally buys more quotas than it fishes. This time, quotas were reduced to reduce the cost of the agreement. The contributions of shipowners increase by 40-50%. The agreement also allows for the introduction of additional species and quotas if stocks permit. Because of these positive points, I am voting in favour of the text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Greenland is one of 26 overseas countries and territories covered by Part IV. treaty on the functioning of the European Union. Its economy is largely dependent on the fisheries sector, greenland's second largest economic sector. The new protocol, covering the five-year period from the date of its signature, provides for an annual financial contribution of EUR 17 799 978.  The Protocol should strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Greenland and promote the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible use of fishing resources in greenland's fishing zone. The agreement concerns several species and provides for fishing opportunities for cod, pelagic grouper, adjectious grouper, a large leaf (plate), a northern prawn, a chaplain and a grenadier. For all of the above, I welcome the signing of the agreement.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report focuses on the new Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, on the one hand, and the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland, on the other. This agreement provides eu member states' fleets with access to a wide range of fish stocks in Greenland's Exclusive Economic Zone. This agreement, which already has a long history, is the third most important for the EU in terms of its economic value, considering the rapporteur that the benefits for both parties have been significant. It is stated, however, that indirect benefits for Greenland have been limited (e.g. in terms of job creation and intervention of local ports in the fishing product cycle) – a fact which, once again, runs counter to the expressed objectives of the so-called partnership agreements. The new Protocol provides for a slight reduction in EU contributions to the existing protocol. This reduction, however, reflects the reduction in fishing quotas and is not considered to be significant. On the other hand, there is an increase in the part for sectoral cooperation. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report by a colleague of Affronte's. In my view, it is in the interest of both the European Union and Greenland to renew the Protocol, which provides important economic benefits to both parties and helps ensure coherence between the European Union's fisheries activities elsewhere in the region. This will also strengthen cooperation with Greenland and develop a sustainable fisheries policy as well as responsible use of fishing resources in the Greenland fishing zone. I consider it important to support the Protocol, as it is the third most important agreement for the EU according to economic value.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Greenland Agreement is the third most important agreement for the EU in terms of economic value. I therefore very much welcome the adoption of the proposal to extend the duration of the protocol relating to this agreement, which has so far brought considerable benefits to the EU. Not only has it significantly expanded fishing opportunities for EU citizens, but has also created new full-time jobs. I am convinced that this protocol has brought and will bring further benefits for both parties in the future.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 16 July 2015, with a view to the expiry of the previous Protocol, the Commission adopted proposals for the renewal of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland.  The new protocol provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 17.8 million per year. It also promotes a favourable partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and for the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in Greenland's fishing zone. In terms of economic value, the Partnership Agreement with Greenland is the third most important agreement for the EU.  I believe that the content of this partnership agreement is in the interests of both parties. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the protocol to the fisheries agreement between the EU, Denmark and Greenland.  The five-year text is in line with the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy and promotes a partnership between the EU and Greenland that will enable sustainable and responsible fishing. Also, European vessels with adequate licences will have the opportunity to fish certain species in the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) concerned and the surplus clause will be preserved by this new agreement.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because we oppose this standard EU agreement structure.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. In recent years, the EU has signed a number of fisheries agreements and protocols with third countries, providing technical and financial support in exchange for fishing rights for a wide range of fish stocks in the exclusive economic zone of partner countries. This report relates to the agreement with the Government of Denmark and the Government of Greenland, now called eu/greenland FPA and which began to be drawn up in 1985. It is a mixed agreement that allows the EU access to a wide range of fisheries resources in Greenland's Exclusive Economic Zone. I welcome the vote in favour of this report of great interest to both the EU and Greenland, as it provides important economic benefits and helps to ensure consistency with EU fishing activities elsewhere in the region.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Extension of the fisheries agreement (5 years from March 2015). It is a multi-species agreement and the third most important for the EU in terms of economic value. The new Protocol provides for a financial contribution of EUR 17,799,978 per year. It promotes a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of resources, combating illegal fishing and supporting the local fisheries sector.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. On 20 March 2015, the new Protocol resulting from the negotiation between the Commission and the Government of Denmark and that of Greenland was initialed. This new Protocol covers a period of five years and is in line with the objectives of the Partnership Agreement on Fisheries, granting fishing opportunities to Union vessels in the Greenland fishing area, in accordance with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of available surpluses. Cooperation between the Union and Greenland is strengthened and a collaborative framework is promoted to develop a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenland fishing area.  This Protocol establishes an annual financial contribution of EUR 17,799,978 during its term, of which EUR 13,168,978 for access to the Greenland fishing area, 2,931,000 euros of additional endowment paid by the EU in support of Greenland's fisheries policy and EUR 1,700,000 as a reserve for additional new fishing opportunities that may be accepted by the EU , in reserve for scientific advice and surplus resources. I voted for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The initial fisheries agreement between the European Union and the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland dates back to 1985. This agreement was extended at length until it was finally replaced by the APA that is currently in force. Almost all of Greenland's exports of fisheries products go to the European Union; Denmark accounts for more than 90% of EU imports.  The European Union pays fixed annual financial compensation for access, regardless of the fishing opportunities provided in the protocol. The current protocol provides for a financial consideration of 17.85 million euros per year. The agreement with Greenland is the third agreement in order of economic importance for the Union. The new protocol between the Government of Denmark and the Greenland Autonomous Government is in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement: it strengthens cooperation between the EU and Greenland. It also fosters a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Greenland fishing area. This is in the interest of both parties, in accordance with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of the available surplus.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because this recommendation deals with substantive issues. One is the aim of protecting the highly sensitive and vulnerable Flora and Fauna of the Arctic. This can be achieved through sustainable resource use and conservation measures. Another important aspect is the annual amount of the financial contribution of EUR 17,799.978 provided for in the Protocol, which will be allocated over the entire period of validity of the Protocol, i.e. five years. This will ensure access for EU vessels to the fish market in the Greenland Free Economic Zone.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation aims to adopt the Protocol on fishing opportunities between the European Union and the Government of Denmark and the local government of Greenland, as the initial fisheries agreement dates back to 1985. The agreement with Greenland is the third most important for the Union in terms of economic value. Around 90% of the products exported by Greenland come from fishery products, with almost the vast majority destined for the European Union.  This new Fisheries Partnership Protocol, with the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland, aims not only to strengthen existing cooperation between the EU and Greenland, but also to promote a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the fishing area. These are objectives in which both sides share a clear interest as the renewal of this Protocol provides for important economic benefits for both, which is why I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this approval of the fisheries partnership agreement with Denmark and Greenland. The initial agreement between the EU, Denmark and the Greenland Autonomous Government dates back to 1985. This is the adoption of the protocol setting out fishing opportunities and financial consideration. Fishing products account for almost 90% of Greenland's exports, almost all of which go to Denmark. The EU provides annual financial compensation for access to these products, taking into account the special relationship between Denmark and Greenland. I supported this report because it calls, however, for the establishment of a sustainable fishery for certain fish stocks, greater attention to scientific advice and enhanced control, as well as an adaptation of the Union's financial counterpart to the post-assessment of the fishing possibilities provided for in the protocol.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the European Union in recent years, the European Union has signed a number of fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with 'third countries'. Through these agreements, the EU grants financial and technical assistance in exchange for fishing rights in relation to a wide range of stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. In this case, a specific fisheries collaboration agreement has been concluded with the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland, hereinafter 'the EU-Greenland Fisheries Partnership Agreement'.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting approval of the new protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution between Greenland and the EU. This new Protocol promotes a collaborative framework to develop, for the benefit of both sides, a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenland fishing area. It grants fishing opportunities to Union vessels in the Greenland fishing area, in accordance with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of available surpluses.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union, on the one hand, and the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland, on the other, promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in greenland's exclusive economic zone.  The financial compensation paid by the EU will be EUR 17.8 million per year for five years and will allow European vessels access to mixed fishing in Greenland waters, in line with the relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of the available surplus. I would like to remind you that the greenland agreement is the third most important agreement for the EU in terms of economic value.  In fact, it is sufficient to recall that in 2013, the agreement generated as much as EUR 10 million in direct value for the EU catch sector and a further EUR 12 million in indirect value added in the upstream and downstream sectors. I therefore voted in favour of the new protocol, in view of the important economic benefits for both parties.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland is the third most important economic in the European Union. The ex ante and ex post evaluations consider the renewal of the Agreement to be in the interests of the European Union and Greenland. This has also contributed to the financial capital gains created in the European Union which amount to EUR 10 million.  The new Agreement is a burden on the European Union of almost EUR 18 million per year. Of these, almost 3 million are attached to so-called support for the local fisheries sector.  I voted positively for this agreement, but I will pay particular attention to compliance with it. Among others, it is essential that the funds alused are used as planned, thus including the appropriate use of funding for the fisheries sector.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because we oppose this standard EU agreement structure.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour in this consent procedure as it serves to maintain fishing opportunities for EU ships in the fishing zone of Greenland’s Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). But this arrangement serves as a warning to the UK if it leaves the EU, as although the UK will benefit from charging those using its EEZ, as Greenland does today, the UK will also have to pay when in other EU Members’ EEZs. This benefit of being able to use the EEZ of other Member States is used and is a great source of income for many of the UK’s fishers. A factor which makes more sense when you consider that, unlike Greenland’s waters which are more self-contained, the EEZ of the UK is certainly not.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution consists of a protocol for a fisheries partnership agreement between the EU and Denmark/Greenland. The agreement considers both the economic and environmental sides, so therefore I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fisheries Partnership Agreements are a way for EU countries to gain access to fishing rights in the exclusive zone of a partner country. The initial fisheries agreement between the EU, on the one hand, and the Government of Denmark and the Home Rule Government of Greenland, on the other, was concluded as early as 1985. In the meantime, it has been updated several times and last year the Commission adopted a proposal to renew the Protocol to this Agreement. As this is a mixed agreement that gives EU vessels access to large fish stocks in Greenlandic waters, the EU provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights to the partner country. In addition, the EU is involved in supporting a number of activities that are important for Greenland's efforts to manage and control its fisheries sustainably. Fishing is an important part of economic for Greenland, as fish account for almost 90% of the goods exported. Virtually all exports of Greenlandic fishery products are destined for the EU, with the vast majority going to Denmark. The agreement has considerable benefits for companies in EU countries, as it also generates added value in other up-to-coming sectors. I support the introduction of the new protocol, and I believe that it will continue to be beneficial for both countries. In the future, however, consideration should be given in particular to options for the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks, with greater emphasis on better compliance with scientific advice.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Through the Fisheries Partnership Agreements, the EU acquires fishing rights for a large number of fish stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone, while providing financial and technical support to that country. The Fisheries Partnership Agreement with the Government of Denmark and the Home Government of Greenland (EU/Greenland Partnership) is the third most important agreement for the EU in terms of its economic value. Parliament's approval is necessary for the conclusion of a new protocol to the agreement setting out the details for its implementation over the next five years. The new Protocol foresees an EU financial contribution of EUR 17.8 million per year, representing the amount for access to the Greenland Exclusive Economic Zone (EUR 13,17 million) and a specific amount (EUR 2,931 million) allocated to support for greenland's sectoral fisheries policy. Fish account for almost 90% of Greenland's export goods; the most important segments are fishing for northern prawns, Greenland halibut and cod. This mixed agreement will provide EU vessels with access to a large number of fish stocks in greenland's exclusive economic zone. The new Protocol is consistent with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement, as it promotes and strengthens EU-Greenland cooperation and foresees the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Greenland fishing zone. For this reasons, I voted in favour of the report in order to approve the conclusion of the protocol.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement concluded in 2006 between the European Union, on the one hand, and Denmark and Greenland, on the other, as this is an important instrument for ensuring access to fishing for European fleets in the partner country's exclusive economic zone, in this case Greenland.  The aim of the protocol is, in fact, to maintain fishing opportunities for European vessels in Greenland waters and thus contribute to better management and conservation of fishery resources through sectoral support, in particular for the monitoring of domestic and foreign fleets, the fight against illegal fishing and the development of local fisheries.  In return, the EU will make a financial contribution for access to Greenland's fishing zone and for support for Greenland's sectoral fisheries policy. The text provides for regular monitoring of these measures, thus ensuring that the implementation of the partnership and the protocol is correct and reflects any changes in the situation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In recent years, the European Union has signed a large number of fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with third countries. These agreements provide financial and technical assistance to the European Union in exchange for fishing rights in the exclusive economic zone of partner countries. The Agreement with Denmark and the Autonomous Province of Greenland, which replaced the original 1985 fisheries agreement, is also in force.  Greenland's economy is highly dependent on the fisheries sector and the new protocol, covering the five-year period from the date of signing, should strengthen cooperation between the EU and Greenland by promoting the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishing resources. Given the economic value, the agreement with Greenland is the third most important for the European Union and I consider the signing of the agreement to be in the interest of both sides. Consequently, I support this recommendation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which is simply to replace the protocol that expired at the end of 2015 with a new protocol to allow EU vessels access to Greenland’s Exclusive Economic Zone.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The first fisheries agreement between the European Union and Denmark, namely Greenland, its autonomous province, was concluded in 1985 for 10 years and was extended for an additional six years after which it was replaced by the Fisheries Partnership Agreement currently in force. The agreement is of great importance, as almost all of Greenland's fishing products are intended for export to the European Union. Likewise, the agreement mentioned is, as far as economic value is concerned, the third most important for the Union. I support my colleague Affronte's recommendation on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland, as I consider it in the interest of both the European Union and Greenland that the protocol be renewed. The Protocol provides important economic benefits to both parties and contributes to ensuring coherence with other EU fishing activities in the region. Furthermore, the protocol is in line with the objectives of the agreement already mentioned, as it strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland and promotes a partnership framework that develops a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fish in greenland's fishing area.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal in view of the economic value brought to the European Union by the partnership between Denmark and Greenland.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of a Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, of the one part, and the Government of Denmark and the Home Government of Greenland, of the other part. The purpose of the agreement is for the EU to provide financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights. I support the conclusion of a new agreement that continues to provide the European Union and Greenland with significant economic benefits.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a renewal of the Protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the two parties, Denmark and Greenland. The current Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement expired on 31 December 2015. At the end of these negotiations, a new protocol was initiald on 20 March 2015. The new Protocol is in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement, strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland and promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Greenland fishing zone in the interests of both parties. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought that promote the development of the Member States of the European Union, but without prejudice to their national and economic interests.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of parliament's agreement on the protocol.  The common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, aquaculture and, in particular, freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations.  Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has concluded several fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with "third countries" in recent years. Through fisheries partnership agreements, the EU provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights for a wide range of fish stocks within the exclusive economic zone of partner countries. The original fisheries agreement between the EU, of the one part, and the Government of Denmark and the Home Government of Greenland, of the other part, dates back to 1985. This agreement was in force for 10 years and was extended for a further six years until it was finally replaced by the fisheries partnership agreement currently in force. I supported this report because the new Protocol is in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement: it strengthens cooperation between the Union and Greenland. It will help to build a partnership framework in which a sustainable fisheries policy can be established by responsibly exploiting fishery resources within the Greenland fishing zone, for example by supporting local employment. This is in the interests of both Parties, in accordance with the relevant conservation and management measures and up to the additional resources available. The Recommendation also draws attention to some of the factors that need to be improved on the basis of the protocol analysis of the previous Convention, including the sustainable exploitation of fish stocks, the fight against illegal fishing, the improvement of some operational difficulties, closer follow-up to the principles of scientific advice and the surplus available, and stricter monitoring and adjustment of the EU's financial contribution.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, which was rapporteur for our colleague Marco Affronte, on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union, Denmark and Greenland, is one of the most sustainable fisheries agreements in terms of the exploitation of fish stocks. Thanks to the agreement between the EU, Denmark and Greenland, less inequality is created in the fisheries market because it is followed, controlled and protected directly by the Danish Government.   I voted in favour of this agreement with a view to implementing the provisions of the UNITED Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea relating to the conservation and management of transnational and highly migratory fish stocks. I stress that it is in our interests to continue to promote responsible fishing in order to ensure the long-term conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biological resources.  With my vote in favour, I would also like to highlight a number of aspects that need to be improved in the agreement, such as giving importance to scientific data and ensuring strict financial control over financial compensation.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's relations with third countries and entities have seen a sharp development in recent years. The relationship with Greenland has always been characterised by openness and enhanced cooperation in areas of common interest. Although formally dependent on Denmark, an EU Member State, Greenland is not part of the territories under the jurisdiction of the European institutions, but benefits from a special relationship with the Union. Since Greenland's main economic activity is fisheries, which provide almost 90% of the country's exports, the achievement of an agreement between the EU and Greenland in this area has been considered necessary since 1985. In recent years, due to the revision of European fisheries policies, the duration of the agreements has been reduced from 10 to 6 and 3 years respectively, the last being in force in the period 2013-2015. The application of a new fisheries protocol in the period 2016-2020 required three rounds of negotiation and concerns the fishing of several species for which the Union has allocated around EUR 18 million, of which more than 13 million for access to Greenland resources, almost 3 million to support fishing in the region and the rest to reserve.  The implementation of this agreement, which supports sustainable development and jobs and combats illegal fishing, deserves to be supported.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text, following the experts of our group. The new protocol is consistent with the objectives of the fisheries partnership agreement; it strengthens cooperation between the EU and Greenland and promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Greenland fishing area, for the benefit of both sides. The fishing protocol would cover a period of five years from the provisional application date - from the date of its signature and no earlier than January 1, 2016. It provides fishing opportunities for EU vessels in the Greenland fishing area, in accordance with relevant conservation and management measures and within the limits of the available surplus. To this end, the protocol sets an indicative annual level of fishing opportunities granted by Greenland to EU vessels (tonnes).

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of renewing the Protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU, Denmark and Greenland, which expired at the end of 2015, for five years. Its aim is to strengthen cooperation between the EU and Greenland, and to promote a partnership in which to develop a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible exploitation of fishery resources in the Greenlandic fishing zone. The Protocol grants fishing opportunities to EU vessels in the fishing zone of Greenland by setting a fishing level each year limited to the available surplus, fully in line with conservation and management measures. This is an economically beneficial agreement for both the EU and Greenland, as virtually all of Greenland’s exports of fish products are destined for the EU, with Denmark accounting for more than 90% of EU imports.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I would point out that it is necessary to regularly evaluate the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, on the one hand, and the Government of Denmark and the Local Government of Greenland on the other, since this Agreement is by profitability the third most important economic agreement the European Union has with a foreign country. The European Union benefits greatly from the agreement on the use of Greenland's fishing zones, and greenland also benefits greatly from the financial resources received from the coffers of the European Union. The new protocol will strengthen cooperation between the Union and Greenland and promote a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and responsible use of fishing resources in greenland's fishing zone in the interests of both parties. Therefore, I supported this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community, on the one hand, and the Government of Denmark and the Home Government of Greenland, of the other part, I supported, as these two countries cover a large fishing area which, from an ecological point of view, is bio-diversified, unrea good and, consequently, healthy seafood is entering the EU market. The EU-Greenland Fisheries Partnership Agreement is one of the most important for the EU in terms of economic value and the only such agreement with the northern country. Almost all Greenland's fish products are destined for the EU, with Denmark representing more than 90% of imports into the EU. Frozen prawns, Greenland hali ply and cod are the most important exports. The EU pays a fixed annual financial compensation for access, regardless of fishing opportunities in agreement with the Protocol. The current Protocol sets an EU financial contribution of €17.85 million per year.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the last few years, the European Union has signed a number of fisheries collaboration agreements and protocols with 'third countries'. Through these agreements, the EU grants financial and technical assistance in exchange for fishing rights in relation to a wide range of stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. In this case, a specific fisheries collaboration agreement has been concluded with the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland, hereinafter 'the EU-Greenland Fisheries Partnership Agreement'.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a 5-year agreement that sets out the fishing possibilities of EU vessels in Greenland (Denmark's autonomous government). The agreements with Denmark and Greenland have been in place since 1985. As every year, the EU buys more fish quotas than it fishes, and this time the quotas have been reduced to also reduce the cost of the agreement with Greenland. Both sides are winners.  I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union (EU) has concluded several fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with "third countries" in recent years. Through fisheries partnership agreements, the EU provides financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights for a wide range of fish stocks within the exclusive economic zone of partner countries. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the European Union in recent years, the European Union has signed a number of fisheries partnership agreements and protocols with 'third countries'. Through these agreements, the EU grants financial and technical assistance in exchange for fishing rights in relation to a wide range of stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. In this case, a specific fisheries collaboration agreement has been concluded with the Government of Denmark and the Autonomous Government of Greenland, hereinafter 'the EU-Greenland Fisheries Partnership Agreement'.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. This is a mixed agreement that provides EU vessels access to a wide range of fish stocks in the Greenlandic Exclusive Economic Zone. The previous protocol applied from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2015 for a period of three years, whereas the current one will be in force for a period of five years, beginning 1 January 2016. It provides for an EU financial contribution of EUR 17.85 million per year.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for by the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with the Government of Denmark and the Home Rule Government of Greenland. Recently the European Union has signed a number of Fisheries Partnership Agreements (FPAs) and Protocols with ‘third countries’ providing financial and technical support in exchange for fishing rights to a wide range of fish stocks in the partner country’s exclusive economic zone. The specific FPA with the Government of Denmark and the Home Rule Government of Greenland is particularly significant to the EU for generating substantial economic benefits through fishing opportunities. While Greenland’s economy is highly dependent on the fisheries sector, its flora and fauna should be well preserved as part of the unique Arctic region. The renewed Protocol takes into consideration ecological and economic aspects of the agreement, which is the reason I voted in favour of its conclusion.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This new protocol is in line with the objectives of the fisheries partnership agreement. It strengthens cooperation between the European Union and Greenland and promotes a framework in which to develop a sustainable and responsible fisheries policy in the Greenland fishing area. We are talking about an agreement which satisfies both sides so I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this partnership agreement because it provides important economic benefits for both parties and ensures greater coherence in EU fisheries policy.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement, which already has a long history, is the third most important for the EU in terms of its economic value, considering the rapporteur that the benefits for both parties have been significant.  This agreement provides eu member states' fleets with access to a wide range of fish stocks in Greenland's Exclusive Economic Zone.  It is stated, however, that indirect benefits for Greenland have been limited (e.g. in terms of job creation and intervention of local ports in the fishing product cycle) – a fact which, once again, runs counter to the expressed objectives of the so-called partnership agreements. The new Protocol provides for a slight reduction in EU contributions to the existing protocol. This reduction, however, reflects the reduction in fishing quotas and is not considered to be significant. On the other hand, there is an increase in the part for sectoral cooperation. We voted in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. There is no objection to the renewal of the Protocol on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Denmark and Greenland. It also contributes to ensuring coherence with fishing activities within the EU and in other areas in the region, and also provides financial support to fishermen.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. Through Fisheries Partnership Agreements, the EU provides financial and technical support and, in return, obtains fishing rights for a wide range of fish stocks in the partner country's exclusive economic zone. This is an economically understandable procedure, and that is why I agree with the specific fisheries partnership agreement with the Danish Government and the Autonomous Government of Greenland. However, the rapporteur points out that 'while the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement as a whole may be coherent, EU fleets are fishing stocks that are overexploited under the Fisheries Partnership Agreement and/or contribute to catches that exceed the recommendations under the precautionary approach. There are therefore cases where the actual impact of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement does not fully correspond to the objectives of the CFP, the scientific opinions of NAFO and ICES and the objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement." This should be better verified by the Member States in the future.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The Fisheries Partnership Agreement (PA) is the third most important agreement with a strong economic value and mutually beneficial to the economies of both partners. That is why I supported it, as it strengthens cooperation between the EU and Greenland, and promotes a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2003, the Council authorized the Commission to start negotiations with third countries in order to replace certain provisions in bilateral agreements with an agreement at EU level, which I consider positive. The EU-Macao Agreement on certain aspects of air services is one of the outcome of these negotiations. I voted for it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This mainly technical-legal report aims to bring into line with European law the pre-existing air services agreements between the EU countries and the autonomous region of Macau but declared contrary to European law by the ECJ. So I voted in favour.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission has negotiated an Agreement which will bring all Member States’ bilateral air services agreements with Macao into conformity with EU law. I voted against this report as the EU has no mandate to negotiate terms of bilateral agreements between countries on behalf of the United Kingdom.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it allows EU air carriers, based in the territory of a Member State, to exercise their freedom of establishment and the same treatment in the host Member State as that granted to EU nationals.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on certain aspects of the Agreement between the European Union and Macao on air services. The proposal amends some of the provisions of the 15 bilateral air services agreements in the special administrative region of Macao of the eu Member States in force and the People's Republic of China. In 2002, the Court of Justice of the EU ruled that traditional clauses in member states' bilateral air service designation agreements infringe EU law. On the basis of those Articles, a third Country may refuse, revoke or suspend authorisations or authorisations of an air carrier designated by a Member State but not owned by that Member State or its nationals.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I approved this essentially technical-legal report which aims to bring into line with European law the pre-existing air services agreements between EU countries and the autonomous region of Macau, in line with the ECJ's indications that they were contrary to European law.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. On 23 November 2013, on behalf of the Union, the Commission negotiated an agreement on certain aspects of air services with the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. Relations between the EU and Macao have been based on a trade and cooperation agreement since 1992. Since then, the Union has contributed as much as it can to the economic and political development of this autonomous region. I voted in favour of this act because it strengthens the Union's ties with this customs territory separate from the rest of the People's Republic of China.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of Mr Koch's report on the new agreement on certain aspects of air services between the EU and Macao. The text of the agreement, while presenting technical aspects, introduces important innovations amending certain requirements in the areas of safety, competition and fuel taxation. Among the relevant aspects of the new legislation is what defines the new designation clause. It will enable all carriers in the Union to benefit from the right of establishment. exceeding the existing agreements and the repeated infringements of Article 49 TFEI spawned by them. Specifically, the new rules will lead to the amendment of the 15 existing air service agreements between the EU and the Macao Special Administrative Region in the PRC.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. On behalf of the Union, the Commission has negotiated an agreement on certain aspects of air services with the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China which replaces certain provisions of existing bilateral air services agreements.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this Recommendation on the EU-Macao Agreement on certain aspects of air services. International relations between Member States and third countries in the field of air services have been regulated by bilateral agreements, but in 2002 the Court of Justice of the European Union held that traditional designation clauses infringe EU law. TheREFORE, the EC has negotiated the Agreement replacing certain provisions of the fifteen bilateral air services agreements concluded between the States of the Union and Macao.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have chosen to vote for this EU-Macao agreement on certain aspects of air services. Its main objective is to comply with European law of pre-existing agreements in this area, which have been declared contrary to European legislation. Such a technical and legal adaptation seems logical to me given the importance of this special administrative region that is Macau.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by Mr Beazley on be it is a good one. Koch, who analyses certain aspects of air services between the European Union and Macao, is acceptable and balanced and I wanted to support it with my vote. I believe that this text improves in terms of simplification, security and competition compared to previous bilateral agreements concluded;  the EU and our markets will benefit more from the changes that have been made.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Macau Special Administrative Region on certain aspects of air services. This Agreement replaces certain provisions of the fifteen bilateral air services agreements concluded between Member States of the Union and the Macau Special Administrative Region, after, in 2002, the Court of Justice of the European Union held that the traditional designation clauses of the member states' bilateral air services agreements infringe EU law. Those clauses allow a third country to refuse, revoke or suspend the permits or authorisations of an airline designated by a Member State, but whose effective ownership and control do not correspond essentially to that Member State or its nationals. That circumstance is considered to constitute discrimination against Union airlines established in the territory of one Member State, but whose ownership and control correspond to nationals of other Member States.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation, which deals with the Agreement between the European Union and Macao on certain aspects of air services. International aviation relations between Member States and third countries have traditionally been established through bilateral air service agreements. In 2002, the Court of Justice of the EU ruled that traditional clauses in member states' bilateral air service designation agreements infringe EU law. On the basis of those Articles, a third Country may refuse, revoke or suspend authorisations or authorisations of an air carrier designated by a Member State but not owned by that Member State or its nationals. This has been assessed as discrimination against EU air carriers established in one Member State but owned and controlled by another Member State. This is contrary to Article 49 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which guarantees that nationals of Member States may enjoy the same rights as nationals of that Member State in the Member State in which they are established. There are also other issues, such as competition, where compliance with EU law should be ensured by modifying or supplementing the current provisions on bilateral air service agreements between Member States and third countries. In this way, the Commission has agreed on an agreement replacing some of the existing provisions of the 15 bilateral air services agreements between the eu Member States and the People's Republic of China special administrative region, Macao.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. International aviation relations between Member States and third countries are normally governed by bilateral air transport agreements. The European Court of Justice has found that the agreement with Macao so far is contrary to the acquis, allowing a third country to refuse, withdraw or suspend the authorisation or authorisation of an air carrier designated by a Member State. Since this has been found to constitute discrimination against EU carriers established in the territory of a given Member State, even though that carrier is not the majority owned by that Member State or its nationals and is contrary to Article 49 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, this proposal amends or supplements the existing provisions of bilateral agreements. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this agreement, which also regulates the rights of establishment, the provisions on safety, the taxation of aviation fuel and the anti-competitive practice.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Agreement which changes the provisions relating to clause labelling, security, competition and taxation in existing AIR TRANSPORT agreements between the EU and Macao.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the renegotiation of the Agreement on certain aspects of air services between the European Union and Macao completed by the Commission improves the previous agreement and provides greater guarantees the principle of freedom of establishment for European citizens.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 International relations in the field of air transport between the Member States of the European Union with a large number of third countries have mainly been based, until now, on bilateral international agreements that have nevertheless caused repeated violations of EU law causing significant distortions in competition, penalising in particular European companies operating from territories of other Member States. With this in mind, the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement on air transport between the EU and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region (People's Republic of China) makes it possible to correct the main distortions of competition and to harmonise the sector in question with European law. This type of initiative will also have to be promoted in respect of other third countries where similar problems have been encountered.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China envisages the regulation of certain aspects of air services. International aviation relations between Member States and third countries are traditionally governed by bilateral air services agreements. It is therefore intended to replace certain provisions of the 15 existing bilateral air services agreements concluded between the EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. The most important clauses are designation clauses, which replace traditional clauses with an EU designation clause, which allows all EU carriers to benefit from the right of establishment, as well as safety clauses, which ensure that the safety provisions of bilateral agreements apply in situations where regulatory control over an air carrier is carried out by a Member State other than that designated by the air carrier. The clause on compatibility with competition rules also prohibits anti-competitive practices.  I was in favour of this draft decision because I believe that the EU-Macao Agreement on certain aspects of air services incorporates coherent provisions aimed at ensuring a safe legal framework favourable to both parties.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour: Back in 2002, the Court of Justice ruled that the designation clauses contained in bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries relating to the aviation sector were unlawful. The report seems to be improving in terms of simplification, security and competition.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. Different judgments of the Court in the early 2000s concluded that the European Union has exclusive competence over various aspects of external aviation which had traditionally been regulated through bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries. Following this case-law, in June 2003 the Council sent the Commission to start negotiations with third countries with a view to replacing the 47 existing bilateral agreements with Community agreements. The agreement with Macau extends to all EU states the rights already enjoyed by 15 states with which Macau had bilateral agreements and which allows the right of establishment and non-discriminatory access by nationality to airlines wishing to establish routes to Macau

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ By voting in favour of this report, I gave my consent to the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China. This agreement will benefit EU airlines in the areas of safety, taxation and competition.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and Macao to replace certain provisions of the bilateral air service agreements concluded with Macao by the Member States. In fact, in the field of international air transport, relations between Member States and third countries are traditionally governed by bilateral air service agreements. However, the Court of Justice of the EU ruled in a 2002 judgment on the illegality of the traditional designation clauses contained in the bilateral air service agreements concluded by the Member States. As laid down by the Court, such clauses allow a third country or to refuse, revoke or suspend the authorisations or licences of an air carrier designated by a Member State. This report makes the necessary changes to the existing agreements in order to bring them into line with the rules laid down by the Court of Justice and, therefore, we fully support them.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the agreement, recalling that international air relations between Member States and third countries are traditionally defined by bilateral agreements in the field of air services.  However, there are issues, such as competition, in which compliance with European Union law should be ensured by amending or supplementing the existing provisions of bilateral air transport agreements between Member States and third countries.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Recommendation on a draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on certain aspects of air transport between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China is part of an effort to intensify and regulate Europe's relations with a region of increased economic and commercial interest.  At the same time, the existence of such projects can only have positive effects in areas of security and smooth cooperation. That is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it argues for better regulation of certain aspects of air services between the Eu ropean Union and Macao. The intention is to ensure compliance with EU law on the substance of existing bilateral agreements, by amending and supplementing the existing provisions in such a way as to ensure maximum respect for principles such as non-discrimination and fair competition. I think it is right and essential to ensure that nationals of Member States who have exercised their freedom of establishment of a company in another Member State receive the same treatment as their nationals. I therefore voted in favour because I believe that this document demonstrates the difference between a Europe united not only in paper but also in practice.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2002 the EU Court of Justice ruled that designation clauses in Member States’ air services agreements are an infringement of EU law. They were found to be contrary to Article 49 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. They enable a third country to reject or withdraw authorisation of air carriers not substantially owned or controlled by the Member State or its citizens. To ensure fair competition in the Union, and compliance with EU law, these provisions in bilateral air service agreements must be modified.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 International relations between Member States and third countries in the field of aviation have traditionally been regulated through bilateral air service agreements whose designation clauses infringe Union law because they allow third countries to reject, withdraw or suspend the licences or authorisations of an air carrier which has been designated by a Member State, but whose considerable share of the capital does not belong to that Member State or to its nationals and whose effective control is not by any these exercised.  I support the Koch report which approves a new Agreement which, among other things, replaces traditional designation clauses with an EU designation clause allowing all carriers to benefit from the right of establishment.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the agreement replacing certain provisions existing in the 15 bilateral air service agreements concluded between the Member States of the European Union and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report provides for the placement of traditional designation clauses with an EU designation clause, permitting all EU carriers to benefit from the right of establishment. Regulatory control will also strengthen safety. The agreement will also seek to provide a level playing field.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2003, the Council authorized the Commission to start negotiations with third countries in order to replace certain provisions in bilateral agreements with an agreement at EU level, which I consider positive. The EU-Macao Agreement on certain aspects of air services is one of the outcome of these negotiations. I voted for it.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to amend the Agreement replacing certain provisions of existing bilateral air services agreements between euMember States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, agreements that contravened the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which guarantee equal treatment applied to both nationals and members of the host State.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Commission has negotiated an agreement replacing certain provisions of the fifteen existing bilateral air services agreements between EU Member States and the Macau Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. One of its main elements is the designation clause, which allows all EU carriers to exercise their right of establishment, taxation of aviation fuel and the prohibition of anti-competitive practices.  I voted IN FAVOUR.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report replaces some of the provisions of the 15 existing bilateral air services agreements between EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. This report establishes a designation clause allowing all EU carriers to benefit from the right of establishment, transport security in bilateral agreements and tax provisions with a tax on aviation fuel.
