Considering that China is one of the largest economic markets in the world and that it is a real opportunity for European companies, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China on certain aspects of air services. The insertion of an EU designation clause is important because it allows all EU carriers to benefit from the right of establishment, one of the fundamental freedoms.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International air relations were based on bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries until the European Court of Justice ruled in 2002 that bilateral air agreements infringed EU law.  Accordingly, the European Commission has renegotiated the agreements between the EU and Macao. The new agreement was signed on 23 November 2013, but requires the consent of the European Parliament. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I therefore supported the entry into force of the agreement as soon as possible.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This mainly technical-legal report aims to bring into line with European law the pre-existing air services agreements between the EU countries and the autonomous region of Macau, but which have been declared contrary to European law by the ECJ. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation for an EU-Macau agreement on certain aspects of air services because it guarantees the right of establishment of all EU carriers. The agreement guarantees compliance with EU law in the areas of competition and safety protection.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International air relations were based on bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries until the 2002 ruling of the European Court of Justice, which ruled that bilateral air agreements infringed EU law. Accordingly, the European Commission has renegotiated the agreements between the EU and Macau. The new agreement was signed on 23 November 2013, but requires the consent of the European Parliament. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I therefore supported the entry into force of the agreement as soon as possible.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Agreement between the EU and Macao was signed on 23 November 2013. International relations between Member States and third countries in the field of aviation have traditionally been regulated through bilateral air service agreements which have included clauses which infringe EU law. Such clauses are considered to constitute discrimination against EU carriers which are established in the territory of a Member State but are owned and under the control of nationals of other Member States. There are other issues, such as competition, on which compliance with Union law should be ensured by amending or supplementing the existing provisions of bilateral air service agreements between Member States and third countries. However, the Commission has therefore negotiated this Agreement, which replaces certain provisions of the current 15 bilateral air service agreements by improving the final document. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote in favour: aims to bring pre-existing air services agreements into line with European law.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Relations between Member States and third countries in the field of aviation have been regulated through bilateral air service agreements. On the basis of CJEU decisions, these agreements were considered to infringe EU law, as they provide for situations of discrimination against EU carriers which are established in the territory of a Member State but are owned and are under the control of nationals of other Member States. This agreement (non-agreementable) replaces the provisions of the current 15 bilateral air service agreements between Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. Taken together, these agreements are part of the logic of the ongoing monopolistic concentration in the aviation sector in the EU. They serve this objective, as all EU legislation for the sector serves. A sector dominated by five major groups: Lufthansa, Iberia-British Airways and Air France-KLM, plus the two low-cost Ryanair and Easyjet. The companies that still resist outside this lot, especially if, like TAP, they are flag airlines, and especially if they are still public, are to dismantle, disappear in the long term, being absorbed – their business, assets and routes – by the giants of the sector. A deeply indest of national interests, which we reject and fight. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Agreement between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region implementing certain aspects of air services.  The amendments made replace the traditional designation clauses, allowing all air carriers in the European Union to benefit from the right of establishment. I believe that the centrality that has been given to the role of security and taxation within the bilateral agreement with the Macao region is important, bringing EU-Macao cooperation in the right direction.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as it was positive overall.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement in question amends the provisions concerning the labelling, safety, competition and taxation clauses in the existing fifteen bilateral air services agreements between the Member States of the European Union and the Special Administrative Area of the People's Republic of China Macau. Amendments to existing provisions in bilateral air services agreements concluded between Member States and third countries should ensure compliance with European Union law.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour, as the report seems to improve in terms of simplification, security and competition.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU-Macao agreement on certain aspects of air transport, because this agreement also gives the Union super powers, undermines the sovereignty of the Member States, and once again serves the interests of the major airlines.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ International relations in the field of air transport between Member States and third countries have traditionally been governed by bilateral agreements on air services. The Court of Justice of the European Union estimated in 2002 that traditional designation clauses in bilateral agreements between Member States’ air services were contrary to the legislation of the European Union. They allow a third country to reject, withdraw or suspend the permissions or authorisations of an air carrier that has been designated by a Member State, but whose ownership and effective control is not vested essentially with this Member State or its nationals. The Court found that this constituted discrimination against carriers of the Union in the territory of a Member State but owned and controlled by nationals of other Member States. This is a violation of Article 49 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which guarantees nationals of Member States who have exercised their freedom of establishment the same treatment in the host Member State as that accorded to nationals of that Member State. The Agreement replaces the traditional designation clauses with an EU designation clause, permitting all EU carriers to benefit from the right of establishment. I therefore gave a favourable opinion on the conclusion of this Agreement.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International air relations were based on bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries until the 2002 decision of the European Court of Justice, which ruled that bilateral air agreements infringed EU law.  Accordingly, the European Commission has renegotiated the agreements between the EU and Macau. The new agreement was signed on 23 November 2013, but requires the consent of the European Parliament. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I therefore supported the entry into force of the agreement as soon as possible.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International air relations were based on bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries until the 2002 ruling of the European Court of Justice, which ruled that bilateral air agreements infringed EU law.  Accordingly, the European Commission has renegotiated the agreements between the EU and Macau. The new agreement was signed on 23 November 2013, but requires the consent of the European Parliament. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I therefore supported the entry into force of the agreement as soon as possible.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Agreement which the Commission has negotiated and which replaces certain provisions of the fifteen bilateral air services agreements concluded between EU Member States and the Macau Special Administrative Region. This Agreement is intended to ensure competition and compliance with EU law.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the position on the EU-Macao agreement on certain aspects of air services, which was drawn up by my group colleague Roberts Zéle, as I support the technical-constructive approach of this document.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The previous bilateral agreements on international aviation relations were contrary to freedom of establishment and included discrimination against EU-based companies. I therefore agree with the renegotiated approach without any discrimination.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. On behalf of the Union, the Commission has negotiated an agreement on certain aspects of air services with the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China which replaces certain provisions of existing bilateral air services agreements.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, the objective of which is to give all European Union air carriers non-discriminatory access to routes between the European Union and third countries, in this case the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China. This will bring the bilateral air service agreement between Member States and this third country in line with the law of the Union.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of granting the consent for the agreement. It will allow compliance with EU law in terms of competition.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International air relations were based on bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries until the 2002 decision of the European Court of Justice, which ruled that bilateral air agreements infringed EU law.  Accordingly, the European Commission has renegotiated the agreements between the EU and Macau. The new agreement was signed on 23 November 2013, but requires the consent of the European Parliament. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the entry into force of the agreement as soon as possible.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We supported the report on the EU-Macao agreement on certain aspects of air transport. The agreement is the product of negotiation between the EU, through the Commission and the Macao authorities of China, and replaces certain provisions in existing bilateral air transport agreements.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Agreement on certain aspects of air services between the European Union and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China. In terms of EU law I welcome this agreement that will ensure compliance with EU competition regulations and prohibit any anti-competitive practices in air services. More specifically this agreement will prevent third countries discriminating against EU air carriers that are established in a Member State but which are not owned or controlled by nationals of that Member State, as well as align the taxation of aviation fuel between the EU and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International air relations were based on bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries until the 2002 decision of the European Court of Justice, which ruled that bilateral air agreements infringed EU law.  Accordingly, the European Commission has renegotiated the agreements between the EU and Macau. The new agreement was signed on 23 November 2013, but requires the consent of the European Parliament. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I therefore supported the entry into force of the agreement as soon as possible.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The objectives of agreements like this are to give all European Union air carriers non-discriminatory access to routes between the European Union and third countries, and to bring bilateral air service agreements between Member States and third countries in line with the law of the Union. Today’s vote will allow for a helpful agreement on the development and regulation of air transport routes and so Labour MEPs voted in favour.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement changes some provisions related to safety, competition and taxation in the 15 bilateral air services agreements between the European Union and the Macao Special Administrative Region.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on the Completed Aspects of Air Transport Services between the European Union and the Government of the Macaa Special Administrative Area of the People's Republic of China, as this gives consent for the conclusion of this agreement.  The agreement ensures compliance with European competition legislation and prevents discrimination, by third countries, of European air carriers established in one Member State and not owned or controlled by nationals of the country concerned. I believe that effective measures aimed at combating anti-competitive practices need to be ensured, and therefore I support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This mainly technical-legal report aims to bring into line with European law the pre-existing air services agreements between the EU countries and the autonomous region of Macau but declared contrary to European law by the ECJ. I am in favour of this text and have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Dieter-Lebrecht Koch's report on the EU-Macao agreement on certain aspects of air services. This report allows all EU carriers to enjoy the right to establish and strengthens the safety provisions. It also contains tax provisions that set fuel taxes and prohibit anti-competitive practices. I support this proposal which will facilitate the development and security of air services between Europe, Macao and China. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report focused on an agreement negotiated by the Commission to replace certain provisions of the 15 existing bilateral air services agreements between the EU Member States and Macao. This text updates several provisions on security, competition or taxation relating to air services with Macau and will serve as the basis for future agreements. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the agreement, as its objectives are to give all EU air carriers non-discriminatory access to routes between the EU and third countries, and to bring bilateral air service agreements between Member States and third countries in line with the law of the Union.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International air relations were based on bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries until the 2002 ruling of the European Court of Justice, which ruled that bilateral air agreements infringed EU law.  Accordingly, the European Commission has renegotiated the agreements between the EU and Macau. The new agreement was signed on 23 November 2013, but requires the consent of the European Parliament. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I therefore supported the entry into force of the agreement as soon as possible.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the amendment or supplementation of existing provisions of bilateral air transport agreements between Member States and third countries. The usual clause defining an air carrier in those agreements allegedly infringes the right of free establishment of Community air carriers appointed by a Member State but owned by another Member State, enabling the third country to suspend and reject an air carrier's licences.  On this basis, the agreement on certain aspects of air transport between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region provides for the replacement of these traditional clauses with a clause allowing all European air carriers to enjoy free establishment on an equal footing, as well as a ban on practices that conflict with competition rules.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the agreement on air services between the European Union and the Government of Macao because in practice it replaces certain provisions in the existing 15 bilateral air services agreements concluded between EU Member States and Macao.  To clarify this statement, it is important to emphasise the fact that traditionally international aviation relations between Member States and third countries have been governed by bilateral air services agreements. In the long term, these agreements have broken EU laws and have promoted anti-competitive practices. Therefore, the negotiated agreement with Macao will solve many issues when it comes to safety, taxation and compatibility with competition rules. Last but not least, it will become example for other countries.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Macao agreement on certain aspects of air services. This mainly technical-legal report aims to bring into line with European law the pre-existing air services agreements between the countries of the European Union and the autonomous region of Macau, but which have been declared contrary to European law by the European Court of Justice.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this technical report because it aims to regularise past air services agreements with Macau, which the ECJ has declared contrary to European law.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this draft Council decision. Indeed, the aim is the homogenisation of European law, as well as the agreements signed between the air services of the European Union and the autonomous region of the People's Republic of China, Macau.  The text wants to restore the existing agreement in European law, which is normal.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2003, the Council authorized the Commission to start negotiations with third countries in order to replace certain provisions in bilateral agreements with an agreement at EU level, which I consider positive. The EU-Macao Agreement on certain aspects of air services is one of the outcome of these negotiations. I voted for it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Through this resolution, the European Parliament supports the Council's decision to sign an aviation agreement between the European Union and the Government of the Macau Special Administrative Region (People's Republic of China). The origin of such agreements is that bilateral air services agreements between Member States and third countries were declared by the Court of Justice of the European Union contrary to EU law in 2002. That is why my vote will be favourable.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. The EU-Macau agreement only summarises the member states' agreements with Macao on the safety and taxation of air transport. However, I note that I do not agree with the principle that these new agreements should be negotiated by the EU on a member-by-member basis.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ International aviation relations between Member States and third countries are governed by bilateral agreements on air transport services. A ruling by the Court of Justice of the European Union in 2002 ruled on a clause allowing third countries to refuse, withdraw or suspend the licences or authorisations of an airline appointed by a Member State but in which that Member State or its nationals do not have a significant ownership stake or actual control.  This discriminates against EU airlines, which is against Article 49 of the treaty on the functioning of the European Union. It is also necessary to address the issue of competition, which should be brought into line with EU law by amendments to existing provisions. The agreement replaces certain provisions and aligns them with the EU acquis in 15 existing bilateral air traffic services agreements concluded between EU Member States and the Government of the Macaa Special Administrative Area of the People's Republic of China, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Some time ago, the Commission negotiated with the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China an agreement replacing certain provisions in the 15 bilateral air service agreements in force between EU Member States and this territorial component of the PRC, which has autonomy on a number of issues, including air transport policy. The main idea of the new agreement is to legally replace any currently active bilateral air transport agreements concluded between certain EU Member States and Macao. This is done in order to contractually fully level the risk of any discrimination against airlines operating within the EU or belonging to nationals of its Member States. The primary aspects of the agreement are safety, taxation, compliance with competition rules, and the designation clause of the carrier.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 With this resolution, the European Parliament approves the Council's proposal for an agreement between the EU and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, which regulates the air services agreements concluded so far. The agreement removes the discriminatory measures to date which allowed a third country to refuse, withdraw or suspend the authorisations or authorisations of an air carrier established in the territory of a Member State but which was owned and controlled by nationals of other Member States. Such a practice was contrary to EU law, according to a ruling of the Court of Justice.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on certain aspects of air transport between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this draft Council decision on the agreement between the European Union and the Administrative Region of Macau. In this case, it was a simple compliance with agreements that already existed, but which were rejected by the European Court of Justice.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ International aviation relations between Member States and third countries have traditionally been governed by bilateral air services agreements. The EU Court of Justice ruled in 2002 that traditional designation clauses in Member States’ bilateral air services agreements infringe EU law. They allow a third country to reject, withdraw or suspend the permissions or authorisations of an air carrier that has been designated by a Member State but that is not substantially owned and effectively controlled by that Member State or its nationals. This has been found to constitute discrimination against EU carriers established in the territory of a Member State but owned and controlled by nationals of other Member States. This is contrary to Article 49 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union which guarantees nationals of Member States who have exercised their freedom of establishment the same treatment in the host Member State as that accorded to nationals of that Member State. Thus, the Commission has negotiated the Agreement that replaces certain provisions in the existing 15 bilateral air services agreements concluded between EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the agreement on certain aspects of air services between the European Union and Macao is in favour of me. The agreement in question involves amendments to certain agreements which constituted a breach of Article 49 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union by amending 15 bilateral air service agreements concluded. That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of conceding a new agreement on certain aspects of air services between the European Union and the Government of the Macau Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China to remove previous non-regular clauses.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report aims to endorse the agreement between the EU and Macau on certain aspects of air services. This European agreement aims to replace the 15 existing bilateral agreements to allow all EU air carriers indiscriminate access to air links between the European Union and Macao.  The provisions relating to fuel taxation are also in line with EU legislation.  But the only objective of the text, of course, is to speed up the liberalisation of the air market, with the potential risks to passenger safety.  I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The ECJ had declared agreements with Macau on certain aspects of air services incompatible with EU law. This technical report must reconcile European law with these agreements.  As a result, I voted for this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has negotiated the revision of the agreement replacing certain provisions of the current 15 bilateral air service agreements between Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, allowing it to be compatible with Article 49 TFEU. I presented my concordant vote.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation as the agreement ensures better safety provisions and harmonised aviation fuel taxation, and prohibits anti-competitive practices in bilateral agreements between the EU and Macao.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the vote in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. The conclusion of this agreement by the European Union helps to harmonize relations in the field of air transport long governed by bilateral agreements on air services.  This agreement replaces certain provisions of the 15 existing bilateral air services agreements between EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region. It puts all Member States on an equal footing and thus prevents unfair competition between them. This is a step towards more Europe in the field of air transport.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Aviation is an important sector of our economy and as such contributes EUR 365 billion a year to Pan-European GDP and the creation of around 5 million jobs. From a strategic point of view, the EU must remain competitive on a global scale and continue to develop the aviation industry, as the most important aviation markets are located outside the Union. In this context, investments in the construction and modernisation of infrastructure, as well as relations with our foreign partners governed by bilateral agreements in the field of air transport, are crucial. With the special administrative area of the People's Republic of China, Macau, we currently have 15 such contracts concluded, but they contained discriminatory provisions as regards the right of destination. The proposed decision would remove these provisions and replace them by enshrining the right of all EU carriers to settle, thus bringing the agreement into line with the 2002 decision of the Court of Justice of the EU. I believe that the Union must ensure that the current legislation and rights are respected, including in the area of external relations, which are important for the development of air transport, which is why I am voting in favour of the recommendation that has been made.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the EU—Macao Agreement on certain aspects of air services since it changes provisions concerning the designation clause, safety, competition and taxation in the existing 15 bilateral air services agreements between EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 International aviation relations between Member States and third countries have previously been governed by bilateral air transport agreements. However, in 2002, the Court of Justice of the European Union ruled that the traditional designation clauses of member states' bilateral air transport agreements infringe Eu law in so far as they allow a third country to refuse, revoke or suspend the licences or licences of an air carrier designated by a Member State whose majority ownership and effective control are not in the hands of that Member State or its nationals.  The Commission has therefore negotiated an agreement replacing some of the provisions of the 15 bilateral air transport agreements between the Member States of the Union and the Macau Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. The agreement replaces traditional designation clauses with an EU clause allowing all EU air carriers to exercise their right of establishment, aligns other provisions of bilateral agreements with this change and prohibits anti-competitive behaviour.  The Council adopted a draft decision on the conclusion of the agreement, but to do so it must obtain Parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on Transport and Tourism recommended that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to bring into line with European law the pre-existing air services agreements between EU countries and the Autonomous Region of Macau but declared contrary to EU law by the ECJ. He does not call for opposition.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This aviation agreement on certain aspects of air services aims to replace certain provisions of the current 15 bilateral air service agreements between Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China.  Since 2002, according to the Judgment of the Court of Justice, certain designation clauses inserted in bilateral agreements on air services have been in breach of EU law and contrary to Article 49 TFEU. For the reasons set out above, I am in favour of this agreement.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU-Macao agreement on certain aspects of air services. This agreement, which prohibits anti-competitive practices, will allow all EU carriers to benefit from the right to land in Macau.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The transposition of the air services agreements between the European Union and Macau, which I supported, does not involve a change in substance but centralises the various agreements into a single framework. This transposition is therefore part of an effort to simplify the current regulations and should be welcomed.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the field of international air transport, relations between Member States and third countries are traditionally governed by bilateral air service agreements. The Commission negotiated the agreement replacing certain provisions in the existing 15 bilateral air service agreements concluded between the Member States of the European Union and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. I voted in favour of Mr Koch's report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Bilateral Air Services Agreements govern international aviation relations between EU Member States and third countries. I have voted for this report that will replace certain provisions in the existing 15 bilateral air services agreements between the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China and EU Member States.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement between the Union and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China is the most effective instrument for aligning with Union law all existing bilateral air services agreements between the Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. The objectives of these agreements are to provide all air carriers in the European Union with non-discriminatory access to air routes between the European Union and third countries and to bring bilateral air services agreements between Member States and third countries into line with Union law. At the same time, the proposal provides for a simplification of the legislation.  I voted for this agreement because it will respond to a fundamental objective of the Union's foreign policy in the field of aviation by aligning existing bilateral agreements on air services with Union law.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China on certain aspects of air services. It was necessary to conclude this agreement, since the Court of Justice of the European Union has ruled that certain provisions of bilateral agreements concluded by Member States contravene EU law. To this end, this Agreement rectifies this situation and prohibits anti-competitive practices.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt it appropriate to vote in favour of the conclusion of the agreement on certain aspects of air services between the EU and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, as the proposal by the rapporteur Dieter-Lebrecht Koch is aimed at ensuring greater compatibility of air transport agreements with EU law. The preceding provisions did not allow EU carriers to benefit from the right of establishment, which constituted an infringement of Article 100a of the Treaty. Article 49 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ There are several bilateral air traffic agreements between the Macau Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China and the Member States of the European Union. I welcome this Agreement because it changes certain legal provisions in 15 bilateral agreements. In my view, this simplifies the operation of airlines, increases transparency and empowers the legal certainty of applying and interpreting the many provisions of the agreements adopted so far.  The agreement covers essential aspects of the airline, e.g. labelling clauses, security, taxation and compatibility with competition rules. The European Parliament's Transport and Tourism Committee made a positive statement on the proposal for an Agreement and I also supported its adoption.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This mainly technical-legal report aims to bring into line with European law the pre-existing air services agreements between the countries of the European Union and the autonomous region of Macau, which have been declared contrary to European legislation by the ECJ. I therefore vote for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ International aviation relations between Member States and third countries have traditionally been governed by bilateral agreements on air transport services. In 2002, the Court of Justice of the European Union ruled that the usual naming clauses in Member States' bilateral agreements on air transport services violate EU law.  Those clauses allow third countries to refuse, withdraw or suspend the licences or authorisations of an airline appointed by a Member State, but in which that Member State or its nationals do not have a significant ownership stake or over which they have no actual control.  This has been found to discriminate against EU airlines established within the territory of a Member State but owned or controlled by nationals of other Member States. This is against Article 49 of the European Parliament. a Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union which guarantees nationals of a Member State who have exercised their freedom of establishment that they will be treated in the host Member State the same as nationals of that Member State.  There are also some other issues, such as competition, where amendments to existing provisions in bilateral air transport services agreements between Member States and third countries should ensure compliance with EU law. For these reasons, I give my consent to the conclusion of this agreement.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Relations between Member States and third countries in the field of aviation have been regulated through bilateral air service agreements. On the basis of CJEU decisions, these agreements were considered to infringe EU law, as they provide for situations of discrimination against EU carriers which are established in the territory of a Member State but are owned and are under the control of nationals of other Member States. This agreement (non-agreementable) replaces the provisions of the current 15 bilateral air service agreements between Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. Taken together, these agreements are part of the logic of the ongoing monopolistic concentration in the aviation sector in the EU. They serve this objective, as all EU legislation for the sector serves. A sector dominated by five major groups: Lufthansa, Iberia-British Airways and Air France-KLM, plus the two low-cost, Ryanair and Easyjet. The companies that still resist outside this lot, especially if, like TAP, they are flag airlines, and especially if they are still public, are to dismantle, disappear in the long term, being absorbed – their business, assets and routes – by the giants of the sector. A deeply indest of national interests, which we reject and fight. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support my colleague Dieter-Lebrecht Koch's recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of an Agreement concerning certain aspects of air traffic services between the European Union and Macao. The agreement will allow all EU carriers to benefit from their right of establishment and will prohibit distortion procedures. I agree with all aspects of the Agreement replacing certain provisions in the 15 existing bilateral air traffic services agreements concluded between EU Member States and Macao. Consequently, I give a positive opinion on the conclusion of this Agreement.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the field of international air transport, relations between EU Member States and third countries are governed by bilateral air service agreements. The traditional designation clauses allowed a third country to refuse, revoke or suspend the authorisations or licences of an air carrier designated by a Member State, but of which a significant proportion of the ownership, and effective control, did not apply to that Member State or its nationals.  The Court of Justice of the EU, in 2002, considered this practice to be discrimination against EU carriers established on the territory of a Member State but which are owned or controlled by nationals of other Member States. The Commission therefore considered it necessary to negotiate the agreement replacing certain provisions of the existing 15 bilateral air service agreements concluded between the Member States of the European Union and the Special Administrative Region of Macao, part of the People's Republic of China.  In order to ensure a more efficient air transport market, I voted in favour of this proposal for a recommendation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I have approved the signing of an agreement replacing certain provisions of the 15 existing bilateral air services agreements between the Member States of the European Union and the Macao Special Administrative Region.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 International relations between Member States and third countries in the field of aviation have traditionally been regulated through bilateral air service agreements. According to a judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union in 2002, the traditional designation clauses included in bilateral air service agreements concluded by the Member States infringe EU law. They allow third countries to reject, withdraw or suspend the licences or authorisations of an air carrier which has been designated by a Member State but whose considerable share of the capital does not belong to that Member State or to its nationals and whose effective control is not exercised by them. I have approved this report which aims to replace certain provisions of the current 15 bilateral air service agreements between Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. Essentially, this agreement will allow all carriers to benefit from the right of establishment and will improve aspects such as security, taxation, as well as competition rules.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim is to grant all EU air carriers non-discriminatory access to links between the EU and third countries (in this case the Macao Administrative Region) and to make bilateral air service agreements between Member States and third countries in accordance with EU law.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Macau Special Administrative Region on certain aspects of air services between the two parties. This agreement replaces certain provisions of the fifteen bilateral air services agreements concluded between Member States of the Union and the Macau Special Administrative Region, after the Court of Justice of the European Union declared that the traditional designation clauses of the Member States' bilateral air services agreements infringe EU law. Those clauses allow a third country to refuse, revoke or suspend the permits or authorisations of an airline designated by a Member State, but whose effective ownership and control do not correspond essentially to that Member State or its nationals. That circumstance is considered to constitute discrimination against Union airlines established in the territory of one Member State, but whose ownership and control correspond to nationals of other Member States.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement between the European Union and Macao was signed on 23 November 2013. To conclude this agreement, the Council needs the approval of the European Parliament. In accordance with Article 99 and Article 108, paragraph 7, of its regulation, the European Parliament votes in a single vote, which it did yesterday.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in the light of the judgment of the European Court of Justice and the conclusions of the Transport Council. The Commission has agreed on an agreement replacing some of the existing provisions of the 15 bilateral air services agreements between the existing EU Member States and the Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, Macao. They also include a prohibition on anti-competitive practices, the establishment of a level playing field for carriers and their mandatory compliance.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Relations between the Member States of the European Union and third countries in the field of aviation have been regulated through bilateral air service agreements. However, according to a judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union of 2002, the traditional designation clauses included in the bilateral agreements mentioned infringe EU law as third countries were allowed to reject, withdraw or suspend the licences or authorisations of a European air carrier which is established in the territory of a particular Member State although their effective control/ownership is carried out by a company owned by nationals of a different Member State. After the Commission has negotiated this Agreement, which replaces some provisions of the current 15 existing bilateral air service agreements between member states and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, I voted in favour of this recommendation as it will aim at complying with Article 49 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China on certain aspects of air services. This text is part of the Commission's negotiation of an agreement that replaces certain provisions of 15 existing bilateral air services agreements between EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. These agreements mainly relate to provisions relating to the designation clause, security and taxation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. On behalf of the Union, the Commission has negotiated an agreement on certain aspects of air services with the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China which replaces certain provisions of existing bilateral air services agreements.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2003, the Council authorized the Commission to start negotiations with third countries in order to replace certain provisions in bilateral agreements with an agreement at EU level, which I consider positive. The EU-Macao Agreement on certain aspects of air services is one of the outcome of these negotiations. I voted for it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, the European Parliament concludes the agreement replacing some provisions of the 15 bilateral air service agreements concluded between the Member States of the European Union and the Macao Special Administrative Region. It relates in particular to the designation clause, certain provisions on security and taxation and the prohibition of all anticompetitive practices. These amendments will also simplify the current legislation. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as it will give all EU air-carriers access to routes between the EU and Macao without discrimination. Agreements like this are great for the EU's airline industry and bring bilateral air service agreements between Member States and third countries in line with the law of the Union, which has been developed by all of the Member States - and therefore in line with all the values of the UK. Today's vote will allow for a helpful agreement on the development and regulation of air transport routes.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The content of this resolution is an agreement of the EU and the Macao special administrative region (China) on certain aspects of air services. As this agreement has a positive impact for the airlines of both the EU and Macao, I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recommendation on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on certain aspects of air traffic services between the European Union and the Government of the Macaa Special Administrative Area of the People's Republic of China, referring to the 2002 decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union that the usual naming clauses in Member States' bilateral agreements on air transport services violate EU law.  These clauses discriminate against EU air carriers established within the territory of a Member State but owned or controlled by nationals of other Member States. It is also important to stress that amendments to existing provisions in bilateral agreements on air transport services between Member States and third countries should ensure compliance with EU law and thus protect competition. The Commission has therefore concluded an Agreement replacing certain provisions in 15 existing bilateral air services agreements between EU Member States and the Government of the Macaa Special Administrative Area of the People's Republic of China. The main aspects of the agreement include the exercise of the right of establishment to all CARRIERS in the EU, guarantees safety provisions in bilateral agreements applicable in cases where regulatory control over an airline is exercised by a Member State which has not appointed that airline, the taxation of aircraft fuel and the prohibition of distortions of competition.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the conclusion of an agreement on certain aspects of air services between the EU and Macao, as this agreement is intended to replace the provisions of the 15 bilateral air services agreements in force between Member States and Macao. The Commission negotiated this agreement in response to a decision of the Court of Justice of the EU which established that the usual designation provisions in Member States' bilateral air services agreements are contrary to EU law. This would constitute discrimination against EU carriers established in the territory of a Member State but owned and controlled by nationals of other Member States. The Macao Agreement is thus intended to regulate a number of aspects of air services, such as the provisions on the determination, safety, taxes and compatibility of the competition rules. For example, in safety matters, the provisions will apply to cases where regulatory control over an air carrier is exercised by a Member State other than that whose designation it bears. The provisions also apply to the taxation of aviation fuel and also prohibit anti-competitive practices. The agreement was signed as early as 2013 and requires the consent of the European Parliament to approve it. I agree with its conclusion and hope that it will bring more legal certainty to the European aviation industry.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Commission has concluded an agreement with the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China on certain aspects of air transport. Normally, international aviation relations between Member States and third countries are governed by bilateral agreements. In 2002, the European Court of Justice ruled that certain clauses in these bilateral aviation agreements are contrary to the acquis, as there could be discrimination against certain EU carriers (for example, if they are established in the territory of a particular Member State but are owned and controlled by nationals of other Member States). In order to ensure equal treatment of nationals of the Member States and, in general, compliance with the acquis, they decided to amend/supplement the existing provisions of bilateral agreements. The Commission has negotiated an agreement with Macao, replacing some of the provisions of the existing 15 bilateral air transport agreements concluded between EU Member States and Macao. The main aspects of the agreement are as follows: an EU designation clause allowing all EU carriers to exercise their right of establishment; safety provision; a provision on the taxation of aviation fuel; article prohibiting anti-competitive practices. For this reason, I voted in favour of the recommendation and thus gave a positive opinion on the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposed agreement replacing certain provisions in the existing bilateral air service agreements concluded between the EU and Macao, in order to allow equal treatment of all European airlines operating in that country and compliance with competition rules. Bilateral air service agreements between a Member State and a third country must include an 'EU designation clause' which recognises that the terms of the agreement also apply to all EU airlines and not just to the airlines of the Member State in question, in accordance with the rules of the internal market and the right of establishment.  According to the "traditional" designation clauses, the third country could refuse, revoke or suspend authorisations or licences if a significant proportion of the ownership and effective control of the carrier did not come under the Member State of designation. The text voted on today therefore eliminates discrimination against European carriers established on the territory of one Member State but which are owned or controlled by nationals of other Member States, thus bringing bilateral agreements with Macao back into line with European law.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Member States and third countries traditionally regulate international aviation relations through bilateral agreements on air transport services. The agreement between the Member States of the European Union and the Government of the Macau Special Administrative Area of the People's Republic of China contains certain clauses that do not comply with EU law and the Commission concluded the Agreement, signed on 23 November 2013, which replaces certain provisions in 15 existing bilateral air traffic services agreements.  These clauses concern appointments, security, taxation and compliance with competition rules. I support the recommendation and consider it essential to ensure compliance with EU law by amending or supplementing existing provisions in bilateral agreements.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. The objectives of such agreements are to give all European Union air carriers non-discriminatory access to routes between the European Union and third countries, and to bring bilateral air service agreements between Member States and third countries in line with the law of the Union. Today’s vote will allow for a helpful agreement on the development and regulation of air transport routes.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Member States and Macao have concluded bilateral agreements on air services containing commissions contrary to EUROPEAN Union legislation. Therefore, such commissions should be fully harmonised with EU laws in order to create a solid legal basis for air traffic services between the Union and Macao and to maintain the continuity of such services. It is important to note that this agreement will not increase the total volume of air traffic between the Union and Macao or affect the balance between Union and Macao air carriers or alter the commissions of existing bilateral air services agreements concerning the right of travel. I support my colleague Koch's recommendation on the EU-Macao Agreement on certain aspects of air traffic services. I think it is positive that the commissions of air services agreements will only be amended to the extent necessary to ensure compliance with EU laws. I believe that this Agreement is the most effective instrument for harmonising all existing bilateral air services agreements concluded between Member States and Macao, as well as for simplifying overall EU legislation.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it will help make air transport between the EU and Macao more efficient.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an Agreement on certain aspects of air transport between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. The agreement will upgrade and update the existing 15 bilateral air transport agreements between Member States and the Macao Special Administration. The new agreement extends safety provisions also in cases where regulatory oversight of an air carrier is not carried out by the Member State which designated the air carrier and introduces an article prohibiting anti-competitive practices.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against, because the Agreement gives the Union super powers, undermines the sovereignty of the Member States and once again serves the interests of the major airlines.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 International air relations were based on bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries until the 2002 ruling of the European Court of Justice, which ruled that bilateral air agreements infringed EU law. Accordingly, the European Commission has renegotiated the agreements between the EU and Macau. The new agreement was signed on 23 November 2013, but requires the consent of the European Parliament. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I therefore supported the entry into force of the agreement as soon as possible.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air transport is one of the areas where international cooperation is essential for the proper conduct of current activities. The European Union has pursued greater coordination of air services in recent years, both in the territories of the Member States and with third countries. Bilateral agreements with various states have been concluded in this latter direction, but a number of problems have remained concerning discrimination between air carriers of some EU states established in the territory of other states and carriers in those states. Special agreements have therefore been concluded between the EU and third-party entities, which avoid this type of discrimination and regulate a level playing field of safety, competition and taxation. One of these third entities is the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. By virtue of traditionally good relations with this territorial entity, the EU has negotiated an agreement that replaces the 15 bilateral agreements previously adopted. The European Parliament is the forum that will enshrine the entry into force of these agreements that are very necessary for air services. For this reason, I support the adoption of this document in its current form.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I agree with Mr Koch on this issue. International relations in the field of air transport between Member States and third countries have so far been governed by bilateral air services agreements. The European Court of Justice ruled in 2002 that the traditional designation clauses in member states' bilateral air services agreements were contrary to EU law. They allow a third country to reject, withdraw or suspend the licences or authorisations of an air carrier that has been designated by a Member State, but whose ownership and effective control do not essentially belong to that Member State or its nationals.  The Court found that this constituted discrimination against EU carriers based in one Member State, but who are detained and controlled by nationals of other Member States. This is a violation of Article 49 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which guarantees nationals of Member States who have exercised their freedom of establishment the same treatment in the host Member State as that granted to nationals of that Member State.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution to conclude the agreement on certain aspects of air services between the EU and Macao. The negotiations aimed at replacing the existing 15 bilateral air agreements from EU Member States with Macao. The scope of the agreement covers the right of establishment of all EU carriers, safety rules and taxation of aviation fuel. This agreement will eventually allow compliance with the EU competition law by preventing any discrimination against EU air carriers. In addition, the Asian air market is growing and the perspective for the EU airlines to benefit from it must to be encouraged if we want to maintain our leading position in the air sector. While the European Commission is seeking mandates to negotiate new comprehensive air agreements on behalf of the EU, I find it of utmost importance to finalise the pending negotiations to unblock the development of EU airlines.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported an Agreement replacing certain provisions in 15 existing bilateral air traffic services agreements concluded between the Member States of the European Union and the Government of the Macaa Special Administrative Area of the People's Republic of China. The naming, security, taxation and compliance clauses of competition rules are the main aspects of this Agreement.  The naming clause allows all carriers in the European Union to benefit from the right of establishment, while the safety provisions in bilateral agreements apply in cases where regulatory control over an airline is exercised by a Member State which has not appointed that airline. I would also emphasise the importance of the article relating to the taxation of aircraft fuels, which is in line with the Council Directive on the restructuring of community energy and electricity taxation systems and the importance of an article prohibiting distortion procedures.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement on certain aspects of air services between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, as the Commission has thus negotiated an Agreement replacing certain provisions of the existing 15 bilateral air transport agreements between EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. On behalf of the Union, the Commission has negotiated an agreement on certain aspects of air services with the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China which replaces certain provisions of existing bilateral air services agreements.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to bring into line with European law the pre-existing air services agreements between the countries of the European Union and Macao, which have previously been declared contrary to European law by the European Court of Justice. This update of the air agreements between the EU and Macao is beneficial for both sides. So I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 International aviation relations between Member States and third countries have so far been governed by bilateral air transport agreements. In 2002, the Court of Justice of the European Union ruled that the traditional designation clauses of member states' bilateral air transport agreements infringed EU law. The Commission has therefore negotiated an agreement replacing some of the provisions of the 15 bilateral air transport agreements between the Member States of the Union and the Macau Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. The Agreement was signed on 23 November 2013. In order to conclude this agreement, the Council needs the agreement of the European Parliament. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. On behalf of the Union, the Commission has negotiated an agreement on certain aspects of air services with the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China which replaces certain provisions of existing bilateral air services agreements.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ On the basis of decisions of the European Court of Justice and the Transport Council, the Commission is mandated to negotiate with third countries agreements on air services (‘Open Skies’), coordinating EU external air transport relationships and bringing bilateral agreements by single Member States into the EU—line. After a series of other agreements, the Commission has now achieved such agreement with Macao. The main aspects are the avoidance of discrimination between air carriers (designation clause) and obligatory commercial agreements between airlines. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the conclusion of the Agreement on specific aspects of air services between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China. The international aviation relations between Member States and third countries have traditionally been governed by bilateral air services agreements, which were found discriminatory and in breach of the EU law by the European Court of Justice in 2002. The Commission has, hence, negotiated the Agreement replacing certain provisions in the existing 15 bilateral air services agreements concluded between EU Member States and Macao Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China with the aim of prohibiting anti-competitive practices.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. By this document, the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of the EU-Macao agreement replacing certain provisions of the 15 bilateral air services agreements concluded between Member States of the Union and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China concerning the designation clause, air safety, taxation and compatibility with competition rules. We are talking about a consensus and beneficial agreement for the Union, so I consider voting in its favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this agreement because it aims to give all European airlines access to the air routes between the European Union and third countries in a non-discriminatory manner. In addition, this agreement also aims to bring the bilateral agreements between Member States and third countries into line with European law.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This agreement, which was signed on 23 November 2013, aims to replace certain provisions of the bilateral air services agreements currently in force between some Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region in the People's Republic of China.  It is a standard trade agreement for the ultra-liberalized and ultra-competitive air transport sector with this curious region of China, Macau, which is, in fact, a tax haven. Moreover, in accordance with Article 99 and Article 108, paragraph 7, of the European Parliament's regulation, MEPs can only vote in a single vote for or against this agreement, and do not have the right to make amendments, i.e. to make amendments to the text. It was these elements that determined my vote on this agreement, to say the least, astounding.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement (non-emendable) replaces the provisions of the current 15 bilateral air service agreements between Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. Taken together, these agreements are part of the logic of the ongoing monopolistic concentration in the aviation sector in the EU. They serve this objective, as all EU legislation for the sector serves. A sector dominated by five major groups: Lufthansa, Iberia-British Airways and Air France-KLM, plus the two low-cost Ryanair and Easyjet.  The companies that still resist outside this lot, especially if, like TAP, they are flag airlines, and especially if they are still public, are to dismantle, disappear in the long term, being absorbed – their business, assets and routes – by the giants of the sector. This is a deeply harmful path of national interests, which we reject and fight. We voted against it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The conclusion of an air transport agreement with the Macao Special Administrative Region in order to replace the existing 15 bilateral air services agreements with this Special Administrative Region and thus to put an end to the existing discrimination that exists against the Member States is to be welcomed.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China on certain aspects of air services. The agreement on certain aspects of air services relates to the simplification of existing legislation. International aviation relations between Member States and third countries are traditionally governed by bilateral air services agreements. The Court of Justice of the European Union ruled in 2002 that the traditional designation clauses in the Member States are in breach of EU law. The Commission has now negotiated an agreement between the EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, replacing the existing air services agreements. The new clauses include issues such as the regulation of safeguards, taxation and compatibility with competition rules. This resolution is an example of simplification of EU legislation and has my support. That is why I voted in favour of this agreement in plenary.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the EP Recommendation on the EU-Macao Agreement on certain aspects of air services. The recommendation follows that the Commission negotiated the agreement replacing certain provisions of the 15 existing bilateral air services agreements concluded between the EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. This agreement was signed on 23 November 2013 and, for its conclusion, the Council needed the approval of the EP.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – I supported the Agreement on certain aspects of air transport between the European Union and the Government of the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. It will replace and supplement certain provisions of the existing 15 bilateral air service agreements between EU Member States and the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, which were contrary to the EU acquis and the principles of free establishment, the principle of equal treatment in a Member State and the provisions on competition.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This retrospectively extends the period to which minimum standard rates of VAT apply; accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2006\112 EC codified, in a single act, all the changes made in the field of VAT at European level. This directive has made it possible to harmonise the minimum level of taxable tax between Member States, anchoring it at a percentage of 15%, thus ensuring uniform tax treatment among European citizens. I believe, however, that the provision for a minimum level of VAT common to the Member States must also be accompanied by the identification of a maximum threshold, which will be the limit for the national authorities. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. Value Added Tax (VAT) is one of the main taxes in the internal market, and is partly a very relevant source of funding for the Union.  That is why I voted in favour of extending the current minimum rate of 15%, so that in the meantime the European Parliament and the Council have time to consider the new proposal for a VAT Directive, which is very complex and where we will have to tackle a new anti-fraud strategy, in particular, but not just the cross-border one.  In particular, I am particularly pleased that Parliament has supported extending the extension to 31 December 2018, rather than 31 December 2017, as proposed by the Commission, which is the result of an amendment tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation. This achievement is yet another sign of the added value of parliaments, so as a consultation procedure, I hope that the Council will support the decision.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because this legal framework establishing the minimum VAT of 15% at European level creates many problems, but due to the lack of definition of the Commission's new proposal, it is necessary to extend that scheme for the sake of legal certainty. In 2017 the Commission will propose the new IVE regime which is likely to delve defund on the regressive aspects of that tax by trying to link it further with the framework of economic governance. This regime gives the European Commission the power to set the reduced rates, on basic necessities, which has created many problems. However, the specific recommendations of economic governance insist on the transfer of direct to indirect taxation, with the clear intention of increasing inequalities. That is why, despite the need for extension, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I spoke out against this report on the standard rate of VAT. The aim of the text was to extend by two years the application by Member States of a standard VAT rate of a minimum of 15%. Pending proposals on the final VAT regime planned by the Commission for January 2016, this period of application would be renewed for the sixth time. I cannot support a text to give the Commission the power to impose a minimum tax rate on Member States. This fiscal union would further weaken the sovereignty of national authorities already condemned to meet Brussels' budgetary requirements.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The background to this report is that the European Parliament is being consulted on the extension of the current VAT regime which expired on 31st of December last year. Our party is opposed to minimum rates of tax rates being set by the EU as this fundamentally undermines a Members State’s national sovereignty. A key point worth noting is that the VAT Action Plan is seeking to abandon the origin principle (taxation where goods and services are produced) and replace it with a destination principle (taxation where goods and services are consumed). For consumers, the destination principle favours national production over imports as imports would in principle become more expensive. For export countries with a surplus on the current account balance, the origin principle is preferable. For deficit countries the destination principle is preferable. Sinn Féin would have a number of concerns in relation to these proposals, however, there are other aspects of the action plan, which we would be supportive of, such as Member States being provided with greater scope for VAT powers domestically, which seems to be one of the options on the table. Therefore, on the basis of the action plan and the positive and negative provisions contained within the EP consultation report, we decided to abstain.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. In 2016, the Commission will publish a set of proposals on the final VAT regime for intra-EU trade. Pending decisions on the final VAT regime, the Commission therefore proposes to change the period of application of the minimum VAT rate by extending it until 31 December 2017. I voted against this amendment which gives the Commission the power to impose a minimum tax rate on Member States.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report retrospectively extends the period to which the minimum standard rate of VAT applies to 31st December 2018. Currently 1% of all VAT collected in the United Kingdom is creamed off the top by European Union. The EU considers UK VAT as an "own resource". I believe that Member States should be able to set their own VAT rates in line with their own requirements and individual economies.   The European Union and its VAT regulations are putting small businesses in my constituency and all over the country out of business. Businesses who want to trade with other EU countries must obtain a VAT Registration Number (even if below the threshold for VAT in the UK), travel through the minefield of whether they have any allowable expenditure that can be offset directly against non-UK sales and submit a cross-border VAT Refund Application, complete a quarterly VAT return and a quarterly VATMOSS return. Small businesses are sunk by the European Union´s VAT regulations and leave big business with a huge competitive advantage. British consumers pay extra every day for the added cost EU VAT rules add to our everyday purchases.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, as it maintains the principle of a standard minimum VAT rate of 15% over a three-year period. This measure ensures the establishment and functioning of the internal market and avoids distortions of competition.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
