text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to prevent the standard rate from being below 15% between 1 January 2016 and 31 December 2018. Given that the VAT rate currently applied by all Member States is higher than 15%, the current fixed minimum standard rate of 15% also guarantees member states room for manoeu state, as it allows for VAT reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate by extending the VAT base and limiting the possibility of reduced rates.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Pending the Commission's decisions on the final VAT regime, and after extending the "VAT Directive" five times, which provided that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015, the normal VAT rate could not be less than 15%, the aim was to vote on the extension of this minimum VAT rate for intra-EU trade for two years. This is a proposal that I could not accept in that it symbolizes the Commission's tendency to overstep its prerogatives, as here by arrogating itself the power to decide on a minimum tax rate. Taxation must remain a competence of the Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report will enable better international regulatory cooperation, transparency, accountability and democratization. The mandate of each organization should be clarified, as well as the ways in which they operate and are funded, including voluntary contributions, gifts and donations, to ensure the legality of decisions and the absence of special interests. This sixth extension maintains the existing situation, which is satisfactory, and guarantees legal certainty to stakeholders, while allowing the final VAT regime for intra-EU trade to enter into force on the basis of a revised set of rules for normal and reduced VAT rates. The VAT Directive stipulates that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015, the normal rate cannot be less than 15%. Pending decisions on the final form of the final scheme, MEPs agree with the Commission's proposal to retroactively maintain the principle of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15%. However, they propose that the current provisions be extended for a period of three years, i.e. until 31 December 2018 (instead of 31 December 2017 as proposed by the Commission).

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 92/77/EEC established a temporary system which introduced a system of minimum rates from 1 January 1993, thus making it impossible for the Council to adopt the measures proposed by the Commission for the establishment of a definitive system of tax harmonisation.  The legislation, which has been extended several times, provides that a Member State may not set a standard rate below 15%, thereby ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market and avoiding possible distortions resulting from competition in tax matters.  Since 2011, the Commission has announced, in a communication on the future of VAT, the development of a plan to abandon the current mechanism and establish definitive rules on value added tax. Pending the implementation of this project, I have decided to vote in favour of the Simon report, which extends the existing provisions until December 2018.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In this vote, we abstained in this vote extending the minimum rate of VAT to 15% pending a commission proposal. While we consider indirect taxes to be regressive and should be reduced, in this case this is a formal decision pending the Commission's presentation of its final proposal to be discussed.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work in this report on the proposal for a Directive on the common system of VAT, as regards the duration of the obligation to respect a minimum standard rate. I support the rapporteur's proposal , which is awaiting the decisions of the European Commission — to retroactively maintain the principle of a minimum normal VAT rate of 15% and to propose the extension of existing systems for three years.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I rejected this report, which tends to give the European Commission ever more prerogatives in terms of tax rates, to the detriment of the Member States. The report aims to extend for two years the obligation for Member States to set the standard VAT rate at a minimum of 15%. Our nations, because of the directive on the common value-added tax system, are therefore deprived of the opportunity to use essential fiscal leverage according to their national situation. This measure is only a temporary means of depriving States of part of their tax competence, until the Commission's proposal for a set of proposals on the final VAT regime for intra-EU trade. There is still time to prevent this tax harmonisation.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are many critical issues in the report and I do not agree with some of the points, so I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. •u2012 Fundamentally technical report, developed under the simplified procedure. Its sole purpose is to extend the ordinary minimum VAT rate of 15% until 31 December 2017, where the Commission introduces a new Directive.  I voted for it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report amending Directive 2006/112/EC on the common system of value added tax as regards the duration of the obligation to apply the minimum standard rate. The VAT Directive provides that for the period from 1 January 2011 to 31 December 2015, the standard rate may not be less than 15%. The minimum rates in the field of VAT are based on the fact that the rate of VAT below the minimum threshold for cross-border trade and distance selling is still applicable in the country of origin and not in the country of destination. Therefore, in all Member States, a minimum standard rate, as is currently the case, measures are being taken to protect the proper functioning of the internal market. In this context, until decisions have been taken on the final form of the system, the European Parliament's rapporteur agrees with the Commission's proposal to maintain and apply retroactively the principle of a minimum standard rate of VAT of 15% and to propose an extension of the current rules for a period of three years (until 31 December 2018).

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards VAT, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that, in the case of cross-border purchases not exceeding a certain threshold, VAT is still payable in the country of origin and not in the country of destination. Therefore, the minimum standard rate applicable in all Member States, which is still in force, serves as a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market. Given that all Member States currently impose a general rate of taxation above 15%, the current legislation on a minimum standard rate of at least 15% also gives Member States room for manoe margin for reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate, which could widen the VAT base and limit the use of reduced rates. In view of these circumstances, and subject to decisions on the final form of the definitive system, I agree with the Commission's proposal, I voted in favour of the report, which provides for the retroactively preserving the principle of a minimum general rate of VAT of 15% and proposing to extend the current measures by two years.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The old Value Added Tax Directive, which was in force from 1 January 2011 to 31 December 2015, provided that the rate of value added tax should not be less than 15 per cent. Such legislation is necessary to establish and function the internal market and to avoid distortions of competition, which means that cross-border shopping and distance selling below a certain threshold are still charged at the place of origin and not at the place of destination. Therefore, the uniform application of the minimum rate of value added tax in all Member States is a useful measure to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market. The Commission is already working on an action plan setting out the guidelines and main features of the definitive VAT regime for intra-EU trade. As decisions on the final version of the scheme have not yet been taken, I voted in favour of extending and maintaining the 15% minimum general VAT rate for the period up to 31 December 2017, allowing for a more in-depth debate on VAT rates in the light of the European Commission's future action plan.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the renewal of the provision of Directive 92/77/EEC, which provides for a system of minimum rates in which the standard rate could not be less than 15% in a given Member State, until 31 December 2018 would ensure legal certainty for interested parties and would allow a wider discussion on VAT rates in relation to the Commission's upcoming VAT Action Plan.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The VAT Directive has established that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015 the standard rate may not be less than 15%. This provision, based on Article 113 TFEI, provides that the Council shall adopt provisions concerning the harmonization of legislation relating to turnover taxes to the extent that such harmonisation is necessary to ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market and to avoid distortions of competition.  Today we need a time frame in which the principle of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15% is maintained, extending the existing legislation for three years (until 31 December 2018) in order to ensure legal certainty for interested parties and allow for a wider discussion on VAT rates in relation to the forthcoming VAT action plan by the European Union.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the two-year extension of the Common Value Added Tax Directive, which states that the standard VAT rate set by Member States cannot be less than 15%. The Commission's proposal is part of tax harmonisation within the European Union. This fiscal union would further weaken the sovereignty of national authorities already condemned to meet Brussels' budgetary requirements. That is why I objected to this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application of a minimum standard rate in all Member States is intended to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market. The minimum rates are justified by the fact that VAT applied at the place of origin, rather than at the place of destination, still applies to cross-border trade and distance sales below a certain threshold. The Value Added Tax Directive therefore provides that the standard rate shall not be less than 15 % by 31 December 2015. The proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC on the common system of value added tax, as regards the duration of the obligation to comply with the minimum standard rate, provides for the retroactive maintenance of the principle of a minimum value of 15% for the standard rate of VAT, proposing to extend the current provisions by three years. I was in favour of this report because I consider it necessary to apply a minimum standard quota to ensure the protection of internal markets.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure extends by one year (2018) the normal "minimum" VAT system (15%) goods and services subject to it. Against, for all possible cases of the insertion of certain primary goods.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. Value Added Tax (VAT) is one of the main taxes in the internal market, and is partly a very relevant source of funding for the Union.  That is why I voted in favour of extending the current minimum rate of 15%, so that in the meantime the European Parliament and the Council have time to consider the new proposal for a VAT Directive, which is very complex and where we will have to tackle a new anti-fraud strategy, in particular, but not just the cross-border one.  In particular, I am particularly pleased that Parliament has supported extending the extension to 31 December 2018, rather than 31 December 2017, as proposed by the Commission, which is the result of an amendment tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation. This achievement is yet another sign of the added value of parliaments, so as a consultation procedure, I hope that the Council will support the decision.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. In 1993, Member States agreed on a minimum VAT rate of 15%. No EU Member State has the right to fall below this threshold. This provision is particularly important for the proper functioning of the internal market. This avoids excessive unfair tax competition at the VAT level. The provision for a minimum VAT rate has already been extended five times. It was important to renew this measure. However, the crucial need for transparency and harmonization in the area of taxation is to be recognized. The minimum VAT rate is a start, tax harmonisation must become the objective. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC on the common system of value added tax, in relation to the duration of the obligation to apply a minimum standard rate, as I consider a minimum standard rate applied in all Member States, as it is now, to be a useful guarantee for the proper functioning of the internal market. The current provisions also provide room for manoeuvre for the Member States.  I therefore agree with the rapporteur on the Commission's proposal to retroactively maintain the principle of a minimum standard rate of 15% and I welcome the extension of the existing provisions until 2018. In addition, this ensures legal certainty for interested parties and allows for a wider discussion of VAT rates.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The background to this report is that the European Parliament is being consulted on the extension of the current VAT regime, which expired on 31 December last year. My party is opposed to minimum rates of tax rates being set by the EU as this fundamentally undermines a Members States national sovereignty. A key point worth noting is that the VAT Action Plan is seeking to abandon the origin principle (taxation where goods and services are produced) and replace it with a destination principle (taxation where goods and services are consumed). For consumers, the destination principle favours national production over imports as imports would in principle become more expensive. For export countries with a surplus on the current account balance, the origin principle is preferable. For deficit countries the destination principle is preferable. Sinn Fein would have a number of concerns in relation to these proposals; however, there are other aspects of the action plan which we would be supportive of, such as Member States being provided with greater scope for VAT powers domestically, which seems to be one of the options on the table. Therefore, on the basis of the action plan and the positive and negative provisions contained within the EP consultation report, I decided to abstain.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report to maintain the minimum rate of Value Added Tax at 15% for all of the Member States until the end of the year 2018. Such a measure is needed to avoid unfair competition until new measures are agreed. This will ensure a fair minimum that will ensure a good functioning of the internal market

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to abstain from the amendment to Directive 2006/112/EC aimed at extending the application of the harmonised minimum level of Value Added Tax from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. Adaptation does not create any problems whatsoever, but it is an incomplete provision since adaptation is not accompanied by a maximum threshold which cannot be exceeded by the various national authorities.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The harmonisation of European tax laws has already led to some satisfactory results. These rules have, in fact, restricted the possibilities for companies to carry out cross-border transactions in search of lower VAT rates, and curbed distortions of competition between Member States. Although there is still no unified VAT system within the EU, the current directive is a useful guarantee to ensure fair competition in the European market by setting a minimum rate of 15 % common to all Member States. I voted in favour of the transitional measure extending the minimum rate until 2017 in order to prevent, pending the revision of European legislation, the divergences between the VAT rates applied by the Member States leading to structural imbalances within the Union, leading to distortions of competition in certain sectors of the economy, can be accentuated.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, since the setting of minimum rates in the field of VAT is justified by the fact that in cross-border purchases and distance sales below a threshold VAT of the place of origin and not of the place of destination still applies. Therefore, the application of a minimum standard rate in all Member States — as is currently the case — is a useful guarantee for the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it aims to establish a definitive system of tax harmonisation. I believe that this is a step towards a stronger European Union, because a minimum standard rate applied in all Member States, as is currently the case, is a useful guarantee for the proper functioning of the internal market. That is why I voted in favour of extending this provision, for a more united Europe not only on paper but also on facts, especially given that the government is currently deciding to lower the VAT rate on truffles thanks to pressure from the Commission.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This initiative will create directions for future work leading on from the success since the 2011 Communication. That Communication suggested that the origin principle be abandoned and detailed several ways of ensuring taxation at destination. The new action plan by the Commission aims to detail the main parts of the definitive VAT regime for intra-EU trade. It will also illustrate the reform envisaged to existing rules on VAT rates, creating a definitive regime characterised by the destination principle. This proposal would retroactively include the principle of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15%, the current arrangements would also be kept in place for a further three years until 31 December 2018. This harmonisation is essential for functioning competition within the internal market.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This retrospectively extends the period to which minimum standard rates of VAT apply; accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with my colleague Simon in retroactively maintaining the principle of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15% and proposing the extension of the existing provisions for three years (until 31 December 2018). This time frame would ensure legal certainty for interested parties and allow for a wider discussion on VAT rates in relation to the forthcoming VAT action plan.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Directive 92/77/EEC introduced a system of minimum rates. It stipulated that from 1 January 1993 to 31 December 1996, the standard rate could not be set lower than 15% in any Member State. This provision has been extended five times and applied until 31 December 2015. The purpose of the current proposal is to extend the application of the actual minimum standard rate of 15% in Member States, for a period of two years, retroactively from 1st of January 2016.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because this legal framework establishing the minimum VAT of 15% at European level creates many problems, but due to the lack of definition of the Commission's new proposal, it is necessary to extend that scheme for the sake of legal certainty. In 2017 the Commission will propose the new IVE regime which is likely to delve defund on the regressive aspects of that tax by trying to link it further with the framework of economic governance. This regime gives the European Commission the power to set the reduced rates, on basic necessities, which has created many problems. However, the specific recommendations of economic governance insist on the transfer of direct to indirect taxation, with the clear intention of increasing inequalities. That is why, despite the need for extension, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur supports the Commission's proposal to maintain the minimum value of 15% for the standard VAT rate and proposes to extend the current provisions until 31 December 2018. I voted to allow Member States to carry out VAT reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate. As is the case in all Member States, a standard minimum rate provides useful protection for the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Directive 92/77/EEC introduced a system of minimum VAT rates. According to its content, from 1 January 1993 to 31 December 1996, the basic rate could not be less than 15%. The period of validity of that provision was extended five times. The last validity period expired on 31 December 2015.  In the current proposal, the Commission proposes to retroactively maintain the current requirement on EU countries to apply a minimum basic VAT rate of 15%. The proposal will therefore have no impact on tax rates. The Commission proposes that the rule be extended by 2 years, i.e. until 31 December 2017.  Due to the nature of the document, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the rapporteur's idea that extending the deadline for maintaining a minimum value of 15% for the standard VAT rate until 31 December 2018 allows for a more comprehensive debate on VAT rates in the context of the future VAT action plan. It is beneficial for the EU to establish guidelines for future activities and characteristics of the definitive VAT regime for intra-EU transactions, in order to adapt existing rules to a definitive regime characterised by the point of destination.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This codecision report proposes a two-year extension of the minimum VAT rate in the Member States, currently at 15%. Considering that, within the prerogatives of the European Union, the establishment of a minimum VAT rate in the Member States is necessary in order to ensure a fair effort on the part of all European citizens, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text extending the current VAT provisions, pending the future action plan and in order to guarantee the legal security of the stakeholders. The current text stipulates that the normal rate cannot be less than 15% in any Member State. However, it is important that the action plan be presented as soon as possible in order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and to combat fraud effectively.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards VAT, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that, in the case of cross-border purchases not exceeding a certain threshold, VAT is still payable in the country of origin and not in the country of destination. Therefore, the minimum standard rate applicable in all Member States, which is still in force, serves as a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market. Given that all Member States currently impose a general rate of taxation above 15%, the current legislation on a minimum standard rate of at least 15% also gives Member States room for manoe margin for reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate, which could widen the VAT base and limit the use of reduced rates. In view of these circumstances, and subject to decisions on the final form of the definitive system, I agree with the Commission's proposal, I voted in favour of the report, which provides for the retroactively preserving the principle of a minimum general rate of VAT of 15% and proposing to extend the current measures by two years.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Common Value Added Tax System Directive ("VAT Directive") stipulated that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015, the normal rate could not be less than 15%. This text aims to extend the application of this minimum minimum VAT rate of 15% in member states from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. The current minimum rate has already been extended five times. I was opposed to the Commission having the power to impose a minimum VAT rate on the Member States, so I voted against it.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards VAT, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that, in the case of cross-border purchases not exceeding a certain threshold, VAT is still payable in the country of origin and not in the country of destination. Therefore, the minimum standard rate applicable in all Member States, which is still in force, serves as a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market. Given that all Member States currently impose a general rate of taxation above 15%, the current legislation on a minimum standard rate of at least 15% also gives Member States room for manoe margin for reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate, which could widen the VAT base and limit the use of reduced rates. In view of these circumstances, and subject to decisions on the final form of the definitive system, I agree with the Commission's proposal, I voted in favour of the report, which provides for the retroactively preserving the principle of a minimum general rate of VAT of 15% and proposing to extend the current measures by two years.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The VAT Directive provides that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015 the standard rate may not be less than 15 %. Directive adopted in a transitional manner introducing a system of minimum rates which are justified by the fact that VAT is still applied at the place of origin, and not at destination, to cross-border purchases and distance sales up to a certain value. In 2016, the Commission will publish an action plan for a simple, efficient and tax-free definitive system for value added tax, adapted to the single market and where the guidelines for future work and the main features of the definitive VAT regime for intra-EU trade will be defined, as well as the reforms envisaged to adapt existing VAT tax rules to a definitive system. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it because I am opposed to this amendment, which gives the Commission the power to impose a minimum tax rate on Member States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The intention of setting a minimum limit for the normal rate was to create a band that would harmonize up to a single RATE of VAT. However, this option would attack the fiscal sovereignty of the Member States and their options for financing the Community budget. Directive 92/77/EC determined that from January 1993 until December 1996 the normal rate could not be less than 15% in any Member State. This provision has been extended five times and is now applicable until 31 December 2015. The European Parliament is now proposing that the extension be extended until the end of 2018 and not until 2017, as the European Commission proposes, as it will allow for a more comprehensive debate on VAT rates under the VAT Action Plan. In fact, this is the only amendment tabled by the European Parliament. The action plan was presented on 7 April and aims to be the first step towards a single VAT zone in the EU.  All Member States now apply a standard rate of more than 15%. The application of a minimum standard rate of 15% guarantees a certain margin of manoeuvre to Member States, allowing them to reform VAT to reduce the standard rate. We abstained.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against. It should be for Member States to decide VAT rates.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report is a purely technical proposal to extend the minimum base rate period of 15% from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. This Directive regulates the transitional system of minimum rates and provides that the basic rate of VAT may not be set at less than 15 % in the Member States of the European Union. Given that all Member States collect a base rate of more than 15%, the current system of a minimum basic rate of 15% also provides room for manoeuvre for Member States, allowing for VAT reforms that intend to reduce the uniform rate by broadening the VAT base and limiting the use of reduced rates.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report for all possible cases of the inclusion of certain primary goods in the scheme.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with this report and I am voting against it. The mandatory application of a minimum standard rate of VAT, hence the extension until 31 December 2018 proposed in the report, is a utopia in a free competition market, especially in cross-border transactions, where VAT on the place of origin and not the place of destination applies.  This may favour the functioning of the internal market, but it does not give a solution to national economies since, quite simply, there is no maximum rate of VAT. VAT indices must provide for a maximum rate for both normal and reduced rates.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the Commission’s proposal to retroactively maintain the principle of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15%, and I support a more comprehensive discussion on VAT rates in connection with the forthcoming action plan on VAT. The Commission’s 2016 action plan will set out the directions for future work following the achievements attained since the 2011 Communication on the future of VAT. It will in particular set out the main features of the definitive VAT regime for intra-EU trade that the Commission wants to propose and the reforms it envisages to adapt the existing rules on VAT rates to a definitive regime characterised by the destination principle.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards VAT, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that, in the case of cross-border purchases not exceeding a certain threshold, VAT is still payable in the country of origin and not in the country of destination. Therefore, the minimum standard rate applicable in all Member States, which is still in force, serves as a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market. Given that all Member States currently impose a general rate of taxation above 15%, the current legislation on a minimum standard rate of at least 15% also gives Member States room for manoe margin for reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate, which could widen the VAT base and limit the use of reduced rates. In view of these circumstances, and subject to decisions on the final form of the definitive system, I agree with the Commission's proposal, I voted in favour of the report, which provides for the retroactively preserving the principle of a minimum general rate of VAT of 15% and proposing to extend the current measures by two years.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards VAT, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that, in the case of cross-border purchases not exceeding a certain threshold, VAT is still payable in the country of origin and not in the country of destination. Therefore, the minimum standard rate applicable in all Member States, which is still in force, serves as a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market. Given that all Member States currently impose a general rate of taxation above 15%, the current legislation on a minimum standard rate of at least 15% also gives Member States room for manoe margin for reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate, which could widen the VAT base and limit the use of reduced rates. In view of these circumstances, and subject to decisions on the final form of the definitive system, I agree with the Commission's proposal, I voted in favour of the report, which provides for the retroactively preserving the principle of a minimum general rate of VAT of 15% and proposing to extend the current measures by two years.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report bearing in mind that the VAT Directive provides that, from 1 January 2011 to 31 December 2015, the normal rate may not be less than 15%. Such harmonisation is necessary to ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market and to avoid distortions of competition. The Commission will publish in 2016 an action plan for a simple, efficient and fraud-proof VAT system designed for the single market.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The Value Added Tax (VAT) is one of the main taxes in the internal market and is partly a relevant source of funding for the Union.  That is why I voted in favour of extending the current minimum rate of 15% so that, in the meantime, the European Parliament and the Council have time to consider the new proposal for a VAT Directive. This is a proposal of enormous complexity in which we will have to address a new strategy not only anti-raude, but of a cross-border nature.  In particular, I am particularly pleased that Parliament has supported extending the extension to 31 December 2018, rather than 31 December 2017, as proposed by the Commission, which is the result of an amendment tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation. This achievement is yet another sign of the added value of parliaments, so as a consultation procedure, I hope that the Council will support the decision.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. Value Added Tax (VAT) is one of the main taxes in the internal market, and is partly a very relevant source of funding for the Union.  That is why I voted in favour of extending the current minimum rate of 15%, so that in the meantime the European Parliament and the Council have time to consider the new proposal for a VAT Directive, which is very complex and where we will have to tackle a new anti-fraud strategy, in particular, but not just the cross-border one.  In particular, I am particularly pleased that Parliament has supported extending the extension to 31 December 2018, rather than 31 December 2017, as proposed by the Commission, which is the result of an amendment tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation. This achievement is yet another sign of the added value of parliaments, so as a consultation procedure, I hope that the Council will support the decision.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending a previous Council directive on the common system of value added tax, in relation to the duration of the obligation to apply a minimum standard rate, because I agree with the Commission's proposal to maintain a minimum VAT rate of 15 % for a transitional period. Taxation remains the prerogative of the Member States, so the European Parliament, in expressing its opinion on this matter, considered that it agreed with the extension of the principle that the standard VAT rate, as proposed by the European Commission, cannot be less than 15 % for the next three years, and therefore until the end of 2018.  In this regard, I believe that, in the run-up to the adoption of the forthcoming VAT Action Plan, this decision is a measure aimed at guaranteeing legal certainty for the parties concerned, with a view to the adoption of a new system, while at the same time allowing for a broader discussion. The action plan will have to define guidelines for future work in the light of the results of the presentation of the 2011 communication, with it the Commission will announce a simple, effective and, above all, fraud-proof definitive VAT system adapted to the single market.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the minimum VAT standard rate as I welcome the freezing of the EU-wide minimum rate to 15 per cent by 2018 in the interests of our taxpayers and share the position that a fundamental action plan by the European Commission to modernise this system in a citizen-friendly way makes sense.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. As a Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we are in favour of better EU-wide compliance with the VAT system. A uniform minimum rate of 15% contributes to the harmonisation of the tax base and thus to the functioning of the common internal market. At the same time, it leaves the Member States the necessary leeway with regard to their fiscal sovereignty.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Value Added Tax Directive will give clarity to VAT payments within the internal market. By continuing to make tax requirements as simple as possible we will foster and encourage small and new business growth. For that reason, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The VAT Directive has played an important role in stimulating the EU’s Single Market since it was first introduced in 1993. Unfortunately however, the latest proposal from the Commission was published too late to allow for sufficient consultation.  This report is therefore very much welcomed and has my full support. By confirming the agreement to prolong the application of the existing VAT regime, this report allows enough time to consider the new VAT regime as well as the additional flexibilities that have been proposed alongside it. Initially, there were concerns over the continuation of the current 5% VAT applied to sanitary products. This matter however was resolved during the March Council meeting following the Commission’s proposal to allow greater flexibility for Member States by extending the number of zero rate VAT products, which includes sanitary products. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. As of 1 January 2011, the standard VAT rate in EU Member States could not be less than 15%. In the same year, the Commission announced that it would publish a set of proposals on the VAT regime in 2016, with the aim of framing trade within the European Union. Although this proposal avoids unfair competition, the Commission obliges Member States to maintain a minimum tax rate on their territory, while the tax competence is the responsibility of the Member States. Each country must be free to define its tax policy as it sees fit. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In this vote, we abstained in this vote extending the minimum rate of VAT to 15% pending a commission proposal. While we consider indirect taxes to be regressive and should be reduced, in this case this is a formal decision pending the Commission's presentation of its final proposal to be discussed.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of this report is that a minimum standard rate applied in all Member States - as is currently the case - provides useful protection for the proper functioning of the internal market. In the area of value added tax, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that VAT applied at the place of origin, rather than at the place of destination, still applies to cross-border trade and distance sales below a certain threshold.  Given that all Member States currently apply a standard rate of more than 15 %, the current provisions providing for a minimum standard rate of 15 % also provide leeway for Member States, enabling them to carry out VAT reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate by broadening the VAT base and limiting the use of reduced rates.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal on the Value Added Tax Directive because it will give continued clarity over VAT payments within the internal market. This is essential in order to create a clear system within which new and small businesses can excel. Labour MEPs will engage with the Commission’s forthcoming review of VAT legislation.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I felt it was essential to maintain and extend the normal VAT rate for the next two years to a minimum of 15% for all Member States. It is an effective measure to protect our economy and our businesses from situations of distortion of competition that are particularly unfavourable to them. However, this measure is only transitional and I encourage the European Commission to present an ambitious reform of the VAT regime in order to simplify it, to make it more transparent and effective.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. Value Added Tax (VAT) is one of the main taxes in the internal market, and is partly a very relevant source of funding for the Union.  That is why I voted in favour of extending the current minimum rate of 15%, so that in the meantime the European Parliament and the Council have time to consider the new proposal for a VAT Directive, which is very complex and where we will have to tackle a new anti-fraud strategy, in particular, but not just the cross-border one.  In particular, I am particularly pleased that Parliament has supported extending the extension to 31 December 2018, rather than 31 December 2017, as proposed by the Commission, which is the result of an amendment tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation. This achievement is yet another sign of the added value of parliaments, so as a consultation procedure, I hope that the Council will support the decision.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I believe that a minimum standard rate applied in all Member States provides a useful safeguard to the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards VAT, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that, in the case of cross-border purchases not exceeding a certain threshold, VAT is still payable in the country of origin and not in the country of destination. Therefore, the minimum standard rate applicable in all Member States, which is still in force, serves as a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market. Given that all Member States currently impose a general rate of taxation above 15%, the current legislation on a minimum standard rate of at least 15% also gives Member States room for manoe margin for reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate, which could widen the VAT base and limit the use of reduced rates. In view of these circumstances, and subject to decisions on the final form of the definitive system, I agree with the Commission's proposal, I voted in favour of the report, which provides for the retroactively preserving the principle of a minimum general rate of VAT of 15% and proposing to extend the current measures by two years.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report sets the minimum VAT rate for euro area Member States, which is prohibited from falling below 15%. This clause exists and is renewed every year. Our position is that there should be no common VAT and therefore the amount of vat is secondary. For these reasons we have held a position of abstention.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of retroactively maintaining the principle of a minimum standard of VAT in all Member States, for an extended period of three years, until 31 December 2018. Minimum rates in the field of VAT are warranted by the fact that VAT at origin, rather than destination, is still applied to cross-border shopping and distance sales below a threshold. Therefore maintaining the minimum standard rate applied in all Member States provides a useful safeguard to the proper functioning of the internal market. Taking into account that all Member States currently levy a standard rate above 15%, the current agreement for a minimum standard rate of 15% also ensures room for manoeuvre for Member States, allowing for VAT reforms intending to reduce the standard rate by broadening the VAT base and limiting the use of reduced rates.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion as it provides continuity for the standard level of tax rates in Member States.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. \u2012 This report adheres to the European Commission's policy of a minimum VAT rate of 15% until 2017. This is a missed opportunity, because Member States should have the opportunity to charge a much lower VAT rate for sustainable, healthy, environmentally and animal-friendly goods and services. On the one hand, the Commission preaches sustainability, but when it comes to it, Member States are not free to reward the production of sustainable products and services in tax and to encourage the purchase of these products. The Commission's VAT Action Plan should provide much more flexibility to Member States to set VAT rates for sustainable, healthy, environmentally and animal-friendly goods and services. However, that idea is lacking in the report, which is why I have not agreed to it.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards VAT, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that, in the case of cross-border purchases not exceeding a certain threshold, VAT is still payable in the country of origin and not in the country of destination. Therefore, the minimum standard rate applicable in all Member States, which is still in force, serves as a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market. Given that all Member States currently impose a general rate of taxation above 15%, the current legislation on a minimum standard rate of at least 15% also gives Member States room for manoe margin for reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate, which could widen the VAT base and limit the use of reduced rates.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the extension of the period of application of the EU’s minimum standard rate of VAT. Nevertheless, the whole question of VAT rates is going to be considered more fully by this House in the not-so-distant future. We must be take full account of the needs of Europe’s citizens and should adapt the law where necessary. In this regard my party colleague Alison Thewliss MP has campaigned strongly for an end to the so called ‘tampon tax’, and I commend her work to the House.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The standard rate of VAT could not be set lower than 15% in any Member States starting 1 January 1993 as was stipulated in the Directive 92/77/EEC. The Commission proposal aims at a system of tax harmonization within all EU Member States. I have voted in favour of the renewal for 3 years of the VAT Directive until 31/12/2018.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I voted for a report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC on a common value added tax system, in relation to the duration of the obligation to comply with the minimum standard rate, as the minimum standard rate currently applied in all Member States constitutes a useful backstop for the proper functioning of the internal market. The current system gives Member States room for manoeuvre to implement VAT reforms.  The decision that from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2018 the standard rate must not be lower than 15 %, provides for the necessary period for setting out the final SYSTEM of VAT for intra-EU trade which the Commission plans to propose these reforms by which the Commission plans to adapt the existing RULES on VAT rates, namely the establishment of a final system based on the principle of place of destination rather than origin.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this vote is to extend by two years the existing situation in which Member States apply a normal VAT rate of a minimum of 15%. Indeed, the Directive on the Common Value Added Tax System ("VAT Directive") provided that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015, the normal rate could not be less than 15%. The current minimum VAT rate has been extended five times. As announced in its 2011 communication on the future of VAT, the Commission will publish in 2016 a set of proposals on the final VAT regime for intra-EU trade. Pending decisions on the final VAT regime, the Commission therefore proposes to change the period of application of the minimum VAT rate by extending it from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. We are opposed to this amendment which gives the Commission the power to impose a minimum tax rate on Member States. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Retrospectively extends the period to which minimum standard rates of VAT apply; accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. Value Added Tax (VAT) is one of the main taxes in the internal market, and is partly a very relevant source of funding for the Union.  That is why I voted in favour of extending the current minimum rate of 15%, so that in the meantime the European Parliament and the Council have time to consider the new proposal for a VAT Directive, which is very complex and where we will have to tackle a new anti-fraud strategy, in particular, but not just the cross-border one.  In particular, I am particularly pleased that Parliament has supported extending the extension to 31 December 2018, rather than 31 December 2017, as proposed by the Commission, which is the result of an amendment tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation. This achievement is yet another sign of the added value of parliaments, so as a consultation procedure, I hope that the Council will support the decision.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Minimum rates in the field of VAT are justified by the fact that VAT at origin, rather than destination, is still applied to cross-border shopping and distance sales below a certain threshold. Hence, a minimum standard rate applied in all Member States – as is currently the case – provides a useful safeguard to the proper functioning of the internal market. Until we adopt the new definitive VAT regime - which proposes that the origin principle be abandoned, it makes sense to prolong the minimum VAT standard rate for two more years. By then, negotiators will hopefully have adopted a new policy on VAT rates. Indeed, I believe this question has to be extensively discussed in the framework of the negotiations on the COM proposal for a simple, efficient and fraud-proof definitive system of value added tax tailored to the single market.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Peter Simon's report on the minimum normal rate of VAT. The report states that the minimum standard RATE of VAT is expected to remain at 15% for the next two years, which has remained unchanged since 1993. I have approved the continuation of this rate, although I regret that the Commission is slow to carry out the tax harmonisation it promised, making it necessary to extend this minimum rate, which was supposed to be a transitional measure. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This text aimed to extend the standard VAT rate in force in the EU since 2011, which is at least 15%, for a further three years. This will strengthen the single market and avoid tax competition between Member States. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Value Added Tax Directive because it will give continued clarity over VAT payments within the internal market. We need to continue to make tax requirements as simple as possible to encourage new and small businesses to flourish. Labour MEPs will engage fully with the Commission’s forthcoming review of VAT legislation to make sure that any new VAT regime reflects our values and priorities.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards VAT, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that, in the case of cross-border purchases not exceeding a certain threshold, VAT is still payable in the country of origin and not in the country of destination. Therefore, the minimum standard rate applicable in all Member States, which is still in force, serves as a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market. Given that all Member States currently impose a general rate of taxation above 15%, the current legislation on a minimum standard rate of at least 15% also gives Member States room for manoe margin for reforms aimed at reducing the standard rate, which could widen the VAT base and limit the use of reduced rates. In view of these circumstances, and subject to decisions on the final form of the definitive system, I agree with the Commission's proposal, I voted in favour of the report, which provides for the retroactively preserving the principle of a minimum general rate of VAT of 15% and proposing to extend the current measures by two years.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taxation is a national competence, so the setting of a general rate is in violation of national sovereignty, while at the same time reducing the possibilities for tax evasion should be supported. In addition, the 15% rate is unjustifiably high for many commodities. In this form, I do not consider the report to be good enough, I would propose a different methodology and a more complex approach to achieving the objectives.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Undoubtedly, extending the minimum standard rate for VAT at 15% is in the interest of the proper functioning of the internal market. This is a significant achievement, since current rules have not been updated to reflect new developments and new economic realities such as the rise of a digital industry. In this sense, extending the minimum standard rate for VAT at 15% will on the one hand facilitate economic growth and on the other hand will fight tax fraud. Therefore, we should support it.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the minimum standard rate of VAT. The aim of this vote is to extend by two years the existing situation in which Member States apply a standard VAT rate of a minimum of 15%. Indeed, the directive on the common value-added tax system provided that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015, the normal rate could not be less than 15%. The current minimum VAT rate has been extended five times. As announced in its 2011 communication on the future of VAT, the Commission will publish in 2016 a set of proposals on the final VAT regime for intra-EU trade. Pending decisions on the final VAT regime, the Commission therefore proposes to change the period of application of the minimum VAT rate by extending it from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. I am opposed to this amendment, which gives the Commission the power to impose a minimum tax rate on Member States.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it wants to allow the minimum VAT rate to be extended until the end of 2017. It thus gives legitimacy to the Commission's power to impose minimum tax rates on Member States.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Member States have been applying a standard VAT rate of a minimum of 15%, in line with the Common Value Added Tax System Directive, known as the VAT Directive, since 1 January 2011. However, for the fifth time, the Commission is calling for a two-year extension of this situation, pending a set of proposals on the final VAT regime for intra-EU trade in 2016. However, it is unacceptable for the Commission to have the right to set the minimum tax rate for Member States. So I voted against this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Value Added Tax (VAT) is one of the main taxes in the internal market, and is partly a very relevant source of funding for the Union.  That is why I voted in favour of extending the current minimum rate of 15%, so that in the meantime the European Parliament and the Council have time to consider the new proposal for a VAT Directive, which is very complex and where we will have to tackle a new anti-fraud strategy, in particular, but not just the cross-border one.  In particular, I am particularly pleased that Parliament has supported extending the extension to 31 December 2018, rather than 31 December 2017, as proposed by the Commission, which is the result of an amendment tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation. This achievement is yet another sign of the added value of parliaments, so as a consultation procedure, I hope that the Council will support the decision.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because this legal framework establishing the minimum VAT of 15% at European level creates many problems, but due to the lack of definition of the Commission's new proposal, it is necessary to extend that scheme for the sake of legal certainty. In 2017 the Commission will propose the new VAT regime which is likely to delve into the regressive aspects of VAT by trying to link it further with the framework of economic governance. This regime gives the European Commission the power to set the reduced rates, on basic necessities, which has created many problems. However, the specific recommendations of economic governance insist on the transfer of direct to indirect taxation, with the clear intention of increasing inequalities. That is why, despite the need for extension, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The following directive provides that the normal rate cannot be less than 15 % as a common basis for all Member States. The aim is to carry out the necessary legislative harmonisations to ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market, avoiding as much as possible any distortion of competition.  I support this initiative because this minimum level of the tax rate provides a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market, ensuring that cross-border purchases are not made under a certain threshold.  I vote in favour as this is one of the first steps needed to establish an action plan which the Commission will publish to achieve a definitive system of simple, efficient and fraud-proof VAT designed for the single market.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the proposal for the EU to start dictating the minimum VAT rate to the Member States again, and I do not agree at all that this proposal should apply retroactively from January 2016. I do not agree either with the Commission's proposal that the minimum rate should apply until the end of 2017, nor with the amendment to apply until the end of 2018. The Commission proposes to regulate VAT rates contrary to its previous response to my interpellation on VAT regulation. If the proposal passes, the Czech Republic will not be able, for example, to introduce a uniform VAT rate of 14 percent.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Under the VAT Directive, it is defined that from 1 January 2011 to 31 December 2015, the standard rate must not be less than 15 %. The report proposes extended timeframes to two years, i.e. until 31 December 2017.  The minimum VAT rate applies as VAT is still applied in the place of origin of the product rather than the destination, and serves as a security framework for the proper functioning of the internal market. The report proposes to extend the timeframe of the standard rate of 15%, which will ensure further development and stability in the internal market, so I supported the report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 When it became clear that the introduction of the single market would not make it possible to implement the Commission's proposals for the establishment of a definitive system for tax harmonisation, Directive 92/77/EC was introduced, according to which the basic rate of VAT in all Member States should not be set below 15 %. The provisions of the Directive were extended five times and the last one until 31 December 2015, which means that it is time to do so again, this time until the end of 2018. Given that the VAT rate exceeds 15% in all EU Member States, there will be no distortion of any national tax policy in this respect. As a result, the existing system will continue to operate until the date on which a common tax policy for all EU Member States could possibly be implemented. It would be worth noting that the Commission initially proposed an extension of the existing rules until the end of 2017, but this proposal was subsequently changed to the above date.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This Directive, in the interests of the functioning of the single market and competition, pursues the harmonisation of legislation in the field of value added tax. Retroactively, until 31 December 2015, the lowest basic VAT rate of at least 15 % is confirmed, while at the same time extending this transitional VAT rate setting mechanism until 31 December 2018. In 2016, the Commission should propose a new system for the final solution of INTRA-EU VAT, based on the principle of destination (so far it is the country of origin principle).

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC on the common system of value added tax, as regards the duration of the compulsory application of a minimum standard rate, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  European VAT systems are supposed to be subject to European harmonisation. Pending a directive to this effect, an interim regime has been introduced: it sets a minimum normal rate of 15% applicable to all Member States for the period 2011-2015. The Commission is proposing an extension of this transitional regime until 2017. At the same time, its proposals on European VAT are expected to be published in the course of 2016. We are opposed to any harmonisation of taxation at EU level. Taxation is, in fact, a prerogative of sovereign states, and the setting of rates depends on factors specific to each of them.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal and look forward to the publication by the Commission of an action plan for a simple, efficient and fraud-proof definitive system of value added tax tailored to the single market.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the application of a minimum standard rate of VAT is in my favour. It states that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015 the standard rate may not be less than 15%. This will be a valid rule within the EU and is necessary to ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market and to avoid distortions of competition. Given that all Member States currently apply a standard rate of more than 15%, the current provisions on the minimum standard rate of 15% also provide room for manoeuvre for Member States, which can carry out VAT reforms to reduce the flat rate by broadening the VAT base and limiting the use of reduced rates.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The system of a minimum standard VAT rate has worked well for 20 years, and should continue to maintain this consistency in our single market. I agree with the rapporteur that extending the rate until the end of 2018 will allow for a more constructive debate on this issue given the next VAT Action Plan.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the Commission's proposal to retroactively maintain the principle of a minimum normal VAT rate of 15% and to extend existing systems for three years. Such a period would ensure that interested parties have the necessary legal certainty and would allow for a broader debate on VAT rates in relation to the future VAT action plan.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The minimum VAT rates are justified by the fact that the imposition of VAT still follows, in many cases, the original principle, rather than the destination principle (including cross-border short-distance purchases and sales). Therefore, the application of a minimum rate in all Member States, as is currently the case, prevents tax dumping and is a useful guarantee for the proper functioning of the internal market. In addition, all Member States now have a normal rate of more than 15%; this extension of the 15% threshold therefore also provides room for states to make VAT reforms, for example with a view to reducing the normal rate by broadening the VAT base and limiting the use of reduced rates. In these circumstances, and pending a major communication from the European Commission on VAT planned for 2016, it is indeed wise to extend the normal minimum VAT rate of 15% and that the current provisions be maintained for a period of three years (until 31 December 2018). I voted in favour of this necessary adjustment.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Article 113 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union stipulates that the Council should decide on the provisions relating to the harmonization of legislation relating to turnover taxes, as this harmonisation is necessary to ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market and avoid distortions of competition. The report proposes here to keep the normal minimum common VAT rate in the EU at 15%, until 2018. In fact, since 1993, the standard RATE of VAT cannot be less than 15%. However, value-added tax (VAT) is the most unfair tax paid by everyone, regardless of their level of resources. An ambitious tax policy should address this tax, which will be impossible in this context. In the age of widespread tax evasion, there is much better work to be done. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. By this text, the Commission could decree a minimum tax rate in the Member States. As this measure is against the freedom of states, I have not resolved. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2006/112/EEC on the common value added tax system as regards the duration of the obligation to respect a minimum standard rate.  The aim is to maintain retracting the application of a standard VAT rate of 15%, while proposing the extension of existing measures until 31 December 2018.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report, as it provides the necessary clarity for stakeholders, allows a long term perspective for investors and contributes to a level playing field for businesses across Europe.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to extend the existing situation for a period of two years, in which Member States apply a normal VAT rate of a minimum of 15%. The VAT Directive provided for the end of this floor rate on 31 December 2015. It is therefore a matter of renewing it until December 2017. However, the Commission will publish an action plan in June 2016 to reform the current system. This revision will give Member States greater flexibility in setting rates and will address the concept of temporary exemptions.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Tax harmonisation at EU level is an important tool for achieving the proper functioning of the internal market. Back in 1992, the Council adopted a Commission proposal to set a minimum basic rate of VAT in all Member States of the Union of 15%. The purpose of regulating the minimum amount of VAT is that cross-border purchases and distance sales not exceeding the threshold should use VAT at the place of origin and not at the place of destination. In general, tax harmonisation and coordination of member countries' tax policies are seen as a serious economic and political issue that governments must address in order to preserve economic growth and stability. It is also a process quite demanding and controversial, since, on the one hand, Member States are bound by compliance with binding EU legislation and policies, on the other hand, they seek to maintain a competitive advantage over other countries. Tax harmonisation in the EU is therefore still an ongoing process, the completion of which will require further legislation. For the time being, the present proposal for a directive proposes to maintain the existing minimum amount of VAT, which I see as economically advantageous for promoting cross-border exchanges of goods. I am therefore voting in favour of the report as it stands.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which is a purely technical proposal extending the duration of the minimum standard rate (15%) from 1 January 2016 until 31 December 2017. This Directive is a transitional system of minimum rates, and stipulates that the standard VAT rate could not be set lower than 15% in any Member State. Minimum standard rate applied in all Member States – as is currently the case – provides a useful safeguard to the proper functioning of the internal market without distortion of competition. Considering that all Member States currently levy a standard rate above 15%, the current arrangement for a minimum standard rate of 15% also ensures room for manoeuvre for Member States, allowing for VAT reforms intending to reduce the standard rate by broadening the VAT base and limiting the use of reduced rates.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Directive 2006/112/EC on the common system of value added tax (VAT) ensured that the overall rate of VAT should not be less than 15% between 1 January 2011 and 31 December 2015. The Commission has proposed to the Council that the VAT Directive be amendd to cover the period from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. The Council should consult Parliament before deciding on the motion.  In its report, the Committee on Economic and Financial Affairs recommends that Parliament support the Commission's proposal, but proposes that the scope of the Directive be extended to 31 December 2018 instead of 31 December 2017. I voted in favour of the proposal of the Committee on Economic and Financial Affairs.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this vote is to extend by two years the existing situation in which Member States apply a normal VAT rate of a minimum of 15%. Indeed, the VAT Directive provided that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015, the normal rate could not be less than 15%. The Commission will publish a set of proposals for the final VAT regime for intra-EU trade in 2016. In the meantime, the Commission is therefore proposing to change the period of application of the minimum VAT rate by extending it from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. However, we are opposed to this amendment, which confirms the principle giving the Commission the power to impose a minimum tax rate on Member States, thus undermining their fiscal sovereignty.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets the minimum standard rate of VAT in the Member States. In a European Union where differences in social and fiscal legislation between states still allow for the practice of dumping, I support all convergence measures to stop them.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The application of a minimum VAT rate, introduced in 1993, is one of the foundations of the European common market. Ensuring a minimum rate between each EU Member State is part of the search for harmonisation between the different markets of the States. It is in this capacity that I supported the extension of the common VAT system.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal calls for a further extension of a permanent vat system, which has been in temporary operation since 1993 and will be extended continuously until 31 December 2015. I believe that harmonised VAT is a proven and necessary instrument for the functioning of the internal market and to avoid distortions of competition in the market, in particular by helping small and medium-sized enterprises. The extension is, in my view, crucial for legal certainty, but I think it is important to point out that a complex, long-term solution is needed, which requires more in-depth measures, with a constant focus on the protection of SMEs, the reduction of administrative burdens and the stability of the system in the face of fraud. I voted in favour of this proposal, but I will actively follow the commission's action plan promised for 2016, which is an inevitable element in the development of a new long-term VAT strategy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The standard VAT rate among EU Member States may not be less than 15% as provided in the VAT Directive that was introduced from 1 January 1993 until 31 December 1996. This directive has been extended five times already and has been into force until 31 December 2015. I have voted for this report that will extend the VAT Directive for a period of three years, until 31 December 2018. This VAT Directive represents a transitional system in view of establishing the internal market.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report by vote because I believe that maintaining the minimum value of 15% for the standard RATE of VAT provides useful protection for the proper functioning of the internal market of the European Union.  Also, as the report voted on today, all Member States now have a standard value added tax rate of more than 15%, and maintaining a minimum rate gives Member States leeway to carry out reforms. At the same time, the imposition of a minimum rate of VAT avoids situations of unfair competition from one State to another, as the European Union market becomes increasingly interconnected.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this proposal as it offers an opportunity to strengthen the competitiveness of Austria as a business and trade location by restricting tax dumping in the area of the European internal market.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. It should be noted that VAT is one of the most important sources of taxation and income. It should be noted that in countries where VAT is lower, consumption is higher, which also leads to the state of the economy. I believe that it is appropriate to maintain and apply retroactively the principle that the minimum standard rate of VAT is 15%. I support the proposal that the current rules should apply for a further three years until 31 December 2018. In such a case, Member States will continue to be able to achieve the VAT rate they deem necessary, but it may not be less than 15%. It should be noted that in many EU countries preferential VAT is applied specifically to foodstuffs and other consumer goods most used. The main reason why EU countries introduce reduced VAT rates for food is to increase the purchasing power of the lowest income earners, as it is in their consumer basket that food accounts for the most important part of consumer spending.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This retrospectively extends the period to which minimum standard rates of VAT apply; accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Whereas the transitional arrangements provided for in Council Directive 92/77/EEC on the common system of value added tax in the Member States of the European Union provide, within a common system of minimum rates, that the standard rate may not be less than 15% in each Member State; that this transitional arrangements have been extended several times and that it is a useful instrument for the proper functioning of the single market; that all Member States have complyed with the provisions of the VAT Directive and that during 2016 the Commission will publish an action plan for a definitive vat regime, I believe that the proposal to maintain the retroactivity of the principle of a minimum standard rate of 15% and to extend it for a further 3 years is to be voted on in a positive way.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Value added tax is a major source of tax revenue in the Member States and as such it should be clearly and precisely regulated. With the report on the minimum VAT rate, we make sure that these revenues are present. Even though the amendment of the directive has come a bit too late and for several months there was no legislation on the minimum threshold for VAT, I am glad that the report is being voted and I fully support it.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A single market, with a monetary union and economic union, needs to fully converge also at fiscal level. I support the fact that the Union should further undergo a harmonisation process of its tax system. Even though the proposal of the Commission mainly addresses the extension of the current situation, setting a minimum of 15% for VAT in all Member States, the adequate response calls the Commission to keep on working on a proposal that could definitely put all Member States under the umbrella of a common tax system, not only at the level of VAT.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The lowest standard VAT rate of 15% has been applied for years, and with this proposal to amend the VAT Directive, the European Parliament proposes to use it by 31 December 2018. The VAT Directive stipulates that the standard rate cannot be less than 15%.  It should be noted that this provision, based on Article 113 of the TFEU, is envisaged with a view to harmonising sales tax legislation to the extent necessary to ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market and to avoid distortions of competition.  It is also not a problem to reiterate that the current system, with a standard rate of more than 15% currently in force in all Member States, also gives Member States room for manoeuvre, as it allows them to implement VAT reforms aimed at broadening the VAT base and limiting the application of reduced rates to reduce the standard rate.
