In view of the stated possibilities, I underline the need to apply flexibility mechanisms at national levels, especially in the food production sector, with a view to raising the purchasing power of citizens, but also to assist the crisis-affected agricultural sector. For all of the above, I supported the amendment to the Directive in the present.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this vote is to extend by two years the existing situation in which Member States apply a normal VAT rate of a minimum of 15%. Indeed, the Directive on the Common Value Added Tax System ("VAT Directive") provided that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015, the normal rate could not be less than 15%. The current minimum VAT rate has been extended five times. As announced in its 2011 communication on the future of VAT, the Commission will publish in 2016 a set of proposals for the final VAT regime for intra-EU trade. Pending decisions on the final VAT regime, the Commission therefore proposes to change the period of application of the minimum VAT rate by extending it from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. I am opposed to this amendment, which gives the Commission the power to impose a minimum tax rate on Member States, and I therefore vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. In order to establish an internal market, on 1 January 1993 the Commission presented proposals for the establishment of a definitive tax harmonisation system. Given that a standard rate of more than 15% is currently in force in all Member States, the current system also gives Member States room for manoeuvre by extending the VAT base and limiting the application of reduced rates.  On 6 December 2011, the Commission adopted a Communication on the Future of VAT, which proposed that the country of origin principle should be stopped and described several ways in which taxation can be achieved at the place of destination. In 2016, the Commission will publish an action plan for a simple and effective final value added tax system that will be fraud-proof and adapted to the single market. I agree with the Commission's proposal to retroactively maintain the principle of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15 % and to propose extending the application of existing rules by three years (until 31 December 2018).

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The VAT Directive provided that, by 31 December 2015, the normal rate would not be less than 15%. The establishment of a minimum limit aimed at creating a band with a ceiling that would be harmonised up to a single VAT rate for the whole Community area, looking at the fiscal sovereignty of the Member States and their options for financing the Community budget. The European Parliament is now proposing that the extension be extended until the end of 2018 and not until 2017, as the EC proposes, as it will, they say, allow for a more comprehensive debate on VAT rates under the VAT action plan. We do not disconnect this whole framework from the underlying intention to bring European harmonisation to tax matters as well.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The previous VAT Directive stipulated that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015 the standard rate could not be less than 15% in a given Member State. As far as VAT is based, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that VAT at the place of origin, rather than at the place of destination, is still applied to cross-border purchases and distance selling, below a certain threshold.  Consequently, a minimum standard rate applied in all Member States is a useful guarantee for the proper functioning of the internal market. In 2016, the Commission will publish an action plan for a definitive vat regime. Pending the final decisions, the Commission proposes to maintain the principle of a minimum vat standard rate of 15% and an extension of the existing provisions for three years, until 31 December 2018.  I am convinced that, in order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market, it is essential to ensure fair and well-defined taxation. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the normal rate of VAT. Applying a minimum VAT rate in all EU Member States allows for harmonisation within the internal market. The normal rate above 15% applied in the EU will be extended until 31 December 2018. Now it is a matter of waiting for the European Commission's Communication on VAT, scheduled for 2016.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Retrospectively extends the period to which minimum standard rates of VAT apply; accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I have approved in favour of this report, the action plan of which will define the main characteristics of the definitive VAT regime applicable to intra-EU trade which the Commission intends to propose, as well as the reforms envisaged to adapt existing VAT rate rules to a definitive system characterised by the country of destination principle.  Minimum VAT rates are justified by the fact that they still apply at the place of origin, not at destination, to cross-border purchases and distance sales up to a certain value. Therefore, applying a minimum standard rate in all Member States – as in the current case – is a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market and avoids unfair tax competition. In these circumstances, and pending decisions on the final form of the final arrangements, the report agreed with the Commission's proposal to retroactively maintain the principle of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15 % and propose the extension of existing measures for a period of three years (until 31 December 2018) - a deadline that ensures the necessary legal certainty for interested parties and allows for a more comprehensive debate on VAT rates within the framework of the future action plan.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2006/112/EC on the common value added tax system ("VAT Directive") provides that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015 the standard rate may not be less than 15% in any Member State. This provision on the minimum standard rate has been extended five times.  The Committee on Economic Affairs is now proposing the extension until 31 December 2018 (one year more than in the Commission proposal).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. •u2012 Fundamentally technical report, developed under the simplified procedure. Its sole purpose is to extend the ordinary minimum VAT rate of 15% until 31 December 2017, where the Commission introduces a new Directive.  I voted for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The voted text adheres to the European Commission's proposal to retroactively maintain the principle of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15% and proposes that the current provisions be extended for a period of three years, until 31 December 2018. The European Parliament believes that this deadline guarantees the necessary legal certainty for stakeholders and allows for a more in-depth examination of VAT rates as part of the forthness of the forthesty VAT action plan.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The VAT Directive provides that the standard rate may not be less than 15% between 1 January 2011 and 31 December 2015. It should be noted that even at present, no EU country is subject to VAT of 15%. The lowest rate is in Luxembourg, where it stands at 17%.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which endorses the Commission's proposal to maintain a minimum standard VAT rate of 15%. On 7 April, the Commission proposed an action plan to reform the VAT collection system, in particular to better combat fraud. Until this reform is implemented, we must continue to ensure that the internal market functions properly. Thus, for the next two years, it is important to maintain this minimum VAT rate, as it has been in place since 1993, in order to avoid distortions of competition within the internal market.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the legislative motion for a resolution on the amendment of Directive 2006/112/EC on the duration of the obligation to comply with a minimum standard rate on the common value added tax system which is set at 15% and will be in force for a period of three years (until 31/12/2018). It is a regulatory provision aimed at tax harmonisation which, on the one hand, is a useful safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market and, on the other hand, allows member states to be given some room for manoeuvre, in particular as to the possibility of reforming VAT in order to reduce the normal rate and to extend the vat base. It will then be important to monitor the Commission's action plan on the definitive regime applicable to EU internal trade, as well as reforms to a new VAT rate regime, which will be based on the application of the tax at the place of destination.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's proposal for a directive amending directive 2006/112/EC on the common value-added tax system with regard to the duration of the obligation to meet a minimum normal rate. The VAT Directive stipulates that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015, the standard VAT rate cannot be less than 15%. The Commission therefore proposes, pending decisions on the final form of the final scheme, to retroactively maintain the principle of a minimum standard VAT rate of 15%. It should be noted that the adopted text also specifies that these provisions are extended for a period of three years, i.e. until 31 December 2018.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taxation is a sensitive issue for internal trade in the European single market. The VAT Directive was born in 1993 together with the European single market, and states that the standard rate within the EU cannot be less than 15%. This ensures minimum harmonization in the field of taxation, leaving the Member States free to manoeuvre and at the same time preventing distortions of competition. I voted in favour of renewing this directive for two reasons. Firstly, because legal certainty in the field of taxation is an act due to those who trade and businesses; secondly, because this renewal will maintain this certainty for the time it takes the Commission to draw up its proposal for a reform of VAT in intra-EU trade. With this vote, we are also asking the Commission to consult Parliament on the outcome of this reform, which aims to establish a single and definitive system, abandoning the application of VAT at the place of origin and applying it at the place of destination of the product.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In this vote, we abstained in this vote extending the minimum rate of VAT to 15% pending a commission proposal. While we consider indirect taxes to be regressive and should be reduced, in this case this is a formal decision pending the Commission's presentation of its final proposal to be discussed.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote provided another opportunity to assert that current exemptions on VAT rates allowed to national economies for items such as food or health products should not be removed, unless it is with the express and free assent of the national government involved. VAT is a tax which proportionately burdens lower income earners more than it does higher income ones. Exemptions from it, especially those granted for social reasons, should be safeguarded. The effects of the 2008 recession, still with us, have been different across the Member States. Only in one area has the negative impact been similar everywhere: lower income citizens and families have been the most affected. Worse: while this happened, the strong and the wealthy were finding very good ways to avoid and evade other non-consumption taxes that they were subject to. No matter what the original reason was for opt-outs from uniform VAT levels across the Member States, their removal now should be considered exclusively on their own merits, seen from a social perspective. The final decision should be left to national governments. The case against the adoption of a comprehensive minimum rate of VAT across the board in the EU remains valid and extremely strong.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because this legal framework establishing the minimum VAT of 15% at European level creates many problems, but due to the lack of definition of the Commission's new proposal, it is necessary to extend that scheme for the sake of legal certainty. In 2017 the Commission will propose the new IVE regime which is likely to delve defund on the regressive aspects of that tax by trying to link it further with the framework of economic governance. This regime gives the European Commission the power to set the reduced rates, on basic necessities, which has created many problems. However, the specific recommendations of economic governance insist on the transfer of direct to indirect taxation, with the clear intention of increasing inequalities. That is why, despite the need for extension, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on the duration of the obligation to apply a minimum standard rate proposes to maintain a minimum standard rate of VAT of 15% for a further three years until 31 December 2018. I voted in favour of this proposal because this extension, in addition to having no impact in terms of tax rates, since all Member States currently apply a standard rate of 15% or more, is above all a guarantee for the proper functioning of the internal market. It reduces the possibilities of cross-border transactions in search of lower VAT rates which would lead to distortion of competition.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the VAT Directive because I believe that it will give the clarity over VAT payments that we need and have been enjoying whilst members of the Single Market. We need to continue to make tax requirements as simple as possible to encourage new businesses to flourish. I, and my Labour MEP colleagues in this place, will fully engage with the forthcoming review of VAT legislation from the Commission to make sure that nay new VAT regime reflects our values and priorities.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting this resolution because it is practically only an extension of the common system of the standard VAT rate already in place for the period from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. This system provides that, on the basis of Directive 92/77/EEC, the standard VAT rate may not be less than 15 %.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a directive that the Commission has come up with to extend the minimum VAT rate until 2018, even though the proposal has been published late, which will make it necessary to apply the minimum VAT rate retroactively. The directive establishing the VAT system entered into force as early as 1993, when it was established that the basic VAT rate would not be less than 15 % in any country. The objective of this measure is to harmonise the necessary for the establishment and functioning of the internal market and to prevent distortions of competition. The setting of a minimum VAT rate is justified by the fact that cross-border and distance purchases will use VAT at the place of origin and not at the place of destination. This instrument is thus a useful safeguard to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market. Taking into account that all Member States currently apply VAT rates above 15 per cent, there remains ample room for national governments to manoeuvre and adopt VAT reforms. The extension of the current minimum VAT rate mechanism should be the last stage before the final form of the VAT regime is adopted. The Commission should already present an action plan this year to achieve a definitive VAT system, which should be simple, effective and fraud-proof. I believe that such a system will be established in the near future.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. When the internal market was exposed on 1 January 1993, the Commission presented proposals for the introduction of a definitive tax harmonisation regime. Following the Council's decision, a transitional system followed, so Directive 92/77/EEC introduced a system of minimum rates for VAT vat rates for VAT vat rates and provided that the standard rate of VAT should not be less than 15 % in any Member State. First, that provision was in force from 1 January 1993 to 31 December 1996, before being extended five times and in force until 31 December 2015. The minimum standard rate of VAT in all Member States is a useful provision, since this ensures the proper functioning of the internal market. Moreover, this also provides the Member States with room for manoeuvre for VAT reforms, since only the minimum standard rate is set (currently the standard rate of VAT in all Member States is higher than 15 %). The Commission aims to publish an action plan in 2016 to introduce a simple and effective definitive value added tax system that is appropriate for the single market. A decision on the final system has not yet been taken, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal to extend the current regime by three years, i.e. until 31 December 2017.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the technical report which retroactively maintains the principle of a minimum standard rate of VAT at 15% in accordance with the VAT Directive (Directive 92/77/EEC). In this respect, the minimum rates are justified by the fact that VAT at the place of origin, rather than at the place of destination, is still applied to cross-border purchases and distance selling below a certain threshold. Consequently, a minimum standard rate applied in all Member States, as is the case today, is a useful guarantee for the proper functioning of the internal market. Furthermore, given that all Member States currently apply a standard rate of more than 15%, the minimum rate provisions also provide room for manoeuvre for States wishing to carry out reforms of this tax. However, for the S&D Group, the approval of this extension is conditional on the Commission presenting an action plan for an effective VAT system adapted to the single market, providing for a reform to adapt the existing rules on rates to a definitive system, characterised by the country of destination principle.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The minimum standard VAT rate applicable in all Member States provides an appropriate guarantee of the proper functioning of the internal market and transparency of competition.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Common Value Added Tax Directive provides that in no Member State from 1 January 1993 to 31 December 1996 the standard rate shall not be lower than 15 %. The application of this provision has been extended five times and applies until 31 December 2015. Recent amendments to the VAT Directive propose the cessation of taxation in the country of origin and introduce taxation in the place of destination.  This greatly reduces the possibility of cross-border transactions where lower VAT rates are applied that can distort competition. In 2016, the Commission promised to publish an action plan for a simple and efficient, fraud-proof and single market-friendly definitive VAT system. As the standard rate of more than 15% is currently in force in all Member States, this sixth extension maintains the current satisfactory situation until the adoption of the action plan. Consequently, I support this report, as I consider that the lowest standard rate is currently a useful backstop for the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Value Added Tax Directive because it will give continued clarity over VAT payments within the internal market. We need to continue to make tax requirements as simple as possible to encourage new and small businesses to flourish. Labour MEPs will engage fully with the Commission’s forthcoming review of VAT legislation to make sure that any new VAT regime reflects our values and priorities.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. In January 1993, the Commission proposed to harmonise the tax system across the European Union with a view to creating a single market. However, this Commission proposal could not be adopted by the Council at the time and decided to adopt a transitional form on the collection of value added tax. This allows goods to move within the single market, with such movement of goods no longer considered as imports or exports.  A minimum VAT tax rate has been set for the efficient functioning of the single market in Directive 92/77/EEC. On this basis, the standard rate shall not be lower than 15 %. The provisions of that Directive were to apply by December 2015. On 14 December 2015, the Commission proposed to amend Directive 2006/112/EC by extending the application of this rate until December 2017. I support this Commission proposal, as I believe that in practice the minimum standard rate of 15% has proven to be a good instrument for the functioning of the single market, which is also one of the EU's most important objectives.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with tax harmonisation at European Union level.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council directive amending the Directive on the common system of value added tax as regards the duration of the obligation to respect the minimum rate. As the Commission published its proposal so late, the minimum standard VAT rate of 15 % will apply retroactively. From the beginning of 2016, however, the standard RATE of VAT should not be less than 15 % until the end of 2018, giving Member States room for manoeuvre for VAT reforms. I expect and hope that this year the European Commission will publish as soon as possible an action plan defining a VAT system that, with its ease, efficiency and security against fraud, is adapted to the single market.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The mandatory application of a minimum standard rate of VAT, hence the extension until 31 December 2018 proposed in the report, is a utopia in a free competition market, especially in cross-border purchases, where VAT on the place of origin and not the place of destination applies. This may favour the functioning of the internal market, but it does not give a solution to national economies, since there is simply no maximum rate of VAT. VAT indices must provide for a maximum rate for both normal and reduced rates.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report amending Directive 2006/112/EC on the common system of value added tax. The provision, which expires on 31 December 2015 and has been approved by the report, ensures that the overall rate of taxation in the Member States should not be less than 15%. This rule serves as an important safeguard for the proper functioning of the internal market in the current system. As the Commission plans to publish its action plan for the final single market VAT system in 2016, it was reasonable for the Commission to extend the current measure by two years until 31 December 2017.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 VAT is levied at every stage of trade in goods or services and should not, in its mind, have a direct impact on the activities of undertakings. Unfortunately, 60 years after its inception, it has become a burden on many companies, while for others it has become a method of unfair competition.  Every year, the Union loses almost €200 billion in VAT fraud and almost €50 billion in so-called tax carousels for cross-border transactions within the Single Market. It is therefore good that the European Commission plans to introduce a new system to combat the current abuses next year. Thanks to it, the company supplying the goods to another EU country will have to pay tax in its country at the VAT rate in force in the country of destination and only the tax office will transfer the received amount to the tax office in the country of the importer's premises. However, cross-border abuse is only part of the problem. With the development of VAT, most countries have decided to introduce different reduced or zero rates. These decisions were to be part of a combination of two policies – fiscal and social. As a result, however, they have resulted in an increase in fraud or even tax fraud, while with little effect on improving the situation of the poorest. For these reasons, I believe that VAT law requires much deeper, systemic and comprehensive changes, and not just as random as before.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ VAT is a major and growing source of tax revenue in the EU. However, in its current form, the system does not provide guarantees for an efficient collection to the benefit of European citizens, nor does it fully prevent unfair competition among Member States. In this context, I believe that a minimum standard rate applied in all Member States, as has actually been the case so far, is essential in safeguarding the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. The action plan will set out the direction of future work, in light of the results achieved since the 2011 communication. In particular, it will define the main features of the final VAT regime for intra-EU trade that the Commission wishes to propose, as well as the reforms it is considering to adapt the existing VAT rate rules to a final regime characterised by the destination principle.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of extending the minimum standard rate of VAT at 15% for three more years, as a provisional measure meanwhile the VAT system is being reformed in 2016. Harmonisation in the area of taxes is necessary to ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market and to avoid distortion of competition. I am looking forward to the Commission’s publication in 2016 of an action plan for a simple, efficient and fraud-proof definitive system of value added tax tailored to the single market, setting out the directions for future work. Its aim will be to set out the main characteristics of the definitive VAT regime for trade inside the EU. This will provide investors and businesses with much needed legal certainty.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The lowest standard rate applicable in all Member States, namely the VAT Directive which stipulates that from 1 January 2016 to December 2018 the standard VAT rate must not be lower than 15 %, constitutes a useful backstop for the proper functioning of the internal market. This sixth extension of the minimum standard VAT rate maintains the current situation, ensures legal certainty for stakeholders and enables the entry into force of the final VAT system for trade within the European Union.  I consider it extremely positive to harmonise sales tax legislation to the extent necessary to ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market and to avoid distortions of competition. Given that the Commission intends in 2016 to publish an action plan for a simple and effective definitive value added tax system that will be fraud-proof and adapted to the single market, it seems appropriate to maintain the principle of the minimum standard rate currently in force.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC on the common system of value added tax as regards the duration of the obligation to respect the minimum rate of interest. With a view to the completion of the internal market from 1 January 1993 onwards, the European Commission has presented proposals aimed at establishing a definitive tax harmonisation system. However, when it became clear that it would be impossible for the European Commission to adopt proposals before 1 January 1993, the Council decided to adopt transitional arrangements. As regards VAT rates, it adopted Directive 92/77/EEC. This Directive introduced a system of minimum rates. It provides that, from 1 January 1993 to 31 December 1996, the standard rate cannot be in any Member State below 15 %. This provision has been extended five times and fixed until 31 December 2015. The purpose of this proposal is to extend the current situation for a period of two years, i.e. the minimum standard RATE of VAT in the Member States is 15 %.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In this vote, we abstained in this vote extending the minimum rate of VAT to 15% pending a commission proposal. While we consider indirect taxes to be regressive and should be reduced, in this case this is a formal decision pending the Commission's presentation of its final proposal to be discussed.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission proposes to change the period of application of the minimum VAT rate by extending it from 01/01/2016 to 31/12/2017. I objected to this amendment to the VAT Directive, which gives the Commission the power to impose a minimum tax rate on Member States.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the VAT Directive, from 1 January 2011 to 31 December 2015, the standard rate shall not be less than 15 per cent. The TSI( 10000000000 The provision, based on Article 113 of the Treaty, provides that the Council adopts provisions on the harmonisation of traffic tax legislation to the extent necessary to create, operate and avoid distortions of competition in the internal market. In view of the circumstances and subject to decisions on the final form of the definitive system, the rapporteur agrees with the Commission's proposal to retroactively preserve the principle of a minimum general RATE of 15% and to propose an extension of the current measures by two years. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in this vote extending the minimum RATE of VAT to 15% pending a commission proposal. While we consider indirect taxes to be regressive and should be reduced, in this case this is a formal decision pending the Commission's presentation of its final proposal to be discussed.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this technical report of which I have been shadow rapporteur, since it only means extending the minimum rate of 15% of VAT for two years.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the common system of value added tax, with regard to the duration of the obligation to respect a minimum standard rate. The VAT Directive provides that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015, the standard rate may not be less than 15%, specifying that the Council shall adopt provisions for the harmonisation of legislation concerning turnover taxes. The harmonisation is necessary to ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market and to avoid distortion of competition.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal aims to extend for a period of two years the current situation where the minimum normal rate of VAT in the Member States is 15% and to wait until progress can be made within these two years in order to be able to propose in the future by the Commission a system for harmonisation of fees in this regard. As long as the debate is not mature enough to move forward on this issue, I think it is appropriate to continue to extend the current situation. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. Value Added Tax (VAT) is one of the main taxes in the internal market, and is partly a very relevant source of funding for the Union.  That is why I voted in favour of extending the current minimum rate of 15%, so that in the meantime the European Parliament and the Council have time to consider the new proposal for a VAT Directive, which is very complex and where we will have to tackle a new anti-fraud strategy, in particular, but not just the cross-border one.  In particular, I am particularly pleased that Parliament has supported extending the extension to 31 December 2018, rather than 31 December 2017, as proposed by the Commission, which is the result of an amendment tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation. This achievement is yet another sign of the added value of parliaments, so as a consultation procedure, I hope that the Council will support the decision.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ If the only certainties in life are death and taxes, it is possible taxes is the less popular of the two. Yet tax is the glue that holds countries together. We need to continue to make tax requirements as simple as possible to encourage new and small businesses to flourish, it is important to make sure that businesses are clear on what they have to pay and how this will affect their prices. Yet, this document also recognises that there needs to be a review of the greater flexibility that could be granted to member states in this area. We hope this procedure will allow members to adopt new rules, for instance on sanitary products. Labour MEPs will engage fully with the Commission's forthcoming review of VAT legislation to make sure that any new VAT regime reflects our values and priorities, this directive does not represent an end, but a beginning. Tax is one of the key tools that we have to ensure that Labour values and priorities are upheld, while equally ensuring that small companies and new businesses have a very clear route set before them on tax.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted for the minimum level of the normal VAT rate because it is my belief that this will lead to a better functioning of the internal market.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report discusses the minimum threshold below which the normal RATE of VAT cannot be set by Member States. As a reminder, the Value Added Tax (VAT) is a consumption tax. Almost all the products we buy are subject to VAT: food, clothing, energy, furniture, etc. This indirect tax is unfair and weighs heavily on the budgets of the most modest households, who spend all of their income on consumption. In France, in 2015 it accounted for more than half of the state's tax revenue (51.1%). This report builds on the principle adopted in 1993 that the VAT rate cannot be less than 15% and supports the extension of such a rate until 31 December 2018, to "ensure the establishment and functioning of the internal market and avoid distortions of competition". At a time when the Panama Papers remind us of the extent of tax evasion, proposing to maintain such an unfair tax at such a high minimum rate is a matter of indecency. I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The VAT Directive provides that from 1 January 2011 until 31 December 2015 the standard rate may not be less than 15 %.  The first intention of setting a minimum threshold for the rate was to create a band with a ceiling that would be harmonised up to a single VAT rate for the whole community area. However, the establishment of this band and for that purpose would be as to the fiscal sovereignty of the Member States and their options for financing the Community budget. It should also be noted that all Member States now apply a standard rate of more than 15 %, the current application of a minimum standard rate of 15 % also guarantees a certain margin of manoeuvre to Member States, allowing them to reform VAT to reduce the standard rate by extending the VAT base and limiting the use of reduced rates. The European Parliament is now proposing that the extension be extended until the end of 2018 and not until 2017, as the EC proposes, as it will allow for a more comprehensive debate on VAT rates under the VAT Action Plan.  In fact, this is the only amendment tabled by the EP.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In my view, an extension of the minimum standard rate for VAT, which is intended to achieve harmonisation in order to avoid distortions of competition, should be supported.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC on the common VAT system with regard to the duration of the obligation to comply with a minimum standard rate. Apart from the fact that the EU should generally have no tax powers and therefore should not harmonise VAT in order to have genuine tax competition, this decision is also, in concrete terms, wrong because it sets minimum tax rates. It could still be painful if there are uniform rules, but uniform (minimum) rates of 15 percent mean that consumers across the EU are very burdened. I reject that.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the extension of the duration of the minimum basic rate of vat on goods and services, VAT, defined as a value of not less than 15 %. I firmly believe that such a decision will maintain structural balance throughout the European Union. This directive has been successively continued for several years and is proof that it has a key impact on bridging distortions in the economic areas concerned with regard to competition activities. In the context of the functioning of the internal market of eu countries, the amount of vat proposed is still an effective safeguard against loss of stability.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal tabled because at the moment it is only about extending the minimum VAT rate, which has existed for more than 10 years, for another three years. However, we know that a difficult debate on the harmonisation of tax systems has already begun in Europe – both at Member State level and in the European Parliament. This debate will continue in the coming years and it will be important for Slovakia to intervene actively. Lower taxes are one way for my country to try to compete with other EU members in attracting investment. With a lower tax rate, we are trying to compensate investors for less developed infrastructure. Tax harmonisation is therefore acceptable from Slovakia's point of view only if it is accompanied by a guarantee of increased support for the completion of expressways, the modernisation of railways, as well as the improvement of suburban transport, etc.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today voted on an amendment to Directive 2006/112/EC in order to extend the application of the harmonised minimum level of value added tax between Member States, amounting to 15%, from 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2017. This extension was necessary pending the entry into force of the VAT action plan to be adopted this month. Adaptation, in itself, does not create any problems whatsoever, but the principle of setting a minimum VAT level between Member States seems incomplete if not accompanied, in turn, by a maximum threshold that cannot be exceeded by the various national authorities. Since I do not agree with this 'half-legislation', I preferred to abstain.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported the proposal to extend the current regime of the minimum general rates system for three years, which stipules that the general rate in any Member State should not be less than 15%. The extended timeframe provides the necessary legal certainty for stakeholders and it is appropriate to develop qualitative reforms to introduce definitive tax harmonisation arrangements that will enable the effective and easy functioning of the internal market to prevent fraud.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal to conclude a cooperation agreement between Europol and the Federative Republic of Brazil is justified by obvious practical requirements, aiming to intensify the exchange of information on criminal investigations, crime prevention and strategic analyses.  According to Europol, Brazil currently plays a key role in the fight against organised crime, illegal immigration and cybercrime. On the basis of these considerations, I voted in favour of concluding the agreement, believing that strengthening international cooperation could, without doubt, improve and facilitate the fight against organised crime in all its forms.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this agreement between the Brazilian authorities and the Europol agency excludes personal data, this agreement will allow the exchange of information regarding cases opened by the police. One of the assumptions on which information is intended to be exchanged is on migration activities, so we oppose this agreement when considering migration a crime to fight against. In addition, we are against increasing Europol's autonomous working capacity, as it is an agency that is not subject to democratic control of any elected institution.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. Strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol would facilitate and intensify the fight against crime. The agreement provides for exchanges of information on criminal investigation procedures, methods of crime prevention, the results of strategic analyses, as well as participation in training. On the other hand, there is no provision for the exchange of personal data. While this strategic cooperation may be effective in a country particularly affected by organised crime (which is likely to increase at the 2016 Olympic Games), I abstained on this text. This agreement is in fact part of a move towards a European criminal law which we strongly dispute.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report. A new Europol Regulation with a novel and more thorough process for concluding these kinds of cooperation agreements has been agreed upon. Therefore, there is no need to rush through such agreements last-minute. When legalisation does not come under the appropriate scrutiny, this leads to a whole host of problems in the future.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The terms of cooperation governed by the strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, and the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations. There is no provision for the exchange of personal data in this strategic agreement. I did not vote against this proposal but abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a procedural vote giving consent to the agreement between Brazil and Europol on strategic co-operation.  In September 2015 €1.2 billion of taxpayers´ money was given to Europol. I voted against this report as I do not believe that the European Union should have its own unaccountable police agency.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to launch strategic cooperation between Europol and Brazil in the fight against organised crime. Europol has a clear need to cooperate with Brazil, as Brazil is becoming an increasingly important state in the fight against organised crime, such as aid for illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime and credit card fraud, as well as cybercrime. This strategic agreement does not include the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is irrelevant in this case.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite the neutrality on its face of this project of cooperation between Europol and Brazil in the fight against crime in sectors as diverse as aid for illegal immigration and human trafficking, drug-related crime and credit card scams, I could not support a measure that is another step towards the creation of a European criminal law.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil that will allow the exchange of information, opinions, expert analyses as well as training and advisory activities in the context of specific criminal investigations, but excluding the exchange of personal data. Europol seems to have a clear need for operational cooperation with Brazil. According to Europol, Brazil's weight is steadily increasing in the fight against organised crime, including aid to illegal immigration, human trafficking, drug crime and credit card scams, as well as other activities related to cybercrime. Brazil is also of particular interest in the fight against terrorism and asset recovery.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Council is responsible for approving, after consulting Parliament, agreements between Europol and third countries or international organisations, on the basis of Article 23 of Decision 2009/371/JHA. The Moraes report, voted on today by Parliament and supported by me, gives a favourable opinion on the conclusion of a new strategic agreement between Europol and the Federative Republic of Brazil.  The object of the agreement is the exchange of technical, operational and classified information, thus excluding the passage of information on personal data. The current situation, linked to the holding of the Olympic Games in the South American country and brazil's growing commitment to the fight against crime, fraud and trafficking in human beings, makes it essential to develop in-depth relations in these matters.  I supported my colleague's report precisely because I strongly support the objective of starting a strategic relationship by strengthening cooperation on law enforcement.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this agreement excludes the exchange of personal data we voted against as a new regulatory framework for Europol (pending approval) has recently been developed which includes a procedure for such agreements. There is no need to hastily approve agreements with the old, less restrictive regulations.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his readiness for the agreement in this report, but I abstained, as my group has done. Second reading agreement has been reached on Europol and it makes no sense that today we are voting on this agreement with Brazil when, after the adoption of the new text, everything will have to be revised and obsolete.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report on the strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol. Of course, working with Brazil could facilitate and intensify the fight against organised crime, especially as Brazil's weight is on the rise in this area as the country faces problems of illegal immigration, human trafficking or drug trafficking, criminal activities that are also likely to increase sharply with the organization of the 2016 Olympic Games. Therefore, it would be interesting to be able to exchange information on the results of strategic analyses, criminal investigation procedures or methods of crime prevention. However, I question the legitimacy of the European Union in criminal matters, and in particular the institutions such as Europol or Eurojust, which it uses as an armed arm towards the emergence of a European criminal law. What is needed in this and other areas is genuine intergovernmental cooperation, bilateral or multilateral, which would simplify communication and allow us to be truly effective and efficient in the fight against crime.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the proposal for an agreement on strategic cooperation between the Federative Republic of Brazil and Europol. Brazil is proving to be a very active strategic partner in the fight against crime, illegal immigration, human trafficking and illicit trafficking. Therefore, considering it essential to develop greater cooperation between the EU and Brazil in these areas, I supported the report with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and Brazil, which aims to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime, illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and credit card fraud, as well as other activities related to cybercrime and the fight against terrorism. The exchange of personal data has been excluded from the scope of the Agreement, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case. The information exchanged could include expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods and training activities, as well as advice and support in specific criminal investigations.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which supports the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Federative Republic of Brazil and Europol between the European Police Office (Europol). Such an agreement with Brazil would be concluded on strategic cooperation, as it will contribute to the fight against organised crime and will contribute to increasing cooperation in the field of international law enforcement. Such agreements may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The operational cooperation agreement shall include the exchange of personal data. This proposal concerns the proposed acceptance of strategic cooperation between Europol and Brazil. This strategic agreement does not include the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is irrelevant in this case. Information could be exchanged in the areas of expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, methods of crime prevention, training activities, as well as advice and assistance in specific criminal investigations.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe has the power to conclude agreements with third countries referred to in a Decision of the Council for mutual cooperation in the prevention and fight against organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime. MePs voted in support of the proposal relating to the proposed approval of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and Brazil. Since the proposal is based on strategic cooperation and excludes the exchange of personal data, the protection of personal data is not called into question, as it is the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. As Brazil's role is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, trafficking in human beings, drug trafficking, credit card abuse and other activities related to cybercrime, such cooperation is certainly useful, as it will help to strengthen international cooperation in the field of crime prevention, detection and investigation.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report, which is intended to grant Europol the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between Brazil and the EU relating to the exchange of operational, strategic or technically confidential information other than personal data.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the conclusion of this Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Brazil and Europol is an important instrument in the fight against organised crime and that, ultimately, it increases the security of European citizens.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The cooperation agreement between the Federal Republic of Brazil and Europol is an act to be welcomed, useful in the context of the best strategic and operational cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and the partner countries with a view to improving the efficiency of the fight against terrorism, mafias, smuggling and international crime.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol, which the rapporteur calls for, would facilitate and intensify the fight against crime. The agreement provides for exchanges of information on criminal investigation procedures, methods of crime prevention, the results of strategic analyses and participation in training. On the other hand, there is no provision for the exchange of personal data. While this strategic cooperation may be effective in a country particularly affected by organised crime, which is likely to increase during the 2016 Olympic Games, I did not vote in favour of this text. Indeed, this agreement is part of a move towards a European criminal law which we strongly dispute. The sovereignty of our nations is priceless. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Federative Republic of Brazil and Europol is intended to include an exchange of information which may include specialised knowledge, reports on the general situation, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on methods of crime prevention, training activities and the provision of advice and support in certain criminal investigations, excluding exchanges of personal data. The main aim of the agreement derives from the importance of the fight against organised crime, with Brazil being a state that has stood out for its ongoing efforts to combat organised forms of illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime and credit card fraud, as well as other activities related to cybercrime, as well as in the field of combating terrorism. I was in favour of this report because I believe that strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol would intensify efforts against organised crime, being an important pillar in the fight against terrorism.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the agreement between Europol and Brazil. The proposal excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case.  It is considered important to develop cooperation between Europol and Brazil, as brazil is gaining increasing prominence in the fight against organised crime and activities such as becoming more and more involved in financing illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and credit card fraud. Furthermore, as the rapporteur points out, a significant increase in criminal activity is expected for the 2016 Olympic Games.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The objective of the agreement is to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organized crime and terrorism.  This agreement contains provisions on operational cooperation between Eurojust and Brazil, including the exchange of criminal prevention and staff training practices. Important needs have been identified to justify operational cooperation between Brazil and Europol. Brazil is a key country for Europol in the prevention of human and narcotics trafficking and in cybercrime-related activities. The fact that the JJ.OO. is held in Brazil in 2016 may favor an increase in crime, a factor that has been taken into account when reaching the agreement.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Federative Republic of Brazil and Europol. According to Europol, Brazil is becoming increasingly important in the fight against common and organised crime. In addition, as with any other major sporting event, a significant increase in criminal activity is expected for the 2016 Olympic Games. Finally, Brazil is also a country of particular interest in the fight against terrorism and the recovery of assets. Strategic cooperation with Brazil as well as with other countries that have a strategic role, is an aid and support to the fight against crime and strengthens international action with regard to financial investigations but also in all other cases of violation of the law.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. A new Europol Regulation with a novel and more thorough process for concluding these kinds of cooperation agreements has been agreed upon. Therefore, there is no need to rush through such agreements last-minute. When legalisation does not come under the appropriate scrutiny, this leads to a whole host of problems in the future.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the agreement between Brazil and Europol which is designed to prevent and combat organised and cross-border crime and terrorism. Such breaches of law can only be fought and prevented if law enforcement agencies from different countries cooperate with each other.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil. This excludes the exchange of personal data (and this is therefore not relevant), but police cooperation with third countries is of paramount importance. According to Europol, Brazil is gaining increasing prominence in the fight against organised crime and activities such as joining illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and cybercrime. I voted strongly in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement as I think it is extremely important we allow to exchange data between the EU and its relevant partners when it comes any criminal activity, especially when it relates to cross-border, organised criminal acts. It starts with money laundering and could finish with a serious terrorist threat, therefore we need all instruments available to counter it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the report is to authorise Europol to conclude an agreement on strategic cooperation with the Federative Republic of Brazil; agreement that would allow the exchange of strategic, technical, operational and classified information. I am in favour of concluding this agreement because I believe that, in order to combat crime effectively, and organised crime in particular, it is essential not only for close cooperation between the Member States of the Union, but also for a strong partnership with third countries. In particular, effective cooperation can only be based on mutual trust, the most obvious sign of which is precisely the exchange of information. Often, in fact, what prevents the detection of crimes and responsibilities is the fact that the national authorities have only a partial framework which, if completed, would make it possible to combat criminal phenomena of a transnational dimension with a great impact on the lives and safety of citizens. I believe that the agreement between Europol and Brazil will make it possible to combat crime much more effectively, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report on the proposed adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil. There is a clear operational need for Europol to cooperate with Brazil. According to Europol, Brazil is becoming increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, such as facilitating illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and credit card fraud, and other activities in relation to cybercrime.  Moreover, due to the 2016 Olympic Games, as was the case in other major sporting events, there is expected to be an increase in criminal activity. The conclusion of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement with Brazil will help and strengthen the fight against organised crime and contribute to improving cooperation in the field of enforcement of international law.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was easy to vote in favour of this report as it represents the intention to establish a relationship of mutual cooperation between Brazil and Europol in the prevention and fight against organised crime. I am of the opinion that this agreement can only benefit the fight against the various forms of crime, especially at a difficult time like this. Indeed, I believe that, particularly in view of the recent terrorist attacks, any form of cooperation and exchange of information is a valuable support. It was therefore my duty to speak in favour because, in my opinion, everything possible must be done for a safer Europe.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement would provide for a cooperative agreement between Europol and Brazil. Unlike other cooperation agreements with third states or international organisations this would not include the exchange of personal data, making the issue of data protection void in the present case. This arrangement would enable the exchange of criminal investigation procedures, sharing of crime-prevention methods, training exercises, specialist knowledge and other provisions of support in criminal investigations. Europol has found that cooperation with Brazil is an essential factor in the fight against organised crime, such as human trafficking and drug related crimes. The 2016 Olympic Games may also lead to increased levels of crime activity in Brazil, so urgent action in the form of cooperative measures are necessary.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Under its mandate, Europol may conclude agreements with third countries and other organisations in order to establish ways of cooperation, in particular in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. In this context, it is up to Parliament - given the agreement reached - to consent to its signature by Europol. This is given its assent, demonstrated compliance with all legal requirements and guaranteed all safeguards for European citizens. Due to the history that unites us and the close relationship that we still have today, it is particularly important for Portugal that the cooperation between the Federal Republic of Brazil and the Union take this step further.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and Brazil, as Brazil has taken on a very important role on the international stage in the fight against organised crime and activities such as the aiding of illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and credit card fraud, as well as other activities related to cybercrime. The agreement excludes the exchange of personal data and focuses on the exchange of specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, as well as the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information should be mandatory to ensure an effective operational agreement. This proposal concerns the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil which excludes the exchange of personal data in line with data protection.  Brazil is increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime, such as facilitated illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug related crimes and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime related activities.   For this reason we need effective tools preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime with Brazil as it could be a strategic partner.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this agreement between the Brazilian authorities and the Europol agency excludes personal data, this agreement will allow the exchange of information regarding cases opened by the police. One of the assumptions on which information is intended to be exchanged is on migration activities, so we oppose this agreement when considering migration a crime to fight against. In addition, we are against increasing Europol's autonomous working capacity, as it is an agency that is not subject to democratic control of any elected institution.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a context of various threats, there is a need for the EU to strengthen its police instrument, Europol, by increasing its role in the field of international intelligence. More than ever, the exchange of information is a priority and a key element in strengthening the fight against terrorism and all other forms of crime. In this respect, a number of strategic cooperation agreements on the exchange of information have already been concluded between Europol and third countries.  These agreements allow Europol to access information that is important to ensure the security of European citizens. As has already been demonstrated by many past cases, Brazil is a key partner for the EU in the fight against various threats and precisely in order to enable the EU, through Europol, to be more effective against terrorism and organised crime, I have chosen to support the resolution.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As the Olympic Games in Brazil approach, which will take place this year, strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol is absolutely necessary. Brazil is seeing a noticeable increase in the fight against organised crime, and a direct exchange of information based on the data of Brazilian structures is a necessity. I voted for the transition to a new era of the fight against organised crime.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the current Council Decision on Europol, the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, must approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third countries or international organisations. Such an agreement may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information.  This proposal concerns the proposed approval of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Brazil and Europol. According to Europol, Brazil is playing a growing role in the fight against organised crime. Furthermore, crime is expected to increase during the 2016 Olympic Games, as with other major sporting events. Finally, Brazil also deserves special attention in the fight against terrorism and asset recovery.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between Brazil and Europol, as this would help and strengthen the fight against organised crime and contribute to strengthening international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Increasing the effectiveness of action to combat serious crime and terrorism is particularly important today. By improving the exchange of information between law enforcement agencies, we limit the use of loopholes by criminals. Any agreement in this area must be concluded in compliance with the data protection rules of the new Europol Regulation.  The text of the report expresses Parliament's agreement to conclude a cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil with a view to supporting, enhancing and combating the effectiveness of actions and mutual cooperation in the prevention and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime that affect two or more Member States.  The terms of the agreement provide for the exchange of information and may include expertise, reports on the overall situation, the results of strategic analyses, information on investigation procedures and methods of crime prevention, participation in training activities, as well as the provision of advice and support in specific investigations.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this codecision report, the European Parliament approves the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between the European Police Office (Europol) and Brazil. In order to increase efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, Europol has initiated the procedure for concluding an agreement that involves the exchange of information, excluding personal data. Considering that Brazil is increasingly effective against organized crime, illegal immigration, drug against and other activities related to cybercrime, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. By my vote, I support the conclusion of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement in the fight against serious crime and terrorism between Brazil and the European Police Office (Europol). It is imperative that the European Union strengthen its cooperation with third countries in order to be able to face the current challenges, including the fight against terrorism, organised crime and human trafficking.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Strategic cooperation with Brazil is supposed to help combat organized crime and strengthen international law enforcement action. The strategic agreement provides for exchanges of information: expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and crime prevention, training, advice and support in criminal investigations. There is no provision in the text for the exchange of personal data. Nevertheless, categorically refusing the development of a European criminal law (Europol, Eurojust, European Prosecutor, etc.), I abstained.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support cooperation between Europol and Brazil because its aim is to improve and strengthen common action between them in the field of combating organised crime, terrorism and other serious crimes affecting several Member States.  The terms of this Agreement shall include the exchange of information in criminal proceedings, the methods of combating and preventing criminal offences and assistance in the investigation of criminal offences. I believe that cooperation is an important factor in addressing security challenges not only for the EU and its Member States, but also for the whole world.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil. Such a strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. According to Europol, Brazil is increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime in areas such as aid for illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime-related activities. Furthermore, it is to be expected that the 2016 Olympic Games, as with any other major sporting event, will lead to an increase in criminal activity. I am in favour of concluding this strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil, as it supports and intensifies the fight against organized crime and will contribute to greater international cooperation in favor of law enforcement.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: we challenge the move towards a European criminal law.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil. The shared information may involve "expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation processes, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, providing advice and support in certain criminal investigations". This exchange of information may involve the exchange of personal data, although the document states that "the issue of data protection is not relevant" in such a strategic agreement. In addition to this issue, of major importance, the fact that it grants Europol, a supranational structure, out of democratic scope and control, the delegation of tasks which are the responsibility of only the States. We believe that Europol should not overdo it with national police and its activities, and we advocate cooperation between the internal security structures of the various countries. Since the creation of Europol, the EU has given it powers to counter the sovereignty of states. We advocate a model based on cooperation between national authorities and structures and not on the concentration of power in supranational structures, outside the reach and scrutiny of national states and their peoples. For the above, our vote against.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the strategic cooperation agreement between Brazil and Europol. In view of the difficult and complex times that Europe and the international community as a whole are going through, an effective global exchange of information is now more necessary than ever. In particular, Brazil is gaining increasing prominence in the fight against organised crime and trafficking in human beings. Improving the sharing of information between judicial authorities will reduce the gaps and legal shortcomings from which criminals benefit.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against because we have a new Europol Regulation concluded (which will be voted soon) where there is a new procedure for such cooperation agreements, and I do not see a need to rapidly conclude new cooperation agreements under the old (and less stringent) procedure.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of this proposal is to enable the European Police Office to conclude a Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Brazil and Europol, which may concern the exchange of operational, strategic or technical or classified information, with the exception of personal data.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report to ensure greater cooperation between Europol and Brazil in the fight against crime.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of report A8-0070/2016 as the need for EUROPOL's strategic cooperation with third countries is clear, in the fight against organised crime and the enforcement of international law. In addition, that agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. Finally, Brazil is a pioneer in the recovery of stolen assets and in the fight against terrorism.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of the proposal is to authorise the European Police Office (Europol) to conclude an Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Brazil and Europol, which may concern the exchange of operational, strategic or technical, or classified information, excluding personal data. I voted in favour of the Commission proposal.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we approve the conclusion of the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and Brazil. This agreement has the objective of supporting and strengthening action and mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime, through the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal data and classified information. We support this agreement with Brazil, since it’s an important contribution in the fight against international organised crime.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I approve parliament's position on the agreement on strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol. It is important to conclude this strategic agreement with Brazil, as the country plays an important role in the fight against organised crime, trafficking in human beings, drug crime and credit card fraud, as well as other activities related to cybercrime. We must also remember that Rio de Janeiro is hosting the 2016 Olympic Games, so crime is expected to increase.  Overall, strategic cooperation between Europol and Brazil would help and strengthen the fight against organised crime and contribute to strengthening international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the agreement with the need to improve global security cooperation. This strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. There are clear operational needs for Europol to cooperate with Brazil, as Brazil is gaining an increasingly relevant role in the fight against organized crime, such as illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug and credit card fraud offences, as well as other cybercrime-related activities.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the agreement between Brazil and Europol on strategic cooperation. The fight against organised crime and terrorism must not be hindered by a lack of cooperation. The cooperation between Europol and Brazil is a good approach.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Brazil and Europol is an important step in improving international cooperation in law enforcement and in the fight against organised crime. The containment of organised crime in Brazil is of great international importance.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this agreement excludes the exchange of personal data we voted against as a new regulatory framework for Europol (pending approval) has recently been developed which includes a procedure for such agreements. There is no need to hastily approve agreements with the old, less restrictive regulations.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it authorises Europol (the European Police Office) to bring an Agreement on Strategic Cooperation with Brazil to a conclusion, which will aid the fight against international organised crime through the exchange of information, excluding personal data.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
