text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from the vote on this report. The information exchange does not include the exchange of personal data, which is one of the most crucial points when fighting organised crime, and especially terrorism.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As with the previous EUROPOL cooperation agreements we voted against since there is already a new EUROPOL regulation which will be adopted soon and we therefore felt it was right to wait for the new cooperation agreement, rather than to sign the existing one (completed under the old one) which contained less stringent procedures with regard to the operation of EUROPOL.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion as it is a step towards improving the effectiveness of tackling serious crime.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I have approved the cooperation agreement between the Europol agency and the Brazilian authorities in the prevention and fight against organised crime, terrorism and other serious forms of crime. This agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. The forms of terrorism and crime are very different from what they were 20 years ago. Strengthening cooperation between national authorities with Europol is essential to better combat these new forms of crime that do not concern themselves with state borders.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Council believes that Brazil has an important role to play in the fight against organised crime and we vote on this report on the very day the Brazilian congress has recommended an impeachment of that country’s president. The Panama Papers have however revealed that we do not have to look quite so far to find political leaders embroiled in dubious business in Latin America. Senior figures in the UK Tory party have been implicated in shady dealings – and we should remember that impeachment is a tool available in European Member States too.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this proposal is to authorise Europol to conclude an Agreement on Strategic Cooperation with Brazil. The agreement concerns the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. However, it is very important to mention that this excludes personal data.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒When voting for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision authorising the European Police Office (Europol) to conclude a Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the Federal Republic of Brazil and Europol, I was restrained, on the view that the agreement is strategically relevant to both sides and allows the exchange of technical, operational and confidential information, and therefore we should be of particular caution.  Brazil has shown positive results when it comes to fighting organised crime and drug trafficking, and this is particularly important given that the 2016 Olympic Games are being held in Brazil. I believe that international cooperation in the field of security needs to be further strengthened and perfected, and the recent terrorist attacks have confirmed this very fact, and therefore I have been reticent that the position of the ALDE Group is also.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Strategic cooperation with Brazil would facilitate and intensify the fight against organized crime and help strengthen international cooperation in law enforcement. The terms of cooperation governed by the strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, participation in training activities, and the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations. There is no provision in the strategic agreement for the exchange of personal data. We will therefore not vote against this proposal. The demand for agreements with third countries often comes from Member States. However, we dispute the move towards European criminal law (Europol, Eurojust, European prosecutor, etc.). I have therefore decided to abstain on this vote.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Moraes report on the agreement on strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol. As stipulated in its mandate, Europol can enter into agreements with third countries on the prevention and fight against organised crime, terrorism and other serious forms of crime. In order to increase efficiency in this regard, Europol has initiated the process of concluding a strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil. I therefore approved this legislative proposal, as it would help to strengthen international cooperation and intensify the fight against organised crime. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to facilitate and intensify the fight against organised crime between the EU and Brazil. In concrete terms, this agreement will allow for the exchange of information between Europol and Brasilia on the fight against organised crime, trafficking or terrorism. In the run-up to the 2016 Olympic Games, which are likely to be accompanied by a surge in criminal activity, it is crucial to cooperate with Brazil to ensure maximum security at this event, especially for European tourists.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil, as it will aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and will contribute to enhancing international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2016 Summer Olympics will be held in Brazil in the month of August. No Olympics have ever been held in a South American city before. Today, international terrorism is a very serious challenge for all countries. Underestimating this can lead to regrettable consequences such as those resulting from the negligence of the Belgian authorities. In my view, this cooperation should have been strengthened a long time ago, and I hope it is not too late.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no doubt that we are living in a very globalised and developed world. But today’s world is not peaceful and secure. Because of increasing globalisation, the world is facing security threats and challenges that are different in scale and sophistication. In light of this, it is important to note that today’s global security threats and challenges such as organised crime, terrorism, cyber-attacks, credit card fraud, human and drug trafficking cannot be resolved by independent state, organisation or specific sector policy. Therefore, we need more ambitious, more coordinated and more holistic approaches to solve them. In this context, strategic cooperation agreement between Brazil and Europol can be regarded as a big step forward in fight against organised crime, illegal trafficking, cybercrime, terrorism and etc. In addition, it is also important to note that security cooperation between EU and Brazil is urgent since upcoming 2016 Olympic Games in Brazil are expected to increase criminal activities in the state. In this sense, security cooperation between Europol and Brazil will ensure safety for athletes, delegations, tourists and guests.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the proposal to conclude the strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil to prevent and combat any form of terrorism and/or organised crime. The agreement includes the exchange of information useful for the prevention of these crimes, and involves the formation of a system of continuous advice and support.  Given the tension in Europe following the various terrorist attacks that have rocked some of Europe's major capitals, I believe it is essential to fortify agreements with foreign countries, thereby creating greater security between borders.  Our priority must be the security of our citizens, and everything about cooperation and the exchange of information can only be well received.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europol's strategic cooperation with Brazilian law enforcement is designed to strengthen the fight against international organised crime, trafficking in human beings, narcotics and international financial and cybercrime. This type of crime does not recognise national borders, and criminal groups are using precisely the fact that international cooperation in this area is not sufficient. The network of third countries with which such agreements are concluded should therefore be extended.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the agreement on strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol in the area of organised crime. According to Europol, Brazil's weight is steadily increasing in the fight against organised crime, including aid to illegal immigration and human trafficking, drug crime and credit card scams, as well as other activities related to cybercrime and terrorism. The strategic agreement does not include provisions on the exchange of personal data. So I don't object to that. The demand for agreements with third countries often comes from Member States. However, I dispute the move towards European criminal law (Europol, Eurojust, European prosecutor, etc.).

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this agreement between Europol and Brazil because it is part of the development of a European criminal law, which I dispute.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposal put to the vote is to establish strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol. Indeed, Brazil has gained an important place in the fight against organized crime, drug-related crime and credit card scams, cybercrime... In addition, following the many sporting events it has hosted and will host (World Cup 2014, 2016 Olympic Games), the country has strengthened its competence in the fight against terrorism. As a result, the terms of cooperation between Brazil and Europol include general reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal proceedings, methods of crime prevention and many others. Although the proposed measures do not include the exchange of personal data, they are established by a European criminal law adrift, which is why I abstained.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this agreement between the Brazilian authorities and the Europol agency excludes personal data, this agreement will allow the exchange of information regarding cases opened by the police. One of the assumptions on which information is intended to be exchanged is on migration activities, so we oppose this agreement when considering migration a crime to fight against. In addition, we are against increasing Europol's autonomous working capacity, as it is an agency that is not subject to democratic control of any elected institution.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the adoption of this cooperation agreement, where the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, encourages the exchange of information and personal data with Brazil to improve strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol.   I support this agreement as it promotes in the same way the exchange of expertise, results, strategic analyses and information on crime prevention methods. It promotes training activities and advice between the two and supports different criminal investigations.  The importance of this agreement lies, in the relevant role that Brazil is taking in the fight against organized crime, terrorism and data recovery.  Taking into account the considerations set out above and since cooperation with Brazil will contribute to the fight against crime, strengthening it and establishing a closer link at the international level, I vote favorably for approval.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. Europol is an office that does not help security, it means wasting taxpayers' money. The agreement with Brazil does not concern the exchange of personal data, but all sorts of training and analysis exchanges that will not help security in Europe or Brazil. If member states want, they can agree with Brazil on their own to exchange police information.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. In consultation with the European Parliament, the Europol Council decides on the conclusion of strategic agreements on international cooperation with third countries or organisations. The Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Brazil and Europol aims to combat organised crime, human trafficking and other criminal activities.  According to Europol's latest report, Brazil is the key country with which the Agreement should be signed. The current signing timeframe coincides with the holding of the 2016 Olympic Games when a higher rate of criminal activity is expected. I supported the Report on the Conclusion of the Agreement between Europol and Brazil, as this allows for a contribution to better international security and the reduction of criminality.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As has already been the case a few times in recent months, a vote was held today on the conclusion of a Europol strategic cooperation agreement with a third country, this time with the Federative Republic of Brazil. In particular, the summer Olympic Games , which are always intensifying the activities of different types of criminals, are about to take place here. Beyond them, it will be possible to promote more active and effective combating of illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug-related crime and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime-related activities. Counter-terrorism activities also play an important role in cooperation with Brazil. Given that this agreement will help to combat organised crime more effectively, as well as to significantly strengthen cooperation between international law enforcement bodies, it is impossible to think of any single reason that would prevent the proposal for a Council agreement from being supported.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Brazil is one of the countries with the highest crime rate in the world. At the same time, a substantial part of the crime stems from the drug trade. Cybercrime, bank robberies and credit card fraud are increasing. The exchange of personal data is excluded from the strategic agreement in question, the agreement is limited to the exchange of expertise, situation reports, strategic analyses and expert advice. In the context of this year's Olympic Games, the capital of which has become Rio de Janeiro, the role of the agreement is also increasing in the fight against terrorism and possible terrorist threats and attacks.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement on strategic cooperation between the Federal Republic of Brazil and Europol, because it is sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This initiative is, in principle, positive, given Brazil's weight in global organized crime (this issue will be at the forefront at the 2016 Olympic Games). Nevertheless, we question the emptiness of this text, which is limited to the exchange of information of a general nature. There are no plans to exchange personal data. This type of agreement of primary importance must remain the responsibility of sovereign states, and we challenge any institution of European criminal law.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal for a new cooperation agreement between the European Police Office (Europol) and Brazil to crack down on organised crime and terrorism. Europol says that Brazil is increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime, including illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings. It also has an eye on the 2016 Olympic Games, which, like other major sports events, could create opportunities for increased criminal activity.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Brazil and Europol sees my vote in favour. This strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil excludes the exchange of personal data, but includes specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigations and more. As Brazil is gaining a growing prominence in the fight against organised crime and activities such as illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, I am also in favour of this.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Brazil is a particularly important partner in the fight against organised crime, so I supported the Moraes resolution in order to expand Europol's cooperation with the South American state. Given the upcoming international events taking place in Brazil, we should work together to ensure security on both sides of the Atlantic.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the report giving the approval of this House to the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil. I am sure it will contribute to the fight against organised crime, strengthening it, as well as strengthening police cooperation at the international level.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 A prerequisite for the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third States or international organisations is the adoption of the Council, after consulting the European Parliament. One category of these agreements is operational cooperation agreements, but they often include the controversial issue of the exchange of personal data. This proposal for a strategic agreement between Europol and Brazil is, in my opinion, desirable, because in principle it does not allow the exchange of personal data, but only specialised material such as reports, strategic analyses and methods of crime prevention. I would like to support this resolution taking into account Europol's position on Brazil's growing importance in the fight against organised crime (trafficking in human beings, drugs, cybercrime, etc.), but also terrorism. A supporting argument for the conclusion of the agreement on strategic cooperation with Brazil is also the upcoming organisation of the Olympic Games, since such sports organisations are seeing an increase in crime.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report focuses on the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol, the European Police Office, which arbitrarily collects personal data in Europe and may refuse to share it with the citizens concerned who request it, and Brazil. It is important to ensure that the countries with which the European Union concludes police cooperation agreements offer all the guarantees of respect for freedoms. In the wake of the large-scale spying scandals, by the NSA and by the German authorities, European governments and institutions, we are no longer in a position to provide these guarantees on the European side. Finally, one can question this eagerness to conclude cooperation agreements between Europol and third countries, even though a new Europol regulation is being discussed, and it introduces new, more restrictive procedures for this type of agreement. Should we take the lead? I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This cooperation, including the exchange of information, is interesting from a crime-fighting perspective. Brazil has a strong interest in this, especially in the organisation of the Summer Olympics. It is not stipulated that there may be exchanges of personal data. However, I am opposed to the growing influence of European criminal law. As a result, I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Brazil and Europol. It is extremely important to strengthen the fight against terrorism and organised crime. According to Europol, Brazil is increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime in areas such as aid for illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime-related activities. Exchanges of information between Europol and the Brazilian authorities are essential. These may include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation processes, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, advice and support in certain criminal investigations.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report for increased cooperation between Brazil and Europol. By exchanging strategic information both Brazilian and European authorities can more effectively fight organised crime, tackle fraud and combat trafficking in human beings and illegal drugs.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Parliament was consulted on the future international agreement establishing operational and strategic cooperation between Europol and Brazil. This agreement was voted on before the vote on the future Europol regulation, which will give the European Parliament more prerogatives and ensure better safeguards, especially in the area of personal data protection. Although totally in favour of cooperation between Europol and Brazil, I wanted to send a clear signal and defend Parliament's role on such essential issues as cooperation in the fight against crime and trafficking. To that end, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Europol is authorised, within the limits of its powers, to conclude international agreements with third countries and international organisations in the field of the exchange of information or classified information. In order to comply with the EU legislative procedure, the conclusion of these agreements is subject to the approval of the Council and to consultation of the European Parliament. Brazil has been one of the Union's strategic partners since 2007, and our cooperation covers a number of areas: economic growth, cooperation on key foreign policy issues, joint face-to-face with global challenges such as respect for human rights, climate change and the fight against poverty. The fight against terrorism and organised crime is also an important area of enhanced cooperation. Brazil has long-term experience in combating crime, organised crime, drug trafficking, which will be subjected to a rigorous test in the run-up to this summer's Olympic Games. In the enhanced cooperation between Europol and Brazil on interior and security issues, I see a chance for both sides to exchange best practices and methods used in criminal investigations, not least information that can make a significant contribution to detecting perpetrators. In order to keep our citizens safe, it is important that personal data is excluded from such exchanges. I express my support for the report and am voting in favour of its adoption.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which aims to authorise the European Police Office (Europol) to conclude an Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Brazil and Europol, which may concern the exchange of operational, strategic or technical, or classified information, excluding personal data.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council adopted a draft decision approving europol's conclusion of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Federal Republic of Brazil and the European Police Office (Europol). The Council should consult Parliament before approving it.  The strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, so there is no data protection problem. According to Europol, Brazil is playing a growing role in the fight against organised crime and deserves special attention in the fight against terrorism and asset recovery. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament support the Council's draft decision in order to combat organised crime and strengthen international law enforcement cooperation. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol would facilitate and intensify the fight against organised crime and help strengthen international cooperation in law enforcement. According to Europol, Brazil's weight is steadily increasing in the fight against organised crime, including aid to illegal immigration and human trafficking, drugs and credit card scams, as well as other activities related to cybercrime. There is no provision in the strategic agreement for the exchange of personal data. We will therefore not vote against this proposal, especially since the demand for agreements with third countries often comes from Member States. However, we are challenging the move towards a European criminal law (Europol, Eurojust, European prosecutor, etc.), as a result of which we abstain on this text.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document refers to the proposal for the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil. Information exchanged under this agreement includes expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation processes, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, advice and support in certain criminal investigations. I advocate the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil, as it supports and promotes the fight against organised crime in areas such as aid to illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and credit card fraud, as well as other activities related to cybercrime.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the agreement on strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol. This agreement strengthens cooperation between Europol and the Brazilian authorities in the prevention and fight against organised crime, terrorism and other serious forms of crime.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. In view of the tragic events on European territory, and the increase in attacks and criminal acts in other states, the fight against terrorism, organised crime and forms of serious crime is essential. We have a duty to facilitate the task of the European authorities which, through their work, guarantee the safety of European and non-European citizens. As such, the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol, on the one hand, and Brazil, on the other, will allow the exchange of information, while excluding the exchange of personal data. I obviously voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report providing for the agreement on strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol as I believe it can support the fight against organised crime and to strengthen international cooperation in the field of law enforcement. This strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case.  The information exchanged could include specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, as well as the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europol's main task is to maintain security throughout Europe. Cooperation not only between EU Member States but also with the third countries concerned is essential to achieve this. Since I believe that Brazil can serve as an important strategic partner for the European Union in many respects, I voted in favour of approving the cooperation agreement.  We must not forget, for example, the upcoming Olympic Games, which will be held in Brazil in 2016 and which are regularly a visit by many European citizens. Thanks to the Cooperation Agreement, the authorities will be better prepared for the security challenges that may arise in the event of such an event.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ International cooperation agreements with third states or international organisations are approved by the Council after having consulted the European Parliament. I have voted for this report regarding the strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil that will aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the approval of the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Federative Republic of Brazil and Europol. The information exchanged could include expert knowledge, reports on the general situation, results of strategic analysis, information on prosecution procedures, information on methods of crime prevention, training activities, and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. Such a strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case. We support the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil, as it would help and strengthen the fight against organised crime and help strengthen international cooperation in law enforcement.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I consider global cooperation and increased action between states and international organisations, with the aim of combating organised crime, as objectives of the utmost importance to the European Union and its partners. The events of recent years have shown us that the deficiencies of communication between the structures charged with our safety have led to the loss of thousands of lives. Thus, the report adopted today approves the strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol, which intensifies the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information with the aim of preventing and combating crime, while also creating a framework for collaboration in the increasing fight between countries and the phenomenon of terrorism.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because it is intended to be purely strategic cooperation and not to exchange data.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal by the rapporteur Claude Morales, as I believe that the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil can allow a useful exchange of information between the two parties on sensitive issues, such as the fight against organised crime, illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – In these times of turmoil and increased threat of terrorism attacks in Europe, we should use all means to strengthen our capacities to cope with the threats. Brazil is increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime, including illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings. An agreement between Europol and Brazil, especially months before the 2016 Olympic Games, is important for the enable the exchange of specialist knowledge, information as well as advice and support related to criminal investigations. Hence, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Agreements with third countries, such as this agreement with Brazil, may include the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or confidential information. According to Europol, Brazil is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime such as assisted illegal immigration and human trafficking, drug-related offences and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime activities.  Furthermore, as the 2016 Olympic Games are expected to lead to an increase in criminal activity, for the safety of all athletes and guests, it is necessary to take steps already and raise the existing level of security through this bilateral agreement. The operational cooperation agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, therefore the issue of data protection in this case is irrelevant. Given that there is a clear operational need for Europol to cooperate with Brazil, I supported the adoption of this agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. According to Europol, Brazil's weight is steadily increasing in the fight against organized crime, including aid to illegal immigration and human trafficking, drug crime and credit card scams, as well as other activities related to cybercrime. In addition, the 2016 Olympic Games, like all other major sporting events, will certainly be accompanied by a surge in criminal activity. Finally, Brazil has a particular interest in the fight against terrorism and asset recovery. The terms of cooperation governed by the strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, participation in training activities, and the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations. There is no provision in the strategic agreement for the exchange of personal data, which I find particularly positive. In these circumstances, because I challenge in principle the evolution towards a European criminal law, I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ There is a clear operational need for Europol to cooperate with Brazil. According to Europol, Brazil is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, such as assisted illegal immigration and human trafficking, drug-related offences and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime activities.  Furthermore, the 2016 Olympic Games are expected to lead to an increase in criminal activity, which is true for all other major sporting events. Finally, Brazil is also a country of particular interest in the area of counter-terrorism and property recovery. I support the signing of a strategic cooperation agreement.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the proposal for the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Brazil and EUROPOL. The shared information may involve "expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation processes, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, providing advice and support in certain criminal investigations". From the outset, the exchange of information will not involve the exchange of personal data. The most relevant political element is that EUROPOL, a supranational structure, out of reach and any democratic control, is granted the delegation of tasks that should be the exclusive competence of the States.  Like other EU agencies, EUROPOL is a structure created in a logic of federalisation of this process of capitalist integration, and which pursues its security policies. Since its creation, the scope of its powers has been amplified, attacking the sovereignty of states and the individual freedoms and guarantees of citizens. By the above the vote against.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report by my colleague Claude Moraes on strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol. Brazil is a country of particular interest in the fight against terrorism and the return of property. At the same time, it is also very important in the fight against organised crime, such as assisted illegal immigration and human trafficking, drug offences and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime activities. In my view, this agreement could increase efficiency in preventing and combating serious crime and strengthen international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to approve a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil, as it has good potential to strengthen the EU's role in the fight against organised crime. At the same time, this agreement does not pose a threat to the protection of personal data, since it excludes their exchange.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Council Decision 2009/371/JHA, it is for the Council to approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements between europol and third countries or international organisations after consulting the European Parliament. This proposal concerns the proposal to approve the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil. This strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. Therefore, the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case.  According to Europol, Brazil is becoming increasingly important in the fight against organised crime as the South American country is becoming an increasingly important hub for financial and economic crimes. In addition, as with any other major sporting event, an increase in criminal activity is expected for the 2016 Olympic Games.  I voted in favour of this report because I believe that cooperation between the EU and Brazil can provide concrete support for the international fight against financial fraud and to strengthen cooperation with regard to criminal investigations.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved the cooperation agreement between Europol (European Police Office, established in 1995) and the Brazilian authorities in the prevention and fight against organised crime as well as terrorism. This fight against evil has no borders and must be at all times. In this sense, cooperating with our partners, even beyond the EU's borders, is a priority. Finally, it should be noted that this agreement excludes the exchange of personal data.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. According to Europol, Brazil is increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime in areas such as aid for illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime-related activities. I approved in favour of this report establishing an agreement between Europol and Brazil in the call to combat organised crime, with the aim of contributing to greater international cooperation in the interests of law enforcement. The information exchanged in this agreement will relate to expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation processes, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, providing advice and support in certain criminal investigations.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Authorises Europol to conclude the strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil in order to strengthen the fight against organised crime and increase the strengthening of international cooperation in law enforcement.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil, an agreement which aims to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against serious crime, in particular organised crime, illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related offences and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime-related activities , and the fight against terrorism. The exchange of personal data has been excluded from the scope of the agreement, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case. The information exchanged could include expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods and training activities, as well as advice and support in specific criminal investigations.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The vote on this draft decision calls on the European Commission to assess, following the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation (2013/0091 (COD)), the provisions contained in the cooperation agreement and ask the EU executive to inform the Council and Parliament of the conclusions of this assessment and, if necessary, to make a recommendation to authorise the opening of an international renegotiation of the agreement.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report. It should be noted that the report contains positive aspects. It expresses the hope that strategic cooperation between the EU and Brazil should contribute to the fight against organised crime and contribute to increasing cooperation in international law enforcement. However, the report does not refer to the real current situation in the country, especially in the fight against organised crime. There are also reasonable doubts about the ability of the Brazilian responsible authorities to ensure the confidentiality of data and to prevent their leakage.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil and the information exchanged under this Agreement relates, inter among others, to expertise, results of strategic analyses or information on crime prevention methods. The main purpose of this exchange will be the prevention and fight against organized crime. According to Europol, Brazil plays an increasingly important role in the fight against organised crime in areas such as aid to illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes, as well as cybercrime-related activities. In addition, it may be possible that the 2016 Olympic Games will lead to an increase in criminal activities and, as such, Brazil has a particular strategic interest in the fight against terrorism. I consider it absolutely essential, for international cooperation in favour of the implementation of existing international legislation, as well as for intensifying the fight against organised crime, the conclusion of these agreements between the European Union and third states or international organisations, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text on the draft enforcement decision of the Council, which approved the conclusion by Europol of the agreement on strategic cooperation between the Federal Republic of Brazil and the European Police Office (Europol). The text therefore asks the Commission to assess, after the new Europol regulation comes into force, the provisions contained in the cooperation agreement, to inform Parliament and the Council of the conclusions of this assessment and, if necessary, to make a recommendation to authorise the opening of an international renegotiation of this agreement. Such an agreement would facilitate and intensify the fight against organized crime and help strengthen international law enforcement cooperation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this agreement excludes the exchange of personal data we voted against as a new regulatory framework for Europol (pending approval) has recently been developed which includes a procedure for such agreements. There is no need to hastily approve agreements with the old, less restrictive regulations.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this agreement between the Brazilian authorities and the Europol agency excludes personal data, this agreement will allow the exchange of information regarding cases opened by the police. One of the assumptions on which information is intended to be exchanged is on migration activities, so we oppose this agreement when considering migration a crime to fight against. In addition, we are against increasing Europol's autonomous working capacity, as it is an agency that is not subject to democratic control of any elected institution.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal concerning the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil because I believe that it is of major importance in strengthening the fight against international organised crime and terrorism. According to the provisions of the agreement, the information exchanged should include specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results and information on criminal investigation procedures.  In addition, information on crime prevention methods, participation in training activities, provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations should also be included.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the Federative Republic of Brazil and Europol aims at the exchange of information at various levels, including the exchange of information on criminal investigation processes and on methods of crime prevention, provision of advice, support in certain criminal investigations, general situation reports and results of strategic analyses. However, the agreement does not cover provisions on the exchange of personal data.  Brazil appears to be a key partner in the fight against organized crime, especially as it will host the 2016 Olympic games, where there may be an increase in activities such as drug trafficking, arms trafficking, illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings. I voted to approve the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Brazil and Europol because greater cooperation between the information services of the parties involved is essential with regard to making known, analysed, evaluating and better responding to the new dimensions of organised crime, not only in Europe but also in the world. Therefore, this strategic cooperation agreement is essential to detect threats that endanger the security of our societies.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of the proposal is to authorise Europol - the European Police Office - to bring an Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Brazil and Europol to a conclusion, which may concern the exchange of operational, strategic or technical, or classified information, excluding personal data. This is something that I can support.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement on strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol is in my opinion an important agreement as it is necessary to work together to fight organised crime. Since this agreement is not about the exchange of personal data, I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I abstained for this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the conclusion of the agreement between the Federative Republic of Brazil and the European Police Office (Europol), as this strategic cooperation is essential to combat transnational crime. This Agreement shall include the exchange of operational, strategic and professional information as well as classified information. However, the exchange of personal data is excluded from this strategic cooperation. The Agreement should only exchange information involving expertise, general situation reports, the results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training activities and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. I am glad that Europol is also starting to cooperate with Brazil, as Brazil's importance in the fight against organised crime is proving to be important. These are mainly cases of illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, drug crime, credit card fraud, but also cybercrime. The forthcoming Olympic Games, which will be held in Brazil this year, pose an increased risk of crime. For this reason too, I supported the conclusion of the agreement, as I hope that it will contribute to the fight against international crime and improve cooperation in the field of the enforcement of international law.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Council decision authorising Europol (European Police Office) to conclude a strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil, aimed at combating organised crime and terrorism. According to Europol, Brazil is gaining increasing prominence in the fight against organised crime and activities such as becoming more and more involved in financing illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related crimes and credit card fraud, as well as other activities related to cybercrime.  In addition, as with any other major sporting event, a significant increase in criminal activities is expected for the 2016 Olympic Games in Brazil, where such an agreement could be particularly useful in strengthening international cooperation on law enforcement.  The agreement provides for the exchange of information, specialist knowledge, strategic analyses, information on criminal proceedings and support in criminal investigations, while completely excluding the exchange of personal data.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The new agreement between Brazil and the European Police Office EUROPOL is strategic for strengthening the fight against organised crime and terrorism. The agreement is an important tool to increase security, also in view of the fact that Brazil is the venue for the 2016 Summer Olympics. As this is one of the biggest sporting events of the year, with concerns about increased criminal activity, closer cooperation, particularly through the exchange of information and knowledge, is in the strong interest of both sides.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Police Office (Europol) assists EU member states in the fight against organised crime within the European Union. As organised crime is an international problem and requires cooperation with third countries, Europol has launched a procedure for concluding strategic cooperation agreements with Brazil.  This agreement ensures the exchange of information that may include expert knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on crime prevention methods and criminal investigation procedures, participation in training activities and providing advice and support in individual criminal investigations. The Strategic Agreement does not contain provisions relating to the exchange of personal data and confidential information.  The strategic agreement aims to support and strengthen the competent authorities of the Member States and to foster their cooperation with each other for the prevention and fight against organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more Member States. Therefore, I support this report and consider it important to contribute to the security of the Member States of the European Union through joint cooperation in the prevention and fight against organised crime.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil, which would aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement cooperation. Organised crime is a global problem, and so global cooperation is necessary if we are to tackle it successfully.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ By a Decision of the European Council, Europol (European Police Office), which assists state law enforcement authorities in the fight against serious international crimes and terrorism, may conclude agreements with third countries on the Council's list of decisions, in order to contribute jointly to the prevention and fight against organised crime, terrorism and other serious crimes. The conclusion of strategic cooperation agreements between Europol and Brazil would increase the exchange of operating, strategic and technical information, excluding personal data and classified information, which would greatly contribute to the effectiveness of Europol and the national authorities responsible for the prevention and fight against crime. I support colleague Moraes' report, as I believe that europol would increase its effectiveness in preventing and combating crime and crime by concluding this agreement, thus helping the security of Member States, in particular citizens of the European Union. Organised crime and other forms of serious crime are an international problem as they cross borders, which means that it is essential that the EU cooperates with third countries that can be directly or indirectly linked to crime and serious crimes in the EU.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it is a potentially beneficial way of streamlining cooperation in the fight against organised crime.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Europol of a strategic cooperation agreement between the Federative Republic of Brazil and the European Police Office (Europol). I support the conclusion of an agreement that will allow the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information, without the exchange of personal data, between Brazil and Europol. I am working on all such agreements with third countries to strengthen the fight against organised crime, such as illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings or drug-related offences.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This proposal concerns the adoption of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil. Such agreements concern the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The operational cooperation agreement also includes the exchange of data.  We have strong concerns about such agreements as it provides for strong monitoring mechanisms and there is a risk that basic civil and political rights will be undone and democratic freedoms will be affected. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The need for EUROPOL's strategic cooperation with third countries in the fight against organised crime and the enforcement of international law is clear.  In addition, that agreement excludes the exchange of personal data. Finally, Brazil is a pioneer in the recovery of stolen assets and in the fight against terrorism.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I agreed that the European Parliament should give its support to the Council for the formal authorisation of the conclusion of the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and Brazil. I have considered all the information that suggests that Brazil is an increasingly important partner for Europe in the fight against international organised crime and terrorism. Hosting this year's Olympics in Brazil is an additional element that has now made it urgent to include this cooperation, professional methods and information exchange, as well as mutual advice, within the organised legal framework.  European and other experience in the fight against international terrorism shows that major sporting events such as the Olympics are a priority target for terrorists, and I therefore considered it appropriate that this important agreement should in no way be delayed in consulting the EP.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Brazil is considered by Europol as increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime, such as drug related crimes, credit card fraud, illegal immigration, illegal trafficking of human beings, as well as cybercrime. Furthermore, Brazil is relevant in the area of counter-terrorism and asset recovery and the 2016 Olympics are expected to lead to an increase in criminal activities. Therefore, there seems to be an urgent need for Europol to increase its strategic cooperation with Brazil, which would aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement cooperation. Thus, I supported the proposed legislative resolution.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. This is an important piece of crime." Europol seems to have a clear need for operational collaboration with Brazil. According to Europol, Brazil's weight is steadily increasing in the fight against organised crime, including aid to illegal immigration and human trafficking, drug crime and credit card scams, as well as other activities related to cybercrime. On the other hand, the 2016 Olympic Games, like all other major sporting events, will certainly be accompanied by a surge in criminal activity. Finally, Brazil has a particular interest in the fight against terrorism and asset recovery.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil, since it will contribute to aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement cooperation. According to Europol, Brazil is increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime, such as facilitated illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug related crimes and credit card fraud, as well as other cybercrime related activities. Furthermore, the 2016 Olympic Games are expected, as is the case with any other major sports event, to lead to increased criminal activities. Lastly, Brazil is also of particular interest in the area of counter-terrorism and asset recovery.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I voted in favour of the report because strategic cooperation between Europol and the Brazilian authorities will improve the security of nationals of the Member States. This agreement does not concern the exchange of personal data, so the most sensitive issues are not covered here in international agreements. In the meantime, this agreement will require Europol to have more tools to combat drug trafficking and organised crime. In addition, it will be possible to introduce a more effective barrier to cybercrime and fraud related to payment using payment cards. Without this agreement, such measures have so far been difficult to take, and sometimes not impossible. The conclusion of a strategic agreement with Brazil will remove most of the obstacles to the effective fight against cross-border crime.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the conclusion of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between the Federal Republic of Brazil and Europol, as I believe it will strengthen the fight against organised crime, terrorism and other criminal offences.  The terms of cooperation governed by the strategic agreement exclude the exchange of personal data, but provide for the exchange of information that complies with Europol's tasks and includes expertise, general affairs reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures and methods of crime prevention, participation in training activities and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations.  Given the clear operational need for Europol to cooperate with Brazil, it is of utmost importance that this agreement will contribute to reducing loopholes exploited by criminals and strengthening the fight against serious crime and terrorism.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the report by Europol on the draft Council Implementing Decision approving the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between the Federative Republic of Brazil and the European Police Office (Europol). This proposal concerns the proposed approval of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and Brazil. Such strategic cooperation excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of the protection of personal data is irrelevant in this case. The data exchanged could include expertise, general status reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and methods for crime prevention, information on training activities and advice and support for individual criminal investigations.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this agreement excludes the exchange of personal data we voted against as a new regulatory framework for Europol (pending approval) has recently been developed which includes a procedure for such agreements. There is no need to hastily approve agreements with the old, less restrictive regulations.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement does not include provisions on the exchange of personal data. This request for an agreement with a third country comes from the member countries of the European Union. However, I dispute the current evolution towards a European criminal law (Europol, Eurojust, European prosecutor, etc.). So I chose abstention.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the current Council Decision on Europol, the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, must approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third countries or international organisations. Such an agreement may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The operational cooperation agreement also includes the exchange of personal data. This proposal concerns the proposed approval of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Brazil and Europol. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although this agreement excludes the exchange of personal data we voted against as a new regulatory framework for Europol (pending approval) has recently been developed which includes a procedure for such agreements. There is no need to hastily approve agreements with the old, less restrictive regulations.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I abstain from this report why, although in principle an agreement with Brazil on cooperation and coordination in security policies, there are still many doubts as to the content of this agreement, how the process followed to approve it and the level of respect for certain guaranteeing principles enshrined in European legislation and absent in Brazil.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the decision approving the conclusion of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between the Federative Republic of Brazil and Europol. This report entails strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Brazil, where the information exchanged could include specialist knowledge, information on criminal investigation procedures and crime-prevention methods. Brazil is increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime, such as illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, as well as drug and cyber—crime related activities. This report helps to reinforce the fight against organised crime and contributes to enhancing international law enforcement and cooperation.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. To increase efficiency in preventing and combating the various forms of crime, Europol has initiated the procedure to conclude a strategic cooperation agreement between Brazil and Europol. The purpose of this decision is to conclude such an agreement, which is necessary in order to continue to fight in this area. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the Agreement on Strategic Cooperation between Brazil and Europol because it will contribute to a better fight against organised crime. Europol sees Brazil as increasingly important in the fight against serious crimes such as drug-related crime, credit card fraud, illegal immigration and human trafficking.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Under this agreement, the information shared may involve "expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation cases, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, provision of advice and support in certain criminal investigations". This exchange of information may involve the exchange of personal data, although the document states that "the issue of data protection is not relevant" in such a strategic agreement. In addition to this issue, of major importance, the fact that it grants Europol, a supranational structure, out of democratic scope and control, the delegation of tasks which are the responsibility of the States only. We believe that Europol should not overdo it with national police and its activities, and we advocate cooperation between the internal security structures of the various countries. Like other European Union (EU) agencies, Europol is a structure set up to enforce the implementation of the federalisation path. Since its inception, the EU has given it powers to counter the sovereignty of states.  By the above the vote against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. It concerns strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol in the fight against crime and terrorism, which will lead to improved law enforcement cooperation. The agreement excludes the exchange of personal data.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. The constant and worldwide increase in cross-border and organised crime, as well as the growing global terror threat, have been supported. Especially global threats such as those posed by organised crime and international terrorist networks can only be countered through cross-border cooperation.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of europol's Strategic Cooperation Agreement with Brazil. The content of the agreement rightly concerns increasing the effectiveness of action in combating serious forms of crime. The European Police Office may conclude agreements with countries which are not members of the European Union, which are determined by a Decision of the Council.  The cooperation with Brazil will benefit both the security of the EU Member States and Brazil itself. This is a hugely important issue given that Brazil will soon host the 2016 Summer Olympics. The joint prevention of organised crime, assistance in the fight against terrorism and the unlawful activities of criminal groups should eliminate the dangers of non-joint action.  The continued expansion of cooperation to countries outside the European Union has a positive impact on the effect of the activities carried out. Analysing, exchanging, gathering information and efficient coordination will help to gradually minimise the number of illegal crime areas. I agree with the proposed cooperation strategy, which is a strategic agreement on the exchange of information that does not include personal data.  Such an agreement has already been concluded with other countries outside the European Union. Europol is currently cooperating with eighteen non-EU countries, including four countries, with a strategic agreement. The number of countries cooperating with Europol should continue to grow in order to increase the effectiveness and effectiveness of the actions taken.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it would aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement cooperation with Brazil. As a post graduate student of development I worked in Brazil and learnt of the epidemic of street violence and the high level of murders amongst the young male population who too often get caught up in organised crime and gang warfare. This is the number one factor holding back the country from achieving its full potential and we in Europe can help through our excellent Europol agency run by British security expert Rob Wainwright.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement on strategic cooperation between Brazil and Europol, because it will help and strengthen the fight against organised crime and contribute to improving cooperation in the field of enforcement of international law.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. Europol aims to increase effectiveness in preventing and combating terrorism and other forms of serious crime. Within this process, a key point is the cooperation agreement with Brazil. I therefore support this report, considering that it will contribute greatly to the reduction of criminal activities in all its aspects and will also be a key pillar for the implementation of the international cooperation law.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Strategic Agreement between Brazil and Europol, as there is an objective need to establish cooperation between the two actors. Brazil has become an important state in the fight against organised crime, illegal immigration, trafficking in human beings, cybercrime and the like. At the same time, Brazil is also of particular interest in the fight against terrorism and the search for criminal assets. I also consider it an important argument for adopting this agreement that the 2016 Olympic Games are being held in Brazil, which are expected to increase crime rates in the same way as other major sporting events, and wider cooperation is therefore necessary. Personally, I consider it necessary to mention the fact that this agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, which disproves concerns about the misuse of this sensitive information.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I gave my vote to the report by which the European Parliament gave its consent to the conclusion of europol's strategic cooperation agreement with Brazil. I support this type of strategic agreement between the European Union and third countries, as I believe that countries outside the European Union have very valuable experience in the fight against terrorism or organised crime, helping the European Union to improve its practices and strategies through the exchange of information. In the case of Brazil, it is mainly the long-term experience of combating drug crime, financial fraud or illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings. I therefore believe that the exchange of expertise, the results of strategic analyses or criminal investigation procedures will help us to make the fight against organised crime more effective and will contribute to improving cooperation in the field of the enforcement of international law.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A broad network of international cooperation is important for the effectiveness of police services. The detection of cross-border threats, the fight against international crime or the effective search for those prosecuted by law can only be achieved through the cooperation of police from different countries and continents.  The conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between Brazil and Europol is a good step that will improve the functioning of the police services in the Member States of the European Union. Brazil, as south America's largest country, has well-organised security services experienced in the fight against organised crime. The exchange of experience in this area and the strengthening of cooperation will also contribute to making European services more effective. This cooperation will be very valuable in securing sporting events, including the Olympic Games to be held in Rio de Janeiro this year, also in the context of the terrorist threat.  South America is also one of the main sources of drug crime, so close cooperation with the continent's largest country in the exchange of information, training and study visits will undoubtedly increase the detection of drug smuggling from this region of the world into the European Union.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Moraes report authorising the European Police Service (Europol) to conclude a Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Brazil and Europol. This report will allow the Agreement to cover the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, or confidential information, excluding personal data. I welcome the adoption of this report, which is another important step in strengthening the strategic relationship between Brazil and the European Union.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported Europol's cooperation with Brazil, as, according to the latest data, Brazil's cooperation is increasingly important in preventing and combating terrorism, organised crime, for example in the areas of facilitating illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings, drug-related offences and credit card abuse, as well as other activities related to cybercrime.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Hermann Winkler is a German MEP (CDU/EPP). On 23 September 2015 he was a party to a serious road traffic accident. The German Prosecutor seeks the lifting of his immunity so that the MEP can become a subject of the investigation into the incident. There is no nexus to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances, our policy is to vote in favour of lifting his immunity.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls for the lifting of the diplomatic immunity of German MP Hermann Winkler so that he can deal with the justice of his country on accusations which have nothing to do with his political mandate as an MEP.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. German MP Hermann Winkler is accused of causing a road accident. In order for him to be able to answer for it in court, the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office has issued a request to waive his parliamentary immunity.  The facts alleged against him have nothing to do with his work as an MEP and it has been confirmed on the other hand that this request was not submitted with the intention of harming his political activity. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. A German MP is suspected of causing a road accident. The Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office has therefore issued a request to waive its parliamentary immunity. In this case, the facts alleged have nothing to do with his mandate as a Member of Parliament. Moreover, Parliament could not establish a presumption that the application had been submitted with the intention of interfering with the political activity of the Member concerned. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency I would like to confirm I voted in favour of this report. Hermann Winkler is a German MEP who was involved in a road traffic accident in September 2015. There is no nexus to his duties as an MEP and his parliamentary immunity should be waived.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted as the committee recommended on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Hermann Winkler is a German MEP (CDU/EPP). On 23 September 2015 he was a party to a serious road traffic accident. The German Prosecutor seeks the lifting of his immunity so that the MEP can become a subject of the investigation into the incident. There is no nexus to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances our policy is to vote IN FAVOUR of lifting his immunity.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this request to waive the parliamentary immunity of the German Member of Parliament Hermann Winkler (EPP), suspected of having caused a road accident: the facts alleged by the author of this application, in this case the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office, have nothing to do with his mandate as a Member of Parliament, and there is no evidence to suggest that there is fumus persecutionis in this charge.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Following the unanimous opinion of the Board of Prosecutions, I approved the lifting of Mr. Winkler's immunity.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Keeping to the instructions of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market and noticing the non-existence of fumus persecutionis, I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mr Hermann Winkler, who was subject to a preliminary investigation by the Leipzig public prosecutor's office.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I supported this report in favour of the lifting of Hermann Winkler's immunity. This member of the EPP group is being prosecuted by the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office for his involvement in a serious road accident. It seems that the facts alleged against him have nothing to do with his mandate as a Member of Parliament: they are not political statements or positions relating to the performance of his duties.  For this reason, it seems entirely justified to waive his immunity so that Mr. Winkler can be held accountable for his actions in the courts of his country.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of Hermann Winkler's parliamentary immunity since, in the light of the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office (Germany) has requested such a suspension in relation to the opening of an investigation procedure relating to an alleged traffic offence, a criminal procedure which has nothing to do with the exercise of the functions of a Member of the European Parliament , and given that there is no reason to assume that the intention to impair the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis) is hidden behind the proceedings.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament agrees with the request to waive the immunity of Hermann Winkler. The Public Prosecutor's Office in Leipzig, Germany, has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of this Member of the European Parliament, as a pre-trial investigation into the alleged criminal offence has been initiated.
