That request concerns a preliminary pre-trial investigation into a serious accident of 23 September 2015 involving Hermann Winkler. Criminal proceedings shall not relate to an opinion expressed by a Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties or by a vote under the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Hermman Winkler, because the Public Prosecutor's Office in Leipzig, Germany, requested the withdrawal of it in connection with the opening of an investigation into an alleged offence of causing a serious traffic accident, which occurred on 23 September 2015 and in which the said Member was also involved. According to the information, there is no reason to believe that legal proceedings would be initiated with the intention of politically damaging the Member.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. German MP Hermann Winkler is accused of causing a road accident. In order for him to be able to answer for it in court, the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office has issued a request to waive his parliamentary immunity. On the one hand, the facts alleged against him have nothing to do with his work as an MEP. On the other hand, this request was not submitted with the intention of harming its political activity. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Revocation is requested on the basis of the charge of dangerous and intoxicated driving that caused a road accident. There does not appear to be any grounds for immunity under Rule 9 of the Rules of Procedure.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for waiver of parliamentary immunity as in this particular case there is no reason to believe that the accusations made are in connection with his political activities. The relevant German authorities should be therefore allowed to investigate.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The request concerns a preliminary investigation into a serious road accident which took place on 23 September 2015 and in which MEP Hermann Winkler was involved. As the alleged crime is not related to the mandate of a Member of the European Parliament, parliamentary immunity should be waived. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report on the waiver of my colleague's immunity.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Report on the application for waiver of Hermann Winkler's immunity concerns an issue outside the Member's political activities in his country of origin.  As I believe that such cases should follow a smooth path to justice, I voted in favour in order to complete the process.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The criminal proceedings concerning MEP Hermann Winkler do not include any opinion expressed or vote taken in the performance of duties as a Member of the European Parliament. As such Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union would not be breached by an investigation into the serious road traffic accident in which the MEP was involved. There is no reason to conclude that there is any intention to damage the Mr Winkler’s political activity by these criminal proceedings as it has no link with the position held by the MEP.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Hermann Winkler is a German MEP (CDU/EPP). On 23 September 2015 he was a party to a serious road traffic accident. The German Prosecutor seeks the lifting of his immunity so that the MEP can become a subject of the investigation into the incident. There is no nexus to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances our policy is to vote in favour of lifting his immunity.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving Mr Winkler's immunity because the alleged offence is not related to the role currently held and there is no reason, as the JURI Committee considers on the basis of the information acquired, to believe that the intention behind the criminal proceedings is to damage the political activity of the Member.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls for the lifting of the diplomatic immunity of German MP Hermann Winkler so that he can deal with the justice of his country on accusations which have nothing to do with his political mandate as an MEP.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 25 September 2015, the European Parliament received a request from the Public Prosecutor's Office in Leipzig asking for the waiver of the immunity of Mr Hermann Winkler in order to allow criminal proceedings against him to be opened. Mr Winkler was one of the participants in a serious car accident on the motorway in September 2015 and appears to have been under the influence of alcohol at the time. Mr Winkler declined to comment before the JURI committee. It is clear to the rapporteur that the alleged offence has no direct or obvious connection with mr Winkler's performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. Therefore, the report submitted to the European Parliament recommends that Mr Winkler be waived his immunity.  I voted in favour.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Taking into account that the pleading relates to a preliminary investigation into a serious traffic accident on 23 September 2015 involving Hermann Winkler and that the alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with Mr Georgios Kyrtsos' activity as a member of the European Parliament, there is no reason to suspect that the intention of criminal proceedings is to damage the activity of the MEP.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Hermann Winkler, member of the European Parliament, relates to preliminary investigations into a serious road accident on 23 September 2015 in which he was involved and there is no reason to suppose that the intention underlying the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member. Moreover, the alleged infringement is clearly unrelated to the position of Hermann Winkler as a Member of the European Parliament. I therefore agree with the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: MP is suspected of causing a road accident.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a procedure for withdon immunity for Mep Hermann Winkler. The Member concerned suffered a car accident which caused him various injuries. The authorities in his country, Germany, claim that he was driving under the influence of alcohol and that, as such, he must answer to justice. This is not an issue that influences the activity of the Member in his parliamentary activity, nor is it a process for political reasons. In these circumstances, like other similar situations, we voted in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I followed the rapporteur’s recommendation to waive the immunity of Hermann Winkler.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the waivers of the immunity of Representative Herman Winkler (EPP, DE), which was initiated by the Leipzig Attorney General in connection with the cause of a road accident in September 2015.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported waiving the Parliamentary immunity of Hermann Winkler, so that he can be investigated in accordance with German law.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of Hermann Winkler. The public prosecutor’s office in Leipzig has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Hermann Winkler in connection with launching investigative proceedings concerning an alleged offence.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the request for the waiver of Hermann Winkler's parliamentary immunity, which was forwarded on 25 September 2015 by the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office in connection with a preliminary examination concerning a road accident, and which was announced in plenary on 14 December 2015, we voted in favour of the request.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Hermann Winkler's immunity, on the basis that it was an alleged criminal offence, namely a serious traffic accident. Criminal proceedings cannot be linked to Article 8 of the Code of Procedure. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunity of the European Union, i.e. with the expression of opinions or the vote of Members in the performance of his duties, nor is there any doubt that Mr. Winkler is about causing political damage. Therefore, I support this decision lifting Mr. Winkler's immunity.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. German MP Hermann Winkler (EPP) is suspected of causing a road accident. The Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office has therefore issued a request to waive its parliamentary immunity. In this case, the facts alleged have nothing to do with his mandate as a Member of Parliament. On the other hand, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of harming the political activity of the Member concerned. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Hermann Winkler is a German MEP (CDU/EPP). On 23 September 2015 he was a party to a serious road traffic accident. The German Prosecutor seeks the lifting of his immunity so that the MEP can become a subject of the investigation into the incident. There is no nexus to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances our policy is to vote in favour of lifting his immunity.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Angel Dzhambazki's report on Hermann Winkler's request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity.  This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work.  A preliminary investigation into a serious road accident involving Hermann Winkler occurred on 23 September 2015. The alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with Hermann Winkler's duties as a Member of the European Parliament. Thus, I agree with the decision to waive Hermann Winkler's immunity. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the request to waive Hermann Winkler's parliamentary immunity. He is suspected of causing a road accident. The Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office has therefore issued a request to waive its parliamentary immunity.  In this case, the facts alleged have nothing to do with his mandate as a Member of Parliament. On the other hand, Parliament could not establish that there was fumus persecutionis, that is, a sufficiently serious presumption and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of harming the political activity of the Member concerned.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to waive Mr. Winkler's immunity because he is being prosecuted for facts (road accident) that have nothing to do with his mandate.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls for the lifting of the diplomatic immunity of German MP Hermann Winkler so that he can deal with the justice of his country on accusations which have nothing to do with his political mandate as an MEP.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Leipzig State's Attorney's Office has requested the waiver of mp Hermann Winkler's immunity for an alleged criminal act. The Mp for Winkler is being investigated for involvement in a serious car accident that occurred on 23 September 2015. The MEP invoked immunity and the Leipzig attorney general's office forwarded an inquiry to the European Parliament to lift the immunity. I supported a request to lift Representative Winkler's immunity in order to establish the role of an MP in a serious car accident.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The role of the European Parliament as a branch of the Road Police and CSDD authorities has been significantly strengthened in recent months, which is, of course, quite welcome. If previous votes were held to deprive Members of their immunity for failure to respect the speed regime, this time it was about an initial investigation into a traffic accident in the case of German MEP Hermann Wincler. Since this case is by no means linked to Mr Wincler's work in the European Parliament and all Members clearly have no problems with the national or international courts, it was logical to vote in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity so that the German court could fully hear the case and arrive at the final conclusion, which in turn would decide the role of Mr Wincler and, consequently, the possible consequences of this traffic accident.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Public Prosecutor's Office in Leipzig has requested that the immunity of Member Hermann Winkler be waived in connection with a suspected crime in a road accident. This procedure is in line with the EP's Rules of Procedure, the rulings of the Court of Justice of the EU and the rules of Germany, so in order to thoroughly investigate the EP case, I agree with the waiver of immunity.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on her request for the waiver of Hermann Winkler's immunity, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. The allegations against the German MP Hermann Winkler are unrelated to his mandate as an MP: it was a road accident. It is therefore natural to respond favourably to the request by the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office to waive parliamentary immunity.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the removal of the parliamentary immunity of Hermann Winkler.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I expressed my opposition to the request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Hermann Winkler because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that in these cases we must take a guarantee line, so I will continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The request concerns the lifting of parliamentary immunity of Hermann Winkler, German EPP MEP.  Indeed, on 23 September 2015, a serious road accident occurred, involving Hermann Winkler, the public prosecutor's office in Leipzig (Germany) therefore requested the lifting of parliamentary immunity as part of the preliminary investigation.  Considering that the offence is unrelated to his activities as Members of Parliament and that there is no reason to believe that the underlying intention of the criminal proceedings is to interfere with the Member's political activity, I vote in the application to waive immunity.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Mp in question would be the trigger for a road accident. The motive is therefore not bound as such to his work as a parliamentarian. There is no indication that the immunity waiver proceedings were driven by a desire to harm his business. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. The Attorney General of Leipzig (Germany) requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Hermann Winkler, a Member of the European Parliament, as part of the initiation of an investigation procedure for an alleged offence. The request relates to preliminary investigations into a serious road accident on 23 September 2015 in which Hermann Winkler was involved.  The alleged infringement is clearly unrelated to the position of Hermann Winkler as a Member of the European Parliament. I therefore vote in favour of the waiver of Hermann Winkler's parliamentary immunity.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Hermann Winkler, Member of the European Parliament, in connection with launching investigative proceedings concerning an alleged offence.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office requested the waivement of Hermann Winkler's immunity in connection with a preliminary investigation into a serious traffic accident involving Hermann Winkler on 23 September 2015. The Report of the Committee on Legal Affairs points out that, since criminal proceedings do not relate to the expression of an opinion or a vote on the exercise of the mandate of a Member of the European Parliament, and there is no reason to believe that the criminal proceedings were initiated with a view to causing political damage to the Member, the alleged act is clearly not related to Hermann Winkler's position as a Member of the European Parliament. It therefore proposes to parliament that Hermann Winkler's immunity be lifted in relation to the matter in particular. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. German MP Hermann Winkler (EPP) is suspected of causing a road accident. The Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office has therefore issued a request to waive its parliamentary immunity.   In this case, the facts alleged have nothing to do with his mandate as a Member of Parliament. On the other hand, Parliament could not establish that there was a sufficiently serious presumption and specified that the application was submitted with the intention of harming the political activity of the Member concerned.   Accordingly, there is no need to object to this request.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, once all the legal procedures required have elapsed and, because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and because there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Hermann Winkler's parliamentary immunity.  Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee.  I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The request for Mr Winkler's parliamentary immunity following a traffic violation, I obviously voted in favour.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The laws of the European Union and of each Member State apply to everyone, and we MEPs are no exception. I believe that the investigation and closure of the road accident involving Hermann Winkler's name should not be hindered. As this is necessary to get to the bottom of this, and this can only be possible by temporarily suspending the Member's immunity, I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report according to the evaluation made by the JURI Committee.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. A request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity has been made following an investigation into an alleged offence. I voted in favour of the deprivation of liberty at the expense of Hermann Winkler and Am in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity until this case is resolved and no more accusations are made.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Hermann Winkler is a German MEP (CDU/EPP). On 23 September 2015 he was a party to a serious road traffic accident. The German Prosecutor seeks the lifting of his immunity so that the MEP can become a subject of the investigation into the incident. There is no nexus to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances our policy is to vote IN FAVOUR of lifting his immunity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity against my colleague Hermann Winkler, because, on the basis of Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the EU, immunities must be recognised for actions and opinions expressed in the performance of their duties. However, in the present case, the preliminary investigation against Mr Sleyn. Winkler is about an action that goes beyond his parliamentary functions.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. German MP Hermann Winkler (EPP) is suspected of causing a road accident. The Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office has therefore issued a request to waive its parliamentary immunity.  In this case, the facts alleged have nothing to do with his mandate as a Member of Parliament.  So I'm voting for this waiver of immunity.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The immunity of members of parliament is not a personal privilege of Members, but a guarantee of the independence and integrity of Parliament as a whole. This seeks to ensure that MEPs cannot be subjected to any form of questioning, detention or judicial proceedings due to opinions expressed or voting in the performance of their parliamentary duties. However, the relevant national authorities may ask the European Parliament to lift a Member's immunity.  Since the Office of the Attorney General in Leipzig (Germany) requested the lifting of parliamentary immunity of MEP Hermann Winkler in connection with the initiation of investigative proceedings for an alleged criminal offence, and that the criminal proceedings are not related to the expression of an opinion or the vote of a Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties, nor is the alleged offence related to the function of Hermann Winkler as a Member of the European Parliament , I support the Proposal of the European Parliament's decision to lift Hermann Winkler's immunity in order to allow national judicial authorities to carry out their duties smoothly.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity to Mr Hermann Winkler. The data obtained indicate that the request for waiver of immunity originates from an alleged car accident. The German authorities consider that he was driving under the influence of alcohol and that, as such, he has to answer to justice. The waiver of parliamentary immunity is indispensable in order to establish responsibilities. Since the request is not directly related to the performance of its duties, nor is it a process based on political considerations and motivations, we voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. I support colleague Angel Dzhambazki's report on herman Winkler's request to lift immunity. The Leipzig Attorney General's Office has requested the lifting of parliamentary immunity for that MEP in connection with the initiation of an investigation into the alleged offence - a car accident that occurred on 23 September 2015 in which he was involved. Since there is no reason to assume that criminal proceedings are to damage the political activity of Mp Winkler, and under the German Constitution a Member of Parliament cannot be held accountable for a criminal offence without the approval of parliament, I believe that the lifting of herman Winkler's immunity is justified.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Pursuant to Rule 9(3) of the Rules of Procedure, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that the European Parliament waive The honourable Member's parliamentary immunity. Hermann Winkler. I voted in favour of waiving Therendt's immunity. Hermann Winkler because I believe that the German Attorney-General should be allowed to carry out the appropriate investigations.  The request concerns a preliminary investigation into a serious road accident, which took place on 23 September 2015 and in which Hermann Winkler was involved. In any case, I would like to stress that my vote in favour of such a revocation does not involve a judgment as to the guilt or innocence of the Member.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. We were called upon to vote on the lifting of Hermann Winkler's parliamentary immunity. Following the advice of the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, I have agreed to this waiver of immunity for a traffic violation which has not been challenged by the Member concerned.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Hermann Winkler is a German MEP (CDU/EPP). On 23 September 2015 he was a party to a serious road traffic accident. The German Prosecutor seeks the lifting of his immunity so that the MEP can become a subject of the investigation into the incident. There is no nexus to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances our policy is to vote in favour of lifting his immunity.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Attorney General of Leipzig, Germany, requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Hermann Winkler, a Member of the European Parliament, as part of the initiation of an investigation into an alleged offence. The request relates to preliminary investigations into a serious road accident on 23 September 2015 in which Hermann Winkler was involved. In view of the fact that the judicial procedure does not concern opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and that there is no reason to suppose that the intention underlying the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member, this request, which I voted for, decides to lift the immunity of Mr Hermann Winkler.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The judicial procedure does not concern opinions or actions in the performance of Hermann Winkler's duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of Hermann Winkler's parliamentary immunity since, in the light of the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office (Germany) has requested such a suspension in relation to the opening of an investigation procedure relating to an alleged traffic offence, criminal proceedings which have nothing to do with the exercise of the functions of a Member of the European Parliament and given that there are no grounds to assume that behind the procedure lies the intention to harm the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis).

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr Hermann Winkler's immunity, so that the German justice system could carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, on the understanding that the investigation, linked to a serious road accident involving the Member, is clearly not related to mr Winkler's office as a Member of Parliament, and is not motivated by the desire to interfere with the Member's action.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Member of the European Parliament Hermann Winkler. This is a request made by the Attorney General of Leipzig (Germany) concerning a case relating to an alleged offence in which the MEP was involved in a serious road accident on 23 September 2015. Since this is conduct allegedly practised outside your mandate as an MEP and there is no reason to believe that there are any intentions underlying the legal action to undermine political activity, I voted in favour of this request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity, as apart from the verification of the conditions listed in Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls for the lifting of the diplomatic immunity of German MP Hermann Winkler so that he can deal with the justice of his country on accusations which have nothing to do with his political mandate as an MEP.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Hermann Winkler is a German MEP (CDU/EPP). On 23 September 2015 he was a party to a serious road traffic accident. The German Prosecutor seeks the lifting of his immunity so that the MEP can become a subject of the investigation into the incident. There is no nexus to his duties as an MEP. In those circumstances our policy is to vote in favour of lifting his immunity.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ According to German Basic Law, a Member may not be called to account for a punishable offence without the permission of Parliament unless apprehended while committing the offence. The Public prosecutor has requested the wavering of Hermann Winkler’s immunity in connection with a preliminary investigation concerning a traffic accident.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As the lifting of the immunity of Mr Winkler doesn’t affect his political work at all, I voted in favour.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Legal Affairs examined the request by the Public Prosecutor's Office in Leipzig to waive the parliamentary immunity of MEP Herman Winkler in connection with the investigation into a road accident in which an MEP was involved. I supported the motion for a resolution on waiving the immunity of MEP Herman Winkler. On 25 September 2015, the Prosecutor General's Office in Leipzig filed a request for waiver of immunity in connection with a preliminary investigation into the accident of MEP Herman Winkler. In order for a road accident to which an MEP was a party to be investigated, it was necessary to waive the immunity of an MEP, as there is no reason to believe that the criminal proceedings are intended to harm a Member's political activity and since the alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with Herman Winkler's status as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Attorney General's Office in Leipzig( Germany) has requested the lifting of parliamentary immunity for MEP Hermann Winkler in connection with the initiation of investigative proceedings for an alleged crime. In accordance with Article 9 Protocol on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament on the territory of their country enjoy immunity recognised by members of the Parliament of that State.  Given that the request relates to a preliminary investigation into a serious traffic accident that occurred on 23 September 2015 involving Hermann Winkler, and whereas the criminal proceedings are not related to the expression of an opinion or the vote of members of the European Parliament in the performance of its duties within the meaning of Article 8(1) TSR. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, I supported the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This proposal for a decision advises the European Parliament to revoke the immunity of German MEP Winkler. Namely, the Leipzig State Attorney's Office has requested the lifting of parliamentary immunity, since hermann Winkler has been investigated for an alleged offence in a serious traffic accident in which he was involved.  Under the German Constitution, a Member of Parliament cannot be held accountable for a criminal offence without parliament's approval, unless he or she is caught committing a crime or is not arrested during the following day. Furthermore, MEMBERS of the European Parliament on the territory of their country enjoy immunity recognised by members of the Parliament of that State. I support the initiative to lift Hermann Winkler's immunity, as no investigation can be carried out without it. The offence allegedly committed by him is not directly linked to his function in Parliament nor can it harm his political activity.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this waiver of immunity so that this elected official could explain himself without constraint before the justice of his country

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the waiving of the parliamentary immunity of the Member of the European Parliament Hermann Winkler, to be able to launch a preliminary investigation concerning a serious traffic accident. This is not with the intention of damaging Mr Winkler’s political activity nor has it anything to do with his political opinions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a request to lift the immunity of German MEP Hermann Winkler, who is under investigation for allegations that he was involved in a serious car accident under the influence of alcohol on 23 September 2015.  In my view, there is no reason to assume, i.e. serious and reasonable enough doubt, that the proceedings were initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member concerned, since the alleged offence is not directly or manifestly linked to the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament.  Since the Leipzig Attorney General's Office has applied for the waiver of the immunity of that Representative in connection with the preliminary investigation into the road accident, I consider it correct that the Member be waived his or her immunity and given a fair and impartial trial.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the request for waiver of hermann Winkler's immunity in the light of the request for waiver of immunity submitted on 25 September 2015 by the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office in connection with the investigation of a road traffic accident (under No 600 AR 3037/15) and which was announced in plenary on 14 December 2015.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. German MP Hermann Winkler (EPP) is suspected of causing a road accident. The Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office has therefore issued a request to waive its parliamentary immunity. The alleged offences have nothing to do with his mandate as an MP. On the other hand, Parliament could not establish that there was "fumus persecutionis", i.e. a sufficiently serious presumption and specifies that the application was submitted with the intention of harming the political activity of the Member concerned. I therefore voted to lift Mr Winkler's parliamentary immunity so that he would be answerable for this potential offence like any citizen of the European Union.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 25 September 2015, the Leipzig Public Prosecutor's Office requested the waivement of hermann Winkler's immunity in connection with a preliminary investigation into a traffic accident. Since, on the basis of the information obtained by the committee, there is no reason to believe that the criminal proceedings were initiated in order to cause political damage to the Member, I supported (also) following the S&D group.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI committee. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this non—controversial request to waive immunity.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of Hermann Winkler in connection with launching investigative proceedings concerning an alleged offence, as the alleged offence has no connection with the position of Hermann Winkler as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted to lift Hermann Winkler's immunity because these are facts that have nothing to do with his political mandate.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The alleged infringement which motivates the request for waiver of parliamentary immunity does not have a direct and obvious link with the exercise of the duties of the Member as a Member of the European Parliament, and Parliament has also found no reasoned evidence that the request is intended to undermine the political activity of the Member. In the express, we voted in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The request for the waiver of Hermann Winkler's immunity must be approved, since it relates to an investigation into a serious traffic accident in which Hermann Winkler himself was involved.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the European Parliament's decision to waive Hermann Winkler's parliamentary immunity, as he was subject to investigation into the alleged offence and, according to the information obtained by the Committee, there is no reason to believe that legal proceedings were initiated with the intention of political harm to the Member.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I have just one thing to say. In years of watching hypocrisy and double standards in this House, I have not come across anything that matches the complaints about what we found out in the Panama tax returns, coming from bureaucrats and MEPs who are exempt from national taxation. This really is a new level of utter hypocrisy from this Chamber.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – I abstained in this report because, although it includes positive aspects in relation to the conservation and sustainable use of biological and marine biodiversity in areas outside the jurisdiction of States, I believe that this will not be possible because it is at odds with mineral exploitation or drilling for energy purposes , of which he also realizes in the report and with which, logically, I do not agree.  I believe that the report should be positioned to avoid these practices, since recital U recognises that they constitute other factors for the mortality of fishery resources.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I supported this report. In my opinion, it is very important that the biological diversity of the seas, the marine environment is preserved. I would like to point out that it is the coastal settlement that makes it very difficult to maintain this biodiversity, and in this matter the EU should also do its part to preserve biodiversity.  On the other hand, I would also like to say that if there is an abandonment of a certain fishing ground that the EU and its Member State are still fishing for, then at the moment it is usually taken up by a completely different state, which does not take these environmental aspects into account at all. In my opinion, the EU should push the international community to make the protection of biodiversity a truly immanent part of the protection of the marine environment.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr By the end of 2017, the UN plans to draw up an international legally binding document aimed at promoting marine biodiversity beyond national territorial jurisdiction, its conservation, sustainable exploitation. This already means a modern concept of sustainability, the development of management of marine ecosystems and so on. I believe this is extremely important because of animal breeding... I apologize (speech interrupted). I agree with the call on the Commission to cooperate as actively as possible with all other parties involved in the development of new frameworks, as well as to pay regular attention, in principle, to the sustainable use of marine resources, both on a regular basis and from other partners. Of course, I voted in favour, because it should be added that the involvement of the European Union in this matter cannot, of course, be limited to the common fisheries policy, as in the case of ESA ecology, unilateral action will never deliver effective results. Thank you!

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained because UNCLOS needs general recognition even when we dispute the EU’s claim to competence.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2004, a working group was set up at the United Nations Assembly to address the conservation and sustainable use of marine resources in those areas not under national jurisdiction. With a view to creating coordinated action with the Member States, the last report of 2015 underlined the need to prepare a legally binding instrument, at international level, on the law of the sea and, in particular, on the protection of marine biodiversity. In so doing, an all-encompassing global regime is finally being established for those areas which, without national jurisdiction, are not subject to any form of control. For these reasons, I voted in favour, believing that it is right for the EU to have a positive influence on the work of the committee responsible for drawing up the document, thus making sure that this issue is given due importance.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an important step forward in defending the planet's marine natural resources beyond the jurisdictional waters controlled by states. This report welcomes the development of a binding legal instrument aimed at resource conservation and the protection of marine biodiversity. The report also urges the Member States of the Union to ratify the agreements envisaged as soon as possible. The development of binding standards has proven to be the only way to develop environmental protection in states, developing these standards for international waters is a fundamental tool for advancing the protection of the planet's resources. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report highlights the fact that intensive fishing in international waters poses a significant threat to marine biodiversity and no longer ensures the conservation and exploitation of its resources. The text therefore calls for the creation of marine protected areas as well as global management tools, including vessel registration.  I abstained on this text, because even if this report goes in the right direction by strengthening the protection of marine biodiversity, the UN Convention risks creating management tools that are beyond the Control Of Member States.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report. This was a non-controversial file, where all of the MEPs voted in favour of this report in the committee. The background of the report is based on recommendations made to the UN General Assembly in 2015 regarding the creation of a legally-binding instrument which would come under the auspices of the ‘United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea’ which seeks to promote the conservation of marine biodiversity and sustainable usage of marine resources, it also acknowledges the negative impact that the rapid growth and expansion of marine activities (industrial fishing , marine drilling, shipping, etc.) on the marine environment across the globe. Two important provisions were contained within the report: 64% of the sea consists of areas beyond national jurisdiction. These unchartered waters should be have stronger legal protections under international law,  Inclusion of measures which should insure accountability for parties participating in marine activities. Therefore, on the grounds outlined above, we voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The report calls for the creation of marine protected areas, global management tools, including vessel registration, and scientific monitoring of new marine resource development activities. I cannot vote in favour of this report, because the UN convention risks creating global management tools that are beyond the control of sovereign states. We can already know that the new regulatory constraints will affect European fishermen little but rather their competitors. With the report making only recommendations, I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am opposed to further EU regulation being forced upon UK fishermen. However part of this report binds the EU into accepting the law of the sea. It officially makes the EU recognise and comply with international fisheries law. I abstained on this vote.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. There is an urgent need to implement measures for the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction. That is why I voted in favour of this text. Nevertheless, I would like to point out that the protection of marine biodiversity must be part of an international framework, not just a European one, in order to be fully effective.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to develop a new international legally binding instrument for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction. In 1995, the UN adopted the Fish Stocks Agreement. The fisheries community sees the UN Agreement on Fish Stocks as a good agreement, which creates a good legal framework that provides the tools needed to keep up with change while achieving and renewing the main objectives. As regards the effectiveness of the current system, it is important to establish a comprehensive global framework in order to better address the problem of the conservation of marine biodiversity and to develop an international legally binding instrument.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because UNCLOS needs general recognition even when we dispute the EU’s claim to competence.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. If the legal framework - in international law - concerning the high seas (seas beyond the jurisdiction of states, i.e. 64% of the seas), developed more than thirty years ago and based on the principle of freedom of the high seas, no longer allows for the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biodiversity, a strengthening of international legislation would affect little European fishermen. , already subject to the greatest constraints in this area. In addition, the report merely makes recommendations on the creation of marine protected areas or the development of global management tools and scientific monitoring of new marine resource development activities. Nevertheless, I have not been able to vote in favour of a report which, coming from the United Nations Convention, results in the establishment of global management tools that escape the sovereignty of States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report, which welcomes the decision of the United Nations General Assembly to develop, under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, a legally binding international instrument on the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biodiversity in areas beyond the limits of national jurisdiction. It stresses the importance of progress in the development of this new instrument and of meeting the planned objective of finalizing its drafting by the end of 2017. MEPs believe that the EU and the international community should act towards the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity by implementing, among other things, modern and sustainable concepts of managing the marine ecosystem, as well as principles of ocean governance, through: - the controlled exploitation of marine resources (whether mining minerals , energy drilling, etc.) and fishing; Science-based governance of the marine environment; Restoring stocks and keeping them above levels to achieve maximum sustainable yield; Ecosystem-based management and conservation of marine biodiversity; The application of existing legislation and the precautionary principle.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Seas and oceans make up 71% of the earth's surface and contain 97% of the planet's water, representing an incomparable heritage in terms of biodiversity. The European Union has played and continues to play a key role in the protection of marine habitats and ecosystems, with participation in various international organisations dedicated to fisheries management and continuous activity to combat illegal, unregulated and undeclared fishing.  The Nicolai report, which I supported with my vote, reiterates the need for the EU to play a proactive role in ensuring a genuine affirmation of marine governance based on science, supporting the draft of a new international agreement at the UN that complements the previous Agreement on the Conservation of Fishery Resources (UNFSA) signed in 1995.  Only through a common commitment at global level will it be possible to take action to stem the consequences of climate change and ocean acidification and the negative repercussions due to over-use, pollution, waste and the destruction of marine habitats and ecosystems

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as the report aims to establish mechanisms linking the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea but in the field of fisheries, stressing the importance of the conservation of marine biodiversity and the sustainable use of marine resources.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank my colleague Norica Nicolai for her great work in approving the agreement on marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction, united Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. Marine activities develop and multiply rapidly, so pressure on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity is constantly increasing. More coordinated marine biology activity is needed. The new agreement should include instruments for accountability by all actors involved, as without these instruments efficiency and real progress are difficult to foresee.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, and in particular the fisheries aspects, called for a vote of abstention on my part. It must be recognized, in fact, that 64% of the seas are governed by international law, taking into account the fact that they are located outside the jurisdiction of the States. In fact, the existing legal framework is considered obsolete by the rapporteur, particularly in terms of protecting marine biodiversity and sustainable exploitation. If the fishing sector finds itself in the sights of new, more restrictive legislation (creation of marine protected areas, global management tools, scientific monitoring of new marine resource development activities), this is expected to have little impact on European fishermen, who are already under severe stress. Measures that are supposed to be laudable but which would put water management entirely in the hands of an international jurisdiction, to the detriment of sovereign states, which, in my desire to defend the French and European fishing sector, does not seem acceptable to me.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While it is partly acceptable, the text remains unclear and has some steps that over time could be a source of criticality for the sector. For all these reasons, I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (1982), its Agreement on Fish Stocks (1995) and Agenda 21, the United Nations has addressed the importance of protecting the waters of the world. In this context, a Working Group was set up to discuss the possibility of promoting international cooperation and coordination for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity outside areas of national jurisdiction. The Group recommended the development of a legally binding international instrument. On the basis of this recommendation, in July 2015, the United Nations General Assembly decided to establish a Preparatory Committee to develop the text of a legally binding instrument at international level by the end of 2017. In this context, this report of the European Parliament emerges, before the holding of an Intergovernmental Conference on the Conservation and Sustainable Use of Marine Biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction.  I voted for it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with fisheries in areas not under national jurisdiction in the International Agreement on Marine Biological Diversity (United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea). The Position of the European Parliament is that maritime activity is changing rapidly and increasing, so the pressure on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity is constantly increasing. From this perspective, Parliament welcomes the continued work of the UN GA and the open informal ad hoc working group.  It is difficult to imagine an effective and well-coordinated measure relating to marine biodiversity, which does not cover one of the most important activities taking place in the waters: fishing. Therefore, the UN Fish Stocks Agreement should also not be amended or repealed, creating a system which, as in the case of the EU, can improve the situation and produce results if properly applied. In addition, the new agreement should include accountability measures for all relevant actors, as without such measures it is difficult to predict real effectiveness and progress. The aim of taking into account the needs of developing countries, capacity building and information sharing should also be given priority. From this perspective, and given the sharing of good practices, the EU should continue to play a leading role in the preparation and implementation of this new instrument.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on fishing aspects of the international agreement on marine biodiversity. Maritime activities are rapidly evolving and their numbers are increasing rapidly, increasing the burden and exploitation of marine biodiversity. The latest report of the Working Party stresses the need for a comprehensive global system to better address this issue and recommends the development of an internationally legally binding instrument for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report recognises that the European Union has been a key player in the proper exploitation of marine biological resources. It advocates the creation of marine protected areas, global management tools, including ship registration, and scientific monitoring of new marine resource development activities. The United Nations Convention risks creating global management tools that are beyond the control of sovereign states, which is why I cannot vote in favour. Knowing that we can anticipate that the new regulatory constraints will affect European fishermen little but rather their competitors, it is also useless to vote against it. So I abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is up to the European Union to maintain its leading role in the field of the law of the sea and fisheries and that this role must be used to achieve the approval of an instrument that regulates at international level and in a binding manner the issue of the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not subject to national jurisdiction.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Marine activities are developing and multiplying at a fast pace, and therefore the pressure on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity is constantly increasing. The international community recognises the need for an international approach to managing pollution, human activities that degrade the environment and, in general, the dangers to marine biodiversity. By the end of 2017, a legally binding international instrument should be presented to protect marine biodiversity, within the framework of the International Convention on the Law of the Sea.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report finds that intensive fishing in international waters poses a significant threat to marine biodiversity and is no longer sustainable from the conservation and exploitation of its resources. For this reason, this text calls for the creation of marine protected areas as well as global management tools, including vessel registration.  Even if this report goes in the right direction by strengthening the protection of marine biodiversity, the UN convention risks creating management tools that are beyond member's control. That's why I abstained.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on fisheries issues under the International Agreement on Marine Biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdictions underlines the need for a comprehensive global regime to better address fisheries issues. Given that seas and oceans cover 71 % of the Earth's surface and comprise about 97 % of the planet's water, and the marine environment is home to a significant part of the world's biodiversity, greater attention is needed to protect and conserve marine biological diversity. Thus, the new agreement envisages the creation of certain tools to empower all actors involved, as well as capacity building and information exchange, both between Member States and between the EU and third countries. It is also recommended to establish a legally binding international instrument under UNCLOS for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity of areas outside national jurisdictions. I welcome the progress made by the UN on the issue of marine biological diversity in areas outside national jurisdictions, by voting in favour of this report and expressing my constant concern for the conservation of marine habitats and the sustainable development of this area.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report promotes a legally binding instrument at international level under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas not under national jurisdiction. Abstention vote.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The United Nations is currently preparing a legally binding international agreement on the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction. This report supports this approach. With regard to fisheries, it calls for an improvement of the existing framework, not a major change in the existing framework. This framework relies in particular on regional fisheries management organizations (PMOs) and the Fish Stocks Agreement. These United Nations instruments are effective and proven but could be better coordinated with other international biodiversity instruments. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on "Fisheries aspects under the International Agreement on Marine Biodiversity in Areas Not Under National Jurisdiction, UNITED NATIONS Convention on the Law of the Sea" because I believe that the united nations' intervention in the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not subject to national jurisdiction is right and very appropriate.  The increase in maritime activities and the increased pressure on marine sustainability make protective action no longer delayed, but the development of a legally binding international instrument that wants to be truly effective and well coordinated in the field of marine biology must necessarily also include fishing activities, among the main maritime activities; It is also necessary to include in the new international agreement the principle of liability through the recognition of ecological damage at sea and the assessment of the chain of responsibility for this damage. We must proceed carefully so as not to underestimate anything and to take into account all the aspects that an international agreement requires, but at the same time it is necessary to meet the 2017 deadline for its drafting.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This was a non-controversial file, where all of the MEPs voted in favour of this report in the committee. The background of the report is based on recommendations made to the UN General Assembly in 2015 regarding the creation of a legally-binding instrument which would come under the auspices of the ‘United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea’ which seeks to promote the conservation of marine biodiversity and sustainable usage of marine resources, it also acknowledges the negative impact that the rapid growth and expansion of marine activities (industrial fishing , marine drilling, shipping, etc.) on the marine environment across the globe. Two important provisions were contained within the report: 1. 64% of the sea consists of areas beyond national jurisdiction. These unchartered waters should be have stronger legal protections under international law,  2. Inclusion of measures which should insure accountability for parties participating in marine activities. Therefore, on the grounds outlined above, I voted in favour.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that international cooperation is needed in order to protect biodiversity in international waters. I welcome the decision to set up international conservation management systems which will help us preserve marine biodiversity.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The working group set up by the UN General Assembly on the effectiveness of the current framework in addressing the issue of the conservation and sustainable use of marine resources in areas not under national jurisdiction underlined, in its latest report, the need for a comprehensive global regime and recommended the development of a legally binding instrument at international level.  Parliament expresses its opinion in order to influence the position of the United Nations Preparatory Committee and, for the rapporteur, it is extremely important that fishing activities are included in the new instrument. I fully agree with the approach, and I certainly voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The growing development of maritime activities is compromising the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity even in areas not under national jurisdiction. The working group set up ad hoc by the UN General Assembly to address this issue has identified the need for international coordination for the conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity and sees the creation of a legally binding international instrument under the UNITED Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) as the most effective way of tackling the problem globally. The group is already working on the definition of the instrument to be ready for 2017 in view of the international conference.  I believe, as also advocated in the report voted on in plenary and on which I voted in favour, that this is now a must, but I believe that the new instrument must also include fisheries-related activities that are one of the main causes of the loss of marine biodiversity. In order to increase the effectiveness of the instrument, I believe that instruments should also be provided for the responsibility of all the actors involved, and I hope that the European Commission will accept the indications made by this House.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as maritime activities are growing and multiplying rapidly, and therefore the pressure for the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity is constantly increasing.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the Report on fisheries aspects under the International Agreement on Marine Biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction. It is clear that this issue is directly linked to issues of an environmental nature and the protection of natural balances. I therefore believe that we should all be very aware and support such proposals. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as this report aims to develop a legally binding international instrument on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not under national jurisdiction.  In fact, I believe that we need a concrete and effective response to the increase in marine activities that are increasingly multiplying and developing in the European area. A response capable of protecting marine biodiversity from the growing dangers to which it is exposed, such as pollution or illegal fishing. As a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I feel particularly sensitive to this issue and I believe that my vote in favour was a necessary expression of international modernisation that is increasingly taking care of the collective good that the sea represents.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The sea covers 71% of the Earth’s surface, while less than 1% of regions beyond national jurisdiction enjoy the protection of marine protected areas (MPAs). For most of the ocean there is no legal mandate to create marine protected areas. Existing legal framework on this matter was developed more than 30 years ago and further elaboration will be necessary to promote the conservation of marine biodiversity in areas beyond jurisdiction. The Commission should encourage a holistic approach to MPAs, because coordination amongst many stake holders involved marine activities is necessary. The UN must implement existing rules and seek to establish additional ones to ensure the protection of biodiversity, also allowing for the creation of global management tools. This may include a centralised instrument for vessel registration, developing the Global Record of Fishing Vessels under the authority of the FAO. It is essential that fishing activities be added to this new agreement, to ensure efficient coordination of marine biology related instruments.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Nicolai report as it considers it necessary to establish a legally binding international instrument under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea for the sustainable conservation and use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction through modern and sustainable concepts of marine ecosystem management, ocean governance principles and fisheries. This new agreement should include instruments for the accountability of all actors involved, without whom it will not be possible to achieve the objectives we are set to. I believe that an exchange of good practice in this area should continue to exist under the leadership of the EU.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained because UNCLOS needs general recognition even when we dispute the EU’s claim to competence.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with this report to support the decision of the UN General Assembly to develop, by 2017, a legally binding international instrument in the context of UNCLOS, relating to the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not under national jurisdiction.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European fisheries policy is geared towards sustainability and maintenance of healthy marine habitats and sustainable fish stocks. This is essential for the long-term sustainability of fisheries. I support proportionality towards specific circumstances within Member States to take steps to implement management plans, monitor the application of the rules, deepen their knowledge base and strengthen research networks and the coordination of information on marine biodiversity. Strict control and inspection programmes are needed to monitor all aspects of the bluefin tuna fishery and enforce the rules, but we should be sensitive towards specific realities like Malta’s tuna industry.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an important step forward in defending the planet's marine natural resources beyond the jurisdictional waters controlled by states. This report welcomes the development of a binding legal instrument aimed at resource conservation and the protection of marine biodiversity. The report also urges the Member States of the Union to ratify the agreements envisaged as soon as possible. The development of binding standards has proven to be the only way to develop environmental protection in states, developing these standards for international waters is a fundamental tool for advancing the protection of the planet's resources. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to support the position and objectives of the European Commission, committed on behalf of the Member States to negotiate this new International Agreement. In the report, an important aspect is the inclusion of fishing activities among those covered by the new international legal instrument.  Regional fisheries management organisations must also be expanded and gain greater importance under the new International Agreement. The existence of marine protected areas can only be guaranteed if there is coordination and collaboration in all fields of activity. In this respect, it is very important that this new Agreement includes an institutional decision-making structure.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The own-initiative report deals with the international management of areas outside national jurisdiction, sometimes referred to as the "high seas". UN members are responsible for the conservation and conservation of "world waters" under two international agreements: (1) the UN Agreement on Fish Stocks and (2) the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). This report is a positive response to the decision to develop an international legally binding instrument within UNCLOS to address the challenges of the protection of the north sea.  Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, mineral extraction, energy drilling, pollution and marine litter contribute to damage to marine habitats and ecosystems. The report calls on the Commission to work with stakeholders to support the new instrument and highlights the important role of the EU in ensuring the sustainable management of marine resources on the high seas.  I voted in favour of this document.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the European Union plays an important role on the international fishing scene, but also the fact that the oceans play a fundamental role in many of the Earth's systems, including climate, and is the framework in which many human activities such as fisheries, energy production, transport and trade take place, Support and reinforce the rapporteur's idea of including fishing activities in this new instrument.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report makes a series of recommendations for the development of a legally binding international instrument for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside the national jurisdiction.  Considering that sustainable and responsible fishing is a prerequisite for the preservation of the fishing industry in Europe and around the world, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the creation, by the end of 2017, of a legally binding international instrument relating to the 1995 UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. This instrument deals with the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside the national jurisdiction. The measures contained in this report also underline the importance of the European Union's role in ensuring the sustainable management of marine biological resources and recommend that the EU continue to be active in the development and implementation of this new instrument.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The creation of marine protected areas and management tools on a global scale, including vessel registration and scientific monitoring of new operations, can help preserve marine biodiversity. However, the terms of these devices are not precise enough. These, although not meaningless, would be in addition to a European framework recognised as being very restrictive for fishermen. While waiting to find out whether the new regulatory obligations will affect European fishermen or their competitors, I abstained on this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that international waters must be protected from harm and stricter controls must be carried out against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, mineral exploitation, drilling, pollution and marine litter. I support the establishment of an international instrument within the framework of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, which will reduce the damage currently done to the marine ecosystem by ensuring sustainable management of marine resources in international waters.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the Group of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the Nicolai report. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: The UN Convention risks creating global management tools that ely escape sovereign states.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report follows the recommendations made in 2015 at the United Nations General Assembly on international cooperation for the protection of ecosystems and the sustainability of the use of marine resources. It emphasizes the need to establish a binding instrument under the responsibility of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The position of the Working Group which made the recommendations and the UN General Assembly points to the negative impact that the rapid growth and expansion of maritime activities (including industrial fishing, marine drilling, transport, etc.) will have and have had on the marine environment. The need to deepen international legislation, in a context where 64% of the existing sea area is outside national jurisdictions, is therefore considered fundamental. Reviewing us in its overall sense, the report nevertheless contains some valuable references to EU policies, in particular the Common Fisheries Policy, in which we do not review ourselves. Nor do we support a centralising vision, supporting the EU's positions and conferring power on its institutions, in particular the European Commission. This logic has favored large fishing industries, but has negatively affected small-scale fishing, small industries and fishing communities, with a negative impact on ecosystems.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
