text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it commits the Commission, within the framework of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, to play a leading role in creating a legally binding international instrument that guarantees the protection and correct use of marine resources in high-seas areas. We cannot allow activities such as unregulated or undeclared fishing or, worse still, pollution and the dumping of waste at sea to endanger our marine ecosystems for everything they represent from an environmental, economic and social point of view.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Marine activities are developing and multiplying at an unusually rapid pace, thus increasing the pressure for sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity. The international community recognises the need for a common international approach in order to better control pollution, human activity and increase the danger to marine biodiversity. Internationally legally binding instruments should be presented by the end of 2017. Over the last decades, human activity at sea has multiplied. The potential for growth and jobs is huge and should be used within the ecological limits of the marine environment. Fisheries and aquaculture play an important role in the marine economy. Responsible fisheries and aquaculture are key to sustainable development and a healthy marine ecosystem.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because the report seems to be laying down instruments that are too legally binding.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. Biodiversity, not only at sea but everywhere, is something we need to make sure it lasts. In fact, the greatest must be done to safeguard our seas and oceans and prevent their pollution, as this is the only way to continue fishing without threatening fish and the health of consumers. For the above reasons I am voting in favour of report A8-0042/2016.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Blue growth has to be one of our main priorities, as pressure on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity is constantly increasing. In recent decades, human activities at sea have multiplied. The potential for growth and jobs is enormous and should be used within the ecological limits of the marine environment. Fisheries and aquaculture play an important role in the marine economy, but we must be determined in tackling the environmental problems and the need for sustainable development. I am therefore in favour of an international approach in order to manage pollution, human activities and increasing dangers to marine biodiversity. Responsible fisheries and aquaculture are key to sustainable development and a healthy marine eco-system; fishing must be integrated into this vision of the future of the sea that is blue growth.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I accept the report and I am of the opinion with the rapporteur that marine biodiversity should be placed beyond national competence in an international, legally binding set of instruments. However, fishing should also be included in the new instrument system.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind that marine activities are developing and multiplying rapidly, so the pressure on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity is constantly increasing. This is why the ongoing work of the United Nations General Assembly is important. The new agreement should include instruments for accountability by all actors involved. In addition, taking into account the needs of developing countries, capacity building and information exchange should be a priority.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this report because it is very important that the European Union lead the way in the process of finding more sustainable ways to use the resources of the sea and to protect the sea’s biodiversity. A sustainable way to use the sea is especially important in areas where there is currently no jurisdiction as we can have no control over activities in these areas.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I welcome the report by my colleagues in the Committee on Fisheries, in which the European Parliament welcomes the decision of the UN General Assembly to develop a legally binding international instrument in the context of the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity.  Promoting the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity is in fact essential for our continent, and will be even more effective if we are able to apply modern and sustainable approaches to the management of marine ecosystems, the principles of ocean governance and management of the exploitation of marine resources.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on fisheries aspects under the International Agreement on Marine Biodiversity in Areas Not Under National Jurisdiction, UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, because I believe that it is based on a balanced and positive approach to one of the great challenges facing the fisheries sector in Europe, namely the achievement of the necessary balance between sustainability and the protection of biodiversity on the one hand. , and economic activities and fishing on the other. Since 1995, the international community has recognised the issue of the environmental consequences for the biodiversity of human activities and has taken important initiatives such as the signing of UNFSA, the establishment of specific working groups and, lastly, the mandate for the drafting of an internationally binding text by 2017. The EU, with its common fisheries policy, has always promoted very high international environmental standards, combining blue growth and environmental protection. I also welcome the calls to combat illegal and undeclared fishing, the need for better data on marine biodiversity in European seas and the call to take a leading role in the fight against plastic waste at sea.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea: Fisheries Aspects. Large and small fisheries in Europe stand for responsible, sustainable fishing that recognises the needs of biodiversity.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea on the Sustainable and Selective Use and Conservation of Biodiversity outside national territories. It is important to work hard to develop an internationally legally binding instrument to address deficits in this still very unexplored area and to protect the environment. The agreement is also central to the work and progress of the EU's common fisheries policy.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In waters outside of national jurisdictions, or the ‘high seas,’ the United Nations (UN) is responsible for environmental sustainability and conservation through two international agreements, one of which – the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) – is an international, legally-binding framework. The European Parliament own initiative report which was voted on in plenary reacts positively to the UNCLOS and welcomes this framework as a means to address the challenges of protecting the ecosystems of the high seas. Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, mineral exploitation and energy drilling, and pollution and marine litter are all damaging marine habitats and ecosystems. The EU has an important position in securing the sustainable management of marine resources in the high seas. This is reflected in the report’s call for the Commission to work closely with interested parties and support the UNCLOS framework. I voted in favour of this report as I hope that demonstrating support for the UNCLOS will help find international solutions for this environmental degradation and demonstrate the EU’s commitment to global environmental issues.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The Law of the Sea negotiations aim to fill the gaps in the Montego Bay Treaty on the high seas in order to defend biodiversity. The Nicolai report proposes marine protected areas, the registration of ships on a global scale, as well as scientific monitoring of new activities to exploit marine resources. The objective is laudable, but above all we must fight illegal fishing. It is the one that seriously harms biodiversity. For the time being, the Nicolai report merely encourages international cooperation. This is not enough, but negotiations are only just beginning and are not expected to conclude until 2022. We will then be able to judge this report on the results it has produced.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as the report aims to establish mechanisms linking the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea but in the field of fisheries, stressing the importance of the conservation of marine biodiversity and the sustainable use of marine resources.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as while there is considerable potential for jobs and growth in the marine sector, it is also one that requires protection and balance in terms of working within the sector’s ecological capacities.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The report stresses that this new international agreement should secure a level playing field among all stakeholders.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report focuses on the need to enhance and preserve marine biodiversity and sustainable use while recognising the risks and negative impacts caused to the global marine environment by the rapid development and expansion of marine activities (industrial fishing, marine drilling, shipping, etc.). The report also takes into account that some 64% of the sea, mainly the high seas and the deep sea seabed, are areas outside the national jurisdiction of the States and are governed by international law and are therefore of the utmost importance as these areas are better protected under international law.  Finally, there is also another important, explicit reference that each country has the right to benefit from the conservation and sustainable use of its resources, in particular with regard to blue development. In view of the above, we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this motion. The conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity under the auspices of international law is a common concern for all mankind and essential to ensure that our dependence on the ocean does not become too burdensome. The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) provides for a mechanism whereby all actors with an interest in the development of the ocean’s resources are held accountable for their actions in relation to the sea. I feel that this reflects the attitude of the EU which should continue to play a leading role in the development of this new instrument and in the implementation process.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion as it is crucial that an internationally recognised and agreed-upon, legally binding text is created, in an effort to protect the waters of the world.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea pre-dates many recent technological innovations in global fisheries and it is important that the law keeps up with these developments. I therefore was happy to support this text.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Nowadays, marine activities are developing and multiplying at a fast rate, with the pressure on marine biodiversity constantly increasing. I agree with the rapporteur that the solution for these issues should come from an internationally legally binding instrument, and this can be foreseen in the near future.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on fisheries aspects covered by the international agreement on marine biodiversity in areas outside the national jurisdiction of the United Nations Conventions on the Law of the Sea, on the basis that I believe it is necessary to ensure sustainable management of oceans and seas in order to provide a concrete solution to the problem of environmental pollution. 71% of our planet is covered by the sea, where a significant part of the world's biodiversity is present and is also an invaluable heritage that is increasingly in serious danger.  The increasing number of marine activities taking place in the underwater world is uddling biodiversity conservation and reducing the level of marine resources. In my view, such activities should be, in part, sustainable and in line with international obligations and rules. In this context, it is essential to prevent excessive, illegal and unregulated fishing and huge amounts of marine litter. I believe that it is necessary to strengthen international binding instruments and to fully exploit and launch the potential of the blue economy in accordance with the principles of fair and sustainable exploitation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report acknowledges that the European Union has been a key player in the proper exploitation of marine biological resources. It also advocates the creation of marine protected areas, global management tools, including vessel registration, and scientific monitoring of new marine resource development activities. This report cannot be voted on because the UN Convention does risk creating global management tools that are beyond the control of sovereign states. However, it is equally pointless to vote against it, as it can be anticipated that the new regulatory constraints will affect European fishermen little but rather their competitors. In any event, the report merely makes recommendations. That's why I abstained from this vote.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained because UNCLOS needs general recognition even when we dispute the EU’s claim to competence.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Norica Nicolai's report on fisheries aspects in the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. In response to international concerns and debates about the effectiveness of the current framework for addressing the issue of conservation and sustainable use of marine resources beyond areas of national jurisdiction, an ad hoc working group at the United Nations recommended the development of a legally binding international instrument on the preservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity on the high seas. I have approved this legislative proposal, which supports progress on the creation of international legislation for marine biodiversity. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report "welcomes the decision taken by the United Nations General Assembly to develop a legally binding international instrument within the framework of UNCLOS on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction in order, inter alia, to address current deficiencies" which I share , as well as supporting measures to protect marine biodiversity, for which the European Union and the Member States need to be more actively involved. However, I do not subscribe to the paragraph included in the report "Recognises and supports the positive and leadership role played by the Union and the Commission, taking into account the leading position of the Union's fisheries industry and market and the fact that the European fisheries policy is sustainability-oriented", because I cannot share the assertion that European fisheries policy is sustainability-oriented.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The report welcomes the unseating General Assembly's decision to develop, under UNCLOS, a legally binding international instrument on the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction. It stresses the importance of progress in the development of this new instrument and of meeting the planned objective of finalizing its drafting by the end of 2017. As this report is balanced, I voted in favour of it.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Man's great wealth is the environment and everything that mother nature gives us. But we can't always respect what we have. In addition, our population is growing rapidly, resulting in an increasing demand for raw materials and natural resources. One such resource is the seas and the animals that live in them. It is therefore extremely pleased that the UN initiative and the issue of marine biodiversity is of great importance and the creation of an instrument to control marine resources. In the management of marine resources, it is necessary to take fisheries into account. The creation of an effective instrument to ensure that fishing is reasonable for eco-sytems, respects conservation periods and respects endangered species, should therefore be supported. In order for such an instrument to be at least minimally effective, it is necessary to establish a control system that will allow the accountability of all offshore users. Such an instrument must take into account the specificities of developing countries and the difficulties that will arise in implementing and enforcing this tool in the future. We must therefore ensure that the European Union plays a significant role in creating and implementing this instrument.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We borrowed our land from our grandchildren, and it is hardly possible to say that we care well with its goods. This is particularly true of wildlife, such as the conservation of the biodiversity of the seas and oceans. This report is very important for the future of all of us and should be fully supported because it makes its proposals with due care and reasoning in order to prepare the draft for the UN General Assembly well on the part of the EU.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the resolution because there is no doubt that we should support efforts made by the UN (in particular UNGA) to move the issue of marine biological diversity beyond areas of national jurisdiction to a point where an internationally legally binding instrument can be foreseen. In fact, it is our common international duty to suppress the increased pressure on the sustainability and conservation of the marine biodiversity caused by marine activities. In this context, I fully believe that the EU should play an important role not only in development of this new instrument but also in its implementation process because the Union has experience in regulation and coordination of marine activities beyond areas of national jurisdiction.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I support this report on the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). As reported by the United Nations, it is our duty to find a system of international laws to manage marine pollution and to safeguard the biodiversity present in our waters. In its latest report, the General Assembly stresses the need to formulate a global system capable of developing regulations with international value, going beyond national laws. The EU is therefore committed to continuing a process of adoption of legal measures on fishing activities and the protection of seaweed, thus contributing to the progress of a global and important project.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. In fact, 64% of the seas are located beyond state jurisdiction and are governed by international law. According to the rapporteur, the existing legal framework, developed more than 30 years ago on the basis of the principle of freedom of the high seas, no longer ensures the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biodiversity. Fishing is obviously an activity that has a significant impact on marine biodiversity and will therefore be covered by all conservation and management measures. However, if international legislation were strengthened, this would have little impact on European fishermen, who are already under the greatest strain to achieve maximum sustainable yield. I believe that this report cannot be voted in favour of it, because the UN Convention risks creating global management tools that are beyond the control of sovereign states. However, it is equally pointless to vote against it, as it can be anticipated that the new regulatory constraints will affect European fishermen little but rather their competitors.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report because, under the pretext of ensuring the conservation of fish stocks, it recommends the creation of global management tools that could lead to further attacks on the sovereignty of States.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The report examines the legal framework governing international waters, 64% of the seas, which ensures the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biodiversity. Established more than 30 years ago, this framework shows its limits and is no longer sufficient to protect marine biodiversity from mass fishing. The European Union, as a recognised player in the respectful exploitation of maritime biological resources, makes many recommendations through this report to improve the law of the sea. Thus, the text submits to the study several proposals such as the creation of marine protected areas, management tools on a global scale, scientific monitoring of new marine activities. However, while the intent of the report is correct, it merely sets out a set of recommendations and does not propose an action plan; so I abstained.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an important step forward in defending the planet's marine natural resources beyond the jurisdictional waters controlled by states. This report welcomes the development of a binding legal instrument aimed at resource conservation and the protection of marine biodiversity. The report also urges the Member States of the Union to ratify the agreements envisaged as soon as possible. The development of binding standards has proven to be the only way to develop environmental protection in states, developing these standards for international waters is a fundamental tool for advancing the protection of the planet's resources. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Through this report, the European Parliament urges the European Commission and Member States to take firm steps in environmental conservation and the promotion of sustainable development. In particular, we propose to Member States that have not yet done so, the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and its commitment to marine protected areas, since, although sixty-four per cent of the total sea is regulated by the various national jurisdictions, less than one per cent of it is protected by them.  In this way, from the European Parliament we would like to draw attention to the Member States on the importance which, not only on the Member States, but on the whole world population, has the preservation of marine ecosystems. That is why my vote will be in favour of this report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The United Nations has demonstrated the importance of protecting the world's waters through the Agenda 21 study, which was published as part of the "Earth Summit" conference in 1992. The conference highlighted the necessity of an international approach in preventing, reducing marine pollution and preserving marine biodiversity. This conference served as a fundamental support for further development of studies and development of awareness of sea protection. Over the past few decades, the dynamics of marine activities that directly affect marine biodiversity have increased significantly. It has influenced the reduction of biodiversity and the degradation of ecosystems. Given the international impact, the Union actively promotes the protection and control of marine biodiversity as well as the preservation of the marine ecosystem and defines the instruments to achieve this. The Union, in cooperation with third countries, is making efforts to build the necessary capacities, transfer marine technology, protect sensitive and rare ecosystems and protect endangered species of marine life. Sustainable use and conservation of marine biodiversity is closely linked to sustainable development, long-term and of utmost importance for all countries in economic, social and environmental terms, so I supported the report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on fisheries issues under the International Agreement on Marine Biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction, the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/4/2016, and because this Report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This report aims to strengthen the European Union's role in protecting global maritime spaces. In addition, it advocates the creation of protected maritime areas as well as global maritime area management structures, most of which are not subject to sovereign control of any state. Purely incantatory, this report is, in any case, devoid of any real legal significance. However, it is at odds with the principle of state sovereignty, advocating an ever-increasing globalization of the management of maritime spaces.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The UN addressed the importance of protecting the waters of the world in the paper that was published as a result of the Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, UN Conference on Environment & Development that took place on 3-14 June 1992, called Agenda 21. This showed that the international community was acknowledging the necessity of an international approach in order to manage pollution and increasing dangers to marine biodiversity. This was followed by the Johannesburg Declaration on Sustainable Development and the Plan of Implementation which were agreed upon during the UN World Summit in South Africa, on 2-4 September 2002. In 2012, in the document published as a result of the latest UN Conference on Sustainable Development held in Rio de Janeiro, called Rio+20 as a link to the first Rio Agenda, the international community restated its determination in tackling the environmental problems and the need for sustainable development. This shows that although the UN and all those who are part of these declarations and agreements commit themselves to these objectives, they need to adapt their plans and priorities to a fast developing world, with activities being diversified and multiplied every single year.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on fisheries aspects under the International Agreement on Marine Biodiversity in areas not under national jurisdiction. This report welcomes the decision of the UN General Assembly to develop an international instrument on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not under national jurisdiction by 2017. The report highlights the importance of including fisheries-related activities in this new instrument and the key role that the EU must play in the expansion of this new instrument and in the implementation process.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Marine biodiversity in areas outside a national jurisdiction is at serious risk of pollution in the absence of an organised effort to protect it from the international community. Fortunately, the UN from very early on stressed the importance of protecting it and so today, there is international acceptance of the issue put out through international legal texts.  Despite the declarations, the US should prioritise this issue with activities that achieve this objective. In this context, the UN Agreement on Fish Stocks (UNSFA 1995), which is an implementing agreement of the previous United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS 1982), establishes the necessary legal status. The latest efforts focus on the drafting of a new text, which is a strict international law and therefore binding on participating States with immediate implementing measures and is expected to be ready in 2017.  Welcoming this effort, I share the rapporteur's positions, which stresses that fisheries should also be included in regulatory matters, given the impact it has on marine biology. Finally, in relation to technical issues, it is important to have a mechanism to check the conformity of the Contracting Parties, but also the efficiency of this mechanism.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In its 200,000-year history, the human species has never weighed so much on its ecosystem. The sea is also a source of hope for humanity. Food, fresh water or energy will come from the sea, as long as the conditions of exploitation of the oceans break with selfish and short-termist logics. Nothing is less certain. In fact, 64% of marine areas are not under any international jurisdiction and 45% of the Earth's surface is a lawless space. The UN Convention on the Law of the Sea is developing, as part of a new international agreement, a legally binding international instrument for the conservation and management of marine biodiversity. This report calls on parliamentarians to engage the EU in this process. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The international legal framework to protect biodiversity is outdated, according to the rapporteur. If the legislation were strengthened today, it would have a small impact on European fishermen, given the heavy constraints already on them. On the other hand, it would have an influence on competition. However, I cannot accept that the United Nations Convention can forge decisive tools that are beyond the reach of states. As a result I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on fisheries aspects under the international agreement on marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction, the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. It is very important to discuss a new international instrument regulating our seas. A new instrument including fishing activities. It is not enough just to manage pollution and the growing threats to marine biodiversity. The EU must continue to lead in this area.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to this report on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity. The EU has shown that properly implemented measures in this field can lead to an improvement of habitats and fishing stocks, and I welcome the efforts undertaken by the United Nations towards internationally and legally binding instruments in this field.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this resolution on the fisheries aspects of the future international agreement on marine biodiversity beyond the areas of national jurisdiction.  Concluded under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, the agreement should be a central tool for the preservation of marine biodiversity on a global scale. The close link between fishing opportunities and the preservation of marine biodiversity will have to be given due consideration. Parliament also recalls, among other things, the importance of selective fishing techniques, the need to make the fight against IDT fishing a priority and the key role that the Union must play in the global governance of the seas and oceans.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, governing the rights and obligations of nations in relation to the exploitation of the oceans and seas, is an essential instrument of international law in the commercial exploitation, management and conservation of the natural resources of the world's marine waters. By agreement on marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction, the international community has confirmed the need to protect marine fauna and flora from pollution caused by human activity, as well as the sustainable use of natural resources in areas outside the jurisdiction of states. I believe that effective measures must be taken that are binding on the entire international community in order to achieve effective regulation of the protection of marine biodiversity. In this context, I fully share the work of the UN General Assembly Working Group, which aims to create and subsequently adopt such an instrument at the UN, because without binding rules it would be very difficult to make any progress. The new instrument could also bring dynamism to the process of exchanging information, best practices and methods or building qualified capacities at the level of signatory countries. In the spirit of its status as guardian of respect for international agreements, the EU should continue to lead the way in the development of this new legal instrument and its effective implementation. I am voting in favour of the report as it stands.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because blue growth is one of the main priorities on our agendas. Over the past decades, human activities at sea have multiplied. The potential for growth and jobs is enormous and should be used within the ecological limits of the marine environment. Fisheries and aquaculture play an important role in the marine economy. Responsible fisheries and aquaculture are key to sustainable development and a healthy marine eco-system. It is important that fishing is integrated into this vision of the future of the sea that is blue growth.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The UN General Assembly established a preparatory committee in July 2015 with the aim of drafting by the end of 2017 the text of a binding international agreement on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdictions, within the framework of the UNITED NATIONS Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). In its report, the Committee on Fisheries recommends that Parliament welcome this step and take a position in favour of the EU playing a leading role in the drafting of the agreement and in the implementation process.  It points out, however, that the new convention should also cover fishing activities and calls, to this end, for the incorporation of the UN Fish Stocks Agreement (UNFSA) into the new agreement. Finally, it stresses that the new agreement should also include accountability for all relevant actors. I supported the adoption of this resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. According to the rapporteur, the existing legal framework, developed more than 30 years ago on the basis of the principle of freedom of the high seas, no longer ensures the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biodiversity. This report cannot be voted on because the UN convention risks creating global management tools that ely escape sovereign states. However, it is equally pointless to vote against it, as it can be anticipated that the new regulatory constraints will affect European fishermen little but rather their competitors. In any event, the report merely makes recommendations, which is why abstention should be preferred.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is estimated that 64% of the sea, in particular the high seas and the large seabed, are areas outside the national jurisdiction of states regulated by international law. The current legal framework, created more than 30 years ago and based on the maximum freedom of the high seas, needs to be improved to successfully promote the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction. It is important to highlight the leading, and frankly positive, role played by the European Union and the Commission, given the prevailing position of the fishing industry and the EU market and the fact that European fisheries policy is aimed at sustainability. I endorse the rapporteur's position, in particular in recognition of the importance of establishing a legally binding international instrument which includes fishing activities in that instrument. In order to achieve an effective and well-coordinated instrument in the field of marine biology, it will have to take fishing into account, as it is one of the most important activities carried out in the waters.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission to commit states that have not yet done so to ratify the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. This text is fundamental because it establishes a legal framework in which the exploitation of the resources of the sea is established, notably through the creation of the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea, the International Seabed Authority and the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Nicolai report. Due to the international community's concerns and debates about the effectiveness of the current framework for responding to the issue of conservation and sustainable use of marine resources beyond areas of national jurisdiction, UN General Assembly Resolution 59/24, paragraph 73, established an informal special working group with an unrestricted membership in 2004. In January 2015, the working group presented its latest report, stressing the need for a comprehensive global system to better address this issue and recommended the development of a legally binding international instrument relating to the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction. On the basis of this recommendation, in July 2015, the UN General Assembly decided to establish a preparatory committee to draft the text of a legally binding international instrument by the end of 2017, before an intergovernmental conference was held.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. Taking up the positions of the United Nations and the international community on the law of the sea, the report that Parliament has just adopted calls for the establishment of a legally binding instrument by the end of 2017, for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdictions. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcomed Mr Nicolai's report on the DECISION of the UN General Assembly to develop a legally binding international instrument in the context of UNCLOS (UN Convention on the Law of the Sea) on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not under national jurisdiction by 2017.  The report stresses the importance of including fisheries-related activities in this new instrument and the primary role that the EU should play in the development of this new instrument and in the implementation process.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rapid development of maritime activities is putting considerable pressure on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity, which requires EU action. Of course, we must not forget about fishing. This is one of the most active and important activities in the waters, so we must strive to develop an instrument that can include this sector. The motion for a resolution by the European Parliament draws attention precisely to its development, which is why I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to tackle pollution and increasing dangers to marine biodiversity the UN published a paper addressing the importance of protected waters of the world during the Rio de Janeiro UN Conference on Environment and Development that took place on 3-14 June 1992. I have voted for this report that stresses the need for a comprehensive global regime to better address the issue of conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it, in its form adopted today, expresses both a clear message of support for the position and objectives of the European Commission, committed to the negotiation of this new international agreement, and an exposition of the priorities that the Parliamentary Committee on Fisheries has in relation to these negotiations. I think it was very important for the European Parliament to express its clear opinion on the negotiations to come at the UN in order to give the Commission the mandate it needs to represent the EU in these negotiations.  The most important point of today's report is the unreserved inclusion of fisheries in the new international agreement. As regards marine protected areas, they cannot be successful unless there is coordination and collaboration between all areas of activity and if they are not established in an overall logic for the protection of marine biodiversity. In this respect, it is very important that this new agreement includes an institutional decision-making structure.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the report contains areas that are not subject to national control.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on the UN resolution on the development of a legally binding international instrument on the conversation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction, adopted in June 2015. The report supports this resolution while emphasizing the rapid growth and expansion of maritime activities and their potentially negative impact, particularly industrial fishing. It calls on the European Commission to complete the current structure and ensure that protection is extended to areas where no international text is applicable.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. Fishing is a very important activity in both areas of national jurisdiction and areas outside its jurisdiction. Another important aspect is that the EU plays a key role in global management of the seas and oceans and is responsible for the adoption of a proactive policy on the protection of marine biodiversity worldwide. It is therefore essential that a new international legally binding instrument under UNCLOS on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction is established in accordance with the decision of the UN General Assembly. The new legal regulation will close existing legal gaps, ensure the conservation of marine biodiversity and the sustainable use of resources, and enable all actors involved in maritime activities to coordinate their actions and consult each other properly.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the formulation of the legal regime in relation to the law of the sea and the conservation of biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction, recognising the need for an international approach in order to manage pollution and the growing risks to marine biodiversity. The conservation of biodiversity in areas outside the framework of maritime law regulation is becoming imperative in view of the rapid changes in the field of fishing activities worldwide. This report raises a serious issue which mainly also concerns environmental issues and aims to preserve marine biodiversity. The importance of the EU's Blue Growth strategy, which aims to support growth in economic activities at sea, is also highlighted.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because UNCLOS needs general recognition even when we dispute the EU’s claim to competence.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On the proposal by the rapporteur, Norica Nicolai, on the need to include fisheries in the international agreement on biodiversity, I voted in favour.  The United Nations has on several occasions addressed the problem of the protection of world waters, thus noting the real danger of water pollution and the need for sustainable development. The latest UN report also stressed the need to establish a comprehensive global regime for the conservation and protection of marine biodiversity in areas not under state jurisdiction and to adopt a binding legal system. In this respect, It seems to me that my colleague's proposal goes in the same direction as the work of the United Nations and that the inclusion of fishing activities, as well as the proposal for greater liaison between the Member States, should be encouraged at European level.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. Aware of the importance of preserving and sustainably using the oceans, seas and their resources, I support the report, which calls for the EU and the international community to promote the conservation and sustainable use of marine resources by introducing modern fisheries management concepts together with other measures. I also welcome the decision of the UN General Assembly to take steps towards developing a new international instrument under UNCLOS for marine biodiversity in areas outside the borders of national jurisdiction in order to address shortcomings in the current situation. The EU is a current leader in the world in terms of ocean governance and in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (IUU), and I therefore support the requirements of the report asking the Commission to take a leadership role when it comes to other international issues. The Commission should support and promote the establishment of connected, clear and representative networks of marine protected areas, as networks are necessary to ensure ecological and biological connectivity, as this new international agreement should guarantee a level playing field for all stakeholders. I support the overall report by highlighting the important role of the industry and the fisheries market in the EU, but also in the Republic of Croatia.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report calls for the creation of marine protected areas, global management tools, including vessel registration, and scientific monitoring of new marine resource development activities. I cannot vote in favour of this text, because the UN Convention does risk creating global management tools that are beyond the control of sovereign states. However, it is equally pointless to vote against it, as it can be anticipated that the new regulatory constraints will affect European fishermen little but rather their competitors. In any event, the report merely makes recommendations. So I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As a representative coming from a country with access to the open sea, and where the majority of the coastal population depends precisely on fishing as a branch of the economy, I stress that the preservation of healthy marine habitats and sustainable fish stocks, both in national waters and in areas outside national jurisdiction, is essential for the long-term sustainability of fisheries. In recent decades, the number of activities carried out in the marine environment has increased, thereby putting pressure on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity.  The potential for growth and jobs is enormous and should be used within the ecological boundaries of the marine environment. Fishing and aquaculture play an important role in the marine economy, and responsible fishing and aquaculture are essential for the sustainable and healthy development of marine ecosystems. For this reason, I welcome the global comprehensive regime initiative, which will better cover the conservation and management of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report follows the recommendations made in 2015 at the United Nations General Assembly on international cooperation for the protection of ecosystems and the sustainability of the use of marine resources. It emphasizes the need to establish a binding instrument under the responsibility of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The position of the working group which carried out the recommendations and the UN General Assembly points to the negative impact that rapid growth and expansion of maritime activities (including industrial fishing, marine drilling, transport, etc.) will have and have had on the marine environment. The need to deepen international legislation, in a context where 64% of the existing sea area is outside national jurisdictions, is therefore considered fundamental. Reviewing us in its overall sense, the report nevertheless contains some valuable references to EU policies, in particular the Common Fisheries Policy, in which we do not review ourselves. Nor do we support a centralising vision, supporting the EU's positions and conferring power on its institutions, in particular the European Commission. This logic has favored large fishing industries, but has negatively affected small-scale fishing, small industries and fishing communities, with a negative impact on ecosystems.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Nicolai's report. It is necessary to stress the importance of a comprehensive global regime on the protection of world waters in order to cope with pollution and the growing danger to marine biodiversity, as the conservation of healthy marine habitats and sustainable fish stocks is essential for the long-term sustainability of fisheries.  The UN shows that it is committed to these goals through its documents, but I think it is necessary to adapt plans and priorities to a rapidly evolving world. I therefore support the effort to develop an international legally binding mechanism for the protection and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside the competence of sovereign states.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The seas and oceans occupy most of the surface of the Earth and have an irreplaceable role in many systems of our planet. I therefore consider it very important to strive to preserve biodiversity, maintain healthy marine habitats and fish stocks. Taking into account the fact that up to 64% of marine areas are governed by international law, comprehensive global action is needed. I therefore very much welcome the proposal by the UN Working Group to create a legally binding international instrument aimed at preserving and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. I believe that this new agreement is necessary in view of the obsolescence of the existing legal framework, which does not correspond to the dynamics of change, with which, for example, the number of activities developed in the marine environment is changing. It is these changes that have a major impact on the conservation of marine ecosystems, as well as on the sustainable use of the oceans and seas and their resources. Given the important role the EU plays in the sustainable management of living marine resources, greater involvement in international cooperation is necessary. At the same time, this new agreement should ensure a level playing field for all stakeholders.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 1995, the United Nations adopted the Agreement on the Conservation of Fishery Resources (UNFSA). One of the main objectives of this agreement has been to promote international cooperation and coordination for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not under national jurisdiction.  Finally, the UN General Assembly has succeeded in bringing the issue of the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not subject to national jurisdiction to a point where it is possible to provide for a legally binding instrument at international level, including fishing activities. I therefore voted in favour of adopting this report, in the hope that the EU can continue to play a leading role in the development of this new instrument and its implementation process.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the underway approach to preparing a legally binding international agreement on the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. This future agreement will focus on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in maritime areas outside the national jurisdiction. While this new UN instrument is in line with existing and proven mechanisms, I call for better coordination with other international mechanisms for the preservation of biodiversity.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because UNCLOS needs general recognition even when we dispute the EU’s claim to competence.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Resolution because marine biodiversity is of particular importance in the outermost regions, such as the Azores which give An Atlantic dimension to Europe. Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing threatens marine biodiversity and compromises the preservation of ecosystems. This justifies enhanced cooperation, coordination, transparency and accountability among all actors involved. The conservation of marine biodiversity and its sustainable use are directly linked to long-term sustainable development. It is urgent to tackle plastic waste at sea and to finance relevant research in the field of the 'blue economy'. The positive role of eco-labelling in the seafood sector is highlighted, which allows consumers to contribute to the sustainability of resources and the preservation of biodiversity. It is desirable for the UN to work together with states to effectively implement existing rules and, where necessary, draw up additional rules that can indirectly help protect biodiversity on the high seas and improve social, security and control conditions, such as the establishment of a centralised instrument for the registration of fishing vessels , avoiding, however, the increase in the bureaucratic burden for fishermen.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Blue growth must be a priority. Human activities at sea have multiplied in recent decades. The potential for growth and job creation is enormous and must take into account maritime ecological limits. Fisheries and aquaculture play an important role in the maritime economy and must be developed responsibly, enabling sustainable development and ecosystem balance.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In the UN Charter on the Law of the Sea (1982), in its Fish Stocks Agreement (1995) and Agenda 21, the United Nations has addressed the importance of protecting the world's waters. In this context, a working group was set up to discuss the possibility of promoting international cooperation and coordination for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity outside areas of national jurisdiction that recommended the development of a legally binding international instrument. On the basis of this recommendation, in July 2015, the United Nations General Assembly decided to establish a Preparatory Committee to develop the text of a legally binding instrument at international level by the end of 2017. In this context, this report of the European Parliament emerges, before the holding of an Intergovernmental Conference on the Conservation and Sustainable Use of Marine Biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction.  I voted for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In 1992, the United Nations mentioned the importance of protecting the world's waters in the document "Action 21," which was published after the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, that same year. Thus, the international community recognized the need for an international strategy to combat pollution and the growing dangers that threatened marine biodiversity. Then came the Johannesburg Declaration on Sustainable Development and the Implementation Plan, adopted at the UN World Summit in South Africa in September 2002. In 2012, in the document called Rio-20, the international community reaffirmed its determination to address ecological problems and the need for sustainable development. In 2004, UN General Assembly Resolution 59/24, paragraph 73, established a special working group. In January 2015, the working group presented its report, stressing the need for a comprehensive system at the global level and recommended the development of a legally binding international instrument on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction. The report voted today repeats the same terms.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. On 19 June 2015, the UN General Assembly adopted a resolution on the development of an international legally binding instrument under UNCLOS on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction. This report seeks, in essence, to highlight the objectives mentioned in that resolution, as well as to fill the gaps by extending the powers of global, regional or sectoral bodies, which must also include the impact of fishing on marine biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The UN stressed the importance of protecting world waters following the 1992 United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Brazil- Agenda 21. In 2012, in the document published after the UN Conference on Sustainable Development, the international community reaffirmed its determination to address environmental problems and the need to promote sustainable development. This shows that while the international community recognises the need for a global approach to managing pollution and growing threats to marine biodiversity, there is a need to adapt plans and priorities locally to a rapidly developing world. Since I agree with the rapporteur's emphasis on the inclusion of instruments for the accountability of all actors involved in the future agreement, which are important tools for achieving real efficiency and progress, I voted in favour of this report. Also taking into account the needs of developing countries, capacity building and information sharing, they should be a priority in accordance with good practice and the EU should therefore continue to ensure a leading role in the development of this instrument as well as in its implementation process.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on fisheries aspects in the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. In 2004, the United Nations established an informal special working group on the effectiveness of the current framework for addressing issues of conservation and sustainable use of marine resources beyond regulated areas of national jurisdiction. The working group published its latest report in January 2015 calling for the development of a legally binding instrument on the conservation and sustainable exploitation of marine biodiversity in these areas beyond national jurisdiction.  In this text, Parliament believes that the European Union and especially the Member States should act in favour of marine biodiversity by implementing modern and sustainable concepts of managing the marine ecosystem.  I supported this text which reaffirms its commitment to put in place such an instrument before the end of 2017 in order to preserve the marine ecosystem.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as the report aims to establish mechanisms linking the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea but in the field of fisheries, stressing the importance of the conservation of marine biodiversity and the sustainable use of marine resources.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted for the Nicolai report on fisheries issues under the International Agreement on Marine Biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdictions - the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, and I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her work. Fishing has intensified in recent times, as well as related marine activities, and therefore the pressure on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity is constantly increasing. I am pleased that the UN General Assembly and the Ad Hoc Working Group have managed, despite strong opposition, to make progress on the issue of marine biological diversity in areas outside national jurisdictions, reaching the intention to create a legally binding international instrument. I hope that the new agreement will include tools to empower all the actors involved, because without these instruments, neither real progress nor real efficiency can be foreseen.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the fisheries aspects of the International Convention on Marine Biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction, as the need for an international approach to tackling pollution and the increasing threat to marine biodiversity was recognised at the UN Conference in Rio de Janeiro as early as 1992 and is still relevant today. Addressing the conservation and sustainable use of marine resources requires comprehensive global regulation.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the report voted on today, which addresses the issue of the international governance of areas not subject to national jurisdiction or high seas areas, the European Union renews its commitment, alongside the United Nations, to addressing the challenges associated with the conservation and sustainable use of marine areas.  In this context, the report supports the decision to develop a legally binding international instrument, in accordance with the UNITED Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, in order to promote international cooperation and coordination for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in high-seas areas. I voted in favour of this report because I hope that this new instrument will offer effective solutions to problems such as illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing, pollution and waste at sea, which seriously damage marine habitats and ecosystems.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. As shadow rapporteur, I helped ensure that this report mentioned points such as the need to develop consistent instruments for access to the benefits of exploiting genetic resources and strengthening the protection of marine biodiversity in the context of new UN initiatives. The document now also approved with my vote could contribute to provide political consistency in support of the implementation of a worldwide network of Marine Protected Areas in Areas Beyond National Jurisdiction, a fundamental option for the conservation of the oceans and their resources. This European report, as well as the others related to fisheries approved today, explicitly assimilate and embode the work done by various experts at the level of the Convention on Biological Diversity and, in particular, to the work completed in the Azores in which the criteria and rules for selecting the Ecological and Biologically Significant Areas were determined" ("EBSA") , recognized as "Azores Criteria".

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because UNCLOS needs general recognition even when we dispute the EU’s claim to competence.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The 'Blue Growth' is one of the main priorities of my group, and I voted in favour of this report because I agree that it should be a major priority; over the past decade human activities in the sea have increased dramatically. While the potential for growth and jobs in this sector is enormous, it should be used within the ecological limits of the marine environment. It is important therefore that fishing be integrated into this vision of the future of the sea that is 'Blue Growth' and hence I supported this INI report today.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The international agreement on marine biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction takes into consideration both the economic and environmental arguments, therefore I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 the UN addressed the issue of the protection of world waters already at the 1992 conference in Rio de Janeiro. Further declarations followed, in which the international community is aware of the need for an international approach to tackle pollution and the increasing risks to marine biodiversity. An international agreement should ensure a level playing field between all stakeholders, and the new international agreement should address the specific needs of developing countries, in particular small island states. The UN Convention on the Law of the Sea stresses the importance of the conservation and sustainable use of oceans and seas and their resources, calls on the EU and the international community to promote the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity by applying, among other measures, modern and sustainable concepts of marine ecosystem management, ocean governance, management of marine resources and fisheries. In order to deal with the pressures on marine biodiversity by 2020, Member States will have to take measures to implement management plans, monitor vessels and coordinate information on marine biodiversity.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In June 2012, a UN resolution launched the development of a legally binding new international instrument for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national competence. This instrument is being developed within the framework of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). The ocean plays an essential role in many systems on Earth, but it is also a place where a large number of human activities such as fishing, trade and transport are carried out. More than half of the sea (64%) – especially the high seas and deep seabed – are areas that go beyond the national jurisdiction of states and which are governed by international law. However, less than 1 % of these areas outside national jurisdiction are protected by the establishment of marine protected areas. In this new instrument, it is important to also include fishing activities, as fishing is one of the most important activities in the waters. The new instrument must complement the current structure (networks of international regional authorities regulating fishing in certain maritime areas) and not replace it. This will also take into account fishing in those areas where there is currently no international organisation. I believe that marine biodiversity must be protected and preserved, taking into account aspects of fishing, which is why I supported the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the text in which Parliament expresses its position on the decision of the UN General Assembly to develop a legally binding international instrument in the context of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) focusing on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity in areas not under national jurisdiction, in order to address current shortcomings.  Currently, within the framework of UNCLOS there is the United Nations Agreement on Fish Stocks (UNFSA), considered a good multilateral agreement establishing a legal framework on the management of marine resources to combat problems such as marine pollution, invasive human activities and other phenomena that endanger marine biodiversity. By the end of 2017, the United Nations should present a new legally binding multilateral agreement to include fishing activities in the regulatory framework, starting as a basis for the UNFSA agreement now in force. This is an important step in the development of the blue economy, whose potential for growth and work is enormous and should be realised by respecting the ecological limits of the marine environment, in particular through responsible and sustainable fishing.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The UN General Assembly adopted a resolution on 19 June 2015 on the development of a new international instrument under UNCLOS for marine biodiversity in areas outside the borders of national competence, with a view to addressing shortcomings in the current situation. It emphasises the necessity of an international approach to manage pollution and increasing threats to marine biodiversity.  It also highlighted the importance of preserving and sustainably using the oceans, seas and their resources and introducing modern fisheries management concepts, maintaining fish stocks at levels that provide maximum sustainable yield, and preserving and managing ecosystem-based biodiversity.  I believe that the preservation and responsible management of natural resources are one of the most important tasks, not only of the European Union, but of the whole world. Enhanced accountability, cooperation and transparency of all sectors involved is needed. Consequently, I support this report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. In 2011, the Ad hoc informal working group, set up by the UN, submitted a package of recommendations to the UN General Assembly on various issues outside the border of national jurisdiction. Many limitations of the current situation were already seen at the time. Each country is obliged to protect the marine environment and habitats of rare species, which require good coordination by all operators involved in marine activities. I support the proposal for a resolution, as I think it is very important to preserve marine biodiversity, especially outside the borders of national competence. Fisheries are also one of the most important activities taking place in the seas, and I believe that it must be covered by all measures for management and conservation. The resolution helps to arrange fisheries and accompanying facilities that come with fisheries, which have a positive impact on the EU economy, as well as people involved in the activity.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal and support activities leading to more effective protection of international waters.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report on the aspects of fishing in the international agreement on marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction, the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. I support the report, which stresses the importance of the conservation and sustainable use of the oceans and seas and their resources, while calling on the EU and the international community to promote the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity by introducing, together with other measures, modern and sustainable concepts of marine ecosystem management, the principle of ocean management and the management of the exploitation of marine resources.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Aspects relating to fisheries to be included in the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea include in particular the conservation of biodiversity.  Parliament was asked to give its opinion on this development and despite some negative reports we decided to support the report. On the one hand, because the conservation of biodiversity concerns all of us, and on the other hand because the Convention gives each Member State the inalienable sovereign right of separate blue development, if it naturally respects marine biodiversity.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. Biodiversity, and not just at sea, is something we need to take care of in order to last. In fact, the greatest must be done to safeguard our seas and oceans and prevent their pollution, as this is the only way to continue fishing without threatening fish and the health of consumers.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which promotes good governance and conservation in areas beyond jurisdiction, in order to ensure the conservation of the high seas.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the UNITED NATIONS Convention on the Law of the Sea. I welcome the resolution of the UN General Assembly to develop a binding international instrument under UNCLOS on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdictions in order to remedy the current shortcomings. This instrument will play a key role in the conservation and sustainable use of the oceans and seas and their resources.  Furthermore, I also support the report's call for the Commission to promote and support efforts to conserve marine protected areas, as this can only be achieved with the broadest involvement of stakeholders.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fishing is, at both European and global level, a booming economic activity that can generate sustainable development of society and, by implication, stable jobs. However, the development of this activity must take account of the conservation of marine biodiversity and limit pollution and other adverse events that may occur in the maritime space. Since most of this space (64%) is not governed by national laws, but by the law of the sea, the international community is directly responsible for complying with the rules adopted in this field. This concerns, first of all, the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, adopted in 1982 and, on the basis of this document, the International Agreement on Marine Biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdictions, including fisheries issues, adopted in 1995. Mandatory instruments for fishing activities in the international maritime area are expected to be adopted by 2017. The European Union can only support these measures, which are in line with the principle of 'blue growth' of maritime space. Sustainable development of global fisheries is one of the important resources for achieving healthy economic growth, generating jobs and food for the society of the future. I therefore support the adoption of this document.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text. I just wanted to add that the new agreement should include instruments so that all the players involved are accountable, since it is difficult, if not, to envisage real efficiency and progress. Given the needs of developing countries, capacity building and information sharing should also be a priority. From this point of view, both in terms of the exchange of good practices, the European Union should continue to play a leading role in the development of the new instrument and in the process of its implementation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The sea is home to a large part of the world’s biodiversity, and its preservation is a common concern for all humankind. However, as 64% of the sea is in areas beyond the national jurisdiction of states, there is no legal framework in place to establish marine protected areas. In 2015, the UN Working Group studying that topic recommended the development of an international, legally binding instrument under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) to manage pollution and the increasing dangers to marine biodiversity. I voted in favour of this resolution, as I agree that the EU should continue to play a leading role in the development of this new instrument. Fishing should also be included, as it is one of the most important activities there. It should also make sure that all actors involved are accountable to ensure real efficiency. Capacity-building and sharing of information should be prioritised.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea raises important aspects relating to fisheries. This is important because more than 60% of the seas are areas that do not fall under national jurisdiction and are subject to international law. Sensible and cost-effective management of marine resources requires un-supervised regulations. This is very important for sustainable fisheries in the long term. The existing provisions were drawn up 30 years ago and do not take into account current trade needs and the latest conservation standards on marine and ocean biodiversity. The report draws attention to a very important fact, without which it is difficult to imagine a coordinated policy on maritime areas, and it is about rational fisheries. The new agreement provides in this case for the use of all possible legal instruments to better involve all stakeholders. I therefore support the report in question.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I have supported the suppression of illegal, unregulated and unreported fishing which is by its very nature a threat to marine biodiversity and seriously endangers the conservation of the marine ecosystem. Seas and oceans have a lot of potential for blue growth and development in the form of renewable energy sources, pharmaceutical products, the development of knowledge about the marine environment and its ecosystem, and are therefore very important for all countries and territories. In my view, the protection of natural resources is essential for economic and social development, which serves as a precondition for the sustainable development of fishing. I would also highlight the role of the Commission working to protect and access international waters, as well as to encourage all states to ratify or access the Convention on the Law of the Sea. Because of all of the above, as well as the crucial role of the European Union in global sea and ocean governance and the major impact in fisheries on the international stage, I voted to adopt this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing.
