The report on fishing aspects of the international agreement on marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction, I supported the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. Agenda 21 is a document addressing the importance of water protection in the world and was published at the UN Conference on Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro in June 1992. This showed that the international community recognises the need for an international approach to pollution management and to increase the threat of persistence to marine biodiversity. Several declarations and documents on sustainable development on the subject followed in the coming years. In January 2015, the Working Party presented its latest report, highlighting the need for a comprehensive global system to better address this issue and recommending the development of an international legally binding instrument, in line with UNCLOS for the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity areas outside national jurisdiction. On the basis of this recommendation, in July 2015, the UN General Assembly decided to set up a Steering Committee with a view to drawing up an internationally legally binding instrument to be adopted by the end of 2017.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as the report aims to establish mechanisms linking the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea but in the field of fisheries, stressing the importance of the conservation of marine biodiversity and the sustainable use of marine resources.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The legal framework on international waters is no longer sufficient to control biodiversity conservation. This report states that the European Union is an essential player in the protection of biodiversity. It also advocates the creation of marine protected areas, global management tools, including vessel registration, and scientific monitoring of new marine resource development activities. The United Nations risks creating global management tools that are beyond the control of sovereign states, so I cannot vote for it. However, European fishermen should not be affected by this report (unlike their foreign colleagues). That is why I preferred to abstain on this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Maritime activities are developing and multiplying rapidly, increasing pressures on the sustainability and conservation of marine biodiversity. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as the report aims to establish mechanisms linking the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea but in the field of fisheries, stressing the importance of the conservation of marine biodiversity and the sustainable use of marine resources.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. In June 2015 the UN adopted a resolution on the development of an international, legally binding instrument under the UN Law of the Sea on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biological diversity of areas beyond national jurisdiction. The goal of this report is to make clear that the new instrument must not attempt to replace the current institutional structure but rather to complete it, to ensure that coverage is extended for fisheries to those areas where no international body currently exists.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on fisheries aspects within the international agreement on marine biodiversity. The report emphasizes the importance of the preservation and conservation of marine biological diversity as a global concern. It praises the work of the UNGA and Ad Hoc Open-ended Informal Working Group in making the issue of marine biological diversity an international, legally binding instrument beyond areas of national jurisdiction. It equally underlines the need for the inclusion of fishing activities in this new instrument.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report welcomes the decision taken by the United Nations General Assembly to develop a legally binding international instrument within the framework of UNCLOS on the conservation and sustainable use of marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction in order, inter alia, to address current deficiencies in this area. For this main reason I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this proposal because I think it is important that an internationally recognised and legally binding text is drawn up with the aim of protecting international waters.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In June 2015, the UN General Assembly Working Group adopted a resolution to warn that maritime areas beyond the limits of national jurisdictions (200 nautical miles) rarely enjoy protection and are beyond any jurisdiction, including international jurisdiction. In fact, 64% of the seas, including the high seas and the deep seabed, are areas beyond national jurisdictions and only 1% of areas beyond these limits are protected by the establishment of protected maritime areas.  However, the growth and expansion of maritime activities, particularly industrial fishing, and their potentially negative impact on fisheries resources and biodiversity makes the need to better protect these areas urgently. The report proposes to extend the provisions for the protection of maritime areas from national courts to areas not currently covered. This is a good thing for the protection of these spaces and their biodiversity. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The need to deepen international legislation, in a context where 64% of the existing sea area is outside national jurisdictions, is considered essential. This report follows the recommendations made in 2015 at the United Nations General Assembly on international cooperation for the protection of ecosystems and sustainability of the use of marine resources, emphasizing the need to establish a binding instrument under the responsibility of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. Reviewing us in its overall sense, the report nevertheless contains some valuable references to EU policies, in particular the Common Fisheries Policy, in which we do not review ourselves. Nor do we support a centralising vision, supporting the EU's positions and conferring power on its institutions, in particular the European Commission.  This logic has favored large fishing industries, but has negatively affected small-scale fishing, small industries and fishing communities, with a negative impact on ecosystems.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on fisheries aspects within the framework of the international convention on marine biodiversity in areas outside national jurisdiction (United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea). The UN Convention on the Law of the Sea concerns marine areas that do not fall within the scope of a national jurisdiction. While issues such as marine biodiversity and water pollution have long been a focus of the United Nations General Assembly and informal working groups, there is still a need to improve the focus on fisheries concerns. The motion for a resolution supports the idea of a new agreement that focuses not only on marine biology, but also on the problems of fisheries. This agreement concerns international waters where no national jurisdiction is valid and therefore does not exceed the principle of subsidiarity. As the motion for a resolution is an example of international cooperation, I voted in favour of it.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the own-initiative report on the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea: fisheries issues. The UN addressed the importance of protecting the world's waters in the document called 'Agenda 21', published following the UN Conference on Environment and Development, held in Rio de Janeiro in 1992. It demonstrated that, at the level of the international community, the need for an international approach to manage pollution and the growing dangers of marine biodiversity was recognised.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on fisheries aspects under the International Agreement on Marine Biodiversity in areas beyond national jurisdiction - United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, as it is extremely important to include fishing activities in this new instrument.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on fisheries aspects in areas outside national jurisdiction. These are areas of the so-called high seas which do not fall under the jurisdiction of any State and are governed by international law. However, it is these areas that are exposed to illegal fishing, exploratory drilling or the extraction of minerals and minerals, which cause great damage to biodiversity. I consider the creation of a binding legal instrument for the protection of the high seas to be a positive step in order to prevent pollution and damage in these areas and thus to preserve as diverse ecosystems as possible.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The conservation of marine biodiversity and its sustainable use is directly linked to long-term development and therefore has social, economic and environmental significance for all countries and areas. The seas and oceans have tremendous potential in the field of renewable energy and pharmaceutical products. The EU plays a key role in the global management of the seas and oceans and has a major international impact in fisheries. I therefore support efforts in the field of conservation and management of the long-term development of marine biodiversity.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because this goes far beyond consolidation to create a harmonised structure of animal breeding.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Eu ropean livestock legislation aims to promote the free trade of breeding animals and their genetic material, ensuring the sustainability of the programme and the preservation of genetic resources. The regulation lays down the basic principles for breeding animals of the bovine, pig, sheep, caprine and equine species. I have chosen to abstain in this vote because we would have liked to see a clear split between cloning and the use of germ material.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report combines all directives related to zootechnical legislation into one. I voted in favour because the result of the trilogue is much better than the commission's original proposal and has a very clear line of view to maintaining the genetic heritage of less commercial, local, rare or endangered species. It also adds some point of small improvements in animal welfare and strengthening of the European domestic market.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This technical file deals with rules regarding the structuring of the breeding sector, management of breeding books/registers, intra-EU trade, and imports from third countries. At Committee level, the report was broadened to also cover conservation of rare breeds, thereby protecting biodiversity. At EU level the intention is to harmonise the approach to trade in breeding animals. It was for these reasons that we voted in favour of this file.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the quality of his report. Like him, I agree with the Commission's proposals which, without questioning the foundations of zootechnical legislation, aim to simplify and clarify the existing rules and bring them more coherence. Bringing all zootechnical rules together in a single regulatory framework and in the form of regulations should avoid the enforcement problems we have so far experienced in intra-community trade. Above all, I would like to acknowledge the contributions of the European Parliament to enable the better preservation of local breeds or endangered breeds. As I observed at the Paris Agricultural Fair, these breeds are a considerable development asset for many territories and especially for the less prosperous among them. These breeds adapted to difficult production conditions and their ecosystem allow small farms to develop quality chains that, while meeting consumer demands, preserve employment in rural areas.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it includes legislative measures concerning the approval or recognition and registration of livestock organisations, breeders' associations and relevant private undertakings, the registration and classification of animals in herd books and in the case of hybrid breeding pigs in registers, the control of performance and genetic evaluation, the content and form of zootechnical certificates for the rearing of animals.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report followed a complex procedure until it was voted on in plenary. The original text presented by the Commission was widely criticised, in particular on the fact that the Commission sought to take as many prerogatives as possible on the subject. The Committee on Agriculture improves the initial version, in that it takes into account low-numbered breeds, takes up equine-specific criteria, and limits the Commission's prerogatives, but all this is still largely insufficient. I have therefore objected to this report, which leaves far too much scope for the Commission.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation, which is in line with the Better Legislation programme by compiling seven regulations into one, which I welcome. This regulation has first raised many concerns within the equine industry, the only species that is not only destined to end up on our plates and which must benefit from different treatment. Nevertheless, thanks to the listening and the work of rapporteur Michel Dantin, the equine sector comes out reassured and strengthened.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to harmonise the animal breeding system, which will have a significant impact on the European animal breeding sector. EU zootechnical legislation aims to promote and facilitate the free trade in and imports of breeding animals and their genetic material in the EU, while ensuring that breeding and conservation programmes for all genetic resources in Europe are maintained. The rearing of productive animals, in particular those with valuable genetic characteristics, not only contributes to the economic and social development of the region in which they are reared, but is also one of the union's main food security factors. The European Commission wants to merge all directives relating to zootechnical legislation on different species into a single piece of legislation – this regulation – to complete the single market in this area. I agree with the urgent need to harmonise the animal breeding system, which would have a significant impact on the European animal breeding sector.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 A very important report has been decided today in this field, we could say that it is a single animal husbandry regulation. The report is niche in the sense that it unifys the production of bovine, ovine, caprine, swine and equidae, the turnover of their reproductive material and the breeding programme of each species in the EU, which has been managed under the responsibility of the Member States. Improving the genetic performance of livestock production is more successful because the larger number of the number of the population is a carrier of genetic diversity. Thus, uniform treatment of breeding material at EU level helps farmers to choose the most appropriate genetic basis for their breeding objectives, which directly affects their livelihoods. Despite all these positives, I abstained in the final vote because, by a separate vote, the majority decided not to exclude any discrimination against breeding material from third countries. This is risky because there is no regulation compatible with the EU, which is particularly dangerous in the light of the free trade agreement negotiated with the US.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because this goes far beyond consolidation to create a harmonised structure of animal breeding.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to a report that leaves far too much scope for the Commission; despite Mr Dantin's consideration, in a new version of his report, of a number of our remarks - taking into account low-strength breeds, resuming the equine-specific criteria, limiting the Commission's prerogatives - this new version retains a number of points which represent as many infringements on our sovereignty in an area as crucial as agriculture.  Indeed, as this text is a regulation, it will be applied without transposition into national law; it also serves as a pretext for the Commission to take on new prerogatives in the establishment of selection and import criteria; And finally, the clause to protect farmers in EU countries from possible third-country failures is too vague - and therefore insufficient - in that it leaves the full definition of what these breaches are to the Commission.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union's zootechnical legislation concerning the production of livestock (cattle, swine, sheep, goat and equine) and their germ products is made up of various standards that could curb trade and import into the EU. I voted in favour of this regulation proposed in co-decision because it offers legal harmonisation to the principles that govern the process of breeding the high genetically quality animal species mentioned above. This unique legal framework will allow for greater fluidity in their trade and imports.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The breeding of pig, bovine, sheep, goat and horse species is a huge asset for the Union. It occupies a key position within the agricultural sector and is an important income resource for a large part of agricultural communities.  The Dantin report, which I voted on today in Parliament, addressed the issue of zootechnical and genealogical conditions applicable to trade in and imports of breeding animals and their germ material within the Union. I supported this proposal because I believe it is important to support the work of the many breeders' associations that are at the forefront of defending genetic diversity within Europe.  The proposal for a regulation presented by the Commission has set itself the objective of unifying and simplifying the existing legislation, which is now defined by four different acts. The new regulation will serve to clarify the provisions on animal husbandry, leading to greater protection of the great cultural heritage of the thousands of native species which, over the centuries, have adapted to the different regions of the continent.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, since despite improvements and the intention to meet livestock criteria across the EU, and their general lines point in the right direction, there were amendments on cloned animals that were rejected. On the other hand, the report delves into the current unsustainable model of livestock exploitation of the large industry, when we should tend to a model that is more respectful of the environment and animal life, and to closer, quality and sustainable livestock.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I rejected this report on breeding animals and their germ products because it endorses an unbearable arbitrary power of the European Commission in this area. Of course, the text from Parliament is some improvement over the Commission's original proposal: in particular, it is taken into account the low-strength breeds or the equine-specific criteria, ideas that my ENL colleagues had brought to the AGRI committee. However, the regulation (thus leading to direct application without possible debate at national level) from the trilogue leaves the scope open to the Commission in defining the criteria for selection or import. Moreover, the safeguard clause is far too weak, as the definition of "serious and far-reaching breach of the rules" is left to the discretion of the Commission! The importation of breeding animals and germ products from third countries is therefore not limited and there are no real constraints in this text on zootechnical and genealogical rules.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I agree with much of the content of this text, I believe that it adds new burdens to operators in the livestock sector, leaving some disciplinary aspects of relations with third countries unclear. As I do not think it is appropriate to give my full support to this report, I have decided to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade in breeding animals and their reproductive products and their importation into the Union, by which the Plenary of Parliament ratifies the agreement reached with the Council and Commission.  This Regulation brings together in a single legal text the directives on zootechnical legislation, legislation aimed at promoting free trade within the EU and facilitating the importation of breeding animals and their genetic material, ensuring the preservation of genetic resources in Europe. The text also reinforces the preservation of indigenous breeds that are not always accompanied by high economic performance.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the proposal for a regulation on zootechnical and genealogical requirements applicable to trade in and imports into the EU of breeding animals and their germinal products in the European Union. European Union (EU) zootechnical legislation aims to promote and facilitate the free trade in and imports of breeding animals and their genetic material in the European Union, while ensuring that breeding and conservation programmes for all genetic resources in Europe are maintained. The rearing of productive animals, in particular those found to have valuable genetic characteristics, not only contributes to the economic and social development of the region in which they are reared, but is also one of the union's main food security factors. The European Commission wanted to merge all the directives relating to zootechnical legislation on different species into a single piece of legislation – this regulation – to complete the single market in this area. However, it should be stressed that the European Commission's objective is not only to merge and simplify legislation. Indeed, it proposes harmonising the animal breeding system, which will have a significant impact on the European animal breeding sector. The rapporteur supports this general approach, but some aspects should be clarified or reassessed.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Members have voted in uniform support for the European Commission's proposal for a draft law on zootechnical and geneadological conditions for trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germs. The law provides for greater transparency over the breeding of breeding animals and their embryos. It covers four major areas: the structured breeding sector, the rules for keeping the registers/registers, the rules on intra-EU trade and imports from third countries, and the rules on official control and control by the Commission. It is a very sophisticated draft law that regulates areas where various issues and a number of ambiguities have so far arised.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Breeding domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, horses, pigs and goats is extremely important for EU agriculture and the people who live off it. With this document, the Commission planned to unifies all the rules governing animal breeding and their genetic material. The proposal at technical level governs this important issue and that is why I supported it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this regulation because I believe that, by regulating the trade and import of breeding animals and their germinal material uniformly throughout Europe, it would bring many economic and legal benefits.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The production and breeding of domestic animals with particular genetic characteristics and the trade in their germ-like materials in order to encourage their reproduction have long been recognised and encouraged as some of the main factors capable of ensuring a high quality of the product and protecting the food safety of European consumers.  In this sense, it is right to try to bring together the various European regulations that already exist in this field and to harmonise national ones in order to simplify the rules of the sector and eliminate those unnecessary technical barriers that often penalise international trade. In the context of this harmonisation work, in line with the opinion given by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, we must, however, promote high and effective standards and control mechanisms, for example by supporting a policy of competitiveness of large European breeds that respects the various local breeds and thus protects biodiversity, and by promoting a privileged role for the International Committee for the Control of Livestock Performance in the drafting of livestock legislation. All while always paying particular attention to the well-being and safety of animals.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on zootechnical and genealogical conditions applicable to trade within the Union and imports into the Union of breeding animals and germination material therefrom aims to harmonise trade in this field and to standardise the official controls to be carried out on breeding programmes, taking into account both the cross-border nature , as well as the principle of subsidiarity. Current zootechnical legislation promotes free trade in breeding animals and their genetic material, taking into account the sustainability of breeding programmes and the conservation of genetic resources. However, at present, the Union's zootechnical legislation is vertically organised according to species, which is why similar provisions have been concentrated, being rendered in a clearer and coherent language, precisely in order to avoid their transposition into national law creating obstacles to trade. The proposal therefore contains a number of new provisions describing the relationship between breeders and breeding societies, provisions on the acceptance of breeding animals and artificial sowing, on performance testing. I was in favour of this report because I consider it essential to create a coherent legal framework that allows the exercise of citizens' rights in a transparent regulatory framework.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure is very technical; Over the past twenty years, the Commission has had to respond to a significant number of complaints from farmers and practitioners carrying out genetic programmes regarding the terms of transposition and interpretation at national level of Union legal acts on reproduction in the various Member States.  In order to ensure the uniform application of Union rules on reproduction and to avoid obstacles to trade in breeding animals and their germ material as a result of differences in the transposition of these directives at national level, a 'framework' text is proposed which undoubtedly adds burdens to operators. While recognising that such detailed legislation also represents a minimum 'barrier' to reciprocity to be respected in trade agreements with non-EU countries, some references such as 'non-discrimination' with respect to the (generic) country of origin of animals do not allow us to give full support to the measure. Abstention vote.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The purpose of EU zootechnical legislation is to promote free trade within the EU and to facilitate the importation of breeding animals and their genetic material, ensuring the preservation of genetic resources in Europe. The Regulation brings together all the Directives relating to zootechnical legislation into a single legal text. The text reinforces the preservation of indigenous breeds that are not always accompanied by high economic performance.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to promote the free trade of breeding animals and their genetic material, while ensuring the sustainability of breeding programmes and the preservation of genetic resources. In addition, this report simplifies various provisions in various regulations because it finally brings together in a single legal framework the principles governing the recognition and definition of a list of breeding organizations, breeders' associations and private undertakings, the approval of their selection programmes, the inclusion of bovine, ovine, caprine and equine animals in their respective herd books and their classification according to their genetic merits. , the inclusion of breeding hybrid pigs in registers, performance testing and genetic evaluation, as well as the content of zootechnical certificates of breeding animals, their semen and their ova and embryos. In addition, this report lays down rules on imports from third countries of breeding animals and improves the legal framework for such imports by creating a model pedigree and zootechnical certificate providing information on the offspring, identification and, where appropriate, genetic evaluation of breeding animals and their germline material.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This technical file deals with rules regarding the structuring of the breeding sector, management of breeding books/registers, intra-EU trade, and imports from third countries. At Committee level, the report was broadened to also cover conservation of rare breeds, thereby protecting biodiversity. At EU level the intention is to harmonise the approach to trade in breeding animals. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this file.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because a new regulation on animal breeding is needed. The rules should be more comprehensive and precise in order to avoid different interpretations and misunderstandings. That is why I especially welcome the introduction of definitions of terms such as ‘breed’ or ‘endangered and rare breed’. Clearer and more specific rules will help us in conserving rare breeds and protecting biodiversity.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation is part of the Eu ropean Union's package of animal husbandry legislation which aims to promote the free trade in breeding animals and their genetic material while ensuring the sustainability of breeding programmes.  This proposal contains clarification on the regulatory framework for the recognition of breeding companies, a clearer definition of the term 'breeding animal' and introduces the possibility for farms to produce performance tests according to the different registered breeds. With regard to these aspects, the proposal is certainly to be welcomed. However, I have chosen to abstain from voting because it would have been preferable for the Regulation not to deal with the issue of clones, which I believe should be part of a separate legislative package.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The rearing of food-producing animals of high genetic quality not only contributes to the economic and social development of the area in which they are reared, but is also one of the pillars of the Union's food security.  The European Commission has decided to consolidate all directives on zootechnical legislation for different species into one. The Commission proposes a harmonised structure of animal breeding that will have a significant impact on animal genetics in Europe. We are in favour of this general approach.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on zootechnical and genealogical conditions applicable to trade and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their reproductive material does not concern only economic conditions and procedures. It is part of a more general framework for the protection of both fauna and citizens, since it has implications for food, production process and food trade. It is therefore an important report that we must all support, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to replace the current rules on animal husbandry in order to clarify the obstacles that arose in previous legislation with more precise language and better structural organisation.  I voted in favour because the proposal to improve this report represents a significant step forward in the regulation of livestock farming at European level. For example, it is intended to guarantee a minimum level of rights and obligations for farmers or even to simplify official controls and controls by the Commission without reducing efficiency and quality. I will always be in favour of reports that aim for better regulation with the intention, on the one hand, of simplifying bureaucracy, and therefore the lives of citizens, and, on the other, of protecting the quality of our European products. This report also represents a simple improvement in the quality of legislation.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union zootechnical legislation is aimed at facilitating intra-EU free trade for the breeding of animals and their genetic material. The Commission’s proposal to consolidate these texts has been expanded to produce a synchronised structure of animal breeding which will affect animal genetics in Europe. Local breeds must not be put at risk in an attempt to improve competitiveness by exporting major European breeds internationally. Animal breeding will now be required to meet certain criteria to receive recognition from the competent authority. This approach will enable European breeds to be structured efficiently on the global market.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against because this goes far beyond consolidation to create a harmonised structure of animal breeding.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal to regulate the current intra-EU commercial practices of animal producers and their genetic material, safeguarding the process of selection and conservation of genetic products and protecting the well-being and reproduction of the different animal breeds present on European territory.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There are far too many delegated acts which are far too broad in scope concerning this topic. Animal health and welfare, including transport conditions for live animals, are concerns that need to be taken into account by all actors in the zootechnical sector, in particular with regard to genetic improvement of breeds. Our legislation on the breeding of animals has also contributed to the preservation of animal genetic resources, the protection of genetic biodiversity, the Union’s cultural heritage and the production of typical-quality regional products that rely on the specific hereditary characteristics of local breeds of domestic animals. This is something which should be sustained.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation presented aims to promote free trade in breeding animals and their genetic material. The proposal has already been approved in the AGRI Committee, and it is now being asked for final approval in plenary. It should be remembered that the rearing of bovine, pig, sheep, goat and horse species plays a strategic role in EU agriculture, both in economic and social terms.  That is why I would have preferred the proposal to have highlighted more clearly the difference between cloning and the use of germ material in farm animals. Certainly the best way to encourage the breeding of animals of the species mentioned is the use of pure-bred animals or hybrid pigs of high genetic quality.  Nevertheless, I am satisfied with the wording of the proposal for a regulation and I am abstaining.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report combines all directives related to zootechnical legislation into one. I voted in favour because the result of the trilogue is much better than the commission's original proposal and has a very clear line of view to maintaining the genetic heritage of less commercial, local, rare or endangered species. It also adds some point of small improvements in animal welfare and strengthening of the European domestic market.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution, the European Parliament wanted to approve the proposal for a regulation on the conditions of production underlying trade in and entry of breeding animals and their germ material within the EU.  EU legal acts should promote initiatives for the reproduction and improvement of breeds, as well as for the competitiveness of the livestock sector, without endangering the conservation of breeds and their biodiversity. For this reason, I voted in favour of this resolution, which regulates in detail the rights and obligations of farmers, selector bodies as well as hybridists and, at the same time, safeguards genetic resources, local animal breeds and endangered breeds.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Farmers should have the right to know whether the reproductive material they purchase comes from a cloned animal or a descendant of it. I voted for the principles of transparency and accountability, thereby guaranteeing the preservation of the genetic diversity of the breed.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Commission's proposal combines four legislative acts on the fundamental principles of the management of breeding animals of the bovine, ovine, ovine, equine and equidae species into a single horizontal directive. The aim of this Directive is to provide a simplified and clear legal framework for the structustructuisation of the livestock sector, rules for the management of breeding books/breeding records, animal husbandry and performance assessment or genetic evaluation, rules on intra-EU trade and imports from third countries and the rules on zootechnical official controls. The Directive will facilitate free trade in high-quality breeding animals and their genetic material, contribute to the protection of breeds across the EU and to improve cooperation between competent authorities of different Member States in this regard.  I voted IN FAVOUR.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the grouping of all directives on zootechnical legislation in this regulation, because actors in the livestock sector must take into account the health and quality of life of animals

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. I myself have been rapporteur of this codecision report which proposes a clear legislative framework for animal breeding and guarantees a minimum level of rights and obligations for breeders and breeding bodies.  This report proposes to introduce measures to safeguard the specifics of each species and introduce specific provisions for endangered breeds. The aim is to establish a balanced approach between the preservation of pure breeds and the development of the internal market.  Through these provisions, I wanted to strengthen and simplify official controls for breeders and reduce delegations of power vis-à-vis the European Commission.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Michel Dantin's report on breeding animals and their germ products. This text takes into account the case of rare or endangered breeds, but also the health and welfare of animals.  Indeed, this text introduces special provisions such as the prohibition of the use of a purebred breeding animal and its germ products in the event that such use compromises the conservation and genetic diversity of this breed. In addition, the text recommends that zootechnical actors take into account the health and welfare of animals.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this legislative resolution. Europe’s genetic biodiversity is indispensable to a healthy Europe and therefore needs to be protected. As the biodiversity of one Member State affects that of the other, this can only be achieved through harmonised EU-wide legislation. However, at the same time, we need to leave enough breathing space for science and innovation. In its current form, this resolution will do both these things. It will protect our valuable local breeds both efficiently and effectively, where needed. With regard to innovation, it calls for harmonisation and simplification. The combination of these two will result in a healthier, more competitive livestock industry, increasing the EU’s competitiveness and ensuring the food-safety of our citizens. It will be easier to import animals and their genetic material for the sake of breeding, according to specific, transparent and harmonised rules, that are safeguarded by one central authority.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the report of my colleague Michel Dantin. In my view, the role of the European Union is to propose a single horizontal legislative framework for animal breeding. The regulation thus passed also replaces nearly a dozen vertical directives structuring by species the Community acquis in animal breeding. This therefore helps to simplify the legislation.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation on breeding animals and their germ products. It should help to better preserve local breeds and endangered breeds.  This regulation aims to simplify the zootechnical rules in force in the European Union. At the same time, it values local breeds and especially herds from mountain areas that could be threatened by the search for competitiveness in the animal husbandry sector.  Genomic and selection tools (with the security of the selection process and the approval process for their selection program), as well as new information and communication technologies, can help preserve these breeds whose traits are adapted to particular biophysical contexts.  In addition to preserving biodiversity, this new regulation aims to strengthen the guarantee of traceability for citizens increasingly attached to the origin of the food they eat.  On a more global level, European agriculture and the CAP of tomorrow must promote an extensive development model that respects local territories, biodiversity and resources.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The text of the report, which was significantly better than its original version, included several laudable aspects: taking into account low-strength breeds, taking into account equine-specific criteria, limiting the Commission's prerogatives.  Unfortunately, the settlement subsequently negotiated in a trilogue endorses several infringements of our sovereignty: recourse to the European regulation, strengthening the Commission's power to establish criteria for selection, import or to define "serious and large-scale" breaches of the rules by third countries.  For these reasons, I objected to this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report in question reports a number of amendments to the Regulation on zootechnical and genealogical conditions applicable to trade and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germinal products. Amendments introducing a number of improvements to the commission's proposal, in particular on animal health and welfare, are issues of concern and which should be taken into account by all actors in the zootechnical sector, in particular as regards the genetic improvement of breeds. With the amendments introduced, the Regulation becomes clearer and easier to interpret.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: we oppose this report, which leaves far too much scope for the Commission.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this Regulation is to establish zootechnical and genealogical rules for the preservation and reproduction of animals, as well as rules governing the conservation and reproduction of native or endangered breeds. The report improves the Original Proposal of the European Commission in several respects (extended scope, clarification of the legal framework, provisions on animal health and welfare). Cloning issues are not dealt with in this regulation. It is intended to place in a single legal framework several important aspects, such as the structuring of the animal breeding/breeding sector; lay down rules for the management of herd books, breeding records, for animal husbandry and for performance testing and genetic evaluation. Rules for trade within the EU and for imports from third countries, as well as for official controls, are established. One of the negative aspects of this proposal, in addition to the assumption that the meat production sector needs to be more competitive in order to allow European species and breeds to be exported, is the aspects relating to animal cloning, which have been left out, even as regards the genealogical register, and it is not recorded whether the parent is a cloned animal or whether the germinal products come from a cloned animal.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal.  The adoption of a clear and simplified regulatory framework meets the needs of farmers and consumers. The flexibility guarantee allows industry operators to outsource testing and performance evaluation, ensuring that the measures are proportionate and aligned with actual risks.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe has a rich range of breeds of domestic livestock, representing the largest genetic population of animal farms. The rearing of domestic animals of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats and horses, and to a lesser extent the rearing of other species, has an important place in the agriculture of the Union and is a source of income for agricultural communities. Breeding of these species is best supported if purebred breeding animals of high genetic quality are used. The proposed Regulation lays down, within a single legal framework, principles relating to the approval or recognition and listing of breeders' organisations, breeders' associations and private establishments, the registration and classification of animals in herd-books, performance testing and genetic examination, the content and format of the zootechnical certificate of breeding animals.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because some of the references in the text are not fully acceptable.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Europe has a rich variety of breeds of domestic farm animals, constituting the largest genetic population of farm animals. Those breeds were selected by generations of farmers and breeders to be better adapted to their region, more productive, stronger, thus, creating local breeds that are part of our heritage. Breeders’ societies are at the core of the preservation and improvement of our breeds and clear rules are needed in order to better protect their actions and the breeders themselves. I strongly support the inclusion of zootechnical and genealogical rules governing the conservation and improvement of native or endangered breeds, beside the general rules on the preservation and improvement of animal breeding. I welcome the provision of a definition of the concept of ‘breed’, as I consider that, in order to create legal certainty, such a definition was needed.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of Parliament's position. We call on the Commission to refer the matter back to Parliament if it intends to substantially amend its proposal or replace it with another text. In order to achieve the single market, the main objective is to transform all directives aimed at regulating zootechnical regulations of different animal species into a single legal text.  This ambition of the Commission should be supported, but some provisions need to be adapted to encourage free trade in agriculture within the EU. In addition, the concepts of 'breed', 'breeding programme', 'conservation programme' and 'endangering the conservation or genetic diversity of the variety' are missing, which are key to the interpretation of the Regulation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour as I believe that the purpose of this legislation is to promote free trade within the EU and to facilitate the importation of breeding animals and their genetic material, ensuring the maintenance of Europe's breeding programmes and the preservation of genetic resources. The rearing of animals, especially those in which a high genetic peculiarity has been observed, not only contributes to the economic and social development of the area in which it is carried out, but also constitutes one of the pillars of the Union's food security.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted ‘Yes’ to this proposal on the grounds that there is a need for a single legal framework surrounding breeding organisations, breed classifications and genetic evaluation. This proposal will also broaden this single legal framework to the imports of breeding animals and their germinal products from third countries. This will allow this part of the agricultural sector to operate with more certainty and on a more open and secure internal market where everyone is playing by the same rules. I hope that legal certainty and a secure market can be the key drivers for growth in the animal husbandry sector, in particular for Italy, where we have more than 10 million livestock units.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the final agreement with the Council on the zootechnical and genealogical conditions applicable to trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germinal material, because I believe that the livestock sector is a fundamental sector for the European economic fabric and therefore needs regulatory certainty and clarity. This is an area which characterises the territories and regions of all the Member States not only from an economic point of view, but also from a cultural and social point of view. I therefore support the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council, which takes account of parliament's suggestions and additions. Finally, I welcome the introduction into the legislation of the definition of 'breed' because this choice goes in the direction of ensuring regulatory certainty, as does the provision for breeding organisations, which will have a single procedure for their recognition and identification.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report 'Breeding animals and their breeding material', as Europe-wide cross-border trade in them is a fact that needs to be regulated. I very much welcome the emphasis of the report, which calls for the preservation of biodiversity in this area.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The traceability of the ancestry of animals and breeding materials is very important for farmers. This is the only way to prove the proven origin of the animals.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK is a major exporter of animal genetic material and germinal products so having legislation that supports trade in this industry is crucial. I am pleased that this is what has been achieved in the ‘breeding animals and their germinal products’ regulation. It facilitates free trade in animal breeding while preserving valuable animal genetic resources including rare and endangered breeds. The legislation also reflects the ‘better regulation’ policy, something which I fully support. It substantially streamlines and consolidates four existing pieces of EU legislation. It means that UK breeders and exporters of genetic material operating within the Single Market will have less burdensome bureaucracy. Important changes to the text have effectively tackled problematic elements, for example the Parliament secured the inclusion of special rules and derogations (exceptional circumstances only) to allow for the separation of horse breeding information from the equine identification document (horse passport). Additionally, ECR amendments ensured the legislation is in line with UK objectives, for example regarding the setting of common rules on performance testing and genetic evaluation, by building flexibility into the final text. It is for these reasons that I voted to adopt this legislation.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This regulation defines the conditions under which breeding animals and their seed are exploited. This topic is crucial for the future of our livestock industry, to preserve the quality of our meat and improve the conditions of our breeders.  With this text, the Commission will be able to define on its own the criteria for importing and selecting breeding animals and their germ products. It does not, however, provide the guarantees requested against fraud in third countries. Moreover, his recent positions on animal cloning or the lack of visibility on the protection of our farms under the transatlantic treaty suggest that our agriculture will only be a variable of adjustment. The amendments proposed by our group to protect our sector were not voted on by the other MEPs, so I voted against this text.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it has achieved a substantial improvement in the commission's proposal, introducing elements for improving animal welfare, maintaining the genetic heritage of indigenous breeds and boosting the domestic market. This draft legislation combines and simplifies pre-existing legislation on the rearing of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats and equine for consumption.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal; the breeding of livestock, particularly of animals with a high level of genetic particularity, not only contributes to the economic and social development of the rural areas where it takes place, but is also one of the pillars on which the EU’s food security is based. On top of that, the new draft regulation delivers the necessary consolidation and simplification of existing laws, completes the Single Market while reaffirming Member States’ competences where appropriate and clarifies the rights and obligations of animal breeders and their organisations.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Efforts to achieve competitiveness in the animal breeding sector should not lead to the disappearance of breeds with characteristics that are adapted to specific biophysical contexts.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report brought together all the directives related to zootechnical legislation on different species into a single legislation. It is a step forward for animal rearing in the EU, and as an updated legislation it is also one of the pillars of the EU food security system.  The result of the trilogue carried out is much better than the Commission's original proposal. It harmonises the structure of the breeding industry in the EU with an impact on animal genetics in the EU, while also strengthening the conservation of the variety of pure breeds and the protection of endangered local and rare European breeds. For these reasons, we voted in favour.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this report. This will help to build a more cohesive single market for breeding in the EU compared with the current situation where legislation is fragmented across a number of directives. In addition to that, this legislation plays a key role in conserving rare breeds and thereby in protecting biodiversity, something which I am very concerned about as there are many endangered breeds of animals in Ireland and Europe. I was very happy that Parliament amended the Commission regulation to lay down zootechnical and genealogical rules for the preservation and improvement of animal breeding as well as rules governing the conservation and improvement of native or endangered breeds. Likewise, I was pleased to note that special provisions for endangered breeds and for the horse-breeding sector were included in the agreed text, along with clear definitions such as ‘breed’ which is essential to bring clarity to breeders and operators yet ensuring competitiveness throughout the EU. Overall the text was proportional and allowed flexibility for Member States to refuse the approval of a further animal-breeding programme.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion as it ensures the quality of controls along with the reintroduction of the principle of transparency. This is alongside the benefits of guaranteeing a minimum of administration burdens on the sector.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ One of the main pillars on which the EU’s food security is based is the breeding of livestock and their genetic material. The Commission’s intention is to standardise all the directives concerning the zootechnical legislation on different species into a single body of law in order to complete the Single Market. I have voted in favour of this report that will allow major European breeds to be exported taking into consideration the biogenetic diversity in Europe.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on zootechnical and genealogical conditions for the trafficking of farmed animals and their genetic material as well as their import into the Union, as this simplifies and aggregates different parts of specific legislation concerning cattle, pigs, goats and equines.  Such a thing includes provisions for the recognition and list of breeding organisations, classification and certification of breeding animals, their seeds, eggs and embryos, and official controls and zootechnical checks. In this context, I believe that breeders play an extremely important role in the protection of biodiversity, and therefore I support the preservation and progress of animal breeding, as well as the rules governing the conservation and improvement of native and endangered breeds.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. My colleague from the ENF group Philippe Loiseau has tabled, on behalf of the group, two amendments (one abolished, the other added) aimed at limiting the importation of breeding animals and germ products from third countries, or even banning them when deficiencies in zootechnical and genealogical rules are passed. But apart from our plenary amendments, the text has reached consensus among all political groups. We therefore oppose this report, which leaves far too much scope for the Commission, something which all groups have accepted without raising an eyebrow, and my vote has naturally turned against this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against because this goes far beyond consolidation to create a harmonised structure of animal breeding.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Michel Dantin's report on breeding animals and their germ products.  This text proposes the strengthening of legal certainty in this area and prescribes a simplification of official controls and the Commission. I have therefore approved this decision, which aims to safeguard the specificities of each species, to preserve the strength of this European sector, to ensure special provisions for certain breeds and to guarantee a minimum level of rights and obligations for breeders and breeding establishments. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Michel Dantin's report. This text aims to propose a single horizontal legislative framework for animal breeding to replace a dozen directives. This will enhance legal certainty by clearly defining important terms, strengthening the safeguarding of the specificities of each species or protecting rare and endangered breeds. I obviously voted in favour of this very good report.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Good legislation on trade in animals and their biological material is a prerequisite for high-quality farming in Europe, animal welfare and the provision of high-quality food to European consumers. Detailed information in the trade in animals is very important for the cleanliness of breeds, which is of great importance e.g. in the field of horse breeding. Just as the consumer has the right to know where the products he buys come from, the breeder must know the origin of the breeding material he acquires in order to be able to inform buyers of his products fairly afterwards.  Simple and transparent procedures are also important for producers to facilitate compliance with established rules. Simplification of procedures and modifications to official controls will allow for the effective enforcement of new legislation. Such a right will make a well-functioning livestock sector an excellent basis for all livestock production in the European Union.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal. The breeding of livestock, particularly of animals with a high level of genetic particularity, not only contributes to the economic and social development of the rural areas where it takes place, but is also one of the pillars on which the EU’s food security is based. On top of that, the new draft regulation delivers the necessary consolidation and simplification of existing laws, completes the Single Market while reaffirming Member States’ competences where appropriate and clarifies the rights and obligations of animal breeders and their organisations.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 12 April 2016, we voted in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on a proposal for a regulation on zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade in and importation into the Union of breeding animals and their germ products. The aim of this proposal was to combine all the directives on zootechnical legislation on different animal species into a single piece of legislation. Unfortunately, the preparation of the document has struggled from the outset with the fact that there are different practices within the different species of livestock, which are a great complication in finding uniform rules acceptable to all species. However, the most fundamental problems have been eliminated in the ongoing negotiations between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. In the end, despite a number of recesss, the proposal was also acceptable to the Czech Republic, so I was able to support it in the end.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because in order to facilitate the agricultural sector and to guarantee food security in the EU, we should pay serious attention to proposals for the revision of EU legislation on zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germinal products (semen, oocytes and embryos). I believe that there are two important steps that have to be taken. First, we should work to ensure animal health and welfare, including transport conditions for live animals inside and outside the Union. Thus, the EU and all actors in the zootechnical sector will take responsibility and will tackle the inhuman treatment of animals not only within the EU but also in third countries. Second, we should facilitate cooperation between breed societies and breeding operations in order to remove obstacles to the free movement of breeding animals and their genetic material.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the proposal to regulate zootechnical and genealogical conditions during the marketing and import of animals and animal products. The legislation is not only intended to simplify its trade, while maintaining efficient controls, but also to safeguard the process of selection and conservation of genetic products, and to preserve the well-being and reproduction of the different animal breeds present on European territory, paying particular attention to species in extension. The provision for single legislation for the Member States of the Union will also enable us to improve current trade practices between Member States.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved my colleague Michel Dantin's report on breeding animals and their germ products, which aims to propose a single legislative framework for animal breeding in place of nearly a dozen directives.  By harmonizing the provisions concerning the management of the genealogy of breeding animals, acceptance to the reproduction of these animals, performance control and genetic evaluation, this regulation will allow the Community's species in animal selection to be structured by species.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on breeding animals and their germ products.  The settlement negotiated between the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council endorses several infringements on our national sovereignty on an issue that remains important for agriculture. The text will be applied without transposition into national law, as it is a regulation. Under the guise of simplification, the Commission is arrogating new prerogatives in setting selection criteria, importing criteria, etc.  The safeguard clause to protect European farmers from possible failures or abuses by third countries is too weak. It depends on the definition of "serious and far-reaching breach of the rules" found in a third country. The definition and finding of this breach are left to the Commission's discretion.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it makes it too easy to import the breeding animals concerned, and therefore does not protect European breeders enough.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text put to the vote deals with the importation and exchange in the Union of breeding animals and their germ products. It details, in particular, the number of low-numbered breeds and equine-specific criteria, and it has the merit of reducing the Commission's prerogatives in this regard.  However, there are many negatives that qualify the proposal. First, the text will be applied without transposition into national law since it is a regulation. Secondly, despite the text's attempt to limit the Commission's powers, it grants it new prerogatives, notably in setting the criteria for selection and imports. Finally, European farmers are too little protected by the safeguard clause against the excesses of third countries. The role of this clause, however, is to avoid any "serious and far-reaching breach of the rules provided".  It was therefore impossible for me to support such a report, I voted against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report combines all directives related to zootechnical legislation into one. I voted in favour because the result of the trilogue is much better than the commission's original proposal and has a very clear line of view to maintaining the genetic heritage of less commercial, local, rare or endangered species. It also adds some point of small improvements in animal welfare and strengthening of the European domestic market.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. As expressed in this report, Parliament proposes to the Commission a number of amendments which seek to alter to some extent its original legislative proposal for Regulation on zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade in breeding animals and their reproductive products and their importation into the Union. With the amendments which, from Parliament, we propose we understand that the text is substantially improved and certainly contributes to the ultimate objective of this legislation which is nothing more than to ensure that the free trade in breeding animals and their genetic material is developed with broad guarantees for all parties involved, that is, both for the agricultural sector and for consumers , as for animals. That is why my vote will be in favour of this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The proposal regulates the breeding and breeding of livestock and trade in them. Breeds of bovine animals and other animals vary from state to state and there is no reason to harmonise their breeding practices. The proposal confers unnecessarily large powers on the Commission, e.g. as regards the recognition of individual breeds and breed societies.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is making continuous efforts in zootechnical legislation to encourage internal trade and easier breeding of animals with genetic specificities. Such cultivation is of utmost importance for the Union, as it is one of the main pillars providing a food source. In addition to food insurance, farming also contributes to economic development, providing revenues from the export of products of animal origin. The Commission aims to unite all directives relating to zootechnical legislation into one applicable regulation in order to facilitate business in the single market. Clear and simplified rules contribute to easier functioning within the Union's borders and allow for easier cooperation with partner countries, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this Directive is to bring together in a single act several directives on zootechnical regulations for different species, thereby contributing to the creation of a single market in this area. This would facilitate the free movement of breeding animals and their genetic material within the territory of the Member States. The same applies to more efficient import and export procedures. The animal breeding system has a direct impact not only on the agricultural sector, but also on consumer rights, economic development, health and much more, so it is perfectly understandable why it was necessary to table such a large number of amendments - no misunderstanding can simply be there. Not to mention the need to make the most of the characteristics and historical characteristics of existing systems in the Member States. The proposal also pays great attention to the protection of the rights and interests of breeding societies, the rules on recording results, cross-border cooperation and, of course, the protection of rare, endangered and also 'indigenous' species. Overall, given the great importance of the proposal, it was necessary to support it. It is hoped that in the future, adapting its performance to the real ist of my country, Latvia, will bring maximum benefits to our farmers and consumers.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the areas of animal husbandry, cultivation and production of animal and plant products, the need to promote and preserve native breeds and plants is increasingly urgent in order to preserve biodiversity and ensure a healthy human diet. Preserving heritage in these areas is of strategic importance to future generations. I therefore support the adoption of a regulation which takes into account the need for competitiveness and, at the same time, the balance in the area of breeding and breeding of productive and livestock.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on zootechnical and genealogical conditions applicable to trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their reproductive material, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This report has positive elements: taking into account low-numbered breeds, resuming equine-specific criteria, etc. Nevertheless, this regulation, which will be applied without prior transposition into French law, grants excessive prerogatives to the European Commission. It also offers only limited protection to breeders in the face of third-country failures.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal. Animal health and welfare, including transport conditions for live animals, are concerns that need to be taken into account by all actors in the zootechnical sector, in particular with regard to the genetic improvement of breeds. The Commission should therefore ensure that those concerns are duly taken into account in the delegated and implementing acts that are to be adopted for the effective implementation of this Regulation.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament on zootechnical and genealogical conditions applicable to trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germ material. Union animal husbandry legislation aims to facilitate the import of breeding animals and their genetic material, while ensuring the conservation of genetic resources

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. – I vote in favour of the report on the proposal to regulate zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade in breeding animals and their reproductive products and their importation into the Union.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Union's (EU) zootechnical legislation aims to encourage intra-EU free trade and facilitate the importation of breeding animals and their genetic material.  Livestock farming plays a fundamental role in the conservation of rare breeds, and thus in the protection of biodiversity. In fact, local breeds may be threatened if they do not maintain sufficient numbers, which would represent a loss of genetic biodiversity. The best way to promote this breeding is to use purebred breeders or breeders with high genetic quality. The report proposes to give the Commission the power to carry out checks in third countries from which imports into the Union of breeding animals or their sperm, eggs and embryos may be authorised, and to set the conditions for such imports, particularly regarding traceability through zootechnical certificates that prove their origin. I am voting for this text which aims to increase the quality and diversity of the breeds bred in Europe.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. On this text, we shared certain points of view with the rapporteur (including the consideration of low-numbered breeds and the resumption of equine-specific criteria). But the complex procedure he underwent spoiled him. In the end, it leaves too much freedom to the European Commission at the expense of the sovereignty of states under the pretext of simplification, which is not conceivable. As a result, I voted against this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on zootechnical and genealogical conditions applicable to trade and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germinal products. Eu zootechnical legislation aims to promote free trade within the EU and facilitate the import of breeding animals and their genetic material by ensuring the maintenance of breed breeding programmes and the conservation of existing genetic resources in Europe. However, it is not enough just to want to encourage the export of the great European breeds, it is also necessary to take into account the local breeds, of enormous value for the different EU countries. Breeds that are part of Europe's genetic biodiversity.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report on breeding animals and germinal products, as it would both help in the preservation of genetic resources and encourage intra-EU free trade in breeding animals and their genetic material.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The purpose of this revision of the current legislation is to establish the individual and specific regulations relating to the trade, importation and registration of breeding animals and derivatives traded for breeding in a single legal framework. This review already offers the benefit of greater clarity for all stakeholders in the sector, while ensuring competitiveness.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The topic of animal breeding is increasingly resonating on EU territory. Day-to-day practice has created a growing need for comprehensive, coherent and clear regulation, which is currently relatively fragmented and contained in a number of legislation. I consider the new regulation, which would harmonise the relevant provisions regulating the breeding of animals and the issues related thereto, as a step forward. Livestock breeding plays a key role in the common agricultural policy, as it contributes to achieving and maintaining food security in the EU, in addition to the conservation of rare species and thus the protection of biodiversity and cultural heritage. I see the positives of the new uniform legislation, particularly in the creation of a stable terminology, which will apply in all Member States, the introduction of a uniform standard of animal welfare and their export, in particular in activities aimed at genetic improvement of breeds, clear recording in the form of the entry of cross-breeding animals in additional parts of herd-books and a strengthened control system. I also welcome the fact that the new regulation is by no means intended to address the issues of cloning breeding animals. I am voting in favour of the report as it stands.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
