text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on breeding animals and their germinal products because I believe that breeders’ societies are at the core of the preservation and improvement of our breeds and clear rules are needed in order to better protect their actions and the breeders themselves. Europe has a rich variety of breeds of domestic farm animals, constituting the largest genetic population of farms animals. Those breeds were selected by generations of farmers and breeders to be better adapted to their region: more productive, stronger, thus creating local breeds that are part of our heritage.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted a proposal for the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the technical and genealogy conditions for trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their reproductive material. In the form of this Regulation, the Commission intends to combine all directives on zootechnical regulation of different animal species into a single legal text in order to achieve the single market in this area. In addition to the mere merging and simplification of the texts, the Commission proposes a harmonised structure for livestock production, which will have a not insignificant impact on the animal genetics sector in Europe. The Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development supports this general approach in its report, but considers that some issues need to be defined or revised more precisely. To this end, it proposes that Parliament adopt the Commission's draft with almost 200 amendments. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This regulation endorses several violations of our sovereignty on a subject that remains important to agriculture.  There are many negatives. It will be applied without margin of appreciation by national law, in the case of a regulation, and under the guise of simplification, the Commission is arrogating new prerogatives in setting the criteria for selection and import. The safeguard clause to protect European farmers from possible failures or abuses by third countries is also too weak. It depends on the definition of "serious and far-reaching breach of the rules" found in a third country. The definition and finding of this breach are left to the Commission's discretion.   In the end, it is appropriate to vote against this text.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. EU zootechnical legislation aims to promote free trade in breeding animals and their genetic material, taking into account the sustainability of breeding programmes and the conservation of genetic resources. The basic principles of zootechnical legislation have proved to be adequate and adapted to technical progress in the field of animal production, and they are so set out in this proposal. However, since the current legislation is organised on the basis of species, the almost identical provisions have been simplified and drafted in more precise and coherent language in the form of a regulation in order to avoid barriers to trade resulting from national transposition. As a difference in the national transposition of the directives to be applied, there have been numerous problems raised by breeders, breeders' associations and competent authorities due to the different interpretations given to the existing provisions of the competent authorities of the Member States. The Commission is therefore aware of the needs of the animal production sector and the competent supervisory authorities. I advocate, like the rapporteur, a harmonised approach to trade in breeding animals and their germinal products and their imports into the Union, as well as the official controls that need to be carried out on breeding programmes carried out by breeding associations and livestock centres.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The breeding of livestock, particularly of animals with a high level of genetic particularity, not only contributes to the economic and social development of the rural areas where it takes place, but is also one of the pillars on which the EU’s food security is based. On top of that, the new draft regulation delivers the necessary consolidation and simplification of existing laws, completes the Single Market while reaffirming Member States’ competences where appropriate and clarifies the rights and obligations of animal breeders and their organisations.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes a simplification of animal breeding legislation, which until then had been regulated by a dozen directives.  At a time when farmers, especially French farmers, are suffering from too vague European legislation, which some states such as France are over-transposing into their national law, the adoption of this simplification report was necessary.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The report on the zootechnical regulation, for which I voted, will enable the establishment of enhanced legal certainty, through the adoption of a single horizontal legislative framework replacing the multiple previous vertical directives.  The report is therefore part of a desire for regulatory simplification. The introduction of the definitions of the terms 'race', 'selection programme', and 'rare and endangered' the introduction of special provisions, as well as all the provisions taken in this report contribute to the enhanced supervision of the zootechnical sector.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 A well-functioning livestock sector is vital for the Union. The current zootechnology legislation is complex, divided into many small parts – animal breed, different certification codes, pedigree rules, performance tests – which is why the Commission already signalled in 2014 the importance of a single, comprehensive zootechnology regulation, which is also intended to remove obstacles to different translations of many trade standards at Member State level. I believe that greater transparency, the use and introduction of more precise, consistent terminology can only benefit the European livestock sector. The Regulation also includes official official controls, which I consider to be particularly useful in the light of the shortcomings of the regulations in force in this area. However, it must be kept in mind at all costs that normally operating undertakings are not burdened with overly administrative tasks.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Livestock breeding contributes to the economic and social development of the area in which it takes place and also represents one of the pillars on which the EU’s food security is based. I have voted for this report that reiterates the fact that efforts to achieve competitiveness, in particular to allow major European breeds to be exported internationally, should not jeopardise local breeds which are a part of the biogenetic diversity of Europe.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. In the report, some terms are not clearly defined (race, breeding program). On the positive side, genetic diversity is particularly important for rare breeds, otherwise any species would be threatened with extinction. Furthermore, the increase in animal welfare plays a particularly important role. On the basis of the above facts, I voted against this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation, which aims to harmonize all directives on zootechnical legislation on different species in Europe. This regulation is a step forward for animal husbandry in the European Union.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. The new regulation will facilitate and facilitate the free trade in breeding animals and their genetic material and ensure that breeding and conservation programmes for all genetic resources in Europe are maintained. It should be noted that the new Regulation discusses requirements for breeding animals and their genetic material, principles and mechanisms for the recognition of breeding organisations, breeding programmes, prohibitions of certain breeding methods in breeding programmes, trade, import and movement of breeding animals and their genetic material inside or outside the European Community. It is also envisaged to distinguish between procedures for approving associations and selection programmes. For reasons of legal clarity, it is important to ensure that other species are included in this Regulation only by common decision. In addition, it is essential that breeders have the right to use all relevant services of the breeding programme in a non-discriminatory manner.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because this goes far beyond consolidation to create a harmonised structure of animal breeding.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has animal husbandry legislation to encourage free trade between the 28 countries and facilitate the import of breeding animals. This Regulation has brought together all existing legislation in this area. The sustainability and conservation of breeds is of great importance to the EU. Finally, given that further improvements to European legislation in this area are not only necessary but also possible, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the successfully completed negotiations and the final text of the Regulation on Geotechnical and Geological Conditions for Marketing and Imports into the Union of Breeding Animals and Their Products. The aim of this adopted proposal is to boost free trade within the EU and facilitate the import and breeding of animals as well as their genetic material and to ensure that breeding programmes and genetic resources are supported by all breeds that exist in Europe. This is extremely important because livestock farming, in particular animals with a high degree of genetic distinctiveness, not only contributes to the economic and social development of the area in which it is maintained, but is also one of the pillars underpinning food production safety in the EU.  I welcome special care for the preservation of endangered and rare breeds. A better defined scope of the Regulation in this regard enables the protection of biological and genetic diversity, the preservation of valuable indigenous breeds important for the development and promotion of local agriculture and, ultimately, a greater variety of the supply of agricultural products with excess added value. Such products with added value are a special contribution to the success of European agriculture and internationally.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In its final version, the report is better than the Commission's original proposal. But several aspects remain prohibitive: - this text will be applied without transposition into national law, since it is a regulation; - under the guise of simplification, the Commission is arrogating new prerogatives in setting selection and import criteria; - the safeguard clause to protect European farmers from possible failures or abuses by third countries is too weak. It depends on the definition of "serious and far-reaching breach of the rules" found in a third country. The definition and finding of this breach are left to the Commission's discretion. I cannot accept these attacks on the sovereignty of France and the interests of its farmers, which are already far too badly abused by the European Union, and I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Breeding cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and equines, and to a lesser extent breeding other animal species, is an economic and social activity that has strategic importance for EU agriculture. Breeding of these species is best encouraged if purebred breeding animals of recorded high genetic quality are used. Regulated farming, on the one hand, contributes to food safety in the EU and, on the other hand, plays a key role in the conservation of rare breeds and thus biodiversity.  Europe has a rich variety of breeds of domestic animals on farms, which make up the largest genetic population of farm animals. These breeds have been chosen for generations by farmers and breeders to be better adapted to the region, stronger and more productive, thereby creating local breeds that have become part of the heritage.  As a representative coming from a country where 26 recognized native breeds of domestic animals live – 4 breeds of horses, 3 breeds of donkeys, 3 breeds of cattle, 9 breeds of sheep, 3 breeds of goats, 2 breeds of pigs, 2 breeds of poultry, 1 breed of bees and 7 native breeds of dogs – I believe that breeders' societies are the core of improving and preserving our breeds and that clear rules are needed to better protect both breeders and animals , therefore, I support this resolution of the European Parliament.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this regulation is to establish zootechnical and genealogical rules for the preservation and reproduction of animals, as well as rules governing the conservation and reproduction of native or endangered breeds. The Regulation concentrates on a single legal framework several relevant matters: the structuring of the livestock/breeding sector, rules for the management of breeding books or breeding records for breeding and for performance testing and genetic evaluation. It also lays down rules for trade within the EU and for imports from third countries, as well as laying down rules for official controls and commission controls. As negative elements, the conditioning to competitiveness, as a presupposition to facilitate the export of European species and breeds, the absence of references to animal cloning.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support colleague Dantin's report. I am in favour of adopting a new, comprehensive zootechnical regulation on breeding animals to replace existing rules. In doing so, it is important to note the fundamental parts of the proposal: structuring the sector, adopting rules on the management of registers of farmed animals, breeding, growth and development testing and genetic assessment, adopting rules on intra-EU trade and imports from third countries, and adopting rules on official control and control of the European Commission. I support the introduction of legal certainty by defining concepts relating to the breeding, protection of the specificity of each species of animals, the introduction of specific rules on endangered animals, minimum rights and obligations of breeders. At the same time, I would like to stress the importance of the principle of transparency that will ensure a high level of official control.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agreed to adopt a proposal for a regulation on zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade in breeding animals and their germ products in the Union and their import into the Union in order to promote free trade in breeding animals and their genetic material, taking into account the sustainability of breeding programmes and the conservation of genetic resources. This Regulation defines, in a uniform legal framework, the principles for the recognition and establishment of breeding organisations, breeders' associations and private enterprises. I believe that this proposal for a regulation on zootechnical issues in particular will be a quality document, given the long-standing consultations between the Commission and the Standing Committee on Zootechnics, on the basis of which this legislation was jointly drawn up.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission wanted to group all the directives on animal husbandry legislation of the various species into a single legal corpus in the form of a regulation. This is a harmonised structure of animal selection which will have a considerable impact on the field of animal genetics in Europe.  EU animal husbandry legislation aims to promote intra-EU free trade and facilitate the import of breeding animals and their genetic material, while ensuring the sustainability of programmes for the selection and conservation of genetic resources and therefore of all breeds that exist in Europe today. I welcome the Commission's simplification work and vote in favour of this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to propose a single horizontal legislative framework for animal selection (for bovine, sheep, goat, equine and swine species) simplifying the ten vertical directives structuring animal breeding until now. This text, which will allow for a better structuring of the livestock sector, will lead in particular to a strengthening of the rules of the internal market for animals and genetic products as well as trade with third countries. I also welcome the strengthening of the checks carried out by both the Commission and the Member States.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because this goes far beyond consolidation to create a harmonised structure of animal breeding.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the vote in favour of this report because the production of animals of bovine, swine, sheep, goatand equine species occupies a strategic place in the Union's economic and social agriculture. This Regulation should apply to breeding animals of these species and their germinal products where those animals or offspring are intended to be entered as purebred breeding animals in a breeding book or registered as hybrid breeding pigs in a breeding register, in particular for the purpose of trade on the Union internal market. The best way to promote the production of animals of these species is to encourage the use of purebred breeding animals or hybrid breeding pigs of high registered genetic quality. The Commission adopted decisions establishing specific criteria for each species and established a list of animal production organisms from third countries and the models of genealogical or zootechnical certificates for the entry into the Union of breeding animals and their semen, oocytes and embryos. However, it should be reassing that the demand for competitiveness in the animal production sector should not result in the disappearance of breeds whose characteristics are adapted to specific biophysical contexts.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade in breeding animals and their reproductive products and their importation into the Union, by which the plenary of Parliament ratifies the agreement reached with the Council and Commission.  This Regulation brings together in a single legal text the directives on zootechnical legislation, legislation aimed at promoting free trade within the EU and facilitating the importation of breeding animals and their genetic material, ensuring the preservation of genetic resources in Europe. The text also reinforces the preservation of indigenous breeds that are not always accompanied by high economic performance.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which includes: the introduction of special provisions for rare and endangered breeds; seeking a balanced approach to the derogatory grounds for the accreditation of a selection body, between the preservation and management of pure breeds and the internal market; a guarantee of a minimum level of rights and obligations for breeders and breeding establishments and breeding bodies, as well as additional fees in the event of membership and seasonal movement of animals; The application of the principle of subsidiarity to dispute resolution (national law and private settlement mechanisms); and simplifying the Commission's official controls and controls without compromising efficiency and quality.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The new Regulation brings together all existing zootechnical legislation and presents a harmonised, structured breeding approach covering ovine, caprine, porcine and equine species.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament concerns a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on zootechnical and genealogical conditions applicable to trade and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germinal products. In fact, such a resolution aims to ensure a harmonised approach to trade in breeding animals and their germinal products, their import and control, by laying down rules applicable, inter alia, to the carrying out of official controls by breeding associations and breeding centres in order to verify compliance by Member States with zootechnical and genealogical rules, as well as other official and administrative assistance activities. In view of the fact that we are dealing with a proposal offering a regulation with a single legal framework in this area, with clear and well-defined rules, I do not see any obstacle to the adoption of this resolution and, to that extent, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to propose a single horizontal legislative framework for animal selection (regarding bovine, sheep, goat, equine and swine species) and replaces nearly a dozen vertical directives structuring the Community's animal selection acquis by species. The agreement reached with the Council and the Commission strengthens the legal security of the text, improves definitions, proposes a balanced approach, guarantees a minimum level of rights and obligations for breeders, selection bodies and selection institutions and, finally, simplifies the official controls and checks carried out by the Commission without compromising their effectiveness and quality.  Finally, the European Commission will also have the opportunity to recommend remedial and preventive measures and to call for intensified measures in the event of serious failures in a Member State's control system.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, although it has achieved a substantial improvement in the commission's proposal, introducing elements for improving animal welfare, it promotes the livestock farming model of the large industry. In addition, the proposed amendments on the prohibition of cloned animals were not accepted.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the report on animal husbandry and pedigree provisions for the trade in breeding animals and their breeding material in the Union and for the importation of them into the Union, as it is very comprehensive and covers the most important areas in terms of quality assurance and the lack of administrative measures. Among other things, it introduces definitions that increase legal certainty, simplifies official controls without reducing quality, and introduces specific provisions for rare and endangered animal breeds.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report combines all directives related to zootechnical legislation into one. I voted in favour because the result of the trilogue is much better than the commission's original proposal and has a very clear line of view to maintaining the genetic heritage of less commercial, local, rare or endangered species. It also adds some point of small improvements in animal welfare and strengthening of the European domestic market.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, which provides for the grouping of all the directives relating to the animal husbandry legislation of bovine, porcine, sheep, goat and horse species in a single, simpler and more harmonised horizontal directive.  The new regulation will facilitate the free trade in high-quality genetic breeding animals and their germ material by helping to preserve animal breeds throughout the EU and by improving cooperation between the competent authorities of the different Member States in this regard. Furthermore, thanks to a more precise and defined wording, the regulation will be clearer and more coherent. Finally, the report introduces some simplified rules on official controls and special provisions for rare or endangered breeds and the equine sector.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. Animal legislation is one of the pillars of animal improvement processes in that it regulates the import of breeding animals and their genetic material. The conservation of existing genetic resources in Europe is a concern that should guide regulatory developments in this area. The objective of competitiveness, which leads to the export of large European breeds, as well as to the import of other breeds, should not jeopardise the survival and reproduction of indigenous breeds, some with small populations, and which are part of European genetic biodiversity.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against because this goes far beyond consolidation to create a harmonised structure of animal breeding.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, along with my Labour colleagues because I believe that the breeding of livestock, particularly of animals with a high level of genetic particularity, not only contributes to the economic and social development of the rural areas where it takes place, but it is also one of the pillars on which the EU's food security is based. On top of that, the new draft regulation delivers necessary consolidation and simplification of existing laws, clarifies the rights and obligations of animal breeders and their organisations as well as contributes towards the completion of the Single Market while reaffirming Member States' competences where appropriate.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Breeding animals and their germinal products need to be protected, as they are part of the creation. At the same time, we need to make sure that the economic aspects of this topic are covered as well. As this is the case in the resolution, I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on zootechnical and genealysical conditions for the trafficking of farmed animals and their genetic material as well as their import into the Union, as the Commission intends to unite several laws relating to zootechnical topics of different animals into a single law in the form of regulation. In addition to simplifying the law, the Commission proposes a harmonised mating structure for animals that will have significant implications for animal genetics in Europe.  The report points out that the Commission proposal does not contain definitions of the term mating and mating programmes, and are important for the interpretation of this regulation. The rights and obligations of the mediators will be governed by national laws, therefore it is not necessary to bring unnecessary extreme provisions into the regulations that would regulate the practices of the partners. An exemption shall be made for equines, notably as their mating is organised internationally. Europe is a world leader in equine production, so I think diversity and quality should be preserved.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the breeding of livestock of bovine, porcine, ovine, caprine and equine species and, to a lesser extent, the breeding of animals of other species to play a very important role in the Union's agriculture from an economic and social point of view. Although opinions differ on the breeding of animals and their germ products, I believe that without breeding and breeding, no species of livestock (especially those for which a high degree of genetic peculiarity has been established) can progress. I believe that, as before, breeding will continue to play a key role not only in the preservation of rare breeds and thus in protecting biodiversity, but will also make a significant contribution to the Union's food security. I supported the resolutions because I believe that this proposal will also improve the free trade of breeding animals on the EU market, ensure the preservation of breeding programmes and protect the genetic resources that exist in Europe. I expect that, on the basis of and supervision of harmonised Union criteria by the competent authority of a Member State, it will be ensured that there are no differences between breeding programmes and breeding standards that could create technical barriers to intra-Union trade.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report by which the European Parliament amends the proposal for a regulation on zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade in and imports into the EU of breeding animals and their germ products. This Regulation aims to promote a free internal market, simplify import conditions, while maintaining the level and quality of breeding programmes in the EU and protecting European biodiversity.   The proposal for a regulation maintains the existing main and well-functioning rules of EU zootechnical legislation. The amendment consists in the creation of a uniform legal framework guaranteeing the same principles for the recognition of breed societies and societies, the approval of their breeding programmes, the same criteria for official controls and clearly defines the relationship between breeders and breeders' associations. Furthermore, the Regulation unifies terminology and reintroducing definitions of the terms 'breed' and 'breeding programme'.    I consider it important that this proposal for a regulation is based on regular consultations with experts and responds to differences in the implementation of the basic directives in the Member States, which are highlighted by the Member States themselves during the regular meetings of the Standing Committee on Zootechnics with the Commission.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. A well-functioning breeding sector of breeding of breeding animals is crucial for EU animal rearing, generating an estimated value of €1.89 billion. The new regulation brings together all existing zootechnical parts of the legislation and establishes a harmonised structure for breeding animals, in particular for bovine, ovine, caprine, porcine and equidae. The new rules cover internal trade in breeding animals and germs, their importation into the EU and rules for EU breeders exporting to third countries. Breeding plays a key role in the conservation of endangered species and in the protection of biodiversity. The Regulation therefore lays down zootechnical and geneatic rules for the conservation and improvement of breeding animals and rules governing the conservation and improvement of native or endangered breeds. 'Breed societies' and breeding programmes will have to fulfil certain conditions for recognition from national authorities; the new rules will ensure a minimum level of their rights and obligations. In addition, there will be harmonisation of the rules on the registration and classification of breeding animals and the strengthening of performance testing for imports of animals by ensuring compliance with EU standards. I believe it is important to establish specific rules to take account of the specificities of each species, as well as to the conservation and improvement of native or endangered breeds. For this very reasons, I supported the report.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Farming of domestic animals has strategic importance for EU agriculture in economic and social terms and is an essential source of income for the agricultural community. The aim of european union zootechnical legislation is to promote free trade in farmed animals and their genetic material, given the sustainability of breeding programmes and the conservation of genetic resources, thereby maintaining the competitiveness of the breeding and genetic material sectors in the Union.  This Regulation simplifies almost identical provisions in pre-existing zootechnical legislation and is drafted in a more precise and consistent language. I believe that the agricultural sector occupies an important place in the EU economy and it is essential to ensure the simplicity and consistency of Union legislation. Consequently, I support this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. The breeding of livestock – particularly of animals with a high level of genetic particularity – not only contributes to the economic and social development of the rural areas where it takes place, but is also one of the pillars on which the EU’s food security is based. On top of that, the new draft regulation delivers necessary consolidation and simplification of existing laws, completes the Single Market while reaffirming Member States’ competences where appropriate and clarifies the rights and obligations of animal breeders and their organisations.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The basis of EU zootechnical legislation is to encourage free trade within the EU, simplify imports and breeding of animals and maintain all animal species on European soil. Animal breeding, with the safety of genetic material and the maintenance of existing species in Europe, is an essential part of EU law. This proposal for a regulation contains all directives on zootechnical legislation and unites them into a single joint document. The regulation aims to complement the EU single market and help growers, while preserving biogenetic diversity within Europe. I support the proposal for a regulation on breeding animals and their genetic material. In my view, this helps the social and economic development of the area in which it takes place, but also the EU economy as a whole. Animal farming and their genetic material is one of the cornerstones of food safety that EU citizens rely on, and I believe that this regulation further strengthens the trust that citizens have in food safety.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on zootechnical and geneasological conditions for trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germs. I support the amendments in the report, such as the draft text, that the promotion of competitiveness must not lead to the extinction of breeds whose characteristics are adapted to a specific biophysical environment. The proposal also provides, inter alia, for all actors in the zootechnical sector, in particular in the genetic improvement of breeds, to take into account animal health and welfare, including the conditions for the transport of live animals.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the report there are very important reports on the need to protect genetic biodiversity and the production of regional products of typical quality and the importance of taking into account animal health and welfare. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This plan is unrealistic and will complicate the breeding methods of these animals. Cloned animals and their offspring must not participate in the breeding process. This process will act as a "washing machine" in which the registered characteristics and data of the animals will be changed in order to over-profit.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which improves and supports the Commission proposal for a single framework on the principles of rearing bovine animals, porcine animals, ovine animals, goats and equidae and, to a lesser extent, on the principles of breeding, trade and imports of other animal species. I agree that the production of these animals occupies a strategic place in EU agriculture in economic and social terms. I share the view that livestock farming plays an essential role in preserving biodiversity, in addition to ensuring food security and job creation in the Union. The report highlights that the survival of local breeds could be threatened in the absence of an adequate number of species, which would be a loss of genetic diversity. I believe that animal health and welfare are aspects that should be taken into account by all actors in the zootechnical sector, in particular as regards the improvement of the genetic stock of breeds. Cross-border cooperation between breeding and hybrid breeding organisations should be facilitated, while freedom of enterprise should be ensured and barriers to free trade in breeding animals and their reproductive material should be eliminated. Europe, including Hungary, has a rich local animal breed and a genetic population, which breeders' organisations and cooperatives play a central role in preserving and improving. I therefore consider it necessary to be able to defend their activities on clear, uniform principles.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A well-functioning animal husbandry sector is essential for animal production in the EU and its added value is estimated at almost €2 billion. At present, each species is subject to a separate basic directive and specific decisions and directives concerning m.in the recognition of trade organisations, the entry of breeding animals in the books, certificates, value assessment, genetic evaluation, etc. The European Commission's proposal to consolidate all existing zootechnical legislation into a single regulation is definitely a step in the right direction. The amendments proposed by Parliament are equally important. Particular attention should be paid to the decision to simplify official controls, which aims to minimise the bureaucratic burden on breeders, many of whom run small and medium-sized enterprises. The rearing of commercial animals not only contributes to economic and social development, but is one of the fundamental pillars of the Union's food security. I am therefore pleased that an agreement has been reached between the institutions to significantly simplify the existing legislation in this area, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of Parliament's report.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of the report. It is important to harmonise existing fragmented breeding legislation for different animal species, thereby clarifying and harmonising the provisions and the implementation of the provisions throughout the EU.  The European Parliament reached a good result with the Council, which will have an impact on the competitiveness of EU breeding animals and their germ cells.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Livestock farming is one of the important sectors of agricultural activity carried out within EU Member States. The pursuit of this activity shall entail compliance with certain zootechnical and genealogical conditions with regard to breeding and germination material from the various species of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats and horses existing in the territory of the States of the Union. Those conditions relate to the use of quality genetic material, obtained as a result of a long hybridisation activity carried out by European farmers and governed by substantial legislation at European level. The present document proposes the unification of this legislation, in particular as regards the recognition and publication of lists of profile organisations, breeders' associations and private structures, the registration and classification of animals in databases on herds, genetic specimens and protected species, performance testing and genetic evaluation, i.e. zootechnical certification of animal specimens and their genetic breeding material. This codification will contribute to the conservation and improvement of local and threatened species, as well as to clarify the rights of livestock farmers within the Union. This is about significant progress in this area, which is why I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted positively on the European Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation on zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germ products. The associations affected in Belgium have not reported to us any negative consequences on their activities

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this the proposal to put in place zootechnical and genealogical rules for trade in and imports into the EU of their breeding animals and their germinal products. Breeding plays a key role in conserving rare breeds and thereby in protecting biodiversity. However, efforts to achieve competitiveness should not lead to the disappearance of breeds with characteristics adapted to specific natural contexts. These rules will enable the preservation and improvement of animal breeding, as well as rules for the conservation and improvement of native or endangered breeds. Agreeing on a definition of the concept of ‘breed’ would be useful to clarify the common legal framework. This would also be facilitated through greater cross-border cooperation.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, as a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I supported the report because it promotes free trade in the Union and facilitates trade in bovine animals and biological substances used for breeding. And, most importantly, supports the programme for the protection of genetic resources of all varieties that live in Europe. This is very important for the future of agriculture. The final report should take into account the specific local conditions specific to each Member State. The rights of breeding organisations should also be supported and strengthened, which will help them to operate in a complex market. It is also appropriate to comment from the rapporteur on the fact that this Regulation should define more precisely a number of terms, such as 'breed', 'breeding programme', 'protection programme'. This will allow a better understanding of the new legislation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒The Commission's proposal on farmed animals and their genetic material consists of a combination of four types of specific basic acts setting out the basic principles, in particular with regard to breeding-rolled animal species of bovine animals, pigs, sheep, goats and equines.  Since this legislation on livestock farming within the European Union aims to encourage free trade, facilitate the import, breeding of animals and their genetic material while providing breeding programmes and genetic resources for the maintenance of programmes, I supported the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on zootechnical and genealytic conditions for the trafficking of farmed animals and their genetic material as well as their import into the Union. I believe that in the economic and social aspect the strategic importance for the agriculture of the European Union is the breeding of livestock, cattle, pigs, sheep, goats and equines and to a lesser extent the breeding of other animal species.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on zootechnical and geneadological conditions for trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germs. The report updates and improves existing EU zootechnical legislation covering breeding, trade and imports of breeding animals, thus reducing bureaucracy, thus simplifying procedures, which in the present case is good for both humans and animals. A well-functioning breeding sector is crucial for animal husbanding in the EU. Its added value is estimated at almost €2 billion. The European Commission's proposal addresses four main issues: (1) structuring the breeding sector; (2) rules on management of registers/registers, animal husbandment and performance testing and genetic evaluation; (3) rules on intra-EU trade and imports from third countries; (4) rules concerning official controls and controls by the Commission.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it has achieved a substantial improvement in the commission's proposal, introducing elements for improving animal welfare, maintaining the genetic heritage of indigenous breeds and boosting the domestic market. This draft legislation combines and simplifies pre-existing legislation on the rearing of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats and equine for consumption.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report concerned the management of breeding animals and their germ products. This text is not satisfactory because it gives too much power to the Commission over the treatment of these breeding animals.  We have proposed two amendments, which are rejected by the majority of the other political groups. Our breeders are therefore exposed to drifts from third countries.  Moreover, the infringement of France's sovereignty being a crucial criterion of our struggle in parliament, I voted against this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 A good functioning of the breeding animal sector is essential for EU agriculture and can generate an added value of EUR 1.89 billion. Currently, European zootechnical legislation aimed at promoting free trade in breeding animals and their genetic material is organised by species (cattle, pigs, sheep and goats), and for each species there is a basic directive. The aim of the proposed Regulation is to establish uniform rules on trade in breeding animals and their germination material and on their importation into the Union, with a view to promoting sustainable breeding programmes for breed improvement and the conservation of the genetic biodiversity of domestic animals. The idea is to avoid obstacles that might arise because of the disparities between the current rules. The Regulation also lays down rules on imports of breeding animals and their germination material from third countries and stresses the need to preserve endangered breeding animals. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on trade and imports of breeding animals and germination material from them.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Eu breeding legislation aims to encourage free trade within the Union and facilitate the import of breeding animals and their reproductive material, ensuring the maintenance of breeding programmes and programmes for the conservation of genetic resources existing in Europe. I supported the relevant document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it has achieved a substantial improvement in the commission's proposal, introducing elements for improving animal welfare, maintaining the genetic heritage of indigenous breeds and boosting the domestic market. This draft legislation combines and simplifies pre-existing legislation on the rearing of bovine animals, swine, sheep, goats and equine for consumption.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this text which I believe achieves adequate harmonization of animal feed standards for reproductive purposes.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the zootechnical and genealogical conditions for trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germinal products. The proposal seeks to modernise and strengthen in one regulation a number of individual segments of species-specific legislation relating to bovine, porcine, ovine, caprine and equine species including requirements for recognition and listing of breeding organisations, classification and certification of breeding animals and official controls and zootechnical checks.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a necessary, timely and technical regulation that has taken into account the aspirations of livestock sectors and public administrations, collecting important changes in the criteria for zootechnical harmonization of breed regulation and harmonizing trade in these animals, while en enticing that such trade is compatible with national measures aimed at preserving genetic resources and biodiversity of indigenous breeds. We are therefore talking about a regulation which takes an important step in animal trade and thus helps the progress of the European single market in agricultural matters. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I abstained in voting on this report because this regulation threatens to threaten the future of the export of the semen of the Belgian white-blue variety. In my opinion, the amendments tabled in the Committee on Agriculture are not problematic, nor do they address the threat of declining exports of the semen of our Belgian white-blue variety. I abstained in order to send a signal to the European Commission and the Council to reject this threat. The export of semen of our white-blue variety must be possible, because it is a breed that is characteristic of our livestock (and which we are proud of) and that there is a great demand abroad.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this Regulation is to establish zootechnical and genealogical rules for animal preservation and reproduction, as well as the rules governing the conservation and reproduction of native or endangered breeds.  This Regulation thus places, in a single legal framework, several important aspects, such as the structuring of the animal husbandry/breeding sector, laying down rules for the management of breeding books, breeding records, breeding and performance testing and genetic evaluation. It also lays down rules for trade within the EU and for imports from third countries, as well as laying down rules for official controls and commission controls. One of the negative aspects of this proposal, in addition to the assumption that the meat production sector needs to be more competitive in order to allow European species and breeds to be exported, is the appearance of animal cloning being left out, even as regards the genealogical register, and it is not recorded whether the parent is a cloned animal or if the germinal products come from a cloned animal.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. On the one hand, the rapporteur's aim to increase animal welfare and to create legal certainty, which would also provide greater clarity for breeders, should be positively emphasised. However, on the other hand, the report would create more bureaucracy, which would reduce the position of European horse breeders.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the rules on animal husbandry and pedigree for the trade in breeding animals and their breeding material in the Union and for the importation of them into the Union. The EU should have no competence in this area. Their action is a violation of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The breeding of livestock, particularly of animals with a high level of genetic particularity, not only contributes to the economic and social development of the rural areas where it takes place, but is also one of the pillars on which the EU’s food security is based. Additionally, the new draft regulation delivers necessary consolidation and simplification of existing laws, completes the single market while reaffirming Member States’ competences where appropriate and clarifies the rights and obligations of animal breeders and their organisations.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. This report proposes a proposal, the measures of which aim to harmonise trade in purebred animals and their genetic material. Taking into account the wide variety of species (especially indigenous breeds) that Spain has in terms of livestock species and their ability to adapt to the different geographical and climatic areas, I consider this report to be very important and positive. I support the measures proposed in the document because I believe it takes into account the needs of the livestock sectors in Spain, promoting their activity and their efficient functioning.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on zootechnical and geneadological conditions for trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germs, as I note that it provides greater legal certainty for all stakeholders and ensures a coordinated approach to trade in and imports into the Union of breeding animals and their germs in the Union and to official controls to be implemented for breeding and company programmes. The purpose of the proposal for a regulation cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States at national level and can therefore, by reason of its impact, complexity and cross-border and international nature, be better achieved at Union level.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The latest news on the migrant issue, which was revealed in this report: point 1: They now make no distinction between refugees and economic migrants, point 2: They are looking for the opportunity to bring Hungary to its knees, in particular, and states that do not want to allow mass immigration into their country.  Point 3: They do this by emotional means, on the one hand, it was visible here in the debate that they are taught, our fellow mainstream politicians, to be extremists, xenophobes, racists, and to use a wide variety of terrible adjectives for both states and individuals who do not want mass immigration. Point 4: seek legal means of tying him to his knees. I report that they will not find it, because this is not the 'United States of Europe'. It is not a federal state that can compel a Member State to do anything, but a union of sovereign nations.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because the phenomenon of migration is the result of momentous geopolitical changes that we cannot stop, but which the European Union must address by prioritising the management of a situation that is no longer an emergency.  Priority of method, priority of content: we must proceed together and have a European approach, we can no longer see, every day more, even Member States that raise walls and put barbed wire and others who are engaged in the search and rescue at sea of migrants, and then of content because I come from Sicily, which is one of those regions that see the lifeless bodies of men arriving on its shores , women and children and who turn schools into morgues. The Dublin review provides for the creation of a single asylum system with centralised application at European level, automatic relocation and effectiveness of migrants to all European countries and security returns; That is why I voted strongly in favour.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I did not vote in favour of this report. I believe that the proposals and options set out in this report, such as centralised asylum procedures, are extremely dangerous in today's political situation and in the state of the EU. I cannot imagine how such a proposal would be enforceable in the Czech Republic today, so as not to further downsite the credibility of European integration in the eyes of the Czech public. I personally disagree. I am not in support of the transfer of the asylum agenda from individual national states to the central authorities in Brussels and for a body other than the state to be able to decide which people enter the territory of that state. From my political point of view, this runs counter to the principles of national sovereignty.  That is why I did not support this report and why I believe that solutions need to be sought other than those proposed in the report, which are against the sovereignty of individual Member States.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I did not support this report, I abstained and I would like to explain the reasons that led me to do so.  Unlike last year's vote on one-off measures in favour of Hungary, Italy and Greece, this report describes the system for setting a mandatory centralised asylum agenda. This is contrary to the programme for which I ran for the EP, TOP 09 and Mayors, where we had written that it is precisely asylum and immigration policy that will remain in the national wine, in other words, it is of course possible for the Czech Republic to join certain asylum standards, standard procedures, but it must be its free consent, it must be an expression of the position of the Czech Republic as a Member State.  I think that in these politically sensitive matters, where there is actually some incorporation of the population on the territory of the Czech Republic or other states, the EU should be more sensitive.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the situation in the Mediterranean is indeed dire. For those millions of people who are suffering because they are leaving the areas of Syria and Afghanistan where war and deprivation is affecting them, that is clear. But once again we have a failed EU policy that will have an impact on the United Kingdom. The EU’s policy here today has rejected the idea that open borders, including Schengen, have been a major problem. They have rejected the idea that Angela Merkel’s open welcome has caused millions of people to feel that they should come to the EU and they have rejected the idea that Australia’s solutions have meant fewer people dying. But what they have decided to say, in taking this one bull by the horns, is that there is a real need for a permanent mandatory Union-wide resettlement programme with mandatory control and distribution across the European Union. If Britain wants to avoid this in the future, it must vote to leave the European Union on 23 June. Otherwise it will also be dragged in.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Clearly, the events of last year showed that the existing European Union's migration policy is not working. It can be sufficiently effective in the case of a small number of migrants, but is simply not able to function effectively or overcome such a large number of migrants. It is clear that there are different attitudes to the current situation in different countries, particularly following the events in Paris and Brussels, and therefore it is vital that coordination between the national, supranational, regional and municipal levels of government is necessary. Clearly, the principle of solidarity is undeniably important, so I support this document and support the reporters who worked it. But i have to say that we have not yet created an ideal system, and we - the European Parliament and the Commission - and the entire European Union still have a great deal to do to ensure that an effective system for overcoming the migrant crisis is implemented. But i repeat, I voted in favour. Thank you!

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report and we have tabled RCVs for particular areas of the report in which we strongly disagree with the text. In particular, UKIP believes that national sovereign governments should have the right to control their own borders and should not be forced to take migrants under an EU resettlement scheme. Similarly, we are also concerned with segments of the report which suggest that the EU should create rules governing the entry and residence of third country nationals. UKIP has, however, supported aspects of the report which criticise the Schengen Area as a facilitator and accelerator of both the migrant crisis and the movement of terrorists within Europe.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on an own-initiative report on the EU's long-term migration policy. The report highlights a number of points that I welcome. The emphasis on member states' joint responsibility for the issue of migration, the need for legal routes into Europe, the security of external borders and the preservation of Schengen cooperation, as well as a permanent redistribution mechanism. I therefore voted in favour in the final vote. On the other hand, I believe that the agreement concluded by the EU with Turkey in the report is mentioned in too positive a way. There is every reason to be sceptical about the agreement in question, which has essentially only been created as a consequence of the lack of a sustainable European migration policy.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report is Parliament's response to the current migration crisis. In my opinion, the strength of this report is the fact that it is shared by the vast majority of the political groups, which makes it possible to send a strong signal from Parliament to the Commission and the Council. Specifically, the part relating to the revision of the Dublin III Regulation can lead to the management of the migration crisis based on the principle of solidarity and not just on the mere allocation of competences. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it. Immigration is perhaps the most important challenge the EU has posed because, like the refugee crisis, it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are. The importance of this report is that it addresses the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea, to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a share of the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of Humanitarian Visas and promoting legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as redouble our commitment against mafias exploiting people and improving reception and integration policies, is important.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is a missed opportunity for the LIBE Commission to put on the agenda the problems currently faced by people trying to reach the EU. Instead of requiring the issuance of humanitarian visas or ensuring that no collective expulsions are carried out (prohibited by international law and enshrined in the EU-Turkey agreement), it has been chosen to maintain the current aggressive policy imposed by the Commission and the Council. Although the agreement includes positive things, such as the need to create secure access routes, or the need to overcome the Dublin System and the states welcome, these issues are mentioned without concrete measures, so they are left empty again. However, it details the plan to militarize the Mediterranean with nato's help, the need for returns, cooperation with military and security forces from third countries, or the development of a list of safe countries from which asylum claims will not be accepted, in clear violation of the Geneva Convention. For all this, we have not had to vote against this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. At a time when European states are facing an unprecedented migration crisis, this scandalous report calls for harmonising national asylum systems and creating a distribution mechanism that would require Member States to accept migrant quotas. The text even goes so far as to propose family reunification. It is absolutely unacceptable to organise Europe's migration submersion at a time when our peoples are already suffering from mass unemployment, increased poverty and precariousness, and an increase in social inequalities. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union is sinking into tinkering. It is the very inability of Member States to implement European rules and commitments that leads to dubious agreements with third countries and to unravel what has been achieved, even if it means ignoring international values and obligations. In view of the revision of the Dublin Regulation, the Common European Asylum Scheme and the Commission's proposals on legal migration routes, I welcome this report of initiative which takes the side of a reorientation of migration policy, a comprehensive, forward-looking, coherent, united and protective policy.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The aim of the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need to develop a holistic European approach to migration is to form a cross-party view from the European Parliament on the Union's migration policy.  According to the report which I voted in favour of, a holistic approach to migration should include, inter alia, the revision of the Dublin III Regulation, in order to create a centralised system for the division of responsibilities between Member States, the organisation of coordinated humanitarian operations of the Union, the existence of a binding and mandatory legislative approach to the resettlement of refugees. , the revision of the Blue Card Directive, the introduction of more general rules on the entry and residence of third-country nationals seeking work in the Union, in order to fill the gaps in the labour market and the mutual recognition of positive asylum decisions by all Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is a veritable catalogue of the immigration lobby.  A few examples: he calls for the creation of "new safe and lawful routes" to enable asylum seekers and refugees to enter the EU; it advocates the establishment of "appropriate" channels of legal economic migration and the blue card system (para. 131); It wants new measures to make the common European asylum system a 'truly uniform system'; it encourages Member States to "ensure the preservation of family unity" and therefore wants to facilitate the snowball effect of family reunification. I obviously voted against this report

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concedes that the open border policy of the EU is an incentive for migrants to make the dangerous attempt to cross the Mediterranean. I voted in favour of amendments suggesting that the abolition of internal borders has contributed to the ‘free passage of ISIS’ and criticising the EU list of ‘safe countries’ for refugees. I voted against the aspects of the report requiring the ‘need for a permanent Union-wide resettlement programme’ with mandatory participation from Member States. As a whole the report ‘considers the Schengen Area as one of the major achievements of European integration’. I wholeheartedly object to this view and therefore voted against this report as a whole.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. We are facing an unprecedented migration crisis in Europe. I voted in favour of this report because we must work together to establish a new European asylum policy, in order to welcome refugees travelling to Europe and safeguard the Schengen area. There is an urgent need for the European Union to have a common policy to enable it to protect its borders and, at the same time, to establish a European coastguard and border guard. Europe cannot abolish internal borders and leave it to states to monitor external borders on their own.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 During the vote on the report on "Situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration" amendment no 19 was voted on by the political group Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left, which recognises the positive action of the Portuguese government in resolving the refugee crisis. Portugal's action on this issue underpines our country and can make a decisive contribution to countering the nationalist drivethat calls into question the soundness of the adoption of a common European orientation. By assessing the actions of the Portuguese government, I understood to vote in favour of the amendment in question, contrary to the voting orientation of my political group.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to establish a common asylum system. I agree that the EU must establish a common system for registering asylum applications, which will allow them to be examined more quickly in the face of huge migratory flows. The EU must ensure new safe and legal routes for entry to the EU, so that refugees seeking entry to EU countries do not risk their lives and avoid smugglers. It is very important to better protect migrant children, especially those who travel alone. Migrants who cannot be granted asylum should only be returned to countries where they will be safe.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report and we have tabled RCVs for particular areas of the report in which we strongly disagree with the text. In particular, UKIP believes that national sovereign governments should have the right to control their own borders and should not be forced to take migrants under an EU resettlement scheme. Similarly, we are also concerned with segments of the report which suggest that the EU should create rules governing the entry and residence of third country nationals. UKIP has, however, supported aspects of the report which criticise the Schengen Area as a facilitator and accelerator of both the migrant crisis and the movement of terrorists within Europe.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Among other bad ideas, the report calls for the creation of "new safe and lawful routes" to enable asylum seekers and refugees to enter the EU (considering R) as well as the establishment of "appropriate" channels of legal economic migration (considering V and W), calls for new measures to make the common European asylum system a "genuinely uniform system" (para. 28) , calls for an overhaul of the Dublin system in the sense of more 'solidarity', thus through a distribution mechanism (para. 38), and encourages Member States to 'ensure the preservation of family unity', i.e. the fatal family reunification (para. 49). I therefore voted against a project that promotes an immigrationist policy in defiance of the vital interests of our peoples as well as the migrants themselves, a mass of uprooted people who have been projected to have an Eldorado that does not exist. Terrible leak forward...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have obviously supported this report, which calls for a plural and open approach to migration. The report stresses the fundamental importance of continuing search and rescue operations at sea and calls for the replacement of the Dublin system with a centralised European system based on solidarity, which would distribute refugees in solidarity and compulsory among Member States. In addition, it calls for the establishment of legal, clear and precise access routes to Europe or the creation of humanitarian visas that would allow their holders to travel directly to the country where he wishes to seek asylum. Finally, it calls for adequate funding for humanitarian aid.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to data provided by FRONTEX, in 2015 1.83 million people attempted to cross the external borders of the European Union. This is unprecedented and is the result of an international situation characterised by wars, major imbalances and factors of instability that threaten the lives of millions of people. In this context, it is clear that the current asylum system is not in a position to offer an adequate solution.  I supported the Metsola and Kyenge report because I deeply agree with the need to think holoistically about the issue of managing migratory flows. The revision of the Dublin system must be the priority, and provision must be made for the creation of hotspots from which asylum seekers can be distributed on the basis of a pre-established quota system for each Member State. With regard to readmission, the aim must be to establish new agreements at Community level to allow Member States to return migrants only if the country of origin is considered safe. Article 80 TFEI places the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility at the heart of the whole system of the Union, Italy and Greece cannot be left alone.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on the basis that, despite some progress on the original text and with regard to the current terms of EU migration and asylum policy, the text enshrines the validity of the unacceptable and illegal EU-Turkey Agreement which implies the irresponsible relocation of the management of the European migration and asylum and refuge system to countries where disrespect for human rights is evident and systematic.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. I would like here to denounce the dismal agreement reached between the European Union and Turkey last month. Turkey got what it wanted: 6 billion euros to support the reception of migrants on its territory, a visa exemption to Europe for its nationals and the relaunch of its accession process. Erdogan, the perfect blackmailer, won. But what about migrants? In reality, it is a disgrace. A shame because the Union is deliberately turning its back on them by sending them back to Turkey, as would be the case for simple cattle; a shame in calling Turkey a safe country, when the rule of law is not present. And a shame at the number of violations of international law. Moreover, even if this agreement with Turkey would have the effect of drying up the sea route that stretches from the Turkish coast to Greece, other routes of penetration are already opening up. When one turns a river from its bed, it digs another to sink... Smugglers reorganize and react to stick as close as possible to the needs of their customers... European governments must now open their eyes, take responsibility and Europe must stop being so attractive.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it.  Immigration is perhaps the most important challenge the EU has posed because, like the refugee crisis, it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are.  The importance of this report is that it addresses the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea, to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a share of the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of Humanitarian Visas and promoting legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as redouble our commitment against mafias exploiting people and improving reception and integration policies, is important.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the situation regarding asylum in Europe. The Common European Asylum System (BEPS) includes common rules governing the common asylum policy, the same status of asylum and common union-wide asylum procedures. The European Parliament stresses that saving life must be a top priority, and it is therefore essential that search and rescue operations be adequately funded at EU and Member State level. Notes, moreover, that the number of irregular migrants arriving by sea has increased, that there is a dangerous increase in the number of deaths at sea and that better European responses remain necessary. Of course, Parliament calls for a clear distinction between persons smuggled into the European Union and those brought to the EU for the purpose of trafficking in human beings, because political countermeasures must not only be properly integrated, but also properly targeted. It points out that, in general, the criminal introduction of migrants involves aiding a person with the purpose of entering the Member State illegally, and that trafficking in human beings involves recruiting, transporting or receiving a person by means of violence, fraud or abuse in order to exploit it. The European Parliament is therefore of the opinion that any holistic approach to migration must necessarily include measures to disrupt the activities of criminal networks involved in trafficking and smuggling.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The migration crisis cannot be blurred with the refugee crisis, nor can it respond to the demographic problems of some Member States. Only a fraction of the masses heading to Europe are genuine refugees, most of whom we can help by supporting reception camps close to their country. If they can be provided with dignible conditions, health care and education, we will make it easier for them to return to their home countries as the situation stabilises. At the same time, for the immigrant masses arriving in the hope of a better livelihood, any ambigrat gestures are interpreted as invitations. Solidarity can take many forms, not artificially imposed mandatory quotas.  As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I did not vote in favour of the report on migration adopted today, because it is unacceptable for them to centrally say who is being put on our hands and for others to decide who should be allowed into our own Member States and with whom to live.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. My fellow Members and I supported the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for an integrated EU approach to migration. We agreed with the fact that the EU must take an even more active approach to saving and preventing the loss of migrants' lives at sea, while ensuring the successful integration of migrants and a high level of internal security for the Member States.
