We strongly condemned the criminal activities of criminal organisations such as smuggling, trafficking in human beings and labour exploitation in connection with illegal migration.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the resolution voted on today, which sends out a positive signal towards a shared and effective approach to managing the migration crisis facing Europe.  The current system for managing asylum flows and asylum seekers, in particular the so-called 'Dublin system', has in fact failed in the face of the challenges we face and needs to be reviewed as soon as possible. The creation of a centralised asylum system, based on a fair division of burdens and therefore consistent with the principle of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities, is essential in order to respond effectively and fully to the spirit of the Union to today's challenges.  In line with this, the proposed global approach is moving in the right direction: the implementation of member states' relocation obligations, increased shared efforts in the control of external borders and the fight against human trafficking, as well as the development of appropriate legal migration channels and the development of effective cooperation strategies with third countries are some of the aspects on which to work so that the Union can maintain its solidity even in times of serious difficulty. With the strategic plan on immigration that has just been presented, Italy has already sent out an important signal in this regard.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration, which calls for a thorough "overhaul" of The Dublin III Regulation, with a view to sharing responsibilities between Member States on the basis of fair and objective criteria. I believe that the EU must find a strong and effective response in search and rescue operations at sea, as well as the resettlement of a meaningful number of refugees, taking into account the number of refugees seeking EU protection. Most importantly, the EU must show its humanist towards people in need, i.e. it must prove all those European values that we constantly stand for!

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the creation of "new safe and lawful routes", as well as for the establishment of "appropriate" legal economic migration channels and for the blue card system. Moreover, it wants the common European asylum system to become a 'genuinely uniform system', is in favour of overhauling the Dublin system in the sense of more 'solidarity', encourages Member States to 'ensure and preserve family unity' and thus facilitates the snowball effect of family reunification. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is essential, in order to deal decisively and effectively with the migration crisis that has hit the southern coasts of our continent, to find a common approach between all the Member States of the Union and its institutions.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 2015 was an extremely complicated year compared to the phenomenon of the influx of refugees and migrants to the EU, with over one and a half million people trying to enter European territory illegally, more than one million applications for international protection and about four thousand dramatic deaths in the Mediterranean.  It is therefore necessary to promote a European approach, promoting the creation of a centralised system for collecting asylum applications, the effective application of the common European asylum system, the fight against human traffickers and the strengthening of the role of the European Asylum Support Office, all within the framework of a more complete review of the Dublin system.  It is also necessary to combat, by strengthening cooperation and funding to third countries within the framework of existing dialogue mechanisms such as the Rabat process, or the EU-Africa dialogue on migration and mobility, on the structural causes of the current migration crisis (including wars and persecution), while bearing in mind the growing need, due to the progressive ageing of the European population , the integration of more people of working age into the European labour market, as well as respect for the values of solidarity and humanity that under undersea our identity as European citizens.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. At a time when European peoples are facing an unprecedented influx of migrants, this scandalous report calls for harmonising national asylum systems and creating a distribution mechanism that would require Member States to accept migrant quotas. The rapporteur goes further and even proposes to promote family reunification, the cost of which would be borne entirely by taxpayers. It is absolutely unacceptable to organise Europe's migration submersion at a time when our peoples are already suffering from mass unemployment, increased poverty, a reduction in their purchasing power and an increase in social inequalities. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have spoken out against this resolution because it is another step towards the permanence of quotas. As I have said on other occasions, I appreciate that account must be taken of the ability of member States to fulfil their obligations objectively when we talk about refugee relocations. I believe that the definitive solution lies outside the borders of the European Union and not within it, where we can only have momentary solutions!

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by the Metsola reports for the People's Party and Kyenge for the Socialists is a classic example of a child labour of the grand coalition PPE and S&D. In short, this is a great compromise (very unbalanced on the left) between those who want an 'open door' policy such as the Socialists and other left-wing groups and those who, like the PPE and also the ECR in this case, are afraid to blatantly oppose this policy and therefore try to block by demanding only more rules and procedures. A report which has seen since its inception our work as shadow rapporteurs with Mr De Clercq, on behaving as shadow rapporteur. Fountain. That is why we confirm the negative vote in the Libe Committee.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it.  Immigration is perhaps the most important challenge the EU has posed because, like the refugee crisis, it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are.  The importance of this report is that it addresses the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea, to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a share of the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of Humanitarian Visas and promoting legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as redouble our commitment against mafias exploiting people and improving reception and integration policies, is important.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The massive influx of migrants at the EU's borders requires appropriate measures to provide a European response to this problem. The situation in the Mediterranean is particularly dramatic given the many shipwrecks that occur each year. We cannot decently let these tragedies happen without acting. In this context, the Commission has proposed the creation of a European coastguard and border guard. I have been fighting for years for the creation of a European coastguard corps. I therefore welcome this proposal while paying particular attention to the smooth running of this project. This report highlights all kinds of issues that need to be addressed in order to put in place a holistic approach to migration. We cannot continue to respond urgently to migration. The Union needs a long-term strategy in this area. I voted in favour of this report, which seeks to strike a balance between solidarity and migration security.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to immigration. The serious immigration crisis continues to be exploited. Due to the closure of some Member States, the plan to relocate refugees arriving on European territory was a failure.  On 20 March 2016, the agreement signed in Brussels between Europe and Turkey on managing the flow of migrants entered into force. Doubts and misgivings about this agreement have been expressed on several sides. The European Union must take responsibility for guiding and supporting safely, with respect for human rights and international agreements, those who enter the European political and legal area. We need a global approach to dealing with the situation, for example by launching cooperation programmes aimed at reducing the causes of immigration. What has been done so far is still very little.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree that the European Union needs a common and comprehensive response to the current refugee crisis. The report covers a wide range of aspects related to migration and outlines promising measures which should help us deal more effectively with the current situation. These cover the very important aspects such as border management, which is a crucial part to ensure the survival of Schengen, as well as a plan to return those not eligible for protection. As outlined by the report, our migration strategy should be based on cooperation, solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to express Parliament's position on the current migration crisis and was intended to inform the EU agenda for migration. Unfortunately, the sensitivity of this issue has led to considerable delays in the presentation of the report and, when it comes to the vote in plenary, the Commission will have already presented its agenda.  However, especially with regard to the revision of the Dublin III Regulation, the report can still be topical and the proposals made in this regard are highly acceptable. They are aimed at a system in which the responsibilities of the Member States in the distribution of refugees are indeed based on the principle of solidarity. I voted in favour with conviction.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 However sensible this report contained some very sensible measures to address the refugee crisis in Europe, I could not support it, as it mentions two fundamental things that I consider to be completely excluded on this subject. One of these is the recurring theme of the mandatory redistribution of refugees, asylum seekers. I do not consider this measure to be operational. The second point is the proposal for a centrally managed place for the processing of asylum applications from Brussels. This proposal is as absurd as the first, it is difficult to see how it should actually work. I believe that the responsibility for both parts should be with the Member States in particular, and the European Union should focus on the solutions it can offer together. Thank you.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support this very important report. The need to deal with the influx of migrants into Europe is undeniable. This can only be achieved through a coordinated approach, based on solidarity and responsibility, supported by common instruments.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the situation in the Mediterranean region and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. We all know that the period we are going through is particularly turbulent, both for the Member States and for the European Union.  I think it is particularly important to understand the benefits that a single, coordinated effort by Europe would have in order to address the problems created by the refugee issue and migration. At the same time, we must focus on showing solidarity, as well as adopting the right policies to help fellow people at risk. That is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was important for me to vote in favour of this report because, first of all, it summarises the current situation in the Mediterranean and the European Union's response to the migratory flow, and, what is more, it is anxious to build new bonds of solidarity between the different Member States with the aim of creating a concrete and immediate reaction to the increase in irregular arrivals by sea as well as to the alarming increase in deaths at sea.  It is clear that Europe needs a better response, and I therefore believe that it is necessary for each State to invest more resources in the context of an EU-wide humanitarian operation dedicated to the relief and assistance of migrants in danger. In my opinion, therefore, it is necessary for the European Union to have a global approach to the problem with the concrete participation of each State.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2015, 1.83 million persons were found attempting to cross the EU’s external borders. 20% of the incoming migrants who arrived by sea were children. It must be acknowledged that the current system for asylum does not alleviate pressure on Member States with EU external borders. Change needs to be implemented in order to facilitate a fairer system which would include shared responsibility, with a central system for allocating asylum applicants. This would include a quota of refugees for each Member State. A binding and mandatory legislative approach is necessary for the relocation of asylum seekers. Currently only a small proportion of 106 000 refugees in Italy and Greece have been relocated. In the event of a returns procedure, migrants should only be returned if their safety would not be at risk.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. In the face of the huge influx of people that eventually resulted in the so-called "refugee crisis", the European Union has been slowly and slowly reacting rather than preventing or foreseeing. Much has been done, but much is still to be done. I have often said that this crisis has two distinct but complementary levels of action. On the one hand, we must respond to the emergency, essentially humanitarian. On the other hand, we must tackle structural issues such as the origin of the largest number of displaced people since the second world war. This report presents a comprehensive vision, which draws a precise diagnosis, looks critically at the emergency response, presents a set of structural reforms – such as the common European asylum system, or the external borders – and achieves something the Union desperately needs: solidarity and long-term vision. I support this report. Now it's time to act.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the call for EU uniform rules so that we can better cope with the growing influx of migrants and asylum seekers in the future.  We need to revise the Dublin system and improve where difficulties arise today: we need to introduce uniform standards so that asylum applications are examined and processed everywhere according to the same criteria, and that safe and legal routes must be created for third-country nationals wishing to enter the EU without them having to risk their lives and resort to smugglers. This is not about quick solutions, but about a sustainable approach that will bring us a sustainable workable solution!

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report and we have tabled RCVs for particular areas of the report in which we strongly disagree with the text. In particular, UKIP believes that national sovereign governments should have the right to control their own borders and should not be forced to take migrants under an EU resettlement scheme. Similarly, we are also concerned with segments of the report which suggest that the EU should create rules governing the entry and residence of third country nationals. UKIP has, however, supported aspects of the report which criticise the Schengen Area as a facilitator and accelerator of both the migrant crisis and the movement of terrorists within Europe.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In these days we are witnessing yet another sad reality in which we see some Member States raising anti-refugee barriers instead of rolling up their sleeves as many European countries are doing, first and then Italy, which has seen more than 19 thousand people arrive on their shores, not to mention all those that will arrive between now and the next few months taking advantage of the favorable weather situation. Of the more than 40,000 people that Italy was supposed to distribute in Europe, to date only a small percentage have been relocated, this is because the relocation system is completely bankrupt: there is no solidarity, no collaboration and no fair distribution of responsibilities. Well, I believe that, under these conditions, Member States that are indifferent to the cause should not benefit from European funding. A long-term strategy would be needed to help counter the 'push factors' (conflict, persecution, ethnic cleansing, extreme poverty, violence, climate change and natural disasters) that force people into the hands of criminal networks of traffickers by seeing in them the only chance to reach Europe.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The creation of new safe and lawful routes for asylum seekers and refugees irrespective from where they come, entering the Union needs to be supported. This will also help to address the tragedies that occur in these voyages as well as undermine the business model of smugglers. Malta has consistently maintained that Dublin rules place an unfair burden on frontier countries and called for amendments to achieve a fairer distribution of asylum seekers across the EU. Reform must not be seen in isolation but would have to be part of a holistic package, including fostering relations with third countries and addressing the root causes of migration.   An effective holistic reform must deliver more solidarity, both towards migrants and towards other member states dealing with the crisis.   The commitment of Member States’ prime ministers should do away with national electoral blinkers so as to ensure the much—needed progress on migration is achieved. Migration is not an issue for one single Member States, but for all together as much as with third countries.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is a missed opportunity for the LIBE Commission to put on the agenda the problems currently faced by people trying to reach the EU. Instead of requiring the issuance of humanitarian visas or ensuring that no collective expulsions are carried out (prohibited by international law and enshrined in the EU-Turkey agreement), it has been chosen to maintain the current aggressive policy imposed by the Commission and the Council. Although the agreement includes positive things, such as the need to create secure access routes, or the need to overcome the Dublin System and the states welcome, these issues are mentioned without concrete measures, so they are left empty again. However, it details the plan to militarize the Mediterranean with nato's help, the need for returns, cooperation with military and security forces from third countries, or the development of a list of safe countries from which asylum claims will not be accepted, in clear violation of the Geneva Convention. For all this, we have not had to vote against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The relocation of asylum seekers between Member States, migrant smuggling and the management of the EU's internal and external borders are issues of absolute topicality, which require a unified response from all Member States, in the short and long term, that is consistent with the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities established by Article 80 TFEU.  My vote in favour of the European Parliament resolution is intended to support EU action for comprehensive migration management. I believe that this resolution introduces a fair and homogeneous approach between Member States in addressing common issues, such as the relocation and resettlement of refugees at EU level.  In this regard, I support the proposal to revise the Dublin III Regulation, which has proved inadequate in relation to migratory pressure on the countries of first arrival, especially in terms of finance and assistance to hotspots, and which derogates from the fundamental principles of fairness and solidarity in the distribution of competences and responsibilities among the Member States. I therefore welcome the option of establishing a centralised European system for collecting asylum seekers' applications and distributing them within the EU.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A comprehensive approach to migration at EU level, ensuring coherence between internal and external policies, is absolutely necessary. I voted for such a strategy, which would prevent similar humanitarian crises from occurring in the future. Full respect for human rights is a value that underpins the EU. The important issues contained in the report are the revision of the Dublin II Regulation (which determines which State is responsible for processing certain asylum applications), the need for a binding legislative approach to the transfer of refugees, the duty of Member States to fulfil their obligations on urgent relocation measures, the need for technical and financial assistance for Member States in order for reception centres to function as well as possible and the highlighting of the vulnerable position of children and their rights.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not vote in favour of the report on migration adopted today. The migration crisis cannot be mixed with the refugee crisis. Only a fraction of the hundreds of thousands of refugees heading to Europe are genuine refugees, and the best way to help them is to support reception camps close to their country and to help resolve the conflict. If conditions, health care and education can be provided in reception camps in neighbouring countries, we will make it easier for them to return to their home countries as the situation stabilises.  Although the report makes a number of positively appreciable suggestions and projects a solution, I have not been able to support the adopted report. According to the report, a permanent resettlement programme at EU level, binding on all Member States, is needed and the aim would be to set up a central system for sharing responsibility for persons seeking asylum in the Union. I am convinced that there are many forms of solidarity, but artificially imposed mandatory quotas are not the solution.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Parliament's own-initiative report responds to the Migration Programme presented by the European Commission in May 2015. The report aimed to present an ambitious and horizontal approach to all forms of migration in the EU, including legal migration, refugees, irregular migration and the Schengen area.  The proposals contained in the final report include m.in. a call for a mandatory EU-wide system for the relocation of refugees, the replacement of the existing Dublin Regulation with a centralised asylum application procedure through European rapid registration points for migrants ('hotspots') (to allow for effective asylum applications across the Union and not in individual Member States) and a call for humanitarian visas.  In the absence of increased emphasis on strengthening external border controls, increasing the efficiency of the return and readmission of those who have not been granted asylum, and combating trafficking in human beings, I could not support this report because the policy recommendations made do not provide a sensible or balanced solution to the current crisis in Europe.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose both this report and its proposal for a compulsory EU—wide system for the relocation of refugees, Member States and national governments are best placed to set their own immigration policy and relocation and resettlement of refugees should be done on a voluntary basis only. We should focus much more on enhancing external border controls to tackle the migration crisis, as well as increasing the efficiency of returns and readmission of failed asylum seekers. Much more can also be done on combatting human trafficking and increasing the implementation of existing rules and preventing secondary movement of asylum seekers, only with a multi-front approach can we deal with the current ongoing crisis.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that there must be a comprehensive approach when it comes to migration at European Union level that ensures coherence between its internal and external policies, based on solidarity, but also on better coordination between Member States.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to establish cooperation between the European Union and Tunisia in the areas of migration, asylum and border management. It assesses the various policies at stake in the areas of migration, asylum and border management, and makes a series of recommendations to improve coordination between these policies. Considering that the European Union must work with its neighbouring countries to develop healthy and constructive relations, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Despite its weaknesses, I voted in favour of this text on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive approach to the issue of migration on the part of the European Union. Indeed, while I do not support all the provisions of this report, particularly with regard to legal economic migration, it does provide a complete picture and offers interesting answers to the challenges posed by the migration crisis. In particular, I thought it was essential to recall Parliament's support for the measures proposed by the European Commission in the face of migratory pressure. It was also necessary to stress the importance of creating a common eu list of safe countries of origin in order to facilitate the asylum process. I also support the need to adopt new European readmission agreements and strengthen our cooperation with third countries.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The situation in the Mediterranean is dire. The only way we can find a solution is to adopt an approach at EU level. That is why I voted in favour of this parliamentary resolution. It does not just focus on the usual negative aspects – such as smuggling and human trafficking – of this issue. It investigates how we could actually resolve the situation, such as the cooperation with third countries through regional protection programmes and by developing legal economic migration channels. In addition, it stresses the importance of taking responsibility in adhering to the systems that are in place, for example, by stressing the importance of how emergency funds are spent and the effective implementation of the Common European Asylum System. Most importantly, it indicates which steps are needed in order for the Common European Asylum System (CEAS) to become a uniform and therefore efficient system. In this regard the resolution calls upon going even further, stressing that Article 78 (2) on ‘a uniform status of Asylum’ that would be valid throughout the Union, is fully implemented. Finally, it acknowledges the necessity of reinforcing FRONTEX and of the new European Border and Coast Guard.

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'The SP Group abstained in the vote on the report. The SP has serious objections to the EU agreement with Turkey of 18 March 2016, as there are no guarantees that Syrian refugees will not be returned to Syria. Reports from Amnesty International, among others, show that this is happening, which is contrary to the Convention on Refugees.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which is not without its problems. Indeed, I do not believe that a binding mechanism for resettling refugees is an effective way forward in resolving the crisis. Responsibility for migration management must remain at the level of the Member States, which can make decisions according to their capacity to host. I call on the Member States to manage this crisis by coordinating with each other and remain in favour of a temporary resettlement mechanism on a voluntary basis. Finally, I am against the creation of a humanitarian visa. This would create a call for air that our administrations, and consulates in the first place, would not be able to manage. This would put already vulnerable populations in even more difficulty.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The migration crisis cannot be blurred with the refugee crisis, nor can it respond to the demographic problems of some Member States. Only a fraction of the masses heading to Europe are genuine refugees, most of whom we can help by supporting reception camps close to their country. If they can be provided with dignible conditions, health care and education, we will make it easier for them to return to their home countries as the situation stabilises. At the same time, for the immigrant masses arriving in the hope of a better livelihood, any ambigrat gestures are interpreted as invitations. Solidarity can take many forms, not artificially imposed mandatory quotas.  The Hungarian People's Party delegation could not vote in favour of the report on migration adopted today because it is unacceptable for them to centrally say who is being put on our hands and for others to decide who should be allowed into our own Member States and with whom to live.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. This text is the result of a long work of compromise which has the merit of coming out of the proposals crafted urgently, under the pressure of events, and of considering the issue of migration in a global way. While some of the Commission's proposals, published on 6 April 2016, for the revision of the Dublin Regulation and the common European asylum system clearly undermine the asylum system in Europe, this initiative report calls for a central system that would collect, process and distribute asylum applications from hotspots, through a "distribution key" system for each Member State based on just and objective criteria. The influx of refugees imposes an exercise in redefining the European project, outlined in this text which I support.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support this resolution because I find in it fundamental bottleg points that I do not identify with. This is mainly the adoption of a system of permanent redistribution quotas. The adopted text also stresses that, when implementing relocation, the preferences of the asylum seeker should be taken into account as far as possible in order to prevent secondary migration within the Union as far as possible. However, we know from experience that previous attempts to introduce quotas have been unsuccessful. The one-off quota system adopted last year, despite opposition from some states, is not working. Of the 160,000 people from Italy and Greece, only a few hundred have been relocated. Moreover, the rapporteurs have not put forward a way of dividing refugees in solidarity between Member States, while at the same time satisfying asylum seekers in their preferences for the destination State. I believe that neither the permanent relocation mechanism nor the proposed asylum system are appropriate instruments to provide a lasting and acceptable solution to the migration crisis. On the contrary, I welcome the efforts to reform the Blue Card Directive, which will allow the efficient use of skilled labour. We should focus on the consistent protection of Schengen's external borders and the systematic acquisition of information on incoming immigrants. There is no point in constantly returning to the issue of mandatory quotas if we are unable to guard Europe's borders and effectively register incoming immigrants.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the creation of "new safe and lawful routes" to enable asylum seekers and refugees to enter the EU. It also advocates the establishment of legal economic migration channels. Finally, it aims at the standardisation of the common European asylum system and defends a distribution mechanism, as well as family reunification. The encouragement of mass immigration directly threatening the security, cohesion and social system of European countries, as well as their macroeconomic balance, I voted against this text. Moreover, the asylum criteria should not be imposed by the European Union but should remain at the discretion of each country.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration, as it is a continuation of the cowardly liberal policy. The report sets out as key priorities the establishment of a mandatory system for the redistribution of migrants, the replacement of the existing Dublin Regulation with a centralised asylum application procedure organised by European hotspots (so that a person will effectively apply for asylum across the EU rather than in a single Member State), and more legal legal routes for economic migrants.  This is completely inconsistent with my understanding of dealing with the immigration wave that is flooding Europe. I and my EQF colleagues believe that the priorities should be to increase controls at the European Union's external borders, increase the effectiveness of repatriation of failed asylum seekers, and spend more funding on Europol, the European Asylum Support Office and FRONTEX.

Only a fraction of the masses heading to Europe are genuine refugees, most of whom we can help by supporting reception camps close to their country. The Hungarian People's Party delegation could not vote in favour of the report on migration adopted today because it is unacceptable for them to centrally say who is being put on our hands and for others to decide who should be allowed into our own Member States and with whom to live.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The migration crisis is a huge political challenge in several EU Member States. This report advocates a "holistic approach" to migration and highlights the need to review the Dublin III Regulation, which determines the Member State responsible for managing a particular asylum application. The report calls on Member States to fulfil their obligations on the urgent resettlement of refugees and to provide technical and financial assistance to EU countries at the forefront with the aim of improving the functioning of reception centres. I voted in favour.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the report we are to vote on, we welcome the efforts to highlight the inadequacy of current migration and asylum policies at European and international level, as well as the need for greater harmonisation. In particular, we agree with the part relating to the revision of the Dublin system, in order to make the principle of solidarity effective and to establish fair criteria for sharing the responsibility of the Member States for the distribution of refugees.  We expect the Member States and the European Union to also demonstrate the political will to take action to influence the root causes of migratory flows, namely situations of war, poverty, corruption, hunger and lack of opportunity, to which arms sales, financial and political support from dictatorial regimes and the exploitation of third-country resources have contributed.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report follows a logic, only apparently paradoxical, of criticizing to facilitate acceptance. It certainly contains some positive and critical proposals on aspects more mediated by the media. However, the general sense, the political position it adopts, understakes the political choices of the Council, the European Commission and the European Parliament. There is no single paragraph or a single line in this report denouncing the EU's responsibilities in migration flows or clearly condemning the measures that have been implemented. The essential axes of the EU's migration policy in the face of this very serious humanitarian crisis are the deepening of "Fortress Europe", with the criminalisation and expulsion of refugees and migrants, promoting a xenophobic and racist agenda, alongside other discriminatory, intolerance, authoritarian and anti-democratic practices. The Decisions of the March European Council confirm an inhuman and cruel policy, in clear violation of international law. They choose to deepen the militarized response to the drama of those fleeing extreme poverty, hunger and military conflicts, closing them in the sinister circle of war that doubly condemns them. The recently concluded agreement illustrates the EU's hypocrisy and the total absence of basic values of respect for human and democratic rights. They're reasons for our vote against.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which I think is an appropriate way to assess the various policies at stake in the areas of migration, asylum and border control, as well as to develop a set of recommendations and a plan that encompasses both short-term and long-term responses.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft report does not address the situation of migrants already on European Union territory and does not take into account the position of some Member States rejecting mandatory redistribution. Moreover, we have a debate on the fundamental rights of migrants and on what moral right any institution or national government has to decide on their future location or on sending them to a country where they are not interested in living.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The policy of mass migration is not a solution to Europe's demographic and labour problem. On the contrary, it leads to population change, the dismantling of the social fabric and unfortunately Islamisation with the accessories of the creation of jihadist terrorist pockets. Open borders policy is an incentive and encouragement for greater incursion of illegal immigrants into Europe. A Europe which, on the altar of multiculturalism and diversity, has lost its moral values and is seeking to lose the national consciousness and homogeneity of the Member States.  For the above reasons I am voting against report A8-0066/2016.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support a fundamental overhaul of the Dublin III Regulation, in favour of a centralised Union system for allocating responsibility for all those arriving in the Union who are seeking international protection fairly among the Member States – treating each asylum seeker as someone seeking asylum in the Union, and not in an individual Member State – based on fair and objective criteria along the lines of those used in the recent Urgent Relocation Decisions. Moreover, I welcome the call for a permanent, robust and effective Union response in search and rescue operations at sea in the context of a Union wide humanitarian operation. Finally, I believe the Union should establish more general rules governing the entry and residence of third country nationals seeking employment in the Union to fill gaps identified in the Union labour market.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes a long-term strategy for a genuine comprehensive, common and humanitarian management of the migration crisis in Europe. It is a structured and balanced document, in which the principle of solidarity underlies the proposed approach. Solidarity, both internally between Member States and externally towards third countries, is divided into a series of measures, such as relocation and resettlement systems. The document also makes recommendations for the successful integration of refugees into the EU and the inclusion of vulnerable people. Furthermore, the report also looks at the external dimension of this policy, stressing the importance of strengthening the protection of external borders, which also requires strengthening EU agencies and effectively combating the smuggling of migrants. Finally, I welcome the emphasis on cooperation with third countries, which remains unavoidable if we are to address the root causes of migration flows and anticipate future crises as much as possible.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report considering the serious humanitarian situation facing the EU. Member States should understand that it is imperative that the EU has the capacity and means to combat human trafficking and irregular immigration, and that it has a common asylum policy capable of responding to the challenges posed by the exodus of several million Syrian refugees. We must protect those with the right to international protection, while showing our determination to control our borders, preventing the illegal entry of economic immigrants and returning to all those who are not susceptible to international protection. The only real solution to ensure the survival of Schengen is the creation of a true common European external border, with greater powers for Frontex, as well as a common asylum policy. If we are unable to ensure external control of EU borders, the Schengen free movement area is in serious danger of disappearing under eu migration pressure.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it.  Immigration may be the most important challenge the EU has posed because it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are.  The importance of this report lies in its purpose of addressing the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea - to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit - and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a quota for the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of "humanitarian visas" and the promotion of legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as the strengthening of our commitment to human-exploiting mafias and the consolidation of reception and integration policies, is important.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it.  Immigration is perhaps the most important challenge the EU has posed because, like the refugee crisis, it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are.  The importance of this report is that it addresses the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea, to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a share of the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of Humanitarian Visas and promoting legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as redouble our commitment against mafias exploiting people and improving reception and integration policies, is important.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Mr President, I should like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent report. Kyenge has done a very valuable job of analysis and elaboration on the sensitive issue of migration policy reforms.  In recent months, as we know, the refugee emergency has disruptively characterized our topicality and public debate. The text we have voted on is marked by a very responsible approach, stressing in particular the need for an overall reform of the phenomenon of migration, for which ordinary choices and legislation are certainly not sufficient, but which instead requires a strong political will based on solidarity between The European States and on the solution of the problems at the root of the flows.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's non-legislative resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to immigration, because I shared the main idea behind this own-initiative report in which the EP wanted to give the Commission precise indications on the problem of migration, as well as clear signals to the Council on the urgency and need to review the Dublin rules , overcome by the crisis, through a binding European mechanism, because we are facing a European problem. I supported the EP's demands, and in particular European asylum, a binding resettlement mechanism that aims to overcome the Dublin Regulation with a European reception system, so that an application for asylum no longer arises for Italy or Greece, but for the EU. Member States are therefore asked to fulfil their obligations to relocate asylum seekers within the EU, in accordance with the principle of solidarity and full sharing of common responsibilities.  Furthermore, I shared the need for a binding mechanism for the resettlement of a considerable number of asylum seekers directly from third-country refugee camps to the Member States, the so-called 'humanitarian corridors'. Now is the time for legislative action.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I, as my group's shadow rapporteur responsible, ultimately voted against the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. As much as I would like to see more European approaches to refugee policy – and formulated them back in June 2015 in the "asylum agenda" of the German Family Party that I drafted – I do not share many of the positions in the dossier adopted today. We need more pragmatic solutions. We need more compliance with existing law rather than constantly new approaches.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. According to Frontex, 1.83 million people tried to cross European borders in 2015. Addressing the current situation requires a single European solution in the form of a corresponding distribution of refugees and a single European asylum system. A country alone cannot cope with this conflict. Mutual solidarity is needed.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In an attempt to find consensus, the co-rapporteurs produced a report that not only lacked any real ambition, but was also without clear proposals on how to tackle the migrant crisis. The priorities of the UK conservative delegation, as well as the ECR Group more broadly, were also not properly considered and as a result, were left out of the final version of the text. Instead of focusing on issues such as enhancing border controls, combatting human trafficking and resettlement, the report emphasised the importance of a compulsory EU wide system and measures that would directly interfere with national immigration policy. The report’s policy recommendations did not therefore offer a sensible or sustainable solution to the current crisis Europe is facing.  I firmly believe that Member States are best placed to set their own national immigration policy and that offering relocation and resettlement of refugees should be done on a voluntary basis. Opting in to EU legislation in this area should only occur when there is clear added value to the UK’s immigration system and the British people. On this occasion, I do not believe this was the case. It is for these reasons that I voted against.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. For this report on immigration, especially illegal, left and right saw fit to join and finally be honest in showing that their positions are the same: the Union must take in as many migrants as possible, even if the Europeans do not agree and even if these migrants are dangerous.  Fortunately, this report has no legislative effect, but it will justify the future binding arrangements taken by the Member States under the Commission's leadership, for the compulsory distribution of migrants in all countries.  This report proposes, among other things, to create direct air bridges, to grant asylum according to the declared sexual orientations, omitting European women who have been raped by self-proclaimed homosexual migrants. It obviously supports family reunification and transforms every emergency intention (asylum for unaccompanied minors or excised women for example) into a new route of immigration that will be exploited by smugglers at the expense of local populations.  By following the proposals of this report, the Union would not only go against the will of the peoples of Europe, but it would itself be complicit in the trade it encourages.  I have, of course, voted against this report, whose sole purpose is to promote mass immigration.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on the basis that, despite some progress on the original text and with regard to the current terms of EU migration and asylum policy, the text enshrines the validity of the unacceptable and illegal EU-Turkey Agreement which implies the irresponsible relocation of the management of the European migration and asylum and refuge system to countries where disrespect for human rights is evident and systematic.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to ensure a compassionate and organised response to the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War. Europe urgently needs to take a global approach to migration based on the principle of solidarity between states. Member States urgently need to uphold their responsibilities and show solidarity with countries on the periphery such as Greece and Italy by offering humanitarian assistance, quickly implementing the relocation agreement and working together to enhance safer and legal routes to Europe.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it.  Immigration is perhaps the most important challenge the EU has posed because, like the refugee crisis, it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are.  The importance of this report is that it addresses the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea, to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a share of the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of Humanitarian Visas and promoting legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as redouble our commitment against mafias exploiting people and improving reception and integration policies, is important.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. With 3,771 people drowning trying to reach Europe in 2015 and 1.83 million people attempting to cross the EU's external borders, it was high time to react on all fronts of migration policy. The European Parliament has long advocated a comprehensive, common and supportive approach to migration, in order to share responsibilities equitably, while placing fundamental rights at the heart of the process. This report sets out this position and aims to tackle all facets of the migration challenge. Indeed, it proposes avenues of action that include cooperation with the countries of origin of migrants, the fight against human trafficking, hot spots, the Schengen area, the management of external borders, the reception and integration of third-country nationals.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report, at a time when the EU is sinking into tinkering. In view of the revision of the Dublin Regulation, the Common European Asylum Scheme and the Commission's proposals on legal migration routes, I welcome the adoption of this text which proposes the reorientation of migration policy, a policy that must be comprehensive, forward-looking, coherent, supportive and protective.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The report presented comprehensive information on the current migration situation in the region.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The situation in the Mediterranean is perhaps one of the biggest problems facing the EU today, but also humanity as a whole.  The report contains important positive references, which we have highlighted on many occasions. The need for practical solidarity, the report of the failure of the Dublin Regulation and the call for the creation of legal and safe routes, the sharing of responsibilities in the Member States and the protection of the rights of refugees are some of them.  However, the report follows the stumbling block by supporting NATO's involvement in the Aegean Sea, strengthening border controls that make Europe a fortress and sustain crime against refugees. Furthermore, as a group we have spoken out against the EU-Turkey agreement and the report calls for it to be implemented. For these reasons, we consider this abstention to be an appropriate attitude.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour colleagues, I voted in favour of this report which gives key recommendations to the Commission as well as Member States to ensure a compassionate and organised response to the refugee situation. Europe urgently needs to take a global approach to migration based on the principle of solidarity between states. Member States urgently need to uphold their responsibilities and show solidarity with countries on the periphery such as Greece and Italy by offering humanitarian assistance, quickly implementing the relocation agreement and working together to enhance safer and legal routes to Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I have decided to abstain on this report, of which I recognise certain qualities but which I cannot endorse in its entirety. Indeed, unlike the majority, I do not share the principle of a binding and permanent mechanism for the resettlement of refugees. I believe that Member States must remain responsible for the management of arrivals on their territory in terms of their needs and specificities. I do not forget, however, that the migration issue would be better managed if states were more united. That is why I remain in favour of a voluntary and temporary resettlement mechanism. Similarly, I am opposed to the creation of a European humanitarian visa which, in the current drafting, would have the effect of increasing applications on a global scale and thus overburdening our embassies and consulates, which do not necessarily have the adequate staff in terms of number and skills to deal with this risk of influx.  Finally, all the recommendations on integration, family reunification and the development of legal immigration channels leave me very cautious.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current situation in the Mediterranean is a human tragedy of unprecedented proportions. It is essential that the EU takes an affirmative and holistic approach to this grave situation and I believe that this report was well balanced and fair.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, honourable Members, I am grateful for the impressive support both in the LIBE Committee and in voting today on the amendment I proposed, that countries on the frontline which are not part of the Schengen area can participate and benefit from the establishment of a European Border and Coast Guard on equal grounds with the Schengen States. It is particularly significant for countries such as Bulgaria and Romania, which are tasked with the responsible task of defending external borders of the European Union, but which, despite the criteria for admission, remain outside the Schengen area. Insisting on the abolition of Europe at two speeds, I will continue to work for the equal treatment of Bulgaria and Romania in the formation and operation of the European Border and Coast Guard in all reports that lie ahead.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration, because it is necessary to establish a long-term strategy for a common asylum and migration policy as soon as possible, as it is now clear to everyone that the current solution does not produce the desired results. To be able to plan an EU policy towards the Mediterranean in the long term, we need to openly analyse our actions so far in Libya and Iraq.  I give my full support to the implementation of the new Dublin Agreement. I am convinced that only cooperation between all EU member states can result in the solution of the migrant crisis in the Mediterranean. Moreover, I believe it is necessary to ensure safe and legal routes for those seeking asylum within the European Union, and to perfect the asylum system in such a way that it is primarily based on sharing responsibility and solidarity.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report (33 pages, plus the opinions of 8 other commissions) has 134 paragraphs. It is a veritable three Swiss catalogue from the immigration lobby. Some examples: it calls for the creation of "new safe and lawful routes" to enable asylum seekers and refugees to enter the EU (considering R) as well as for the establishment of "appropriate" channels of legal economic migration (considering V and W) and for the blue card system (para. 131); it wants new measures to make the common European asylum system a 'truly uniform system' (para. 28), favours the overhaul of the Dublin system in the sense of more 'solidarity', thus through a distribution mechanism (para. 38), and encourages Member States to 'ensure the preservation of family unity', thus facilitating the snowball effect of family reunification (para. 49). I then voted against this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report and we have tabled RCV for particular areas of the report in which we strongly disagree with the text. In particular, UKIP believes that national sovereign governments should have the right to control their own borders and should not be forced to take migrants under an EU resettlement scheme. Similarly, we are also concerned with segments of the report which suggest that the EU should create rules governing the entry and residence of third country nationals. UKIP has, however, supported aspects of the report which criticise the Schengen Area as a facilitator and accelerator of both the migrant crisis and the movement of terrorists within Europe.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While there were some aspects of this report which I felt were balanced and correct, I could not support it overall due to its support of a mandatory resettlement scheme for refugees. I remain convinced that such schemes are not the correct way to deal with the migration crisis. The EU should instead have implemented, from the beginning of the crisis, the Temporary Protection Directive. This tool would have granted short term access to the EU for those refugees fleeing the war in Syria. Should the war come to an end and the situation improve in the region, those granted temporary protection would be able to return home. Indeed, this report points out that the Temporary Protection Directive should have been used when Europe faced a mass influx of refugees. I support the call in the report for clarification of the term ‘mass influx’ and believe that if a similar crisis were to arise in the future, the Temporary Protection Directive should be the first mechanism used by the EU to help deal with it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Roberta Metsola and Kashetu Kyenge on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive approach to the issue of migration on the part of the European Union. The report aims to assess several policies on the issues of migration, asylum and border control. It is also a matter of ensuring the integration of migrants or ensuring the return of those who do not meet the protection criteria, as well as cooperating more with Turkey to manage migration flows. In view of the current situation, the validation of such a report seems essential.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This text, which has no legal value, aims to discuss various issues related to the migration issue, such as relocations and resettlement, and to propose a long-term strategy for managing the refugee crisis. However, while some elements are interesting, I abstained because the text proposed a number of ineffective or undesirable proposals in the face of the refugee crisis we are currently experiencing.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe is currently experiencing flows of refugees that have not been seen since the Second World War. The war in the Middle East and poverty in Africa are forcing thousands of people to seek refuge and a better life in Europe. We must not turn our backs on those people fleeing war, but we must not accept those who want to come to Europe for a better life. First of all, we need to arrange for the protection of the external borders and find the opportunity to return them to safe third countries. Uncontrolled human flow is not allowed. Unfortunately, in my opinion, the European Parliament resolution does not sufficiently emphasise the need to organise external borders. I do not believe that it is fair to propose that refugees be distributed by Member State forcibly. Such a mechanism has already shown that it is incapacitation. Nor is it possible to support the proposal to set up a European Union Office for the Screening of Refugees, which will decide which refugees and in what number should be admitted, thus imposing criteria on the Member States. Member States should have the right to determine this themselves. Given that the resolution does not offer a solution to the situation, but it is only complicated, I voted 'no'.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which gives key recommendations to the Commission as well as Member States to ensure a compassionate and organised response to the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War. Europe urgently needs to take a global approach to migration based on the principle of solidarity between states. Member States urgently need to uphold their responsibilities and show solidarity with countries on the periphery such as Greece and Italy by offering humanitarian assistance, quickly implementing the relocation agreement and working together to enhance safer and legal routes to Europe.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report seeks to provide a holistic response to the challenges posed by the current migration and refugee movements to Europe. The report contains good approaches, for example on combating trafficking in human beings and smuggling, improving rescue measures for migrants or strengthening aid for those in need of protection on the ground. However, the rapporteurs want to introduce compulsory redistributionof asylum seekers between EU Member States. As the last few months have shown, this will not work. It would be far more promising to fulfil humanitarian obligations to those in need of protection, preferably in crisis-prone regions, and to involve the Member States additionally through voluntary commitments regarding the reception of asylum seekers. The report also advocates increased economic migration to Europe, which is unrealistic in view of the sometimes high unemployment rates in individual Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration once again concealed support for quotas for the redistribution of refugees, I could not support this document in principle. The report as a whole contained good points, but I think it is time for us to stop rechedubling quotas over and over again and concentrate on other work. The vote on proposals in plenary often resembles a walk in a minefield rather than a solid job, as support for quotas is in various documents. We are still not addressing what is at the beginning of the whole issue and we are talking about quotas. Over and over again. We are not presented with an alternative. I think I will also speak for the citizens of the Czech Republic when I say that we are tired of this and we are asking for a change of approach.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The migration crisis cannot be blurred with the refugee crisis, nor can it respond to the demographic problems of some Member States. Only a fraction of the masses heading to Europe are genuine refugees, most of whom we can help by supporting reception camps close to their country. If they can be provided with dignible conditions, health care and education, we will make it easier for them to return to their home countries as the situation stabilises.  At the same time, for the immigrant masses arriving in the hope of a better livelihood, any ambigrat gestures are interpreted as invitations. Solidarity can take many forms, not artificially imposed mandatory quotas.  The Hungarian People's Party delegation could not vote in favour of the report on migration adopted today, because it is unacceptable for them to centrally say who is being put on our hands, so that others decide who should be allowed into our own Member States and with whom to live.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The positive points of this report are the recognition of solidarity as a principle for migration, not to criminalise NGOs which provide assistance, the call on Member States to fulfil relocation obligation and the need for a binding and mandatory legislative approach to resettle refugees. I voted in favour of this report, since it goes beyond existing resolutions and tries to facilitate the asylum procedure.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 In EU policy and legislation, the plight of indigenous European minorities is, for some reason, constantly forgotten to enforce fundamental solidarity and humaneness. At the same time, in the case of masses of unknown origin, nationality and intentions who often burn their documents and conceal their personal data, the union's officials are fully supportive, in unison with the vast majority of NGOs and the press. On the basis of humaneity, Europe has exactly as many obligations in terms of accepting refugees as rich Gulf countries. Moreover, the latter are understaffed and are almost culturally identical.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 While appreciating the effort made in preparing the report on the need for a holistic EU approach to migration and supporting the overall direction of humanitarian aid to migrants and the eradication of the illegal smuggling industry that has accrued in recent years, I strongly oppose some of the thesis and proposals contained in the document.  First of all, I do not support criticism of those countries that, in order to properly exercise national and EU border protection law, build walls and fences, carefully inspect every asylum application and call for assistance to migrants in situ or in transit non-European countries.  Secondly, I do not agree with the argument expressed several times that only a binding relocation mechanism will bring a solution to the migration crisis. The opposite is true: this mechanism weakens the determination of border countries in the EU to stem the flow of refugees and effectively combat irregular migration.   Thirdly, I do not agree that accepting refugees can be a cure for the European demographic collapse and the associated labour shortage. A much better solution to this problem would be legal labour migration, where the process of integration into the labour market is faster, cheaper and less risky for unwelcome infiltration.  In this context, the European Commission should consider amending the Blue Card Directive to include groups of workers other than highly qualified professionals.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Undoubtedly, nowadays we are facing unprecedented migration crisis across the Mediterranean. Undoubtedly, we are in need of a holistic approach in order to tackle effectively the migrant crisis, its scale and the complexity of the problems related to it. In fact, such a holistic approach we can find in the roadmap proposed by the ALDE to get a grip of a migrant crisis. The roadmap proposes seven urgent measures such as creation of European Rapid Refugee Emergency Force (ERREF), establishment of European Border and Coast Guard (EBCG), creation of European Blue card for economic migrants, peace plan and Marshall Plan for the Mediterranean region. I believe that the EU should implement these measures in order not only to grip of migration crisis but also to strengthen global approach to migration and mobility.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have expressed my positive opinion on this proposal, in view of the need to create a holistic system involving economic and political cooperation between the EU Member States on the migration crisis.  In the current scenario, the reassessment of the policies envisaged for the management of the migration flow, asylum and European borders is urgently urgent. The border states, and Italy in particular, cannot be left alone, as they are unable to resolve the migration crisis, which has taken on momentous proportions. This is a global problem which must therefore receive a comprehensive solution, focusing on the aspects of reception and solidarity with the necessary security profiles for citizens.  I would like to thank the report-readers for their work, which has lasted over a year, and for defining the European Parliament's position on a very sensitive issue, which will be able to act as a basis for work on the legislative packages now under review. We need concrete action, such as the revision of the Dublin Convention, the provision of resources to deal with the crisis and the definition of a common and coordinated policy.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am in favour of solidarity between EU Member States, but I cannot support an EU asylum policy based on mandatory allocation quotas. It is clear that the forced element on such a sensitive issue, which concerns a wide range of spheres, including those that are fundamentally within the competence of EU Member States, from education to national security, will not be effective. Eu Member States facing unprecedented migratory pressures need to be helped, but solidarity should not be seen as a direct resettlement of refugees. No less important, and in particular, are other measures, such as effective management of the southern EU border, assistance in hotspots, contribution to and appropriate arrangements for the capacity of third countries concerned to manage migration flows, the creation of refugee centres in the EU's neighbourhood and the elimination of the direct causes of migration.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report on the European Union's migration policy defends European leadership and solidarity in the management of the migrant crisis. Based on the current failures and the need to create safe migration channels for asylum seekers, the European Parliament supports the creation of a central system for registering and distributing asylum applications, backed by a strengthening of European borders with the creation of European border guards to support countries in difficulty. It is therefore a necessary European approach that is being defended to manage asylum applications and, above all, to allow a fair distribution of asylum seekers among European countries. But this report unfortunately fishes on the question of respect for the fundamental rights of these men, women and children who are fleeing their country, by not going back on the outsourcing of the problem to countries like Turkey and by allowing themselves to be overwhelmed by the security aspects of the European response.  That is why I have chosen to abstain on this report, which addresses the right angle of response: a European response, not confiscated by national selfishness, but which forgets the necessary human dimension.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the 'need for a comprehensive approach to the issue of migration on the part of the European Union'. It is a veritable three Swiss catalogue from the immigration lobby.  Here are some examples. It calls for the creation of "safe and lawful new routes" to enable asylum seekers and refugees to enter the EU (considering R). It advocates the establishment of "appropriate" channels of legal economic migration (considering V and W) and the blue card system (para. 131). He wants new measures to make the common European asylum system a "truly uniform system" (para. 28). He favours the overhaul of the Dublin system in the sense of more 'solidarity', thus through a distribution mechanism (para. 38). It encourages Member States to "ensure the preservation of family unity" and therefore wants to facilitate the snowball effect of family reunification (para. 49). This report therefore aims to solve the problem of mass immigration through more mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this long report because it is a text that wants to organise two legal channels of mass immigration: -one for asylum seekers, to whom it wants to open "safe routes"; -the other for economic migrants, which he wants to bring in millions (!) to compensate for the demographic deficit of some European countries like Germany. The anti-Schengen amendment of the ENL group, which wanted to recall that "the abolition of internal borders contributes to uncontrolled immigration and terrorism", received only 73 votes out of 751. Poor France!

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. From the outset, he wants to plunge the European Union into mass immigration, and catalogues proposals that are more outliers than the others.  For example, it calls for the creation of "new safe and lawful routes" for asylum seekers and refugees, for the establishment of channels of legal economic migration, for a standardisation of the European asylum system, complementary to the Dublin system, which tends towards more solidarity through a distribution mechanism, etc. In view of the current situation of agricultural and economic crisis, the European Union continues to revel in the destruction of an already cracked Europe, and adds a serious social crisis to the list of ills of the Member States and their citizens.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it.  Immigration is perhaps the most important challenge the EU has posed because, like the refugee crisis, it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are.  The importance of this report is that it addresses the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea, to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a share of the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of Humanitarian Visas and promoting legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as redouble our commitment against mafias exploiting people and improving reception and integration policies, is important.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it.  Immigration is perhaps the most important challenge the EU has posed because, like the refugee crisis, it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are.  The importance of this report is that it addresses the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea, to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a share of the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of Humanitarian Visas and promoting legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as redouble our commitment against mafias exploiting people and improving reception and integration policies, is important.
