name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is a missed opportunity for the LIBE Commission to put on the agenda the problems currently faced by people trying to reach the EU. Instead of requiring the issuance of humanitarian visas or ensuring that no collective expulsions are carried out (prohibited by international law and enshrined in the EU-Turkey agreement), it has been chosen to maintain the current aggressive policy imposed by the Commission and the Council. Although the agreement includes positive things, such as the need to create secure access routes, or the need to overcome the Dublin System and the states welcome, these issues are mentioned without concrete measures, so they are left empty again. However, it details the plan to militarize the Mediterranean with nato's help, the need for returns, cooperation with military and security forces from third countries, or the development of a list of safe countries from which asylum claims will not be accepted, in clear violation of the Geneva Convention. For all this, we have not had to vote against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to assess the different policies involved and the latest data from different agencies and associations on the situation of migrants and refugees who arrived or attempt to reach the EU, as well as applications that were submitted for international protection. It also makes an assessment of the damage, which lacks means, such as disappearances and deaths, of men, women and children who risk their lives every day in order to seek a better life.  This report also considers human trafficking and labour exploitation arising from these extreme situations and awareness of the need to take steps to prevent it.  I support its approval because it also runs on the different measures that the Commission implements and/or proposes to improve border management and stresses the need for safe routes for both refugees and economic immigrants to have the protection they need.   Taking into account the considerations set out above and the importance of cooperation and coordination in this regard at European level, I vote in favour for approval.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report seeks to provide a holistic response to the challenges posed by the current migration and refugee movements to Europe. The report contains good approaches, for example on combating trafficking in human beings and smuggling, improving rescue measures for migrants or strengthening aid for those in need of protection on the ground. However, the rapporteurs want to introduce compulsory redistributionof asylum seekers between EU Member States. As the last few months have shown, this will not work. It would be far more promising to fulfil humanitarian obligations to those in need of protection, preferably in crisis-prone regions, and to involve the Member States additionally through voluntary commitments regarding the reception of asylum seekers. The report also advocates increased economic migration to Europe, which is unrealistic in view of the sometimes high unemployment rates in individual Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report says that migrant relocation is a "practical example of solidarity within the Union", that the relocation proposal is a "step in the right direction", that the Union needs a "binding and mandatory legislative approach to resettlement" and that "a permanent resettlement programme at Union level with compulsory participation by Member States should be put in place to allow the resettlement of a significant number of refugees". I reject the mandatory quotas for the relocation of migrants, and I consider European migration policy to be a huge and fatal failure.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The report tosses on the different elements that are crucial in addressing the refugee crisis, the first being the principle of solidarity, where it stresses that the EU must act on the principle of solidarity covering asylum, migration and border control policies. Smuggling, labour exploitation and trafficking in human beings are different criminal offences from a legal perspective and are subject to a different legal framework at Union level.  Human smuggling networks can easily change their way of working and therefore it is necessary to quickly adapt the response and how to respond to such crimes. There are several Union financial instruments that can finance Member States and third countries in the fields of refugees, asylum and border management, so states should be encouraged to take advantage of all the opportunities they are given. I supported the report, as the refugee crisis must stabilise and the only way to achieve this is through solidarity between Member States.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 If the Union wants to maintain its existing integrity and be safe for its people, it must strengthen its position on the current migration crisis. The policy in this area to date has raised natural mistrust and doubts among eu citizens and in the authorities of some Member States about the Union's strength and ability to solve this fundamental and ongoing problem. They see solutions as liqueuring, poorly effective and accepted almost always belatedly. The Union is still not sufficiently prepared for the migration crisis, lacking foresight and decisiveness, as evidenced by the continuing blossoming smuggling that has become an illegal source of high incomes, which ultimately harms, among other things, the EU's economic and financial interests.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. Eu Member States committed to taking in 160,000 asylum seekers at the end of 2015. To date, just over a thousand have been relocated from Italy and Greece to the rest of Europe.  In doing so, Member States have failed to meet their commitments. After the recent conclusion of the highly criticised agreement with Turkey, this initiative report reaffirms Parliament's voice in the ongoing debate. This text thus proposes many concrete avenues on all fronts of migration policy: cooperation with countries of origin, including on development, European arrangements for the reception and resettlement of refugees or the fight against migrant trafficking and human trafficking. I welcome this and therefore vote in favour of this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the situation in the Mediterranean region and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/4/2016, and because this report is not substantiated.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the need for a comprehensive EU approach to the migration phenomenon. I believe that the priority is securing the external borders. Avoiding loss of life due to the sinking of boats in the Mediterranean is achieved most easily and efficiently by blocking them at arm. There is a need for an effective contribution to calming conflicts in refugee areas of origin. Reforming the Union Visa Code Regulation, revising the Blue Card, strengthening the FRONTEX Agency's capacity to respect fundamental rights, including by authorities in third countries, and EASO's involvement in agreements with third countries are actions to be regulated at European level in the coming months. The European asylum system remains another area that needs to be regulated. There is also a need to speed up negotiations on the Smart Borders Package. With regard to legal labour migration, I believe that the EU must regulate the entry and residence of third-country nationals seeking work in the EU as soon as possible. The unregulated influx of economic migrants must not be justified by the reason for the demographic decline in the EU. The youth unemployment rate is around 20%, so the gaps in the labour market must be filled primarily by these young people.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Our approach to the migration situation in the Mediterranean must start from the premise that saving lives must be a first priority and that proper funding, at Union and Member State level, for search and rescue operations is essential. We must sadly note that there has been an increase in the number of irregular arrivals by sea and an alarming increase in the number of deaths at sea, and that a better European response is still required

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to immigration. The report assesses the various policies at stake in the areas of immigration, asylum and border management. It would also be the first step in the subsequent adoption of Eu ropean Union guidelines on the crucial issue of migrants, based on a model that revolves around the principles of full shared responsibility and solidarity.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an important report that will transform the EU's approach to migration. I am pleased to see that the report calls for an end to the Dublin mechanism, which has disproportionately affected Greece, Italy and Malta. For a united Europe, everyone must share responsibility, both in terms of the number of migrants and the financial burden. Moving forward, it is also important to remember the problems of security, namely the control of external borders, as well as the monitoring of what is happening within them, and the recent attacks in Brussels demonstrate the urgent need for better controls in Europe. I agree with my colleague, Mrs McKenna, that we are not in a position to do so. Metsola, on the fact that there is no magic wand or the perfect solution to this problem, but we are taking the right steps, and that is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the situation in the Mediterranean Sea and the need for a comprehensive Union approach to migration which we have adopted in this Parliament makes clear the need for us to deal with the terrible situation currently being faced from unity and with an approach that takes into account all the factors involved in this crisis. Only in this way will the EU be given an answer to what is expected of us, because there are no easy exits or shortcuts, but we have to be brave and make decisions that allow us to reconcile the rights of people living in Europe and those who try to reach our continent fleeing war

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union is facing a series of crises that threaten its existence. These challenges include managing migration flows. The selfishness of a number of European states has dealt a further blow to the principle of solidarity, which is supposed to govern the functioning of the Union. In this context, the European Parliament - whose position is summed up by the Metsola/Kyenge report - is proving to be the only European institution capable of proposing a responsible and united plan for exiting the crisis. Since it is impossible to live in a constant geography of exodus, the report proposes to tackle resolutely the root causes of migration: wars, persecution, poverty, climate change. But this cooperation with third countries must not exempt European countries from taking a fair and equitable share in the reception of refugees: Europe must provide migrants with legal access routes. Finally, the Dublin Agreements have been a long time coming and it is now essential to create a permanent resettlement/relocation instrument to relieve front-line countries.   I voted for this report, which proposes ways that the European Commission must urgently explore in order to spare Europe another unglamorous compromise with Turkey.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 It is clear that the piecemeal efforts made by various non-governmental organisations are impossible to deal with one of the greatest crises facing humanity today. Frontex data for 2015 found 1.83 million people trying to cross EU borders illegally, compared to 282000 who arrived at the Union's borders in 2014. At the same time, 1.4 million asylum applications were submitted in 2015, according to the EASO. Most tragic of all, are the figures for the dead amounting to 3771 for 2015. Finally, 10000 unaccompanied children disappeared after arriving in the Union in the same year.  The above figures leave no room for contradiction and reveal the EU's duty to take immediate measures to tackle the problem. These measures must form part of a coordinated broader policy, inspired by a spirit of solidarity between Member States for effective assistance to countries receiving increased refugee flows at their borders. This holistic response to the refugee crisis should also include a radical revision of the Dublin II Regulation in favour of a centralised European system of fair and equitable distribution of applicants in the Member States according to reception possibilities.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report reports on the alarming situation in the Mediterranean: in 2015, 1.83 million people were apprehended while trying to cross the EU's borders illegally and more than 3,771 people disappeared in the Mediterranean during the same period. However, the report does not propose any solution. The EU-Turkey agreement, negotiated by the German government alone, is referred to as a "new cooperation initiative", even though it recognises some lines after "the appalling living conditions of millions of people living in refugee camps, especially in Turkey",. And even if there are some minor criticisms, "ship captains or non-governmental organizations that actually help people in distress at sea should not risk punishment for this purpose." I am voting against this text which legitimises the Union's disastrous migration policy.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This extended report is an inventory of the Immigrationist Prevert. It promotes, for example, family reunification - a powerful vehicle for mass immigration - by encouraging Member States to "ensure the preservation of family unity", which we oppose. As a result, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The humanitarian emergency experienced by the European Union in the context of the refugee crisis requires a coordinated and effective approach to migration. I reaffirm that Europe has, first of all, the obligation and lucidity to ensure security for its peoples. And then, because you are safe, you have an obligation to do others good and welcome refugees with humanism.  I share the view that any holistic approach to migration must necessarily contain measures to dismantle the activities of criminal networks involved in trafficking in human beings and the smuggling of persons. I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was proud to support the final text, after months of hard work with MEP Kyenge. The level of cross-party support for this report sends a strong message that this house needs to look beyond emergency measures for emergency situations and look towards a long term vision on this issue by pushing for the Union to adopt a holistic approach that provides the best opportunity to take responsible action as regards migration.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome The adoption by Parliament of its report on the need for a holistic European approach to migration. The result of long-term but fruitful work in the LIBE Committee, this report expresses Parliament's position on European migration policy and identifies avenues for reform for the future.  These avenues are in line with what the ALDE Group has been advocating for several months: the adoption of a resettlement mechanism, a complete overhaul of the Dublin system to ensure equitable sharing between Member States and substantial strengthening of the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) are all measures that will have to be taken to ensure the coherence and effectiveness of our asylum policy.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The complex migration crisis plaguing Europe urgently requires joint and coordinated action by all EU Member States in a spirit of solidarity and respect for international legal principles, in particular the provisions of the Geneva Convention for the Protection of Refugees. Under this document, a person who has been forced to leave his home country under threat of serious harm is entitled to asylum, thereby qualifying for international protection. A single asylum policy involving the establishment of a so-called 'asylum policy'. I therefore see the Common European Asylum System as a conditio sine qua non when it comes to harmonising the process of assessing individual asylum applications, speeding up the relevant administrative procedure and ultimately preventing an increase in the number of stateless persons. The solution, in my opinion, does not, under any circumstances, constitute the introduction of mandatory quotas which would significantly and de-iure unduly interfere with the exclusive competences of any sovereign state, or factually unfounded proposals for the need to abolish the Schengen Agreement. On the contrary, a starting point must be sought in a coherent policy and the efficient use of available resources. Dialogue with our foreign partners, such as Turkey, is crucial in this context, but it should not be a way of promising to open chapters in the accession process. I fully share the proposal to establish a list of safe countries, as well as the setting up of an action plan for the integration of asylum seekers on EU territory, both on a work and social scale.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'The SP Group abstained in the vote on the report. The SP has serious objections to the EU agreement with Turkey of 18 March 2016, as there are no guarantees that Syrian refugees will not be returned to Syria. Reports from Amnesty International, among others, show that this is happening, which is contrary to the Convention on Refugees.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration, which highlights the need of a well-rounded approach to migration. The main elements of any holistic approach to migration must include: a fundamental overhaul of the Dublin III Regulation, in favour of a centralised Union system for allocating responsibility among the Member States based on fair and objective criteria; a permanent, robust and effective Union response in search and rescue operations at sea in the context of a Union wide humanitarian operation; a binding and mandatory legislative approach to resettlement providing for resettlement of a meaningful number of refugees having regard to the overall number of refugees seeking protection in the Union;

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs not only argues for the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration, but also outlines a comprehensive approach. It takes a position on the establishment of a common and single European asylum system, in this context in addition to the revision of the Dublin III Regulation and the common and uniform protection of the Schengen borders, and urges the establishment of HOTSPOTS. It reiterates its call for the introduction of a mechanism for the distribution of asylum seekers between Member States. It focuses on facilitating the integration of refugees, the problems of family reunification, the vulnerable situation of children and, in particular, the problem of unaccompanied children who have been ripped away from their relatives. It also address and combat trafficking in human beings and trafficking in human beings. I supported the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. I express my concern at the incidents at the EU's borders as a result of this unprecedented migration crisis which have highlighted the shortcomings of the current refugee and migrant reception system. I believe that the current migrant and refugee crisis is largely due to the conflict in Syria and other parts of the Middle East, together with instability in the Middle East and North Africa region, and that the EU will have to play a leading role in ending this situation. I endorse the rapporteurs' position that the current migrant and refugee crisis in the Mediterranean can only be fought through sustained political will and international cooperation and coordination in all EU institutions and Member States, and that an international conference should be organised on the initiative of the EU under the auspices of the United Nations in order to respond to the current humanitarian crisis. It is important to highlight the vulnerability of women and children, especially unaccompanied women, as they are at risk of becoming victims of trafficking in human beings, and the importance of ensuring special care to this group, with psychological support and medical assistance, as well as adequate protection.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This comprehensive report on the situation in the Mediterranean and on migration to Europe calls for the introduction of far-reaching reforms for the pooling and management of migration: a common asylum system, a distribution system, facilitation of illegal immigration through the establishment of new routes, strengthening of family reunification, etc. Being opposed to this positive and naïve view of immigration, as well as its assumption at European level and above the sovereignty of States, I voted against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which gives key recommendations to the Commission as well as Member States to ensure a compassionate and organised response to the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War. Europe urgently needs to take a global approach to migration based on the principle of solidarity between states. Member States urgently need to uphold their responsibilities and show solidarity with countries on the periphery such as Greece and Italy by offering humanitarian assistance, quickly implementing the relocation agreement and working together to enhance safer and legal routes to Europe.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which supports the irresponsible policy of migrant quotas that the European Union has been pursuing for almost a year now and which only raises an air appeal for illegal immigration. In this text, everything calls for an unconditional reception of migrants when we are unable to welcome them with dignity (as evidenced by the "Jungle" of Calais or the slums that emerge at the gates of certain cities), to provide them with housing, a job or the means to integrate properly.  Almost nothing is said on the question of the return to their country of origin of illegal immigrants denied asylum: 40,000 a year in France alone, less than 10% of whom are actually deported. Our migration policy will only be credible and supported by our peoples when it is finally accompanied by a real firmness towards the illegal immigrants who are devoting the asylum chain.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, because the migration crisis facing the European Union today is unprecedented and only innovative and pragmatic solutions will enable Europe to respond to it. In this debate, there is no place for populism that delays the emergence of real solutions by fixing debates on lies.  As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I have particularly stressed the importance of the social inclusion of refugees. This can only be done through their professional integration. The emphasis must therefore be on language learning and recognition of diplomas and qualifications.  But I also wanted to warn the Member States that the relocation of refugees must take place in territories where they will have professional prospects.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. In view of the considerable pressure on Europe's borders, in particular those of the Mediterranean coastal States, weighted by the volumes involved in the phenomenon and assessed the dramatic situation in the countries of origin and humanitarian conditions during the crossings, I can only express my full and heartfelt support for the Metsola-Kyenge report. The intensive work in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has also enabled the legislative text to enjoy widespread and cross-party support from the European Parliament which, especially in these circumstances, could not lack a cohesive and strong voice.  The constant violations of human rights in the countries of the Middle East and North Africa and the resulting deep migration crisis require, on the European side, an essentially holistic and unified approach which, through a broad rethink of the legal framework laid down in the Dublin Regulation, makes measures to regulate migratory phenomena more effective and which wishes to see a common policy on political asylum. The establishment of a centralised allocation and relocation system at European level, governed by values of responsibility and equity, responds precisely to the need for a common European response to current and future crises.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I chose not to vote for the report on the situation in the Mediterranean, considering that the political line he defends cannot provide the necessary answers to restore legal and controlled migration to Europe. In particular, the report provides for a permanent and binding resettlement mechanism that ignores the reception capacity of Member States. Similarly, while the temporary re-establishment of internal borders has led to a reduction in flows, the report gives priority to support for the Schengen area at the expense of tighter controls. However, the report explores a number of important issues such as the necessary revision of the Dublin III protocols, the importance of combating the trafficking and exploitation of migrants and refugees, relocation and the European Union's obligation to rescue those who risk their lives crossing the Mediterranean in makeshift boats.  For all these reasons, and in a spirit of coherence and respect for the position of my political family, I chose to abstain.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The power to take in the country has not yet been transferred to the EU and I do not see the need for this in the future. That is why I voted again today against mandatory quotas. The forcibly introduced of such a permanent mechanism could only be ensured in principle by a permanent Schengen border closure, because without it, the resettled would sooner or later escape back to their chosen country of destination. The closure of Schengen is unacceptable to us.  A permanent migrant distribution system would only encourage economic migrants from all over the world who have been hesitant so far, which could trigger another, more huge wave of refugees. If, nevertheless, some Member States insist on central distribution, it is not only the British who should be exempted. However, this could not be achieved through lengthy international court proceedings, but through negotiations.  From a humanitarian point of view, it is unacceptable for me to forcily resettle groups of people, both from the point of view of the local population and from the point of view of immigrants.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that underlines the fact that solidarity should be the basic principle upon which the EU’s action on migration is based with the first priority to saving lives.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it presents the complexity of the migration problem, while managing to highlight the main problems that the EU has in managing this situation. I believe that the moral and legal obligation to seek and save people whose lives are endangered by the routes they choose to enter the territory of the Member States in an attempt to escape war is paramount. This obligation is directly linked to the need to combat migrant smuggling and to create legal and safe routes of entry into the EU. The development of these routes will help reduce accidents and give Member States a clearer overview of the real situation. It is also very important to stress the need to revise the Dublin III Regulation and the importance of a common solution, throughout the European Union, without which this problem cannot be managed.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the EU's approach to migration. The resolution, which is legally non-binding and which is not an opinion on the Commission's recent proposals in this area, has 134 points and contains many important elements, such as the emphasis on external border control and the fight against smuggling, the requirement to return failed asylum seekers, the need to maintain the Schengen system, the change in the Union's asylum policy, the need for a list of safe countries or the strengthening of Frontex. Point 23 refers to the need for a permanent system of resettlement of refugees, i.e. the migration of selected refugees from outside the EU to the Union as now agreed with Turkey. As I do not consider resettlement to be a central point in the context of the whole strategy, I did not support this point in the vote on this point. I did not hold the report as a whole accountable without presenting another approach to tackling the migration crisis. I do not see a better alternative for dealing with the migration crisis than a European one. No country is able to face the migration crisis alone, and a national solution can start a very dangerous disintegration of the Union for us.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the report calls for female asylum seekers entering the country to be granted independent legal status as part of family reunification. It also calls for a Europe-wide and centralised system for asylum applications, which is intended to ensure that competence is allocated.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the European Union's approach to managing the refugee crisis, because while the text contains positive points, such as the recognition of the principle of solidarity, opposition to the criminalisation of NGOs, the obligation to relocate and the creation of legal and safe routes for migration , it also includes a number of very negative points.  The report stresses the need to strengthen the effectiveness of the European return system, which runs counter to international law and fundamental rights, but also the need to maintain border controls and the rapid establishment of "hotsposts" at EU borders. It also stresses the role of third countries, such as Turkey, in the "management of illegal migration flows" and the need to outsource borders through cooperation agreements with third countries, including readmission agreements.  In the end, the report suggests that the European approach to migration will eventually become nothing more than a policy of sending back migrants, a vision far removed from the humanist aspirations that underpin the European Union.

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no simple solution to the current migration crisis in Europe. I very much respect the difficult work done by the co-rapporteurs, however, this report includes too many elements which are not acceptable to my country; it mixes asylum, labour market needs, demography and stateless persons. While coordinated approach is needed, and Latvia takes part in relocations from Italy and Greece; solidarity cannot be enforced. A permanent, mandatory resettlement programme for all EU MS on the basis of criteria such as the size of the country and the population density are unfair conditions. We need to finally implement existing rules, including the Dublin Regulation, instead of writing new. Asylum decisions are a national competence and I cannot support idea that people would apply to asylum in the EU and Brussels would decide to which MS and how many applicants are sent. Labour migration is a national competence; it is not Brussels which can determine the labour market needs of EU MS. Furthermore, the request to MS to reduce the number of stateless persons is unacceptable given that it goes beyond the scope of this report. Therefore I could not support the report on a holistic EU approach to migration.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. What is happening in the Mediterranean is a disgrace. This very comprehensive report is Parliament's hope that the Council and the Member States will stop turning their backs on all the tragedies that are happening every day. Because we don't just need texts and we don't need money, we need it too. We need political will. It is a very difficult situation that the EU will mark for the future.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted against this resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. It should be noted that a number of legislation on refugees has recently been adopted, but the solution to the problem has not moved out of place. Another resolution cannot change the situation. The European Union does not know what to do with refugees, but Community borders remain open to illegal migrants and there is a lack of political will for decisive action. Instead of preventing this, the EU institutions are looking only for new asylum opportunities. I do not believe that another permanent Union resettlement programme, which would require the participation of Member States and which provides for the resettlement of a large number of refugees, given the total number of refugees seeking international protection in the Union, will help to resolve the current situation. First of all, there is a need for the EU's external borders to be closed, that no illegal movement of migrants between the EU's internal borders must disappear and quotas must be abolished as a non-justified solution.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report on migration reinforces the whole inhuman framework of the EU's policy implemented by the SYRIZA-ANEL government against refugees and migrants, which is why the COMMUNIST Party voted against it.  The adjustments to Dublin III proposed in the report and the Commission's proposals signal a further strengthening of the conditions it imposes, explicitly providing for the return of asylum seekers from other Member States to Greece as a host country. It also includes sanctions against "secondary movements", legitimising the entrapment of thousands of refugees and migrants in our country. Asylum applications will only be accepted for those who are classified as "applicants in clear need of international protection", unacceptably limiting the concept of refugee and in violation of the Geneva Convention.  The proposed system already operates on the basis of hotspot-type detention centres, where cheap labour is sorted for the needs of monopolies. The rest are incarcerated and mass deportations. The single list of 'safe countries of origin' for all EU Member States is the driver of these expulsions. Along with popular solidarity, popular vigilance and the fight against the real causes of war and refugees, imperialist wars and competition, in which the Greek government is increasingly deeply involved, must be strengthened.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report and we have tabled RCVs for particular areas of the report in which we strongly disagree with the text. In particular, UKIP believes that national sovereign governments should have the right to control their own borders and should not be forced to take migrants under an EU resettlement scheme. Similarly, we are also concerned with segments of the report which suggest that the EU should create rules governing the entry and residence of third country nationals. UKIP has, however, supported aspects of the report which criticise the Schengen Area as a facilitator and accelerator of both the migrant crisis and the movement of terrorists within Europe.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas in the last period there has been an increase in irregular immigration in Europe; that providing assistance to those in dangerous conditions at sea is an obligation under international law of the sea; that there is often a tendency to assimilate those who are victims of trafficking in human beings and those who seek to enter Europe illegally; that the Dublin III Regulation should pay more attention to the conditions of European countries which, because of their geographical position, find themselves receiving migrants, I agree with the need for more effective action and with the need for the European Union to strengthen the protection of its borders. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the report and agree that only the EU can provide the right answers to the migration crisis, which is not a challenge only for the countries that face the Mediterranean, but also those facing the South—Eastern routes. Uncoordinated action from Member States is highly deterring and the EU is the best frame to endeavour a truly holistic approach.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In the way we have been managing the migrant crisis so far, we have lacked a good foundation – solidarity. We left it to the Member States to deal with a burden on their own that they could not cope with while at the same time trying to find a common response to the migrant crisis. In this regard, I welcome this resolution. Based on solidarity and shared responsibility, it puts before us a common European asylum system mechanism and calls for compliance with the obligations of all Member States to resettle and relocate. Existing legislation needs to be revised to be adapted to the time and situation we face and to be a guarantor of fairness and solidarity. This resolution recognises the particular pressure to which states located at the external borders are exposed. The rise in irregular arrivals in Europe, the rise in deaths and the rise in human trafficking must worry us all. Saving lives must be made a priority, as well as combating human trafficking, protecting children and family unity. We need a long-term strategy to address the drivers of the migrant crisis - conflict, persecution, ethnic cleansing in the Middle East. All of this is recognised in the right way in this resolution, so I supported it and I hope it is a step on the road to effectively managing the migrant crisis – for the benefit of refugees and migrants, but also for EU citizens.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report offers no solution to the terrible migrant crisis. On the contrary, all the measures he suggests are additional incentives for those who would still hesitate to risk their lives to reach Europe. Families are basically encouraged to send their minor children on their own on this perilous journey. The major problems posed by the presence of large numbers of recent migrants are forgotten. The material impossibility of properly caring for hundreds of thousands of people, many traumatized by war and their conditions of travel and life, is completely ignored. The difficulty in returning migrants who are not entitled to refugee status is not resolved at all. As for the will of the peoples of the European Union, it obviously does not exist in the logic of this text. So I'm voting against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The situation in the Mediterranean has shown that the existing mechanisms under the Dublin system have not proved objective as they have not served to establish fair criteria for determining competences for applications for international protection and have not helped to provide quick access to protection. Many parts of the world are affected by war and violence, which could cause more violence and insecurity and lead to additional population movements, further imposing the need for a holistic EU approach to migration.  For this reason, I welcome this resolution, and would like to point out that one option for a fundamental reorganisation of the Dublin system would be to establish a central system for collecting applications at Union level, with all Member States accountable and migrants reassigned on the basis of fair and objective criteria. Furthermore, I consider that a sustained, reliable and effective response from the Union as part of search and rescue operations at sea is essential to prevent an increase in the number of migrants killed in their attempt to cross the Mediterranean Sea, the figure of which stands at 444 this year alone, of which 77 are children killed.  A binding legislative approach to resettlement, more general rules on the entry and residence of third-country nationals seeking employment in the Union and mutual recognition of a positive asylum decision by all Member States are also needed.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some criticism and even positive proposals that are set out in this extensive report, its background matrix accepts and sanctions the European criminal policy on migration imposed by the Council and the measures that have been implemented, promoting a xenophobic and racist agenda, alongside other discriminatory, authoritarian and undemocratic practices. The essential axes of the EU's so-called migration policy in the face of this very serious humanitarian crisis are based on the deepening of Fortress Europe, the closure of borders, the militarisation of the response to the plight of those fleeing extreme poverty, hunger and war, the criminalisation of refugees and migrants and the implementation of the policy of return, in clear violation of international law , in particular since the so-called hotspots, transformed into genuine detention and deportation camps, after the unspeakable agreement with Turkey.  Throughout the document, there is not a single element that denounces the EU's responsibilities in this humanitarian drama resulting from its interventionist action, in conjunction with the US and NATO, on the African continent and in the Middle East.  By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. With more than 800,000 people entering the EU in recent months and as many as 120,000 of them this year, the key task is to try an uncontrolled and illegal influx of people fleeing the threat of their own lives, to organise admission in a solidarity and humane manner in accordance with legal regulations. Saving lives must be a top priority, it is necessary to provide adequate funding for operations, searches and rescues, both at Member State and Union level. A holistic approach to migration must include measures aimed at disabling the activities of criminal networks engaged in human smuggling or human trafficking. I welcome the initiative to revise the Dublin Regulation, protect the Schengen acquis and the maximum effort to dialogue with Turkey, where it is necessary to prevent smugglers from illegally transporting people across the Aegean Sea leading to tragedies. The Countries of the Western Balkans, which are on a path for refugees and migrants to come to the EU, are under increasing and stronger pressure that has serious implications for the humanitarian front, and I think they need to be helped.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe faces an unprecedented migration crisis. The causes of this crisis are manifold. That is why we needed a comprehensive EU approach to immigration. The current asylum system does not take sufficient account of the particular migratory pressure to which Member States at the Union's external borders are subjected. We must therefore ensure greater fairness and shared responsibility and amend the Dublin III Regulation as soon as possible.  It is also essential to ensure the implementation of return operations, especially by promoting the adoption of bilateral readmission agreements between the EU and the countries of North Africa. It is also essential to proceed with the full implementation of the relocation programme and, in my opinion, the relocation should be extended to all nationalities, once the relocations of those belonging to nationalities for whom the percentage of positive decisions recognising international protection in the Union was 75 % or more in the previous quarter have been exhausted. For all these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Parliament's own-initiative report responds to the Migration Programme presented by the European Commission in May 2015. The report aimed to present an ambitious and horizontal approach to all forms of migration in the EU, including legal migration, refugees, irregular migration and the Schengen area. The proposals for the final report include: a call for a mandatory system for the relocation of refugees in force in the EU, the replacement of the Dublin Regulation with a centralised asylum application procedure through European rapid registration points ('hotspots') (to allow for effective asylum applications across the Union rather than in individual Member States), a call for humanitarian visas and other ways for migrants to legally gain economic access to the EU.  The report places too little emphasis on strengthening external border controls, increasing the efficiency of the return and readmission of non-asylum seekers, combating trafficking in human beings, focusing on resettlement rather than relocation within the EU, the need to implement existing rules more widely and prevent the secondary movement of asylum seekers, and the need to fund agencies such as Europol, EASO and Frontex in order to speed up the processing of applications , decision-making on applications and dactyloscopes for all arrivals. Policy recommendations are not a sensible or sustainable solution to the current crisis in Europe. For these reasons, I could not support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The situation in the Mediterranean, due to the migration crisis, is very worrying. I would like to remind you that this initiative report has no binding value, but I wished to support it. However, following the principle of subsidiarity, Member States must fulfil their obligations, particularly in terms of emergency relocation measures. Also, states on the front line for the arrival of migrants such as Greece or Italy should receive financial support to ensure better functioning of "hot spots".

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report and we have tabled RCV for particular areas of the report in which we strongly disagree with the text. In particular, UKIP believes that national sovereign governments should have the right to control their own borders and should not be forced to take migrants under an EU resettlement scheme. Similarly, we are also concerned with segments of the report which suggest that the EU should create rules governing the entry and residence of third country nationals. UKIP has, however, supported aspects of the report which criticise the Schengen Area as a facilitator and accelerator of both the migrant crisis and the movement of terrorists within Europe.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Through this report, which I fully support, the European Parliament defends a comprehensive and common approach to migration and asylum, aimed at reorienting the Union's migration policy in its various aspects. Solidarity and the sharing of responsibilities cannot remain meaningless words and must be translated into concrete actions. MEPs are calling for a complete overhaul of the Dublin system to implement a harmonised European asylum system instead. They also call for a binding and mandatory resettlement mechanism, and call on Member States to honour their commitments on the relocation of asylum seekers.  Beyond the need to respect our obligations to search and rescue at sea, it is essential to develop legal and safe access routes to the Union to prevent people from risking their lives fleeing war and persecution. In this sense, I welcome Parliament's decision in favour of the creation of a European humanitarian visa. Finally, the Union must change its paradigm on legal economic migration, which represents an opportunity and a real opportunity in order to fill the gaps in the European labour market.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report stresses that solidarity must be the Union's fundamental principle of migration and that a better response on the part of Europe to this scourge is still needed. It states that great importance should be given to search and rescue operations and that there should be a clear distinction between people who are smuggled into the European Union and those who are victims of trafficking. Furthermore, it considers that resettlement is an important stage in granting safe and legal access to the Union and stresses that further measures are needed to ensure that the Common European Asylum System (ESC) becomes truly uniform. The report also addresses topics such as the integration and participation of refugees in society, the preservation of family unity, the vulnerable situation of refugee children, the need for better quality data and labour exploitation, whereas, finally, the safe return of persons who, following an individual assessment of the asylum application, are not considered eligible for protection in the Union , should be ensured in the context of the correct application of the ESD. From the foregoing, I voted positively.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. A particularly sensitive subject for European citizens, this report demonstrates the European Parliament's willingness to fully engage in the debate on the resolution of the refugee crisis, in particular by urging Member States to take a coordinated and comprehensive approach to the issue.  While it is regrettable that the European Union's competence in migration policy is more than limited, if not almost non-existent, this report nevertheless reminds us of the need for European action as the only relevant and serious response to the scale of the migration crisis.  In addition, MEPs expressed the need to establish legal and safe routes to Europe for those seeking political asylum, which, moreover, is an obligation for European states under international law, as well as the need for the Union to establish a new system based on common solidarity and shared responsibility between countries.  In line with these political lines, I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it.  Immigration is perhaps the most important challenge the EU has posed because, like the refugee crisis, it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are.  The importance of this report is that it addresses the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea, to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a share of the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of Humanitarian Visas and promoting legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as redouble our commitment against mafias exploiting people and improving reception and integration policies, is important.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the long-term management of migration in the European Union, which calls for a radical overhaul of the Dublin system. The text of the report also calls for safe and legal channels for third-country nationals to enter the EU without the latter having to resort to smugglers and risk their lives. The vote on this text was also an opportunity to point out the failure of the European asylum system to cope with the ever-increasing number of migrant arrivals. The radical reform demanded of the so-called Dublin rules proposes to create a central system for collecting and distributing asylum applications. The system could include a quota for each EU member state and would operate on the basis of access points ("hotspots") from which refugees would be distributed.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The report deals with many essential aspects. First of all, it aims to avoid tragedies where thousands of people die on their way to Europe. The text notes that saving life must be a top priority, and it is therefore essential that search and rescue operations be adequately financed at Union and Member State level. The report also refers to the safe return of migrants whose asylum applications are not satisfactory.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to analyse the outcome of the specific work carried out by the European Union in the Mediterranean, in particular in various operations carried out in Italy and Tunisia in the areas of security and rescue operations, migration, asylum and border management. The report underlines some of the main aspects highlighted as a result of the evaluation mentioned, supporting the need for a comprehensive plan with medium and long-term responses. The rapporteurs point to some suggestions to help the situation in the Mediterranean, such as: a permanent union response in search and rescue operations, the implementation of measures to prevent the trafficking and labour exploitation of irregular immigrants, or the taking on of integrated border management, with a view to managing migration effectively while also ensuring a high level of internal security.  Solidarity and fair and equitable sharing of responsibilities by the various Member States should also be an integral part of this package of measures as an EU principle. Because I believe that these measures are not only necessary but also urgent, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the implementation of a holistic approach to managing the migration crisis in the Mediterranean. In 2015, 1.83 million people crossed the EU's external borders illegally. In the face of an alarming humanitarian situation, it is a reminder of the principle of solidarity that binds European countries. Saving lives must be a top priority, and funds to match the challenge must be allocated. This text calls for a review of the current asylum system which does not adequately take into account the current migratory pressures facing Member States at the EU's external borders. A revision of Schengen is also requested. I have therefore supported this report which provides new avenues for implementing a policy to manage the refugee crisis responsibly and humanistic, by facilitating access for refugees fleeing conflict zones while advocating the implementation of readmission agreements.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on the basis that, despite some progress on the original text and with regard to the current terms of EU migration and asylum policy, the text enshrines the validity of the unacceptable and illegal EU-Turkey Agreement which implies the irresponsible relocation of the management of the European migration and asylum and refuge system to countries where disrespect for human rights is evident and systematic.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge. Hundreds of thousands of refugees have come to Europe because of war and persecution in their home country and are entitled to protection in Europe Today, each country alone faces the challenge. It's unsustainable. A pan-European solution, agreed between eu Member States, is needed and increased and effective action is needed to secure the EU's external borders. Similarly, there is a need for fairer burden-sharing between countries. However, what the solution should look like in practice must be up to the Member States that will take part in it. Denmark has, and will continue to have, a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. Therefore, we cannot vote for all 28 Member States to be responsible for all refugees arriving in the EU, stressing that the Danish asylum and refugee policy is determined only in Denmark.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I was able to vote in favour of the report on a comprehensive approach to migration policy. The report is comprehensive and identifies all the possibilities in the areas of asylum, border control management and migration in general, with clear recommendations.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is a missed opportunity for the LIBE Commission to put on the agenda the problems currently faced by people trying to reach the EU. Instead of requiring the issuance of humanitarian visas or ensuring that no collective expulsions are carried out (prohibited by international law and enshrined in the EU-Turkey agreement), it has been chosen to maintain the current aggressive policy imposed by the Commission and the Council. Although the agreement includes positive things, such as the need to create secure access routes, or the need to overcome the Dublin System and the states welcome, these issues are mentioned without concrete measures, so they are left empty again. However, it details the plan to militarize the Mediterranean with nato's help, the need for returns, cooperation with military and security forces from third countries, or the development of a list of safe countries from which asylum claims will not be accepted, in clear violation of the Geneva Convention. For all this, we have not had to vote against this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. However, I cannot fail to reinforce the concern of Amnesty International's statements about the alleged illegal detention of refugees and, as advocated by Portugal, I believe that the European Union should prepare itself to receive, and effectively receive, as many refugees from war as possible. It is a case of basic human rights and values and with which we must be sympathetic. For these reasons, I also voted in favour of Amendments 34 and 35.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report and we have tabled RCVs for particular areas of the report in which we strongly disagree with the text. In particular, UKIP believes that national sovereign governments should have the right to control their own borders and should not be forced to take migrants under an EU resettlement scheme. Similarly, we are also concerned with segments of the report which suggest that the EU should create rules governing the entry and residence of third country nationals. UKIP has, however, supported aspects of the report which criticise the Schengen Area as a facilitator and accelerator of both the migrant crisis and the movement of terrorists within Europe.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D)
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a good contribution from the European Parliament to a better response of Europe to the refugee crisis. However, I have moved away from the S&D group's voting orientation on a specific point, because I believe that it would be appropriate to praise here the attitude that the Portuguese Government has taken on the readiness to take in refugees, even beyond the quota established. This was rightly highlighted in an amendment proposed by the GUE/NGL group, welcoming the Portuguese Government's readiness to directly relocation refugees from Greece. That is why I voted in favour of that amendment.  While understanding that the voting orientation of the S&D group does not reflect a judgment on Portugal's attitude, but only the consequence of the overall commitment that was possible to negotiate with the other political forces to enable the adoption of this resolution, I understood to express by my vote the support of the Portuguese Government in its exemplary attitude of solidarity in facing the current challenge of refugees arriving at the union's external borders.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report because it is giving clear, key recommendations to the Commission as to how we are going to ensure a compassionate and organised response to the biggest refugee crisis that we have faced since the Second World War. It goes further and calls on the Member States to commit action to the cause and respond to this urgent need to take a global approach to migration based on the principle of solidarity between states. The Member States of the EU urgently, urgently need to uphold their responsibilities, show solidarity with our brothers and sisters across Europe and offer humanitarian assistance. By working together we can quickly implement the relocation agreement, as this report calls for, and enhance safer and more legal routes to safety.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Mediterranean migration crisis is a crucial challenge where the European Union can demonstrate its co-operation and capacities. We need wisdom and compassion, as well as justice in tackling the different groups involved. Sadly, what this report has advocated for is a 'red carpet' into Europe without any discernment about who is being welcomed in.  We cannot afford to continue the catastrophic open door policy for everyone, without discerning who are those genuinely fleeing for their lives. Therefore I voted against this report because, despite many helpful suggestions for life—saving, resourcing and resettlement, it failed to honour the principles of the Dublin Regulations, where our external borders are strengthened so that our internal borders can remain open. It also advocated a more centralised approach, establishing a new European body to process all asylum seekers, again taking power away from sovereign nation states.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the motion for a resolution because the report again talks about a permanent refugee redistribution mechanism, which I cannot agree with, because past practice has shown that this mechanism does not work in practice. In their report, the rapporteurs described in detail the situation with refugees, the problems with smuggling groups, that the measures taken so far are ineffective. For example, of the 106 000 asylum seekers awaiting relocation to other Member States from Italy and Greece, only 660 had been redistributed by 3 March this year. It is therefore clear that even those States which have agreed to a permanent redistribution mechanism do not comply with this Regulation. Furthermore, the report highlights the causes of the migration wave and the strategy for cooperation with third countries, in particular with regard to regional protection programmes, resettlement, returns and a focus on addressing the root causes of migration. In addition, they focused on creating appropriate legal ways of economic migration, which I also disagree with. The own-initiative report describes the problems in terms of the real situation, on the basis of which the Commission should take more effective measures to address the refugee crisis in the EU.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive approach to migration seek to combine all aspects of the migration crisis as we experience it in the EU, especially as seen by colleagues from Malta, Italy, Greece and other countries with many years of experience in migration. The report makes a number of correct measures as a requirement for better clarity and control of funds spent on tackling migration or the effective deployment of the European Border and Coast Guard. Unfortunately, there are also points in this report that I cannot support because they deny the principle of solidarity based on a voluntary approach and agreement. This report puts aid to refugees above the security and compliance aspect, which are laid down and which include the obligation on Member States to protect the external border of the Schengen area. I therefore voted in favour of deleting the points that speak of the need for a permanent resettlement programme at EU level with the compulsory participation of The Member States. I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole because these measures failed to be released.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. According to Frontex, 1.83 million people were detected in 2015 trying to cross the EU's external borders illegally; in 2014 there were 282,500. Of all migrants arriving by sea, 20% are children, according to the International Organization for Migration and Unicef. In addition, more than 3771 people lost their lives or are missing in the Mediterranean sea in 2015, according to the International Organisation for Migration, and an integrated EU approach to migration is urgently needed. The prepared report stresses that the Union's action on migration must be based on the principle of solidarity, which includes policies in the areas of asylum, immigration and border control. On the basis of the principle of solidarity, the report highlighted areas where action will need to be taken: search and rescue, the fight against trafficking in human beings and people smuggling, relocation and resettlement, humanitarian admissions, the revision of the Dublin III Regulation, the list of safe countries of origin, the new European border and coastguard, the management and security of external borders, cooperation with third countries, additional funding in the field of migration, legal labour migration and other aspects. In view of the above, I supported the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for an integrated EU approach to migration.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report in which Parliament draws up its proposals to tackle the refugee crisis in the Mediterranean through a comprehensive EU approach to immigration.  The seriousness of the situation can no longer be addressed by the current approach and requires real change: we need an immediate response to save lives through permanent search and rescue operations and a long-term response to manage the asylum system in the European Union humanely and effectively.  As we have been repeating for months, the second-level solution is to go beyond the mechanism established by the Dublin Regulation with a centralised asylum application management system at European level that allows the redistribution of refugees in all Member States fairly and a compulsory relocation system for refugees already in Europe , in order to relieve the pressure on countries such as Italy and Greece that are at the forefront.  In the long term, we also believe that it is necessary to create legal channels of migration to Europe for qualified refugees and economic migrants: humanitarian visas and an ambitious and concrete reform of the Blue Card Directive are therefore needed.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report seeks to provide a holistic response to the challenges posed by the current migration and refugee movements to Europe. The report contains good approaches, for example on combating trafficking in human beings and smuggling, improving rescue measures for migrants or strengthening aid for those in need of protection on the ground. However, the rapporteurs want to introduce compulsory redistributionof asylum seekers between EU Member States. As the last few months have shown, this will not work. It would be far more promising to fulfil humanitarian obligations to those in need of protection, preferably in crisis-prone regions, and to involve the Member States additionally through voluntary commitments regarding the reception of asylum seekers. The report also advocates increased economic migration to Europe, which is unrealistic in view of the sometimes high unemployment rates in individual Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's non-legislative, legally non-binding report on the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration, in which the EP seeks to define politically the whole set of migration issues. Introducing a holistic approach to migration is a complicated task. Unfortunately, despite good intentions, the report as a whole has in many respects fallen victim to the search for compromise between political factions. Parliament's objective of presenting a comprehensive approach to migration has thus not been fully achieved. However, the resolution also contains many very important and beneficial elements for combating the migration crisis (such as the fight against smuggling, legal routes for refugees or return policy and others). As most of the points in the report were voted en bloc, it was not possible to comment separately on some of the above problematic points. However, I did not consider it responsible to vote against the entire EP resolution, which is a summary of Parliament's views and approaches on the complex issue of the phenomenon of migration. Finally, I appreciate that the resolution is conceived in a solidarity spirit to address the migration crisis. A European solution is now needed more than ever.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The basic principles of european union action on migration are solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities. The principle of solidarity covers asylum, immigration and border control policies. There is a noticeable increase in irregular arrivals by sea as well as an increase in the number of deaths at sea, so saving lives should be a top priority.  In this regard, sufficient financial resources must be provided for search and rescue operations, both at Union and Member State level. Saving lives is an act of solidarity, but also a legal obligation prescribed by international law. On 27 May 2015, the Commission adopted the EU Action Plan against Migrant Smuggling ('Anti-Smuggling Action Plan'), which envisages the establishment of a contact group of Union agencies to combat migrant smuggling in order to strengthen operational cooperation and information sharing.  Also, one of the priorities is the development of a security and legal route for returning people who do not qualify to be under EU protection. Refugee integration is a two-way process, Member States need to provide full support and refugees should respect the principles on which the European Union was founded. Consequently, I support this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report which gives key recommendations to the Commission as well as Member States to ensure a compassionate and organised response to the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War. Europe urgently needs to take a global approach to migration based on the principle of solidarity between states. Member States urgently need to uphold their responsibilities and show solidarity with countries on the periphery such as Greece and Italy by offering humanitarian assistance, quickly implementing the relocation agreement and working together to enhance safer and legal routes to Europe.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. —Solidarity is a basic principle in addressing the migration crisis: from fair sharing of responsibilities between Member States, through mutual recognition of asylum decisions, to humanitarian reception and resettlement of migrants. Even more challenging in the Mediterranean area are smuggling and trafficking in human beings and illegal immigration. This is why financial assistance should be provided to the Member States most affected by this crisis, all to protect human life. I find a holistic approach necessary in this situation. This means that in this crisis, the EU should fight as a whole against the negative consequences affecting individual member states. Third countries should also be involved in co-operation. I support this proposal because I think external and internal borders within the EU need to be protected. The security of EU citizens is imperative and can only be achieved if all countries have binding legislation. This will allow migrants to be resettled in the EU, and only with mutual effort will their integration into the community be possible.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I fundamentally disagree with the system of compulsory relocation of refugees.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for an integrated EU approach to migration. According to Frontex, 1.83 million people tried to enter the EU illegally last year, several times more than the previous years, and once again more points to the scale of the refugee crisis. From the perspective of the EU budget, I welcome the increase in asylum, migration and integration funding for last year and this year, but I regret the reduction in funding for legal migration and integration and better, fairer and effective return strategies. There is also a great deal of room for improvement in transparency over the use of funds for the functioning of Member States and third countries in the areas of migration, asylum and border management, thus giving a clearer picture of the European Union's overall spending on migration. The scale of the crisis and the need for swift action should not be an alibi for the opaque use of funds from the European Union budget.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's vote on the motion for a resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a comprehensive EU approach to migration, I abstained, as I agree with the need for a holized approach to addressing the current situation, which means, above all, solutions at European (EU) level, but I do not believe that some passages of the voted resolution fulfil this very requirement for the complexity of the solution. The reform of the Dublin system is certainly one of the fundamental components of the future solution, but I believe that it is now too early to define the precise parameters of this reform, because it is only one element whose form can be influenced by other elements of the solution, the parameters of which we do not know exactly now and which need to be discussed first. This element of interdependence has not, in my view, been applied sufficiently in the proposed text.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the report there are important positive references such as the need for practical solidarity, the reference to the failure of the Dublin Regulation and the call for the creation of legal and safe routes, the sharing of responsibilities in the Member States and the protection of the rights of refugees.  Unfortunately, however, the report also supports inhuman military operations, NATO's involvement in the Aegean, and the strengthening of border controls that make Europe a fortress and sustain crime against refugees.  Equally negative is the call for the implementation of the EU-Turkey Action Plan, an agreement that even the United Nations has denounced as violating international legitimacy. For these reasons we have abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The policy of mass migration is not a solution to Europe's demographic and labour problem. On the contrary, it leads to population change, the dismantling of the social fabric and unfortunately Islamisation with the accessories of the creation of jihadist terrorist pockets. Open borders policy is an incentive and encouragement for greater incursion of illegal immigrants into Europe. A Europe which, on the altar of multiculturalism and diversity, has lost its moral values and is seeking to lose the national consciousness and homogeneity of the Member States.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order not to be in self-contradiction because of my obligation as Vice-President of the European People's Party in relation to the resolution, since the Fidesz PP delegation voted differently from the group, I did not directly participate in the vote. In other words, I did not press the voting button, but I indicated to the PP group with my hands the voting position that had been decided jointly.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of a very thorough report, which I believe could prove very important in the future, provided that it can make a meaningful contribution to finding a truly comprehensive pan-European solution to the inoperable Dublin system, based on the experience of the refugee crisis that first developed in the Mediterranean. I agree with the holistic approach to this issue, and in particular to make the requirement of solidarity with the Member States a mandatory standard as a premise of the package of proposals. I hope that this report will help to recognise the Union's own current weaknesses in migration policy. As I said in the debate, it is hardly possible to build a new EU migration order on solidarity with each other and refugees where some Member State governments base their refugee policies on the rejection and even hatred of immigrants and refugees. As a Hungarian opposition politician, I have a particular pity that the Orban government is running a persistent anti-foreigner campaign and is organising a referendum against a non-existent reception decision. I trust that the adoption of this important EP report can also contribute to the eradication of such anomalies in the Member States, thereby paving the way for a new and effective EU migration policy.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
