text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As a result of the conflict in Syria, more than one million refugees have joined the European Union in the last year only, leading to a migration crisis on a scale unprecedented since the end of the Second World War. So far, EU countries have not found a solution to the influx of such a significant number of people. Above all, Europe needs to change its thinking on migration. You can't keep looking for emergency solutions for emergencies. Real deal with this problem is a lengthy process. The services must draw a clear line between those in need of protection and those who come to the Old Continent for profit. The former, who are fleeing war and persecution, have the right to EU protection. The latter must rely on the decisions of the Member States, as they are the ones who control their labour markets. There is also a need to improve the return system, as in 2014 only 36% of those who were due to leave the Union were sent back. Moreover, the abolition of controls at the internal borders of the Schengen area must go hand in hand with the strengthening of the Union's external borders, and those who stay in Europe must respect the values on which the Community is based. All these elements are contained in the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration, which is why I have chosen to support them.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report prepared in the LIBE Committee reinforces the idea that only cross-party collaboration can respond to the crisis we are facing in the Mediterranean. Our objective is to help those who migrate to Europe, but also to help ourselves manage this exceptional situation. In other words, we need compassion and solidarity, but also a set of measures to responsibly regulate the flow of migration in the long term. The large number of immigrants and refugees, as well as the reactions of the societies in which they end up, prove that we need a centralised European system for the reception and integration of newcomers.  I welcome the work of my colleagues to take these issues into account and I agree my vote on this project.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague's report. I share the view that the approach to migration in Europe needs to be profoundly and permanently overhauled. Any long-term sustainable strategy must cover all aspects of migration and asylum, including foreign and diplomatic policies, the global crime economy, the delivery of humanitarian aid and better assistance to people already in Europe. In addition, the gender dimension must be integrated into all areas of action.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current refugee crisis has shown that our migration system is not suited to today’s realities anymore. We need a collective European response to resolve the current disastrous humanitarian situation and lay the ground for a better future system. While the resolution goes proposes positive steps, some elements are still contradictory and some measures proposed not acceptable in the current situation. I could not support a relocation scheme for refugees. I remain convinced that such schemes are not the correct way to deal with the migration crisis. This is one of the main reasons why I voted against it. There is no doubt that we need to rethink the Dublin regulation and the all migration system on our continent. However, establishing a central collective system for distribution of applicants would be ineffective as long as the EU’s external borders are not secured and migration flows is not effectively managed. A strong European Border and Coast Guard is an essential measure in this respect. It is only once this is done that we can progressively establish a new EU Asylum system, based on a fair sharing of responsibility between Member States.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union faces the challenge of the arrival of thousands of refugees fleeing war and persecution in the Middle East. Efficiency and moral demand call for a common response, based on the solidarity and responsibility of the Member States.  Parliament has mobilised to remind Member States of their commitments: they have promised to take in 160,000 refugees from Greece and Italy and must act immediately! It is unacceptable that so far only 600 of them have actually been relocated.  Parliament calls for a major overhaul of the asylum system and dublin rules, which are unsuitable for the situation. We call on the Commission to prepare an ambitious legislative proposal, establishing a centralised European asylum system, able to distribute refugees in a fair, supportive and binding manner within the Union. We also demand the creation of safe and legal passages, in order to prevent refugees from resorting to smugglers, at the risk of their lives.  Our Union is at a crossroads: either we can determine a common and solidarity response, which will strengthen our institutions; either national selfishness will take over, and the Union will disappear.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The migration crisis cannot be blurred with the refugee crisis, nor can it respond to the demographic problems of some Member States. Only a fraction of the masses heading to Europe are genuine refugees, most of whom we can help by supporting reception camps close to their country. If they can be provided with dignible conditions, health care and education, we will make it easier for them to return to their home countries as the situation stabilises.  At the same time, for the immigrant masses arriving in the hope of a better livelihood, any ambigrat gestures are interpreted as invitations. Solidarity can take many forms, not artificially imposed mandatory quotas.  The Hungarian People's Party delegation could not vote in favour of the report on migration adopted today because it is unacceptable for them to centrally say who is being put on our hands and for others to decide who should be allowed into our own Member States and with whom to live.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Since I believe that the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic approach by the European Union to migration does not offer a sustainable solution to the current crisis facing Europe and does not provide clear proposals on how to tackle the migrant crisis, I voted against it. In fact, I believe that we cannot reduce the unbearable pressure on Europe's borders by simply applying costly technological solutions, but by changing migration and asylum policy. Also, a large number of migrants come from countries unaffected by conflicts, and this report offered no solutions to such cases.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for an integrated EU approach to migration. The report is the result of almost one year of work in the LIBE Committee, 8 working documents, an exchange of views with experts and a large number of stakeholders, one LIBE operation in Lampedusa related to security and rescue and one operation related to EU-Tunisia cooperation on migration, asylum and border management. The aim of the report is to assess the different views that are delicate in the areas of migration, asylum and border management, to develop a series of recommendations and reporting in the form of a strategic report with an all-en-line plan, towards a short, medium and long-term response.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is on the verge of reforms related to the reception and migration of refugees. The old rules do not apply, changes are necessary. What they will be like – will be decided in the coming weeks.  The report rightly talks about the necessary reforms. However, many members of my group, like myself, are driven by more radical positions. If Europe wants to become an important international player and to ensure internal stability and security in crisis situations - as it is today - there is no alternative to moving towards federalisation.  In other words, we need european police structures and services with great powers to deal with refugee issues. It is necessary to transfer border, counter-terrorism and refugee status issues to supranational (Pan-European) level.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on the basis that, despite some progress on the original text and with regard to the current terms of EU migration and asylum policy, the text enshrines the validity of the unacceptable and illegal EU-Turkey Agreement which implies the irresponsible relocation of the management of the European migration and asylum and refuge system to countries where disrespect for human rights is evident and systematic

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report seeks to provide a holistic response to the challenges posed by the current migration and refugee movements to Europe. The report contains good approaches, for example on combating trafficking in human beings and smuggling, improving rescue measures for migrants or strengthening aid for those in need of protection on the ground. However, the rapporteurs want to introduce compulsory redistributionof asylum seekers between EU Member States. As the last few months have shown, this will not work. It would be far more promising to fulfil humanitarian obligations to those in need of protection, preferably in crisis-prone regions, and to involve the Member States additionally through voluntary commitments regarding the reception of asylum seekers. The report also advocates increased economic migration to Europe, which is unrealistic in view of the sometimes high unemployment rates in individual Member States. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report hoping that it will help to find a European solution to the refugee crisis. I am really worried by the attitude of Member States that don’t want to comply (or make no efforts) in order to achieve the quota distributed by the European Commission. What’s more, I find deeply disappointing that this has forced the EU to a bad deal with Turkey that should be revised in order to tackle many concerns voiced by civil society groups and the European Parliament, which has been totally sidelined from finding solutions to the crisis.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the current flood of migration from the Mediterranean. This report is the result of the pro-immigration lobby and advocates, among other things, for the creation of 'safe and lawful new routes' to enable asylum seekers and refugees to enter the European Union, for the establishment of 'appropriate' channels of legal economic migration, and encourages Member States to 'ensure the preservation of family unity'. He therefore wants to facilitate the snowball effect of family reunification. I voted against it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on the view that, despite some progress on the original text and with regard to the current terms of EU migration and asylum policy, the text enshrines the validity of the unacceptable and illegal EU-Turkey Agreement which implies the irresponsible relocation of the management of the European migration and asylum system and refuge to countries where disrespect for human rights is evident and systematic.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. The report analyses the current state of affairs touching upon the matters such as trafficking and exploitation of illegal immigrants, border management and visa policy and the overall complexity and tragedy of the unsafe refugee routes. The report underlines solidarity as the principle upon which Union action on migration is based, where the main priority is to save lives, calling for strengthening of the search and rescue capacities.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a report that is the result of more than a year of work in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and which aims to evaluate the different policies put in place in the area of migration, asylum and border control as well as develop a battery of recommendations to be made both in the short term , as in the medium and long term.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The refugee crisis has shown that the current approach to immigration in the EU is not sustainable. This holistic report is trying to give a comprehensive answer and that is why I voted in favour of it.  Immigration is perhaps the most important challenge the EU has posed because, like the refugee crisis, it confronts us with the question of solidarity as the basis of the European model. How we treat people who come to the EU in search of a better tomorrow says a lot about who we are.  The importance of this report is that it addresses the main issues that characterize the migration challenge. Among the most important are the reform of the Dublin System, rescue operations at sea, to prevent the Mediterranean from becoming an underwater pit and the establishment of a permanent and legally binding mechanism establishing a share of the distribution of refugees between Member States. In addition, the inclusion of Humanitarian Visas and promoting legal and secure access routes to the EU, as well as redouble our commitment against mafias exploiting people and improving reception and integration policies, is important.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is universally acknowledged that at the moment we face the biggest refugee crisis in Europe since the end of the Second World War. The seemingly unending bloodshed in Syria, as well as global issues of poverty and climate change have brought us face-to-face with a very real challenge. We cannot afford to sit idly by and ignore this problem. I therefore voted in favour of this report, for reasons that I will outline below. This is not just a European problem, this is a global problem but one that can have a European solution if we have the courage to act on the impeccably Labour principle of solidarity, solidarity between people and solidarity between countries. Member States urgently need to uphold their responsibilities and show solidarity with countries on the periphery such as Greece and Italy by offering humanitarian assistance and quickly implementing the relocation agreement as well as working together to enhance safer and legal routes to Europe. If the only routes into Europe are the illegal ones, then people will take them in ever greater numbers. We cannot morally afford to see more drowned children, or leave peripheral Member States with a burden that they cannot hope to shoulder alone.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I was responsible for this dossier in the Liberal Group. The current refugee crisis proves time and again that our current system of migration is no longer workable in today's reality. In Europe, we urgently need a collective European response to this crisis. This is the only way we can resolve today's dramatic humanitarian situation.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The European Parliament today voted on a resolution on immigration which calls for the creation of a centralised asylum system for the EU. I voted against the adoption of the resolution because I do not consider the paper model to be supported. Decision-making must remain in the Member States. Coordination between Member States must be continued and deepened.  Refugees should be helped in refugee camps outside the EU, where, together with UNHCR experts, it is decided who will be granted asylum. Asylum recipients are accepted under national refugee quotas. All Member States must open a quota. Persons who have been granted asylum in one Member State should have the right to move from one Member State to another.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Sad anniversary that the adoption of this report, begun in April 2015 after the death of nearly 800 migrants in a shipwreck in southern Italy. A year later, the toll of the humanitarian crisis continues to rise. Yet the heads of state and government are increasingly cynical. Not content with not being up to the task, they are taking dangerous decisions: questioning the right to asylum, "sorting refugees", through the scandalous agreement between the European Union and Turkey, nothing is too shocking to prevent refugees from entering European soil. This report rightly recalls the need for legal access routes, strengthening search and rescue at sea and mutual recognition of asylum decisions. Unfortunately, he is not really critical of the decisions taken in recent months. Worse, it favours readmission agreements, the establishment of a European list of so-called safe third countries and the establishment of European coastguards. My group, the GUE/NGL, has tabled a number of amendments to denounce these decisions, all of which have been rejected. This report without any criticism misses its objective, I abstained to support at a minimum the few positive points.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, there is not a single paragraph or a single line of text in this document which denounces the responsibilities of the European Union and condemns the measures that have been implemented. The essential axes of the EU's so-called migration policy in the face of this very serious humanitarian crisis are to deepen "Fortress Europe", with the criminalisation and expulsion of refugees and migrants, promoting a xenophobic and racist agenda alongside other discriminatory practices, intolerance, authoritarian and undemocratic. The recently concluded agreement illustrates the EU's hypocrisy and the total lack of basic values of respect for human and democratic rights when, in addition to the €3 billion commitment, it waves Turkey's accession to the European Union as a counterpart to serve as a buffer state, withholding refugee waves on its territory and borders. By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The creation of an EU-wide central isaled and allocated to 'competence', the right to free movement of asylum seekers and the proposal to systematically refrain from imposing penalties in cases of asylum.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the situation of migration in the Mediterranean. The aim of the report is to establish a common vision for all groups on the most relevant aspects of migration policies. The topics covered are solidarity, integration and the revision of the Dublin Convention to identify and stop human traffickers. Other topics covered refer to work related to migration, recognition of the right of asylum and cooperation with countries outside the EU. I am convinced that this report lay the foundations for improving the migration scenario in Europe.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. This was a must for reasons of national and European responsibility. Contrary to what the report to be voted on suggests, neither the 'management' of migration or the concern for the welfare and security of Europe's pressing 'refugees' can be at the heart of EU Mediterranean policy; emphasising the importance of managed immigration for the European labour market is also wrong. Migration must be repelled (and not to be "controlled") and the primary focus of a European border regime must be to prevent further immigration.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in the Mediterranean and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. Among other things, the text calls for a binding mechanism for the distribution of asylum seekers among the Member States, which I strongly reject. The resolution then calls for a Union-wide system of asylum seeker status whereby any asylum seeker would be regarded as a person seeking asylum throughout the Union and not in a single Member State. This is a step towards the abolition of national sovereignty, which I strongly reject. It is the right of a sovereign Member State to freely decide on the reception of persons. In this case, mandatory EU regulation is an interference with the principle of subsidiarity. As the report exceeds the competences of the EU, I rejected it.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which gives key recommendations to the Commission as well as Member States to ensure a compassionate and organised response to the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War. The refugee crisis has shown that the current EU approach to migration is not sustainable. We need to have a complete rethink in order to create a system that is fit for the 21st Century. This report outlines the European Parliament's vision of what that could look like. Europe urgently needs to take a global approach to migration based on the principle of solidarity. Member States urgently need to uphold their responsibilities and show solidarity with countries on the periphery, such as Greece and Italy, by offering humanitarian assistance, quickly implementing the relocation agreement and working together to enhance safer and legal routes to Europe. We also need to ensure that the voices of migrants and refugees are heard and in that respect I was pleased to attend the recent parliamentary screening of Jakob Brossman’s award-winning film ‘Lampedusa in Winter’.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which gives key recommendations to the Commission as well as Member States to ensure a compassionate and organised response to the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War. Member countries urgently need to uphold their responsibilities and show solidarity with countries on the periphery such as Greece and Italy by offering humanitarian assistance , quickly implementing the relocation agreement and working together to enhance safer and legal routes to Europe.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the situation in the Mediterranean region and the need for a holistic EU approach to migration. Addressing the migration and refugee issue will largely judge the EU's progress in the coming years. Only through a common European solution can we see real results.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the situation in the Mediterranean is of great importance. The text proposes a complete picture of all the measures currently taken by the European Union to deal with the refugee emergency and, for each of them, lists a number of possible corrections to make them even more effective.  The principles underlying the history of the European Union have been affirmed on several occasions: it is about solidarity, responsibility and respect for human rights. This is the European identity that we must defend, committing ourselves to giving concrete help to those who face a troubled journey every day and with uncertain results in order to find hope for a better life. Among the various proposals, I particularly welcome the suggestion to revise the Dublin Regulation, so that refugee management between the different Member States can be allocated more fairly, and the call for the legal access channels to Europe to be implemented effectively in order to combat trafficking in human beings effectively.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the European Parliament resolution on the need for an EU holistic approach to migration, as it stresses that a centralised asylum system will allow effective resolution of the influx of migrants and asylum seekers. Populism – although painted in different shades – at least for the moment in the European Parliament, proves stronger. Moreover, it is being implemented by left and centre-oriented parliamentary colleagues, of whom the majority do not expect political power in the Member States. Therefore, however, the position of the COUNCIL of the EU on this issue is, however, different, and there is a turning point towards a sensible and realistic decision-making path. It must be understood that the forced voluntary quotas, which are dressed up in the shell of solidarity this time, do not work, because in conclusion it is not beneficial for the majority of Member States or for the migrants themselves, who, on the basis of the proposed plan, would be sent to different Member States with different standards of living and social guarantees against their will. Moreover, it does not resolve the issue of restricting secondary movements, but on the contrary, if a large majority of migrants and asylum seekers are compulsively located in countries where they would rather not want to end up, this poses serious risks to the existence of the Schengen area. The basic principle of the Dublin Regulation must remain in force. It is also necessary to ensure that any migrant who has paid smugglers is returned; and only indeed those fleeing the threat of war would obtain their refugee status in camps of third countries, where a particular Member State would apply for the examination of its status.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report, created at the initiative of two political groups, the European People's Party and the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats. The report was to outline the European Parliament's position on migration and the asylum system in response to the Migration Agenda published by the European Commission in May 2015. In particular, the report talks about the need for a holistic approach to migration, but ultimately lacks any ambition and solution to the problem. The main proposals to address the issue centre around the compulsory relocation system, which I disagree with from the outset, as well as around the new proposal for a centralised asylum procedure, in which asylum seekers would no longer be sought at national level, but at European Union level. I cannot support such a proposal for a solution, as I am of the opinion that the asylum procedure should not be transferred to the European Union and should continue to be left to the competence of individual Member States. I also do not support compulsory quotas, and I am of the opinion from the outset that the refugee crisis can only be managed on the principle of voluntary solidarity between Member States. For these reasons, I voted against the report.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The migration crisis is a problem that is the result of political instability and very poor living conditions in the Middle East and Africa. All the proposals to solve this problem, which come out of the European institutions, relate only to current affairs and the treatment of the symptoms of this crisis, but there is nothing new to solve the fundamental problem – to stop the distribution of countries in the immediate vicinity of the European Union.  This report is yet another such voice that does nothing new and reproduces the erroneous reasoning that has been made so far. A demand with which I particularly disagree is to call for the continuation of the policy of relocation of so-called refugees. Such a policy, conducted without proper preparation, without the possibility of verifying the identity of the persons relocated and without taking into account the will of the Member States, exacerbates the crisis and weakens the authority of the European institutions. The EU should focus on tackling mass immigration and improving living conditions in refugee camps in Lebanon or Turkey.  The liberalisation of asylum and schengen border rules will increase the threat of terrorism and lead to an escalation of the migration crisis. As a result, many Member States will take action on their own to secure their borders, which risks breaking up the Schengen area. This report dismisses the prospect of an effective solution to the migration crisis affecting Europe. I voted against it.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Metsola/Kyenge report proposing a holistic approach to migration in the EU. The report calls for permanent and effective search and rescue operations to prevent the loss of more lives in the Mediterranean Sea. At the same time, we call for a review of asylum application management in the EU by replacing the current Dublin system with a centralised European system for distributing refugees in a fairer and more transparent manner. The report also provides for the creation of humanitarian visas to allow the holder to travel directly to the country where he wishes to apply for asylum. The refugee crisis has shown that the EU's current approach to migration is not sustainable, so we need a full review to create a response system that corresponds to the 21st century.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the situation in the Mediterranean. However, in the face of the findings, I would add that the EU needs an integrated approach to tackling the migrant crisis, which is also linked to the security situation. In particular, it is necessary to secure external borders, to speed up the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard, to support Frontex and Europol financially and in human resources, and to stand up to Turkey's blackmail. However, I would like to point out that I am strongly against so-called dialological or two-way integration, as it presupposes the mutual acceptance of value and behavioural forms.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Although I did not vote in favour of this report, I was pleased that the principle of subsidiarity and subsidiarity remain explicitly regarded as one of the guiding principles of the European Union. But if so, I do not know, and I do not understand why our fellow Members who have been raving about this debate today, and why they are constantly angry that Hungary is choosing Hungary different path to migration and, by the way, on some other issues than they see well. Once there is subsidiarity, once decisions have to be taken there, as close as possible to the citizens, except in areas where we have s give up our sovereignty. In the area of migration and immigration, we have not given up on our sovereignty, so let us stop now trying to discipline Hungary and bring it to its knees. This area belongs to us in terms of decision-making. You decide the fate of your own country. Thank you very much!

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I support the verification of the use of European funds, the strict verification of these projects, especially those involving large amounts of money - and that is part of the report. I believe that when it comes to large investments in particular, it is necessary for the European Commission, in the middle of the implementation period, to strictly check whether the objectives of that project are being achieved, if things are going well, and to take corrective action if they do not go well. That's because we don't want to throw money out the window, nor do we want it to end up in the pockets of politicians or people in the administration who don't deal with the public good. These projects are aimed at the well-being of people and the development of their country. Sovereignty must not cover fraud or non-application of European laws under this pretext, that we are a sovereign country and as such the Commission has no right to see, to worry about what we do with European funds. No, the Commission has to do these checks.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr On the one hand, it is a welcome fact that, in 2012 and 2013, the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality were largely effectively implemented in life under the governance of the European Union. And, consequently, I also join in calling on national parliaments in the European Union to become more actively involved in these processes, both in general and in the light of overall development. But the same is true of regional and municipal authorities, because it must be said that these institutions are the main institutions for the implementation of the principles of subsidiarity and, I would say, de facto are the closest authorities to the citizens of the European Union. But it is a pity that, in recent years, the implementation of the principle of subsidiarity has been suffering more and more, I would say, defeat and is not fully implemented in our lives. But I agree with the need to simplify the procedure for requesting European Union funding to the maximum and repeat that I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Karim Report today. As a matter of principle we cannot support a report which endorses the current legislative system under the Treaties. UKIP is opposed to any system which gives the EU the right to impose legislation on the UK and of any concomitant system of giving national parliaments permission to legislate on some issues, a system which is the very negation of Parliamentary sovereignty. ‘Subsidiarity and proportionality’ are weasel words intended to convey the sense that the EU is not a monolithic, all-pervading entity and that the ability of Member States to legislate has somehow been left intact by the Treaties. In reality the concept makes no difference whatsoever to the nature and extent of the ‘competences’ of the EU and the vast areas of policy over which the EU an effective monopoly in its ability to legislate. The EU’s power of legislation remains intact.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the annual monitoring of the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality within the European Union. Member States are given the opportunity to submit 'reasoned opinions' on acts proposed by the European Commission to challenge the infringement of this principle, and if such opinions come from a sufficient number of Member States the Commission must reconsider the proposal. The report also proposes a series of measures to ensure greater participation and closer involvement of national parliaments. The 5-Star Movement is in favour of greater involvement of nation states in European decisions. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it jeopardizes the fragile but essential balance for the proper functioning of the Union. The report calls for the creation of additional procedural steps in our legislative process that slow the already heavy bureaucratic burden on our institutions and make it almost impossible to carry out the legislative process.  Under these principles and outside the areas of exclusive competence, the European Union should intervene only if it is able to act more effectively than EU countries at their respective national or local levels. These principles require that the means used by the EU, in order to achieve the objectives set by the Treaties, cannot go beyond what is necessary. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be balanced with the need for the efficiency of the work of our institutions. This balance must be balanced with measures. We must say yes to these principles, but not at the expense of the effectiveness of the Union for its citizens.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report adequately observes how the principle of subsidiarity can be invoked to curb proposals which are very harmful to the working class, as was the Monti II directive (which limited the right to strike in States) or in the present, the inclusion of ISDS (which sanction States governing against the interests of multinationals) in trade treaties. It also values it as a democratising element by allowing national parliaments greater weight in European decisions. Similarly, it notes the importance of legislation being proportionate (something that, as the employment opinion annexed to the report argues, should not be used as a pretext for the reduction of social rights). However, the text is reluctant to explicitly denounce how the ambiguity inherent in the concepts of subsidiarity and proportionality is being used by the EU to reduce its legislation to its neoliberal core (competition, governance, single market, trade agreements...) and to contribute to a deregulatory agenda, respectively. The complicit silence on the issue of governance, which represents a clear attack on subsidiarity with its blackmail on public finances, is particularly serious. For all this, I abstained.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained on this report as while the objectives and intentions on this report were very positive; any positive provisions were undone by a negative agenda running throughout the text.  Let us be clear, there is no party more committed to protecting Irish sovereignty than Sinn Féin. In our role as an MEP in the European Parliament, we are continuously seeking to ensure that the interests of the Irish people are placed at the forefront of any EU policy. It goes without saying that principle of subsidiarity must represent the starting point for policy formulation. However, the negative provisions in relation to EU trade policy and the ISDS, means that we were left in no position but to abstain on this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report contains positive points and recommendations (greater use of impact assessments, particularly on competitiveness, and public consultations, importance of ex post-emphasised evaluations, a stated principle of priority for SMEs), but it is feared that many of them will be given no concrete application. Given the overall balance of the report, I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report on subsidiarity and proportionality from 2012/13 is now over three years out of date. It has no value being discussed in the Chamber today. Notionally Article 5 TEU is supposed to invite consideration of whether an EU competence is necessary or whether the proposed action could properly and effectively be carried out at Member State level. The unelected European Commission has no desire to allow Member States any say in the subsidiarity and proportionality of new laws. The power-hungry bureaucrats have only one desire, to see national parliaments’ independence sacrificed into that of a superstate.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to assess compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. Parliament welcomes the closer and more active involvement of national parliaments in European legislative processes in recent years. The annual reports drawn up by the Commission are somewhat resoupprius and often lack more detailed reflections on how EU policies respect the principles of subsidiarity and, in particular, proportionality. Moreover, the reasoned opinions received from national parliaments differ sufficiently between the arguments put forward and in their form. There is no common model and it is therefore more difficult to assess on the basis on which national parliaments give opinions. There is an urgent need to address these problems.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Karim report today. As a matter of principle we cannot support a report which endorses the current legislative system under the Treaties. UKIP is opposed to any system which gives the EU the right to impose legislation on the UK and of any concomitant system of giving national Parliaments permission to legislate on some issues, a system which is the very negation of Parliamentary sovereignty.  ‘Subsidiarity and proportionality’ are weasel words intended to convey the sense that the EU is not a monolithic, all-pervading entity and that the ability of Member States to legislate has somehow been left intact by the Treaties. In reality the concept makes no difference whatsoever to the nature and extent of the ‘competences’ of the EU and the vast areas of policy over which the EU an effective monopoly in its ability to legislate. The EU’s power of legislation remains intact.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. While the principle of subsidiarity, enshrined in Article 5 of the Treaty on the European Union, is fundamental to decision-making within the Union in that it aims to determine the most relevant level of intervention in the areas of shared competence, as well as the resulting principle of proportionality, this report does nothing to ensure that it is more faithfully respected.  While he denounces the Commission's rejection of the yellow card procedures by which national parliaments call on the Commission to reconsider a legislative proposal when it has been the subject of "reasoned opinions" - protests by a third of the national parliaments of the Member States - he merely calls on the Commission to engage in a dialogue with national parliaments, and refuses to put in place a veto , a red card that would really enshrine the principle of subsidiarity.  It is because this report refuses to take the necessary measures to enforce a fundamental principle, a revealing failure of the European deception, that I have opposed it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are important from the perspective of a coherent and structured policy. The first determines the most relevant level of intervention in the areas of shared competence between the European Union and its Member States, while the second frames the Union's actions in the exercise of its competences. I voted in favour of these annual reports, which consist of examining a strict application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality because they must be respected, even more so at a time when the institutions of the European Union are being criticised as too intrusive in the political action of the national, regional and local bodies of the Member States.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Karim report today on subsidiarity and proportionality. The proposed text contains many points that cannot be supported and run counter to the objective, which I believe to be fundamental, of strengthening the European Union by equipping it with the necessary instruments to improve the lives of its citizens.  The Group of the Party of European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has tabled a number of amendments in an attempt to bring the text back into a framework which would make it possible to interpret in an organic way the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality which undersea the Treaties, but this has not been possible. The report is therefore too unbalanced in favour of the nation states, with elements that risk jeopardising other proposals put forward in plenary.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain in this report on subsidiarity and proportionality because, although it has some interesting aspects in terms of transparency and evaluation of the legislative process for the protection of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the general view of the text is conservative, and proposes to regulate the systems of international litigation between investors and states, which we reject.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. I voted without hesitation in favour of my British colleague's report. It was time for someone to remind this assembly of the importance of subsidiarity in the legislative work of our institutions. This is an importance that we tend to forget, or even deny, because subsidiarity is one of the last weapons left to European nations when their interests do not correspond to the dictates that the Commission wants to impose on them. And subsidiarity - have we forgotten it? - is anchored in the Maastricht Treaty, adopted more than 25 years ago. It was even with the principle of subsidiarity that the recalcitrant citizens of my country were persuaded at the time to vote in favour of Maastricht in the referendum organised by François Mitterrand. And now the Socialists, sneakily, have tried, by amending this report, to empty the principle of subsidiarity of its substance. Europe will only survive if the institutions understand that subsidiarity must remain the foundation on which legislation can be built that benefits all Europeans without harming the interests of the Member States.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I unfortunately had to vote against this report, which, if it fully identifies the disease in the European Union, is seriously mistaken about the remedy. Indeed, the report concerned the principle of subsidiarity, which is enshrined in the European treaties and in particular by Article 5 of the TUE, and aims to determine the most relevant level of political intervention: European, national, or local. A principle of common sense regularly shamelessly violated by the European Commission, which in recent years has accepted only one "yellow card" from national parliaments, which had ruled in 2012 that the Commission was overstepping its jurisdiction by simply trying to abolish the right to strike. The report therefore criticises this arbitrary Commission which regularly disregards the rule of proportionality. But it does not go far enough and merely asks for "impact studies" and more dialogue with national parliaments. When David is threatened by Goliath, he doesn't just beg him on his knees.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report strongly criticises the European Commission for its abuses of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality with regard to national parliaments. The parliaments of the Member States should, in fact, have more say, being able to intervene not only at the beginning of the legislative procedure but throughout the codecision process. That is why I supported the report with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've abstained. My basic position is that the EU has centralised too much power to its own institutions, especially to the bureaucrats of the European Commission. National parliaments need far more power within the EU system. I appreciate the fact that the report is critical of the Commission and that it emphasises that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are not being properly observed. However, the report also contains unclear wordings, particularly on the issue of investment protection.  With these arguments, and my anti-European attitude fundamentally, I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The principle of subsidiarity is intended to determine the most relevant level of intervention in the areas of competence shared between the EU and EU countries, whether at national, regional or local level. In any case, the EU can intervene only when its action is more effective than that of the national, regional or local administrations of the Member States.  The principle of proportionality, applicable to all EU action, provides that Union action must be limited to what is necessary to achieve the objectives set out in the Treaties. The application of these principles makes it possible to determine when the EU has jurisdiction to legislate and contributes to decisions being taken as close to citizens as possible. The European Parliament draws up annual reports on the application of these principles in the Union. I have decided not to support with my vote the reports relating to the years 2012 and 2013 used by the British Conservative rapporteur to shape his anti-European and Eurosceptic agenda. These reports aim to strengthen the powers of national parliaments to impede the decisions taken by the Union, reduce its legislative capacity and weaken the European project.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the annual reports on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality 2012-2013. The European Parliament welcomes the closer and more active involvement of national parliaments in European legislative processes in recent years, as it has increased awareness of the application of the principles on which the EU is founded, including the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, in an interinstitutional context. Notes, however, that additional work still needs to be done in this context and suggests that the Commission first discuss with each national parliament every year in order to strengthen dialogue between the Commission and national parliaments. Parliament also points out that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are the basis for policy-making, and it is therefore important to assess, at the start of the legislative process, whether policy objectives can be better achieved at European level than through national or regional initiatives.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of the report is the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the Union, the examination of how these two principles have been enforced by the EU institutions in the course of legislation and enforcement, and how those two principles have been put into practice. The report examines whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice. The progress and situation of these processes are examined in the report, comparing the practices of recent years. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Members have majorityly supported the Annual Reports on Subsidiarity and Proportionality for 2012 and 2013, as they form an integral part of policy-making to determine the appropriateness of the European Union's action in achieving policy objectives vis-à-vis national and regional initiatives. I find it very positive, therefore, the initiative to adopt a green card that would allow national parliaments to propose the introduction, amendment or repeal of Union legislation. There are certainly still areas where national and regional policies have more experience and a better overview of regulating certain things than the Brussels administration has.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this document because instead of drawing the conclusions that it would be normal to draw from the data of the very low participation of national parliaments in the so-called early warning systems (just 292 opinions in 2012 and 313 in 2013, of which only 25% justified), i.e. those mechanisms, such as the "Yellow Card" and the "Orange" one, responsible for safeguarding the two principles , proposes to extend its competences, thus completely distorting the Union's decision-making process.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are enshrined in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU) and Protocol 2 to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). Their value is not merely formal: the principle of subsidiarity and the principle of proportionality govern the exercise of the Competences of the European Union.  In areas which are not the exclusive competence of the EU, the principle of subsidiarity is intended to protect the decision-making and action capacity of Member States and local communities and, at the same time, serves to legitimise Union intervention if the objectives of action cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States but can, "because of the scope or effects of the action in question" , be better achieved at Union level.  The inclusion of this principle in the European Treaties was therefore intended to bring the exercise of competences as close as possible to the citizens, which is why the purely bureaucratic and compiler-based attitude adopted too often by the European Commission on these issues is regrettable. It is in the interests of the European Parliament to bring the institutions closer to the citizens, by focusing EU action on macro-themes of common interest, by limiting its regulatory hypertrophy and by practising the principles of federal institutions: no man alone is enough, not even European officials.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report examines the extent to which the Union respects the principle of subsidiarity, which limits the scope of intervention and the competences of the European institutions. However, the rapporteur points out that only a yellow card procedure has succeeded in convincing the Commission to abandon a legislative proposal. As a reminder, this type of procedure allows national parliaments to compel the Commission to respect the principle of subsidiarity. It is in this context that this report calls on the Commission to establish a constructive dialogue with national authorities and to improve its impact assessments. Although this text makes a rather realistic observation of the current situation, the proposals put forward in it are absolutely paltry to compel the European Union to respect the sovereignty of the Member States. As such, a red card procedure would give national governments a veto if they consider a proposal contrary to the vital interest of their people.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental guiding principles for the European Union, on which the exercise of competencemust be based. The 2012-2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality underline that compliance with these principles has been closely monitored by the institutions of the European Union as well as by national parliaments. Therefore, the active participation and deeper involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process in recent years has led to increased awareness of the principles on which the EU is founded. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are the foundation of any public policy, and it is important that the European institutions and national parliaments continue to promote a culture of subsidiarity throughout the EU. In this sense, the 'yellow card' procedure has proved to be an appropriate tool to influence the decision-making process at EU level, especially in the period 2012-2013, but it is necessary to duplicate these instruments through a constant exchange of information between national parliaments. I was in favour of this report because I consider it essential to apply the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in order to ensure a dialogue that facilitates citizens' access to the decision-making process.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report is absolutely positive.  The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality – according to Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union – are at the basis of the legislative activity of the Brussels institutions and their respect, especially for a political group such as ours, is fundamental. For this reason, since the text of the Committee on Legal Affairs is very strict with regard to the European Commission, we cannot fail to support it with a positive vote. It must be said, however, that the Group of the Party of European Democrats is intervening with a whole series of amendments which seek to reduce the prerogatives of the Member States (on which we shall vote against). The report, in fact, underlines the important role of the national parliaments and also assumes that, in future, the possibility for the national legislator to plead, perhaps with more time, for the EU legislator to respect the principle of subsidiarity. Not only that, it is also emphasised that the Treaties regulate the exception of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality only at the beginning of the legislative procedure, while it would be desirable for national parliaments to be able to express themselves even in the later stages of the sometimes lengthy codecision procedure.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it jeopardizes the fragile but essential balance for the proper functioning of the Union. The report calls for the creation of additional procedural steps in our legislative process that slow the already heavy bureaucratic burden on our institutions and make it almost impossible to carry out the legislative process.  Under these principles and outside the areas of exclusive competence, the European Union should intervene only if it is able to act more effectively than EU countries at their respective national or local levels. These principles require that the means used by the EU, in order to achieve the objectives set by the Treaties, cannot go beyond what is necessary. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be balanced with the need for the efficiency of the work of our institutions. This balance must be balanced with measures. We must say yes to these principles, but not at the expense of the effectiveness of the Union for its citizens.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the Karim report today. As a matter of principle we cannot support a report which endorses the current legislative system under the Treaties. UKIP is opposed to any system which gives the EU the right to impose legislation on the UK and of any concomitant system of giving national Parliaments permission to legislate on some issues, a system which is the very negation of Parliamentary sovereignty. ‘Subsidiarity and proportionality’ are weasel words intended to convey the sense that the EU is not a monolithic, all-pervading entity and that the ability of Member States to legislate has somehow been left intact by the Treaties. In reality the concept makes no difference whatsoever to the nature and extent of the ‘competences’ of the EU and the vast areas of policy over which the EU an effective monopoly in its ability to legislate. The EU’s power of legislation remains intact.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union states that the exercise of EU competences should be guided by the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, so it is important to encourage greater participation and involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process in order to achieve the same political results together while avoiding fragmentation. It is also essential to involve the citizens who, unfortunately, still do not feel that the European Union is close to their needs.  I am therefore voting in favour of Mr Karim's report, calling for improved political dialogue not only in the case of a yellow or orange card, but as a general rule.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important for national parliaments to exchange views on the scope and evaluation methods applied in order to assess conformity with the subsidiarity and proportionality principles. EU’s competences should always be guided by these principles. The EU only has exclusive competence in circumstances where the proposed action cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States on their own, either at central level or at regional and local level, but can rather, by reason of scale or effects of the proposed action, be better achieved at Union level.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report adequately observes how the principle of subsidiarity can be invoked to curb proposals which are very harmful to the working class, as was the Monti II directive (which limited the right to strike in States) or in the present, the inclusion of ISDS (which sanction States governing against the interests of multinationals) in trade treaties. It also values it as a democratising element by allowing national parliaments greater weight in European decisions.  Similarly, it notes the importance of legislation being proportionate (something that, as the employment opinion annexed to the report argues, should not be used as a pretext for the reduction of social rights). However, the text is reluctant to explicitly denounce how the ambiguity inherent in the concepts of subsidiarity and proportionality is being used by the EU to reduce its legislation to its neoliberal core (competition, governance, single market, trade agreements...) and to contribute to a deregulatory agenda, respectively. The complicit silence on the issue of governance, which represents a clear attack on subsidiarity with its blackmail on public finances, is particularly serious.  For all this, I abstained.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The annual reports on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality examine how these two principles have been put into effect by the EU institutions in legislation and enforcement. The examination concerns whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice. The report deals with the development and situation of these processes, while comparing the practices of recent years.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report "on the 2012 and 2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality" because it makes some unacceptable proposals. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are guiding principles of the European Union's action and the validity, effectiveness and effectiveness of the policies implemented depend on their correct application. However, this must not allow national parliaments to exceed their competences and run counter to the prerogatives of EU legislative bodies. The proposal for a 'green card' procedure, which would allow national parliaments, having secured the support of the European Parliament, to make constructive proposals for consideration by the Commission, should therefore be rejected. Just as the proposal to introduce a mid-term evaluation after the start of the adoption procedure, as well as at the end of the legislative process, is to be rejected, with the possibility of warning Those Member States that do not respect the principle of subsidiarity. It represents an unnecessary burdening of procedure and damaging EU control over Member States in the exercise of their prerogatives.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as while the objectives and intentions on this report were very positive; any positive provisions were undone by a negative agenda running throughout the text.  Let me be clear, there is no party more committed to protecting Irish sovereignty than Sinn Féin. In my role as an MEP in the European Parliament, I am continuously seeking to ensure that the interests of the Irish people are placed at the forefront of any EU policy. It goes without saying that principle of subsidiarity must represent the starting point for policy formulation. However, the negative provisions in relation to EU trade policy and the ISDS, means that I was left in no position but to abstain on this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a good analysis of the implementation of subsidiarity and proportionality principles in the years 2012-2013. The two principles are an integral part of EU’s policy making procedures and are linked to democracy. They are essential to ensure the trust of citizens in the EU and reduce the democratic deficit. Despite the decent situation as presented by the report, I believe that there is always room for improvement and National Parliaments should be even more involved in the EU policy making.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to increase member states' control over the activities of the European Union and especially the Commission, a critical position shared several times by the 5-Star Movement. I voted in favour.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report. I bitterly regret the adoption of certain amendments whose content weighs down and weakens the European legislative process in favour of national particularisms.  I am referring in particular to the 'green card' procedure, which allows national parliaments to submit legislative proposals to the Commission. Is such a procedure necessary when it is precisely up to MEPs, elected at the local level, to make the interests of their compatriots to the European institutions in particular?  In addition, some amendments adopted in plenary require evaluations on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality mid-term and at the end of the legislative process. I believe that these additional controls would only slow down an already complex legislative process. Above all, how can we justify the need for such assessments even though the inter-institutional agreement "Better regulation" provides for a strengthening of impact studies on subsidiarity control?  At a time when Europe is (de)constructed according to national withdrawals, Parliament is sending a very bad message to those who believe in a true Union.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report, and we welcome the closer involvement and more dynamic involvement, in recent years, of national parliaments in the European legislative process which has led to increased awareness of the principles on which the EU is based, including the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the interinstitutional framework. We note, however, that much remains to be done in this area.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was obvious to vote in favour of this report on the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. These are fundamental guiding principles and the whole organisation of the European Union is based on them. In my opinion, these are essential principles for increasing citizens' confidence in the institutions while respecting the individual Member States. It is essential, however, that these principles work best, that the individual national parliaments participate more in the European debate and, for our part, we need to reach out more.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are pinnacle principles of the EU. National parliaments, having had closer involvement in the European legislative process over the last years, have increased awareness of the EU’s guiding principles. Impact assessments in the legislative process are essential and issues relating to subsidiarity and proportionality must be dealt with in detail. These assessments, considered a key part of the democratic process, are necessary to engage the trust of citizens. National parliaments should exchange their views on the evaluation tools used in order to assess conformity with subsidiarity and proportionality principles. This would strengthen the yellow card procedure, which is integral for influencing EU decision making. As such this procedure should be made more accessible for parliaments. The Commission is called to make the procedure for applying EU funds, particularly the application process, more efficient.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are of utmost importance for the functioning of the European decision-making process. The first allows decisions to be taken at the level closest to voters, the second guarantees (in)action appropriate to the objectives pursued. Subsidiarity, in particular, has seen its role strengthened with the Treaty of Lisbon. National parliaments can now stop the legislative process for breaching this principle. The years 2012 and 2013 do not seem to have been very active in this area, but on two occasions the so-called "yellow card" was used, forcing at least to reassess the proposal. I do not think it is time to review these procedures, as national parliaments are just beginning to make use of these procedures, but I welcome the adoption of the report in that it shows a clear evolution and increasing importance of these two principles.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report stresses the importance of subsidiarity and proportionality and the need for national parliaments to be more involved in the legislative process in the EU. The report proposes to include more suggestions made by national parliaments, including preparatory work such as green and white papers, an extension of the consultation period with national parliaments as part of subsidiarity checks and a broader dialogue between the European Commission and each national parliament through an annual debate.  I voted in favour of the report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report from my colleague Mr Karim, in particular its emphasis on strengthening national parliaments’ role in the EU legislative process, which is an important tool in improving the quality of legislation. Similarly positive is its emphasis on the need for the Commission to provide serious and detailed feedback when the compliance with subsidiarity of a piece of legislation is questioned by national parliaments. The report’s proposal not only for a subsidiarity check but also a full impact assessment to be undertaken at the conclusion of legislative negotiations is also important to ensure that the final legislation, which we all know can change substantially from the original proposals, complies with subsidiarity and proportionality. Better legislation should be the result of these reforms.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report looks at annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality. It establishes an overview of the procedures and mechanisms for monitoring the subsidiarity and proportionality of national parliaments.  The rapporteur highlights the importance of political dialogue between national and European institutions, and the possibility for national parliaments to propose the adoption, amendment or rejection of certain legislative provisions.  Considering that collaboration between national and European institutions improves respect for the competences of Member States and promotes the effective implementation of standards, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report.  The principles of proportionality and subsidiarity are fundamental principles of the European Union. It is essential that these two principles are respected and that the institutions and national parliaments ensure this, through careful consideration. In order to reduce the democratic deficit, it is crucial that in-depth impact assessments of subsidiarity are carried out by the Commission in order to increase the confidence of citizens and businesses.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of the report is the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the Union, the examination of how these two principles have been enforced by the EU institutions in the course of legislation and enforcement, and how those two principles have been put into practice. The report examines whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice. The progress and situation of these processes are examined in the report, comparing the practices of recent years.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the principle of subsidiarity, enshrined in Article 5 of the TUE, the European Union can only intervene if it is able to act more effectively than The Member States at national or local level.  The report regrets the ineffectiveness of the yellow card procedure, which is the main weapon of national parliaments to force the Brussels Commission to respect the principle of subsidiarity. It also deplores the massive use of "delegated acts", i.e. commission decrees-laws. Unfortunately, the report merely calls on the Commission to engage with national parliaments and improve its impact assessments.  To the extent that the report makes a straight statement, but does not respect the sovereignty of the Nations, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Karim's report because I believe that it largely underlines the importance of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, as well as enhanced cooperation with national parliaments, as enshrined in European legislation.  I agree, in particular, with the call on the European Commission to pay more attention to how the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are respected in the process of establishing European legislation.   I believe that national parliaments should be encouraged to be more involved in the monitoring process in respect of the principle of subsidiarity, as in most cases only the Polish and Swedish Parliaments send their position. I also support the initiative to verify subsidiarity and carry out a full impact assessment at the end of the legislative negotiations before the entry into force of the relevant legislation.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of the report is the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the Union, the examination of how these two principles have been enforced by the EU institutions in the course of legislation and enforcement, and how those two principles have been put into practice. The report examines whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice. The progress and situation of these processes are examined in the report, comparing the practices of recent years. In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The principle of subsidiarity and the principle of proportionality are fundamental to the proper functioning of the European Union and are the starting point for European policies. The principle of subsidiarity brings European policy closer to the citizen and determines when the European Union has jurisdiction to legislate. The same is true of the principle of proportionality, which makes any action by the European Union meaningful and adapts to the aim pursued. This report is very important, as it seeks to ensure effectiveness and also democratic legitimacy in decision-making and somehow strengthens the European project. It is true that a whole series of cards available to national parliaments have been created after the Lisbon Treaty to establish mechanisms to properly monitor the application of these principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. It should be noted that this has been carried out normally, but that it is true that all these mechanisms have to be agile, have to be really simple and have to be effective. The most important thing in these cases is cooperation between all national and European administrations and ensuring and reinforcing these two principles.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that emphasised the importance of the principle of subsidiarity in the development of EU law and policy. This core EU principle should be central to Wales’ relationship with the EU but the UK Government interprets subsidiarity as operating between the EU and UK Government levels only. It is important that decisions are made at the most appropriate level so this principle must be built upon to include people at all levels.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental guiding principles of the EU and by which it must be governed. The Commission presented the "Monti II" proposal on which national parliaments issued 12 reasoned opinions, which triggered, for the first time, the 'yellow card' process which obliges the institution from which the draft legislative act is in motion to re-review and to justify its decision on the withdrawal, amendment or maintenance of the project in question. The Commission withdrew the proposal even though the principle of subsidiarity was safeguarded. I agree that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are the starting point for policy-making and I believe it is important that, at the beginning of the legislative process, it should be assessed whether policy objectives can be achieved more effectively at European level than through national or regional measures.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: this red card would be a veto that would allow each state to enforce its sovereignty.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The trend in the EU at the legislative level has been to strengthen the EU's action to the national level, with the argument – almost always fallacious – that certain objectives are best achieved at EU level. In fact, what we do is to subvert and reverse the principle of subsidiarity. National parliaments end up having little relevance and their opinion being scorned. An example of this is the case of the "European Public Prosecutor's Office", which had a "yellow card" from parliaments, and the European Commission nevertheless maintained the proposal. Why ask the national parliaments if their opinion does not count? This report is in line with this trend. Criticism is made of the European Commission and its action, but on the other hand there is talk of the difficulty of different views at the level of national parliaments, as if everyone had to think the same way – already now, the way the EU wants – to go over the differences between Member States. The truth is that common policies within the EU always end up benefiting some. National parliaments become mere spectators of the EU legislative process. Or mere "notaries" of directives that have to transpose. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft report on subsidiarity and proportionality. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are the founding pillars of the European Union, the basis of an effective and transparent legislative procedure. The report has the virtue of strengthening the involvement of the national parliaments of the Member States, including them more in the preparatory work and improving the dialogue between them and the European Commission. Furthermore, I believe that the implementation of subsidiarity controls to be initiated at the beginning and end of the legislative process is of fundamental importance: this is a strong and real signal of a change towards a fairer European Union.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
