text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity in areas which do not fall within the exclusive competence of European Union action, they must be adopted only if the objectives of the action planned cannot be achieved at Member State, regional or local level. The principle of proportionality, which applies to all activities of the European Union, requires that the European Union, when it acts, does not go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objectives of the Treaties. The points of contention in this particular report were mainly the introduction of green red cards by national parliaments, the enhanced procedure for the award of yellow cards, the mid-term evaluation and evaluation at the end of the parliamentary term, and others.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report, which highlights the commission's poor and inadequate responses to national parliaments.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Public distrust and Euroscepticism is the result of non-compliance with the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity in EU policy-making. Obviously it is not the peoples of Europe who are to blame, no matter how much propaganda is used. The 2012 - 2013 reports demonstrate the impossibility of applying the principles for the benefit of citizens, businesses and workers, in order to reduce costs and avoid unnecessary regulatory burdens, which is why I am voting against them.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Sajjad Karim’s report because it supports subsidiarity by giving national parliaments greater influence in the EU legislative process. My Conservative colleagues and I remain strongly committed to leading the way in reducing the EU’s democratic deficit.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in a strong Europe, which is capable of acting and of making the lives of European citizens better. This report follows a different aim and I will therefore not support it. I believe we need to consolidate better law-making procedures, to simplify EU law and reduce administrative and regulatory burdens. The legislative process already takes two years. Mid-term evaluation and evaluation at the end of the legislative term would make the work of the European Parliament much harder, longer and add more bureaucracy. I don’t support the introduction of green card and red card procedure for national parliaments. Further subsidiarity check and full impact assessment to be undertaken at the conclusion of the legislative negotiations would also make the process much longer.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of the report is the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the Union, the examination of how these two principles have been enforced by the EU institutions in the course of legislation and enforcement, and how those two principles have been put into practice. The report examines whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice. The progress and situation of these processes are examined in the report, comparing the practices of recent years.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support Parliament's position on the 2012-2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality. I agree that the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality is the starting point for policy-building. At the beginning of the legislative process, it is necessary to assess whether policy objectives can be better achieved at Union level and not through national or regional initiatives.  I also consider it important to consult, dialogue and involve citizens, businesses and civil society in the EU's decision-making process on trade policy.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour completely convinced that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental principles of the European Union. Therefore, we must always keep in mind that, whenever possible, it should be the administration closest to the citizen to develop the policies. This means that regions must play a key role in the configuration and implementation of European policies.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it jeopardizes the fragile but essential balance for the proper functioning of the Union. The report calls for additional procedural steps in our legislative process that slow down the already heavy bureaucratic burden on our institutions and make it almost impossible to carry out the legislative process.  Under these principles and outside the areas of exclusive competence, the EU should intervene only if it is able to act more effectively than EU countries at their respective national or local levels. These principles require that the means used by the EU, in order to achieve the objectives set by the Treaties, cannot go beyond what is necessary. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be balanced with the need for the efficiency of the work of our institutions. This balance must be balanced with measures. We must say yes to these principles, but not at the expense of the effectiveness of the Union for its citizens.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it jeopardizes the fragile but essential balance for the proper functioning of the Union. The report calls for the creation of additional procedural steps in our legislative process that slow the already heavy bureaucratic burden on our institutions and make it almost impossible to carry out the legislative process.  Under these principles and outside the areas of exclusive competence, the European Union should intervene only if it is able to act more effectively than EU countries at their respective national or local levels. These principles require that the means used by the EU, in order to achieve the objectives set by the Treaties, cannot go beyond what is necessary. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be balanced with the need for the efficiency of the work of our institutions. This balance must be balanced with measures. We must say yes to these principles, but not at the expense of the effectiveness of the Union for its citizens.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the EP resolution on the 2012 and 2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality because I did not share the structure of the report and the approach taken by the rapporteur. I believe, in fact, that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are absolute values, since they govern the Union's action by ensuring effectiveness and efficiency and allowing a fair balance between institutional levels: I am therefore convinced that I support the balance achieved in the negotiation of the Treaties. I do not, however, agree with too broad an interpretation of these principles, which will end up weakening the Union and its legislative action at a time of crisis and increasingly complex challenges, in order to respond to which we therefore want a strong and just Europe that makes citizens' lives better. I did not, among other things, support the introduction of a green card and a red card available to the national parliaments and an extension of the control of the national parliaments, both during and at the end of the legislative process, which go in the opposite direction. They risk paralysing the Union's action and slowing down the European decision-making process, going in the opposite direction to the recent interinstitutional agreement on better regulation. For all these reasons, I have therefore decided to reject the report as proposed by the rapporteur.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the 2012-2013 annual reports on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, as it calls for exactly what is important to me in my work: more lived and taken seriously subsidiarity in the EU. Closer to the citizens.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality is the basis for the functioning of the European Union. They make it possible to determine when the EU has the competence to draft laws and contributes to decision-making in accordance with the principle of 'as close as possible to citizens' and which actions taken by the Community institutions are necessary and necessary to achieve the objectives of the Treaty.   The increased involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process in recent years has resulted in greater awareness of the principles on which the EU is based, including the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in an interinstitutional context.  The subsidiarity control mechanism is essential for cooperation between the European and national institutions. It allows the parliaments of the Member States to deliver opinions where they do not believe that the draft EU legislative act in question complies with the principle of subsidiarity. In recent years, the number of such opinions has increased significantly, accounting for 25% in 2012 and 30% of all applications in 2013.   In addition, the yellow card procedure was launched for the first time in 2012, which led m.in. to the Commission's decision to withdraw the proposal for collective action in the context of freedom of establishment and freedom to provide services, due to a lack of political support.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are two of the EU's main legal principles. They are essential for effective legislation and fair distribution of interests and should therefore be further developed, adapted and promoted by the EU budget.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am strong believer in the principle of subsidiarity and thus firmly welcome this report. By stressing the importance of both subsidiarity and proportionality, as well as a stronger involvement of national parliaments in the EU legislative process, this report does much to enhance the democratic functionality of the EU. Many have expressed concern over the perceived democratic deficit of the EU. However with greater consideration of suggestions made by national parliaments, extended periods for consultation in addition to more comprehensive dialogue between the European Commission and national parliaments, transparency and more effective oversight of the EU’s legislative process can be achieved. Subsidiarity checks and full impact assessments to be taken at the conclusion of the legislative negotiations and in advance of the adoption of a final text will also reinforce and clarify the division of powers between the EU and national level, minimising any competence creep and interference in areas which are better left to the national level. Such measures will ensure that all policies made are representative and reactive to the needs of all EU citizens. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. Subsidiarity and proportionality are the two fundamental principles that should ensure that the European Union is built in a way that respects the sovereignty of the Member States. Annual reports on these subjects are therefore important because they are intended to reveal the abuses of the Commission's powers.  In particular, the report points out that few national parliaments explore remedies (so-called "yellow card") and that when they try to do so, the Commission does not give the expected follow-up. It is regrettable, however, that this report does not propose the introduction of a red card, allowing it to oppose an act of the Commission that undermines its vital interests.  My personal experience on objections to enforcement (on the authorisations of GMOs or chemicals), the Commission's final decisions, shows that the European Parliament itself is reluctant to exercise its mission of monitoring and defending the interests of citizens.  So I voted against this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain in this report on subsidiarity and proportionality because, although it has some interesting aspects in terms of transparency and evaluation of the legislative process for the protection of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the general view of the text is conservative, and proposes to regulate the systems of international litigation between investors and states, which we reject.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it recognises Labour’s belief that national parliaments need a stronger role in EU legislation, this will enable national parliaments to submit amendments to the Commission for consideration as well as enabling better communication between national parliaments.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It provided comprehensive information about the activities of the main EU institutional bodies.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the Union, examining how these two principles have been enforced by the EU institutions in the legislative and application of the law. The report examines whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The positive aspects of the report are the recognition of subsidiarity and proportionality as key principles for the functioning of the EU and the need for greater involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process (but underlining the protection of the Union's exclusive competences).  In this context, one of the proposals in the report is to further strengthen national parliaments in the legislative process. However, there is no criticism of the content of EU initiatives/proposals/legislation, in particular as regards the negative economic impact they have/may have on European citizens. That's why we kept abstaining.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission’s annual report that looks at how the EU institutions and bodies have implemented the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The report carefully examines the control mechanisms for the principles and suggests several modifications enabling national parliaments to have further involvement in the legislative work of the European Union.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion as the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are an important element of policy formulation to allow the EU to effectively achieve policy goals and these measures would allow for a more transparent process.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. \u2012 Proportionality and subsidiarity are essential principles of the European legislative process. A subsidiarity test is necessary, because not everything needs to be directly harmonised. If it can be better regulated at national or regional level, then European legislation is certainly not necessary. It is a shame that some of the amendments have been adopted, which includes the controversial investor state dispute settlement (ISDS) mechanism in the text. This increases the influence of companies. Multinationals use ISDS clauses in trade treaties to claim money from countries that, in their view, draw up restrictive rules to protect, for example, the environment, animal welfare or public health. This undermines democracy and the rule of law, and ISDS will certainly not pass the proportionality and subsidiarity test.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of the report is the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the Union, the examination of how these two principles have been enforced by the EU institutions in the course of legislation and enforcement, and how those two principles have been put into practice. The report examines whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice. The progress and situation of these processes are examined in the report, comparing the practices of recent years.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support a greater role for national parliaments, including enabling better and earlier communication between parliaments, and parliaments being able to submit proposals or amendments for the European Commission’s consideration. We also support the report’s proposals for mid-term and full-term evaluations of the legislative process, full impact assessments and more regular checks to ensure the principle of subsidiarity is adhered to – that decisions are taken at the most local, least centralised level of governance. Labour MEPs support an EU which takes into account the views and needs of its citizens and national parliaments, ensures legislation is adopted at the most appropriate level, and is subject to regular, ongoing review of its legislative process.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a Labour Euro MP, I fully support the provisions for a greater role for national parliaments in EU decision-making. I have always seen the European Parliament as a democratic partner to our national parliamentary colleagues. It is our job to hold the European Commission and the presidency of the European Council to account, the role of national parliaments to hold to account positions proposed and taken by national governments in the Council of Ministers. If we both do our jobs – and collaborate together in doing so – there is better democratic scrutiny for the European Union as a whole. The proposal for an enhanced ‘warning card’ system for national parliaments to have greater opportunity for national parliaments to intervene earlier on pending EU legislation where there is a concern about subsidiarity, was first proposed by the British Labour Party and only subsequently adopted by our Conservative colleagues. All of us who say Europe needs reform but that Britain is better off in a reformed European Union, should support these proposals. The benefit in the end is for our citizens, increasing democracy and ensuring that legislation is adopted at the level which is closest to the people.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report.  Subsidiarity is a fundamental part of the EU, as set out in the Treaty of Lisbon.  This House has nothing to fear from it or indeed from impact assessments into the work of the EU. The EU must be properly engaged with its citizens and subsidiarity is a key element of that engagement.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We need a strong Europe and I don’t agree with the direction in which this report is going. We need another Europe—friendly strategy for subsidiarity and proportionality. I voted against this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the 2012-2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality, because I consider these two principles to be the basis for the functioning of the Union structure. In this context, I believe that greater involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process and the design of other policies is necessary; whether certain objectives can be better achieved at European than regional or local level.  Accordingly, I support the use of the yellow card procedure by national parliaments, as was the case in 2012. In addition, the impact assessment process, political dialogue and efforts to promote the principle of subsidiarity across the Union are important in order to apply it consistently and effectively. Therefore, I strongly support the requirement, in line with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, which requires the Commission to simplify the application procedures for European funds.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The yellow card procedure is the main weapon of national parliaments to force the Brussels Commission to respect the principle of subsidiarity. It obliges the Commission to reconsider a legislative proposal when it has been the subject of "reasoned opinions", i.e. protests, by one third of the national parliaments of the Member States. Subsidiarity is therefore a decoy. The Commission does not respect it and violates it either directly or indirectly through 'delegated acts', i.e. decree-laws to which it uses it massively, as the report deplores.  The report has the merit of denouncing this situation. But he disappoints by merely calling on the Commission to engage in dialogue with national parliaments and improve its impact studies. This is a much more radical solution that should be put in place: it would be to create a real red card procedure, which would allow each Member State to oppose a legislative proposal by the Commission if it considers that this proposal undermines its vital interest.  I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the Karim report today. As a matter of principle we cannot support a report which endorses the current legislative system under the Treaties. UKIP is opposed to any system which gives the EU the right to impose legislation on the UK and of any concomitant system of giving national parliaments permission to legislate on some issues, a system which is the very negation of parliamentary sovereignty.  ‘Subsidiarity and proportionality’ are weasel words intended to convey the sense that the EU is not a monolithic, all-pervading entity and that the ability of Member States to legislate has somehow been left intact by the Treaties. In reality the concept makes no difference whatsoever to the nature and extent of the ‘competences’ of the EU and the vast areas of policy over which the EU an effective monopoly in its ability to legislate. The EU’s power of legislation remains intact.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality to be at the heart of the democratic process and the drafting of legislation in the EU. At a time when the European public is very sensitive to excessive EU interference, it is certainly a good idea to use this instrument, to involve national parliaments in legisating and thus to improve citizens' awareness of decisions in Brussels. I therefore welcomed the report calling for the European Commission to communicate consistently with parliaments and an adequate explanation of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality for individual documents. I also think that the Commission should respond better in the case of yellow cards and explain its position both in the national parliament and before the relevant Committee of the European Parliament.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the 2012 and 2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality proposed by my colleague Sajjad Karim.  The report highlights the fact that extensive impact assessments that assess compliance with subsidiarity in depth are essential to improve citizens' confidence. I have endorsed this Commission proposal which helps decision-makers assess whether legislation is in line with EU principles and improves transparency about the outcome of negotiation periods. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This text dealt with two Commission reports on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the European Union, and in particular on the link with national parliaments and on the use of impact assessments in the framework of the legislative procedure at European level.  In particular, the report suggests better integration of national parliaments into the legislative process. As this text is balanced, I therefore voted in favour of it

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report, as it calls for reform of the European Union’s law-making procedures, including a greater role for national parliaments, and regular reviews of the legislative process.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of the report is the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the Union, the examination of how these two principles have been enforced by the EU institutions in the course of legislation and enforcement, and how those two principles have been put into practice. The report examines whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice. The progress and situation of these processes are examined in the report, comparing the practices of recent years

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report on the European Commission's report on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality comes at a time when the future of the European Union and the principles of the joint functioning of the Member States are being re-discussed. The broad support for this report and the good opinions on it show that the fundamental principle of the functioning of the EU, which is subsidiarity, should be examined more frequently and more deeply in law-making, so that it benefits Member States, provides added value, a tool that solves problems at European level better than single Member States could do.  This report, in addition to calling for greater involvement and a stronger voice of national parliaments in the creation of European law, recalls the existing tools for assessing the effects of regulation in the context of the principle of subsidiarity. This is necessary at a time when numerous EP reports go beyond eu competences, encroach on member states' competences and create unnecessary tensions and divisions.  The principle of subsidiarity does not mean that the EP cannot comment on national policies, but merely that common solutions in this area require voluntary cooperation between Member States and cannot be imposed in advance as a 'European response to the problem', but should be based from the bottom-up basis on the exchange of good practices and then the coordination of selected actions so as to benefit cooperation without restricting the freedom of the Member States.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no doubt that principles of subsidiarity and proportionality should apply to EU’s common commerce policy in a proper way. This is so, because of the importance of the policy in the formation process of EU’s economic relations with third countries and regional organisations. Thereby, in a long term perspective, both principles (subsidiarity and proportionality) will bring transparency in cases when the Union carry out trade negotiations which on the other hand will speed up ratification procedure of trade agreements between the EU and a third party.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have decided to support Mr Karim's report on the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, which are linked to the whole interinstitutional context. These principles form an integral part of the political order and aim to establish whether EU action is capable of developing better policy objectives than those of national or even regional policies. Examples of this are the threshold of "yellow cards", reached in 2012 on the Monti II proposal; the introduction of the 'green card' which would allow national parliaments the opportunity to propose the introduction, amendment or repeal of EU legislation and the 'red card', which considers the extension of the consultation period of national parliaments under the control of subsidiarity and to introduce a stronger procedure.  In the light of the above, I believe that this issue deserves further action and action to increase its potential, and I also believe that the Commission must make every effort to ensure that its dialogue with each of the national parliaments can be capable of strengthening its dialogue with them.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against reports on subsidiarity and proportionality.  The principle of subsidiarity is fundamental. The EU can only intervene if it is able to act more effectively than the Member States.  The yellow card procedure is the main weapon of national parliaments to compel the Commission to respect this principle. It obliges the Commission to reconsider a legislative proposal when it has been the subject of "reasoned opinion" by one third of national parliaments. The report notes that this yellow card has succeeded only once in persuading the Commission to abandon a proposal. It's a very meagre record.  The report has the merit of denouncing this situation. But he disappoints by merely calling on the Commission to engage in dialogue with national parliaments and improve its impact studies.  A red card procedure should be created, which would allow each Member State to oppose a Commission legislative proposal if it undermines its vital interest. This right of veto that would allow each state to enforce its sovereignty. It would be a first step towards replacing the European Union with the Europe of Nations.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because, while it does find that the EU is undermining the principle of subsidiarity, it proposes, to deal with it, only homeopathic remedies: dialogue, impact studies, create a 'green card' allowing national parliaments to make suggestions to the Commission...

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it jeopardizes the fragile but essential balance for the proper functioning of the Union. The report calls for the creation of additional procedural steps in our legislative process that slow the already heavy bureaucratic burden on our institutions and make it almost impossible to carry out the legislative process.  Under these principles and outside the areas of exclusive competence, the European Union should intervene only if it is able to act more effectively than EU countries at their respective national or local levels. These principles require that the means used by the EU, in order to achieve the objectives set by the Treaties, cannot go beyond what is necessary. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be balanced with the need for the efficiency of the work of our institutions. This balance must be balanced with measures. We must say yes to these principles, but not at the expense of the effectiveness of the Union for its citizens.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it jeopardizes the fragile but essential balance for the proper functioning of the Union. The report calls for the creation of additional procedural steps in our legislative process that slow the already heavy bureaucratic burden on our institutions and make it almost impossible to carry out the legislative process.  Under these principles and outside the areas of exclusive competence, the European Union should intervene only if it is able to act more effectively than EU countries at their respective national or local levels. These principles require that the means used by the EU, in order to achieve the objectives set by the Treaties, cannot go beyond what is necessary. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be balanced with the need for the efficiency of the work of our institutions. This balance must be balanced with measures.  We must say yes to these principles, but not at the expense of the effectiveness of the Union for its citizens.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report adequately observes how the principle of subsidiarity can be invoked to curb proposals which are very harmful to the working class, as was the Monti II directive (which limited the right to strike in States) or in the present, the inclusion of ISDS (which sanction States governing against the interests of multinationals) in trade treaties. It also values it as a democratising element by allowing national parliaments greater weight in European decisions.  Similarly, it notes the importance of legislation being proportionate (something that, as the employment opinion annexed to the report argues, should not be used as a pretext for the reduction of social rights). However, the text is reluctant to explicitly denounce how the ambiguity inherent in the concepts of subsidiarity and proportionality is being used by the EU to reduce its legislation to its neoliberal core (competition, governance, single market, trade agreements...) and to contribute to a deregulatory agenda, respectively. The complicit silence on the issue of governance, which represents a clear attack on subsidiarity with its blackmail on public finances, is particularly serious.  For all this, I abstained.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 The 2012 and 2013 annual reports are carried out to ensure that the principles of Subsidiarity and Proportionality protected by the ETE are respected when the EU institutions make use of their powers conferred. However, they clarify that much remains to be done to strengthen their consideration.  It suggests that the EC participate in annual discussions with each of the national parliaments in order to strengthen dialogue with them. I support the adoption of this report, which also provides a study of the reasoned opinions of recent years, from national parliaments, in expressing concern to the Commission about the lack of respect for these principles. It further emphasizes the value of some instruments used by the EC, such as impact assessments, which support decision-making during the legislative process, and thus properly assess issues relating to subsidiarity and proportionality.  I therefore vote in favour of the adoption of this report and underline the importance of political dialogue as a tool for improving and ensuring respect for these principles.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report is outdated, dealing with the situation of 2012 and 2013. In the meantime, Slovakia and Hungary have brought an action against the EU for the disproportionate and in breach of subsidiarity of the decision taken on the redistribution of migrants, and this report does not take this into account.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are the fundamental guiding principles of the European Union and the starting points for policy-making. The annual reports for 2012 and 2013 show that the Institutions of the European Union and national parliaments carefully monitored whether these two principles were respected. It also shows the more active participation and involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process in recent years. It is important that national parliaments and European institutions exchange views and practices to monitor the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, as they are essential to increase the trust of citizens who see them as an important tool for reducing the democratic deficit. In order to ensure compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, political dialogue is becoming increasingly important.  In this regard, efforts by the Commission and rapporteurs to appear more frequently and contact national parliaments should be encouraged. These reports ask the Commission to simplify eu fund application procedures in line with the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity in order to be more efficient and results-oriented, so I supported this proposal.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality enshrined in the EU Treaty are an essential instrument for adjusting relations between union bodies and Member States. In order to adopt standards, it will always be important to properly assess in advance whether the policy objectives pursued can be achieved more effectively at Pan-European or national level. I agree that a re-examination of subsidiarity and impact assessment should be carried out before any final text of the regulation or directive is adopted, thereby increasing the transparency and compliance of standards with Union principles.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the 2012-2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/4/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This report aims to substantially change the definition of the principle of subsidiarity, currently set out in Article 5 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The principle of subsidiarity is to limit the european Union's interventions outside its exclusive powers and thus preserve the prerogatives of sovereign states. The principle of proportionality is closely associated with it.  In fact, the application of the principle of subsidiarity is flawed and is the subject of many twists and starts by the European Commission. The remedies of national parliaments are, in fact, largely illusory. It is therefore the procedure of appeal that needs to be strengthened, by establishing a real mechanism of "red card" of national parliaments.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the closer participation and stronger involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process in recent years, which has resulted in an increased awareness of the principles on which the EU is founded, including the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the inter institutional context; notes, however, that further work still needs to be done in this context; suggests as a first step that the Commission engage in a yearly debate with each of the national parliaments in order to strengthen the dialogue between the Commission and the national parliaments.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2012 and 2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality.   The aim of the report is to highlight the increased participation and closer involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process in recent years, which has led to increased awareness of the principles on which the EU is founded, including the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the interinstitutional context.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Here in the European Parliament we must not forget the path we have taken and the principles on which the European Union was formed, without forgetting respect for the authority of the national institutions. Whatever we do, we must not impose excessive burdens on businesses. Overall, we need to reduce the perception of a democratic deficit and improve trust and participation among our citizens, so for these reasons I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental to the proper functioning of the EU and are the starting point for European policies. This report is important because the attempt is to ensure effectiveness and also democratic legitimacy in decision-making, so I support the 2012 and 2013 reports.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are unquestionably fundamental principles of the Union found in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union. Any European legislation must comply with these principles, which strengthen the legal basis and legality of the Union's legislative process. While I consider the efforts of previous years to apply the two principles to Union policies to be remarkable, I would like to highlight the need for more strengthening of the mechanism for monitoring their implementation through effective cooperation between the European and national legislative bodies. The resolution also provides for dialogue with the Member States at the initial stage of each legislative process and the taking into account of the reasoned opinions of the national parliaments, which have the first say in matters outside the exclusive jurisdiction of the Union. However, there are further important means of monitoring the principle of subsidiarity, as well as monitoring the consequences of its ignorance in legislative negotiations with the States. The above-mentioned principle of subsidiarity, in addition to the principle of proportionality where the instruments used are proportionate to the purpose served, are crucial guarantees of the legitimacy of the Union legislative process and I am therefore voting against this resolution.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report hypocritically discusses subsidiarity and proportionality. It certainly makes some criticisms of the "yellow" card procedure and the consideration of national parliaments.  If it welcomes the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism, it is to better welcome the fact that this area is an exclusive competence of the EU and, therefore, that the principle of subsidiarity does not apply to this policy". This means that the TAFTA could not be voted on in a Member State (referendum, Congress of Parliamentarians).  Finally, he concludes by calling for "extensive integration of the Union's foreign policy instruments, combining trade policy, development policy and the common foreign and security policy". All regal attributions will be removed from popular control.  I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality help to establish the EU's scope of action and its legitimacy.  The yellow card procedure sent by national parliaments to the Commission is a remedy in case of abuse of prerogative. However, I note that this procedure has only been successful once, against a questioning of the right to strike in 2012. The rest of the time, she was scorned with some autocratic assurance. This warning tool is therefore a decoy.  The report itself notes this, but its measures are not radical enough, as they recommend that the Commission engage in dialogue with national parliaments. We would be in favour of the establishment of a veto of the Member States. As a result, I have spoken out against this text

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it highlights the progress already made in the field of subsidiarity and proportionality, but also provides concrete proposals for improvement, such as in the inclusion of SMEs and civil society in the EU decision-making process.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental principles of the EU, under which the Union can only act in areas outside its exclusive competence "if, and to the extent that the objectives of the proposed action cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States, both at the central and regional and local levels. , but can be better, because of the dimensions or effects of the action envisaged, at EU level" and as long as "the content and form of the Union's action do not exceed what is necessary to achieve the objectives of the treaties".  In order to promote a genuine 'culture of subsidiarity' within the Union, I believe that it would be appropriate to extend the consultation period of national parliaments from 8 to 12 weeks for subsidiarity analyses because in most cases national parliaments have internal priorities, imposed by national legislation. This extension of the consultation period would involve a treaty change and therefore should lead to a revision of the treaty.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are essential essential elements on which EU law is built. They enable European legislatures to assess whether the objectives set can be achieved as effectively as possible by adaptation at national, regional or European level. When developing new legislation, the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are examined at an early stage of the legislative process as part of the impact assessment. I share the rapporteur's suggestion that, in order to assess credibiliously the maintenance of those principles, it is necessary that their observance be assessed at later stages of the drafting of new legislation, as this is in many cases lengthy. I also believe that we will only achieve the objective of quality standardisation by working more closely with national parliaments, thereby guaranteeing a greater degree of continuity between the work of the European Parliament and national legislatures and thus a higher level of citizens' confidence in European legislation, which I consider ultimately to be our primary objective. I am voting in favour of the position as presented.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of closer participation and stronger involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process, which has resulted in an increase in the awareness of the principles upon which the EU is founded, including the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the inter-institutional context. However, I also believe that the Commission need to involve all stakeholders including social partners, consumers organisations, NGOs in the impact assessment of EU legislation, to run the proportionality and subsidiarity check (at ex-ante stage), and to monitor implementation (ex-post stage). This Report follows a different aim, therefore I voted against.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. 'Subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental guiding principles of the European Union. The Commission presented its annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality for 2012 and 2013 under the subsidiarity control mechanism introduced in the Treaty of Lisbon. The importance of these two years is that both have had yellow card procedures: in 2012, in relation to the Commission's proposal for a Council Regulation on the exercise of the right to collective action in the context of freedom of establishment and freedom to provide services, and in 2013 the Commission's proposal for a Council Regulation establishing a European Public Prosecutor's Office.  The report contains a number of elements that would weaken EU decision-making, the role of the European Parliament and even hang the EU legislative process. As a result, I was ultimately unable to support the report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report notes that this yellow card has succeeded only once in persuading the Commission to abandon a proposal. It was in 2012, about the scandalous "Monti 2" proposal that called into question the right to strike. This is a very meagre record because the rest of the time, the Commission has rejected with some arrogance the other yellow cards. Subsidiarity is therefore a decoy. The Commission does not respect it and violates it either directly or indirectly through 'delegated acts', i.e. decree-laws to which it uses it massively, as the report deplores.   The report has the merit of denouncing this situation, but it disappoints by merely calling on the Commission to engage in dialogue with national parliaments and improve its impact studies. This is a much more radical solution that should be put in place: to allow each Member State to oppose a commission legislative proposal if it considers that this proposal undermines its vital interest.   Therefore, it is appropriate to vote against this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of Article 5 OF the ET and Protocol No 2 TFEU, the European institutions shall respect the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, which are of a general nature and bind the institutions in the exercise of the powers of the Union, except in the case of areas of the union's exclusive competence, where the principle of subsidiarity is not applicable. Subsidiarity and proportionality are key GUIDing principles of the EU as key tools for shaping policies for the benefit of EU citizens, and are also instruments for assessing the financial impact of legislation. I am pleased to record that the number of reasoned opinions as a percentage of the total number of communications has increased significantly. I support the rapporteur's regret about the lack of common standards, which makes it more difficult to assess on which basis the intervention of the parliaments of the Member States is based. I highlight the importance of impact assessments for decision-making during the legislative process and, in this context, it is essential to implement rigorous impact assessments, which verify compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, with the aim of regaining the confidence of citizens, for whom subsidiarity is often an essential aspect of the democratic process.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on strengthening and perfecting the internal single market, through strengthening the Powers of the Commission, reducing States as mere "partners" to implement the policy set out in Brussels, and implementing integration tools aggressively and without consultation.  I favoured a Europe of nations and not a Europe of the market, so I voted against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which supports a greater role for national parliaments, including enabling better and earlier communication between parliaments, and parliaments being able to submit proposals or amendments for the European Commission’s consideration.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the annual reports for 2012 and 2013 published by the European Commission on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the European Union.  In particular, I supported the provisions aimed at better integrating national parliaments into the legislative procedure, in particular with the creation of the 'green card', the better consideration of 'yellow card' procedures and the establishment of an impact assessment at the end of each legislative process to ensure that the result of the review work is always in line with the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We reject the 2012-2013 annual report on subsidiarity and proportionality. Subsidiarity is a key principle of the European Union which aims to define, in a relevant way, matters of shared competence between the Union and the Member States. Introduced in 1992 by the Maastricht Treaty, it also helps to establish the Union's exclusive competences. The principle of proportionality, on the other hand, is a necessary corollary to the definition of the limits of Community action and the prerogatives of the Member States. It is therefore absolutely essential that these principles are respected. Unfortunately, the report does not go in the desired direction, introducing a number of controversial elements that do not conform to our vision of the relationship between the Member States and the European Union. The Group of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament believes in a strong and united Europe, capable of acting in the interests of the citizens in order to improve the quality of life and of our Community institutions. This report, on the other hand, does not follow the indications that our group had indicated. That is why I am voting against it.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality form the basis of EUROPEAN Union policy, as they guarantee action as close as possible to European citizens and respectful of the specifics of each state.  In voting on the report on subsidiarity and proportionality, we recall the importance of maintaining these principles in the conduct of European policy. We also call for in-depth impact assessments at the end of legislative negotiations to ensure compliance with the EU's fundamental principles and to strengthen the democratic process through greater transparency.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2012 and 2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality welcome the increased participation and closer involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process in recent years, which has led to increased awareness of the principles on which the European Union is founded. I have chosen to vote in favour of this measure and I believe that there is still work to be done in this area and that the Commission must engage in an annual debate with each national parliament in order to strengthen its dialogue.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. 'Subsidiarity and proportionality are two very important principles of EU legislation. The basic idea of subsidiarity is that decisions should be taken as close as possible to citizens, taking into account the individual characteristics of the group that will be most affected by it. In order to improve the quality of legislation, it is necessary to assess the best possible at eu, national or regional level before the start of the process. The report, which I voted in favour of, calls for these two principles to be strengthened.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against the annual report 2012-2013 regarding the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental principles of the EU and are the basis of the European Union. As stated in the document adopted today, the constant evolution of the participation of national parliaments in the European legislative process is one that has led to an increase in the visibility of these EU guiding principles, namely subsidiarity and proportionality. I also appreciate that the report recommends that the European institutions and national parliaments continue to promote the culture of rapprochement with local communities through an annual interinstitutional debate, but also by integrating several positions formulated by national parliaments into the legislative texts.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which recalls the importance of the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality in ensuring the proper functioning of the Union's decision-making processes. The annual report of the Impact Assessment Committee (IAB), according to which more than 30% of the impact assessments reviewed in 2012-2013 contained an unsatisfactory analysis of compliance with the subsidiarity principle, and in 2014 this figure was even 50%, shows that the EU still has significant reserves and much improvement.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the report was not carefully drafted and was watered down in terms of content. Furthermore, the consequences of the negative trend are not adequately assessed in terms of content.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution on the annual reports on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality for the period 2012-2013. The principles of proportionality and subsidiarity form the basis of the European Union's decision-making process. The exercise of EU competence should be based on the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The proper application of these principles strengthens the protection of rights at both national and supranational level. In this context, checks on the application of the principle of subsidiarity should be strengthened, including in the legislative framework of national parliaments. In particular, it is necessary to facilitate greater involvement of the positions, perspectives and other proposals of national parliaments in political dialogue. In addition, in the light of requests from national parliaments, the time limits for consultation with national parliaments agreed between national parliaments and the Commission in accordance with the checks on the application of the principle of subsidiarity should be extended. It should be noted that the annual reports drawn up by the Commission are somewhat resoup point of view and often lack more detailed considerations on how EU policies respect the principles of subsidiarity and, in particular, proportionality.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Karim report today. As a matter of principle we cannot support a report which endorses the current legislative system under the Treaties. UKIP is opposed to any system which gives the EU the right to impose legislation on the UK and of any concomitant system of giving national Parliaments permission to legislate on some issues, a system which is the very negation of Parliamentary sovereignty. ‘Subsidiarity and proportionality’ are weasel words intended to convey the sense that the EU is not a monolithic, all-pervading entity and that the ability of Member States to legislate has somehow been left intact by the Treaties. In reality the concept makes no difference whatsoever to the nature and extent of the ‘competences’ of the EU and the vast areas of policy over which the EU an effective monopoly in its ability to legislate. The EU’s power of legislation remains intact.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, enshrined in Article 5 TFEI, are fundamental principles of the European Union. The need for greater involvement of Member States in the definition of European policies must always be in line with these principles, and in some cases the definition of these principles and the division of competences between the Member States and the EU is confusing. Given that greater dialogue between the national parliaments and the European institutions can help to respect these principles and reduce the so-called 'yellow card', I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the European Commission's decision to launch a public consultation on the revision of the impact assessment guidelines and on the guidance for stakeholder consultation following Parliament's request to improve communication with civil society in a Resolution of 14 September 2011 on better legislation, subsidiarity and proportionality. In my view, assessing the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality is an important part of the EU's policy-making process.  I welcome the process that, during the drafting of the European Union budget, budgetary authorities would use a full assessment of the results of policies supported by the European Commission, which would achieve greater efficiency, as it outlines the fact that EU budgetary resources are in some cases spent on projects that do not deliver concrete results. I call on the Commission to consider introducing on-the-spot assessments for projects with high local financial impact and to simplify the application procedures for EU funds in line with the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity in order to make such procedures more efficient and successful.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report notes that the so-called yellow card procedure succeeded only once in persuading the Commission to abandon a proposal in 2012. The rest of the time, the Commission arrogantly rejected the objections. Subsidiarity is therefore a decoy. The Commission does not respect it and rapes it directly or indirectly through 'delegated acts', i.e. decree-laws to which it uses it massively, as the report deplores.  The text denounces this situation. But he disappoints by merely calling on the Commission to engage in dialogue with national parliaments and improve its impact studies. This is a much more radical solution than it should be: to create a real red card procedure, a veto, which would allow each Member State to oppose a commission legislative proposal. This would be a first step towards replacing the European Union with the Europe of Nations.  As it stands, I therefore vote against this report, which is too pusillanimous.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are the starting point for policy-shaping and the fundamental guiding principles of the European Union. I therefore emphasise that the application of EU competences should be inspired by these principles. In areas that are not within the exclusive competence of the European Union, the principle of subsidiarity aims at protecting the right of Member States to take decisions and act and to give legitimacy to Union action if Member States cannot sufficiently achieve the objectives of an action, and therefore has practical importance in particular through legislative procedures.  Through the principle of proportionality, the action of the EU institutions seeks to be set within certain limits. Under this rule, EU action must be limited to what is necessary to achieve the objectives of the Treaties. For this reason, I underline the need for the European institutions to respect the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, and note the importance of impact assessments and mechanisms for verifying the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, as they are essential for cooperation between european and national institutions.  I am concerned that the Commission's annual reports are routine in some way and often do not consider in more detail how subsidiarity, and in particular proportionality, is respected when designing EU policy. I believe in a strong Europe that is able to make lives better for its citizens, and I regret that this report does not follow the same beliefs.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 These annual reports monitor the application of Article 5 OF the ETS. The application of these principles is closely related to the relationship between the European Union and the authorities of the Member States, the national parliaments.  Despite the pleadings of this article, the practice demonstrates the ongoing trend of strengthening the Union's action in favor of national or regional action, on the grounds that certain objectives are better achieved at Union level. National Parliaments end up not only having little relevance but also disregarded. This is an example of the case of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which had a yellow card from parliaments, but which the Commission eventually held. National parliaments cannot become mere spectators of the EU legislative process, which covers key areas of their day-to-day life and their collective. Although it promotes some criticism of the Commission, the rapporteur supports the idea of the need to centralise the decision, valuing the policy of legislative reduction in an economic ism. The imposition of common policies has as its end, in addition to the loss of sovereignty of states, the benefit of some states to the detriment of others. We reject the attack on sovereignty and the attempt to empty the role and responsibilities of national parliaments, structures representing citizens. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported colleague Sajjad Karim's report on the 2012 and 2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality. These are integral principles of policy-making, to determine whether the EU can achieve its objectives better than local or regional initiatives. I consider it necessary to stress the importance of the principle of subsidiarity, in particular through full impact assessment procedures, which thoroughly evaluate compliance with the principle and thus are essential for improving the trust of citizens, who closely bind the principle of subsidiarity to democracy.  I am committed to carrying out further subsidiarity checks and a full impact assessment at the end of the legislative process, as this period will help policymakers assess the compatibility of legislation with the EU's founding principles and increase the transparency of the overall process.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the 2012 and 2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality, whose initial vote had been postponed due to negotiations on the institutional agreement "Better Legislate".  With this text, I wanted to support a better integration of national parliaments into the European legislative procedure through a 'green card' procedure, giving the possibility of asking the European Commission to work on an initiative, revision or withdrawal of EU legislation. It is also proposed that an impact study be carried out at the end of each legislative process to ensure that the outcome of the review work is consistent with the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Karim report today. As a matter of principle we cannot support a report which endorses the current legislative system under the Treaties. UKIP is opposed to any system which gives the EU the right to impose legislation on the UK and of any concomitant system of giving national Parliaments permission to legislate on some issues, a system which is the very negation of Parliamentary sovereignty. ‘Subsidiarity and proportionality’ are weasel words intended to convey the sense that the EU is not a monolithic, all-pervading entity and that the ability of Member States to legislate has somehow been left intact by the Treaties. In reality the concept makes no difference whatsoever to the nature and extent of the ‘competences’ of the EU and the vast areas of policy over which the EU an effective monopoly in its ability to legislate. The EU’s power of legislation remains intact.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree that the verification of the principle of subsidiarity is very important for collaboration between the European, national and regional institutions. The principle of subsidiarity only enables the Union to act beyond its competence where the objectives of the action in question cannot be achieved by the Member States, both at central and regional and local level, but may, due to the size or effects of the action under consideration, be better achieved at Union level. On the other hand, the principle of proportionality requires that the content and form of Union action should not go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objectives of the Treaty. I therefore agree that policy-making must respect the principle of subsidiarity and have tangible European added value. And I believe that it is essential that the principle of subsidiarity be respected in view of the role of the social partners and ensuring their autonomy in accordance with the customs and traditions of the Member States; violations of the principle of subsidiarity can have consequences for citizens' loss of confidence.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The principle of subsidiarity is intended to determine the most relevant level of intervention in the areas of competence shared between the EU and EU countries, whether at national, regional or local level. In any case, the EU can intervene only when its action is more effective than that of the national, regional or local administrations of the Member States.  The principle of proportionality, applicable to all EU action, provides that Union action must be limited to what is necessary to achieve the objectives set out in the Treaties. The application of these principles makes it possible to determine when the EU has jurisdiction to legislate and contributes to decisions being taken as close to citizens as possible. The European Parliament draws up annual reports on the application of these principles in the Union. I have decided not to support with my vote the reports relating to the years 2012 and 2013 used by the British Conservative rapporteur to shape his anti-European and Eurosceptic agenda. These reports aim to strengthen the powers of national parliaments to impede the decisions taken by the Union, reduce its legislative capacity and weaken the European project.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which welcomes the increased participation and commitment of national parliaments in the European legislative process in recent years, but notes that efforts still need to be made in this regard. For example, the adopted text suggests, in particular, that, as a first step, the European Commission should engage in an annual debate with each national parliament to strengthen its dialogue with them.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report. I believe that the document is well designed: it raises an important issue of consultation with national parliaments, contains valuable proposals for improving the impact assessment of draft legislation, green card, speeding up the adoption of legislation, introduction of a procedure and more. At the same time, I share the group's view that the report is not ambitious enough. It identifies objectives already or has been achieved, such as extending the consultation period with national parliaments from 8 to 12 weeks or, in the case of an impact assessment, already being implemented. On the other hand, the proposed impact assessment reform, which provides for a full impact assessment of the legislation before it enters into force (instead of the current simplified assessment), would, in my view, significantly complicate and prolong the legislative process and certainly do not contribute to the objectives of better law-making. I am therefore voting against, but I ask you to see this as a constructive criticism, calling for the work that has been started to continue and to draw up further efforts to prepare the report's thesis.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The control of subsidiarity and proportionality by national parliaments examined by this report is a fundamental part of the application of these principles in the framework of the European legislative building. In fact, subsidiarity and proportionality are an integral and guiding element in european policy-making in order to establish the level of improvement that the political results of Eu action can achieve, in terms of strengthening, dialogue and cooperation with national parliaments.  What the 2012-2013 reports on subsidiarity and proportionality demonstrated was greater participation and greater involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process, demonstrating greater effectiveness of objectives at a macro level than through simple national or regional measures. Like the rapporteur, I believe that strengthening the political dialogue between the Commission and national parliaments is essential, as is the implementation of credible impact assessments to assist in decision-making processes during the legislative process, where issues relating to subsidiarity and proportionality arise with greater autility. In view of the above, I have decided to support this report by Mr Karim.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which reminds us that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are an integral part of the development of EU policies. These two principles determine whether EU action is better able to achieve political objectives or whether national or regional action is preferable.  The 2012 and 2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality highlight in particular the importance of in-depth impact assessments, which provide information and assess compliance with subsidiarity in a thorough manner.  In the end, respect for these two principles improves the confidence of citizens and achieves, using the most effective way, the political objectives we set for ourselves.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament's vote on this report on EU decision-making calls on the Commission to take into account the reasoned opinions of national parliaments and to encourage dialogue between national parliaments and the Commission from the initial stage of the legislative process. It is a question of reaffirming the centrality of the principle of subsidiarity enshrined in the Treaties. Its respect and commitment to its real implementation are essential to reduce the democratic deficit currently suffering the Union and on which the confidence of its citizens in the institutions depends.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain in this report on subsidiarity and proportionality because, although it has some interesting aspects in terms of transparency and evaluation of the legislative process for the protection of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the general view of the text is conservative, and proposes to regulate the systems of international litigation between investors and states, which we reject.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 2012-2013 Annual Reports on the Application of the Principles of Subsidiarity and Proportionality. These are an integral part of EU-level policy-making to determine whether European Union policy objectives can be better achieved through national initiatives or EU actions. It is essential to have a thorough impact assessment of compliance with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report adequately observes how the principle of subsidiarity can be invoked to curb proposals which are very harmful to the working class, as was the Monti II directive (which limited the right to strike in States) or in the present, the inclusion of ISDS (which sanction States governing against the interests of multinationals) in trade treaties. It also values it as a democratising element by allowing national parliaments greater weight in European decisions.  Similarly, it notes the importance of legislation being proportionate (something that, as the employment opinion annexed to the report argues, should not be used as a pretext for the reduction of social rights). However, the text is reluctant to explicitly denounce how the ambiguity inherent in the concepts of subsidiarity and proportionality is being used by the EU to reduce its legislation to its neoliberal core (competition, governance, single market, trade agreements...) and to contribute to a deregulatory agenda, respectively. The complicit silence on the issue of governance, which represents a clear attack on subsidiarity with its blackmail on public finances, is particularly serious.  For all this, I abstained.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Parliament reiterates that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental guiding principles for the European Union.   The two European Commission reports of 2012 and 2013 examine how these two principles were implemented by the various European institutions. In particular, the national parliaments, which are more incisive on the ground, should be more closely involved in the EU legislative process and in the subsidiarity controls. With regard to this last point, I maintain that in addition to the impact assessments that are usually drawn up at the beginning of the legislative procedure, further evaluations should be carried out both at the intermediate stage and at the end of the legislative process and before the adoption of a final text, in order to ensure that subsidiarity and proportionality are respected.  I therefore supported the report with my vote in favour, convinced that closer monitoring by the European and national institutions will make it possible to take legislative action more efficiently, avoiding unnecessary regulatory burdens and bringing concrete benefits to citizens.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Karim report today. As a matter of principle we cannot support a report which endorses the current legislative system under the Treaties. UKIP is opposed to any system which gives the EU the right to impose legislation on the UK and of any concomitant system of giving national parliaments permission to legislate on some issues, a system which is the very negation of parliamentary sovereignty. ‘Subsidiarity and proportionality’ are weasel words intended to convey the sense that the EU is not a monolithic, all-pervading entity and that the ability of Member States to legislate has somehow been left intact by the Treaties. In reality the concept makes no difference whatsoever to the nature and extent of the ‘competences’ of the EU and the vast areas of policy over which the EU an effective monopoly in its ability to legislate. The EU’s power of legislation remains intact.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on these important principles in the European Union because it reinforces Labour’s backing of an EU that takes into account the views and needs of its citizens and their national parliaments. This increases democratic quality and closes the deficit of democracy in the EU.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual report ’12-’13 on subsidiarity and proportionality in the European Union as the idea of the report is in line with my stands on subsidiarity. It calls for a subsidiarity culture in the EU and that all reports should be checked on this matter as well.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report because important amendments have not been tabled, although I consider the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality to be a key Union policy-making tool that helps Member States at national, regional or local level to effectively address the objectives implemented. Once again, the report is faced with a reassment to cases where the principle of subsidiarity has not been adequately addressed in the Commission's impact assessments. In particular, I find it unacceptable that more than 30% of the impact assessments examined by the Committee in 2012 and 2013 point to an unsatisfactory analysis of the principle of subsidiarity. Worse still, that number rose to 50% in 2014.
