I trust that the Commission, when revising the guidelines relating to impact assessments, will deal more seriously with this issue and will do its best to improve this uncheasy situation in the next period. It is very important that, in order to respect the principle of subsidiarity, we strengthen political dialogue not only in cases of yellow or orange card, but also as a general rule (or consider the green card procedure). I also expect the European institutions and national parliaments to continue their efforts to promote a 'culture of subsidiarity' throughout the EU.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental guiding principles of the European Union and the report welcomes the fact that in 2012 and 2013 the compliance of these two principles by the EU institutions and national parliaments was carefully reviewed. What is positive is the fact that national parliaments work more closely together and become more involved in the European legislative process, as this raises awareness of the EU's fundamental principles, including subsidiarity and proportionality in the interinstitutional framework. Furthermore, national parliaments are important because of their territorial influence and proximity to citizens, and all parliaments must get even more involved in the European debate. As impact assessments are an important tool for decision-making in the legislative process, they should also take into account issues relating to subsidiarity and proportionality. Thanks to thorough impact assessments, citizens' trust could be increased, because the principle of subsidiarity is a key element of the democratic process and impact assessments could lead to a detailed assessment of compliance with this principle. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality set out in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union should guide the exercise of EU competences. For this very reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The principle of subsidiarity and proportionality are cornerstones of European integration, as they frame the European Union's action in its relations with the Member States.  Thanks to the former, in areas which do not have exclusive COMPETENCE of the EU, it acts only if and to the extent that the objectives of the action in question cannot be achieved by the Member States, at central, regional or local level, and, in accordance with the second, such intervention cannot go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objectives set out in the Treaties. The application of these two principles to EU actions and policies has allowed over time the creation of the internal market with freedom of movement and the progressive economic and political integration that progressive forces continue to pursue.  Unfortunately, the annual reports on the application of the two principles voted on today support a Eurosceptic and misleading view, as they propose to introduce a series of procedures to limit EU legislative action in an instrumental way and beyond the conditions laid down in the provisions of the Treaties on the basis of the principles mentioned above. For these reasons, I voted against the report as a whole.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The principle of subsidiarity and proportionality is a fundamental principle of EU law, which defines its competences. Compliance with these principles is controlled by the European institutions and national parliaments. However, on the basis of the annual reports drawn up by the European Commission, national parliaments need to be more actively integrated into the decision-making process in order to ensure that these principles are effectively respected.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are one of the principles of European Union action and are the starting point for policy-shaping. The annual subsidiarity and proportionality reports for 2012 and 2013 indicate an increase in the percentage of reasoned opinions in total submissions compared to 2010 and 2011.  National parliaments have noted that the inclusion of important and numerous delegated powers makes it difficult to effectively assess the full compatibility of final rules with the principle of subsidiarity. Furthermore, Commission reports often do not consider in more detail how the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are respected in EU policy-shaping. Certain political objectives cannot always be achieved by European action better than national or regional initiatives can.  Full impact assessments assessing compliance with subsidiarity principles are key to increasing transparency and increasing citizens' trust in the democratic process. A stronger approach and political dialogue is needed to fully recognise and ensure compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, and I therefore support this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I advocate an EU which takes into account the views and needs of its citizens and national parliaments, increasing democracy and closing the ‘democratic deficit’, as well as ensuring that legislation is adopted at the most appropriate level to be most effective.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality indicate how much more effective the EU is in achieving political goals than national and regional institutions. For this, detailed impact assessments are used after the implementation of the legislation. This post-implementation period allows for a better assessment as it favours the progress of transparency in the publication of results. In this way, strong political dialogue gains meaning. The early dialogue and involvement of EU rapporteurs with national parliaments is encouraged. I support the 2012 and 2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality. I believe that the principle of subsidiarity is essential for the trust of EU citizens in legislation and processes relevant to democracy and life in the EU. One of the fundamental principles of democracy is subsidiarity and this is what the whole process is based on, which also contributes to the transparency of the process of democracy.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal and fully support all efforts to increase the subsidiarity of decision-making in the European Union. Although the European Union is officially committed to the principle of subsidiarity, it is in fact constantly violating it in practice, which, along with not respecting its own rules, is the main root of today's EU problems.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality 2012 and 2013. By applying the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality correctly, we will actually be able to come up with legislation that will benefit citizens, businesses and workers and avoid unnecessary administrative burdens. In particular, the Committee on Budgetary Control has taken a stand that the Commission, in accordance with both principles, simplify the procedures for obtaining EU funds. Application procedures must be effective and result-oriented. At the same time, the Commission should better demonstrate and demonstrate the added value of the MFF programmes in the beneficiary Member States. The assessment of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be an essential element of the Union and the preparation and evaluation of its policies and for citizens' trust in the EU. There is enough hammer to nail, and heavy machinery is not needed and not every problem needs to be solved at EU level, but can be properly solved at national level.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and I fully support its calls for greater respect for national parliaments, and subsidiarity and proportionality, in the EU legislative process.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Public distrust and Euroscepticism is the result of non-compliance with the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity in EU policy-making. Obviously, it is not the peoples of Europe who are to blame, no matter how much propaganda is used. The 2012 - 2013 reports demonstrate the impossibility of applying the principles for the benefit of citizens, businesses and workers, to reduce costs and avoid unnecessary regulatory burdens.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of the report is the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the Union, the examination of how these two principles have been enforced by the EU institutions in the course of legislation and enforcement, and how those two principles have been put into practice. The report examines whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice. The progress and situation of these processes are examined in the report, comparing the practices of recent years.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I did not support the report on subsidiarity and proportionality, because at this stage I do not feel it is sufficiently elaborated, a document that promotes closer European cooperation in the right direction.  Nevertheless, I underline, as highlighted in the report, subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental guiding principles of the EU, on which it is necessary to assess at the beginning of each legislative process whether policy objectives can be better achieved at EU level through national or regional initiatives. I approve of the fact that the reporter drew attention to the fact that EU budget resources have in some cases been allocated to projects that do not achieve effective results, and it is therefore essential that the Commission consider introducing on-the-spot evaluations for projects with a significant financial impact at local level.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the annual reports on compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the European Union. The exercise of the powers of the European Union must be based on these principles, moreover - just as stipulated in Article 5 of the Treaty on European Union. The EU may intervene in areas beyond its exclusive competence 'only if and to the extent that the objectives of the proposed action cannot be satisfactorily achieved by the Member States either at central or regional and local level'. At the same time, the Union's action must not go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objectives of the Treaties. Thus, we must make collaboration between national parliaments and the European institutions a priority. Exchanges of views at this time and the control practices of these principles do not take place within the optimum parameters. We believe in a strong Europe that is capable of acting and transforming the lives of European citizens for the better. EU action must be directly proportional to the need to achieve the common objectives. Everything that crosses this border can be understood as an excess of control. We therefore believe in a strong Europe, but at the same time we believe that it is precisely the decision-making power of the Member States that strengthens us.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We note that the current preferential trade agreements have shown that they can benefit the European economy and lead to growth and employment. The impact of trade agreements depends on the outcome of the negotiations, and impact projections are therefore always based on assumptions. The Commission must therefore carry out assessments of the impact on sustainable development before the launch of trade agreement negotiations as part of an ex ante impact assessment exercise in order to analyse the economic, social and environmental impact on EU citizens and businesses, and in particular on SMEs. Member States should also play a crucial role in assessing the potential benefits and benefits of preferential trade agreements on their own economies. I stress the crucial importance of an adequate mechanism for consultation, dialogue and participation of citizens, businesses (particularly SMEs) and civil society in the decision-making process on EU trade policy

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Many Europeans believe that the EU is both too distant and too involved in national matters. I voted in favour of this report assessing the implementation of these two principles in 2012 and 2013, as I agree that we should work on making impact assessments more effective, and involve our national parliaments in the European legislative process even more. This will bring the citizens closer to the EU, and bring the EU closer to the citizens.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The subject of the report is the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the Union, the examination of how these two principles have been enforced by the EU institutions in the course of legislation and enforcement, and how those two principles have been put into practice. The report examines whether the EU institutions and their bodies apply these two principles and, if so, how this works in practice. The progress and situation of these processes are examined in the report, comparing the practices of recent years.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The more active participation and stronger involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process in recent years certainly marks a positive shift, but I agree with the rapporteur's view that further work is needed to fully apply the principles underpinning the European Union, primarily the principle of subsidiarity that protects Member States' right to take decisions and their action in areas agreed by the Treaty on European Union.  I therefore consider it necessary to create patterns that define more clearly when and on what basis national parliaments should intervene and when the institutions of the European Union should intervene. I also support the proposal for more active participation and greater involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process. I believe that a strengthened dialogue between the Commission and national parliaments will contribute to increasing citizens' trust in the democratic processes of the European Union, so I supported this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the 2012 and 2013 Annual Reports on Subsidiarity and Proportionality, as I support closer cooperation and greater involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process, resulting in greater awareness of the principles on which the EU is founded, including the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in the interinstitutional framework. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are an integral part of EU policy making and governance, and they determine whether EU action delivers better results than national or regional policy.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain in this report on subsidiarity and proportionality because, although it has some interesting aspects in terms of transparency and evaluation of the legislative process for the protection of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the general view of the text is conservative, and proposes to regulate the systems of international litigation between investors and states, which we reject.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report denounces the Commission's disparaging attitude to the yellow card procedure. It illustrates very well the anti-democratic nature of the European institutions.  Unfortunately, he remains too evasive about the measures to be taken to remedy this, including the possibility of introducing a red card which would be a veto and which would allow each State to enforce its sovereignty. It would thus be a first step towards the replacement of the European Union by the Europe of nations.  I voted against this report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent years, national parliaments have become more closely involved and closely involved in the European legislative process, which has led to greater attention being paid to the principles on which the EU is based, including the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality in interinstitutional aspects. More work is still needed in this regard, so the report we are discussing proposes, as a first step, that the Commission hold annual deliberations with parliaments in order to strengthen the dialogue between the Commission and the national parliaments. With my vote, I followed the position of the S&D group.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain in this report on subsidiarity and proportionality because, although it has some interesting aspects in terms of transparency and evaluation of the legislative process for the protection of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the general view of the text is conservative, and proposes to regulate the systems of international litigation between investors and states, which we reject.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this file because it emphasises the importance of impact assessment and calls for a further subsidiarity check and full impact assessment to be undertaken at the conclusion of the legislative negotiations and in advance of the adoption of a final text, in order that compliance with subsidiarity can be guaranteed and that assessments including proportionality can be made.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Annual reports 2012-2013 on subsidiarity and proportionality. The report emphasises that the use of the EU’s competences should be guided by the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. It equally points out the crucial importance of proper consultation, dialogue and involvement of citizens, SMEs and civil society in the EU decision-making process for trade policy.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are a key element in establishing cases in which the European Union can achieve policy objectives better with respect to national and regional authorities. This report shows how the proportion of reasoned opinions has increased significantly. The rapporteur rightly addresses the need to enhance political dialogue and engagement in this area. We are therefore talking about a balanced report which has been the result of a broad commitment on the part of the House, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it jeopardizes the fragile but essential balance for the proper functioning of the Union. The report calls for the creation of additional procedural steps in our legislative process that slow the already heavy bureaucratic burden on our institutions and make it almost impossible to carry out the legislative process.  Under these principles and outside the areas of exclusive competence, the European Union should intervene only if it is able to act more effectively than EU countries at their respective national or local levels. These principles require that the means used by the EU, in order to achieve the objectives set by the Treaties, cannot go beyond what is necessary. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality must be balanced with the need for the efficiency of the work of our institutions. This balance must be balanced with measures.  We must say yes to these principles, but not at the expense of the effectiveness of the Union for its citizens.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of these annual reports because the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are an extremely important guide to European policy-making. These reports provide a great deal of information on the activities of the European institutions in relation to these two principles.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The principle of subsidiarity seems positive. The problem is that the trend we are talking about is that the Union's action should be strengthened to the national or regional level, on the grounds that certain objectives are better achieved at Union level.  In general, national parliaments end up having little relevance and their opinion is little considered. An example of this is the case of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which had a yellow card from parliaments but whose proposal the Commission eventually upheld.  So why ask the national parliaments if your opinion doesn't count? The emptying of the sovereignties of the structures representing the citizens who are closest to them is negative. National parliaments become mere spectators of the EU legislative process (as demonstrated by the experience of the card mechanism on the surveillance of the principle of subsidiarity), which covers key areas of their day-to-day and collective life.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental principles in the EU. Both the establishment of the 'green card' procedure as a precursor to the pre-warning mechanism, as called for in the report, as called for in the report, as well as the required subsidiarity assessment and impact assessment at the end of the legislative procedure, must be approved.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the annual report on subsidiarity and proportionality. According to the principle of subsidiarity, in areas outside the exclusive competence of the Union, action should only be taken if the objectives of the proposed action cannot be achieved by the Member States. According to the principle of proportionality, which applies to all Union actions, any action by the Union must not exceed what is necessary to achieve the objectives of the Treaties. I firmly believe in Europe, which is capable of acting and improving people's lives. This report is not compatible with this objective.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the annual reports 2012-2013 on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The issue itself is outdated, and the issues raised in the report are no longer relevant, as more than three years have passed. Furthermore, this is an own-initiative report and not a legislative regulation, and therefore it has no binding force. The text therefore does not represent a change in EU legislation and was therefore rejected by me.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the Report on the 2012-2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality. I welcome the fact that the rapporteur also included in the final document the recommendations of THE INTA, which noted the importance of the common trade policy, in which the EU can take advantage of its own stature to maximise the impact in terms of negotiations, and the EU's economic relations with third countries and regional organisations, for economic growth in Europe and job creation. Moreover, INTA stressed the need to clarify, in relation to the principle of subsidiarity, the division of competences when trade policies have consequences for investments other than foreign direct investment, i.e. portfolio investments, because some controversy persists in the case of current free trade agreements. INTA also stressed the importance of good consultation, dialogue and involvement of citizens, businesses (i.e. SMEs) and civil society in EU trade policy decision-making.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the Annual Report on Subsidiarity and Proportionality, as these principles are the fundamental principles that govern the entire European Union. Personally, I also agree with the closer involvement of national parliaments in the European legislative process, but I recognise that there is still a long way to go to strengthen these national parliaments and thus deepen the required principle of subsidiarity. I also find it a positive step on this issue that in 2012 the so-called yellow card procedure of national parliaments was applied for the first time, resulting in the withdrawal of the Commission proposal on the exercise of the right to collective action under the freedom of establishment and the freedom to provide services (Monti II Regulation). I consider it important that this yellow card procedure remains easy for national parliaments to apply.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the opinion on the 2012-2013 annual reports on subsidiarity and proportionality. In this opinion, the rapporteur stresses the importance of subsidiarity, proportionality and the need for greater inclusion of national parliaments of individual Member States in the European Union's legislative process. I, as well as the ECR Group, have long stressed precisely the need for a thorough review of subsidiarity and proportionality, both through enhanced dialogues with national parliaments and through impact assessments of new legislative proposals. Like the rapporteur, I believe that subsidiarity control should not be carried out only at the beginning of the legislative process and therefore in the initial proposal, as we know from experience that the texts of the original proposals can change very significantly during the process. I therefore also appeal for consideration of further additional subsidiarity tests before adopting the final proposal for new legislation.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The subsidiarity principle is an extremely valuable tool in the process of creating European law. It provides an opportunity to verify that the measures taken at European level are appropriate and effective. Member States and national parliaments thus have the opportunity to speak and take a position that takes into account their perspective. In many cases, the application of this principle has avoided the adoption of regulations which would have been much more effective if national specificities had been taken into account and the matter had been left to the legislator of a particular Member State.  Promoting the principle of subsidiarity and its particular importance should be an important task for the European institutions, and in particular for the European Parliament, which is the voice of the citizens of the Member States. In many cases, taking this voice into account more broadly would avoid legal absurdities and improve the functioning of the European administration.  I agree with the report's thesis, which indicates that the European Commission is not listening sufficiently to the voice of the Member States and to the reservations they have raised. Constructive dialogue between the Commission and the Member States should be the basis for effective legislation. It should take into account the key role of Member States in Shaping European policy and be more open to the reservations expressed by national parliaments about the Commission's proposals. I agree with the proposals made in this report and support the call for a better application of the principle of subsidiarity in the work of the European institutions.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are fundamental guiding principles of the European Union for determining whether measures taken at Union level can achieve objectives more effectively than at national, regional or local level. Of course, it is also necessary to take into account the principle of the economics of the legislative procedure, so that the procedure for lysoaing legal acts remains transparent, rapid and effective. The annual reports represent a good compromise between the principles of subsidiarity, proportionality and economics, which is why I supported them.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted whole much for this report. I believe that a danger has been averted, because we have avoided the idea of a nutritional profile, which is completely alien to that relating to good and poor nutrition, but above all in clear contrast to what European regulations already provide for, namely information on prepared foods and foods.  On the other hand, by voting in favour and removing this possibility that was on the report, we have helped to ensure that the European industry chain, the food industry, is able to ensure that the food we produce in Europe, and I say also in Italy, has the right value on the market without being affected by possible regulations that would certainly have damaged its production and export.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this report regulates important issues as to how to implement, implement and verify the effectiveness of the measures taken with regard to the objective of the common market. I would like to say that it is very important to look at how legislation is transposed in the Member States with regard to the regulation of the common market, but also very important are the internal rules of application, because often the internal rules of law enforcement totally change the law, the destination of the law, the heart of the law and the objectives of the law. It is important to circuit documents, it is important how decisions are made, how many people have to sign for a decision. All this in order to remove any red tape and any additional time for the normal application of these rules, these acts of the European Union, which are implemented in the Member States and which govern the common market.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I supported this report because I believe that any commission procedure concerning the review and improvement of the quality of European legislation is correct.  After my experience in national legislation, I believe that when legislatation is adopted, there is always less, and this is doubly true of European legislation. Therefore, if the European Commission's programme is created here to examine the quality of individual legislative proposals and to evaluate subsequently the application of this legislation, that seems to me to be the right thing to do. As well as welcoming the fact that one of the Juncker Commission's programming thes was to slow down the legislative process and really take it down. This is also seen compared to the amount of proposed legislation under the previous Commission, the Juncker Commission proposes fewer regulations.  I think that this is the right thing to do and that we should look much more at how the legislation is then implemented and how it works in practice.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé agus mo ghrúpa leis na leasuithe go léir anseo agus dar ndóigh leis an tuarascáil féin, rud atá eisceachtúil. Ach ní nach ionadh mar is tuarascáil maith é. The REFIT programme especially is a very good one, and I strongly welcome the Commission’s move towards a better regulation agenda led by Vice-President Timmermans. I especially welcome the emphasis on SMEs and how they can sometimes be hindered by excessive bureaucracy. SMEs are the drivers of employment and economic growth in the European Union. This time in particular we must do everything we can to ensure that all small businesses can prosper and create more and more jobs. Bad or excessive regulation is one of the main barriers to entry for small businesses. Incumbent market players can deal with this, but SMEs cannot, and for that reason I welcome the opportunities to have better regulation, removing excessive red tape, which will allow market access for SMEs. This will drive innovation, growth and lower consumer prices.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The regulatory compliance and enforcement programme can clearly be described as one of the most logical innovations ever implemented in the European Union, but of course its main objective is to simplify legislation, reduce regulatory costs and so on. But when our citizens ask sometimes us, the Members, and in general... When they express their views on why they are against or partly sceptical about the European Union, the clear answer is that bureaucracy and too much bureaucracy are the reason why sometimes the citizens of the European Union do not trust the European Union and its authorities. Because of maximum transparency, consultation with stakeholders and, in general, dialogue with citizens and social partners, this is task number one that we have to fulfil, and it does not, in principle, require so much time and effort for all this to happen. But in general, I support this document. I think it is very point-to-point. Thank you!

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Kaufmann report today. As a matter of principle we do not support and will not vote for any report which accepts the right of the EU to make the laws of the United Kingdom, however virtuous the proposals seem in isolation. The report makes it clear that, in whatever form, the process of legislation is going to continue. Its only virtue is that it impliedly damns the method of legislation that has pertained over the last sixty-odd years and which has so damaged the fabric of British trade, manufacturing and business since our entry into the then EEC in 1973 by burdensome and anti-competitive legislation. Sadly, the damage – vast damage – has already been done and is ongoing. Only by returning all legislative power to a newly-liberated UK Parliament with all its sovereignty restored, can the legislative process be made relevant to UK interests and legislators fully accountable to the people.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution concerns the current situation and the prospects for the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT) introduced in the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking. The platform aims to control the adequacy and effectiveness of regulation. The report is particularly critical of the risk of deregulation in the REFIT programme. In addition, more attention could be paid to transparency. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it is a step forward in legislation, advancing the simplification of EU regulations and reducing the costs it causes. In this sense, and in order to promote employment in Europe, reducing bureaucratic burdens seems to us to be an appropriate means.  Employment standards cannot be reduced and job precariousness cannot be reduced or should grow, so the idea of 'better regulation' should not become an excuse to eliminate management and reduce eu legislative capacity.  The aim is to get the entire EU regulatory apparatus in shape, while assessing the performance of regulation emanating from the European institutions.  It was also possible to ensure the protection of social dialogue and the role of consumers and social partners, as well as environmental, social, health and safety standards. Conservative and anti-European appeals have also been rejected.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because despite its technical appearance, it is a political backlash to the Commission's strategy to increase its legislative power and avoid scrutiny of its decisions. Ex ante, the Commission politically strengthens its neoliberal agenda with consultations and technical studies tailored to its interests, which allow it to set the limits of political discussion. Ex post, reserves the right to withdraw legislative proposals which Parliament has amended (as was the case with the maternity directive) or to make changes to its implementation that end up emptying its contents (as has happened with the new parameters of NOx emissions or chemical toxicity, REACH). Both changes, under the slogans of "better", "more appropriate", "more informed" or "more effective" regulation cannot hide the undemocratic bias that characterizes European construction.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text on the programme for a sharp and efficient regulation.  This report aims to identify administrative constraints in order to reduce the European bureaucracy that weighs on our businesses and our citizens. It recommends, for example, more frequent use of impact assessments, particularly on competitiveness, and stresses the importance of ex post evaluations.  While it is honourable to want to address over-regulation, we dispute some of the recommendations made in this report, particularly the one to prioritize regulations over directives. Moreover, the rapporteur never calls into question the European Commission, whose measures are at the root of the administrative burdens that economic agents face on a daily basis.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report which concealed its real agenda under terms such as ‘administrative burdens’ or ‘regulatory burdens’ These are codes for an economy of low-pay, long-hours, non-unionised, de-regulated, two-tier, universal labour with the very barest minimum of social welfare support and privatised public services.  The discussion around lifting administrative burden for SMEs is something of a red herring: the extension of the Better Regulation Agenda is biased towards deregulation and will be used to justify lower standards for EU workers (including those in SMEs).  REFIT is linked to 'better law-making' and it is primarily concerned with de regulation. It is being concealed under the cover of efficiency but the agenda is very much related to financial de regulation.  Moreover, important initiatives such as maternity leave, cancer protection at the work place, etc. have already been blocked by EU-Commission with reference to REFIT. Better regulation was also major part of the Brexit deal to promise the UK an even more market liberal European Union and it also seems to play a role in the TTIP negotiations.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it includes legislative measures that will reduce unnecessary legislative burdens, while at the same time simplifying and improving the design and quality of legislation aimed at further employment growth in Europe.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report contains positive points and recommendations (greater use of impact assessments, particularly on competitiveness, and public consultations, importance of ex post-emphasised evaluations, a stated principle of priority for SMEs), but it is feared that many of them will be given no concrete application. Given the overall balance of the report, I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ After 60 years of imposing thousands of pages of onerous and anti-competitive legislation, the EU has become vaguely aware that the Member States are being regulated to death. In addition, they have also realised that Brussels is not popular and this report on ‘better’ law making is more propaganda from the European Commission. I am opposed to each and every part of the European legislative process. I believe good legislation can only originate in the UK, be designed and debated in the UK and democratically amended and passed throughout the legislative process.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which allows policies and legislative acts to be developed so that they can achieve their objectives at a minimum cost. This programme allows for more open and transparent legislation, based on the best available data and with the participation of stakeholders.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to simplify legislation, reduce the administrative burden of regulation and remove barriers to growth and job creation. The REFIT programme is one of the main elements of the Commission's new better regulation strategy. It aims to establish a better law-making procedure, simplify EU law and reduce administrative and regulatory burdens. Given the excessive level of bureaucracy across the EU and the need for simplification of legislation, better regulation should include a culture of public administration at all LEVELS of the EU, the implementation and application of Union acts at European Union, as well as at national, regional and local level, in order to ensure good administration. I agree that the Commission should give priority to the development of certain measures and pay more attention to the quality of legislative acts and to better implementation of existing legislation than to the amount of legislation.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report welcomes the Commission's intention to make the legislative process more transparent and to involve citizens and stakeholders more fully in the whole process. The Commission should give priority to the development of certain measures rather than the number of legislative acts and should focus on the quality of legislation and the better implementation of existing legislation. In this respect, it emphasises that costs should not be decisive factors. In particular, the Commission's commitment to further improve the impact assessment for SMEs, given that more than 20 million SMALL and medium-sized enterprises account for 99% of EU businesses and that SMEs are thus the cornerstone of the economy, growth and employment. The report calls on the Commission not to give up its objectives of reducing the administrative burden on SMEs. On this basis, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Kaufmann report today. As a matter of principle we do not support and will not vote for any report which accepts the right of the EU to make the laws of the United Kingdom, however virtuous the proposals seem in isolation. The report makes it clear that, in whatever form, the process of legislation is going to continue. Its only virtue is that it impliedly damns the method of legislation that has pertained over the last sixty-odd years and which has so damaged the fabric of British trade, manufacturing and business since our entry into the then EEC in 1973 by burdensome and anti-competitive legislation. Sadly, the damage – vast damage – has already been done and is ongoing. Only by returning all legislative power to a newly-liberated UK Parliament with all its sovereignty restored, can the legislative process be made relevant to UK interests and legislators fully accountable to the people.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the European Commission's "Programme for Sharp and Effective Regulation" aims to identify binding or ineffective regulations in order to implement more effective European regulation, has many positive points, from the call for more frequent use of impact studies to the principle of priority given to SMEs too often limited by administrative constraints. However, I have not been able to agree with this in that it welcomes the measures taken by the Commission, which is often responsible for regulatory hypertrophy, and which, in defiance of any sovereignty of the Member States, in defiance of the primacy of the European regulation, which is wrongly presented as strengthening the internal market. In addition, no concrete application is proposed to match the positive points outlined above.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report by my colleague Kaufmann. On the one hand, I would like to underline the quality of this report, which repeatedly states that a simplification of European legislation cannot undermine environmental, health and social standards and must respect the implementation of agreements between the social partners. On the other hand, the REFIT programme remains a potential danger for us for workers' health and environmental protection which motivated my abstention.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme proposed by the Commission aims to improve the legislative production process by reducing administrative and regulatory burdens and simplifying Union law. Improving the legislative proposal means, in a broader sense, meeting the expectations of citizens, who require an increasingly clear and accessible regulatory framework and rapid and effective responses to social, economic and environmental problems.  I have chosen to vote in favour of the report on the programme to monitor the adequacy and effectiveness of regulation because I believe that it contains appropriate solutions to the challenges facing the legislative process at European level. Action on legislation is an action that combats excessive bureaucracy while at the same time disoping the risks of deregulation of entire sectors and the questioning of fundamental values such as social protection, environmental protection and the right to health. The Commission's approach to transparency and the involvement of citizens and stakeholders in the legislative process is positive.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report remains in line with the implementation of the REFIT programme (regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme). While we are critical of many aspects of their implementation in the regulatory framework of legislative procedures, we voted abstention because the regulatory framework is not aimed at harming the rights of workers.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for this report on the adequacy and effectiveness of regulation. In this report, I differed with my group in the vote in paragraph 47, which refers to the nutritional profile and nutritional and health claims in food and in particular the problems of distortion of competition. It calls for a review of the scientific basis, usefulness and realism of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I rejected this report, which curses the consequences of the causes it cherishes. Indeed, it reacts to the Commission's communication entitled "Programme for Sharp and Effective Regulation (REFIT): Results and Next Steps", which details guidelines for reducing legislative overproduction, proposals transcribed in the "Better Legislation" package. The report certainly points to many interesting elements: the need to clarify the lines between acts of execution and delegated acts; the importance of impact assessments, including competitiveness, and the need for increased public consultations and ex post evaluations; or the principle of priority for SMEs, which includes a desire to reduce administrative burdens on businesses. However, in an attempt to address these dysfunctions, the report recommends measures that will have the exact opposite effect. Thus, the rapporteur highlights the more effective nature of the regulation, which has a direct and obligatory effect: to advocate the increase in its use and to show contempt for national parliaments. Moreover, the report seems to forget the fact that the Commission is the first responsible for this legislative bulimia and in particular the burdens on our companies.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While it is a largely shareable text, there are still unclear passages that could generate critical issues. That is why I abstained.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've voted no. The Commission has long talked about simplifying legislation and reducing administrative burdens. Companies and their demands have been at the heart of this interest. As a result, the Commission, during talk of simplification and lightening burdens, has made proposals that would make it easier for businesses but which would also have reduced the working environment, health and social rights for workers. The report partly addresses this problem, which is a good thing, but it is not enough to celebrate various new commitments from the Commission. I would like the principle to be established that simplification must never, under any circumstances, lead to deterioration for workers, consumers and the environment. Eu-harmonised legislation also threatens the original legislation of some countries in various areas of deterioration. For these reasons, I choose to vote 'no'.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. REFIT is the European Commission's Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness programme. The programme envisages measures to simplify EU rules and reduce the costs it causes. The REFIT program is part of a broader concept that is "Smart Regulation" or "Better Regulation". This improvement in legislation is to devise EU rules and policies so that they achieve their objectives at the lowest cost.  For the Socialists, the idea of 'better regulation' should not become an excuse to eliminate regulation and reduce the EU's legislative capacity. With this socialist-led report, we have managed to ensure, within the framework of this programme, the protection of social dialogue and the role of consumers and social partners, as well as environmental, social, health and safety standards. We have also succeeded in rejecting conservative and anti-European calls for the establishment of an independent Regulatory Improvement Advisory Agency, limiting the claims of Eurosceptic groups to impede the Union's legislative capacity. For all this, I have decided to vote for it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the programme on the quality and performance of eu legislation. Firstly, the European Parliament stresses that only by greater transparency will the functioning of the EU become more effective and that civil society's confidence in the EU will increase. Welcomes, in this context, the Commission's emphasis that dialogue with citizens, social partners and other economic and civil society stakeholders contributes to a transparent, well-targeted and coherent EU legislative process, and welcomes the Commission's intention to show more clearly how it prepares proposals, such as legislative texts or communications. In addition, Parliament also calls on the Commission to review its evaluation guidelines by strengthening the involvement and consultation of stakeholders and using as direct a approach as possible to enable EU citizens to participate in decision-making.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 EPP Members have majorityly supported the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) because we believe that bureaucratic procedures need to be shortened. By simplifying and improving legislation, we are working to ensure that the objectives of this policy, of course, in full respect of the Treaties and, in particular, respect for the principles of subsidiarity, are achieved through as few administrative procedures as possible and as soon as possible. As a result, we are also reducing the administrative burden on businesses and removing barriers to economic growth and job creation.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is at times of difficulty such as the one facing the EU today that efforts need to be redoubled in order to use transparency policies that bring citizens closer to the Union project. I therefore welcome the approval of the REFIT programme voted on today in Strasbourg. This programme will make it possible to strengthen the link between Parliament and the Commission by encouraging bureaucratic simplification, greater effectiveness of the decision-making process and an increase in parliamentary control over acts adopted by the Commission. The simplification of certain procedures will reduce the administrative burden, especially for SMEs. With regard to more efficient legislation, I voted in favour of paragraph 47 on the indications of nutrient profiles in foodstuffs. These profiles, in addition to being devoid of scientific basis, would generate proven problems of distortion of competition by favouring a simplistic classification between "good" and "bad" foods, and would support forms of restriction such as traffic light labelling. I would like to stress that the nutritional composition is not in itself able to guarantee a correct diet for consumers: a balanced diet is based on a balanced consumption of the various foods. That is why we have asked the Commission to remove the concept of nutrient profiles.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report contains positive points and recommendations (the recommendation of greater use of impact studies, the principle of priorities for SMEs, clarification of delegated acts/acts of implementation) but it is feared that many of them will be given no concrete application. Another number of points are by no means acceptable (EU regulation more effective than the directives, many congratulations given to the Commission while it is responsible for the over-regulation that is affecting our companies). Given the overall balance of the report, I abstained.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Monitoring Programme represents an important step towards greater efficiency of European legislation and greater transparency.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme promoted by the Commission since 2014 with the aim of simplifying and making clearer a European legal framework that is often overloaded and sometimes twisted is an excellent initiative that can reduce some of the excesses that European bureaucracy suffers from, make decision-making more inclusive and transparent and thus improve the quality of European legislation, all for the benefit of citizens, consumers and businesses.  I also wholeheartedly support the call for the Commission to review the scientific basis and usefulness of the concept of 'nutrient profile' contained in Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 on nutrition and health claims provided on food products, as it is the cause of misleading information to European consumers. Rather than taking into account the nutritional profile of a particular product alone, it is necessary to promote conscious consumption of the same within a varied and balanced diet, while also combating traffic light labelling which, in the United Kingdom, has helped to create a distinction between 'good foods' and 'bad foods' without scientific foundations, which has adversely affected the competitiveness of excellent PDO, PGI and TSG products.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The programme for sharp and efficient regulation aims to identify administrative constraints in order to reduce the European bureaucracy that weighs on our businesses and our citizens. For example, the report recommends more frequent use of impact assessments, particularly on competitiveness, and stresses the importance of ex post evaluations. While it is honourable to want to address over-regulation, we dispute some of the recommendations made in this report, in particular the one to prioritize regulations over directives. Moreover, the rapporteur never calls into question the European Commission, which is mainly responsible for the administrative burdens that economic agents face on a daily basis. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Programme on Adequate and Functional Regulation aims to strengthen procedures for better regulation, simplify EU law and reduce administrative and regulatory burdens, as well as engage on the path to good governance, based on policies developed on the basis of concrete data, in which impact assessments and ex post assessments play a key role, without replacing political decisions. This programme is a focal point of the Commission's new strategy for better regulation, helping to improve legislative practices. Impact assessments are therefore an important tool to support decision-making in all EU institutions and play a significant role in better regulation, which is why it is essential for Member States to treat impact assessments seriously as well as ex-post ones. Stronger involvement of regional and local authorities is needed both in European policies and in the application of instruments of administrative simplification and reduction of red tape. I was in favour of this report because I believe that the REFIT programme is a fundamental component in simplifying EU law and strengthening good governance.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme, launched by the Juncker Commission as part of its plan for better lawmaking, is dictated by principles that we can support: scrutinising the body of European laws in order to make it simpler and less costly to apply. It is based on the following criteria: transparency and consultation of stakeholders; ex ante and ex post impact assessments and European value added assessment; impact on SMEs ("Thinking small first"); to examine all legislative initiatives pending in accordance with the principle of political discontinuity. The report provides positive indications of Parliament's involvement as co-legislator in the implementation of this programme. We are also not convinced by the Euro-centralist tendencies underlying several paragraphs, such as considering the flexibility attributed to Member States in transposing directives as 'over-regulation' that undermines the single market. For this reason, an indication of abstention is preferred.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it is a step forward in legislation, advancing the simplification of EU regulations and reducing the costs it causes.  In this sense, and in order to promote employment in Europe, reducing bureaucratic burdens seems to us to be an appropriate means.  Employment standards cannot be reduced and job precariousness cannot be reduced or should grow, so the idea of 'better regulation' should not become an excuse to eliminate management and reduce eu legislative capacity.  The aim is to get the entire EU regulatory apparatus in shape, while assessing the performance of regulation emanating from the European institutions.  It was also possible to ensure the protection of social dialogue and the role of consumers and social partners, as well as environmental, social, health and safety standards. Conservative and anti-European appeals have also been rejected.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report "on the regulatory adequacy and effectiveness monitoring programme (REFIT): current situation and prospects" because I believe that this programme can be a very useful tool for the work of the European legislator because it makes it possible to assess the progress made in all policy areas and for each initiative, provided, however, that this instrument is used to the full. For example, it needs to be supplemented by an annual declaration on the net costs and benefits of European legislation so as to assess more fully the progress made in eliminating unnecessary red tape; Similarly, it is important to separate issues relating to the adequacy and effectiveness of regulation from the political objective pursued. Turning to the merits of an initial evaluation offered by this programme, it emerges that the Commission should focus more on the quality of existing legislation than on the quantity of legislative acts, and in this regard costs should not be the decisive factor because the only appropriate benchmark must be the quality of legislation.  I support the introduction of 'temporary clauses' in time-limited legislative initiatives and 'review clauses' in legislative measures in order to regularly assess the relevance of legislative measures at European level.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which concealed its real agenda under terms such as ‘administrative burdens’ or ‘regulatory burdens’ These are codes for an economy of low-pay, long-hours, non-unionised, de-regulated, two-tier, universal labour with the very barest minimum of social welfare support and privatised public services.  The discussion around lifting administrative burden for SMEs is something of a red herring: the extension of the Better Regulation Agenda is biased towards deregulation and will be used to justify lower standards for EU workers (including those in SMEs).  REFIT is linked to 'better law-making' and it is primarily concerned with de regulation. It is being concealed under the cover of efficiency but the agenda is very much related to financial de regulation.  Moreover, important initiatives such as maternity leave, cancer protection at the work place, etc. have already been blocked by EU-Commission with reference to REFIT. Better regulation was also major part of the Brexit deal to promise the UK an even more market liberal European Union and it also seems to play a role in the TTIP negotiations.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I welcome the Commission’s agenda for better regulation. I welcome the Commission’s Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) with its aims to remove regulatory burdens and to improve the quality of legislation and most importantly its implementation, among others. A very important part of this report aims to give full respect the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity. Additionally, I would like to point out that another important element concern the impact assessments, which should also be more comprehensive and include a competitiveness assessment.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution concerns the prospects for the regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme introduced by the Commission under the interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking.  The report is acceptable in its entirety. The text, however, also has many critical issues, especially with regard to the risk of deregulation that the programme would entail. In addition, the paragraph on transparency could be considerably improved. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain from voting on the motion for a resolution.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – I contend with the majority view that food information provided to consumers is adequate without nutrient profiles. Nutrient profiling is endorsed by the Word Health Organisation to determine whether food producers can claim their products to be healthy. This is a sad example of what pro-industry conservatives mean when they talk about reducing bureaucratic burdens for business and streamlining law-making in the EU. Consumer information was the target in this case, which sends a loud pro-food industry message from Parliament. Just because there are EU law provisions on health claims and food labelling, which always suffer a barrage of sniping from global food conglomerates, this does in no way mean that we are providing clear and useful information to our citizens when they choose food products. There is no reason to allow products that are high in salt, sugar or saturated fats to be promoted as healthy just because producers added some vitamins to make the claim. This is not a call for better regulation. It is yet another nod to the peddling of junk in shiny packaging.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and call on the Commission, in view of the serious and on-going problems that arise in the implementation of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. It is therefore necessary to amend Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 on nutrition and health claims made in foodstuffs, including distortion of competition, to review the scientific basis of that Regulation, its usefulness and its realistic nature, and to delete, where appropriate, the concept of nutritional characteristics.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted on the Refit programme to check the adequacy and effectiveness of legislation, an issue which is directly linked to the issue of improving the legislative process, as discussed in recent years.  While we all recognise that there is a need to improve and speed up procedures with a view to creating a mechanism that is faster, more flexible and effective, in practice we must be very careful, as issues arise of weakening the rights of citizens, social groups or bodies. In this light, I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I realise, working in this environment, that we are now prisoners of an increasingly stringent bureaucracy and therefore reducing it by eliminating the regulatory burden, obviously in full compliance with the Treaties, represents, in my opinion, an improvement on the entire institutional machinery.  I therefore agree with the need for this exercise, as well as with the general structure of the report. I also felt it necessary to vote in favour of paragraph 47 for the removal of the concept of nutrient profiles from European legislation. In fact, this concept has no scientific basis and on the contrary tends to generalize by labeling foods as "good" or "bad" when it would be necessary to talk about "good diets" and "bad diets" in favor of a varied diet. Among other things, such an approach risks penalising many excellences of "made in Italy", such as cured meats and cheeses, which instead do well in the right doses and within a balanced diet.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The REFIT Programme is central to the Commission's new strategy for enhanced law-making. This strategy sets out better law-making procedures with an aim to simplifying EU law whilst reducing the regulatory burden. Clarity and transparency is however absent from the many different names used by the Commission for various programs, making it confusing for citizens. The Commission confirms that the REFIT Programme does not put any existing policy objectives in danger. It will not have a negative impact on the safety or health of citizens on the Union, nor workers, or the environment.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the Kaufman report today. As a matter of principle we do not support and will not vote for any report which accepts the right of the EU to make the laws of the United Kingdom, however virtuous the proposals seem in isolation. The report makes it clear that, in whatever form, the process of legislation is going to continue. Its only virtue is that it impliedly damns the method of legislation that has pertained over the last sixty-odd years and which has so damaged the fabric of British trade, manufacturing and business since our entry into the then EEC in 1973 by burdensome and anti-competitive legislation. Sadly, the damage – vast damage – has already been done and is ongoing. Only by returning all legislative power to a newly-liberated UK Parliament with all its sovereignty restored, can the legislative process be made relevant to UK interests and legislators fully accountable to the people.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the need to remove nutrient profiles from European regulation. The approach based on the adoption of nutrient profiles has always given rise to a great deal of concern, firstly because they do not have a real scientific basis, but above all because, while informing consumers about the composition of individual foods, this will not affect lifestyle, as food is often associated according to the eating habits and traditions of the various countries. That said, nutrient profiles are outdated, as citizens already find all the information on the label to make responsible purchasing choices. In addition, the introduction of nutrient profiles could have a negative impact on the competitiveness of various sectors of the European agri-food chain and in particular on typical quality label products (PDO, PGI, STG).

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT): State of Play and Outlook One third of the administrative burden linked to EU legislation stems from national implementing measures or flexible transposition options. I agree with the call on the Commission, therefore, in reviewing the legal framework of regulations and directives, to promote a revival of the principle of the common internal market and, wherever possible, to avoid allowing scope for differing national provisions. The assessment of REFIT and further efforts on better regulation should follow the shift towards digitisation of the economy, society and public administration.  I believe that extensive use of the REFIT tool and the use of fitness checks could also contribute to assessing the coherence and consistency of regulatory areas within the broader framework of the digital single market.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because despite its technical appearance, it is a political backlash to the Commission's strategy to increase its legislative power and avoid scrutiny of its decisions. Ex ante, the Commission politically strengthens its neoliberal agenda with consultations and technical studies tailored to its interests, which allow it to set the limits of political discussion. Ex post, reserves the right to withdraw legislative proposals which Parliament has amended (as was the case with the maternity directive) or to make changes to its implementation that end up emptying its contents (as has happened with the new parameters of NOx emissions or chemical toxicity, REACH). Both changes, under the slogans of "better", "more appropriate", "more informed" or "more effective" regulation cannot hide the undemocratic bias that characterizes European construction.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on strengthening the REFIT programme, which aims to simplify and improve EU legislation, because I believe, in line with the 'Better Lawmaking' agenda, that optimising the decision-making process and the evaluation of European legislation not only reduces administrative inefficiencies and regulatory burdens, but also ensures the democratic and inclusive participation of citizens, alongside the institutions , in decision-making and evaluation processes.  I am convinced that an improvement in the REFIT programme can make a significant contribution to raising the quality of legislation, governance, impact assessment of all the elements underlying current and future legislative proposals and, finally, consultation of the European institutions with civil society and stakeholders, increasing their confidence in the EU. Finally, I support greater involvement of local and regional authorities in the development of EU policies, on the one hand, and national parliaments in the ex-post evaluation of new legislation, on the other.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Actions provided for in the REFIT Programme should be seen as an ongoing process, ensuring that the legislation in force at European level is fit for purpose, contributes to the common objective of legislators and meets the expectations of citizens, in particular employees, businesses and other stakeholders. A reduction in red tape, the removal of administrative barriers blocking the economy is a first step towards better development and the creation of new jobs.  I voted for ACTIONS under REFIT not only for short-term effects, but also for the added value of long-term legislation, such as the elimination of harmful effects in the workplace.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme, introduced in 2012, is now an important part of the EU's Better Regulation agenda. It seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system to simplify the lives, activities and operations of EU citizens and businesses within the UNION. Its main aim is to put an end to bureaucratic burdens and to simplify and improve legislation.  Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ On balance I support this report, especially its proposals for ex-post evaluations of EU legislation by national parliaments and flexible rules for SMEs and exemptions for microbusinesses from excessive red tape. However, I would have liked to see a burden reduction target included in the report; it is all very well talking about reducing the administrative burden for SMEs, but we need concrete progress on achieving positive change in that area.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report provides an overview of the REFIT programme, which aims to reduce administrative burdens, eliminate regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation in order to better achieve the Union's objectives in full compliance with the treaties. This initiative report stresses the importance of maintaining this momentum and ensuring that the institutions agree on a new, strong inter-institutional agreement. Considering that the rationalisation of European legislation aims to improve the implementation of the rules and the achievement of objectives, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the "Programme for Sharp and Effective Regulation (REFIT)". While respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, this programme, which aims, in particular, to reduce administrative constraints and simplify legislation, allows for lighter, simpler and less costly EU legislation. It is particularly interesting to note the Commission's commitment to consider less stringent rules for SMEs, as long as this is reasonable and feasible, while checking the environmental, social and economic impacts of the proposed legislation.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system for both business sector workers and EU citizens. It aims to put an end to red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation.   Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Commission's REFIT programme was set up in December 2012 to identify and address ineffective administrative constraints or ineffective European regulations. While this intention is laudable, the text of the report sees the European Regulation, which has a direct and binding effect in all its elements, as a preferred tool for strengthening the internal market. In addition, this report welcomes the commitment to the Better Legislation Programme, which we voted against in the plenary session on 9 March 2016. Finally, this report seems to ignore the fact that the Commission is the first responsible for the "over-regulation" which weighs particularly on our companies. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague Kaufman's report on the REFIT programme, which supports the ongoing process of verifying that European legislation is fit and focuses on quality and not just the quantity of legislative initiatives.  I also support the proposal to enable national parliaments to assess the new legislation. This will help to assess the challenges they have to face in enforcing laws and regulations.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system for both business sector workers and EU citizens. It aims to put an end to red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation. Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating. In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The REFIT program was launched in December 2012. It is the continuation of a project to reduce administrative burdens that were implemented between 2007 and 2012. Since then, it has continued to work, simplified and reduced charges in a range of fields, such as: patents, public procurement, electronic VAT invoicing, etc. Until you create this REFIT platform. The objectives pursued, as regards simplification and improvement of regulation, are to improve regulation to increase the competitiveness of enterprises, to ensure legal certainty and to contribute to the market unit and to reduce the bureaucratic weight of the administration, eliminating hurdly and increasing simplification to facilitate administrative processing by citizens and entrepreneurs for a better exercise of rights and compliance with their obligations.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme as I was concerned by the language in the report, which is unclear and does not properly distinguish between regulatory and administrative burdens. We should of course look to cut red tape wherever possible, and it is vital to my constituents in Wales that practices are efficient, transparent and accountable, but the deregulation agenda lobbied by business interests puts the well—being of people and the environment at risk.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme is the key element of the Commission's new strategy as it aims to consolidate procedures for better regulation, simplify EU legislation and reduce administrative and/or regulatory burdens, fighting for good governance on the basis of a policy-making process based on concrete facts, in which impact assessments and ex post assessments play an important role without replacing policy decisions. I therefore agree that this spirit should permeate the culture of public administration at all levels of the European Union, bearing in mind the excessive levels of bureaucracy throughout the Union and the need to simplify legislation.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Abstention: this report contains positive points and recommendations, but it is feared that it will not be given any concrete application.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
