text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution, although I support the introduction of some interesting concepts, such as sunset clauses, presents some critical issues, especially as regards the risk of deregulation that the REFIT programme entails.  We also believe that the paragraph on transparency could have been considerably improved.  For these reasons, since we cannot express a judgment of full sharing of the REFIT report, we prefer to abstain.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 REFIT – a Programme of the European Commission which, according to certain criteria defined by itself, assesses the performance, quality of regulation, its suitability and effectiveness – is an integral part of the Better Regulation programme, the report of which we voted recently (against). Despite some of the positive aspects contained in this report, a federalist perspective prevails throughout the report, a certain view that there is no national legislation that is better than that of the EU. We are therefore faced with a tendency to deflate the importance of the action and legislative production of states. In other words, it is a question of turning the principle of subsidiarity authentically upside down. At the heart of this programme is the reduction of all legislation (in particular social and environmental) that is considered to have burdens that undermine the so-called competitiveness of enterprises (not so much small and large, especially large economic groups). This is the capital, so are the politicians at their service: when they need a lot of legislation they make a lot of legislation (excessive procedural mechanisms that benefit, for example, cases of economic corruption); when they want less they do less (simplifying lawsuits for dismissals of workers). In any case, always with the purpose of increasing profits and not of improving people's lives.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Kaufmann's report. The positive result of the REFIT control programme represents, in fact, a victory for the protection of the competitiveness of "Made in Italy" production. In particular, paragraph 47 of the report calls into question the practice of traffic light labelling of food, establishing certain nutrient profiles that put the main products of the Mediterranean diet at a disadvantage.  Parliament's message to the Commission is clear: the protection of food excellence concerns not only Italy but Europe as a whole. It is the first step to put an end to the damage that traffic light labelling leads to the most typical production of "Made in Italy", with inevitable repercussions on agri-food supply chains at regional level that, on the contrary, must be protected by Brussels.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against paragraph 47 as it will create a situation whereby people are misled as to the health benefits of foods.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report in question follows a report on better law-giving of February 2014. Its main objective is to reduce bureaucracy, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve the design and quality of legislation. The European Commission should give priority to the development of certain measures and should focus on the quality of legislation and better enforcement of existing legislation, rather than on the number of legislative acts. Costs should not be a determining factor, but the quality of legislation is the only appropriate benchmark and REFIT must not be used to undermine sustainability or any social, labour, environmental and consumer standards.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because, despite some positive principles, there are some Euro-centralist tendencies that I do not share.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Programme for the Control of the Adequacy and Effectiveness of Legislation (REFIT): Current situation and prospects, as I believe that policy-making cannot in any way depend on the statutory opinion of companies, or simply on the results of statistics. It is an unacceptable degradation of politics, a mentality that is no different from the logic of the Memorandums.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The REFIT Programme aims to cut red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve the design and quality of legislation and is therefore essential for the legislative work. Under REFIT, the Commission is able to screen the entire stock of EU legislation on an ongoing and systematic basis to identify burdens, inconsistencies, ineffective measures and identified corrective actions. I am satisfied with the fact that we managed to secure the social dialog and role of social partners and consumer, environmental, social, health and safety standards. I welcome the fact that we managed to rebut conservative and anti—European calls for an independent high-level Better Regulation Advisory Body. Moreover, we managed to limit the request for sunset clauses and fight the introduction of any net targets and the ‘one in and one out’ principle. I expect that unnecessary burdens are being cut in order to promote employment in Europe. This does not mean that employment standards may be reduced or that precarious employment contracts may increase: the compromise on the SME test ensures that there will not be this risk.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system for both business sector workers and EU citizens. It aims to put an end to red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation.   Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system for both business sector workers and EU citizens. It aims to put an end to red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation.   Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report. We must keep in mind—as President Juncker announced at the beginning of his term—the need to better legislate to meet citizens' expectations. The objective of better legislating should cover the need to simplify legislation and should include the implementation and implementation of Union acts at European level, as well as at national, regional and local levels. Similarly, the EU institutions must always keep in mind in their actions the need to maintain an open, transparent and regular dialogue with representative associations and civil society.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it is a step forward in the legislation, in particular in simplifying EU rules and reducing the costs it entails. In this sense, and in order to promote employment in Europe, reducing bureaucratic burdens seems to us to be an appropriate means.  Employment standards cannot be reduced or work precariousness should grow. In this way, the idea of 'better regulation' should not become an excuse to eliminate management and reduce the EU's legislative capacity.  It is about strengthening the entire EU regulatory apparatus, while assessing the performance of regulation emanating from the European institutions.  It was also possible to ensure the protection of social dialogue and the role of consumers and social partners, as well as environmental, social, health and safety standards. Finally, the rejection of conservative and anti-European appeals was achieved.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it is a step forward in legislation, advancing the simplification of EU regulations and reducing the costs it causes.  In this sense, and in order to promote employment in Europe, reducing bureaucratic burdens seems to us to be an appropriate means.  Employment standards cannot be reduced and job precariousness cannot be reduced or should grow, so the idea of 'better regulation' should not become an excuse to eliminate management and reduce eu legislative capacity.  The aim is to get the entire EU regulatory apparatus in shape, while assessing the performance of regulation emanating from the European institutions.  It was also possible to ensure the protection of social dialogue and the role of consumers and social partners, as well as environmental, social, health and safety standards. Conservative and anti-European appeals have also been rejected.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mrs Kaufmann for the careful and fruitful work she has done in recent months on the REFIT dossier, an issue of the utmost importance, not only interinstitutional and legislative, but above all in political terms.  Improving the quality of our legislation, making relations between the institutions more transparent, eliminating procedures that slow down and make the action of the European institutions less effective is not only a useful tool for our day-to-day work in Parliament: it is first and foremost a step towards closer relations between the EU and its citizens. Today we are voting on a text of great political responsibility, and I congratulate the Group of the Party of European People's Party (European Parliament) on its achievement.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's non-legislative resolution on the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Monitoring Programme (REFIT): current situation and prospects, because in the EP's intentions this resolution is intended to be a further contribution in terms of proposals and observations to the REFIT programme. The Latter responds to the EP's requests and notes the high political importance of this issue; and it is hoped that it will lead to European legislation that is of the best possible quality, that meets the expectations of citizens and stakeholders, and that ensures that strategic public objectives – including consumer, environmental and social standards and health and safety standards – are not compromised. It is precisely with regard to health and safety, and precisely with regard to nutritional indicators, that I particularly welcome the result achieved on this issue. My group in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy strongly supported the revision of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 in order to eliminate the reference to nutrient profiles and, in essence, traffic light labelling, which, through the traditional colours of traffic lights, trivialises information on nutrient content that is critical to health. This is an important victory for the Italian agri-food industry engaged in quality production and for Italian exports.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the programme to ensure the efficiency and performance of legislation. Better regulation in the EU and the Member States is exactly what we need! That is what I stand for.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. In legislation, the quality of legislation and the impact assessment of the law are crucial, which contribute to the creation of a secure area of justice and less bureaucracy for individuals. I support this proposal, in view of the growing and confusing regulation of the EU. Less, but more efficient, is a great relief, especially for citizens and the administration.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report represents an important step towards better regulation in the European Union. Simpler regulation that reduces the regulatory burden on Member States and businesses is a welcome change. In addition, there is consideration for subsidiarity and proportionality principles, another key aspect of better regulation and a principle that I think it crucial to respect.  Crucially, the report takes into consideration the needs of small businesses. Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) play a key role in growth and job creation in Britain and in the South—West, but their competitiveness can be restricted by burdensome European regulations. This report represents progress towards reducing these burdens. Important ECR amendments concerning competitiveness have been adopted and the report introduces a general rule that proposals with a negative impact on competitiveness should not be adopted by the Commission. This, along with the emphasis placed on the Commission committing to reducing the administrative burden on SMEs and the inclusion of exemptions for microbusinesses, will be beneficial for productivity of British industries. It is for these reasons that I chose to vote in favour.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The REFIT programme aims to make recommendations for more effective European regulation.  We can highlight some positive points in this report, including the recommendation for a more judicious use of delegated acts (which Parliament may oppose and force the Commission to review its proposal) and enforcement actions (which Parliament may oppose but without any coercion over the Commission). The report also calls for more impact studies, particularly in terms of the competitiveness of our companies, because it is often sacrificed on the altar of the fight against pollution without ever questioning the globalist model that transforms our industries into soldiers amputee of their agility.  However, the report recommends that the regulation, which is directly applicable in national rights, should be used more often, in particular to promote the internal market. Provisions to which we are of course opposed.  In view of all these points, I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report remains in line with the implementation of the REFIT programme (regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme). While we are critical of many aspects of their implementation in the regulatory framework of legislative procedures, we voted abstention because the regulatory framework is not aimed at harming the rights of workers.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because there is a need for adequate and functional regulation. The measures proposed in the report aim at simplifying EU legislation and reducing regulatory costs, which is very important in the current context. I support the need for legislative simplification and the decrease in red tape, but this is especially necessary at national level, where in many cases over-regulation occurs. The REFIT programme would have a positive impact on the stability of the regulatory framework and support economic growth and job creation. Eliminating the obligation to establish and adopt nutritional profiles is not a negative thing. This would avoid the creation of a new set of regulations which would practically double the provisions of Regulation No 17. 1169/2011 on consumer information on food, according to which it has become mandatory to indicate the nutrition declaration for all foodstuffs, thus providing consumers with complete information on the basis of which they can make sound, informed choices. The Commission's concern must be more towards control of non-European products entering the market without rigorous control, destroying European producers through dumping prices.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the REFIT Programme aims to cut red-tape, remove regulatory burdens, and simplify and improve the design and quality of EU legislation. Under REFIT, the Commission is screening the entire stock of EU legislation on an ongoing and systematic basis to identify burdens, inconsistencies, ineffective measures and identified corrective actions.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The Commission has now proposed a coherent holistic approach to better law making that takes account of the entire policy cycle of law—making and requires targeted interaction among all the institutions.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system for both business sector workers and EU citizens. It aims to put an end to bureaucratic burdens, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation.   Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 REFIT is a European Commission programme aimed at improving the adequacy and efficiency of regulations by taking measures to simplify EU legislation and reduce regulatory costs so that there is a clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework conducive to growth and employment.  The report placed particular emphasis on encouraging a more 'federalist approach', arguing that uniform EU legislation could adequately and additionally replace national legislation/law and support the so-called 'SME first approach/first approach for small and medium-sized enterprises'.  Bearing in mind that the last approach to small and medium-sized enterprises was reinforced by an amendment by our group (the amendment stressed that such an approach should in no way be detrimental to workers' rights) it prompted us to abstain.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it proposes to overhaul all EU legislation to ensure that legislation is more accessible, by cutting red tape and removing unnecessary regulatory barriers. The REFIT Programme aims to correct any legislation that contains burdens, inconsistencies, and ineffective measures in order to proceed with corrective measures. The emphasis on maintaining political trust and balance between the Parliament and the Commission is also a positive aspect for the functioning of this institution.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. The Healthy and Results-Oriented Regulation Programme (REFIT) should aim to reduce the bureaucratic pressure of European regulations on citizens and businesses. But it is mainly used in the areas of environmental protection, social legislation, animal welfare, public health, consumer protection and food safety. Regulations that should protect citizens, animals and the environment must now give way to short-sighted commercial interests and pursuits of profit; pressure could jeopardise turnover.  However, this REFIT is mainly used to reduce consumer protection. For example, it calls for the removal of so-called 'nutritional profiles'. However, these nutritional profiles ensure that consumers are not misled by health claims on unhealthy foods with too much fat, salt or sugar. Junk food is and remains unhealthy and should not be advertised as a 'healthy' or 'vitamin-rich' product.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system for both business sector workers and EU citizens. It aims to put an end to red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation.   Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The REFIT Programme has the proper aim of cutting unnecessary red tape and administrative burden, to promote more effective and appropriate regulation. Today’s vote demonstrates that those of us who argue for fair regulation do not do so for its own sake, but where there is clear benefit for the people we represent. In this report, we call for the protection of workers' rights and secure the role of social dialogue and social partner agreements. We reiterate the importance of consumer, environmental, social, health and safety standards. We support more flexible rules for SMEs, but only if the internal market and ensuring social, ecological and economic objectives are not undermined. We support ‘review clauses’ to regularly reassess legislative measures but deliberately avoided a crude and arbitrary ‘one in, one out’ rule. The report maintains the role of parliamentary oversight. Finally our resolution recognises that four members of the High Level Group of Independent Stakeholders – associations of professionals, environmental, consumer and health representatives – issued a dissenting opinion that there should be a better understanding of the case for appropriate regulation. Our aim should be to lift burdens not just for some, but for all.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report regarding the REFIT programme (Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme) that aims to reduce bureaucracy, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve the legislation.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the removal of nutritional profiles (paragraph 47). I think it is good for consumers to know what the dietary composition is in food. In addition to the EU, the World Health Organisation (WHO) is doing a good job of developing informative and clear profiles. This work needs to be continued.  Nutritional profiles are one way to tell about healthy food. However, education alone is not enough for the consumer to take up a healthy alternative.  Our choices about nutrition and food are often unconscious and dictated by necessity. It is easy to speak up for a healthy diet if you can afford it. Healthy food and diet must be available to everyone.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Programme for Etiness and Efficiency of Regulations (REFIT): The current situation and prospects for the future, because I think that rules are needed that are less burdensome and more efficient legislation at European level. Impact assessment and evaluation are essential to monitor the legislator's objectives and to distinguish rules at European level from laws adopted at national level.  In this context, REFIT provides a clear, simple and predictable legislative framework for entrepreneurs and citizens and contributes to addressing the unnecessary burden and raises the quality of the legislation itself. However, while over a hundred measures have been taken to reduce and simplify the burden on legislation in existing laws and regulations, there are still some sectors where such a thing has not been done and further efforts are needed accordingly. Therefore, I support measures that go towards reducing the legislative burden, and I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report implies (paragraph 5) that the European regulation, of direct and compulsory effect in all its elements, is the most effective and therefore preferred tool over the directive, and that it has the effect of strengthening the internal market. We are totally and firmly opposed to these two considerations.  He welcomes the commitment to the Better Legislation programme. We voted against the conclusion of the inter-institutional agreement "Better Legislation" between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on 9 March 2016 in plenary.  This report congratulates or welcomes too many times the measures taken by the Commission when it is the first responsible for 'over-regulation', the administrative burdens on our companies and deserves a definitive red card.  It contains positive points and recommendations, but there are concerns that many of them will have no concrete application. Another number of points are by no means acceptable. I then abstained on the vote of this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the Kaufmann report today. As a matter of principle we do not support and will not vote for any report which accepts the right of the EU to make the laws of the United Kingdom, however virtuous the proposals seem in isolation. The report makes it clear that, in whatever form, the process of legislation is going to continue. Its only virtue is that it impliedly damns the method of legislation that has pertained over the last sixty-odd years and which has so damaged the fabric of British trade, manufacturing and business since our entry into the then EEC in 1973 by burdensome and anti-competitive legislation. Sadly, the damage – vast damage – has already been done and is ongoing. Only by returning all legislative power to a newly-liberated UK Parliament with all its sovereignty restored, can the legislative process be made relevant to UK interests and legislators fully accountable to the people.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann's report on the Sharp and Effective Regulation (REFIT) programme. The REFIT programme aims to reduce administrative burdens, eliminate regulatory burdens, and simplify legislation so that it can achieve strategic objectives while reducing administrative burdens. I agree with this proposal and recall that the Commission must also be encouraged to continue its efforts to create jobs by reducing regulatory and administrative constraints, and to ensure the preservation of public policy objectives.  This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the application of the so-called REFIT programme for sharp and efficient regulation, implemented in response to the idea that the European Union has become too bureaucratic. The text welcomes the Commission's commitment to reduce administrative burdens and limit the effects of legislative over-bidding, which is particularly the case in France. So I voted in favour of this good report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 12 April 2016, we voted in plenary in Strasbourg on a report on the Regulatory Fitness andEfficiency Programme (REFIT). To begin with, I very much welcome the efforts of the Institutions of the European Union to reduce unnecessary regulations that are not effective or are not used at all and merely burden the entire legal order. It is one of the processes aimed at reducing the overall regulatory burden as well as secondary administrative burden. Reducing regulatory burdens can help develop the EU's internal market. Even though my colleagues managed, in the juri report, to explicitly state that the fight against the 'regulatory burden' should not be directed against workers' rights, I had to abstain in the end. At the same time, the report also advocates greater involvement of private actors in the legislative process. This would, of course, lead to even greater interference in the drafting of legislation by already aggressive lobbying. Which cannot be allowed.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system for both business sector workers and EU citizens. It aims to put an end to red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation.   Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour because we should acknowledge that the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) represents an important step towards simplifying legislation and reducing administrative burdens of regulation for businesses as well as eliminating barriers to growth and job creation. Looking from this perspective, we should work to ensure predictability, legal certainty and transparency of REFIT. In doing so, however, we should not forget that the impact of legislation on large enterprises and on SMEs may differ. Therefore, we should propose and implement legislation that clearly states that all employees have a right to the highest level of protection regarding health and safety in the workplace, regardless of the size of the employer or the underlying contract.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have given a positive opinion on our report on the Commission communication on the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT). With it, the European Commission aims to revise legislation in order to reduce regulatory and administrative burdens.  One of the points made by Parliament, and for which I have fought, calls on the Commission to review and possibly eliminate the concept of nutrient profiles. This is a great achievement, which demonstrates the Great Will of the European Parliament to stand up for our quality production. We have won a battle of method and prevented the "Made in Italy" from being damaged by senseless choices by some European countries that, according to their labelling system, see extra virgin milk or olive oil, noble foods, branded red while some light drinks, such as Coca-Cola, have a green stamp.  Thanks to this vote, we can combine consumer protection with the competitiveness of our companies.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the "program for sharp and efficient regulation". This report contains positive points and recommendations, but there are concerns that many of them will have no concrete application. Another number of points are by no means acceptable. This report welcomes or welcomes too many times the measures taken by the Commission, when it is the first responsible for over-regulation and administrative burdens on our companies and therefore deserves a definitive red card.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. Of course, it aims to legislate better and has the merit of caring for SMEs. But it is an ode to the process of european regulation which I cannot endorse. Finally, he welcomes the Commission's decision to combat 'over-regulation', forgetting a little quickly that it is the first responsible...

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained. Indeed, the report takes stock of the REFIT programme, "Programme for Sharp and Effective Regulation", created in December 2012 by the European Commission. Among the guidelines is the identification of administrative constraints or ineffective regulations of the European Union, to make changes. In addition, the rapporteur is trying to identify both the positive and negative aspects of the REFIT programme.  Overall, good measures have been adopted, such as the principle of priority for SMEs, whose ambitions are not to be scaled back.  On the other hand, the Commission's programme favours regulation (applicable directly in national law), instead of the directive, administrative burdens... The report does not note the "compressor roll" effect of EU legislation and the resulting "over-regulation." Therefore, despite the interesting proposals advocated and the balance of the report, some measures remain unacceptable, so I abstained.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it is a step forward in legislation, advancing the simplification of EU regulations and reducing the costs it causes.  In this sense, and in order to promote employment in Europe, reducing bureaucratic burdens seems to us to be an appropriate means.  Employment standards cannot be reduced and job precariousness cannot be reduced or should grow, so the idea of 'better regulation' should not become an excuse to eliminate management and reduce eu legislative capacity.  The aim is to get the entire EU regulatory apparatus in shape, while assessing the performance of regulation emanating from the European institutions.  It was also possible to ensure the protection of social dialogue and the role of consumers and social partners, as well as environmental, social, health and safety standards. Conservative and anti-European appeals have also been rejected.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because despite its technical appearance, it is a political backlash to the Commission's strategy to increase its legislative power and avoid scrutiny of its decisions. Ex ante, the Commission politically strengthens its neoliberal agenda with consultations and technical studies tailored to its interests, which allow it to set the limits of political discussion. Ex post, reserves the right to withdraw legislative proposals which Parliament has amended (as was the case with the maternity directive) or to make changes to its implementation that end up emptying its contents (as has happened with the new parameters of NOx emissions or chemical toxicity, REACH). Both changes, under the slogans of "better", "more appropriate", "more informed" or "more effective" regulation cannot hide the undemocratic bias that characterizes European construction.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I believe that the REFIT instrument is an essential element in improving legislation at European level, in order to better legislate, simplify EU law and reduce administrative burdens. Thus starting a path to good governance, where impact assessments and ex post controls play the relevant role that I believe they deserve when making political decisions. I support this report as it includes the ec's updates on the REFIT programme and assesses all the progress made in the different policy areas and in respect of the initiatives selected by the Commission, including the measures taken by Parliament and the Council. I also believe that it is necessary since the 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation has become outdated as a result of the creation of the current legislative environment under the Lisbon Treaty. I therefore vote in favour of this report because of the importance I consider to be this legislative instrument as it will also help to establish a work programme and a coherent political approach, which will increase the transparency of the EU and the acceptance of its citizens.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. This is an unnecessary report that will do nothing to help us have more effective legislation. On the contrary, the report itself is an example of a completely ineffective piece of legislation. In order to have more effective legislation, such reports will not be help, but by a more sensible vote by Members on the commission's various regulatory proposals.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Smart Regulation Programme aims to consolidate better law-making to simplify the EU's legal and administrative burden. The programme aims to formulate evidence-based policies that include impact assessment and subsequent controls for key policy elements. The cultural aspect of EU public administration at all levels should also be addressed with better decision-making, as there is currently too much red tape across the EU.  The report notes that it asks all EU institutions to maintain transparent, open and regular dialogues with civil society. Impact assessment is a key tool to support decision-making in all EU institutions and the impact of decision-making on SMEs should be taken into account. I supported the report because it encourages dialogue between the EU institutions, with the aim of simplifying regulations and reducing administrative barriers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the report on the Programme for the Control of the Adequacy and Effectiveness of Legislation (REFIT): Current situation and prospects, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/4/2016, and because this report is not complete.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This programme, launched in 2012, serves the positive objective of simplifying the regulatory burden caused by EUROPEAN legislation, which handicaps SMEs.  In particular, the report calls for the introduction of simplified standards applicable exclusively to SMEs. In addition, frequent impact assessments should be used to measure the potentially harmful effects of each regulatory act. While the objective may seem laudable, we recall that the European Union is responsible for increasing the legal and administrative constraints hindering the development of SMEs. In addition, under the guise of administrative simplification, the report calls for an increased use of direct-effect legislation in place of directives, which involve a prior transposition into national law. We are protesting against this new attempt to interfere in the national laws of sovereign states.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the rapporteur that what we need are no longer laws, but better laws. As the report states, we should allow greater input from citizens and the business community so that we have better predictions about the possible effects of the new legislation. I am convinced that we are on the right track, and that is why I supported this report.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. We are all clear that our legislation needs to be further improved. It is not a question of doing more legislative acts because yes, but of doing few and well and improving existing ones.  In this Parliament we are clear that the REFIT programme should not be used to undermine sustainability or any social, labour, environmental and consumer regulations. And we believe that every effort should be made to improve transparency and facilitate stakeholder participation throughout the legislator process.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2013, the Commission launched its "ReFIT" programme for sharp and effective regulation. Its assessment on which Parliament is called to vote notes the tendency to "over-regulation", too many European laws.  While it is true that the European Union regulates both asparagus size and labour law, the aim here is to seek further upstream to limit 'administrative and regulatory burdens', a 'burden' for businesses and for the completion of the single market.  Under the pretext of helping SMEs, it is a matter of deregulation and breakdown of the rights of workers whose first satisfactions are the European union of large companies, Business Europe. Worse, the report recommends that this "culture" of deregulation be extended to member state administrations. Myriam El Khomri didn't wait for them!  The report supports the sustainability of an expert body responsible for impact assessments, already undermined by lobbyists. This real political tool will be able to block any legislation that would propose greater protection for citizens and ultimately be integrated into the "regulatory cooperation body" provided for in the TAFTA.  I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report contains interesting points, such as the principle of priority for SMEs. However, it is likely that no concrete application will come in the aftermath that will be given to it. On the other hand, I disapprove, among other things, of the strengthening of the internal market or the commission's untimely and hegemonic decisions, even though the Commission is directly responsible for the regulatory overload. As a result, I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have put forward my vote in favour of the report on the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT): current situation and outlook. Since the 2003 Interinstitutional Better Regulation Agreement was passed down by the current legislative framework set up by the Treaty of Lisbon, a new Commission strategy for Better Regulation is needed.  The 'Regulatory Fitness and Effectiveness Programme' (REFIT) is essential in the process of simplifying legislation and reducing the administrative burden of regulation for businesses, as well as removing barriers to growth and job creation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it critically assesses the Commission’s Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme, and the consequent impact on the legislative process.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. It is essential to strengthen and improve the European regulatory framework in order to move towards a "well-sharpened" regulation of the European Union, which is part of the inter-institutional agreement "better legislating". Better regulation means working for a dynamic Europe that creates growth and jobs. It means working for effective, transparent and readable legislation for businesses, especially SMEs and micro-enterprises. It is finally working in the interests of workers' rights. In order to strike the right balance, the impact assessments of legislative proposals must be conducted in a systematic and rigorous manner. Replacing 28 national standards with a European standard presupposes working with all European bodies and with all relevant stakeholders.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – I view the report on the Regulatory Fitness and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT) very positively. We live in an age in which every area of life is strictly regulated. Regulation by legal acts is very necessary, but in order for it to be effective and function well, legal acts must be well prepared. In recent years, we have witnessed a kind of 'legislative whirlwind' where both the Member States and the European Union are literally overwhelming us with huge numbers of new legislation, which often requires re-amendments and, moreover, is increasingly preachy. This situation leads to the questioning of the good functioning of the States and of the Union, and at the same time to the eeding of legal certainty, which is one of the features of the rule of law. In this day and age, as the number of 'Eurosceptics' grows across the european Union, it is essential to take measures that will lead to simplification, clarity and what we popularly call 'common sense'. In this context, I am happy to vote in favour of the report tabled because I see it as the first clear step towards a real improvement in regulation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because I am in agreement with the principles of Regulatory Fitness and Performance and support the initiative at a European and national level. I also support initiatives launched by the European Commission which aim to strengthen the continuation of the reduction of administrative and regulatory burdens.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 "Effective and effective regulatory programme (REFIT): situational picture and outlook" was published by the Commission in 2014. The REFIT programme is at the heart of the commission's new strategy to improve regulation, with the aim of consolidating the procedure for improving regulation, simplifying EU legislation, reducing administrative and regulatory burdens and starting good governance based on evidence-based policy-making, in which impact assessments and ex-post controls play an essential role, without triggering policy-making.  The Report of the Committee on Legal Affairs welcomes the better regulation package of 19 May 2015, the Commission's announcement that it intends to simplify the management of aid under the common agricultural policy, the European Structural and Investment Funds and Horizon 2020, and the fact that Commission President Juncker entrusts the First Vice-President of the Commission with the task of improving regulation, which underlines the political importance of this issue. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The REFIT programme has laudable objectives: more efficient, understandable and appropriate European regulation, better supervision of delegated acts, etc. However, the report says that the European regulation, which has a direct and obligatory effect in all its elements, is the most effective tool and therefore to be favoured over the directive, which we reject. It also welcomes the measures taken by the Commission when it is the first responsible for over-regulation, administrative burdens on our companies and deserves a final red card. This report therefore calls for abstention.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 'Regulatory Fitness and Effectiveness Programme' (REFIT) is the key element of the Commission's new strategy for better regulation. It is considered essential in the process of simplifying legislation and reducing the administrative burden of regulation for businesses, as well as removing barriers to growth and job creation. The 2003 Interinstitutional Better Regulation Agreement has been exceeded by the current legislative framework created by the Treaty of Lisbon and requires its renegotiation and updating. I believe that the objective and ambition of the better regulation package should be massified and applied in public administration at all levels of the European Union, given the exaggerated levels of bureaucracy across the Union and the need to simplify legislation in order to ensure good administration and procedures beneficial to Europe at all levels. I welcome the efforts to simplify the legislative process in general. I support the need for simpler, more accessible and clearly drafted legislation, without complexity and easy to implement. REFIT cannot be a source of legal uncertainty. EU legislation must ensure predictability, legal certainty and transparency.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which aims to cut red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve the design and quality of legislation. Under REFIT, the Commission is screening the entire stock of EU legislation on an ongoing and systematic basis to identify burdens, inconsistencies, ineffective measures and identified corrective actions.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the application of the ReFIT programme put in place by the Commission, which aims to make EU legislation simpler and less costly. In a difficult economic context, it is necessary to reduce administrative burdens, especially for SMEs, and to limit as much as possible the regulatory excess, practised in particular by France, which penalizes many major economic sectors such as agriculture.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of dense and complex European regulation, it seems to me essential to achieve a reduction in administrative and regulatory burdens. The initiative we are taking is part of the search for this simplification that is more than necessary, while respecting the fundamental principles of the European Union, first and foremost proportionality and subsidiarity. I have therefore voted in favour of this text, and would like to commend the work of the European Commission in favour of the REFIT programme, which is part of the same quest to simplify the legislation.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The strategic plan developed by the Commission, known as the Effective and Effective Regulation Programme, targets such as simplifying EU legislation and reducing administrative burdens. We have been talking for many years about excessive bureaucracy at both European and national level, the main enemy of efficiency and transparency. I welcome the report and trust that the effective and effective regulation programme will bring about noticeable changes.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The REFIT (Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme) programme represents a key component of the Commissions strategy for better law—making. I have voted for this report that should prioritise the development of certain measures and should focus on the quality of legislation and better enforcement of existing legislation rather than on the number of legislative acts.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Better regulation must result in the highest quality European legislation that meets the expectations of citizens and stakeholders and ensures that public policy objectives, including those related to consumers, the environment and social and safety standards, are not jeopardised. The Commission should focus on the quality of legislation, on better enforcement of existing legislation, and not on the number of pieces of legislation. The quality of legislation must be the only appropriate benchmark and the REFIT programme must not be used to undermine the sustainability of social, labour, environmental or consumer standards. We encourage the Commission and the Member States to step up the exchange of best practices in the context of the implementation and application of EU directives. Stakeholders and local and regional authorities could be encouraged to participate in identifying difficulties in implementing EU policy at local, regional and national level.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the programme for the effectiveness and effectiveness of legislation, in line with my view, points out that, in addition to the cost-benefit analysis, a comprehensive impact assessment should be carried out, including in particular the economic, social and environmental consequences and impacts on citizens' fundamental rights and gender equality. Among other things, the report highlights the benefits of the existence of independent committees that constructively support governments in legislative procedures to reduce administrative costs for businesses and citizens, and cites the Czech Republic as an example of good practice.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the report contains very good approaches and deserves support for me. A high-level group of independent stakeholders has submitted proposals to the European Commission to reduce administrative burdens.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. In particular, greater attention must be paid to better regulation, which should include a culture of public administration at all levels of the European Union, the implementation and application of Union acts at European Union, as well as at national, regional and local level. In order to ensure a transparent and coherent EU legislative process, dialogue with citizens, social partners and other economic and civil society stakeholders needs to be further promoted. In addition, regional and local authorities should be more involved in EU policy-making, especially at an early stage of legislation. It should be noted that impact assessments must be comprehensive in order to properly assess the regulatory implications for the economy, social sphere, the environment and fundamental rights of citizens. I believe that all EU institutions should develop a common methodology for impact assessments. In addition, SMEs should be subject to more flexible rules and micro-enterprises should be able to waive the requirements completely where possible, ensuring that the social, environmental and economic objectives of the proposed legislation are at least achieved.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Kaufmann report today. As a matter of principle we do not support and will not vote for any report which accepts the right of the EU to make the laws of the United Kingdom, however virtuous the proposals seem in isolation. The report makes it clear that, in whatever form, the process of legislation is going to continue. Its only virtue is that it impliedly damns the method of legislation that has pertained over the last sixty-odd years and which has so damaged the fabric of British trade, manufacturing and business since our entry into the then EEC in 1973 by burdensome and anti-competitive legislation. Sadly, the damage – vast damage – has already been done and is ongoing. Only by returning all legislative power to a newly-liberated UK Parliament with all its sovereignty restored, can the legislative process be made relevant to UK interests and legislators fully accountable to the people.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to mrs Kaufmann's report, I agree that more efficient regulation by the European Commission (under the REFIT programme) must include regulatory and bureaucratic simplification and encourage simpler application of EU law at national, regional and local level. To this end, I would like the Commission to review the scientific basis of the regulation.  In addition, I am convinced that lower administrative burdens can help SMEs, which, as we know, account for 99% of European businesses, and that these measures can contribute to the revival of competitiveness and employment. I am also in favour of both impact and result assessments, and have therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Unnecessary bureaucracy tarnishes the image of the European Union and is a burden for businesses and citizens. It also slows down economic growth and the creation of new job opportunities. I strongly support the necessity to cut red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation, so that the EU policy is able to deliver results faster and more efficiently. Therefore, I welcome the REFIT report and I voted in favour of it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. —REFIT is an important first step towards simplifying legislation and reducing the administrative burden that regulations create on businesses and removing barriers to growth and job creation.  I welcome the Commission's presented package for better regulation and consider it to be an important tool for better regulation. In my view, the REFIT programme is the first step towards reducing unnecessary regulatory burdens and removing barriers to growth and job creation. However, I note that 'better regulation' must not be used as an excuse for deregulation in order to undermine the rights of workers or consumers.  Furthermore, I welcome the efforts to simplify the legislative process in its entirety, while maintaining high standards. I believe that simpler, more clearly worded legislation is needed that is not complex and can be applied in a simple way in order to better comply with the rules and better protect workers.  I strongly and support further measures in the field of public procurement, such as encouraging smaller procurement packages, with a view to helping SMEs and microenter enterprises participate in public procurement tenders. I am convinced that good impact assessments are an important tool to support decision-making and play an important role in better regulation.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report contains a number of positive points and recommendations, particularly on SMEs. It recognises the Commission's expressed desire for less stringent rules for SMEs when this is both reasonable and feasible. It asks it not to scale back its ambitions for reducing administrative burdens on SMEs and not to question the public policy objectives pursued, particularly in the areas of consumer protection, the environment, social protection, health and safety.  But other points are prohibitive: the report implies that the European regulation, of direct and compulsory effect in all its elements, is the most effective tool and therefore to be preferred over the directive, and that it has the effect of strengthening the internal market. I strongly oppose both of these principles. Moreover, the text often congratulates the Commission, whose results should rather make all supporters of the European Union blush with shame.  In these circumstances, I prefer to abstain.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 REFIT is a key tool for simplifying legislation and reducing the administrative burden on businesses, as well as for removing obstacles to growth and job creation. However, this simplification and deregulation must not have a negative impact on the health and safety of citizens, consumers, workers or the environment. The Commission must, in fact, focus on the quality of legislation and better application of existing legislation, and costs should not be the only factor taken into account. I agree with the call for greater attention to be paid to compulsory and regular dialogue with representative associations and with civil society. Through greater transparency, it is possible to ensure a more effective functioning of the Union and to increase the confidence of civil society. Impact assessments are an important tool in support of EU decision-making. The assessment of competitiveness is central, but we must also consider the economic, social and environmental consequences, and the impact on citizens' fundamental rights and on equality between women and men. I also welcome the attention that has been paid to SMEs. Finally, I support the proposal to remove the concept of nutrient profiles. There are no "good" or "bad" foods, only "good" or "bad" diets.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒REFIT Smart Regulation Programme aims to consolidate better law-making, simplify EU law and reduce administrative and/or regulatory burdens. The REFIT programme is a key component of the Commission's new better law-making strategy, and the programme's performance review provides an assessment of the progress made in all policy areas identified by the Commission for each initiative.  I welcome this package of measures and the Commission's continued commitment to a better law-making agenda and that this measure does not intend to deregulate certain policy areas or call into question the values that are important to us, starting with social protection, environmental protection and fundamental rights, one of which is the right to health.  I emphasise that this package of measures leads to greater transparency that can lead to a more efficient functioning of the EU and greater trust of civil society in the EU. I expect REFIT to reduce unnecessary regulatory burdens and to have a positive impact on SMEs and an increase in employment as a whole.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 REFIT is an integral part of the Better Regulation programme against which we voted in the last plenary session. Despite some positive elements, in particular with regard to workers' rights, the document exacerbates a federalist and European integration perspective, in a logic in which Community legislation is sold as always superior and better than national legislation. There is a tendency to withdraw the initiative of action and legislative of the States. The project focuses on reducing all legislation that has supposed burdens on competitiveness, competition, the economy and economic operators. The logical sequence is the deepening of attacks on workers' rights, moving towards the reduction of wages, the increase in working hours, the reduction of the burden of companies on social protection. It defends a logic of designing laws that are subjugated to economic interests and according to their needs, with a view to boosting the profits of large companies, in a vision of capitalist exploitation. This will produce excess legislation to create mechanisms that benefit profit or economic corruption, or by default, by simplifying legal proceedings for dismissals of workers, for example. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. I support my colleague Kaufmann's report. We need to have a strong focus towards better regulation in the EU and in this regard I find the Regulatory Etiability and Efficiency Programme (REFIT) useful. The Programme will remove regulatory barriers, improve and simplify the legislative process, thus achieving policy objectives with as few administrative barriers as possible, in line with EU principles, such as proportionality and subsidiarity. I think it is necessary to identify what these obstacles and ineffactive measures are, and it is also not in dispute that better regulation will send a signal to EU citizens who perceive the EU as too bureaucratic. The European Parliament must take action and send a strong message that it must be consulted in adopting such measures and that the mutual trust of the European institutions must not be undermined. I am particularly committed to adopting measures to combat over-regulation, while stressing the need to ensure predictability, legal certainty and transparency.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Responding to the idea that the European Union is too bureaucratic and far away from citizens is a daily concern. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which welcomes the European Commission's commitment to improved regulation. The challenge is to reduce administrative burdens, particularly for SMEs, and to increase the compliance of EU legislation with the objectives set out in the treaties. Above all, this will allow a limit on the regulatory excess, a practice particularly common in France.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the Kaufmann report today. As a matter of principle we do not support and will not vote for any report which accepts the right of the EU to make the laws of the United Kingdom, however virtuous the proposals seem in isolation. The report makes it clear that, in whatever form, the process of legislation is going to continue. Its only virtue is that it impliedly damns the method of legislation that has pertained over the last sixty-odd years and which has so damaged the fabric of British trade, manufacturing and business since our entry into the then EEC in 1973 by burdensome and anti-competitive legislation. Sadly, the damage – vast damage – has already been done and is ongoing. Only by returning all legislative power to a newly-liberated UK Parliament with all its sovereignty restored, can the legislative process be made relevant to UK interests and legislators fully accountable to the people.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT): current situation and prospects" is a key element of the Commission's new strategy for "better regulation" and aims at simplifying EU legislation and reducing administrative and/or regulatory burdens, fighting for good governance on the basis of a policy-making process based on concrete facts, in which impact assessments and ex-post assessments play an important role, without replacing policy decisions, and I voted in favour. This report draws attention to the fact that the spirit of better regulation should permeate the culture of public administration at all levels of the European Union, bearing in mind excessive levels of bureaucracy. Furthermore, it stresses that the Commission should make the development of certain measures a priority and focus on the quality of legislation and better implementation of existing legislation, not on the number of legislative acts.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. 74% of Europeans believe that the European Union generates too much bureaucracy. In response to this concern, the Commission has in recent years focused on streamlining legislation and reducing regulatory constraints. This is even more true under the Commission chaired by Jean-Claude Juncker. A desire to reduce the "law machine" which sometimes negatively impacts a whole chain of economic activity and which contributes to citizens' distrust-distrust of the European Union. It is therefore natural that I supported the Kaufmann report on the annual progress in the implementation of the programme for sharp and effective regulation (REFIT).  I, like the majority of MEPs, also supported paragraph 47 rejecting nutritional profiles. An interesting idea, but one that has proved impossible to implement since the first discussions on the subject in 2006. In practice, when the thresholds for sugar, saturated fatty acids and sodium are exceeded, products would no longer be allowed to promote their other nutritional characteristics. To give an example: a cheese too rich in fatty acids could no longer highlight the fact that it is also rich in calcium. A little excessive as a proposition!

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to remove obstacles, simplify and improve the quality of legislation. This aims to promote employment, but without lowering quality standards or increasing precarious employment. In the commitments, the rapporteur has succeeded in ensuring social dialogue and environmental, social and health standards.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. EFIT is the European Commission's Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness programme. The programme envisages measures to simplify EU rules and reduce the costs it causes. The REFIT program is part of a broader concept that is "Smart Regulation" or "Better Regulation". This improvement in legislation is to devise EU rules and policies so that they achieve their objectives at the lowest cost.  For the Socialists, the idea of 'better regulation' should not become an excuse to eliminate regulation and reduce the EU's legislative capacity. With this socialist-led report, we have managed to ensure, within the framework of this programme, the protection of social dialogue and the role of consumers and social partners, as well as environmental, social, health and safety standards. We have also succeeded in rejecting conservative and anti-European calls for the establishment of an independent Regulatory Improvement Advisory Agency, limiting the claims of Eurosceptic groups to impede the Union's legislative capacity. For all this, I have decided to vote for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I decided to vote against the Kaufmann report in plenary. While the pursuit of better regulation is to be part of our objectives as European parliamentarians, I remain concerned about the negative impact that a programme such as REFIT can have. Concerned first of all because at times this text tends to encourage the Commission not to adopt proposals that would have a negative impact on competitiveness without taking into account potential progress for workers and citizens. I am also concerned about the possibility of the Commission being able to withdraw a legislative proposal provided that the Council has not yet decided on it.  I must admit, however, that this report also contains important advances aimed at defending the interests of consumers, workers and citizens more broadly. I say this and I repeat, I am in favour of a regulatory simplification that can relieve SMEs without harming workers, consumers and citizens. This message is beginning to be heard, and I can only be pleased to see that the lines are moving on this subject.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support this report. The report lacks ambition and clarity. It has never been able to properly distinguish between reducing administrative burdens and reducing the regulatory burden.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Kaufmann's report.  The REFIT programme aims to consolidate best practices in regulation, simplify and improve EU legislation. The report stresses that the objective of the REFIT programme must be primarily the quality of the legislation and not its cost. In these circumstances, it must not lead to a weakening of standards in social, environmental, consumer and worker protection matters.  Thus, this report supports the Commission in its desire to simplify and make European legislation more efficient, while making it clear that this should not result in deregulation.  It also stresses the importance of transparency, stakeholder consultation and social dialogue in the development of rules, highlights the essential role of impact studies but also of ex-post studies and evaluation of legislation.  Finally, the report states that the stricter standards, taken in according the directives by the Member States, should not be regarded as excessive regulation. However, they must not degrade the image of the European Union's legislative action and therefore remain proportionate.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, referring to a motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT), aims to take note of the current state of the SITUATION of REFIT itself, thereby identifying new, more ambitious actions and targets under the Better Regulation agenda. To that extent, I consider it imperative that there be less bureaucratic burden and less and better European legislation, which meets the legitimate expectations of citizens and stakeholders, and also ensures that the objectives of public policy, which are part, for example, of the rules on consumers, the environment, social protection, health and safety, are not called into question. This own-initiative report also presents other legislative suggestions that aim to contribute to further simplification, transparency and enhanced dialogue and public consultation in decision-making. Since these principles are the ones I endorse and which I consider to be essential for the definition of serious, credible and responsible European policies, I have decided to give my vote in favour of the report in question.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 Legislation determines quality, not quantity.  Unfortunately, this basic then is sometimes forgotten in Brussels. Regulation on top of regulation, more bureaucracy, unnecessary and opaguous laws. This is what the Union does. Sometimes it's good to admit mistakes and take a step back. For the EU, it is a step forward. The REFIT programme is a key element of the Commission's strategy for better law-based legislation, which is why I welcome it.  Less, clearer and better, it is good to continue the legislative work on these notes.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this important report on European regulation, in particular by supporting paragraph 47. Parliament reiterates before the European Commission the principle of 'thinking first of SMEs', indicating them as a reference point for EU policies (as they make up 95 % of European industry and production). Furthermore, the vote in favour of paragraph 47 has a first concrete effect for the entire agri-food chain: Parliament called on the Commission to review the part of Regulation (EC) No 1924/2006 which gives the green light to highly penalising labelling for a large number of quality products (PDO, PGI, TSG). According to this regulation, foods were classified according to their fat, sugar and salt content, thus offering partial and incorrect information, and classifying as harmful to health a large number of products of the Mediterranean diet by the introduction of new 'nutrient profiles' (the famous 'traffic light labelling' already implemented in the United Kingdom), with the risk of justifying additional taxation. Parliament thus reaffirmed that the correctness of consumer food information is not improved through the implementation of existing rules, such as Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011, according to which information must be mandatory and complete.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report remains in line with the implementation of the REFIT programme (regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme). While we are critical of many aspects of their implementation in the regulatory framework of legislative procedures, we voted abstention because the regulatory framework is not aimed at harming the rights of workers.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted today in favour of nutrient profiles in food legislation and I am disappointed that many colleagues voted differently on this issue. Nutrient profiling has been done by the World Health Organisation and could serve as a tool to prevent misleading health claims on foods and restrict the advertising of junk food to children. The Commission has failed in its legal obligation to propose nutrient profiles as part of health claims legislation, and as a result has missed an important opportunity to improve information to consumers. There will be many now considering whether health claims on foods should continue to be allowed at all given that such an essential piece of the legislation is lacking.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the inventory and outlook of the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT), as it can, among other things, restore the confidence of EU citizens, who often combine EU activity with high administrative burdens, into the efficient functioning of the European Union. The programme's intention to reduce bureaucracy and regulatory burdens, while simplifying and improving legislation in order to achieve policy objectives with low administrative burdens, continues to contribute to effective functioning in the EU. Among other things, stakeholder consultation and impact assessments are particularly important.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because despite its technical appearance, it is a political backlash to the Commission's strategy to increase its legislative power and avoid scrutiny of its decisions. Ex ante, the Commission politically strengthens its neoliberal agenda with consultations and technical studies tailored to its interests, which allow it to set the limits of political discussion. Ex post, reserves the right to withdraw legislative proposals which Parliament has amended (as was the case with the maternity directive) or to make changes to its implementation that end up emptying its contents (as has happened with the new parameters of NOx emissions or chemical toxicity, REACH). Both changes, under the slogans of "better", "more appropriate", "more informed" or "more effective" regulation cannot hide the undemocratic bias that characterizes European construction.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report voted on today on the adequacy and effectiveness of regulation aims to underline the importance of quality legislation that meets citizens' expectations and does not involve excessive bureaucracy.  In this regard, it called for the removal of the concept of nutritional profile, which was considered redundant and unnecessary, with the aim of avoiding unjustified discrimination in foods of Mediterranean origin and generating negative consequences for the competitiveness of the European agri-food sector. Nutrient profiles provide, in fact, that foods are classified according to their nutritional composition, and therefore according to the content of salt, sugar and fats, not taking into account how these foods are actually associated with each other.  This type of classification, in addition to having no scientific basis, greatly penalizes Italian excellence and products, paradoxically branded as "bad foods", causing great damage to agri-food companies. I therefore voted in favour of this report, in the hope that the elimination of the distortive concept of nutritional profile will guarantee the protection of our products and the protection of our production.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider that the system of "traffic light" on complementary nutrition labelling, which is used voluntarily by some countries, may lead to discriminatory practices of certain products, without any rationale or consequence in improving the nutritional balance of consumer diets. For this reason, the feasibility, from a legal point of view, of the use of this particular system should be verified. As regards nutrition claims of products, in accordance with the rules laid down by their legal framework, I consider that they allow access to a food choice on the basis of scientifically founded characteristics.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The ACP (Africa Caribbean Pacific) countries are poor countries which the EU aims to dominate politically and economically. One of the primary tools by which it does this is politicised trade deals, whereby market access is conditional upon submitting to EU political demands. The Economic Partnership Agreements are amongst the most intrusive and formalised means by which the EU gains control over poor countries. We will vote against any attempt to make the EU more powerful towards actors in the Global South.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The REFIT programme aims to cut red-tape, remove regulatory burdens, and simplify and improve the design and quality of EU legislation. While there is always a risk for vulnerable groups to be unduly affected by the reduction of administrative burdens, as tends to be the meaning behind ‘red-tape’, I can sympathise with the time-consumption and loss of revenue that such things introduce for many businesses. In this case I voted in favour of the report as I am confident that this report calls for the reduction of commercial burdens without reducing employment standards and will not encourage precarious types of employment. Furthermore, there is a clear commitment in this report for the inclusion of social partners and consumers in the programme, which was guaranteed by the work of the S&D Rapporteur, Sylvia Kaufmann.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution on the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme gives an overview of the progress and implementation of EU legislation. As this resolution calls for a focus on better quality in legislation and standard checks on subsidiarity, I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the European Commission's priorities is to simplify EU legislation and reduce the regulatory burden of EU legislation. I therefore consider the Regulatory Fitness and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT) to be a key element of the Commission's new strategy in developing new but, above all, quality legislation. I supported the resolution because I believe that the programme presented and the measures adopted will simplify legislation, remove its complexity and also reduce the costs associated with its application.
