In order to ensure the effectiveness of EU action, I expect all levels of government to be involved in the programme, which should ensure that the implementation of legislation or policy is achieved in the most effective and efficient way possible. I share the bottom-up approach to deregulation and the Commission has created a European Stakeholder Forum for Better Regulation and Reduction of Bureaucracy, which will have a quantitative target of reducing the administrative burden by 25% by 2020. I believe that REFIT will become an effective tool that eliminates unnecessary bureaucracy and regulation that burdens citizens and entrepreneurs, especially small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) is a key element of the Commission's new better law-making strategy. Refit is to consolidate procedures to improve law-making, simplify EU law and reduce administrative and regulatory burdens. The report covers various areas such as better regulation, transparency and stakeholder consultation, impact assessments and implementation of EU legislation in the Member States. Simplification of legislation (REFIT) can reduce the level of ambition in legislation on certain issues, namely human well-being and environmental protection, because there is no proper distinction between reducing administrative barriers and reducing regulatory burdens. Reducing regulatory burdens may put the very existence of laws and the protection provided by them into question. The report does not limit the emphasis on the impact assessment and, more specifically, on the competitiveness assessment, as it remains an important part of the impact assessment process. Furthermore, the report does not make a clear distinction between reducing administrative barriers and regulatory burdens, which is why I voted against the Report on the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT).

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report expressing Parliament's position on the REFIT programme, launched by the European Commission with the aim of reducing the bureaucratic burden of regulating certain sectors, removing excessive regulatory obstacles and simplifying and improving the quality of legislation.  As the Commission monitors all EU legislation through the REFIT programme to identify possible obstacles and inconsistencies in European action, we have expressed our concerns that behind this exercise there is a risk of a downward revision of many of the protection rules contained in sectoral legislation. From this point of view, the final text of the report is positive, as it maintains as a priority to be followed in the implementation of the programme the social dialogue and with stakeholders, the maintenance of environmental and employment standards and consumer protection.  I therefore hope that the Commission will take account of the European Parliament's recommendations in taking the REFIT programme forward in a balanced manner that is attentive to the interests of the citizens of the Union.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) stresses that costs should not be a determining factor, but that the quality of legislation is the only appropriate benchmark and REFIT must not be used to undermine sustainability or any social, labour, environmental and consumer standards. Simplifying EU legislation and reducing administrative and regulatory burdens guarantees a reduction in bureaucracy for citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises. I see more flexible rules for small and medium-sized enterprises as streamlining administrative processes, thus ensuring public interest objectives, workers' rights and the economic activity of the whole state.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Regulatory Efficiency and Emancy Programme (REFIT) is a key component of the Commission's new strategy to better draft legislation, simplify EU law and reduce administrative burden. There is too much red tape across the European Union and legislation needs to be simplified while maintaining high standards.  Furthermore, it is important to include the implementation and application of Union acts at European and national level with a view to ensuring good governance, in line with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The fulfilment of these objectives requires cooperation between all eu institutions, Member States and stakeholders. Consequently, I support the report on the programme for the efficacy and effectiveness of the regulations. I believe that it is in the interest of the citizens of the European Union to make the legislation easier and more clearly worded.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The REFIT programme aims to cut red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve the design and quality of legislation. Under REFIT, the Commission is screening the entire stock of EU legislation on an ongoing and systematic basis to identify burdens, inconsistencies, ineffective measures and identified corrective actions.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The 2012 Agenda for Vigilance and Efficiency of Regulation is an important part of the Commission's progress in drafting legislation. He worries that too much bureaucracy is not slowing down work within the EU institutions and helping to make decisions in all EU institutions. It also ensures the legal certainty of citizens and businesses and regulates the implementation of EU acts and regulations in member states.  It is based on the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality and represents better compliance and protection of EU workers. I support the Report on the Program for Ethality and Effectiveness of Regulations. The Programme simplifies EU administration and legislation, assesses the impacts and uses the advanced control system, which is very important in linking EU legislation with citizens. I believe that the interaction of all EU institutions is essential in reducing red tape and increasing efficiency.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report and support all efforts to reduce the regulatory burden on the part of the European Union. However, despite repeated grand plans to reduce regulatory burdens, EU action in this area is desperately inadequate and European Union legislation remains one of the biggest obstacles to economic growth in the EU.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme: State and Outlook. We often stress that we need good legislation at European Union level, which will not be complex and will contribute to good governance, where impact assessment and subsequent control play an important role without replacing political decision-making. I support the report, which stresses that better regulation should encompass the 'culture' of public administration at all levels of the European Union and take into account excessive bureaucracy in the EU and the need to simplify legislation.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's report on the programme for the effectiveness and effectiveness of legislation, as a compromise was reached at the level of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which, as it turned out, also received support in plenary. This compromise also included a section on so-called nutrition profiles, where the European Commission is invited to examine the scientific basis and usefulness of the regulation regulating these nutritional profiles and, as a result, to propose further action.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Policy-making in no way can depend on the statutory opinion of companies or simply on the results of statistics. It is an unacceptable degradation of policy. Such a mentality is no different from the logics of the Memorandums.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I am pleased to see it highlighting the importance of the better regulation culture, including the need to reduce red tape, simplify legislation and ensure that EU legislation does not negatively affect competitiveness.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system for both business sector workers and EU citizens. It aims to put an end to red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation.   Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on a programme of effective and effective regulation, which highlighted the need for a very high level of bureaucracy and simplification of legislation throughout the Union. I agree with the reporter that the Commission should give priority to the development of certain measures rather than the number of legislative acts. Greater attention should be paid to the quality of legislation and to better implementation of existing legislation. The report also rightly stressed that the REFIT programme should not under any circumstances be used to undermine sustainability or social, labour, environmental and consumer protection standards.  I also share the view that the Commission should continue to work to reduce the administrative burden on SMEs, which could provide a basis for creating high-quality jobs.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Excessive bureaucracy is one of the most serious problems facing the EU today, which affects not only the quality of the existing law, but also the lives of European citizens and their attitude towards the Community. The REFIT Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme was to consolidate better regulation procedures and reduce administrative and regulatory burdens. Legislative practice has been slightly improved since its introduction, but much remains to be done. In this respect, the Commission's 2015 decision to examine all legislative initiatives adopted so far and, if necessary, to update or eliminate them, welcomes this aspect. Parliament's report rightly emphasises the need for an ex post evaluation of eu law, as well as the Commission's commitment to test the impact of the new legislation on small and medium-sized enterprises, especially as 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises account for 99% of all businesses in the EU. All these steps are important elements in the process of improving the functioning of the European Union and should be introduced as quickly and efficiently as possible, otherwise the Union will remain a bureaucratic juggerthotic, multiplying low-quality legislation that does not serve European citizens as it should.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 As a whole, I voted in favour of the report, albeit against paragraph 47 on the elimination of nutritional profiles, because it would be inconsistent to remove nutritional profiles, given that the ultimate objective of the profiles is to prevent consumers from being misled by claims. The evaluation and review of profiles is welcome. In general, the REFIT programme plays an important role towards less, better and lighter regulation.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme represents a good opportunity to remove administrative barriers and simplify and improve European legislation. We have both the need and the obligation to create a framework that stimulates the economy and generates jobs. At the same time, it is important to also consider the social component. The concept of better regulation does not and should not mean deregulation or precarious employment contracts. We are not talking about the absence of rules, but about improving them for all actors involved, for institutions, companies, but also for citizens. This document must be understood as a necessary step towards a healthy and transparent legislative framework that fits a modern, efficient and fair European Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I abstained in the final vote. On what has become of REFIT, namely a catch-all legislative proposal, I am deeply against this way of doing legislation and politics. However, I must admit that the text proposes important progress. That explains my decision.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While regulations are necessary, they are often too complex, opaque and entail too many administrative burdens. This is especially true for SMEs, which should be able to benefit from various EU legislations and funds, but are often hindered because rules are unclear and administrative costs too high. The European Commission’s Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) is a step towards making EU law simpler and its implementation easier, thus contributing to a clear, stable and predictable regulatory framework supporting growth, investment and jobs. This is why I voted in favour of this text, which is in line with the inter-institutional agreement I have worked on. I especially welcome the newly created REFIT platform, which establishes an ongoing dialogue between all EU institutions, national governments, and representatives of business, social partners and civil society on how to improve EU legislation. This will simplify and clarify legislation for our business and citizens.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Democracy is also easy access to regulations. That is why the European Commission has launched a programme called 'REFIT' aimed at simplifying and clarifying European regulations and making them more readable by citizens The Kaufmann report takes up and improves the European Commission's simplification programme.  We had to be vigilant because, under the guise of simplification, the right has found a way to cut back on the European Union's protection standards, for example by voting for the removal of "nutritional profiles" that are used by consumers to know the characteristics of a food. Legislation must be understood by all, but it must also increase the protections of Europeans, guaranteeing demanding social, health, safety and environmental standards.  For the European Socialists, simplification must keep the same high level of standards and protections, which is why we will continue to fight for simple, demanding regulations that are a source of progress for citizens. So, if I objected to the abolition of the concept of nutritional profile, I voted in favour of this report, which is going in the right direction.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme seeks to establish a simple, clean and predictable regulatory system for both business sector workers and EU citizens. It aims to put an end to red tape, remove regulatory burdens, simplify and improve legislation.   Within the framework of REFIT, the Commission monitors the whole of European legislation, focusing, inter alia, on the definition of these burdens and on measures to prevent them from legislating.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒The Regulatory Ency and Efficiency Programme is a key component of the Commission's new strategy, which aims to consolidate better law-making, simplify EUROPEAN Union law, reduce administrative and regulatory burdens and move towards good governance. Taking into account the excessive level of bureaucracy at all levels of the European Union, I believe that better regulation should cover the 'culture' of public administration at all levels of the European Union.  I believe that dialogue with citizens, social partners and other stakeholders in the field of economy and civil society will contribute to guaranteeing transparent, effective and coherent EUROPEAN Union legislation, so I supported the report on the Programme for Etiness and Efficiency of Regulations (REFIT): The state of play and prospects for the future. I emphasise that the Commission's strategy underlines the importance of social dialogue and respect for the autonomy of social partners and that the programme does not intend to deregulate certain policy areas and call into question values such as social protection, environmental protection and fundamental rights.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 Report on the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT): I supported the situation and outlook. The REFIT programme is an important first step towards simplifying legislation and reducing the administrative burden of regulation for businesses and removing barriers to growth and job creation. What matters is the Commission's commitment to the simple, clear, coherent and predictable regulatory framework presented in the programme.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report remains in line with the implementation of the REFIT programme (regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme). While we are critical of many aspects of their implementation in the regulatory framework of legislative procedures, we voted abstention because the regulatory framework is not aimed at harming the rights of workers.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Decisions taken by the institutions of the European Union concern us all, and assessing the impact of the legislation being drafted requires particular rigour, so that the changes that are introduced during the legislative process and political decisions are made in full knowledge of the facts and on the basis of concrete studies. The new package proposed by the European Commission on Better Regulation takes into account the requirements of citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and the rules drawn up are made in such a way as to be understood by all. The REFIT programme aims to strengthen procedures for better regulation, simplify European Union law and reduce the administrative and regulatory burden. I welcome the Better Regulation package, because I believe that the current Commission has a coherent and holistic approach to better regulation, which takes into account the entire political cycle of this process and involves the targeted interaction of all institutions and local and regional authorities.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The REFIT programme aims to consolidate the procedure for improving regulation, simplify EU legislation, reduce administrative and regulatory burdens and start good governance based on evidence-based policy-making, in which impact assessments and ex-post controls play an essential role, without triggering policy-making. With my vote, I followed the position of the S&D group.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report remains in line with the implementation of the REFIT programme (regulatory adequacy and effectiveness programme). While we are critical of many aspects of their implementation in the regulatory framework of legislative procedures, we voted abstention because the regulatory framework is not aimed at harming the rights of workers.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was against since I am concerned that the regulatory simplification (REFIT) might lower in the legislation the level of ambition on issues related – i.e. to the well—being of people and the protection of environment by not properly distinguishing between the reduction of administrative burdens and the reduction of regulatory burdens, as reducing regulatory burdens questions the very existence of the laws and the protection provided by those laws.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT): State of Play and Outlook, as the programme represents a key component of the new Commission strategy for better law making. The REFIT Programme aims to consolidate better law—making procedures, to simplify EU law and reduce administrative and regulatory burdens, while maintaining open, transparent and regular dialogue with representative associations and civil society.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objectives of the Regulatory Adequacy and Effectiveness Programme (REFIT) are to reduce bureaucracy and administrative burdens on the one hand and to simplify and improve legislation on the other in order to achieve policy objectives and respecting the legality of treaties and the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. We are talking about a report which is currently giving an important political signal in supporting the Commission's 'better regulation' agenda. A report which has been broadly committed to the rapporteur's support and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it is a step forward in legislation, advancing the simplification of EU regulations and reducing the costs it causes.  In this sense, and in order to promote employment in Europe, reducing bureaucratic burdens seems to us to be an appropriate means.  Employment standards cannot be reduced and job precariousness cannot be reduced or should grow, so the idea of 'better regulation' should not become an excuse to eliminate management and reduce eu legislative capacity.  The aim is to get the entire EU regulatory apparatus in shape, while assessing the performance of regulation emanating from the European institutions.  It was also possible to ensure the protection of social dialogue and the role of consumers and social partners, as well as environmental, social, health and safety standards. Conservative and anti-European appeals have also been rejected.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'European regulations are often too complex and too opaque. Moreover, European rules all too often lead to an additional administrative burden. This is especially true for SMEs which often cannot benefit from relevant European regulations, because the administrative costs and lack of clarity about regulation are too great. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal, as it aims to make european Union law and its possible transposition considerably easier.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Despite some positive aspects in this report, such as the reference to workers' rights, what prevails and which we reject is a federalist and European integration perspective in which there is no national legislation that is better than the Community. That is, a tendency to empty the importance of the action and legislative production of states. Even if we put the concern for workers' rights, which is fair, the heart of this project is the reduction of all legislation that has burdens on competitiveness, competition, the economy and economic operators.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for the earlier involvement of third parties (consultations), a more detailed impact assessment in terms of content and ex-post considerations. The report also refers to initiatives by some Member States which, in the legislative procedure, identify the additional burden on SMEs and then weigh them up. It should be noted that 30 per cent of the additional burden on SMEs comes from the implementation of directives by the Member States. Maintaining higher standards in the Member States leads to gold-plating and, therefore, to an additional burden on SMEs.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament resolution on the Programme to Ensure The Efficiency and Performance of Legislation (REFIT): I voted in favour of the stocktaking and outlook. This does not in any way achieve the necessary level of institutional reform to improve legislation, but it is a drastic improvement in the status quo. Real reforms would require a new understanding of the role of the EU and its tasks, in particular legislation. This is not foreseeable. Nevertheless, I think it is important not only to focus on the future, but to achieve small successes now. This report is also part of this, although I see little hope that this will actually change something fundamental in the way the Commission and its remoteness from its citizens.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: In writing. As a doctor, I have always believed that there are no food products to avoid. Of course, there are specificities, but everyone knows their medical situation and, today in Europe, consumers receive all information about food products through the regulation on labelling and consumer information. The concept of "nutritional profile" is not based on scientific knowledge and is even partial because it would be limited to indicating and classifying food products on too limited a basis such as: sugar, salt and fats. I believe that the current regulation is sufficient to inform consumers in Europe and that, already today by reading the labels, it is possible to obtain any information on the products on sale. We often talk about childhood obesity which, in my opinion, is fought through a multidisciplinary approach and through a healthy lifestyle adapted to the conditions of each. This is not a political or ideological issue, it is biochemistry!

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Law Suitability and Effectiveness Control Programme (REFIT): Current situation and prospects, bearing in mind that the REFIT programme is crucial for the Commission's new strategy on better regulation, simplification of EU law and reduction of administrative burdens.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report assessing the state of play as well as the outlook for the future of the Regulatory Fitness and Efficiency Programme (REFIT). In general, I consider REFIT as a process of reviewing European Union legislation as a beneficial step towards clear and effective legislation. Like REFIT, this report calls for greater emphasis to be placed on its quality than quantity when drafting legislation, and overall recommends focusing on clear, consistent and comprehensible legislation. Other positive elements of the report include a recommendation to include so-called sunset clauses, which would determine from the outset the life of a legal act, the inclusion of revision clauses, but also closer monitoring of compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. As I support all these principles in the drafting of European legislation, I have given my voice to the report.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The whole concept of nutrient profiles needs to be reviewed and possibly eliminated. Nutrient profiles are not of use to the consumer and their scientific basis is doubtful. Nutrient profiles could justify 'traffic light' labelling, which causes distorting effects on the market and deceives the consumer into classifying food as good or bad. There are, however, no good or bad foods, but good or bad diets. Protecting health means promoting an appropriate way of life by combating the abuse, not the use, of food. Traffic light labelling can create damage to italian products of excellence that form the basis of the Mediterranean diet, recognized as one of the most complete and balanced.  Protecting health means promoting a healthy lifestyle and a varied and balanced diet, educating about the right use and avoiding abuse, not misleading the consumer by inducing him to classify individual foods as good or bad on the basis of traffic light labelling.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. Refit is the stated programme to reduce the costs of regulation and bureaucracy. I have defended paragraph 47 of the report with the intention of preventing the introduction of traffic light labels on products that contain a high caloric value. The traffic light label system is extremely misleading because it focuses only on the amounts of fats, sugars and salts contained in the product. According to this system a flagship of our "Made In" such as olive oil would be labeled as harmful, with a large red sticker. On the contrary, laboratory-prepared chemical drinks with low sugar and fat levels would see a nice green stamp. We do not need scientific knowledge, common sense is enough to understand the absurdity of these labels. This system would be a disaster for consumers and serious businesses. I have therefore fought to eliminate any future attempts to create an English-style model of traffic light labelling by voting in favour of the paragraph. However, on other points the report was not sufficiently clear about the scope that increased deregulation can have on consumer rights, so I abstained with regard to the final vote.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Supervision of the adequacy and effectiveness of regulations is a key element for better european law-making so that it does not become an end in itself. That is why I supported the report on the REFIT Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme, which calls, inter alia, for a clearer formulation of the rules, a simpler implementation and a contribution to the functioning of all entities within the rule of law. Simpler and smarter regulation leads to consistent transposition and more effective and uniform enforcement in the Member States.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Towards improving regulation of the single market, says the report. Well, I have some ideas, even though I was looking for them in the report, so I couldn't even vote on what else should be improved on this particular single market regulation.  Everything is already regulated, up to the curvature of the legendary cucumber, but it is not regulated that those who produce goods produced in the framework of the free movement of goods or provide services should achieve what minimum standard of living they should achieve, and how much uniformity would be needed in this, because, say, if we look at the standard of living and wages of Hungary and Austria, we can talk about many things, but not uniformity. This should now finally be addressed so that it is not possible to give wages of EUR 200 and EUR 300 within the European Union and to make people work in inhumane conditions, as in the third world. Thank you very much!

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I did not support the report on the single market regulations. It contained several controversial elements which I do not feel will positively contribute to the further single market integration that we all want to see. References to consumer, social and environmental objectives as criteria to guide fitness checks, impact assessments and evaluation processes of current and future EU legislation were absent from the initial draft report and had to be introduced by my group via 15 plenary amendments, which were sadly lost. Furthermore, instead of emphasising the need for better regulation, regulatory action in general in this report is regarded as a bureaucratic burden. Subsidiarity is used as a tool to greatly undermine EU competences already agreed upon by Member States, eluding the possibility that action at EU level is justified in specific and detailed cases where it is deemed more effective than action taken at a national, regional or local level. Additionally, the wording on gold-plating could be potentially interpreted as a means to limit policies aimed at ensuring social, workers’ and consumer rights. Instead the report should have made a stronger call for greater clarity on how to transpose EU directives correctly in order to avoid extra costs for businesses, consumers and citizens.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – This report builds on the previous report. It again concerns the quality of legislation, in this case the single internal market.  I personally consider the single internal market to be one of the main positives of European integration, and it is therefore good that this issue is dealt with separately, especially compared to the previous report, which generally assesses the implementation and application of European legislation.  It is important, especially in this matter, to recognise the importance of the quality of European legislation. If European legislation is very general, then implementation in different Member States, in each country it is different and we have 28 different legal national regimes.  It is therefore a good idea to look at the quality of the various directives and regulations that regulate the EU's internal markets, and i am therefore glad that the European Commission has given us clear figures to see how the implementation is going.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir agus glacadh leis ag an deireadh. Without doubt the single market is there to promote competitiveness, innovation, growth and job creation, and it is vital that we ensure that the single market legislation is an effective well-designed policy, particularly now as we seek to continue along the path to economic recovery. It will set the right environment for businesses to prosper. There are three aspects I just want to emphasise briefly. One: impact assessments, which have been mentioned already. These have to be careful and detailed and undertaken in a proper manner. Two: consultation with stakeholders is crucial, and again this has to be open, transparent and inclusive. Three: the legislation itself must be fully implemented. This is not always the case, and if we want to reap the benefits of the single European market, effective and high-quality implementation is crucial to realising a fully—functioning single market.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The single market is to a large extent the cornerstone of the European Union's existence. Consequently, we must all constantly strive to maximise the principles of the relevant framework. The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality have already been addressed today, and it is clear that they are absolutely essential also in the case of the single market, because its functioning depends in fact on all the administrative mechanisms of the European Union. I have to say that, while a number of administrations are dealing with legal mechanisms for the functioning of the single market, its main players, I would say, are, however, a number of companies located in the territory of the European Union. Consequently, we must always strive to maintain and intensify dialogue with them so that they take the most of the benefits of this single market. And in parallel, of course, in order to improve contacts between decision-makers and economic operators, I agree with the need to increase the effectiveness of conflict resolution methods. Thank you!

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report as we believe that the best way to improve single market regulation is to deregulate. UKIP are particularly concerned by aspects of the report that criticise Member States’ lack of transposition of single market legislation. The report further calls on the Commission to launch infringement proceedings against these Member States, which UKIP are vehemently opposed to.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report states that the development of the Single Market should not clash with fundamental rights, while stressing the need for dialogue with organised civil society and protecting the social, environmental and security and security standards contained in European regulation. However, it continues to interpret the deepening of the Single Market as a priority over the 'overregulation' and 'barriers' that would leave the European economy, ignoring those of us who believe that improving the living conditions of Europeans must prioritise the upward harmonisation of social legislation and the democratisation of the institutions governing the Single Market. That's why I abstained.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which aims to strengthen the internal single market. The text aims to strengthen the governance of the single market as well as the powers of the European Commission. To achieve this, it calls for the aggressive implementation of market integration tools such as EURES, the European network of public services and employment, which aims to promote the mobility of workers within the Union. I cannot support this initiative, which aims to give the European Commission additional prerogatives at the expense of the sovereignty of our nations. The European Union wants to close the competitiveness gaps and macroeconomic divergences that result from the single market, by promoting budgetary transfers and geographical mobility of employees, which we formally dispute. So I voted against it.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. This is an own-initiative report setting out Parliament’s views on the implementation of measures relating to the single market. The report contained some positive provisions such as a call for the inclusion of worker and consumer rights in addition to considering environmental and socio-economic considerations. However, it did not call for any new measures, but for the effective use of existing instruments, a code word for further single market integration, thereby stripping Member States of their governmental autonomy

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as it contains a reasonable number of proposals to make single market legislation more efficient and efficient and to move towards growth and job creation within the Union

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I refuse: the strengthening of the Commission's powers; Putting Member States on the back of the way (considered in the text as "partners"); Strengthening the governance of the single market; aggressive implementation of market integration tools (e.g. EURES); the pinnacle of the single market, a unique solution to the problems of the European Union. The Europe of Nations is the only credible alternative to the resolution of imbalances: I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As much as this report talks about the importance of transparency and reducing the administrative and regulatory burden of the European Union it considers achieving this by further wasting taxpayers’ money. I voted against it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. The single market was set up to facilitate trade between businesses and consumers within the EU and to reduce costs. I voted in favour of this resolution because it aims to make the functioning of the single market more efficient, by setting simple standards for economic growth.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to improve the regulation of the single market. To improve the regulation of the Single Market is a shared responsibility of all EU institutions. It is a shared responsibility for respecting the fundamental principle of subsidiarity when deciding whether to take action and what action is best if regulation is needed, and ultimately to ensure that the measures and obligations envisaged are simple and effective. I agree that a more thoughtful approach that sets, responds, simple and effectively implements, responds rapidly to problems and ensures consistent legislative review, will make a significant contribution to the overall objectives. I agree that the aim of improving the regulation of the single market does not mean that any regulation must be abolished.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report assumes that the single market is still fragmented more than 20 years after its formal creation, in particular because Member States have not fully transposed or correctly implemented EU legislation and that improving single market regulation should therefore be a priority and a shared responsibility of the EU institutions. The material refers to it in several places, but it is clear from the referenced history that, in essence, it is a matter of the fact that, while the single market has already been achieved for products, it has not yet been achieved in the field of services. However, I rejected the whole thing because, with the vague text of this report, they are essentially trying to achieve a stronger expansion of the services market and a stronger enforcement of EU legislation on the Member States.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report as we believe that the best way to improve single market regulation is to deregulate. UKIP are particularly concerned by aspects of the report that criticise Member States’ lack of transposition of single market legislation. The report further calls on the Commission to launch infringement proceedings against these Member States, which UKIP are vehemently opposed to.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I cannot accept this report on the strengthening and "development" of the internal market, because of all that such a project entails in terms of the sovereignty of the Member States and democracy within the Union: in fact, this report leads to the strengthening of the powers of the Commission - whose members, it must be recalled, are appointed and unelected - and advocates the use of the 'single market' as a miracle solution to the Union's problems as well as the implementation of the Union's problems aggressively implementing tools for the integration of audit single market (like EURES) in defiance of the specific policies of the Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which I think favours too much liberal vision of how the single market works, without paying sufficient attention to the social, human and environmental dimensions of the European project.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Van Bossuyt report, which is dedicated to new single market legislation, makes a number of suggestions with a view to making the single market more functioning in terms of growth and job creation.  I voted against this report because I believe that the proposed measures are in stark contrast to the stated objectives. Fundamental principles of the Union, such as subsidiarity, have been interpreted with a view to limiting the Union's regulatory action as much as possible, indirectly harming the EU's role in setting high social standards for workers and consumers.  Considering the commitment to a single market that protects the citizens of the Union at the same time, within a common and not a national framework, to be essential, I have chosen to vote against this report.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report has some positive elements in terms of the implementation of the single market - especially in terms of transparency, the role of national parliaments or market surveillance, which we voted for - it does not significantly correct the profile of the single market dominated by the commodisation of any socio-product relationship, without redistribution or compensatory elements. The report does not make it possible to substantially correct the structural inequalities of the European Union, which are reinforced by the mechanisms of the single market. That's why we voted against it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on improving the regulation of the single market, a responsibility shared by each of the institutions of the Union. Promoting the achievements of the single market and taking advantage of the possibilities offered by the digital single market implies a firm commitment from each of the participants. Institutions need to be firm in this fundamental objective.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. As I am strongly opposed to the single market principle, I could only vote against this report on strengthening it. However, I welcome the criticisms made in this report against the inefficiency of this single market, including the lack of transparency on the part of the Council, the disregard for the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality enshrined in the treaties, and the inanity of the impact assessments provided, 40% of which were rejected by the Committee on The Monitoring of Impact Assessments. Finally, the strongest criticism, in my view, remains the reality of the excessively heavy regulations that this single market imposes on our SMEs. Despite these common-sense findings, I remain firmly opposed to the increase in the Commission's prerogatives in this area, a Commission which also does not hesitate to impose market integration in an almost dictatorial way through tools such as EURES. This single market is built in a genuine contempt for the Member States, which are supposed to be sovereign and regarded as mere 'partners', i.e. as species of provinces to be tamed by the Commission, which sees as a solution to all the problems caused by the European Union as more than the European Union.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. We consider the single market to be a key tool for relaunching economic growth and job creation in the Union, but we believe that an emphasis should be placed on a number of crucial issues, such as promoting better regulation and greater subsidiarity. In addition, we want to achieve more accessible and balanced EU legislation with the prerogatives of Member States, in order to achieve harmonised European standards on social, labour, environmental and consumer protection standards.  That is why I voted in favour of the report entitled 'Towards better regulation of the single market'.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which aims to improve the regulation of the single market, which is the shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is a concept that should underpin the methods by which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market. It is a shared responsibility for respecting the fundamental principle of subsidiarity when deciding whether to take action and what action is best, if regulatory, and ultimately to ensure that the measures and obligations envisaged are simple and applied effectively and effectively in order to achieve the agreed policy objectives.  Good legislation is not achieved through a single stage of the process, but through effective and effective action throughout the policy cycle. The transposition and implementation of single market regulation are essential for the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. It is important to see the implementation of legislation and secondary rules not as a separate element of the process, but as an integral part of efforts to reap the benefits of the Single Market. This is influenced not only by decisions taken by Member States in the transposition of legislation, but also by decisions taken in the first stages of policy-making on objectives and policy structures, and the way in which our acquis is reviewed and updated is equally important.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued achievements of the single market and the exploitation of the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market require a strong commitment from the actors concerned. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean removing all the rules, but creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps employment and business in Europe.  I voted in favour of this report, and I believe that improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market.  I agree that better legislation is not guaranteed by a single measure during the procedure, it is done through effective and effective work throughout the political cycle. It is therefore of the utmost importance for me to transpose and implement the rules of the single market. A single market that does not place too much of a burden on production, innovation and trade is a structure that will stimulate growth in Europe. In this context, shared responsibility will lead to the realisation of common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market will be created that will contribute to Europe's development.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. By voting in favour of a resolution on improving single market rules, MEPs supported the initiative with a view to improving the regulation of the single market in order to make it more effective. We are aware that the Single Market is an essential tool for restarting economic growth and creating jobs in the European Union. At the same time, the main objectives of the announced strategy should be, in particular, better regulation of the single market, based on past experience in the areas of free movement of goods and services, the digital single market, professional qualifications and public procurement. There is an need to further explore specific tools to ensure a competitive regulatory environment for our businesses, to support growth and create new jobs and to strengthen consumer confidence in European legislation.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report 'towards better single market legislation' was intended to make a number of recommendations to promote more effective European legislation on this issue. The single market is central to the future of the EU project, always bearing growth, competitiveness, employment and social cohesion in mind as the pillars of tomorrow's EU.  That is precisely why I was unable to support this report. Although the text contains positive ideas, it is too une ambitious overall. I believe that the principle of subsidiarity cannot be seen as a justification for abandoning decisions to be taken at common level and that the response to today's problems must be based on increasing ambition and integration.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. Thank you to Christel Schaldemose for his excellent work on this report. Better regulation is one of the main goals. It is particularly significant in the area of the internal market and consumer protection so that cross-border deposits are facilitated, in particular for SMEs and consumers.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this document because I believe that it presents several critical issues and that, ultimately, it does not contribute positively to finding solutions for greater integration of the single market. In particular, I would like to draw attention to the text's view that any kind of market regulation is merely a bureaucratic burden rather than a necessary instrument for its better functioning.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proper functioning of the single market is one of the vital aspects of the future of the European Union and still has an important aspect of the life of the Union: each EU institution is jointly responsible for improving its legislation. Improving regulation does not mean eliminating it, nor does it mean making it less ambitious from the point of view of environmental protection, consumer protection, safety, quality or social legislation. Instead, it means the elimination of unnecessary rules, bureaucracy and negative effects, as well as the achievement of strategic objectives and the creation of a harmonious regulatory environment to support employment and businesses in Europe.  We must understand that achieving a rationally regulated single market does not impose excessive burdens or affect production, innovation and trade. It is in this context that shared responsibility can lead to common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market capable of contributing to sustainable and long-term growth in Europe and, therefore, to the prosperity of citizens. The European Parliament is morally obliged not to delegate this responsibility to other institutional entities.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen the internal single market. The rapporteur tells us in the text of his desire to strengthen the governance of the single market as well as the powers of the European Commission. To achieve this, it calls for the aggressive implementation of market integration tools such as EURES, the European network of public services and employment, which aims to promote the mobility of workers within the Union. We are highly critical of this initiative, which aims to give the European Commission additional prerogatives at the expense of the sovereignty of our nations. The European Union wants to close the competitiveness gaps and macroeconomic divergences that result from the single market, by promoting budgetary transfers and geographical mobility of employees, which we formally dispute. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Single Market is a fundamental tool in creating jobs in the European Union and encouraging economic growth. The report on improving single market regulation provides the main directions for strengthening the governance of the Single Market and regulating the Single Market. Improving the regulation of the single market aims to create a clear, coherent and competitive regulatory framework to support innovation, production and trade and boost the economic growth of the European Union. This requires a concerted effort, a joint responsibility of the European institutions to transpose the principle of subsidiarity. The Single Market must be a priority for the European institutions, and good regulation is needed, policy-making based on the principle of subsidiarity. I was in favour of this report because I believe that boosting competitiveness, innovation, reducing unemployment and job creation at Union level cannot be achieved without coherent, harmonised and comprehensive legislation.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The problem with reports like this, which was approved in the Committee on the Internal Market, is that, in addition to indications that we can fully endorse, they contain whole paragraphs that we cannot politically approve. Remember that the internal market and consumer protection are not exclusive competences of the European institutions, but shared with national parliaments. That is why a central issue is respect for the principle of subsidiarity. In our opinion, the Van Bossuyt report could have defended the prerogatives of the Member States more. Not only is this not the case, but in some passages the Member States are accused of incorrect or belated application of the rules of the single market. In addition, the report contains statements which, in our opinion, speak excessively of an internal market as a potential driver of the economy. The facts now show that this is not entirely true, but on the contrary rules on the internal market create problems for our production system. Think – just this example – of the problems with the transposition of the Services Directive (so-called Bolkestein Directive) into Italy. Of course, voting against this report would be excessive. The text also contains steps that can still be shared. Abstention vote.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the proper functioning of the European Union is the key to a promising future. A big step towards this future is the economic stabilisation of Europe, also achieved by strengthening a strong single market. The cooperation of the Member States of the European Union is indispensable for this. The transparency of the Member States and the proper transmission of information between them will form the basis of a united, strong, informed and ready Europe for everything. I therefore agree with the changes to the rules of the single market, because with the evolution of the European Union it is necessary that European regulations also need to be improved and adapted to the needs of the citizens of the Union. The new regulations are making changes, among other things, to services, so that the European Union can help Member States in the employment and empowerment of businesses. These changes will lead to better communication and networking, an effective one and politically. Thus, optimal collaboration will lead to positive results in terms of the internal market, consumers and, ultimately, the strengthening of a single market.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report today because it describes a single European market that totally ignores the social and environmental aspects.  In addition to the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital, we need above all a social market economy aimed at full employment and social progress, with a high level of protection and improvement of the quality of the environment.  This report forgets that without regard to the social aspect of the Union, it is not possible to achieve a real improvement in the living and working conditions of European citizens. The well-being of the European citizen in the broadest sense must not, in any way, be limited by the pursuit of the objective of the single market, but must be fully achieved in it. The single market must become the end and a means of the Union in order to achieve the highest degree of integration, which means an improvement in the living conditions of the citizen. I think it is essential to emphasise the need for a stronger employment and social dimension in EU governance and to outline new strategies to involve employers' and workers' representatives more closely in setting the Union's priorities.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. This is an own-initiative report setting out Parliament’s views on the implementation of measures relating to the single market. The report contained some positive provisions such as a call for the inclusion of worker and consumer rights in addition to considering environmental and socio-economic considerations. However, it did not call for any new measures, but for the effective use of existing instruments, a code word for further single market integration, thereby stripping Member States of their governmental autonomy.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Single Market is one of the most important components of our Community, the key to economic growth and job creation, and should be regularly improved and updated in line with the continuously changing economic conditions. I particularly welcome more flexible rules for SMEs and the greater focus on consumers which recognises their importance to our economy. The report seeks improvements to the Single Market and I voted in favour of it.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report supports a number of general principles for improving single market legislation. The text as it appears as a result of the amendments tabled in committee is acceptable. Among these, the part that underlines the importance of supporting sustainable socio-economic growth to protect consumers and workers is particularly positive. However, the text is not acceptable on the aspects relating to the results produced so far by instruments such as ADR and ODR. I have therefore chosen to abstain from voting on the report.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I believe any new EU legislation needs to be based on thorough impact assessments and to be as technology-neutral and future-proof as possible. We also need consultation processes to be open, inclusive and accessible to SMEs and start-ups in order to make sure there are not unintended consequences of our decision. If we can have better regulation and not over-regulation, I have no doubt growth and jobs will return to Europe. I thank the rapporteur for all her work supporting this goal.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and consider that improving legislation on the single market is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept that should frame the way in which the European Union seeks to improve legislation on the single market.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on which we voted on, on improving legislation on the single market, concerns issues of improving the functioning of the Union but also economic sectors and is therefore particularly important.  However, as there are not enough answers to questions of evaluation of proposals, the possibilities of the Member States and the possibility of checking the effectiveness of the proposed policies, I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it represents a further step towards the establishment of a single market in Europe. I am of the opinion that this process can lead to quality legislation that is fully at the service of citizens. Indeed, a single European market can only help to stimulate competitiveness, job creation and the growth and development of individual Member States and their businesses while ensuring a high level of consumer protection.  I am in favour of a more competitive and influential Europe at world level and I am of the opinion that this report, by promoting our economy, is heading in the right direction towards the long-term growth of Europe and therefore towards the prosperity of its citizens.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The continuous improvement of Single Market regulation must be shared amongst each institution of the Union. Measures that are created should be easily applied and efficient with a view to achieving the agreed policy aims. Effective legislation cannot be achieved by one step, it must be created from an effective functioning of the whole policy cycle. The removal of all regulation is not necessary for the improvement of Single Market regulation; however a competitive regulatory environment must be created which keeps employment and enterprises within Europe.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving single market regulation should be a priority as good legislation contributes to the good of citizens, boosting competitiveness, job creation and growth, while ensuring a high level of consumer protection and stimulating the European economy. I support the Van Bossuyt Report because it considers that it establishes a set of guidelines of the utmost importance for the proper functioning of the market either through the inclusion of specific indicators to measure the success of legislation not only in the initial impact assessment, but throughout the policy-making cycle, either through the requirement of transparency and accessibility to information. I stress the need to focus on digital platforms to improve the functioning of the Single Market, such as one-stop shops and consumer service portals and networks. The responsibility for improving regulation cannot only be with the institutions in Brussels, but shared with Member States, national parliaments and other local bodies, within a framework of efficiency and respect for subsidiarity.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report as we believe that the best way to improve single market regulation is to deregulate. UKIP are particularly concerned by aspects of the report that criticise Member States’ lack of transposition of single market legislation. The report further calls on the Commission to launch infringement proceedings against these Member States, which UKIP are vehemently opposed to.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The completion of the single market is now a top priority. The challenges we face are increasingly looming and have a major impact on the internal market: unemployment, the weakening of the entrepreneurial fabric and competitiveness and increasing immigration. The current context therefore requires us to take a more pragmatic and incisive approach. The Juncker Commission has already taken important action in a short time. We must continue in this direction and in a timely manner. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The forthcoming internal market strategy should be aimed at improving single market regulation through an effort to learn from the experiences of the past in the areas of free movement of goods and services, the digital single market, professional qualifications and public procurement. We all know that digital innovation is outpacing politics, and entrepreneurs are driving the digital agenda.  In this situation it is of key importance to provide rules that are digital by default and this report advocates for that. Through a ‘digital by default’ section, the Commission is seeking to gain a deep understanding of user needs. I agree with the statement that small businesses often do not have the time or resources to participate in regular consultations and their participation needs to be facilitated. Through my vote I call upon the Commission to find user-friendly and innovative ways to reach out to SMEs and start-ups.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report states that the development of the Single Market should not clash with fundamental rights, while stressing the need for dialogue with organised civil society and protecting the social, environmental and security and security standards contained in European regulation. However, it continues to interpret the deepening of the Single Market as a priority over the 'overregulation' and 'barriers' that would leave the European economy, ignoring those of us who believe that improving the living conditions of Europeans must prioritise the upward harmonisation of social legislation and the democratisation of the institutions governing the Single Market. That's why I abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The revival of economic growth and employment in the Member States depends on the proper functioning of the single market, which creates a uniform regulatory framework within the EU for economic integration between states.  Given that today, as and more than 20 years ago, this instrument is necessary to contribute to the competitiveness of businesses and the labour market, as well as to consumer protection, I welcomed the European Parliament's resolution, in order to remove the obstacles that still prevent the full implementation of European legislation in the Member States and better single market legislation.  In particular, with my vote, I wanted to support the European Parliament's call for the consultation process to be open, transparent and to include the various stakeholders, and for consumers and businesses to be consciously involved in the legislative process through the use of assistance services, such as SOLVIT, ADR and ODR, which are still little known. In this regard, I agree with the proposal to remedy the overlaps between the various assistance services promoted by the EU and, if necessary, to replace them with a one-stop shop of clear understanding for consumers, avoiding the unnecessary and costly bureaucracies that have so far hindered quality legislation in the single market.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report presents issues important for the preparation of high-quality legislation in order to better meet the objectives of the Single Market. It complements the work undertaken in the JURI Committee on better regulation, as well as the EMPL report on the conditions for companies to operate and create jobs, prepared by the ECR rapporteur, which adopted the principles of better regulation for the work of the Committee on Employment.  The report shall support a number of political priorities of the ECR, including respect for the principle of subsidiarity; the value of impact assessments and consultations; the need for an effective enforcement and monitoring system. These different areas must work in conjunction so that the single market can operate effectively and ensure a level playing field for all.  That being said, I voted in favour.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this report from my colleague Anneleen Van Bossuyt and its strong support for improving competitiveness in the EU, and calls for scrapping unnecessary laws, which strongly ties in with the red-tape-cutting agenda in the UK. Importantly, as well, this report references targets for burden reduction and improved enforcement of EU laws: with serious improvements in these areas we can help ensure a level-playing field for all companies and that the single market works better for business.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving single market lawmaking is a priority for the EU institutions, because better regulation is always in the interests of citizens. On the other hand, this contributes to boosting competitiveness, job creation, economic growth and the development of SMEs, while ensuring a high level of consumer protection. In addition, the private sector can and must be much more involved in sectors such as agriculture, education, green technologies, research and innovation, health services and property rights, sectors that remain largely untapped.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objective of the report on "Towards better single market legislation" was to make a number of recommendations to improve and make more efficient legislation concerning the internal market, so as to ensure the correct and more effective implementation of its rules. The Union should provide the ideal regulatory conditions to facilitate the activities of businesses and our citizens and take full advantage of all the opportunities presented by the ongoing digital transformation: essential elements to stimulate growth and the creation of new jobs in Europe in the twenty-first century. Although some parts of the report are heading in the right direction, I cannot support a text that interprets the principle of 'better lawmaking' and the principle of subsidiarity as legislative instruments that limit legislative actions and measures by the European Union as much as possible. In fact, the creation of a more competitive and simple regulatory environment on the single market will necessarily have to take into account the added value of EU rules that protect social and environmental rights and ensure full consumer protection. I believe that the text presented today is far below the expectations and objectives that were desirable; For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report makes recommendations to improve internal market regulation to make it more effective. The report stresses the importance of regulatory transposition and implementation, it is essential that the single market promotes growth by supporting production, innovation and trade. The aim is to make the regulation of the single market and its political cycle less complex and effective. Considering that clear and effective regulation is a positive signal for European business development and investment, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to improve the regulation of the single market in order to make it less complex and more efficient and thus avoid an even longer legislative process. As this is in the interests of SMEs and consumers and takes into account existing tools in the single market, such as the consultation process, I supported this report.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – It should come as no surprise that I strongly approve this parliamentary resolution. I always grasp the opportunity to improve Single Market legislation. This resolution stresses the importance of delivering a competitive regulatory environment in order to ensure the competitiveness of the EU. In this regard, the resolution focuses on every step of the policy process. Concerning impact assessments, it stresses the importance of their effectiveness and importance as a policy tool, followed by the necessity of transparency and inclusiveness during the consultation process. The whole process would of course, be useless if there were no actual full implementation of the Single Market legislation. Therefore, the resolution reminds the Commission of the importance of regularly executing its monitoring function. It hereby reminds us of the Commission’s complementary role as a problem-solver.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Intra-European trade accounts for two-thirds of eu trade. It is therefore necessary to promote its operation, by reducing the various administrative constraints.  The measures advocated in this legislation should therefore reduce the burden of bureaucracy, and simplify administrative procedures. This is an important step that could contribute to the growth of the Union.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued achievements of the single market and the exploitation of the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market require a strong commitment from the actors concerned. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean removing all the rules, but creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps employment and business in Europe.  I voted in favour of Mrs Van Bossuyt's report, because improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market.  I believe that better legislation is not guaranteed by a single measure in the procedure, it is done through effective and effective work throughout the political cycle. It is therefore of the utmost importance for me to transpose and implement the rules of the single market. A single market that does not place too much of a burden on production, innovation and trade is a structure that will stimulate growth in Europe. In this context, shared responsibility will lead to the realisation of common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market will be created that will contribute to Europe's development.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report acknowledges the Council's lack of transparency, the lack of respect for subsidiarity and proportionality, the lack of consultation with civil society, the indigence of impact assessments and excessive regulation for SMEs.  On the other hand, the objectives of this report are to strengthen and improve the internal single market, which I am up against. I also oppose increasing the Commission's powers at the expense of states, strengthening the governance of the single market, aggressively implementing market integration tools (e.g. EURES) and defending the single market as a single solution to the problems of the European Union. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I agree with some of the key issues it highlights. We need better and better rules if we want our commercial sectors to grow and be able to support the creation of new businesses, which are often major drivers of innovation. Given the principle of subsidiarity, I believe that the report does not seek to interfere with our work in the JURI Committee.   The results of impact assessments, before taking hasty steps on policy and overregulation, as well as the focus on an effective implementation mechanism, are crucial issues. Not only will they contribute to a more fruitful economic environment across the EU, but they will also achieve levelling the playing field.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued achievements of the single market and the exploitation of the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market require a strong commitment from the actors concerned. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean removing all the rules, but creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps employment and business in Europe.  I voted in favour of Mrs Van Bossuyt's report, I believe, because improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market.  I believe that better legislation is not guaranteed by a single measure in the procedure, it is done through effective and effective work throughout the political cycle. It is therefore of the utmost importance for me to transpose and implement the rules of the single market. A single market that does not place too much of a burden on production, innovation and trade is a structure that will stimulate growth in Europe. In this context, shared responsibility will lead to the realisation of common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market will be created that will contribute to Europe's development.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because its focus is on deregulation rather than more effective regulation. It does not take social and environmental indicators into account and does not put enough emphasis on workers’ rights. I voted for paragraph 29 of the original text which calls for making public consultations available in all official languages. Welsh is a co-official language rather than a full official language, but if public consultations are to be meaningful they need to use the languages people speak. In Wales this would include Welsh.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The improvement of single market regulation is a shared responsibility for each of the institutions of the European Union and consists of complying with the guiding principle of subsidiarity when deciding on the action to be taken, deciding on how best to act, if regulatory needs to be adopted and, finally, of ensuring that measures and obligations are implemented in an effective manner in order to achieve the agreed strategic objectives. Improving single market regulation is not synonymous with eliminating all regulation, but rather offers a regulatory environment that is conducive to employment and business in Europe. I voted for it.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: strengthening and perfecting the internal single market are the objectives of the report, which is enough to position our vote.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The deepening of the EU Single Market has encouraged the dismantling of sovereign regulation instruments for economies at the disposal of Member States. Barriers to the movement of goods, services and capital have been removed, imposing the privatisation and liberalisation of strategic sectors and public services. Harmonisation of legislation for the large economic and financial groups has intensified.
