The report argues for the need to "improve" single market regulation, arguing with the supposed "excess" and "complexity" of existing regulation. But more than quantity, what is the quality, meaning and objectives of this "regulation" is what it means.  The report states that "improving" and "easing" regulation could provide a regulatory environment that is conducive to employment and businesses. Again: "improvement" and "relief" in favor of whom? We know what they're talking about. For the apostles of the single market, this "improvement" is synonymous with regulations that essentially serve to protect the economic interests of large enterprises, deregulating workers and social rights and reducing the levels of environmental protection, safety and consumer protection. That is, deregulate in the name of the market and the increase in profits and wealth for the major powers and large economic groups.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving single market legislation means creating a competitive regulatory environment that supports jobs and businesses in Europe. An effective single market is a structure that stimulates growth in Europe. I voted in favour of better legislation on the single market because it takes into account very important elements, such as respect for the principle of subsidiarity, the value of impact assessments and consultation and, above all, the need for effective implementation and monitoring.  In order to contribute to the results of the single market and to make full use of the opportunities offered by the digital single market, I believe it is necessary and I hope for a firm and direct commitment on the part of all the actors concerned. I am convinced that shared accountability and transparency, together with better single market legislation, can lead to greater prosperity for the citizens of the EU Member States.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Protection of workers, sustainability and the role of SMEs are included and I am happy with the final result. No new measures are called for, no new powers for the Commission. I voted in favour.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because, despite some positive points, the prerogatives of the Member States could be better defended.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on improving legislation on the single market. The single market does not consider it to be in the interests of European citizens, but it has contributed greatly to the current economic crisis as well as to the stripping of certain states by valuable trained workers who could have contributed to the recovery of their economy.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it supports our Prime Minister’s aim to reduce EU bureaucracy and improve the enforcement of EU law.  It also aims to provide a level playing-field for all companies which trade in the Single Market.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report which prescribes a number of suggestions to make regulation in the area of the single market more effective and efficient, emphasising the importance of a functioning single market for growth and job creation in the Union.  References to consumer, social and environmental objectives are set as criteria to guide fitness checks, impact assessments and evaluation processes of current and future EU legislation. However, we need to re-balance further the accent on slimmer EU legislation and Members States’ prerogatives with due consideration of the advantage of harmonised and solid EU rules on social, workers’, consumer and environmental standards. ‘Subsidiarity’ cannot be interpreted as diminishing as much as possible EU regulatory actions; ‘better regulation’ cannot be identified as a way to limit as much as possible EU regulatory powers. Finally, I do not support the reference to gold-plating, as it would diminish social, workers’ and consumer standards.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued achievements of the single market and the exploitation of the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market require a strong commitment from the actors concerned. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean removing all the rules, but creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps employment and business in Europe.  I voted in favour of Mrs Van Bossuyt's report, and I believe that improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market.  I believe that better legislation is not guaranteed by a single measure in the procedure, it is done through effective and effective work throughout the political cycle. It is therefore of the utmost importance for me to transpose and implement the rules of the single market. A single market that does not place too much of a burden on production, innovation and trade is a structure that will stimulate growth in Europe. In this context, shared responsibility will lead to the realisation of common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market will be created that will contribute to Europe's development.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued achievements of the single market and the exploitation of the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market require a strong commitment from the actors concerned. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean removing all the rules, but creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps employment and business in Europe.  I voted in favour of Mrs Van Bossuyt's report, and I believe that improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market.  I believe that better legislation is not guaranteed by a single measure in the procedure, it is done through effective and effective work throughout the political cycle. It is therefore of the utmost importance for me to transpose and implement the rules of the single market. A single market that does not place too much of a burden on production, innovation and trade is a structure that will stimulate growth in Europe. In this context, shared responsibility will lead to the realisation of common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market will be created that will contribute to Europe's development.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report. I am convinced that the European Parliament and the other EU institutions must work to improve the rules on the single market. There is no doubt about the benefits that the single market has brought and can continue to bring, so we must be able to maximize its benefits, for example with regard to the possibilities offered by the digital single market. Europe needs a competitive regulatory environment that supports employment and business in the EU, a single market that does not overload or frustrate production, innovation and trade.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted ‘Yes’ to this report on an improved single market. The single market is one of the pillars of the European Union and its regulations influence the whole economy of Europe. I agree with the report, which asks for the removal of unnecessary regulations and needless or obsolete bureaucracy. In these times of fragile economic recovery we must do all we can to support economic growth and to provide jobs and opportunities to our citizens; removing" red tape" is a cheap and easy way to make the single market more competitive and business-friendly, as well as more consumer friendly. This will give natural incentives for entrepreneurship, innovation and could also boost production and consumption.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on 'Towards better regulation for the Internal Market'. The EU's internal market is the European instrument that affects all citizens, our families in Europe on a daily basis. That is why it is good and important to ensure greater efficiency here. I would like to express my thanks to my ECR colleague Daniel Dalton for his valuable work on this dossier!

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. •u2012 Arbitrator regulatory urge is usually not a good solution. Only an internal market, in which neither over-regulated nor hindered is created, creates new incentives and innovations. Impact assessments are an important tool for avoiding unnecessary over-regulation.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on strengthening the internal single market.  Some of the criticisms of the report are relevant, notably on the insufficient application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the lack of transparency of the Council, or the excessive and excessively burdensome regulations borne by SMEs. Nevertheless, the report does not share our findings on the internal single market: we reject, among other things, the strengthening of the Commission's powers, the strengthening of the governance of the single market or the aggressive implementation of market integration tools.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report has some positive elements in terms of the implementation of the single market - especially in terms of transparency, the role of national parliaments or market surveillance, which we voted for - it does not significantly correct the profile of the single market dominated by the commodisation of any socio-product relationship, without redistribution or compensatory elements. The report does not make it possible to substantially correct the structural inequalities of the European Union, which are reinforced by the mechanisms of the single market. That's why we voted against it.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because the single market is the most important pillar of the European Union, and improving its regulation is the joint responsibility of the EU institutions. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean eliminating all regulations, but ensuring a competitive regulatory framework that supports employment and businesses in Europe. This improvement process should aim at simplicity, transparency, coherence and respect for fundamental rights. Boosting economic growth in Europe will be the result of a single market that does not overload and hinder production, innovation and trade. It is important that national institutions, in particular parliaments, are also actively involved in consultation processes.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which contained several controversial elements and which was missing references to consumer, social and environmental objectives as criteria to guide fitness checks, impact assessments and evaluation processes of current and future EU legislation.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it was necessary to optimise the regulation of the internal market in order to increase its efficiency. An efficient single market is a growth-promoting market that benefits SMEs and European consumers. However, it is essential that these measures to make improvements in legislation be accompanied, at the same time, by measures aimed at properly transposing and implementing single market standards.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Any new legislation needs to be based on thorough impact assessments and to be as technology-neutral and future-proof as possible to ensure better regulation. Consultation processes need to be open, transparent, inclusive and accessible to SMEs and start-ups.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued achievements of the single market and the exploitation of the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market require a strong commitment from the actors concerned. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean removing all the rules, but creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps employment and business in Europe.  I voted in favour of Mrs Van Bossuyt's report, and I believe that improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market.  I believe that better legislation is not guaranteed by a single measure in the procedure, it is done through effective and effective work throughout the political cycle. It is therefore of the utmost importance for me to transpose and implement the rules of the single market. A single market that does not place too much of a burden on production, innovation and trade is a structure that will stimulate growth in Europe. In this context, shared responsibility will lead to the realisation of common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market will be created that will contribute to Europe's development.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although the report contains several positive references (protection of workers and better use of existing European structures) however a number of amendments tabled by our group to improve the text were rejected. We have therefore abstained.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is essential to the continued development of the single market that we regularly review the implementation of regulations that nurtures the free movement of goods and the free movement of services, enhances competitiveness, promotes a business- and consumer-friendly environment based on transparent, simple, and consistent rules offering legal certainty and clarity.  While this report focuses less on individually assessing these factors of single market legislation and more on better legislation in a larger and more general sense, I did vote in favour of this report as it calls on the Commission to improve its understanding of factors which influence policy implementation, and asks that new legislation be based on thorough impact assessments and to be as technology-neutral and future-proof as possible to ensure better regulation.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution due to its reassurance that improving the single market is a responsibility to be shared among all EU institutions whilst emphasising the need for an effective and efficient policy cycle to produce good legislation.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued achievements of the single market and the exploitation of the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market require a strong commitment from the actors concerned. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean removing all the rules, but creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps employment and business in Europe.  I voted in favour of Mrs Van Bossuyt's report, because improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market.  Better legislation is not guaranteed by a single measure during the procedure, it is done by effective and effective work throughout the political cycle. It is therefore of the utmost importance for me to transpose and implement the rules of the single market. A single market that does not place too much of a burden on production, innovation and trade is a structure that will stimulate growth in Europe. In this context, shared responsibility will lead to the realisation of common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market will be created that will contribute to Europe's development.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I support the report on improved regulation of the Single Market, as it is a good basis for achieving a holistic and integrated approach that does not unnecessarily burden the manufacturing sector, innovation or trade, but contributes to the creation of a sustainable market as a prerequisite for the long-term economic development of the EU and the prosperity of its citizens. Building a single market is at the heart of the European project and continues to be a means of boosting economic growth and job creation in the EU. To increase the achievements of the European single market and the digital single market, a strong commitment and the shared responsibility of each of the European institutions to open and transparent regulation is needed, taking into account the positions of all stakeholders at European and national level.  A step of paramount importance for improving single market regulation is the elimination of unnecessary regulation, red tape and their negative consequences. Simplifying access to the single market and using the digital revolution are key factors in achieving a competitive regulatory environment that supports employment and business in Europe.  In addition, as we work towards the creation of technologically neutral and forward-looking market regulation, we must also focus our efforts on increasing awareness of existing single market services aimed at business and citizens, such as SOLVIT, ADR and ODR.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report has some controversial issues. Better regulation is not a way to limit as much as possible EU regulatory powers, and subsidiarity cannot be interpreted as diminishing as much as possible EU regulatory actions. I voted against this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the topic Towards Better Regulation of the Single Market (2015/2089(INI)), as a number of recommendations are made regarding mechanisms to improve internal market regulation, such as implementation, oversight, problem solving and more. Europe needs a strong internal market, unencumbered by unnecessary regulations and barriers.  Improving single market regulation does not mean abolishing all regulations or reducing the level of ambition of regulations, but eliminating unnecessary regulations, red tape and negative impacts while achieving a competitive regulatory environment that encourages employment and entrepreneurship in Europe. There is a great responsibility on this in all European institutions. It is imperative a single market that does not burden or threaten production, innovation and trade too much and enables jobs and growth.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Our project is diametrically opposed to theirs. We reject the strengthening of the Commission's powers, the introduction of Member States (considered in the text as 'partners'), the strengthening of the governance of the single market, the aggressive implementation of market integration tools (e.g. EURES), the pinnacle of the single market, a unique solution to the problems of the European Union. The Europe of Nations is the only credible alternative to resolving the regretted imbalances. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report as we believe that the best way to improve single market regulation is to deregulate. UKIP are particularly concerned by aspects of the report that criticise Member States’ lack of transposition of single market legislation. The report further calls on the Commission to launch infringement proceedings against these Member States, which UKIP are vehemently opposed to.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Anneleen Van Bossuyt's report on improved regulation of the single market. The report explores several possibilities for making changes to internal market regulation so that SMEs and consumers can benefit more. The report argues that good legislation requires effective work throughout the political cycle, and in particular stresses the importance of regulatory transposition and implementation. I support this legislative proposal based on the evidence that a single market that supports production, innovation and trade also promotes growth. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to improve the means of regulating the single market. The single market is an essential instrument for boosting growth and jobs: improving the regulation of the single market should be both a priority and a shared responsibility of the EU institutions. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued achievements of the single market and the exploitation of the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market require a strong commitment from the actors concerned. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean removing all the rules, but creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps employment and business in Europe.  I voted in favour of Mrs Van Bossuyt's report, because improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market.  I believe that better legislation is not guaranteed by a single measure in the procedure, it is done through effective and effective work throughout the political cycle. It is therefore of the utmost importance for me to transpose and implement the rules of the single market. A single market that does not place too much of a burden on production, innovation and trade is a structure that will stimulate growth in Europe. In this context, shared responsibility will lead to the realisation of common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market will be created that will contribute to Europe's development.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 In some parts of the report, it is logical, coherent and eligible, but it is not in the interests of my country as a whole because it seeks to force member states to unify the market for services to an exaggerated extent. I agree that legislation should benefit citizens, contribute to improving competitiveness, creating jobs, stimulating sustainable growth and the development of SMEs, but the report does not ensure equal opportunities in the countries that joined later

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is the biggest player on the global trading scene because we are the world’s largest single market with transparent rules and regulations. In fact, the Single Market has brought tremendous benefits for European citizen and businesses but it has not always operated smoothly. The full potential of free movement of goods, services and capital has been unexploited due to missing legislation and lack of enforcement. Therefore, I believe that we should work to implement Single Market regulation, regulation that is based on the principle of subsidiarity and aims before all to be effective and efficient. This necessarily means that we should create a competitive regulatory environment which in practice will facilitate but not frustrate production, innovation and commerce. In a long-term perspective, a competitive regulatory environment will bring economic growth to the EU and prosperity to its citizens

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I was not able to participate in the votes of the report "Towards improved regulation of the single market" as I was called to participate in the Conference of Presidents which took place during the votes. However, I would like to take advantage of this explanation of vote to express my opposition to this report. I reject the strengthening of the Commission's powers advocated in this text, the implementation of the Member States regarded in the text as 'partners', the strengthening of the governance of the single market, the aggressive implementation of market integration tools and the introduction of the single market, presented as a single solution to the problems of the European Union. The Europe of Nations is the only credible alternative to resolving the regretted imbalances.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it seeks to strengthen the single market, to which I am hostile. Moreover, he wants to strengthen the powers of the Commission, even though he acknowledges that it often acts with a certain arrogance.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I spoke out against this text.  Indeed, the two guidelines that structure it are the strengthening and development of the internal market.  However, for once, the rapporteur has the courage to make a stern statement on the effectiveness of the single market. It deplores, among other things, the Lack of Transparency of the Council, the lack of respect for the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the lack of consultation in civil society, the overwhelming regulations to be respected for SMEs...  On the other hand, I cannot agree with the general draft implemented which contains the strengthening of the Commission's powers, the implementation of the Member States, the strengthening of the governance of the single market, the aggressive implementation of market integration tools... I continue to defend the Europe of Nations as the only credible alternative.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report states that the development of the Single Market should not clash with fundamental rights, while stressing the need for dialogue with organised civil society and protecting the social, environmental and security and security standards contained in European regulation. However, it continues to interpret the deepening of the Single Market as a priority over the 'overregulation' and 'barriers' that would leave the European economy, ignoring those of us who believe that improving the living conditions of Europeans must prioritise the upward harmonisation of social legislation and the democratisation of the institutions governing the Single Market. That's why I abstained.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The report calls on the Commission to 'better regulate'. The report calls for the creation of commissions to examine how to better regulate. The problem is overregulation, and it is ridiculous when Members who vote in favor of new and new nonsensical regulations on a daily basis also vote in favor of creating new committees to examine how to cut red tape.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Better regulation of the single market is a shared responsibility of all EU institutions. Good legislation is not a guarantee that the single market will operate efficiently, and it is necessary to actively work on the efficient and effective operation of the market. In order to enhance the single market and the Digital Single Market, it is important to actively integrate all the factors that create it. I supported the report because better regulation of the single market is key to boosting competitiveness and creating new jobs.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Meeting the objectives of the Single European Market requires the adoption of clear and comprehensible regulations and directives, which must be flexibly transposed into the internal rules of the Member States and easily accessible to all. The aim of improving the adjustment is not to overregulation and unnecessary regulation, but to develop a competitive regulatory policy aimed at increasing employment and facilitating entrepreneurship in the Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained when voting on the report on better single market legislation because it is not complete.  Furthermore, I would point out that the single market has greatly strengthened the large enterprises and industries of the North, which have not invested their economic surpluses and profits in the countries of the European South, in order to develop and reduce their deficits and public debts.  Moreover, wealth from the single market has not been fairly distributed to all EU member states, resulting in countries such as Greece continuing to experience the austerity policies imposed on them by the troika. Legislation on the single market should therefore take more drastic measures to boost employment, starting with the countries of the South.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  This report recognises the many institutional dysfunctions of the European Union: non-application of the principle of subsidiarity, lack of consultation with civil society, etc. However, this project is unacceptable in that it calls for a strengthening of the powers of the European Commission and the strengthening of the single market, the excesses of which are proven to be a result of its excesses.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on better single market legislation. Improving the single market is one of the priorities and responsibilities of the Union institutions with a view to improving the regulation of the single market in the interests of SMEs and consumers. In order to contribute to the results of the single market and to make full use of the opportunities offered by the single market, a firm commitment on the part of all Member States is essential.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is our responsibility in the European Parliament to do everything possible to promote the growth of the sector, especially SMEs. In this way, we must not lose sight of consumer protection; it is vital that citizens are able to contact their government, because that is the way to strengthen the EU. I support this resolution because it prepares our economy for the future, especially in view of the challenges of e-commerce and online services.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We must work to improve the rules on the single market. That's the way to make this concept and its application more and more a reality. We must foster the achievements of the single market and take advantage of the possibilities offered by the digital single market. We want a strong and dynamic single market that contributes to Europe's long-term growth and thus to the prosperity of all the people living in Europe.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The benefits of the single market are undeniable and should therefore be protected and strengthened through European legislation. It is therefore the joint responsibility of all of us who are part of the legislative process, the constant effort to improve it. All the institutions of the Union can, through proper and effective cooperation, improve these policies while also applying the principle of subsidiarity. This is combined with an appropriate check that the measures imposed are being implemented by the Member States. Secondary rules of law are also part of the legislation, which are just as important a part of the legislation and should not be left out of the way by participants. The aim should be to achieve a competitive regulatory environment within the EU, at the same time sharing the needs of businesses and promoting employment, production and innovation. With a developed internal single market, we will be able to ensure long-term growth in Europe and the well-being of our citizens.  However, I am voting against this resolution because I believe that there needs to be a greater balance between this weak legislation and the various privileges enjoyed by the Member States, while taking into account the important rules for the protection of workers, consumers and the environment.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve the European single market through proposals on transparency, the role of national parliaments and the European Parliament. While some of these proposals may appear positive, they are nevertheless aimed at strengthening the single market and removing any regulation, arguing that "a single market that does not overload or hinder production, innovation or trade is a tool that will bring back jobs and growth that would previously have been generated elsewhere in Europe". This catechism has already proved its dangerousness. I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of the report is to improve and strengthen the internal market. Some findings are interesting, such as lack of subsidiarity, lack of civil society consultation and regulations that are too cumbersome for SMEs. This report promotes European integration with a particularly derisory vocabulary towards states - considered "partners" - it aims to strengthen the Commission at the same time; which I object to. As a result, I voted against this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have put forward my vote in favour of the report "For better regulation of the Single Market". Improving single market regulation should be a priority and shared responsibility of the EU institutions. Good legislation contributes to the good of citizens and should contribute to boosting competitiveness, job creation and growth, as well as the progress of SMEs, while ensuring a high level of consumer protection, enabling the European economy to stimulate rather than hindering it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this resolution as it emphasises the need for a shared responsibility in improving regulation in our single market and helps to reduce the burden on our enterprises, producers and innovators.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The single market is 508 million consumers and a huge potential market for businesses. This pillar of European integration is the basis of our prosperity and influence in the world. We have a highly skilled workforce, which makes Europe competitive. But to remain so it must continue to innovate. Europe alone is the solution to the sometimes frightening challenges that too often mislead us into doubt and uncertainty. But a successful Europe is a Europe that innovates, works in transparency, applies the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality, which tends to be closest to the needs and expectations of citizens. It is also a Europe that agrees to question itself in order to create and maintain favourable conditions for our companies. Impact assessments will help to better identify truly effective, modern legislation that leads to concrete results.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The present report clearly highlights the burning problems of the single market. I appreciate the work of the rapporteur, because the report has identified shortcomings with the right concepts. The Single Market is widely regarded as the European Union's greatest achievement. To become a reality, we had to go a long and difficult journey. We have adopted hundreds of directives to remove technical, regulatory, legal and cultural barriers. It is our duty for our work to keep moving forward so that the single market continues to function. The speed of digital innovation is frustrating, so we are not able to respond properly and in a timely manner. Although this is difficult, we must find solutions that allow us to keep up with the times. Single market rules must go hand in hand with technical and digital progress. I particularly highlight the fact that the rapporteur did not mention this issue in the report in question. I also consider it important to simplify legislation, which will have a positive impact, especially on small and medium-sized enterprises, which represent the skeleton of the entire European economy. Let us not forget that they are extremely important for the future of the Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support a number of suggestions in the report seeking to make regulation in the area of the single market more effective and efficient emphasising the importance of a functioning single market for growth and job creation in the Union. Nevertheless, there are some paragraphs implying that ‘better regulation’ and reducing gold-plating should be used as an excuse to limit as much as possible EU regulatory powers, and to get rid of the existing solid EU rules on social, workers’, consumer and environmental standards.  Therefore, I voted against the final resolution as a whole.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The single market is a key tool to boost economic growth and job creation in the Union. A single market that does not place too much of a burden on, or threatens, production, innovation and trade is an instrument that brings back to Europe jobs and growth that would have been achieved elsewhere.  However, the report of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection states that the single market for goods has been achieved but that services have not; more than 20 years after its formal creation, the single market is still fragmented, in particular because Member States have not fully transposed or correctly implemented EU legislation. It emphasises that improving single market regulation does not mean removing all rules, and not reducing the level of striving for regulation, but eliminating unnecessary regulation and negative effects. It points out that single market legislation must take into account the new opportunities offered by the digital revolution and be in line with the dimension of e-government. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The strengthening and perfecting of the internal single market is the objective of the report, which is enough to position our vote against the text.  However, some relatively harsh findings on the effectiveness of the single market are relevant, notably on the Lack of Transparency of the Council, the lack of respect for the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the lack of consultation with civil society, the destitution of the impact assessments provided or the excessive and excessive regulations that are too burdensome for SMEs to bear.  On the other hand, we reject proposals to strengthen the Commission's powers, the governance of the single market.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Single Market is a key tool for relaunching economic growth and job creation in the Union. Improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility for each of the EU institutions, which is to observe the guiding principle of subsidiarity when deciding on the action to be taken, deciding on how best to act if regulatory needs to be adopted and, finally, ensuring that measures and obligations are simple and effectively implemented in order to achieve agreed strategic objectives. Better regulation does not mean eliminating all regulation, but rather providing a regulatory framework conducive to employment and business in Europe. I advocate a Single Market that does not hinder production, innovation and trade and is a tool that stimulates growth in Europe. I endorse the rapporteur's view that good legislation cooperates for the good of citizens and should contribute to boosting competitiveness, job creation and growth, as well as the progress of SMEs, ensuring a high level of consumer protection, and stimulating the European economy.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs are in favour of having more streamlined EU legislation and Members States’ prerogatives, with due consideration given to the advantages of harmonised EU rules on social, workers’, consumer and environmental standards.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on improving legislation for the internal market, which is a major priority shared by all the European institutions. In the current economic context, this improvement is necessary in order to provide businesses in Europe with a regulatory environment that will strengthen their competitiveness and hire.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Van Bossuyt report entitled "Towards Better Regulation of the Single Market". This initiative report aims to examine ways to improve internal market regulation to make it more effective. It analyses how to make the entire policy cycle more effective in the interests of SMEs and consumers, taking into account existing single market tools (impact analysis, consultation process, implementation, monitoring and problem-solving, enforcement of legislation, ex post evaluation and review). The report points out that improving the regulation of the internal market is the shared responsibility of the EU institutions. It also points out that good legislation requires effective and efficient work throughout the political cycle, and stresses in particular the importance of regulatory transposition and implementation (which are an integral part of the means necessary to enjoy the benefits of the single market). It also points out that a single market that supports production, innovation and trade promotes growth.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. Improved regulation of the European single market is essential to enable business development and enhanced trade. However, this improvement can only be undertaken if all the European institutions concerned are on the path of regulatory reform. This text, which I voted for, examines the various possibilities for improvement available to the European Parliament as well as other institutions. It therefore participates in our commitment to simplify the regulation of the internal market.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving single market legislation is a shared responsibility of each of the Eu ropean Union institutions. Contributing to the results of the single market and making full use of the opportunities offered by the digital single market requires a strong commitment from all stakeholders.  I voted in favour of this report, which aims to examine how to make legislation more effective and less complex, optimising the so-called 'political cycle' in the interests of SMEs and consumers, taking into account existing single market instruments such as impact assessment and the process of consultation, implementation, monitoring and problem-solving.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The single market is one of the cornerstones of the Union and undoubtedly its most significant achievement. The uncertainties of recent years have shown that it is important to underline the importance of the Union and to point out the indispensable value to the people. The single market is the best example of this, providing member states with many unquestionable benefits for years. The legal framework of the internal market is available, it is our job to talk about efficiency and efficiency.  I therefore welcome the motion, which is in order to give a new impetus to exploiting as much as possible the potential of the internal market that has been created. I think it is important to emphasise the implementation and transposition of the regulation, its transposition – this stimulates production and the growth of innovation. Codifying the regulation into a simple, comprehensible form can be a major step forward, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this report regarding the single market regulation.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in support of the European Single Market, one of the most important instruments for generating growth and jobs at Member State level. In view of the numerous bottlenecks of Romanian firms providing services on the European market, situations created by the different laws of the Member States, I believe that it is for the benefit of service providers, but also of consumers, to have a homogeneous and clearly legislated single market in Europe. Although we have been talking about the single market for more than 20 years, it continues to be dysfunctional due to the different and sometimes malicious application of national or European legislation. That is why the report voted on today refers to legislating and improving the functioning of the single market by reducing unnecessary environmental regulations, consumer safety, etc. The decline in red tape also ensures a strong economic environment that supports innovation, production and trade, with the aim of creating new jobs and increasing European economic competitiveness.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the road to better regulation of the single market as one of the important aspects mentions an effective impact assessment. It is an important tool for formulating legislation in order to achieve the objectives of the single market without excessive burdens on businesses and individuals. In this respect, it is alarming that around 40% of the impact assessment proposals analysed by the Impact Assessment Committee between 2010 and 2014 were not of sufficient quality and were returned for recast. It would be worth adding to the impact assessment attached to the proposal on the impact assessment of the substantial changes adopted by the EP and the Council.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the report contains a number of points which I do find useful. A positive example of the report would be the support of small business owners. Furthermore, the REFIT programme should bring greater legislative efficiency and efficiency. European law should thus become simpler and therefore also incur less costs. The negative point of the report is the creation of bureaucracy, which I cannot support.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report on improving the regulation of the Single Market. In particular, the implementation of existing legislation needs to be properly assessed in order to improve the functioning of the single market. I believe that specific indicators should be used throughout the policy cycle to assess the success of the implementation of legislation.  REFIT proposals should be more transparent and targeted, quantified by assessing the potential benefits and cost savings of each proposal. Greater attention must be paid to consultation of stakeholders. Consultation should be a continuous process throughout the legislative cycle and should be applied as far as possible. It should be noted that the overall regulatory burden often faces obstacles for single market players, in particular SMEs. It is therefore essential to identify and remove barriers to entry in a timely manner and to ensure fair competition for all market participants.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report as we believe that the best way to improve single market regulation is to deregulate. UKIP are particularly concerned by aspects of the report that criticise Member States’ lack of transposition of single market legislation. The report further calls on the Commission to launch infringement proceedings against these Member States, which UKIP are vehemently opposed to.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas the undoubted need to improve single market legislation requires a joint commitment by all European institutions; that efforts must be made to ensure that legislation in this regard is clear, but above all effective and fully functioning in the long term; that the Member States and the European institutions must make a greater effort to achieve a concrete result, identifying the policy objectives and working towards their full and effective implementation; that improving single market legislation can offer significant added value in terms of employment and innovation, as well as contributing to long-term European growth, I voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – As a firm supporter of policies which encourage and support the development of SMEs and also a member of the IMCO Committee, I welcome the report that analyses how to make the whole policy cycle more efficient in the interest of SMEs and consumers. Establishing a functioning European Single Market which supports production, innovation and trade is of utmost importance for the stimulation of growth across the EU. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ With Croatia's accession to the European Union, croatian producers and industry have opened the door to a single market of 500 million consumers. Many have expanded their business beyond the borders of the Republic of Croatia in these three years, with more or less success, because it is not easy to reach customers in competition with products and services from the other 27 European countries.  However, the benefits of the common single market contribute to greater competitiveness of European and Croatian products on the international market. While the single market is a key instrument for initiating economic growth and job creation in the Union, more than 20 years after its formal establishment, the single market framework is still fragmented, primarily because Member States have not fully transposed Union rules into national law or are not implementing them in good quality.  I support this report in its call on the Commission and the Member States to work even more closely towards better regulation of the single market and its better integration due to common benefits such as increasing competitiveness, which contributes to job creation and the necessary economic growth.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In this report, the Council's lack of transparency is deplored; - lack of respect for the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality; - the lack of consultation with civil society; - the poverty of the impact assessments provided (rejected at 40% by the Impact Analysis Supervisory Board); - excessive regulations that are too burdensome for SMEs to bear. While I share these criticisms, I am totally opposed to the proposed solutions. One wonders how the rapporteur plans to change the effects by strengthening the causes: - strengthening the powers of the Commission; - putting member states in step (considered in the text as "partners"); - strengthening the governance of the single market; - aggressive implementation of market integration tools (e.g. EURES); - putting the single market at the pinnacle, a unique solution to the problems of the European Union. I am, of course, voting against this report, which is neither the first nor the last to see the damage that the European Union is causing without thinking for a moment about questioning the main source of the problems.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Single European Market is a key instrument for initiating economic growth and job creation. I believe that good legislation contributes to the well-being of citizens, fosters competitiveness, job creation, growth and development of SMEs, while providing consumers with a high level of protection and that this must be achieved in a way that encourages rather than threatens the European economy. Good legislation not only guarantees one stage in the process, but effective action throughout the policy development process.  I therefore emphasise the importance of all the institutions of the European Union in order to improve legislation in the single market. Shared responsibility leads to the realisation of shared well-being and a strong and vital single market to Europe's long-term growth and thus to the prosperity of its citizens. From all of the above, I support the Report on the topic Towards better regulation of the single market, which aims to improve the regulation of the single market, based on the idea of shared responsibility.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The deepening of the EU Single Market has encouraged the dismantling of sovereign regulation instruments for economies available to Member States. Barriers to the movement of goods, services and capital have been removed, imposing the privatisation and liberalisation of strategic sectors and public services. Harmonisation of legislation has been intensified. The report argues for the need to "improve" regulation at single market level, arguing with the supposed "excess" and "complexity" of existing regulation, from which the "burden" and "barriers" to production, innovation and trade arise, "conditioning" the potential and advantages of a unified market.  It states that "improving" and "easing" regulation could provide a regulatory environment that is conducive to jobs and businesses, contributing to long-term growth and, consequently, to citizens' prosperity. We know what they're talking about. For the apostles of the single market, this "improvement" is synonymous with regulations that serve essentially to protect the economic interests of large enterprises, deregulating workers and social rights and reducing the levels of environmental protection, safety, consumer protection. That is, deregulate in the name of the market and the increase in profits and wealth for the major powers and large economic groups. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support MP Anneleen Van Bossuyt's report. Improving the regulation of the Single Market is a shared responsibility of all the Institutions of the European Union, as it is a key instrument for initiating economic growth and opening up jobs in the European Union. In its future internal market strategy, the European Commission should take into account the recommendations contained in this resolution in order to contribute positively to creating a competitive regulatory environment through strengthening, amending or better promoting certain instruments.  A coherent and regulated EU single market must be a priority of our action and we must believe in the causal relationship between good legislation and the well-being of citizens, fostering competitiveness, job creation and growth and development of SMEs. A more harmonised market would help the Republic of Croatia revive production and would be a breeding ground for stimulating growth, trade and innovation. In this context, I give a positive response to this resolution that would stimulate rather than jeopardise the European economy.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, better regulation of the single market will help the unity of the European Union. Quality legislation should lead to effective and effective cooperation throughout the policy cycle. And the application of legal and secondary rules must be seen as an integral part of the way to achieve the benefits of the single market. There is, of course, the risk that, in the event of a lack of commitment by each stakehous party, regulation may be thwarted in order to regulate too much. It is therefore necessary to review our legislation consistently over time to see if the objectives set at the same time are actually being met. I believe that better regulation of the single market will create a competitive regulatory environment that will help to preserve jobs and businesses in Europe, which will contribute to long-term growth in the European Union and thus to the well-being of its citizens.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 A strong commitment from all stakeholders is needed to take full advantage of the opportunities offered by the digital single market. Improving single market legislation is a shared responsibility at EU level and that is why quality legislation must be ensured.  It is essential that the implementation of legislation and secondary standards is seen as an integral part of the process to make the benefits of the single market usable. I believe that shared responsibility can lead to the achievement of common benefits and the creation of a strong and dynamic single market that can contribute to the long-term growth and prosperity of European citizens. For all this, I voted in favour of adopting this motion for a resolution.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the word regulation originating from the European Union is not very popular with the people of individual Member States, the strategy for regulating the single market, as described in this report, is a sensible way to make it more uniform, to simplify and to seek a fair and optimal system across the Union. This proposal addresses the long-term deficit of the common market, as until now there was a single market for goods, but not a single market for services. The expected consequences of adopting this report are worth noting, in particular ensuring a competitive regulatory environment for our businesses, promoting growth and job creation, and last but not least, strengthening confidence in European legislation. The existence of high-quality yet simple legislation dealing with the regulation of the single market will be important for individual businesses and citizens of the Member States of the European Union. The very importance of the single market must be emphasised.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European single market is a major tool which, in order to promote growth and job creation, must have improved and simplified regulation. That is why I voted in favour of the report, which sets out ways to achieve these objectives. Thus, we call for increasing the quality of impact assessments or the consultation process of actors in the economy and civil society. Finally, it makes it clear that improving the regulation of the single market does not mean eliminating or diminishing the ambition of certain rules, particularly in the area of consumer protection. Simplification and efficiency must guide all public action, serving those who energize the single market.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report as we believe that the best way to improve single market regulation is to deregulate. UKIP are particularly concerned by aspects of the report that criticise Member States’ lack of transposition of single market legislation. The report further calls on the Commission to launch infringement proceedings against these Member States, which UKIP are vehemently opposed to.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Single Market is an essential tool for relaunching economic growth and job creation in the Union. This report states that the future strategy must be to improve its regulation, as good legislation contributes to the good of citizens and should work together to boost the competitiveness, job creation, growth and progress of SMEs, while ensuring a high level of consumer protection, as well as stimulating the European economy rather than hindering it. It therefore states that the institutions should jointly make efforts to ensure that the principle of proportionality is reflected in the drafting of the relevant legislation. Finally, it considers that single market legislation should take into account the new opportunities offered by the digital revolution, be fully compatible with the size of eGovernment and that the role of the Single Market should be highlighted as a distinct pillar of the European Semester, supported by an annual report. As far as i'm sorry, I voted in favour.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims at improved regulation of the single market. We need to look at the whole public policy process, i.e. before impact assessments or consultation processes, but also during - with the implementation, application and monitoring of the market - as well as after - with an ex post assessment and a review of the legislation. This process will have positive effects, both in terms of economic growth, employment and consumer protection, because improving the regulation of the single market does not mean less regulation or lowering the level of regulatory requirement, quite the contrary.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. We consider the single market to be a key instrument for relaunching economic growth and job creation in the Union, but we believe that a number of controversial issues should be emphasized, such as better regulation to limit EU regulatory powers and greater subsidiarity to maximiatly reduce EU regulatory action. In addition, we want to achieve more accessible and balanced EU legislation with the prerogatives of Member States, in order to achieve harmonised Community standards on social, labour, consumer protection and environmental standards.  That is why I voted in favour of the report 'Towards better regulation of the single market'.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the Van Bossuyt report because I do not agree at all with the report's conception of what better regulation of the internal market should be.  As a convinced European, I am of course in favour of better regulation for our internal market. However, according to the rapporteur, this better regulation should only concern businesses and consumers, and the sole purpose is to improve competitiveness. The consideration of SMEs and consumers is important in the same way as that of workers. Unfortunately, it seems that the rapporteur does not agree with me.  With regard to impact assessments, I am more in point for the European institutions to have elements to help them in their choices. However, these analyses are in no way a substitute for political analysis and decision-making. Unfortunately, some passages in this report tend to give importance to these impact assessments that they should not have. Other elements in this report do not correspond to the vision of society that I defend in this Parliament, which is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which aimed to improve the regulation of the single market. However, this intent was not reflected in the text. The rapporteur has sought to introduce 'better' regulation where it is not needed at all. The report is incomplete, with the results of the vote showing 387 votes in favour and 293 against.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The Single Market is proven to be one of the greatest successes in Community Europe. Increased competition, the free movement of people and products and the deregulation of protectionist standards have led to a significant increase in European GDP and the creation of around 3 million jobs. As recently advocated by the European Group of the Social Democratic Party, the contribution of European legislation towards the establishment of an effective single market - which has been improving consumer access to a wider range of products, with lower prices and more demanding quality controls - has led to the need to complete and improve legislative building and market access conditions , in order to eliminate existing situations that do not allow exploiting the full potential of the European market. However, by wanting to improve the regulation of the single market in order to make it more effective, this own-initiative report promotes the process of European construction and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which aims to examine ways to improve the regulation of the internal market in order to make it more effective. The aim is to make procedures simpler for SMEs and consumers, while taking into account existing single market tools such as impact assessments, consultation processes, problem-solving and ex post assessments. In particular, the text stresses that in order to improve regulation, the emphasis must be placed on the transposition and implementation of regulations. Improving the regulation of the single market must continue and we must continue to support production, innovation and trade in order to promote growth.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report has some positive elements in terms of the implementation of the single market - especially in terms of transparency, the role of national parliaments or market surveillance, which we voted for - it does not significantly correct the profile of the single market dominated by the commodisation of any socio-product relationship, without redistribution or compensatory elements. The report does not make it possible to substantially correct the structural inequalities of the European Union, which are reinforced by the mechanisms of the single market. That's why we voted against it.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on better regulation for the internal market, as it is a joint responsibility of the institutions of the European Union to make the legislation of the internal market and its policy cycle less complex and therefore more efficient. I believe that this is also in the interests of SMEs (small and medium-sized enterprises) and consumers.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report states that the development of the Single Market should not clash with fundamental rights, while stressing the need for dialogue with organised civil society and protecting the social, environmental and security and security standards contained in European regulation. However, it continues to interpret the deepening of the Single Market as a priority over the 'overregulation' and 'barriers' that would leave the European economy, ignoring those of us who believe that improving the living conditions of Europeans must prioritise the upward harmonisation of social legislation and the democratisation of the institutions governing the Single Market. That's why I abstained.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it aims to develop more effective single market legislation in order to achieve the objectives of economic growth and employment more quickly and efficiently. The innovations introduced by the report include the use of a range of instruments aimed at improving regulation, including impact assessments, consultations between institutions and stakeholders, monitoring and monitoring of the market and the implementation of the principle of subsidiarity. I am of the opinion that quality legislation that does not involve excessive burdens or excessive bureaucracy and that is regularly updated and simplified can enable the European Union to be even more competitive economically, and to contribute to the growth and well-being of its citizens.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against this non-legislative report as we believe that the best way to improve single market regulation is to deregulate. UKIP are particularly concerned by aspects of the report that criticise Member States’ lack of transposition of single market legislation. The report further calls on the Commission to launch infringement proceedings against these Member States, which UKIP are vehemently opposed to.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution towards an improved single market regulation gives guidelines on how to improve the single market, but also does not over-burden or frustrate production, innovation and commerce. Since this is reflected in the resolution, I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒The report on the topic Towards better regulation of the single market speaks of a lower level of implementation of existing legislation in the Member States, due to a subsidiarity mechanism that does not leave national parliaments sufficient time to consider in detail the various aspects of implementation and how to measure the performance of legislation implementation in different areas of the single market.  It also highlights the need to create a single market for services and warns that digital innovation is evolving rapidly, which is why existing legislation needs to be changed. Despite all the arguments mentioned in the report, I believe that the single market is working well and that there is no need to go into the amendments to the existing regulation proposed by this report and, accordingly, I have not given my support to this report.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the resolution because key amendments have not been adopted, although I consider improving single market legislation to be a key tool for relaunching economic growth and job creation in the Union. The Single Market is still fragmented 20 years after its official creation and major differences remain between Member States. However, I believe that, in future, by adapting the Single Market, we will be able to contribute to better stimulating competitiveness, job creation and growth, and the development of small and medium-sized enterprises. If we want the new legislation adopted to be effective, we must ensure that the measures taken and the commitments proposed are simple and effective and effectively applied in order to achieve the agreed policy objectives. On the other hand, however, I do not believe that only legislation will improve the conditions of the single market. Only through the effective work of all the EU institutions and our shared responsibility will we be able to achieve greater benefits for a strong and viable single market that will contribute to Europe's long-term growth and thus to the prosperity of its citizens.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The purpose of the report is to express Parliament's opinion on the level and type of regulation needed to improve the functioning of the single market. I do not agree that improving the functioning of the single market means more power and more subsidiarity by the Member States. The fact is that the Member States have decided to lose part of their sovereignty when they join the EU. Therefore, in my opinion, it is not the essence of a better single market in deregulation, but in closer and better cooperation between Member States. I believe that an efficient and well-functioning internal market can make a positive contribution to competitiveness and job creation in the EU. As far as the sovereignty of the Member States is concerned, it is necessary to keep it at a certain level and to allow member states to decide for themselves on certain important matters. It is necessary to respect the principle of moderation when it comes to subsidiarity. This is important for the Member States, of course, but if they want the single market to function as planned and desired, then the Member States must give up to a certain extent. It is also important to remember that improving the regulation of the single market does not mean the elimination of all regulations, but the necessary regulatory environment, which will not place too much strain on businesses, but will not be too lax. For this reasons, I voted against the adoption of the report.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'In Europe, there is a feeling that many people today believe that more efficient and in some cases less regulation will ensure the proper functioning of the internal market. This report by Mr Van Bossuyt illustrates that parties can hijack this discourse in order to drive complete deregulation.  The report 'Towards improved regulation of the internal market' does not seek better regulation. On the contrary, it seems to want to stop any possible form of European regulation. The proposal to introduce a 'red card system' allowing national parliaments to delay the legislative process has been blocked. Nevertheless, there are plenty of other elements, including the misre gnation of the European level to regulate the internal market, which make this report unacceptable.   Through amendments, we tried to steer this report in the right direction. We stressed the need for European regulation in the pursuit of sustainable development and consumer protection. We stressed that barriers to trade alone should be removed and called for a multidimensional approach in assessing policy outcomes that take social and environmental aspects into account. Unfortunately, all of the amendments we have tabled have all been rejected. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving single market legislation, which is the key to European integration, is necessary to make it more efficient and simplifyed, while at the same time conversing with the needs of citizens and businesses. I am of the opinion that the Single Market must adapt to the development of society in order, for example, to reflect the digital age. However, when changing legislation, it is important not to reduce environmental protection, safety, consumer protection and social standards.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Improving the Single Market Regulation is a shared responsibility and priority for all institutions of the European Union. Better regulation of the single market and full and proper implementation of legislation should contribute to competitiveness, job creation for EUROPEAN Union citizens and economic growth and innovation. The focus is on legislation, as not all Member States have transposed OR implemented EU rules.  Furthermore, in the regulation of the single market, the principle of subsidiarity is essential, including the involvement of national, even regional parliaments, with a view to achieving better political dialogue. Consequently, I support this report. I believe that effective and effective regulation of the single market, as the main instrument for initiating economic growth in the European Union, is of particular importance for the long-term growth and competitiveness of the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The Commission's report on the topic 'Towards better regulation of the single market' deals with the study of the single market, all in the interests of consumers and SMEs (SME). The importance of legislation across the process is noted, as it has been some 20 years since the creation of the common market and not all Member States have yet implemented EU rules in national legislation. Furthermore, cooperation between all Union institutions is essential, as all institutions are jointly responsible.  In fact, production, innovation, trade-stimulated economic growth should be encouraged in the single market in order to create new jobs within the Union. I believe that instruments should be introduced to achieve this objective and therefore I support this report. I believe that all benefits bestowed on us by the digital revolution have not been fully recognized or used to help achieve these goals. Monitoring and impact assessment are just some of the instruments to be used by the EU, as this would see negative effects and reduce unnecessary regulations and weaken the role of administration.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal and fully support all efforts to deepen the Single Market, which is the greatest asset of the European Union's existence.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Report Towards better single market regulations. Following the economic and financial crisis, which has affected all the Member States and the consequences of which some countries still feel today, which is most reflected in the high unemployment rate, the single market represents an important tool for restarting economic growth and job creation in the European Union. I agree with the report, which considers that single market regulation should be a priority and a shared responsibility for the EU institutions, while stressing the importance of transparent and accessible information.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the road to better regulation of the single market, as the single market is one of the fundamental pillars of the European Union and its existence brings concrete positives for entrepreneurs and individual citizens in all Member States. In particular, further discussions on the possibilities for the development of the Single Market need to focus on further supporting SMEs and further working in the Digital Single Market in order to exploit the potential of new technologies to increase economic growth and further integrate the Union. We are not talking about regulation where it is not strictly necessary, but about promoting innovation and harnessing the potential of the entire European market.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which focuses on better regulation in the single market. I have long argued against overly burdensome regulation in the EU, I therefore welcome this report’s focus on creating a competitive regulatory environment and an efficient single market, which will encourage innovation, production and trade.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Single Market is not in the interests of European citizens. On the contrary, it has so far contributed greatly to the current economic crisis as well as to the stripping of certain states by valuable trained workers who could have contributed to the recovery of their economy.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The continued achievements of the single market and the exploitation of the opportunities offered by the Digital Single Market require a strong commitment from the actors concerned. Improving the regulation of the single market does not mean removing all the rules, but creating a competitive regulatory environment that keeps employment and business in Europe.  I voted in favour of Mrs Van Bossuyt's report, because improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market.  I believe that better legislation is not guaranteed by a single measure in the procedure, it is done through effective and effective work throughout the political cycle. It is therefore of the utmost importance for me to transpose and implement the rules of the single market. The single market, which is not too burdensome for production, innovation and trade, is a structure that will stimulate growth in Europe. In this context, shared responsibility will lead to the realisation of common benefits: a strong and dynamic single market will be created that will contribute to Europe's development.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on improving single market regulation because it does not adequately represent the necessary direction for strengthening the single market.  However, I approve of the fact that, as recommended in the report, we are treating the improvement of single market regulation as a priority and a shared responsibility of the EU institutions.
