As the report points out, we must seek to create legislation that benefits citizens, thus contributing to improving competitiveness, creating jobs and the development of SMEs, while providing a high level of protection for consumers. To this end, it is crucial that the Commission continues its efforts and regularly updates its regulatory guidelines to meet the challenges of the digital age. However, despite my 'no' vote, I share the reporter's concern that Europeans have very little information on the services and organisations that help them exercise their consumer rights. The Commission and the Member States should play a more active role in promoting such instruments while at the same time examining the effectiveness of the services.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union is currently under fire for its overregulation and excessive bureaucracy. Effective action is needed to ensure that the Community is better and clearer able to demonstrate its usefulness to citizens. Creating more and more unnecessary legislation is definitely not a step in the right direction. This situation not only leads to the creation of poor quality legislation, but also creates a great deal of confusion and uncertainty among consumers and businesses. Parliament's report aims to examine how to improve the functioning of the single market in order to make it more effective. It rightly emphasises the importance of small and medium-sized enterprises and calls for its impact on SMEs to be assessed at every stage – consultation, implementation, monitoring and enforcement of the law. It is of the importance for economic operators that the law they create is transparent, predictable, efficient and interferes as little as possible with their activities.  In my opinion, European legislative initiatives can only be justified if their implementation has added value. This position is also expressed in the report on the aim of improving the single market, which is why I decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Our group has a moral duty to protect the rights and freedoms of European citizens. Better functioning of the European Single Market means more than removing from red tape; a functioning single market must serve both citizens and companies that create jobs. That is why it is important for all of us in this House to have ownership of the terms we use and to be clear in defining the concepts that affect the lives of millions of European citizens. Whether we are talking about better regulation, subsidiarity or proportionality, we need to understand that the success of the European market lies in balancing the need for simplification by preserving standards for consumers, employees and, last but not least, the environment. I believe that this document fails to achieve this vital balance.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against the text. I cannot share this view of things on the part of the rapporteur. Improved regulation of the single market must be treated in a different way, including prioritizing workers' rights!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ More than 20 years after its creation, the single market is still fragmented. It is high time to move towards a fully-fledged single market based on the principle of shared responsibility, which is why I voted in favour of this regulation.  A functioning single market will benefit European citizens by stimulating competitiveness, job creation, growth and SME development, while delivering a high level of consumer protection. An important aspect is to ensure that policies are decided at the most appropriate level, be it local, regional, national or European. Legislation needs to be effective, efficient, and its impact should be assessed before, after and during the time it becomes law. We should also avoid unnecessary regulation and administrative burden. Stakeholders should be consulted on a regular, transparent and open basis when drafting laws. Moreover, we need to ensure proper implementation of this legislation, which remains one of our weak spots.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the Report towards better single market regulation, as improving the single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. On the basis of this concept, the European Union should endeavour to improve this regulation. It is the responsibility of all people to respect the guiding principle of subsidiarity when deciding on action, to decide what best to act when regulation is needed, and finally to ensure that the measures and obligations are simple and applied in an effective manner to achieve the agreed objectives. Good legislation cannot be ensured in a single part of the process, but through effective action throughout the policy-making cycle. The transposition and implementation of single market regulation is of paramount importance to the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. It is important that we see the implementation of legislation and secondary regulations not only as an individual element of the process, but as an integral part of the process of ensuring the benefits of the single market.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report has some positive elements in terms of the implementation of the single market - especially in terms of transparency, the role of national parliaments or market surveillance, which we voted for - it does not significantly correct the profile of the single market dominated by the commodisation of any socio-product relationship, without redistribution or compensatory elements. The report does not make it possible to substantially correct the structural inequalities of the European Union, which are reinforced by the mechanisms of the single market. That's why we voted against it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Strengthening and perfecting the internal single market are the two nipples of the report. It presents a sometimes harsh and realistic observation of the functioning of the single market, but follows, in the solutions it proposes, the dominant line of the European single market ideology, to which I am strongly opposed.  The Europe of Nations is the only credible alternative for resolving the regretted and listed imbalances.  I voted against this report.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The concept of improving the regulation of the single market is the common responsibility of the institutions of the European Union, which must be based on the guiding principle of subsidiarity. The draft report on improving single market regulation underlines that the transposition and implementation of Single Market regulation is very important, especially when the acquis communautaire needs to be reviewed and updated throughout the process. Improving the regulation of the Single Market means ensuring a competitive regulatory environment that supports employment and businesses in Europe. I voted in favour of the draft report because I believe that a single market is needed that does not overload or hinder production, innovation and trade, because a strong and dynamic single market contributes to Europe's long-term growth and the well-being of European citizens.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving single market regulation is a shared responsibility of all the institutions of the European Union. This is the concept in which the European Union seeks to improve the regulation of the single market. It is a shared responsibility to respect the principle of subsidiarity when deciding whether action is needed; to decide on the most appropriate action when regulation is needed; and, finally, to ensure that the measures and obligations developed are simple and applied effectively and effectively in order to achieve the policy objectives pursued. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although the report has some positive elements in terms of the implementation of the single market - especially in terms of transparency, the role of national parliaments or market surveillance, which we voted for - it does not significantly correct the profile of the single market dominated by the commodisation of any socio-product relationship, without redistribution or compensatory elements. The report does not make it possible to substantially correct the structural inequalities of the European Union, which are reinforced by the mechanisms of the single market. That's why we voted against it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because the report is unbalanced and mainly calls for a deregulation, or even a ‘refrain-from-regulating’ agenda.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on ‘Towards improved single market regulation’. The report states that the single market is a key tool for boosting economic growth and job creation in the Union. However, its market framework remains fragmented, as the Member States have not fully transposed or correctly implemented EU legislation. The report suggests strengthening the role of the single market as a separate pillar of the European Semester process. It equally presents tools to improve single market regulation, the consultation and implementation processes, as well as monitoring and problem solving.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report aims to examine how to improve regulation on the single market to make it more effective. Improving single market legislation and improving efficiency and efficiency throughout the legislation-building cycle are necessary elements to further deepen the improvement of the single market. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. More than 20 years after its creation, the internal market is still too fragmented. It is time to commit now to a fully-fledged internal market based on the principle of shared responsibility. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some positive aspects in this report, as is the case of the reference to workers' rights, what prevails and which we reject is a federalist and European integration perspective in which there is no national legislation that is better than that of the Community. That is, a tendency to empty the importance of the action and legislative production of states. Even if we put the concern for workers' rights, which is fair, the heart of this project is the reduction of all legislation that has burdens on competitiveness, competition, the economy and economic operators.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report is for SMEs as well as for less administrative burden and costs. Nevertheless, it represents a clear intervention in the administrative structures, especially from a legal point of view, of the Member States.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on 'Towards better regulation of the internal market'. It is true that the EU should not harmonise the internal market in general. The better way to achieve a single internal market would be to mutually recognise national regulatory frameworks. However, the aim of the report is to mitigate the interventions of these harmonisation efforts that are currently taking place. This is better than the status quo, although the system change is necessary.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on improving legislation on the single market. The single market is a key tool for restoring economic growth and job creation in the Union, which is why improving legislation on the single market should be a key priority for the Union.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the European Parliament's report entitled 'Towards better regulation of the single market', because I believe that quality legislation involving market regulation benefits the citizens of the European Union because it strengthens competitiveness, leads to job creation and causes economic growth and the development of SMEs. I am sure that these regulations also guarantee a high level of consumer protection. I also consider it crucial that the principle of subsidiarity is the starting point for the formulation of regulatory policy. In this respect, I consider it important that the principle of proportionality should also be taken into account already in the preparation of the relevant legislation. In my opinion, the main objective in the creation of regulations should be to achieve maximum simplicity, transparency and coherence.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Caring for the efficient functioning of the single market is a key task of the European institutions. The European Union is a community of economic interests which is based on close economic cooperation between The Member States. Greater transparency of the legislative process and simplification of many rules will certainly contribute to improving the functioning of the single market. We need to create a better environment for the development of entrepreneurship and job creation, also in a cross-border context.  This report responds to a number of demands from the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists on the development of European law, including calls for a better application of the subsidiarity principle, the preparation of a sound impact assessment of the regulations adopted before they are adopted, a broader public consultation on proposed legal solutions with the communities and entities targeted by the proposed legislation, and a greater focus on assessing the real impact of the legislation adopted and their impact on the effective functioning of the single market. I believe that the report presented takes good account of the demands made by the JURI, EMPL and IMCO committees to improve the legal process in the European Union for the regulation of the single market. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the own-initiative report, which contains a number of general principles for improving existing single market legislation.  If it is able to take account of social and environmental objectives and the importance of supporting socio-economic growth that protects consumers and workers, as expressed in the report, the single market will be able to boost economic growth and job creation in the EU. Better regulation of the single market means removing the excessive bureaucracy that hampers the competitiveness of companies and therefore does not stimulate the growth of the European labour market. The idea is therefore to focus on simplification, taking into account all the opportunities offered by the digital revolution. With this report, Parliament reaffirms its desire to strengthen the legislative bases on which the European Union is based, while also strengthening the instruments of control over the Commission's work. These arguments have found my favor.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the resolution's recommendations calling for improved governance of the single market. Effective regulation is based on transparent and consistent legislation and respecting the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality. I believe that a well-functioning internal market system is essential to boost the European economy, which maintains the competitiveness and development of small and medium-sized enterprises and creates jobs.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: "I stopped in a small German village the other day on my way home, I came to an inn. Tiny, couple-room accommodation, restaurant below where I had dinner. I had a chat with the owner. It's a typical family business, they've owned this inn and this restaurant for generations. He tearfully informed me that a large group of migrants would be resettled at the house next month, and that their business would be destroyed.  I propose that this case be included in the textbook in this particular subject of learning about the European Union, and that there should be a discussion with pupils in the subject about how to prevent the en masse of decent small business and decent people in all 28 countries of the European Union. Thank you very much!

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: – I must confess that I have experienced a lot in the EP, but there has rarely been a vote on something as terrible as the report on EU teaching at school.  I spent 26 years of my life under the communist regime, which was distinguished, among other things, by preparing children from the 1st grade with various, pre-prepared brainwashing for a kind of career as a new socialist man. Here I feel like I'm reading a dictionary in another little language that I read when I was young in those socialist schools. Of course it didn't work then and it won't work now. No European propaganda, some pre-prepared, prefabricated, will simply improve the EU's image in the public eye. It will only improve practical steps, it will improve the demonstration of realism, it will improve if it does not push for integration at all costs, but no such European propaganda will simply improve the face of the EU in the eyes of the public.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Zahradil, the European Union is not quite like the Soviet Union, in short, there is some difference.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurobarometer figures are a wake-up call for us.  Almost half of Europe's citizens, 40 %, admit that they have no real knowledge of the European Union, 50 % are convinced that Europe is really distant and that its voice and interests do not count in the European Union. These data on the perception of the relationship between citizens and the Union are then translated into reality, with massive abstentions – the last one we have seen that concerns us, in which only 42 % of voters voted. Even more serious are the spread and success of anti-European populist movements that use simplistic communication that is easy to understand for those who do not know Europe.  I voted in favour of this report because it is essential to go beyond Erasmus and to include the Union at all levels of education in order to form a new European civic consciousness, to train European citizens who know what a huge opportunity Europe is in fact.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – In the absence of quality knowledge and information, the ability to think critically is lost and thus the ability to come up with new stimulating ideas that can move our society forward on real foundations. I therefore consider it necessary to teach objectively about the European Union in our schools, but I cannot agree, like my colleague, that the Union should be promoted unhealthy in schools, and only in a positive sense, and so pink glasses are deployed in our children by creating an artificial pro-European atmosphere. For this reason, I could not support this resolution; After all, the field of education is within our own competence of individual states. In fact, teaching about the European Union, as proposed in the present report, certainly cannot contribute to the development of our children's critical thinking.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European One of the European Union's most important long-term tasks is to create and maintain European civic awareness by making the growing generations aware of and understanding the common history of the Union and its Member States, thus fostering peaceful coexistence, a sense of tolerance and subsidiarity in the future. Through quality-minded teaching methods adapted to the level and needs of learners, young people can be able to think critically, form opinions and exercise their democratic rights and responsibilities. At the same time, in the context of EU knowledge, young people can also get a topical picture of indigenous minorities in Europe: all the ethnic groups who have contributed and are still contributing to the expansion of Europe's depository. Thank you!

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Parliamentary Labour Party abstained on this report because, although we fully support citizenship education in schools, we do not believe that it should be decided at an EU level. Education is a Member State competence and in the case of my own constituency, Scotland, a devolved competence. Therefore it is up to Member States and regional governments, where authority lies on education policy, to determine the curriculum in schools.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – In the end, I supported this material on the grounds that when I travel around the Czech Republic as an MEP and debate in different schools with children about the EU, I feel an imbalance of information and an imbalance of knowledge among our young generation. In some schools, emphasis is placed on issues related to public events and issues related to the EU, in some schools this topic is underestimated.  I therefore believe that we should encourage Member States to encourage the dissemination of information on the EU in their school systems. I am by no means interested in any propaganda and celebration of the EU. I think that we should not do that in any way, but young people should have enough information to decide for themselves how to proceed with the European integration process and whether to support it, but I feel that they simply do not have that information. So if this material leads to young people in Europe having more information, then the material will fulfil its role.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report contains many positives, in particular with regard to addressing such issues as racism, multiculturalism, tolerance, awareness and understanding of other cultures as well as democratic values and human rights.  However, the concept of the European dimension in education as raised in the report is rather complex and unclear. Therefore, many points in this report are controversial such as the fact that it recognises the democratic deficit and the existence of inequalities between and within the Member States, but makes no specific criticism of the current European policies and practices that have created these realities. It therefore deliberately gives the false impression that if citizens are more informed about the EU, then their lives will automatically improve. The structures and practices of the EU and its institutions are not in question here. The European Commission is also given a full mandate to interpret the broad concept of the European dimension in education (from the design and implementation of the framework to the identification of the best practices of the European dimension in private sector/enterprise education and participation). That is why we voted to abstain.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, over the past few years the European Union has been through a severe economic and financial crisis and all efforts have been focused on overcoming it. In addition to it, however, the Union is also suffering from a crisis of civility. According to the latest Eurobarometer data, 44% of citizens feel that they do not have sufficient knowledge of the functioning of the European Union, while 52% are of the opinion that their vote is irrelevant. I find these statistics alarming. It is no surprise to anyone that people feel increasingly distant from Brussels and from what is happening and deciding in the European capital. In order to regain its legitimacy, the European Union must inevitably reconnect with its citizens. That is why I supported the report on the study of the European Union in school. Among adolescents, a critical reading of European integration needs to be nurtured, they need to know not only what the role of Member States is in developing the European Union, but also how the Union affects political processes at national level. The European Union is influencing every aspect of our lives, European citizens, especially young people, need to be aware of the added value of our membership of the European Union.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The school is supposed to convey knowledge and culture, not political propaganda. However, the educational recommendation presented is not only a recommendation of political propaganda aimed at the most legitimate views of millions of our countries, critical views, on the state of the European Union (as my colleagues Škripek and Zahradil have said), but it is also ideological propaganda of multiculturalism and the political homosexual movement against which millions of citizens of our countries, from Croatia and Slovenia to France and Spain, have created. This is an action that directly undermines the rights of the family, and it is these rights of the family as defined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Along this path, the European Union not only denies the principle of subsidiarity, but directly undermines the very basis of it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé arís le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir anseo agus is dóigh liom gur tuarascáil mhaith í.  Is dóigh liom féin gur trí fhoghlaim sna scoileanna a thiocfaidh ár saoránaigh ar an bhfírinne maidir leis an Aontas. Mar má fhéachann tú ar na meáin, agus go háirithe sna táblóidigh, ní fhaigheann siad an fhírinne ansin. De ghnáth bíonn siad claonta agus uaireanta insíonn siad bréaga. Agus sin ceann de na cúiseanna go bhfuil Brexit ar siúl anois, mar níl an t-eolas ag saoránaigh.  Dá bhrí sin is trí na scoileanna go bhféadfaimid teacht ar an bhfreagra agus trí chláracha cosúil le Erasmus+, An Eoraip do na Saoránaigh, Comenius agus mar sin de. Tá clár iontach i mo thír féin anois, clár Réalta Ghorm, ina bhfoghlaimíonn leanaí sna scoileanna go léir faoin Aontas agus déanann siad tionscnamh ar an Aontas – na tíortha, an teanga, cultúr agus mar sin de. Is trí na cláracha sin a thiocfaidh siad ar an bhfírinne faoin Aontas.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, in the seminal book on Communism, The ABC of Communism, the chapter on schools said schools had three tasks. One: it had to inspire the coming generation of workers with devotion to the regime. Second, they had to create a young ruling class who could be cultured controllers, and they must assist those in power to control the economy. It is clear, having lost the argument that the EU has benefit to our young, when we have youth unemployment of over 35% in most countries, that the EU’s response is to ensure greater propaganda. They are learning from The ABC of Communism, in short, in this programme to inspire the coming generation of students to have devotion to the EU through Euro teacher of the year awards, to create a young ruling class of cultured controllers, like those in the Socialists and to my right, or people like Margrethe Vestager, who started here to become a commissioner. If you want your children to think independently and not be indoctrinated by the EU: vote to leave the EU on 23 June.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Two years ago, 52% of Europeans felt that their voice was not heard at all in Parliament, and 44% simply did not understand how it all functions. As a result, the percentage of participation in European elections is well known – increasing percentages – every time a percentage is getting smaller and needs to be changed. Consequently, I am very pleased that today we voted in favour of this report (I also) aimed at drawing attention to the effective awareness of our citizens. The information starts, clearly, from the school, as the next voters of the European Parliament and the future of the European Union sit on the school bench. And so it is very good that we can also use all these men for this growth potential and, for example, good mechanisms such as Erasmus+ and Creative Europe are just one of the assurances that this process has a future.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on an own-initiative report dealing with the learning of EU knowledge in schools. The low level of knowledge of EU cooperation among citizens is an urgent problem that should be taken seriously. This is especially the case in Sweden, where the EU dimension of public debate is often conspicuous by its absence. But just because a problem is identified does not mean that it is the EU that should solve it. Among other things, the report calls for EU funds to be used to target efforts to increase EU knowledge among The Union's pupils and also provides detailed views on Member States' curricula. Increasing the edicts from Brussels is not the way to go in order to achieve greater European knowledge among citizens.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report develops the theme of the EU's institutional structure and activities at school in a positive way, highlighting the fact that an EU dimension in education should make it possible not only to acquire knowledge and develop a sense of BELONGING to the Union and European citizenship, but also to encourage critical reflection on the current EU; It also stresses the need to address and resolve the growing gap between the voice of citizens and the institutions of the European Union. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to introduce a European dimension to education in schools to restore citizens' confidence in the European Union. But the report ignores the reasons why mistrust and discrediting citizens to the present EU has increased. With complete cynicism, the report promotes the principles and values set out in Article 2 of the EU Treaty, but does not criticise the systematic violation of these same principles within the EU territory itself. For these reasons I have not been able to vote in favour.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text on learning the European Union in schools.  This report assumes that the rise of Euroscepticism in the Member States comes from a lack of knowledge of European integration. To curb this phenomenon, the rapporteur therefore proposes to focus on the European dimension in school curricula.  I have, of course, objected to this scandalous text. On the one hand, the rapporteur's proposals undermine Member States' prerogatives in education. On the other hand, this report is a real propaganda tool that goes against the fundamental principles of our society.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report contained some positive provisions specifically regarding the positive and proactive role that the EU can play in everyday life. However, it does not encourage critical engagement or thinking within the EU. This is absolutely crucial for any well rounded and robust learning programme. It is not simply good enough to blindly accept the authority of the EU project without it being subject to greater scrutiny and debate. If the introduction of an EU dimension into school education is being introduced, then a wider array of views must be taught to school goers than the simple assertion of the immutability of the status quo. That mind set serves no-one and it was for these reasons that I abstained on the report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 With this report the European Parliament aims to better learn the values, culture and history of the EU, as well as to shape a European identity. All these resources will enable tomorrow's European citizens to better understand the Union's decision-making process in order to combat widespread Euroscepticism.  For all these reasons I voted in favour of the report on the inclusion of the European element in education on the part of the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats, as one of our objectives is to promote non-discriminatory and inclusive intercultural education.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is unacceptable: its main aim is to spread European propaganda and multi-culturalism within schools. I obviously voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for more funding for EU programmes such as the European House of History. It also wants to incorporate an ‘EU dimension into teaching’ and for the EU to be ‘better highlighted in teaching materials’. The report actually suggests that people only become eurosceptic due to a lack of information and education on the EU. It calls on Member States to encourage and facilitate high-quality training on EU topics for teachers, other educational staff, youth leaders and trainers. This is another example of EU propaganda and interference in the education system of Member States. The European Union has no competency in this area as Article 165 of the TFEU clearly states. The European Union’s desire to interfere in the UK education system with propaganda sets a dangerous precedent for the future.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. At a time of rising Euroscepticism and even Europhobia, there is an urgent need to destroy the technocratic and incomprehensible image of the European Union. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. I believe that it is essential to make young people aware of European citizenship and to teach them how institutions work. I also do not forget that European citizenship is forged through European mobility.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to increasingly mainstream the EU dimension in school curricula. At present, citizens do not have much knowledge of the work of the EU and its institutions: 44% of citizens do not agree with the statement 'I understand how the EU works'. Citizens feel marginalised or increasingly repellent about the European political project, their Eurosceptic attitudes are growing and they regard the Union's decision-making processes as undemocratic. I agree that the situation can be rectified if citizens are better informed about, encouraged and actively interested in the European Unification Project. One of the best ways to achieve this is to increasingly involve the EU dimension in school curricula, which would help to defeat Euroscepticism and prepare citizens to live and work in an increasingly complex globalised world. Many citizens have limited knowledge of the EU and eu-related issues should be more visible in the textbooks.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report. We oppose any form of EU interference in Member States’ national curricula, especially with regard to the EU being better highlighted in teaching materials, disseminating EU propaganda and calling for more funding to do so. The EU has no competency in the education systems of Member States and in fact is going against Article 165 of the TFEU which states that the EU ‘fully respect the responsibility of the Member States for the content of teaching and the organisation of education systems and their cultural and linguistic diversity’.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This project is a veritable weapon of massive propaganda, considering the European Union as a point of dogma, which must be instilled from an early age in contempt of state competences, education being an exclusive competence of states according to Article 6 of the FUE Treaty. On the assumption that the rise of Eurosceptic views is primarily due to a lack of information from citizens about the functioning of the Union, this report actually calls - behind the desire to harmonize school curricula and increase European mobility - that education is now within the competence of the Union, an unacceptable attack on the sovereignty of States. For this reason, coupled with the lack of democratic legitimacy of the Union and the call to strengthen the participation of pupils and parents in the governance of the school in defiance of the faculty authority, I could only oppose this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. According to a 2014 Eurobarometer survey, 44% of EU citizens feel they have only a limited understanding of how the Union works. Based on this observation, the report proposes a series of initiatives to better integrate the European dimension into education systems. Among these initiatives, the report, which I approved, calls for better integration of European integration into teaching and extracurricular materials, providing teachers with materials and resources so as to enable them to incorporate a dimension of the Union into their teaching, or promoting multilingualism and intercultural skills of educators.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Drăghici report entitled 'Learning the EU at School'. It is a text that deals with an important issue, closely linked to the sense of distance that all too often characterises the relationship between citizens and the European institutions. According to a 2014 Eurobarometer report, in fact, 44 % of citizens believe that they have limited knowledge of the European institutions and to this is added 52 % of citizens who believe that they have no voice within its institutional dynamics. These are worrying figures which require coordinated action to strengthen the sense of belonging and the construction of the European identity.  The path proposed in the report is to create a European dimension in education that will move through greater attention to the issue of European integration, citizenship education and the history and culture of the continent. Many Member States have already integrated parts of the study of Europe into school curricula, but there is still a long way to go. It is important that the institutions and in particular the Commission dedicate resources to all those projects and platforms such as Erasmus+, eTwinning, School Education Gateway and EPALE that can foster a true education in European citizenship. Only in this way can Euroscepticism be defeated.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Most of the aspects that we have opposed are due to the vagueness of the concept of European dimension that is used. We are not opposed to greater information on the EU being provided at different levels of training, we believe that greater knowledge of the procedures and competences of EU bodies is clearly positive. However, we believe that it is not appropriate to confuse training with propaganda, and in this regard this report does not forese or incorporate the causes or responsibilities of the authors causing the situation of inequality in which we live in today's Europe, whereas on the contrary, it abounds in additional clarifications on the term Euroscepticism.  We note the existence of positive and relevant contributions, but the general spirit of the report we believe has an objective aimed at addressing a deficit of legitimacy, such as that suffered by the European project in different regions, without to publicize the functioning, causes and consequences of the European project. For this reason our vote has been abstention.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. "It is not enough to sit in a chair and shout: "Europe, Europe, Europe" to solve all the economic problems of our continent," General De Gaulle said some 40 years ago. What a premonition, when we see how desperation some of our colleagues want to convince our fellow citizens and children in school of the benefits of 'all-Europe'. Because in order to pass a report which aims to "learn Europe in school", one really has to be desperate. In my country, in the Netherlands, Italy, Flanders, Poland and Hungary, all over the Union, Europeans are telling their leaders that they want a different policy. They are not against Europe. They want another Europe. But this Europe does not listen to them. And now we believe we have found the sesame that will save the bureaucratic Europe that we have built and which we continue to build against the will of the people by indoctrinating students from an early age. George Orwell didn't invent anything. The newspeak so well written in his 1984 novel is more current than ever.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. This report on the acquisition of knowledge about the EU in school is without palliative support. This presents two fundamental and interrelated aspects. The first, the acquisition of knowledge, and the second based on the idea of the legitimacy and stability of the entire democratic political system that is largely based on civic commitment. There is limited knowledge of what the EU is, with a negative view, and what it represents and has represented since its constitution. This is a legacy that our future generations must know.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. As a member of the Culture Committee, I have fought fiercely against this report, which is a real insult to respect for the pluralism of ideas and freedom of expression. Indeed, under the pretext of learning the European Union in school, it will now be forbidden to express Eurosceptic opinions, criticising the European edifice being described in this report as a dangerous virus to be eradicated thanks to the miracle vaccine that would be pro-European Union propaganda. This drug, which actually amounts to an extensive promotional marketing campaign with our children, you want to inoculate it at the expense of the sovereignty of the states that officially retain exclusive jurisdiction over education. But European nations will be asked to harmonize their school curricula and to fund measures touting multiculturalism, an objective which, for you, seems to be a priority in terms of learning fundamental knowledge such as reading, writing, or mathematics. In order to combat this massive propaganda weapon, I have tabled, on behalf of the ENL Group, a proposal for an alternative resolution which aims to restore the sovereignty of the Member States which in theory still have this competence, and to refocus priorities in education and training.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which advocates the need to integrate a European dimension into education as a key element in helping citizens to better understand and reconnect with the EU, deepen the role of the Union's core values and promote accession to them. As the report points out, knowing and understanding the common history and values of the EU and its Member States is key to mutual understanding, peaceful coexistence, tolerance and solidarity, as well as understanding the fundamental principles of the Union. The report reviews and proposes specific measures for curriculum, teacher training, teaching methods, mobility, research and use of new technologies. It also recognizes the role played by social partners and civil society organizations. At a time when the EU faces serious challenges, the integration of a European dimension into education must enable students to acquire knowledge and develop a sense of belonging, but also to initiate critical reflection on the EU, in particular through learning the EU's core values based on the rule of law and human rights.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with training and education in schools in the European Union (EU). The EU is currently facing unprecedented challenges. In recent years, the EU has experienced a major economic and financial crisis. Its social and political consequences have led to mistrust of the institutions and the common values of the Union, including the concept of EU identity.  In this context, it seems now more important than ever to promote dialogue on the EU in schools, associations and public spaces, in order to restore citizens' confidence in the benefits and importance of the European integration process. At present, citizens do not have much knowledge of the work of the EU and its institutions: according to a Eurobarometer survey conducted in spring 2014, 44% of citizens do not agree with the statement 'I understand how the EU works'. With this in mind, it is not surprising that citizens feel distant from the European political project, or they seem increasingly repellent, their Eurosceptic attitudes are growing, and they regard the Union's decision-making processes as undemocratic. The situation could be remedied if citizens were better informed about, encouraged and actively interested in the European Unification Project. One of the best ways to achieve this is to increasingly involve the EU dimension in school curricula, which would help to defeat Euroscepticism and prepare citizens to live and work in an increasingly complex globalised world.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is facing new challenges today, so it is more important than ever to have a dialogue on the European Union and its values in schools and in public life, so that citizens know the benefits and systems of the European integration process. EU citizens currently have a lack of knowledge of the European Union and the functioning of its institutions, as shown by the Eurobarometer spring 2014 survey: 44% of EU citizens do not understand how the Union works. It is no wonder, then, that citizens do not feel close to the Union and are increasingly turning away from EU policy and project. We can improve this by providing citizens with better information at school age. One way to do this is to increase the EU dimension of school education, which can prepare citizens to live in an increasingly complex and globalised world. I am convinced that in today's Europe there is an even more need to know the pillars and values of the European Union, and that knowledge and understanding of the history and values of the Union and its Member States is key to further peaceful coexistence, mutual understanding, tolerance and solidarity. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 By voting in favour, I expressed my support for the motion for a European Parliament resolution on learning about the EU in schools. I consider it very important that one of the important tasks of the education system is also to educate fully informed citizens and prepare them for life and active citizenship in increasingly complex, complex and integrated societies, whether at home or abroad. Recent polls have shown that more and more people feel they do not fully understand how the EU works, and more than 50 per cent of Europeans believe that their vote does not count in the EU. I believe that raising awareness and learning about the benefits of European policy in schools, such as the free movement of persons and services within the Union, EU mobility programmes, the benefits of the single market, etc., can contribute to the development of a sense of belonging to a common European Union. This also prevents the rise of general Euro-scepticism in the Member States and candidate countries, which stems mainly from ignorance and ignorance of the EU's functioning.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this initiative because I think it is necessary to explain to young people why the EU exists and what are the main objectives of European integration. Euroscepticism is on the rise, but the reasons for this are not rational but populist. Schools can be one way to disseminate objective information that can suppress Euroscepticism.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that people's knowledge of the European Union is extremely limited and deficient and I therefore believe that it is important for children and young people to be able to come into contact with the European world from an early age.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. Between the economic crisis, the democratic deficit and the difficulty in bringing European citizens closer to institutional mechanisms that seem increasingly distant and abstract, the European Union is now in a very precarious situation, immersed in pluralistic societies, the various components of which also show a growing unease in inter-relation and understanding each other. In this sensitive context, we strongly support the resolution 'Learning the European Union at school', which aims to encourage the relaunch of a greater European dimension within national education programmes which are often too uneven from one country to another, as well as the promotion of training tools (including, in particular, erasmus+ programmes, Europe for citizens, Creative Europe or virtual platforms such as eTwinning). , EPALE, School Education Gateway and Teacher's corner) capable of improving language skills and promoting a greater knowledge of European history, values and decision-making mechanisms.  We also hope, in this way, to further encourage the development of a healthy critical sense on the part of professors and students, capable of facilitating, by promoting their renewal, a greater understanding of the European Union and capable of promoting the development and consolidation of European citizenship and identity.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report assumes that the rise of Eurosceptic views in most Member States stems from a lack of information from citizens about European integration. To curb this phenomenon, the rapporteur proposes to focus on the European dimension in school curricula. It also calls for promoting free movement and strengthening mobility programmes in order to create a sense of belonging to the European Union. Finally included in this report is the promotion of multiculturalism. I have, of course, objected to this scandalous text. On the one hand, the proposals, formulated by the rapporteur, violate the prerogatives of the Member States in matters of education. On the other hand, this report is a veritable work of massive propaganda in favour of the European Soviet Union which goes against the fundamental principles of our society and reminds us of certain methods used by totalitarian regimes. I voted against this unacceptable text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, the EU has been facing a major financial and economic crisis. Its social and political effects have called into question the EU's common institutions and values, even the idea of European identity. Strengthening the dialogue between the EU and schools, associations and public spaces is therefore more important than ever, as it is beneficial for restoring citizens' confidence in the process and value of European integration. At the moment, citizens have very limited knowledge of the EU and how the Union institutions work. Thus, it is not surprising that citizens distance from the European political project. Citizens are becoming increasingly eurosceptic and perceive a democratic deficit in the Union's decision-making processes. I voted in favour of the report on knowledge of the European Union in schools, because I believe it is appropriate for the citizens of the Member States to be as informed as possible about the EU and its work, in order to better collaboration between citizens and the Union institutions.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 A report that is fully exploited in favour not of quality education, which of course also teaches our recent history and therefore the European Union, but in favour of uncritical support for the EU. I am voting against.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Building on the current economic, political and social context, I consider it important to introduce EU knowledge courses in schools, because awareness of the idea of European identity is needed among Union citizens. School is nothing but a mirror of society, and in a world facing rapid change, the elements that make the difference are education and research, innovation and creativity. I stress that one of the most effective ways of combating inequality and poverty is to strengthen education. According to the 2014 Eurobarometer survey, 44% of EU citizens have limited knowledge of how the Union works and 52% of citizens believe that their opinion is not taken into account. I am concerned about the low level of turnout at the last elections to the European Parliament, where only 27.8% of citizens aged 18-24 came out to vote. Therefore, in particular, the disinterest and misinformation of young people for this institution is noted. Measures must be taken to reduce the large number of people with a low level of knowledge of the European Union and to increase the employability of young people and their integrity in the workforce at both national and EU level.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Learning about the European Union in schools is of considerable importance in the current context. The rise of Euroscepticism can be partly explained by citizens' lack of understanding of the European institutions. For this reason, the European Union must be an integral part of the education of our children so that they understand from an early age the interest of the European project. This gap between the European institutions and the citizens must be closed at all costs. It is also important that we make available to our young people the necessary information about the various mobility programmes in Europe, such as Erasmus. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on 'Learning the EU at school' because I believe that it is essential to give school education throughout the Union a uniform 'European dimension'. In order to effectively build the European identity, it is necessary for students – citizens of the Union – to acquire knowledge about the functioning of its institutions from school and to learn to reflect critically on European issues. However, it is also essential to avoid disparities within Member States in the integration of the EU dimension into school education, and this reasoning concerns not only programmes (often fragmented and lacking in complementarity with other subjects taught), but also teacher training, textbooks (which do not always give due emphasis to EU issues) and teaching methods (introducing examples of EU relevance in students' daily lives). For its part, the EU must continue its work to promote language skills, active citizenship, cultural awareness and intercultural understanding through continuous financial support and wider access to mobility opportunities.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report contained some positive provisions specifically regarding the positive and proactive role that the EU can play in everyday life. However, it does not encourage critical engagement or thinking within the EU. This is absolutely crucial for any well rounded and robust learning programme. It is not simply good enough to blindly accept the authority of the EU project without it being subject to greater scrutiny and debate. If the introduction of an EU dimension into school education is being introduced, then a wider array of views must be taught to school goers than the simple assertion of the immutability of the status quo. That mind set serves no-one and it was for these reasons that I abstained on the report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Too many Europeans still know too little about the EU, which leads to a distrust in the EU institutions and the false, but growing belief that the European project is failing.  Measures need to be taken in order to change this and I voted in favour of this report as it outlines many of them, for example an adequate financial support for student exchange programmes which help greatly in the development of a European mentality and appreciation for the benefits that the EU citizenship brings. Education should be a key component in our struggle against populism and different forms of extremism.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text focusing on EU learning at school. I agree that an EU dimension in education should enable students not only to acquire knowledge and develop a sense of belonging and European citizenship, but also to engage them in critical reflection on the EU, studying its fundamental values, and in particular the rule of law and human rights, its governance and decision-making processes and how they influence the Member States.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is experiencing perhaps the most difficult and complex period in its history, not only because of the persistent economic and social crisis, but also because of the loss of public confidence in the institutions and in the European project which identified citizenship and membership of Europe as its deepest roots.  The limited public's knowledge of the functioning and role of the Union fuels the detachment and makes complex decision-making processes appear unseeded and transparent. We need to start from school and education. Many Member States have progressively integrated the EU dimension into school curricula and teacher training, and this is where we need to continue. Programmes such as Erasmus have enabled young people to develop a strong sense of belonging and feel like European citizens, and it is on this type of action that the Union must also focus in the future. Networks and virtual platforms such as eTwinning, EPALE, School Education Gateway and Teachers' Corner should be encouraged, allowing access to up-to-date and high-quality materials to give young people useful tools to learn and learn about the EU. I believe a great deal in the role of education and education in rediscovering the values and role of the institutions. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and highlight the growing importance of the European dimension in different disciplines, levels and types of education, while stressing the need for a broad and deep understanding of the idea that takes into account its complex, dynamic and multi-layered nature, with EU learning at school being the central component.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on EU learning in school is a truly innovative proposal aimed at assimilation of the idea of a united Europe, from an early age through school education.  Despite its positive elements, however, there are also weaknesses, such as the failure to mention the structural problems that currently exist in the functioning of the Union, and incorrect policies are also proposed, such as providing additional possibilities for the Commission, vis-à-vis Parliament, to implement this programme. That is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it aims to improve the dialogue between the European Union and our schools, which is a clear step towards better European integration.  I am of the opinion that the Union brings endless possibilities and it is our task to make all citizens aware of their rights and obligations by educating them from the outset in order to prepare them also to be citizens of a complex and globalised world. An education in this sense can only expand one's knowledge and values by helping to train critical and informed thinking in order to better exercise one's rights. I am of the opinion that education in this regard can only encourage intercultural dialogue by helping to combat discrimination and strengthen citizenship and to further bridge the current gap between citizens and Europe.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As many as 44% of European citizens do not understand the functioning of the EU and as such feel like their voice is neglected within the Union. It is important, especially amongst young Europeans, that they be aware of their rights and also the history of Europe. This education could be used as a tool against euro-scepticism. Although many Member States already have content on the subject of the EU included in school curricula, the content is often too general, and there is a need for consistency with other subjects being taught.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mr Draguici's report which positively underlines the role that education and school can and should play in strengthening European citizenship. We cannot, on the one hand, legally conceive of this citizenship and call for the participation of citizens and then not provide the necessary information that gives meaning to such participation. And it is not worth expressing sadness at the high abstention rates in the European Parliament elections because investment has to be made sooner. I agree with a European dimension of education and endorse the concrete proposals both in valuing successful initiatives by the Union (such as Erasmus) and within the Member States (such as curricula and study plans).

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the rapporteur's call for a stronger dialogue on the EU in our schools. People are increasingly losing confidence in the EU and distancing themselves from our policies. Europe is too far away for many.  Unfortunately, I also learn this from the school classes, which I regularly welcome here in Parliament: knowledge of Europe is not sufficiently available. We urgently need to remedy this, and we need to make a change here. We need to bring Europe closer to the people. It is the right approach to provide better information in schools about Europe and how it works.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report. We oppose any form of EU interference in Member States’ national curricula, especially with regard to the EU being better highlighted in teaching materials, disseminating EU propaganda and calling for more funding to do so. The EU has no competency in the education systems of Member States and in fact is going against Article 165 of the TFEU which states that the EU ‘fully respect the responsibility of the Member States for the content of teaching and the organisation of education systems and their cultural and linguistic diversity’.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support this report, which aims to encourage the development and promotion of a European dimension in education, which is essential to help citizens better understand and bring the European Union closer together. Only by investing in education is it possible to transmit values and to make known and understand history, essential prerequisites for mutual understanding, peaceful coexistence, tolerance and solidarity. It is also necessary to promote and encourage the multilingual and intercultural skills of children as well as educators, offering mobility opportunities, peer learning and exchanges of best practices.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Amidst the threat of radicalisation striking at the heart of shared values, it becomes even more pertinent that our youths are empowered to make the European project their own. Education on EU values, such as social inclusion, solidarity, democracy, good governance and rule of law are common treads in European culture which can facilitate students’ understanding and contribute towards the development of European societies. Most Member States teach European studies; European values and culture go beyond the study of formal structures and processes. I call upon the Commission to strengthen its contribution towards facilitating education on European values and culture by contributing towards educators’ continuous training opportunities, provide common guidelines that set  high standards in education, support networking and sharing of good practices and provide teachers with e-learning platforms and digital materials that facilitate their teaching.  Teaching European values and culture is not, however, just for the classroom, and measures of informal and non-formal education that create links between youths and the institutions, and that bring students and teachers from different Member States together, need to be strongly supported.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although students and young people are a key resource for the future of the European Union, they still know too little about Europe. Supporting the need to make the teaching of European citizenship a effectively operational element of school planning and not a subject to be dealt with episodicly in 'one-off' initiatives and projects has become necessary.  The report highlights the need to acquire knowledge about the European Union from the earliest years of school, enabling young people to learn about European values, develop a sense of belonging, also engage in critical assessments of the work of the European Union or simply 'learn more' about its institutions. Due to a lack of knowledge of EU systems, a crisis of legitimacy is taking place, the voice of European citizens is not represented enough and they have little opportunity to intervene directly in key EU issues.  Certainly, an adequate presence of EU citizenship issues in school curricula is a basic condition for the exercise of conscious and active European citizenship; That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to introduce a European dimension to education in schools to restore citizens' confidence in the European Union. But the report ignores the reasons why mistrust and discrediting citizens to the present EU has increased. With complete cynicism, the report promotes the principles and values set out in Article 2 of the EU Treaty, but does not criticise the systematic violation of these same principles within the EU territory itself. For these reasons I have not been able to vote in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution takes into account a crucial issue for the younger generation of Europe: understanding the fundamental values of the European Union and actively involving citizens in the reality of the institutions and in the concrete opportunities they offer.  I voted in favour of this resolution, because I believe that all the European institutions, with the current and candidate Member States, must respond to the widespread feeling of Euroscepticism that has been fuelled, in recent years, by a limited knowledge of the functioning and added value of the European Union on the part of the citizens. I also believe that the resolution adopted contains effective instruments to deal with this situation, including the introduction of ad hoc training programmes in schools, together with the need to have educators with intercultural, multilingual and digital skills, in step with the needs of the new generations. I fully support the role of active and participatory citizenship, which recognises cultural diversity between and in the Member States as a common wealth and values as an opportunity.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The political and economic crises that the European Union has been through have caused the inhabitants of the city to lose confidence in it. I voted for this project aimed at informing citizens and their involvement in the European unification project, because, as a Eurobarometer survey carried out in 2014 shows, 44% of those interviewed do not know the mechanisms by which the EU works.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is often said that today's students are overwhelmed with educational material, but that the education of conscious citizens has a place in education, and that eu knowledge, the history and value system of the European Union must be better acquired, and should be the curriculum of all European students. The Member States, but also the European Commission, have an essential role to play in the way in which the common values set out in Article 2 TSI are transmitted to future generations. It is very important that students also get acquainted in time with the roots of a free Europe built on common European Christian-Jewish values, its current functioning and the principles of democratic coexistence in Europe. At local level, more support and opportunities for teachers and students to learn about and pass on the EU dimension can be of particular help.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report by Damian Drăghici entitled 'Teaching about the EU in schools' expresses the hope that the actions described therein will be 'from an early age, also outside the school class', to combat the phenomenon described in the report as 'conviction of the existence of a democratic deficit' and 'widespread Euroscepticism', as well as to create a 'sense of belonging to the EU' and 'acceptance for multicultural and multinational societies'.  In order to meet such ambitions, states are required, by any means, to urgently step up so-called 'political education' aimed at Citizenship of the Union and to allocate more financial resources for this purpose. According to the document, all means and tools should be used for this. I am strongly against the very logic of the report – I believe that school teaching and after-school education are among the member states in which the Union should never interfere.  I voted against.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this report, the premise of which undermines the fact that Member States alone are responsible for the content and organisation of their education systems. This report repeatedly proposes actions that go beyond the scope of EU competence and that promote an overtly pro-EU agenda and a specifically European approach to the teaching of history. This slanted approach is a very good example of why education systems should remain firmly in the hands of Member States.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Effective implementation of the Europe for Citizens programme can and must contribute to improving citizens' participation in decision-making processes. I consider it beneficial to develop and promote on the widest possible scale the eTwinning, EPALE and School Education Gateway virtual platforms, as well as Teachers' Corner, in order to facilitate access to high-quality, easy-to-use and up-to-date teaching materials relevant to EU knowledge and available in all Union languages. In addition, the role of the information offices of the European institutions in encouraging relations with educational institutions, youth organisations and the media at national, regional and local level is beneficial, in order to ensure that young people understand the role that institutions play in their daily lives.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Many European citizens do not feel concerned about the European construction project. This distance is due to a lack of knowledge about the European Union. Based on this observation, this initiative report looks at the European dimension in education, and aims to encourage the sharing of good practices between national and European networks that participate and contribute to the learning of the European Union at different levels. Considering that education plays a key role in the sharing of knowledge and the development of a sense of belonging to the European Union, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This report, with no binding legal value, aims to develop the European dimension in education. It is important that younger people have an increased knowledge of the European Union so that they can develop language skills, cultural sensitivity and a sense of belonging as a European citizen. The various programmes put in place play an essential role in the learning of the European Union. I naturally supported this report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. For several years now, there has been a serious crisis of European confidence in European integration.  The answers are at least twofold: Europe must prove its effectiveness in responding to the major challenges it faces, and at the same time democracy must be in its operation in order for citizens to finally find their way there. This report addresses part of the issue, and proposes concrete actions to bring about a 'European identity'. It is thus recalled that the school plays a fundamental role. And proposed that the different education systems of the Member States incorporate a European approach into the programmes, especially for the history of the continent.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. This resolution is important in that it provides support and support for associations and organisations involved in the defence and promotion of the European Union.  Based on the observation that insufficient knowledge of the Union and a misunderstanding of its concrete added value can contribute to the perception of a democratic deficit and give rise to a spread of Euroscepticism in the Member States and candidate countries, this text makes a welcome reminder of all the tools and devices already in place and those that have yet to be invented to make the School the ally and vector of a shared European culture. It calls on the Commission to propose a common framework and to develop guidelines with concrete examples that would be made available to Member States. They, while respecting their competence in the field of education and training, are encouraged to do even more.  I fully share the content of this resolution, which makes schools and apprenticeships the essential starting point for the process of building European citizenship and the union's institutions.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report. We oppose any form of EU interference in Member States’ national curricula, especially with regard to the EU being better highlighted in teaching materials, disseminating EU propaganda and calling for more funding to do so. The EU has no competency in the education systems of Member States and in fact is going against Article 165 of the TFEU which states that the EU ‘fully respect the responsibility of the Member States for the content of teaching and the organisation of education systems and their cultural and linguistic diversity’.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the adoption of this report calling on Member States to strengthen the European dimension in education.  Many European citizens do not feel close to the European project. This distance is linked in particular to a lack of knowledge about the European Union. A survey shows that 44% of Europeans do not understand how the European Union works and that many feel that they cannot make their voices heard.  At a time when we are experiencing a major identity crisis and we are seeing an alarming rise in Euroscepticism everywhere, I think it is essential to better integrate the European dimension into school curricula and to integrate this dimension with the other subjects taught so that current and future generations know their rights better, learn about the history of Europe and are informed of the many ways in which they can get involved in a better Europe.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to strengthen the interest of the younger generations in the European Union, in particular by emphasizing European citizenship and denouncing Euroscepticism and populism. It is of course to forget that citizenship is intrinsically linked to nationality and therefore to nations. In order to promote Eurofederalism in school curricula, the text seems to ignore the prerogatives of Member States in education. However, the latter falls within the competence of the States, in accordance with Article 6 of the FUE Treaty. For this reason and because the instrumentalization of education for ideological purposes is not tolerable, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support this report and I will explain why. I believe that we should leave the training and training programmes to the Member States and not claim powers not provided for in the treaties. I defend the idea of subsidiarity and believe that we do not have the power to impose such advice, such as in this report on EU studies in schools in Europe.  And look at the reasons that are at stake in this report - to prevent Euroscepticism! I do not consider myself a Eurosceptic and my view is that the EU, as a political and economic community, provides many advantages that a country like mine would not have, in particular the common market and free trade. However, I believe that studying the EU and the history of the creation of the Union in order to strengthen the European belonging of citizens, as stated in the report, is not what my constituents are fighting for – we want a Europe of nations! Not federal Europe!

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. According to an opinion poll, 44% of Europeans do not understand the functioning of the EU and many feel that their voice is not heard in the European Union. According to one report, in 2013 there was already some content about the EU in most Member States at all levels of education, except for four where no mention was found in primary education. I agree that this can be corrected if citizens are better informed and encouraged to get involved and actively participate in the European unification project. To this end, it is essential to strengthen the European dimension in education in order to overcome Euroscepticism and prepare citizens to live and work in an increasingly complex and globalised world.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a nutshell, this report advocates the dissemination in advertising schools in favour of the EU. A kind of cateschet, understood to have a "crucial importance" to restore citizens' confidence "in the merits and necessity of the European integration process". In other words, citizens' lack of confidence in the EU lies in the policies it promotes and its devastating consequences on the daily lives of people, especially workers and the people, but rather the fact that people have limited knowledge about the EU and how it works. That is why we advocate a specific education, guided and formatted by "EU values", which alters the wrong perception (of course) that citizens have of the EU. Thus, the imposition of single thought from an early age is defended.
