Along the way, concepts such as the integral formation of the individual are thrown out, they will not stimulate creativity and critical thinking, when what matters is "preparing for the needs of the labor market", "vocational training". The report advocates the harmonization of the structure of knowledge and curriculum content, ignoring the specificities of the educational systems of each country. There's no point where to get this report. Obviously we voted against it.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: this is a veritable work of mass propaganda.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to strengthen the European dimension of school education in order to enable students not only to acquire knowledge and develop a sense of belonging and European citizenship, but also to engage them in a critical reflection on the EU and its fundamental values, enshrined in Article 2 TEU, primarily the recognition of the rule of law and respect for human rights.  I fully support the report's denunciation of the Union's democratic deficits, which is manifested in a growing gap between the voice of citizens and the EU institutions. In this respect, it is essential to re-establish close links with the citizens, through their greater involvement in democratic decision-making. We also agree with the need to strengthen the study of civic education in order to allow students to think critically and form informed and balanced opinions, strengthening active and responsible citizenship and encouraging intercultural, interreligious dialogue and the exercise of democratic rights and responsibilities, including the right to vote.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that promoting dialogue on the Union in our schools is crucial to restoring citizens' faith in the process of European integration, as well as to prepare citizens to live in a globalised and complex world.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – There is no doubt that we need to know a lot more about the guts of the EU, considering its impact now on our own legislation, on our lives; no doubt either this should begin as early in life as possible. But who controls the agenda, who writes the curriculum, how much will be included in that syllabus about the amount of damage the EU is doing? I abstained.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The inclusion of the European dimension in education and learning about the European Union in schools in the Member States is very important and aims to help create a sense of European citizenship, to deepen knowledge of the european Union's challenges and values, and thus to help address deepening and broad Euroscepticism across the European Union. The measures in question should enable a better understanding of the history and culture of the European Union, policy-making and decision-making, and allow critical reflection on European matters in civil and cultural dialogue. The main objective of the European Union should be to include a European dimension in education and to inform schoolchildren more about the benefits of European citizenship and to promote intercultural, non-discriminatory and inclusive education in schools and universities in the Member States of the European Union.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because this report is being used in favour of uncritical support for the EU.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on EU learning in school, as the report institutionalises the imposition of unprecedented perceptions on education, in fact it is nothing more than overt propaganda and brainwashing for pupils.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In my view this own-initiative report is very damaging. It looks to give school students a biased view of the EU.  It will force schools to give only a positive view of the EU. I strongly believe that the report strengthens the case for why education systems and curricula must remain protected from EU intervention and should remain in the hands of Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe this report is absolutely fundamental for the future of the EU, as it will introduce real concrete measures at EU level and to Members States to achieve learning EU at school. The inclusion of the European dimension in education, with learning EU at school being a crucial component, aim at creating a sense of European citizenship and at deepening knowledge of the role of EU values to tackle the widespread Euroscepticism. It will allow a better understanding of the EU’s history and culture as well as its policy-making decision process, and will enable children to critically reflect on European matters and to engage themselves in the civic and intercultural dialogue that reflects the diversity of the Union.  We must be committed to EU values and to fighting Euroscepticism. Our goal has to be including a European dimension in education to strengthen European citizenship and promote intercultural, non-discriminatory and inclusive education in school and university.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU citizens generally currently have little knowledge of the European Union and the functioning of its institutions, do not feel close to them, but rather feel distant from Brussels, the EU institutions. This can be changed by providing citizens with better information, and one of the central ways to do this is to increase the EU dimension of school education. The parts of national core curriculums with a European dimension are often too general, making it difficult for learners to get a comprehensive picture of the Union. Given its impact on citizens' daily lives, the Union should be given greater visibility in educational materials, at all levels of education and in all its forms. Examples of the EU's role in the daily lives of learners should be sought. At European level, the opportunities offered by EU programmes in the field of education and culture should be taken advantage of in order to promote language skills, active citizenship, cultural sensitivity and intercultural understanding. Wider access to the mobility opportunities provided by these programmes is essential to ensure and increase the civic awareness and civic participation of the younger generation.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I will vote in favour of this report. By bringing European identity out of the crisis, it is important in schools to have a dialogue about the European Union so that citizens can once again believe in the benefits of the European integration process. Many citizens have limited knowledge of the Union. I therefore support the need to increase the EU's visibility in textbooks and to ensure that the education of European knowledge reflects the complex relationship between the Union and the Member States: the Union has been shaped by the Member States with their own history and culture, and its development remains inseparable from the Member States.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. There is no doubt about the enormous benefits, economic, social, etc., that the existence of the EU has brought to the States and the citizens that make up it. However, the EU is a great unknown to many of our citizens, so it is more important than ever that there is a dialogue on the EU in our schools, associations and public spaces in order to restore citizens' confidence in the advantages and need of the European integration process. It is our obligation to encourage citizens to participate and be actively interested in the European unification project. For these reasons I voted in favour of the report.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes on this report because I think that all young people should have the right to learn how they are governed, and as the EU has come to play a larger and larger part of this governance it is only natural that young people’s political education should reflect this. As the report mentions a 2014 Eurobarometer poll showing that 44% of EU citizens felt that they had a limited understanding of how the EU works, I believe that this limited understanding can breed suspicion towards the EU and can drive people to populism.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Investing in the development of a civic and social responsibility of young people and contributing to the growth of a pro-European feeling that is recognised in the values of intercultural dialogue and in the fight against discrimination are essential ambitions for the European Union, which has always been the leader in promoting policies to protect human rights. That is why I am voting in favour of an increasing commitment by Europe, using dedicated funding lines and specific programmes, to encourage the growth of the sense of European citizenship, especially among the youngest, through a constant and in-depth educational path from primary schools to universities, responding with an education in inclusion, comparison and social responsibility to growing Euroscepticism.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the EP resolution 'Learning the EU at School', because today the European Union is facing a difficult and long economic crisis which is also having serious effects on the political stability of Europe and on the founding values of the Union.  The concept of a European dimension in education is essential to raise the awareness of students in the Union of the importance of developing a European value culture that takes into account the study of languages and youth mobility and the system of coordination between schools.  Taking into account the lack of knowledge of the European Union by citizens, learning at school could be a driving force for the cultural and civic dissemination of European values, through the introduction of a specific subject such as citizenship education.  Despite the instruments already available to the European Union and the Member States to promote intercultural dialogue, greater efforts are needed to ensure wider financial support for the opportunities offered by the EU.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the acquisition of knowledge about the EU in schools because, in principle, I want children and young people to be better prepared at school for a critical-constructive approach to the EU and its policies. We all benefit from it!

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I particularly like to take appointments to schools in my region to report on how the EU works and to inspire young people to come to Europe. I therefore support Parliament's resolution to harmonise the curricula on EU issues in the individual Member States and to continue to provide financial support for their implementation.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to ensure that children appropriate the flag of the European Union as a standard of allegiance from an early age.  A veritable propaganda monument against the manifest and growing wishes of another Europe, this report does not hesitate to propose the homogenisation of school curricula by incorporating a component on European citizenship and, above all, to argue that the Union would be better placed to define programmes than the Member States.  Education is one of the few areas where Member States still have exclusive competence, which provokes the ire of pro-EU MEPs, often the same people who promote gender education. This point is also addressed with the demand for education promoting multiculturalism and non-discrimination.  Our group has tabled an alternative resolution reminding that education is the exclusive responsibility of the Member States and that fundamental knowledge must take precedence over ideology.  I of course supported Dominique Bilde's proposal and voted against the Draghici report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Most of the aspects to which we have opposed are due to the vagueness of the concept of European dimension used. We are not opposed to greater information on the EU being provided at different levels of training, we believe that greater knowledge of the procedures and competences of EU bodies is clearly positive. However, we believe that it is not appropriate to confuse training with propaganda, and in this regard this report does not forese or incorporate the causes or responsibilities of the authors causing the situation of inequality in which we live in today's Europe, whereas on the contrary, it abounds in additional clarifications on the term Euroscepticism. We note the existence of positive and relevant contributions, but the general spirit of the report we believe has an objective aimed at addressing a deficit of legitimacy, such as that suffered by the European project in different regions, without to publicize the functioning, causes and consequences of the European project. For this reason our vote has been abstention.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider this report important because strengthening the dialogue about the EU in our schools, associations and public spaces is essential to restore citizens' confidence in the benefits of the European integration process. Today, citizens have little knowledge of the EU and how its institutions work, but this could change if they were better informed and encouraged to get involved. At European level, the possibilities offered by EU programmes in the field of education and culture should be fully exploited in order to improve language skills and promote the concepts of active citizenship, cultural awareness and intercultural understanding.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my fellow Labour MEPs, I abstained on this report because, although we fully support citizenship education in schools, we do not believe that it should be decided at an EU level. Education is a Member State competence, therefore it is up to Member States and regional governments, where authority lies on education policy, to determine the curriculum in schools.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. The unrecognized Europe and the victim of disaffection at the time of the European elections: this is the result of the congruous portion reserved for European affairs in education.  On the basis of this analysis and considering the definite added value of increasing awareness of the benefits of European policies such as the free movement of people and services in the Union and mobility programmes, I voted in favour of Mr Draghici's initiative report.  I am convinced that if the European democratic deficit is growing today, it is partly due to a strong lack of knowledge of what Europe does on a daily basis for our citizens. I therefore believe that the EU should be more visible and better integrated into the teaching materials and extracurricular activities organised in the Member States.  By increasing knowledge of European institutions and history, it is also a question of contributing to the development of critical reflections on the EU and of making our young people citizens engaged in the life of their city and in intercultural dialogue.  The report also recognises the role of social partners and civil society in this pedagogical work, which also deserves support at all levels.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It is increasingly important for students to gain an understanding of the mechanisms of the European construct in which they live and the growing impact of the European Union in their lives.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Enhancing dialogue about the European Union and its institutions in schools would be an innovative method for educating citizens on the European political process. Greater education on the EU would encourage EU citizens to engage with the EU institutions more frequently and simultaneously combat Euro-scepticism. Rapporteur Drăghici notes that 44% of European citizens feel that they have limited understanding of how the EU works and 52% of Europeans believe that their voice does not count in the EU. The benefits would be manifold if schools within the Union were to disseminate information regarding the functioning of EU institutions and their competences. This initiative would also help to celebrate the cultural and linguistic diversity of the EU, which, in turn would help to resolve several challenges which it faces, and for these reasons I support the motion.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of this motion as education is a key feature of European integration. It is important to continue the work currently in place and foster these European programmes to allow for the continued sharing of good practices among networks. It is beneficial that this support is urged by the report to include the continued active distribution of information on European educational programmes such as Europe for Citizens. As progress continues it is a necessity that funding is appropriately increased to ensure that EU education is available to all ages.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst there are many aspects of this report which I can support, I think that Members of this House are deluding themselves if they think that hostility to the EU can or should be ‘educated’ out of people. I support the EU and will vote in June for Scotland to remain in. However the EU has no role in directing Member States as to what should be taught in schools, and reports of this kind will do nothing positive for those of us arguing against Brexit.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, honourable Members, I supported the report on 'Training for the European Union at School' as I believe that the measures envisaged therein will improve the awareness and interest of European citizens about the European measures affecting their lives. The introduction of a study of the European Union will lead to a better understanding of its institutions and the relationship between them, the mechanisms and timing of their work, as well as to improve awareness of the rights that the Union provides to its citizens and the means of protecting them. Last but not least, training for the European Union will remind children in Europe of the historical reasons for its creation and the need to protect it in the name of our common area of justice, freedom security and solidarity.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of this report is to conclude a European dimension in education in order to strengthen European citizenship and promote intercultural, inclusive education in schools. By learning EU at school pupils would better understand their European citizenship, the EU’s cultural history as well as its policy-making decision process. I have voted in favour of this report that promotes the educational values and future networks and exchanges at all educational levels.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the SCHOOL EU Learning Report (2015/2138(INI)), as it is essential to continue with European integration, which also includes common standards on school learning about the European Union. We are witnessing that a small number of citizens know the EU, european institutions and, for example, have little knowledge of common European history.  Euroscepticism is growing, distrust of european institutions, as evidenced by numerous polls and low voter turnout in european elections. A minimum common level of education on European topics is needed, as integration is not only made up of countries, institutions, laws, the market, etc., but are primarily citizens who understand the common sense of creating a European environment.  This is important for Member States to support, revise and update their education systems and all parts of the EU-related curriculum at all levels of education. In addition to such a process, I believe that it is extremely important to include in addition to the national aspect of education the obligation to implement the regional and local dimension of education in order to preserve the local and regional dimension of the identity of citizens of the European Union in addition to "building" a European identity.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report by the Socialist MP Damian Drghici is a veritable work of massive propaganda.  It is therefore a matter of once again trying to override the prerogatives of the Member States in matters of education (which is still an exclusive competence of the States, according to Article 6 of the TFUE) in order to make our dear blonde heads good little soldiers in the pay of Euro-federalism.   Logically, my vote was against this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report. We oppose any form of EU interference in Member States’ national curricula, especially with regard to the EU being better highlighted in teaching materials, disseminating EU propaganda and calling for more funding to do so. The EU has no competency in the education systems of Member States and in fact is going against Article 165 of the TFEU which states that the EU ‘fully respect the responsibility of the Member States for the content of teaching and the organisation of education systems and their cultural and linguistic diversity’.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Lack of knowledge of the EU and its functioning is undoubtedly one of the reasons for the declining confidence of European citizens and the growing Euroscepticism. I believe that, in order to promote a better understanding of the so-called added European value and the deepening of the European identity of citizens, individual Member States should inform more and more clearly about the facts about the EU and its functioning. And it is only logical to start with the education of the youngest generation, i.e. pupils and students. I also agree with the need to help teachers in their difficult work, through training, adequate teaching materials and sufficient funding.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Damian D-heghici's report on learning about the European Union in schools.  This report aims to strengthen the European dimension in education and thus promote the values of the Union and its Member States. While emphasizing the cultural diversity of the Member States on which the EU has been built, this teaching will affirm the role of Member States in the development and influence of the Union. I support this and call on the Commission to develop a common framework and to develop guidelines to strengthen the European dimension in education.  This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. 44% of Europeans do not understand how the EU works. It is very important that young Europeans learn to be familiar with the values of the EU. This report proposes to create a common framework for Member States for a European dimension in education. It is therefore part of an effort to open up the EU and the institutions to combat Euroscepticism. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The "Learning EU in School" report foresees that in future teaching content of school teaching will be regulated uniformly across the EU. This concerns in particular the functioning of the institutions of the European Union. I strongly oppose the proposals mentioned in this report, as they are intended to violate the constitutionally regulated competence of the German Länder in the field of school education and to give pupils an undifferentiated picture of the European Union.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I agreed in principle with My colleague Drăghici's report, I could not support it in the final vote and decided to abstain. The European Parliament resolution of 12 April 2016 on teaching the EU at school was heading in a good direction, but I still consider education to be the domain of nation states. However, it is true that Member States should make a significant addition to informing the European institutions of the competences, activities and results of the work. Awareness of the possibilities provided by the EU is often pitiful and leads to the fact that, for example, subsidies are often redistributed by the same people, and especially those who do not need them (see Stork's Nest). On the other hand, I did not like the fact that Mrs Drăghici puts all the criticisms of the current functioning of the EU in the box of Eurosceptics. Personally, I consider myself a critic of the EU, but not a Eurosceptic. I believe that the current course of European integration helps large firms, banks and multinational corporations rather than citizens, who, moreover, do not have much room to do anything about the situation. I see Europe as united in order to provide Europeans with decent living conditions, and not as an opportunity for the rich to enrich even more at the expense of the majority. Am I therefore part of a Eurosceptic camp? Personally, I don't think so, and I don't want to be labeled that way.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ In the midst of social and economic challenges, it is important to enhance knowledge about the functioning and tasks of the European Union and its institutions. To that end, the present report introduces the idea of a European dimension in education. The concept embraces the promotion of learning about the EU’s history, geography and culture at school, as well as the development of skills in order for young people to live and act as citizens of pluralistic societies, without providing any harmonisation in this field.  I acknowledge some positive aspects of the report, mostly relevant to the key role of programmes like Erasmus+, the enhancement of intercultural exchanges, and training on EU topics for teachers at a national level. Nevertheless, I decided to abstain. I believe that a European dimension in education should reflect both the role of the Member States and the European Union. On this basis, I can barely see any references to the impact that the ongoing European policies and the infringement of fundamental rights within the EU have on the way in which citizens apprehend the Union nowadays.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report on the acquisition of EU knowledge at school rightly notes that little knowledge of the EU of the citizens of the Member States, but above all a sense of little impact on the EU, can have an impact on declining sympathy for the EU and low turnout in European Parliament elections. According to the 2014 Eurobarometer, 44% of EU citizens have a limited understanding of how the Union works and 52% of Europeans believe that their voice does not count. Low voter turnout is of the most concern to young people: in 2014, only 28% of 18-24 year olds took part in european elections. The development and complexity of EU ruling processes is not accompanied by an increased information campaign or a campaign involving citizens in shaping the Union; the absence of such a campaign promotes distancing ourself from the Union and the development of Eurosceptic sentiment. I share the report's thesis that European content must be included in school and higher education programmes. This also applies to the issues of European values: tolerance, non-discrimination, respect for diversity, the rights of minorities, which shape the EU on an equal footing with the common market. I support the report's call for citizens' teaching and foreign languages to be updated and disseminated in the Member States, so that they also equip pupils with knowledge of the European project and increase civic participation in the EU.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have expressed my positive opinion on this innovative proposal, which concerns learning about EU history and values in schools, including teacher training and the promotion of a multilingual and multicultural culture that promotes coexistence, integration and the creation of an active population.  In a society in which borders are narrowed by mobility, made possible by our policies and initiatives, it is essential that children and young people are educated on this system of integration and fully acquire its principles. Only through investment in school education, and on the EU's founding values, will we be able to create pillars for the economic, political and socio-cultural progress of this Europe, making an essential contribution to strengthening a solid European identity.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 More targeted, attractive, more thoughtful teaching about the European Union, its principles, values and history in the schools of the European Union are fully in line with the educational objectives and the need to deepen each other's knowledge of history and the EU. The European Parliament calls for better use of existing EU instruments and closer cooperation at Member State level by promoting links between educational institutions, educators and learners in different EU countries. Lessons on the EU through technical, financial, mobility and innovation opportunities can become one of the most interesting topics and the most attractive ways to develop critical thinking and active citizenship from an early age.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I was not able to participate in the votes of the report "Learning the European Union in School" as I was called to participate in the Conference of Presidents, which took place during the votes.  However, I would like to take advantage of this explanation of vote to express my opposition to this report. This report, written by the Socialist MP Damian Drghici, is a veritable work of massive propaganda. Once again, it is a question of trying to override the prerogatives of the Member States in matters of education (which is still an exclusive competence of the States under Article 6 of the TFUE) in order to make our dear blonde heads good little soldiers in the pay of Euro-federalism.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it seeks to strengthen EU propaganda in schools. Unfortunately, this work of indoctrination of our children was adopted by 482 votes to 146, despite the efforts of FN MP Dominique Bilde, who had tabled a very nice counter-proposal, where it was recalled that the priority of schools should be the acquisition of fundamental knowledge (reading, writing), as well as the revaluation of national history and culture.

name: Andrew Lewer (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The decision of the British Conservatives to vote against MEP Drăghici’s ‘Learning EU at school’ report reflects deep concerns about its overall premise and content. Its proposals go well beyond the supporting competence of the EU in the area of education, advocating a concerted effort by the Commission, Parliament and Member States to put more positive content about the EU into national curricula, rather than giving young people the necessary tools to develop their own conclusions. UK legislation requires schools to deal with political issues, including consideration of the EU, in a balanced way. It is up to schools to decide how to achieve this and for Member States alone to decide the content and organisation of their education systems. In addition, we profoundly disagree with the report’s assumption that either pro-or anti-EU views are rooted in ignorance, or what is, or is not, taught in schools. The European Parliament must stick to supporting policy and best-practice exchange on education amongst Member States, where the EU can add real value.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text put to the vote is the very demonstration of European propaganda and its interference in all national areas, in particular education.  Under the guise of combating major threats such as Euroscepticism, xenophobia, populism, the report promotes absurd new measures. This would strengthen European citizenship by deepening the harmonisation of school curricula in the European Union, strengthening teacher and teacher training in this area, strengthening the participation of pupils and parents in school governance, etc.  A whole set of proposals that violate the sovereignty of each Member State, whose education is a recognised competence in Article 6 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFUE).  So I voted against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to introduce a European dimension to education in schools to restore citizens' confidence in the European Union. But the report ignores the reasons why mistrust and discrediting citizens to the present EU has increased. With complete cynicism, the report promotes the principles and values set out in Article 2 of the EU Treaty, but does not criticise the systematic violation of these same principles within the EU territory itself. For these reasons I have not been able to vote in favour.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. A large majority of Europeans are unfortunately unaware of the functioning and relevance of the European institutions and tend to perceive a certain democratic deficit in them. This has two terrible consequences: on the one hand, the low participation of European citizens in European electoral processes and, on the other hand, the growth of so-called Euroscepticism. That is why, from Parliament and through this report, we propose that in European schools the knowledge of the European Union be strengthened, that children develop the feeling of European citizenship, that they understand what it means to be European and the fact that they share, as fundamental values, the defence of the rule of law and human rights. To this end, we propose that the Commission, among other issues, continue to maintain and increase the funding of education and mobility programmes and to develop a common framework for learning on the Union. We also ask Member States to use all means at their disposal to promote a high profile among their teachers in the knowledge of the European Union. From the above, my vote will be favorable.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The "Learning EU in School" report foresees that in future teaching content of school teaching will be regulated uniformly across the EU. This concerns in particular the functioning of the institutions of the European Union. I strongly oppose the proposals mentioned in this report, as they are intended to violate the constitutionally regulated competence of the German Länder in the field of school education and to give pupils an undifferentiated picture of the European Union.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The proposal calls for the spread of EU propaganda in schools: 'The EU should be more visible and better integrated into teaching materials and extracurricular interest', pupils should 'develop their sense of belonging and skills of European citizenship' in schools, teachers should include the 'Union dimension' in teaching, a 'European approach to teaching history' is to be promoted, 'EU-related civics' should be strengthened to 'promote intercultural and interreligious dialogue'.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ According to a 2014 Eurobarometer opinion poll, Since 2010, 44% of EUROPEAN Union citizens believe that they have limited understanding of how the EU works, 52% of Europeans believe that their voice in the EU has no weight, and insufficient knowledge of the European Union and its concrete added value can contribute to creating an image of the lack of democracy and leading to pervasive Euroscepticism in Member States and candidate countries.  Most Member States have integrated teachers' training curricula into their curricula for teaching about the EU. The report highlights the need to strengthen the visibility of the European Union in teaching materials and extracurricular activities and to strengthen integration, given the impact it has in the daily lives of its citizens.  The EU dimension in education should enable learners not only to gain knowledge and develop a sense of belonging and European citizenship, but also to participate in critical thinking about the EU, including through learning about: the EU's core values based on the rule of law and human rights, governance and decision-making processes in the EU, and how they affect Member States and their own democratic participation. I supported this report because it highlights the importance of better understanding the functioning of the European Union, understanding EU decisions and how they affect citizens' daily lives, resulting in better social integration and strengthening of European values.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament's report on training for the European Union in school. I had the opportunity to participate in its preparation as rapporteur for the European People's Party.  I am convinced that the European Union must be studied at school not in terms of its functioning, but through the rights and freedoms it provides to young people. Each Member State should draw up a methodology based on its own experience, because only through knowledge and overcoming history can we explain the reasons for the existence of the Union as it is today and the benefits of our membership there.  Member States are responsible for their education systems, but the Union supports them in setting common objectives and exchanging good practices. One of these objectives and ideas is the inclusion of Europe and the European Union in school subjects. The Committee on Culture and Education in the European Parliament believes that there is a need to deepen the examination of EU issues in order to shorten the distance between Europe and its citizens.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Persistent regional disparities, unemployment, the refugee crisis, together with a lack of information on the functioning of the Union and its authorities, are causing an increase in Euroscepticism, populism and extremism in Europe. There is an increasing distrust and distrust of the population in the EU. According to surveys, 44% of respondents do not know how the EU works. If the Member States and the Union do not take immediate reforms in the field of EU education, the resolution of European active citizenship issues and European integration will be jeopardised. The Commission must make every effort to integrate eu issues and its functioning into the education system and inform Member States about the possibilities for funding curricula and training teachers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on EU learning at school because it is complete and documented.  Furthermore, I note that in the last elections to the European Parliament only 42.61% of citizens and 27.8% of young people aged 18 to 24 voted, which is due, not so much to the lack of learning about the functioning of the EU at school, but above all to the extremely unpopular, neoliberal austerity policies imposed by the EU on its Member States. It is also due to the anti-grassroots action of the troika in Greece and other countries of the Memorandum.  Deepening and clarifying school curricula in matters relating to the functioning of the EU can be useful if teachers' approaches are fully objective and combined with a critical approach to European institutions and the decisions they initiate. In particular, EU learning at school should not be used as a means of counterfeiting the history of member states and adopting unspeakable narratives about European integration. Before taking the initiative on controversial education reforms, the EU must put an end to the continued flattening of its democratic structures and the weakening of the peoples of Europe by lenders.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This is a further interference by the European Union in the Member States' own competences, in this case, in education.  According to the report, the rise of Euroscepticism is the result of a lack of information from "European citizens" on the benefits of the European Union. For example, national education systems should be mobilised in order to develop, from the first classes, training programmes on the functioning of the European Union and its 'values', in particular 'multiculturalism and non-discrimination'. More seriously, the report calls for the eventual harmonisation of primary and secondary education systems, based in particular on the principle of increased participation by parents of pupils and pupils themselves. Nothing very gratifying, at a time when teachers are facing exceptional difficulties in carrying out their missions.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We must convey the true European values from the beginning of our education and make ourselves against the fact that in our schools we are training the next generation of European citizens and we must ensure that they arrive well prepared to contribute to the growth of our Union.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The incorporation of a European dimension into education is essential to help citizens better understand the EU and continue to support this project. The EU should have greater visibility and be better integrated into educational materials and extracurricular activities. And we need to use all active and participatory teaching methods tailored to the age, levels, needs and interests of pupils, as well as take full advantage of the opportunities provided by information and communications technologies and the media, including social media, as outlined in the motion for a resolution on the acquisition of knowledge about the EU in school , to which I openly.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Education is an important tool in educating and informing EU young people by making them active citizens within today's multicultural and complex societies. In view of the current challenges facing the EU, the integration of EU teaching programmes into schools can help restore European citizens' confidence in the Union and the common European vision. Properly informing citizens from an early age can reduce the indifference and alienation that is currently being observed with regard to the functioning of the EU and the phenomenon of Euroscepticism.  The need for measures in the field of education is immediate, as 44% of European citizens feel they have a limited understanding of how the EU works and 52% believe that their opinion does not count, according to a Eurobarometer poll in 2014. Therefore, learning the various aspects of the EU in schools, aspects that include not only economic policy issues, but also the social and cultural opportunities that the Union offers young people, will help to better and more fully understand the principles and values of the EU, such as peaceful coexistence, solidarity and respect for human rights.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The history of European integration and the functioning of its institutions are necessarily an integral part of the history of the States that compose it. However, here the objective is clear, it is to teach the EU to develop the "feeling of European citizenship and pro-European attitude" in the face of the risk of "spreading Euroscepticism". The report assumes that the EU's "crisis of democratic legitimacy" is in fact due to "inadequate knowledge" of citizens, not to its anti-democratic functioning.  So a history course on the 2005 referendum on the European Constitutional Treaty will have to explain to the children how their parents were wrong in opposing it? Or even ignore this historical episode?  At the same time, Parliament stresses the need for education that is accessible to all or training for teachers and calls on 'Member States to increase investment in quality education', but even then it is the usual blah blah that wants to 'strengthen partnerships with the private sector'.  I am voting against such a biased teaching of the European Union.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite growing Euroscepticism in the Member States, Europeanist hysteria continues in the European Parliament. This phenomenon is therefore understood as being only a lack of communication to citizens. According to this report, the sense of European belonging and the ideal of integration among the younger generations must therefore be strengthened.  Education tends to become an exclusive prerogative of the EU in this report. There are plans to promote multiculturalism, non-discrimination and a Europe of 'mobility'. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report "Learning about the EU at school". According to a Eurobarometer opinion poll conducted in 2014, 44% of EU citizens believe they misunderstand how the EU works and 52% of Europeans believe that their voice is not heard in the EU. There is clearly insufficient knowledge about the EU. That is why education about the EU at school makes perfect sense, so that the common values of the Union and the European identity can be given to it. It is very important to strengthen the European dimension in education in order to overcome Euroscepticism.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution which aims to improve knowledge about the Union at an early stage. By educating students about our Union and preparing citizens we can make it easier for them to contribute to the policy-making process and reduce the European Union’s perceived democratic deficit.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Research has shown that 44% of citizens feel they do not know how Europe works. 52% of the citizens of Europe also think that their vote does not count in the EU. The EU is still not well known. It is plausible that this sometimes leads to confusion, disillusionment and misunderstanding about the functioning of the EU. It is therefore advisable to bridge the information gap that has arisen between the inhabitants of Europe and the European institutions. Education is an important lever to help young people close that gap and better understand the EU. In order to better understand the impact of the EU on people's daily lives, this report calls for a more intense and visible integration of the EU dimension into the teaching material. In addition to the transfer of knowledge about Europe, it is desirable to teach young people skills that promote European citizenship. In this way, young people are taught to think critically about European decision-making while at the same time promoting the EU's sense of community and fundamental values.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – I have been a Member of the European Parliament for many years. During that time, I have met a huge number of people I speak to and find out what their feelings and problems are. I also often ask about their opinion of the European Union, and I have to say that I am increasingly seeing their negative attitude, including among young people. We know that there is a sharp increase in the number of Eurosceptics in the European area, and we are no wonder, because they are concerned about a number of problems that go unnoticed from their point of view, even though we are dealing with them. This is based on the fact that they do not understand how the European Union works. They don't even have basic knowledge! In schools, young people learn things about the Union that are distant from them. They do not see in any way that they are members of such a proud community. I find it sad that today's young people do not know personalities such as Konrad Adenauer or Robert Schuman, and in doing so, without their help, we would not live in the peace and stability that we take for granted! It is essential that teaching in schools in this area be united in order to contribute to making young people aware of their rights and responsibilities, how charming the idea of establishing the Union has been, so that the efforts of these great personalities are not in vain.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the report on the acquisition of knowledge about the European Union in school. We must ensure that our young people gain a better understanding of the European Union. Deep down, only what is known can be valued. It is therefore necessary to encourage young people to know the process of European construction. This will also contribute to the creation of a sense of belonging to the Union and also to the overcoming of radical nationalisms. I think it would be useful if a specific subject on the background, objectives and functioning of the institutions of the European Union were included in the high school studies — or equivalents .

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on learning EU at school because I believe that the inclusion of the European dimension in education, with learning EU at school being a crucial component, aims to help create a sense of European citizenship, and deepen knowledge of the role of EU values to tackle the widespread Euroscepticism. It will allow a better understanding of EU history and culture as well as its policy-making decision process, and enable children to critically reflect on European matters and became engaged in the civic and intercultural dialogue that reflects the diversity of the Union.  The report highlights the role of the Union and Member States, calling for guidelines and a common framework to promote learning EU at school, enhance existing and future networks exchanges at all educational levels and focus on curricula, teacher training, teaching methods, mobility, research and the use of new technologies. It also recognised the role played by social partners and civil society organisations.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has been through a serious economic and financial crisis in recent years, the social and political effects of which call into question the raison d'ediability of the institutions and the common values of the Union, and with it the concept of European identity. In this respect, it is now more important than ever for citizens to once again believe in the benefits and necessity of the European integration process. By comparison, only 42.61% of EU citizens and only 27.8% of 18-24 year olds voted in the last European Parliament elections, the lowest turnout since 1979. According to a Eurobarometer poll in 2014, 44% of EU citizens feel that their knowledge of how the EU is functioning is limited and 52% believe that their views do not matter in the EU. The report of the Committee on Culture and Education points out that a lack of knowledge about the Union can create a feeling of democratic deficit and lead to the spread of Euroscepticism in the Member States. However, increasing the EU dimension of school education can help combat Euroscepticism. The report states that, under the conditions created by the Maastricht Treaty, which delegates the content of the curriculum and the organisation of the education system to the exclusive competence of the Member States, and explicitly excludes the harmonisation of the laws and regulations of the Member States, how to achieve a strengthening of the EU dimension of school education. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report by the Socialist MP Damian Drghici is a veritable work of massive propaganda.  The aim is to try to override the prerogatives of Member States in education (which is still an exclusive competence of states under Article 6 of the EUF) in order to indoctrinate young people.   The premise is that the rise of Eurosceptic views, a real danger to the EU, is coming from a lack of information from citizens about the Construction of Europe and its so-called benefits.   Clearly, it is not a duty of education and objective information, it follows the political goals that have nothing to do in schools.  The vote is therefore clearly negative.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to a Eurobarometer opinion poll conducted in 2014, 44% of EU citizens feel that they misunderstand how the EU works and 52% of Europeans believe that their voice is not heard in the EU. It is important to note that insufficient knowledge of the EU can contribute to the perception of a democratic deficit and lead to widespread Euroscepticism in the Member States. Education must have a European dimension, with the aim of helping its citizens to better understand and bring the EU closer to life. The EU should be more visible and well integrated into teaching materials and extracurricular activities, given its impact on citizens' daily lives, and the inclusion of EU-related content can substantially enhance school programmes and pupils' personal development and growth. I support the decisive role of Member States in implementing the European dimension of education systems and all types of EU-related curricula at all levels of education, including vocational education and training.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, a massive propaganda work, offers a methodical and general learning of the supposed benefits of the EU from an early age, at school, to enable the EU to contain Euroscepticism and populism. The text proposes to override the exclusive competence of States in education (Article 6 TFUE) to increase the effectiveness of the teaching of European-based doxa by harmonising school curricula in particular in this very political area. I therefore voted against this socialist and propagandist resolution.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Labour Party abstained on this report because, although we fully support citizenship education in schools, we do not believe that it should be decided at an EU level. Education is a Member State competence, therefore it is up to Member States and regional governments, where authority lies on education policy, to determine the curriculum in schools.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to encourage learning about how the European Union works in schools. In particular, I support the provisions which emphasise the cultural diversity of the Member States on which the European Union has been built, and which show that the European Union must be a Europe of nations, with different but complementary identities, which must be made to be discovered.  In this context, I welcome the presence in this report of a desire to strengthen and expand Erasmus programmes, Europe for citizens, creative Europe or the European voluntary service which participate in the acquisition of language skills and which enable the culture of each Member State to be valued.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Eurostat, 52 % of European citizens believe that their item does not count in the EU and 44 % say they have a limited understanding of the functioning of the EU. The turnout at the last European elections was, of course, low: these figures should make us reflect.  Convinced that the legitimacy of every democracy depends on the active participation of its citizens in the res publica, I wanted to support this report, which includes the European dimension in educational projects as a fundamental tool to help promote a sense of European citizenship and to counter a Euroscepticism that risks thinking about tomorrow by proposing an anti-historical, unreal return to a past that is not repeatable today. Accompanying young people in critical reflection on European events and issues makes them part of civil, political and intercultural dialogue that reflects diversity, but at the same time the EU union, that is, the key principle of unity in diversity.  Knowledge and understanding of the history and common values of the EU and its Member States are, in fact, a key factor in mutual understanding, peaceful coexistence, tolerance and solidarity.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report "Learning the European Union in School". This initiative report aims to strengthen the European dimension in education.  Education is fundamental to spreading values to citizens as well as knowledge. Lack of knowledge about European integration can contribute to the perception of a democratic deficit and the spread of Euroscepticism.  The rapporteur therefore wants the EU to encourage the launch of new local, national and European initiatives to bring the EU closer to its citizens and improve understanding of the integration process. However, the report respects subsidiarity in the competence of the European Union in the field of education.  The report also stresses the cultural diversity of the Member States on which the EU has been built. The role of Member States in the development and influence of the Union must play an important role in EU education in schools.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly support Drăghici's report on teaching and raising awareness of European issues at school. At a time when Europe is facing essential challenges for the growth and development of the European political project, it is important to promote a European culture and sense among young people, particularly in schools and associations. The project, through information and culture, is a useful tool to combat feelings of Euroscepticism based on disinformation.  The proposal to include the dissemination of a European dimension in school education by establishing a common teaching guideline for all Member States, based on different intercultural instruments and continuous refresher courses, is therefore an essential opportunity to train a conscious generation of future European citizens. It is therefore essential to use information as a means of involving and encouraging citizens to engage and take an active interest in the project of European integration. Only in this way, with the active participation of citizens, with the circulation of information, with the promotion of a European culture from school age, will it be possible to pursue the great project of the formation of the European Union, which already sees us as protagonists.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of the rise of absurd and dangerous anti-European discourse, devoid of meaning of reality and ignoring the many advantages that the European Union provides us, we have a responsibility to train our youth, to pass on our values to them.  Parliament's position, which I share, is that of promoting the European Union in schools. We also call on the European Commission to communicate more widely on education programmes such as Erasmus Plus or Europe for Citizens, as well as to promote the mobility of education actors. Only in this way will we be able to strengthen the European integration process.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has faced a major economic and financial crisis in recent years, the social and political effects of which call into question the Union's common institutions and values, including the concept of European identity. There is therefore a need to strengthen the DIALOGUE on the EU in our schools and associations in order to restore public confidence in the substance and necessity of the Process of European Integration. That is why I voted to make this report which highlights aspects such as the recognition of the essential role of EU learning at school and the importance of knowledge and understanding of the history and common values of Europe and the Member States.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main role of education is to educate consciously thinking, active citizens with basic knowledge of the functioning, role and added value of the European Union. The best way to achieve this is to smuggle a little European civic education into the education systems of the Member States, thereby attracting the interest of students and boosting the dialogue on the EU. In this way, we will ultimately be able to bring the European Union, often referred to as 'far away', closer to its citizens, the positive impact of which is likely to be seen in the increase in the number of people taking part in elections. At the same time, we are creating an opportunity to regain people's trust and to eminent Euroscepticism.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU faces unprecedented challenges after experiencing major economic and financial crisis. The social and political effects call into question the institution and common values of the Union. I have voted for this report that will progressively integrate an EU dimension into educational curricula and into teachers’ training.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament resolution on EU knowledge in school, because the EU should be more visible and better integrated into teaching materials and extra-curricular activities, with the introduction of a European dimension in education being essential to help citizens better understand the Union. I believe that the possibilities offered by digital technologies must be made the most of in order to develop cross-border teaching and the exchange of best practices. We call on the Commission to develop and promote existing virtual platforms as widely as possible and to continue to support and develop other digital platforms (dedicated to teachers and pupils) in order to facilitate access to high-quality, user-friendly and up-to-date teaching materials relevant to EU knowledge and available in all Union languages. We encourage Member States to increase investment in the quality of education, including through strengthening partnerships with the private sector, promote universal equality of opportunity and provide the necessary support to all educational and training institutions, teachers and other educators, so that they are able to introduce and continuously develop a European dimension in education.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report by my colleague Damian Drăghici, because I am certain that, at the heart of any society, but especially of the European Union, the education system must lie. Since a good part of European citizens do not know how the EU works, have insufficient knowledge of the Member States and do not exercise their right to vote in elections to the European Parliament, I am convinced that, by adopting the measures provided for in this report, we will take important steps towards knowledge, understanding and, above all, tolerance. I am pleased that today's report insists on the introduction of a European dimension into the educational curriculum, with the aim of gaining knowledge about the EU. I also appreciate the fact that Member States are invited to take further measures to promote the benefits of education, of understanding citizenship characterised by interculturality; we can acquire values, principles like non-discrimination and social inclusion by modernising the education system in our countries. I consider this report absolutely beneficial and I believe that it is, by what it is, a basic pillar for creating a legitimate sense of European citizenship.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of this report. The European Union is not only a member state, but also a community of citizens. It is therefore important that future generations are also given adequate information on the union's core values, history and functioning, so that they can become responsible citizens of the Union. I also consider it particularly important that students learn about the history and culture of other Member States and of minorities in Europe. To this end, I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe in the need for the European dimension in education, given the huge impact of the EU in citizens' daily lives. The EU needs to be more visible and better integrated into learning materials and extracurricular activities – this would help to further understand and promote attachment to its core values. The EU is going through a crisis of its democratic legitimacy, but this would be a logical way of restoring and strengthening the Union's relationship with its citizens. The report also highlights the important role of Erasmus+, Europe for Citizens and Creative Europe in promoting education and training, language skills, active citizenship, cultural awareness and intercultural understanding. These programmes undoubtedly help to strengthen European citizenship and it is necessary to provide adequate financial support for these programmes.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I think the basic idea is very good, because a lot of citizens know little about the European Union and its functions. In my opinion, knowledge does not harm, so the EU should appear in textbooks. It is important that the information is conveyed completely free of value. In my opinion, the report conveys exactly the opposite, this is just non-value-free EU propaganda. That is why I voted against this report. I am opposed to the introduction of EU propaganda into classrooms and that it is financed by various sectors.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote the learning in schools of the European Union, its values and its functioning. The report also supports European training actions such as Erasmus and promotes exchanges of good practices between Member States on learning about Europe.  The history of Europe, its values, is an integral part of the history of today's European citizens and its learning is important for the development of everyone's critical sense.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – Education must remain within the competence of each Member State. Socio-economic conditions vary from country to country, and national authorities play a crucial role in determining education programmes. Only they can properly assess the improvements needed in the field of the content of school teaching and primary teacher training. It should be noted that citizens must be encouraged not only to learn about the EU, but must be given priority over the history of their country. Only by acquiring sufficient knowledge can they properly understand the process of building Europe. In this context, it is important to promote dialogue on the benefits and importance of the European integration process in the EU's schools, associations and public spaces, in order to restore citizens' confidence in the european integration process. I believe that the Commission must continue to promote the mobility of education representatives and actively disseminate information to key stakeholders and citizens.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Further strengthening the EU's propaganda mechanism by seeking to infuse pupils and teachers from the so-called "values" of large capital, in the name of so-called "European consciousness", the report on "learning about the EU at school" seeks. The Communist Party voted against it, stressing that the unpopular policy of the EU and governments that brings unemployment, work with hunger wages to the deep old age and poverty are not being built.  The report brings to science the "brainwashing" of "adaptability to market needs" with perpetual skill hunting, "lifelong learning" for the profits of business groups.  "Within matter" means the justification of imperialist interventions leading to refugee while the role of an active propagandist of these blood-covered EU "values" is intended for teachers in the context of their "lifelong professional development" and their evaluation of the "Core" of the EU indoctrination is the rewriting of the history of peoples with anti-communism in which the "special programmes for pupils and teachers" from the "House of European History" will take the lead. With meaningful discussion in schools, the operation to "niceise" the EU's wolf alliance could fall into limbo. The peoples have the power to overthrow the power of monopolies, to free themselves from the vise of the EU, paving the way for their interests.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report prepared by the Committee on Culture and Education on the promotion and learning of EU actions by member states' education systems and the latter's call on the EU Commission to take a legislative initiative immediately. Among other things, the report clearly states that the EU is going through a period of crisis in terms of its democratic legitimacy, not only because of the lack of knowledge by European citizens of EU mechanisms, but also because of the limitations of their participation in decision-making processes.  At a time of intense Euroscepticism, therefore, the introduction of a more European dimension in the field of education can be a key factor in maintaining EU cohesion.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report. We oppose any form of EU interference in Member States’ national curricula, especially with regard to the EU being better highlighted in teaching materials, disseminating EU propaganda and calling for more funding to do so. The EU has no competency in the education systems of Member States and in fact is going against Article 165 of the TFEU which states that the EU ‘fully respect the responsibility of the Member States for the content of teaching and the organisation of education systems and their cultural and linguistic diversity’.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the serious economic and financial crisis facing European countries has called into question the "sense of Europe" among citizens. Given that, in the absence of action to bring citizens closer to the European institutions, the European identity is being put to the test. Given that the promotion of the European dimension in schools is a valuable tool for bringing citizens closer to the EU.  Given that according to a 2014 Eurobarometer survey, 44 % of European citizens said they did not know how the European Union works. Given the many efforts made so far to create a 'European citizenship' in the strict sense. Given the importance of informing young people about the functioning of the EU and encouraging them to reflect on European issues, it can be an effective way of training and educating today's young people to become protagonists in the Europe of tomorrow. Given that the Member States are called upon to play a central role in this process of European revival and that, although many countries have already integrated the European dimension into school curricula and teacher training, there are still many disparities, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I supported this resolution because I believe that education on knowledge of the EU's common history contributes to a better understanding of our different cultures and traditions, all of which contribute to the unity of our vibrant and numerous community of nations. In addition to educating children about the history of the EU, it is necessary to encourage critical thinking and social awareness in every EU citizen.  I welcome the resolution, as it calls on the Commission to continue to support efforts to develop and promote different dimensions of the EU through education and the mobility of education stakeholders. In addition, I consider it necessary to encourage better use of new communication technologies and media, including social media.  According to Eurobarometer data from 2014, 44% of European Union citizens think they have limited understanding of how the EU works, which also affects citizens' turnout in European Parliament elections. The lack of interest and will contributes to creating an image of the lack of democracy and leads to Euroscepticism. Croatia is one of seven countries where the 2014 elections to the European Parliament have increased, although it is still a very low exit.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is an interesting example of Europeanism: it attacks a competence that is completely outside the European Union's jurisdiction, education, to transform the school into a genuine European propaganda centre.  It therefore is doubly damaging to democracy, on the one hand by not respecting the sovereignty of the Member States and the principle of subsidiarity, on the other hand by considering that citizens must be ideologically formatted from childhood.  The school should be a place of knowledge where students acquire knowledge and not an officiine that distorts the process of building a political consciousness. Such instrumentalization of schooling is usually found only in the worst dictatorial regimes that humanity has known.  I am obviously voting against this liberticidal text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it recognises one of the main challenges that the European Union has not yet resolved, that of the concept of identity. The economic crisis and the resulting crisis of representativeness have made this area of reflection around Europe more slippery by requiring a rethink of the instruments of integration and democratisation of ideas. In an attempt to recreate a European public space and restore public confidence in the relevance and inevitability of this process, education plays a major role. Promoting European education means, in practical terms, providing the teaching and dissemination of the languages of the Member States, strengthening actions to promote the mobility of students and teachers and promoting cooperation between educational establishments. The Union can also promote the exchange of information on Member States' education systems and best practices, encourage civic engagement and the participation of young people in democratic life in Europe. Pillars of this process of European education must be, on the one hand, the acquisition of knowledge relating to European geography, its history and culture, and the functioning of its institutions; on the other hand, to promote education in European citizenship, which is the foundation of any democratic political system.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Education is a fundamental human right and public good, whose main role is to form fully conscious citizens and prepare individuals for life and active citizenship in increasingly complex, demanding and integrated societies that are also increasingly multicultural. As in 2014 44% of EU citizens felt they had limited understanding of how the EU works, and 52% of Europeans felt that their voice in the EU lacked any weight, I want to highlight the growing importance of the European dimension in education in various disciplines, levels and types of education.  In particular, I underline that the EU dimension in education should enable learners not only to gain knowledge and develop a sense of belonging and European citizenship, but also to participate in critical thinking about the EU. In the context of the social and political impacts of the crises facing the EU recently, strengthening dialogue in schools, associations and other public spaces seems more important than ever. For this reason, I welcome the report on EU learning in schools, as the inclusion of the European dimension in education empowers European citizenship and promotes intercultural, non-discriminatory and inclusive education in schools and universities.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Defends this report that they are conscious, distorting reality and painting, with the most vivid colors, the so-called values of the capitalist integration project that is the European Union, an inevitable condition for changing the "wrong" perception of the majority of citizens about the EU. In what way? Deepening in the EU the harmonisation of skewed and single-thinking education programmes; promoting the benefit of the neoliberal policies imposed on the Member States; developing policies based on a logic of privatisation and underfunding of education, an insufficient pre-school network, the centralisation of schools and the apology of a school and teaching at the service of market interests; preventing the integral formation of the individual to enhance his creativity and the elevation of individual and collective consciousness. The dynamics of progressive transformation of societies have always passed through the affirmation of the secular state at school. Those that today require the necessary affirmation of the sovereignty of states and peoples to decide their own direction and national development project, free from the corset of impoverishment and austerity policies that the EU has imposed. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support Damian Drăghiti's report on EU learning in schools. The fact that, according to a 2014 Eurobarometer opinion poll, 52% of Europeans think their vote in the EU has no weight is really problematic. Only 42.61% of EU citizens voted in the last European Parliament elections, indicating a lack of information about the European Union, which can lead to a picture of a lack of democracy and growing Euroscepticism in the Member States. Therefore, I consider it necessary to exchange dialogue on the EU in schools, society and public spaces in order to restore the faith of our citizens in the European project. We need to start from the youngest generations by increasing education about the EU in schools that will help them live and work in a complex and globalised world. I am aware that this entails large investments, but only in this way will we reduce the gap between the vote of EU citizens and the EU institutions.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The lack of awareness of the functioning of the European Union and the roles of its institutions has a direct impact on the growth of Euroscepticism in the Member States and candidate States. It is a sad result that less than half of citizens, especially young people, came to the last elections. It is precisely because of this erosion of democratic legitimacy and the widening of the democratic deficit that it is important to reverse the negative trend of non-use of the right to vote. Deeper teaching on European history and context will enable the creation of the knowledge base needed to participate in society and critical reflection. I am therefore of the opinion that Member States should establish a common framework on the basis of which, for example, improvements in teaching, mobility at all levels of education, teacher training, research and the use of new technologies should be improved.
