Education on European affairs goes hand in hand with increasing the necessary intercultural tolerance, solidarity, respect for the rule of law and other principles of our democratic heritage. If teaching about the European Union improves, citizens will be able to make not only a democratic but also an informed choice at the next elections. They will also reduce the chances of succumbing to the radical and nationalist attitudes that historically have always led Europe into conflicts of war.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is part of our daily lives. However, in this turbulent time of economic, financial and refugee crisis, the importance of European integration and the EU's fundamental values is being questioned. I believe that these causes, together with citizens' lack of knowledge of the functioning of the EU, are grounds for improving their awareness. The proposal to introduce EU-related teaching will provide students with insight into the processes of adopting European legislation and the overall functioning of the EU. Such an approach will improve their critical-analytical thinking in relation to media reports and will thus be able to better distinguish truthful information from those fabricated. I believe that teaching about the EU will also lead to an increase in citizens' interest in EU affairs, reduce growing Euroscepticism, allow for better formulation of factual criticism, while preparing citizens for life and work in an increasingly complex and globalised world. Pupils and students need to be presented with an overall picture of the EU in order to create a comprehensive picture of how the EU affects and affects their daily lives. Awareness of the EU is just as important as, for example, teaching history, as it is part of our history and today's reality. And we should not forget that.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 European citizens currently have limited knowledge about the EU and the functioning of its institutions. That is why I believe that strengthening the knowledge of the new generations is a priority for the EU. We therefore need targeted action from schools. Promoting a European dimension within school curricula can help overcome Euroscepticism and prepare citizens to live and work in an increasingly complex and globalised world. Also thanks to my vote in favour today, I hope that all Member States will take new actions to promote education that values the common European identity and that can give young people the pride of belonging to a great civilisation.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report by Damian Drăghici entitled 'Teaching about the EU in schools' expresses the hope that the actions described therein will be 'from an early age, also outside the school class', to combat the phenomenon described in the report as 'conviction of the existence of a democratic deficit' and 'widespread Euroscepticism', as well as to create a 'sense of belonging to the EU' and 'acceptance for multicultural and multinational societies'. In order to meet such ambitions, states are required, by any means, to urgently step up so-called 'political education' aimed at Citizenship of the Union and to allocate more financial resources for this purpose.  This includes all means and tools: teaching materials, textbooks and school programmes (EU history, eu governance system, values, languages, etc.), teacher training, extracurricular activities, social media, virtual platforms, role-playing games, research, apprenticeships, volunteering, sport, geographical mobility, exchange of good practices, creation of the Euro Teacher quality label, exchanges between schools, visits to European institutions, meetings with EU officials, etc. However, school and out-of-school education are among the member states in which the Union should never interfere. I was hereby in favour of the report

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I fully support this report, which aims to strengthen the European dimension in education. Too often criticised, the European Union is in fact little known.  To remedy this, I wanted to encourage new local, regional, national and European initiatives to bring the EU closer to its citizens by improving understanding of the integration process.  However, following the principle of subsidiarity in the field of education, it will be up to the Member States to develop concretely these new initiatives to promote European values and information related to its history and operation.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. This afternoon's vote calls for a more coherent education of Europe in schools within each Member State and a better complementarity with the other subjects taught.   Forty-four per cent of Europeans do not understand how the EU works: this is unacceptable. How could citizens know their rights, make their voices heard, and get involved in shaping the Europe of tomorrow if the institutions and democratic mechanisms that serve them remain a mystery to them? A 2013 ICF GHK study found that 85% of Member States were already talking to their schoolchildren about Europe. What today's report wants is to strengthen these figures and make europe's learning more coherent and structured.  This demand is part of a real effort to open up the institutions and fight Euroscepticism, to keep European democracy alive!

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. While many of today's challenges call for a collective response, citizens' distrust and disengagement from the European Union has never been greater. It therefore needs to be better understood and strengthen the civic and political link it maintains with Europeans.  This "education on citizenship" and this involvement of citizens in European decision-making and democratic processes are all the more fundamental for young people, the voters of tomorrow.   European identity is also based on a foundation of common values, such as tolerance, justice and solidarity, which we must pass on to future generations.  With this in mind, the initiative report calls on Member States to better integrate the European dimension into school teachings and curricula, to enable children and students to understand the history, functioning and added value of the European Union and its institutions, while providing them with the tools for critical thinking. In this respect, it is the active participation in the European debate by all citizens that is targeted. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. Why do we have to "learn the European Union in school"? Some figures are sufficient to demonstrate the need to improve the visibility and understanding of the European Union among citizens through education. 44% of citizens feel that they have only a limited understanding of how the Union works; 52% of Europeans consider that their voice does not count in the EU. Consequence? Less than half of citizens and about 28% of young people voted in the last European elections. Citizens must be able to reclaim the European project. That is why efforts must be made to improve the union's learning, based on concrete examples. Moreover, it seems essential to increase financial support for programmes such as Erasmus, Europe for Citizens and "Creative Europe" while increasing access to mobility through these programmes.  Member States also have a responsibility both in terms of information on available European programmes and in terms of reviewing and updating their education systems. We must relearn how to live the European dream. Learning about the European Union in school can help.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Learning about the EU at school can help develop a sense of European citizenship from an early age, make European values known and thus combat the growing Euroscepticism in all Member States.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which defends the need to integrate a European dimension into education as a key element in helping citizens to better understand and reconnect the EU; deepen the role of the fundamental values of the European Union and promote adherence to them. As the report points out, knowing and understanding the common history and values of the EU and its Member States is key to mutual understanding, peaceful coexistence, tolerance and solidarity, as well as understanding the fundamental principles of the European Union. The report reviews and proposes specific measures for curriculum, teacher training, teaching methods, mobility, research and the use of new technologies.  At a time when the EU faces serious challenges, the integration of a European dimension into education must not only enable students to acquire knowledge and develop a sense of belonging, but also initiate critical reflection on the EU, in particular through learning the EU's core values based on the rule of law and human rights.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report. We oppose any form of EU interference in Member States’ national curricula, especially with regard to the EU being better highlighted in teaching materials, disseminating EU propaganda and calling for more funding to do so. The EU has no competency in the education systems of Member States and in fact is going against Article 165 of the TFEU which states that the EU ‘fully respect the responsibility of the Member States for the content of teaching and the organisation of education systems and their cultural and linguistic diversity’.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, to which I voted, stresses that EU-related topics should be more visible and well integrated into teaching materials and extracurricular activities and believes that the inclusion of content explicitly related to the EU can substantially enhance school programmes and the personal development and growth of pupils. Furthermore, it stresses that knowledge and understanding of the history and common values of the EU and its Member States are essential for mutual understanding, peaceful cohabitation, tolerance and solidarity, as well as for understanding the fundamental principles of the European Union, and i have deserved my positive vote. In this way, these measures will allow students to reflect critically on the EU, on governance, on decision-making processes and on how they themselves and their democratic participation influence the Member State to which they belong. In addition, the document calls for the adoption of an intercultural approach in the field of educational policies that provides for a true integration of immigrant pupils in schools, based on mutual knowledge of different cultures and the development of shared common values.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the learning of the European Union in schools, because I am convinced that there is a real need to know and understand Europe in order to enable it to evolve and even change its functioning.  From an early age, European citizens must learn about history and become familiar with the values of the EU, because this knowledge is essential to understanding the other and to the common development - because it is imperative to involve them - of the European project.  To do so, the Commission is asked to propose a common framework for EU learning and to strengthen the European mobility of learners. Member States maintain their preponderance of education, so they should facilitate "intercultural, non-discriminatory and inclusive education" and promote the values of citizenship in their school and university curricula.  It is by deconstructing prejudices and caricatures through knowledge, while promoting critical thinking, that together we can re-enchant the European project.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which contains many good ideas for better organizing education in schools. The report stresses the need to develop critical thinking and stresses the benefits of ensuring mobility for knowledge of the world and different cultures of young people. It also focuses on language learning as a means of conveying knowledge of Europe.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. Today the European Union suffers from a lack of public awareness that fuels criticism of the democratic deficit.  According to a 2014 Eurobarometer survey, 44% of EU citizens felt they had only a limited understanding of how the union works and 52% of Europeans felt that their voice did not count in the EU.  The report by Mr Dr-ghici calls on Member States to strengthen the European dimension in education. It emphasizes the importance of understanding European integration from a historical point of view but also from a practical point of view, the aim being to promote an understanding of how it works and to develop the civility of pupils.  Although the EU has a subsidiary role in education, the report stresses the importance of European programmes as well as cooperation platforms to advance education in Europe. It also encourages Member States to strengthen the European dimension in their education programmes. Finally, it takes into account teacher training on European issues.  I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the historical moment in which we live, the European Union faces unprecedented challenges and, in recent years, has experienced a serious economic and financial crisis. The social, economic and political effects of this crisis call into question the Union's common institutions and values, including the notion of European identity. In this context, the intensification of the study and dialogue on the European Union in schools, associations or in public spaces is crucial in restoring citizens' confidence, the sense of belonging to this union of peoples and States and, consequently, the promotion of the Process of European Construction. It is therefore essential for us to improve the European dimension in school education by giving citizens better tools to live and work in a Union of 28 Member States that is part of a very complex and globalised world. Although competence is exclusively in the Member States, we note that, unfortunately, the situation regarding the inclusion of content about the EU in national school programmes is far from uniform, so we believe that specific measures are necessary on this matter, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses learning in the School of the European Union and how it works.  A recent survey suggested that 44% of Europeans do not understand how the European Union works. There is therefore an urgent need to strengthen the dialogue on the Union in schools, associations and public spaces in order to restore citizens' confidence and promote the process of European integration. At the same time, we also need to disseminate more information on these topics. As such, the Erasmus, Europe for Citizens and Creative Europe programmes have a central role to play in promoting education and training, language skills, active citizenship and intercultural understanding.  Finally, it is important that Member States invest more in quality education that can arouse the curiosity of schoolchildren or students and generate real interest in the European Union and its functioning.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Most of the aspects that we have opposed are due to the vagueness of the concept of European dimension that is used.  We are not opposed to greater information on the EU being provided at different levels of training, we believe that greater knowledge of the procedures and competences of EU bodies is clearly positive. However, we believe that it is not appropriate to confuse training with propaganda, and in this regard this report does not forese or incorporate the causes or responsibilities of the authors causing the situation of inequality in which we live in today's Europe, whereas on the contrary, it abounds in additional clarifications on the term Euroscepticism. We note the existence of positive and relevant contributions, but the general spirit of the report we believe has an objective aimed at addressing a deficit of legitimacy, such as that suffered by the European project in different regions, without to publicize the functioning, causes and consequences of the European project. For this reason our vote has been abstention.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There clearly needs to be more education about the role of the EU, its decision making structures, and the relationship between the EU institutions and Member States. A lack of information about these issues feeds euro-scepticism and prevents citizens from engaging effectively with the European policy process. I therefore welcome this report and its call to improve education and awareness, and the emphasis it places on including all actors, including civil society and social partners.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the acquisition of knowledge about the EU in schools, as I believe it is very important to promote the European integration process and restore the confidence of EU citizens. I support the existing national and international programmes and networks that promote knowledge about the European Union at various levels. The creation of an EU dimension in education should, among other things, help to inform citizens about concrete funding opportunities to promote education, training, language learning, intercultural understanding and cultural awareness.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Eu citizens show very limited knowledge of the EU and its institutions. Of all respondents in a survey produced by Eurostat, 44% admit that they do not know how the EU works. This is very problematic from a democratic point of view, because Europe has a significant impact on our lives. Without knowledge of the EU, common education plan and common public media space, the EU will remain a paper structure hypersensitive to political cyclical fluctuations. The fact that this is happening in a context where the EU is grappling with several serious crises is even more alarming. European citizens therefore need to learn much more about Europe, not only in schools, but also in political parties, associations, businesses, etc.  When Garibaldi united Italy, the Italian patriot Massimo d'Azeglio said: "Now that we have created Italy, it remains to create Italians." Today, people are tempted to say: 'Now that we have created europe, we have yet to create Europeans – before europe breaks down'. I therefore welcome this report.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to introduce a European dimension to education in schools to restore citizens' confidence in the European Union. But the report ignores the reasons why mistrust and discrediting citizens to the present EU has increased. With complete cynicism, the report promotes the principles and values set out in Article 2 of the EU Treaty, but does not criticise the systematic violation of these same principles within the EU territory itself. For these reasons I have not been able to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report. We oppose any form of EU interference in Member States’ national curricula, especially with regard to the EU being better highlighted in teaching materials, disseminating EU propaganda and calling for more funding to do so. The EU has no competency in the education systems of Member States and in fact is going against Article 165 of the TFEU which states that the EU ‘fully respect the responsibility of the Member States for the content of teaching and the organisation of education systems and their cultural and linguistic diversity’.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the School Eu Learning Report, as statistics show that Europeans' familiarity with the European Union is at a devastating level, best reflected in the turnout for the European Parliament elections due to poor perceptions of the importance of voting.  Education is a fundamental human right, and the goals of education include preparing individuals for life and active citizenship in complex, multicultural societies. Integrating the European Union dimension into education will contribute to better understanding and reconnecting the Union with citizens and citizens. An important role is played by teaching staff who need to be encouraged to mobility, to teach each other and to exchange best practices.  The report calls on the Commission to design and prepare a common framework and prepare guidelines with concrete examples for learning about the Union, both for learners and teachers. The report cites ERASMUS+, Europe for Citizens and Creative Europe, as programmes that have shown excellent results and should continue to be implemented, putting more focus on their qualitative outcome and wider approach to mobility.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for the report presented, because I consider the acquisition of knowledge about the EU at school and the strengthening of the EU dialogue to be a very serious challenge that can significantly support the shaping of civic awareness in pupils and students in schools. During the year I take part in many sessions and discussions in various schools throughout Slovakia, so I can responsibly declare that the knowledge of pupils and students regardless of age is currently quite limited. Although most Member States have gradually included the EU dimension in their curricula and training, there continue to be significant differences between and within Member States. As there is no methodology for teaching about European and democratic values in schools, it is no wonder that students in schools often feel distant and detached from the European political project and have a growing Euroscepticism. I supported the resolution because I believe that, on the basis of the measures taken, pupils and students in schools will be able to equip them with sufficient knowledge of how the EU works, while at the same time preparing them for the work and life of active citizens in an increasingly integrated Europe.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report of the Committee on Culture and Education on EU teaching at school. Teaching about the EU is a topic that is now more topical than ever. In all EU countries, teachers try to teach about the EU. The results are different and unfortunately not always sufficient. While the EU cannot tell Member States or schools what and how to teach, the European Commission should provide them with systematic support and establish a common framework for the content of education. The emerging House of European History, on the other hand, could contribute by working out methodologies and educational modules for teaching history in a European context. In the report, we also call for better use of erasmus+ for the education and exchange of teachers and students in order to strengthen their motivation and exchange of experience. The European Commission should initiate the creation of a certified teacher education module, including certified output, on a voluntary basis, of course. I am convinced that teachers are interested in the subject of the European Union and aware of its values, but their duties are focused on the performance of pupils in exams. However, if we want pupils to have a better understanding of the functioning of the EU and not be subject to populist campaigns, we need to take better care of how citizenship education takes place in schools, including awareness of the EU.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Only 42.61% of EU citizens and only 27.8% of people aged between 18 and 24 took part in the last European Parliament elections, the lowest turnout since 1979 (Eurobarometer data). The European Union faces the challenge of growing EU scepticism. It is crucial to find ways to inform citizens about EU structures and policies. It is necessary to affirm the values of democracy and diversity, to allow access to all rights and to report on the EU in general. It is also clear that the distance between the EU and its citizens has deteriorated due to the inability to understand how the institutions work and how they can participate in the EU's political life. In order to raise citizens' awareness, it is necessary to start in schools by including EU affairs in the curriculum. The main topics included in the report to increase the sense of belonging to the EU are the following: formal and non-formal education, intercultural approach to education policy, participation in critical reflection, mobility between pupils and teachers (to have direct experience in learning about other contexts in the EU), language learning and recognising the importance of language issues in the transmission of European messages. It is necessary to strengthen the dialogue on the EU in schools, associations and in the public space. In order to promote awareness of European identity, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Including a European dimension in school education is a crucial element in creating a sense of common belonging and giving substance to European citizenship and also an important tool to counter growing Euroscepticism. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a strategy to promote learning about EU action and policies at school, improving current and future exchange networks at all levels of education and focusing on educational programmes, teacher training, mobility and new technologies in order to achieve the objective of greater knowledge of EU action by young citizens.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The "Learning EU in School" report foresees that in future teaching content of school teaching will be regulated uniformly across the EU. This concerns in particular the functioning of the institutions of the European Union. I strongly oppose the proposals mentioned in this report, as they are intended to violate the constitutionally regulated competence of the German Länder in the field of school education and to give pupils an undifferentiated picture of the European Union.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the EU's impact on Member States is considerable and that education on the EU in schools should take into account both the role of Member States in EU development and the EU's impact on developments in individual Member States. The European dimension in education enables pupils and students to acquire knowledge, develop a sense of belonging, and also helps to develop critical thinking in relation to the EU, including through education on the EU's fundamental values based on the rule of law and human rights, on EU governance and decision-making processes and on their implications for their Member State and their democratic participation. The Member States and the EU must set an example to all actors involved in teaching and learning about the EU at school and practice the fundamental European values of social inclusion and European and international solidarity.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on teaching about the EU in school. European values are not something distant and elusive. These are values on which there is consensus across the Union and on which sufficient scope for their universal character should be systematically devoted in teaching. Such values are, for example, the rule of law and free elections. Every citizen should be aware of such values and aware of their importance in the historical context. The expansion of the Union dimension in education can serve as a catalyst for critical discussions between pupils and teachers on such values, as well as an incentive for pupils to actively participate in governance both within their own community and within the EU. 44% of Union citizens have a lack of awareness of its functioning. It is therefore necessary that the union's decision-making procedures and institutions are given sufficient space in the context of teaching. If a citizen is to understand the Union, he must obtain clear basic information about it. Pupils' awareness should also be strengthened in the area of 'free movement', ideally in the form of simple practical examples. The report's appeal to improve teachers' knowledge and skills in this regard can be welcomed. I also support practical projects, such as the European Youth Parliament, in which young citizens value their acquired knowledge in practice. I also appreciate the plan to make better use of the ERASMUS+ exchange programme in the future.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The report rightly underlines the fact that the EU is made up of its Member States, each of which has a unique history and culture. It is also positive that the emphasis should be placed on informing citizens. This should make it possible to think critically and debate the importance of European cooperation. Although the report recognises the member state's competence in education and training policy, it seems to ignore this in certain paragraphs. In particular, the report is often too prescriptive when it comes to education with regard to the past and the future of European integration. The N-VA delegation therefore abstained.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Most Member States of the European Union have integrated learning about the European Union into their curricula and teacher training programmes. The European Union has been shaped by Member States with their unique history and culture and there is an inseligible connection between the Union and the Member States.  The European Union is currently facing a number of challenges, including the economic and financial crisis, which challenges the institutions and common values of the Union. This focuses on the concept of European identity. Most CITIZENS of the European Union are unfamiliar with or have limited knowledge of how the EU works and the work of the institutions, so it is not surprising that Euroscepticism rises and that citizens feel distant from the European project.  In order to inform the citizens of the European Union, it is necessary to strengthen the EU dimension in school education, and for this reason I support this report. I believe it is essential that all Member States integrate the EU dimension into school education in order to convey relevant knowledge, skills and abilities to learners and create a sense of belonging and strengthen community spirit.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Given that, according to a 2014 survey, as many as 44% of EU citizens do not understand the functioning of the EU, the Commission's report proposed introducing learning about the European Union in schools. It specifies the roles of the EU as a whole and the role of Member States. Member States should certainly adapt their education systems and the Union should work to unequalize and coordinate them. I support this report and its proposals, primarily because I think citizens are unaware of the importance of elections to the European Parliament and how important their vote really is. If children were taught about the EU and its institutions from an early age, the most important awareness would awaken, namely that we are all European citizens. This is why the European Union should be visible in teaching materials throughout education. This path also promotes multicultural tolerance among children and motivates them to learn foreign languages.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I fundamentally disagree that there is a lack of 'political education' behind the growing perception of the democratic deficit, the spread of Euroscepticism and the overall low support of the European Union. I believe that the image of the EU can only really be corrected if the functioning of the European Union itself also changes.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on learning about the EU in schools. A number of opinion polls show that there is still a high percentage of women and citizens who are not familiar with the European Union. This is due to several factors. We will certainly significantly correct this percentage and bring the European Union closer to the people if we introduce learning about the European Union into schools. Today, we are also faced with a great electoral abstinence in the European Parliament elections and a lack of trust in the European institutions, so that learning about the European Union in schools would also contribute to increasing participation in elections and to increasing people's trust in the EU institutions. I support the need for the EU to be more visible and better involved in teaching materials and extracurricular activities.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Report had several positive references to tackling racism and the need to respect and promote human rights. However, the concept of the European dimension in education as raised is unclear.  Many reports are controversial. For example, while the democratic deficit and the existence of inequalities between and within the Member States are recognised, there is no criticism of the European policies and practices that have created these realities. Also particularly negative is the attempt to link education to employability and to engage with the private sector. There is also no mention of human rights violations in the EU. Unfortunately, a number of amendments tabled by the Group of the European United Left to improve the text have been rejected. We have therefore abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report institutionalises the imposition of unprecedented perceptions on education. It is essentially an overt propaganda and brainwashing of students

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the acquisition of EU knowledge in schools, which rightly shows that the institution of EU citizenship must be filled with real knowledge. As the reporter points out, a greater emergence of the European dimension in educational materials would bring many benefits: it would develop competences related to EU citizenship and help to develop critical thinking by helping learners to understand the fundamental values of the Union, the EU decision-making processes and their impact on their daily lives. A wider knowledge of the Union would enable young people to explore other cultures and become active and tolerant citizens. I agree with the need to increase the motivation and opportunities for teachers and learners to learn more about the EU on the basis of their own personal experience. The majority of Member States have gradually integrated the European dimension into their curricula and teacher training, but there are still significant differences between countries. I thus share the reporter's view that further action is needed in this area at national and local level, but also at European level. Politics can only serve citizens if we all play an active role in it. It is therefore also important to educate citizens' knowledge and knowledge of the European Union.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The years-long economic and financial crisis has significantly weakened Euro-enthusiasm in the Old Continent and even called into question the legitimacy of the institutions and common values of the European Union. In this context, it appears necessary to step up efforts to raise awareness of the importance of the Community in educational institutions. Fostering the spirit of European values and faith in the need for an EU in young people is extremely important for the creation of European civil society. Citizens know little about the EU and the functioning of its institutions. It is not surprising, therefore, that they do not feel connected to the European political project or even are hurt by it, as is manifested in the growing power of Eurosceptic movements. It is therefore necessary to better inform citizens and encourage their active participation in the Community. Greater emphasis should be placed on the EU dimension in school education, which will hamper the development of Euroscepticism and, at the same time, prepare citizens for life in an increasingly globalised world.  Given the importance of promoting knowledge of the European Union, I have decided to support the report submitted.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the own-initiative report on strengthening the EU dimension in education. We believe that, as the report states, education is a fundamental human right and a public good to which all citizens must have access, and it is crucial that there should be a critical reflection on the role of the Union in their lives. We recognise that the report is heading in the right direction by pointing out to the Commission and the Member States concrete measures to give a real European dimension to education systems, with the aim of halting democratic degradation in the institutions, promoting fundamental values such as social inclusion, solidarity and dialogue, and strengthening active citizenship and the exercise of democratic rights and responsibilities, including voting rights and responsibilities. We hope that the Commission and the Member States will follow the report's recommendations, promoting the dissemination of knowledge, the creation of a European dimension in history, the interaction between education systems and the mobility of their actors, in order to guarantee all citizens of the Union a public and quality education. However, I cannot help noticing that this will be possible as austerity policies are leading to the destruction of public schools in many Member States.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The inclusion of the European perspective in education, by learning EU at school, aims to help creating a sense of European identity, to deepen knowledge of the role of the EU. It will allow a better understanding of the EU history and culture as well as its policy-making decision process. This measure will engage children in the civic and intercultural dialogue that reflects the diversity of the Union.  The report highlights the role of the European Union and the importance of promoting learning EU at school, enhancing existing and future networks and exchanges at all educational levels and focusing on curricula, teaching methods, mobility, research and the use of new technologies. It also underlines the role played by social partners and civil society organisations. I support this report, because it is very important to include a European dimension in education in order to strengthen EU citizenship and promote intercultural, non-discriminatory and inclusive education in schools and universities.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I am of course in favour of this initiative. It is important to underline the growing importance of a European dimension in education in different disciplines and different levels and forms of education, while emphasizing the need for a broad and in-depth acceptance of the concept that takes into account its complex, dynamic and multidimensional nature, with EU learning in schools being an essential element.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ According to a 2014 Eurobarometer opinion poll, 71% of EU citizens felt that they have limited understanding of how the EU works and 52% of Europeans believe that their voice does not count in the EU. I voted in favour of introducing the EU dimension in education to remedy to this appalling situation. This will equip our children with a concrete understanding of how the EU works and enable them to critically reflect on European matters and how they influence their own country and identity. Instead of allowing the gap between the citizens and the EU to grow even further, it is important to start a dialogue on the EU from a young age, to enable our children to become educated citizens, capable of making their own choices about the European project.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ This report openly calls on the Member States of the European Union to foster the creation of a sense of belonging to the European Union and to create a European identity through school books, curriculum, teaching resources, professional teacher training, extracurricular and similar political education activities.  While I believe that citizens of the European Union should be educated about the European Union and the institutions, I believe that the introduction of the proposed programmes, instruments and activities will not provide an objective representation of history, as well as a free development of consciousness and a faithful representation of European reality. This approach acts as propaganda that has the ultimate aim of supersinging or annulling the national identities of citizens of the European Union.  In addition, education and education should remain the responsibility of the Member States and the European Union must never interfere in this sector. Moreover, I believe that Member States should benefit from membership of the European Union in order to further strengthen and promote their own national identities.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on learning about the EU in schools, as the European Union is currently facing unprecedented challenges. It has been experiencing a major economic and financial crisis over the last few years. However, the social and political consequences of this crisis call into question the institutions and the union's common values, including the concept of European identity. In this context, strengthening the EU dialogue in our schools, associations and public space seems more important than ever to restore citizens' confidence in the strengths and urgency of the European integration process.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Most of the aspects that we have opposed are due to the vagueness of the concept of European dimension that is used. We are not opposed to greater information on the EU being provided at different levels of training, we believe that greater knowledge of the procedures and competences of EU bodies is clearly positive. However, we believe that it is not appropriate to confuse training with propaganda, and in this regard this report does not forese or incorporate the causes or responsibilities of the authors causing the situation of inequality in which we live in today's Europe, whereas on the contrary, it abounds in additional clarifications on the term Euroscepticism.  We note the existence of positive and relevant contributions, but the general spirit of the report we believe has an objective aimed at addressing a deficit of legitimacy, such as that suffered by the European project in different regions, without to publicize the functioning, causes and consequences of the European project. For this reason our vote has been abstention.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to redefine the EU's role in member countries' education systems and strengthen European integration. We have here a new intrusive approach of the European Union advocating integration at the expense of the fundamentals of education which are the learning of writing, reading and our national history. Without these solid foundations, we are nothing.  That is why I supported the alternative resolution of my colleague Dominique Bilde, and I voted AGAINST a text dangerous for the future of our children.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to a 2014 Eurobarometer survey conducted at European level, 44% of EU citizens consider that they have only limited knowledge of its functioning. Moreover, only 42.61% of citizens and only 27.8% of young people between the ages of 18 and 24 voted in the last elections of the European Parliament. Insufficient knowledge and a bad understanding of EU mechanisms can contribute to increasing the democratic deficit and propagating Euroscepticism. There is therefore a need to fill the space between EU citizens and the European institutions. In this perspective, the report underlines the need for a European dimension of education in order to help citizens better understand the EU's functioning mechanisms and to restore the link between them and the EU. This European dimension of education should not only contribute to the acquisition of knowledge and the development of a sense of belonging to the EU, but also to the development of critical reflections towards the EU, in particular through knowledge of fundamental values. In this respect, the report proposes, with a view to increasing the EU's visibility, to integrate it as much as possible into pedagogical materials and extra-curricular activities. I therefore voted in favour of the Report on EU knowledge in schools.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently facing unforeseen challenges. He has been through a severe economic and financial crisis over the last few years. Its social and political effects call into question the raison d'ediability of the institutions and the common values of the Union, while at the same time the concept of European identity. In this respect, it is now more important than ever to have a dialogue on the European Union in schools, associations and public meeting places, so that citizens can once again believe in the benefits and necessity of the European integration process.  EU citizens currently have little knowledge of the European Union and the functioning of its institutions, as shown by the fact that forty-four per cent of EU citizens disagreed with the statement 'I understand how the Union works' in the Eurobarometer spring 2014 survey. It is no wonder, then, that citizens do not feel close to themselves, but are increasingly turning away from the European political project and becoming Eurosceptics and discovering democratic shortcomings in the EU decision-making process. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Most of the aspects that we have opposed are due to the vagueness of the concept of European dimension that is used. We are not opposed to greater information on the EU being provided at different levels of training, we believe that greater knowledge of the procedures and competences of EU bodies is clearly positive. However, we believe that it is not appropriate to confuse training with propaganda, and in this regard this report does not forese or incorporate the causes or responsibilities of the authors causing the situation of inequality in which we live in today's Europe, whereas on the contrary, it abounds in additional clarifications on the term Euroscepticism.  We note the existence of positive and relevant contributions, but the general spirit of the report we believe has an objective aimed at addressing a deficit of legitimacy, such as that suffered by the European project in different regions, without to publicize the functioning, causes and consequences of the European project. For this reason our vote has been abstention.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive. The initiative is taken obviously on the grounds of growing EU-scepticism and in the urgent need to find ways to familiarise citizens with the EU structures and policies, reaffirm values of democracy, sharing diversity and giving access to all to their rights, and communicate on the EU at large. It is also quite clear that the gap between EU and its citizens is aggravated by the impossibility to grasp the functioning of institutions, and how one could participate in the political life of the EU. In order to empower citizens, it is necessary to start at school level, to integrate EU issues within the curriculum.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, the EU faces unprecedented challenges that need to be addressed at European and national level, but most importantly these reactions have support from citizens. Unfortunately, according to the 2014 Eurobarometer, citizens have limited knowledge of the EU, the work of its institutions, general policies protecting their rights and well-being. Moreover, Euroscepticism and the number of citizens who feel distanced from the European project are growing. In these circumstances, it is necessary to start an orderly dialogue for the EU in schools in an orderly manner. While education is the competence of the Member States, the EU can promote cooperation between them, support and complement national action in this field. Previous pan-European programmes in the education sector and today's Erasmus+ programme have contributed little to integration processes in the EU.  Action at EU level is needed to bring about a European dimension in our children's education so that they know not only European geography, history and culture, but also that they are citizens of a great union of established freedoms and values. Member States have an interest in the EU being more visible and understandable to their own citizens, so they should not oppose the initiative to study the EU in schools.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on ‘Learning EU at school’. The report underlines the increasing importance of a European dimension in education across the different disciplines, levels and forms of education. It equally points out that the Union should be more visible, and better integrated, in teaching materials and extracurricular activities.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a key issue today as increasing the debate and dialogue on the European Union in our schools, associations and public spaces is essential and essential for citizens to be able to more without impetus support the process of European integration. It is therefore vital to continue to increase the European dimension in school education, as this report rightly points out. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. According to a Eurobarometer poll, 71% of all Europeans feel that they do not understand the workings of the European Union. Moreover, 52% of all European citizens feel that their voice does not count in Europe. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal, because I believe that this measure can reduce these disastrous figures in the long term.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report on 'Learning EU affairs at school', voted today, looked at increasing EU skills through education. In Finland and in schools in several other EU countries, EU issues are already being discussed in the teaching of history and social studies, for example. In my opinion, however, the most important thing is to acquire a broad civilisation and to learn one's own data collection, which will provide the best means of looking at the EU as well. In addition, according to Article 6 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), education and training falls within the competence of the Member States. For these reasons, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report assumes that the fact that people have limited knowledge of the EU and how it works is the key factor for people to feel distant and increasingly unrelated to the "European political project" and more Eurosceptic and "perceit a democratic deficit in the EU's decision-making processes".  This report does not condemn, of course, the task of subordination of education and training to the fulfilment of the 2020 strategy, advocating the harmonization of the structure of knowledge and even content, ignoring the specificities of the educational system of each country, in a tendency towards vocational training rather than integrated "education".  In the first place for people to believe in the "European project" it is necessary, first of all, that this project is for the realisation of rights, for cooperation and solidarity between countries; what is needed in schools in the EU Member States, as we advocate, is to guarantee everyone's right to free and quality public education.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report is a single EU propaganda that will be found in classrooms and funded by various sectors.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. A 'no' vote was required here, because it is not the implantation of a European consciousness or an "EU dimension" of education that is desirable, but the mediation and introduction to one's own national traditions and histories. In the light of experience, it is also to be feared that the implementation of an "EU dimension" in school and especially history teaching would open the door to subtle EU propaganda.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. The concept of EU teaching in schools is not only ridiculous, but also frightening. The control of the national school system is clearly a competence of the Member States. Any kind of EU intervention in the national education system is a blatant violation of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ According to a 2014 Eurobarometer opinion poll, 44 % of European Union citizens feel that they have limited understanding of how the EU works and 52 % of Europeans believe that their voice is not taken into account. This disconnect from political institutions also exists at national and local level, with few people voting in the UK Police and Crime Commissioner elections, for example.  Enhancing dialogue about the EU in public spaces is important in order to rebuild citizens’ involvement in common European ideals and fundamental values of freedom and democracy, as enshrined in the treaties. Sharing knowledge about the EU in formal, non-formal and informal education settings is a way to address democratic deficits and tackle the gap between the voice of European citizens and the EU institutions. I fully support citizenship education in schools.  However, ‘education’ remains a Member State competence as reflected in the non-legislative status of this report which seeks to support educators and learners through the sharing of best practice. I am very proud of schools and education organisations in my region which have recognised the democratic deficit and are addressing it through innovative programmes to teach pupils about their rights and responsibilities in respect of British, European and global citizenship.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the adoption of the own-initiative report on EU knowledge in school. I voted for this report, which underlines the growing importance of a European dimension in education, in its various subjects, levels and forms, with a focus on the need for a broader and deeper understanding of the concept, taking into account its complex, dynamic and multi-layered character, the essential component of which is the acquisition of knowledge about the EU in school. The report also shows that the introduction of an EU dimension in education is essential to help citizens better understand and re-connect with the Union, as well as to emphasise the role of the values enshrined in Article 2 TEU and maximise the Union's position in an interdependent world.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Historically the lowest voter turnout of Slovak citizens in the last European Parliament elections is one of the consequences of the lack of citizens' knowledge of the European Union, its history and functioning. The curriculum is a competence of the Member States, but at EU level it is possible to offer states and teachers quality information in a form that best meets the needs of schools and teachers. At the same time, care must be taken to maintain quality standards that ensure that the materials offered stimulate critical thinking in pupils.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on EU learning at school, which was discussed at length within the Committee on Culture and Education. Learning about the EU at school will help citizens better understand the functioning and institutions of the EU, while knowledge and understanding of common history and common values is crucial for mutual understanding, peaceful coexistence, tolerance and solidarity.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the current context, I believe that this initiative is key to being able to restore the confidence of all citizens in the European Union and to improve the integration process. I believe that the best option to achieve this objective is undoubtedly to promote EU values from education. In this way, it will be possible to ensure that all citizens have full knowledge of the EU in all its aspects, such as its functions, its component institutions, activities carried out and promoted values. Although education on Europe is already being offered, I believe that Europe has a great deal of room for improvement, which could begin by providing more tools to teaching staff with information on the EU and learning platforms.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the teaching of history and the European institutions in all schools in the Member States. This measure will provide a series of initiatives to promote European values more strongly among the young strata of the population. Among these, I believe that the proposal to create a common educational platform inherent in European history to be extended to all Member States and the proposal to guarantee ad hoc training courses for all teachers are particularly important. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur and my colleague Damian Draghici for his excellent work. With its initiative, the S&D Group is once again demonstrating that it is the leading political force in initiatives to spread European values and to combat Euroscepticism.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support this report. I believe that without a basic understanding of how the European Union works, any European issues, including the values on which European integration is built, as well as how this project affects the daily lives of people within the EU, cannot be critically considered. I believe that teaching about the European Union in schools should prepare pupils for the role of active citizens within an increasingly integrated Europe in a globalised world. Personally, I consider it necessary for the citizens of the European Union to have basic historical knowledge of the eu's historical development and how the EU institutions operate, and to know the values and objectives to which this project is heading. I firmly believe that one of the main ways to overcome the Euroscepticism that is present in a large part of the population is to strengthen the Union dimension in school education.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report on raising awareness of the EU at school has undoubtedly come at a time when the EU is facing a growing Eurosceptic problem and citizens are all the more aware of the problem of the democratic deficit in EU decision-making processes. However, the motivation for Eurosceptic attitudes is often a lack of knowledge about the functioning of the EU and the values on which European integration is based.  Opinion polls from 2014 show that 44% of European Union citizens feel that they have a limited understanding of how the EU works and nearly 52% of Europeans believe their vote does not count in the EU. The lowest turnout in the last European Parliament elections since 1979 is undoubtedly a reflection of these statistics.  I strongly support the report's assumptions, while pointing out that the EU dimension of education should be based not only on learning, but also on critical reflection on EU issues. In this context, I stress the role, and therefore also the need to ensure stable funding, initiatives based on the objective of strengthening the sense of belonging to the EU and promoting cultural awareness and intercultural understanding – the EU's Erasmus+, 'Europe for Citizens' and 'Creative Europe', the newly emerging House of European History in Brussels, or the Euranet+ pan-European radio network aimed at reducing the distance between the European Union and its citizens.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of this report is to counter the spread of Euroscepticism from an early age, to create a sense of greater connection with the European Union and to instil a stronger European identity, as well as to promote the adoption of a multicultural society. In the report, the rapporteur calls on the Member States to swiftly integrate subjects with this content into school curricula and to allocate the necessary resources to this. International mobility, improved textbooks and visits to the European institutions are to be among other means of raising awareness of the European Union. However, the challenges thus conceived go well beyond those of the European Union. Education, in particular the creation of school curricula, is the exclusive competence of the Member States, in which the European Union cannot intervene. That is why I voted against the report as a whole.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The demand to deepen European identity by increasing the amount of teaching materials and activities on the European Union in schools is difficult to defend and evokes the worst associations of the time when ideology was the subject of lectures in my country. The statistics on participation in European elections cited in this report should not be an argument for mandatory indoctrination on the benefits of the EU, as low participation in elections is also characteristic of national elections.  It also seems inappropriate to call for the unilateral presentation of the benefits of the European Union without being able to present the entire economic and political context of the functioning of the Community. I believe that every EU citizen has the right to have a negative assessment of its functioning and should not be forcibly informed and persuaded to change its views.  Free access to knowledge is today a standard thanks to the Internet, thanks to which anyone interested in European subjects can acquire such knowledge. Recent history curricula in schools also take into account the topic of European integration, where this issue is discussed and discussed. The preparation of this report is proof that the European institutions are leaving their role and are starting to care more about good public perception and poll posts than about solving the problems facing the EU. I voted against this report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. In the current situation, strengthening dialogue on European Union topics in schools and other public spaces is crucial for restoring citizens' trust and promoting the Process of European Integration. To this end, I also supported the report on learning about the EU in schools. I believe that one of the most important objectives of education is to prepare individuals for life and active citizenship in the European Union and to contribute to strengthening the role of values set out in Article 2 TEU.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I support the creation of the seven-year Erasmus+ Programme, as I stand for Europe-wide mobility and educational cooperation among European countries. I strongly believe that education is a fundamental right and that it is a public good that should be equally accessible to all EU citizens and young people, because we are talking about young people here. Erasmus+ provides opportunities for vocational education and training for students to carry out work experience abroad, allowing them to learn new skills and languages which will improve their employability in the future. Let us not forget that youth unemployment across the EU is at 22%; it is at a high. Therefore we need the recognition and accreditation of study and working practices between certain countries. Validation and recognition of learning skills and competences are key aspects to improve implementation of the European qualification framework for lifelong studying and learning.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Yes, I voted for it, because it is a great thing, after all, that, say, a Hungarian apprentice carpenter, upholsterer or shoemaker can learn the skills of the profession together with a German or an English professional. The problem is, they probably won't be able to practice their profession, their profession, after they've passed the apprenticeship. At the very least, hungarians will have far fewer ways to do so, thanks to the same EU that, as a good idea, has graciously organised this Erasmus 2 programme. Because, by the way, liberal free trade in the European Union is causing cheap and often poor quality products to flow in from all over the world, which means that these excellent skilled workers are either unable to start work or have to give up. Thank you very much, take that into account.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Erasmus Programme has been a great success story in providing opportunities for student mobility across the European Union. In Scotland alone, 1 877 students participated in the scheme in the 2012-13 intake. However, we must ensure that students involved in vocational training and education also enjoy the benefits of an Erasmus experience. The opportunity to study and train abroad can be life-changing. It is unsurprising that Eurosceptics do not want young people in the UK and Scotland to benefit from these opportunities – opportunities we would lose if we came out of the European Union. I hope Scottish students and apprentices alike can benefit from these life—changing and enhancing opportunities.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Erasmus, for what it has built in recent years, for the people to whom it is addressed, for what it represents, is indeed one of the effective ways out of the economic crisis, but even more so of the conscience that affects Europe.  Strengthening Erasmus means supporting our students, our professionals, but supporting culture in a Europe that today appears to be all economic. There are key issues, but they still need to be improved, on which to work: the economic capacity of students to take advantage of mobility, for example, because many do not have the resources that Erasmus does not finance; the recognition of training credits; the inclusion of trainees in the programmes; access to the world of work after the training experience. These are some of the issues that need to be resolved as soon as possible in order to widen as much as possible the spread of the Europe that we like and that the citizens of Europe especially like.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – I consider European student mobility to be one of the important benefits of the European Community, especially for students from central and eastern European countries, erasmusplus not only represents the possibility to leave my home country and expand their knowledge, but above all the chance to apply well in the labour market. The graduates of this programme are thus a great added value for both Member States and the private sector. It is for these reasons that I must express my disappointment at the report that I could not support. I see no reason for the report to take into account the so-called discrimination against people reporting to the LGBTI group. What discrimination are we talking about, in what sense is this group discriminated against in student mobility? And as the rapporteur wants to address their equatoisation, again in quotation marks. Instead of trying to promote a 'gender ideology', which is becoming part of a large part of the proposed documents, we should look at the real needs of Europeans. They want to see good, practical solutions, not burdened by ideological divisions in the European Parliament and in the thinking of the European Union.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we support this Erasmus+ report because it will enable vocational training students to access European mobility programmes in their studies. However, greater mobility of training cannot in any case mean greater mobility or greater diffusion of precariousness. Currently, cities such as London, Paris or Berlin are full of young Spaniards in precarious jobs because of lack of job expectations in their country. There has to be strict vigilance over this program and the status of the apprentice must be regulated. We know that many workers and many workers who have been replaced by less-paid and fewer labour rights fellows have been dismissed in these years. Under no circumstances can internships replace stable jobs. Under no circumstances can practices be used to lay off workers and use them as a common form of work. In the southern countries where this happens, we know what the dire consequences are on the quality of employment. That is why mobility for training, for opportunities, combating discrimination and promoting equal opportunities, yes. Labour mobility as an obligation, as an alternative to quality employment, no.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report, because mobility in vocational education and training (VET) is a source of genuine and diverse learning experience. Unfortunately, just a small percentage of young people currently in professional training are involved in a mobility programme during their training. Experience-oriented education, and of course the learning and training mobility within it, incorporates inputs from the business environment to enable participants to react in a flexible way to the rapidly changing world and labour market demands. Individuals need to be motivated to engage in mobility and to take up lifelong learning through efficient and sustainable financing tools and themes. Erasmus+ proved to be the most successful mobility programme, but we should do better in organising, facilitating and promoting mobility in VET and ensuring full recognition of the knowledge and skills acquired in the context of VET. It also has to be clear that the modernisation of VET systems for lifelong learning and mobility require active involvement and commitment from all stakeholders.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I was happy to support this proposal. As a former university lecturer, I have practical experience in student mobility across Europe. This is extremely beneficial for young people, not only for acquiring knowledge and learning a foreign language, but also for social maturity and maturity.  It is good that we are trying to extend Erasmus to other groups of young people or to groups of people who are retraining. It is a really big problem if, for example, in the field of apprenticeships only 1% of apprentices in Europe have experience of some kind of exchange traineeship, and it is good that this material seeks to expand the number of people who do not have a university degree and give them the chance to also take educational and other courses in other EU countries. If successful, it would certainly be good for the younger generation to increase the possibility of applying to the labour market.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE). Mr President, lifelong learning is crucial to the development of workers at every level. Just as an athlete trains and stays fit so that he becomes better and has alternatives, so an employee can't stand still. On this occasion, let me put some lesser-known parameters concerning the employment of hundreds of thousands of athletes around the world. Strengthen the lifelong learning and mobility of athletes in order to acquire additional professional alternatives, in addition to their sporting career and to open up their horizons, as well as the full recognition and observance of their employment rights at every level, especially in the so-called "small" categories and younger athletes.  I supported this report on Erasmus+ and vocational education support.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Erasmus+ is one of the most successful programmes of the European Union and its kind of symbol. The opportunity to live in another country, to get to know a new culture and to communicate with different people is a great opportunity for both the professional and personal development of young people. Experience abroad has proven a plus in the search for a new job. This is why mobility opportunities must cover different target groups. I support the report calling for the promotion of mobility in vocational education and training. Unfortunately, in the new Erasmus+ programme, it remains in the background. There is also a further complication in the procedures for recognising and acreating work experience abroad in individual Member States. Increasing mobility in this area will help to increase the attractiveness of vocational education. Young people who have chosen the path of vocational training must have the same mobility prospects available to higher education students. Currently, only 1% of them participate in mobility schemes. I believe that Erasmus+ must provide equal opportunities for all.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Erasmus+ is an excellent opportunity not only to study or work abroad, but also to qualify such periods of work as a full length of service, which will then be taken into account throughout the territory of the European Union and in each Member State. In other words, there must be a clearly defined, maximised link between education, access to education and job opportunities throughout the EU. But there is one "but". I did not vote in favour. I abstained for one reason because, unfortunately, in the European Parliament, the majority did not support an amendment allowing erasmus+ documents to be obtained in all languages where education in schools in the European Union is carried out. For example, in my country in Latvia there are not only schools with Latvian language training, in which I now speak, but also traditionally exist Belarusian, Ukrainian, Russian, Hebrew Hebrew schools. What happens if we also send these documents to young people in their mother tongues? Unfortunately, I do not understand this. Thank you!

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, this is another dimension in which the EU are trying to widen its scope and introduce new definitions in order to justify the free movement of people. We oppose calls for additional funding: this report suggests increasing the contributions made by Member States, as well as at European level. We do not support the EU intervening in the national curricula of Member States, the EU has no competency in this area and this is stated in Article 165 of the TFEU.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report as a whole has positive aspects, but these aspects run counter to the timidity with which the EU's existing instruments to combat very high youth unemployment, widening gaps in socio-economic protections and employment rights for young people and early school leaving are being tackled. We must tackle all the socio-economic constraints that hinder equality, including those relating to vocational education and training. Furthermore, these results cannot be expected to be achieved by persevering with the logic that has so far guided economic governance in the EU or by not clearly indicating that instruments such as the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative have failed to meet the objectives for which they were designed. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as its main objective is to increase efforts and actions for vocational education and training, including through the different mobility instruments such as Erasmus+ or Leonardo. The report also stresses the need to strengthen knowledge of qualifications and certificates at European level, and notes that in no way is mobility between students at European level understood only as the solution to the problem of youth unemployment in the EU.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to combat youth unemployment, the report recommends promoting student mobility in education and vocational training through existing programmes such as ERASMUS. Strengthening these programmes would also require increased individual grants and better coordination with the European Social Fund.  Although we reject the idea that mobility is the solution to the mass unemployment that afflicts young Europeans, we consider that the ERASMUS programme is one of the european Union's few successes (provided it does not promote brain drain). Furthermore, the rapporteur stresses the importance of learning in the integration of young people into the labour market and stresses the need to rely on craft and craft chambers, which we fully agree with.  So I voted for this text.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This is a very positive report on the Erasmus programme and calls for better access to mobility programmes for learners in vocational education and training. Programmes such as the Erasmus provide key opportunities for our young people to study in various European cities.  These opportunities not only enrich the lives and education of our young people, but also provide a great boost to Irish cities and towns in terms of European funding.  Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Erasmus+ report, which refers to the continuation of the previous Leonardo programme. This report calls on the European Commission and the Member States to adopt concrete measures to improve vocational training and education of THE EU's human resources through exchanges.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite the shortcomings of this report, I voted in favour, as it re-energizes apprenticeships, vocational training, and the role of SMEs in this area.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is just another path in which the EU can widen its scope to further justify the movement of free people. It calls for the creation of new definitions such as a ‘European Apprentice’ seeking to intervene in national curricula once again.
