This report creates a ‘European student card’ and encourages the implementation of a European network of knowledge alliances. I voted against allowing the EU to interfere in the UK educational system.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Erasmus programme is one of the European Union's greatest achievements. It allows young people to acquire new skills, including language skills, and to raise their awareness of European citizenship. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution. In addition, I am strongly committed to European mobility with the establishment of a pilot project allowing apprentices to study for a year in a European country other than their own. This project aims to provide the same mobility opportunities for young apprentices as university students and to strengthen their employability through apprenticeship training and the acquisition of new skills abroad.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to promote mobility. In 2014, the unemployment rate was still 10.2%, despite a slow recovery; The eu-wide youth unemployment rate currently stands at 22.1%, employs only 51% of 55-64 year olds, while the gender gap in employment rates in the older age group is 13.6 percentage points. However, the skills gap remains in the labour market. Erasmus and other mobility programmes in the field of education and training have contributed to the Process of European Integration, fostered the understanding of European citizenship, facilitated the development of individual skills and critical thinking among learners and encouraged the learning of new languages. I agree with the need to provide students with more opportunities for vocational training and to improve them, to adopt common and complementary instruments of the European Social Fund and erasmus+ in order to strengthen each other and be coordinated jointly in order to avoid duplication. It is necessary to make mobility a way of making up employment opportunities and to achieve recognition of studies and qualifications and professional experience, including when acquired in other countries under mobility programmes, etc.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is about Erasmus+, and emphasises the usefulness of the mobility programme in the framework of education for the learning and qualification of young people. Unfortunately, only higher education students take advantage of the potential of the programme and they are only a low percentage. It would be appropriate to increase the role and importance of existing student mobility programmes, which are specially set up in other school areas and financed under this programme, including comenius for secondary school students and Leonardo DaVinci for adult education. The report calls for a desirable move to increase the use and popularity of Erasmus+, with the expected results of the development of highly qualified, language-speaking and good professionals through the programmes. Unfortunately, lifelong learning is also rapidly showing the negative side due to non-marketable knowledge or profession and overquality, which is not appreciated by the labour market. It is important that the programme adheres to the mobility option for vocational training and does not go towards the training of an EU citizen, which would allow national and ethnic diversity to be exchanged within the EU, and to make a bed for the development of a federal state.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, this is another dimension in which the EU are trying to widen its scope and introduce new definitions in order to justify the free movement of people. We oppose calls for additional funding: this report suggests increasing the contributions made by Member States, as well as at European level. We do not support the EU intervening in the national curricula of Member States, the EU has no competency in this area and this is stated in Article 165 of the TFEU.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls for the establishment of a European status for apprentices, recognition between countries of school curricula, greater involvement of companies in the construction of apprenticeship measures and increased funding for the Erasmus programme.  Although the report aims in particular to promote, through the Erasmus programme, the construction of an illusory European identity concealing the will to encroach on the prerogatives of the Member States, and calls for a preferential treatment of certain minorities (migrants, LGBTI, etc.), I did not vote against this text, which is the aim of enhancing vocational training and apprenticeships. , emphasizing the role of SMEs as a means of solving youth unemployment, and recognises that Erasmus has been one of the EU's - too rare - successes.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this report which calls, among other things, to remove all socio-economic barriers that jeopardise equal access for all to vocational education and training (VET) opportunities and calls on the Commission, in particular, to increase the visibility of VET programmes or to promote European mobility of apprentices. The persistent level of unemployment in the Union requires strengthening vocational training, which is an essential tool to combat school drop-out, skills mismatches and any other reason that prevents thousands of European citizens from accessing employment.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The introduction of the Erasmus+ programme, which replaced previous mobility programmes, has been an important development and simplification, enabling more and more European citizens, especially young people, to benefit from important training experience in another EU country. However, there remains a structural deficit which involves the relationship between training and work and is reflected in less mobility for vocational training studies. The Maragall report, which I supported today with my vote, effectively underlines the relationship between employability and mobility, providing guidance on how to implement policies that encourage the exploitation of mobility opportunities by those involved in vocational training and education studies. The main route is to remove obstacles to certain groups of citizens and prevent us from assessing all the direct and indirect benefits of training experiences in another Member State. The Commission and the Member States must strengthen the role of the intermediary, territorial and sectoral institutions involved in the management, preparation and monitoring of mobility while promoting coherent, complementary and well-coordinated co-financing schemes for training centres.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of this report. This report identifies some of the problems that have been occurring in European mobility programmes and in particular addresses the difficulties in accessing these programmes. We believe that mobility programmes in training are positive and that this extension to VET programmes enables access to European mobility at other levels of training. This dossier emphasizes the recognition of different qualifications, certifications and long-term learning. As well as advocating for the regulation of learning periods, in order to try to prevent training positions from engaging in uns recommendable practices such as job replacement, or labour exploitation.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. Education is a fundamental human right and a public good that must be accessible to everyone. Having said that, if there is one area where European cooperation works, it is that of higher education, learning and training of young people, and in particular through the Erasmus programme.  Since its inception in 1987, there have been many programmes that have enabled millions of young Europeans to travel and study abroad. These programmes have undoubtedly contributed to European integration, facilitated the personal development and critical thinking of students and improved the learning of new languages, thus helping to prepare them for the world of work. Today, there seems to be a need to encourage mobility in vocational training. This is particularly the proposed under the Erasmus programme and I fully support this Commission initiative. Youth unemployment is a real challenge and its resolution is a social issue. Let us encourage young people to find internships and study abroad, they will come back only richer in a European culture that we owe it to ourselves to preserve and export.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mr Maragall for his immense work in bringing this Erasmus+ report and other instruments to promote mobility in vocational training to fruition. In this regard, I disagreed with my group's line of vote and voted in favour and signed the amendment calling on the Commission and the Member States to transmit Erasmus+ documents for programmes managed by each of them in the official vehicle languages of European school systems.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on Erasmus is quite satisfactory, and I welcome the fact that my colleagues have incorporated realistic proposals that I had tried to bring to committee, including the need to rely on the chambers of trades and crafts to promote vocational training. Other good elements include, such as the essential involvement of small and medium-sized enterprises in the construction of learning pathways; or the recognition between countries of school curricula, in particular by the system of "credits". However, I will have some reservations. First of all, I am not sure that simply increasing mobility will solve the problem of unemployment, especially youth unemployment. It seems to me that several common-sense measures must be taken beforehand: to ensure that studies are aligned with the needs of the labour market, including by refocusing guidance advice; the acquisition of fundamental knowledge: I would remind you that, according to the latest joint report of the Council and the Commission on the monitoring of the ET2020 strategic framework, in the EU, 22% of 15-year-olds have gaps in mathematics and 18% have serious reading gaps.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've abstained. The main objective of the report is to increase mobility and cooperation with the private sector in vocational education and training as a means of reducing youth unemployment. Rather, I believe that we should emphasise the importance of expansionary economic policies as a measure against unemployment, and that education and training systems should not primarily adapt to the needs of businesses.  On the other hand, the report highlights very important aspects of how Erasmus+ should become more inclusive and also reach groups that are not currently participating in the programmes. It is a self-critical and important reflection. With these arguments, I have chosen to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report by Parliament on the implementation of the Erasmus+ programme and, in particular, the promotion and improvement of mobility in Vocational Education and Training, especially important for young entrepreneurs and trainees. Through this report, Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to take concrete measures to improve the social and economic impact of this European programme and in particular to improve the mobility options of young people studying vocational training. In this regard, it is necessary to increase the visibility of VET programmes in order to remove cultural barriers and combat the phenomenon of lack of motivation, active predisposition and language skills, especially in those areas most affected by youth unemployment

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with erasmus+. This programme aims to replace the various previous programmes. The adoption of this programme has made significant progress in defining the concept of European mobility in the field of higher education in the single European area. In this area, it can be clearly noted that differences in academic and teaching concepts, the organisation and management of scientific institutions, the relationship between the education system and the business world are becoming increasingly complex, costly and increasing operational difficulties in developing mobility between different European countries and regions. More specifically, there remain obvious difficulties in properly implementing the procedures for the proper recognition of study credits and work practices carried out in different countries. The Europass and ECVET programmes are theoretically excellent, but still face difficulties that are not always acceptable in order to gradually adopt and implement them in practice. The different economic and social realities of the various Member States require an immediate assessment of the possibilities of reintroducing this vocational training regime across Europe. The large differences in unemployment rates in the various regions of Europe are in themselves a problem that needs to be addressed properly and in different ways.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Learning and training mobility is important for personal development, the social integration of young people, competitiveness in the labour market and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. This is part of quality education and promotion of employability.  Non-formal and informal learning, as well as vocational training, play an important role in the lifelong learning process and in addressing challenges such as early school leaving, the high number of NEETs and unemployment. Erasmus+ has been successful, but the results so far show that not all opportunities have been used to encourage mobility in the field of vocational training. Greater mobility attracts more employment. Labour market divergences mean that we need to act as soon as possible. There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work, between entrepreneurship, including SMEs, with a view to ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of young Europeans.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. My fellow Members and I supported the Report on Erasmus+ by a large majority and increased promotion of mobility in vocational education. The launch of Erasmus+ has provided many new opportunities for the participation and education of young people in the Higher Education European Area, and we are therefore committed to taking a similar initiative in the vocational education field on a similar principle. Accessibility and openness, with a view to promoting an individualised approach in the field of vocational education, are just a few things that would enable future generations of learners to gain certain virtues through experience gained in a different working and learning environment, e.g. facilitating mobility, language skills, a more appropriate response to critical situations, entrepreneurial logic, communication skills, experience in teamwork, exchanging good practices and strengthening cooperation with entrepreneurs and chambers of commerce.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Erasmus generation is probably the most tangible result of the sense of belonging to the European family. For 29 years, Europe has been allowing students to broaden their horizons and increase their skills by spending a period of their university studies abroad. As with education, vocational training-oriented mobility is now crucial for the integration of young people into the labour market, making the Erasmus+ programme a valuable tool that needs to be strengthened. The employment objective of the 2020 strategy also concerns these aspects, posing the challenge of reducing the number of NEETs (children not involved in educational or training processes) and reducing the "skill mismatch", the mismatch between skills possessed and required by the market. In this sense, the Erasmus+ programme presents enormous opportunities: employability and the European civic sense are enhanced, new professional skills, versatility, adaptability, linguistic and cultural skills are acquired. However, there are many challenges, particularly in terms of the recognition of skills acquired, the lack of compatibility of training in the countries of origin with programmes abroad and language barriers. We must work to make Erasmus+ work more flexily. I therefore wholeheartedly supported the text presented by Mr Maragall.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Erasmus has proven to be an outstanding student training programme over the years. Erasmus plus also has an additional dimension that improves educational opportunities for all. I support this report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is important, in order to try to resolve the employment crisis that has affected the younger generations of the European Union, to develop to the maximum the potential of those instruments, such as Erasmus+, which promote mobility in vocational education and training.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. In a context characterized by a growing difficulty on the part of students and young people to integrate properly into the European labour market, a high rate of early school leaving, and the major inhomogeneities of the economic and productive systems of the various Member States, it is necessary to encourage the development of European programmes capable of promoting the revival of the international mobility of young workers, students and professors and the means devoted to them. , as essential factors capable of promoting access to stable and quality work and facilitating a better adaptation of the workforce to current socio-economic developments. In particular, special attention should be paid to the development of mechanisms for the recognition of skills acquired through work and exchange programmes, to encouraging the creation of an overall framework capable of adequately presenting existing mobility opportunities to potential beneficiaries, and to the harmonisation and greater coordination of existing programmes (e.g. Erasmus + and the ESF). , with an eye to those most disadvantaged social groups often excluded from this type of extremely important initiative, not least, for strengthening the sense of belonging to the European project.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to combat youth unemployment, the report calls for promoting student mobility in education and vocational training through existing programmes such as ERASMUS, whose budget has been increased by 40% by the Commission.  Strengthening these programmes also requires increased individual grants and better coordination with the European Social Fund.  Although we reject the idea that mobility is the solution to the mass unemployment that afflicts our young people, we consider that the ERASMUS programme is one of the european Union's few successes provided it does not promote brain drain.  Furthermore, the rapporteur stresses the importance of learning in the integration of young people into the labour market and stresses the need to rely on the chambers of trades and crafts, which we fully agree with. So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of Erasmus+ at the expense of other previous programmes has been a very important development of the concept of mobility in higher education in the European area. Important, at the same time, is also the reduced mobility of vocational training courses, with the old Leonardo programme successfully implementing a first mechanism of simultaneous exchanges and visits to work and studies in countries other than the country of origin. The grouping of programmes into a single concept, Erasmus+, and the effects of the economic crisis that have been being felt since 2008 have revealed a structural deficit of mobility programmes in relation to the relationship between training and employment, so it is very clear that differences in the design of courses and programmes for study, organisation and administration of study centres, relations between education systems and business environment increase the complexity , the costs and difficulty of running mobility between countries and regions in Europe. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that this single programme, Erasmus+, is beneficial instead of the various programmes that have existed above, in particular for the mobility offered within the European Higher Education Area.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report stands out for a serious and pragmatic approach to the vast world of training and the challenges/criticalities of this historical period. We support the rapporteur's line, which identifies, as we have long maintained in schools, the need for greater integration between the world of school and the world of work. Furthermore, the attention paid to the importance of vocational education (especially in a situation such as ours) makes us appreciate the report even further. That is why we recommend a vote in favour.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Erasmus+ is an international mobility programme that facilitates access for all European students to study opportunities in another country, based on the diversity and inclusion of disadvantaged young people. One of the basic principles of the European Union is free movement. Urgent and effective measures that take account of the needs of these people must be taken in order to facilitate their access to the Erasmus+ programme. The role of education is to prepare man as an active element of social life, as a labour force and as a subject of social relations. Nowadays, technical vocational education must no longer be considered only a vocational path, but is an alternative path of academic background, which contains many elements of academic training and which can ultimately lead to a tertiary level of university training. I support this project and am sure that this initiative will contribute in the future to improving not only the civic values of learners, but also their academic skills and job prospects, combating the still so high unemployment rate that we face today at European level.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Erasmus programme is a significant step forward for student mobility.  However, it is clear that much progress remains to be made to ensure that the objectives of the programme are fully achieved. We need such a programme in order to motivate European students to travel to other Member States and thus promote cultural exchanges.  This includes ensuring the compatibility of the different education systems, strengthening the recognition of learning achievements and providing assistance to training centres.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to ensure that the European resources allocated to Erasmus+ and vocational education and training (VET) programmes are increased and proportionate to the number and needs of potential beneficiaries of the mobility offered by these programmes. I call on the Member States to promote bilateral agreements complementing the actions promoted by Erasmus+ and the European VET programmes, so as to strengthen the mobility of young Europeans. It is also necessary to facilitate the implementation of the mobility provided for in the Erasmus+ programme by taking actions to increase the success rate of applications, by simplifying the use of electronic means for mobility management, by organising awareness-raising campaigns on the value of mobility programmes in all educational institutions in the Union and by providing more targeted information and training to the beneficiaries and intermediaries of programmes and actions , including staff from schools and universities. With regard to vocational education and training (VET) programmes, I believe that the Commission and the Member States must increase their visibility and access in order to remove obstacles, particularly in the sectors most affected by youth unemployment and for workers with low-level qualifications.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very positive report on the Erasmus programme and calls for better access to mobility programmes for learners in vocational education and training. Programmes such as Erasmus provide key opportunities for our young people to study in various European cities. These opportunities not only enrich the lives and education of our young people, but also provide a great boost to Irish cities and towns in terms of European funding.  Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Unemployment among young people is still very high and as policymakers we need as many initiatives as possible that will help reduce it. This report outlines one such initiative and I therefore voted in favour.  Mobility programmes such as Erasmus+ have proven to increase employability among the participants, but unfortunately they are only available to university students. I believe it would be a very good idea to introduce mobility programmes in vocational education and of course to promote this type of education itself and make them more attractive for young people. This will lead to a more diverse workforce in the future. The programmes should also be designed in cooperation with the employers, particularly the small and medium enterprises.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this resolution, Parliament calls for better use of the Erasmus+ programme to increase the mobility of young trainees and students during vocational training. However, although the Commission and the Member States are invitations to ensure that adequate resources are allocated to the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative for the entire 2014-2020 programming period, I have found that the report only emphasises their importance and does not highlight clear evidence of their failure to meet the proposed objectives and the inadequacy of these measures and of those taken overall to adequately address the very high youth unemployment and the widening of gaps in the social and economic protection and labour rights for young people. That is why I preferred to abstain on the final vote.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. Mobility, promoted by the Erasmus+ programme, has given young Europeans the opportunity to train in another EU country and has undoubtedly contributed actively to their personal, cultural and professional growth. The comparison with different cultures, languages and working and educational methods has strengthened the sense of belonging and European citizenship. The potential of mobility programmes, in particular Erasmus+, is attributable not only to training and education but also to the world of work as they broaden employment prospects for young people.  Today, specific professional profiles are required and it would therefore be appropriate for there to be a careful selection of applicants in order to cross-reference supply and demand in order to make mobility a real tool for job placement.  The experience gained from the programme should encourage the Commission and the Member States to identify complementary and shared measures between the European Social Fund and the Erasmus+ programme to strengthen its effects and ensure economic sustainability. It is with this in mind that we will have to consider whether mobility programmes are to have sufficient coverage to ensure that the widest possible number of users benefit from the opportunities envisaged. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and note that the adoption of the Erasmus+ programme in place of the various previous programmes has been an important development for the concept of mobility throughout the European area of higher education.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the Erasmus+ programme and other tools to promote mobility within the EU, in a lifelong learning approach. Such tools can indeed help to strengthen cooperation, but also efficiency in Europe, in economic and social fields. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report highlights one of the many advantages that Europe offers, so It was my duty to speak in favour. I am in favour of the Erasmus+ programme as well as of all international mobility programmes because they allow anyone, students, graduates and non-graduates, to live, express themselves and relate in an increasingly broad international context. It is a unique possibility of cultural growth that promotes the knowledge of foreign languages and the ability to communicate, to act, to decide and to adapt in the face of new situations, all of which are fundamental today and which represent specific needs in an increasingly dynamic, international and competitive labour market. It has therefore been taken for granted to me to be in support of these international exchanges because, in my opinion, they lead to advanced vocational training which can only encourage, support and enrich our countries by providing greater opportunities for professional development and by strengthening cooperation between the various Member States. These international projects, by bringing together countries that are often different, are often complex to implement, so I am delighted with this report, which represents an important step forward in promoting international mobility.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Erasmus+, which was created to replace other preceding programmes, has created the gateway for mobility at the level of European higher education. The social and economic circumstances in some Member States point to a need for a revival in the form of vocational education throughout the Union. There is a huge imbalance in unemployment rates amongst Member States and a multidimensional response is required. A common framework which outlines possibilities available to students should be created. Programmes should be introduced to tackle language barriers, different cultural realities and create successful environments for mobility. The programme should also see to it that mobility leads to employability, one of the main aims.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mr Maragall's report which calls for the strengthening of mobility mechanisms in vocational education and training (VET). I agree with the emphasis on the need to meet the training needs of young people who wish to enter the labour market earlier or seek training with more professional characteristics and with the need to contribute to reducing school drop-out rates. I also agree that these trainees should be able to access European mobility programmes without discrimination, that actions should be developed to reduce cultural barriers and strengthen language skills, and that particular attention should be paid to areas where youth unemployment is most significant.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, this is another dimension in which the EU are trying to widen its scope and introduce new definitions in order to justify the free movement of people. We oppose calls for additional funding: this report suggests increasing the contributions made by Member States, as well as at European level. We do not support the EU intervening in the national curricula of Member States, the EU has no competency in this area and this is stated in Article 165 of the TFEU.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobility within the European higher education area needs to be consolidated in all Member States. There has been a structural deficit in mobility programmes since 2008, particularly in the relationship between training and work. , have not had the opportunity to complete secondary education or vocational training. Rather, an ambitious and concrete offer of mobility would be an integral part of any overall strategy for economic recovery and the reduction of youth unemployment levels. It is necessary to create a frame of reference that presents with simplicity and clarity the possibilities within the reach of students; adopt complementary and shared measures between the European Social Fund and the Erasmus+ programme; to define programmes aimed at removing obstacles and creating an environment as favourable as possible to the success of mobility initiatives; support the transition between mobility and work, consolidating the battle for the recognition of studies and skills.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am convinced that VET is not an educational pathway of less worth.  The negative perception on VET when contrasted to formal education has to be addressed through a concerted and common approach. We can start by establishing common high standards in European VET to provide learners with training of good standard and facilitate mobility and recognition of competences amongst diverse national systems. Tackling the negative perception revolving around VET also means that Member States have to cease using VET as a means to depict a decrease in the number of early school leavers by lowering the educational and training component or else pushing learners towards VET from a very young age without ensuring that they gain basic skills.  VET is not the stop plug to early school leaving. It is just one of the measures that may entice early school leavers to return to training but other measures taking place earlier on in a learner’s life are needed. Erasmus + and it’s effective implementation represents an important tool for re-skilling, widening and upgrading skills within a lifelong learning programme that can facilitate employment.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report calls on the EU and all Member States to address the limits that prevent access for all to equal opportunities for VET vocational education and training. Erasmus is undoubtedly one of the most successful programmes in Europe since it was set up in 1987, as more than three million people have chosen to leave to study or teach abroad. The report calls for the improvement of existing programmes and initiatives, in terms of accessibility, openness and inclusion. It is, of course, necessary in the Erasmus programmes to ensure that traineeships remain training opportunities and do not replace professional positions, as is all too often the case. There are some critical issues in the report, there are no describes of the measures implemented to deal with the enormous youth unemployment and the growing gap in socio-economic protections and employment rights for young people. Having noted many positive points in the report, but also as many shortcomings, my vote is abstention.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as its main objective is to increase efforts and actions for vocational education and training, including through the different mobility instruments such as Erasmus+ or Leonardo. The report also stresses the need to strengthen knowledge of qualifications and certificates at European level, and notes that in no way is mobility between students at European level understood only as the solution to the problem of youth unemployment in the EU.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobility programmes set up by the EU are undoubtedly one of the EU's greatest successes. Every year, through mobility programmes such as Erasmus+, more and more European citizens choose to study, to have professional experience or to work for a few months in an EU country or partner country other than their country of origin. The Erasmus+ programme has proved to be an instrument that strengthens intercultural dialogue and tolerance and, at the same time, allows participants to acquire new skills, both personally and professionally. Although Erasmus+ can be considered a success, some obstacles to participation persist. Many European citizens continue to associate the programme mainly with post-high school training. In fact, the programme also provides opportunities for citizens who want to have professional experience or who are already engaged in a professional activity. In addition, the many administrative procedures can hinder participation. Finally, while fair access to education is a right promoted by the EU, there are still significant socio-economic barriers which, unfortunately, limit the number of participants. I therefore voted in favour of Parliament's resolution promoting mobility in education and vocational training in order to enable more European citizens to participate in such rewarding experiences.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The percentage of young people who do not have a job in the European Union is 22.1%. I voted for this initiative because it gives young people the mobility to discover the areas to which they have a vocation. This mobility provided by the ERASMUS+ programme will improve transnational collaboration and competitiveness within the EU.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Erasmus+ has been successful, but the results so far show that not all opportunities have been exploited to encourage mobility in the field of vocational training. Greater mobility has been shown to attract more likely employment.  What we need to improve is the synergy between education systems, the world of work, the entrepreneurial sphere, including SMEs, with the aim of ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of Young Europeans.  Non-formal and informal learning and vocational training have an important role to play in the lifelong learning process and in addressing those challenges. Learning and training mobility is an advantage for personal development, increasing labour market competitiveness and developing skills to work in an intercultural environment.  Mobility opportunities in all regions should be made more accessible and visible to young people and to EU citizens wishing to train themselves further.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Erasmus+ is an EU programme for education, training, youth and sport. The aim of the report is to draw attention to the tools used in lifelong learning and mobility and to put forward proposals for improvements. The final report voted on in committee contains a number of positive ideas, such as a call for the extension of existing VET mobility initiatives in terms of accessibility, especially for disadvantaged families, as well as measures to facilitate integration into the labour market.  However, it also contains a number of problematic issues, such as the call for funding for language support for all Erasmus+ participants without language restrictions, and unnecessary recommendations, such as the creation of an EU e-mobility card and the recognition of Erasmus+ names and graphic signs as brands, with the possibility of using them only in Erasmus+ publications.  In addition, the report calls on Member States to introduce a dual education approach into the secondary education system, which is too prescriptive and falls outside the EU's remit. Some of the proposals contained in the report are insufficiently detailed, such as the proposal to create a European standard for VET mobility.  With this in mind, I abstained.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it beneficial to draw up a Green Paper on vocational education, vocational training, mobility and recognition of skills and competences in Europe, to which all stakeholders must contribute, because non-recognition of competences has a negative impact on the employment rate objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and hinders the free movement of European citizens within the Union. On the other hand, greater mobility linked to employment, education, apprenticeships and training courses in the context of the national 'European Youth Guarantee' programmes can and must contribute to improving young people's skills, as well as reducing the geographical differences between acquired skills and the offer of work in the EU.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution we adopted today pays particular attention to the importance of a common European education area focused on mobility, of great value for the development of the European identity and for the strengthening of a feeling of Community citizenship. The report reminds us that education, as a fundamental human right, must be easy for everyone to access and that, in this regard, we must make real efforts to remove all socio-economic obstacles preventing equal access to Opportunities for European Mobility. As the Maragall report emphasises, I believe that the Erasmus+ programme is an excellent opportunity for students and trainees to experience abroad, as it enables them to develop a common European citizenship and awareness. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution because I believe it is essential to invest in education and to increase the visibility of mobility programmes, in order to remove cultural obstacles, reduce youth unemployment and create an even deeper European identity.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution deals with methods of supporting and promoting the mobility of European students within the framework of Erasmus. The aim of this resolution is to promote the mobility of European students in vocational training, by providing new opportunities for young people's mobility and by enabling validation and recognition of the results of learning abroad.  Considering on the one hand that vocational training is essential in Europe by offering many opportunities in the labour market, and on the other hand that mobility must be accessible to all students and young people in training, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Erasmus is a great opportunity for young people in higher education to develop language skills and study in another country.  I supported this text, which particularly encourages the creation of a programme to enable the mobility of young people in the field of vocational training, such as the former Leonardo da Vinci programme.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The competitiveness of the EU depends on the quality of our workforce. In order to answer to the needs of our companies, it is essential that it is as flexible as possible. An important tool that helps us to achieve this goal is the Erasmus+ exchange programme of which we can already reap the benefits.  After having this programme in force for several years now, it was time for an evaluation. Although the programme is overall successful, some apparent problems came to light. One of these is the gap between academic and vocational educational training (VET). Systems such as Europass and ECVET were designed to address these problems but have encountered opposition themselves. This makes the accreditation between educational institutions of various countries more difficult. Such imbalances are also reflected in the unemployment data from across the EU.  Following the report of 4 March, this resolution stresses the need for a more extensive and more qualitative Erasmus+ programme, for a more varying number of students. To incentivise the programme, a list of 10 objectives has been created, which will serve as a guideline. Having taken all of the above into account, I have approved of this parliamentary resolution.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the European Union, the youth unemployment rate stands at 22.1%, more than twice the overall unemployment rate. In this context, apprenticeships and vocational training that enable better job integration for the unemployed and young people who drop out of school need to be improved.  The strengthening of mobility under Erasmus, a better visibility of vocational education and training programmes for SMEs, the unemployed and apprentices, and the reduction of red tape are useful and necessary advances in this regard.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Erasmus report. It is a programme to promote employment in Europe by supporting education, training, youth and sport.  Four million Europeans will be able to benefit from it to acquire new skills and work experience. I wanted to support the mobility and professional integration of young people by voting in favour of this programme, which is part of the 'Strategic Education and Training Framework 2020', which aims to move 6% of graduates.  Indeed, it seemed important to me to recall the importance of European cooperation for the education and training of young people, in order to promote economic growth in Europe, social equality and the integration of young people.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Learning and training mobility is important for personal development, the social integration of young people, labour market competitiveness and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. This is part of quality education and promotion of employability.  Non-formal and informal learning, as well as vocational training, play an important role in the lifelong learning process and in addressing challenges such as early school leaving, the high number of NEETs and unemployment. Erasmus+ has been successful, but the results so far show that not all opportunities have been used to encourage mobility in the field of vocational training. Greater mobility attracts more employment. Labour market divergences mean that we need to act as soon as possible. There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work and entrepreneurship, including SMEs, with a view to ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of Young Europeans.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite the Europeanist, multiculturalist and even communitarian ideology that appears in this text, I supported this report because it tends to enhance apprenticeship and vocational training.  It stresses the role of SMEs but also of the chambers of trades and crafts in the development of related policies. The Erasmus programme and intergovernmental cooperation, allowing students to train abroad, are a step in the right direction, as is the recognition of curricula between states.  However, mobility should not promote brain drain and worker uprooting.

name: Damian Drăghici (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Erasmus+ is one of the most successful EU programmes that gives learners more opportunities to acquire new professional skills as well as linguistic, social and intercultural competences that can help them become more competitive on the labour market and also more aware of and engaged in the social and political life of the Union.  Erasmus+ can make a major contribution in achieving EU2020 objectives and in addressing the current challenges posed by huge unemployment (especially among young people), skills shortages and mismatches between education and labour market, high rates of early school leaving and of young people not in education, employment or training. Therefore I fully support the constructive proposals included in this report for expanding and improving mobility options for all learners in VET starting with creating a European reference framework. In order to boost the quantity and quality of mobility in VET, the Commission together with the Member States need to correlate their efforts in order to ensure that the right to quality and inclusive education is much better protected and that there are no constraints or barriers to programmes or initiatives taken at EU and national level, especially for learners from vulnerable or disadvantaged groups.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Erasmus+ is perhaps one of the EU's greatest successes and therefore we need to closely monitor its application and citizens' feedback on its improvement. Vocational education and training is promoted through various EU instruments and mobility is an important moment in character building and experience.  The report, which I have been tasked with following on behalf of my Conservative group, provides some successful ideas, such as calls for an improvement in accessibility in existing mobility initiatives in vocational education and training, especially for economically disadvantaged families, as well as measures to facilitate labour market integration.  At the same time, however, there is a focus on this mobility in different sectors, which I do not think should be the goal. It is also proposed to establish a European standard for mobility in vocational education and training, without specifying exactly what this includes.  It is important that we listen well to the problems of citizens in this regard and see exactly where the problems lie - whether in bureaucracy and paperwork or in the inaccessibility of such programs for many low-income people. In the end, I abstained from voting.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Learning and training mobility is important for personal development, the social integration of young people, labour market competitiveness and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. This is part of quality education and promotion of employability.  Non-formal and informal learning, as well as vocational training, play an important role in the lifelong learning process and in addressing challenges such as early school leaving, the high number of NEETs and unemployment. Erasmus+ has been successful, but the results so far show that not all opportunities have been used to encourage mobility in the field of vocational training. Greater mobility attracts more employment. Labour market divergences mean that we need to act as soon as possible. There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work and entrepreneurship, including SMEs, with a view to ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of Young Europeans.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: this report carries the desire for the necessary revaluation of apprenticeships and vocational training.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report in question, while presenting positive aspects, such as the qualification of education as a fundamental human right and as a public good whose access must be guaranteed to all on an equal footing, also presents critical elements. In particular, there is no clear denunciation of the failure of the Youth Guarantee programme and the Youth Employment Initiative in relation to the proposed objectives. Above all, there is no reference to the inadequacy of these measures and of those taken as a whole to adequately address the very high youth unemployment and the widening of gaps in socio-economic protection and labour rights for young people. In the final analysis, our opinion of this resolution cannot be definitively approved.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The various pre-existing EU mobility programmes have been incorporated into one, Erasmus+. The effects of this measure are also to be assessed in depth. The overall objective of the report is to ask the European Commission and the Member States to make efforts in favour of vocational education and training within all existing mobility tools. The report identifies a number of challenges that EU mobility programmes must address, highlighting access difficulties. If Erasmus is seen as a successful mobility programme in the EU, the truth is that mobility rates are low. This is mainly due to the fact that the grants awarded are few and do not reach the costs of tuition, food, housing, study material, transport and others. Only a restricted social group has access to mobility. The report is not free of contradictions. Education is defended as a right that should be guaranteed to all people. But "market education" is privileged over "life education". We follow many of the criticisms that the report makes, namely the lack of access to education by the most disadvantaged population. We agree with actions aimed at removing barriers and with greater support for learning other languages.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, considering it a major step forward for mobility as a concept in the area of higher education, which will mean greater and better employability in the near future for European citizens.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This is a worthy attempt to incorporate Vocational Education and Training into the already very successful Erasmus programme. I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The new Erasmus+ programme merges all existing European Union programmes for education, training, youth and sport, including erasmus, Leonardo da Vinci, Comenius, Grundtvig, Youth in Action and five international cooperation programmes. Too many young people are leaving school early and are thus at great risk of being unemployed and socially marginalised. Many low-skilled adults are also at the same risk. Technology is changing the way society works, and there is a need to ensure that they are best used. Businesses in the European Union must become more competitive and make better use of talent and innovation. Europe needs a more cohesive and inclusive society that allows its citizens to play an active role in democratic life. Education and youth work are key to preventing dangerous radicalisation by promoting common European values, fostering social inclusion, increasing cultural understanding and a sense of belonging to society.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour because I support the need for greater integration between the world of school and the world of work.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because it promotes the mobility of young workers within the Union, but it is responsible for draining many Member States from a valuable skilled workforce. Moreover, it degrades education into simple education, suitable only to meet the needs of the market and exploit the goodwill of young workers.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Learning mobility and training mobility have clearly proved their potential to contribute to high-quality education and employability; I therefore believe they should be should be further strengthened in EU programmes in the area of education and training, employment and cohesion policy. Member States must adopt as quickly as possible concrete measures to improve the social and economic impact to achieve a highly skilled workforce with inclusive education policies. It is absolutely important to have tools, like Erasmus+, that push for this goal. I strongly believe that Erasmus + documentation must be made available in all EU official languages. Enhanced mobility for VET (Vocational Educational Training), in particular for youth apprenticeship and trainees, will contribute to growth and jobs creation in the EU.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Learning and training mobility is important for personal development, the social integration of young people, labour market competitiveness and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. This is part of quality education and promotion of employability. There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work and entrepreneurship, including SMEs, with a view to ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of Young Europeans.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Learning and training mobility is important for personal development, the social integration of young people, labour market competitiveness and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. This is part of quality education and promotion of employability.  Non-formal and informal learning, as well as vocational training, play an important role in the lifelong learning process and in addressing challenges such as early school leaving, the high number of NEETs and unemployment. There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work and entrepreneurship, including SMEs, with a view to ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of Young Europeans.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I am pleased to support the report which promotes tangible measures for socio-economic growth and new appropriations aimed at combating unemployment through the promotion of the Erasmus plus programme, which goes well beyond the objectives set previously with the Leonardo programme and which represents for young people the concreteness of a Union commitment that stimulates, focuses and invests in accessibility, integration and mobility of the new generations.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the Erasmus Plus programme and other instruments to promote mobility in the field of VET – a lifelong learning approach – because the Erasmus Plus programme, which replaces all the different programmes previously implemented, promotes a simpler understanding of the opportunities offered by the European Union to young people, as well as the concept of intercultural mobility in higher education. However, we cannot fail to highlight the economic disparities that exist within the Member States and the different development models, which create many difficulties for the full implementation of these programmes. There are, in fact, situations of severe social crisis arising from the impossibility of providing employment opportunities for thousands of young people and other situations in which there is a lack of qualified young people for a given production segment. For all these reasons, I believe it is essential to set more forward-looking and ambitious objectives and to define strategies that meet the conditions of flexibility and operation of education and production systems.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on 'Erasmus+ and other instruments to promote mobility in vocational education and training— an approach to lifelong learning'. Erasmus+ brings together young Europeans and people of all ages across borders in the diversity of its funding instruments. It is a vital instrument of European encounter and understanding – an instrument that we need more than ever at this time of crisis.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. In my view, the promotion of young generations in terms of practical foreign experience is a fundamental task for the further development of the EU. Student or occupational mobility is now required by many employers as a qualification. A good concept and management of the programmes as well as financial support make the success possible.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, the Erasmus+ programme is a fantastic way of improving young people’s intercultural and language skills. One of the challenges, though, is to ensure that these programmes are not limited to students in higher education but also to more disadvantaged young people – and provide them with an opportunity to study or work abroad. I therefore welcome this report, which calls for expanding and improving mobility for vocational training and education.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In line with the UK government, I welcome and subsequently support the development of Vocational and Educational Training (VET) as well as the Erasmus+ programme. As examples of EU-level culture and education programmes, both offer a good degree of EU added value and consequently offer significant benefits for UK citizens. Indeed, such programmes help to ensure people have the skills both they, and our economy, need in order to grow. Unfortunately however, a number of less favourable proposals were adopted during the committee stage. Not only do these proposals risk increased spending and red tape for Member States, but they also seek to promote a ‘stronger European identity’ and are overly prescriptive in respect of Member State education systems. As a firm supporter of the principle of subsidiarity, such attempted competence creep is unacceptable and as a result, limited the extent to which I could support this report. The UK must remain in the position whereby it can develop its own systems to reflect the needs of its citizens. It is the UK, and not the EU, that is in the best position to make decisions on such matters. It is for these reasons that I abstained.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve the Erasmus programme. The Commission has already set out to provide this programme with a budget of EUR 14.7 billion, an increase of 40% over the current budget. In particular, there are plans to strengthen the programme at the level of vocational training and apprenticeships, in order to strengthen the link between education and the world of work, particularly with small and medium-sized enterprises.  Although the report assumes that the mobility of young Europeans will solve the problem of unemployment, it does include measures that are in line with better qualifications and employability of young people.  So I voted for this text, because Erasmus allows students to train abroad, without organising a brain drain or uprooting of workers.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report underlines the importance of Erasmus+ and other tools to promote mobility in vocational and technical education. These instruments demonstrate that a real and ambitious mobility offer must be part of any overall strategy for economic recovery and reduction of youth unemployment rates, which have reached far too high levels in recent times. In some European regions the real unemployment rate is close to zero, while in other areas there is an increase in it to more than 40% among young people, especially among those who have not been able to complete their secondary education or vocational training. That is why, in order to avoid dropping out of school, it is very important for the EU to take the necessary measures, and European mobility programmes are such a measure.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Erasmus programme, which we are celebrating this year's first anniversary, is one of the great successes of the European Union.  It allows millions of young people to go on a mobile basis, whether they are students, in training or in professional mobility. Above all, it subsequently promotes, and significantly, the employability and professional mobility of people who have experienced this experience.  Increasing the resources of this programme, completing the process of recognition of studies and professional experiences, are all reasons why I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report which will improve mobility options for students in disadvantaged positions who rely on this programme to study and gain work experience abroad. Mobility has an undeniable positive effect in terms of skills and competences development and, ultimately, employability of young people. It also represents a key opportunity for the self-development of individuals who will learn another language, open up to other cultures and acquire intercultural skills, on top of the specific competences they will be trained for.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of this motion as enabling more  Erasmus+ opportunities is a positive in enabling  more mobility options for young people among European Union networks. This will be enhanced by closing the gap between vocational education and training systems.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The introduction of the Erasmus+ programme is seen as an important step forward in the direction of mobility between higher education institutions, but less wide-spread in the field of vocational training. The aim of the report is to find solutions to differences between Member States in terms of curricula, the organisation of education and the relationship of the education system with the business sector, which make European mobility programmes more complex, costly and difficult to run. The resolution approved by the Committee on Culture and Education recognises the challenges of education systems, such as reducing the proportion of early school leavers relevant in Hungary, developing foreign language and entrepreneurship skills, improving the knowledge of vet teachers and promoting personalised education. The directives set out in the draft will increase mobility opportunities for young people by better coordinating the Structural Funds with certain education programmes. The validation and joint recognition of skills and competences will help to overcome the differences between vocational training systems in each Member State, with a number of existing instruments, such as Europass and ECVET. By expanding the Erasmus+ programme, Young Hungarians can acquire new professional knowledge, learn business practices from other countries and, last but not least, increase their personal development and adaptability. I am voting in favour of this report because it is an important step forward for our country in promoting quality education and employment for our young people.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ One challenge of the Erasmus+ programme is ensuring that it reaches out to students in higher education but also to more disadvantaged young people who would not otherwise have access to such opportunities of learning abroad. Labour MEPs welcome this report which calls for expanding and improving mobility for VET (vocational training and education) through existing European programmes, but also through the establishment of a common European framework setting out the possibilities open to young people in terms of available courses, locations, range of professional activity and sector, companies, duration, and the final qualification they would achieve.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The ability of students to study for part of their course in each other’s countries is a major European success story. The universities of Essex, Hertfordshire and East Anglia offer the chance to study abroad in over 20 different countries, and more than 150 students from the University of Cambridge participated in Erasmus exchanges abroad in 2013-2014. Today I am backing extending such exchanges to students from a wider spectrum of society, with more emphasis on exchanges involving vocational training as well as more traditional, academic education.  As a Co-President of the all-party Disability Rights Intergroup in this Parliament, I particularly commend the provisions to ensure specific support so disabled young people are fully given the opportunity to take part. All of this is not just about students being able to experience life and learning elsewhere in Europe, but being able to use that learning to benefit from life opportunities in their careers for the rest of those lives.  There are those from my own country who are looking to cut off these life chances to our young people. Labour MEPs are working here in the European Parliament and campaigning in Britain to maintain them for future generations.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report convinced that Erasmus+ has made an important step forward for the concept of mobility in the european higher education area as a whole. However, we must address large inequalities in the Member States, with States where about 40% of young people are in unemployment. We must bet on a real and ambitious mobility offer as part of an overall strategy of economic recovery and reduction of youth unemployment rates. Similarly, we must work to accelerate the completion of quality recognition, accreditation and evaluation processes. We must also work to be able to provide information on this important European programme in the different official languages of the Member States, therefore respecting the rights of European citizens.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Erasmus is undoubtedly one of the European Union's greatest achievements.  Since 1987, 3 million students have been able to continue their studies at a university in another Member State. It is a program that I am particularly keen on. It is the symbol of a Europe of peoples and mobility that allows young people to benefit from the richness of a cultural exchange and to have a quality university and vocational education.  But in order for young Europeans to face today's challenges, it is necessary to continually rethink Erasmus. That is why I voted for Erasmus' reform proposal.  Today, access to the Erasmus programme remains largely facilitated for students. The resolution passed in Parliament will make better use of Erasmus funding to increase the mobility of young apprentices and students through vocational training.  This project is necessary because youth unemployment must be at the heart of our concerns. It is an initiative that will improve their professional integration by guaranteeing them better training through linguistic, cultural and personal enrichment.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Learning and training mobility is important for personal development, the social integration of young people, labour market competitiveness and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. This is part of quality education and promotion of employability.  Non-formal and informal learning, as well as vocational training, play an important role in the lifelong learning process and in addressing challenges such as early school leaving and the large number of young people who do not receive or work in education or training. Erasmus+ has been successful, but the results so far show that not all opportunities have been used to encourage mobility in the field of vocational training. Greater mobility attracts more employment. Labour market divergences mean that we need to act as soon as possible. There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work and entrepreneurship, including SMEs, with a view to ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of Young Europeans.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the encouragement and facilitation of students' access to education/training with a view to enhancing their mobility, while also including actions aimed at removing cultural barriers and supporting language learning.  All disadvantaged groups and people with disabilities should be effectively included in information meetings and preparation. The report also insists on strengthening the recognition of professional qualifications, certificates and informal learning, as well as the importance of ensuring a strong learning component in the field of vocational education, training and apprenticeships.  It also admits that mobility should not be the only solution to the unacceptable dimensions of youth unemployment in the EU. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I congratulate my colleague Mr Maragall on this report. I am however disappointed that his amendment supporting the languages used in each country’s education system did not pass. Education in Europe is provided through mediums which go well beyond the EU’s official languages and this reality should be recognised within Erasmus. It is ironic that on a day this House voted to promote an ‘EU aspect’ in education systems, it voted to deny the rights of speakers of Scots, Gaelic, Welsh and Catalan.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Erasmus is one of the most successful projects of the European Union. We cannot imagine a single economy, a single European market, unless we are talking about a single labour market, mobility of young people within the borders of the European Union, exchanges of experience between universities and graduates of higher education who have the same training for the labour market across the European Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on Erasmus+ and other measures to boost mobility in vocational education and training – a lifelong learning approach, as I assess this programme as extremely important in professional training and skills acquisition in young people needed on the labour market, but I also see this programme as a programme that contributes to a better understanding of European reality in young people acceptance of the European idea and European values.  It is particularly important that this contributes to the transfer of knowledge between those countries that have exceptionally high quality vocational education and have therefore succeeded in almost eliminating youth unemployment, towards less successful member states. It is important to facilitate the implementation of erasmus+ mobility by taking measures to increase the success rate of applications, simplifying the design and use of electronic mobility management tools, raising awareness of the value of mobility programmes in all general and professional educational institutions in the Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, carried by Greens MP Maragall, focuses on improving the Erasmus programme. It builds on the Commission's programme for 2014-2020, which aims to "strengthen skills and employability, as well as modernise the education, training and work of young people".  The Commission has already planned to provide this programme with a budget of EUR 14.7 billion, a 40% increase over current spending levels. We recognise that Erasmus has been one of the EU's few successes and we support intergovernmental cooperation that allows students to train abroad, provided that this does not replace the acquisition of basic knowledge and that such an initiative does not become the "sas" of preparation for brain drain and worker uprooting.  I voted in favour of this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, this is another dimension in which the EU are trying to widen its scope and introduce new definitions in order to justify the free movement of people. We oppose calls for additional funding: this report suggests increasing the contributions made by Member States, as well as at European level. We do not support the EU intervening in the national curricula of Member States, the EU has no competency in this area and this is stated in Article 165 of the TFEU.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 While the vast majority of university students now take advantage of exchange programmes, only 1% of apprentices are involved in mobility programmes. I am therefore glad that we have adopted this report by a large majority today. It sends a signal to both the Member States and the Commission that we also need better access and more exchange programme options for vocational school students. It will boost the competitiveness of the European labour market and provide young people with significant experience and skills that will increase their chances of future application.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ernest Maragall's report on the Erasmus programme and other tools to promote mobility in vocational education and training.  The aim of this report is to maximise the compatibility of different vocational education and training systems by developing mobility programmes that are accessible and open to EU citizens to establish a network of workshops and incubators within the Union. I encourage the development of such a program as part of vocational education and training.  This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to improve mobility in vocational training and education in Europe. To this end, this report proposes to improve the mobility possibilities of young people, to move towards validation and recognition of the results of learning, skills and skills throughout the Union and to enable the implementation of accessible and open mobility programmes. Mobility during studies and under an employment contract improves employability. In the current context of massive youth unemployment in Europe, it is important to support such initiatives. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The new Erasmus+ programme is a great opportunity for young people. It is also a support for the European labour market and a response to challenges. An ageing population or ever-increasing youth unemployment mean that we need to look for new solutions. Until now, we have placed great emphasis on exchanges in academia, and yet the labour market is also admonished for highly qualified professionals. The economy also needs good workers with lower education who will be professionals in their field, have good knowledge and will do their job solidly. Going to another country and being able to practice their profession in a new environment is a unique experience that allows young people to become more open, flexible, mobile and independent. These are, after all, the characteristics that employers are looking for the most now. Such an exchange is also an opportunity to compare the technologies and traditions of different countries.  Thanks to such a programme, the most talented, but also poor young people who cannot afford to go privately will be able to expand their educational horizons and improve their skills. Erasmus+ will allow for a level playing field among young people, which will also support the equal development of Member States' economies.
