name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it calls for the EU’s Erasmus student exchange programme to be extended to more disadvantaged young people, for example those in vocational training, who cannot currently access the scheme.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union can be successfully blamed for much, but on the other hand, we must not forget its pros. Few would agree that Erasmus+ and other tools to promote VET mobility are among the most successful elements of European integration. I supported the report on the grounds, inter alia, that mobility in education and training is important for personal development, social inclusion of young people, multicultural dialogue, tolerance, the ability to work in an intercultural environment and active citizenship, and has clearly demonstrated its contribution in terms of high-quality education and employability. Moreover, we must not forget that youth unemployment is now 22.1% across the EU. In the Czech Republic, the situation is not so tragic, but in Spain, for example, youth unemployment is still up to 50% and there is already talk of a lost generation. It is clear that Erasmus+ cannot solve the socio-economic problems caused by a non-conceptual and ill-thought-out policy of cuts. However, it will allow at least students from all over Europe to exchange experiences and improve their position in the labour market.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Learning and training mobility is important for personal development, the social integration of young people, labour market competitiveness and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. This is part of quality education and promotion of employability.  Non-formal and informal learning, as well as vocational training, play an important role in the lifelong learning process and in addressing challenges such as early school leaving, the high number of NEETs and unemployment. Erasmus+ has been successful, but the results so far show that not all opportunities have been used to encourage mobility in the field of vocational training. Greater mobility attracts more employment. Labour market divergences mean that we need to act as soon as possible. There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work and entrepreneurship, including SMEs, with a view to ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of Young Europeans.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ We must acknowledge that programs like Erasmus+ represent a key element for mobility within the EU. Consequently, there is a need to guarantee the access of learners to vocational education, and to remove obstacles that are able to dissuade students from participating. I share the opinion of the rapporteur that disparities among Member States in terms of economic and social realities, affect the effective accessibility to these programmes.  However, we must not give the false impression that mobility is the unique solution in order to combat unemployment. Even if the link between mobility and employability is still mentioned, the final report presents several improvements and provides some considerable guidelines for policy action implicating all the responsible actors.  These are the reasons that have led me to vote in favour.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Education is one of the veterinary horses both in my country and in the EU as a whole. Overtraining and underqualifiedness are present at the same time. Universities are shed on those with unnecessary qualifications, while there is a shortage of IT professionals, doctors and engineers, for example. The situation in secondary education is not much better either. The result of the educational chaos is the simultaneous shortage of professionals and the high level of youth unemployment. Despite my reservations, I supported this report because, even with its flaws, it creates some chances for progress.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report on Erasmus+ and other mobility support tools in vocational education and training highlights the role of mobility, international traineeships and traineeships in improving employment opportunities and eliminating skills mismatch. The report recalls the 'Copenhagen process' launched by EU education ministers in 2002 to strengthen cooperation and the attractiveness of VET in Europe. Further developing the European education space is important not only for improving the educational and life opportunities of young people in Europe, but also for developing intercultural dialogue and EU integration.  I agree with the report's thesis that more effective language teaching is a prerequisite for increasing mobility, especially in vocational schools; insufficient language skills is the first barrier to mobility in Europe. Information on Erasmus+ programmes and other tools supporting mobility in vocational training should also be disseminated to potential stakeholders. Strengthening the mobility of vocational training participants, its internationalisation, could contribute to the recognition and rehabilitation of vocational training in those countries where it has been subject to years of degradation and marginalisation in favour of general education. Meanwhile, an efficient vocational training system is the first condition for a healthy labour market, low unemployment and the consistent development of SMEs, family and craft companies, which are a pillar of the European economy. It should therefore be developed and involved in EU mobility programmes.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the motion for a resolution to encourage student mobility both academically and in terms of vocational training. We are increasingly witnessing a winning Erasmus programme, which has beguned sustainable mobility by young students and which has made it possible to exchange experiences and develop skills that are essential for their academic and work growth. These skills are most sought after in the professional sector that is becoming increasingly competitive. I therefore believe it is essential to promote Erasmus + more as a whole, but above all professional mobility, which has unfortunately not so far shown the same positive results as mobility in education. We need to optimise the transition from the education system to the working world, and Erasmus is the right tool to do so.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it extends the Erasmus programme to help people stay abroad, which has demonstrated its interest in students, to apprenticeships and vocational training.

name: Andrew Lewer (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ British Conservatives opted to abstain on this report due to a mix of positive and negative elements. We broadly welcomed, for example, the rapporteur’s commitment to tackling the gender gap in STEM education through EU supporting programmes (§40); the suggestion that priority should be given to longer-term work experience over short-term equivalents, which reduces administrative burden (§7); and the call to assess the impact of Erasmus+ and other vocational and educational training (VET) mobility programmes, in matching work experience placements with real jobs (§65). However, other paragraphs propose unnecessary measures likely to create additional costs (§9, 15, 24) and interfere in areas of national competence, for example, secondary education systems (§27) and in how we define and develop VET (§20), which UK Members were unable to support. With a record number of people in work and youth unemployment reaching near 10-year lows, the UK must remain free to develop its own VET and is best placed to do so. Inflexible, EU-wide definitions of apprenticeships should be avoided, just as exploitation and unfair working practices must continue to be countered if Member States are to develop flexible labour markets that help to provide opportunities for young people.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The report focuses on improving the Erasmus programme. This programme allows young Europeans to go abroad to train, strengthen their skills and gain language experience.  For the implementation of this programme between 2014 and 2020, the Commission has budgeted for EUR 14.7 billion, a 40% increase over the current level of expenditure. In addition, the improvement focuses on the enhancement of apprenticeships and vocational training, focusing on small and medium-sized enterprises and fostering intergovernmental cooperation.  Of course, some not inconsiderable flaws are inscribed in this text, including the idea that the Erasmus programme will help to solve the problem of unemployment; it promotes the development of communitarianism, and is an ode to European multiculturalism.  However, as the programme is one of the few successes of the European Union and a real opportunity for young people, I voted FOR.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as its main objective is to increase efforts and actions for vocational education and training, including through the different mobility instruments such as Erasmus+ or Leonardo. The report also stresses the need to strengthen knowledge of qualifications and certificates at European level, and notes that in no way is mobility between students at European level understood only as the solution to the problem of youth unemployment in the EU.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In this report, Parliament urges the European Commission and Member States, within the framework of the Education and Training 2020 strategy, to allocate sufficient financial resources for the maintenance and strengthening of the Erasmus+ programme. The importance of such programs is that mobility in learning is shown to be key to ensuring quality education and, therefore, a higher level of student employability.  We are particularly concerned that young people believe that Erasmus+ is designed for university students and therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to disclose the existence of this programme in Vocational Education and Training. That is why my vote for this report will be favourable.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree that the Erasmus programme 'should take into account the needs of people identifying as LGBTI'. For God's sake, how?! Should they have a preferential right to choose a course of study abroad? Should they have special accommodation? Special equipment? I really don't get it, and I'm happy to explain.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Lifelong learning and vocational education and training are key to achieving better employment prospects, especially for the long-term unemployed. Erasmus+ is a programme in the fields of education, training, youth and sport for the period 2014-2020 ̶ 2020. The fields of education, training, youth and sport can make a significant contribution to addressing the main socio-economic challenges facing Europe by the end of the decade, as well as implementing a European policy for growth, jobs, equality and social inclusion. European funding allocated to Erasmus+ and VET programmes is not proportionate to the number and needs of those interested in mobility under these programmes, and Member States should promote bilateral agreements complementing the activities of Erasmus+ and European VET programmes, the same way increasing the mobility of young Europeans. It is important to facilitate the implementation of Erasmus+ mobility by taking measures to increase the success rate of applications, simplifying the design and use of electronic mobility management tools and reducing excessive and complex administrative burdens, as excessive bureaucracy in schools and universities involved in the programme is an obstacle to the rapid implementation of the programme.  Erasmus+ contributes to better education, training and greater mobility of young people, which are the Union's objectives in economic and social terms, so I supported the report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Erasmus+ support greatly helps to increase mobility, gain education and experience of students and educators, increase language skills and remove barriers to learning from other countries. At the same time, acquired experience and skills should make it easier for graduates to get jobs. However, statistics continue to show persistent differences in unemployment across eu regions, with young people in particular being among the most at risk. In 2014, youth unemployment was 22.1% at 10.2%. It turns out that there are still differences between young people's acquired skills and the need for a labour market. It is therefore essential that the Member States and the Union take measures to strengthen mobility in vocational education and training, creating the conditions for tackling this problem. Erasmus+ must be applied to all levels and types of education;

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the Erasmus+ programme and other tools to promote mobility within VET – a lifelong learning approach, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/4/2016, and because this report is comprehensive and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. Apart from the initial premise, which sets up "international mobility" as a sesame against mass unemployment in Europe, I welcome the strengthening of the Erasmus programme and its openness to vocational training. The Erasmus programme replaces the Erasmus programme, which has enjoyed undeniable success. This change is not purely in form: Erasmus' budget is increased by 40% compared to previous editions. In addition, Erasmus strengthens its vocational training component and finally values learning, encouraging internships and training within SMEs.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the Erasmus+ programme and other instruments to promote mobility in VET- A lifelong learning approach, I welcome. Education is one of the fundamental rights that must be accessible to all, also taking into account the needs of people who are victims of different forms of discrimination. Mobility for learning and training is of primary importance for personal development and helps to contribute to high-quality education. Learning and vocational training systems need to be more efficient and accessible, extending and improving mobility opportunities, increasing financial resources, removing obstacles, so as to contribute to European integration and the strengthening of the idea of citizenship.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We need to work harder to end youth unemployment by giving our young people the skills they need for the 21st century economy. In doing so, we must above all promote education and training for non-traditional skills for girls, in order to put an end to discrimination in employment opportunities, to close the wage gap. This resolution is an opportunity to resolve these issues as soon as possible, so I have expressed my support for it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for the proposal to strengthen the Erasmus+ programme in order to ensure that vocational training students can access and benefit from it. In this Parliament we believe that the recognition and validation of all types of training should be better organised at national level, whether in the form of credits or certificates, as well as language learning and the organisation of curriculums and curricolades. However, we strongly rejected the proposal that all Erasmus+ programme documents should be submitted solely and compulsorily by the European Commission and the Member States in the vehicle languages.  We want Erasmus+ to remain a mechanism for promoting unity among students across Europe and not a language division tool.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to take this opportunity to contribute to the debate by highlighting the results already obtained by the region I represent: Lombardy.   The Lombardy Region has already responded in the last three years to the concerns we are discussing today. There are personalized training courses in work "Studying in the company and finding work at school". An interesting combination, which sees with a regional law dedicated to the dual system, apprenticeship and internationalization, the school-work alternation materializes (the first region to follow up national law 107/2015). Not forgetting the investment in new technologies for all students (Web Generation).  International mobility and lifelong learning are the two key aspects of the Lombard education system. The regional institutional level is fundamental, in order to guarantee personalized tools and paths. Non-formal skills are the basis of a growth path that must accompany institutionalised learning. In the absence of this complementarity, the young person is in danger of not seeing the encounter between his training and the labour market. We must promote a system for the recognition of these competences: the only ones that can make a difference to the legal value of the qualification alone.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Erasmus+ programme promotes the mobility of European students and staff of higher education institutions. The parallel exchange of studies between Union institutions is thus achieved with the ultimate aim of reducing the divergence in unemployment rates between Member States. By providing mobility opportunities to young scientists, the productive economy is also strengthened, since young people have the opportunity to come into contact with new scientific methods.  Nevertheless, the problem is the difficulty of adequate and full recognition of qualifications and traineeships from country to country, as well as the lack of a programme on vocational training for young people, because the efforts made relate mainly to higher education. Among other things, I believe that the main beneficial effect of the whole effort is to increase employability, to spread the values of the European citizen and to better educate young people in the Union. For this reason, the present difficulties should be overcome through policies, such as the adaptation of education systems to effectively address the difficulty of matching skills and the existence of a corresponding policy relating to vocational and technical training.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report proposes ways to extend access to mobility in other mobility programmes, in the field of education and vocational training, such as apprentices.  But we should still give ourselves the means to welcome and prepare for mobility and provide adequate allowances for internships so as not to serve as yet another precarious contract.  I therefore regret the initial approach of the report, of a presumed mismatch between "supply and demand in the labour market" which invites the private sector to further orient student paths. This logic is widely denounced in the countries of the South, where large sections of the youth are then forced into exile to find work.  Under these conditions, I vote against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Erasmus is a programme that goes beyond what Erasmus is planning. It is a herald of "mobility" that Erasmus was merely sketching. The aim is to link education and work closely to enable competent people to be sent to the eu's poor regions.  I do not accept "mobility" as a solution for employment among young people. However, this report emphasizes the value of learning and the role of small and medium-sized enterprises.  In short, despite passages on multiculturalism and communitarianism (in favor of LGBTI and migrants) I found the whole correct. I only hope that it will not give rise to a brain drain or that it will not become an instrument of worker expatriation. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Erasmus+ report and other tools to promote mobility in VET. Erasmus as a mobility programme for learning and personal development has shown its important potential for promoting employment, social cohesion and skills development. It is essential that funding for learning mobility programmes such as Erasmus+ is a priority of the European Union as part of the political agenda for promoting education and youth.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the use of Erasmus+ and other European tools to improve the mobility of students enrolled in vocational education and training. By using these tools in the proposed way we can improve opportunities for young Europeans.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Student Exchange Programme, ERASMUS, is one of the Success Stories of the European Union. In 2012-13, some 270,000 young people completed part of their academic studies at another European university through this programme.  In addition to the ability to fine-tune language learning, Erasmus is a unique experience of opening up to Europe. "Erasmus": with a budget of 14 billion euros for the period 2014-2020, it offers 4 million young Europeans the opportunity to study or train abroad.  This new programme covers not only training, education and youth but also for the first time sport. With Erasmus, students who have not had the chance to win a scholarship will have the opportunity to receive a loan on favourable terms to do a master's degree in another EU country.  I would like the Union to go even further in the area of language employment. In my opinion, the system existing in European schools (learning several languages from an early age) should be the basis of school curricula in the Member States.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – European mobility programmes such as Erasmus, Erasmus Mundusči or Leonardo, which successfully completed its first phase and was subsequently replaced by Erasmus+, are demonstrably contributing to the development of the knowledge society, which is one of the EU's objectives of the 2020 strategy. In particular, Erasmus+ is part of the European Lifelong Learning Programme and focuses primarily on vocational education and training. It is these areas that I consider particularly important at the moment, when Europe is struggling with an ever-high unemployment rate – which in some regions is climbing to the ominous figure of 100% (the so-called hunger valleys) – caused by underdeveloped vocational training systems, often not taking into account the needs of the current labour market. It is Erasmus+ that aims to remove such barriers, as it provides the opportunity to participate in training courses and courses aimed at acquiring knowledge and skills, for which there is real demand in practice, overcoming language barriers or providing european funds. I am convinced that by training the skills valued in the labour market and the right link between educational institutions, their students, companies and fund providers, we will be able to overcome the long-term employment crisis and bring job opportunities back to many European regions. I express my support for the report that has been tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this important report, which focuses on the implementation of Erasmus+ and the mobility aspect to Vocational Educational Training as the continuation of previous Leonardo programme. It considers the objectives of the mobility programme and calls on the Commission and the Member States to adopt concrete measures to improve the social and economic impact to achieve a highly skilled workforce with inclusive education policies. Enhanced mobility for VET, in particular for youth apprenticeship and trainees, will contribute to growth and job creation in the EU.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU unemployment remained at 10.2% in 2014 and youth unemployment stood at 22.1%. Meanwhile, there is a structural labour shortage in the labour market, as indicated by the high proportion of vacancies. There are huge differences in this area between european regions: in some cases the real rate is close to zero, while elsewhere unemployment has stabilised above 40% among younger people, many of whom have not been able to obtain a secondary education or qualification. Real mobility opportunities are therefore an essential part of any general strategy to boost the economy and reduce the youth unemployment rate.  The replacement of the various previous programmes with Erasmus+ has been a significant step forward in the interpretation of the concept of mobility in relation to the European Higher Education Area. However, while the previous Leonardo programme succeeded in the first phase of the introduction of exchanges with non-domiciled countries and interconnected learning and working periods, the consequences of the single-structure Erasmus+ and, since 2008, the economic crisis have made clear the structural shortcomings of mobility programmes linking learning and work.  The report of the Committee on Culture and Education takes into account the directions associated with the Erasmus+ programme, the addition of greater quantitative and qualitative characteristics to this problem. I supported the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite its flaws, it is possible to vote in favour of the report. Indeed, while we reject the idea that mobility is the solution to youth unemployment, this report carries the desire for the necessary revaluation of apprenticeships and vocational training, emphasizing the role of small and medium-sized enterprises that must be heard in the development of these policies.   Furthermore, we recognise that Erasmus has been one of the EU's few successes and we support intergovernmental cooperation that allows students to train abroad, provided that this does not replace the acquisition of basic knowledge and that such an initiative does not become the means of preparing for brain drain and worker uprooting.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the improvement of the Erasmus programme, an extension of the traditional Erasmus programme, one of Europe's few successes, in terms of traditional training and learning.  Despite the ode to multiculturalism and communitarianism carried out by this text, several interesting proposals in the direction of a revaluation of apprenticeships and vocational training, emphasizing the role of SMEs and the regional and local levels, allow me to vote in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ One of the challenges of European mobility programmes such as Erasmus + is to ensure that they not only reach out to students in higher education but also to more disadvantaged young people who would not otherwise have access to such opportunities of learning abroad. I therefore welcome this report which calls for expanding and improving mobility for VET – vocational  training and education – through existing European programmes, but also through the establishment of a common European framework setting out the possibilities open to young people in terms of available courses, locations, range of professional activity and sector, companies, duration, the final qualification they would achieve, etc.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report relates to the Erasmus programme and other tools to promote mobility in vocational training.  The possibility for a European citizen to go to another Member State to learn the language, to immerse himself in his culture is an asset for him, for his training or for his conversion. The cultural and linguistic diversity of European nations is a wealth that must be protected and valued.  This report aims to promote these exchanges. So I voted for it.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Maragall report, on which I worked hard as a shadow rapporteur for my political group.  Several issues and objectives were essential for me to achieve and improve in order to promote mobility in vocational training.  The first step was to strengthen coordination, complementarity and coherence between the European Structural Funds and in particular with the ESF.  Secondly, partnerships with consular chambers and businesses needed to be enhanced.  Finally, I wanted mobility for all, by promoting programmes in both urban, suburban and rural areas, by best accompanying students and apprentices with low and discriminating incomes, and finally by reducing the administrative burden on candidates, companies and national agencies in the constitution of files.  Mobility during studies where under an employment contract is a factor of employability that we must never neglect, at a time when unemployment is reaching dramatically high percentages in Europe.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We fully support the Maragall report aimed at promoting the Erasmus+ programme and improving the concept of mobility within the European area. We welcome the experience of the Leonardo programme, as well as that of the ECVET and Europass programmes, and consider it necessary to continue. Vocational training cannot take second place to university training; It is, in fact, a fundamental instrument in the fight against inequalities, able to offer young people tools that can make a difference in terms of employability and personal fulfilment. We believe that it is in the interests of the Member States to support international mobility programmes effectively, not least with a view to a comprehensive strategy for economic recovery and the fight against youth unemployment. It is therefore essential to facilitate the mutual recognition, between Member States, of the different paths and qualifications relating to vocational training, and more generally to remove obstacles to international mobility as far as possible. Finally, we believe that it is essential for companies to contribute to reducing the gap between skills required by the world of work and skills offered by the education system; we hope that strong cooperation between business and education will strengthen and support mobility programmes.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. While we are working to improve student mobility, guaranteed in particular through programmes such as Erasmus Plus, the mobility gap between recipients of higher education and beneficiaries of vocational education is a major axis on which we must act.  The resolution that the European Parliament has adopted, and which I have supported, is based on several pillars that will enable the mobility of vocational students to be strengthened.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The previous Leonardo programme had successfully completed the first phase of exchange and stays for both study and work purposes in countries other than their country of residence. Its successor, Erasmus+, has taken a significant step forward in the concept of mobility within the European higher education area, but at the same time by uniting everything into one subject, there has been a structural deficit in mobility programmes, namely in the relationship between training and work. I voted in favour of this measure, which aims to set more ambitious quantitative and qualitative targets for some of the lines of activity under the Erasmus+ programme, such as speeding up the completion of the recognition, accreditation and quality assessment procedures, which should be the common framework for all Member States.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The merging of the various mobility programmes and the birth of Erasmus+ have been a huge success for university students and young graduates. Participants in the programme will be given the opportunity to learn about new countries and cultures, to learn languages and to acquire acquaintances. During our time as an exchange student, young people become more open and independent, and we often have a stronger sense of European identity. They acquire skills and experience that can ultimately facilitate their employment in the labour market. I believe that Erasmus+ is a particularly well-functioning and successful European project, the maintenance and expansion of which must be supported.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Erasmus+ is the EU’s programme to support education, training youth and sport in Europe. It has a budget of EUR 14.7 billion and provides opportunities for over 4 million Europeans to study, train, gain experience and volunteer abroad. I have voted for this report that calls, amongst others things, for the expansion and improvement of mobility options for students.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A common European mobility-based education area, including higher education and vocational and technical education (VET), will contribute to the creation and development of a stronger European identity and strengthened citizenship. In the context of the transition to the digital economy, a redefinition of jobs and skills is taking place, and the Member States and the Commission must work together with the private sector to develop skills strategies and programmes for vocational and technical education for the retraining of workers. The industry and services sectors, both private and public, including the production sector (in particular SMEs and micro-enterprises) should be consulted and/or involved in the design, development, implementation and support of quality VET mobility programmes. The Commission must monitor the evolution of supply and demand in the EU labour market, as well as geographical and occupational mobility, in order to adapt to labour market needs. This would bridge the gap between the supply of training and market needs in value-added sectors (e.g. the digital economy and the green economy, energy, etc.). Thus, I voted for Parliament's resolution on Erasmus+ and other tools to promote mobility in vocational and technical education.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Erasmus+ is one of the EU's most successful programmes, enabling thousands of students to learn more about other EU countries and gain experience in higher education in other Member States. In this way, this programme has a significant positive impact on the open, inclusive approach and academic performance of young People in Europe, which is why I supported the report. I also supported the amendment aimed at accessing Erasmus+ material in the language of minority education.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report recognises the Erasmus+ programme as a success for mobility, but tries to identify its shortcomings. Mobility is key to the social integration of young people to make them more competitive in the labour market. However, excessive bureaucracy in educational establishments undoubtedly constitutes an obstacle to the efficient implementation of the Erasmus+ programme. Action is needed to boost the number of successful applications.  The youth unemployment rate in the EU as a whole currently stands at 22.1%. This raises the question of skills mismatches and labour market requirements, illustrated by the high percentage of vacancies. The report calls for account to be taken of socio-economic constraints hindering equal access to vocational education and training, including mobility. It must be ensured that these programmes are accessible to all citizens without any discrimination. The creation of a common European education area would help create and develop a stronger European identity and stronger citizenship.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I supported this report because experience abroad is particularly important for the future. Especially for students it is often very difficult financially to complete a semester abroad. The report contains very good approaches, in particular the mobility of students and apprentices.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the imbalance of access to European mobility between apprentices and university students and the existing barriers to employability, and proposes solutions to improve access to education and vocational training programmes for European citizens of the most disadvantaged classes.  In particular, it proposes to raise awareness of European training and mobility programmes, other than Erasmus, the creation of a "European apprentice" status in order to improve the conditions and availability of apprenticeships in the Union and the common recognition of learning achievements.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. In particular, greater attention must be paid to vocational education and training, providing students with more opportunities and incentives for vocational training. A European Apprentice's Statute needs to be drawn up. A method of dual training must be used on a larger scale. VET students must be facilitated by sustainable integration into the labour market and their participation in international mobility programmes. In addition, it is essential to establish common instruments of the European Social Fund and erasmus+ and to increase economic resources. I believe that documents for Erasmus+ programmes should be drawn up in the official languages used in the European School Systems. It is also essential to establish a European network of laboratories and incubators.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 "Promoting mobility" and making full use of the Erasmus+ programme, calls for its report to be adopted by the European Parliament. In fact, these guidelines are given as a priority for the fields of training and apprenticeships and with the proposal to establish a 'European Apprentice Scheme'.  These are programmes that legitimise work wandering, the lifelong collection of scattered fragmentary trainings. They seek to create cheap labour, especially young people, who will learn to move from city to city and from country to country on wages - crumbs, without pension rights, in the name of gaining work experience, bespoke business groups.  This so-called "sustainable integration into the labour market" which entails even greater intensification of exploitation for workers and profitability for monopolies is at the heart of the report, even calling on entrepreneurs "to participate actively in the design, organisation and implementation of Vocational Education and Training". All these programmes the GOVERNMENT SYRIZA - ANEL propagandies them and implements them to the letter.  The Communist Party of Greece (KKE) European Parliamentary Group voted against the report, stressing the need for workers to fight for permanent and stable work with full rights and to meet their expanded modern needs against EU, government and capital projects.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Erasmus+ report and other tools to promote mobility in vocational education and training, which highlights in the most obvious way the need to improve and broaden mobility options for vocational training students Clearly capturing available European programmes in conjunction with available vocational training options will enhance mobility , and will become an essential tool for contributing to the reduction of unemployment rates in several Member States. On the other hand, I cannot help but point out that the Commission's legislative initiative in this regard cannot ignore the need to guarantee acquired skills as certified professional experience, as well as the need to avoid phenomena that make employees a cheap labour choice.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, this is another dimension in which the EU are trying to widen its scope and introduce new definitions in order to justify the free movement of people. We oppose calls for additional funding: this report suggests increasing the contributions made by Member States, as well as at European level. We do not support the EU intervening in the national curricula of Member States, the EU has no competency in this area and this is stated in Article 165 of the TFEU.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Differences between Member States over curricula and school management make it difficult to mobilise young people at European level and require European action that is not only fully applicable in the various national education systems, but also to respect the educational specificities of each country. All European initiatives in favour of intra-European mobility for study and work purposes are brought together in a single macro programme (Erasmus Plus). It noted, however, that the establishment of the Erasmus Plus programme, while marking a step forward, has at the same time led to a slowdown in mobility for vocational training. Given the presence in some geographical areas of a large gap between skills and capacities possessed and those required by the market, an ambitious mobility offer for both categories therefore appears necessary to reduce the high rate of youth unemployment in Europe. Given the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy with regard to creating more jobs and promoting global competitiveness, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Since its launch in 1987, the Erasmus Programme has seen not only a constant increase in the number of students taking part, but also in the quality and diversity of the activities proposed. Since then it has proven to be the world’s most successful mobility programme. During my mandate I have devoted a large part of my work towards education policies, both in my home country and on a European level. Mobility in vocational education and training is essential for ensuring personal development, improvement of language skills and employability and, therefore, I vote in favour of the report.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report by vote because I am convinced that facilitating the mobility of European citizens is the foundation of the EU. We are faced, and I speak on behalf of most Member States, with a very high degree of school drop-out, but also with unfair accessibility in terms of mobility, and here I am referring to the disparity between universities and technical education. In this respect, the report adopted today promotes mobility in vocational and technical education through Erasmus+ and other instruments, which is beneficial as it increases the inclusion of young people in society, strengthens the ability to work in a multicultural environment and, last but not least, allows knowledge about the EU to be acquired.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 While Erasmus has established itself very well in higher education and represents a significant added value used by many students across the EU, its weakness is its low participation in apprenticeships. Currently, only 1% of young people participate in job-related training systems, including apprentices. It is therefore necessary to create the conditions for greater mobility of apprentices in the EU so that apprentices have the same opportunities as higher education students. It is necessary to inform the general public that Erasmus+ is not only a programme for university students, but includes a programme of school education (Comenius), higher education (Erasmus), international higher education (Erasmus Mundus), vocational education and training (Leonardo da Vinci) and adult education (Grundtvig), as well as youth support (Youth in Action) and sport.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the introduction of erasmus+ programmes in place of previous programmes with a view to making progress in employment and vocational education, especially today when we have extremely high unemployment rates among young people in some areas of Europe. These measures would also foster an entrepreneurial spirit among young Europeans who fear for their livelihoods as a result of the labour market situation.  Existing instruments such as Europass, which has not been sufficiently promoted and offers information on vocational education and training, need to be better brought closer to EU citizens. I believe that expanding and improving the programme would make it more accessible for students to learn about qualifications, jobs and businesses, thus finding a job more easily.  Mobility is driving the way for the employment of young people as well as all unemployed, so I support the encouragement of these measures. Establishing a permanent and sustainable system that is fully operational encourages free movement and skills acquisition, which would be of great benefit to young people.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Mr Maragall's report assumes that increasing youth mobility in the European Union will help to solve the problem of unemployment.  Better yet, mobility would have made it possible for the citizens of the Member States to become aware of belonging to Europe. Although this initial premise is wrong, on the whole the text is rather balanced, for example by citing the need to rely on chambers of trade and crafts and the necessary strengthening of the role of SMEs in the process of improving learning.  Erasmus has been one of the EU's few successes and I am in favour of intergovernmental cooperation allowing students to train abroad, provided that this does not replace the acquisition of basic knowledge and that such an initiative does not become the "sas" of preparation for brain drain and uprooting of workers.  It is therefore with certain reservations that I vote for this report, which is generally positive.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider mobility for learning and training to be extremely important for the socio-economic inclusion of young people, personal development and the strengthening of multicultural dialogue. There are many challenges in this respect, given the rate of unemployment across the Union, and there is still a high need to make lifelong learning and vocational education and training systems not only more efficient, but also more accessible and inclusive for disadvantaged groups and people with special needs. In other words, mobility must be facilitated in order to strengthen its attractiveness and to balance opportunities for access to professional positions so as to have a positive impact on social cohesion and the quality of the labour market. Education must be understood as a fundamental human right and a public good and must therefore be accessible on an equal footing. The Commission and the Member States must commit themselves to removing cultural and socio-economic obstacles in order to ensure the accessibility of VET programmes to all citizens without discrimination, and must also commit themselves to increasing women's capacity in areas such as science, technology, engineering and mathematics in order to reduce the current skills gap and representativeness that characterises these areas.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Mobility with a view to education and training is important for personal development, youth social inclusion, multicultural dialogue, tolerance, ability to work in an intercultural environment and active citizenship, and its potential in delivering high-quality education and employability has been clearly demonstrated. According to Eurostat, the UNEMPLOYMENT rate in the EU in 2014, despite a small recovery, was still 10.2%. Non-formal and informal education and training can make a significant contribution to addressing current lifelong learning problems, such as early school leaving, an unacceptable number of young people not in employment, education or training. Education is a fundamental human right and a public good that should be equally accessible to all. I underline the importance of a common European area of education based on a strong mobility component. The Commission and the Member States and EU agencies, such as CEDEFOP, should take measures to improve vet and mobility training programmes.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We follow several criticisms expressed, including the elitism of education, or the inaccessibility to the mobility programmes of vocational education and training students.   The integration of various mobility programmes for education, training and youth work into the Erasmus+ programme has resulted in Portugal reducing jobs and redundancies, despite the concentration of skills in a single Agency. The promotion of student mobility through this program has not only fallen short of an unacceptable and unavoidable tax of access, which is clear with low mobility rates. Not only has it been above all at the level of higher education that access to the programme has been verified, but it is clear that it is not accessible to anyone. Without the proper financial backline that allows to pay for the entire period outside the country of origin (tuition, accommodation, food), only an elite with greater financial resources benefits from this mobility.  The report promotes the perspective of education and training in a mercantilist logic of market satisfaction and endorses the logic that mobility should serve to solve the problems of youth unemployment by relating mobility to employability.  We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Ernest Maragall's report on Erasmus+ and other measures to boost mobility as a lifelong learning approach. The Erasmus+ Mobility Programme has marked a major step forward in the concept of European higher education, however, mobility in terms of vocational education and training remains less prevalent and is a key instrument in the fight against unemployment.  I consider increasing compatibility between different vocational education and training systems and recognising the skills and competences acquired in companies in different Member States relevant and necessary. As this mobility programme increases employability, facilitates job finding, acquires the skills and experience needed in today's EU labour markets where there is a lot of competition, I call on Member States to advertise Erasmus+ programmes as much as possible to raise awareness of it.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Erasmus+ programme, which promotes mobility in higher education and youth of an international dimension. I believe that quality education is the best investment in the future of young people, which will be evaluated many times in life. Foreign experience is an opportunity to develop language skills, gain unique experience and stimulate fulness, which is extremely important for gaining competitiveness in today's labour market. Moreover, building international networks of young people can help to mutual tolerance among EU nationals, cross-border cooperation and a deepening sense of belonging to Europe. However, the exercise of the right to education should not increase poverty or lead to distress, so it should be accessible to all, regardless of social background and background. The Erasmus+ programme needs to support individuals who might face socio-economic or other constraints in accessing VET. The EU must be involved in removing barriers and any forms of discrimination in education systems across Member States, thus motivating not only university students to take advantage of Erasmus+ opportunities. I am glad that the European Parliament is looking at options for simplifying administrative processes that discourage some individuals from participating in the programme and prevent its simple implementation.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am pleased to receive the report on Erasmus+ and other instruments to promote mobility in vet education and training. Erasmus is the EU's most important tool for strengthening and improving the mobility of pupils, students and teachers, which regularly enables them to gain unique experiences through education and experience abroad. Erasmus+ was created to roof and replace various previous programmes and to bring about significant progress in the concept of education-related mobility. However, there is still much to improve and this programme is no exception. There is therefore a need to focus more on neglected areas, such as vocational education and training for employment. The widering differences between the education system and the business world appear particularly problematic. This is also closely linked to inconsistencies in the recognition and accreditation of studies and work experience. For this reason, I welcome this report, which puts forward proposals to address this problematic situation and thus seeks to bridge the widening gap between education and employment. I believe that this initiative is the right way to improve the mobility of all students, including those without a higher education, and has ambitions to reduce the unemployment rate among young people in the regions with the largest labour deficits.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Erasmus+ programme was created to replace several previous programmes. While the adoption of the Erasmus+ programme has taken a major step forward in the concept of mobility within the European higher education area, the specific importance of mobility in vocational training studies must be recorded. The previous Leonardo programme had successfully completed the first phase of exchange and stays for both study and work purposes in countries other than their country of residence. But the fact that everything is united in a single programme and the fallout from the economic crisis have revealed a structural deficit in mobility programmes and in particular in the relationship between training and work. I voted in favour of this report in order to allow the new strategies provided for in the Erasmus+ programme and to offer maximum flexibility, in order to adapt to very different realities and to facilitate coordination and maximum operationality in the service of mobility conceived as a useful tool to promote employment and social inclusion.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider erasmus+ to be a desirable means of promoting education and employment of people, with an emphasis on gaining new experience and individual development. Its concept offers it as an important instrument in narrowing the demonstrable difference between offered and demanded skills in the labour market and in solving the problem of unemployment, especially among young people. The promotion of various forms of non-formal and informal learning and training is a pleasing fact. I also see great importance in reflecting the importance of the Common European Education Area, which is based on a key element of mobility. I believe that the issue of optimising the skills offered and required in the labour market needs to be addressed in the long term, the problem of artificial academization of certain professions and the possibility of mobility should be strengthened. I see Erasmus+ as a well-prepared project that deserves support.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Erasmus+ is an EU programme for education, training, youth and sport. Vocational education and training is a broad concept usually defined at European level as a form of preparation for professions based on physical or practical activities, traditionally non-academic and in complete connection with a particular profession or professional or commercial activity.  The final report voted on in committee contains a number of positive ideas, such as the call for the extension of existing VET mobility initiatives in terms of accessibility, especially for disadvantaged families, as well as measures to facilitate integration into the labour market, but also contains a number of problematic issues, such as the call for funding for language support for all Erasmus+ participants without language restrictions , and unnecessary recommendations, such as the creation of an EU e-mobility card and the recognition of Erasmus+ names and graphic signs as brands, with the possibility to use them only in Erasmus+ publications.  In addition, the report calls on Member States to introduce a dual education approach into the secondary education system, which is too prescriptive and falls outside the EU's remit. Some of the proposals contained in the report are insufficiently detailed, such as the proposal to create a European standard for VET mobility. I have hereby abstained.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I support the European Parliament's resolution calling for better use of the Erasmus funding programme to increase the mobility of young apprentices and students in vocational training.  Erasmus is the key mobility support action planned under the Erasmus programme, created in 1987, which allows millions of Europeans to participate in university exchanges within the EU.  Finally, future developments will be marked by partnerships between local and regional authorities, businesses, chambers of commerce or trade unions to plan and manage these apprenticeship vocational training programmes abroad.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, this is another dimension in which the EU are trying to widen its scope and introduce new definitions in order to justify the free movement of people. We oppose calls for additional funding: this report suggests increasing the contributions made by Member States, as well as at European level. We do not support the EU intervening in the national curricula of Member States, the EU has no competency in this area and this is stated in Article 165 of the TFEU.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the vote in favour of this report as it calls on the EU to remove all socio-economic limitations that prevent equal access for all to vocational education and training opportunities, including mobility. In addition, this report stresses that the results of education systems can be important in reducing early school leaving and empowering students with cross-cutting skills that will help them combine their qualifications with labour market requirements. It should also be stressed that mobility for learning and training is essential to respond to social and cultural challenges, with a view to maximising young people's opportunities to develop their own action plans in society.  This report states that there is a need to have a flexible, diverse and adapted range of mobility options for training purposes, available to cover people from immigration or economically disadvantaged families, participants from the outermost regions, people with disabilities and people with specific needs.  Finally, the document calls for a revision of the multiannual financial framework on the basis of a prior assessment of the effectiveness of anti-unemployment measures and that funding for less effective measures should be cut.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. This vote broadens the Erasmus programme to include apprentices and vocational training.  Erasmus is an EU programme for education, training, youth and sport in Europe established in 1987. It has a budget of 14.7 billion euros and helps to offer the opportunity to study, train, gain experience or volunteer abroad to more than four million Europeans. Parliament today called for better coordination of this great asset for young people, and for local authorities, businesses, chambers of commerce and trade unions to develop inclusive and ambitious learning partnerships. He also hoped that the validation of achievements would be better recognized, including when developed as part of professional or non-formal learning.  Life paths are changing and lifelong learning is a growing phenomenon that needs to be encouraged and facilitated. In this regard, Erasmus is an essential tool for social cohesion, innovation, growth and employment throughout the Union.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. Two figures: the youth unemployment rate in 2015 stands at 22.1% in the EU and only 1% of young people currently in vocational training (including apprenticeships) are part of a mobility programme, in contrast to those with a university education.  In the face of this assessment, this initiative report draws the attention of the Commission and Member States to the need for concerted action to strengthen mobility in education and vocational training, in order to improve the language skills and employability of Europeans. The ultimate aim is to increase competitiveness and boost employment in the Union.  In concrete terms, the emphasis is on greater use and simplification of Erasmus for young people, better access to information on the various mobility programmes and increased awareness of them in the Union's general and vocational institutions. The creation of a one-stop shop is called for to centralise information and facilitate contacts between all stakeholders involved in mobility programmes.   Offering a positive perspective for vocational training, worker mobility and youth within the EU, this text has my full support.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. According to Eurostat, the youth unemployment rate currently stands at 22.1% in the European Union as a whole. Non-formal and informal learning and vocational training have a role to play in combating school drop-out, reducing the number of young people who are not working, not in education or training, and combating skills shortages and skills mismatches. That is why I supported the resolution on Erasmus and other tools to promote mobility in vocational education and training (VET). Mobility can have positive effects on Europe's employability, transnational cooperation and competitiveness and must be accessible to all. To do this, it is necessary to make known the Erasmus programme and other available instruments, especially from SMEs. The mobility of apprentices within the Union should also be increased or the role of intermediate institutions involved in the preparation, management and monitoring of mobility should be strengthened.  Finally, it is important to note the need to provide sufficient financial resources to support such programmes.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 All measures to increase the mobility of vocational and educational training are positive and welcome dwellers in order to contribute to growth and job creation in the EU.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report by Parliament on the implementation of the Erasmus+ programme and, in particular, the promotion and improvement of mobility in Vocational Education and Training, especially important for young entrepreneurs and trainees. Through this report, Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to take concrete measures to improve the social and economic impact of this European programme and in particular to improve the mobility options of young people studying vocational training. In this regard, it is necessary to increase the visibility of VET programmes in order to remove cultural barriers and combat the phenomenon of lack of motivation, active predisposition and language skills, especially in those areas most affected by youth unemployment, I have also supported with my signature and my vote an amendment calling on the Commission and the Member States to transmit the Erasmus+ documents , for programmes managed by each of them, in the official vehicle languages of European school systems.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Maragall report on Erasmus, to which I contributed, because the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy are far from being achieved in terms of education and it is more necessary than ever to carry out work to promote mobility for all learners, particularly within the vocational courses of alternating education.  In the European Parliament, together with MEPs from the various parties, we are setting up a pilot project of Erasmus Pro, convinced that mobility and alternation, supported at national and European level, open a royal path to apprenticeships leading to employment. We also suggest that the Commission create an 'electronic European student card' and bring the status of European apprentices to fruition.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the report sends a very clear message that the European Commission must continue to improve the effectiveness of this programme, paying greater attention to vocational training and ensuring integration into the labour market. The report also calls for the removal of various obstacles that prevent young people from participating in mobility-enhancing programmes, as mobility often offers opportunities for recruitment. Recognition of education, especially when qualifications and professional experience have been acquired through participation in mobility programmes, is equally important. The Commission is actively calling for this problem to be tackled by enabling young people to provide evidence of qualifications acquired.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The introduction of ERASMUS+ marked an important step towards greater mobility in European higher education. The differences still existing in the academic/curricular perspective, the organization and management of educational establishments and the relations between the education system and the business world have been suppressed, thanks to the introduction of a system that allows standardising costs and other operational difficulties. This is a programme for young people that I consider extremely important because of the greater offer of academic and professional opportunities it allows, while contributing to the sociological, civic and even personal construction of an effective European identity. Continuing to identify key challenges by promoting a personalised approach to education, reducing drop-out rates while ensuring equal access to Erasmus mobility actions are some of the factors that have led me to support this report. The promotion of language skills, the capacity for action and adaptation in the face of new situations, entrepreneurship, self-determination, cultural submersion in a different country, the exchange of experiences and the tolerance that comes from it are some of the examples that result from the implementation of programmes such as this, and their promotion should therefore continue.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The Erasmus programme has made many advances in mobility in the field of European higher education. We must continue this work and also promote mobility in vocational training. To do this, we need to improve mobility opportunities for young people by strengthening coordination, complementarity and coherence between structural funds and programmes at all levels. It is also about developing validation and recognition of learning outcomes, skills and skills. Finally, it is important to ensure that mobility programmes are accessible and open to all by building the capacity of training centres and establishing a European network of workshops and incubators. Promoting mobility in vocational education and training will contribute to the development objectives of education, language skills, reducing dropout rates and developing entrepreneurship skills.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. This report identifies some of the problems that have been occurring in European mobility programmes and in particular addresses the difficulties in accessing these programmes.  We believe that mobility programmes in training are positive and that this extension to VET programmes enables access to European mobility at other levels of training. This dossier emphasizes the recognition of different qualifications, certifications and long-term learning. As well as advocating for the regulation of learning periods, in order to try to prevent training positions from engaging in uns recommendable practices such as job replacement, or labour exploitation.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ For many young people, Erasmus may provide their first opportunity to live in another EU Member State, and it is a vital basis for educational, cultural and linguistic exchange across the EU.  Vocational Educational Training helps to create a mobile and adaptable work force which promotes economic growth and increases employment opportunities for the individual. These programmes are therefore of great social and economic importance and should be protected and enhanced.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on Erasmus+ and other instruments to promote mobility in vocational education and training as an approach to lifelong learning, as Erasmus+ is a significant step forward in the concept of mobility across the European Higher Education Area. Almost all aspects of promoting mobility in vocational education and training are covered. It is a question of identifying key challenges, including accessibility, the promotion of foreign language skills, leadership, communication skills and the reduction of early school leaving; improving mobility options for young people; validation and recognition of learning outcomes, knowledge and skills and accessible and interactive mobility programmes, such as the creation of a European network of workshops and incubators.  I am very much in favour of the programme and I hope that it will achieve the objective of making the organisation and management of educational institutions and cooperation between the education system and the economy clearer.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Erasmus+ makes a significant contribution to reducing youth unemployment and increasing the competitiveness of the European economy. There is therefore a need to further simplify, for example, the mutual recognition of studies, professional practices, and attention should also be paid to the preparation and mobility of teachers involved in the training process. I have therefore supported this report, which calls for the introduction of a common frame of reference. It is particularly important that the report also addresses people with disabilities who should be given barrier-free and non-discriminatory access to all Erasmus+ scholarship programmes.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as its main objective is to increase efforts and actions for vocational education and training, including through the different mobility instruments such as Erasmus+ or Leonardo. The report also stresses the need to strengthen knowledge of qualifications and certificates at European level, and notes that in no way is mobility between students at European level understood only as the solution to the problem of youth unemployment in the EU.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The "Erasmus+ report and other tools to foster mobility in vocational education and training – a lifelong learning approach" reinforces the European Union's commitment to supporting lifelong learning and vocational education and training, enabling the opportunity to acquire new skills, increase employability, gain cultural awareness and increase the field of foreign languages. The report highlights society's role in promoting increased visibility of vocational education and training programmes, with the aim of addressing barriers that hinder access for discriminated people to the programme. It is also important to prioritise a European network of incubators and as a fundamental element the exchange of knowledge between schools, universities and companies. The Commission calls for up-to-date statistics on the programme to be made available to assess its impact on the employability of young people and its mid-term review. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to promote youth mobility and expand access to education and vocational training, especially for disadvantaged groups and people with special needs.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative, non-binding report, this is another dimension in which the EU are trying to widen its scope and introduce new definitions in order to justify the free movement of people. We oppose calls for additional funding: this report suggests increasing the contributions made by Member States, as well as at European level. We do not support the EU intervening in the national curricula of Member States, the EU has no competency in this area and this is stated in Article 165 of the TFEU.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report because, as far as I understand, Erasmus+ and other such European mobility programmes are not doing enough to be accessible to more disadvantaged young people who do not otherwise have access to learning abroad. Which is a great loss of potential for young people: mobility has an undeniably positive effect, unlocking the potential of young people. It also represents a key opportunity for the self-development of individuals who will learn another language, open up to other cultures and acquire intercultural skills, on top of the specific competences they will be trained for.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Erasmus+ report and other measures to boost vet mobility – a lifelong learning approach, as it speaks of further steps to improve existing Erasmus+ programmes, with a focus on how the Programme must be more accessible to vulnerable groups and people with special needs. I believe that a very important part of the report is to simplify the process of recognition and validation of skills and competences acquired in companies or training centres in various Member States, and this is a big burden when deciding to apply to the Programme. The report says that in non-formal and informal learning, tools such as Europass and ECVET should be better used.  It also needs to further strengthen agencies that play the role of preparing, monitoring and managing mobility programmes, such as the Mobility Agency and EU programmes. With this draft report, Parliament calls for additional measures from the European Social Fund (ESF) and erasmus+ and good coordination of all measures at all levels, namely national, regional and local planning.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because I believe that Erasmus and its other instruments to strengthen mobility in vocational education and training will further support the EU's actions so far in the field of study or training abroad and thus their professional, social and intercultural skills. I am very happy that the Commission is coming up with a new programme that will enable up to 5 million people to receive an EU financial contribution to study, train or volunteer abroad between 2014 and 2020. I also consider Erasmus to be extremely important because vet education and training mobility plays a key role in combating unemployment, reducing skills shortages and facilitating job assignments, especially for young people. I expect that the measures taken will in many cases remove the unnecessarily complicated administrative burden of applying, registering and reporting, as well as the projects themselves. I believe that the correct use of mobility instruments will enable more people to take advantage of these opportunities, and this will also achieve the objective of mobility.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today, 29 years after its establishment, the Erasmus programme is not just the European Union’s best known and most successful project, but also the biggest student mobility programme in the world:  Its existence has allowed more than 3 million students from over 3 000 universities from the EU and beyond to live and study in other countries, fostering not just high quality education and employability , but also understanding, respect and dialogue among cultures. As its success is largely due to the latter aspect, I believe that it is time for the openness that is at its foundation to be taken one step further and its multicultural approach extended to minority languages from within Member States. The provision by the Member States of Erasmus+ documents in minority languages would be the most natural step in this regard.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on erasmus+ and other tools to strengthen mobility in the field of vocational training. Erasmus+ is one of the Flagship Projects of the European Union, which has an impact on improving the quality of vocational training in the European Union. The EU cannot order schools to do anything, but it should support procedures that have proven themselves, which deliver results, improve the quality of education and the success of school leavers. EUR 14 billion for this programme should be used as effectively as possible, which is why this report by the European Parliament is constructively critical. The report rightly emphasises the need to focus on removing cultural and linguistic barriers to mobility. There is also a need to create greater synergies between Erasmus+ and the use of the European Structural Funds and other EU instruments. The adopted report stresses that mobility should serve to bring practical experience in the spirit of linking the practice and content of teaching. Mobility can also be part of the solution to the problems of long-term unemployment and the lack of skilled people in a particular sector.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on Erasmus+ and other tools to promote mobility in vocational education and training – a lifelong learning approach calls on the Member States and the Commission to take new measures, both in qualitative and quantitative terms, with a view to enabling erasmus + mobility opportunities to facilitate a better and more effective link between vocational education and integration into the labour market. The proposed lines of reform and adaptation include, inter alia, simplifying the Erasmus+ application process, strengthening the role of intermediary institutions (territorial and sectoral, involved in the preparation, management and monitoring of mobility), evaluating and recognising skills and competences, promoting a long-term mobility period, facilitating complementary financial measures, appropriate training and professional development for teachers.
