The report also aims to contribute at least a partial response to the current economic and social situation in the various European countries. It aims to reduce the unemployment rate, especially among young people, by creating a strong link between education and training and employment. The introduction of mobility programmes for all (apprentices, staff and schools) through Erasmus + represented a major step forward for mobility as a transverse concept in the European Higher Education Area. The report proposes measures to improve opportunities for mobility of young people in vocational training and to improve the validation and recognition of learning outcomes, skills and competences. For this reasons, I supported the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Erasmus+ is clearly an example of a successful mobility project in higher education and training and key to improving skills and expertise. However, there are still barriers and shortcomings of these programmes, such as difficult access to programmes for disadvantaged groups and insufficient recognition of studies and accreditations. It is therefore essential to remove all obstacles to access to mobility programmes and to establish a common framework for the recognition of qualifications.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was pleased to support the European Parliament's report on Erasmus+ and other mobility instruments in the field of education. Erasmus+ is one of the most successful programmes in the European Union and it is therefore necessary to support its further development. The programme allows not only young Europeans to travel and get to know other EU Member States, their history and culture, to learn new languages effectively and to look into different European education systems. The Programme also helps to break down the linguistic and cultural barriers to the mobility of European citizens, as well as contributes to deepening European integration and creating a common European culture and identity. Erasmus+ increases the added value of the original Erasmus programme by enabling people not only to study abroad, but also to provide the opportunity to gain work experience in an international environment in the form of traineeships in a wide range of fields. I consider it very important that this report places considerable emphasis on the concept of continuous lifelong learning, without which a competitive economy can not do without.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation voted in favour of this report. Erasmus+ deserves our attention and support. Investments in education, training and informal learning are important to give people the opportunity to constantly develop and develop, or to learn for a lifetime. This will benefit labour mobility and then the degree of activity. However, the N-VA delegation would like to continue to stress that it is the EU Member States responsible for education and training policy.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Existing mobility initiatives have contributed to participants' civic values and their sense of belonging to European values as well as their academic and employment opportunities. There is a strong importance of education systems in developing academic, but also personal skills, such as self-confidence, critical thinking, perseverance and motivation.  However, there are some problems with the implementation of Erasmus+ mobility measures, such as funding cuts and insufficient information and competence of school and faculty staff. Furthermore, there is a problem of diverse and unequally developed validation and recognition systems in the Member States and highlights the need to simplify these processes. Consequently, I support this report.  I would like to stress the need to develop and improve measures to simplify access to vulnerable groups and people with special needs through Erasmus+ mobility activities. I also think it is important to achieve good communication with entrepreneurs with a view to further recognising the experience gained under the mobility programme.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Mobility is important for personal development and develops tolerance of other cultures. It increases the social inclusion of young people in society and promotes active citizenship. Among other things, the concept of mobility was created to reduce the number of young unemployed people and to enable contacts between young people and employers to be created.  However, it is clear that mobility does not play an overriding role in vet education and training. Therefore, I support Parliament's proposal, as I believe that mobility needs to continue to strengthen. At EU level, it is essential to enable better coordination and organisation of mobility programmes. Regional and local levels should better promote and support it, as the benefits that mobility brings to young people have been demonstrated.  Then, it is necessary to recognize and confirm the mobility results achieved through formal and non-formal learning. As one of the main objectives, I see enabling the mobility of even more young people through various forms of funding.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal, given many of its problematic or unclear sections on issues ranging from increasing financial support to linguistic support for Erasmus+ participants to calling for the use of renewable energy to be extended.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on erasmus+ and other instruments to promote mobility in vocational education and training – an approach to lifelong learning. The global economic and financial crisis that has hit the EU in the past still has negative consequences in some countries, which is mainly reflected in high unemployment. Moreover, the problem is that the supply of skills and demand for them are not in line. I strongly support the clear view in the report that education is a fundamental human right and a public good that should be equally accessible to all.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report promotes the mobility of young workers within the Union, but is responsible for draining many Member States from a valuable skilled workforce. In addition, it degrades Education into a simple education, suitable only to meet the needs of the market and to exploit the goodwill of young workers.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Learning and training mobility is important for personal development, the social integration of young people, labour market competitiveness and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. This is part of quality education and promotion of employability.  Non-formal and informal learning, as well as vocational training, play an important role in the lifelong learning process and in addressing challenges such as early school leaving, the high number of NEETs and unemployment. Erasmus+ has been successful, but the results so far show that not all opportunities have been used to encourage mobility in the field of vocational training. Greater mobility attracts more employment. Labour market divergences mean that we need to act as soon as possible.  There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work and entrepreneurship, including SMEs, with a view to ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of Young Europeans.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on Erasmus+ and other instruments for supporting vocational mobility. Education is a fundamental human right, one of the public good and, in many cases, a way out of unemployment. I therefore agree that lifelong learning and vocational education and training systems should not only be made more efficient, but also more accessible and inclusive. In addition, I support the report's proposal that the Commission and the Member States increase the visibility of their vocational training programmes, especially in the areas most affected by youth unemployment. Ensuring wider access to mobility programmes such as Erasmus+ can encourage and promote entrepreneurship, creativity, promote the building of international networks, have a positive impact on employability and, ultimately, on Europe's competitiveness.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Erasmus+ is one of the most well-known and widespread EU programmes that has changed the lives of more than 3 million students across the European Union. The programme aims to increase skills, employability and the development of characteristics such as tolerance, intercultural work capacity and civic activity. In its report, Parliament rightly highlighted the problems of funding this and other educational programmes, as well as the existing bureaucratic burdens, which significantly restrict access to Erasmus+. The EP document also points out that Erasmus should be as accessible as possible, contributing not only to increased mobility and cultural tolerance, but also to the promotion of an innovative and digital EU economy. At a time of globalisation of markets, promoting education and youth mobility is crucial for Europe's competitiveness. Indeed, the Union needs enterprising people who have experience in interacting with other culturally and organisationally in places of work and education.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report as a whole because mobility in vocational education and training is essential in improving language skills, personal development and employability. It is therefore important to increase the mobility in the field of VET. Concerning amendment 1, I voted against it for two reasons. Firstly, it does not concern the core content of the report. Secondly, the national agencies have the obligation to translate the programme guide in their EU official language(s) and have the opportunity in choosing to translate it in the co-official language of the territory of the Member State.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We abstained on the report on promoting mobility in vocational education and training (VET). We believe that high unemployment is even more dramatic and worrying for certain particular groups such as young people and women. Action determined at European level is therefore required, starting precisely from lifelong learning programmes such as Erasmus+. We recognise that, in general, the report proposes good measures to strengthen these programmes, with the aim of removing all socio-economic and linguistic barriers. We voted in favour of those paragraphs calling for greater coordination with civil society at the planning stage, decent working conditions and salaries for students and trainees and the focus of VET on areas such as circular economy, sustainable mobility and decarbonisation. However, we believe that the report does not take a sufficiently firm position in condemning the failure of the measures to combat youth unemployment taken so far and in excluding fossil energy sectors, and the companies operating there, from VET planning. In view of these serious challenges, which jeopardise the promotion of truly fair, sustainable and forward-looking access to mobility in VET, we did not vote in favour.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Erasmus programme places great importance on mobility and furthering career prospects through learning and developing intercultural dialogue within academia. The report focuses on the implementation of Erasmus+ and the mobility aspect, considering the objectives of the mobility programme and calling on the Commission and the Members States to adopt concrete measures to improve the social and economic impact. It underlines the diversity of languages requested for the Erasmus+ documentation and the importance of developing a highly skilled workforce with inclusive education policies.  In my opinion, we need to enhance mobility, in particular for youth apprenticeship and trainees, which will contribute to economic growth and job creation in the EU. In addition, one of the main goals would be to ensure that Erasmus+ documentation is available in all EU official languages.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the amendment on the Erasmus programme and other tools to promote mobility in vocational education and training: a lifelong learning approach. I am pleased that an overwhelming majority of Members also voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Experience-oriented education and mobility is essential for personal development, social skills, and language skills, and enables us to react in a flexible way to the rapidly changing world. These qualities are essential for employability on an increasingly competitive and demanding labour market.  While most university students participate in exchange programmes, still only 1% of apprentices and other young people currently in professional training are involved in a mobility programme. I voted in favour of the report on Erasmus+ and other tools to increase mobility in vocational education, as I truly believe that it can help talented youths and adults get out of unemployment and reach their full potential, and thereby boost the competitiveness of the European labour market. Sufficient financial means should therefore be provided. This initiative will also enhance social cohesion, integration and tolerance of diversity, and sustain innovation.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobility for learning and training purposes is important for personal development, youth social inclusion, multicultural dialogue, tolerance, the ability to work in an intercultural environment and active citizenship, have clearly demonstrated potential for high-quality education and employment skills. In particular, I welcome in the report the call on the Commission, the Member States and public employment bodies to implement the dissemination and knowledge of the Erasmus+ programme and other instruments in favour of SMEs aimed at promoting labour mobility.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Learning and training mobility is important for personal development, the social integration of young people, labour market competitiveness and the development of skills to work in an intercultural environment. It's all part of quality education.  Non-formal and informal learning, as well as vocational training, play an important role in the lifelong learning process and in addressing challenges such as early school leaving and unemployment. Erasmus+ has been successful, but the results so far show that not all opportunities have been used to encourage mobility in the field of vocational training. Greater mobility attracts more employment. Labour market divergences mean that we need to act as soon as possible. There is a need for greater synergy between education systems and the world of work and entrepreneurship, including SMEs, with a view to ensuring that the potential of Erasmus+ fully meets the needs of Young Europeans.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because it meets the expectations of young people. Erasmus+ will undoubtedly enhance the concept of mobility in the European Higher Education Area. The report draws attention to the very important problems that require urgent solutions. The deficit in vocational training programmes is shown. Emphasis is made on the difficulties encountered in the implementation of the recognition and accreditation of study and traineeship processes in the Member States. For these reasons, the idea of activating various forms of vocational training across Europe needs to be supported, with the aim of reducing unemployment through a better and more accurate choice of education profile.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on Erasmus+ and other tools to promote mobility in vocational education and training – I supported the approach to lifelong learning, as the adoption of the Erasmus+ programme, which has replaced several previous programmes, represents an important step forward for the concept of mobility throughout the European higher education area. We therefore need a real and ambitious mobility programme, which will be an indispensable part of all the general strategies for economic recovery and reducing youth unemployment rates, which are completely unacceptable for individual countries as well as for Europe as a whole. All this shows that the increased quantitative and qualitative ambition of some of the current work areas envisaged under the Erasmus+ programme is becoming increasingly urgent.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of this report. This report identifies some of the problems that have been occurring in European mobility programmes and in particular addresses the difficulties in accessing these programmes.  We believe that mobility programmes in training are positive and that this extension to VET programmes enables access to European mobility at other levels of training. This dossier emphasizes the recognition of different qualifications, certifications and long-term learning. As well as advocating for the regulation of learning periods, in order to try to prevent training positions from engaging in uns recommendable practices such as job replacement, or labour exploitation.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am a strong supporter of the Erasmus programme and student exchange programmes in general. My constituency, and Barcelona, is a very popular destination for foreign exchange students. I fully supported and voted in favour of the Amendment signed by 76 MEPs from all the pro-European groups including 5 MEPs from ALDE: ‘Asks the Commission and the Member States to provide the Erasmus+ documents for the programmes they each run in the official vehicular languages of the school systems in Europe’. Its objective is as simple as to ensure that all students in Erasmus+ can receive all the documents in the language used in its school system. The defence of language diversity is a core value in my political activity. This is why I voted in favour.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union wants to improve the Erasmus system and promote mobility for young professionals in education and training. During the discussions on this report, the political groups took up many amendments from our ENF group. Thus, this gives a balanced text between ideological errors on a possible reduction in unemployment through ERASMUS, for example, and a willingness to rely on local authorities, businesses or chambers of trades and crafts to strengthen learning in Europe. ERASMUS is a success for me, if it obviously does not become a preparation for a brain drain. So I voted for this report.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The inclusion of several programmes in a single concept, Erasmus+, as well as the effects of the economic crisis, felt since 2008, highlights a structural deficit of programmes aimed at student mobility in terms of the relationship between training and employment.  Unfortunately, there is a very large difference in the design of courses and curricula, while the organisation and management of education centres and business escarcing in particular increase the costs and difficulties of running in terms of the development of mobility between countries and regions in Europe. I believe that we must take into account the socio-economic reality in the various Member States of the European Union, and it is necessary to urgently reactivate this way of training in Europe, given the extremely high differences between unemployment rates in different European regions.  I strongly support the adoption of Erasmus+ because, on the one hand, it accelerates the completion of recognition and accreditation processes that are a common reference framework valid in all Member States, and the field of vocational training requires major importance in order to overcome limitations on both mutual recognition of studies and employment issues.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Replacing the various previous programmes with Erasmus+ has been a significant step forward in the interpretation of the concept of mobility in relation to the European Higher Education Area. At the same time, it should be noted that mobility related to vocational training has been given less emphasis. The previous Leonardo programme successfully implemented the first phase of the introduction of exchanges with non-domiciled countries and linked learning and working periods. However, the consequences of the single Erasmus+, on the one hand, and the economic crisis since 2008 on the other, have made clear the structural shortcomings of mobility programmes linking learning and work. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. This report identifies some of the problems that have been occurring in European mobility programmes and in particular addresses the difficulties in accessing these programmes. We believe that mobility programmes in training are positive and that this extension to VET programmes enables access to European mobility at other levels of training. This dossier emphasizes the recognition of different qualifications, certifications and long-term learning. As well as advocating for the regulation of learning periods, in order to try to prevent training positions from engaging in uns recommendable practices such as job replacement, or labour exploitation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive. The report expresses a clear position and gives a boost to the role Vocational Education and Training (VET) should play within the Erasmus+ Programme framework. It also calls for further commitments of Member States and the Commission, both in qualitative and quantitative terms, so that the Erasmus+ mobility options allow a better and more effective connection between VET and  labour integration.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, colleagues, young people's mobility is a cornerstone for European integration and the promotion of European citizenship, but it also supports their personal development through more prospects for their realisation. The Erasmus+ programme, which brought together the many previous programmes, brings mobility as an important part of the concept of European higher education. But Erasmus+ should not be closed only with the academic part of education. I support the report on the expansion of student mobility with training in manufacturing, traineeships and practices for young people in other countries, which today best meets the needs of the labour market. Vacancies, according to the Commission's Autumn Economic Forecast of 2015, are growing in the European economy and one reason is the mismatch between jobseeker's knowledge and skills relative to labour market requirements. Given the strategic objectives of reducing unemployment by 2020, especially among young people, any sensible measure to improve Erasmus+ towards young people's vocational training is worth taking. I expect the EC to lead in creating the right legislative, financial and regulatory conditions, as well as providing the necessary levers and responsibilities to the institutions concerned in order to obtain as soon as possible targeted mobility for vocational training of young people.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on Erasmus+ and other tools to foster mobility in vocational education. We in ALDE consider mobility in vocational education and training (VET) crucial for ensuring personal development, improvement of language skills and employability. The report’s primary aim is to attract attention to the need to implement measures to foster mobility in vocational education, such as centralising information and facilitating contacts among all participants involved in mobility programmes.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The introduction of the ERASMUS+ programme has marked a step forward for mobility in the European higher education area. This report aims to identify the main current challenges of the programme, improve mobility options for young people and develop inclusive and accessible mobility programmes. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The struggle to get young people the opportunities they deserve is an increasingly difficult one. In my own constituency the potential closure of steel works at Port Talbot, Llanwern and others highlights the closing doors that many disadvantaged young people face. Although the EU has helped, through funding for schemes such as Jobs Growths Wales, the Erasmus + programme can provide real extra value, if it can ensure that it meets the needs of disadvantaged young people who are not in formal education.  I was therefore very happy to back this report which calls for real effort to go into building up mobility for vocational training and education. This would be achieved both through existing programmes, but also through the establishment of a common European framework setting out the possibilities open to young people. It is often only a lack of information that holds people back; it is rather difficult to take an opportunity if you don’t know that it’s there. These are the reasons why, together with my fellow Labour MEPs, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 As a student I studied in Madrid for three months as part of the Erasmus programme and that was a wonderful experience. That is why I was delighted to vote in favour of the Erasmus + report. In this way, students who are also in vocational training will also be able to enjoy an Erasmus experience.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We follow many of the criticisms that the report makes, in particular about the lack of access to education by the most disadvantaged population, that pupils' access to vocational education and training to mobility programmes should be encouraged and facilitated, in particular through actions aimed at removing cultural barriers and there should be greater support in learning other languages. All disadvantaged groups and persons with special needs should be effectively included in information and preparation sessions. Despite stating that mobility should not become the only solution envisaged for the unacceptable dimensions of youth unemployment in the EU, the link between mobility and employability is still mentioned in one or two paragraphs.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because it has good approaches, particularly in the area of promoting the mobility of students and apprentices, who thus have better opportunities in the labour market.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. The resolution on the promotion of mobility in vocational education and training is a sham. The truth is that instruments are to be created here to favour so-called LGBTI (sexual marginalised) and non-educational migrants. Moreover, the unification of European education systems in a common European educational area represents a step backwards towards pure vocational learning.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's report on Erasmus+ and other instruments to promote mobility in vocational education and training. I am fully in favour of strengthening the education system and of creating wider access to education. This does not mean, however, that I welcome the EU's intervention in these matters. Quite the opposite. The regulation of education is clearly a question of the competence of the Member States, and it should remain so. In this case, EU legislation is a clear violation of the principle of subsidiarity and therefore something that I strongly oppose. That is why I voted against this report in plenary.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ One of the challenges of European mobility programmes such as Erasmus+ is to ensure that they not only reach out to students in higher education but also to more disadvantaged young people who would not otherwise have access to such excellent opportunities to learn abroad. I therefore welcome this report which calls for expanding and improving mobility for VET – vocational training and education – through existing European programmes, and also through the establishment of a common European framework setting out the options open to young people in terms of available courses, locations, range of professional activities and sectors, companies, duration, the final qualification they would achieve, etc.  Mobility has an undeniable positive effect in terms of the development of skills and competences and, ultimately, the employability of young people. It also represents a key opportunity for self-development of individuals who will learn another language, open up to other cultures and acquire intercultural skills, on top of the acquisition of specific competences. These are the reasons why, together with my fellow Labour MEPs, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls for expanding and improving mobility for vocational training and education through existing European programmes, but also through the establishment of a common European framework that will widen the availability of the programme for young people not at university. Erasmus+ has been a great success in the UK, giving young people the opportunity to learn another language, experience another culture and making them more employable – past participants of the Erasmus+ programme are half as likely to suffer long term unemployment.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the own-initiative report on Erasmus+ and other tools to promote mobility in vocational and technical education. The adoption of Erasmus+ in place of the various previous programmes has been an important development of the concept of mobility within the European Higher Education Area. The report comes with proposals that seek to address a structural deficit in mobility programmes in terms of the ratio of training to employment.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. Not only does Erasmus+ offer vocational training students a guarantee of mobility in different EU countries, but in turn give them the opportunity to learn a new language and culture and, above all, to achieve high-level training.  All this is not only positive for them, both personally and professionally, but it is also positive for the EU as it favours the integration process. I am very much in favour of this report, as I support any initiative that promotes the improvement of the conditions of vocational students and students and, above all, those that offer a range of mobility options. I believe that Erasmus+ is key to improving and increasing employability in the future. In addition, this program contributes to the reduction of school drop-out.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Erasmus+ and VET programmes and the proposal to pay more attention to their socio-economic receipts. These programmes are not only an important means by which young European citizens can travel and develop their European consciences, but also a concrete political response to combat the serious phenomenon of youth unemployment, which is now above the 20% threshold on our continent. In particular, I welcome the fact that adequate emphasis is placed on vocational education (VET), that is, the type of learning that concerns not traditional university study but the practice of manual trades. The report calls for the network of European exchanges in this area to be extended, thus enabling both young job seekers to meet a wider offer and companies to find more motivated future workers.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I express my full support for this Erasmus+ report. I am aware that there is still much to improve under this programme, such as the recognition of accreditation of studies and work experience between countries. On the other hand, However, I believe that the Erasmus+ programme, which has replaced various previous programmes, represents significant progress in the field of mobility and education in the common European area. In my opinion, this programme has a number of positive impacts, such as the ability to solve problems, manage new and unpredictable situations, make difficult decisions and so on.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Learning and training mobility is undoubtedly an important part of the educational path nowadays and contributes to improving the quality of education and creating employment opportunities. It also plays a key role in strengthening and implementing the idea of active citizenship, intercultural dialogue and the ability to work in a multicultural environment. In this context, I would like to stress the importance and need for sound funding, preceded by a proper evaluation of the results, of the Youth Employment Initiative proposed by the European Council in response to the persistent problem of high levels of youth unemployment.  Similarly, the Erasmus+ programme, in all its complexity including m.in. school education, higher education and its international dimension, vocational education and training or adult learning, represents significant progress in the field of learning and training mobility. I therefore stress its importance once again, and in line with the letter of the report I supported, in order to achieve effective management of funds, I call for coherence and coordination between the Structural Funds, including the ESF and programmes such as Erasmus+, at national, regional and local level.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I support the concept of a more effective link between education and practice through vocational education, in which, for example, the Slovak Republic has gaps and where we are not yet able to effectively attract pupils and students' interest in this type of education, I believe that the area of school curricula and decisions on dual type of education fall within the exclusive competence of the Member States, in which the European Union should not interfere. I also do not support the practice of including proposals on problematic issues unrelated to the subject of the report, such as environmental proposals, which have also been included in this case. On the other hand, however, I think that the report also contained many positive objectives and recommendations, such as improving the accessibility of mobility under the Erazmus+ scheme for students from economically disadvantaged families or simplifying the entire application process under this programme. However, after final consideration, in view of the negatives mentioned above, I have decided to abstain.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Erasmus+ programme enables the training of European citizens who share the same heritage of values common to all the States of the Union. While appreciating the report by the Committee on Culture and Education, it is necessary to highlight the importance of making the programme even more accessible and accessible, in particular by moving towards a reduction and simplification of bureaucratic procedures, a real obstacle to mobility, perhaps through the creation of a single online management platform, where all the necessary documents can be inserted for the participants and institutions involved. It is also important to make available a funding tailored to the cost of living in the specific destinations, covering a larger part of the expenditure. By improving the service offered, the EU can be strengthened and a programme can be supported which creates more Union and more Europe every year.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Maragall report on Erasmus+ and other tools to foster mobility in vocational education and training which proposes a lifelong learning approach, with particular emphasis on learning young people and trainees. Erasmus+ aims to continue the previous Leonardo mobility programme and invites the European Commission and the Member States to take concrete steps to improve the social and economic impact of mobility with the aim of achieving a highly skilled workforce through inclusive education policies. I believe that these initiatives that focus on university mobility and vocational training within the European Union could contribute to growth and job creation within Europe.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report has positive aspects where it is made clear that education is a fundamental human right and a public good that must be accessible to all. The EU and its Member States are invited to work to remove all socio-economic limits that hinder equal access for all citizens to vocational education and training opportunities, including mobility. However, while the Commission and the Member States are asked to ensure that adequate resources are allocated to the Youth Guarantee and the Youth Employment Initiative, the reason for the failure of the policies implemented so far is not analysed. The measures taken to adequately address the very high youth unemployment, the widening gap in socio-economic conditions and the loss of employment rights by young people have proved insufficient. More needs to be done. Only one reference context is mentioned in the text of policies for the implementation of the Erasmus+ programme: 'EuropeanSchoolNet'. It is a non-profit organization that includes in partnership the ministries of education, schools, teachers, researchers but also industries, including Shell. In view of these factors, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report, which advocates greater visibility of VET programmes. The report shall define policy measures for all vocational training actors. I believe that it is essential that entrepreneurs, chambers of commerce and industry and the relevant chambers of craft, handicraft and agriculture, as well as trade unions and other relevant social partners, be actively involved in the design, organisation, implementation and financing of vocational education and training.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I voted for this report because I support the idea of a single European voice. We often face fragmentation and delays due to insufficient coherence or a lack of coherence when it comes to the application of internationally agreed financial rules and guidelines. It is important for the Union to have the ex ante evaluation before leaving for negotiations, to start global negotiations on the financial sector. I also believe that the Union must become a member of international economic and financial institutions, such as the IMF or the OECD, but that does not mean that Member States must lose their seats. And cooperation between them will be better, and the competition is also very good. Last but not least, I support the idea of a European code on transparency, integrity and accountability of those who represent the European Union in financial institutions.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The thing is, dear Colleagues, I do not even regret that if the European Union is represented in these particular financial institutions and regulatory bodies, of course, if, by the way, the Member States are there in their own right.  What matters a lot more than that is the values they have there and who they represent. My problem is not that they are there, but that they are primarily in the interests of the banks and not of consumers. To me, this has been irrefutably demonstrated by the European Union when it has acted or has not acted on the case of Hungarian foreign currency creditors. They even managed to lead me, because even I had hoped that, given the gross breaches of EU consumer protection provisions, these foreign currency credit schemes were destroying hundreds of thousands of people and families. The European Union, for its part, has withdrawn from this matter, it has remained in the background, it does not wish to have a say. Cucumber curvature, corner yes, not in this question.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Despite all the factors that are developing rapidly in other world markets and competitors, the European Union is a very strong player on a global scale. This means, of course, that our participation in a number of international organisations has a huge role to play. I agree that we must clearly define the role of each international and regional authority, dialogues, the specifics of dialogues, regulation and so on, and it is clear that, while the European Union is represented on several occasions as a single member, there is still a great deal of disagreement with regard to concrete steps. It would be necessary to move on. Clearly, we must consolidate our positions, because in the end the European Union defends the common interests of all Member States, including at international level. Thank you!

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Seeks to extend the influence of the EU in international organisations like the IMF, OECD, G20 etc. at the expense of Member States’ independence, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Some of the premises and considerations expressed in the report are acceptable, especially where there is a lack of transparency and democratic accountability (accountability) regarding the functioning of certain financial institutions and bodies. However, the problem arises where solutions are put in place to make these bodies more efficient and democratic. Firstly, it proposes the creation of a kind of European code of conduct on transparency, integrity and accountability, aimed at directing the action of EU representatives within the framework of international organisations and bodies: this would in fact mean obliging the Member States to respect the will expressed by the Union, without the possibility of dissent, depriving all freedom of action and dissent from choices dictated by those who impose hegemonic positions. The second step is to create a single EU representation in these organisations, thus also limiting national scope for action. The last major proposal would also be to create a new world financial organisation, which is now difficult to see in the consequences that this could entail. For these reasons, I have decided to vote against.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a clearly European orientation in requesting to unify the representation of the Member States of the European Union in international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund or the OECD.  The overall weight of the Union cannot be effectively projected if the Member States continue to resist ceding their posts in international organisations. In particular, the Eurozone should be represented as such in the International Monetary Fund, while all Member States should concentrate their actions on development banks such as the World Bank (a proposal which the report does not contain).  Nor does it make sense that the European Central Bank is not the only eurozone institution represented at the Bank for International Payments, an issue that will need to be addressed in the future.  The report also provides important guidance on the type of positions the EU should take in the international organisations in which it participates (promoting sustainable development, combating climate change, promoting human rights, etc.) that I fully share.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it transfers fundamental representative powers to the European Commission which will be able to make decisions in different international economic for a such as the International Monetary Fund, OECD or the World Bank on behalf of the Member States of the European Union. The Commission has shown, especially in the field of economic policy, to develop policies contrary to the will expressed by the Peoples of Europe. The orientation of many developed policies has shown the unequal treatment of economies in the center and periphery of the continent. With this experience the transfer of additional powers, in this case representation in international economic forums is a detriment of democratic participation in economic decisions. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report provides an overview of the European Union's relations with international institutions. In particular, the rapporteur criticises these international bodies for a lack of dialogue and transparency. It also addresses the problem of the representation of the Union and the euro area in these bodies. In the face of this, it calls for a deeper dialogue between stakeholders. While the rapporteur is lucid about the consequences of differences of interest between Member States on the coherence of decisions taken between the Union and international bodies, the solutions still remain the same: the federalisation of Europe at the expense of the sovereignty of our nations. I therefore objected to this report.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report contains many positive recommendations regarding the EU's participation in international financial bodies – recommendations that could increase transparency and accountability opportunities. However, we are opposed to the wording of introducing binding mechanisms to prevent Member States from taking positions in global organisations that are contrary to decisions taken within the EU. Preventing Member States from taking individual positions would undermine the national sovereignty of states.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 With this report on the role of the EU in the international monetary and financial regulatory bodies and bodies, which I voted for, we, as the Group of the Socialists and Democrats of the EP, call for greater international regulatory cooperation, more transparency, accountability and democratisation of the system.  In order to achieve all this, the involvement of the European Parliament must be strengthened and the European Commission accountable directly to the citizens. Finally, the EU should improve its representation in multilateral organisations and bodies.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is only wishful thinking in a sense of more European integration and more constraints for the Member States.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report encourages the extension of EU influence globally at the expense of Member States. Practically this means the EU would replace the UK on bodies such as the IMF and International Standards Committees. I voted against giving up more British sovereignty to the unelected bureaucrats at the European Commission.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, the result of a long work by my colleague Sylvie Goulard, who analyses the role of the Union in a supranational financial system. There is an urgent need for the Union to contribute to the birth of more balanced multilateral economic and financial cooperation. To do this, Europe must become aware of its power in this area in order to promote financial stability, growth and employment.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report by Sylvie Goulard on the EU role in the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies, adopted by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Stabilisation of the economic and monetary system is on the agenda and we need global rules and coordination on a broader scale to overcome crises and become more resilient as a Union. Therefore, I strongly support enhanced international regulatory cooperation, as well as a more proactive  role of the EU in all related processes. Moreover, it is crucial to make the EU heard with its own voice at the global scale and seek full membership at of international economic and financial institutions where this has not yet been granted and is in our interest. Such measures as the European code of conduct on transparency, integrity and accountability will strengthen the unity and positions of the Union as a whole.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to help answer the following questions: Who makes decisions? Who sets out the rules governing the financial sector? Do parliaments and governments affected by experts and private interests still say the last word? How do the EU and the euro area defend their strategic interests? I agree that, given the strategic importance of the financial sector for growth and employment, global multilateral cooperation should be reviewed, increasing the importance of the EU and the euro area.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the report, eu representation in multilateral organisations and bodies should be streamlined and included in rules in order to increase the transparency, integrity and accountability of the Union's participation in these bodies and to strengthen its influence. The report considers that situations in which delegates representing a Member State or a national authority in an international body take a position which is contrary to European legislative or regulatory decisions adopted by majority decision are detrimental to the Union. This is proposed to be prevented.  I rejected the report because it essentially strengthens supranational organisations over nation states and essentially represents the interests of international capital and thus in no way the interests of the European population.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Seeks to extend the influence of the EU in international organisations like the IMF, OECD, G20 etc. at the expense of Member States’ independence, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which, although it notes the inconsistencies and failures of the European Union , when it imposes regulations on its Member States contrary to those taken by those of those of these same States - presents only eternal wishful thinking of 'dialogue' and 'democracy'. All the more so since these wishful thinking is compounded by a more practical and harmful response: to move forward towards the federalisation of the Union, which would only strengthen the power of a few in the Union in terms of finance under the guise of democracy.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report will enable better international regulatory cooperation, transparency, accountability and democratization. The mandate of each organization should be clarified, as well as the ways in which they operate and are funded, including voluntary contributions, gifts and donations, to ensure the legality of decisions and the absence of special interests.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The global economic crisis has made the interdependence between the world's economic and financial systems increasingly apparent. The need for a new type of global democratic governance is becoming increasingly clear, as is the lack of a single European voice within the international institutions. I have chosen to vote in favour of the Goulard report because I believe it provides a detailed analysis of the relationship between the EU and international institutions in economic matters, while at the same time indicating the problems that need to be addressed. The most important challenges relate in particular to the issues of transparency and accountability, which involve a clear affirmation of the principle of verifying commitments made in different for a. Parliament's role in this context can be extremely important as a privileged forum for public debate on issues affecting the international economy and finance. The basic objective must remain to protect the strategic interests of the EU and the euro area with the ambitious goal of single representation within international for a.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this report, which, on the basis of current or ongoing European economic and financial integration (monetary union, capital market union, banking union, etc...) argues that the European Union has a unique representation in international for a related to financial matters. In our view, economic integration is opposed to one based on solidarity and redistribution and not on financial markets. We also think that given the enormous inequalities within the Union, it is wrong to think that the Union can have a unique voice that represents its interests.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Goulard, on this report, which I have supported without mitigation. The EU's role within the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies is important. The stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on the ability to conceive and enforce rules and rules of conduct at supranational level.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Another report that notes the stinging failure of the European Union and the euro, but nevertheless persists in its desire for more Union! This report thus notes the lack of democracy and coherence in the decisions taken by international financial bodies such as the IMF, the OECD, the G20, etc. The lack of transparency is also pointed out and the rapporteur calls for a more in-depth dialogue between the European Parliament's ECON committee and international financial regulators. Pure varnish of democracy because noting that the unity of the countries of the euro area is fictitious because of their differences and their multiple interests, the report thus calls for the strengthening of the external representation of the Union, in line with Article 138 of the FUE Treaty. In other words, the federalisation of Europe is seen as the only solution to the divergent interests of the Member States. The solution to the economic, budgetary and financial debacle of the euro area would therefore require, for the EPP/Republican rapporteur, a definitive submission of the sovereign states and the scrapping of their special interests, that is to say those of the European peoples.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is sheer folly to want to deprive Member States of their small economic decision-making power to delegate it to supranational bodies that do not do the interests of our citizens and territories. That is why I voted against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report 'The EU's role within the framework of international financial institutions and bodies', which seeks to unify the European Union's representation in international financial institutions. The stability of the financial system conditions the good allocation of resources to growth and employment and, due to the increasing interdependence of global economies, progress is needed towards forms of global governance, in which the Union must speak with one voice in international institutions and bodies, giving them greater coherence and coordination. It is therefore necessary to clarify the areas of competence of each organisation and body, as well as how they operate and finance.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the EU's role in international finance, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies.  The free movement of capital makes the stability of the financial system, which has a decisive impact on investment and economic growth, depends on the ability to develop and enforce standards and rules of conduct at supranational level. The necessary change in the level cannot lead to a reduction in responsibility and to undermine democracy. In particular, the role of national parliaments and the European Parliament cannot be limited to turning them into bodies that find the facts alone. In addition, the EU and the euro area must be able to defend their strategic interests. However, representation in the EU in these organisations is at least unmanageable. This situation is regrettable, given the significant impact on financial stability, but especially on economic growth and employment. Progress should be made pragmatically, given that the EU's financial strength remains high, but its relative demographic weight is declining globally. The European Union could make a useful contribution to the development of more balanced multilateral cooperation on economic and financial issues.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with many of my fellow Members, I believe that, as a matter of free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with standards and standards of conduct adopted at supranational level. Given the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the realming of finances without changing the scale of public action would prove to be a deceptive fantasy. The EU has already created a global internal market for financial services, which will soon be boosted by the CmU. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, the issues of multilateral global cooperation need to be rethought, reinforcing the weight of the EU and the euro area. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 By voting in favour, I expressed my support for the amendments drafted by my Colleagues of the European Parliament on the role of the EU in the context of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. As a privileged forum for public debate in the internal market in financial services, the European Parliament can contribute in the area of European legislation adopted by the 28 Member States, in particular by directing and presenting a European position in important negotiations. It also monitors whether the commitments made are also being met in practice.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the strategic importance of the financial sector for growth and employment, the role of the European Union in multilateral cooperation needs to be reviewed. The EU has always been stronger when it has been able to speak with one voice at international level. The aim of our actions must therefore be to strengthen this practice, with the ambition of achieving a single European representation in the near future, including within the world's financial institutions and bodies, especially in the IMF. The EU must be able to shape its future and defend the common interests, especially of members of the euro area, when discussing the main issues of global finance. However, all this cannot be separated from increasing democratic control and better openness towards our citizens. Greater transparency must characterise the decisions taken in the financial and monetary fields at international level, clarifying the sources of funding and the internal structures of the various regulatory bodies. The European Parliament can play a decisive role in this game. I believe that the resolution adopted is an important step forward, because it aims to combine an EU that is more united and influential, but at the same time more open to its citizens.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is necessary to rethink the role of the EU in the framework of international monetary and financial institutions, both in terms of external representation and from the point of view of decision-making procedures within the Union, with particular attention being paid to the role of the European Parliament which, as the body representing the citizens of the Union, should be given greater weight.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The stability of the financial system is crucial to implementing the investments needed for growth, but we cannot have a truly stable financial system if – as Europeans – we are unable to define and enforce common rules and rules of conduct at supranational level. And we cannot adopt common rules of conduct that are not based on full transparency and accountability on the part of all market players. It is important to reiterate that, in the face of private interests and party experts, it is Parliament, as the representative of the interests of all citizens, which must have the last word. The European institutions and national governments have so far often struggled to provide satisfactory answers to simple and legitimate questions from citizens about security and transparency in the financial dynamics of the international market.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report provides an overview of the European Union's relations with international institutions. In particular, the rapporteur criticises these international bodies for a lack of dialogue and transparency. It also addresses the problem of the representation of the Union and the euro area in these bodies. In the face of this, it calls for a deeper dialogue between stakeholders. While the rapporteur is lucid about the consequences of differences of interest between Member States on the coherence of decisions taken between the Union and international bodies, the solutions still remain the same: the federalisation of Europe at the expense of the sovereignty of our nations. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the flow of capital and financial professions globally, it is illusory to claim a change in the scope without a change in public actions. The EU has achieved a number of strengths, such as a global internal financial services market that will be revitalised by the Markets Union, has a single global currency that has adopted support mechanisms and has produced unprecedented banking supervisory and resolution bodies for the crisis period, has a committee responsible for systemic prevention, and three authorities that have consolidated their existence in a short period of time. The EU enjoys exceptional know-how in terms of supranational democracy and control of Member States' commitments to non-compliance. At the same time, the strategic importance of the financial sector for economic growth and job creation requires a review of multilateral global cooperation, thereby increasing the influence of the EU and the euro area. I voted in favour of this report on the EU's role in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies because I believe that the EU is an economically important pawn.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text outlines nightmare scenarios of "hyper-globalization" and an even greater shift of economic powers to supranational organizations. For the Northern League, most of these bodies are the negation of democracy and popular sovereignty. The Eurogroup, a place of production of nefariousness already as an informal body, is explicitly mentioned, let it be included if it were to receive official status. The 'censorship' that is being carried out to prevent the voices of dissent at international level of those countries that do not conform to the European majority is incredible.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a clearly European orientation in requesting to unify the representation of the Member States of the European Union in international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund or the OECD.  The overall weight of the Union cannot be effectively projected if the Member States continue to resist ceding their posts in international organisations. In particular, the Eurozone should be represented as such in the International Monetary Fund, while all Member States should concentrate their actions on development banks such as the World Bank (a proposal which the report does not contain).  Nor does it make sense that the European Central Bank is not the only eurozone institution represented at the Bank for International Payments, an issue that will need to be addressed in the future.  The report also provides important guidance on the type of positions the EU should take in the international organisations in which it participates (promoting sustainable development, combating climate change, promoting human rights, etc.) that I fully share.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The 2008 crisis highlighted significant deficiencies in global economic and financial governance. More closely international cooperation and coordination is the then particularly necessary.  International organizations such as the OECD, the IMF and the G20 serve this purpose. In this context, the European Union must be an example, given the high nature of its regulatory standards. In order to do this, the Union's representation in these institutions must be clarified so that it can best represent the interests of European citizens.  I voted in favour of this report, which provides coherent proposals to improve the role of the European Union on the international financial, monetary and regulatory scene.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the role of the EU in the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies, because I believe that, as we increasingly face our sensitivity to the issues of a democratic framework of global governance, in order to meet the challenges of an effective allocation of resources for growth and employment , the revelation of the Panama Papers represents a serious vulnus to the stability of the financial system, which is now a global public good. I can only stress, in fact, that the issues of the inconsistency and fragmentation of the methods of financing, the need for a concept of 'natural' transparency in financial processes and not only imposed, and the need for the protection of sensitive market information, are hotly highlighted. I therefore expect that the Commission's proposal to promote greater tax transparency by companies with turnover of more than EUR 750 million, with an obligation to provide extensive information, will not find any resistance in the Member States.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I think that there are still some shortcomings when it comes to the presence of the EU in international institutions. While their diversity is understandable, more cohesion between them is needed. This would make the creation and implementation of different policies much more effective and would ensure greater transparency and accountability. The EU institutions should also become more active on the international arena and I would especially like to see the European Parliament being more visible.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns Parliament's position on how to strengthen the EU's role in international organisations. Although some aspects of the report were certainly to be welcomed, such as the denunciation of a lack of transparency and democratic accountability with regard to the functioning of certain institutions, the text is equally controversial as regards the solutions envisaged in order to make these bodies more efficient and democratic. The proposal for a European code of conduct on transparency on the one hand, and the creation of a single representation for the EU from the top, are in fact solutions that would tend to significantly limit the possibility of national intervention by Member States that would be forced to respect the will expressed by the Union without the possibility of dissent. In the light of these critical issues, I have decided to vote against.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report taking into account that the respective roles of banks and markets in financing the economy vary by country.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it aims to improve cooperation between Member States in the financial field. I believe that it could be the European Union that can make a useful contribution to the establishment of a multilateral dialogue on economic and financial matters. Indeed, I feel that it is my task, as an MEP, to enable pragmatic progress to be made on the financial stability and growth of our countries. I believe that the European Union is a major financial power and that this can be achieved through continuous dialogue between its Member States. For these reasons, I voted in favour, so that this dialogue will give concrete answers to the problems of the citizens. Furthermore, the report calls for this cooperation to be transparent and consistent with the fundamental values of the Union, all of which I have always defended politically.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As a consequence of the free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system depends on the ability to create and implement regulations of conduct at supranational level. Democracy should not be negatively affected by the dilution of responsibilities. The roles of both the European Parliament and national parliaments must remain important and not become a mere rubber stamp. It is essential that the EU and the euro are capable of protecting their strategic interests.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mrs Goulard's report which notes the need for more articulate and intelligent intervention in international financial and monetary institutions and bodies. The report notes well the lack of parliamentary scrutiny (both of the European Parliament and of national parliaments) and the lack of transparency and information to citizens of many processes linked to these institutions, with emphasis on civil society, SMEs, consumer representatives and social partners. I welcome the approach of EU representation in some of these institutions (and not just through the national representation of some of its Member States) and I share the view that under-representation of the least developed countries contributes to the inequalities and funding of the poorest countries not being properly considered.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Seeks to extend the influence of the EU in international organisations like the IMF, OECD, G20 etc. at the expense of Member States’ independence, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Report on the EU role in the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies I agree that numerous macroeconomic matters require greater coordination, however I reaffirm that the establishment of one-size-fits-all representation for all EU countries within international financial institutions is sensitive and not straightforward, as is the creation of a global financial organisation. Tax harmonisation is outside European jurisdiction and should remain so. This does not mean that full transparency in national tax schemes is not needed; in fact this is needed and I support it. Tax convergence and harmonisation, however, does not take into account the difficulties and obstacles of smaller economies like Malta, and this can lead to financial instability in some Member States.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the report highlights the malfunctioning of some international financial institutions and bodies, such as the International Monetary Fund, the OECD, the G20 and the Financial Establishment Council (FSB). The solution that the report proposes to resolve the malfunctioning of these bodies does not seem adequate at all, it offers the possibility of creating a kind of 'European code of conduct' on the issues of transparency and responsibilities to guide EU actions. This proposal represents a clear lack of freedom of action on the part of the representatives of the Member States in favour of hegemonic positions within the Union, and it is no coincidence that the report has been entrusted to one of the leading voices of the European federalists, who are in favour of a precisely federal Europe. The report also proposes the establishment of a single EU representation within international financial organisations, which would harm the pluralism and opposition of individual Member States. For the reasons I have mentioned, I voted against.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it transfers fundamental representative powers to the European Commission which will be able to make decisions in different international economic for a such as the International Monetary Fund, OECD or the World Bank on behalf of the Member States of the European Union. The Commission has shown, especially in the field of economic policy, to develop policies contrary to the will expressed by the Peoples of Europe. The orientation of many developed policies has shown the unequal treatment of economies in the center and periphery of the continent. With this experience the transfer of additional powers, in this case representation in international economic forums is a detriment of democratic participation in economic decisions. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At global and regional level, numerous institutions have been created with the aim of ensuring responsible global "governance" and ensuring the stability of the international system. The EU, through its various institutions, is itself an integral part of this network. However, some elements suggest that it may be appropriate to reflect and reorganise this system of actors. Firstly, this system is still based on operating methods without any real democratic control. Furthermore, the distribution of their respective tasks and missions within this network is unclear and is a worrying element within the EU. Finally, it cannot be overlooked that the representation of states in international organisations still suffers from a sub-representation of developing countries, which are therefore clearly at a disadvantage. By voting, I wanted to support Parliament's resolution promoting better representation of the euro area in international institutions through more effective coordination, coherence and effective transparency of the international system.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of the financial sector for economic growth and the creation of new jobs requires a review of multilateral global cooperation. In international negotiations, EU representatives must pay particular attention to coherence and consistency between international requirements, standards and binding legislation adopted at EU level, as well as compliance to create a level playing field at international level. The Commission should also include in its work programme the external dimension of economic and financial regulation, precisely in order to increase the coherence of internal policies. I voted to defend the strategic interests of every EU citizen. International regulatory cooperation must be based on solidarity between countries and not on the defence of major financial and economic interests.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The basis of this report is the conviction that control at supranational level is necessary. The institutions/bodies concerned are, for example, the IMF, the G20, the Financial Stability Board and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). The rapporteur believes that it would be better for the EU if it had one voice/seat in these institutions and, if this is not possible, for the EU's negotiating mandate to be agreed ex ante with the European Parliament.  In principle, I do not agree with the assumptions and conclusions of this report. I do not believe that action at international level weakens democracy. I do not believe that Member States should give up their seats in international for a in favour of a single EU seat. I do not believe that the European Commission should represent all EU Member States.  I voted against.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this report, which proposes that Member States, including the UK, should give up their individual seats on international financial fora such as the IMF and the G20 in favour of a single EU one, and further, that the European Commission should be responsible for representing all EU Member States. The UK should never give up its seat on any of these international fora.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to clarify the role of the European Union in international bodies, in order to improve its representation. It aims to establish best practices at European and national level to promote transparency and integrity of Member States, and to improve the accountability of the European Commission to Parliament. As such, the European institutions must be able to define the Union's common position as quickly as possible.  Considering that the proper representation of the Union is an indispensable condition for the defence of our interests on the international stage, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This report examines the European Union's work in various international bodies and institutions in the financial, monetary and regulatory fields. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to put in place more effective mechanisms so that the European Union can act as a single representation to these various international bodies and institutions. Finally, it is important that there is a strengthening of the euro area in its representation at the global level.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this parliamentary resolution because it offers specific and targeted guidelines for the EU to follow if it wants to address the challenges of tomorrow.
