We live in a globalised world at a rapid pace. For the EU, such an environment means that it is ever more important to adapt ourselves to this changing environment. This resolution calls for this to be done, by for example taking the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development into account. Our priority should lie in defending our Union and the values it stands for. At the same time, we need to ensure that our neighbourhood regains its stability and remains stable, facilitating the de-escalation of conflicts. In order to do so, the EU needs to be a strong actor in an environment of multilateral global governance. This resolution correctly implies that only a unified Europe can achieve this goal. In addition, it mentions what is specifically needed to achieve these goals:  strengthened EU competences and resources in CSDP and CFSP, and a more prominent role for the Vice-President / High Representative in conflict resolution and crisis management. Finally, the resolution stresses the importance of engaging EU citizens in the process, which is something I can only applaud.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, believe that, as a matter of free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with standards and rules of conduct adopted at supranational level. Given the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the realming of finances without changing the scale of public action would prove to be a deceptive fantasy. The EU has already created a global internal market for financial services, which will soon be boosted by the CmU. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, the issues of multilateral global cooperation need to be rethought, reinforcing the weight of the EU and the euro area.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the free movement of capital, this report assumes that the stability of the financial system is decided on a supranational scale.  However, there are many international bodies and their complex functioning: IMF, OECD, G20, FSB, Basel Committee, IOSCO, IAIS, IOPS, IASB. The text acknowledges the lack of coherence and transparency in the decisions of these bodies and the exclusion of many countries from the relevant processes.  I voted against this report insofar as the proposed solutions remain those of an illusory 'financial dialogue', but above all of a greater federalisation of the Union. However, the binding legislation of the latter is neither in the interest of the States nor in the direction of financial stability.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report as I strongly disagree that all member states can be represented by a single representative. Economic policy is the prerogative of each Member State and the many different economies, due to regional, political and principled specificities, are exactly what constitutes a democratic forum. This is not only a fundamental principle that must be respected, but it is also an advantage in terms of political influence.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, believe that, as a matter of free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with standards and rules of conduct adopted at supranational level. Given the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the realming of finances without changing the scale of public action would prove to be a deceptive fantasy. The EU has already created a global internal market for financial services, which will soon be boosted by the CmU. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, the issues of multilateral global cooperation need to be rethought, reinforcing the weight of the EU and the euro area.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report contains many positive recommendations regarding the EU's participation in international financial bodies – recommendations that could increase transparency and accountability opportunities. However, we are opposed to the wording of introducing binding mechanisms to prevent Member States from taking positions in global organisations that are contrary to decisions taken within the EU. Preventing Member States from taking individual positions in the economic field would undermine the national sovereignty of states.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. As a consequence of the free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system depends on the ability to develop and implement standards and standards of conduct on a supranational scale. The necessary change of scale cannot lead to a dilution of responsibilities to the detriment of democracy. In particular, national parliaments and the European Parliament cannot be reduced to mere assemblies of approval. Finally, the EU and the euro area should be able to defend their strategic interests. The EU has the means to meet this challenge. Created an internal market for global financial services; it has recognised financial centres, a committee to prevent systemic risks (ESRB) and three authorities whose existence has soon become stronger. Given the strategic importance of the financial sector for growth and jobs, I believe that it is necessary to reformulate multilateral global cooperation, giving more importance to the EU and the euro area.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: the European Union and the euro area are not functional, so we must subject states and peoples even more to the power of a few, while making citizens believe that this is a strengthening of democracy...

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes a single representation of the European Union and the Eurozone in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions, at the expense of sacrificing the sovereign presence of Member States in these areas. "A unique voice" - so they proclaim. What voice is this is not said nor necessary would it be: it is the voice of the great financial capital and the European powers at its service. They would certainly not be able to be deprived of their own voice in the defence of their interests. It would be peripheral countries, such as Portugal, to be deprived of this voice and to submit even more to dictates and interests contrary to their needs and the will of their people. Of course, we have rejected this report. We have presented a minority report with another vision. An alternative vision, respectful of national sovereignties, based on cooperation and solidarity between Member States, which advocates the need for international regulation of the financial system, based on joint cooperation efforts, which refuses the submission of political power to economic power and the transfer of political power to bodies outside the control and democratic scrutiny of peoples.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – As it was expected, none of our amendments was in the compromises so I voted against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report in question calls for increased international cooperation in the areas of regulation, greater transparency, accountability and democratisation, with significant involvement of the European Parliament. At present, due to a lack of coherence within the international framework, implementation of the rules and guidelines agreed at international level is delayed. It is very important that it is clear and unquestionable for each organisation how it is financed, including voluntary contributions and donations, in order to eliminate the presence and impact of interest groups on the decisions taken. For this reason, the European Union should simplify and codify its representation in multilateral organisations and bodies. The European Commission should be directly accountable to the citizens of the European Union and the powers of the European Parliament in this process should also be strengthened.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting totally against the report which, in some passages, is against democracy and popular sovereignty, while helping unbridled globalisation.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report on the role of the EU in international economies, monetary and regulatory bodies and bodies, contains certain positive provisions (such as concern about the distortion of responsibilities to the detriment of democracy, the issue of under-representation of the least developed countries leading to inequality, transparency and free access of citizens to all documents, etc.), but above all promotes the creation of a global financial institution, the imposition of a common code of conduct and strengthens the power of supranational institutions resulting in the loss of sovereign rights of the Member States. For the above reasons I am voting against report A8-0027/2016.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I wholly reject the notion that Member States should give up their seats in international institutions in favour of a single EU seat. If Eurozone states wish to have a single Eurozone seat that is a matter for them, but the UK will not be participating.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the current international framework, the lack of coherence caused by the fragmentation and diversity of the various organisations/bodies is causing delays regarding rules and orientations agreed at international level. Therefore, I support the need to clarify the remit of each organisation and body, as well as the ways in which they operate and are financed. Moreover, I agree that improvement is needed on the coordination between the Commission and the Member States which are members of the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) on tax issues. The EU should streamline and codify its representation in multilateral organisations/bodies and the Commission should be held more directly accountable to citizens and the role of Parliament in this process must be stronger.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, believe that, as a matter of free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with standards and rules of conduct adopted at supranational level. Given the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the realming of finances without changing the scale of public action would prove to be a deceptive fantasy. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, the issues of multilateral global cooperation need to be rethought, reinforcing the weight of the EU and the euro area.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, believe that, as a matter of free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with standards and rules of conduct adopted at supranational level. Given the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the realming of finances without changing the scale of public action would prove to be a deceptive fantasy. The EU has already created a global internal market for financial services, which will soon be boosted by the CmU. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, the issues of multilateral global cooperation need to be rethought, reinforcing the weight of the EU and the euro area.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report fully convinced of the need for the EU and the euro area to defend their strategic interests at international level, especially bearing in mind that European representation in these organisations is now inconsistent. We must make decisive progress, bearing in mind that the EU is an important power in the financial field. The EU can contribute positively to the birth of more balanced multilateral cooperation in the economic and financial fields. The EU must have only one voice in international for a and organisations, in order to defend the interests of the Union and its citizens in this way.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a clearly European orientation in requesting the unification of the representation of the Member States of the European Union in international financial institutions, such as the International Monetary Fund or the OECD.  The overall weight of the Union cannot be effectively projected if the Member States continue to resist ceding their posts in international organisations. In particular, the Eurozone should be represented as such in the International Monetary Fund, while all Member States should concentrate their actions on development banks, such as the World Bank (a proposal which, on the other hand, does not contain the report).  Nor does it make sense that the European Central Bank is not the only eurozone institution represented at the Bank for International Payments, an issue that will need to be addressed in the future.  The report also provides important guidance on the type of positions the EU should take in the international organisations in which it participates (promoting sustainable development, combating climate change, promoting human rights, etc.) that I fully share.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a clearly European orientation in requesting to unify the representation of the Member States of the European Union in international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund or the OECD.  The overall weight of the Union cannot be effectively projected if the Member States continue to resist ceding their posts in international organisations. In particular, the Eurozone should be represented as such in the International Monetary Fund, while all Member States should concentrate their actions on development banks such as the World Bank (a proposal which the report does not contain).  Nor does it make sense that the European Central Bank is not the only eurozone institution represented at the Bank for International Payments, an issue that will need to be addressed in the future.  The report also provides important guidance on the type of positions the EU should take in the international organisations in which it participates (promoting sustainable development, combating climate change, promoting human rights, etc.) that I fully share.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the role of the EU in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies, because I believe that greater clarity is needed on who should take decisions at international level and particularly in the financial sector. As far as the eurozone is concerned, this need is felt even more stringently. First, it expresses a need for democracy for the eurozone in order to defend its strategic interests. So far we have the representation of the interests of Europe and the eurozone, which has been very fragmented, and this situation is regrettable given the crucial importance of what is at stake for financial stability and, in particular, for growth and employment. In contrast, the EU could make a significant contribution to the emergence of multilateral and more balanced economic and financial cooperation.  I also strongly supported, in the light of the 2008 crisis, the need to strengthen global economic governance through the promotion of international bodies with capacity to act and governed by clear rules and thus to develop a concerted EU strategy within supranational bodies. Last but not least, the need to give a stronger voice to the emergence of a new and inclusive approach to the European Parliament.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I am strongly in favour of greater transparency in international financial transfers and economic links. Nevertheless, I voted against the report on the EU's tasks within the framework of the international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies, as it takes the wrong approach in many areas.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Coordination of EU representation in international organisations in the complex financial sector is important in order to maintain control and effectiveness. It is also possible to increase the influence of the euro area and to promote the importance of the financial sector for growth and stability.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There is much in this report which is to be commended – such as strengthening the involvement of the European Parliament and calling for greater international cooperation. However, because of the amendments stating the euro is to become the currency of all Member States, and concerns about the streamlining of EU representation on international financial bodies, I voted against it.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The report highlights the great complexity of financial and monetary regulation, particularly due to a large number of institutions whose transparency and coherence often leave something to be desired. It also notes the failure of all these institutions and their decisions to keep the global financial system stable. Disturbed by the slightest geopolitical shudder, this system shows its limits and especially its effects with the austerity that is now rampant everywhere to satisfy some creditors who know how to defend their interests well.  If the report proposes that the European Parliament should have regular exchanges with these institutions so that the elected representatives better understand this nebula, it proposes above all solutions that guide us towards a federal Europe and an increased loss of sovereignty of the Member States. Rejecting the obvious observation of an inefficient euro area for the development of peoples, this report proposes more Union and more constraints.  I have, of course, voted against this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this report, which, on the basis of current or ongoing European economic and financial integration (monetary union, capital market union, banking union, etc...) argues that the European Union has a unique representation in international for a related to financial matters. In our view, economic integration is opposed to one based on solidarity and redistribution and not on financial markets. We also think that given the enormous inequalities within the Union, it is wrong to think that the Union can have a unique voice that represents its interests.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I disagree with the references to the streamlining of the EU representation in international financial bodies and I fully reject the notion that the euro should become the currency of all Member States of the Union.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a clearly European orientation in requesting to unify the representation of the Member States of the European Union in international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund or the OECD.  The overall weight of the Union cannot be effectively projected if the Member States continue to resist ceding their posts in international organisations. In particular, the Eurozone should be represented as such in the International Monetary Fund, while all Member States should concentrate their actions on development banks such as the World Bank (a proposal which the report does not contain).  Nor does it make sense that the European Central Bank is not the only eurozone institution represented at the Bank for International Payments, an issue that will need to be addressed in the future.  The report also provides important guidance on the type of positions the EU should take in the international organisations in which it participates (promoting sustainable development, combating climate change, promoting human rights, etc.) that I fully share.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The document stresses the need for enhanced international regulatory cooperation, with strong EP involvement.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats support the broad outlines of this report. We believe that it would be useful for EU countries to coordinate more actively in various economic-related international organisations. At the same time, we believe that coordination should not be pursued too far. The creation of directly binding mechanisms for this purpose would risk hampering national self-determination too much.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, believe that, as a matter of free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with standards and rules of conduct adopted at supranational level. Given the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the realming of finances without changing the scale of public action would prove to be a deceptive fantasy. The EU has already created a global internal market for financial services, which will soon be boosted by the CmU. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, the issues of multilateral global cooperation need to be rethought, reinforcing the weight of the EU and the euro area.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This report is another one aimed at further accumulating power in Brussels, removing the sovereign right of Member States to be able to have representation in international organisations. It seeks to transfer this representation to Brussels.  It has been shown that this accumulation of power does not serve small states and peoples, but instead aims to serve the great and especially the great capital. As a group we have tabled a minority opinion presenting the basic parameters of our own position, which is why we voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that seeks to help clarify the role of the European Union in the financial sector by examining the work of the EU within organisations of a political and technical nature. With so many international financial bodies, for example the IMF, OECD, IASB, G20 etc., all showing diversity in legal status, operating jurisdictions, internal structure, and competencies, the relationships between these bodies as well as with the EU are complex.  This report highlights this diversity and fragmentation of international financial bodies and stresses the need for clarification of roles and international regulatory cooperation. In addition, given the strategic importance of the financial sector for growth and jobs, the report calls for a review of multilateral global cooperation, giving increased importance to the EU and the euro area and also calls for the Commission to take initiatives aimed at enhancing transparency and accountability in international fora.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion as clarification is needed of how each international organisation/body at an international level is funded along with its concerns and the ways in which they function and are financed, in order to ensure the absence of vested interests and the legality of decisions.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, believe that, as a matter of free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with standards and rules of conduct adopted at supranational level. Given the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the realming of finances without changing the scale of public action would prove to be a deceptive fantasy. The EU has already created a global internal market for financial services, which will soon be boosted by the CmU. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, the issues of multilateral global cooperation need to be rethought, reinforcing the weight of the EU and the euro area.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Panama Papers have revealed, for those who may have had any doubts, the truly global nature of both financial relations and organised corruption. This in turn underlines the need for international cooperation and for the EU to play a leading role. The EU must aid international institutions in seeking out dubious dealings, whether they are carried out by criminal syndicates, Russian oligarchs or Tory politicians.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report that should enhance international regulatory cooperation, improve transparency and accountability in order for the EU to defend its strategic interests.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Union Role Report within international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies, as I support the conclusions of the report, in particular: to make use of best existing practices at European and national level to develop a European Code of Conduct on transparency, integrity and accountability; where it calls for the adoption of an interinstitutional agreement with a view to formalising the 'financial dialogue' to be organised at the request of the European Parliament in order to establish guidelines on the adoption and coherence of European positions in the period preceding major international negotiations; where European representatives are invited to pay particular attention in international negotiations to the coherence and consistency between international requirements and standards and the binding EU legislation adopted; where it calls on the European institutions and agencies and the Member States to promote the responsibility of each European representative towards democratically elected bodies; where the Commission is invited to include an external dimension of economic and financial regulation in its work programme; considers that a gradual pooling of EU representations beyond the IMF should be implemented over the next few years; calls on the Commission to ensure that any proposal for EU financial legislation is in line with actions at global level, etc.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite the failure of the weak impact of international regulation on the stability of the financial sector, as well as the dilapidation of the European Union, this report attempts to delude us by presenting wishful thinking for dialogue and democracy!  On the other hand, it is appalling that although the report regrets that the divergent interests of the Member States prevent a coherence between the decisions of the Union and those of the international bodies where they are also represented, and that the financial models of those same Member States are too varied to be subject to the same regulation, the proposed solutions remain those of the federalisation of the Union and the establishment of more restrictive legislative processes.  The Union and the euro area are not functional, so we must subject states and peoples even more to the power of a few, while making the citizens believe that this is a strengthening of democracy.... I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Seeks to extend the influence of the EU in international organisations like the IMF, OECD, G20 etc. at the expense of Member States’ independence, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a clearly European orientation in requesting to unify the representation of the Member States of the European Union in international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund or the OECD.  The overall weight of the Union cannot be effectively projected if the Member States continue to resist ceding their posts in international organisations. In particular, the Eurozone should be represented as such in the International Monetary Fund, while all Member States should concentrate their actions on development banks such as the World Bank (a proposal which the report does not contain).  Nor does it make sense that the European Central Bank is not the only eurozone institution represented at the Bank for International Payments, an issue that will need to be addressed in the future.  The report also provides important guidance on the type of positions the EU should take in the international organisations in which it participates (promoting sustainable development, combating climate change, promoting human rights, etc.) that I fully share.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In my view it is imperative that the EU is able to speak with a united voice in international economic fora. Not only will this be more efficient, but it would allow common European goals to be prioritised in discussions in the G20, for example. Currently there are too many EU institutions and bodies as well as individual Member States which, at times, have different priorities when it comes to global economic policy. This can lead to muddled messages whereas the interest of the EU and Member States is to have a strong united voice.   In addition, I wholeheartedly agree that there should be an EU code of conduct on transparency, integrity and accountability which should guide EU representatives in international organisations. Transparency in particular is key to ensuring that citizens can be aware of the important decisions taken on an international level.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sylvie Goulard's report on the role of the Union in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. The report highlights the need to clarify the mandate of each institution and their funding in order to better assess the legality of their decisions. I agree with this resolution which will contribute to the Union's transparency efforts and will maximise coherence between its institutions and the time frames for implementing decisions.  This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report by Mrs Goulard calls for a rationalisation of the representation of the Union's interests within the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. The text proposes to strengthen coordination between Member States, as well as a clarification of the Union's representation in the G20 and wants the formation of a single European zone within the framework of the IMF. As this report is balanced, I voted in favour of it.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, believe that, as a matter of free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with standards and rules of conduct adopted at supranational level. Given the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the realming of finances without changing the scale of public action would prove to be a deceptive fantasy. The EU has already created a global internal market for financial services, which will soon be boosted by the CmU. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, the issues of multilateral global cooperation need to be rethought, reinforcing the weight of the EU and the euro area.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of this report is the stability of the financial system, a coordinated action within the EU and a public intervention within the financial sector. I voted against this report, since I reject the creation of a global financial organisation, the establishment of one global financial and monetary organisation which will undermine national sovereignty.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – It sounds good that the EU's representation in multilateral organisations and bodies needs to be made more reasonable and included in rules in order to increase the transparency, integrity and accountability of the Union's participation and to strengthen its influence. At the same time, these organisations are mostly members of the EU Member States, so the proposal to make the Union a member overrides the interests of the Member States, which I do not consider acceptable. The report effectively eliminates the room for manoe d'2 in the nation-state and serves the interests of international money capital, and we have seen the harmful consequences of this several times. International financial institutions are really needed, but in a different way.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is the world’s leading trading power and single market. However, I supported the resolution because the not concluded Eurozone crisis (European sovereign debt crisis) in several Eurozone Member States (Ireland, Portugal, Spain, Cyprus and Greece) proves that the EU needs assistance from the IMF. In this context, I believe that the EU should seek full membership within the IMF. Full EU membership within the IMF will ensure that the Union exploits its potential fully, protects its interests and those of all its Member States, deepens economic and monetary integration. In a long term perspective, unified external representation of the EU within the IMF will increase the importance of the EU and the euro area and will strengthen global multilateral economic and financial governance.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it is a federalist, which should come as no surprise to Sylvie Goulard...

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report highlights three key points. Firstly, it insists that the stability of the financial system is decided on a supranational scale (through the free movement of capital), on the responsibilities of the players, and finally, that the European Union and the euro area must be able to defend their strategic interests. On the basis of this observation, he makes a series of criticisms such as the lack of transparency in the decision-making processes of the institutions, but also their lack of logic and coherence with the work of other international entities (states, IMF, OECD...).  It also points to the EU's misrepresentation within those international entities. Logically, based on such a finding, the report should advocate concrete and effective solutions to remedy the situation. However, it only advocates establishing a "financial dialogue" between Member States and the European institutions, and strengthening the external representation of the EU, in order to achieve its unification. It is clear, however, that neither federalisation nor the euro area are viable solutions, and only continue to be deluded by European citizens. So I voted against it.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a clearly European orientation in requesting to unify the representation of the Member States of the European Union in international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund or the OECD.  The overall weight of the Union cannot be effectively projected if the Member States continue to resist ceding their posts in international organisations. In particular, the Eurozone should be represented as such in the International Monetary Fund, while all Member States should concentrate their actions on development banks such as the World Bank (a proposal which the report does not contain).  Nor does it make sense that the European Central Bank is not the only eurozone institution represented at the Bank for International Payments, an issue that will need to be addressed in the future.  The report also provides important guidance on the type of positions the EU should take in the international organisations in which it participates (promoting sustainable development, combating climate change, promoting human rights, etc.) that I fully share.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it transfers fundamental representative powers to the European Commission which will be able to make decisions in different international economic for a such as the International Monetary Fund, OECD or the World Bank on behalf of the Member States of the European Union. The Commission has shown, especially in the field of economic policy, to develop policies contrary to the will expressed by the Peoples of Europe. The orientation of many developed policies has shown the unequal treatment of economies in the center and periphery of the continent. With this experience the transfer of additional powers, in this case representation in international economic forums is a detriment of democratic participation in economic decisions. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to answer simple questions from the European institutions and national governments when they ask about those responsible for the implementation and development of the rules applicable to the activities of the financial sector or the making of certain decisions. This report analyses the EU's actions within its organisations, of a political and technical nature.  I therefore support its approval, since I believe that as a result of the free movement of capital, it is necessary to conceive and enforce the rules at supranational level, just as the European Union, and especially the euro area, must be able to defend its strategic interests in order to achieve financial stability, growth and employment.  This report provides transparency and helps to more accurately assess the work of the different institutions individually and not just the European Union as a whole.  Taking into account the considerations set out above and the importance of capital flows and the financial sector within the world economy, I vote in favour of their approval to increase the coordination and transparency of public action.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Vote I am against. The report shows a misunderstanding of how bad international financial institutions, including the International Monetary Fund, have had on the economies of the Member States and how they have contributed to recent currency crises. Nor do I agree that the EU should usurp greater representation in supranational financial organisations at the expense of the Member States.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The report deals with the EU's way of working in international organisations of a political or technical nature. In particular, it seeks to answer questions about who makes decisions, who manages the financial aspect in the EU and whether national parliaments have influence in decisions. Free movement of capital requires a stable financial system at a supranational level in order to further invest and drive growth, while the euro and the eurozone must be able to protect their strategic interests.  Currently, there is a lack of coherence as a result of fragmentation and diversity in organizations during the implementation of rules and procedures. The report proposes further clarifications on the nature of the EU's work in each organisation and how it operates and is funded, in order to ensure equal interests for everyone in the EU, so I supported the report.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The stability of the financial system, which is crucial to investment and growth, depends on the ability to design and enforce international standards and rules of conduct. The necessary change of scale must not lead to a dilution of responsibilities, to the detriment of democratic legitimacy. The EU and the eurozone must be able to defend their strategic interests within international organisations (IMF, OECD, G20, FSB, IOSCO, Basel Committee, IASB, etc.). The text thus calls on the EU to adopt a European code of conduct on transparency and accountability, but also to assess the way the EU is represented in the G20 (the dual-seat problem), and to make progress towards a single representation of the euro area at the IMF.  Convinced that these proposals should both strengthen the EU's influence in these international organisations and streamline their practices, I vote in favour of this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the role of the EU in international economic, monetary and regulatory organisations and bodies, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/4/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The report highlights the interweaving of various international bodies in international financial regulation. This complex system sometimes results in conflicting legislation. According to the report, decision-making processes should therefore be made more transparent, and the European Union's representation in the above bodies should be strengthened. Under the guise of "democratisation" of financial regulation, it is an ever-increasing involvement of the European Union that is, in fact, proposed. The report regrets the divergent voices of the Member States - but they are merely an expression of their respective interests, as well as the will of the peoples who make up them.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I agree with the rapporteur of the report on the EU's role within the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies on the strategic importance of the financial sector for growth and employment.  Multilateral global cooperation must therefore be redesigned by strengthening eu and euro area influence.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Today's globalisation has led to a significant interdependence of economies around the world and so the various international organisations are at risk of failure if another organisation fails. Although these organisations have their own separate governance, I believe that the EU should regulate important aspects of their operation in order to reduce complexity and divergence in practices and thus mitigate the risk of their failure, a failure that will draw with it the entire international economic and monetary community, as was the case with the recent economic crisis.  Through joint governance, the EU will also be able to promote the values of its treaties, such as transparency, accountability and democratisation. Through these principles, the objectives of setting up each organisation should be clear, alongside its operating instruments and sources of funding, including voluntary contributions and donations. Thus, there will be fertile ground for reducing the established interests and legitimacy of the decisions of these bodies.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In the absence of a claim to increase democratisation and transparency in the field of international finance, this text instead wants the EU and its member states to renounce all policies in this area. The report promotes the EU's integration into financial regulators such as the IMF, replacing all member states.  Thus, the EU could only speak with one voice and "prejudicial" situations in which "a representative of a Member State or a national authority would develop, in a global organisation/body, positions contrary to The European legislative or regulatory decisions taken democratically and in the majority" will be avoided. And to achieve this, the text obviously proposes the establishment of "more binding mechanisms". I am voting against this text which denies the sovereignty of states.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report criticises the lack of institutional transparency and dialogue. There should be a substantive dialogue between the Committee on the Economy and international bodies. The prevailing brouillamini would be solvent through dialogue and democracy. I don't believe this demagoguery that kicks the problem into touch. The weakness of this report also stems from the conclusions it draws from its analysis: the models of States are too varied and their interests too divergent to be governed by the same rules, yet the text concludes for more Europe and integration. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of the EU in the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. I share the rapporteur's position that greater policy coherence and coordination between institutions at global level is needed by strengthening the principles of democratic legitimacy, transparency, accountability and integrity.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it helps to clarify the EU’s role within several organisations. It also calls for a review of multilateral global cooperation, which could help in the defence of the EU’s and the euro’s strategic interests.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The current financial situation requires action at european level but above all globally. However, the fragmentation and diversity of international financial organizations does not facilitate the establishment of true global governance. Regulatory cooperation must therefore be considerably strengthened by, for example, ensuring better policy coordination between global institutions.  Common standards will have to be put in place. The European Union must be at the forefront of these issues. Through its construction it has a background allowing it to better understand the necessary dynamics that will allow the various international players to cooperate. We need to be proactive and propose initiatives to address, among other things, the transformation of the shadow banking system and systemic risks.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The financial crisis and its consequences have been plaguing Europe and the world for almost 10 years. These financial problems have brought to light many shortcomings that have remained beneath the surface until then. In this way, for example, it has become clear that we have insufficient economic and financial management in the world, despite the existence of financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund. The Union must find a unified approach to the international institutions of which it is part, while at the same time contributing to their better functioning, in particular through its experience in the field of transnational democracy and state control over compliance with their obligations, and its demanding rules on transparency and access to documents can be taken as a model by global institutions. The European Union itself is a superpower, but its position is very fragile and it must be careful not to lose its place in the world economy. I agree with the arguments in the present report and stress that I consider it important to improve the Union's 'management'. This is naturally linked to improving legislation, reviewing commitments made, ensuring compliance with contracts, transparency in the adoption of regulations, communication with the general public. I thank the rapporteur for a detailed report, which I share.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls to enhance international regulatory cooperation, enhance transparency, accountability and democratisation – with strong involvement of the European Parliament. The remit of each organisation and body should be clarified, as well as the ways in which they operate and are financed, including voluntary contributions, gifts and donations, in order to ensure absence of vested interests and legality of decisions. The EU should streamline and codify its representation in multilateral organisations/bodies. The Commission should be held more directly accountable to citizens and the role of the Parliament in this process must be stronger. The two separate seats currently allocated to the European Council and Commission presidencies at G20 meetings should be thoroughly assessed.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs confronts with ruthless sincerity the consequences of the fact that neither the EU nor the euro area have a single representation in the various international financial institutions. In this way, Europe's effective influence in international institutions ensuring the stability of the financial system falls significantly short of what is possible. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, it is necessary to rethink the issues of multilateral global cooperation, strengthening the importance of the EU and the euro area, and this requires the uniform representation of the Member States in international financial institutions. This would be a significant step towards a federal Europe, so I strongly supported the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Among the proposals in this text, the main one calls for progress towards a unified representation of the EU in external bodies in the financial, monetary and regulatory fields.  This would result in the disappearance of states.  This report attempts to delude us by presenting pious vows of dialogue and democracy.   On the other hand, it is appalling that while the report rightly regrets that the divergent interests of Member States prevent a coherence between THE decisions of the EU and those of the international bodies where they are also represented, the proposed solutions remain those of the federalisation of the EU and the establishment of more restrictive legislative processes.  We're voting against it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The increasingly interdependent world economies determine a mandatory adoption of more globalized concerted strategies. The European Union must take action together, with the objectives and values of the EU Treaties, in a single voice in international institutions and bodies. I believe that the European Parliament, as a democratic body representing European citizens, as well as the parliaments of the Member States, cannot have a limited function to give its agreement. They must play a decisive role in the decision-making process, which is more active and comprehensive. With the awakening of the economic and financial crisis in 2008, an extraordinary lack of economic and financial governance has become apparent worldwide and that numerous macroeconomic issues require greater coordination. I endorse the rapporteur's position that all stakeholders should have as a common objective the development of a comprehensive framework providing financial stability and ensuring coherence between global and local levels.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite a number of good points, like the call for more cooperation on international level, the need for greater transparency of these international financial organisations and stronger involvement of the European Parliament, I voted against the report as Member States should not discard their own representation in international fora, furthermore increasing supranational impositions does not achieve greater democratic legitimacy.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union, which has created an internal market for financial services, which has recognised financial centres, but which mainly has a common currency in 19 states with unprecedented rescue mechanisms, supervisory bodies and bank resolutions, must have a prominent place in international financial institutions and bodies. This report aims to underline and strengthen the role of the European Union in this sector, in particular by combating European scattering which does not help to defend the common strategic interests of all Member States. That is why I supported him.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on the role of the European Union in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. The report highlights a number of essential aspects of financial transactions. Firstly, it stresses the need for enhanced European governance. As a result, three areas are identified in which the Union must intervene: transparency, accountability, representation of the EU and the euro area. The free movement of capital, a pillar of the European single market, requires mechanisms for regulating and stability of the financial system that are defined at supranational level. In addition, the verification of commitments made must be determined by global implementation procedures. The failure to implement genuine measures to combat wrongdoing has led to a gradual distrust of citizens over the years. For this reason, the European Parliament must be made a protagonist, it must regain its centrality. The representatives of the elected representatives together with the rest of the European institutions have shown their ability to act and set up supervisory, banking resolution and rescue bodies, in response to the crisis that has hit the continent in past years. The financial markets also need new regulation, and it is crucial that Parliament plays a central role in the definition of new rules.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union is the world's largest market, the largest donor, the largest donor, and yet suffers from a lack of visibility within international institutions. The lack of coherence of the Union's representation in different institutions greatly affects our capacity for influence. To remedy this, we call for the codification of representation to allow for greater transparency of our positions. The European Commission, for its part, tends to achieve the single representation of the euro area in the International Monetary Fund. In the search for more visibility, I have chosen to vote in favour of this text.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 If we are to build a strong Europe, we must increase our influence on the international stage in addition to transparent, simple internal regulations and an efficient single market. Our role in various international institutions and organisations is essential in order to increase transparency, integrity and accountability.  I believe that we are moving in the right direction if we show our proactivity in our international commitment. Increasing our engagement and status in international organisations can also serve to promote peace and stability. With my vote, I believe that I supported an initiative in the right direction.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the financial professions and the global nature of capital flows, it would be unrealistic to attempt and regulate this sector without public initiatives. I have voted for this report that should enable the EU and the euro area to defend its strategic interests.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament resolution on the EU's role in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies because the EU should speak with one voice within these institutions/bodies. We call for better coherence and political coordination between international institutions by introducing comprehensive standards of democratic legitimacy, transparency, accountability and integrity. This should, inter alia, concern: public relations (e.g. public access to documents, open dialogue with various stakeholders, the creation of mandatory transparency registers and rules on transparency of lobby meetings); and internal rules (e.g. human resources recruited on the basis of competences, sound financial management, prevention of conflicts of interest); The under-representation of the least developed countries in most international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies creates an imbalance and, consequently, the problems of inequalities or the financing of the poorest countries risk not being treated properly. There are also certain sectors – in particular civil society, SMEs, consumer representatives and employee representatives – whose participation in the consultation process can be improved in international discussions on financial, monetary and regulatory bodies. We believe that these bodies and sectors should work to improve the situation.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of international monetary institutions and bodies to the economies of all States, including all EU Member States, is very high - it is understandable - in the context of increasingly interconnected and interdependent economies. In this context, the EU's presence in these international institutions and bodies, through the Member States or through the European Commission, is becoming increasingly important. I support the rapporteur's view, which underlines how important it is to have coordination of Member States' positions and how important it is to represent the whole EU with one voice, a single agenda of objectives and negotiations within these international institutions and bodies. While this is not always possible, the adoption of positions contrary to the EU by a Member State within these institutions and organisations can be significantly prejudiced throughout the Union. I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the importance of coherent and coordinated representation of EU economies in such international institutions and calls on the Member States and the European Commission to work on this.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against the report because the report aims at further allocation of competences by the EU, while limiting national powers.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which, under the guise of promoting democratisation and transparency, aims to sustain and strengthen a monetary and financial system that has demonstrated its opacity and responsibility in the global economic and financial crisis. If I am not against the idea of regulatory cooperation at the global level, to improve financial transparency, I refuse to take these concepts hostage to make them unambitious texts.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Seeks to extend the influence of the EU in international organisations like the IMF, OECD, G20 etc. at the expense of Member States’ independence, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On this issue, I voted in favour. I am convinced that the stability of the financial system must be guaranteed at European level and the European institutions therefore have a central role to play. Nevertheless, I believe that greater attention should be paid to the citizens, through greater involvement of the European Parliament and the national parliaments. In addition, greater cooperation at European level in financial matters will also strengthen the EU's position in relation to other international partners.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Better international regulatory cooperation and more intensive involvement by the European Parliament are essential to achieve better coherence between international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. In this regard, it is necessary to establish the competence of each individual organisation and to introduce comprehensive standards of democratic legitimacy, transparency, accountability and legitimacy. The public, I believe, should have access to the documents and staff in global institutions should be selected on the basis of skills.  It must be possible to involve wider society in international discussions on financial and monetary authorities, in particular consumer and employee representatives. I think the EU should increase its influence in multilateral bodies and be a driver of discussion on issues such as systemic and emerging risks that are easusing the global economy.  I support in the report the proposals put forward on the drafting of the European Code of Conduct, the active involvement of national parliaments in the scrutiny of the positions taken by representatives of their countries and the Greater Responsibility of the Commission towards the European Parliament. Finally, I believe that the Commission must be more accountable to citizens when it represents the Union in international bodies, and that is why I supported this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report notes that the divergent interests of Member States prevent a coherence between EU decisions and those of international bodies where they are also represented and that the financial models of those same Member States are too varied to be subject to the same regulation. Against all logic, instead of proposing a dissolution of the inefficient and harmful economic and monetary union, the report instead advocates the federalisation of the EU and the establishment of more binding legislative processes. This is not what the people want, nor is it what will enable them to regain the prosperity they have lost largely through the fault of the European Union. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The treaties state that every Union citizen and any natural or legal person resident or based in a Member State has the right to access documents from Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies regardless of their medium. The diversity of legal structures and the ways of financing and functioning of international economic organisations and bodies make full monitoring difficult, although consistency in how funding and functioning is essential to ensure a level playing field at international level. Better international regulatory cooperation is needed with the intensive involvement of the European Parliament.  I express concern about the lack of coherence due to fragmentation and diversity of organisations and bodies and the delays in implementing the rules and guidelines agreed at international level. Better policy coherence and coordination between global institutions is needed. I welcome the initiative for the European institutions and agencies and member states to promote the responsibility of each European representative towards democratically elected bodies.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is based on the idea of deepening the power of supranational bodies, a logic of centralisation and subjugation of political power to the economic power to which we strongly oppose it. We reject this EU without reservation, in which cooperation and solidarity between Member States are compromised by attacking national sovereignty. We are absolutely opposed to the idea that peer review allows for greater accountability of citizens than the traditional formal democratic accountability model, as well as the establishment of a single EU representation within international financial institutions, taking advantage of the member states' unique capacity for intervention. Greater democratic legitimacy and accountability are not achieved through the concentration and increase of supranational impositions. It is up to the Member States to represent themselves in international for a and regulatory cooperation at global level should be based on solidarity between countries, not on the defence of major economic and financial interests.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported my colleague Sylvia Goulard's report on the EU's role in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. The stability of the financial system is crucial for the good distribution of funds in favour of growth and employment. I believe that a coherent EU strategy needs to be developed within financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies so that the Union can take a coordinated stance and increase its influence in the decision-making process. Promoting a single and inclusive European approach that could be better achieved through regular and formalised 'financial dialogue' organised in the European Parliament with a view to establishing guidelines for adopting European positions before major international negotiations, taking into account that these positions are made known and that follow-up action is ensured. It is also very important to promote the EU's reform of international economic and financial institutions more actively, in order to make their actions more democratic and transparent, bringing them closer to citizens.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the role of public action in regulating the financial sector should be changed. The EU has created a worldwide internal market in financial services and has recognised financial centres, a committee to prevent systemic risks (ESRB) and has some experience of supranational democracy and state default control. Given the strategic importance of the financial sector to foster growth and employment, I believe that reviewing the EU's role in multilateral cooperation at global level can strengthen our influence and ensure greater protection of the interests of the euro area. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Opening a debate on the role of the European Union in the system of international financial, monetary and regulatory authorities and institutions is undoubtedly the right step to remedy the current dismal situation, where the Union has often been inconsistent in its dealings with various international institutions and bodies and thus a certain apparent weakening of trust in our party. At present, all steps and efforts leading to greater systematicity in the European Parliament's discussions with these organisations and institutions to strengthen international cooperation on regulatory issues need to be encouraged. I welcome the proposal to involve civil society, SMEs, consumer and employee representatives in these discussions, which will undoubtedly lead to better cooperation across different sectors.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the initiative report on the European Union's participation in the activities of international economic organisations in the financial, monetary and regulatory fields. The EU's place in these institutions, which govern international finance in particular, needs to be increased, especially with a view to streamlining cooperation between Member States. I call for more coherence in the representation of the interests of European states in international economic institutions, even if their role must be fully recognised.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Seeks to extend the influence of the EU in international organisations like the IMF, OECD, G20 etc. at the expense of Member States’ independence, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to contribute to a response through an analysis of the action developed by the EU within a dozen political and/or technical organisations and has as its starting point three findings: transparency, accountability and representation of the EU/euro area. The report found that, in view of the overall nature of capital flows and financial professions, it is illusory to frame the financial sector without changing the scale of public intervention. In this way, in order to meet this challenge, the EU has some means: it has created, for example, an internal market for financial services of a global dimension, to which the Capital Markets Union will soon give new impetus, and has recognised financial centres, a committee to prevent systemic risks and three authorities whose existence has become stronger.  Given the strategic importance of the financial sector for growth and jobs, the report noted that multilateral global cooperation needs to be recast, giving more importance to the EU and the euro area. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. This report is clear: European action in international economic and financial forums must be streamlined, and leave more room for transparency and democracy. Three foundations of this text seem to me to be particularly important. First, the stability of the international financial system depends on respect for rules of conduct that apply to all. Second, the change in scale and the international nature of these negotiations cannot justify the opacity or dilution of responsibilities. Finally, the EU and the euro area must give themselves more than ever the means to defend their strategic interests.  This lunchtime, MEPs put forward very concrete proposals for the Council and the Commission to be more structured and transparent in their conduct of international negotiations on behalf of the EU. They reaffirmed the central place of Parliament, the democratic body of the Union, in defining the guidelines for European positions. Finally, they called for national parliaments to be able to play their full role in monitoring representatives in the Member States.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The report highlights the lack of coherence of European action within international institutions and bodies, whose roles and responsibilities are also not always clear to citizens, creating a real problem in terms of democracy.  In this sense, the report calls for greater coordination of the steps of members and institutions of the European Union undertaken in international for a, with a privileged place for the European Parliament as a democratic forum and debate for the development of common positions, without neglecting national parliaments. There is also a need for greater coherence in the policies of global institutions and the establishment of comprehensive standards of democratic legitimacy, transparency, accountability and integrity.  Moreover, to weigh more effectively in international deliberations and on the world stage, the EU should strive as much as possible to appear as a single and coherent player, notably by becoming a full member of international economic and financial institutions such as the OECD or the IMF, which is still not the case.  As he advocates a number of solutions to make the EU a leading player on the world stage, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this resolution on the role of the Union in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. At a time of increasing interdependence of economies, it is necessary to question the question of global governance in international institutions and bodies, and the role of the Union and our Assembly in them.  This text lists a list of proposals such as clarifying the areas of competence, how each organisation operates and funds, and improving their geographical and sectoral representation. There is also a need to ensure consistency between international requirements and European legislation, the gradual rationalisation of the Union's representation beyond the IMF alone, or the promotion of a roadmap for the creation of a treaty-based global financial organisation subject to the highest standards of transparency and accountability.  These proposals seem interesting to me, which is why I have decided to support this text.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 National parliaments and the European Parliament cannot be reduced to mere assemblies of approval. While it is crucial to have an independent assessment of the private and political interests concerned, dialogue between experts and elected representatives should be resumed. The EU and the euro area should be able to defend their strategic interests. In many organisations, Europe is represented in a disorderly way at least. This is all the more regrettable if we take into account the importance of the challenges not only for financial stability, but above all for growth and jobs. It is up to the European Union to make a stronger and more effective contribution to the establishment of more balanced multilateral cooperation in economic and financial matters. This report also calls for increased international regulatory cooperation, transparency, accountability and democratisation with strong involvement of the European Parliament.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a clearly European orientation in requesting to unify the representation of the Member States of the European Union in international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund or the OECD.  The overall weight of the Union cannot be effectively projected if the Member States continue to resist ceding their posts in international organisations. In particular, the Eurozone should be represented as such in the International Monetary Fund, while all Member States should concentrate their actions on development banks such as the World Bank (a proposal which the report does not contain).  Nor does it make sense that the European Central Bank is not the only eurozone institution represented at the Bank for International Payments, an issue that will need to be addressed in the future.  The report also provides important guidance on the type of positions the EU should take in the international organisations in which it participates (promoting sustainable development, combating climate change, promoting human rights, etc.) that I fully share.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a rationalisation of the representation of the interests of the European Union in international financial organisations. Taking note of the European Commission's initiative to move towards a single representation of the euro area at the IMF, the adopted text considers that the legislative proposal on the table should not prejudice the creation, in the long run, of a single constituency for the EU.  Beyond the IMF alone, a gradual rationalisation of the Union's representation should be implemented over the next few years, first through enhanced coordination and then, after an evaluation, unification of seats.  Parliament is also calling, and I welcome this, for a thorough assessment of the dual seats held by the presidencies of the European Council and the European Commission at the G20, in order to determine the extent to which these arrangements undermine European credibility outside.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU's role in international finance, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. It reflects the fundamental priorities of the Group of the Greens in this regard– transparency, the need for cooperation and accountability of international institutions.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported mrs Goulard's own-initiative report on a motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on the role of the European Union in the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. It is a question of addressing, inter alia, issues such as "who decides", "who sets the rules for the activity of the financial sector" and what "the role of national parliaments and governments" in this area. I endorse the tripartition presented by the rapporteur on what should be the main vectors in which the European Union should act: transparency, accountability and representation of the European Union and the euro area. It is essential that the European Union should play a more active and prominent role in the global economic governance process, including through the adoption of international bodies, and it is still truly important that fundamental institutional reforms be initiated to enable the European Union to achieve a strong voice and coherent representation ("enhanced and more effective coordination", using the rapporteur's words) in the various financial institutions and bodies , monetary and international regulators.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock and proposes ways to strengthen the role of the European Union in the framework of international institutions and bodies in the financial, monetary and regulatory fields. There is a need to strengthen regulatory cooperation at the international level, while calling for strong parliamentary participation. Each agency's areas of expertise need to be better defined; and better policy coordination between international institutions must be a priority, through the establishment of standards of democratic legitimacy, transparency, accountability and integrity.  I supported this text because it calls for greater codification and rationalisation of the EU's representation in international and multilateral organisations. It calls for the European Union to be a full member of the international economic and financial institutions that allow it and to encourage Member States to speak with one voice.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this report, which, on the basis of current or ongoing European economic and financial integration (monetary union, capital market union, banking union, etc...) argues that the European Union has a unique representation in international for a related to financial matters. In our view, economic integration is opposed to one based on solidarity and redistribution and not on financial markets. We also think that given the enormous inequalities within the Union, it is wrong to think that the Union can have a unique voice that represents its interests.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it transfers fundamental representative powers to the European Commission which will be able to make decisions in different international economic for a such as the International Monetary Fund, OECD or the World Bank on behalf of the Member States and countries of the European Union.
