The Commission has shown, especially in the field of economic policy, to develop policies contrary to the will expressed by the Peoples of Europe. The orientation of many developed policies has shown the unequal treatment of economies in the center and periphery of the continent. With this experience the transfer of additional powers, in this case representation in international economic forums is a detriment of democratic participation in economic decisions. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Seeks to extend the influence of the EU in international organisations like the IMF, OECD, G20 etc. at the expense of Member States’ independence, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, ultimately because I believed that the references to the streamlining of the EU representation in international financial bodies was not the right direction that the EU should be necessarily taking, and furthermore I objected to the notion that the euro should become the currency of all Member States of the Union.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution concerns the role of the EU in the international financial world. I voted against, as it, in my opinion, doesn’t respect fully the principle of subsidiarity and over-stretches the EU competences.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Shaping the EU and deepening cooperation between EU Member States leads to the continuous emergence of new as well as strengthening the competences of existing European and EU institutions. I am convinced that the growing interdependence between economies around the world will force us to move towards increasingly global forms of governance. The economic and financial crisis that erupted in 2008 has shown us that there is an absence of economic and financial governance in the world, and it is therefore essential to establish a comprehensive framework for financial stability and to ensure consistency at global and local level. I supported the resolution because the report contains many positive provisions (the need for international regulatory cooperation, the fear of weakening accountability at the expense of democracy as a result of global coordination), but I expect that the EU should simplify and codify its representation in multilateral organisations/bodies in order to increase the Transparency, Integrity and Accountability of the Union in these services, its impact and the enforcement of the rules it has democratically adopted.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the consequences of the global financial crisis, and in particular in the context of the euro area crisis, international bodies (such as the G20, the International Monetary Fund, the Basel Committee, etc.) have played a very important role in establishing standards and procedures for the Financial Regulation and cooperation, for financial assistance programmes and, in general, for macroeconomic policy. The aim of the report is to issue a set of specific recommendations from the European Parliament concerning the participation of the EU institutions in these international bodies and their decision-making process, including the adoption of an EU common position. The stability of the financial system is crucial for investment and growth, but the free movement of capital depends on the ability to formulate and enforce standards and codes of conduct at transnational level. The European Union and the euro area must be able to protect their interests effectively. The report calls on global international institutions for transparency, integrity and accountability and encourages a parliamentary procedure for effective ex ante and ex post supervision of EU positions in international bodies such as the G20 Basel Committee, the FSB, etc. It is necessary to strengthen international cooperation, including through strong cooperation between the European Parliament, and to lead to better coordination between international institutions. For this very reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report calling for enhanced international regulatory cooperation, taking stock of the EU's role in this area and expressing the need for greater involvement of the European Parliament. In the current international economic and financial framework, the fragmentation and diversity of the various private organisations and actors (IMF, G20, OECD to name but a few) create a lack of coherence that is leading to delays in regulatory action at international level, for example in the fight against tax evasion. We therefore need clarification of the competences and functioning of the organisations involved, in order to ensure the independence and transparency of the decisions taken. With regard to the EU's role in international financial institutions and bodies, I support the need to rationalise its presence in multilateral organisations, for example by considering the unification of the two posts allocated at the G20 meetings to the European Council and the Commission, in order to be able to defend European interests more forcefully and play a stronger role in international economic and financial bodies.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU should focus more strongly on the global competitiveness of the EU financial sectors in policy-making at European and international level. It should also strive for full membership of international economic and financial institutions in order to avoid incoherence of the positions of the EU and its Member States. It should also simplify and codify its representation in multilateral organisations in order to increase the transparency, integrity and accountability of the Union's participation in those services, its impact and its enforcement.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The stability of the financial system affecting the good allocation of funds for the benefit of growth and employment is of common interest. It depends on the ability to design and enforce standards and rules of conduct at the supranational level. There is a diversity of many international organisations and it is necessary, for the purpose of coherence, to clarify the areas of competence, the legal nature of decisions and to define their priorities more clearly. This is why enhanced international regulatory cooperation with strong involvement of the European Parliament is needed. It is important that the EU plays a more active role in the global economic governance process and institutional reforms are needed to achieve consistent representation of the European Union in international bodies. I support the Union Role Report within international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. I believe it is important to increase the Union's influence in the decision-making process within international institutions with a view to increasing transparency and democracy.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. Whilst it certainly had some agreeable elements, such as the need for greater policy coherence and coordination between global institutions, I was unconvinced on the desirability of the report in its entirety.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The ROLE of the EU within international institutions is very important for the stability of the entire financial system. Each EU member state has its own system of banks and markets related to financing economies where the EU must intervene to provide a framework for financial stability. In addition, the EU ensures transparency and publicly available information to preserve democratic legitimacy. Since the beginning of the crisis, it has been monitoring and solving problems in banks' mechanisms. I support the Report on the Role of the Union within international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. I believe it brings further progress in the formation of the single market, the strengthening of the EU economy and financial sector. It also helps reduce bureaucracy and speed up the whole system. This strengthens the overall link between the EU institutions, thereby also fostering employment, which is the interest of EU citizens.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal as I fundamentally disagree that replacing the voting rights of each Member State with a single voting right for the European Union in international institutions would contribute to greater democratic decision-making, nor that this change should be desirable.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the ROLE OF THE EU in the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. At global level, we need cooperation from international institutions and bodies, which must be transparent and generally coordinated and must lead to more simplification and avoid duplicate tasks. We need a stable financial system that will lead to economic growth and, last but not least, to new jobs. I support the call for a clearer definition of the competences of each organisation or body and the way in which they operate and finance, including voluntary contributions, gifts and donations, in order to prevent personal interests and ensure the legality of decisions.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This report removes the sovereign right of Member States to be able to have representation in international organisations, while instead transferring this right to Brussels. In this way more and more powers are being transferred to the centre of the EU, so that the interests of large and wealthy Member States can be better represented. We voted against, because neither the interests of the peoples nor of small states, such as Cyprus, are being served.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report on the role of the EU in international economies, monetary and regulatory organisations and institutions contains a number of positive provisions (such as concern about the distortion of responsibilities to the detriment of democracy, the issue of under-representation of the least developed countries leading to inequality, transparency and free access for citizens to all documents, etc.) , but above all it promotes the creation of a global financial institution, the imposition of a common code of conduct and strengthens the power of supranational institutions resulting in the loss of sovereign rights of the Member States.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because I, too, believe that, as a matter of free movement of capital, the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with standards and rules of conduct adopted at supranational level. Given the global nature of capital flows and financial professions, the realming of finances without changing the scale of public action would prove to be a deceptive fantasy. The EU has already created a global internal market for financial services, which will soon be boosted by the CmU. As the financial sector is of strategic importance for growth and employment, the issues of multilateral global cooperation need to be rethought, reinforcing the weight of the EU and the euro area.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report examining the role of the EU in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. I think it is right that the REPRESENTATION of the EU should be made more rational in multilateral organisations and included in rules in order to increase the transparency, integrity and accountability of the Union's participation. Indeed, this effort would help to increase the Union's influence. I agree with the reporter when he says that situations in which delegates representing a Member State or national authority in an international organisation take a position which is contrary to European legislative or regulatory decisions democratically adopted by a majority decision are detrimental to the Union. Indeed, there is a need to increase consistency between representations, so it would be useful for the European Commission, as requested by the report, to set up a European Code of Conduct on Transparency, Integrity and Accountability, with the involvement of the EP, building on best practices at European and national level, with the aim of serving as a guide for EU delegates in international organisations.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently one of the main structures represented in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. However, its representation is fragmentary in nature, leading to a certain lack of coherence in the Union's positions and causing certain delays in the application of internationally agreed rules. The way in which each international organisation operates must also be clarified in the light of their increasingly important role in the lives of European citizens, in particular in terms of funding, interests and legality of decisions. In this respect, the participation of the European Union must include a greater role of the European Parliament, the direct representative of citizens, and greater accountability of the Commission. The existence of two separate representations, of the Council and the Commission, is also likely to lead to a number of confusions as to the positions of the European institutions and the Member States, in particular at the G20 meetings. In order to address these problems, this report correctly proposes enhanced cooperation within the Union for the adoption of unified positions, greater transparency, accountability and democratisation of international organisations with economic impact and greater involvement of the European Parliament in this process.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. It is important to strengthen regulatory cooperation at the global level, with strong participation from the European Parliament. It is also an opportunity to be concerned about the inconsistency caused by the fragmentation and diversity of organizations and the delays in implementing international rules and guidelines.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ A global stable financial system that formulates and enforces standards and rules of conduct at supranational level is essential for investment and growth. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for practical measures to ensure that global institutions adopt better standards of democratic legitimacy, transparency, accountability and integrity. The EU has a great role to play in the emergence of a more balanced multilateral economic and financial cooperation. I particularly agree with the initiative to establish a formal ‘financial dialogue’, and to work on coherent European positions to enhance the EU’s geopolitical influence in global and financial institutions, and defending our strategic interests. The European and national parliaments need to be actively involved to ensure accountability at all levels.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The stability of the financial system is of common interest to all countries, including those outside the European Union, as it affects the good distribution of funds in favour of growth and employment, and as we all know this stability has never existed and is the cause of the current crisis. Nevertheless, I believe that Member States should maintain the right to act alone and should not give up their country's interests in international financial forums for the benefit of only one Member State of the European Union.  I believe that the European Commission should not represent members of the European Union and that a large number of votes of the Member States of the European Union in financial forums is an advantage. The role of the European Commission is to protect the interests of the European Union and its citizens on issues that cannot be effectively resolved at national level, and in this case it is not so, so I believe that the supranational level of control of the financial system will not help to resolve the current crisis and I voted against this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report on the EU's role in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies was supported, as the stability of the financial system, which is key to investment and growth, depends on the ability to formulate and enforce standards and codes of conduct at transnational level due to the free movement of capital. The urgent need for proper upgrading must not lead to a dispersion of responsibility to the detriment of democracy. In particular, national parliaments and the European Parliament should not become only 'application offices'. If an independent assessment of private and political interests is required, the dialogue between experts and elected Members should be renewed.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this report, which, on the basis of current or ongoing European economic and financial integration (monetary union, capital market union, banking union, etc...) argues that the European Union has a unique representation in international for a related to financial matters. In our view, economic integration is opposed to one based on solidarity and redistribution and not on financial markets. We also think that given the enormous inequalities within the Union, it is wrong to think that the Union can have a unique voice that represents its interests.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to put the European Union at the centre of decisions taken by the world's major financial authorities. Several idealistic solutions are presented to put dialogue and democracy at the centre of financial decisions, such as involving the European Parliament more in decision-making to avoid actions contrary to European interests.  In addition to these wishful thinking, there are far more dangerous federalist ideological solutions. The EU and the Eurozone are not yet functional in their view; states and peoples should therefore be subjected ever more to the power of a few by giving citizens the illusion of a strengthening of democracy.  So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report is based on three findings: the free movement of capital means that the stability of the financial system, which is crucial for investment and growth, depends on our ability to establish and ensure compliance with supranational standards of conduct and rules. An essential change in scale must not lead to a dilution of responsibility at the expense of democracy. In particular, the role of national parliaments and the European Parliament should not be limited to nodding notes of developments. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this report, which, on the basis of current or ongoing European economic and financial integration (monetary union, capital market union, banking union, etc...) argues that the European Union has a unique representation in international for a related to financial matters. In our view, economic integration is opposed to one based on solidarity and redistribution and not on financial markets. We also think that given the enormous inequalities within the Union, it is wrong to think that the Union can have a unique voice that represents its interests.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for transparency, integrity and accountability of global and international institutions and more importantly for a parliamentary process for an effective ex-ante and ex-post control of the positions the EU takes in opaque international bodies such as the G20, the Basel committee, the FSB, etc...

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the EU role in the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. The report states the importance of transparency for democracy, while, at the same time, taking into serious consideration the protecting of market-sensitive information. It equally stresses the need for enhancing international regulatory cooperation and improving policy coherence and coordination among the global institutions. The report particularly emphasises the crucial significance of the stability of the financial system and the common interests of the euro area.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a report dealing in a comprehensive way with the EU's role within the framework of both international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. It also calls for important measures, including the need for the Commission to develop existing best practices at European and national level to develop a code of conduct in transparency and integrity as well as the adoption of an interinstitutional agreement to develop a financial dialogue. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has a clearly European orientation in requesting to unify the representation of the Member States of the European Union in international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund or the OECD.  The overall weight of the Union cannot be effectively projected if the Member States continue to resist ceding their posts in international organisations. In particular, the Eurozone should be represented as such in the International Monetary Fund, while all Member States should concentrate their actions on development banks such as the World Bank (a proposal which the report does not contain).  Nor does it make sense that the European Central Bank is not the only eurozone institution represented at the Bank for International Payments, an issue that will need to be addressed in the future.  The report also provides important guidance on the type of positions the EU should take in the international organisations in which it participates (promoting sustainable development, combating climate change, promoting human rights, etc.) that I fully share.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report contains many positive recommendations regarding the EU's participation in international financial bodies – recommendations that could increase transparency and accountability opportunities. However, we are opposed to the wording of introducing binding mechanisms to prevent Member States from taking positions in global organisations that are contrary to decisions taken within the EU. Preventing Member States from taking individual positions would undermine the national sovereignty of states.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the sensitive issue of the EU's role in international organisations. Different solutions are proposed. Firstly, it calls for the creation of a European code of conduct on transparency to guide the action of EU representatives in international organisations and, secondly, for the creation of a single EU representation in international organisations. This would mean obliging the Member States to respect the will expressed by the EU by depriving all freedom of action and dissent of choices dictated by those who impose hegemonic positions. Finally, there is a call for the creation of a new world financial organisation, which is difficult to frame, mainly because of the consequences it could have. On the one hand, we believe that there is a need for greater cooperation between states at international level, both at EU country level and with the various world partners, but, on the other hand, we believe that the solution cannot be to bring it all into line with a single model. That is why we have opposed this approach from the beginning, which marks the watershed between those who want more Europe at all costs and those who want a different, collaborative and supportive Europe, without taxation and technocratic approaches that have fallen from above but democratically authenticated by the citizens.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'This report is very clear: the European Union's actions in international economic and financial institutions and bodies must become more streamlined, transparent and democratic. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Motion for a resolution on the EU's role in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies contributes to the federalist integration of the European Union and increases the power of European monetary union piece by piece. The power of citizens and Member States is diminishing and the power of supranational bodies is increasing. I cannot support a dangerous development such as the one we are currently seeing in The European Monetary Union. That is why I voted against the motion.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this report contains positive provisions - the need for regulatory cooperation on an international scale, concern about the dilution of responsibilities to the detriment of democracy as a result of coordination on a global scale - it is based on the idea of deepening the power of supranational bodies, which will further remove political power from people, to which we strongly oppose. We reject this EU, in which cooperation and solidarity between Member States and their national sovereignty are unreservedly committed, to the idea that peer review allows greater accountability of citizens than the traditional formal democratic accountability model, based on the concept of 'agent and principal', as well as the establishment of a single representation that intervenes with one voice by all EU countries within financial institutions International. We strongly advocate that greater democratic legitimacy and accountability will not be achieved by increasing supranational impositions. Member States should not dispense with their own representation in international for a and regulatory cooperation at global level should be based on solidarity between countries, not on the defence of major economic and financial interests.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Capital flows and activities in the financial sector have long been considered globalised, making it all the more difficult to regulate the financial world. The report seeks to identify the main problems relating to transparency, accountability and strategic defence of the EU's interests. It calls for the strengthening of the EU institutions, without, however, going into the future influence of the Member States and their parliaments.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the INI report on the role of the European Union in the context of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions. The report suggests greater international cooperation and greater transparency with the strong involvement of the European Parliament. The European Union should optimise and codify its representation in multilateral organisations. In addition, the European Commission should be more accountable to its citizens. Finally, the report suggests a careful assessment of the two positions occupied by the European Council and the European Commission at the G20. I firmly believe that these measures are necessary to improve the international financial, monetary and regulatory system.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. Regulation and the creation of transparent structures are desirable in this regard. However, it is doubtful that this can be achieved by transferring national powers at EU level. I therefore reject this move.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the EU's tasks in the context of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. It makes no sense to leave membership to the EU's international fora rather than to the Member States. The EU is by no means a entity with definable self-interests. On the contrary, the EU pursues different national interests of its Member States, depending on which one has just prevailed. Therefore, EU action can favour one Member State and penalise the other. A change of system away from national representation in these bodies towards a representative role for the EU is therefore not appropriate. The EU could, if necessary, assume the role of observer in such for a if it were indeed a matter of better regulation at European level, but should not be given voting rights under any circumstances. The report does not take any of these considerations into account.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the adoption of the Own Initiative Report on the EU's role in international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies. In carrying out this document, the rapporteur has gone from 3 findings: the stability of the financial system, a decisive element for investment and growth, depends on the ability to develop standards and rules of conduct and to ensure their compliance at supranational level; the indispensable change of scale must not lead to the dilution of responsibilities at the expense of democracy; The EU and the euro area must be able to defend their strategic interests. The report calls on The Member States to accept the representation of the Banking Union in the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, as well as an in-depth analysis of the situation in which the Council and the Commission each have their place at g20 meetings.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's role in international organisations is one of the issues on which the supporters of a federal Europe are increasingly insisting. Some of the premises and considerations expressed in the text are acceptable, especially when there is a lack of transparency and democratic accountability with regard to the functioning of certain financial institutions and bodies. The problem arises where solutions are envisaged to make these bodies more 'efficient' and 'democratic'. It is proposed to create a kind of European code of conduct on transparency, integrity and accountability, aimed at guiding the action of EU representatives within the framework of international organisations and bodies. The second step is to create a single EU representation in these organisations, thus also limiting national scope for action. The last major proposal would also be to create a new world financial organisation, which is now difficult to see in the consequences that this could entail. It is clear that there is a need for greater cooperation between States at international level, but the solution cannot, however, be to standardise everything on a single model, which has already failed in its application in the form of a single currency.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The lack of eu action within international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and delays in the implementation of legal acts agreed at international level are due to the fragmentation and diversity of different organisations/bodies. I supported the report on the role of the EU within international bodies, as I believe that the Union should streamline its representation in multilateral organisations/bodies in order to increase the transparency, integrity and accountability of cooperation in these bodies. It would also make sense to create a European Code of Conduct aimed at guiding the conduct of EU representatives in international organisations/bodies.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – This report contains many of the amendments tabled by my group to value and to prioritise artisanal fisheries as a key economic activity to maintain coastal areas and to recognise the role of women and the need to improve their working conditions.  Nevertheless, I abstained because I am not at all clear about the intentions of the introduction in this report of paragraphs 34 and 35 concerning the exploitation of other resources at sea and transnational public-private partnerships. In my view, the aspects set out in these two sections pose a threat to artisanal and traditional coastal fisheries. That is why I abstained in this report.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because traditional fishing, especially in coastal and island areas, is identity and lifestyle, as well as the main source of economic livelihood for thousands of micro-enterprises, often family-run.  It is traditional fishing that suffers most both from the adaptation to the standards imposed by the European Union and from the management of fishing quotas by the Member States, which specifically exclude traditional fishing in favour, on the other hand, often of large shipowners. If we really want to support our communities and fisheries districts , and we must do so, there are two ways: first of all, derogations must be granted on the basis of regionalisation in order to create a fisheries policy that favours the productive environment rather than hinders it and, secondly, we must support these fishermen by giving them priority in allocating EAFM funds and gradually increasing the quotas allocated to small-scale fishermen.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are pleased that at last a report supports and supports artisanal fisheries and we welcome the inclusion of a strengthening of the role of women, as their work has always been constantly unvisitable and remains subject to significant pay gaps. However, the Commission cannot deviate from what is considered sustainable, especially in aquaculture. Aquaculture should not, under any circumstances, become an alibi to favour large enterprises at the expense of labour and the efforts of fishermen and seafood. Maritime-fishing resources are not owned by large corporations. They belong to the whole of citizenship and especially to those who have a deep bond with it, to the sea. The people of the sea, who every day struggle to keep our fishing sector alive throughout the value chain, those people, their needs and their way of life is what must be at the heart of any initiative and any policy. I hope that the Commission will always be clear about this.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Coastal fishing vessels account for around 80% of the fleet of the Member States of the European Union. In a number of regions, it is fisheries that are both de facto and historically the primary form of employment. It thus accounts for the largest area of work occupied by them. In other words, effective regulation and, above all, of the importance of quality support for workers in this field must take the first place both in member states' policies and in Union policies. Unlike industrial fishing, small-scale fishing is exactly the same – small-scale – and is often carried out by small businesses or even on an individual basis. We must always take into account this fact when we are once again developing a policy in this area. But I voted in favour. Thank you!

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to say a few words on this important topic, especially as I come from a small island country, Ireland, where  coastal communities are of such vital importance to us, and also I had the privilege of doing an opinion on blue growth in the last mandate. That shows that the opportunities are there to diversify, to innovate and to create jobs in the coastal communities. Fisheries obviously are vital for them and I welcome the suggestions in this report to develop that. Also, it can diversify into other areas. One is the whole area of sport in relation to coastal activities. This is a huge growth opportunity which must be developed. Another is fishing tourism; I was speaking to a man yesterday who told me that in the United States there were ten times more people interested in fishing than in golf. We can see how golf tourism has grown, so these are opportunities which we must help to create for our coastal communities.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Important though small-scale fishing is to many communities, the EU’s CFP approach has too many ulterior motives in its approach so must be opposed.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Inshore fishing has always been a crucial area in European policies. Given that 80% of the European fleet currently consists of small-scale coastal fishing vessels, it is clear that the sector makes an enormous contribution in terms of economic growth and employment. The Tomasic report, however, stresses the need for a review within the framework of technical measures which will make it possible to make greater use of regional specificities. In this respect, the creation of marine protected areas and investments to finance the development of activities complementary to fisheries, which highlight their multi-purpose nature and enormous variety at regional level, are encouraged. For these reasons, I voted in favour, particularly in view of the incredible benefit that both islands and coastal regions could derive from the introduction of socially and ecologically sustainable fishing.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an important and necessary political impetus for the maintenance and development of small-scale fishing activity in fisheries-dependent regions. This report calls on the Commission to develop effective legal definitions to improve support systems for artisanal, traditional and small-scale fisheries depending on their relationship with the territories in which it is carried out and not only on the basis of the size and power of the vessels. There are many traditional arts that have been considered outside these definitions by the size of the boats when their relationship with the territory as well as their environmental impact is much less, for example arts such as the Almadraba. As a commitment to the socially and environmentally more sustainable fishing gear, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report is a step in the right direction as it acknowledges the fact that small-scale fishing should not be categorised in the same manner as industrial, aka large-scale fishing, and thus there should be a clearer distinction. Especially as there are fundamental differences in terms of the scale of the environmental impact, sustainability and socio-economic interdependence between small-scale fisheries and communities that rely on sustainable non-industrial fishing, whereas industrial vessels and their multinational operators are not concerned with having a symbiotic relationship with any particular coastal community and their surrounding marine environments – their general concern is profiteering and maximising the detrimental exploitation of stocks. The focus on more regionalisation and a more equitable distribution of quotas for non-industrial fisheries was something that my party would be very supportive of.  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on coastal fisheries, because it is an extremely important form of fishing in EU countries. It guarantees a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. For most coastal and island regions, coastal fishing is a traditional form of fishing, which is a way of life and an important source of livelihood. Areas dependent on coastal fisheries require specific measures and support in order to develop and evolve. Coastal fishing is also one of the main objectives of the Socialist and Democrat Group for the protection and creation of jobs in small-scale fisheries. Coastal fishing guarantees a high level of employment in coastal areas and generally represents a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. This is in line with the priorities of the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats on fisheries.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The main purpose of the report is to find additional income for artisanal fishermen, but does not really address the underlying problem, namely that quotas are mainly allocated to industrial fishing at the expense of small-scale fishing. Artisanal fishermen make up 80% of European fishermen but receive only about 20% of the quotas allocated by the European Union. Industrial fishing, on the other hand, takes over the remaining 80%. However, our amendment tabled in committee, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to gradually increase the quotas allocated to artisanal fishermen, has been adopted. That is why I voted for this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is based on small-scale coastal fishing. Small-scale coastal fishing is important and the EU should not be allowed to dictate to Member States how to care for these areas. More importantly this report is the usual EU cocktail of claimed data inadequacy and new measures to extend its power.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which takes into account the specifics of small-scale coastal fishing, occupying 80% of the European fleet. This economic sector is economically essential for the maintenance and development of coastal and island territories and for employment in these territories.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to promote small-scale coastal fishing in areas dependent on fisheries. Coastal fishing is an extremely important form of fishing in EU countries, provides high employment and is a sustainable form of fishing from a social and environmental point of view. 2013 The CFP Regulation underlined the importance of economic growth in coastal areas. It provides preferential access for small-scale and traditional fishermen in the 12 nautical mile zone, the most sensitive area in EU waters. In order to facilitate the development of innovation, recognised shortcomings such as insufficient investment in science, lack of adequate data on the seas and oceans, insufficient funding, lack of private-public cooperation, etc. More investment has been in maritime and ocean surveillance systems in recent years, but this is still not enough. In addition, the fundamental problem is that existing data cannot be used. The procedure for requesting and obtaining a proper data authorisation alone is time-consuming and costly. It is therefore necessary to address the main problems in this sector: the decline in employment and profitability in the sector and the fight against the exclusion of the fisheries sector in developing regions.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Important though small-scale fishing is to many communities, the EU’s CFP approach has too many ulterior motives in its approach so must be opposed.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Inshore fishing is a major activity for European coastlines in that it affects almost 80% of European fishermen and allows for a high level of employment in coastal and outermost areas; it is also a more respectful form of fishing of marine flora and fauna than industrial fishing. That is why I supported this report which, thanks to the consideration of the amendments of my colleague Sylvie Goddyn, advocates defending artisanal fishing against industrial fishing - industrial fishing receiving 80% of the EU's fishing quotas when it represents only 20% of fishermen - by providing additional income opportunities for artisanal fishermen in the form of tourism subsidies , to culture or environmental services, or by supporting technological innovation and scientific research programs on fisheries.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Inshore fishing accounts for 80% of the European fleet. It is therefore an extremely important source of employment and income for many European regions. I have therefore approved this report which calls on the Commission to take into account small-scale coastal fishing in island societies, to support innovative projects for coastal areas or to take measures to support groups of women of the sea by encouraging their participation in all areas related to fishing.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, small-scale fishing revenues have suffered severe contractions due to rising fuel costs and a reduction in the value of fish at first sale, affecting numerous small fishing communities. From the coasts of Guyana French to those of the Adriatic, however, coastal and island fishing continues to be an important source of employment and a way of life for many citizens of the Union. 80% of the European fleet is engaged in this activity, together with shellfish harvesting, but defining extremely different ways depending on the geographical areas in which it is practiced. The Tomašić report, which I supported, calls on the Commission to use régionalisation to adapt the definition of inshore fishing to the specific ities of the different areas, and also to pay particular attention, when drawing up legislative proposals, to the different impact that fishing techniques and gears can have in the different areas. The focus on inshore fishing requires an overall vision within the existing dynamics between the environment, tourism, the economy and innovation. The blue economy is linked to the resources dedicated to innovation that are provided for in the Horizon 2020 programme, but it must be exploited to the full by creating transnational public-private partnerships that are able to promote the growth of coastal regions.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because the report talks about the need for a more equitable allocation of quotas that takes into account the protection of the environment and the contribution of fisheries to the local economy. This is something that already provides for in Article 17 of the Common Fisheries Policy, but which Spain has been failing to comply with, as we have repeatedly denounced. The Commission's report also recognises that the recession has hit sea people hard, further increasing the marginalization of the sector; and that diversification and innovation are more necessary than ever for the survival of artisanal fishing. It is a step forward and in the right direction for Europe to recognise and support the development of local communities whose livelihoods depend mainly on fishing and related activities. We also welcome the walk towards the empowerment of women at sea throughout the value chain of the fisheries sector, as their vital work has often been unvisitable and remains subject to wage gaps.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report, which is in favour of small-scale coastal fishing, which allows for a high level of employment in coastal areas as well as a more sustainable fishery. It should be noted that, so far, industrial fishing has fares a much better advantage in terms of quotas, which is why I welcome the measures proposed by the rapporteur in this report, since these include: the creation of local fisheries action groups (GALP), supporting the development of complementary activities for fishermen, such as in environmental services or tourism, or promoting technological innovation in products. equipment, techniques, etc. There is therefore the possibility for artisanal fishermen to receive additional income, although it is regrettable that the report did not tackle the problem of quotas: let us remember that artisanal fishermen represent 80% of European fishermen but receive only about 20% of the quotas allocated by the Union.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The enhancement of small-scale fishing in the Member States and the reduction of burdens on operators through improved regional governance are important goals. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report sets out the need for a definition of artisanal coastal fisheries that is respectful of territorial singularities and in line with the new CFP. It proposes a series of measures that accentuate innovation and promote economic diversification in the artisanal fisheries sector. In this sense, it deepens the capacity of social vertebration that artisanal fishing has in certain communities and takes into account the economic and social crisis, which affects it especially due to its low capitalization. The development of the fisheries tourism segment, the generation of employment that promotes social inclusion, the recognition and visualization of women's work, the promotion of fishing activities outside the informal economy and the need to regulate as a professional disease certain pathologies suffered by women active in this sector have been introduced. All this considering the importance of ensuring the economic and social stability of coastal communities engaged in artisanal fisheries, as well as environmental objectives such as the conservation of fishery resources and the development of responsible practices and the sustainability of coastal marine ecosystems. I voted for it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because coastal fishing is an extremely important form of fishing in European Union (EU) countries. It is particularly important because it ensures high employment and is a sustainable form of fishing from a social and environmental point of view. Coastal fishing is classified and defined differently in individual Member States (coastal, traditional or non-industrial fishing, etc.). Coastal fishing is a traditional form of fishing affecting lifestyles in most coastal and island areas and is an important source of livelihood. Fisheries-dependent areas need specific measures and support to grow and develop. The EU's flagship initiative Innovation Union is essential for the development of the blue economy. Horizon 2020, with a budget of around EUR 79 billion, will be implemented in 2020. The research and innovation programme is the largest programme. In addition, innovation has been funded by the EU Investment and Structural Funds.  In order to facilitate the development of innovation, recognised shortcomings such as insufficient investment in science, lack of adequate data on the seas and oceans, insufficient funding, lack of private-public cooperation, etc.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ meps and I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on small-scale coastal fishing in regions dependent on fishing. We are aware that coastal fishing accounts for 80% of the European fleet and, together with shellfish, ensures a high level of employment. This form of fishing has a versatile impact on social heritage and cultural specialities and is a traditional form of economy or way of life, a source of livelihood and job preservation in coastal and island regions. Support for the resolution is also a start-up measure that will enable these areas to grow and develop by giving small-scale fishing greater value within the 12 nautical mile area, which is the most environmentally sensitive part of EU waters.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Small fisheries are extremely important for EU coastal regions. Its economic impact is essential, and if the rules are respected, it is also an environmentally sustainable way of fishing. Croatian small fishermen, i.e. persons for whom fishing is not the primary economic activity, have been unfairly deprived by the abolition of fishing licences, and therefore I hope that the Commission will take into question the messages in this document and initiate legislative changes.  In conclusion, I support this report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Quotas are mainly allocated to industrial fishing at the expense of small-scale fishing. This report does not really address this substantive problem; its main purpose is to find additional income for artisanal fishermen. However, Sylvie Goddyn's amendment, tabled in committee, calling on the Commission and Member States to gradually increase quotas for artisanal fishermen, has been adopted. Therefore, I voted for it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that inshore fishing plays a fundamental role in the development and economy of very large areas of the Union and that, therefore, it must be strongly supported, especially in the effort towards innovation, so as to improve its profitability and sustainability.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Inshore fishing is of exceptional importance in some EU countries. It guarantees a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. For most coastal and island areas, fishing is a way of life and a significant source of livelihood. Areas dependent on inshore fishing require specific measures and support in order to grow and develop. Coastal regions often face decline and depopulation, mainly for employment reasons. For this reason, the European Maritime Affairs and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) must help to expand coastal economies by investing in data collection and promoting more scientific research. A change in Eu ropean laws is needed to preserve fishing gear and traditional techniques used for inshore fishing and to define a clear differentiation between commercial and inshore fishing.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Small-scale coastal fishing must be defended against industrial fishing, partly because it creates jobs in coastal and outermost areas and because it is a more sustainable form of fishing. To save small-scale fishing, the rapporteur recommends promoting the diversification of their activities: tourism services, cultural activities. It also stresses the importance of supporting technological innovation in equipment, in particular so that it can increase productivity. This report is a good move, with the aim of diversifying the sources of income for these fishermen. In addition, the amendment tabled by Sylvie Goddyn, MEP of the ENF group, to gradually increase quotas for artisanal fishermen, has been adopted. I have therefore spoken in favour of this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Coastal fishing is a very important form of fishing in the EU Member States, being of particular importance because it offers a high level of employment and is an ecologically and socially sustainable fishing activity. Coastal and island areas that depend on coastal fishing require special measures and special support in order to foster both the development of the areas and economic growth. The 2013 and 2014 Fisheries Economic Policy Regulations focused on economic growth in coastal areas, with these regulations recognising the importance of island areas on the high seas that depend on fishing and that need to be supported in order to survive and take the opportunities needed to develop. We voted in favour of the report on the innovation and diversification of artisanal coastal fisheries in fishing-dependent regions because it is very important to encourage and support states that are dependent on coastal fisheries in order to achieve economic growth for both those states and the EU.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Good own-initiative report on the exploitation of small-scale (albeit professional) fishing with references to the CFP and regional governance with some lightening of the burden on operators. I am voting in favour.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes ways to better take into account the specifics of small-scale fishing in fishing-dependent regions. Small-scale fishing provides employment in coastal areas and is a socially and ecologically sustainable form of fishing. It is a traditional form of fishing and a traditional way of life and is an important source of income. Areas that depend on small-scale fishing therefore require specific measures and aid, particularly through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). The report also stresses the specifics of small-scale fishing in the outermost regions and calls for special measures. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I think that the Commission should support innovative projects and legal provisions that facilitate the development of regions dependent on fishing. In particular, priority must be given to projects focusing on the sustainable creation and maintenance of jobs, the introduction of new technologies in the promotion and marketing of fisheries products and services, the promotion of pescaturismo and gastronomy linked to small-scale fisheries products, as well as all activities related to environmental protection, the development of marine renewable resources and the promotion of sustainable growth. The Commission and the Member States must also progressively increase the quotas allocated to artisanal fishermen in order to promote this type of socially and ecologically sustainable fishing. It is also essential to give priority to small-scale coastal fishing in the allocation of funding from the European Maritime affairs and Fisheries Fund (EMFF).

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is a step in the right direction as it acknowledges the fact that small-scale fishing should not be categorised in the same manner as industrial, aka large-scale fishing, and thus there should be a clearer distinction. Especially as there are fundamental differences in terms of the scale of the environmental impact, sustainability and socio-economic interdependence between small-scale fisheries and communities that rely on sustainable non-industrial fishing, whereas industrial vessels and their multinational operators are not concerned with having a symbiotic relationship with any particular coastal community and their surrounding marine environments – their general concern is profiteering and maximising the detrimental exploitation of stocks. The focus on more regionalisation and a more equitable distribution of quotas for non-industrial fisheries was something that my party would be very supportive of.  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very important report, especially to the regions that are most involved in coastal fishing. I voted in favour as it outlines proposals which could help improve the industry, help it grow and develop further. Coastal fishing is a major part of our fleet; it creates employment and is environmentally sustainable. One of the proposals mentioned in the report is the greater support for innovative projects which aim to create sustainable jobs, promote entrepreneurship and introduction of new technologies to facilitate the development of coastal regions.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Inshore fishing accounts for 80% of the EU fleet, providing a large number of jobs. The report states that the revision of the framework for technical measures must take account of the specific characteristics of regional coastal fishing and encourages the introduction of marine protected areas to promote sustainable fishing and facilitate the fight against irregular fishing. The Commission is invited to promote investment in the diversification of fishing activity through the development of complementary activities and career versatility in order to promote the development of tourism. I voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economy of coastal and island areas is strongly linked to fishing activities, especially small-scale fishing, which is the main and sometimes the only source of income for many communities.  The economic crisis we are experiencing has not spared this sector, and in particular that of small-scale coastal fishing, which is also affected by the imposition of technical measures relating to the way in which gear is used and to the fishing techniques provided for in the so-called 'Mediterranean' regulation. In order to protect inshore fishing, it is necessary to move towards a characterisation of small-scale fishing, and that is why we need to have a comprehensive and complete picture, without which there is still a high risk of taking decisions that do not meet the characteristics of the sector. Before revising the existing legislation, data are needed to design actions and interventions adapted to local needs and to chart the path for sustainable coastal fishing from a biological, environmental, social and economic point of view. As small-scale fishing is an activity linked to local traditions, launching plans to safeguard them and developing complementary activities compatible with local vocations, such as nautical tourism or recreational fishing, could contribute to the revitalisation of these areas. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and recall that coastal fishing is an extremely important form of fishing in EU countries. It ensures a high level of employment, and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on small-scale fishing in areas dependent on it. This report concerns environmental, economic and social issues. As it refers to a specific fisheries sector, it contains specific proposals and succeeds in focusing on environmental protection issues, but also good practices when it comes to marine fauna and over-exploitation of specific areas. I therefore voted in favour of the report as I consider it to be a positive step.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it not only protects inshore fishing but also lays a solid foundation for its development. This report aims to regionalise the rules for inshore fishing by adapting it on a case-by-case basis, country by country. I believe that this is an important step forward because, in my opinion, it allows this practice to develop properly with full respect for the individual countries and for the individual specificities that this activity requires. I also voted in favour because I believe that inshore fishing not only guarantees a high level of employment but is also a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. I therefore believe that it is essential to strengthen this activity by regionalising its regulation, because it is full of positive external effects not only in terms of social and economic cohesion but also in terms of environmental protection and development, because I believe that its strengthening could lead to an increase in employment as well as to greater profitability of the sector.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Coastal fishing ensures high levels of employment in depopulated areas. Areas depending on this form of employment need specific measures and support so they can develop and grow. Shortcomings must be acknowledged, particularly in terms of investment in science and the lack of data on seas and oceans. The monitoring of seas and oceans, although improved, is still not sufficient. Data is difficult to access and the procedure for doing so is time-consuming and costly. Tourism, culture and artistic activities could be used to diversify the fisheries sector, thus ensuring its continuation. Activities which tie into renewable energy and environmental protection must be accessed to provide a sustainable future for the fisheries sector.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Important though small-scale fishing is to many communities, the EU’s CFP approach has too many ulterior motives in its approach so must be opposed.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I  support the key objective to fund activities that are socially, environmentally and economically viable and capable of creating employment, particularly for young people and women.  This is a challenge which is not easy to overcome.  Making marine aquaculture compatible and complementary with coastal fishing often presents issues which affect people’s living. This entails long-term support for sustainable growth for all marine and maritime sectors, acknowledging the importance of seas and oceans as the powerhouses which generate employment and create employment in the coastal regions. Malta has approximately 90% of its commercial vessels less than 12 m in length and more than half of them are of a traditional design, mainly ‘Luzzu’ and ‘Kajjik’ which operate mainly in coastal waters. Some coastal and island regions are facing a significant economic decline of such fleets, which is resulting in depopulation and the exodus of their inhabitants, who seek opportunities in areas offering better prospects for employment and education.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an important and necessary political impetus for the maintenance and development of small-scale fishing activity in fisheries-dependent regions. This report calls on the Commission to develop effective legal definitions to improve support systems for artisanal, traditional and small-scale fisheries depending on their relationship with the territories in which it is carried out and not only on the basis of the size and power of the vessels. There are many traditional arts that have been considered outside these definitions by the size of the boats when their relationship with the territory as well as their environmental impact is much less, for example arts such as the Almadraba. As a commitment to the socially and environmentally more sustainable fishing gear, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In some island territories, small-scale and traditional fishing is an important, if not the main, source of income at local level, making these regions extremely dependent on this type of fishing. Although there is a well-established common fisheries policy at European level, the Commission has not taken sufficient account of the specific socio-economic characteristics of the territories dependent on small-scale and traditional fishing. It therefore seems essential to pay more attention to this type of fishing, which, moreover, turns out to be socially and ecologically more sustainable. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution, so that the Commission can take into account the particularities and socio-economic characteristics of the territories where traditional and small-scale fishing is a key economic sector.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 When we talk about fishing in coastal and island areas, we are talking about a way of life and even a livelihood that provides living. They require special measures and special support to foster development and economic growth. I voted to amend the existing legislation, thus protecting fishing in coastal and island areas.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Coastal fishing is an extremely important form of fishing in the Member States. In most coastal and island areas, coastal fishing is a traditional form of fishing that is a way of life and an important livelihood. Special measures and support are required to ensure the growth and development of areas dependent on coastal fisheries. The report calls on the Commission to take more intensive action to protect small-scale coastal fishing in fisheries-dependent regions and to adopt a definition of small-scale coastal fishing in line with the specific characteristics of the different regions. The report also addresses ways in which diversification and innovation could help coastal regions. It also analyses how the economic structure of coastal regions is diversification through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). The rapporteur stresses the importance of innovation and research for coastal regions. Due to the content of the document and its nature, I supported it in the vote.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents a blue economy development strategy. It sets out the main challenges for the fishing sector, namely the decline in employment, profitability and the fight against the marginalization of the fishing sector in developing regions. Considering that the European fishing sector must find new resources in order to restructure and become more efficient, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the innovation and diversification of small-scale inshore fisheries in fishing-dependent regions. This report encourages the creation of new and innovative enterprises in fisheries-dependent regions, which is crucial for the development and growth of traditional coastal fisheries.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Small-scale coastal fishing accounts for 80% of the European fleet and many jobs in coastal, island and outermost areas. This sector must therefore be protected and encouraged, taking into account its regional and territorial specificities.  This is why it is important for the European Union to provide the artisanal coastal fishing sector with appropriate regulation and to promote innovative projects that ensure the economic and sustainable development of coastal, island and outermost regions.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Inshore fishing is practised by 80% of European fishermen, who are involved in a high level of employment, especially in the outermost regions. However, its fishermen receive only 20% of the quotas allocated by the EU, even though it is a more sustainable form of fishing. Instead of questioning the system, this text was limited to finding additional income for artisanal fishermen. However, my colleague Sylvie Goddyn's amendment, which asks the Commission and the Member States to gradually increase the quotas of artisanal fishermen, has been adopted. That is why I voted for this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I agree that coastal fishing is an important form of fishing in EU countries. It ensures a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable way of fishing. I believe that the Commission should take measures to protect artisanal coastal fishing in the regions dependent on it for its livelihood, and furthermore, I think it is of particular importance to take into account the specificities of the different regions in determining the allowed scale of fishing.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the Group of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the Tomašić report. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: the main purpose of the report is to find additional income for artisanal fishermen.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on small fishing communities, artisanal coastal fishing and the factors for their protection and development in a strongly industrialised context. The report refers to and advocates the promotion of specific regulations and legislation, financing and technology transfer instruments and know-how, the regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), a more equitable distribution of quotas, the protection of the environment and the value of socio-economic diversity, the development of the sea economy with the involvement of actors, the development of gender policies that strengthen the economic and social empowerment of women , strengthening sustainable aquaculture, job creation and improving working conditions and enforcement. In general, in its approaches and proposals, the report is going towards our positions, so we voted in favour. On this occasion, however, we cannot fail to recall the report adopted in the previous legislature on small-scale coastal fishing and artisanal fishing, for which we were responsible, containing recommendations to improve the situation of this specific segment of the fishing fleet, with a high prevalence in Portugal. For the most part, these recommendations remain valid, but unfortunately they have not come out of the paper. Moreover, the new CFP has degraded an already difficult and precarious picture of itself.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report given the fundamental role that inshore fishing plays as a source of livelihood and development for many regions of the EU. As already recognised in previous regulations on the common fisheries policy, and on the European Maritime Affairs Fund, these areas require further support to promote economically and environmentally sustainable growth. In particular, I welcome the fact that the report considers the possibility of using instruments that make it possible to implement activities complementary to traditional fishing such as catering, environmental services, cultural activities linked to fishing and tourism linked to sport fishing. I welcome the recommendation concerning the need for legislation to control and value the different inshore fishing practices, taking into account the specific characteristics of the individual areas concerned, in particular by supporting small-scale fishermen.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as the report is positive overall.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report because it enhances and supports small-scale fishing, including some reductions in the burden on operators.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I agree and vote in favour of the report as it promotes a more realistic and sustainable form of fishing, based on tradition and local society away from the industrialisation of this profession. Combining fishing with tradition, tourism and various other activities can offer multiple benefits to these societies.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Coastal fishing is an exceptionally important form of fishing in EU countries. It guarantees a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. For most coastal and island areas, coastal fishing is a traditional form of fishing that forms a way of life and a significant source of livelihood. Areas which depend on coastal fisheries require specific measures and support in order to grow and develop.  The report looks at how innovation and diversification can help coastal regions dependent on fishing to survive. Not only is coastal fishing a way of life for many communities, but for islands and coastal areas it can also provide a number of people’s livelihoods. Coastal regions face decline and depopulation as people move elsewhere to find work. I supported the report as I believe it will protect and create jobs in small-scale, artisanal fisheries. Coastal fishing guarantees a high level of employment in coastal areas and generally represents a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I approve the report on coastal fishing. I support all the things that have a positive impact on job creation, the main European challenge of the present. This area is of particular importance within fisheries as it creates jobs and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. It is also a traditional form of fishing, which we must support for its survival and development.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report aware of the importance of fisheries in many EU States, as it employs a large number of citizens and represents in itself a socially and environmentally sustainable activity. Coastal fishing represents a traditional form of fishing that is an important source of livelihood, so areas that depend on this type of fishing require specific supportive measures and in order to develop. We must bet on innovation for the development of the blue economy. In recent years, more has been invested in sea and ocean control systems, but it is still insufficient. Similarly, diversification in the fisheries sector is needed due to falling employment and profitability in the sector.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the basis that it will support non-industrial-scale fishing in general, and that this is important because these smaller and often family-run fisheries play an important role in many rural coastal communities all around Europe. This resolution and the support it could provide would not only support the local fisheries themselves but also the surrounding community and countryside and it could help to maintain an important historic way of life.  With this report we also stress the great social and economic impact of small-scale fishery.
