Support of small costal fisheries means that we promote a more sustainable way of fishing and support the availability of local products for the local consumer. Both of these effects can help save us from negative environmental impacts.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in regions dependent on fishing because I am convinced that inshore fishing is a fundamental and essential activity for the economic but also environmental and social fabric of those territories of southern Europe that live sustainable growth and that have always been fed by genuine forms of economy. I am convinced of the importance of the blue economy as a new driving force for the development of coastal areas, as a form of combating the emigration and desertification of those areas and a source of jobs for small and very small producers. I welcome the call for the Commission to adapt the definition of coastal fishing by involving the regional level and calibrating it on the characteristics of the territories, and to support innovative projects and legal provisions that facilitate the development of this activity in coastal, island and ultra-peripheral regions. I also welcome the call for better use of the EMFF to promote coastal zones, the need for instruments to promote women's employment in inshore fishing and references to the social economy sector and local development groups: women, local development and employment as sources of coastal zone growth.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As a Member of the European Parliament of the mecklenburg-western coastal region, I voted in favour of the report on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in areas dependent on fishing. I believe that The European promotion of small and medium-sized fisheries and family-owned maritime businesses is extremely important.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Coastal fishing in the north of my region is an important source of income and employment and needs separate support because of its mostly traditional form. As a member of the Committee on Fisheries, I campaigned for financial support and development to protect the environment and secure the livelihoods of fishermen.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Coastal fishing is an important industry in the UK and especially in the South-West with many individual fishermen and coastal communities relying on these operations for their livelihoods. With such small-scale and often traditional operations, a one-size-fits-all approach is not appropriate and flexibility is required within legislation to accommodate these practices and other local conditions.  I am pleased that this legislation is focusing on supporting and developing this sector in a way that is sensitive to this, whilst using the powerful tools we have available in the form of European-level funding from the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) to promote diversification and growth. This represents a step towards environmental and economic sustainability for coastal communities.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. 80% of European fishermen are artisanal fishermen, but receive only 20% of fishing quotas, while industrial fishing takes up the remaining 80%. However, artisanal fishing creates many jobs in local communities and better selectivity, and thus better viability. In order to increase fishermen's incomes, the Toma-i report proposed to develop complementary activities: environmental services, tourism, culture or product processing. But fishing must remain the main activity and the main source of income for fishermen. I have therefore tabled an amendment calling on the Commission and the Member States to gradually increase the quotas allocated to artisanal fishermen. This amendment has been voted on, but the allocation of quotas is at the level of the Member States. All national authorities must now strongly influence the distribution of quotas in favour of artisanal fishermen.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because the report talks about the need for a more equitable allocation of quotas that takes into account the protection of the environment and the contribution of fisheries to the local economy. This is something that already provides for in Article 17 of the Common Fisheries Policy, but which Spain has been failing to comply with, as we have repeatedly denounced. The Commission's report also recognises that the recession has hit sea people hard, further increasing the marginalization of the sector; and that diversification and innovation are more necessary than ever for the survival of artisanal fishing. It is a step forward and in the right direction for Europe to recognise and support the development of local communities whose livelihoods depend mainly on fishing and related activities. We also welcome the walk towards the empowerment of women at sea throughout the value chain of the fisheries sector, as their vital work has often been unvisitable and remains subject to wage gaps.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it looks at how innovation and diversification can help coastal regions dependent on fishing to survive. The S&D Group believes in the importance of the further development of socially and environmentally sustainable small-scale and artisanal fishing.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The document calls on the Commission and on Member States to gradually increase the quotas allocated to non-industrial fisheries, in order to boost socially and sustainable forms of fishing.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Despite the general consensus that the Common Fisheries Policy, in relation to small-scale fisheries, is particularly negative, this report is a step in the right direction. Since it recognises the fact that small-scale fishing should not be categorised in the same way as large-scale fishing, and that there should therefore be a clearer distinction. For these reasons, we consider this vote to be an appropriate stance.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very happy to support this report along with my ALDE colleagues. Many coastal and island regions in Ireland and the EU are facing a significant economic decline, which is resulting in depopulation and the exodus of their inhabitants. It is precisely in such areas where the pressure in terms of using the sea’s resources is growing, and the fisheries sector is being marginalised in favour of tourism.  Thankfully this report addresses these structural issues and offers solutions to support small-scale and coastal fisheries in the EU. The report calls on the Commission to take into account socio-economic and environmental considerations and to promote, through the regionalisation process, a new definition of coastal fishing in line with the specificities of each fishery. It also calls on the Commission and on Member States to gradually increase the quotas allocated to non-industrial fisheries, in order to boost socially and sustainable forms of fishing. This is vital for the continuation of small-scale coastal fishing which is of historical and traditional importance.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion as diversification is a required path to take, in order to prevent further decline in the sector whilst also allowing for new developments to be explored that have the potential to be greener.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. This report on small-scale fishing is a step in the right direction, but it lacks a critical note. European fish stocks are heavily overfished and populations are in danger of disappearing. There is a great need for a switch to less fishing and more sustainability. The report calls for more exceptions, more quotas and more flexibility for small fishing companies, but that is contrary to the common fisheries policy. If we do not start now to drastically reduce the impact of fishing on the marine environment, many species of fish will become extinct. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report correctly highlights the fact that the fishing industry is hugely varied throughout the EU. Whilst the new CFP does well in underlining the importance of small-scale fishing, it is important that the necessary definitions are now dictated from the centre. The rapporteur took these points on board and I was able to support her report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Coastal fishing, classified and defined differently in each Member State, is an extremely important form of fishing in EU countries that guarantees a high level of employment that is socially and environmentally sustainable. I have voted in favour of this report that reiterates the economic importance of small-scale coastal fishing.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in areas dependent on fishing, as I believe this type of fishing needs to be provided with strong and decisive assistance.  Small coastal fishing is a way of life, a tradition, an environmentally sustainable way of fishing, it stimulates employment and is a stability factor for individual Member States. Unfortunately, there is still no common definition of small-scale fishing at European level, only the criteria for the size and strength of fishing vessels are used in the form of small and large-scale fishing differentiation.  I believe that sustainable ways of fishing need to be promoted more strongly and the role of fisheries-based communities in the development of local areas should be strengthened. Also, diversification and innovation in the field of fisheries can certainly contribute to the strengthening and progress of this sector, as well as the role of women and the development of other related activities such as tourism and gastronomy.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The main purpose of the report is to find additional income for artisanal fishermen, but does not really address the underlying problem, namely that quotas are mainly allocated to industrial fishing at the expense of small-scale fishing. Artisanal fishermen make up 80% of European fishermen but receive only about 20% of the quotas allocated by the EU. Industrial fishing, on the other hand, takes over the remaining 80%. However, my colleague Sylvie Goddyn's amendment, tabled in committee, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to gradually increase the quotas allocated to artisanal fishermen, has been adopted. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Important though small-scale fishing is to many communities, the EU’s CFP approach has too many ulterior motives in its approach so must be opposed.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ruza Tomasic's report on small-scale inshore fishing in fishing-dependent areas. In most coastal and island areas, inshore fishing is an important source of income. Areas that depend on inshore fisheries require specific measures and aid to ensure growth and development. The decline in employment and profitability in this sector, its marginalization in developing regions on the one hand, and opportunities to take advantage of new opportunities such as "green" development on the other, are all factors that show the importance and identify opportunities to revive activities in this sector. I therefore agree with this proposal that it is essential, in order to protect the inshore fishery, to initiate a process of modification of existing regulations.  This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. Inshore fishing is a very important form of fishing in the territory of the European Union states. It is particularly important because it provides a great deal of employment and is a socially and ecologically sustainable form of fishing. It is essential to protect inshore fisheries to initiate a process of modification of existing regulations and to adopt specific aid measures to ensure the development and growth of these areas. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Coastal fishing guarantees a high level of employment in coastal areas and generally represents a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. Therefore, I voted in favour of the report, as it looks at how innovation and diversification can help coastal regions dependant on fishing to survive.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In my opinion, it is imperative to differentiate the fisheries sector, in particular coastal fisheries, from other sectors of economy. This need stems not only from the smaller environmental impact of coastal fishing, but above all from the fact that some coastal and island regions are suffering from an economic downturn and are unable to achieve sufficient growth and innovation.  This report emphasises the restoration of recognised shortcomings in adequate funding and obstacles to the use of available resources and calls for a new legal framework that aligns the relevant fisheries policy regulations with the needs of coastal fisheries. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is essential that we manage the marines and oceans well, preserving their biodiversity. It is equally important to salvage the still salvageable minds of European culture, such as artisanal coastal fishing, which is also an environmentally friendly way of living and even harmonises well with tourism. The report is fully eligible and summarises the socially useful aspects of this activity

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is mainly aimed at finding additional income for artisanal fishermen. In addition, it has the merit of taking up the amendment tabled by FN MP Sylvie Goddyn, which plans to gradually increase the quotas of fish allocated to artisanal fishermen.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. In Europe, 80% of fishing is practiced by artisanal fishermen. This traditional sustainable activity contributes to the dynamism and employment of coastal and outermost regions. However, it is fiercely competitive with industrial fishing, which benefits from generous fishing quotas.  The proposed text is a defender of artisanal fishermen. Indeed, it proposes many measures in this direction, such as preferential access to traditional coastal fishing up to 12 nautical miles (22.2 km), support for the development of complementary activities for fishermen (environmental services, tourism, etc.) or support for technological innovation (products, equipment, etc.). Although the report does not address the substantive problem, which is the majority allocation of quotas to industrial fishing, it is important for artisanal fishermen who will obtain additional income. In addition, an amendment (ENF) allowing Member States to gradually increase quotas for artisanal fishermen was passed. For all these reasons, I voted FOR.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is an important and necessary political impetus for the maintenance and development of small-scale fishing activity in fisheries-dependent regions. This report calls on the Commission to develop effective legal definitions to improve support systems for artisanal, traditional and small-scale fisheries depending on their relationship with the territories in which it is carried out and not only on the basis of the size and power of the vessels. There are many traditional arts that have been considered outside these definitions by the size of the boats when their relationship with the territory as well as their environmental impact is much less, for example arts such as the Almadraba. As a commitment to the socially and environmentally more sustainable fishing gear, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The adoption of this report expressly supports The European regions dependent on artisanal coastal fisheries by Parliament.  This type of fishing gives work to many European citizens and, moreover, from an environmental point of view, does not carry the usual risks associated with mass fishing. Consequently, we understand it essential to ensure continuity this traditional style of fishing.  We call on the Commission to encompass under a definition common to all these types of fishing, the methods and traditions of which differ considerably from one Member State to another and, from there, to focus on promoting innovation and diversification in this type of activity.  Therefore, because of the important support this report entails for coastal areas and islands, my vote will be favourable.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Small coastal fishing is one of the most important forms of fishing for the Territory of the European Union. It represents tradition, way of life and a source of food and income for the population living off fishing. For this reason, it is essential to ensure a high level of employment and sustainable development in areas dependent on fishing.  Small coastal fishing is environmentally friendly and is an economic basis for the conservation and development of coastal and island communities. In the outermost regions, it contributes to economic development and plays a role as a supplier at local level. Under the new Common Fisheries Policy, the importance of fisheries-dependent coastal and island regions has been recognised, resulting in the necessity of ensuring a dignified standard of living for those engaged in fishing activities. States must promote greater diversification and innovation in order to encourage more fisheries activities and reduce the pressing problem of depopulation of island and coastal areas. I supported my colleague Tomašić's report because Croatia is witnessing the depopulation of the island and the ageing workforce in the fisheries sector. Innovation and diversification are therefore the key to recovering coastal and coastal areas.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fisheries in areas dependent on fisheries, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/4/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, even if it does not resolve the imbalance between small-scale fishing, which accounts for 80% of European fishermen, and industrial fishing. The latter takes up 80% of Europe's fishing quotas. Nevertheless, these proposals would generate additional income for artisanal fishermen, including the creation of local fishing groups, supporting technological innovation and strengthening institutional support. An amendment by ENF MEP Sylvie Goddyn in favour of increasing fishing quotas for artisanal fishermen was also adopted.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur cites data unavailability as one of the main obstacles. Fishing is sometimes a small, almost informal type of industry. In light of this I agree that we need to learn more about small-scale fishing to support our communities, with more money for research. Traditional coastal fishing has declined in some areas, where a tourism industry is developing. I agree with the rapporteur that we must bear in mind the interests of the sector both for tourism and fisheries as important sources of growth.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Coastal fishing is a well-known form of fishing for many Member States of the Union. As a form of employment, it is also environmentally friendly. Having a different name in each country, such as "traditional" or "artisanal" fishing, it is an important livelihood, but also a way of life for many inhabitants of coastal and island areas. Taking into account the needs of these coastal areas, the EU has already adopted a number of regulations relating to this sector, such as the 2013 Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) Regulation and the 2014 European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMS) Regulation. Through these regulations, the need to protect this employment has been recognised by measures such as its preferential access to an area of 12 nautical miles. The EMSR also supports innovation and new investment in this area, such as investing in educational information programmes. It is therefore necessary, through new ideas and policies, to deal with the recession that has been observed in recent years, as a result of the general economic difficulties that prevail in many such island regions. This can be achieved with a new CAP, which will offer a more modern framework adapted to the new challenges.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that emphasises the importance of, and challenges to, traditional coastal fishing and its impact on livelihood of citizens in island areas.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Inshore fishing is a disaster zone. As a purveyor of permanent jobs on the coast, it is a cultural marker of the territory to be preserved. The aging of the fleet hinders the modernization capabilities needed to improve the selectivity of fishing techniques, reduce unwanted catches and implement zero discharge on a forced basis. The report proposes targeted support for fleet renewal in outermost regions without increasing capacity. It also provides for an increase in the share of fishing quotas allowed for tourism activities. It would have been desirable if it had also concerned the metropolitan coastal fleet, which was over 35 years old. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I am in support of small-scale fishing, especially as it is truly sustainable and provides a large number of jobs. The report seeks additional income for these artisanal fishermen but does not pose the problem, which is that the quotas are overwhelmingly allocated to industrial fishing. Artisanal fishermen account for 80% of fishermen and have only 20% of fishing quotas. However, my colleague Sylvie Goddyn passed an amendment for the gradual increase of their quotas.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on innovation and diversification of artisanal fishing in fishing-dependent regions. We must make every effort to protect artisanal fishing, especially in the outermost regions. This report advocates coastal fishing, which guarantees a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. It is also important to stress that tourism and fishing should not be dissociated. Both are important to local economies.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fisheries in fisheries-dependent regions. By implementing the measures in this resolution Europe can make an organised effort to improve economic growth and reduce unemployment in both the long and short term.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome Parliament's adoption of this report on the innovation and diversification of small-scale inshore fisheries in fishing-dependent regions. Because of its social, economic and environmental benefits, inshore fishing is of crucial importance and should be preserved as best as possible.  Innovation and diversification will both contribute to the economic development of coastal fishing areas. In terms of innovation, improving the collection of reliable and up-to-date data and its accessibility will be an indispensable prerequisite for the development of innovation. In terms of diversification, sustainable tourism has the potential to play a particularly beneficial role for coastal communities. Marine and underwater tourism can combine environmental and biodiversity awareness with the economic development of regions dependent on coastal fishing.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Islands and coastal areas have been in the european Union's spotlight for a long time. These are the parts of the European area that, through their culture, history and working areas, constantly sustain traditional European life, to which fishing is inherently one. Fishing is a normal part of life for the inhabitants of islands and coastal areas, it is a way of subsuling the local population, which literally "keeps it alive" without exaggeration. A common fisheries policy is currently in force through which inshore fishing is to be jointly regulated. Despite the great positives that this legal act has undoubtedly brought, it does not harmonise small-scale fishing in Europe, and therefore there is a constant lack of regulation that would adequately regulate all the necessary areas of small-scale coastal fishing. This is an issue that will require a quick and high-quality solution through well-prepared regulations that clarify concepts and make life easier for many people who do honest work. For these reasons, I agree with the report that has been tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Coastal fishing is an exceptionally important form of fishing in EU countries. It guarantees a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. For most coastal and island areas, coastal fishing is a traditional form of fishing that forms a way of life and a significant source of livelihood. Areas which depend on coastal fisheries require specific measures and support in order to grow and develop. The report looks at how innovation and diversification can help coastal regions dependant on fishing to survive. Therefore, I fully support and voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The main purpose of the report is to find additional income for artisanal fishermen, but does not really address the underlying problem, namely that quotas are mainly allocated to industrial fishing at the expense of small-scale fishing. Artisanal fishermen make up 80% of European fishermen but receive only about 20% of the quotas allocated by the European Union. Industrial fishing, on the other hand, takes over the remaining 80%.  However, Sylvie Goddyn's amendment, tabled in committee, which calls on the Commission and Member States to gradually increase quotas for artisanal fishermen, has been adopted. That is why we can vote in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is our duty, especially when we know the reality well, to safeguard the interests and defend the specificities of regions suffering from some constraints such as the outermost regions. Differentiated treatment is needed to treat what is different and, in the case of fisheries and fishing or sea-related activities, we need to find different solutions. The adoption of this report defends small-scale coastal fishing and values the professions linked to maritime activity, i.e. all those who have their source of income in fishing. We have achieved differentiated treatment in the future of European fisheries. It insists on the creation of new types of support, framed in existing European funding, so that more and new areas can deserve funding. As the ePP's rapporteur in charge, I am pleased to see the report adopted by a large majority.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report deals with artisanal inshore fishing practised by the majority of European and French fishermen, which allows a high level of employment in coastal and outermost regions and is also a more sustainable form of fishing. To save small-scale fishing, this text proposes: to create and subsidize local fishing action groups, to support the development of complementary activities for fishermen, as well as to support technological innovation in the products, equipment and techniques of artisan fishers. In addition, the FN amendment proposing the gradual increase in fishing quotas allocated to small-scale fishing was adopted, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I support the development of small-scale inshore fishing, which is fundamental both from the point of view of social and economic cohesion as well as from the point of view of environmental protection, but which was not sufficiently recognised in the old common fisheries policy. This report calls on the Commission to take this type of fishing into account. That is why I voted for it.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Tomasic report on the diversification of inshore fisheries. Inshore fishing is a very important form of fishing on the territory of the Member States of the European Union. It is particularly important because it provides a great deal of employment in coastal areas and is a socially and ecologically sustainable form of fishing.  Inshore fishing is the subject of different classifications and definitions in the different Member States (coastal, traditional, artisanal, etc.). In most coastal and island areas, inshore fishing is a traditional form of fishing and lifestyle, and is an important source of income. Areas that depend on inshore fisheries require specific measures and aid to ensure growth and development.  The main reasons why diversification is needed in the fisheries sector are: the decline in employment in the sector and the profitability of the sector, the fight against the marginalization of the fishing sector in developing regions and opportunities to take advantage of new opportunities, such as "green" development. Etc.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. In addition to providing employment, inshore fishing is a socially and ecologically sustainable form of fishing. However, areas dependent on inshore fisheries require specific aids and measures to ensure the growth and development of activity. Although inshore fishing activities need to diversify in order to cope with its declining profitability and gradual marginalisation, it is important that the European Union supports this vital sector. This starts with improving existing regulations. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal, which highlights the importance of the tradition of coastal fishing in the light of local culture and is intended to protect and promote local traditional forms of fishing. Unfortunately, legislators and bureaucracy treat the sea as a whole and do not give sufficient attention to the specificities of fishing regions. The heritage of coastal fishing can even be understood as a local culture, the protection of which is a priority for me, even for my own country. A very important dimension of the report is the focus of small businesses and family businesses at regional level, which is essential for the healthy functioning of the local economy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Coastal fishing represents an exceptionally important form of fishing in EU countries guaranteeing a high level of employment that is socially and environmentally sustainable. I have voted for this report that addresses shortcomings such as inadequate investment in science, lack of data on seas and oceans, insufficient funding, lack of cooperation between the private and public sector.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I support the position expressed by the rapporteur on the importance of artisanal coastal fishing for both local economies and the entire EU fishing industry. Coastal fishing, artisanal or traditional, although defined differently from the Member States, is, for some communities, the most important economic activity, if not the only one. I support the principles expressed in this report, in particular those on the application of regionalisation, as also provided for in the framework of the common fisheries policy. I also think it is extremely important that the report underlines the need to encourage artisanal fishing, a clearer definition of artisanal coastal fishing and a constant analysis of socio-economic realities.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes measures to promote innovation and diversification of small-scale inshore fisheries, in order to preserve the artisanal and ecologically sustainable fishing methods and the traditional ways of life that depend on them.  The proposed measures include the regionalisation of the management of fishing fleets, the specificity of island communities, a fairer distribution of quotas for small-scale fishing, the protection of the environment and socio-economic diversity and, finally, more technical measures such as the prioritization of the FEAMP for small-scale fishing or the classification of fishing gear. My amendments, covering the outermost regions, including recommending a better exchange of information and good practices between the different outermost fishing areas and calling for the development of local distribution channels and the potential of the oceans, coastal areas and coastal areas in terms of development, jobs, energy autonomy, innovation and sustainable development, have all been adopted and integrated into the report.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Important though small-scale fishing is to many communities, the EU’s CFP approach has too many ulterior motives in its approach so must be opposed.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation 380/2013 on the common fisheries policy promotes the economic development of coastal and island areas, and that the fisheries in question contribute to the growth of employment in these areas and Regulation 508/2014 on the EMFF gives great attention to precisely this type of fishing and that in the current programming period 2014-2020, research and innovation benefit from considerable European funding thanks to the Horizon 2020 programme. At present, there is a lack of information and difficulties in accessing data on the situation of the seas and oceans, and more investment in research and innovation is therefore needed. Finally, diversification in the inshore fisheries sector would make it possible to cope with the economic difficulties of certain geographical areas due to over-exploitation of resources, with a consequent reduction in profits, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Resolution on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing because it tosses the key problems faced by the inhabitants of the Mediterranean countries of Europe, where small-scale coastal fishing has been present in this area for thousands of years, is a way of life and is an integral part of cultural and traditional intangible heritage.  As I have pointed out several times in my discussions, I believe that in order to achieve the objectives of protecting biodiversity and marine resources, a regional approach should be applied, taking care of all geographical, biological, sociological and economic specificities. In particular, I stress the necessity of stopping the existing negative trends of depopulation of coastal areas and islands and finding the right balance between the interests of the local population and the protection of biodiversity and marine resources, as this is the only way we can contribute to achieving the desired goals. In this regard, cooperation with the local population is necessarily necessary, as the failure of the existing, perhaps over-restrictive, fishing policy can lead to undesirable results and depopulation of the coastal and island areas as well as excessive depletion of marine resources, and this is certainly not the purpose of the CFP.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The main purpose of the report is to find additional income for artisanal fishermen, but does not really address the underlying problem, namely that quotas are mainly allocated to industrial fishing at the expense of small-scale fishing. Artisanal fishermen make up 80% of European fishermen but receive only about 20% of the quotas allocated by the European Union. Industrial fishing, on the other hand, takes over the remaining 80%.  However, the amendment by my colleague Sylvie Goddyn, tabled in committee, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to gradually increase the quotas allocated to artisanal fishermen, has been adopted. That is why I am voting for this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Inshore fishing is an extremely significant type of fishing in EU countries, it is particularly important as it ensures a high employment rate and is socially and environmentally sustainable. I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the idea that areas dependent on inshore fishing require specific measures and support that offer them opportunities for growth and development. To this end, the various gaps found in areas that are fundamental to the profitability of the sector must be filled. In recent years, investment in sea and ocean control systems has increased, but is still insufficient, and the procedure for finding and obtaining appropriate data authorisations in itself requires a great deal of time and additional financial resources. All this considerably restricts the development of innovation and the use of resources, which is also affected by the lack of cooperation between the public and private sectors. A further significant aspect concerns diversification in the fisheries sector, which is necessary to cope with the decline in employment and profitability. Given the importance of the environment and a sustainable economy, diversification of fisheries must make use of the contribution of activities related to renewable energy sources and environmental protection.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Given that there has been a gap in Croatia's accession negotiations with the European Union, we now have to fight for small fishermen through the institutions of the European Union. That road isn't even easy and there are more steps. The first step has been taken in the past week. This report contains a multitude of positive provisions that essentially call for the amendment of existing provisions that recognise only professional and sport-recreational fishing, which is why our small fishermen have been deprived since last year. I am particularly pleased that the Fisheries Committee has adopted all 9 amendments I have tabled, including this amendment which seeks to encourage the Commission to allow the use of networks up to 150m to the coastal population for non-commercial purposes. This is in fact a step towards provisions that already have a large number of countries in the EU, as they protected small-scale fishing as a cultural heritage, which I also stated in the amendments, while warning of the problem of loss of traditional fishing skills and knowledge due to unfavourable regulations for coastal communities.  Given that this is a non-allegislative report that I certainly support, in which Parliament articulated its position, I expect that within a year a legislation report will arrive in the procedure, which will finally amend the existing Mediterranean Regulation and its provisions that limit us.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on small fishing communities, artisanal coastal fishing and factors for their protection and development in a strongly industrialised context. The report refers to and advocates the promotion of specific regulations and legislation, financing and technology transfer instruments and know-how, the regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), a more equitable distribution of quotas, the protection of the environment and the value of socio-economic diversity, the development of the sea economy with the involvement of actors, the development of gender policies that strengthen the economic and social empowerment of women , strengthening sustainable aquaculture, job creation and improving working conditions and enforcement. In general, in its approaches and proposals, the report is going in the direction of our positions, so we voted in favour. On this occasion, however, we cannot fail to recall the report adopted in the previous legislature on small-scale coastal fishing and artisanal fishing, for which we were responsible, containing recommendations to improve the situation of this specific segment of the fishing fleet, with a high prevalence in Portugal. For the most part, these recommendations remain valid, but unfortunately they have not come out of the paper. Moreover, the new CFP has degraded an already difficult and precarious picture of itself.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the report of my colleague Ruzic Tomašić. Taking into account the experience from Croatia, I can confirm that coastal fishing is an extremely important form of fishing in EU member states. In addition to ensuring high employment and being socially and environmentally sustainable, it is also a specific way of life in coastal countries, such as Croatia. That is why I am committed to changing legislation towards the protection of coastal fisheries and fostering diversity in fisheries, due to the current decline in profitability and employment, in order to counter the marginalisation of fisheries in developing regions and to benefit from new innovative opportunities. To achieve this objective, I support the use of funds earmarked for innovation and blue growth.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal on the innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fisheries in areas that depend on fishing, mainly because of the important role of coastal fisheries in the EU. I see its importance, in particular, in the fact that it means an important and, in most cases, a single form of livelihood for many people, and at the same time it is also one of the types of environmentally sustainable fisheries. I consider it necessary to support areas that depend on fishing in order to continue to develop and provide people with sufficient livelihoods. The gradual decline in employment and declining profitability in the sector must be reversed. The new initiatives have the potential to prevent a significant economic downturn, which is accompanied by depopulation and exodus of residents from certain coastal and island areas. However, in order for innovation and the resources provided to be sufficiently exploited, it is first necessary to improve data collection on the state of the seas and oceans. Only then will it be possible to evaluate which innovative projects or ways of diversification to implement in a given area.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The definitions and classifications of inshore fishing vary in the individual Member States. For most coastal and island areas, it is a traditional form of fishing which characterises a way of life and is a significant source of livelihood; therefore, in these areas there is a need for appropriate measures and specific support that offer opportunities for growth and development. The basic regulation of the new CFP of 2013 emphasises the economic development of coastal areas. The EFF (European Maritime Affairs Fund) also pay particular attention to the sector. In view of the fact that some coastal and island areas are facing significant economic decline, the European Commission was invited to invest and support investments in diversification through the development of complementary activities linked to traditional fisheries. The Commission is therefore invited to initiate a procedure for amending existing legislation, in particular the 2006 regulation on management measures for the sustainable development of fishery resources in the Mediterranean adopted, which must be in line with the new CFP. For all this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report because it aims to take better account of the specifics of small-scale small-scale fishing, particularly in fishing-dependent territories. Thus, it is essential that these areas, like the outermost regions, benefit from special provisions, particularly within the framework of the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF).

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Important though small-scale fishing is to many communities, the EU’s CFP approach has too many ulterior motives in its approach so must be opposed.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has a huge impact on the Azores. This document expresses the recommendations for adapting the definition of small-scale coastal fishing according to the characteristics of the regions, as there is no uniformity in this concept, and it is also recognised that there are island communities that traditionally depend on fishing for their subsistence, so that there should be greater regionalisation in order to have a fisheries policy closer to the sector. Aspects such as the progressive increase in quotas allocated to artisanal fishermen, the strengthening of the role of fishing communities in local development, the priority given to small-scale coastal fisheries in allocating funding and simplification of procedures were also reasons for my positive vote. On the other hand, and since we are seeing a decline in employment and profitability in this sector, a certain marginalisation of fisheries in developing regions and opportunities to benefit from the new possibilities, I also argue that it is necessary to continue with diversification in this sector, deepening the relationship between local communities and universities/technology centres, in order to create new business incubators that enhance the generation of business ideas in this sector.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Coastal fishing is particularly important in the EU as it ensures a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. For most coastal and island areas, traditional coastal fishing is a way of life and an important source of livelihood. Some coastal and island regions are face a significant economic decline that translates into depopulation and the exodus of their inhabitants, who are looking for opportunities in sectors that offer better prospects for employment and education. Moreover, some coastal fishing regions are situated close to economically developed and tourist regions, but are unable to achieve adequate economic growth. Areas that depend on coastal fishing need specific measures and support to grow and develop. The EMFF can support investments in diversification and contribute positively to fishermen's incomes by developing complementary activities such as investments in vessels, restaurants, environmental services in the fisheries sector, cultural and educational activities in the fisheries sector, fishing tourism, etc.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This report presents the need for a definition of artisanal coastal fisheries that is respectful of territorial singularities and in line with the new CFP. It proposes a series of measures that accentuate innovation and promote economic diversification in the artisanal fisheries sector. In this sense, the capacity for social vertebration that artisanal fishing has in certain communities is deepened and the economic and social crisis affecting it is taken into account especially due to its low capitalization. The development of the fisheries tourism segment, the generation of employment that promotes social inclusion, the recognition and visualization of women's work, the development of fishing activities outside the informal economy and the need to regulate as occupational diseases certain pathologies suffered by women who carry out their activity in this sector have been introduced.  All this considering the importance of ensuring the economic and social stability of coastal communities engaged in artisanal fisheries, as well as environmental objectives with the conservation of fishery resources and the development of responsible practices and the sustainability of coastal marine ecosystems. I voted for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because inshore fishing in the European Union is important in more ways than one: not only is inshore fishing a sector that provides jobs in coastal areas, but it is also a socially and ecologically sustainable form of fishing. As a result, areas that depend on coastal fishing require specific measures and aid to ensure growth and development. The 2013 Regulation on the Common Fisheries Policy focused on the economic development of these coastal regions. It also recognizes the importance of offshore island regions that depend on fishing and that need to be supported so that they can survive and develop.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Coastal fishing is an extremely important form of fishing, but classification and definition varies from one Member State to another. Coastal fishing is facing a number of problems this year, and a procedure for amending existing legislation had to be introduced in order to protect coastal fishing.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which concerns a European Parliament resolution on the innovation and diversification of artisanal coastal fishing in fishing-dependent regions. It is not new that this is a sector lacking in deep reforms, taking into account the socio-economic characteristics and specificities of the different regions. This is a matter that I have followed with some interest, because the territory of my country consists of 97% of the sea and because it has the largest EE SIE in Europe (if the United Nations approves the Portuguese claims in the context of the enlargement of the EZE - Exclusive Economic Zone). However, and returning to the report, it is largely clear that fishing communities are limited in their sphere of action, thanks to the strict rules inherent in the Common Fisheries Policy. To that extent, I am in favour of the adoption of instruments aimed at providing, inter alia, greater possibilities for small-scale coastal fishing in the island communities dependent on it, a progressive increase in the quotas allocated to artisanal fishermen, support for development projects in coastal, island and outermost regions, as well as the promotion of nautical tourism.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the innovation and diversification of small-scale inshore fisheries in fishing-dependent regions. Inshore fishing accounts for a significant share of fishing-related jobs, accounting for 80% of the European fleet. This text asks the Commission to adapt the definition of inshore fisheries on a case-by-case basis according to the specifics of the fisheries and the indicative criteria. The main aim is to take into account the specifics of inshore fishing and to ask the Commission to support innovative projects, as well as to coordinate a European study on the impacts of recreational fishing on traditional fishing activities. I supported this text, because it calls on Member States to give priority to inshore fisheries in providing funding from the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, and it also calls on the Commission to encourage investment for more diversification of fisheries.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because the report talks about the need for a more equitable allocation of quotas that takes into account the protection of the environment and the contribution of fisheries to the local economy. This is something that already provides for in Article 17 of the Common Fisheries Policy, but which Spain has been failing to comply with, as we have repeatedly denounced. The Commission's report also recognises that the recession has hit sea people hard, further increasing the marginalization of the sector; and that diversification and innovation are more necessary than ever for the survival of artisanal fishing. It is a step forward and in the right direction for Europe to recognise and support the development of local communities whose livelihoods depend mainly on fishing and related activities. We also welcome the walk towards the empowerment of women at sea throughout the value chain of the fisheries sector, as their vital work has often been unvisitable and remains subject to wage gaps.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the innovation and diversification of small-scale inshore fishing in areas dependent on fishing, as inshore fishing is particularly important because it ensures a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable type of fishing. Diversification of the fisheries sector is necessary in order, among other things, to counteract the decline in employment and profitability in the sector and to open up opportunities for the exploitation of new opportunities, such as environmentally friendly development.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Small-scale fishing involves about 80 % of the vessels in the European fleet. Italy has one of the largest small-scale fishing sectors in Europe, with around 7 500 fishing vessels and more than 13 000 workers on board.  This sector has always been an important economic and commercial resource for our country, but also an opportunity to reconcile an activity with a strong social and cultural value with a more sustainable management of fish and environmental resources. Our artisanal fishermen can be regarded as 'custodians of the coastal area', holders of traditions and knowledge that cannot be lost due to the serious crisis that is dangerously undermining the sector.  Within the EU, inshore fishing differs significantly both from one Member State to another and within the same State. It is therefore important to adopt a regionalised approach in order to correctly define small-scale coastal fishing activities and to adapt existing European rules according to the socio-economic characteristics and specificities of the various areas. I hope that the Commission will take on up Parliament's recommendations, in order to protect small-scale fishing and promote its development through innovation and diversification. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. It is important to emphasize that there is a defence of fisheries in the most remote areas in this report, i.e. in the outermost regions of Europe. In fact, in the Azores, there are particularities that need to be defended, ensuring the protection of smaller fleets and the implementation of real alternative blue economy projects. The result should be addressed on topics such as diversification of the use of the sea, dignification and increased training of fishing professionals and the enhancement of biological resources. I would also like to point out the possibility pointed out in the report of expanding the action of the European Fund for Sea and Fisheries Affairs to include schemes similar to the late POSEI. For all these reasons, I voted positively to approve this report and i call on the European Commission to materialise the proposals expressed here.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Important though small-scale fishing is to many communities, the EU’s CFP approach has too many ulterior motives in its approach so must be opposed.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this PECH report by rapporteur Ruža Tomašić because it looks at how innovation and diversification can help coastal regions dependent on fishing to survive. Although not something that especially affects my region, the West Midlands, I can sympathise with the people who live in these areas and whose lives depend on fishing. Furthermore, it is an objective of my group to protect and create jobs in these small-scale and artisanal fisheries, and as coastal fishing guarantees a high level of employment in coastal areas, we can make it into a socially and environmentally sustainable industry.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Small-scale coastal fishing in regions dependent of fishing is a very important form of fishing in the EU. The agreement takes into account both the economic and environmental sides, so therefore I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Small Coastal Fisheries Innovation and Diversification Report in fishing-dependent areas, as coastal fishing represents an extremely significant form of fisheries within the territory of the Member States and existing regulation needs to be changed on the principle of a non-indiscriminate approach. Diversification and innovation in the fisheries sector are the main pillars of further development. Tourism, as a growing industry, also represents potential when it comes to diversifying fisheries. The tourist offer can be used in the fisheries sector in such a way that they are presented as part of the traditional offer, which contributes to the capitalization of the fishing heritage and recognition of a particular fishing area. In relation to the possibility of diversifying fisheries in the field of the environment and the 'green' economy, it is necessary to highlight activities related to renewable energy sources and environmental protection. The report focuses on the need to propose new frameworks and amendments to the Regulation on fisheries resource protection measures in the Mediterranean, the so-called Mediterranean regulation, which was adopted in 2006. This Regulation regulates the technical characteristics of the tools and how they are used and needs to be aligned with the new CFP and coastal fishing needs.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Coastal fishing is an extremely important form of fishing, ensures a high level of employment and represents both a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. Some coastal and island areas are experiencing significant economic downturns, resulting in depopulation and population migration, which is looking for opportunities in places where there are more opportunities for employment and education. In addition, some coastal fishing areas are close to economically developed areas and are nevertheless unable to achieve economic growth. It is in these areas that the pressure on the exploitation of marine resources is increasing and, in the context of tourism, the fisheries sector is being marginally affected. Coastal fishing also encounters many problems in relation to the prescribed choice of gear and fishing techniques. In order to protect coastal fishing, the procedure for changing existing legislation needs to be started. We have a new common fisheries policy, so new frameworks need to be proposed and the procedure for changing the regulation on management measures for the sustainable and exploitation of fisheries resources in the Mediterranean must be launched. This Regulation needs to be brought into line with the new CFP and the needs of coastal fishing.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. For coastal and island regions, small-scale fishing is not only of particular importance for local development and employment, but also represents a socially and environmentally sustainable economic activity that must be protected and promoted. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the European Commission to support with specific measures new opportunities for growth and development for coastal regions, through innovation and diversification of activities complementary to fishing, through investments for less polluting fishing vessels, environmental services linked to fishing, cultural and educational activities related to fishing and tourism linked to sport fishing. I also fully support the call to amend the regulatory framework on the sustainable management of fishery resources in the Mediterranean in order to allow the preservation and enhancement of traditional coastal fishing techniques, such as tuna, so as to establish a clear differentiation between commercial and traditional fisheries in line with the different impact on marine resources caused by the two types of fishing.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Coastal fishing covers 80 % of the European fleet and ensures a high level of employment in coastal, island and outermost regions and represents a significant socially and environmentally sustainable form of fisheries. For most coastal and island areas, coastal fishing is a way of life and an important source of livelihood and requires specific measures and support that will enable them to grow and develop.  Coastal fishing is differently defined and classified in individual Member States and a clear definition of coastal and small-scale coastal or traditional fishing is needed, based on the socio-economic characteristics and specific characteristics of a given area.  Extremely important for the development of the blue economy is the Initiative "Innovation Union" which represents the largest research and innovation programme partly financed by the european union's investment and structural funds. It is therefore essential to support projects enabling the development of coastal, island and outermost regions and to promote and support investment in fisheries innovation and diversification. For these reasons, I support the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Coastal fishing accounts for 80% of the European fleet and, together with shellfish collection, ensures a very high employment rate in coastal, island and outermost regions, thus contributing to a socially and environmentally sustainable form of high-potential fisheries. Furthermore, this type of fishing has a very positive impact on the cultural heritage of coastal and island areas, as well as on social characteristics. What is important is that small-scale coastal fishing and traditional fishing are clearly defined and that fishing activities are diversified, which can bring more profit to small fishermen. In Croatia, small fisheries are of utmost importance because it is part of our identity and is crucial for the livelihood of the islanders. Unfortunately, small fishermen in Croatia have been greatly harmed by the abolition of centuries-old practice and the use of traditional tools. I support this report because I think it is essential to protect and encourage the development of coastal and remote regions that need to be provided with some profit given their peripheral character. It is also important to harness the potential of grades and coastal and coastal areas that can be of great benefit to sustainable development, employment, energy autonomy and innovation. The creation of new innovative businesses in fishing-dependent regions should also be encouraged, as their performance can contribute to the entire maritime sector and retain or attract populations.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal and agree that when making legislative proposals on regulating the use of fishing gear and fishing, the Commission should first of all look at the real impact of these measures.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report Innovation and Diversification of Small Coastal Fishing in regions dependent on fishing. The current arrangements at European Union level are not satisfactory, so we need improvements to the system. Coastal and traditional fishing should be based more on the socio-economic characteristics and specificities of the different regions than on the size and strength of fishing vessels. I also support the call for the European Commission to examine the possibilities for small-scale coastal fishing in island communities, which have traditionally depended on fishing for their own livelihoods and carry out fishing activities throughout the year.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report promotes a more realistic and sustainable form of fishing based on tradition and local society away from the industrialisation of this profession. Combining fisheries with tradition, tourism and various other related activities can offer multiple benefits to these societies.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Areas and communities that depend on coastal fisheries require specific measures in order to grow and develop. I am therefore pleased to support this report, which highlights the importance of such small scale coastal fishing and calls on the European Commission to do more to protect it, including by looking at measures in the area of diversification and innovation.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Coastal fishing is an exceptionally important form of fishing in most Member States because, in addition to creating jobs, it is sustainable from a social and environmental point of view. I therefore voted in favour of this report. It should be noted that the definition of coastal fishing varies between Member States (e.g. coastal, traditional or artisanal), yet it covers a well-defined range of activities.  I agree that the areas concerned need specific measures and support for growth and development. Already the 2013 Regulation on the Common Fisheries Policy has emphasised the economic development of coastal areas. The Regulation provides preferential access for small-scale and traditional fisheries in a zone of 12 nautical miles, i.e. the most sensitive part of EU waters. In addition to a number of programmes to help develop the so-called 'blue farms', I believe that innovation and diversification should be given further space to prevent the marginalisation of the fisheries sector and to ensure green development. Of course, the known shortcomings need to be addressed: insufficient investment in science, lack of data on the seas and oceans and their incompatibility, insufficient funding, lack of cooperation between the private and public sectors.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Fishing activities generate significant revenues to the budgets of EU Member States. This concerns in particular fishing in coastal and island areas, which is a traditional, clean economic form and guarantees a high level of long-term labour use. Unfortunately, the survival of these ways of earning a living is jeopardised by economic decline and depopulation of those areas, which are largely dependent on fishing activity. In order to avoid this negative trend, coastal economies can be diversified and strengthened through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, enabling better commercial exploitation of the products of these regions and promoting scientific research into biodiversity in these areas, which can serve as a model for other regions. At the same time, these areas can be better promoted for their tourism and gastronomic potential, creating the prerequisites for new sources of development in the future. From this point of view, this document constitutes a commendable initiative, which deserves to be supported by the European Parliament.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have spoken in favour of this proposal, which calls on the Commission to adapt the definition of inshore and small inshore or traditional fisheries according to the socio-economic characteristics and characteristics of the different territories, and not only according to the size and power of fishing vessels, because the current EU provisions are unsatisfactory. We would also like to use regionalization to adapt the definition of inshore fisheries on a case-by-case basis depending on the specifics of the fisheries.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that support for the small-scale coastal fishing sector is important for the livelihood of many communities, the promotion of maritime tourism of our islands and tradition. Current regulation which is based on a common policy has hindered the development of fishing communities because it has not taken into account the diversity in the coastal regions. This new framework will permit the development of traditional and small-scale fishing communities in line with local and regional specificities. It will need to take into account size of the vessels, gears, techniques, but also socio-economic characteristics and its impact on local communities.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in regions dependent on fishing, because coastal fishing is an extremely important form of fishing in EU countries. It is particularly important because it ensures a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. Each Member State differently terms and defines coastal fishing (coastal, traditional or artisanal fishing, etc.). For most coastal areas and islands, coastal fishing is a traditional form of life-conditional fishing and is an important source of survival. Areas dependent on coastal fishing need specific measures and support in order to grow and develop.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The main purpose of the report is to find additional income for artisanal fishermen, and to solve the problem of quotas charged by industrial fishing. This text proposes to help fishermen in several different ways by promoting their diversification. In addition, my colleague Sylvie Goddyn's amendment on increasing quotas for traditional fisheries was adopted. I voted for this report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Coastal fishing is an exceptionally important form of fishing in EU countries. It is particularly important because it provides jobs for many people and is socially and environmentally sustainable. Coastal fishing is classified and defined differently in each Member State. For most coastal and island areas, coastal fishing is a traditional fishery that determines lifestyle and is a significant source of livelihood. Areas dependent on coastal fishing need specific measures and support for growth and development. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because the report talks about the need for a more equitable allocation of quotas that takes into account the protection of the environment and the contribution of fisheries to the local economy. This is something that already provides for in Article 17 of the Common Fisheries Policy, but which Spain has been failing to comply with, as we have repeatedly denounced. The Commission's report also recognises that the recession has hit sea people hard, further increasing the marginalization of the sector; and that diversification and innovation are more necessary than ever for the survival of artisanal fishing. It is a step forward and in the right direction for Europe to recognise and support the development of local communities whose livelihoods depend mainly on fishing and related activities. We also welcome the walk towards the empowerment of women at sea throughout the value chain of the fisheries sector, as their vital work has often been unvisitable and remains subject to wage gaps.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report consists of a series of measures proposed to improve the treatment of the small-scale fleet and encourage its development. Therefore I voted in favour.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in fisheries-dependent regions. Coastal fishing is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing of high importance to the EU countries, generating a high level of employment. For that reason the report calls for consideration of the possibility of small-scale coastal fishing in island communities which traditionally depend on fishing for their own livelihood. It equally calls for a gradual increase in the quotas allocated to non-industrial fisheries, in order to boost this socially and ecologically sustainable form of fishing.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. •u2012 Artisanal coastal fishing is important for European countries as it is an engine of employment and a form of socially and environmentally sustainable fishing. In this sense, the innovation union initiative is extremely important for the development of the blue economy. This report points out the benefits of artisanal coastal fisheries in fisheries-dependent regions and the importance of continuing to bet on innovation to continue contributing to the growth and economic development of these areas. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because I believe that small-scale aid for coastal fishing is important for the liveability of certain communities and will improve maritime tourism on the European islands.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The consideration of sustainable development in the common fisheries policy has been a goal pursued by my group, the GUE/NGL, for several years.  Developing a socially and ecologically sustainable fishery while contributing to the development of alternative forms of fishing is the only way to enable sustainable growth of fishing-dependent regions.  The new Common Fisheries Policy aims to support coastal regions in their survival and development.  However, since the necessary balance between economic, social and environmental interests tends to disappear, better taking into account small-scale fishing in these regions would therefore help to meet these different objectives.  This report proposes new frameworks for the sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources and aims to take into account the protection of the environment and the socio-economic diversity of coastal regions. It advocates preferential access to small-scale fishing and traditional fishermen in coastal, island and outermost areas through a fairer distribution of quotas for small-scale fishing.  Supporting local development and sustainable fishing is key to hindering fleet demolition. I have therefore voted in favour of this report, hoping that it will be taken into account by the Commission.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report refers to and advocates the promotion of specific regulations and legislation, financing and technology transfer instruments and know-how, the regionalisation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), a more equitable distribution of quotas, the protection of the environment and the value of socio-economic diversity, the development of the sea economy with the involvement of actors, the development of gender policies to strengthen the economic and social emancipation of women , strengthening sustainable aquaculture, job creation and improving working conditions and enforcement. On this occasion, however, we cannot fail to recall the report adopted in the previous legislature on small-scale coastal fishing and artisanal fishing, for which we were responsible, containing recommendations to improve the situation of this specific segment of the fishing fleet, with a high prevalence in Portugal. For the most part, these recommendations remain valid, but unfortunately they have not come out of the paper. However, and because, in general, in its approaches and proposals, the report is going in the direction of our positions, we voted in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Inshore fishing is of great importance in many countries in the EU, as it ensures a high level of employment and is not only a socially but also environmentally sustainable way of fishing. Since these areas also need a special form of support in order to grow and develop, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Writing. A welcome resolution, especially as the regulatory pressure on small-scale fishing is being reduced. I therefore agree with the motion.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. - Inshore fishing is an extremely important form of fishing in EU countries. It is particularly important that it ensures a high level of employment and is a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. I voted against this report because I am convinced that environmental and labour market issues should remain within the competence of the Member States.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in areas dependent on fisheries. The text rightly calls on the Commission to examine the possibility of small-scale coastal fishing in island communities that traditionally depend on fishing for a living and engage in fishing activities throughout the year.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Mrs Tomašić's report. The report contains measures particularly important for Member States where small-scale fishing is an important source of livelihood, but also a traditional form of life. In order to preserve traditional fishing methods, the report therefore proposes that this be defined and that certain rules be relaxed for it, such as derogations from the prohibition of certain fishing methods, quotas or rules on the obligation to land all catches. It also stresses the need to take into account the specificities of individual regions, as well as the need for innovation in the so-called blue sectors. In these cases, I believe that coastal fishing and its role in the regions dependent on it must be taken into account, as the European Union should protect traditional methods and ways of life that would otherwise disappear, and should take into account the fact that blanket prohibitions and rules could act liquidated on traditional fishing. At the same time, without small-scale fishing, many people in small coastal areas could lose their livelihoods, and since it is these areas that are characterised by already high unemployment, such bans would make the situation even worse.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A very important vote is that of the Tomasic report, which deals with a subject, that of inshore fishing, which accounts for 80% of European fisheries and which for some European regions is the sector with the most employment as a percentage.
