There are very different seas on our continent, as the report points out, and the Commission must take into account the differences not only in fishing conditions, but also in the size and presence of fish, in determining the European fishing rules, which cannot be the same for all seas, from Sicily to Norway. It is also important to attach greater importance to the role of the fishing communities, which must be able to give their opinion on the decisions that affect them closely. So this report is a good one, so let us continue to work to give fishermen and communities living in small-scale fishing the right recognition and help in our political choices.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. Coastal fishing is an extremely important type of fishing in the Countries of the Union, as it ensures a high level of employment in coastal, insular and outermost regions and is generally a socially and environmentally sustainable form of fishing. In order to maintain and develop the potential of coastal fishing, I supported the report's recommendations on innovation and diversification of small-scale coastal fishing in regions dependent on fishing.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are fishing communities and there are some who die from fishing.  There are fishermen who, precisely as evidence of the weakness and fragility of the external dimension of fisheries policy, are the target of shootings or out verise ambushes, are being unjustly imprisoned and are being seized. I am thinking in particular of fishermen on the southern shore of the Mediterranean who meet or clash at sea with the authorities of the border countries who violate their right to fish safely.  When we talk about the external dimension of fisheries, international cooperation and agreements, when the European Union claims to represent the European fisheries sector in negotiations with third countries, it is these fishermen who must think, it is their interests that it must protect, respect for their rights that it absolutely must demand, life and safety first and economic activity immediately afterwards.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The European Union is the world's largest market for catch products, because we consume only 11% of global catches and, at the same time, import 24% of all catches in terms of value. The latter can also be attributed to the fact that the European Union and its companies are important processors of marine resources. The fisheries agreement with Greenland has already been voted on today, but it is only one of a number of agreements of this type that are both bilateral and multilateral. We must therefore continue our efforts to maximise the international systematism of fisheries, particularly in terms of sustainability and, I would say, also in terms of protecting ecosystems. It must be said that active cooperation with partners in other countries, in particular regional fisheries management organisations, and more scientific work sooner or later will bring about results. So this is welcome.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this because even when the objectives are laudable, the reality of the EU policy is a behavioural-economic ‘one-size-fits-all’ disaster.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The common fisheries policy (CFP) aims to make the fisheries and aquaculture sectors increasingly sustainable from an ecological, economic and social point of view. The aim is therefore to promote a dynamic fishing industry while ensuring an adequate standard of living for fishing communities. For these reasons, the EU is committed to ensuring that sustainable fisheries agreements with third countries comply with environmental standards and the eco-systemic approach that characterises the CFP. For these reasons, it has been requested that the European Parliament should play a more active role in the approval procedures, with the recognition of a full and immediate right of information, which undoubtedly ensures transparency and controllability of the protocols. On the basis of these considerations, I voted in favour, trusting in the commitment of the European institutions to the protection and promotion of eco-sustainable fishing, including in agreements with third countries.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. For the first time, the basic regulation of the CFP includes a chapter on the external dimension of the CFP, which includes the minimum conditions for bilateral agreements, responsibility for cooperation between regional fisheries organizations and coherence between the measures they take. In addition to this, the report stresses the need for fisheries agreements to benefit both the EU and third countries, as well as the importance of supporting the development of local communities. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it contained a number of positive provisions. There were provisions contained within which refer to the external dimensions of the CFP, and provisions which accentuated the need to address illegal, unregulated and unreported fishing.  This includes minimum conditions for bilateral agreements, and a duty to foster cooperation among regional fisheries management organisations (RFMOs), not to mention ensuring that the sustainable fisheries agreements with third countries benefit third countries, including their local populations and fisheries sectors, and promoting environmentally, socially and economically sustainable fisheries based on transparency and the participation of non-governmental stakeholders. These are all positive moves and should therefore be supported.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements, because in the EU the external dimension is considered to include fishing outside the EU's exclusive economic zones (EEZs) by EU-flagged vessels covered by two types of regulation.  The first is fishing on the high seas, beyond the areas of national jurisdiction. There is a significant amount of such fishing and a large part usually regulated by Regional Fisheries Management Organisations or REED.  Fishing beyond EU waters also occurs in waters under the jurisdiction of third countries. This can happen within the framework of the bilateral agreement with that third country. The EU has made around 15 to 20 such agreements in force at a time.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The main objective of this report is to know the impact of the external dimension of the European Union, in order to determine whether the fishing practiced is environmentally, socially and economically sustainable. In particular, the rapporteur wants a framework to be created for European companies' agreements with third countries or their joint ventures, in order to improve transparency and avoid competition with local fisheries. It should be noted that paragraph 67 advises the Commission to propose an interruption of trade relations with countries that are identified as illegal fishing. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is the EU wanting more control of fishing in Member State waters. I voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because the Union's new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) includes significant progress and will improve standards for distant European fisheries. Nevertheless, the challenges of distant fisheries are global, the European Union must demonstrate the necessary political will, sufficient leadership and objectivity to help developing countries meet the new requirements.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to introduce new rules to apply the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements. In the 1990s, there were relatively few countries that were engaged in long-distance fishing, operating far from their coastal waters (EU, Soviet Union, Japan, USA fishing for tuna, as well as several other countries that operated to a lesser extent). Now, three decades later, the situation has fundamentally changed in all ocean areas and, for most species, there is strong competition. I agree that the best strategy to achieve the EU's objective of promoting sustainable fisheries is to use the EU's influence on the international stage to improve standards of fisheries management and transparency, to encourage race for higher standards rather than lower standards. It is necessary to achieve greater transparency in fishing activities, to adopt a regional approach to fisheries management, to make serious political efforts in flag States and coastal States to combat IUU fishing and to improve the supply of fish in order to provide food by supporting the work of women in the fisheries sector.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this because even when the objectives are laudable, the reality of the EU policy is a behavioural-economic ‘one-size-fits-all’ disaster.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I approved this report on the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) because it aims to give it to environmental, social and economic objectives: an interruption of trade relations with countries engaged in illegal fishing is proposed, and a framework created for European companies' agreements with third countries or their companies to improve transparency and avoid competition with local fisheries. This report is all the more important because the CFP is essential, with 20-25% of European catches being made in third-country EEZs.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I realistically consider that a global problem requires a global solution. The climate crisis is the best example of this and we need to make progress to live in a greener world. Sustainable management of fisheries resources is another: it can only be achieved through international cooperation, through multilateral and bilateral agreements that will work together for good governance of the seas and oceans. I voted in favour of this report, because it will ensure a coherence between fisheries policy, environmental policy, trade policy and development cooperation, not to mention strengthening the social and environmental standards of the European Union in its internal and external fisheries policy.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the world's leading fish markets, is the largest importer of these products and owns the third largest fishing fleet on the planet. A key role in the European economy is played by the fish processing industry, which provides a large number of jobs that need to be safeguarded. The report on the external dimension of the common fisheries policy, which I supported today, effectively sets out the strategic priorities that must be pursued. In a global context in which new players such as China, Taiwan and Korea are on the rise, acting with fleets operating with less stringent standards than those laid down in EU rules, the Union's potential for influence must increasingly be exploited. The crucial issue must be transparency. The commitment to information on the fishing activities of other actors operating in third countries with which agreements are signed must be accompanied by the creation of an EU-wide database covering all private agreements between EU shipowners and third countries, as well as joint ventures between EU and third-country companies. The eu's new CFP, if properly implemented, will significantly improve the EU's ocean fishing standards.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of regulating the CFP in its external dimension to incorporate into the centralized management of the CFP the different regional realities, participation and sustainability of the sectors, including minimum conditions for bilateral agreements.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which seeks in particular to determine the impact of the external dimension of the common fisheries policy in order to know its consequences from an environmental, social and economic point of view. Indeed, there is a need for a framework for this external dimension, which requires the creation of agreements between European fishing companies with third countries, to ensure transparency and the absence of unfair competition with local fisheries. I welcome the fact that an interruption in trade relations with countries supporting or turning a blind eye to illegal fishing practices has been proposed. Finally, it is positive that the majority of access rights to fishing areas outside the EEZs are no longer fully paid by European taxpayers and that this is now borne by 65% of shipowners.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report analyses the external dimension of the common fisheries policy after its last reform. Following the amendments made to this report throughout the parliamentary process, the document is acceptable, although we consider that it continues to have some elements outside its subject matter – such as charters or joint ventures, which belong fully to third countries – or which are not adequately collected – the lack of available information. In any event, the current external dimension is well explained in the 2008 Regulation on fishing authorisations in non-Community waters and any possible lagoon can be re-filled (in particular as regards the granting of permits in waters of a third country with which there is no agreement Spain imposes on its fleet a system of verification of the authenticity of licences and payments to the third country through its Embassies that could extend to the rest of the EU). I voted for it.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the common agricultural policy (CFP), including fisheries agreements. In the 1990s, when the CFP was still in its first step, there were relatively few countries that were engaged in long-distance fishing far from their coastal waters (THE EU, the Soviet Union, Japan, the US fished tuna, as well as several other countries that were operating to a lesser extent). Now, three decades later, the situation has fundamentally changed in all ocean areas and, for most species, there is strong competition. Among the increasingly important players are China, Korea and Taiwan, all of them taking aggressive policies to take advantage of rapidly declining resources. To varying degrees, these fleets generally operate with less stringent environmental, safety and social standards and benefit from large subsidies and often lower levels of taxation. Many of these long-distance fishing countries do not fulfil their obligations as flag, port and market state, or even respect fundamental human rights, all of which give them a competitive economic advantage over EU vessels. It is clear that the best strategy to achieve the EU's objective of promoting sustainable fisheries is to use the EU's influence on the international stage to improve standards of fisheries management and transparency, to encourage race for higher standards rather than lower standards. The EU is currently the world's largest market for fishery products, has one of the largest fleets flying its flags, and is mostly in the top three of the world's largest fishing entities.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. My fellow Members and I supported the report on the external dimensions of the common fisheries policy, which brings significant advantages and, if properly, improve the fishing standards for fleets of EU-registered ships sailing on the high seas. For the framework of the Regulation on IUU/ We must respect our obligations to promote the environmental and social sustainable development of fisheries through all our policies affecting fisheries in developing countries.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to determine whether fishing is environmentally, socially and economically sustainable, the impact of the eu's external dimension must be known. The report talks about creating a framework for European companies' agreements with third countries or their companies with the aim of improving transparency and avoiding competition with local fisheries. It can also be seen that paragraph 67 advises the Commission to propose an interruption of trade relations with countries that are identified as illegal fishing. So I voted for it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is necessary for the European Union to use its international soft power and influence to reach an agreement that regulations the practice of ocean fishing and allows for sustainable development economically and biologically of the sector.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is currently the largest market for fishery products and has one of the largest fleets in the world. In the EU, the external dimension concerns fishing by EU-flagged vessels on the high seas and in waters under the jurisdiction of third countries, as in the case of a partnership agreement. Many fleets from countries such as China, Korea and Taiwan operate under less stringent environmental, security and social regulations. The best strategy for achieving the objective of promoting sustainable fishing is to use EU influence on the international stage to improve fisheries management and transparency standards, by promoting harmonisation of eu and non-EU fleet rules on access to non-EEZ areas, the fight against IUU fishing, improving the supply of fish for food security by supporting the work done mainly by women in the fisheries sector.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The external dimension of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) extends outside the EU's Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZs). This includes deep-sea fishing, outside any national jurisdiction, and fishing in third country waters, through a bilateral fishing agreement with the State concerned. The aim of this report is to know the impact of the external dimension of the Union in order to determine whether the fishing practised is sustainable from an environmental, social and economic point of view. The rapporteur also wants to improve transparency and avoid competition with local fisheries. Finally, it advises the Commission to suspend trade relations with countries where illegal fishing is tolerated. I therefore voted for this report concerned about the environment and local fisheries.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 the CFP was born in the 1980s and consisted of members of the EU, the Soviet Union, Japan and the US. They practice pelagic fishing or fishing in waters far from their own coastal waters. Three decades later, the situation changed radically, with strong competition emerging in all oceanic areas. Unfortunately, many of the countries engaged in pelagic fishing do not fulfil their responsibilities as flag, port and commercial states, which gives them a competitive economic advantage over the EU. The EU is the world's largest market for fishery products, has one of the largest fleets under its flags and is among the top three catching powers, and the best strategy for achieving the objective of promoting sustainable fishing is to use EU influence on the international stage to improve standards of transparency and fisheries management , to encourage competition at the higher level to the detriment of competition at the lower level. I voted in favour of the report on the common rules for the implementation of the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements, as the new CFP includes significant progress and will improve the standards for pelagic fishing in the EU.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. The external dimension of the CFP concerns ocean fishing; it is hoped that local crews will be employed for the landing and processing of fish on the spot. The profit of EU fleets is mainly determined by individual EU agreements with third countries, although a uniform framework – especially on illegal fishing – would be desirable. Abstention vote.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the external dimension of the common fisheries policy, namely the fisheries agreements between the European Union and third countries. It stresses the requirements to be met by the European Union when it concludes fisheries agreements with third countries. He welcomes the high standards set by the Common Fisheries Policy in this area. I particularly support the recommendations to improve the transparency of fishing activities and the fight against illegal fishing. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report to ensure that a chapter on the external dimension, containing minimum conditions for bilateral agreements and an explicit reference to common rules both inside and outside EU waters, is finally included in the basic regulation on the common fisheries policy (CFP). I stress that the EU should not negotiate partnership agreements for sustainable fisheries with third countries where corruption is an accepted practice. I call on the EU to promote, through these agreements, good governance and specifically the good management of public revenue from the fisheries sector and financial compensation. I note that EU shipowners are signing private agreements with third-country governments outside the scope of the CFP and I am concerned that the Commission is not informed of these agreements. All too often this results in unfair competition, particularly against EU shipowners operating under bilateral agreements. The Commission must therefore improve transparency as soon as possible by setting up and publishing a database registering all private agreements providing for access to fishing grounds in third countries.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it contained a number of positive provisions. There were provisions contained within which refer to the external dimensions of the CFP, and provisions which accentuated the need to address illegal, unregulated and unreported fishing.  This includes minimum conditions for bilateral agreements, and a duty to foster cooperation among regional fisheries management organisations (RFMOs), not to mention ensuring that the sustainable fisheries agreements with third countries benefit third countries, including their local populations and fisheries sectors, and promoting environmentally, socially and economically sustainable fisheries based on transparency and the participation of non-governmental stakeholders. These are all positive moves and should therefore be supported.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I support the idea that the common fisheries policy should have an external dimension, especially given that the EU is the largest importer of fish products. It is therefore important that we increase cooperation with our partners in areas such as promotion of sustainable fisheries, transparency and competition. I particularly welcome the social dimension of this report, namely that it seeks to improve the protection of workers in this industry and promote better, safer working conditions and in general to create more sustainable employment, for example through the hiring of local crews in the context of sustainable fisheries partnership agreements.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The external dimension of the new CFP includes international agreements and fishing activities in areas not subject to national jurisdiction. The report, stressing the need to obtain mutual benefits from the agreements in this area, recalls the importance - also to this end - of promoting the protection of ecosystems. The environmental aspect is, however, also an end in itself, as has been said, and the text therefore also reiterates the need to find more complete scientific information and data on the capture of animals. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that the new EU CAP includes important parameters and, if properly implemented, will improve EU standards for fishing in remote waters. In view of the Treaty's requirement for a coherent development policy, this can only be welcomed.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the adoption of common provisions aimed at implementing the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements, promotes issues of improvement of fisheries policies with a view to adopting a better regulatory framework, protecting the ecosystem, but also better cooperation between the EU and third countries. As it is a positive effort I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was obvious to me to vote in favour of this report as it aims to protect fisheries as a natural, food and commercial resource, a fundamental point for the European Union, which still represents today the largest market in the world for fishery products. I agree with this report because it aims to safeguard this common resource from the threat of overfishing or even illegal fishing in such a way that the productivity of the fish population is not affected in the long term. In addition, the objective is a sustainable, ecological, economic and social form of fishing based on transparency and the participation of each individual Member State. All these are objectives for which I could only speak in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In recent years the amount of nations engaging in distant water fishing has increased dramatically. China, Korea and Taiwan have adhered to aggressive policies to ensure access to dwindling resources. These fleets take less care for the environment, and they do not fulfil their responsibilities to human rights. This provides them with a competitive economic advantage, which vessels from the EU lack. The Long Distance Advisory Council recommended that transparency must be improved in fishing activities. Promotion of harmonisation of condition of access for fleets outside the EU should be worked on. Politics needs to be engaged with in order to aid flag and coastal states in the fight against IUU fishing. Food security could be ensured by ameliorating the supply of fish available.

name: Jane Collins and Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We oppose this because even when the objectives are laudable, the reality of the EU policy is a behavioural-economic ‘one-size-fits-all’ disaster.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Better linkage between the sectorial support provided under fishing agreements and the instruments available falls within the scope of cooperation on development. I support full transparency in the funding of fisheries projects and the use of sectorial support, so as to ensure the proper use of EU funds.   Despite the role played by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM), differences in the rules applied to EU and third country fleets operating in the same fisheries have been causing considerable problems for EU fishermen.   I support the call to increase EU efforts in the Mediterranean Basin by means of closer cooperation with local bodies, regional organisations, scientific institutions, observatories and country-based fisheries clusters.  There is a role for the EU in the resolution of conflicts between vessels in the Mediterranean, and in supporting and assisting fishermen who are frequently subject to confrontations with third-country vessels or even vessels from different Member States.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presents the situation of international agreements and fishing activities in areas not subject to national jurisdiction (ABNJ), with reference to common rules outside Union waters. The EU has an obligation to ensure that sustainable fisheries agreements are based on the best possible scientific advice, insisting on the importance of sustainable fishing, in order to safeguard the future of coastal communities, the employment generated by the fisheries sector and food security. The CFP agreements must be based on a fair relationship between the EU and its partners in third countries, producing mutual benefits. EU action needs to be aimed at protecting ecosystems and sharing information and data. I believe that the European Parliament should play a more active role in the approval procedure, and must be informed at all stages of the conclusion or renewal of partnership agreements for sustainable fisheries, in order to increase transparency. Overall, I agree with the report before us, and I voted in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. For the first time, the basic regulation of the CFP includes a chapter on the external dimension of the CFP, which includes the minimum conditions for bilateral agreements, responsibility for cooperation between regional fisheries organizations and coherence between the measures they take. In addition to this, the report stresses the need for fisheries agreements to benefit both the EU and third countries, as well as the importance of supporting the development of local communities. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is the world's largest market for fishery products, with one of the largest fleets under its flags. I voted for greater transparency in the fishing activities of all major actors and for supporting the EU's objective of promoting sustainable fishing.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report focuses on the external dimension of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which provides a framework for the activities of EU vessels fishing outside EU waters. The EU fishing fleet is one of the largest in the world and is in the top three world fishing powers, so the extent of its influence is important. EU-flagged vessels can fish in waters outside the EU in two ways: fishing on the high seas (areas outside national jurisdiction) and fishing in the territorial waters of third countries under a bilateral fisheries agreement.  The report takes into account a number of issues related to fishing in the territorial waters of third countries m.in. the obligation to strengthen cooperation between the various RFMMs and ensure coherence between their measures, the training of fisheries inspectors and crew members, the transparency of fisheries partnership agreements, the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and the promotion of social and environmental standards in the fisheries sector in the fisheries sector concerned. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important for Europe and its involvement in environmental protection actions to support cooperation between local and regional authorities and entrepreneurs' associations, fisheries and oceanography research institutes, universities, technology centres and local and regional institutions to participate in the innovation process, as development and innovation can play a fundamental role in creating jobs in island and coastal communities. In these communities, artisanal fishing contributes to the viability of communities, to combating the growing phenomenon of depopulation, ageing in the fisheries sector and unemployment. At the same time, we must not forget that artisanal fishing uses old tools and techniques in certain areas which are greener and have less impact on the situation of endangered stocks.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the new Common Fisheries Policy, which aims to improve standards for distant European fisheries. Considering that this common fisheries policy is an indispensable tool for the proper functioning of the fishery, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the external dimension of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), including fisheries agreements. The European Union imposes strict rules on the marketing of fishing products, particularly in terms of management and transparency. Through partnership agreements with various international actors, the European Union plays a key role in the international fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (INN) fishing.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Thousands of people around the world depend on the seas and oceans, which are the primary source of food, from their livelihoods.  The European Union has a leading role to play in the global governance of the seas and oceans to promote sustainable fishing. This objective must be at the centre of the external dimension of the common fisheries policy as well as the union's development policy. The EU's high environmental and social standards must be promoted internationally to move towards more transparent fisheries management, ensuring product traceability, protecting artisanal fishing and preserving fisheries resources.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Today, 20-25% of European catches take place outside the exclusive economic zones of the European Union and constitute the external dimension of the common fisheries policy. This dimension includes deep-sea fishing outside of any national jurisdiction and fishing in third country waters, through a bilateral fishing agreement with the State concerned or a private agreement. The text looks at whether or not fishing is environmentally, socially and economically sustainable. The rapporteur suggests the creation of a framework for European business agreements with third countries or their companies. The aim is to improve transparency and avoid competition with local fisheries. Finally, the text calls on the Commission to suspend trade relations with countries that engage in illegal fishing. For these reasons, I voted for it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on common rules regarding the implementation of the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements, because it builds on the framework defining the fishing rules for European vessels outside EU territorial waters, defining how EU countries interact with third countries and providing for mutual benefit for the EU and third countries, including their population and fisheries sector.  The report provides for the promotion of sustainable fisheries as well as the improvement of fisheries management standards on the international stage and increased transparency on the overall scale of fishing and the identity of the different fisheries actors. Furthermore, I believe that it is of particular importance to introduce stricter measures against the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing provided for in this report.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with the guidelines of the Group of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the Engström report. 30 % of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. Thus, the amount of marine fish fish fished is steadily and significantly reduced. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for marine fishing and aquaculture.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: the main objective is to know the impact of the external dimension of the European Union, in order to determine whether fishing is environmentally, socially and economically sustainable.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) includes a chapter on its external dimension, in particular the establishment of minimum conditions for the establishment of fisheries agreements between the EU and third countries, alongside commitments to increase cooperation and consistency of measures implemented within the Regional Fisheries Management Organisations; an explicit reference to common standards within and outside EU waters; and the valorization of scientific information in decision-making. Despite not all the considerations made, the report emphasises some important issues, which we value: the need to ensure that fisheries agreements provide mutual benefits for the EU and for third countries, including their local populations and the fisheries sector; promoting environmentally, socially and economically sustainable fisheries on the basis of transparency and participation of non-governmental actors, especially fisheries-dependent professionals for their livelihood, in order to ensure a future for coastal communities, the marine environment, the development of local industry, the employment generated by fisheries, processing and trade, and the contribution of fisheries to food security; measures to promote the transfer of technologies and know-how; fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report. The EU must commit itself to strengthening cooperation with local and regional bodies, and especially with the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, thus avoiding unpleasant conflicts in which EU crews are often involved, putting an end to the so-called 'fish war'. Furthermore, I believe that the call to the EU for a stronger commitment to promoting social and environmental standards in the fisheries sector of third countries, and to combating illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing, should be welcomed.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Positive initiative involving a new look at the common fisheries policy from the point of view of its impact on the environment and especially, on its impact on the partner nations in bilateral agreements. I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the world's largest market for fishery products and has one of the largest fleets in the world and usually ranks among the top three fishing powers. Fishing outside European Union waters also takes place in waters under the jurisdiction of third countries. This situation may arise within the framework of a bilateral agreement with that third country. Traditionally, the European Union has about 15 to 20 such agreements in force at any moment. Many fleets from countries such as China, Korea and Taiwan operate under generally less stringent restrictions on the environment, security and social standards, benefiting from high subsidies and often lower levels of taxation. The best strategy to achieve the European Union's objective of promoting sustainable fisheries is to use the European Union's influence on the international stage to improve fisheries management and transparency of standards. This means, in particular, improving fishing transparency, a regional approach to fisheries management, including promoting the harmonisation of the conditions for access to third countries for foreign fleets and, last but not least, the establishment of a sustainability framework for joint ventures.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because the report should deal with the subject better and more fully.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report. The CAP, together with the quotas it imposes, has not had any effect on the chronic reduction of fish stocks in our seas. With the CFP, the EU retains almost complete control over fisheries management, with Member States having no meaningful role in the decision-making process.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is currently the world’s largest market for fisheries products and has one of the largest fleets and usually ranks among the top three world catching powers. I believe we have to improve transparency in fishing activities and support regional approach to fisheries management, including promoting the harmonisation of conditions of access for foreign fleets to third countries’ EEZs (exclusive economic zones) and the development of a sustainability framework for joint ventures as part of the implementation of SFPAs. Moreover, we should improve the supply of fish for food security by supporting the work done by women in the fisheries sector. The external dimension of the common fisheries policy has to be among our priorities for fisheries policy like promoting sustainable fishing in third countries, ensuring that fishery products imported into the EU are produced under acceptable labour and human rights standards, keeping up pressure on states to combat IUU fishing and enhancing controls.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I stand by parliament's report on the external dimension of the common fisheries policy. The EU is still the largest market for fishery products. Sustainable fisheries are part of a strategy to increase the EU's influence at international level, taking into account the management and transparency of fisheries.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because of the need to give the CFP an external dimension to the finding that there is intense international competition in all ocean areas and for most species. Some have adopted aggressive policies to gain access to increasingly scarce resources, providing them with a competitive economic advantage over EU vessels. It is therefore essential to improve the strategy to achieve the EU's objective of promoting sustainable fisheries using its influence on the international stage in order to improve fisheries management and transparency rules and to promote upward rather than down competition.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on common rules for the application of the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements, because I believe that Europe can and must play a role in promoting sustainable fishing standards internationally, spreading its principles and values also vis-à-vis third countries. I am thinking, in fact, of the EU as a drag and promoter of international rules that ensure high social, environmental and biodiversity standards, ensure transparency, ensure fair competition between vessels flying the flags of different countries and, at the same time, promote economic activity and, specifically, the fisheries sector. I welcome the reference to the issue of flag change and the fraudulent practices of some operators in the sector in breach of EU rules, as well as support for EU legislation on illegal fishing, which is a recent example of the EU's ability to influence the behaviour of actors on the global stage.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on common rules for the implementation of the external dimension of the CFP and fisheries agreements. Maritime management must not end at the EU's external borders. We need a working approach to international cooperation.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU's fisheries partnership agreements with third countries help to ensure that EU standards are fished sustainably in these countries and that illegal fishing and overfishing are combated. I support the promotion of surveillance, particularly with regard to my region.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report imposes a number of measures on the EU external fleet (EU-flagged vessels fishing outside EU waters), particularly with regard to fishing in the waters of third countries. The EU fishing fleet is one of the world’s largest and ranks in the top three of the world’s catching powers; therefore, the opportunity for influence is significant. Within the scope of this report, there are measures relating to cooperation among Regional Fisheries Management Organisations (RFMOs) and transparency of Fisheries Partnership Agreements; job creation and training in third countries; combating illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing, as well as promotion of high environmental standards in third countries. The report is both fair and transparent and represents greater cooperation between third countries and the European Union. It is for these reasons I voted to adopt this report.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. Is European fishing environmentally, economically and socially sustainable outside EU territorial waters? Overall yes, but transparency must be improved and fishermen in developing countries should not be unfairly competitive. I note with interest that paragraph 67 of the report calls on the Commission to end trade relations with countries that engage in illegal fishing. Similarly, the European Union is paying less and less access rights in fisheries agreements with third countries. This share has increased from 65% to 35%; shipowners pay the rest.  This rebalancing is favourable to the European taxpayer, but also benefits small-scale artisanal fishermen in Europe and developing countries. Indeed, less subsidies for fishing agreements also means less unfair competition with artisanal fishermen. The latter do not benefit from these agreements, but are still competing with imported products.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of regulating the CFP in its external dimension to incorporate into the centralized management of the CFP the different regional realities, participation and sustainability of the sectors, including minimum conditions for bilateral agreements.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it uses the best strategy for realising the EU’s objective for promoting sustainable fisheries, which preserves natural areas and helps maintain jobs for the future.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The EU’s best strategy for promoting sustainable fisheries is to enhance social and environmental standards, to better control its own external fleet and to use the EU’s leadership on the international scene to improve fisheries management.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is good that the basic regulation on the Common Fisheries Policy includes, for the first time, a chapter on the external dimension, including minimum conditions for bilateral agreements. It has a duty to promote cooperation between regional fisheries management organisations and coherence between the measures they take. It contains an explicit reference to common standards both inside and outside EU waters, and states that measures should be based on the best available scientific advice. That is why we supported the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as did the vast majority of my colleagues in Parliament. I believe that the CFP has a vital role to play in trying to influence and protect Europe’s high environmental and labour standards in external waters. In fact, it is my opinion that the strength of the EU is its normalising influence on others to introduce better standards in all sectors. When the CFP was established, there were relatively few distant water fishing nations, operating a long way from their own coastal waters. Now, three decades later, the situation has changed radically and there is intense competition in all ocean areas. This has its own problems for the environment and fishing stocks as well as workers’ rights. Thankfully this report highlights the importance of the EU distant fleet activity in protecting our interests and at the same time addresses the shortcomings that still need to be tackled. It calls for stricter inspections to ensure EU standards are maintained, greater traceability of products that enter the food supply chain and the need for distant fleets to only fish surplus stocks among others.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was in favour of this resolution as it would allow the EU to promote sustainable fishing whilst also providing an appropriate element of support for the industry in developing countries.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'We need to look beyond European borders in favour of sustainable management of global fish populations. The EU is a big fish on the world stage; the EU market for marine products is one of the largest in the world and the EU has concluded several agreements with third countries on fisheries. Although Europe is a major cause of global overfishing, it is important that this external dimension of European fisheries policy is included in the common fisheries policy. The report makes a good contribution to a more sustainable management of the oceans. Such as including the precautionary principle in fisheries policy, promoting the highest environmental and social standards and tackling systematic corruption in third countries in the conclusion of fisheries agreements. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a fundamental difference between the northern fisheries agreements involving Norway, Iceland and the Faeroe Islands and those involving other countries; the former essentially involve co-management between the EU and the relevant countries, whereas the latter tend to be less well balanced. The rapporteur was happy to take this fact on board and I was therefore able to support her important work in this field.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is the world’s largest market for fisheries products with one of the largest fleets. Its objective is to promote sustainable fisheries on the international stage. I have voted in favour of this report that should improve fisheries management and transparency standards of the common fisheries policy (CEP).

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on common rules on the application of the external dimension of the Common Fisheries Policy, because the global situation in this sector has changed drastically, i.e. new actors have emerged, such as China and Taiwan, to apply aggressive policies to access marine resources. Often ships of such countries have lower standards in terms of environmental protection, safety and compliance with international obligations, and thus an economic advantage over european ones.  However, I think it is necessary to insist on a sustainable way of fishing in order to strengthen the protection of the environment and social standards and to strengthen the role of the European Union on the international stage as a promoter of a sustainable way of managing marine resources. In this context, it is necessary to ensure consistency and coherence between the Union's external and internal fisheries policy. Transparency of all activities, more effective control and oversight measures and easier access to accurate scientific information and studies are therefore needed.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The main objective is to know the impact of the external dimension of the European Union, in order to determine whether the fishing practiced is sustainable from an environmental, social and economic point of view. In particular, the rapporteur wants a framework to be created for European companies' agreements with third countries or their joint ventures, in order to improve transparency and avoid competition with local fisheries.  It should be noted that paragraph 67 advises the Commission to propose an interruption of trade relations with countries that are identified as illegal fishing. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We oppose this because even when the objectives are laudable, the reality of the EU policy is a behavioural-economic ‘one-size-fits-all’ disaster.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Linnéa Engstrom's report on the external dimension of the CFP. The marketing of fisheries products in the EU is constrained by a number of regulations that contribute to the emergence of a European industry with competitive advantage, and this by improving fishing from the point of view of environmental and social sustainability.  The European Union must improve global fisheries management and transparency rules. I have therefore approved this proposal to create an EU-wide database incorporating all the private agreements between European shipowners and third countries, as well as joint ventures between European companies and companies established outside the UNION. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The EU has a key role to play in the global governance of the seas and oceans as it is the world's largest market for seafood. This report aims to strengthen the European Union's role on the international stage of the Common Fisheries Policy to promote sustainable, environmentally responsible fishing standards with a high level of social protection. The Union must be at the forefront of this own competence and defend the most ambitious standards. So I voted for this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it calls for promoting sustainable fishing in third countries, to ensure that fishery products imported into the EU are produced under acceptable labour and human rights standards, to keep up pressure on states to combat IUU fishing and to enhance controls.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The promotion of fisheries agreements at international level must certainly be treated in hand with the situation of our fisheries and our fishermen. Having said that, it is also necessary to create international agreements that will enable us to safeguard our fishing activities. In this regard, I have expressed my positive opinion on the intention to demonstrate leadership, political will and support towards states outside the Union, in order to improve the management and transparency of fishing activities in international waters. It is our objective to promote the development and maintenance of sustainable fisheries at non-European level as well. Thanks to strict traceability measures, and the continuing fight against illegal fishing, the European market is currently among the largest in the world. The extreme competition that is now present in ocean waters and our experience in the sector therefore lead us to work to establish an increasingly fruitful relationship in the field of agreements with third countries.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because, when it comes to fisheries, it makes shipowners pay more and the European Union less. It also advises the Commission to end the EU's trade relations with countries that engage in illegal fishing.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of this text. It focuses on fishing in distant waters, practiced for centuries by European ships. Moreover, the European Union has created a dimension outside its Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which includes fishing activities outside European areas, to adapt to this traditional practice.  Thus, the rapporteur wished to know the environmental, social and economic impact of this policy. This is why it calls for the creation of a framework for European business agreements with third countries or their companies, in order to improve transparency and competition with local fisheries.  In addition, paragraph 67 favours European fishermen by proposing to end all trade relations with countries engaged in illegal fishing. These measures are in line with fishermen and national interests, so I have spoken for this text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. For the first time, the basic regulation of the CFP includes a chapter on the external dimension of the CFP, which includes the minimum conditions for bilateral agreements, responsibility for cooperation between regional fisheries organizations and coherence between the measures they take. In addition to this, the report stresses the need for fisheries agreements to benefit both the EU and third countries, as well as the importance of supporting the development of local communities. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the importance of the European Union in the global market for fishery products, it is important to promote sustainable fishing and use this influence on the international stage in order to improve the management of fishing products, the rules of parking and to promote competition upwards rather than on the down.  This report presents a number of recommendations in this regard, emphasizing the demands for greater parence, a more regional approach to fisheries management, the development of a sustainability framework, an improvement in the supply of fish for food security and special support for women's work in this sector. For the reasons set out above, I welcome the adoption of this report showing the EU's political will to support the implementation of new measures in this regard and to provide the necessary support to developing countries to adapt to the new requirements.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒At the time of the creation of the Common Fisheries Policy, there were very few countries actively engaged in fishing activities outside European territorial waters. In the meantime, the situation has changed, not only are countries operating outside territorial waters, but also actively cooperating with other member states in the fishing. The problem arises in the overfishing and influence of economic powers such as China, South Korea and Taiwan that by acting on aggressive policies allow non-compliance with rules such as markings on ships (flags, coats of arms, etc.). Strict implementation of common rules leading to improved economic, social and environmental sustainability contributes to a better Position of the Union on the market. Therefore, I supported the report.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. In the face of overfishing, and the fierce and often unfair competition facing all oceans today, the European Union must use its international influence to promote a sustainable fishing model based on respect for human rights. This text has the great merit of bringing many concrete and precise proposals on these and many other subjects. I also welcome the fact that this report explicitly mentions the special role of the UPRs in implementing the external component of the Common Fisheries Policy. It therefore calls for ensuring that fisheries in these regions can benefit more from bilateral agreements than the Commission with third countries neighbouring the UPRs. I therefore vote in favour of this text.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the adoption of common provisions aimed at implementing the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/4/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this draft report. This draft report is in line with the Common Fisheries Policy, established in 1982. It concerns both deep-sea fishing (thus outside of all territorial waters) and fishing on the maritime territory of third countries. In particular, it aims to focus on respect for social and environmental standards, by involving transnational companies more in order to avoid competition with local fisheries.  The draft report also proposes the cessation of trade relations with states authorizing illegal fishing.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on common rules for the application of the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements. The European Union is one of the major powers in the field of fisheries and one of the main markets and importers of fish products, which means that strict traceability measures are needed, and that fishing management standards and transparency are improved. It is necessary for the European Union, together with the Member States, to make efforts to strengthen their obligations and take greater responsibility than their citizens involved in fishing activities outside the Union. In this way, the European Union will be able to improve ocean fishing standards and encourage other actors to improve its fisheries policies.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is great potential in "blue growth" in the oceans, but as with ongoing operations in the oceans we must ensure that it meets environmental standards, especially after the Paris talks. Therefore, it is important that we keep our oceans clean according to international standards; I believe that Europe must show its leadership in this regard.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report that underscores the EU’s leadership role in the ‘race to the top’ in environmental, transparency and fish stock management standards, as the EU is the largest market for fisheries products in the world.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Union is the world's largest market for fishing products, has one of the largest fleets flying its flag and is generally in the top three in terms of fishing capacity.  This report aims to improve the EU's fisheries policies, particularly in its external dimension. It encourages the Union in its effort to be transparent, in its fight against IDT fishing (illegal, unreged and unregified) and in promoting "very high environmental and social standards".  Within the framework of bilateral fisheries agreements, the report also stresses the minimum conditions to be met and the need to foster cooperation between regional fisheries management organisations (PMOs). I voted for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The objective is to know the external dimension of the CFP to determine whether the fishery as it is practiced is sustainable. A framework is provided for European business agreements with third countries. It will allow transparency and avoid competition with local fishing. That seems to me to be a good measure. As a result, I voted for this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements. The new EU CFP has evolved significantly. If implemented correctly, it will certainly contribute to improving eu fishing standards in distant waters. It should be noted that a chapter on the external dimension is included in the recent reform of the CFP Regulation, in which sustainable fisheries partnership agreements (Apps) and fisheries under the OTGs are formally regulated for the first time. The EU must ensure transparency while seeking to promote the protection of ecosystems and the maintenance of fish stocks. This is the only way to generate income for fishermen in various types of fishing. It should be noted that the EU currently represents the world's largest market for fishery products and has one of the largest fleets in terms of catch capacities.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this report on the common fisheries policy as it provides clearer common rules on the European Union fisheries policy, but also contributes to a more sustainable use of the dwindling maritime resources. The proposed increased transparency and better management of fishing stocks are a clear and commendable improvement of existing legislation.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the report on common rules for the application of the external dimension of the common fisheries policy, including fisheries agreements.  The EU's foreign policy in fisheries, whether in the framework of bilateral agreements or within the PMOs, will be of paramount importance for the preservation of the world's fisheries resources and therefore for the sustainability of fishing opportunities.  Responsible management of marine resources at the global level can only be done together, through greater consultation and cooperation between countries. The Union must therefore use all its influence and strengthen its efforts to convince them to apply to their fleet the principles that guide EU policy in this area, including sustainability and the precautionary principle.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The rapporteur has presented a very well-prepared report clarifying the problems related to fisheries and, in particular, the shortcomings of the common fisheries policy. There's an old familiar statement that a criminal is always one step ahead of a police officer because he's not hindered by law enforcement. The report presented shows that this is also the case here in the broader scope. The illegal actions of some third-country actors are being put at a disadvantage by EU citizens who, in compliance with high European standards, are in a disadvantageous economic position. On the basis of the arguments put forward, I agree with the rapporteur that, in dealing with this situation, emphasis must be placed on transparency, not only when concluding contracts between fisheries operators, but also after their conclusion in the form of a public database in which all the necessary data on agreements between EU shipowners and third countries will be accessible. This simple instrument will contribute to better competitiveness of EU citizens and thus to improving their standard of living.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE)
text: in writing. I support Mrs Engstrom's report on the external dimension of the common fisheries policy. In particular, fisheries agreements with third countries are very important, both for the Spanish fleet in general and for which it is based in Galicia. It is essential that the European Commission continue the line of recent years, in which important fisheries agreements with third countries have been concluded. I stress, for example, the recent agreements reached with Guinea-Bissaeu and Mauritania.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the report on the external dimension of the CFP, including a fisheries agreement that promotes an excellent strategy for realising the EU objective of promoting sustainable fisheries at a global level by using the EU’s influence on the international stage to improve fisheries management and transparency standards.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The proliferation of EEZs around the world, which has in fact excluded European vessels from many fishing areas, has made it necessary to negotiate fisheries agreements with many third countries.  The external dimension is 20-25% of European catches. The main objective is to determine whether fishing is environmentally, socially and economically sustainable. In particular, the rapporteur wants a framework to be created for European companies' agreements with third countries or their joint ventures, in order to improve transparency and avoid competition with local fisheries.  The text rightly advises the Commission to propose an interruption of trade relations with countries that are identified as illegal fishing. It is proposed to support the text.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important to highlight the inclusion of a chapter on the external dimension in the reform of the CFP Regulation, in which sustainable fisheries partnership agreements (Apps) and fisheries under THE ORPs are formally regulated for the first time. I support the importance of promoting the protection of ecosystems and keeping fish stocks above levels capable of generating a maximum sustainable yield, as the existence of more abundant stocks is an important requirement to enable the development of coastal fishing communities in third countries. Currently, the EU represents the world's largest market for fishery products, has one of the largest fleets flying its flag and is considered one of the world's top three powers in terms of capture capabilities. The EU's influence in the world of fisheries, as a flag State and marketing State, allows it to exert influence over other actors, both coastal states and states that operate in distant waters, so that they improve their own fishing policies. I believe that the EU should use its influence to improve fisheries management and transparency standards.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The main objective of this text is to know the impact of the external dimension of the European Union's common fisheries policy, in order to determine whether fishing on the high seas or in the waters of a third country is environmentally, socially and economically sustainable. In particular, the report wants a framework to be created for European companies' agreements with third countries or their joint ventures, in order to improve transparency and avoid competition with local fisheries. So I voted for this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. While China, Korea and Taiwan are pursuing aggressive, heavily subsidised and low-tax fisheries policies while having less stringent environmental, social and security standards than those we impose on ourselves in Europe, it is essential that the European Union, which represents the world's largest market for fishing products, have an outside view of the policy to be pursued in this area.  The report stresses that the EU must use its influence on the international stage to improve management and transparency rules in fisheries and not be subject to the policies of other countries. That is why I voted for it.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Engstrom report. The European Union still is the world's largest market for fishing products, has one of the largest fleets flying its flag and is generally in the top three in terms of fishing capacity.  The marketing of fish products in the EU is subject to strict measures in terms of traceability, catch verification and control of illegal, unreported and unregulated (INN) fishing. These rules help to create conditions that give European industry a competitive advantage, by improving fishing in terms of environmental and social sustainability, strictly applying international conventions and regulating the market.  There is clearly a need to create an EU-wide database comprising private agreements between European shipowners and third countries, as well as joint ventures between European companies and companies based in third countries.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. In line with the text on support for inshore fishing activities, the European Parliament recalled the measures taken by the Eu to promote sustainable fishing (measures of traceability, verification of catches, control of illegal fishing, etc.).  By adopting this text, we are proposing new measures to further protect sustainable fishing in the EU. Moreover, the new Common Fisheries Policy is part of the search for a normative improvement in the field of distant European fisheries.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I look positively at the initiative, which aims to increase Europe's influence on the international stage in the field of fisheries. This is of particular importance at a time when there is a serious struggle for fishing areas. For the sake of clarity, I believe that we should support an EU database that gives the Commission easy access to private agreements between EU and third-country shipowners. I also welcome the idea of exploiting our international influence for transparent and environmentally friendly fishing. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The common fisheries policy is a set of rules that manages European fishing fleets and conserves fish stocks. Designed to manage a common resource, it gives all European fishing fleets equal access to EU waters and fishing grounds, allowing fishermen to compete fairly. I have voted for this report that will bring more transparency in fishing activities.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is a balanced one, in which both the importance of the external dimension of the common fisheries policy and the main concerns that the Committee on Fisheries has with regard to these agreements with third countries is presented. It is true that the EU is the largest importer of fish products, which means that there is a constant need for fisheries agreements with third countries. However, the EU must ensure that these agreements are mutually beneficial, that they help the development of third countries and, last but not least, that they are in line with the principles of the CFP. Furthermore, given that, in some cases, information on third-country fish stocks is incomplete, encouraging better monitoring and combating IUU fishing must always be a priority of these agreements.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve the transparency of fishing activities outside the European Union.  The report proposes to put in place a regional approach to fisheries management which, thanks to my amendments, takes into account the situation of the outermost regions and ensures that local fisheries in the UPRs benefit from the European Union's fisheries agreements with third countries. The report also includes provisions on combating illegal fishing, improving fish supply and women's work.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this because even when the objectives are laudable, the reality of the EU policy is a behavioural-economic ‘one-size-fits-all’ disaster.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this issue, as I am convinced that the fishing practices put in place by some countries at international level and that they do not respect environmental sustainability, as well as having weakened the EU's competitiveness in the fisheries sector, have underlined the need for the EU to play a more central role in the international context. Standardised practices by Member States would enable the EU to effectively defend investment by European vessels operating outside EU waters and would also stimulate the development of the local economy in third countries. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Better scientific information and data on catches and fishing efforts outside EU waters should be available, especially in the waters of certain developing coastal countries, therefore. In its external fisheries activities (fishing, fish processing and marketing), the EU must adopt and promote the highest level of environmental and social standards and implement strict and effective control and control measures, while ensuring transparency in all its activities. I welcome the opening of the issue of the significant role of women in the value chain, from financing to the marketing of fish products, as these activities strengthen the economic and social empowerment of women engaged in fisheries in fishing contract countries. I consider transparency, i.e. the public availability of detailed data on catches and activities of vessels and established fishing protocols, a priority of this Report and I strongly support it. Particular emphasis should be given to the strict, objective and non-discriminatory application of the Fishing Regulation (illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing) as a precondition for improving competition.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The proliferation of EEZs around the world, which has in fact excluded European vessels from many fishing areas, has made it necessary to negotiate fisheries agreements with many third countries. Previously, the majority of access rights were paid by the European taxpayer, but this problem is being solved little by little: it has gone from 65% of the access fees paid by the European Union to 35%. The shipowners pay the rest.  The main objective of the report is to know the impact of the external dimension of the Union, in order to determine whether the fishing practised is sustainable from an environmental, social and economic point of view.  In particular, the rapporteur wants a framework to be created for European companies' agreements with third countries or their joint ventures, in order to improve transparency and avoid competition with local fisheries. It advises the Commission to propose an interruption of trade relations with countries that are identified as illegal fishing. I therefore vote in favour of this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The EU is a large market for fishery products (including fish caught by the EU fleet and imported fish) and the largest importer of such products and has a consumption of 11 % of the world's total fish production in terms of quantity and imports of 24 % of fisheries products in terms of value.  I underline the importance of ensuring the coherence of fisheries policy, environmental policy, trade policy and development cooperation. I express concern about the possible disruption of fishing activities between the two protocols in the event of an extension of negotiations on the new protocol. In my view, the economic, social and environmental conditions prevailing in fish catching and processing should be clear to consumers.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
