text: in writing. \u2012 The Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) includes a chapter on its external dimension, in particular the establishment of minimum conditions for the establishment of fisheries agreements between the EU and third countries, alongside commitments to increase cooperation and consistency of measures applied within the Regional Fisheries Management Organisations; an explicit reference to common standards within and outside EU waters; and the valorization of scientific information in decision-making. Despite the fact that we do not follow all the considerations made, the report emphasises some important issues, which we value: the need to ensure that fisheries agreements provide mutual benefits for the EU and for third countries, including their local populations and the fishing sector; the promotion of environmentally, socially and economically sustainable fisheries, based on transparency and the participation of non-governmental actors, especially professionals who rely on fisheries for their livelihood, in order to ensure a future for coastal communities, the marine environment, the development of local industry, the employment generated by fisheries, processing and trade, and the contribution of fisheries to food security; measures to promote the transfer of technologies and know-how; and the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported my colleague Linnéae Engström's report on common rules for implementing the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements, as the EU plays a key role in global sea and ocean governance. The CFP must be based on an ambitious vision aligned with the internal dimension set out in the basic CFP Regulation. I believe it is necessary to include a chapter on the external dimension of fisheries policy in the recent reform of the CFP Regulation, which will formally regulate agreements on partnerships in sustainable fisheries and fishing under the auspices of regional fisheries management organisations. I welcome the support of the development of local communities whose live resources depend mainly on fishing and fisheries-related activities, as well as the need to support measures aimed at promoting knowledge and skills transfer, technology transfer, capacity management, multi-stakeholder partnerships and other investments for the benefit of the fisheries industry. I also believe that the EU should promote dialogue with partner countries through SFPASs in order to establish a regulatory framework to ensure that joint ventures in the fishing, fish processing and marketing sectors, concluded with partners from the EU or other countries, do not compete with the local craft sector and contribute to the achievement of the development objectives of the country concerned and operate in a transparent manner.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am convinced of the importance of the EU's role and international cooperation in preserving sustainable fish stocks and biodiversity. As the largest importer of fishery products, the EU must take into account not only the market and industrial aspects of the common fisheries policy, but also its social dimension. For developing countries, fishing is a traditional way of life, a source of livelihood, the basis of the economy and therefore economic development, which is why I believe that it is the EU's responsibility to promote environmental and socially sustainable fishing in third countries. The maintenance of aquaculture can be achieved by involving transparency provisions in fisheries partnership agreements that will contribute to greater accountability of stakeholders, overall control of fishing effort and verification of imported products. It is also important to improve labour standards and protect workers' rights in partner countries in order to ensure the same standards for third-country nationals as for EU citizens. I therefore welcome the call on the Commission to examine the possibility of applying the provisions on working conditions in the IUU Regulation.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I very much welcome this proposal, which for the first time will include in the basic Regulation on the common fisheries policy a chapter on the external dimension of fisheries. In today's ever-evolving world, there is a constant increase in competition between states in various areas, including fisheries. In order to achieve a competitive advantage, some states are willing to accept reduced environmental, social or safety standards. The EU should therefore use its position within the international community to oppose such practices, which also have a far-reaching impact on natural resources. The EU's great influence in world fisheries could already be seen in the event of significant success in the adoption of the IUU Regulation, which has led to better legislation in many countries around the world. I am therefore convinced that this chapter will bring further positive benefits, which will lead to the maintenance of the EU's leading position in the areas of high standards, the environmental and social sustainability of fisheries and the strict implementation of international instruments. Only in this way can the EU remain a model for other countries and build its competitiveness in fisheries on the basis of quality and sustainability.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to its influence in the fishing world, the EU is in a position to encourage other actors, both coastal states and states that fish in the ocean, to improve their fisheries policies. The remarkable success of the IUU Fisheries Regulation (combating illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing) clearly demonstrates that this method can work if the EU shows sufficient political will, leadership, objectivity and appropriate support for adaptation to new requirements by developing countries. I voted in favour because I believe that the new EU CFP has considerable advantages and, if properly implemented, will improve the EU's ocean fishing standards.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on the external dimension of the common fisheries policy, as it recalls the requirements to be met by the European Union in the context of the conclusion of fisheries agreements with third countries.  In particular, improving the transparency of fishing activities, the regionalisation of fisheries management (including a desire to harmonize the conditions for foreign vessels to access third-country EEZs) or efforts to combat illegal fishing are major elements.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this because even when the objectives are laudable, the reality of the EU policy is a behavioural-economic ‘one-size-fits-all’ disaster.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as it advocates the inclusion of the outermost regions in the external dimension of the Common Fisheries Policy and also in the framework of bilateral agreements signed with third countries in order to ensure that local fisheries in these regions benefit. At the same time, this basic REGULATION of the CFP is part of a chapter dedicated to its external dimension, providing for minimum conditions to be respected under bilateral agreements, which I have always advocated. The EU should promote the harmonisation of fishing conditions with a view to creating favourable conditions for fishermen by promoting sustainable and responsible activity. Only regionalised fisheries management can ensure sustainable and equitable exploitation, and further studies on the state of stocks and habitat are essential, and, where necessary, greater protection of deep-sea species and habitats. Aspects such as improving the transparency of fisheries agreements and activities, defending sustainability and improving the supply of fish to ensure food security were also reasons for my adoption of this report.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report relates to the external dimension of the common fisheries policy, i.e. the promotion of sustainable fisheries in third countries, while also ensuring that imported fishery products are produced under acceptable labour and human rights standards.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The external dimension of the Community fisheries policy is discussed here after its last reform. Following the amendments made to this report throughout the parliamentary process, the document is acceptable although we consider that it continues to have some elements outside its subject matter — such as charters or joint ventures, which belong fully to third countries — or which are not adequately collected – the lack of available information. In any event, the current external dimension is well explained in the FAR Regulation (Non-Community Water Fisheries Authorisations Regulation, 2008) and any possible gaps can be re-filled (in particular as regards the granting of permits in waters of a third country with which there is no agreement - Spain imposes on its fleet a system to verify the authenticity of licences and payments to the third country through its Embassies , which may be extended to the rest of the EU). I voted for it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. At present, the European Union is the world's largest market for fish products. The marketing of fish products in the EU is subject to strict measures in terms of traceability, catch verification and control of illegal, unreported and unregulated (INN) fishing.  The significant improvements that the INN Regulation has made to the legislation and fishing activities of many countries of the world are proof that this "levelling up" can work, if the European Union shows political will and gives the necessary impetus and if it helps developing countries to meet the new requirements.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The report unequivocally sends the message that the EU's objective of promoting sustainable fisheries requires the use of EU influence on the international stage to improve standards of fisheries management and transparency, to encourage races for higher standards rather than lower standards. This is also intended to ensure and encourage third countries, starting with those with which the EU negotiates sustainable fisheries partnership agreements, to develop a regulatory framework for joint fishing, processing and marketing of EU actors and other entities in the fisheries, processing and marketing sectors. The report also calls on the Commission to play an active role in promoting the idea that third countries publish the terms of agreements they sign with other States or private entities, including data on the identity, activity and catch of vessels authorised to fish. This would ensure transparency and increase competition to ensure environmental aspects of fisheries.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Three decades after the start of the implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), maritime competition is now more intense. The Union therefore needs to promote sustainable fisheries and, to this end, the best strategy for achieving this objective will be to use its influence on the international scene to improve management standards and transparency in the management of fisheries resources. The Union, as the holder of the world's largest market for fishery products, also has one of the largest fleets for its catch.  The marketing of these products is subject to very stringent measures with regard to their traceability and verification of the size/hygienic conditions of catches, as well as in the fight against IUU fishing (illegal, unreported and not recommended). These measures aim to ensure competitive advantages, taking into account environmental and social sustainability and the protection of consumer rights, as well as strict enforcement of international regulations. In view of the significant advances of the new CFP, with remarkable success in the IUU Fisheries Regulation, which has led to improvements in legislation on fishing activities across the globe, I supported this report, which aims to promote measures for the continuous improvement of overall management of fisheries resources.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on common rules for the application of the external dimension of the CFP.  The European Union is an important market for fisheries products, being the main importer of these products with an 11% consumption of the world's fish production. This text reaffirms that multilateralism and international cooperation must be the preferred places for effective and sustainable management of global fisheries resources. It is necessary that the external dimension of the CFP be consistent with its internal dimension of the Union in order to carry an ambitious vision. In bilateral agreements, the focus must be on environmentally, economically and socially sustainable fisheries. The external dimension of the CFP must be based on fair and mutually beneficial relationships, but also on reliable data on fish stocks. I supported this report, which reminds us that the Union must promote, within the external dimension of the CFP, very high environmental and social standards such as the promotion of sustainable aquaculture or the inclusion of instruments to protect workers and guarantee decent working conditions.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of regulating the CFP in its external dimension to incorporate into the centralised management of the CFP the different regional realities, participation and sustainability of the sectors, including minimum conditions for bilateral agreements

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the common rules for the implementation of the external dimension of the CFP, including the fisheries agreement, as the political will, leadership, objectivity and adequate support for developing countries have led to remarkable successes of the Regulation on Combating Illegal Fishing (IUU-VO). An EU-wide database is now needed to continue to improve the standards of stock management and transparency of the world's largest market for fishery products. I therefore support the report in order to improve the standards of EU fishing on the high seas.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote on this Resolution although it contains positive points such as stressing the importance of the development of small local fishing communities in establishing fisheries agreements between the EU and third countries or applying the highest environmental standards there. However, it does not sufficiently reflect the role of the EU and the CFP in the destruction or obstruction of the development of small-scale coastal, artisanal and traditional fisheries both within the Union and in the third countries with which it establishes agreements.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 When we talk about fishing in non-European waters, we also talk about fishing in the Mediterranean Sea.  Our European fishermen often face unfair competition from third-country fleets that share the same fishing grounds. The diversity of rules for different EU and non-EU fleets not only leads to a competitive gap between companies, but also puts the long-term sustainability of catches at risk. The European Union needs to do more to establish closer cooperation with the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean in order to remedy the current distortions, to support fishermen who are often subjected to clashes with third-country vessels and thus to put an end to the fish war.  In this regard, I believe that it is crucial to involve local bodies, regional organisations, scientific institutes, observers and national associations in the fisheries sector at both European and non-European level, which, through an exchange of best practices and a greater knowledge of management measures, can help to combat illegal and undeclared fishing more effectively and to promote a more responsible and sustainable exploitation of our precious resources.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On this report, for which I was shadow rapporteur, I stress the contribution it will make to more responsible and consistent action by the European Union in international waters. From the European Commission's analysis and implementation of the recommendations that are made here, there will be implications for how the Union relates to the countries with which it signs fishing partnerships, in order to increase the transparency of the relationship, ensuring benefits and extended environmental sustainability. This is an important document that sins only because of the lack of recognition that marine biodiversity is under pressure, with fisheries being among the most immediate threats. Fortunately, for the positive, there are many aspects to be highlighted, and these are the ones that have led me to vote positively in this document. Among them, It seems to me particularly important to mention a single register for vessels circulating in international waters. It is necessary to end with the permanent changes of flag, this expedient so used by the predatory shipowners.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this because even when the objectives are laudable, the reality of the EU policy is a behavioural-economic ‘one-size-fits-all’ disaster.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is the world’s largest market for products derived from the fisheries industry and has one of the largest fleets to boot, ranking among the top three in terms of catching power. I voted in favour of this report as it uses the best strategy for realising the EU’s objective for promoting sustainable fisheries, which preserves natural areas for generations.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution deals with the implications of the Common Fisheries Policy. The resolution takes care of both the economic and environmental sides, so therefore I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently still the largest market for fishery products in the world. Sales of fish products are subject to strict measures in the EU in terms of traceability, verification of catches and the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing. The new CFP contains significant improvements, improves EU standards for fishing in remote areas. European investments in fisheries in third countries within the framework of joint ventures must be covered by the common fisheries policy. Through its Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements, the EU should promote dialogue with partner countries on the establishment of a regulatory framework to ensure that joint ventures in the fisheries, processing and marketing sectors operate transparently, do not compete with the local small-sector fishing sector and contribute to the country's development objectives. I supported the motion for a resolution on common rules on the application of the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The external dimension of the new Common Fisheries Policy covers international agreements and fisheries in areas outside national competence. The European Union leads the way as an important fishing force in the world and has a well-developed network of bilateral fisheries agreements, which has a positive impact on fisheries management (RFMO), fostering the application of good practices and respect for human rights.  Of great importance is the development of the fishing fleet of third countries, as well as the coherence of fisheries policy, trade policy, environmental policy and development cooperation. Cooperation with partner countries is crucial in terms of fisheries management, infrastructure construction and maintenance and improving fish supply with a view to ensuring food security for the population of partner countries.  By 2008, there was an overexploitation of the number of stocks which decreased somewhat in 2011 and it is essential to maintain the exploitation of the number of stocks within acceptable limits. As there is a lack of reliable information on fish stocks and the activities of domestic and partner fishing fleets, it is difficult to put into practice one of the main objectives of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement, i.e. fishing for only surplus stocks.  I support this report and believe that the external dimension of the Common Fisheries Policy is important in order to increase social and environmental standards, both of the European Union and partner countries.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The external dimension of the new Common Fisheries Policy is of great importance, as it covers international agreements and fisheries in areas outside state jurisdiction. Fisheries have historically been present for a very long time in the territory of the Member States of the European Union, which has been promoting the application of good practice and respect for human rights for many years.  However, the number of stocks exploited in oversupply grew continuously until 2008, but decreased somewhat in 2011. (2014 report by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation). In order to reduce overexploitation, it is essential to work with third countries whose development of fishing fleets has an impact on increasing social and environmental standards. I support this report, as I believe that environmental standards must also apply to the external fisheries of the European Union.  Support should be given to partner countries and their fisheries sectors, as cooperation has a positive impact on fisheries management, scientific research, infrastructure development and maintenance and many other areas. Furthermore, one of the main objectives of the agreement is to fish exclusively for surplus stocks, and for the successful implementation of this objective, it is important that reliable information is available on fish stocks and the efforts of domestic fishing fleets, as well as fleets of other countries.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on common rules for the implementation of the external dimension of the common fisheries policy, including fisheries agreements. In addition to being one of the world's most important fisheries players due to its past presence and important activities in all the world's oceans, the EU is also an important market for fishery products. I support the report because it emphasises the importance of coherence between fisheries, environmental and trade policy and development cooperation. All aspects are very important and we must not ignore anything. The report is also clear in promoting environmental, social and economically sustainable fisheries in bilateral and other agreements between the EU and its partners.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The CAP, together with the quotas it imposes, has not had a positive effect on the chronic decline in fish stocks in our seas. With the CFP, the EU retains almost complete control over fisheries management, with Member States having no meaningful role in the decision-making process.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the common fisheries policy should be further strengthened at international level. The report notes that to date, some countries are pursuing aggressive policies in order to gain access to shrinking resources. These fleets operate, to varying degrees, in accordance with less stringent environmental, safety and social standards and enjoy high subsidies and often lower taxes. Many of these high seas fishing countries do not fulfil their obligations as flag, port or market State and do not even respect fundamental human rights, all of which give them a competitive advantage over EU vessels.  I agree that one of the best ways to achieve the EU's objective of promoting sustainable fisheries is to use the EU's influence on the international stage to encourage competition towards higher standards. The new EU Common Fisheries Policy will make significant progress, require policy coherence for development and, if properly implemented, will also improve the quality of EU fishing on the high seas.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the largest market for fishery products worldwide. The total level of the fishing fleet belonging to THE EU Member States is also in the world's top three. This level is based on fishing in the internal waters of the Member States, but also in international waters or belonging to other States. In international waters, fishing is regulated by participation in regional fisheries management organisations (RFMOs); in the waters of other countries, fishing is governed by bilateral agreements with that State. In order to maintain its global competitiveness in fisheries, the EU generally calls for certain management and transparency standards to be met in this area, as well as harmonising access conditions, developing a sustainable framework, combating illegal fishing, ensuring decent working conditions and human rights and promoting women's involvement in this area. The EU also supports at international level the importance of fisheries for the food security of the population; therefore emphasises compliance with fisheries partnership agreements and the establishment of integrated boat flag databases. The adoption of this document constitutes a significant improvement in the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP).

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The EU's new PCP includes significant progress and, if properly implemented, will improve standards for distant European fisheries. Given the treaty's policy requirements for development, we can only welcome that. Given its influence in the fishing world, as a flag state and, in particular, as a trading state, the European Union is well placed to encourage other actors, whether coastal states or distant fishing states, to improve their own fisheries policies, not only theoretically but also in their implementation.  The considerable efficiency with which the INN Regulation has improved the legislation and fishing activities of many countries of the world is proof that this "levelling up" can work, if the European Union shows the necessary political will, sufficient leadership and objectivity, and if it helps developing countries to meet the new requirements. This is why recent signs of the weakening of the Union's determination in the fight against IND fishing, particularly by the delisting of Korea, are worrying.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is one of the world’s main fishing players, and has been an example in terms of fishing policy. However, increasingly important players such as China, Korea and Taiwan, have adopted aggressive policies that are not strictly in line with environmental or fair market policies, to obtain access to declining resources. The EU should take the lead on improving fisheries management and transparency standards, encouraging a race to the top instead of a race to the bottom. It can do so by promoting harmonisation of access conditions, installing regional managements of fisheries, and encouraging third countries to join. The EU has set strict measures to market fish products, in terms of traceability, verification and fighting illegal, unreported, and unregulated (IUU) fishing. This gives the EU a competitive advantage by being better in the environmental and social sustainability of fisheries, strict implementation of international instruments and market regulation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on common rules on the application of the external dimension of the Common Fisheries Policy, including fisheries agreements, as it insists on promoting environmentally, socially and economically sustainable fisheries based on transparency and participation of non-governmental stakeholders, in particular professionals living off fishing.  In my view, the European Union must promote its highest environmental and social standards in its external fisheries activities and implement strict and effective control and control measures. I would also stress the importance of coherence between fisheries policy, environmental policy, trade policy and development cooperation policy.  I believe that the European Union will promote measures that apply to all to ensure coherence between industrial and small coastal fishing fleets, but also to avoid sustainable fisheries agreements with countries that tolerate corruption.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on common rules for the implementation of the external dimension of the common fisheries policy, including fisheries agreements. It is clear that the EU will best achieve its objective of promoting sustainable fisheries by using its influence at international level to improve standards of governance and transparency in fisheries, thereby promoting competition for the best, rather than competing for the worst fisheries. This is the best strategy to achieve the EU's objective of promoting sustainable fisheries. The EU's influence at international level is needed to improve fisheries management standards and its transparent functioning and to boost the EU's competitiveness in this area.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of regulating the CFP in its external dimension to incorporate into the centralized management of the CFP the different regional realities, participation and sustainability of the sectors, including minimum conditions for bilateral agreements.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The main objective is to know the impact of the external dimension of the European Union in order to determine whether fishing is environmentally, socially and economically sustainable. The so-called "outdoor" fishery, outside European waters, accounts for 25% of European products. It is therefore crucial to ensure that our fishermen have the best conditions to ensure their work in a way that respects marine biodiversity. To this end, the report stipulates that a breakdown in trade relations is foreseen with any country engaged in illegal fishing, and the EU is committed to paying only 35% of the access rights, up from 65% before. So I voted for this report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is clear that one of the best ways to achieve the EU's objective of promoting sustainable fisheries is to use the EU's influence on the international stage to improve fisheries management and transparency standards and to encourage competition towards higher, not lower, standards. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of regulating the CFP in its external dimension to incorporate into the centralized management of the CFP the different regional realities, participation and sustainability of the sectors, including minimum conditions for bilateral agreements.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote on this report was positive. One major achievement in the reform of the CFP a few years ago was a formal inclusion of the external dimension in the EU’s fisheries legislation. There are now chapters in the basic regulation of the CFP relating to fishing under bilateral fisheries agreements and on fishing on the high seas under various international management organisations. This own-initiative report set out to build upon these new provisions of the CFP and to encourage the EU fishing industry that is active outside EU waters to aim for the highest standards globally – a ‘race to the top’ rather than to the bottom.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on common rules in respect of application of the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements. The EU is one of the world’s main fishing players, with a strong historical presence, as well as a major market for fishery products. The report emphasises the importance of ensuring consistency between fishery, environmental and trade policy and development cooperation. It equally insists on the importance of promoting ecosystem protection and maintaining sufficient levels of fish stocks. Finally, it underlines the need for protection of local communities whose livelihoods depend mostly on fishing and activities related to the fishing industry.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In this report, the European Parliament deals with all issues of the external dimension of the CFP, including fisheries agreements, from a comprehensive point of view. We are talking about a text which enjoys broad consensus among the members of the House, so I consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution because it will promote the sustainability of the European fisheries sector.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the fact that we do not follow all the considerations made, the report emphasises some important issues, which we value: the need to ensure that fisheries agreements provide mutual benefits for the EU and for third countries, including their local populations and the fishing sector; promoting environmentally, socially and economically sustainable fisheries, based on transparency and the participation of non-governmental actors, especially professionals who rely on fisheries for their livelihood, in order to ensure a future for coastal communities, the marine environment, the development of local industry, the employment generated by fisheries, processing and trade, and the contribution of fisheries to food security; measures to promote the transfer of technologies and know-how; and the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Promoting the protection of ecosystems and the conservation of fish stocks are important elements of this report. However, the report also aims at maximum sustainable yield and emphasises the need for the EU to maintain its standards in its external fisheries-related activities.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's report on common rules for the implementation of the external dimension of the CFP and the fisheries agreements. The regulation of fisheries agreements is clearly in the hands of the sovereign Member States, and although the report also contains positive aspects, it is not the EU's competence to introduce them.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposals in the report on common rules for the implementation of the external dimension of the common fisheries policy, including fisheries agreements, as I believe that they will contribute to sustainable fisheries that provide mutual benefits to the EU economy and third countries, including their local populations.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the fight against terrorism following recent terrorist attacks (2016/2646(RSP)).

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, a European response is required to the horrific terrorist attacks we witnessed in Brussels on 22 March. Our citizens are right to expect concrete action to counter terrorism, both from their governments and from the EU. We share your strong will to fight terrorism, as was expressed by your representative Sylvie Guillaume on 24 March. She said ‘Europe will not bow to terrorism. Our unity and determination to uphold our values and rights are only made stronger. Action must cover every aspect of the threat, from prevention to protection and prosecution’, and she is right. So yes, the EU must build a coherent internal security policy that delivers results and protects human rights. As co-legislator, Parliament has a key role to play in this by, for example, strengthening external border controls, and clearly cooperation on security and information-sharing is key to maintaining freedom of movement without internal border controls. And all of us will have to understand that our internal and external security is closely interwoven. In other words, internal and external security can no longer be kept separate. An integrated approach is needed. To give you a brief update on events: immediately after the attacks in Brussels we convened the Justice and Home Affairs Ministers for a meeting on 24 March. Vice-President Sylvie Guillaume was also present, together with representatives from Europol, Eurojust, the Schengen-associated countries and Interpol. The Belgian ministers briefed their colleagues about the attacks. In a joint statement the ministers condemned the attacks and extended our sympathy to the victims and their families and our support and solidarity to Belgium. They also set out a number of priority areas for action, building on the efforts which are already under way. We are not starting from scratch. Unfortunately, terrorism has been on the agenda for years and at the very forefront since the terrorist attacks in Paris in January 2015. Priorities have been agreed and considerable progress has been made towards implementation, as set out by the EU Counter-Terrorism Coordinator in his latest report of March 2016. But more needs to be done. The ministers’ statement once again underlines the urgent need to increase the amount of data systematically fed into the system, in both qualitative and quantitative terms, and to ensure consistent use of our different databases and their interoperability. We need to make optimal use of the tools we already have. Firstly, maximum feeding and use of the databases by Member States is crucial. SIS II and the focal point traveller at Europol are of particular importance. The Presidency is undertaking work to improve the use of SIS II, with the objective being to agree on a number of actions at the JHA Council in June. Secondly, the European Counter-Terrorism Centre at Europol (ECTC) has been operational since 1 January this year. The ECTC has been asked by France and Belgium to support the investigations after the November Paris attacks and the Brussels attacks, which Europol is doing, discovering links across the EU, which entails not only information collection and sharing but also analysis. Therefore, at the extraordinary meeting on 24 March, ministers decided to set up a joint liaison team of national counter-terrorism experts to support the Member States’ law enforcement authorities in investigating the wider European and international dimensions of the current terrorist threat. Thirdly, special attention will be given to the Commission communication on smart borders and interoperability which was issued last week. Improving the interoperability of the EU’s information system is a priority for the Presidency. It is important that customs, police and law enforcement officials can quickly and effectively consult our common databases. Privacy by design will, obviously, play a key role moving forward on this, and yes, Parliament’s role will be important once again. The Presidency wants ambitious results in June. Counter-terrorism has been added to the agenda of the Justice and Home Affairs Council in April. The roadmap with concrete deliverables on interoperability of databases and information-sharing and better use of information systems will be prepared for the June Council meeting, and there is more that we can do. Together we need to speed up the negotiation of pending legislation. I refer in particular to the Firearms Directive and the Terrorism Directive, as well as the targeted amendments to the Schengen Borders Code about systematic controls of EU citizens at EU external borders. As the statement of 24 March points out, we need preventive measures as well as repressive measures to effectively counter terrorism, which is why it is also important to make progress preventing radicalisation. As you know, the Radicalisation Awareness Network and its working groups are actively sharing experiences and best practices. The Internet Referral Unit at Europol will reach full operational capacity in 2016 and has already made significant headway in cooperation with internet companies to remove online terrorist material. We know there is a strong political will at Parliament to make progress on counter-terrorism measures. We share this determination and we look forward to working with you in order to advance as quickly and effectively as possible.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Madam President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, terrorists know no borders. They are striking in Europe, they are striking outside Europe, because they want to attack our way of life and all of our values. On March 22, they struck in Brussels, a city dear to us, a city we love, a city of our friendships and loves, a city where we are used to living in harmony with those we live with. The Commission is in mourning. She is in mourning because, in these cowardly attacks, we lost Patricia Rizzo, a young Italian woman full of energy, fine, intelligent, radiant. We'll remember it for a long time.  I would like to pay tribute to each of the victims, to have a thought for each of them, for each of these shattered lives, and I wish to give great courage to each of the injured and their families. Similarly, I would like to salute the daily work of all those through whom we can resume the usual course of our activities by feeling safe, while continuing to enjoy our freedoms and, in particular, that of travelling. It is our responsibility to provide them with all the necessary tools so that they can carry out their mission to the best of their ability. This is what the Commission has been working on for months, whether it is to improve air passenger screening, external border control, police and legal cooperation between Member States, not to mention the essential cooperation between the secret services. New momentum is needed today for greater sharing of this information and intelligence efforts. In this regard, cooperation is the strength.  Just last week, the Commission presented new proposals on the subject, including how current and future information systems could both improve the management of external borders and strengthen internal security in Europe. It should be noted, in fact, that there are already a number of information systems throughout the European Union that provide border guards and police with relevant information on the movement of people.  But as too often, when it comes to security issues, the problem is not so much the lack of tools as the lack of use of existing tools and especially the lack of cooperation. Relevant information exists, but it is too often lost and, too often, it comes too late. So we need to move towards more interconnection and interoperability.  The truth is that, whatever the quality of the Commission's legislative proposals, whatever the support of this Parliament or the sophistication of the systems used, the fight against terrorism in Europe will not be fully effective until the Member States are prepared to cooperate more with each other and with European agencies, including Europol.  That is why I would say that in the fight against terrorism, no one can afford to give lessons to anyone, and especially not to Belgium, which, I would like to say here, is a great country that is heavily tested. No condescension towards Belgium! (Applause) Let us not forget that this is not the first time that heavy and indiscriminate terrorism has struck in Europe and, if there is a failure, it is first and foremost a collective failure. We have been vowing for decades to learn all the lessons from such attacks. I remember the European councils in 1999 and again in 2001 when, together with my friend Guy Verhofstadt and others, we vowed to establish a genuine exchange of information between intelligence services.  Now is the time to take action. In the area of security, as in many other areas in Europe, it is fragmentation that makes us vulnerable. Europe needs a true security union. I am counting on the support of this Parliament to bring to fruition every proposal that the Commission has already put forward and which may be precursors to this security union which I would like to see put in place in the long run.  In the aftermath of the November 2015 attacks in Paris, the European Commission presented a package of legislative and non-legislative proposals to make it more difficult to acquire firearms in Europe. It took the Commission six days to come up with proposals. Today, six months later, I see no concrete sign that they will be adopted soon.  The Commission, however, continues to do its job. In a few weeks, we will present an update on the progress of our safety program as well as a roadmap ambitious in its content and timetable, with new measures to be implemented. The Commission must be able to count on the cooperation of the European Parliament and the Council. It is about the security and freedoms of our citizens. It is a common responsibility first. (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Madam President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Council for his excellent work and for the work she has done on this First of all, I am grateful to Jean-Claude Juncker for making it clear what we are talking about today. We are talking about the 37-year-old mother who died at the airport and is leaving behind twins, about the 30-year-old illustrator of children's books who loved the city of Brussels and who dies in the metro, and we are talking about the young Muslim teacher who was on the metro on her way to school. Three examples, three innocents, three victims. This is an attack on us Europeans that has taken place there. First of all, to think of the victims is our PPE-DE objective. The second thing, ladies and gentlemen, is to say thank you – the firefighter who arrives at the scene shortly after the attacks, completely smokes without knowing whether there are any further threats, and yet helps the nurses who have worked long hours to help the people, and the policemen and, by the way, the soldiers who stand in front of our facilities here in Strasbourg and Brussels. to ensure our safety. Thank you very much to all these forces defending Europe! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The third thing we need to address is the question of our responsibility. Within the framework of legislation, we must ask ourselves the question: are we doing enough? Ladies and gentlemen, no, it is not enough what we do. More security requires more cooperation in Europe. That is why the Commission – Commissioner Avramopoulos and our President of the Commission – can count on the support of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats when it comes to this new common European security agency. We need networking. The secrecy of the Member States must finally come to an end. And the interior ministers have a great responsibility to finally put an end to this secrecy. We need better handling of data. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has been calling for months that we need passenger data. They won't solve all the problems, but it's an important tool to move forward. That is why we are pleased that, after much pressure, we will finally be voting on the issue of passenger data on Thursday. It is exciting for our investigative authorities to know who regularly flies to Syria, who regularly flies to Afghanistan. We must have this data. And we need more. We currently have an agreement with the Americans on the evaluation of financial flows, the so-called TFTP agreement. In other words, we are offering our bank data to the Americans so that they can evaluate how terror is financed. I ask myself the question: why do we not do this ourselves? Why is Europe not itself in a position to analyse its own data and to know how terror is financed? We do not have a TFTP in the European Union, but the Americans are, so to speak, our subcontractor. I want to do this independently in the European Union with European data protection standards. That is why we need more commitment. Europol: Voluntary information collection has failed. We need a Europol that has the right to request and request information from the Member States, not to provide information on a voluntary basis. Last but not least, the Internet has lost its innocence. We have room for hatred on the Internet, we have room on the Internet for recruiting new terrorists that are taking place there, for agitation against our principles. That is why it is the duty of the Internet companies to ensure that we play the rules on the Internet. And we need a European structure – a networking authority – that makes it clear that not everything is allowed on the Internet. We need this new European security agency, and the Commission will have our support in this. The Ppe-DE is ready. Finally, I would like to say one more thought: the terrorists basically want to fight our way of life, freedom, liberality, the joy of life. They want to replace them with fear, anger and also hatred. And that is why the most important thing we, as Europeans, can give in response to this terrorism, is simply to continue to practice our lives, simply to live as we see fit. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Weber, I have great respect for what you say and I agree with many. But I have two questions: you say that it is exciting for the investigating authorities to know who is on flights to Europe, for example. Do you know that we have known this for years? Whoever sits in which seat on each aircraft is already being charged today.  Do you know that the European Court of Justice says that when it comes to collecting personal data, the measuring stick that must be used to store that data is 'necessary in a democratic society' and not 'exciting'?

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Honestly, you are stunned by what is going on. When we have the political debate about the fact that we, as Europeans, are being challenged by terror, we are stunned by the fact that some of the questions that are coming – I may say so. We want high levels of data protection, and we now have high levels of data protection enshrined in The PNR legislation– as well as in the data protection regulation that you are responsible for.  We are not going down an American path of the fight against terror, we are going down a European path. But it's also clear that data is powerful tools in the world we live in today– as Google and Facebook prove every day. That is why we must also give our authorities legal, legally secured access to this data. That is why PNR is necessary, and I am very grateful for the question.  It becomes clear who wants to equip our authorities in the fight against terror and who refuses to provide them.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the last year, unfortunately, this House has unfortunately been called upon to discuss terrorism many times over the past year.  The uniqueness of life, of the life that Patricia Rizzo and many others have lost, the idea that every life is sacred is the legacy on which contemporary society was built. I say this because I believe that, in order to combat terrorism, we must first of all ask ourselves how it is possible that our children have come to deny the heart of our civilisation.  I know it is a sensitive subject, but I do not believe that Islam is behind this ideology of death. I think that rather than questioning radical Islam, we should ask ourselves about the radicalisation of Islam. These criminals do not espouse Islam, which is a religion of peace, but instead espouse desperate radicalism, they are, in short, the children of the uprooting of global society. More than the result of religious awareness, they are the poisoned fruits of a multiculturalism that in many cases has failed. Behind the rhetoric of multiculturalism, communi communitism has often been hidden, that is, the idea that men and women of different origins cannot live together, but must each be in separate social groups that then end up being ghettos.  The first response to this attack is therefore to rediscover the reasons that unite us and to reaffirm a citizenship that involves rights, but also common values and duties. This reasoning must then be accompanied by urgent actions: first of all, national governments must implement existing instruments such as the exchange of DNA data, the exchange of fingerprint data.  Against terrorism the main weapons are intelligence and investigations, Europe is lagging behind, unfortunately terrorists strike us in our uniqueness and we respond divided. We must therefore create European intelligence, not yet another coordination structure, but a single intelligence service that collects and networks information, and we also need a European counter-terrorism super-prosecutor capable of conducting investigations throughout the Union and then we also need determination in foreign policy.  I continue to support with great conviction the things that Federica Mogherini is doing, we must be serious. Isis is also there because it is part of a cynical game of regional interests. In order to defeat Isis, we must start by combating those who buy oil produced by Isis in the areas that govern Isis and those who procure its goods. The West cannot, with one hand, attack Isis and do business with those who feed Isis, none of us have the magic wand to defeat terrorism, but we can all provide cohesion, intelligence and humility.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it is rather sad that it is often at moments like this that we as a Chamber come together. We all come together to condemn the acts that we have seen over the last few months, in fact years, in many of our countries. But after each attack we have questions. A few days after the Brussels attacks, a man in my constituency tweeted how he had confronted a Muslim woman in Croydon in South London, and asked her ‘to explain Brussels’. His tweet upset a lot of people. Another Twitter user replied: ‘What has a Muslim woman in Croydon, South London, got to do with the horrific events in Belgium?’ So while his original tweet may have been offensive or clumsy, it also demonstrates that we are all looking for answers, whether we have no faith, another faith or are Muslims. We all want to explain Brussels: a city we know so well, whose citizens have buried family, colleagues and friends prematurely after these appalling acts. Last month I opened a conference of the European Parliament, organised by the Iman Foundation, on tackling extremism and terrorism. What was interesting about this conference was that while there may be people here in this Chamber who call for more European agencies to solve all these problems, none of the speakers or experts present there claimed that there was a single solution or metaphorical silver bullet. Instead they spoke about the need to tackle terrorism at various levels: at an international level, militarily, through use of intelligence and diplomacy; at a national level, upholding the rule of law, defence of our values and security of our citizens; and at a local community level to tackle extremism at its roots. We spoke about the drivers of terrorism: some searching for an identity or a sense of belonging, others radicalised in prisons; some violent individuals looking for a new cause, others with grievances over perceived unfair foreign policy; yet others who are vulnerable and fooled into believing there is a final shortcut to paradise in a world of temptation. While we debate these issues here today, are we really clear about what we as MEPs can do to tackle this issue? Yes, we can vote for a new PNR system that takes account of concerns over data protection and civil liberties. Yes, we could encourage our intelligence agencies to work together. But this will only happen if they can trust each other and feel confident enough to share information, not if you force them. But for those of us who represent constituencies where young people have been radicalised, allow me to suggest one more thing we can do. At the Iman conference last month I invited the Unity of Faiths Foundation (TUFF FC project) from London to speak about how they harness the power of football to give a sense of team spirit and instil British values in youngsters from different religions. At the project I had met a young lady who told me how she almost went to Syria, after being recruited via social media such as Snapchat. The project's founder, when he found out about this, made a few phone calls and gave her the choice of going through the gate of the airport to Syria or the gates of the stadium of the Premier League team that she supported. When she arrived at the stadium she was so overcome that she knelt down to kiss the pitch and now through her experience encourages others not to be recruited to terrorism. Think of how much death and destruction that one act could have prevented; and as the project’s founder said, one of the best ways to counter terrorism is to prevent people from becoming terrorists. There must be similar projects in many of our cities that we can support and encourage, and if not, let me know, since TUFF is willing to come to your town or city to help set up a similar project. So, whilst we may not be able to ‘explain Brussels’, we may be able to help stop more attacks by encouraging cooperation across intelligence and security services, by giving security and law enforcement agencies whatever tools we can in a free and open society and by supporting projects that stop young people becoming terrorists and by all of us saying that we will not treat all Muslims with suspicion. We will not drive more people into the arms of extremists. We will not let the terrorists win. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kamal, last year in Paris a young Romanian couple were shot dead sitting at table on a terrace in Paris. Afterwards the European Union, together with Europol, set up a centre to counter terrorism in The Hague, with 45-50 staff. It is a small measure to counter terrorism. Do you not think that the European Union needs a real agency to counter terrorism, with a special intelligence service to counter terrorism and special anti-terrorist troops to be pooled by the Member States to finally fight this terrible situation?

name: Syed Kamall (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for your question, but actually the answer is no. What we need is better sharing of intelligence. When you speak to intelligence experts, they in fact say – in their candid moments – that they do not have confidence in the intelligence services in other countries. How do we make sure we build that trust so that intelligence can be shared? Let us get away from the idea that, whatever the problem, the solution is more Europe and more agencies. Actually, if we sit in these European agencies, we will ignore the young people in many of our communities who have been radicalised at grassroots level. For far too long we have ignored this because we want to make grand speeches in this Chamber about European solutions. What we can do is to encourage these organisations to learn from each other and come together, but what we cannot do is use it as an excuse for yet more meetings in Brussels.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the first thing I would like to do is to thank Jean-Claude Juncker for his words for my country, Belgium. I agree with him that what we must not do now is repeat the ritual of using strong words and making solemn declarations. Now is the moment to act and to make a number of changes. I fully agree with him. This is the opposite of what Mr Kamall is saying; it is fragmentation which is the problem in Europe, and our intelligence services and police services have to work better with each other. Well, I can tell you, Mr Kamall, that we have been hearing this so-called recipe for decades. It is not a recipe. We need European capacities; this is also the lesson from history. In America the Federal Bureau of Investigation was created in 1901 after the terrorist attack where President McKinley, the President of the USA at that time, was killed. In Germany it was exactly the same story. The Bundeskriminalamt was upgraded and was created as a federal agency after the Rote Armee Fraktion attacks. That was their lesson from history, and it is time, Mr Kamall, that your Group also learned that lesson, and that we created European capacities and European capabilities to solve the problem. Let us be honest. Let us face the reality. I have here the long list of all the terrorist attacks in recent years. In Madrid the perpetrators were known to the French and British police. In London the attackers responsible for the bombing were followed and even partially arrested by the French police. The attack on a Jewish Museum in Brussels was by a French terrorist known to the French authorities and even by the German intelligence services. It is the same story for Charlie Hebdo. They were known by the British authorities before the attacks. The same goes for Abdeslam, who was not stopped at the roadblock in Cambrai because the French did not have him in their files, while the Belgians knew very well who he was. The same goes for what the Germans did a few weeks before the attacks in Paris. They found weapons and did not inform their French colleagues at that time. The same is now true again in the attacks in Brussels, where apparently the Swedish had information and did not send it to the Belgian authorities. How many attacks, Mr Kamall, are still needed before everybody understands that we need a real investigation capacity at European level as quickly as possible? Let us face the reality. We have the possibility to do so. Terrorists do not know borders. It is our police services and our intelligence services who know borders. We have the possibility now to change that and to build that up, Mr Avramopoulos, because we have the file on Europol. We have finished the second reading. My proposal is to use the second reading between Parliament and Council to make a few amendments; not to delay it again until the end of the year, but to act immediately in the coming weeks. There are three changes that can be made. First of all, change the regulation of Europol in Articles 1 and 3 and give them the possibility of having an investigation capacity and not only a coordination role. That is the first proposal. My second proposal is that we amend Article 6 of the regulation to finally give Europol the possibility to launch an investigation or oblige national authorities to do so. They do not even have that possibility today. Finally, and maybe the most important problem, Article 7 of the regulation, Mr Avramopoulos, currently says that the national authorities of Europol have to filter the information to Europol. I thought what they had to do was the opposite, namely to transfer the relevant data to Europol. So my proposal is that, instead of talking again about coordination, coordination, cooperation, cooperation – enough of these words – we use the Europol file to put that in place and also to change the role of the European prosecutor, because the European prosecutor cannot only be responsible for financial fraud. We need to change that so that the prosecutor is also responsible for transnational crimes like, for example, terrorism. So that is my proposal: rather than making minor fixes to an old Europol file, to use it in the coming weeks to make a leap forward and to do what the Americans did 115 years ago. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the This will be my last question and I hope that I will not be insulted again for a factual question.  In any case, I am concerned with the question: you are pointing out here that it was always known in recent attacks – Brussels, Copenhagen, Paris – which perpetrators carried out the attacks. Nevertheless, here, as the Liberal Group, you are in favour of the indiscriminate storage of passenger data, which is not at all capable of remedying this maladministration and which is capable of tying up the hundreds of millions of euros that we would need in order to invest it in an effective Europol and joint investigation teams under this umbrella.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – All storage of data can be useful, including passenger name records, on the condition that there is the capacity to analyse it, to transfer it from one authority to the other, and that there are no walls between the different databases. That is why I am proposing this European capacity for intelligence and this European capacity for investigation. Besides the fact that we are going to create 28 databases, it is also necessary that the Commission comes forward as soon as possible with a horizontal system for mandatory sharing of information, without which it is a useless tool. That is also an initiative I am asking of the Commission.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, first of all I would like to reiterate on behalf of GUE/NGL our anguish and resuation at the recent terrorist attacks in Brussels. Our thoughts are with the victims of the attacks and their families and we express our sympathy and solidarity with the Belgian, French and other peoples who are experiencing terrorism. Because, ladies and gentlemen, the innocent people who pay a death toll because of fanaticism and intolerance are not only in Europe, they are also in Lebanon in Pakistan, India, Tunisia, Iraq, Syria and elsewhere.  These criminal attacks and the rise of fundamentalism are the direct consequence of the wars created by interventions, it is the unfair distribution of wealth and the political interference of the major powers in the internal affairs of the countries. The European Union is not without responsibility. We must remember that large Member States have stubbornly followed American imperialism and have politically and economically supported all the extreme Islamist organisations, of which the terrorist monster of ISIS has emerged.  But the peoples of Europe have a historic duty not to succumb to the Islamophobic, racist slurs of the far right that wants to target foreigners, refugees and Muslims, inside and outside Europe. If European societies accept that their security depends on new draconian measures of file, mass surveillance, further reduction of individual rights and freedoms, then this will be a retreat and defeat of democratic values in the face of terrorism. The best and most effective way to deal with the dark forces of terrorism is through the war against injustice, against widening economic inequalities, against interventions and wars that breed the monster of terrorism.  It is also a fact that the terrorists of Paris and Brussels were naturalised Europeans, born in Europe, and this demonstrates the failure of the migrant integration systems, and I would like to congratulate President Juncker, because from the very first moment he noted this very fact by declaring that the fight against terrorism does not go through the creation of more democracy, but through the strengthening of those social policies that will bring social development, justice and solidarity.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how can we not be appalled by the irretrievable loss of these human lives, by the upheaval of these lives, which are forever bruised, by these coldly prepared acts of death? With all our hearts, we are with the victims of these despicable acts and with their loved ones. But how can we not be worried when danger creeps into the most innocuous gestures and movements of our daily lives? How can we not be outraged by the fact that, as Guy Verhofstadt very well said, most of the perpetrators of these attacks and those in Paris were long-known, but that, for lack of information sharing and, above all, for lack of exploitation, they were left free to move?  How can we not be outraged that even today our countries trade, including arms, with the States of the Middle East which promote the most violent and fundamentalist forms of Islam? Finally, how can we fail to question what has created a breeding ground within our societies for hate speech and violence - discrimination, inequality, exclusion, the reduction of human beings to a factor of production or consumption? Ladies and gentlemen, if we were to respond to these attacks by setting up police states, constantly monitoring the least of our actions, by an even greater stigmatization of our fellow Muslims, by the closure of our society on itself and by the adoption of a warlike rhetoric separating the world between "them" and "us", the terrorists would have won. On the contrary, the best answer we can offer them is the one that combines Belgian and European currencies so well, "unity in diversity is strength". Let us face them, intelligently joining forces to derail their murderous projects, but above all by ensuring that our societies put the human dignity, the dignity of every human being, back at the heart of their project. I would like to finish, Mr President, if I may, with a short quote from my Corsican friend Jean-François Bernardini "do not excuse anything, forget nothing, resist, seek to understand, otherwise we maintain evil. Darkness, you can't fight it with darkness. Hatred is not fought with hate. Eye for the eye and the universe, our entire planet, will become blind." Paris has left us 130 reasons to live, struggle and believe; Brussels gives us 32 more. Thank you.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Sylikiotis, it seemed to me to understand in your speech a mea culpa for the attacks. I wanted to know if you're one of those people who think it's our fault to be killed.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), answer to a question with a "blue card". – First of all, we must not forget that terrorism is born of specific ideas. But, as I said in my first intervention, ISIS, like other extreme fundamentalist Islamist groups, was supported by Western countries. They were supported by large states, both economically and militarily and politically.  Even today, they have trade relations with some countries that are our allies, the West I mean, like Saudi Arabia, like Turkey, and they are supported by these countries economically and commercially. Therefore, the European Union also has responsibilities for the promotion of terrorism, and we must never forget that.

name: Diane James
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the fundamental EU principle of freedom of movement for people, services and goods may well have been well intentioned, but it can only remain so if it is reactive and updated, ideally integrating and responding to both external and internal threats and pressures. Its fundamental weaknesses lie in the turgid, lengthy and often outdated processes required to address what are now fast-moving events, not merely on the European continent but also on a global scale; but more fundamentally in the sacrosanct protection that it enjoys in the face of fundamental threats to civil society and citizens. Trying to connect 28 Member States’ varied cultures and processes at a time of crisis, the EU is unable to anticipate events or to react at adequate speed to these events. This is not an approach capable of countering let alone beating terrorism. When there is a threat, it is important to think like the adversary and not bury oneself in mindless dialogue and consultation with the objective of protecting a sacred cow. The United Kingdom endured some 30 years of conflict and terrorist activities before a resolution in Northern Ireland was found. The UK has much to offer the European and international community on how to counter terrorism: not least money-laundering, a key element in terrorist funding and financing. But in contrast, the EU seems purely focused on unified border control and a central intelligence agency. But these so far have been total failures, critical weaknesses serving only to facilitate the recent terrorist atrocities. Now again, the United Kingdom has led the way in combating international counter-terrorist efforts via the Five Eyes, Signet and as a founding member of the Global Counter-Terrorism Forum, and the UK will maintain those responsibilities, EU member or not. In contrast, the EU reaction to the migrant crisis has been unhelpful in the extreme and its reactions unhelpful and just like those of a rabbit in the headlights. The EU has its border control agency Frontex, which consumes several hundred million euros but is not operational and is little more than a data collection and analysis agency. It produces reports and stats, fine; it is supposed to coordinate the activities of Member States in border control according to its charter, but in fact it has no operational capability, and it has to rely on NATO, individual Member States and other operational forces to do anything useful. Indeed, we have a basic conflict of interests here for Frontex in that the EU mantra is open borders with no control. The EU probably never imagined that its open border mantra would encourage the movement of criminals, terrorists and weapons. The result has been that a number of countries have had to take unilateral action to defend their borders and actually, as a result, break their Treaty obligations. But just look at INTCEN, set up as a fledgling European intelligence agency: yet another failure, doing little more than gathering data. The collection of data, such as fingerprints (already mentioned by others) at the borders within Europe, has been a disastrous example. Only 17% of migrants at key points of entry have been fingerprinted, and to make matters worse, even if their fingerprints have been taken, no one within the Member States has been allowed to share that data. There could be no greater gift to terrorism than being invisible and untraceable, yet this is what the European Union approach facilitates. We have talked about PNR, but that is stuck in turgid debate, as we well know. But there are issues about privacy and human rights, and I do wonder, having been criticised for the comment on frontier Europe, are we not actually building that? For too many in this Parliament, the response is: for rectification of these failures, we need more Europe. And we heard that this afternoon. Why would anyone pour more money into an approach and into structures that are broken, ill-conceived and ineffective? These can be addressed, but just not by doing more of the same; that is the definition of an idiot. It could well be argued that the EU should stick to matters that it can usefully address and do well, but stay out of matters where it does not have the experience or capability. General Michael Hayden, ex-head of the NSA in the US, said security is a national issue. Now is the time for the EU and Parliament to open their eyes to what is going on and bear in mind that the future is – and this should be recognised – bilateral agreements based on good data exchange. Trusted data exchange and experience is the way forward, not trying to coerce 28 Member States to do one thing.

name: Marcel de Graaff
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. I extend my condolences to the victims and survivors of the recent attacks in Brussels.  It is incredibly wry that these attacks could have been prevented. The national borders should have been closed long ago, because these heroes of Islam travelled freely between the Netherlands and Belgium. The fight against Islam should have started long ago, because Islamic ghettos are cheering and protecting these Islamic heroes.  Let me be clear, Mr President, I see it this way: you too are morally responsible for these attacks, as are many other MEPs, Commissioners and national heads of government, all of whom are calling for open borders and a welcome to migrants from Muslim countries. And more people are going to die, thanks in part to you. How hypocritical was the commemoration of the victims of these attacks in this Parliament? Grieve for the victims, while part of this Parliament itself maintains the conditions for attacks. Moreover, israel should not have been missing from the queue of countries affected by attacks! Any form of counter-terrorism begins with the recognition of the cause of terrorism. You do not want to acknowledge this cause or name it. The cause of terrorism worldwide is Islam. Islam has been an ideology of terror for 1,400 years. The so-called "religion of peace" has killed at least 240 million people! Islam is not compatible with our Western values, Islam is not integrated into our Western culture. To you and to the European Commission, I say: recognise your failure and step up. Let someone else tackle this problem! Because the approach to counter-terrorism is clear: close national borders, stop mass immigration and stop Islam!  (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question. – Do you really think that closing borders will be the solution to address this? Do you really think that with the Netherlands you will only fight this terror?
