I have to tell you honestly: my stomach turns when I hear your speech. If you think that all The Islamulous believers are terrorists, I would ask you to read the history books very carefully. I think you're just going to scare people away with your argument. Let us use this hemisphere to make honest comments on these crimes.

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. – Here, too, I hear the typical look away, deny, ignore and downplay the problem as it really is before us. It is in Belgium itself, in Molenbeek, and in all those other parts of Brussels, where people were dancing and cheering in the streets when the attacks on Zaventem and maalbeek took place. And then we still get these kind of stupid questions. I throw that far from me!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again we have held a minute's silence in memory of the victims of the recent Brussels terrorist attack. Mr President, you told us that we will not forget the victims. Unfortunately, we will forget and talk about them if there is a new terrorist attack. The only ones they won't forget are the relatives and friends of the victims. Don't let fear, you told us, become hatred. I don't know if there's going to be hatred, but I'm sure there's going to be rage. Anger at us for trying to shield and protect life in Europe. The enemy is known. They are the ones who, in the name of God, take innocent lives. It is the action of the Islamic caliphate and fanatical Muslims across the globe. There was terrorism before the emergence of the caliphate, so it will exist after its elimination, as long as there are fanatics. Terrorists use migration flows and can move virtually uncontrollably between European states and training camps. It is the incompatibility of most forms of Islam with European values that will always lead to extreme confrontations.  We have to deal with the very root of the problem. Anyone who lives or wants to live in Europe must first and for all embrace European values and principles. Not our own ideas, but of European citizens. Otherwise, the result will always be tragic.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by protesting that the president and the presidents of the far-right and far-left groups are not present in such an important debate as this. I think it's unfortunate. If the dead had occurred in Britain or occurred in France, we would have had them all here noticing. And instead, we've heard them say things like Islam is a terrorist ideology or that Europe is to blame for terrorism. Things like that can't you tell the victims by looking them in the eye. And I ask you, Mr President, to demand a correction from the two parliamentary groups which have said here that Europe is guilty of terrorism or that Islam is a terrorist ideology. That's not how we fight terrorism. (Applause) What we say in this House is heard outside. If we sow fear, we'll gather fear. If we sow a grudge, we'll gather hate. And if we sow division, we'll collect misunderstanding. As Malala would say, a policeman can arrest a terrorist, but only politics can end terrorism. But a policy that is made from unity, a policy that is made by understanding and including victims, a policy that is made clear that well-being and prosperity are not only yearnings of the West, but belong to all humanity. It's not the Muslims, it's not the refugees; they're the terrorists. Islam is not a terrorist. Jihadism is an ideology, not a religion. That's why jihadism isn't just about cops. You also struggle with pencils; you struggle with books; you struggle with schools. Ladies and gentlemen, we cannot face terrorism if we do not know what we are dealing with. They are not enemies of any country; are enemies of freedom. We are living in such a paradoxical situation that we are erecting walls in Europe to stop refugees, because we are afraid of them. And they are the victims, when their executioners, their persecutors are born, educated and live among us. If we close the walls, we will not let the victims in and be left alone in our countries with the executioners. European values are the solution, but if we continue like this, we will end up making politics and Europe the problem. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), "blue card" question. Mr González, you may have misunderstood or not listened very well to what I said. I didn't talk about all Muslims. I talked about the fanatical Islamists. The shouting when they do the terrorist acts, "Allahu Akbar", tells you anything? They murder innocent people in the name of God, their own.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Dear colleague, I did not misunderstand your words because I did not mean you, but the National Front, which, at the time of the Paris attacks, had Marine Le Pen here, together with all of us, asking for a reaction from Europe and, now that the attacks have taken place in Belgium, it seems that it does not hurt the same.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Mr President, on 22 March, barbarism caused us to fall into horror. On 22 March, terrorism struck us in the heart, the heart of Europe. On March 22, we were all victims to varying degrees of these attacks, which are nothing more than attacks targeting our rights, our freedoms, our way of life.  In the face of these sickening acts, we must stand and uncompromisingly stand in the face of those who want to shed blood and install a regime of terror. We must not concede any of our democratic advances, because if the democrats flee, it is the terrorists and the fascists who will occupy the ground. Colleagues, we must forget our political differences and, together, take the necessary actions to put these atrocities to an end. We must focus on security, a fundamental right for all citizens. You can't feel free in fear. We need to strengthen both prevention and repression.  Across Europe, our police, judicial, intelligence and defence agencies must work together in perfect harmony, and above all exchange more effectively the data they collect, as has been pointed out. We must guarantee peace to our fellow citizens. Only together can we defeat terrorism.  It is also clear that, under the mandate of the United Nations, Daesh must be put out of harm's way, and we must allow this part of the world to live in peace and stability. Colleagues, a word to conclude: nothing will ever overcome our values and principles. Solidarity, tolerance, living together will never fall under the bullets of any terrorist. Whether or not these barbarians like it, because there is no other word to describe their actions, we will continue to fight for our freedom, our freedoms, and this will pass through more Europe, no matter what Mr Kamall does. This will go through more Europe and better Europe!

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – First of all, on behalf of my delegation, I would also like to express my condolences to the families of the terror that struck my city on 22 March. We wish all those who have been affected or injured much strength and a speedy recovery. I would also like to pay tribute to our emergency services and law enforcement. The attacks in Brussels a stone's throw from my office and from my home town have shocked us deeply. Brussels is the city where I spent my childhood, Brussels is in my pocket. True people in Brussels are open and tolerant, have a sense of humour and love life, which is why terror affects us so deeply in our hearts and souls.  I am therefore well aware, first-hand, that citizens are also counting on us so that they can feel safe again. The European Union can indeed provide added value through targeted initiatives. What my delegation therefore expects from this Parliament is that it fully supports useful new legislation, such as those on European passenger data. The fact that this dossier was blocked in this house despite great efforts by national authorities is a pity! The fact that this dossier was thwarted even after Paris in this house is disgraceful! How ironic is it that some here are calling for a European FBI and therefore for an amendment of treaties - Mr Verhofstadt is unfortunately already gone - but at the same time blocking legislative proposals aimed at exchanging information? And don't doubt it: Syrian fighters, Europeans, return to Europe on the instruction of IS to shed blood. Is it really so much to put aside the usual dogmas and interests so that these people no longer slip through the cracks? I call for this proposal to be supported on Thursday. I turn to the Council: certain Member States are less industrious in exchanging information. The new anti-terrorism cell within Europol must become a hub of cooperation, otherwise we will not be able to do so! Do data exchange!  I am also addressing the Commission with a very specific question - as Mr Juncker mentioned earlier about the poor use of existing information - how is it that Europol barely looks up data in the European databases of Fish, Sis and Eurodac, which contains wanted persons? The Agency was authorised to do so, but that possibility is being underused, as you published last week. How did this happen?

name: Sophia in’t Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I think we have to note that the so-called war on terror has failed. For 15 years now, since 9/11, we have been passing one measure after the other, and every time the terrorists are one step ahead. It is high time we rethink our strategy and do not, after every attack, in a Pavlov reflex, talk about new megalomaniac IT systems – because what we need is not more dots, but to connect the dots. I have been listening to the debate on PNR for many years now. There is not a debate that is as fact-free as the debate on PNR. There is a lot of genuine ignorance, but also a lot of lies. I would really like to know what has been keeping the Member States from setting up national PNR systems. As a matter of fact, they have received EUR 50 million from the Commission for setting up those systems. We do not know what happened to the money. France, which has been pushing for PNR, received EUR 18 million. What has happened to the money? They have got the legislation in place. So, instead of talking about new IT systems all the time, what we need is, firstly, mandatory information-sharing – and I do not understand why the PPE and the ECR are categorically opposed to this. Secondly, we need human intelligence and, thirdly, prevention. That is what we should be investing in, because that will bring greater security to citizens and not just talk, talk, talk about IT systems. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Ms in 't Veld, you have said that this Parliament has failed to implement measures to protect its citizens and that what we must do is join the dots in order to do so. To quote, for example, the former Secretary-General of Interpol, Ronald K. Noble, who understands terrorism on the international stage: is he someone who has failed to join the dots when he describes Europe’s open border arrangement, which allows travel through 26 countries without passport checks or border controls, as, in effect, an international passport-free zone in which terrorists can carry out attacks on the continent and make their escape? Has he failed to join the dots, or is it you?

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Woolfe, first of all I did not say that this Parliament has failed to implement; quite the opposite. I said that we have been passing one legislative measure after another and actually, like data retention, it is not being implemented by the Member States, and we will have the same problem with the PNR Directive. But you cannot deny – and certainly not after the Brussels and Paris attacks – that so much information on the terrorists was available and it has not been shared. It has been sitting in a drawer and it was not used. Whether we are talking about 9/11, Boston, Toulouse, London, Madrid, Brussels, Paris, the killing of Theo van Gogh, Mumbai: in every single case, the terrorists were known to the authorities beforehand, but they failed to share the information. They need to connect the dots; that is what they need to start doing.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the If we analyse the terrorist attacks with their truly cruel effects, it is clear that it is of course important to track down and hold the perpetrators to account as quickly as possible. And, of course, we need to cooperate better, that is clear. But you can't take one measure after another and one old boot after another out of the shoe compartment. We need to do something else: promote the cohesion of society. We must do something for the cohesion of society. And the police and the judiciary are not enough for this. As long as relevant sections of the population are speechless – as it is – as long as certain groups are socially and economically marginalized, we have a gateway for ISIS – that is fact – and because they do not find themselves in their social life, in our social life. We must not simply leave these mostly young people to the terrorist militias and write them off, but we must work with administrations, social workers, schools and religious communities, as we do in Mechelen, for example. Without the help of the Muslims – you will not like it – without the help of the Muslims, the IS terror cannot be stopped. And we have to accept that. We too must make a difference and not just carry on. We need a holistic approach with which we operate, and we must finally dry up all sources, really all sources of terrorism.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, terrorism has once again hit hard. After Paris, Brussels, but also Tunis, Bamako, Istanbul, Baghdad, Kabul, Lahore and so many other cities still bruised. Collect, heal the wounds first. Act and then prevent. But prevent intelligently, without falling into the escalation of false solutions, effective only in appearance. Reassuring citizens is essential, but actually protecting them without false promises, that is where your priority must be. We will not give up our fundamental freedoms. To those who want to make it seem that an almighty state, in which every citizen is a suspect, always monitored, sometimes under house arrest, is infallible, I say that they are liars in the service of their sole ambition. What has been lacking is not information, it is once again cooperation between our Member States, it is the exchange of information, and when information is exchanged, it is not properly processed. These flaws are partly due to this lack of European ambition that paralyzes everything from the economy to the fight against terrorism to the treatment of refugees.  Finally, work on establishing effective cooperation, creating the area of freedom, security and justice that the European Union must be.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, the tragedy in Brussels, a few months after the appalling attacks in Paris, has once again come to show the failures of your Europe, this colander which allows all criminals, all traffickers, all terrorists to move and act freely.  Again, you are trying to sell to the people that it is through a federal seal that a solution can be found. It's not true! The only thing that can stop criminals are the national borders, the ones you have destroyed, national controls, police resources, customs, which European austerity has also largely eroded. It is the states that have the competence, the capacity, the duty, the responsibility to secure our citizens. By weakening them, the European Union has seriously endangered the lives of hundreds of our compatriots.  Your European agencies have never worked and will never work. Weakened, national services are no longer able to cooperate effectively. Your European agencies will not be able and have never been able to replace them. They only contribute to the crumbling, ineffective and often liberticidal dusting of means. It is no coincidence that it is in one of the weakest states in the European Union that radical terrorist Islamism has largely taken refuge. Your so-called capital of Europe, left to all communitarianism, has unfortunately become a capital of crime. Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, your ideology blinds you and renders you incapable of anticipating anything. However, the Islamic State group had announced that it would use the flow of migrants to infiltrate terrorists, suicide bombers who would kill us. How did you think he wouldn't? I remember in this Chamber that we were laughed at when we sounded the alarm. You deliver the migrants to the traffickers, you enrich the Turkish state whose game in Syria is more than murky, you let the terrorists in and circulate. The European Union's responsibility for these tragedies is terrifying.  Wherever you could go wrong, you were wrong. You should humbly confess your faults and give back to the people the freedom they demand by voting when given the opportunity, for example in the Netherlands and soon in the United Kingdom, against the abominable Europeanist chimera.  Your dear European Union is in danger of disappearing, so much the better! It will be more security, more freedom, more democracy and more prosperity.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The Minister representing the European Council began her speech by referring to the need to protect people's rights. I hope that, for once, we are talking about the rights of citizens of European nations. Because in this parliament, when I hear about human rights, it's always been the right of migrants. Returning to Parliament on Monday, I saw posters of four lectures on the protection of migrants, and none on the events in Cologne.  Of course, there is also a need for coordinated intelligence cooperation against terrorism. But first and foremost, we need to face up to the situation that Europe is in. There's been a terrible act of terrorism in Madrid, London. But what we need to see now is that a war has started against Europe, and only one part of this is horrific acts of terrorism, the other part is flooding Europe with migrants who cannot and do not want to fit in. Thank you very much!

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Firstly, one point: in the fight against terrorism, data exchange is a very important function. Of course, there are shortcomings on the part of the Member States, which do not exchange enough data, are sometimes too slow and have not set up enough in the institutions to exchange data precisely. However, there is also a problem here in this Parliament. Every time it comes to making databases interoperable, there were always concerns, especially on the part of the left of the house, but also, dear Sophie in 't Veld, partly by yourself too. If, for example, Eurodac was to make it accessible to the police and law enforcement authorities to make automatic data matching with the SIS databases, this is not yet possible. In other words, we need data exchange and interoperability, but here too we need confidence in our security authorities, and we must give them the tools to make the best use of the necessary databases in order to make the best use of the data. We need confidence in Europol and, dear Jan Philipp Albrecht, when you say here that Europol should be expanded, then I would like the Greens to vote positively next time on our motions – when it comes to strengthening Europol, better equipping Europol with staff. We must stop standing in each other's way here in this House, but we must also accompany things in a positive way. Thirdly, I would like to see the terrorism directive, the issue, stop people travelling at risk – not those who are already being sought, but those who are in a dangerous environment – stop them travelling, no matter in which direction we inform each other and also prevent them from doing so. I hope that we will be able to stop radicalisation on the Internet, because the Internet must not be a lawless area, but must be just as much a legal area as the normal world in which we live here. And on the subject of terrorist financing, we also have a great deal to do and to do to dry up the ways of financing the terrorists are getting money. Let us work together here and not work against each other, and the pnron system is one point among the other building blocks.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: First of all, I would also like to express my condolences to the victims of this terrible act. It didn't just deeply concern the Belgians. Brussels is the capital of all of us. It is the European capital and in that respect it has affected us at our core. I have to say: I am a little disappointed, not to say deeply disappointed, at the debate that is taking place here. I am used to the far right pointing the finger at Democrats. But I am not used to the fact that, after such a dramatic attack, there is a little finger-pointing between the democratic groups. What the Belgians and the Europeans are asking for is cooperation and solutions from all of us. In this respect, I support the many proposals that have been made here to strengthen security in Europe. But I want to send an extra message today.  Terrorists do not target a country, a nation or a people's community. The attack was not directed against the Belgians, the French or the people of Brussels, but against the way we live, against the core of our European values. Part of the solution will therefore lie in the joint development of these values by putting them forward in our education. Raising our children, our young people with European values: equality between men and women, diversity, openness, justice, freedom of expression. That will be essential and is part of the solution. This also contributes to a European identity. A European identity is what we need and, as strange as it may sound, is part of the solution.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: Mr President, my country, Belgium, is bruised. It is not the first country and, unfortunately, probably not the last to face the horror of the bloodiest terrorism. Our grief is immense in front of the victims, and we thank all those who share it with us.  Of course, we recognize certain weaknesses, some shortcomings, even our too late realization of what was teeming in certain areas of our capital. But that is not a reason, as some do, to overwhelm us as if our country had become the capital of crime and the sole culprit of the terrorist attacks that took place all over Europe. Our police, intelligence services, firefighters, health services do not deserve these unfair accusations and this infamous treatment, and I want to publicly support and thank them here. Let us cease, Mr President, to seek scapegoats or archaic solutions, some of which are being chanted. Let us become better together, broaden Europol's mandate and means, interconnect the European databases we have created, make it mandatory to transmit sensitive data. It is together that we are attacked, it is together that we will win.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, we heard at the beginning of this debate that Guy Verhofstadt said he was sitting together with Jean—Claude Juncker at the European Council after 9/11 discussing security measures, and still we have not achieved what we wanted to have at that time. That also means that you and others have been responsible for security policy for the last 15 years. The security policy of the last 15 years has been a one-track policy which says that more and more data needs to be acquired, and this has come at the cost of policemen on the streets. For the last 15 years we have been reducing the number of policemen on the streets in each of the Member States. We have brought in more and more technology systems and expensive technology in response to heavy lobbying by the security industry. Okay, fine, but the problem is that we now lack a real security policy on the ground which brings effective security. The Greens in this House are the only ones who are proposing a solution to that, which is a targeted approach on passenger name records, for example, that looks at the risks and the suspicions and gathers information on those who are suspects – and all of those who have been attackers in the past have been suspects. That would be the solution, so I would ask Members to follow our advice and go in this direction. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF)
text: blue-card question. – It’s a funny old world when I start agreeing with the Greens, but you are absolutely right. Since 9/11 we have been talking about this; we are now quite a few years on. Now, in my country, as in yours, we have had Muslims living amongst us for 40 years, but when they first came 40 years ago, they had to learn English. They had to integrate. But, because of the Left and the push for multiculturalism, I have met women in my constituency and across my country, as indeed across the European states, where they have forgotten to speak the national language. Until we get to grips with that, would you not agree with me that we cannot move on? No matter what is said in this Chamber today, you should listen to Syed Kamall: he is the one who has spoken the most sense today.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I believe – and Here I must also agree with the previous speakers who have pointed this out – it is unbelievable to suggest that religion was ultimately crucial in the radicalisation of these perpetrators. Many of the victims who died in the horrific terrorist attacks were Muslims. Many of the victims were believers. This has absolutely nothing to do with what happened there. It is a question of radicalisation, which is due to a false policy – especially in prisons where people have been radicalised – but your agitation contributes to this radicalisation. We will not bring peace if we continue to sow hatred.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: – I would like to condemn here, as an MEP with Belgian nationality, the tone in which you, President Schulz, immediately tried again yesterday, at the commemoration of the victims of the Brussels attacks, to pretend that the attacks are an external extremism that happened to us. I want to protest against this blindness.  Of course, not all Muslims are terrorists - that should not be repeated over and over again, because nobody is saying it - but please don't let us be naive. If we were to read in the New York Times yesterday that almost 90% of educated young people in the Brussels Muslim enclaves see the kamikazes of 22 March as 'heroes', then we must dare to say that your post-war immigration policy and Islam socialism have totally failed. It is not an external cause, but the political regimes of the European Union are responsible for this.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: – It is exactly three weeks ago today, the horror of that terrible Tuesday 22 March is still in our heads and in our bodies. Thirty-two people were murdered there in a dastardly way, and for a lot of families, for all of us, I think we can say that March 22 will continue to be a black day. Could these attacks have been prevented? We might as well have asked that question in the wake of the attacks in London, Paris, Madrid, etc. It is a collective responsibility, as President Juncker rightly said earlier. Therefore, please do not look for scapegoats today, let us look for structural interventions that can prevent this abomination from repeating itself in the future. Indeed, a large part of these solutions lies at European level. It is our duty in the coming weeks - and not in the coming months or years - to give the victims, to the families a guarantee that we will not let this momentum pass and that we will now take those measures. It is indeed essential - as has been said here many times - to exchange data between the national intelligence services. It is essential that this exchange is more effective and intensified. A European FBI would of course be fantastic, but that will take time and it will never work with 28 Member States. So let us concentrate on the measures that are possible, let us set up with those countries, governments and national governments, Madam President of the European Council, with a coalition of the willing exchange between the intelligence services. Let us also drain the terrorist networks financially so that the information on their financing is efficiently exchanged and so that they can be drained. Let us, ladies and gentlemen, please approve the exchange of passenger data, which is called PNR, on Thursday. I would like to address the President of the Council: we are also counting on your willingness to cooperate, we are counting on you, with your network, with your party political contacts, to use all your influence to convince your party political contacts in this house to approve the PNR on Thursday. I think we should do this now! That we owe this to the thirty-two victims and their families. (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Thank you very much, Mr President, for the opportunity, and I expect an answer from Mr. Representative, my question is this: You have repeatedly said in your speech the expression of goodwill, that goodwill should guide the cooperation of the secret services and others. My question is whether benevolentness is enough, because there are a lot of concerns about data protection issues, and I see that we are still a little indvolved to this, so that we can take appropriate data protection measures to surround our other measures. Do you see that data protection is ok? Thank you.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. I refer to what our group chairman, Mr Weber, replied to a similar question earlier. I believe that we have built maximum guarantees into the PNR proposals that are on the table today. We certainly do not want to go to American states, where the data of all citizens is being thrown away.  There are explicit and very clear maximum guarantees built in for the preservation of privacy, for the granting of an authority that is competent and which monitors that no invasion of privacy law. I think that's maximum built-in. We don't want American conditions. I think it is now time that we finally adopt these PNR regulations and that we stop using all sorts of pretexts to table last minute amendments and stumbling blocks.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The recent attacks in Brussels had a clear objective: to injure, kill, spread fear in this vibrant European city as possible. And our response to these and other devious attacks can only be: more cohesion and more cooperation. We have many European instruments designed to increase our security: the Schengen Information System for the search for persons and property, the counter-terrorism centre at Europol, Eurojust and many more. But all these measures are not being used effectively, information and intelligence are not being sufficiently exchanged.  Mr Weber pointed out that the voluntary exchange of information at Europol has failed. This makes it all the more incomprehensible that his group deliberately rejects compulsory exchanges on new measures. In addition, there is often a lack of adequate factual and human resources or qualifications in the police and judiciary at national level in more than one Member State. In order to distract from such problems, new measures are constantly being presented, and new data collections are constantly being called for.  The current challenge necessarily requires security policy as a common European responsibility. We must work together more effectively and tackle the problem of radicalisation and violent extremism together in Europe. This is the only way we can oppose terrorism and at the same time preserve diversity, openness and freedom. Therefore, yes, more Europe is the answer to this challenge.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I am afraid the current situation is critical. Firstly, there are countries or regions in the EU South-East Neighbourhood where governing structures or their elements have collapsed or were weakened. Somewhere the power vacuum has been filled by Da’esh and other fanatics spreading hate and terror. This poses an ongoing challenge for the UN, EU external policy and our lives. Secondly, in some European districts, the situation was overlooked and developed in such a way that some people can be easy targets for radicalisation. In addition, the attacks were committed by home-grown terrorists. Coping with this environment and change represents a gigantic challenge for Member States and their municipal authorities. The new unprecedented level of terrorist threat also requires new approaches to cope with it. Sharing information between Member States at least must become a reality at last. It is also our role to work further on it as well as on other elements of our common approach. No country can do it on its own. The EU with its allies can do so together.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by saying that the European capital is Brussels. Is there a study that says that in 2020 more than half of the inhabitants of Brussels will be Islamic, and this would be the European capital?  They say that Muslims are not all terrorists, it is true, but it is also true that all terrorists are Muslims. What do we want to do, we want to keep going and move on like this, to get completely subdued by Muslims? The Koran is like a weapon, now, they use it as a weapon when they do the attacks.  What more are we waiting for, after New York, Madrid, London, Paris, twice Brussels and others, are we still here to say and try to understand what needs to be said? It's called "Islamic terrorism," it's called "Islamic terrorism," it has no other names, that's it, and we have to fight there. That is where Europe must show itself, because when they blow themselves up they say: 'Allah akbar', they say: 'Long live Allah'. And that would be a normal religion? Would that be a democratic religion? It is the only religion that in the name of a God makes death and harms everyone.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am asking you to curb this Member who is insulting a major religion, Islam, saying something which absolutely does not represent that religion. It is not my religion; I have none.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I take note of your lesson, Madam President.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE).
text: Mr President, terrorist attacks in Brussels and Paris must not go unpunished. We do need to obtain strong and very strong condemnations against terrorists, but also to review our methods of monitoring and intelligence, in order to appeal as far as possible to individuals whose behaviour and radicalization lead to this terrorist barbarity.  Last December, I voted on a report on the prevention of radicalization. Members of Parliament from all political groups have committed and contributed to the adoption of this report. Measures are being implemented, such as the reform of the Schengen code, the strengthening of the exchange of information on criminal records, the creation of deradicalisation programmes at European level and, I hope, finally, the vote of the PNR next Thursday. Many other similar measures have begun to be implemented, such as those clearly stated by My Colleague Deprez, to which I fully support myself. I would also like to call on the European Commission to finally make proposals with just as much clarity so that we can fight this barbarism. We can no longer be satisfied with incantations or the mere reminder of principles. European citizens are exasperated by such attitudes.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – We have been shocked by the terrorist attacks in Brussels. It's a throw away, unasuthing of men. I offer my sincere condolences to all the victims, those injured and my sympathies to those affected. Not just with those in Belgium, but with everyone in Turkey, Pakistan, Iraq and elsewhere. Terrorists, racists and extremists spread their hatred through violence, and relations between communities are increasingly strained. We Europeans will only find the right solutions if we stand together against terrorism and hatred. Regardless of religion, race, skin color, position. Greater security will not only provide us with new and tightened security measures, borders, walls, greater security will also ensure that we tackle social issues at home and in third countries, fight poverty, resolve conflicts – because of this and terrorism are fleeing people. We have long warned that European countries have great difficulties in sharing intelligence-criminal information. Greater security cooperation, within Europe and with third countries, is therefore essential. But we must also ask ourselves an uncomfortable question: why are young Europeans going to Syria, Iraq, why are they interfering with killer weapons, why are they closer to an ideology that advocates mass beheadings, slavery, killing? There is a very clear link between the radicalisation and the hopelessness of young people, and we must combat it. As well as against Islamophobia and we need a strong, new impetus to promote interfaith dialogue around the world. (The speaker answered the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: A question raised by raising a blue card. – Dear colleague Fajon, given your attitude towards PNR, I would like to ask you whether adopting this important act in the European Parliament would be a step towards a safer Europe in the future?

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D)
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – In every way, the PNR that we have in today's image, which we are voting on tomorrow, is an important step towards security, greater security in Europe, but we need to be very clear about all these measures when we look at the proportionality of the measures, the interference with the protection of privacy and efficiency. Now that we also have a personal data protection package, it seems to me that, combined together, these measures are appropriate, and we are on the right track to ensure exactly what all citizens expect of us.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was in Brussels both during and after the attacks and, while people were scared, there was a palpable feeling of defiance, a determination not to allow these murderous thugs to condition how we live our lives. But as shock begins to give way to anger, we must have the tools to respond to ensure that our law enforcement agencies are one step ahead. The first step must be to immediately implement a Passenger Name Record (PNR) system – any moves to derail the process within this House would be really unhelpful and unacceptable. We must strengthen Europol. If we do not have adequate sharing of information, then criminals and terrorists will continue to exploit gaps in our intelligence apparatus. States also need better powers to reconsider and revoke passports of those who travel to Syria and other conflicts only to return to Europe to recruit and radicalise more citizens. These so-called foreign fighters do not deserve the protection that their European passports grant them. Finally, we must come down harder on those who spread hate within our communities, as well as those who abuse the internet to spread their message of evil. In Brussels, men women and children of every nationality, from every background and from every religion, were killed. No one was spared. This was an attack on all of us.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by expressing my condolences to the victims of the recent terrorist attacks and my closeness to their families.  On 22 March, I was also in Brussels and experienced the tension of those hours and I hope that such events will not happen again, even though, unfortunately, the situation remains critical and that is why I am working together with my colleagues in the Committee on Civil Policy on a directive on the harmonisation of criminal legislation to combat terrorism. We must update EU legislation in a manner appropriate to the new international terrorist threat, while respecting our principles.  However, we also need closer cooperation between the police, intelligence and national judicial authorities. But repressive policies alone do not solve the systemic problems that generate such serious phenomena of violence that they must, even before they are fought, be prevented by education and integration in order to prevent marginalisation and radicalisation. Finally, I hope that the Union will be able to further develop its action in the common foreign and defence policy in order to address the complex international issues where terrorism is rooted.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: – Mr President, if I had two minutes, one of them would give it to keep quiet in honour of the victims, but since I have only one, I will use my voice as a victim of terrorism since the terrorist organisation ETA murdered my brother and his wife. I will use my voice to condemn from the depths of my heart the savage attacks in the heart of Europe. It saddens me to see how our society is beginning to believe that it is inevitable, that it is what it touches. Well, no, gentlemen. No, not a thousand times. It's not what he touches. What it's like to love, it's to work, it's to dream, it's to live safe and free. But to do so, we need to tackle terrorism without ideological complexes. Enough of all this hypocrisy. Victims need not only photos and candles, but facts that lead to the arrest not only of terrorists, but of those who spread radical ideas and those who travel to Syria to learn how to kill us. I refuse to admit that we are killed because of us. That attitude is irresponsible and favors terrorists. We have to act now, because even if many still ignore it, any of us could be among the dead and wounded. This time it didn't touch us, but it can touch us and it's the victims I want to tell you that we will be here to defend memory, truth, dignity and justice.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, I will do my best. After the terrorist attacks, we all feel emotions, compassion, grief, consternation. However, we must not lose our sanity, above all because only in this case can we prevent further terrorist attacks. We know that there are politicians in Europe, and unfortunately here in this Parliament, who want to profiteer from tragedies. They deliberately confuse immigration with terrorism, seek scapegoats, create enemy images so they don't have to face their own political inertia. They talk about the hopelessness of integration, while pretending not to know that the racism they instability is one of the main opponents and greatest obstacles to integration. Instead of helping social inclusion, they are asking for unrestricted authority to restrict freedom and to monitor citizens uncontrollable. While we now know that it was not the freedom of citizens but rather the occasional dilettantism of the authorities that made terrorist attacks possible. We can only prevent terrorist attacks if the secret services cooperate, if there is a European joint secret service. However, the real task is not only to protect, but also to prevent terrorist attacks, prevent radicalisation, reduce racism, discrimination, the ideals and political practices of an inclusive Europe. Thank you very much. (The speaker agrees to answer a Blue Card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Would you not agree with me that political correctness is one of the biggest barriers to actually combating terrorism? If you identify where a threat is coming from, surely you must therefore take action against it, whether or not it suits the political agenda? If it comes as a result of mass immigration or from a particular immigrant community, surely that must be recognised and action taken to deal with that? Otherwise you put political correctness above safety.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Blue card answer. "Indeed, terrorism must be confronted, as my fellow Member says. However, I do not believe that political correctness is the obstacle to confronting terrorism. I believe that confronting terrorism is a question of responsibility and solidarity, a question of cooperation, not a problem of political correctness. Thank you very much!

name: Ελισσάβετ Βοζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνιδη (
text: PPE). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with so many terrorist attacks and casualties, it is time to move from theory to practice. We know the identity of the perpetrators. They are second generation terrorists, European citizens who have been radicalised and trained to hate Europe, democracy and institutions. But we don't know how they are trained, how they are equipped, how they are funded.  Preventing and suppressing the phenomenon requires organised actions and a single European counter-terrorism policy. Control of the passenger register, control of external borders, control of the Internet, exchange of information, transnational cooperation between judicial and police authorities. How many human lives and how many terrorist attacks we still have to accept to understand that there is no contradiction between security and freedom; Because only the safe citizen can be truly free. (applause)

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We also owe the victims and their families and friends appropriate efforts to apprehend the perpetrators, to put them on trial and also to prevent attacks of this kind at an early stage. We must now understand this threat as a permanent threat and therefore treat it as a priority. This also means taking political responsibility for this, but also investing in the police, intelligence services, technology, but sometimes also military matters. If we approach this only half-heartedly, we will lose this battle. That is why it does not help if we often have the attitude of the left-wingers here: we protect the data of terrorists better than the lives of our citizens. Nor does it help that the ALDE rejected requests from the PPE-DE in this area four or five years ago, which it is bringing back today and thinks it is salvation. That is simply too late today. We also have the amendments on PNR in this area. They are again delaying the whole process. This has nothing to do with political responsibility. (The speaker refused to answer a question about the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of Sophie's Rules of Procedure in 't Veld)

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say that we know, we have discovered with anguish, we have been told, that these terrorists are moving in the shadow cones that are left by the gaps that exist in our legislation, gaps that – at least in part – could have been filled in the past.  Now I'm really embarrassed to hear speeches from people who seem really sure that what they're saying is true, much more than what's going on. We know, for example, that PNR was blocked in committee in June 2013, so we have been fighting for years to have what is certainly not the panacea, but it is a useful, very useful tool, as everyone says, and the director of Europol said it the other day. We had to wait for Charlie Hebdo, we had to wait for Bataclan, we had to wait for the brussels attacks. I hope that on Thursday we will vote for this instrument which, I repeat, is not the panacea but a useful instrument.  (The speaker rejected a blue card question from Mr in't Veld)

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to express my solidarity with all the victims of the Brussels attacks and, of course, strongly repudiate these attacks.  Having said that, I think it is essential that we integrate europe's security and internal security into the competences of the European institutions. And that is why it is essential to strengthen European instruments. This is, of course, not only a strengthening of the institutions - and I am thinking of Europol, I am thinking eventually of some secret services, I am thinking of the best exchange of information - but also by the adoption of the PNR and it is curious that the argument that Mrs Sophie in 't Veld gives here is an argument that does not serve, because if she says that the PNR herself adds nothing. Why is she afraid of the PNR? If she says we don't already have these instruments what harm can the PNR do? No. So if we already have it, we stay exactly as we were. I don't understand why you have this obsession with the PNR. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Sophia in't Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – To be correct, I have never said that we categorically reject the use of PNR data, but first there has to be added value. If there is only collection of data at national level but no exchange, then what is the added value of a European directive? I do not understand – it really escapes me – why the EPP, the ECR and the Member State governments continue to refuse mandatory sharing of information. If we had that, I would be on your side.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – I would like to reinforce this idea: if what Mrs in 't Veld and her group understand is that the PNR adds nothing, why do they reject the PNR? So if it doesn't create any problem, if it doesn't add anything it's because it won't bring more problems, and therefore, that's the issue, we can't accept this argument. So that's the point. If he doesn't give you any impression then please accept it, vote for him once and for all, with us.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: Madam President, terrorism, as we've heard, has no limits. It happened again on March 22nd, with jihadists hitting the heart of Europe spreading terror, killing 32 people and injuring hundreds of innocents. These coordinated attacks have reawakened all of us Europeans and made us aware that there is a threat at our centre, and we politicians are not ready enough to deal with it.  The symbolism of the attack in Maelbeek, right next to the offices of the Institutions of the European Union, strikes at the very heart of the European project, reveals our vulnerability and sends a message that no one can overlook. Madrid, London, Paris twice, Brussels admess us. The EU, the European Union, must remain a safe place and we must insist on the application of all measures.  We want to enjoy our freedoms and therefore cooperation is our strength. I agree with Mr Juncker, we need to exchange information, we urgently need to vote down the Passenger Register Directive, we need to standardise our directives, we need to act in a coordinated way.  Note bene, I want to note, should distinguish the ideology of Islamist extremism from the religion of Islam, that's what I want to make clear. We also need to better monitor both the external and internal borders, whoever thought of it and the 5,000 returnees from (the President was taken away from the word by MPs.) (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EA). Rules of procedure).

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question he asked by picking up the blue card. Thank you very much, Mrs. Suica for accepting my blue card. Namely, I would like to ask you if you agree with me that besides what we have to do and we ourselves within the European Union it is very important that we do at our borders, especially in the Western Balkans?  You talked about it, but I think there is a lot to be done in the Western Balkans, that is, we all know the potential dangers that lie in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and maybe in some other countries, but we all know that about Bosnia and Herzegovina. Do you agree with me that this is very important and that we must do more in cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina?

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Jakovcic, I fully agree with you that Southeast Europe is a potential focal point, especially Bosnia and Herzegovina and on Bosnia and Herzegovina we must work together. I fully understand what is happening there, I even have some data, because I think it is up to us politicians to help Bosnia and Herzegovina succeed on the European path as soon as possible and to prevent everything that could possibly be happening from this hotspot.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The news of any terrorist attack is shocking, as any one of us could have been at any location. The feeling of "it can happen to you anytime, anywhere" is fear-mongering. And it is our job not to allow fear to prevail in our daily lives. That's why it becomes the truth of everyday life, the harsh reality in our own skin, that there is no freedom without security. We need to re-create a sense of security for European citizens, which must mean very decisive, tough steps, coordinated European policing, intelligence and, not least, political action. All kindness must end now and must be done. It must be protected so that people who have already been identified as potential terrorists can enter Europe and then take advantage of the wave of migration and abuse the Schengen system to hide in the heart of Europe.  That's why we need to share information. This is why, for example, it is necessary to create a PNR system. We hope that the left will finally understand that european citizens have a legitimate expectation to restore a sense of security. (the President withdrew the floor from the Member.)

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has What else must happen, that together we should be more determined, more serious, more comprehensive, to do everything possible to prevent the mistakes that have been made, to combat the many causes, to stop the wrong developments in our society and to ensure that the European Union is able to act?  Cooperation – data exchange and commitment – will only work if we create European capacities. That is why I am very much in favour of the proposal, both on the one hand by Mr Verhofstadt and, above all, by the President of the Commission, who spoke of the Security Union. We need a master plan, a timetable and an action plan, which has to be done by when. And it is not only about internal security, but also about external security. We also need to review our foreign policy, our defence and development policy in the regions where the causes of terrorism are created.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am close to the Belgian people and to Brussels at this time of condolence.  However, even in the wake of what the Interior Ministers said in the aftermath of the Brussels attacks, we must continue to work hard to ensure that all legislative anti-terrorism initiatives are approved as soon as possible. Finally, after months and months of postponement, we will be voting on the PNR directive this week. It took a long time to get to a turning point. I am convinced that this instrument can be crucial in identifying all foreign fighters, the foreign fighters, who can provide the national authorities with useful information about the movements and especially the suspects around our territory.  The adoption of the PNR directive must, however, be accompanied by an improvement in the exchange of information between police forces, better cooperation between our intelligence services and better engagement by all Member States.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Madam President, last month many of us were personally touched by the attacks in Brussels. We should act together if we want to ensure our security. The only answer is prevention. This means an obligatory model of sharing information among law enforcement in real time with coordination at European level, first of all cooperation on intelligence, implementation of PNR and ‘smart borders’ control with guarantees of real-time monitoring and processing of the data. We need to adopt PNR in its current form. Fast work is also needed on the directive on counterterrorism, which is the key to fighting all kinds of supporters of terrorism and criminalising their activities. We need a coordinated approach to foreign fighters and returnees to challenge the radicalisation processes, to offer education for young people grappling with extremism in the public area, and to consider how to counteract the growing the role of the Darknet in the promotion and support for terrorist groups. All of those elements are important for better prevention and achieving victory in combating terrorism.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – The terrorist attacks in Brussels have once again proved to us that it is not safe in Europe, as is often said, but instead of linking all the secret and police services as quickly as possible and starting a systematic operation in Brussels, where the police do not cooperate with each other, but also in Paris, London, Berlin, Copenhagen, Stockholm or The Hague, where radical Islamists are based, we are talking about the fact that terrorism poses a real threat to the whole of Europe. We have known this for many years.  Europe is facing not only new arrivals, but also immigrants, third-generation immigrants who do not recognise our values. The war in Syria has led to the radicalization of some fundamentalist religious groups. This must be combated. Ladies and gentlemen, the current Europe and the citizens of Europe do not want weak politicians who will say platitudes but want concrete solutions.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Madam President, my heart is with all the victims and their families. Against terrorism we need to be responsible and join forces across political groups to implement the anti-terrorism pact. Most importantly we need better sharing of information and strengthening the tools we have rather than creating new EU structures, as the problem is mutual trust. Member States must develop secure channels of information-sharing that they can all trust. We should reinforce Europol and also ensure better sharing of information of criminal and terrorist records. We also need better control over our external borders, with biometric passports for EU citizens. We have to update databases such as SIS, VIS and Eurodac, taking fingerprints and ensuring information-sharing and cross-checking in a secure way. We should also adopt the EU PNR and continue with better financial tracking. Data protection should be no obstacle to saving the lives of innocent people. We should stand up for our freedoms and open society and ensure citizens that we have given ourselves the tools to ensure their safety. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Actually, I wanted to see Mrs Corazza's colleague, but, being in the same group, I will ask the question. Europe is not a safe place, it said here. Dear colleague, you have said a few things that the Commission should do, including the exchange of information and the database. But we're in a process already. The database collection takes time. Do you think that it was done correctly, that the Commission did the right thing in starting this refugee programme? What should be done today?

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. –  I did not say that Europe is not a safe place; I said we have to be responsible, join forces and show the European citizens that we take their safety and security very seriously. I do not know why my Social Democrat colleague raises the issue of refugees, because we are talking about terrorism, and the two issues should remain distinct. Refugees are not terrorists; many of them are actually victims of terrorism.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: We have a lot of messages for the catch-the-eye procedure that follows. However, I take only one person per group, because we are very late, and only those who were actually present during this debate and have not yet spoken in a catch-the-eye procedure. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Recent events have made it clear that terrorism has also transformed and threatened our daily lives in a new form. The response to this threat must be swift and effective: if the European Union cannot provide an institutional response, the Member States will do so, because the security of European citizens is paramount. Terrorist organisations see Europe as an area of operation, a continent that cannot stop terrorism at its borders.  We cannot allow European citizens to play war games in Syria or other parts of the world and then return to Europe with impunity. This is an absurd situation that needs to be stopped. I think that those who want to fight for the victory of a jihadist ideology and therefore travel to a war zone are a threat to us even when they return to Europe.

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is a sad truth that the names of traffic offenders travel quickly over the Member States’ borders while the names of terrorists do not. The reason is that intelligence cooperation, like security, defence and foreign policy, is the embodiment of sovereignty – the supreme limit for integration. Ultimately, the response to all terrorist attacks is the responsibility of the Member State that was targeted. It is for that Member State to react first, but equally it is for the EU to help in dealing with the consequences, including in apprehending the perpetrators and, more importantly, in preventing such attacks. After all, just as the recent economic and financial crisis forced us to leave sovereignty aside and start interacting with Brussels in adopting our national budgets, we should realise that we should do the same in respect of intelligence cooperation, because in such cases, jealously guarding our national attributes simply does not save lives. Quite the contrary.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Our countries and European institutions are stronger than any form of terrorism no matter how intense. As long as we face the threat of jihadist terrorism united, we can defeat it. We've got plenty of partisanship. We need a sense of duty and responsibility. The imprisonment of some members of the People's Party against ALDE in this House is not typical of the party that has more responsibility for the consensus we need. And I'm not saying it without knowing what terrorism is: they've killed a lot of my friends, my brother, and they tried to kill me.  We need unity and generosity and a sense of responsibility. We can overcome as long as we are able to understand the hierarchy of problems and do not engage in partisan nonsense in this House. We can overcome as long as we understand that, in a globalized world, we cannot save ourselves. Beyond this we have some important issues, for example, the non-prescription of terrorism offences, the generating of our own office and directive for the victims of terrorism and actually generating a European intelligence agency.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, first of all, from the GUE/NGL Group, our condolences and condemnation for the latest attacks. But we don't want empty speeches or convictions. We want effective instruments within the rule of law, not a unilateral military exit or the cut-off of freedoms, because it is a triumph of terrorism and it is not effective, as we saw with intelligence problems. Attack financing, tax havens, oil. When's a commission of inquiry? Stop the tolerance of our so-called allies with terrorists, arms embargo or support for United Nations negotiators' processes. What is terrible is to hear the spokesman of the People's Party accusing a Member of electing the terrorists for asking for information on data control or that Mr González Pons, with his usual political cainism of the People's Party, accuses us to the left of deserving of these attacks. They, who destroyed the lay states that are the barrier to terrorism or who have strategic partners that propagate Wahhabism, who are the takfirist parents of the Dáesh. It's sarcasm. Stop political cainism.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is interesting that no consequences have been taken for the failure of the Brussels or Belgian authorities in connection with the tragic recent incidents and attacks by the responsible politicians. No ministers resigned. Instead, there were flowery and artful justifications. It is not surprising that one of the masterminds of the attacks worked in the European Parliament, since the Muslim Brotherhood, which is well-known in this House, is also going in and out. A blacklist of Islamist lobbyists has not yet been created. Actionism, however, continues. Instead of collecting all sorts of information on passenger data, we need focused screening of the commonality of the assassins, as the Israeli secret service also recommends. It is bizarre to include details such as sexual preferences in data storage without at the same time putting the inclusion of relevant offences – violent crimes, Islamist propaganda offences – at the centre of this risk analysis.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Madam President, on behalf of the people of Northern Ireland, I want to use this opportunity to condemn the terrorist attacks in Brussels. These barbarous attacks were shocking and brutal, and Northern Ireland stands with you in solidarity and determination to defeat terrorism in all its forms. Sadly, on the same day as the Brussels attack, the community in Northern Ireland was burying one of its own. Prison officer Adrian Ismay was injured and later died when a bomb was planted under his vehicle outside his own home. He was killed by Republican terrorists who have nothing to offer our community but death and tears. I am sure that this House would want to place on record our sympathy to his family and colleagues, and reiterate that we stand together in the defeat of terrorism, whether that be in Brussels, Paris, Madrid or Belfast. Having listened to this debate today, I would suggest that this will not be done by creating more European agencies, but by the proper collaboration of nation states taking responsibility for the lives and well-being of their citizens.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as the honourable Members all stress tonight, the Brussels attacks illustrated once again the severity of the challenges we are confronted with. Terrorism has claimed over 180 lives since January 2015 in Europe and many more have been seriously injured, many more lives changed forever. You know, because I said it many times before, if we do not put aside the national silo mentality, terrorists will strike again. This is about information-sharing, trust, joining forces, working beyond our borders, giving our experts to Europol’s European Counter Terrorism Centre. That is the only way to respond to the threat: together. We all need to live up to our responsibilities – all of us: the Commission, the Member States and this Parliament. There is no time and space for blame games. The priorities and gaps have been identified. Now, more than ever, it is time for joint work to deliver actions. And this can only happen by cooperating to the maximum while respecting the principles of our democratic societies. That is why I welcome the finalisation of the Data Protection Package to be voted by this House this week. This is an important step which will help us to develop our future tools on the exchange of information. You will also vote to adopt the PNR Directive. The PNR framework is one of the tools that can substantially contribute to our security. I will continue pushing Member States to implement this quickly and not wait for two more years. I want to assure you that the Commission stands ready to support Member States, to ensure a uniform understanding and implementation as the Commission also supports interconnected national passenger information units through pilot projects. Therefore your wide support for PNR on Thursday will send a strong signal on the role and contribution of this House to security policies. I count on all of you. We made together some progress in recent months: that has to be acknowledged. More information is being shared between Member States, but still not consistently or comprehensively enough. More alerts are created in the Schengen Information System, which has proven to be one of the most valuable tools to enhance security. The European Counter Terrorism Centre with Europol is operational, and we still expect all Member States to send their experts and use to its full potential this nerve-centre of our operations. Mr Verhofstadt, I share some of your views and took note of your suggestions. We have to reach the point where Member States exchange intelligence information in the future. Europol has a very specific mission by the Treaties, but as Mr Weber reminded us, it is an important one: to support and strengthen action by the Member States’ police authorities and other law-enforcement services and their mutual cooperation. Both Europol and Frontex are already supporting Member States to better protect our external borders. We are working with countries such as Turkey, Tunisia, Lebanon, Jordan and the Western Balkans against terrorism. I was in Turkey last week with Europol’s director in order to accelerate our effective cooperation. We need Turkey just as we need other key countries in the region that can share information with us on radicalised persons or on persons leaving or returning from ISIS-occupied areas. On 20 April, one year after the presentation of the agenda, the Commission will report formally on the progress made so far on what needs to be accelerated and what more is needed on the road towards a genuine security union, as President Juncker said here today. Over the last five months we have put on the table important legislative proposals on terrorism, firearms, criminal records, borders and information-sharing, all of which should still be adopted as a matter of priority. We cannot expect quick results in security if after each attack we proclaim our determination but then water down every good proposal on the table. With regard to information-sharing, here we are finally coming to understand that the less information we share, the less we know and the less we can prevent. Our information landscape for security in the European Union is simply too complex, too fragmented. If our systems do not talk to each other, if they are not connected, we will continue putting data into black boxes. Data must be interconnected to be useful. Many EU tools for information-sharing are still under-used. We do not need to reinvent the wheel: we have to start using it more. Last, but very important, a word also on radicalisation, which is key, as Mr Pittella stressed. Last week I was at the UN Conference in Geneva. We cannot close our eyes to the fact that, again, the terrorists were young persons born and raised in the European Union. These are our youngsters. The roots of radicalisation are complex and multifaceted. There is no button that we can press to solve it. That is why we must rethink our integration and inclusion efforts, our educational structures, our whole approach to promoting tolerance and common values. Let us not repeat ourselves. Let us avoid empty words. Our challenges are considerable and they are shared. Let us prove our unity and resilience with concrete actions.

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, like the Members of this House I share the indignation about the attacks that have taken place. I equally share the sense of urgency: we have to act because of Charlie Hebdo, the Bataclan, and Zaventem and Maelbeek. It is our responsibility to act, and I am pleased to note that most of those who have contributed to this debate are genuinely seeking solutions. Most are trying to understand what causes senseless violence and terror and how to fight and prevent it. But let me be clear: giving up on our freedom is not the way forward. Closing our internal borders is not the solution. This is not about political correctness: it is about our way of living, our values. Several concrete questions have been put to me as the representative of the Council Presidency, including, for example, the calls for greater exchanges and sharing of intelligence and information. Mr Verhofstadt asked me specifically about Europol, and to him I would say yes, we certainly do need to make the information in common databases better in terms of quality and quantity, as well as ensuring consistent use and interoperability of databases. We need to join the dots. The Council will specifically address the challenge of improving the interoperability of databases at its meeting on 21 April. I would also like to draw attention to the joint statement issued by the Ministers for Justice and Home Affairs on 24 March in response to the attacks two days earlier. We think that the ten actions set out in that statement are a comprehensive agenda. Our Presidency will pursue it with the utmost vigour. Specifically as regards Europol, we fully agree that effective cross-border investigation capacity is of the utmost importance. Collection of information is, of course, a prerequisite for connecting and exchanging information, and Member States should step up their efforts here, using agreed methods such as joint investigation teams. Europol plays an important role in supporting cross-border investigations and should continuously enhance its capabilities as the central information broker and as an analysis centre. Soon the Siena information architecture, which connects Europol with law enforcement authorities in the Member States, will be upgraded to confidential level. Our Presidency is committed to improving the collection and exchange of information overall, and yes, in reply to Mr Verhofstadt, we would very much welcome further discussions with Parliament on this initiative. To conclude, let me just repeat that I am grateful for Parliament’s support and for your contributions. We share the same objectives in our common fight against terrorism, and I am convinced that we must live up to the expectations of our citizens, improve their safety and uphold their values and rights. To do that, we have to join forces.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – We are increasingly debating the topic of terrorism, and the brussels attacks on 22 March only remind us how vulnerable we are. I begin by saying that the best form of counter-terrorism is prevention, and in this respect the report voted on in November on preventing radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens is one of the key elements in the fight against terrorism.  The European Union must also carry out a coherent security policy involving the unrestricted cooperation of Member States and increased exchange of information. At this point, we need to show unity, because fragmentation is not the answer. From its position as co-legislator, the European Parliament must also focus its efforts towards the adoption of the Counter-Terrorism Directive. This not only makes a number of changes to current legislation by classifying as a crime travel for terrorist purposes, financing, organising and facilitating such travel, obtaining funds, but also aims to combat the effects of terrorism by ensuring immediate access to aid services and to health and psychosocial care.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – The city of Brussels was the latest victim of terrorism on European soil. Unfortunately I again express condolences for the victims of this barbarism, this time of March 22. We have always been concerned about the security of our citizens and, since 2001, the fight against terrorism has been particularly determined. It is certain that we will never be able to achieve 100% security, but something certainly has to change. I have been using instruments on the ground more effectively for a long time. SIS II, which will soon see its improved ability with the inclusion of fingerprints, is paradigmatic in this regard. Europol, whose mandate is about to be amended, is another example. We need greater cooperation and information sharing between Member States. It is clear that we are faced with new realities, for which we must find new solutions. And we must do so without fear of strengthening European competences, but without forgetting also that internal security is the first and especially a competence of the Member States. We must be ruthless with these criminals and ensure the safety of our citizens. And we can start doing it now.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. – Last 22 March Brussels, the European capital and heart of the EU, experienced a difficult day in which many people lost their lives or were injured. The Plenary of the European Parliament wished to pay tribute to the victims with a minute's silence and to hold a debate on combating terrorism in order to reaffirm the need to be united in this difficult hour and to take stock of the latest developments. Europe must make an effort to adopt an anti-terrorism strategy that addresses all the causes of this scourge and strengthens security measures, police cooperation and the exchange of information between counter-terrorism authorities but does not forget the fight against discrimination against sensitive groups, social inclusion and integration policies and the fight against religious fundamentalism within and outside our borders.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – To date, systematic checks on persons crossing the external borders apply only to third-country nationals. An amendment to the Schengen Borders Code introducing mandatory and systematic checks on EU citizens based on the use of appropriate databases at the external borders should be adopted before the summer break. This will help to counter terrorist threats in Europe.
