In addition, the Commission should also without delay present a decision on interoperability and systematic access to and exchange of information from entire European Union databases such as ECRIS, SIS II, VIS, EURODAC and the broad implementation of an EU automated fingerprint recognition system that would be integrated into the SIS.  The pilot project exists, but must first of all become fully legal. This is necessary in order to prevent further terrorist attacks. Moreover, it is also important to systematically exchange information contained in national databases between Member States. In addition, the European Commission must ensure that data and information between agencies such as Europol and Frontex can be exchanged without further legal obstacles.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Attacks in the heart of the European Union have proved once again that it is taking time to find and implement adequate solutions to tackle the terrorist threat in Europe. Unfortunately, the lives of 32 people have been reaffirmed the need to strengthen the exchange of information between intelligence services and between police services. It is unacceptable for only five Member States, including Bulgaria, to regularly provide information to Europol on suspected terrorists and foreign fighters. A genuine European response requires genuine cooperation and shared responsibility in the fight against this transnational threat. I welcome the efforts made by my home country of Bulgaria to regularly provide europol with information on terrorists who have passed through our therothy. Being on the path of foreign fighters from Western European countries to and from Syria via Turkey, it is of the utmost importance for us to have timely information from the European partners on who crosses the external border. On a number of occasions, the Bulgarian services have demonstrated that, in effective cooperation, they successfully guarantee European and national security by capturing and extraditing terrorists wanted across Europe. It is time for all the measures we have been talking about since the Charlie Hebdo attacks to be put into practice. Europe cannot afford another attack and yet unfulfilled promises.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The Union can bring undeniable added value in the fight against terrorism. However, Member States must be able to work together, through their police, judicial and intelligence services. However, they need to overcome their differences in order to be able to exchange and process information in a relevant way, by providing more information to existing databases.  From this point of view, a European Intelligence Agency and a European Police Office would have their relevance. It is also essential to tighten the noose on the illegal use of firearms. The failures of the current legislation have created legal loopholes that benefit terrorists - the recent attacks were carried out with alarm weapons converted into lethal weapons and neutralized firearms that had been reactivated. Weapons should not be seen as goods for everyday use, but as dangerous tools whose use must be controlled to enhance the security of Europeans.  Finally, the drying up of the sources of terrorist financing, the fight against the trafficking of false papers, but also European harmonisation in the field of rail security, are all huge projects that call for our full mobilization.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The subsequent attacks carried out by THE ISLAMIC STATE make us aware that the struggles of Europe and the world against terrorism are a process that will not have a quick end. The threat persists despite increased precautions and intensified controls, especially in vulnerable areas that could be potential targets for bombers. It is necessary to continue to carry out control, prevention and prosecution activities, especially in situations where they may be linked to terrorism.  It is also important to be aware that the EU's internal and external security are closely interconnected and it is virtually impossible to achieve one without taking the other into account. In this view, it is particularly important to seal borders, to cooperate between Member States and their authorities responsible for security and law enforcement, as well as to efficiently exchange the information needed to guarantee reliable control at the EU's external borders. Security, control, migration, protection of sensitive data are important for our daily lives and their borders will have to be rededesigned. Europe is currently undergoing changes in social governance and this is not a process that we can stop, but we should work to ensure that this new order guarantees us the defence of European life and values and security.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – After the tragic terrorist attacks, it has been proven that Europe needs more effective and consolidated national security cooperation. There's no room for nation-state arrogans, separate paths, we're dependent on each other. At the same time, on the specific paths of the nation-state, I would like to draw attention to an important statement that is recurring in the political communication of populists and therefore causing serious long-term damage.  Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban has already equated migration with terrorism after the Paris attacks, and Fidesz has been strengthening this claim ever since. On the other hand, the reality is– we know well – that the fanatics who carried out the attacks were all young people born and socialised in Europe, many of whom were radicalised in camps in Syria or Iraq. And some of whom have indeed infiltrated our borders with a wave of refugees, but this does not allow us to brand every man, man and woman fleeing murderers like them as terrorists. Europe's threat is a matter of national security, intelligence, policing and social integration. Anyone who knowingly confuses the two and incres hatred with it is playing on the terrorists' cot. Yes, we're dealing with immigration, second- and third-generation, radicalized young people already living here. But detecting bombers in the refugee thresion is a policing task, not a political propaganda exercise.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the effectiveness of the measures taken to date against tax evasion and money laundering in the light of the recent revelations in the Panama Papers (2016/2647(RSP)).

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, regarding the Panama Papers, I would like to start by saying that all this demonstrates yet again the need to continue our fight against tax fraud and money laundering. It is too early, unfortunately, to have a full analysis of the Panama Papers, but all of us are – as you are – examining their implications and the responses to be given. National governments have announced investigations. In discussing what the EU can do, I will distinguish between the tax aspects on the one hand and anti-money laundering on the other. On tax, action needs, in particular, to focus on two policy strands – firstly, access to information, and secondly, measures that can be applied to remedy cases of fraud. The Commission’s Anti—Tax Avoidance Package, presented at the end of January, provides an important basis to implement internationally—agreed standards in binding EU law. As regards access to information, internationally—agreed standards on transparency and the exchange of information have been developed by the OECD. Significant progress has been made in recent years. However, not all international players have totally committed yet to playing a fair game, and this is clearly the case for Panama. In order to ensure efficient tax transparency, we need everyone on board, and the EU, as a major international player, must speak with one voice to convince its partners on the international stage to adopt the standards agreed by the majority. The EU itself is committed to the issue of the exchange of information. We have gone even further than the OECD standards and many consider us front runners, which is good news. We have adopted a directive on administrative cooperation that was recently complemented to cover tax rulings exchange and which will soon cover country—by—country reporting between tax administrations, as proposed in the Commission’s Anti—Tax Avoidance Package. The Council has already reached agreement on this country—by—country reporting, and I would very much welcome the Parliament adopting its opinion as soon as possible. Clearly we will not stop here. Today the Commission adopted a proposal on public country—by—country reporting of multinational accounts to increase transparency, and this proposal will, obviously, receive the full attention of the Council. The Presidency will definitely strive to have swift progress on this proposal. To come back to the revelations, I would like to speak of what we can do beyond increasing the exchange of information in order to fight tax fraud and avoidance, as well as money laundering. In January the Commission issued a communication on an external strategy for effective taxation as part of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Package, amongst other things proposing a common EU listing process to respond to third countries that refuse to respect tax good governance standards. The Presidency is striving to react swiftly to these proposals, explicitly taking into account the Panama Papers. Also in January, the Commission Anti—Tax Avoidance Package contained a proposal for a directive laying down rules against tax avoidance practices – the Anti—Tax Avoidance Directive – which is currently being examined. Some of the rules put forward in the draft directive could be of use, considering that we are also talking about abusive forms of legal tax avoidance. So again, the need for a swift agreement on this directive is stressed. The Presidency is striving to reach an agreement on this proposal during this semester, and I hope that we can count on you – Parliament – as well. Finally, I would like to draw attention to the ongoing work of the Code of Conduct Group on Business Taxation in fighting harmful tax regimes. The Group is committed to promoting the adoption of the code-of-conduct principles in third countries. The group has worked successfully in Switzerland and the Commission is continuing its dialogue with Liechtenstein on behalf of the group. Other countries outside the EU should be involved in the near future. Let me turn quickly to money laundering. This issue, which is closely linked to the financing of terrorism, is also very high on our agenda. In February, in reaction to the Commission’s action plan on the fight against terrorist financing, the Council agreed to proceed swiftly with the implementation of a number of measures which will contribute to combating both terrorist financing and money laundering. Let me outline the ones which are particularly relevant in the context of our discussion today. Firstly, ministers emphasised the need for the identification of third countries with strategic deficiencies in the area of money laundering or countering terrorist financing. As you are aware, in accordance with the Fourth Anti—Money Laundering Directive, Member States should apply enhanced due diligence measures on financial flows from and to these listed countries. In February we called for the identification process to be completed by 1 May. Here, however, we are in the hands of the Commission. We know that our sense of urgency is shared by the Commission, which is working hard on this matter, and we hope that it is also shared by Parliament. Secondly, ministers underlined the importance of speeding up the implementation of the Anti-Money Laundering Package which Parliament and the Council adopted last year. Our shared objective is to aim for completion of this process by the end of this year. Thirdly, we have undertaken to further improve the cooperation and exchange of information between Member States’ financial intelligence units. Fourthly, we called on the Commission to propose, by June, certain targeted improvements to the Fourth Anti—Money Laundering Directive. Furthermore, we have asked the Commission to explore the possibility of introducing limits to large cash payments and to consider, together with the European Central Bank, whether appropriate measures might be necessary for high-denomination notes such as the EUR 500 bill. As you know, the Anti-Money Laundering Directive is very recent and is still being transposed by Member States. For certain areas, however, it has already become clear that targeted amendments are needed, for example aimed at strengthening access to information such as access to bank and payments account information by financial intelligence units, operationalising the list of high-risk third countries, and in view of the handling of virtual currencies. The Council is ready to work on a Commission proposal in this respect as a matter of priority, and I am sure that this would also be the case, again, for Parliament. I know that the issue of money laundering and terrorist financing is also very high on our international agenda, particularly in the context of the Financial Action Task Force, but also in the G20. Let me conclude by saying that the Presidency has decided to put the so—called Panama Papers on the agenda of the informal Ecofin meeting in Amsterdam on 22 April, where the Commission will be invited to give a policy reaction, including an overview of the initiatives on the fight against money laundering and tax fraud. Ministers and Central Bank governors will be invited to exchange views on this issue. I look forward to that specific exchange of views.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, Madam Representative of the Council, Madam Minister, Ladies and Gentlemen, the Panama Papers scandal is giving new legitimacy, and greater legitimacy, to our programme to combat tax evasion and money laundering. If anyone still needed evidence of the importance of our common work in this area, they are now known to all through the remarkable work, and which I want to salute as such, of the media. If all the transparency and good fiscal governance measures that we have long advocated - Parliament and the Commission - had been put in place within the European Union and internationally, this huge cover-up of funds could not have been so colossal. Therefore, the indignation, which I share, is not only understandable, but also salutary, in the face of revelations of such great magnitude and so harmfulness. Citizens cannot understand or accept these practices, which are, in reality, nothing more or less - let us say the word - stealing them. We must now turn what we feel, that is, this public outrage, into concrete positive actions and also seize the opportunity offered by these revelations, because it is indeed a political opportunity that we now have, and a political duty that belongs to us, that to deal decisively with tax evasion, tax evasion, aggressive tax practices or tax optimization. , corrupt and money-laundering practices.  This is an opportunity to strengthen the dynamics of our already very ambitious programme to combat tax evasion, tax evasion and money laundering, in particular by obtaining, I am confused to say here, Member States turning their political commitment into concrete action and also making new political commitments. It is also an opportunity to reassess our whole system and to identify new measures that can be taken to strengthen the European Union's defences against tax evasion. And it is, finally, an opportunity to intensify cooperation with our international partners to put pressure on problematic jurisdictions - let us call them as everyone calls them, tax havens - so that reforms for fairer, more transparent taxation, decided at the international level, can be implemented, and that they take up our own standards for the prevention of money laundering. A word, though, about what has already been done because I believe that we must not constantly beat his coulpe. A lot has been done in recent years. There is a transparency revolution that has begun, and I often say that it will not stop. I think so more than ever. We're not starting from scratch. The Commission has taken strong initiatives to improve the tax environment for citizens and businesses alike. Indeed, in recent months, we have presented no less than three major tax reform packages.  This includes, first, a proposal that includes legally binding measures against tax avoidance. This proposal provides, on the one hand, a general anti-abuse rule that would prevent artificial offshore structures from being used, as is all too often the case, to avoid tax and, on the other hand, rules on controlled foreign companies known as controlled foreign corporation rules, which would allow Member States to tax profits that have been artificially misappropriated through low-tax jurisdictions. , or even zero. In other words, it would capture a number of situations that have been apprehended by the Panama Papers.  Secondly, we have put forward ambitious proposals to advance tax transparency within the Union through the world's largest automatic exchange of tax information between states, on the one hand, and between companies and tax administrations, on the other. Thirdly, we are also advancing tax transparency outside the European Union, first with European third countries. I am very pleased that we have been able to negotiate and conclude agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Andorra and, as will be the case soon, with Monaco through bilateral agreements. This has a very concrete meaning for our fellow citizens, is that what is called bank secrecy is dying and disappearing in Europe; it's a tremendous success. As far as countries outside Europe are concerned, we have proposed to create a pan-European and common list of paradises as part of the external strategy for effective taxation that I presented last January. All this constitutes an anti-tax evasion package which is, for the most part, now on the Council table. We have presented these new initiatives on the basis of strong transparency requirements from the European Union, which are already in place for individual accounts and for the banking sector in the European Union. For example, I want to quote it here, from 2017, Member States will automatically exchange a large amount of information on bank accounts to prevent fraudsters from hiding their savings and money abroad. Even today, a few minutes ago, the Commission decided to push the boundaries of tax transparency even further by proposing that multinational groups make public a country-by-country reporting of their activities.  I have been involved in enough debates now here to let you know that, on the one hand, I have been in favour of this publicity from the beginning and, on the other hand, I am very pleased that the Commission is proposing today that the European Union be - I say to those who say that it is not enough - the first economic zone in the world to shed light on business activity on the other hand I see you nodding, Mr Lamberts, as I know that the OECD has proposed that this should be limited, which is not insignificant, at the moment to exchanges between tax administrations. In the debate, I imagine, I know, that a number of you will ask us about the threshold - EUR 750 million is the same as the OECD threshold; it allows us to understand 90% of transnational activity - and also on the perimeter, wondering why we are not going outside the European Union. From this point of view, I want to tell you that first we are going through aggregated data for the rest of the world, but also - and you will not have missed this - that we will ask for detailed data for the activities of multinational firms working in tax havens. And that can't escape us. This is a first step of decisive importance, and I would like the European Parliament to be able to welcome it as such, but, of course, we will continue to work together. While significant progress has been made on some of the tax initiatives, including the rapid agreement on two transparency proposals, many important measures are still on the Council's table. The Panama Papers are a signal to the Member States that it is time to show the same level of ambition as the Commission and Parliament in the fight against tax evasion, by quickly agreeing on the new eu-fighting provisions. The same goes for our anti-money laundering measures. Member States must fulfil their political commitment and implement the provisions of the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive by the end of the year. This directive provides, among other things, the identification of the true owners of companies and trusts and the establishment of central national registers. And of course, Parliament knows this — it has been asking for it for a long time — absolutely crucial to prevent the misuse of the financial system to launder criminal money. I want to tell you here that the Commission is ready to give all the necessary support to facilitate this transposition process and to ensure the proper implementation of these provisions, but, let us say it, and you know as well as I do, and I also turn to the Presidency of the Council, the primary responsibility lies with the Member States. I hope that this message from the Panama Papers, the message you are sending as a parliamentary institution, the message of the Commission, will be heard and that the Member States understand that there can be no excessive caution on these matters and that the transparency revolution applies to everyone. What else needs to be done? As I have said, much has already been done in the fight against tax evasion, against money laundering, but the recent revelations show that we still have a long way to go to reduce the distortions between legislation and to be fully cooperative within us.  I just want to mention a number of key areas where we need more work. First, there are still a number of proposals that are on the Council's table and will have a major impact. I am thinking of the anti-tax evasion directive, which I know I want, like the Dutch Presidency, to be adopted before the summer. You have mentioned, Madam, everything now the informal Ecofin Council of 22 April, and I know how much Jeroen Dijsselbloem, like me, cares that it is the whole package that is on the table, and the whole package that is adopted. I would like to take this opportunity to say to the ministers who say that they want half of it, that if they have half the package, they will have half the results, that we have no right to do that, that we have to go through with it. It is also time to make the pan-European blacklist of tax havens a reality. The Commission already has a list, but it is only a best of or a compilation of the lists that exist in the national states, which are far too heterogeneous in this area. For example, Portugal has 85 tax havens on its list. No doubt that's a lot. Germany has zero. There, of course, it's too little. If I take the example of Panama, whose whole world has now discovered how much of a tax haven it is, and I hope it will change on this point too, only eight countries of the European Union, nine since last week with France, have named it as such. That's obviously far too little.  Let us work to establish a true pan-European list of tax havens, and I myself have proposed six months to achieve this, six months for the right criteria, six months for the right methods. At the European Union level, it is extremely fast. I think we can and must do it. Then we also need to further strengthen our regulatory arsenal. For example, we have already announced a revision of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive for June of this year, and we will have to learn from the Panama Papers.  Finally, I would add that there is one dimension that is essential, namely the international dimension. Of course, there is what we need to do ourselves, and I think that the European Union is already ahead of the rest of the world, that it has the opportunity and the chance to be a leader and a leader in this area. But everything that is done in the global context is of course more effective. And that is why we must, in the G20, propose a new stage. As it happens, from Thursday, all of the world's finance ministers will be in Washington for the International Monetary Fund's spring meetings, and in this context a G20 meeting will be held at the level of the ministers of the economy and finance. The Commission will be there to propose to go further. I am very pleased that a number of ministers from G20 countries are ready to join us in this area to speak with one voice. Ladies and gentlemen, I have made this introduction an overview of some of the additional steps we could take to eliminate opaque structures, offshore arrangements, and anonymous financial transactions, such as those that came to light last week.  I know that the Commission can count on the European Parliament to feed the debate, to support our ideas, to maintain the political momentum we are building on the next steps on this agenda, and I want to tell you that you can also count on the Commission.  In this case, let us say, we are natural allies. We may have this or that difference or nuance, but we are defending the same cause, and I believe that we must be able to work hand in hand, each with its own sensitivity, to go as far as citizens expect us to do so that this revolution of transparency can eliminate these practices that have scandalized the planet. I am, of course, looking forward to hearing your views on this issue today, but also, of course, in the weeks and months ahead.  If I had the impression that I would be short of tax work until the end of this mandate, that is an impression that I no longer have. I am even certain that we have five years and well beyond in this fight that cannot and should never stop.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Presidency-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, citizens are beginning to be tired. It is our responsibility to prevent them from seeing us as a problem and seeing us as a solution. And for that we have to act forcefully. The revelations in Panama's papers are further proof of the need to continue to move forward as we have done over the past year towards greater fiscal transparency.  The Commissioner said so. This is a political opportunity which we cannot miss and has no doubt, Commissioner, that we support you in all the measures you have proposed here today and in all those you propose in the future to fight tax evasion forcefully. Because it is absolutely necessary to address this problem , as the Commissioner has also said, which is not unique to the European Union. This is a global problem that can only be addressed through a global response involving as many countries as possible. Of course, creating a society in Panama is not illegal, but what can become illegal is what is done with it, and it is our responsibility to prevent these societies from being used to defraud. The PPE Group has always defended, always defended and will continue to advocate greater fiscal transparency. The PPE Group wants Mossack Fonseca and the Government of Panama to come and testify to the European Parliament, as many companies have already done and other States have made in the TAXE Commission. I'm sure the Government of Panama will want to work with us.  We cannot allow both law firms and states to use tax engineering as a business model to live at the expense of other states. The Commissioner has defined it well: that is sincerely stealing.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, billions of euros stolen from public purses, money that is often laundered, the result of illegal trafficking, behind which the Mafia hides, is what this is all about and this is the worst face of our financial capitalism, the corrupt and malfeased one.  That is why I say, on behalf of the Socialists and Democrats, 'zero tolerance' against evaders, 'zero tolerance' against tax havens, and that is why we want a committee of inquiry, here in the European Parliament, so that all forces are put in place to sweep evasion and there is no timidity.  We also want an international conference, a global conference that can deal with the fight against evasion; and then there are the measures that Commissioner Moscovici mentioned. This point was a central point of the government agreement for which we Socialists voted for the Juncker Commission, and I am pleased to see the determination and tenacity that is driving the action of the Juncker Commission and Commissioner Moscovici.  And yet, I ask you to go further, to have more courage also on country-by-country reporting, it must be extended to all countries in the world. We cannot limit ourselves, there is a positive effort that we are pleased to collect, but we must go further, we must have more courage in the face of such an evil cancer, the danger of such an evil cancer.  We also call on the European Commission to commit itself to introducing a statute for whistleblowers. The trade secrets report is a first step in this direction, but we want a clear political commitment to this. There is also a need for harmonisation of the corporate tax base. We want a black list of tax havens and penalties for those companies that help evade. Wipe out tax evasion must be the priority of this mandate of the Commission and the European Parliament.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: mistoqsija karta blu. – Nirrispetta ħafna flower-Onorevoli Pittella - naf li huwa politiku onest u integru, u naqbel miegħu meta qed jgħid li għandu jkollna tolleranza żero għal dawk kollha involuti f'dan l-iskandlu. Però nixtieq inkun naf is-Sur Pittella issa kif ħa jgħaddi mill-kliem għall-fatti. Għandek gvern wieħed involut ta' pajjiż Ewropew fl-Unjoni Ewropea. Naf li dawn, u hu jaf ukoll, ġejjin minn partit so大jalista, però għandna nkunu, f'dan il-Parlament, mhux iktar inħarsu lejn il-partiti, imma lejn dak li hu sewwa, lejn dak li jagħmel ġie liħħħ-dini Ewropej.

name: Gianni Pittella (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not discriminate and I do not make discounts. I didn't mention Cañete. The problem is not to use these issues for political purposes, but to clarify matters, to do so everywhere. My position is that clarity must be made everywhere.

name: Bernd Lucke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We have a major scandal here – no question about it. The Panama Papers brought this to light, but the sparrows have been whistling from the rooftops for a long time. And you have to ask why you have not taken action beforehand. It is the case that if a pot has a hole and the water runs out, then it is very indecent from the water, but one has to ask who actually chose the unsuitable pot. And so one has to ask how it is that tax law has been able to create these many possibilities in the first place, that tax avoidance and tax evasion and money laundering could be carried out on such a large scale. And one has to ask why the tax authorities have not noticed this, or whether it has not been known to the tax authorities for a long time in all countries that this type of tax avoidance and evasion and money laundering is being carried out, and whether they may not have reported it to the finance ministries and to the ministers for a long time. And then you have to ask why the ministers did not take action. There is a major policy failure here. Governments have known for a long time – and everyone in all the countries of the European Union has known – that this type of tax evasion is taking place. And nothing has happened. That, ladies and gentlemen, is the real scandal.

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I am glad to see that the Dutch Presidency is sending us the Minister of Defence. We are going to attack tax evasion with military means, maybe that is a good thing. I salute his presence! Much more seriously, this is an issue on which, for the Liberal group, there is no doubt that there is action to be taken at two levels. First of all, there is an investigative action, and I believe that we, like other groups in this Chamber, are in favour of trying to deepen the work that has been done by journalists and to which Mr Moscovici has paid tribute. So there is the aspect of understanding what happened, checking whether you really have all the information. This is an investigation, and it is also about companies and, for the first time, private individuals. Secondly, I think it is also very important that the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs should devote itself to tax matters - I mean 'tax', the equivalent of tax in English; I insist because it is often translated in a bizarre way - the interest they deserve. That has been said, there are texts to be adopted in a number of areas, and we welcome the new proposals, particularly on the issue of information communication, namely the work that has been adopted by the committee today. Then there is another level, which was raised by Mr Pittella, which is the important criminal aspect, with the laundering of dirty money. To do this, we need other commissions, namely LIBE or JURI. So I believe that this Parliament needs to mobilize beyond competence. In any case, we must not just put things on paper. The issues of implementation, control and possible sanctions against those who do not comply with the rules should, in my view, be explored further, particularly at the global level. We voted this morning on my report, a small initiative report on our role in global for a. I think that one of the added values of the European Union must be to fight for implementation and for sanctions. We are an order of law, and it has to spread globally. Once again, we will be at your disposal, the Presidency and the Commission, to help you. This is a serious subject and unfortunately is not about to disappear from our radar screens.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Panama Leaks is about organized crime of the rich and powerful. Mossack Fonseca laundered dirty money on behalf of Deutscher Bank and Co. and helped the tax thieves. Islamic State banks are allowed to continue to use the international SWIFT system. Dirty money is therefore also used to finance the murders in Paris and Brussels. What a fine society on the Panama list: Russian pimps, Ukrainian oligarch and President Poroshenko, British Prime Minister Cameron, FIFA, of course, the wife of EU Commissioner Caete and also of the National Front. I have my name on my mailbox. The majority of the population tax every hard-earned penny. The truth is that if few super-rich want an ever-larger slice of the cake, they have to take it away from the others. This is called ordinary theft. The debate over Panama reveals hypocrisy: Germany – five places ahead of Panama in the shadow financial index – is blocking a public register for the owners of letterbox companies. Banks in Germany have nothing to fear when it is money laundering. The fourth EU Money Laundering Directive aims to legalise bogus directors of letterbox companies. Cameron advocated for an exemption from offshore trusts and parked money there. The Netherlands does not tax financial flows in tax havens. And the US has Delaware and is boycotting the exchange of information. Are they all now on the EU's blacklist? The US has demonstrated with Switzerland and Liechtenstein how to do it: we need withholding taxes on financial flows in tax havens. We need a criminal law for companies. Banks that help with tax evasion must be stripped of their licences. We need a public register of the true owners of letterbox companies, an asset register and a levy on assets. And we need corporate reporting for each country instead of the bazaar around blacklists. My group is calling for a permanent committee of inquiry into tax havens, which would have a majority in this House. Mr Pittella, too, should have put his own house in order after LuxLeaks. Even Jesus knew that a camel would go through the eye of a needle rather than a rich man going to paradise. Poor Jesus could not know that there are tax havens for this. Finally dry up the tax havens inside and outside the EU, instead of continuing to give Sunday speeches here!

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, among our fellow citizens, the feeling that our democracies are no longer functioning only for the benefit of a minority is growing, and I would like to draw our attention to the fact that, ten days after the Panama Papers scandal, the adoption after—tomorrow of a directive that, under the pretext of protecting trade secrets, will make the work of the journalists and whistleblowers who created Panama Leaks more complicated is an insult to good sense and democracy. I would like to add to the intention of the European Commission and, in particular, Commissioner Moscovici - our previous exchange here was rather in a humorous and light tone - that I have no heart to laugh at. I'm pretty exasperated, Mr Moscovici. It has been three years since Offshore Leaks was revealed, it has been a year and a half since LuxLeaks was revealed, it has been sixteen months since the country-by-country reporting obligation has been imposed on all banks operating in Europe, regardless of country, and the European Commission has been playing the clock ever since.  You don't want country-by-country reporting for all businesses and for all countries. You don't want it! I am sorry, there is no argument - I say well, sir, and I look you in the eye, there is no argument to limit country-by-country reporting to certain companies and countries. You have no argument! A small business that operates between Belgium and France knows how many employees it has in Belgium and France, how many taxes it pays in Belgium and France and what turnover and profits it makes in Belgium and France. Do not tell me that it does not have this data because, if it were, it would be well managed companies.  Therefore, even a small transnational company has this data. And there is no country that we could not impose, that we could not encompass. We have imposed it on the banks, so if you do not, it is because you are playing the watch, but for the benefit of whom? There is only one stakeholder who opposes this measure, and he made his press release today. Businesseurope represents MEDEF, the FEB and all business federations. He does not want it because he knows very well that transparency will cost him not in terms of competitiveness, but in terms of reputation. You're defending their bad reputation. I'm sorry, I'm sorry.

name: Steven Woolfe
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, on the release of the Panama Papers, we have once again seen the usual outcry from politicians saying the rich are not paying their fair share of tax – like Mr Moscovici here in his speech before us today: he wants to make the rich pay their fair share. Well, Mr Moscovici, you are one of those rich: you earn over EUR 20 000 a month; you have a residence allowance of EUR 3 000 a month; a EUR 600-a-month expense allowance; a pension people would only dream of – EUR 300 000 a year. You said tax transparency should apply to everyone. Therefore I say to you: will you agree that you and all your other Commissioners should put your tax accounts online so that the public can see the tax transparency of the Commissioners? You also said that you want to crack down on tax havens. Well, I agree with you. So, therefore, will you crack down on Europe’s biggest tax haven – that of Brussels? Whilst the people of Belgium and across Europe pay tax rates of 30, 40 or 50% you, EU Commissioners, civil servants and EU staff can pay as little as 8%. Whilst we have youth unemployment across many countries of 30 and 40% or even more, you are enjoying the luxury of high salaries and low taxation. And will the EU MEPs pay themselves at the same levels of tax as in their own countries? The biggest scandal of all is that whilst the people pay their tax, the Eurocrats pay virtually nothing. There is the scandal.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, in the face of this new Panama Papers tax scandal, which is not a scoop, the National Front is reminding us of its political and ethical determination. Indeed, since the beginning of the mandate, we have voted on all the European texts to combat fraud and against tax evasion and optimisation. I invite you to check it out. Unlike Mr Juncker, we reject the double language and hypocrisy of some governments. Taxes that are evaded by states and their social systems must be compensated by citizens, while the public deficits you oversee, Mr Moscovici, are at their highest. This fiscal inequity is an economic crime against peoples. Multinationals that use these tax evasion schemes, including US companies Such as Google, Apple, Facebook, Starbucks, etc., whose favourite sport is to evade the payment of corporate tax in Europe through contested schemes, must be condemned.  But we must also denounce the liability of the lawyers of multinationals, their advice, the "Big Four", including PriceWaterhouse, their accountants and certain banks, such as HSBC, UBS, etc. Beyond the simple conviction in principle of fraud, the United States is the main absentee from the investigation of the international consortium of investigative journalists. No revelations about U.S. tax havens, such as Nevada, etc. No North American personality, no big Wall Street bank, no hedge funds, when you know that the lenders that fund the consortium are the Ford, Carnegie, Rockefeller, Kellogg's and a certain Soros, you understand better: tell me where the leaks come from, and I'll tell you who benefits. In the current global economic war, these Panama Papers have an unspeakable purpose, that is to denounce non-American personalities, but beware of this little game of a compromising document [...]  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker) (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I am surprised that in just over two and a half minutes, our colleague from the ENF group did not find the time to mention, with regard to the Panama Papers scandal, the fact that the name of the founder of the National Front was mentioned on behalf in Panama, as well as that of the main company responsible for the communication of the National Front's election campaigns. I think he was talking about the sprinkler, it was a start of self-criticism on his part.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. "You're in a good position to talk, aren't you?" That is right, except that the National Front has nothing to do, near or far, with these tax haven cases. I'm talking about the National Front, okay? The two people you are referring to have made it clear that they had nothing to do with it... All right? There is transparency, everything has been declared; as far as Mr Le Pen is concerned, he has nothing to do with it, okay? So it's defamation and slander, you lean behind your ... how to say...?

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, the recent revelations about offshore companies in Panama have simply confirmed what we already knew or even suspected. Europe's political class is following the example of corrupt businessmen. Many representatives of both classes consider themselves above the law, at the same time as imposing savage austerity measures on citizens and appearing as crusaders against tax evasion. How much of this money has been taxed? How much comes from illegal activities and how much is legal?  There is a very serious moral issue and those involved in this case must be held accountable and take on their grave responsibilities. We should take action to discover all those who hold accounts in offshore companies, as the names that have been leaked are a minimum fraction in front of the total number. The most important thing, however, is to take measures that will prevent a recurrence of the phenomenon. Offshore companies serve no purpose other than to make it easier for them to avoid their own burdens. We need to rethink their status across Europe. Does their existence really serve society? Is there even one plausible excuse for their operation?  Because the answer is that there is in fact none, we must move towards a complete ban on offshore companies. Any company wishing to operate in Europe should acquire a tax registered office within the Union. Of course, ghost companies without any functioning object should not continue to exist. However, I fear that there is no political will for such measures, because probably, as was recently revealed, a large part of these companies belongs to politicians. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask you if you do not think that if the European Bank robs Europeans of eighty billion a month by printing money without coverage, then maybe the activity of these people is, like Robin Hood, that they are robbing this money back.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), answer a question with a "blue card". I totally agree with you. The European Central Bank is taking on European citizens and at the same time, as the Panama Papers have shown, politicians have put too much black money into these offshore companies.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I believe that the Panama Papers scandal confirms the need to take bold and efficient action to improve the firmness and efficiency of taxation. The reasons lie not only in the money that should be collected under the budget, but also in the credibility of the government and fairness on the market. It should also be noted that there are some differences between the Panama Papers and LuxLeaks. First of all, with the Panama Papers we are mostly dealing with individuals and not with firms. I believe that with the Panama Papers we are looking more at tax evasion and not so much at tax avoidance, and the sources of the money in the Panama accounts are probably not always that clean. Also it should be noted that many cases in the Panama Papers are a little bit older. I am saying that because the big difference is that in the area of tax manipulation as described in the Panama Papers, many actions have been taken over the last few years. I am talking especially about the automatic exchange of information and the improvement of anti-money laundering. So that is why I would like to call on the Commission to make a review to ascertain if the measures adopted are sufficient, and eventually what are the holes, the missing elements in the regulation that deal with the problems described in the Panama Papers. Also I would like to encourage the Commission to continue with its tax agenda, especially in the area of corporate taxation and the improvement of VAT collection. It has my full support.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the revelations of the Panama papers require, first of all, public recognition of the extraordinary work of the international consortium of investigative journalists and also of the work of the warning launchers that provide them with the data. It is recalled that Antoine Deltour, one of luxleaks' warning launchers, will be tried this month for breach of professional and commercial secrecy, and that, by joining and joining the European Commission, the Commissioner, in this eume, I would like to see also, in his list, the European statute for the protection of legal aid for these citizens, as recommended in TAXE. A second note on the scale of this iceberg of panama papers: it definitely requires the European Union to move towards a clear definition of what tax havens are, with objective and transparent criteria and a list of sanctions to those who operate with them. I look at the European Commission, not to criticise it, but rather to praise and encourage it, but I would like to have a commitment from the Council, if possible even more firmly, that the blockling that the Council has made to the tax agenda is now reduced to zero in the face of the scandal of the European Union's apathy on tax matters. Thank you so much.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – Rock hard, that's how we have to deal with the Panama scandals, rock hard! Some just don't want to contribute. They avoid the tax authorities, while the common man in the street has to pay sky-high taxes. That is not possible! We must combat this, we do so with more transparency and more cooperation between the tax authorities. And if there is a desire in this House to set up a committee of inquiry, then the N-VA will support that wish.  Cooperation, transparency and not ever higher taxes, because that sometimes seems to be the dream of many here in this House, always higher taxes, when the reality is that the self-employed must give more than three-quarters of their income to the government. Even the government doesn't get along with that and debts are piled up.  Even then, that is not enough and we are relying, for example, on the European Central Bank to print money, which will lead us to take it again: higher taxes, no more interest on our savings. Colleagues, everything is all in place! If we want to cut taxes, everyone will have to pay their fair share. Even those who now prefer to lie under a palm tree in Panama!

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The Panama data leak is the largest in history with 11.5 million documents, and it brings to light a devastating state. Yes – you knew about tax havens, but the dimension is immense, and above all, people from the global elite are affected, not only from the business world, athletes, well-known artists, actors, directors and also politicians.  And if there is the impression that the citizens are not taking a decisive front against these tax avoidance schemes because politicians are involved, then it undermines democratic legitimacy. That is why the European Parliament has an outstanding interest in enlightenment on behalf of the citizens.  TAXE 1 has already laid the foundation. We were not blind to tax havens. We have called for clear measures. We have asked the Commission to come up with a definition and a package of measures. Some things have now been presented, but that is not enough, and we need a TAXE committee that will have real investigative powers.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner. If panama papers are a drop in the ocean, the Commission's proposals are baby birds. I would like us to take advantage of the Panama papers to talk about us and the fundamental problem, which is really the existence of tax havens. Tax havens are that thing that nobody likes but, in fact, no one wants to do anything to end them and if multinationals and large fortunes can be talked about tax optimisation, workers and small and medium-sized enterprises are talking about tax evasion. There is no political will in the European Union, because in the European Union there are tax havens, there are countries that are indeed tax havens, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Belgium, finally, Madeira itself and therefore the European Union has to have political will because it is the largest holder of tax havens in the world and that is really the fundamental problem Mr. Moscovici. The maintenance of tax havens in Europe sends a very clear message to citizens: those who run away from taxes with 100 euros are criminals, who flee with 100 million euros, are entrepreneurs. This is certainly not a matter of tax justice.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I think it is important when we view this scandal to see that it is not mainly a tax scandal, it is a money laundering scandal which has tax consequences. Most of the activities which have been uncovered are already in violation, as far as Europe is concerned, of existing money laundering law which has been in place since 2005. Therefore we have to be serious about implementing existing legislation. I have been informed by a whistle-blower that he has been in touch with the Commission for years to insist that existing money laundering legislation is not being implemented in reality. Therefore it is legitimate that this Parliament looks into why Member States do not implement European law and why the Commission is not insisting enough that law is really arriving on the ground of the Member States. I therefore plead to the Commission to immediately launch infringement procedures against Member States in order to make sure that existing legislation is enforced. This Parliament needs to set up an investigative committee to look into this lack of implementation. Lastly, it is important if we launch a new committee now that we do not shelve the work we have done in TAXE but that we realise what we have done there, because citizens will not accept that we jump from scandal to scandal and finish nothing – that is not acceptable.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has According to an OECD study, national budgets are lost up to €210 billion a year through aggressive tax planning by multinational companies. That is 10% of the tax performance of these companies. This figure makes it clear that combating aggressive tax planning is a top priority. Those who have not yet realised this – at the latest after the Panama Papers, it is obvious: the aim of all these measures must be: profits should be taxed where the economic activity takes place. The UN-OECD BEPS initiative is an important initiative to tackle this global problem of tax evasion globally. The 15-point action plan provides for an international coordination on the taxation of company income, closing financial loopholes and increasing transparency. 96 countries have already committed to carry out the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. Panama does not do so, nor does the United States, which is becoming the number one tax haven. Delaware , this province – has more letterbox companies than residents, and in North Dakota, South Dakota, and Nevada, money is being evaded on a large scale, namely, passing the tax. Simply an e-mail address, and a company foundation is here. The Commission's package of measures of January this year is an important contribution, as are the recent reports in the ECON Committee on greater transparency and the fight against tax avoidance. Country-by-country reporting for companies with an annual turnover of more than EUR 750 million and a transparency register will certainly contribute to transparency. Ecofin has already committed itself to implementing this. But that is not enough. A global problem requires a global network of transparency registers, a global register of beneficial owners, the unification of the blacklist of tax havens and a tightening of the statute of limitations.

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – L-Unjoni Ewropea rnexxielha tagħmel kisbiet importanti fil-ġlieda contra l-ħasil ta' flus in fiż-żieda tat-trasparenza fiskali. Però l-Panama Papers urewna li dawk li jkollhom intenzjonijiet li jqarrqu u biżżejed poter f'idejhom, jistgħu jinfluwenzaw in jduru mal-liġijiet in mar-regola. Qed nirreferi naturalment għall-ħabi ta' fondi permezz ta' strutturi komplessi.  Malta għandha industry tas-servizzi finanzjarji whether hi waħda soda, in tikkonforma mal-ogħla standards regolators. Għandna ġurisdizzjoni you ngawdu l-ogħla reputazzjoni għas-servizzi finanzjarji, b'leġiżlazzjoni stretta in b'sorveljanza regolagic effettiva ferm.  Azzjonijiet ta' clicks żgħira, però, ta' nies fil-poter li kellhom jirrikorru għal servizzi ġewwa l-Panama mhumiex xhieda ta' dan li qiegħed ngħid. Il-persuni involuti mhumiex Malta, għeżież kollegi, u ma jirriflettux il-bżulija, id-dixxiplina u l-karattra onest in korrett tal-poplu Malta. Il-poplu Malta, flimkien magħkom, flimkien mal-maġġoranza ta' din il-Kamra, huwa ekwivoku u qed jgħid illi l-atti ta' corruzzjoni in leġiżlazzjoni laxka huma kitament inaèèettabbli u mhux se jkunu tollerati.  In allura, jiena nixtieq naqbel ma' Membri Parlamentari do ġejjin min-naħa l-oħra ta' din il-Kamra, li huma Maltin bħali, illi jħeġġu lil min għandu jieħu dejiiżjoni f'pajjiżi biex jeħodha kemm jista' jkun malajr biex ma tibqax issir ħsara lil Malta, li hija Malta onesta in Malta conformi mar-regoli Ewropej. (Il-Kelliem aèèetta jwieġeb mistoqsia "map blu" (skont l-Artikolu 162(8) tar-Regoli ta' Proèedura))

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – A simple and direct question to our distinguished colleague, Mr Casa. Can you confirm that there will be a vote of no-confidence in the Maltese Government precisely because of the Panama Papers? I would like a direct answer, please.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: tweġiba karta blu. Iva Sinjura President, nikkonferma li l-oppożizzjoni talbet vot he' sfidu大ja fil-gvern. M'aħniex interessati f'elezzjoni ġdida, m'aħniex interessati li nidħlu fil-gvern - għalissa (il-gvern fadallu sentejn), imma naħseb li l-Prim Ministru, il-Ministru responsabblig tieħu f'dan l-iskandlu għhomand jiżrrienwja.  Però, saret ukoll dimostrazzjoni li għaliha attendew eluf kbar ta' Maltin li ġejjin minn kull naħa tal-lenti politika Maltija. U sfortunatament bħalissa, Sinjura President, qed isir attakk orkestrat kontra individwi li attendew għal din il-protesta, individwi li huma nies serji, li huma nies onesti, li jagmħlu ħafna ġid għal Malta. U dan huwa ta' skandlu ieħor, li jkollok gvern li jħalli li jsir attakk fuq dawn il-persuni.

name: Peter Simon (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Last year, we launched more in Europe in the area of taxation than was possible in many years before, and only because, in the interaction between whistleblowers, the press, the European Commission, but especially this House, with its TAXE Special Investigation Committee and its TAXE 2 Continuing Investigation Committee, we have built up the necessary public pressure here.  If we now reach a new dimension through the outstanding research of the Süddeutsche Zeitung with the Panama Papers, in which not only companies are named, in which also individuals, associations are named, we as a Parliament must find an appropriate answer in order to maintain this pressure. It is time for us to set up a committee of inquiry, which will give us the necessary instruments to work with the Commission for a long time to put pressure on Member States to become much more supple, to be much more willing to work with us on the necessary legislation to close other remaining holes.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President: SwissLeaks, LuxLeaks and now the Panama Papers. How many more data leaks do we need to stop tax evasion? I can say, not at all. There is already enough information and will, which is also beyond party and national borders. Now is the time to act.  Then what do you want me to do? It is clear that global problems require global solutions. The EU alone cannot prevent tax evasion. That is why we need global, comprehensive transparency, as the German Finance Minister, Mr Schäuble, has recently proposed.  We must remember that if we do not succeed in preventing tax evasion, the consequences will not just be economic. The knowledge that the rich and privileged play by different rules from others erods the moral foundations of societies. My own line is clear: tax information must be made public, exchanged and tax havens must be included in this activity in one way or another – if not good, then bad.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – This tax scandal, plus one, alerts us to a reality that is not new. We've had Luxleaks, Swissleaks, Offshore Leaks in the past, and we now have the Panama Papers.  This reality cannot be dissociated from the emergence of the neoliberal paradigm and the deregulation of the financial system that begins to dominate from the 1980s on. It cannot be dissociated from the wave of privatisation stake in public financial institutions created in the post-war period. This scandal is not a road accident. It is a structural phenomenon that requires background measures, such as the end of tax havens, also attacking the heart of the system that lies in the tentacular network of banking and financial institutions. It is up to us to take firm measures to combat fraud and tax evasion, placing barriers to profit and capital transfers to offshore regions. We impose transparency rules on all processes, including free access to all tax information. Don't count on us to pretend what's being done to stay the same.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, last week's revelations remind us of one thing: anti-money laundering rules are not respected, either by some very large banks and other tax intermediaries, or by certain Member States and national supervisory authorities that have allowed this to happen. Money laundering is a business. The citizens' frustration has reached a climax. The dual language of our rulers and the timidity of legislative proposals have undermined confidence. The secrecy and the limited resources put at the service of tax investigators affect our democracies in the heart. We have a right to know who cheated and how, and those responsible must answer to the courts. It is to shed light on this system of industrial-scale fraud that my group has proposed to set up a commission of inquiry. I thank all the colleagues who have given their support. Commissioner, we will not allow the effects of an announcement to follow one another without anything happening, and we do not understand why, when you have a boulevard in front of you and you have the support of the world public, you are not proposing to us a real ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: Madam President, history, like an idiot, mechanically, repeats itself - it is the French writer and diplomat Paul Morand, Commissioner, who saw this in the last century, and unfortunately this is what comes to mind when I discover the excellent work that has been done by the consortium of journalists on the so-called Panama Papers dossier. These whistleblowers must, of course, be protected, as has been said. This is also what comes to mind when I see the procrastination, the questions, the hesitations sometimes in this Chamber about whether or not a commission of inquiry is organised. That is why I am pleased that the group, along with others, has taken its responsibilities quickly to call for the creation of a commission of inquiry. I hope that we will be followed and that a majority will emerge, because we cannot settle for a special commission, such as those set up after the LuxLeaks scandal. Indeed, very quickly, as you know, the members of this committee were confronted with the limits of a special commission. Multinationals even had to threaten to take away their access to the European Parliament and force them to appear before us, and when they did, it was to give an agreed speech and refrain from answering our questions. This has not prevented us from formulating a large number of ambitious proposals, but which have unfortunately not been sufficiently taken up by the 28 Member States - and you have pointed this out, Commissioner. That is why I really call for support for the establishment of this Commission of Inquiry: it is the only way to thoroughly investigate this new scandal in order to delineate responsibilities and understand the mechanisms put in place. I also call for an expanded scope of investigation, also looking at the mechanisms that allow money laundering. These mechanisms finance international terrorism; we talked about it in the previous debate. It is therefore time for the Heads of State and Government to understand that citizens should not be the only ones making efforts in this time of crisis. It is not just them who have to tighten their belts; we know that there is money, we know where he is, now we have to have the courage to go and get him.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the Panama Papers scandal is unprecedented and is appalling. It shows us that we live in different worlds, some who are very rich and who rule the world, basically lead us, are between politicians, and others who work for a decent living and pay their taxes. But it's good that we know. Thanks also to the journalists of the RISE Project in Romania. The annual losses from the use of offshore companies and tax havens are about one trillion euros, as the Commissioner for Taxation has estimated. Now I ask, a man with a decent salary for whom he works, can understand this figure: a trillion euros? No, he won't. I don't understand it either. All we understand is that there is a moral octopus that includes our chosen ones, our leaders, our businessmen. They all mocked us, stole us, took out a trillion euros in investment and consumption, deepened the economic crisis and killed people: those who committed suicide during the financial crisis, those who die of hunger and cold, those who die because they have no medicine. We really need to confiscate this money that comes from tax evasion and money laundering. If not, let's go...  (The President interrupted the speaker's speech.)

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems that what concerns the European authorities is not the extent of tax evasion of Panama's papers, but that the names of the evasors are made public. Names including prominent European politicians, who fill their mouths with patriotism but have their money out or take it out through direct relatives, such as Commissioner Cañete himself, which further compromises the Reliability of the Commission. We already knew that in Europe big fortunes don't need to go to Panama so they don't pay taxes. You can take a train and go to Luxembourg, Switzerland or Andorra. Another thing is to discover that they can also count on the help of the large European banks, which have facilitated the evasion of their customers in collaboration with Mossack Fonseca. What a coincidence that the same week we debated the leaks of Panama's papers presented a directive that hardens trade secrets and leaves leakers unprotected right now. It confirms what we have been shouting in the squares for a long time: that this is not a crisis, it is a scam!

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the debate on the Panama Papers has so far focused on corrupt politicians and downright criminals who have hidden their wealth or laundered money. But at the heart of this scandal are the British overseas territories, and they are crucial to the global network that facilitates tax avoidance. More of half of the companies that appear in the files – 113 000 in total – are registered in the British Virgin Islands. It is the relationship between these overseas territories and the City of London that facilitates tax avoidance by the wealthy. David Cameron has sought to portray himself as the champion of tax transparency. Yet we have seen him personally intervene to water down provisions to control money laundering and to exclude the very sort of trusts that we now know he has benefited from. By enabling tax avoidance by the wealthy, the legal limbo-land of British overseas territories is depriving us of public revenue at the very time when the NHS is showing record debts and services to the disabled and vulnerable in my country are being slashed. So much for the slogan: ‘we are all in this together’.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Madam President, how many papers give a rare insight into how a corrupt global elite keeps millions in offshore tax havens? They cast light on secret structures in Panama that could be used for tax dodging, money laundering, corruption and terrorist financing. And remember, this is only the tip of the iceberg. One law firm, Mossack Fonseca; one country, Panama – but there are many others out there. We know that at least 8% of private household assets are hidden away in tax havens and that corporate profits for many of the biggest multinationals on this planet are shifted to tax havens. What we see is billions in tax money escaping European shores while our citizens are struggling with economic and social crisis – billions in tax money that could be used for public services, health, education and jobs. It is a provocation to ordinary citizens who pay their fair taxes and it destroys jobs when SME tax burdens are 30% higher than those of multinational corporations. And fundamentally, these economic criminals and tax evaders are undermining justice and eliminating trust in our societies and economies. Therefore we need effective rules about transparency and public country-by-country reporting, as is the case for the financial sector. We need to blacklist tax havens like Panama and the UK Virgin Islands. We need an easy way to identify beneficial ownership by public registration and end the secrecy around all types of entities, including trusts. And we need to end the global tax-dodging industry of tax advisers, banks, accounting firms and law firms like Mossack Fonseca when repeatedly and systematically engaging in tax dodging.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, since 2001 and the Clearstream case, there has been a scandal a year concerning tax evasion and tax trafficking. The truth is that all this is installed in the genetic code of the European Union, which promotes tax evasion.  Section 163 prohibits tax harmonization, which is to encourage the least—say. Section 63 facilitates all transactions and prohibits a country-to-country limit. That is why, because this system is legal, you have succeeded in electing as President of the Commission the person who was responsible for one of these scandals. And after two meetings of the session of the parliamentary committee, you still have not found anything. But on April 26, the two whistleblowers who exposed the scandal will be tried. They face up to 10 years in prison and a million euro fine. In these circumstances, with the Panama papers case, the same story starts again. Societe Generale, a French bank, was under the control of the ECB while it opened offshore companies. Its president lied under oath to French parliamentarians, but who is being prosecuted? It's me for defamation.  You have only one thing to do here because your devices are useless, it is to protect whistleblowers, because they pay dearly for their courage for all of us.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Panama is the tip of the iceberg. Someone says it's, in a way, a worn-out or outdated model. An indication in this regard is the striking absence of societies and large fortunes from the United States, perhaps because they already have other locations and even more sophisticated methods. The committee of inquiry we are proposing should look at the entire iceberg, in its entire dimension.  Combating tax avoidance is not just a moral issue: it is a question of fairness and economic efficiency. We must put an end to the parasitic capital that eats our well-being. We must return the productive capital that is to give us back, growth and social equity. The responsibility is, of course, the responsibility of their holders, including these ministers and former ministers, presidents of government, one of them, by the way, still an active member of the European Commission; in any case, also of the legal and financial apparatus that legalizes and launders that money.  But nothing would be possible without the silence or complicity of states. Tax avoidance is a cancer for Europe: when are we going to start applying the relevant preventive and curative treatments?

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Madam President, 'tax havens rob us', said Mr Moscovici literally. And I think it's the right expression. They're stealing from us. They rob all citizens, public estates and welfare. Not only do they launder black money, but they steal money from citizens. And we have to get that money back. For that, I think we have a fantastic opportunity, because there is outrage, there is citizen outrage, there is social alarm and there is an opportunity to get things right. Not with cadastrophism, not with the idea of changing absolutely everything, but with the idea of taking action little by little, in a battle that will be long, that will last a long time, but that can be a real fiscal revolution in the world in the next ten years. Let's start by establishing what the concept of fiscal paradise is, let's start by establishing the consensus list of tax havens, establishing sanctions against them, establishing agreements with banks so that they do not operate there, and we will win this battle, key to the future of tax and social justice in the world.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Panama papers: another global scandal that requires the European Union to combat financial crime schemes that facilitate tax evasion, corruption and all kinds of organised crime, including terrorism. It is imperative and urgent to confiscate the proceeds and punish politicians, banks, consultants and lawyers who serve, and use themselves, offshore secrecy to capture governments, rob citizens and democracy. The European Commission has proposed the mandatory publication of country-by-country accounts by multinationals but, in a thigh-stakes manner, it has to be about all the countries in which it operates and not just in Europe. It should also require the public register of beneficial owners of companies, foundations and trusts, accessible online to all citizens in the announced revision of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive.  But let us make no mistake, without tax harmonisation in the European Union tax dumping will continue, with several Member States serving as genuine tax havens and ruining others. That's what happens to Holland in relation to my country.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, you are in charge of a file which, for years, has not moved. I would hope that, under your leadership, with the support of this Parliament, as we have begun to do, and with the support of all those who, whistleblowers, journalists and citizens, are mobilised to put an end to this tax evasion scandal, we can make progress.  So I want here to assure you of our full support and to tell you my conviction that, if this European Parliament turns its special committee into a committee of inquiry, the only objective is to be able to consolidate our position in this struggle which we must carry out in a determined way, here in the European Union, on the basis of the proposals that we have to , day after day, you put on the table, but also in the G20 meetings, as this issue is an issue that we must deal with on an equal footing with our partners, if we are finally to meet the expectations of our fellow citizens in an area where, in the last few years, we have allowed too many multinationals to lead the way and where it is , today, it is up to us to say what the rule is. (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – The Panama Papers affair is of course attracting a lot of attention these days, but, let's be honest, this is not a matter from yesterday. We've known about her for a long time. Despite the fact that we have already taken a lot of action at European level and made a lot of agreements with third countries, this is clearly still not enough. It still smovs billions of euros past budgets. This is money that could be spent on our education, on our education, for children, employment, for new jobs. Tax evasion and concealment of illegally acquired property is, of course, inadmissible. But have we even tried to look at this story from the other side? Why are tax havens so friendly and attractive? Perhaps we should ask ourselves how unfriendly our domestic tax systems are. And we're going to have to do something about it.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the revelation of the Panama Papers represents a serious vulnus to the stability of the financial system, which is now a global public good.  There is a need for the affirmation of a concept of natural transparency in financial processes, but there is also a need for the European Union to react decisively to guide global governance. Action must therefore be taken as soon as possible to ensure transparency and responsible tax behaviour by providing for effective European provisions against tax avoidance and evasion.  Commissioner Hill's new proposal on country-by-country disclosure, i.e. the obligation for companies to make public the balance sheets of their activities and tax payments, country by country, must be supplemented by provisions blocking the transfer of profits to countries with lower taxes. The turnover threshold must be raised beyond which companies are subject to the notification obligation by extending it to all listed companies with transnational activities. 'European Union, take a hit'. Speak with one voice to protect European values.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, we did not need the Panama Papers to know that large multinational companies, which generate super profits, avoid tax through intra-group transactions and other means and hide their profits in tax havens. After all, experts estimate the amount of capital placed in these states from seven to twenty trillion dollars worldwide, i.e. between ten and thirty percent of Gross Global Product.  In the European Union, losses due to corporate avoidance through the transfer of profits are estimated at EUR 50 to 70 billion per year. The files leaked to the press show that the tax evasion practices mainly involved banking companies such as Société Générale and Deutsche Bank, but also other companies that have been involved in justice in the past, such as Siemens.  The European Union is responsible for the alleged investments of European companies in third countries. It is time to create a fair tax system, without grey areas, at pan-European level with the aim of stopping the tax dumping of multinational companies in Luxembourg and the Netherlands and taxing the profits of multinationals in the countries where they are reaped.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
