text: – Madam President, by which time will the fraudsters be faster than us, by which time the thieves will be faster than us, by which time the terrorists will be faster than us? I really wonder how some here can be against the creation of a common European intelligence body that will enable a truly effective fight against terrorism, but also an effective fight against fraud and thieves who are around us.  It all comes down to the same thing. Someone says yes, it was legal and it's some kind of tax avoidance or money laundering. It doesn't matter because in the end we don't have that money here, and we keep talking about how we're going to find more money for all the problems we face and for all the problems that we continuously discuss in this hall. I invite you, Mr. Commissioner, to perform very vigorously in the coming months. You have our trust and I believe in your efficiency.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the recent revelations via Panama of tax evasion and money laundering on a massive scale highlight the need for the European Union to react in cooperation with all those non-European states that prove willing to follow. The existence, in different parts of the world, of so-called 'tax havens' where all forms of organised economic crime are supported is a constant challenge, especially when the social protection systems of the economically weak are demolished in the name of the budgetary emergency.  A global list of States which confer unfair advantages on offshore funds should be drawn up and all remittances to banks in those States should be taxed. An integrated system for the protection of informants must also be established in order to solve financial crimes. The time for action is now.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: – As rapporteur for the fourth revision of the Directive on Money Laundering, I negotiated the public register for ultimately interested parties in that directive. Thank you to parliament for making that possible. That register is necessary to make letterbox companies impossible to work. To make these kinds of things like Panama papers public and not just have to rely on leaks, on investigative journalists.  Now I know that on 1 June the European Commission will come forward with new proposals to amend this directive again in order to tighten up terrorist financing. That seems to me to be the time to look at the register again, because one shortcoming in that register is that it does not take trusts with it. We could not negotiate that with the Council at that time, partly because David Cameron did not want to. But there were more Member States. So 1 June seems to me to be the right time for new proposals for trusts.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the revelations from the Panama Papers have prompted more states to open investigations. It is clear to everyone that the answer to tax avoidance and money laundering is to adopt global standards and automatic data sharing between all countries in the world. The problems of the Panama Papers were more than obvious. The loss of €50 million to €70 million a year in tax revenues is a huge obstacle to the growth and development of EU countries.  In March this year, the Special Committee on Tax Decisions was attended by representatives of multinational companies, who welcomed the OECD's global standards to help simplify and transparency tax rules, but would prefer to keep information about their business under wraps.  Today, the Commission has taken an important step further and requires the publication of key information, taking into account respect for trade secrets. This is an important step, and we are in for many more new steps and a special campaign to adopt transparency standards at the level of all countries in the world.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, combating tax fraud and money laundering is not a new action and concern of the European Commission and the Council. But the problem is what results we have. And, behold, after we talk in the Member States, in the European Union about good governance, we find that theft, tax fraud and money laundering are flourishing, creating an international network in which world officials are based. It is inadmissible, the citizens of the poor Member States, taxation kills small entrepreneurs while high-level devaluation continues. Rightly citizens ask what the Commission has done, what have the Member States done, what have international and national institutions done? It is a slap in the face to these institutions that some journalists have unmasked this Panama file. What do we do? Commissioner, firm action needs to be taken. Those caught with money laundering and tax fraud offences must pay for this, have their money confiscate and be banned from operating in the economic space.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for I am afraid that the problem that we have actually been in or are suffering from is much greater than what this debate shows today. I say this from personal experience, even as a newspaper reader: I do not know of any major European company that does not have some off-shore subsidiary, perhaps dozens or even hundreds. Banks, oil companies, huge large industrial companies have such capacities, which means that an unimaginable proportion of European income goes abroad virtually without paying tax, and this is why, in the last few years, practically 1% of the world has put its hand on more than 50% of the world's wealth. And I think that if we're going to take action against that, we're going to have to put some clean water in the glass. Thank you very much!

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, thank you Ladies and gentlemen, for this excellent debate which shows on all the benches the shared wish for a strong, active, I would even say virulent, fight against tax evasion and money laundering. The Panama Papers stressed the need for a more comprehensive, more coordinated and stronger approach to combating tax evasion, money laundering in the European Union and beyond the European Union.  We are dealing with a problem of such magnitude that we need a political response that is transnational, and this Commission, I want to say, is built around that and it is united for that. We are here several commissioners and we are really pulling in the same direction with great force. In the immediate future, the Commission has several even more ambitious initiatives in the pipeline, as they say in English.  For example, we will be presenting our amendments to the Anti-Money Laundering Directive by June, and this will further strengthen our preventive approach against this phenomenon, the fight against anonymous transactions and the coherence of our response to deal with this risk in third countries, but my colleague Vera Jourova is here to give you all the necessary details.  We will also return to the old project known as ACCIS (CCCTB), by the end of the year, with a desire to see it also contribute both to economic efficiency and to the fight against tax evasion, at least in the internal market. We will present a table that will trace the different regimes in third countries, and it will also be a first step to build the common blacklist that I mentioned by the summer. Then we will continue to work closely with our international partners — I am thinking of the G20, I am thinking of the OECD, I am thinking of the FATF — to ensure that the commitments that are made are commitments that are gradually becoming standards of good global governance. And I know how much these concerns, I say, are shared by the Dutch Presidency, which is really very invested in this subject. Jeroen Dijsselbloem and his Secretary of State fully share our concern for success, and I believe that by June we must make decisive progress and put Member States in front of their responsibilities. Then we'll go further, too. There are a lot of proposals that have been made here that need to inform our thinking. That is the echo I wanted to give to the reflections of parliamentarians, with three answers that I want to give in a particular way to parliamentarians for whom I have esteem, but with whom I have a slightly different relationship.  First to Mr Lucke, who questioned why the Commission had not acted earlier. He is well aware that the Commission can only propose and, in this respect, I will say, for example, with regard to the proposal for the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings, that we have accelerated the project considerably and that we have taken advantage of the movement to go faster.  I think the Panama Papers are also a point of support. Rather than criticising the Commission, I think that the European Parliament and we really need to work hand in hand because, I repeat, we are allies. We have the same convictions. Mr Woolfe, with his usual elegance, wanted to present the European Commission as I do not know what a tax haven, to accuse the 47,000 civil servants of this system of being so many fraudsters and the Commissioners, basically, to be their leaders. I hardly caricature, and all this is really outrageous because, contrary to popular belief - and I take this opportunity to say it here - we pay taxes! Of course, the Commissioner's idea, which I do not know which international official is tax-free, is totally false, and this applies, of course, to all Commission officials. On the contrary, we have an approach that saves money over the 2014-2020 period. I would remind you that we will make savings for our entire administration in the order of EUR 4.3 billion, and EUR 1.5 billion per year over the long term, with a policy of wage moderation. European Union officials pay progressive taxes of between 8% and 45%, which are in fact far greater than what is done in the Member States. I'm not talking about tax havens. They also, of course, pay social contributions. Therefore, let us stop this kind of demagoguery or I will also go and ask for other income in Britain. And then, still a little decency! I would like to point out here that there are two MEPs, members of Ukip, who have been sentenced to Prison. I say prison, for fraud committed with public money. So, frankly, first of all this is totally wrong, and then it's more than bad taste. You have to start by sweeping in front of your door. Finally, my last answer is for Mr Lamberts, for whom I have the highest esteem, and who is a very good connoisseur of these subjects. Besides, we end up having exchanges that all look the same because he apostrophes me, and then he goes away, and he is not there when I answer him. So this is probably very interesting videos, but it is better from time to time to confront each other and wait for the Commission to respond. I was really hurt by what he said. He said that our last exchange was pleasant and that he had made him laugh, and so did I. This one is not pleasant and it does not make me laugh because basically it has accused the Commission of waiting and of being in the hand of I do not know what lobby. There is nothing that is more false, nothing that is more false! Earlier, Jonathan Hill presented a proposal for a directive on the CbCR that goes beyond what all international bodies are proposing. The OECD threshold of EUR 750 million is the OECD threshold. When you look at the OECD, what does it say about the scope? It says exchange between tax administrations; we say advertising. And then I think, for once, he was wrong. We will know, of course, what any multinational in Belgium, Ireland, elsewhere in Europe and outside Europe does. We will ask for aggregated data and even, for some countries that are tax havens, we will ask for detailed data. We are the first in the world, the first in the world! The most ambitious in the world. So I understand that a parliamentarian is in politics. I understand that it is more demanding, and I can understand that he wants us to go further, and the Member States will have that responsibility, if any. But, finally, when we make collective progress, when we do it together, when it goes in the right direction, we must be able to say: 'Yes, that is good!' instead of stigmatising or accusing the Commission. I repeat: we are allies. We are allies, and this Commission, all the Commissioners who are there, under the authority of the President, who is in constant support on these subjects, we want to be the engines, the leaders in the world of the fight against tax evasion. What is being proposed by this Commission is of unprecedented ambition in the history of the European institutions. That is, because I know that Mr. Lamberts is very intelligent and knows these subjects very well, I am obliged to infer that there is a part of bad faith on this point. This is not the right way to do politics, because we have to respect each other and pull in the same direction. That is what I want to do with him, with the Green Group, as with all the groups in this House, for whom I have the greatest consideration.  Yes, the European Parliament and the Commission have the same purpose. This purpose, we know it, is transparency and it is the fight against tax evasion. So let's move forward together rather than engaging in bad polemics that are, I think, counterproductive in truth. This Commission is an institution like all the others, which is not perfect. No institution is, but I assure you that, frankly, on these subjects, it does not have to be ashamed of what it does, and today, in particular, I am very proud of what we have decided and what Jonathan Hill has presented, because it is a step forward that no country in the world, no region in the world can claim. We can!

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to add a short comment in response to your questions about money laundering. You are right that we have to put in place a number of measures to ensure that authorities have stronger powers to fight money laundering and that suspect transactions are reported to them. As you know, we have already achieved considerable results with the Fourth Anti—Money Laundering Directive, adopted in December 2014, which, among other things, provides for the setting-up of central registers of beneficial ownership. It now awaits speedy transposition and implementation by the Member States, which is crucial because it has to be brought to life. The registers should be set up by the end of 2016. The Commission is prepared to provide all necessary support for this transposition, and I am keeping actively in touch with my counterparts in the Member States on this issue. You are also right that the Commission is now working on the revision of this directive. As announced in the action plan on terrorist financing, the revising proposal should be submitted on 1 June; it is focused primarily on addressing risks posed by terrorist financing, and especially on anonymous payments and the like, given that, according to security experts, financial transactions are very often the first indications that terrorist attacks are being prepared. So we need to tackle this issue. Finally, as also announced in the action plan, the Commission will take forward a legislative proposal harmonising money laundering-related criminal offences and penalties.

name: Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, a lot has been said, so I think I can cut a long story very short. The Panama Papers revelations do show us that the European Union’s work against tax fraud and against money laundering is essential. These are common goals and it is our joint responsibility to pursue them further at a global level by taking up the role of front-runner. To be clear, the Council wants to know the facts as much as you, Parliament, and – I am convinced – the Commission. That is why we will examine the information in the Panama Papers and examine closely our policies with a view to making our fight against evasion and fraud as effective as possible. I am certain all the EU Institutions will take up their responsibility, and I am certain we can and will work together in this. So yes, we will continue our fight and we are determined to work fast and in an efficient manner on all the elements I mentioned. I call on all the Member States and the European Parliament to support us by working with us on the measures currently on the table and on the measures that will follow, most probably, in the very near future.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We have already debated the tightening of anti-money laundering and tax avoidance rules in the EP in May 2005. In accordance with the provisions of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive (AMLD) adopted at the time, banks, financial institutions and persons of "legitimate interest" having access to a central register are required to pay attention to suspicious transactions.  The discovery of the largest-ever "Panama Papers" financial scandal, revealing information about more than 200,000 companies set up in tax havens and their secret owners who have carried out billions of tax frauds, is due to the insight and cooperation of hundreds of journalists affiliated with the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ). Efforts in all Member States need to be stepped up in order to combat tax fraud effectively.  The existence of tax havens must be categorically opposed. A Europe-wide blacklist should be drawn up, together with a list of places where information is concealed, and sanctions should be imposed on the organisations using it. And representatives of mossack fonseca, from which the information was leaked, and representatives of the Government of Panama should stand before a special parliamentary committee dealing with tax matters TAXE II.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. - Change in european politics as a whole! The Luxleaks, Dieselgate and now Panama Papers scandals perfectly show how the issue of transparency and the purity of public life in Europe stands today. Unfortunately, it is safe to say that the whole of Europe has been 'desized and found to be light'. The Panama Papers have revealed one of the tools used by the global elite to conceal their incomes, avoiding the burden of sharing in their home countries. Which also creates the possibility of carrying out all kinds of illegal economic activities. Meanwhile, poverty is increasing throughout Europe, with less and less money coming from public budgets for public services, education, health, the unemployed, the homeless and refugees. This injustice must end. It is the common responsibility of European legislators to prevent 'tax optimisation' without limits. As a first step, transparency of the finances of the political elite must be ensured at European and Member State level. Rules on conflicts of interest and declarations of assets of those in different political functions and their families should be regulated in a strict, transparent and verifiable manner. At the same time, the transparency rules for the economic elite need to be clarified. We complain that people do not trust politicians, as evidenced by the nearly half a million signatories who signed the initiative calling for the accountability of offshore companies and the banks involved. Until we do that, we will not be able to regain the trust of the electorate.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Panama's geographical location promotes the development of international trade and banking services. Panama has worked for more than 100 years on the reputation of a tax haven. The attractiveness of offshore companies operating in tax havens lies in: m.in. in: total secrecy of information (including access to data on company owners), low or zero taxation of income, no requirement for tax returns. Tax evasion and offshore money laundering have thus become some of the most profitable financial crimes for many actors around the world.  The law firm Mossack Fonseca, which has been operating since 1977, has achieved perfection in financial assembly based on the concealment of real beneficiaries and bank accounts associated with the company. The scale of the activities revealed requires the urgent establishment of a common effective policy to combat tax havens. While there are international rules on tax transparency and the EU, working with Member States, has created a number of tools (a list of international tax havens, three fiscal reform packages focusing mainly on the exchange of information within the EU, agreements with third countries to exchange information also outside the EU), the Panama Papers scandal should be used to improve the effectiveness of existing measures and thus crack down on such fraud.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. As always, Europe is only outraged when scandals of this kind explode. How can we hope to change that when some of the highest-ranking politicians are the first to use these methods to steal profits from their own national coffers? I wonder what the credibility is of people like Juncker or Djiesselbloem, who are themselves part of a system of tax havens within the EU. Yesterday we were shocked by LuxLeaks, today by the Panama Papers: tomorrow we may find out something about the Virgin Islands, Bermuda or the Caymans, nothing new in the sun. In order to try to solve the root of the problem, we must start from a certain fact, the clear responsibility of the banks in all these events, the main players in this sick system. It only takes a few hundred euros to set up offshore companies and thus take huge resources away from the community, and the banks make money in these transactions: those who cooperate with tax havens should first be properly penalised in economic terms, and then we should arrive at the withdrawal of the banking licence for those who are complicit in these scams. The means of intervening are there, what is probably lacking is the political will to do so.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It is good that the Council and the Commission have, as a matter of urgency, raised issues relating to tax avoidance and money laundering before the EP. This is the result of the recent Panama Papers scandal, which has shown that tax avoidance is a mass phenomenon. It is not necessary to explain how negative this affects the economies, the equality of market players, the widening of inequalities between people and, finally, how significantly reduces the possibilities for solving acute social problems. It is appalling that only this one scandal reveals information about more than 200,000 companies and their owners who, wanting to avoid paying taxes, register their businesses in tax havens.  Since this is not the first such case, I am in favour of not just finalised the matter in the debate. A special committee should be set up in the EP to deal with tax matters in the European Union as a whole. A Europe-wide blacklist of tax havens and places where tax avoidance information is deliberately concealed should be created. Eu solutions as well as national solutions must lead to a reduction in these pathologies.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Parliament has been urging the European Commission and the European Council to strengthen legislative initiatives and coordination on the ground to combat tax avoidance and money laundering, which, in addition to being actions against fairness and justice, contribute to increasing competitiveness and growth capacity asymmetries within the European Union and in the world.  The TAXE Commission recently adopted a robust set of recommendations to address phenomena such as those identified in the leaks in Luxembourg (Luxleaks) and Panama Papers. In May 2015 the European Parliament approved the revision of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, which requires central registers on beneficial owners of companies, foundations, trusts and other entities to be established and maintained in all Member States. Recent revelations show that the measures in force are not effective. It is urgent to put into force the approved Directive and the TAXE recommendations. Further measures will be needed after the inquiry into what has happened, but first of all, it is important to implement the measures already designed, with a great sense of urgency.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The following item is a debate on the Commission's statement: The decision on public transparency of taxation (2016/2552(RSP)).

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think we just heard in that last debate that it has been a long-standing priority for the Commission to work to make sure that taxes are paid more where profits are generated. I think we heard from Commissioner Moscovici on both the range of the measures that have been taken and the passion with which he is pursuing this. Clearly, as we discussed in the last debate, the Panama Papers have sharpened the focus, but the proposal that the Commission has brought forward today, to require all large multinationals operating in Europe to publish information on the tax that they pay country-by-country, pre-dates the Panama Papers. Our proposal builds on the work that has been taken forward by the OECD to require the sharing of information related to corporate income tax between tax authorities. But it goes a step further, and we are the first in the world to require the biggest multinationals to make key information public. Why? Because this greater transparency will shine a light and help us ask whether we indeed have the right laws in place. It can help the public see whether companies are acting in the best long-term interests of their shareholders from a reputational point of view. In working on this proposal in recent months we have been guided by a number of clear principles. First, that we should aim to be consistent, with international work being taken forward by the OECD and endorsed by the G20. Then, that we should build on the major reforms already taken forward by my colleague Commissioner Moscovici and others to increase transparency and to fight tax avoidance. We should bring forward measures that will affect all the biggest multinationals operating in Europe, not just the European ones. We should be proportionate in what we do in two main respects: first, we should not undermine the position of European businesses vis-à-vis their global competitors; and second, we should not burden small and medium-sized European businesses – the lifeblood of our economy – which typically operate in one country. Indeed, for me it is this wish to protect the competitive position of our SMEs which lies at the heart of, and is an important part of, this proposal. It should not be the case that smaller companies, which do not know how to shift their profits – they cannot afford the clever tax advice to minimise their bills – should be at a competitive disadvantage compared with the big multinational companies. In some higher-tax countries it is the case that some of the big multinationals can pay up to 30% less tax than would be paid by the smaller companies. I say this as someone who is pro-business, but I would prefer businesses to be concentrating on their customers – on the services they offer, on product innovation, on true competition – rather than the competition of the creativity of their tax advisers. So this legislation that we are proposing would require the biggest multinationals – those with a global turnover above EUR 750 million – to publish information in a number of key areas. On a country-by-country basis, they would in future need to publish the nature of their business activities; how many staff they have; their net turnover; their profit before tax; the amount of tax due based on yearly profits; the amount of tax they actually paid in that same year, and their accumulated earnings. They would also be required to report on the total tax they pay outside the EU. In addition – and this links to our last debate on the Panama papers – if they pay taxes outside the EU, in countries that do not abide by international governance standards on tax matters – so-called tax havens – multinationals would have to publish the same detailed information as for a European country. We think that, taken together, this information will give a clear idea of whether a large multinational is paying its tax where it makes its profits. The information would have to be made available for five years on the company’s website so that anyone who is interested could see where multinationals are paying their tax and whether there is a level playing field for all businesses. To make sure European companies are not disadvantaged, these rules would apply also to the subsidiaries of non-European multinationals doing business in Europe, as well as to large European multinationals. European banks already have to comply with a specific transparency regime in the Capital Requirements Directive that includes country-by-country reporting, so they will not be affected by today’s proposal. The only change would be that large banks established outside the EU but doing business inside it would in future be required to publish a country-by-country report. In preparing this proposal we have looked at the rules already in place for the banks in extractive industries. We have given careful consideration to the ideas that were discussed in this House for the Shareholders’ Rights Directive, and we sought to strike a balanced approach – one that does not harm the competitiveness of European businesses but that is nevertheless ambitious on greater tax transparency. It is now, of course, for the Council and Parliament to consider our proposal. The Commission consulted widely before bringing it forward. We have listened to the views of all interested parties and fed them into our analysis. I think that, as a result of that, the College believes we have a simple, proportionate way to increase accountability. Now our ambition is to get this agreed as quickly as possible. With your help and the help of Member States we need to seize this opportunity to promote fairer competition and to build trust not just in our tax system but also to build trust again in Europe’s businesses.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner Hill, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, thank the Commissioner here today and for his explanations regarding his proposal. I agree with the Commissioner that we certainly have to be committed to the fight against tax engineering and, above all, for one reason explained to us by the Commissioner: we cannot allow our SMEs, which are the engine of growth and job creation in the European Union, to be tax disadvantaged over large multinationals. The circumvention of corporation tax and pernicious tax competition are two of the great challenges we face in the European Union. Large companies and large multinationals are without the complexity of tax rules and the lack of cooperation of Member States in shifting their profits and minimizing their tax burden and, dear colleagues, we cannot afford it. Fiscal transparency must be one of our objectives to ensure that past mistakes are not repeated.  The European Commission has presented its proposal to us in defence of the interests of European citizens, SMEs and transparency; welcome these proposals. We must be able to demand sufficient data to distinguish the part of the activity of a business with a multinational scope from that which is related to a specific jurisdiction. In short, we cannot allow the resources of the citizens so needed to be eluded in other fields such as education and health care.

name: Elisa Ferreira
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the European Commission for presenting the proposal which obliges multinationals to publicly report key elements of their activity in the various countries. My words are sincere, they're compliment, they're encouraging. That said, there are, in fact, two elements where progress was still possible and would be welcome. It makes no sense, despite the explanations you were kind enough to give us, that all multinationals with a turnover of less than 750 million are excluded from this report. We end up covering only 10 to 15% of multinationals and the information that is requested is absolutely banal to any company operating in more than one country. As you mentioned, the banking sector also follows this practice and gets along well with it.  The second question concerns the exclusion of this report from operations carried out outside the Union, which may be presented in aggregate form, that is to say, without the identification of the country where the transaction takes place. The inthe meantime obligation to report transactions made in tax havens, once they are defined, goes in the right direction. However, this possibility of reporting, in aggregate, transactions in jurisdictions that are not from the European Union and are also not tax havens, can lead to an unintended effect, which is to relocate the concentration of profit to jurisdictions that have an option, a tax offer, particularly advantageous and that is not what we wanted for Europe. So you can count on the support of this Parliament and you can also count on it if you want to improve the proposal you have put forward to us at the moment. Congratulations on what's been done and let's keep going.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – In this European Parliament, we have already talked a lot about tax fraud, about the special tricks that large multinationals sometimes conjure up. In order to combat this fraud, we need to implement the OECD proposals. And then I refer to the so-called OECD anti-BEPS plan. We could also speak of an anti-Panama plan.  I think it is an excellent thing that today the European Commission is coming forward with proposals. Thank you, Commissioner Hill, for that. The proposal we are discussing today, this country by country reporting, is a good idea. International companies will have to show where they operate, where they make profits, where they employ people, what occupation they have. But also where they pay taxes and how much taxes. This is an important step forward and also logical to regulate this European. Because if we did that with 28 Member States, we would only have a lot more red tape. We get 28 tax returns and we get less transparency. I'm already oping for this win win.

name: Michael Theurer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The Commission's proposal on country-specific reporting requirements is a significant step forward in the fight against aggressive tax planning models. In the report of the TAXE-1 Special Committee, which this Parliament has adopted, we asked the Commission to present a country-by-country reporting proposal. It is important to establish transparency with regard to the tax authorities at long last. That is also the OECD template that is being implemented here. It is gratifying that the Commission's proposal goes beyond the OECD proposal. This is a real, visible signal that the European Union is committed to tax transparency.  It is precisely in the light of the Panama revelations that we are called upon to act here. At the same time, public reporting obligations, which are also being proposed, must now be carefully examined as to what these proposals mean, whether the threshold is correctly chosen, for example, whether this does not cause some companies to fall through the rust and whether the balance between, on the one hand, tax transparency and, at the same time, the legitimate desire to protect trade secrets, which is also called for in the REPORT of the TAXE Special Committee, is sufficiently taken into account.  There are fears from companies that the reports could then benefit competitors and also states that are not to be regarded as constitutional states. It is also right – and this too is a demand from TAXE 1 – to present a blacklist of tax havens.  Finally, I believe that it can be said on this point that public pressure and also the work of this Parliament – in the TAXE Special Committee, above all, and also in the ECON Committee – help to make important progress. In the future, companies will have to show that they pay their taxes where they generate added value and profit. We want to put an end to the aggressive tax avoidance schemes and to put an end to the competitive disadvantages of small and medium-sized enterprises and to create a level playing field.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr Hill, very little and too late what you have presented to us. The Commission's proposal is both delayed and inadequate, but even if it is fully and successfully implemented, it leaves uncovered a large part of the companies that make an of tax evasion, avoidance and tax fraud and will find the techniques to adapt to the thresholds that you set. Unfortunately, the Panama Papers leaks and the journalistic investigation have revealed more than the mechanisms of the European Commission and the Council, as well as of the Member States. We have a provocative lack of justice, but also a lack of healthy competition, in favour of multinationals at the expense of small and medium-sized enterprises, at the expense of fair taxpayers and at the expense of states' efforts to build a social state, public education and public health.  At last, profits need to be taxed where they are produced, there must be a register, tax harmonisation at European level and strict penalties. The Commission must also dare the Council, which is absent, and the Member States not to constantly put obstacles in the way of trying to combat this angry tax evasion and tax fraud.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the Panama scandal is obviously shocking a lot of people. One has the feeling that our democracies are working more and more for a few. And look, the proposal that brings us fiscal transparency - which, by the way, we have been asking for since 2010 - is, once again, a good idea, but it is an insufficient proposal on the part of the Commission. It is insufficient because you, once again, set this cap of EUR 750 million in revenue from which companies will have to do that exercise, but you leave out many others which we think should too. And, on the other hand, with regard to the proposal that they bring us from the list of tax havens on the basis of a delegated act, there is no timetable for this delegated act in their proposal, nor do we have clear criteria on how that list will be made. So it seems to us that it is a proposal which, frankly, falls very short. And let me tell you: if we do not act decisively, clearly and courageously to combat tax havens, this Commission and the Member States will lose all credibility, if they still have it.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this debate highlights the crossroads at which the British people find themselves: in any society there is a balance to be struck on tax and transparency. On the one hand, we could publish every detail of every person’s earnings and every tax return. We could say: if you have done nothing wrong, you have nothing to hide. It would be transparent, but it would provide no privacy. After all, you could allow phone tapping, you could allow looking into anyone’s internet history or you could even ban  curtains, if you followed that logic. On the other hand, we could do the complete opposite. We could respect everybody’s privacy, publish absolutely nothing and allow things not to be exposed when they should be. That would make it difficult to deal with tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. It would make it harder to ensure that multinationals do not have a competitive advantage over SMEs. But here is the point. If on 23 June the United Kingdom votes to leave the European Union, we will have the sovereign right to take those decisions for ourselves and be able to get the balance right between justice and privacy. However, if the UK votes to stay in, those decisions will continue to be taken remotely in Brussels and Strasbourg. So there is a fundamental choice here: who governs Britain? Is it this place, or is it Westminster?

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: - (DE) Mr President, I would like to thank We discussed the Panama Papers beforein, and the subject that Commissioner Hill has presented goes in the same direction: wherever there is no transparency, no reporting requirements, no overview, there is an opportunity for tax evasion, tax avoidance, anonymous one-person companies, etc. That is why your proposal as a whole is in the right direction, but I do not think it is enough. The proposal for the fourth anti-money laundering directive, which has indeed been presented with regard to the fight against terrorism, also needs to be clarified with regard to letterbox companies. I also believe that the last word on one-person societies cannot yet be spoken. If we demand transparency for letterbox companies throughout the world, not only in Panama, but above all in the British crown colonies, then we must not create a new partnership that will make this possible precisely because it is no longer the owner who is made public, but lawyers can also do so. In other words, the great package you have set out to do is supported, it is a first way. In addition, however, I am convinced that we must resolve the outstanding issues in a committee of inquiry, particularly in connection with the Panama Papers. I am also convinced that our group will support this.

name: El Presidente. –
text: I know that there is a request for intervention under the 'blue card' procedure, but I have to inform you that, for reasons we mentioned earlier, we will not be able to grant that right which is also yours. But this time the Regulation is explicit. It's not possible because there's no time. I appreciate your understanding.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Transparency is an essential weapon in the fight against tax evasion and money laundering. Transparency is therefore the first basis for greater fairness in tax morality – but that will not be enough. As mentioned earlier, we need the large package, that is to say a global financial register, as the basis for an automatic exchange of information, so that we can also find out the real beneficial owners, or the protection of whistleblowers – there is a great deal to be done. And genuine full public country-by-country reporting for as many companies as possible, including outside the European Union, is absolutely necessary.  Commissioner, there is more to your proposal. I now have very specific questions for you: firstly, on the 750 million, the threshold: this is the OECD threshold – i do not think it is particularly committed. What do you do with companies like McDonald's that live off everything into small franchises, then be noisy SMEs, how do we approach them?  Please look at the Accounting Directive and the Transparency Directive! There are thresholds here that are lower, so it must be feasible. The cost is not a corresponding explanation. Finally, the definition of the blacklist of tax havens. Here the text still seems to me to be a construction site. Can I take the criteria as an alternative now, or do I have to take them cumulatively? The latter is unacceptable.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I think we all agree in this House that it is unacceptable that large corporations do not pay taxes in the country where they have generated their profits and small and medium-sized enterprises are being subject to the greatest tax burden. He is particularly pleased that President Juncker, too, seems to share this view, which is not always the case in the past, judging by his previous activities.  Country-by-country reporting seems to be the right tool in the fight against tax avoidance, not tax harmonisation. That is why I really think that commissioner Hill's proposal is a good step, in the right direction. It is worthy of emphasising the obligation on corporations to make public tax-important information. It is important that the leaked reports also cover subsidiaries registered in countries defined by the EU as 'tax havens'.  On the other hand, it is worrying that only around 10 to 15 per cent of multinationals would be affected, as the Commission's proposal would require only companies with an annual turnover of more than EUR 75 million to report to the public. And here we should think about changing this point of the proposal.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President! If there is one thing we can learn from the many revelations about tax havens, it is that tax havens and tax evasion are at their best in the dark. They live best hidden from the public. Therefore, we also know that our strongest card against tax evasion is openness, and it is public opinion about tax matters, and not least ownership.  Now we have another tax haven scandal and another chance to show the public that we are actually going to do away with it. So let us put action behind the words and insist on full publicity about country-to-country reporting and, not least, on who are the real owners of companies and foundations. We must not allow ourselves to be restricted by the borders of the European Union. Country-by-country reporting must, of course, apply not only within the EU, but to the activities of companies in all countries, so that we get real and compartmentaled reports that developing countries can also benefit from. There's no need to wait for anyone else. Let us take the lead now - lead the way for full transparency for all businesses.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, everyone will be speaking today to congratulate the Commission on its work on tax transparency. Far be it from me to break this beautiful and touching moment of European communion. But finally, dare I point out that in July this Parliament passed a resolution that is far more ambitious than the text you are presenting today - but that is not the point of my remarks. I would just like to draw attention tonight to those through whom we have been able and we can have this debate today. I would like to pay tribute to those who, despite the risks they face and the prosecution they face, are involved in the defence of the public interest: I am thinking of whistleblowers. So there's only one question, Commissioner. It's simple, but I'm asking you to answer in conscience. Why do we have to wait for ordinary citizens to report facts that everyone knows before the Commission finally wants to act on tax transparency?

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I believe that the Commission has done quite a lot so far towards measures to prevent tax evasion, aggressive tax planning, money laundering. The problem, however, is that people are waiting much longer and, lo and behold, we have been talking for years about this list of tax havens that do not want to cooperate in terms of tax transparency. I am glad that the Commission has finally made a commitment that in a few months it will come out with this list.  Why am I saying this? Because I think we need to be more determined here. I believe that in the European Union we must have the initiative that absolutely no one, no company, no bank will make any more transactions of any kind with these tax havens that do not want to cooperate in tax transparency and that the United States of America and other countries do the same. Today we are surprised to learn that two UK-dependent jurisdictions say they do not want to disclose any financial information. I hope that in the end the UK will succeed in making them understand that we need tax transparency.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in the past few months, this Parliament has adopted a country-by-country reporting text as part of a directive, the directive on shareholder rights, which represents the mountain.  Today, the Commission is presenting us with the mouse that was born from that mountain.  I do not despise anything, but I have a great deal of respect for the work that has been done, but it cannot be denied that we are faced with a largely inadequate solution for the reasons that have been given in the debate. The OECD model has been taken as a reference, but the OECD model was considered by us to be largely inadequate, just like your proposal. Think about the threshold. The threshold, as my colleague Mrs Ferreira reminded you earlier, excludes a large proportion not of small businesses, but of large multinational companies. Parliament's hypothesis involved 20 000 companies, here we are close to the thousand and twentieth century involved. Our information, the information requested, was to include ownership, sale and public subsidies; there is no mention of this in your proposal.  We had imagined that we had this information not only articulated, but from all the States of the European Union and the rest of the world, where these companies work; You are only talking about the European Union and tax havens that have yet to be defined, and I would really be curious to see what criteria you will adopt. So thank you for the effort you've made, but realize that we're in a real place for us...

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the proposal by the Commission on mandatory disclosure by multinational companies of income tax information. This is yet another legislative initiative aimed at improving tax collection and reducing the scope for tax evasion and aggressive tax planning in Europe. It responds to the growing demand from European citizens for more transparency and fairness in tax policies. I believe we are all keen to ensure as conducive a business environment as possible for European companies, but at the same time we expect these companies to pay their fair share of taxes in our countries. The draft directive requires multinational companies to make public information on a well-defined and limited set of tax information. It does not impose on them an additional administrative burden, as all the required information is already reported by companies to their shareholders and respective national tax authorities. It helps to re-establish a level playing field between EU and non-EU companies and it reduces the scope for aggressive tax planning by large multinationals. It also raises public awareness of tax issues and strengthens the sense of corporate social responsibility among European businesses. However, having said that, I would like to call on the Commission and Parliament not to go too far with the new requirements. The need for more tax transparency must not hamper the competitive position of European enterprises vis-à-vis their international rivals. Our ambition should be to ensure that the EU becomes the most attractive and business—friendly region globally.

name: Peter Simon (S&D).
text: Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his I would like to follow on from the speeches made earlier by Mrs Ferreira and Mrs Regner. Setting the threshold for country-by-country reporting at EUR 750 million makes sense first of all if you follow your figures, because it means that you will cover about 90% of all taxable revenue that we are talking about. But taxation is also a justice issue, and when we see, conversely, that almost 90% of all companies operating in different countries do not fall within the scope of this high threshold at all, I have a problem of justice. Large companies as such should explain in which country they pay for what income and how much tax. We have defined the question of what a large company is at various points in EU legislation. 40 million is the threshold, and I believe that this is precisely what we should be building on. This is a balanced proposal in order to avoid what you want to avoid, which is to place unnecessary burdens on small and medium-sized enterprises. But at the same time, there is room for manoeuvre to broaden the scope of the truly interesting companies in the interests of tax justice.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the Commission’s proposals of today and congratulate Commissioner Hill for bringing those proposals forward. I think there is huge public support for his initiative and that of the Commission when it comes to tax transparency. We should not, however, confuse tax competition on the one hand and tax transparency on the other. It is perfectly logical that we can have both, and we need to have both so that Europe remains strong and we can compete against the United States and other regions of the world. I very much support the fact that in the proposals announced today, the Commission has set out its view that companies who operate in Europe can no longer aggregate what they provide in terms of offshore locations. It now has to be provided offshore by offshore, as it were, and also that would be crucially important for making sure that there is some confidence in the use of those companies wherever they have their operation. Finally, I want to say this. If we can do anything to speed up this procedure, rather than having it in place in 2018, we should be ambitious enough to have this in place in the earliest possible timeframe.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, many colleagues have said this on all fronts: it is because there have been whistleblowers, the revelation of scandals, the mobilization of associations and NGOs, the pressure, too, from the European Parliament - for once, we can be congratulated - that we are coming to this text today which, unquestionably, is going in the right direction. , because country-by-country reporting allows both real traceability of multinational profits and a return to tax equality. I would like to remind you, like others, that SMEs now pay much more in taxes on corporations than multinationals, which is good, but as my Social Democrat colleagues and Peter Simon have said many times, at the moment I believe that we can go further on turnover, because the figure of 40 million that we are advancing rather than $750 million, it is already in the accounting directive to characterize a large company - let's go, let's have that audacity.  As for the mapping of information, this was said by Mrs Ferrara earlier - 28 countries, that is good, tax havens are good, but we must not encourage fraudulent schemes in other countries; so, on these two points, the Social Democrats ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Thank you for this proposal, which I welcome. I particularly appreciate the fact that it is built on the principle of not burdening entrepreneurs with further unnecessary administration. In particular, SMEs should not be exposed to competitive disadvantages. In this context, I am glad that these undertakings are not affected by the proposal, but I think it is a pity that this is not explicitly mentioned in the proposal. In any case, because of these small and medium-sized enterprises, your proposal should be welcomed, they are the ones who bear the burden of taxes even for large enterprises that hide in tax havens.  On the issue of transparency, we need to try a solution that does not make European businesses, and especially small and large ones, less competitive.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Mr President, what a difference a scandal makes. Before LuxLeaks and the Panama papers, those of us who were calling for country—by—country reporting were told that it was never going to happen. But here we are today, with the Commission finally acting against the appalling injustice of aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion. It is important to recognise moments like this. I am proud to see the introduction of a measure I called for in my report last year, supported by my Labour and Socialist colleagues, though opposed by the UK conservatives. With the backing of great efforts from civil society right across Europe, it goes to show that, acting together in the EU, we can achieve change. But this is no time for complacency; the Commission’s proposals need improvement. The EUR 750 million threshold is too high, and we need companies to break down their reports by every country in the world, not just the 28 Member States and a handful of the very worst tax havens. Today is a milestone for tax justice, but the hard work is only just beginning.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: – "Tax Freedom Day" appears to have fallen for some very early in the year in recent decades. Just after New Year even for the biggest creatives, it turns out.  For example, such a Tax Freedom Day would essentially lose every sentence and we would get rid of it better. I wasn't in favor anyway. "Celebrating" days like this seems a bit double. Yes, we have to be critical of what the government does with our tax dollars, but at the same time there is also something like civics. On the contrary, we should be proud that by contributing to the public purse, public services are paid for which are the core and strength of our European social welfare states. In this context, I even see this Commission proposal as an opportunity for companies: companies must also be able to show 'citizenry': contribute to infrastructure, to the training of staff and so on, but in those countries where they make their profits.  The government also has a duty: a duty not to make these companies un needlessly vulnerable by allowing them to release overly sensitive information. Fortunately, the proposal seems to be balanced in this respect and, in any case, exempts SMEs from unnecessary administrative burdens.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am neither cynical nor naïve. Big business can be tamed fiscally, but this can only be achieved if we tackle it on a global scale. (The President deprives the speaker of the floor.)

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – I believe that the Commission's actions are going in the right direction. We can say that we are finally moving from words to actions. We need more transparency and more data sharing. In this way, we will certainly also achieve a better tax environment for all, better tax systems.  It is intolerable that large multinationals are enriched at the expense of small and medium-sized enterprises. Everyone has to pay taxes in proportion to their potential. However, we must be consistent in this. We must not allow measures to turn around in such a way that Europe becomes less competitive. Large multinationals also create many jobs.  We must therefore also require Member States not only to be transparent, but to adapt their tax systems in a way that is simple and competitive.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I welcome the European Commission's proposals. Three things I want to pay attention to. Firstly, that there will be changes to the Accounting Directive, or horizontal instrument, that is what we are talking about. The issue of introducing the need for reporting through companies that operate on the European market but are based in other countries. This is what we have been demanding for a long time, and that should improve the fairness of the functioning of the fiscal element. Finally, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the European EU list pointing to specific jurisdictions that do not meet the relevant financial reporting requirements will in fact help us to fight all this more effectively.  There have been quite a few calls for ambition on the part of the European Commission, that this is not enough, that more is needed. For me, it is more important that these will be provisions that will have a real chance of actually appearing in our reality, and this will only happen if the proposed ones remain in their original proposed form.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome Commissioner Hill’s proposals today building on the work that is being done at OECD level and the base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS) movements there, going of course one step further in ensuring that there is public disclosure of tax paid by multinationals and which countries it is paid in within the EU. It is very important in terms of transparency. I welcome and would agree with your comments, Commissioner, also when you say you are pro-business. I would be pro-business also because I think business is important, whether they be multinationals, SMEs or micro-enterprises, because businesses employ people and they do provide very valuable employment. Indeed many SMEs also depend on the existence of multinationals in the supply chain and also provide services to the employees there. So there is a symbiotic relationship that needs to be recognised. Nonetheless, if the figures are that the tax authorities across the EU are losing EUR 50 to 70 billion a year, I think it is time that action was taken to ensure that multinationals pay taxes in the jurisdiction in which they make their profit.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Tax evasion and tax avoidance have become a popular sport. Letterbox companies, profit shifting, abuse and evasion of tax rules – what has become known in the Panama Papers is beyond imagination. This must finally come to an end! Taxes are payable in the countries where the value added takes place. We in the European Parliament have been calling for this for a long time, and that is why we need transparency. Commissioner, I welcome your proposed proposals on country-by-country reporting. I think this is a step in the right direction. We still need to discuss details, in particular how effectively we can tackle the transfer of profits to tax havens. The blacklist proposal that you have put on the table, and also the proposal to strike a balance between the interests of our companies and public transparency, is a sensible proposal. We will discuss details. I also believe that a committee of inquiry into the Panama Papers can enrich this debate on your proposal.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it is paradoxical that an initiative of greater fiscal transparency will be presented the day before the vote to ban leaks such as that of Panama's papers, without which debates like today would not be possible. Despite this, there are positive elements to this proposal.  More information on the taxation of multinationals will help make the European people even more aware of how many European governments have armed complex systems of tax avoidance, which legalize the theft of the richest to the poor. Up to 860 billion annually – according to some studies – are lost every year and go from our schools, our hospitals, our town halls to the pockets of multinationals. However, it is insufficient. If the proposed criteria are followed, we will know nothing about what happens in some tax havens, such as Delaware in the United States, and we will not know what happens to other companies either. We will ask, inter alia, for a simple transparency rule: whether or not tax activity is reporting in any State, whether or not it is from the European Union. You have to be more ambitious.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, according to recent OECD studies, aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance and tax evasion practices, followed by many multinational companies, result in losses of tax revenue of at least EUR 50 to 70 billion per year for the budgets of the Member States of the Union.  Of course, the protagonists in these tax-exempt and tax avoidance practices are multinational companies which pay crumbs as resources, thus eroding the national tax base and hurting the economy. Moreover, these companies through intra-group transactions avoid paying taxes on their profits, thus saving billions of euros.  In order to deal with these tax ruling practices, the profits of each company must be taxed where they take place, in order to stop companies turning to tax havens, such as in the Netherlands or Luxembourg. Otherwise, the countries of Europe will not go down the path of development as long as there are companies that avoid and avoid tax. On the contrary, these states will be increasingly burdened with enormous public debt.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the European Commission's proposal to oblige multinational companies with an annual global turnover of over SEVEN hundred and fifty million euros, operating in Europe, to publish information on countries of origin and tax their profits is positive. Although the limit of seven hundred and fifty million must be reduced.  However, this is not enough to tackle the problem of large-scale tax avoidance by multinational giants, which has the effect of reducing the tax revenues of the Member States of the Union and reducing the tax burden on the shoulders of employees and pensioners. This is the right path to fiscal consolidation, not a sustained reduction in social spending.

name: Jonathan Hill
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for all the comments that have been made in the debate. I take the general thrust of the comments very much as support for this measure. Clearly I hear that there are some parts of the House which understandably want people to go further and to go faster, but I think overall the support for the proposal from the Commission is clear. I also think that there was an important set of remarks about balance, and balance is what we have tried to strike with this proposal: the balance between more transparency and wanting to defend and protect and promote the competitiveness of European businesses. I think that links to the questions I have been asked about the threshold in particular, because one of the principles that we have pursued, not just on this proposal but more generally, is to want to take our ideas forward in concert with international work, with the work being done by the OECD and the G20. The reason for that is that this work in international fora has been taken forward over many years, and I think the more we can do it in step, the more we can ensure we can make progress, and the more we can make sure that we can make progress that will be of benefit for Europe, European taxpayers and European businesses. This point about competition and the need to make sure that this proposal applies equally to non-European multinationals and to European multinationals lies at the heart of the proposal. So, OECD: why 750 million? Yes, because it is consistent with the OECD approach, and I think it is important to preserve an international approach on it. But to be clear: this would capture 90% of the revenues of all multinationals, so that is not an inconsiderable slice of the revenues from the multinationals. I was also asked a question about the aggregated figure. Why do we not have a disaggregated figure for outside the EU as well as within the EU? Again, this comes back to the point of competition. We do not have the wherewithal to insist that companies outside the EU share, for instance, information between the United States and Singapore and publish the same information that we could require companies within the EU to provide. Why is it important to try and pursue an approach in parallel? Because if our companies were having to provide more information than was the case with companies outside the EU, that could not only be of commercial advantage to their competitors, who would have more information on European businesses to be able to find out, for example, what their strategies might be on R&D to help them with their commercial strategies , but also to third-country tax jurisdictions, so that European businesses might end up being taxed twice. So that was why we have gone for an aggregated figure outside the EU, and I think it was sensible to take that balanced approach. In terms of the questions I was asked about the blacklist and how that process is being taken forward, Commissioner Moscovici will be responsible for most of that work. He was saying earlier today that he would hope to be able to get that list together in six months. In terms of that process, his intention here is to come up with one which is a fair but careful assessment using all those four criteria on which the list is based. The process, to be clear, is that all third-country jurisdictions would be screened – not automatically just homing in on any particular country or jurisdiction – and then on the basis of that screening we would talk to the jurisdictions in question and ultimately, depending on the severity of the problem in relation to one or more of those criteria, we would put together a list based on that assessment. So it is more of a dynamic process, where we hope to be able to make progress together. I was also asked about what would happen with a non-EU company that might have a smaller subsidiary or branch in the EU. That is subject to our proposal even if the subsidiary is only medium-sized, so we would be able to get those non-EU multinationals through those subsidiaries or branches. Finally, a couple of comments on timing. I do not accept that this work has been taken forward by the Commission simply because of the Panama Papers and that that is what has belatedly prompted the Commission to ask. As colleagues here will know, we have been working on this proposal for a long time. We have carried out a full impact assessment. We have discussed it over many months. The difference, I think, with the Panama Papers disclosures is that it has sharpened the focus of the proposal and has made us reconsider how we go about tackling the question of jurisdictions that do not have high standards of governance in terms of their corporate governance over the so-called tax havens, and that element of the proposal has been refined in light of the Panama Papers. But we had been working on it, and I think we share the sense of urgency that has been expressed by a number in this debate. And so, finally, on timing: how quickly can we take it forward? I agree with the point made by Mr Hayes that the sooner we can get on with this, the better. I know that Parliament will want to make progress as rapidly as possible, and we will be seeking to make progress as rapidly as we possibly can with the Member States, so that we can get a measure implemented as soon as possible, because I think that is part of how we can have a system of taxation in which our citizens have confidence , but also so that our businesses can go about the task of rebuilding trust with our citizens. Because without businesses in which citizens have trust, we will not have the tax revenues that we all want.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – Ensuring maximum tax transparency is one of the social democrats' long-term priorities. The current Panama Papers case just shows how big a problem we are facing. I welcome the talk of this issue, but the proposal put forward by the Commission is far from sufficient. We do not agree, for example, that the Commission's proposal deals only with the situation outside the European Union, and we will seek to include a much wider range of firms in the assessment, both outside and within the EU. It is important to know who owns the fictitious companies, who benefits from them, and if we really want to be consistent in this fight, then we need to take a number of comprehensive measures.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – The European Commission issued a statement in the European Parliament at its April plenary session on planned measures in the area of public tax transparency. In the case of the Panama Papers, it has been reaffirmed that such desired globalisation is written on the skin of a financial capital that has a virtual owner without responsibility. The affair, which was revealed by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists with the help of 11.5 million documents, reveals the unseen dimensions of tax fraud and money laundering so far. This undoubtedly testifies to the widespread offer and created of tax havens, which has been well exploited over the last half-century and will continue to be in the future if the competent institutions of states and the international community are not shre called. The country's tax policies are different, but it is common for them to want to bring as much funds into the Treasury as possible, and tax revenues represent practically the bulk of the inflows. How successful they are in this, and how they deal with the grey economy, tax evasion and fraud, is another question. We urgently need a thorough tax reform that will tackle firmly the origins of the problem. In this context, greater tax transparency over corporate activity and public reporting across countries, where companies operate and where they pay taxes, is crucial.

name: Sergei Stanishev (S&D)
text: in writing. – Tax avoidance is not always illegal, but it is always immoral. I therefore welcome the Commission proposals for public country—by—country reporting which builds on the work of Commissioner Moscovici to address tax evasion and tax fraud. This is an essential step forward towards achieving tax transparency, and ensuring that taxes are paid where the profit is generated. Behind the numbers and sweetheart deals for large companies, the real victims of tax avoidance and tax evasion are social justice, prosperity and the common good of societies, transparency, fairness and, ultimately, the ordinary people who suffer from all these. European socialists have long campaigned for fair tax policies, including a European Financial Transaction Tax, but also to crack down on tax heavens, as they are used to hide assets and wealth on a massive scale. Instead of facilitating investments, untraceable finance flows fuel global corruption, crime and war, bypassing national legislation, international sanctions and evading justice. In Europe and the world we want to live in, there is no place for such abrupt robbery – robbery of people’s lives and future. We cannot allow crime to thrive right under our nose, hidden in complex legislation and paperwork. EU governments must act. Now.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the discussion on the basis of the Declaration of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the main aspects and fundamental options of the common foreign and security policy and the common security and defence policy (Article 36 OF the ESP) (2016/2564(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Let me start by quoting Article 36, which says that ‘the High Representative of the European Union Foreign Affairs and Security Policy shall regularly consult the European Parliament on the main aspects and the basic choices of the common foreign and security policy and the common security and defence policy and inform it of how those policies evolve’. It goes on to say ‘he’ – so probably not me – ‘shall ensure that the views of the European Parliament are duly taken into consideration’. Let me start by saying that I believe that in the last year we have managed to successfully do this, by having regular consultations and listening to updates, developments and the implications for our policies, in constant dialogue. But for the sake of clarity and frankness, let me also say that I find it hardly acceptable that we are having five debates this evening in this Hemicycle. We have 2.5 hours. I think this is not respectful to your work and to my work. Having said that, let me say that this year has been a very demanding one for our foreign policy. The deal with Iran has opened an intense phase for our  European diplomacy, especially on Syria. After the attacks in Paris, a Member State invoked Article 42.7 for the first time in our history, an issue that we debated the last time we met in this Hemicycle. Our response to the refugee crisis has put together an unprecedented number of foreign policy tools, from operation Sophia in the Mediterranean to the new trust fund for Africa, from financing schools or health care inside the refugee camps to the economic compact for Jordan and Lebanon, which we remarkably put together for the London conference. The months ahead will be just as challenging. The foreign policy community is sometimes tempted to look at the electoral years in the United States as years of transition, but this is not a sabbatical year, especially not for the European Union. On the contrary, in some cases we face a window of opportunity that could soon close, and in others inaction can make things terribly worse. In this debate I will focus on the immediate priorities of our foreign policy, as we will have time for a broader conversation on the medium and long-term in our debate on the EU global strategy later in the night. By the way, let me repeat once again that I see no particular reason for holding two debates in a row on topics that are completely similar. So I would ask you once again to avoid this kind of repetition, and spend our time more logically and efficiently. Back to our priorities: ending the great civil war in the Middle East and North Africa remains our most urgent commitment. It is a war that is being fought on different fronts, from the border between Syria, Iraq and Turkey to Yemen and Libya. Each of these fronts has its own history and its own actors, and probably also its own development. But in each one, the solution to the conflict has to come through national reconciliation. The defeat of Daesh, Al Qaeda and all terrorist groups can only go hand in hand with these political processes. We are working hard for this to happen, and we are beginning to see some fragile first results. For them to consolidate, regional powers will need to stop feeding the war, support and encourage reconciliation and head towards some kind of cold peace. What is happening in Syria seemed impossible just a few months ago; the ceasefire is fragile but it is largely holding. Humanitarian aid has reached a number of besieged areas, even if it is far from perfect. Staffan de Mistura is touring in the region to build support for the talks. We are in constant contact, and I was in Geneva with him last month as I was also meeting the parties in the talks. We coordinated our position on Syria with the G7 Foreign Ministers just yesterday in Japan. We need progress and we need it quickly. Peace has a huge number of enemies. That is why a strong sense of urgency has to drive our engagement, and at the same time we will need the same patience that has led us here.
