The people of Nagorno Karabakh resisted Soviet totalitarianism for sixty years and were not absorbed by authoritarianism and the dictatorial regime of Azerbaijan. After a hard, multi-blooded struggle, he won his freedom and the right to self-determination, which is the only solution.  It is the responsibility of the European Union to support the people of Karabakh who are fighting alone for their freedom, and not to respect the convenient equal distances of maintaining an unjust status quo.  Peace means recognition of the self-determination of the people of Nagorno Karabakh, and the imposition of sanctions against Azerbaijan will bring peace much closer.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in the current situation in the Nagorno-Karabakh region we should strive to stop the violence because it is dangerous for the immediate neighbourhood, and the escalation of conflict could have serious repercussions in the entire region. As rapporteur for neighbourhood policy, I advocated being more active in the Eastern Neighbourhood, which remains affected by both active armed conflicts and frozen protracted conflicts. The situation in Nagorno-Karabakh shows that we must keep working more actively towards a sustainable and peaceful solution. Upholding the cessation of hostilities and the truce remains of utmost importance. We need to help our partners both in Azerbaijan and in Armenia to strive for a peaceful solution. Paraphrasing Tom de Waal, we need to ‘solve the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict before it explodes’.

name: Costas Mavrides (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Vice-President Mogherini has made this very clear by stating that the military confrontation does not offer a political solution to the problem. However, we should stress the importance of the fact that the co-chairs of the Minsk Group called on both Armenia and Azerbaijan to accept a mechanism to investigate ceasefire violations, as has already been stated by some of my colleagues. Without such a mechanism, both sides will continue to blame each other for initiating the attacks, and there will also be a loss of lives. Armenia has agreed to discuss the details of saving the mechanism. So far Azerbaijan has not. So it is one thing to be neutral but another to be impartial. That is why, with this mechanism in place, some lives on both sides could have been saved.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab 99 years ago, Pope Benedict XV, in announcing his exhortation on peace, called for the right to freedom and security of Armenia to be guaranteed in a special way after the end of the war massacre. We all know how hard this nation is when it is hard to experience history – I am talking not only about this genocide that took place a hundred years ago, but also about the dramatic beginnings of Armenian independence in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Armenia has a special right to secure borders. Armenian population in Nagorno-Karabakh for a special right to safety. We have a special duty to bear them in mind. We know under how much pressure Armenia came under when Russia was pushing for its participation in the Eurasian Economic Community and for the weakening of relations with the European Union. We have a duty to bear them in mind. The more we are present there, the more we will be able to support their safety in this dramatic isolation.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like first of all to reiterate what I have heard from many of you in the Chamber: that our support for this process and trying to find the most reasonable way to restart it and proceed in the right way is essential. I would like to echo Mr Karim’s words, which I find very wise: that while we are there to facilitate, to help, to accompany and to try and find a sustainable solution and sustainable compromise, at the end of the day only the political will of the parties themselves will move things towards a peaceful settlement. This is also part of our efforts: creating a conducive environment, or trying to prevent the environment from becoming disruptive, is also part of our job. I take all your comments on board for our work – for the work of our Special Representative – which is daily and nightly dedicated to this, with visits in the region this week, and, obviously, staying ready to increasingly engage in these efforts if necessary in the future.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. – For almost three decades, one of the most dangerous conflicts on the wider borders of Europe has been located in the mountains of the South Caucasus. In recent days, the conflict in The Karabakh has ignited and is in danger of exacerbated if the international community does not intervene.  It is worrying that what is happening is only a few days after the strategic visits of High Representative Mogherini and Vice-President of the Energy Union Commission Mr Shevčovič to Azerbaijan.  I believe that the EU can no longer be a passive observer, but should play a more active role in the peaceful resolution of conflicts, which currently constitute an insurmountable obstacle to the full development of good inter-neighbourly relations in the Eastern and Southern Partnership countries. Gorno Karabakh demands more than just diplomatic shuttles because the region is already connected to the EU – we have an active partnership in the areas of economy, energy and security issues. The EU must insist within the OSCE on participating in the Ming group together with the US, Russia and France and be a guarantor of a peace agreement. The European External Action Service needs to launch consultations with both sides of the conflict as well as civil society in Armenia and Azerbaijan in order to propose a European peace plan for Nagorno-Karabakh in line with UN Security Council resolutions.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I welcome this debate on the end of ceasefires in the Nagorno-Karabakh area. I cannot, however, fail to see that we are not here to discuss matters of history, but to find a solution to a reality. The reality is that Nagorno-Karabakh is a territory belonging to Azerbaijan, and the recent acts are acts of aggression on the part of Armenia. We must take into account the resolutions adopted by the European Parliament since 2010, calling on Armenia to withdraw its troops from the Nagorno-Karabakh area, and also the four UN resolutions on the same issue. The only solution is a political one, which obliges Armenia to comply with acts of international law.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. – Nearly two decades since the European Union signed partnership and cooperation agreements with Armenia and Azerbaijan, with the aim of strengthening democracy and the rule of law in these countries and re-establishing economic life. In addition, the European Neighbourhood Policy aims to strengthen security in the region and promote reconciliation between the two Caucasus peoples.  However, we are deeply concerned that the achievement of the initial objectives has been overshadowed by long-running conflict relations, and the renewed fighting at the beginning of April appear to make a peaceful settlement of Azeri-Armenian relations impossible. We must do everything possible to prevent the ethnic conflict from escalating again into a bloody war in the Caucasus.  The EU supports existing forms of negotiation along the lines of the principles of the Neighbourhood Policy, while at the same time call on both sides to respect the ceasefire and not to jeophold stability in the region. For the sake of a peaceful future in the region, both parties must respect the commitments contained in the Association Treaty with the Union. It's their shared responsibility. Similarly, they can reasonably be expected to fulfil the obligations laid down by the OSCE Group in Minsk, thereby ending the renewed war. In the current crisis situation, the EU External Action Service must use all its strength to finally resolve the relationship between the opposing parties.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (2016/2651(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, last time we discussed Cuba and Latin America in this Parliament, I well remember that I told you that in a world that is changing – and especially in Latin America and in Cuba – Europe will not watch from the sidelines, and we did not. March was a historic month for Cuba, and we were there. Europe was there. My visit to Havana, the second of my mandate as High Representative, preceded by a week the historic visit President Obama paid to the island and also another historic event, which was the Rolling Stones concert. That cannot be underestimated for an island like Cuba. We have been there as a driving force for change. In March we initiated the first ever agreement between the EU and Cuba. Our relations with Cuba have always continued, in good and in difficult times, although over the last decade we have had difficult moments. Our starting point was – and still is – much more positive than that of our friends in the United States. The political dialogue and cooperation agreement we have initialled is totally unprecedented. It touches on the broadest set of issues, from political dialogue to economic cooperation, from sustainable development to our cooperation in multilateral fora, from the protection of the environment to human rights. This moment marks the beginning of a completely new era in our relations with Cuba. Cuba has been changing, slowly but continuously, for a number of years now. On regional and international affairs, our cooperation has already been constructive for quite some time now. I think, in particular, of Cuba’s role in hosting talks between the Colombian Government and the FARC, which we followed very closely. I remember that we had a debate about that very recently. We can only look forward to expanding our cooperation on these matters. But change is happening inside Cuba as well. Over the past few years, the European Union has started to discuss how to accompany Cuba’s evolution. We have a choice to make: should we wait for more structural changes or should we make our voice heard right now, as a friend and partner of the Cuban people, through active engagement and dialogue? The new agreement answers this question. We can now accompany more decisively the process of reforming the Cuban economy and society, fostering sustainable development, democracy and human rights as a trusted and reliable partner, as the Cubans see the Europeans. Since my political dialogue meeting with Foreign Minister Rodríguez last year, we have jointly agreed to give human rights dialogue a head start. This format has now been formally set up by the political dialogue and cooperation agreement we initialled in Cuba last month. But the process was launched before the agreement was even finalised, and the next human rights dialogue will take place at the end of May in Havana. We were able to announce it while initiating the agreement. In the first meeting of the human rights dialogue, which took place last year in Brussels, we touched upon the respective situation of human rights and recent developments, both in the EU and Cuba. Let me say that it was a very constructive and very frank exchange of views, and a useful one. Let me conclude with a note on the work ahead. We now have to go through our internal process to ensure the swift signing and ratification of the agreement. Parliament will have a part to play in this when the time comes, and I hope it will not be too far away. The signature of the agreement will also mark the end of the EU’s 1996 common position as the Union’s instrument defining its external relations with Cuba. As you are aware, the common position had already envisaged the perspective of a bilateral agreement. This has now been accomplished, setting a new framework for our relationship. So it is time we finally developed a partnership that reflects our shared history, serves our interests in the present day and helps us build a future that is shared. For this reason, in parallel to the process leading to the signature of the agreement, I will propose a Council decision to formally repeal the common position. This agreement benefits Cuba and benefits Europe. Let me be even clearer: it benefits the Cubans and it benefits the Europeans, because this is the nature of all good friendships. I am sure we will be able to count on your support in this new phase of our common history. To sum up, it means enhancing EU relations with Cuba, effectively accompanying the modernisation and reform process on the island, promoting democracy and human rights and finding common solutions to global challenges. The path of more engagement in the framework of the future agreement is the most effective one.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for the information you have provided us on the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation with Cuba. I would like to congratulate you on the conclusion of the Agreement. The European Union and Cuba thus have an instrument, a bilateral framework, as you said, to advance the development of their relations.  Cuba is at a very important time at the international level. The recent shift in relations with the United States has historic scope, but the country is, also domestic, at a crucial stage for well-known reasons. With the Agreement, the European Union will be able to strengthen, consolidate its presence in Cuba and thus be able to influence more of the process of change that the country is experiencing. Through the framework of cooperation and dialogue involved in the Agreement, the European Union will be able, as you yourself have said, to stimulate the process of reforms that the country is undergoing, while defending European interests and values. In this regard, I too would like to stress the inclusion in the Agreement of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, by collecting a specific dialogue on this subject. Mrs Mogherini, you are aware of this House's commitment to human rights and our conviction that these are universal rights which all States, also Cuba, must respect.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I wanted to begin by congratulating Mrs Mogherini, firstly, because her work is putting Latin America on the radar of European foreign policy and this is something we appreciate, because for many years it had not been like this. Secondly, because of the courage it has shown in overcoming the Common Position which for fifteen years has blocked Europe's relations with Cuba and signing an agreement which I consider very important. Cuba is a small country, we know, but it is a very important country, you have said so. Seeing Obama a few days ago is largely because the United States wants to change its role, its image, in front of the rest of Latin America, but also because peace is being negotiated in Colombia. It is a country that has a great irradiation towards Latin America. And that's why I think Cuba needs to start dealing with it now with the importance it has in our international politics. Some— today we will hear it here too—will continue to think that Cuba is a triumphant revolution; others will say it's a hateful dictatorship where there are no human rights. I believe that the two archetypes are extreme and distort the reality of a country that is changing a lot. Here's what I think is important to highlight. Old archetypes are no longer good for a world instead. Nor for a deep-changing Cuba. And certainly the problem was what Europe was doing in that position. Stay out, stay isolated, stay in the old position or take charge of a new policy of friendship with Cuba? I think there are four very important things we can do. Firstly, to change the stage of what we have called the Common Position to a stage of economic, political and trade collaboration that this agreement allows us to consider. Secondly, help the Cuban people. Help the people, the Cuban people, with investments, with companies, with market economy, with cooperation, with technology. Thirdly, to understand that this will come from freedoms, democracy and human rights, which I too want for Cubans. But they will probably come with openness, with the Internet, with telecommunications, with the citizenship that is coming. And, from there, respect a very important thing and it is that it is the Cuban people who must decide their future.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. In the run-up to this debate, I consulted several Experts in Cuba. Like me, they are all in favour of cooperation between the EU and Cuba, which is not limited to the regime, but also includes civil society! I would like to underline that! It is precisely the latter that I heard critical noises, including in my country, towards the EU, of people who know Cuba through and through. Whoever fits the shoe, Madam High Representative, put it on. As a member of the Protestant community in the Netherlands, which has had close links with the Cuban Church and Christians for many years, I also urge the High Representative to address the Cuban authorities directly and with continued support for the religion and freedom of faith on its own territory. This freedom excludes, first of all, a system of government informants and snitches in church meetings and congregations. That is very important, because there is just a fear atmosphere and that says a lot about the regime. So please, let us not leave it to a façade that is cosmetic rather than reality. Because then we'll be sunning ourselves in the wrong direction.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to express my view that the policy of the Europeans and the Americans in the past decades has failed. This was not a successful policy, and I welcome the fact that we have managed to agree on an agreement that is a ‘driving force for change’ – and I would underline the word ‘change’. I am not sure that what we have seen in recent weeks – people being imprisoned and acts similar to that – are the change. I wonder: what is for you the objective of changing that agreement? As politicians we should have an objective. I would appreciate it if you could comment on that. The people that I tend to talk to do not feel that the changes are really occurring. It is not even that they are occurring slowly; they are not occurring. Maybe I am ill-informed. I would like to learn more. In fact, the ALDE Presidency delegation, which is to go to Cuba, has been waiting for weeks and weeks to get an answer from the Cuban authorities as to whether it will be welcome or not. I wonder whether this is also a sign of change. I see Cuban diplomats are hopefully taking note of that fact. Am I right in saying that there is a provision in the agreement that we will not intervene in the domestic affairs of Cuba? I am not quoting now, but what is the meaning and your interpretation of that phrasing? So we need a dialogue for sure, a change for sure, but we really need to see change. We will, as you have said, be debating the agreement here. We want to see the conditionality implemented. I would appreciate your comments on the questions that I have posed.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, from the outset I expressed my deep conviction that the cooperation and political dialogue agreement was a strong framework for developing a level playing field between the European Union and Cuba. I stressed that this joint effort must be governed by the principles of reciprocity and cooperation, without conditions and discrimination. The common position of the European Union, although in practice inactive, was a substantial obstacle as it violates the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of states. I'm glad mrs. Mogherini announced its intention to withdraw the common position.  The exclusion of Cuba from the US for sixty years was a criminal behaviour towards its people and its removal must be completed immediately. It is worth noting that excluded Cuba provides universal public free education with impressive scientific results, provides free universal healthcare and has the best indicators at all levels and is a pioneer in the fields of prevention and ongoing research in the pharmaceutical and medical field. I stress this, because I believe that speeding up the completion and signing of the agreement will be undeniably in the interests of both sides. I hope, soon, that the first positive results will become visible to the Cuban people who, even under the most difficult circumstances, have not given up, for a moment, their dignity and right to decide their lives and their country!

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Madam High Representative, first of all, I too agree with the congratulations, because I believe that you have played a very positive role in overcoming a profoundly unfair situation: the situation created on the basis of the Common Position adopted fifteen years ago and which has prevented the European Union and Cuba from having a normal relationship between two neighbouring peoples who must cooperate. Therefore, I congratulate you.  I believe that we should not consider this agreement a point of arrival, but a starting point. Much remains to be done and I believe that European diplomacy can still do much by helping, for example, to end the blockade at once, to repeal some American laws, such as the Helms-Burton Act of 1996, which must be repealed; there's a lot to do. And above all, I believe that the European Union should in no way regard this new relationship as a way to win over the United States or to be at the same level in a trade race; It's not that. It's about helping, having new relationships and putting in all the tools we can to help the Cuban economy develop, and I think that's very important today, so nothing else: congratulate it and move on!

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, Madam Vice President Mogherini, in the dynamic world in which we live, we are witnessing a new division of cards, and in this division it is obvious that Cuba is gradually but surely reintegrating into the political and economic structures of the Western Hemisphere because of course the US has a dominant position. This fact, however, does not mean that we must ignore the relations that historically bind Cuba to Europe. In this context, the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation provides a framework for the development of these relations in various dimensions. Europe's role must continue to be to promote human rights and respect them, which, unfortunately, is not yet the case in Cuba. We do not want and must not forget the Sahara Prize winners, political dissidents and political prisoners, and they are still in Cuba.  It is equally important that in gradually opening up the Cuban economy, the benefits of this opening are not only for the ruling "castrism" elite, as has often been the case in post-communist societies in Eastern Europe. These are some elements that European support for the transition process in Cuba must take into account, but Europe must in any case be present and engaged.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would, of course, also like to thank Mr Mogherini for his words, but also, as has been acknowledged by all my fellow Members, for the timely, precise and important commitment he has made to the successful negotiations between the European Union and Cuba.  I, ladies and gentlemen, believe that it cannot be denied that Cuba has taken important steps over the last twenty years, I would say that much of the progress made is historic, just as the signing of the agreement in Cuba on 11 March is historic. Much still needs to be done, of course, but we can say with certainty that the path taken is the right one and we will do everything we can to maintain it.  I believe that the common position has now been clearly superseded, many things must be overcome, the embargo has already been mentioned and I trust that the measure that has punished the Cuban people for too long must be overcome. I am reminded of the words of John Paul II who said that no nation can live alone, well, I believe that we are here to be genuinely close to the Cuban people, and the work presented by the High Representative gives us hope for a better future for Cuba and for relations with Europe.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mrs Mogherini and the European External Action Service on the signing of the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation, which places relations between Cuba and the European Union in another dimension. A process that responds to the desire and demands of civil society. This Agreement, which is governed by the principles of reciprocity, respect and mutual benefit, will enable the 1996 Common Position to be overcome. It will allow us to normalize relations and deepen political dialogue, cooperation or collaboration in sectoral policies and trade, but without forgetting the area of fundamental rights, freedoms and democracy on an island where human rights defenders and the opposition are still persecuted and arrested. Cuba deserves a better future. It has enormous potential to apply a sustainable development model with human capital of trained people. A heritage that must be recognized in the recent history of the island and that will be fundamental in this opening. Cuba also deserves an end to the embargo and I welcome the European Union's deeming the effects of this measure on European companies illegal. And I stress that this historic step has been promoted in feminine, by a High Representative who earns every day my respect and admiration. Thank you very much, Mrs Mogherini.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I believe that this agreement is not only going to boost economic cooperation and exchanges between Cuba and the EU, but it will also contribute to updating the Cuban economy and society. I firmly believe that allocating a certain amount of money will have a substantial effect on the development of the island. It will enable the modernisation of the country in order to achieve a sustainable agricultural sector and the use of natural resources, such as water, in a more efficient and more focused way. But the most important thing for me – the most sensitive matter for me – remains the same. It is the human rights dialogue. It is our prerogative to ensure that the everyday lives of the Cuban people and society as a whole will be positively affected by this agreement. In recent years I have had the honour and privilege of meeting Cuban dissidents who fight daily for their freedom and democratic change. I hope that because of this agreement we will get closer to making a positive and peaceful change, as once happened in Poland as well.

name: Norbert Neuser (S&D).
text: Mr President, High Representative, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very high-key Congratulations from my side too on the agreement! However, I would also like to specifically include the EU delegation in Havana, which has done a work of trust for years and has helped to ensure that we have now reached this agreement. It is now a matter of dialogue and cooperation, which is a priority. However, we must constantly mention that the blockade continues to exist, and the blockade is a crucial obstacle. Our position as an EU must be clear: we do not accept european companies being penalised. That is why the blockade must go, because it does not serve the people and because it does not bring Cuban society forward. On human rights, we have enough organisations here with which we can cooperate. Finally, i have noticed that when you speak of the Pope, you get extended speaking time, you have to say the role of the Catholic Church: I believe that it plays a very decisive role. Last but not least, the current Pope has visited Cuba twice in recent times and has done much to open Cuba.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to briefly congratulate and compliment the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, who has made sterling efforts in recent times, especially to focus on the relationship between the EU and Cuba. I think it is fair to say that we are now entering a new relationship with Cuba. We have been ahead of the United States of America since 2008, and I very much welcome, as the High Representative has said, the engagement by President Obama and his administration in opening up the relationship between the United States and Cuba. It is only through engagement that we can argue for our values, human rights and democracy. It is not by shutting people out or shutting the door of cooperation with Cuba. I believe that this agreement has the potential, for us at least, to highlight those European values on the world stage. We should not forget the important trading links between Cuba and the EU; the EU remains Cuba’s main export partner. Each year, as we have engaged, our trade with Cuba has gone up exponentially, and I suspect that that will continue into the near future. We should also be proud of the fact that parts of our development aid programme and our expertise programme, especially for young Cuban students and for public officials, is something that we should be proud of.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, we are discussing the recently signed agreement between the European Union and Cuba with a view to normalising relations between them. As early as April 2014, negotiations had begun within the framework of the political dialogue, with the aim of paving the way for economic relations between the twenty-eight Member States of the Union and Cuba.  In addition to trade and political dialogue, the agreement also mentions human rights in Cuba. The European Union is pressing Cuba to sign international agreements.  At a time, of course, when the European Union was suggesting proposals for the protection of human rights in Cuba, it was itself violating the rights of the countries of the Union set out in memoranda every day, thus imposing policies of violent fiscal adjustment and austerity and increasingly pooring these European peoples.  The European Union should therefore take advantage of economic cooperation with Cuba, but without interfering politically in the country, which has been affected for fifty-six years by the United States embargo.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we have just heard members in this House who have the shame of talking about human rights in Cuba while applauding the deportations of refugees to Turkey, or supporting the policies that have led to thousands of refugees drowning in the Mediterranean, or silenced by human rights violations at Guantanamo.  With regard to the Common Position of the European Union on Cuba, this common position promoted by Mr Aznar, which devoted the European Union's hostility to the Republic of Cuba, is today, and despite progress in the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation, the main obstacle to advancing relations with Cuba. This common position, discriminatory and expiring, must be rectified and must be completely eliminated in order for European Union-Cuba relations to be satisfactory.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Council/High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first of all, you were asking about the political objective. Both in my introductory words but also hearing the debate tonight, it is quite clear what it is: it is to engage with an interlocutor, coming out from the common position to encourage and accompany a process that is happening in Cuba – inside the country and with the outside world, starting from the United States, but also with others in the region and beyond – to try to accompany this process in the best possible way. Here the European Union has a special role to play. We are not in competition with the Americans. The United States has a different kind of history of relations with Cuba that we do not have. It has a different kind of geography that probably, in perspective, makes relations with the island potentially huge. We are far away, but our history is much more solid. We have a people-to-people exchange with the Cuban people – as Europeans – that is and always has been in place, even during decades of difficult times. So I believe that, whether it is for the work that we can do on trade or the work that we can do on the development of different forms of small and medium enterprises, cooperatives or small economic steps of change, the role of the European Union – because of the structure of our society, our economy and our social system – can be of great help in the transition, the transformation, the changes and the process of reforms that Cuba is potentially entering into. This is an open debate in Cuba. If I am not wrong, the party congress is taking place in a few weeks. We need to have a respectful stand. You mentioned that we make reference to the fact that we have a process of non—interference. This is the basis of our relationship with all countries in the world. We do not interfere in internal processes, but we have our consistent, coherent, strong and principled positions on many different issues. There are issues where we see space for cooperation and mutual benefit. There are issues where we know very well that we are very distant in our positions, but there are fields where we can work together, accompanying a process that Cuba is starting and making sure that there can be a European – whether businesses, churches, NGOs, tourists, entrepreneurs – common framework that can be beneficial for Europeans and for Cubans. I mentioned the work of the small and medium enterprises and cooperatives. The field of telecommunications is huge and potentially very beneficial. Our experts are working in Cuba, advising the different ministries on the different sectors of reform – even very technical kind of work – because there is a certain level of understanding and trust between our people that has never been interrupted throughout history. Again, with student exchanges or people-to-people contact, I can see a lot of benefits. So we do have a fundamental role as the European Union. Regarding something that you mentioned, namely the blockade: our position has always been very clear. I have stated it again, publicly and in our meetings, both in Cuba and with our American friends. We consider this policy as counterproductive, as it is also affecting European economic interests in a serious way. We know very well that the administration in the United States stands exactly where we do, but Congress does not, so we need to see how the Americans will work on that. Human rights will stay crucial and central in our dialogue, and let me stress that the European Union and Cuba have a human rights dialogue. We have already had the first round of it and we are going to have a second round in Cuba in early June or at the end of May in Havana. We are fixing the date. This is something the Americans do not have. This is precisely because we have a certain level of confidence in each other, and respect. We are engaging in this dialogue, as well as in other dialogues, with a constructive approach. It is frank, because we know very well that there are issues where we do not agree, but with the idea that engaging is always better than not talking. Lastly, regarding the role of the Parliament: this process is just a starting point. We have initialled the agreement. This means that we have finalised the negotiations. We have no open points on our table. I would also thank our delegation in Cuba, the negotiating team – which has been working in an excellent way – and also the Cuban negotiating team. Obviously they had their own position to defend, but they engaged very constructively. I can tell you that seeing experienced officials and diplomats, at the moment when we were signalling the agreement, moved after years of negotiations was something quite special, even for someone who has been working on diplomacy for so many years. Your role will be key when we come to the ratification of the agreement. We have signalled it. We have to sign it, which means, as you know, going through translation into all our languages and all the internal processes, and then we will come to ratification for this Parliament. At that time I will come back to you and ask for swift ratification, because even the overcoming of the common position is linked, as we will proceed in parallel to this advancement process. So a lot of work has been done, but still part of the political work has to be done, and I count on your engagement and support in those steps when they come.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This moment confirms the sovereign and free decision of the Cuban people to affirm their achievements and their just aspiration to build a progressive society, freed from the oppressive corset of the embargo to which it has heroically resisted for 50 years. A blockade which is an unacceptable violation of human rights and international law, and the purpose of which is required. The resistance, persistence and courage of the Cuban people have allowed this country, despite the economic constraints that the blockade puts on them, to achieve progress that in other countries does not exist, such as the right to education or the right to health. The agreement that the EU and Cuba ratified exactly a month ago represents a step that could contribute to the fall of the blockade. It was affirmed by the EU as a milestone for the end of the 1996 Common Position, which is based on a discriminatory and lapsed policy requiring a repeal without further postponement. Statements requiring the council's rapid position to be taken for formal revocation. The dialogue with Cuba must continue to be stripped of any posture of interference and interference, based on absolute respect for the sovereignty of that country and its people and its inalienable right to decide its future.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. – In the European Parliament the Socialists have worked for two decades to ensure that the European Union abandoned the so-called 'common position' which prevented relations with Cuba. This common position of 1996 was an initiative of the Spanish right and sought to isolate Cuba more. A shift in America's attitude now causes greater general availability to these relationships. It's not about joining a fad for the Socialists. It is all about working together, so that: • The signing and ratification of the EU-Cuba Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement ended last March is completed before the end of the year. • And convince the United States of America to lift the blockade, and allow Cuba to have economic and trade relations like any other country. This is because we want to grow these economic relations and that exchanges of all kinds, the joint work of universities, scientists, businesses, can occur normally, to the point where the European Union becomes a real player in improving the situation on the island.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Sandra Kalniete, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the EU in a changing global environment – a more connected world, conflicted and complex ( HYPERLINK "http://www.europarl.europa.eu/oeil/popups/ficheprocedure.do?lang=en&reference=2015/2272(INI)" 2015/2272(INI)) (A8-0069/2016).

name: Sandra Kalniete
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, colleagues, i would like to thank you very well for your excellent work. On 22 March, Parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs began with a moment of silence to honour the victims of the terrorist attack at Zaventem Airport. When the Committee on Foreign Affairs was preparing to vote in favour of my report on the European foreign and security policy strategy, we learned that there had just been an explosion at the nearest metro station in parliament. It was an unreal and strange feeling. We voted in favour of the strategic objectives of European foreign policy, but a few hundred metres away, people died , partly because of Europe's failure to achieve the objectives set out in other strategic documents many years ago. Looking at the European Security Strategy adopted in 2003, we can see that one of the three key strategic objectives set is the stabilisation of Europe's neighbourhood, including the Middle East. Today, 13 years later, we must find that this strategic objective has not been met and the situation in neighbouring regions has become one of the main causes of a major security problem in the heart of Europe. I would very much not like our descendants to find out again after five or ten years: good documents, weak works. Poor lying is because our Union suffers from a chronic lack of political will, which affects the implementation of many European policies. Therefore, one of the important recommendations in the resolution on the EU's global strategy is to follow its implementation, regularly evaluate and update, link objectives to resources. With this resolution, the European Parliament wants to contribute to shaping and concentrating the political will of the institutions and the Member States. In the resolution, we call for a substantial strengthening of the Common European Defence Capability, towards the creation of a European Defence Union in the for a transparent future. We call on the European Union's external action to focus its efforts specifically on stabilising europe's wider neighbourhood, rather than trying to be all for everyone. We call on Europe to be a global actor with a regional orientation that is an active global rule-maker, not a designer. We stress that this is only possible in cooperation with the Union's main strategic partner, the US. At the same time, we must be aware that America's interests are increasingly in Asia and that we ourselves will have to be able not only to act in words, but also to ensure the security of Europe and Europeans. We therefore call on the Member States to increase their defence investments to at least 2% of their GDP by 2024 and, at the same time, to spend these funds wisely, matching our military industries and capabilities and achieving greater return on investment. What do I think are the main challenges and risks of implementing the strategy? The first is the political will and the awareness of the common objective of the Member States and their societies. The second is the growing risks of populism. They present unpredictable challenges and consequences for the Union and its foreign policy, such as the Dutch referendum, BREXIT, the presidential elections in the United States. And who knows what we're going to experience. Finally, we are talking about insufficient resources. Citizens often expect simple and quick solutions. Especially in a context of slow economic growth. It is difficult to explain that for every euro that we do not invest effectively in our external action, we may have to pay many times to deal with internal problems caused by external circumstances. I would therefore like to conclude by stressing that one of the important tasks will be support from European citizens. And it is in this interpretative work that the role of the European Parliament and our Members can be important. We therefore call on you, high representative, to provide Parliament with regular reports on the implementation of the strategy and believe that the global strategy should be reviewed every five years. Thanks for the attention!

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, Madam rapporteur, you know how much I care about this global strategy, and we also discussed that recently. I would like to thank you personally for your work in this Parliament and outside, in this respect. Our world has become so unstable and so dangerous that our foreign policy can simply not afford to guess and check. Our mistakes can be too costly, as impulsive reactions can lead us to very dangerous places, and we see this every single day. The security of our citizens calls for a coherent, rational and united foreign policy. You also know how much I care about the broad discussions we are having about this strategy. It has been a clear political decision for me. This has to be a strategy not for the European institutions but for our Union, and this means it can only be the result of a collective process. All the Commissioners have contributed to it. All the Member States, in different formations of ministerial meetings, have discussed their comments and proposals. We have involved think tanks, foreign policy experts and civil society representatives. We have organised a student essay competition and have met recently with former Erasmus students – and I have to say this was one of the best meetings we have had in the process. Obviously the European Parliament and the national parliaments have a key role to play, also because you represent directly our citizens, and our citizens know today that foreign policy matters to their lives. So let me thank the rapporteur for the excellent work, as our thinking on many different issues also goes exactly in the same direction. This is also very encouraging to see because our strategy, our common work, will not stop in June when the document is ready, as you said. In the report you ask for a review of the strategy every five years. I agree. This should be a regular exercise we will have to do – five years, or even less maybe. But I believe that the first sections of the strategy on our interests and principles could have the potential to drive our actions for many years – probably even more than five – but at the same time, the strategy will have to be a living document. We need constantly to adapt the priorities we have set with the reality that surrounds us around the world, in our region, and also in terms of implementation. I will come to the implementation in a moment. From day one we will have to work on this, especially on the implementation of the strategy, for instance with sectorial papers and action plans. This is not going to be a PhD thesis or an academic dissertation. This has to be a living document on how we achieve our objectives, and I cannot imagine Parliament not being involved in the life of this strategy after June. Looking at your report it is clear, and I do not need to explain why we have opted for a global strategy and not simply a security strategy like the previous one. For sure, traditional security will be crucial, and security includes defence. Still, we all understand that this is not enough. ‘No security without development’ is what we always say, but also ‘no security without democracy, human rights and the rule of law’. I believe the Arab awakening should have told us something about this – that security must be sustainable, and sustainable security cannot be achieved through security and defence instruments alone. It requires development, governance, civil society support, climate action and much more. This is why I put resilience at the core of this strategy: the resilience of institutions, the resilience of societies, the resilience of people and the resilience of countries at the end of today. If you understand this, we should also see that our European Union can truly be a global power and, I would say, a superpower. We hold in our hands a unique mix of hard and soft power that no other power in the world can use. As a Union of 28, we can mobilise public and private investments, soldiers, observers and an unparalleled diplomatic network. This includes your contacts with other parliaments and with civil society organisations worldwide. The real challenge is making the mix of all these assets truly effective with common political guidance, and this is one of the main aims of the strategy. Such a mix already makes us incredibly interesting for our global partners. Just hours ago I got back from Indonesia and Japan, and to them – on the other side of the world – it is absolutely clear that the European Union is a global power and the partner they want to partner with. I fully agree with the report when it says that there is no contradiction between our role in our neighbourhood and our global engagement. Of course we need to prioritise, and of course our neighbours are the top priority, but let us not forget that our neighbourhood is expanding by the day. Think of this simple fact. If we exclude Syria, the highest number of refugees in Europe comes from Afghanistan, but there are also migrants from Pakistan and refugees from Eritrea. These are faraway places and yet so close to us. We need to be a global player because issues are global. We cannot stabilise our immediate neighbourhood if we do not look at the Sahel, the Horn of Africa and Central Asia, and our stabilisation efforts must account both for the roles played by other global players in these regions and for global causes of instability, such as climate change. We cannot build a new global order based on rules and cooperation if we do not fully engage with our partners far away in Latin America or Southeast Asia. So indeed, everything is interconnected, and the global strategy is just that: a global response to global challenges and global opportunities. Let me mention the three principles guiding our external action, in my view. First: engagement, because turning inwards is simply not an option. It would make us more, and not less, vulnerable, as we see when we underline the link between external and internal threats. Second: responsibility – thinking of what happens the day after and what we do the day after an action is taken. Having clear ideas of why we are taking any single step, what happens next, who are our allies and how we engage with them. We have seen too many mistakes in the past, just because we did not consider the consequences of an action. Third: partnership. The days when the weakness of my neighbour was my strength are long gone. You mentioned that. Instability in our neighbourhood can only bring instability here in Europe, so we need strong neighbours and strong cooperation with our partners in their neighbourhoods. No country alone, not even our Union alone, can carry the whole world on its shoulders. Engagement, responsibility and partnership: our engagement needs to be responsible and it needs to be cooperative. The strategy will focus on some broad priorities: the starting points for the work ahead. First, the European Union must strengthen itself. We need a stronger Union. This includes building up our defence and doing so in a cooperative manner; making our intelligence services work together; working against radicalisation in our societies; monitoring hybrid threats; strengthening our energy security, cyber capacities and strategic communications; and preserving the Schengen system with new asylum rules. In a phrase, we need a 21st-century approach to security. Second, we need to invest in the resilience of states and societies in and around Europe, to the east and to the south. We need to support effective and democratic institutions, protect the space of civil society and promote it, address countries of transit and origin of migration, promote socio-economic development, fight climate change and promote energy transitions. This is a complex priority which will need to be fleshed out, country by country, with a targeted approach. We have all the means to make our partners more internally resilient, but we need to focus on every single one to make it happen. Third, we must do all we can to put an end to the current crisis in which the state, far from resilient, is on the verge of collapse – from Syria to Libya, from Somalia to South Sudan – and we must prevent the next crisis from addressing problems before they boil up and get out of control. These may not get us in the headlines, but it is the most effective way to save human lives and increased collective security. Fourth, we must strengthen regional orders, because the causes of conflicts have an increasingly transnational nature. We are seeing this every single day. More often, the key to solving or preventing a crisis lies not only inside the country but in the region. Our cooperation with the US and NATO, with the African Union, CELAC and ASEAN, are all key. In some parts of the world, like Africa, we need to strengthen existing organisations. In other cases, we need new and creative formats. I think of the talks we have on Syria that have somehow established a format that is what I call ‘minilateral’ and that is flexible enough to feed into a process like the complex one in the Security Council of the United Nations, managing to bring results in that multilateral format. We need more of that. A network of bilateral, trilateral, sub-regional and regional organisations can be the best base for a more cooperative and more effective multilateral global order. So the last priority must be better global governance that is truly fit for our age. This was a year of important achievements for the international community, from the Iranian deal to the sustainable development goals, to COP21. We need to stick to this path and preserve a system based on rules, but we need to work on how we can be imaginative. In a world of predictable unpredictability, the international system as it is does not suffice. We do not need conservation but change if we want to preserve the principle of effective multilateralism. There is only one way to succeed in all this and to achieve our objectives, and this is a truly united Europe. I began by saying that our environment has never been so dangerous. I will add that, perhaps for the first time in our history, the European Union faces an existential threat. But these threats do not come from outside our borders. The only existential threat against the European Union comes from our internal divisions, the petty nationalisms, the finger-pointing and the lack of forward-looking leadership. We discussed this early this afternoon when we discussed our response to terrorism inside the European Union. I still believe we can make it, and we must make it – together with this Parliament, which is the best ally in this fight – for the security and benefit of all our citizens.

name: Brian Hayes
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, as the rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development on this report, I would like to congratulate my colleague for her excellent work in this report. I also want to congratulate the High Representative on her speech just now, where she reminded us of the need for collective action across all EU institutions so that, at the forefront of our mind, in trying to address many of these global and regional problems, we have to act decisively together. We do need a clear sense of direction and vision as we try to deal with the complex issues that Europe now faces. We also need to be very clear about what our priorities are. In the drafting of my opinion, I set out the importance of policy coherence as a key issue. I believe it is important that we enhance coherence between our internal and external policies and improve coordination between institutions and Member States. I am particularly happy that the rapporteur continued to make reference in her report to the involvement of national parliaments in the policy coherence agenda. We have to work together, we have to work with national parliaments, and we have to work across all institutions to ensure that our objectives are met in the future.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, first of all, I would like to express my admiration for the High Representative, who has been here with us for eight hours on her way back from Hiroshima. So, sincerely, we very much appreciate the fact that you are available to discuss all these relationships with us. Secondly, I would like to congratulate my colleague, Sandra Kalniete, on the excellent report she has written. This report sums up Parliament's vision of the Union's priorities in terms of foreign and security policy. In the debates we have had in our meetings in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I have stressed that the European Union must speak with a strong voice in international politics and, for that, we need the solidarity of the Member States and also, of course, the resources. In the amendments I tabled, I emphasised the Union's priorities. I mentioned three: first, improving our ability to anticipate conflicts and crises, but also to respond quickly to these crises. Secondly, I stressed the need to contribute to the stabilization and pacification of our neighbourhood in the East and south, not to mention any of its parts. And thirdly, I stressed the maintenance of the need to maintain our commitments with regard to enlargement.  I think that in this terrible identity crisis that we are experiencing in Europe, we must be courageous, we must say things that are not sympathetic to Europe's adversaries. You don't have to get into their game and be soft. You have to be very brave, especially when you are dealing with a subject like enlargement. In fact, we will discuss the enlargement report tomorrow. (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group- I thank Mrs Kalniete for her receptivity in the joint work behind this report. It is not easy to make less of the European Parliament's contribution to the overall strategy that the Union seeks to develop in the face of the humanitarian, economic, political and security challenges it faces, from state and non-state actors, both within and outside common borders. A credible political union requires Europeans to take full responsibility for collective security and defence in the neighbourhood and globally, without ever losing sight of their interests as well as founding values and principles.  The Union must strengthen its strategic autonomy in defence capabilities and not continue to underuse the potential of the CFSP and CSDP to consistently articulate internal and external policies and ensure civil and military resilience in the collective response. This alone will not fail citizens, partners themselves, nato, the United Nations, the EU-Africa Partnership and others, as Mrs Mogherini stressed.  Mutualisation and sharing of military resources, joint research and development projects strengthening the industrial and technological base of European defence, including CBRN security and cyber defence, are crucial to prevent duplication and failures and to ensure economies of scale and interoperability to systems.  Combating terrorism and other forms of organised crime is a priority that no Member State can pursue on its own: it imposes capacity-sharing in the internal and external security sectors, in particular intelligence, police and justice. It imposes coherence and consistency in external policies and actions. From Ukraine to the Mediterranean we see a lack of cohesion and solidarity, with results that shame and discredit the Union. Defending European citizens, principles and interests can only be achieved through a political union that promotes human security, based on rules of global governance – as Mrs Mogherini has also just stressed again – anchored in international law, human rights and the rule of law. We support the effort of the High Representative, who is also Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure leadership and strategic coherence in the pursuit of common interests. We need more than ever the Union for our security and global peace. We reject europe from rivalries and nationalisms, which can only mean war.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – I would like to draw attention to the role of transatlantic cooperation in solving many of the problems outlined in the report. I stress in many other things russia's neo-imperial policies and concerns about the security of my region. I support peace and stabilisation efforts in our southern neighbourhood, but I am concerned about the effectiveness of humanitarian and development aid delivered in conflict areas, and this is a necessary action to reduce the migration crisis that is affecting us.

name: Илхан Кючюк
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, High Representative, colleagues, europe has enjoyed peace and prosperity for more than 20 years. It is obvious that today we have a changed environment and we must all realize that the current challenges, as well as the threats to the European Union, are complex, interconnected and come from both inside and beyond our common borders. To deal with this complicated situation, we need strong political will, leadership for decisive joint action and a collective immune system. The European Union can only become an effective and strategic actor to contribute to global security if it has a clear global foreign and security policy strategy to pave the way for this objective. The European External Action Service needs to consolidate the foreign policy efforts of all 28 Member States and set strategic and operational objectives that can produce concrete results. We need to improve the capacity of the European Defence Agency, but strengthen European intelligence exchanges. This will be possible if we are single, prepared and take greater responsibility.

name: Sabine Lösing
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The report shows where to go when the EU relaunches its security strategy – not as a concept of a peace union, but as a military union. Squeeze more money for weapons, expanding the armaments-industrial complex, and expanding the geostrategic sphere of influence in arms fraternity with NATO and 2% of GDP for defense purposes. As an example, this would mean for Germany: from EUR 30 billion now to EUR 60 billion. Security should be called social security, but there is supposedly no money for it. A "continuing like this" means more conflicts inside and outside the EU. The security problem is growing, and the consequences in this House are likely to be: even more weapons and even higher fences around Europe. How about rethinking? The following is the cause of flight, wars, poverty, climate change or the causes of terrorism. The EU states have helped to trigger these causes of flight through their policies and could therefore effectively combat them.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this report and the whole process of the European Security Strategy ultimately seeks to create a single and cohesive foreign policy for all 28 very different Member States within the European Union. This fundamental rebalancing of Member States’ sovereignty is completely unacceptable. Whilst cooperation is welcome, this continent has NATO, the OSCE and the UN to facilitate better understanding between European nations. Ideally, these organisations are not distracted by the political and economic baggage that comes from European Union membership. The United Kingdom remains a global power with international interests and obligations and can never fit comfortably into such a straitjacket. Indeed, President de Gaulle himself said as much when vetoing Britain’s first two applications to join the then European Economic Community. The best way to secure British security, and indeed the security of the 27 other Member States, is through institutions away from the European Union, where genuine multilateral cooperation can place, rather than the current subservience to EU institutions who have their own – and very different – logic and designs.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would first like to congratulate Mrs Kalniete on her report. It contains important ideas, which will be useful in drawing up the overall strategy to be presented to the June European Council. Since the 2003 security strategy, the strategic context in which the European Union is located – it has already been said – has changed much: much more economically interdependent, much more politically conflicting, very serious security challenges. We need an effective joint external action , before I said it; external action with the capacity to react to crises, yes, but also with a strategic vision and with the capacity to anticipate. I believe that we all know that soft power is not enough to protect our security and to make the European Union a real global player. The threats we face demand – as the report points out – that we also delve into the security and defence dimension. Finally, let me stress that, in this new international context, the United States remains our main ally. The strengthening of the transatlantic link is capital, particularly at a time of some American external fatigue and the pivot towards Asia.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the global strategy is meant to update and replace the European Security Strategy, and the challenge for the High Representative/Vice-President is to make it more strategic, thereby helping to make the people of Europe safer. Whilst I thank Ms Kalniete, I think this Parliament’s report, in total, only partly helps to do this. It is right to identify genuine shared foreign policy interests and the new challenges. My own Group has properly focused our amendments on the concept of human security and on the need for further arms control. We stress the international diplomacy necessary to sustain efforts for global climate action, and we reiterate that there is no solution to the challenge of international migration without the first emphasis being on conflict resolution and international development. Tonight I want to argue that we should not fight shy of Berlin Plus defence cooperation, which cannot, and must not, be deliberately misrepresented as a European army. Those who seek more ambition for EU foreign and security policy must also recognise that this encompasses more ambitious EU security cooperation. Why shouldn’t Europe be ready to undertake peacekeeping if a permanent peace could be established in Syria or even in the Palestinian territories? Surely recent attacks have removed any excuse against greater cooperation in counter-terrorism and intelligence-sharing. Tonight we have heard from some who insist that this can only be achieved through institutional change, and others who resist it altogether. I simply say that this can be done in full complementarity for the EU countries which are also members of NATO. But inside or outside NATO, it does require a commitment to improve capabilities, and that is an issue of political will in Europe’s national capitals to improve our individual – as well as our collective – response, not in EU institutions alone. Strategies are about words. They can be good words, but they have to be good words that lead to good action and to better outcomes. That is the ultimate test of Europe’s new global strategy.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – There are more conflicts that break out or flare up worldwide than those that end. And that, of course, is a bleak, worrying reality. The Union must guarantee the safety of its citizens and its values. I therefore see this report as an important exercise of thought with clear analyses and recommendations.  I also have some reservations. I am in favour of strengthening the European Defence Agency when the focus is on the core tasks and bottom-up work is being done with the Member States. However, I am concerned about the bureaucratic risks of the voluntaristic ideas in the report: a European Defence Community and a permanent military headquarters for the EU.  We already have the EU Military Committee, the EU Military Staff and the Chiefs of Defense meetings today. So why create extra layers of bureaucracy?  I also don't like the idea of mering the NATO Response Force with the EU Battle Groups. The Response Force works on the ground, the Battle Groups are just a paper tiger. Whether their merger will be a win-win is highly questionable.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, when Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton started their term in the leadership of United States foreign policy, they launched a doctrine of three ‘D’s: development was lifted to an equal footing with diplomacy and defence. We have to do the same in the external policies of the European Union. Development must be understood in the widest possible sense. We have to fight against poverty and promote ecologically, economically and socially sustainable development all over the world. In the spirit of real policy coherence, we also have to promote this cause in our internal development. In development policy we have to act in close cooperation with the United States, since in this field our basic values, goals and interests are very close to each other. This is also how we can most effectively tackle the root causes of our recent security and migration challenges.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I thank My Colleague Kalniete for the excellent report that is our contribution to the EU's global strategy, which is being prepared under the leadership of High Representative Mogherini, which is expected to be adopted at the European Council in June. The strategy should serve to keep the EU at the forefront of crisis resolution, dealing with hybrid threats and challenges for the Union and its citizens, and in partnership with other organisations and key countries such as the US, by promoting the values of freedom, democracy, human rights, peace and solidarity.  We have recently adopted an expansion and neighbourhood strategy, and soon we will also adopt a development strategy, which together with this strategy will be a platform for our action in global governance based on respect for international law. We need to work on strengthening defence capabilities and sharing defence budgets smarter at Member State level.  A holistic approach to Union external action must effectively bring together a complete catalogue of available external activity instruments and the overall assessment of the EU's effectiveness will be measured through the performance of our neighbourhood action, with engagements in Ukraine, Syria, Iran, north Africa and the Middle East peace process essential. The priorities are also relations with Russia, the fight against terrorism through a combination of internal and external security measures and the protection of external borders, which must be strengthened by controlling migration and firm agreement with Turkey.  I expect that the global strategy will clearly define ambitious but realistic objectives and, while ensuring adequate budgetary resources, will provide concrete mechanisms for their achievement. This will strengthen and reaffirm the EU's leadership globally as an assertive and effective entity.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D).
text: – Mr President, High Representative, the security of European citizens and countries begins far beyond Europe, but as you, High Representative, said, today's major threats also come from within Europe as nationalism and the rise of extremist groups.  The European Union has very good policy instruments in place, but unfortunately the problem is the lack of political will. Solidarity between member states is weak and there is still a need for more progress. What I personally want in this excellent global strategy is sharpness in controlling arms exports and sticking to common positions on what we ourselves have decided on arms and arms exports and its ban. It is really important to stick to these. Namely, credibility and integrity are at the heart of the global strategy and are core issues for the future of Europe.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask the High Representative two questions: have you been contemplating the notion of working on a new European architecture of security arrangement, and has it crossed your mind that there might be an overall relief and reconstruction plan for the Middle East/North African region? In the sense of the Marshall Plan – it will be 70 years next year since the speech of Secretary Marshall, who launched the plan – would you say that there is room for a Mogherini plan of this same scale? I ask these questions because you have highlighted the need for an imaginative new approach built on engagement, responsibility and partnership. What would you say to these two questions?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, in the major crisis that is a cause for its environment, the European Union has made the wrong choices. In the aftermath of the Arab Spring, which was in fact an Islamist winter, he chose to follow syria's destabilization stream and fed the Daesh monstrosity. Now, it is trying to renounce its responsibilities in the refugee crisis it has created, at the risk of causing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis in Greece. At the same time, it tolerates Turkey's eastern bazaars exploiting the Syrian crisis to advance its own strategy while strengthening Daesh. It is time for the Member States of the European Union to stop perceiving their interests with the ideas of the twentieth century. The European Union's external strategy must achieve coherence with the economy and culture of European states and must be accountable and insightful. Otherwise, Europe will remain what it has become today: an insolvent partner.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I will be very brief, first of all because many of the comments are simply comments that need to be taken on board when drafting the final stage of the strategy. Secondly, because at the various types of meetings, both with this Parliament and the national parliaments, we have had occasion to discuss many of these issues raised here. Thirdly, because the rapporteur has done excellent work in somehow incorporating the different aspects of the concerns and the suggestions of the European Parliament into a single contribution that will obviously be reflected in our work. I will comment only on two things. One is the policy coherence element: this is exactly the kind of exercise we are trying to do. This is also reflected very well in the report. We need to ensure coherence between different institutions, different instruments, different policies and sometimes even different priorities within different policies. We have an enormous amount of tools, but we do not necessarily use them in a coordinated and coherent way. I will also comment on the last comment that was made: the need maybe to have a Mogherini plan or something similar. This would cover for the reconstruction of and support for the Middle East but also Africa, because we have seen the development of trust funds recently and because we need to mobilise resources on specific strategic targets we have as a European Union. This strategy will not, I hope, entail extraordinary plans or measures but rather the pooling of the resources we already have, which are consistent. I hope that we manage to marshal these resources in a natural, coordinated and ordered way to serve our strategic priorities. We all know today what the priorities of tomorrow will be: the reconstruction of the Middle East, a major investment in the future of Africa. We can continue like this and the strategy will be exactly this. So if we manage to be serious on the definition of the strategy and on the implementation of the strategy, I think we will no longer need emergency measures.

name: Sandra Kalniete
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I thank you all very much for all the pertinent remarks you have made. I will just repeat the key words of the work we are doing together. First of all, it is important to have the political will to build the resilience of Europe and Europeans. There is a need for a coherent internal and external policy, and what is most important is that we implement the strategic documents. To do that, we need resources for external policy. I fully agree that we have to keep our engagement and continue with enlargement and our promises. There is the importance of strategic autonomy and the strengthening of our defence capacity. We have to cooperate with NATO and we have to think about building a European intelligence agency. Human security is at the centre of our strategy. Because of that we need to better control arms. We have to be more skilful in conflict resolution and invest more in development, because we want to be a global player with a regional focus in this connected, contested and complex world.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 13 April 2016.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Tamás Meszerics, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the implementation and review of the EU Strategy for Central Asia (2015/2220(INI) (A8-0051/2016).

name: Tamás Meszerics
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all let me thank all of you for being present at this late hour. I especially appreciate the Vice-President/High Representative being present here. Her stamina and perseverance is actually both admirable and indeed exceptional in these long foreign policy debates. Today we have already discussed a number of pressing problems, deadly crises, complex policy problems and precarious situations around the world. The region that we are going to talk about in the last item on today’s agenda, Central Asia, may not seem to require such urgent attention. It may not produce a pressing demand on our resources, but it is – and this is one of the most important conclusions of the report – a region of increasing strategic importance to the European Union. As rapporteur on the implementation and review of the EU-Central Asia strategy, the first fact that I have learned from my colleagues is that we all agree on the growing relevance of the region to the European Union. So this debate comes last, but not least, on today’s foreign policy agenda. First of all, allow me to express my sincere gratitude to the shadow rapporteurs, whose dedication, flexibility and professionalism resulted in the rich – and indeed not very short – text. I am also grateful to the various representatives of the European External Action Service (EEAS), who proved to be very helpful throughout the entire process.
